column2: Scandalous news from rockribbed Vermont is reported by Senator Ralph Flanders (Rep.) of that State and Senator Robert Taft (Rep.) of Ohio. It seems, according to Ralph and Robert, that party-minded President Truman appointed a Democrat to a postmastership up there, though four Republicans wanted it!

THIS new edition of Professor Schumpeter's study of political economy, first published in 1942, reproduces the original text without change but adds a new chapter. In the light of accumulated evidence, the rise of Laborite governments in Europe and permutations of Marxist theory in Russia, his diagnosis and prognosis appear remarkably astute.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- When John L. Lewis today called on the country's soft coal miners to quit work next week in mourning for the victims of an Illinois mine disaster, the nation's labor picture suddenly darkened.

The New York Public Library would like "nothing better" than to serve "shut-ins" and others who cannot conveniently visit its book stacks in person, Ralph A. Beals, the director, declared yesterday in response to requests for such service.

NANKING, March 29 -- Far reaching domestic and international repercussions are expected to result from the bloody, ruthless methods used by the Chinese in dealing with the anti-government movement in Formosa.

NEW ORLEANS--The pink petals of the azaleas are falling to the ground, but other flowers are coming to blossom and New Orleans, as always in its busy life, is getting ready for another festival. This time it is the Spring Fiesta, the slow movement that follows the brilliant allegro of Mardi Gras.

AN unofficial survey of the certificated commercial airlines of the United States indicates that passenger traffic made steady and uniform gains during the month of March after about as bad a January as the airlines have ever known.

To the Drama Editor: AS a student of theatrical history, I have been puzzled about the source of "Brigadoon" ever since its opening. Three summers ago, in the course of preparing for a language examination, I discovered a German story entitled "Germelshausen," written by Friedrich Wilhelm Gerstacker, a German traveler and author who lived from 1816 to 1872.

SHANGHAI, March 29 (U.P.) -- Evidence of friction within China's rightist parties appeared today. The Social Democratic and Young China parties sent a letter to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek threatening to withdraw from the slate for the new Government unless a program for reform was carried out.

The residents of 1 University Place were back to normal yesterday. From Police Headquarters came word that the ominously ticking box with flashing light, delivered to a tenant at that address, was "very harmless."

TOKYO, March 29 -- A staff study that Gen. Douglas MacArthur has submitted for consideration of the Allied Control Council at its meeting next Wednesday asks the Council to propose solutions for Japan's economic tangle.

ANNAPOLIS, March 29--A sixrun third-inning rally gave the Navy baseball team a 12-to-4 victory over Vermont in its opening game today and brought its winning streak to thirteen straight. Ronnie Rubton pitched a five-hit game for Navy and clouted the only home run of the day.

FLORENCE MURRAY, rewrite editor for the New York weekly The People's Voice, has brought out her third annual on the American Negro. It is the best of the lot, but not wholly complete, since as she suggests at the outset, there is in the field of statistics and records an element of confusion throughout the nation over the range of the word "Negro."

AMONG the newly opened oneman shows is the exhibition of recent paintings by BenZion at the gallery of Bertha Schaefer. This artist continues on his individual uncompromising way. Brushwork is vigorous, mood primarily melancholy, subject-matter diverse.

WARSAW, March 29--The Polish Army has begun an extensive search of the wooded and mountainous area of southeastern Poland where Col. Gen. Karol Swierczewski, Vice Minister of Defense, was assassinated by Ukrainian terrorists.

When the Treasury has need of additional revenues, we usually increase the individual income tax rates in the higher brackets. This is called progressive taxation. When the time comes to reduce taxes, however, we reverse the order and make the larger rate of reduction applicable to the lower tax brackets.

BIG architects, city planners, are wonderful people--full of anger, passion and ideas. When they take to writing books the reader has a vision of them, larger than life, striding to and fro on the summit of a mountain, lecturing the little people crawling about in the soot and chaos of the cities below, on how to live decent lives in less indecent surroundings.

A new program designed to increase the participation of college students in extracurricular activities and enable them to make fuller use of their school's counseling services, has been proposed by Dr. A.J. Brumbaugh, vice president of the American Council on Education.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio expressed opposition today to postponing Senate action on the income tax reduction bill, passed by the House, until a final settlement of the question how much President Truman's budget should be cut.

AS America slowly but inexorably begins its descent from the heights of wartime prosperty certain signs of economic dislocation are emerging. Of these a significant one is the rising tide of bankruptcies by small business concerns.

ESSEN, Germany (By wireless). THIS was the sixth largest city of Hitler's Reich. The home of Krupp's vast armament works, it was a city that thrived on war and preparation for war. The Ruhr was the industrial heart of Germany, and Essen with its coal mines and steel mills was the heart of the Ruhr.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (U.P.) --Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, announced tonight that he would support President Truman's Greek-Turkish aid program. In his opinion, it involved "the strong possibility" of war with Russia, but he said also it was "our only hope" of avoiding such a war.

The rights of children should be protected by public and private services in every community, when their parents and their homes fail to do so, Mrs. Crystal M. Potter, second deputy Commissioner of Welfare, declared yesterday.

IT is a brave man who writes about Palestine these days without taking sides between Jew and Arab. This means that the lambasting comes from every direction. Richard Crossman (in England, where he is Labor M.P. for Coventry, he is known as "Dick" to his friends and R.H.S. Crossman to everybody else) is not going to be thanked for this book by Jew or Arab, Zionist or anti-Zionist, American or Briton.

Only one charitable explanation suggests itself for the otherwise inexplicable 46-34 vote by which the Senate acted to amend the sugar control extension bill so as to make termination of rationing and price control effective Oct. 31 instead of a year hence, as the measure originally provided.

The Federal Housing Administration entered 1947 with net resources of over $147,000,000 and current gross income of around $3,500,000 a month, Raymond M. Foley, Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 29--Railroad travel on credit, started in January on three major railroads, will be extended coast-to-coast and border-to-border on Tuesday when another 45 lines will adopt a joint program of credit cards for travelers.
"Spring, that brings out garden tools, Sunday drivers and divots."

WASHINGTON, March 29 (U.P.) --The House Un-American Activities Committee plans to turn a "pitiless spotlight of publicity" on every Communist in the United States through legislation which will drastically restrict, but not outlaw, the party.

LONDON, March 29--Blizzards and floods this year wrought the "greatest food production tragedy this country has ever known," Britain's National Farmers' Union announced today. The organization also opened a national agricultural disaster fund.

Senator Bricker's motion to turn back to committee the nominations of David E. Lilienthal and his Atomic Energy Commission colleagues, and to reopen an investigation of AEC's employes, is shocking in its implications. We have no right to question Mr. Bricker's motives.

ONE of the harbingers of Europe's musical recovery from the ravages of war is the establishment there of music festivals of international imporance. Two of these take place this summer. The earliest is the second international Music Festival at Prague, to be held from May 8 to 8.

THE seventh and eighth centuries in Europe present a confused, sometimes baffling picture. Constant warfare between local rulers attempting to defend or to extend their ever - changing boundaries was the background to the greater dramas being enacted between Rome and Byzantium, between Christian and Moslem.

THE Metropolitan Camera Club Council is sponsoring a contest for members as a feature of the Photographic Carnival May 16-18 at the Seventyfirst Regiment Armory. The carnival is sponsored by manufacturers and dealers.

The main issues in the debate over the "Truman Doctrine"--a debate which began with the President's announcement on March 12--became increasingly clear last week. They were three: First, the question of where our action left the U.N.; Second, the effect on American relations with Russia; Third, the larger implications of the program and its cost.

AFTER the long, weary night of England's war, H.M. Tomlinson has collected a new volume of essays. "The Turn of the Tide" begins with a seventypage log of a sea journey to Istanbul and Alexandria in 1935 and then gives way to nine brief essays on ideas written during the war.
CHICAGO, March 29 -- Business enterprises, the railroads and agriculture in Chicago and other parts of the Central West are feeling the impact of the most serious freightcar shortage since 1922.
VIENNA, March 29--The arrival of 350 Austrian Jews from Russia yesterday grave startling verification of reports of the hard fate of many Jews who fled from Hitler to Russia.

The British proposal that the United Nations take up the Palestine situation at a special meeting of the Assembly gives the U.N. just about the toughest problem it has tackled so far. It will bring into conflict the Arab League and the Zionist organizations, with many nations taking a variety of views on an issue which London says it has been unable to solve.

HERE is a group of some twenty men and women, members of the Overseas Press Club of America, who went to war as press or radio reporters. Good troopers all, they carried typewriters and radio equipment instead of arms.

CANTON, China, March 29 -- Dr. James M. Henry of Lingnan University, who has lived in Kwangtung Province for sixty years, discussed Communist activity here today and stressed: "If the Government did something to help the people there would be less talk of Communists."

ANYONE who thinks that a Dali canvas should be wired for sound or that the Ancient Mariner would be the perfect dinner guest should be entirely charmed with "Crow Field." Readers whose simpler tastes run to a desire to know what an author is talking about will probably leave off after a few pages, pleading sea sickness.

MATCHBOX CAMERA-- The Eastman Kodak Company publishes the news that during the war it developed a camera no bigger than a matchbox and that it made 1,000 for the Office of Strategic Services. An intelligence man could carry the camera in the palm of his hand and make pictures about half an inch square for military use or for publication in resistance newspapers.

PROBABLY at no other time in the world's history has the individual been so much occupied with himself as in the years through which we have recently been living. The mark of that self-absorption has been deep upon our literature.

THERE is enough about Mr. O'Meara's first novel to suggest that it might have been an appealing, unambitious but forceful piece of writing. The narrative frame is unpretentious. A young boy is forced by economic circumstances to drop his schooling and spend a winter working in one of the old-time, northern Minnesota timber camps.

Prices of shares on the Stock Exchange drifted fractionally lower yesterday in the dullest session in five months. Sales dropped to the smallest total since Oct. 26, the turnover of 290,000 shares comparing with 340,000 shares on the preceding Saturday.

JERUSALEM, March 29 (AP)-- Hosts of faithful Christians will walk slowly down the rocky slopes of the Mount of Olives tomorrow to commemorate in their traditional Palm Sunday procession the triumphal entry of Jesus into Jerusalem nearly 2,000 years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Capitol Hill, which has had plenty of occasion in the past year to discuss the problem of price boosts as a result of rising labor costs, is facing the same question in its own biggest business. The Postoffice Department, for the first time in decades, is asking for a general upward revision in prices for most of its services.

Despite the desire of the Maritime Commission to get out of the business of operating ships, it appears that it will have to continue to run passenger tonnage after July 1, the date set by Congress for Government participation to cease, if the nation is to have more than one-ship passenger service in the Atlantic and the Pacific.

IN this, the fourth in his series of books under the general title "The Testament of Man," Vardis Fisher has written one of the dullest erotic narratives in many a season. Its purpose is to dramatize the change from a matriarchal society to a patriarchal society, but the drama is all but lost in a maze of repetition and dogmatic statement.

The hardy souls who brave the surf in midwinter have nothing on the diamond heroes of Fordham and St. Peter's, who exposed themselves to the numbing blasts that swept across Fordham Field yesterday to open the local baseball campaign.

BOSTON, March 29 (AP)--While operating from a strange defense position, Milt Schmidt led the Boston Bruins to their first National Hockey League play-off decision in three starts against the Montreal Canadiens, 4--2, tonight before a crowd of 13,909 at the Boston Garden.
LONDON, March 29--Cambridge beat Oxford in the annual crew race this evening by ten lengths.

SOLDIER'S return from the war is the theme of May Edginton's latest novel, with particular emphasis on the fortunes of the middle-class Stanbro family of Wimbledon, England. The author stresses in sentimental style the general eagerness of home-coming soldiers to find everything unchanged and then to settle down to family life in security.

FEIKE FEIKIMA'S ambitiously conceived novel of farm life in the Sioux region of Northwest Iowa is at first glimpse impressive. Bridging the span of twenty years (1916-36) in the life of one farmer, it attempts the theme of man's responsibility to the earth; combining accuracy of observation with intensity of sensation, it contains striking descriptions of nature and the changing seasons.

A seaman on an unidentified ship in the Port of New York miscalculated current events by a full day and was caught attempting to bring in two undeclared bottles of perfume as gifts for a girl friend, Customs men reported yesterday.

THE war cheated us out of pineapple, that perfumy, exotic fruit. There were few ships to to carry the fresh pineapples from Cuba and Puerto Rico to the mainland. The tin shortage interfered with the canning of the Hawaiian variety, and then, too, there was the problem of getting it from the islands here.

New Coal Stoppage Last Tuesday afternoon, in a sootcovered coal town in southern Illinois, 142 miners descended 500 feet into Pit No. 5 of the Centralia Coal Company. Three Hours later a blast shook Pit No. 5; black smoke spread through the mine, swept up the shaft; deadly carbon-monoxide gas filled the pit.

August Ganzenmuller of Sea Cliff. L.I., and Edward F. McGrath of Brooklyn reached the final of the Eastern indoor tennis tournament at the Kingsoridge Armory, the Bronx, yesterday. They will meet for the title today at 2 P.M.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The Corcoran Gallery's twentieth biennial exhibition opened with a preview here this evening. It opens to the public tomorrow and will remain through May 11. This is the first of the biennial series to be held under the directorship of Hermann Warner Williams Jr., the former director of the Corcoran, C. Powell Minnigerode, having retired in the interim since the last previous show in 1945.

EARLY spring, just before growth begins, is the best time of year to prune old flowering shrubs. An unfortunate characteristic of many otherwise beautiful shrubs--lilacs, mockorange, deutzia--is their habit of losing leaves at the base as they grow taller.

LONDON, March 29--Reading from right to left, European reaction to the Truman Doctrine has varied from thunderous applause to thundering denunciation. A close survey, country by country, shows a wide range of opinions.

Construction of approximately 40,000 housing units for sale or rent will be started in New England this year, according to William P. Homans, New England regional director of the Civilian Production Administration, in a report prepared for the New England Council.

CENTRALIA, Ill., March 29 (AP) --A rescue squad boss stepped up to a communication tube in a coal mine tunnel 540 feet underground today and gave the word all Centralia dreaded: "General search completed--all bodies recovered but one."

Dr. G.N. Gass of the Dupont Research Laboratories came out with the news last week that corncobs will soon play their part in the production of nylon. Ask Dr. Gass how many pairs of nylon stockings can be made from a bushel of corncobs and he will answer "none."

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 29 (AP)--Harry K. Thaw, who died at Miami Beach on Feb. 22, directed in his will, filed for probate today, that the executors and trustee pay $10,000 to "Evelyn Nesbit Montani or her son, to whom she gave the name of Russell Thaw."

MAN faces again life's primeval challenge, how to survive. In any future war between great powers the word "casualty" will be meaningless. Not some percentage of the fighters but the peoples themselves, their cities and all their works, will be destroyed.

The purchase of two high-speed tankers from the Maritime Commisison for use primarily in domestic trade was announced here yesterday by officials of the SoconyVacuum Oil Company, Inc. Both vessels, which saw war service as fleet oilers with the Navy, are now being reconditoned for peacetime operation.

ALBANY, March 29--Gov. Thomas E. Dewey signed today the Gugino bill making fully compensable workmen's claims growing out of total disability or death resulting from silicosis and other dust diseases.

ALICIA MARKOVA'S illness, which prevented her from appearing with the Original Ballet Russe in its recent season at the Metropolitan Opera House, put a great strain on both the box office and the standard of artistic merchandise offered by that organization.

OUR spy in the neighborhood of Brewster, N.Y., files a report on a leading litterateur of that locality, the same being Rex Stout, creator of the famous detective and orchid-fancier, Nero Wolfe. Well, the spy asks us, would it interest us at space rates to know that a great deal of Mr. Stout's time is now given to the cultivation of begonia plants?

HERBS are a problem group of plants, from a planning viewpoint. Where to sow them and what to do with them once they grow are the questions that keep many gardeners from ordering them at all. One solution is to include them in the vegetable patch.
Among the strange stories of New York few have been stranger than that of the Collyer brothers. Here is a chronological account of the Collyer hermits reconstructed from the available facts.

ARRANGED as a benefit for the New York Infirmary, the Cezanne loan exhibition at Wildenstein's, which opened to the public Thursday and may be visited through April 26, is generous in size and often admirable with respect to selections.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein will receive the annual gold medal award given by the Men's League of Brooklyn to the citizen adjudged to have given the most distinguished service to Brooklyn in the last year, the league announced yesterday after a conference with Governor Dewey at the Roosevelt Hotel.

LONDON, March 29--The problem of feeding Britain has been immeasurably complicated by the unprecedented freezing weather of February and raging floods of March. The Minister of Agriculture, Tom Williams, used the words "disaster of the first magnitude" to describe the situation early this week and nothing has happened since to alter his estimate.
Builders in the New York area are working overtime on plans to widen their market by producing houses at a lower price and to offer more homes for rental at a moderate price.

TORONTO, March 29 (AP)--Starting with two quick scores in the first period and closing with a sixgoal barrage in the third session, the Detroit Red Wings crushed favored Toronto, 9 to 1, at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight to even their semi-final National Hockey League play-off series with the Maple Leafs at one game apiece.

THE succession of events that has kept Greece in turmoil for the past two and a half years and that has led to the "Truman Doctrine" is shown in the pictures on these pages. With Britain terminating her aid to the Greek Government as of tomorrow and with UNRRA aid also ending tomorrow, the Greek crisis reaches a climax.

A representative of the Communist party told 600 persons attending a meeting of the Emergency Committee on Rent and Housing yesterday that the "committee must not let itself become split over red-baiting." Though the Communist party fully supported the committee's program, she added, it had no intention of "putting over any secret plan of its own" on the group.

YOUR reviewer's immediate reaction to this book is one of incredulous astonishment. Something impossible has occurred; he has finished a book concerned, largely, with mathematics, and has not only been fascinated but has actually (at least he hopes so) understood it.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 29--The call for a special United Nations General Assembly session on Palestine was put off today at least until Monday to get final support from the Russian, Chinese and French delegations.

Credit requirements are tightening in the women's apparel industry and banks serving that field now are closely watching inventories, expenses, purchases and sales of manufacturers, a survey here last week revealed. Borrowers are being advised to get rid of over-priced, slow moving and inferior quality inventories and work toward a more liquid position.
BALTIMORE, March 29--An influential bloc of horse owners and trainers today refused to go along with a new "code of standards" laid down for the nation's tracks by "racing's FBI."

FOR the first time in several years Washington is to celebrate cherry-blossom time with a festival to be staged around the Tidal Basin in Potomac Park, April 12-13. An elaborate program of pageantry and tableaux with special music and dancing has been planned, and is being sponsored by the Washington Board of Trade.

AFTER twenty years of sporadic and costly experimenting by the organized motion picture industry, the classroom teaching film still is in a nebulous state. So diverse are the opinions of educators and movie makers as to the best means of utilizing the screen for pedagogical purposes that a wag was recently prompted to remark, a la Mark Twain's comment about the weather, "everyone talks about educational pictures, but no one does anything about them."

BERLIN, March 29--German business men in the Soviet zone are quietly shifting their enterprises to the United States zone, it was learned today. This movement is being encouraged by German officials in the United States zone, despite a four-power agreement that forbids the Germans permanently to transfer even their living quarters from one zone to another.

CHICAGO, March 29--More than 1,500 pure-bred dogs from the United States and Canada competed for honors today in the twoday International Kennel Club show in the amphitheatre. The show continues tomorrow with breed and variety group judging on the program.

FEW plants introduced in recent years have made more flower history than the dwarf bunch roses known as floribundas. Developed from large hybrid tearoses and rugged polyanthas, they have merits typical of each, plus some sterling qualities all their own.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 29 -- The initial response to the speech yesterday by Warren R. Austin, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, which formally notified the Security Council of President Truman's $400,000,000 program to aid Greece and Turkey, has been favorable and "appreciative."
Rallying for seven runs in the second inning, City College's baseball team opened its season with a 12-3 victory over Pratt at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.

TONIGHT sees the end of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo's spring engagement at the City Center, and the beginning of a brief interlude in the hitherto hectic and overlapping ballet season. The next company on the schedule is Ballet Theatre, which will open a season of three weeks at the City Center on April 28.

From the fabled days of Daedalus and Icarus men have longed for individual wings. In our time the Wright brothers, tinkering together a crude air machine that now girdles the globe with mighty transports, brought the dream almost to reality. The Hoppi- Copter, if it works out according to plan, seems to fulfill it.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 29--Mrs. Eugenie Lindeman Woodward, retired actress, died here today at 567 North Street, where she resided. Her age was 88.

BECAUSE, in "Palladian," Elizabeth Taylor's prose has something of the texture of twilight and the color of sea-water, her characters seem immersed-- like slow swimmers. Her style is both casual and measured; at times delicately wry, its cadence is in contrast to the occasional, ominous dramatic incident, the strong interplay of emotion between characters who nevertheless maintain a persistent reality against the dream-like setting.

MR. SHUTE'S new novel, his tenth, is clearly a selection more for The Literary Guild than for leather bindings. It is a clever book, a readable book, and in terms of ideas, particularly on the problem of racial prejudice, his most significant book.
The hunt for Langley Collyer shifted yesterday to Atlantic City, N.J., following a report that the missing recluse had been seen in Barnegat, boarding a bus for the resort city.

SIGNS of a slowdown in various lines of business were a bit more evident last week and price adjustment was in the air. President Truman and his Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder both expressed concern over high prices and urged business to follow the good example set by Ford and International Harvester.
ST. LOUIS, March 29 (AP)--Fourteen year - old Mary Catherine Reardon was freed today in the Juvenile Court by a jury which had tried her for the death of her father.

HOLLYWOOD. WHEN Oswald Nelson, a knickered grammar school sprout, submitted a story on lion hunting in the African veldt, hi composition teacher suggested that Master Nelson's writing would improve if it were limited, fact or fiction, to subjects on which he had firsthand knowledge.

WASHINGTON, March 29--William L. Clayton, Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said today that there never had been a more opportune time than the present for obtaining favorable trade concessions from foreign countries.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- One of the liveliest mayoralty campaigns in Chicago's history, in which national and international issues were stressed by the Republicans and ignored by the Democrats, was nearing a close tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The relay transmitters at Munich, which beam the daily short-wave program of the State Department to Russia, were sabotaged recently and the broadcasts were turned away to South America, William Benton, assistant Secretary of State, announced today.
ST. LOUIS, March 29 (AP)--Fourteen year - old Mary Catherine Reardon was freed today in the Juvenile Court by a jury which had tried her for the death of her father.

HOLLYWOOD. WHEN Oswald Nelson, a knickered grammar school sprout, submitted a story on lion hunting in the African veldt, hi composition teacher suggested that Master Nelson's writing would improve if it were limited, fact or fiction, to subjects on which he had firsthand knowledge.

Security among nations cannot be attained without an expanding knowledge of world affairs through a free press, according to pupils who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- One of the liveliest mayoralty campaigns in Chicago's history, in which national and international issues were stressed by the Republicans and ignored by the Democrats, was nearing a close tonight.

Cancer specialists were long ago convinced that more progress could be made by studying growth, normal and abnormal, than by hoping for a cancer "cure" discovered by luck. They were prompted to this conclusion by asking some searching questions. As an egg develops into an embryo, how is it that cells begin to organize themselves and assume definite forms?

MR. PROKOSCH is already well known as the author of several books of original poems and translations, and of a number of novels. The present volume is a selection from his earlier poetry, together with some recent pieces.

With thirteen states now permitting non-housing real estate to be held as investments by life insurance companies throughout the United States, the big underwriters purchased $10,000,000 worth of this type of property in January and have run their holdings up to $87,000,000, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD. OLIVIA DE HAVILLAND is a rare example of what obstinacy, intelligence and a good script can do for an actress in Hollywood.

An attempt to break the roundthe-world flight record of ninetyone hours, eight minutes set in 1928 by Howard Hughes will be made next week-end in a converted Army attack bomber that will take off from La Guardia Field, it was announced yesterday.

OWING to the high standards of good taste that prevail throughout this newspaper, it is impossible to apply to Craig's wife the one word that describes her. In 1925 Chrystal Herne had the congealing job of acting the part in George Kelly's mordant drama which he casually dubbed "Craig's Wife."

TELEVISION finally has received the "green light" for which it has been waiting nearly three years. Ten days ago the Federal Communications Commission ruled that the burgeoning video art should proceed with the presentation of pictures in black and white and should not attempt at this time to offer images in full color.

PARIS, March 29 -- Since the Government crisis last week, when the Communists clung to their seats in the Cabinet while refusing to join in the Assembly's vote of confidence in that Cabinet, the idea has been propagated that the party is split and that one branch of it is growing nationalistic.
ALBANY, March 29 -- The WilsonPakula bill designed to prevent the raiding of a party's primary elections by members of another party was signed by Governor Dewey today without comment.

FROM Endre Hevesi, a Budapest newspaper man, comes background information about Hungary's "Liberty" series of stamps. In this group are honored ten early or modern Magyar figures who were identified with efforts to establish Hungarian independence.

WASHINGTON, March 29--Paul Porter, chief of the President's economic mission to Greece, said today that there were forces of democratic vitality on which to build in Greece but that they needed conditions of economic health before they could be expected to flourish.

MOSCOW, March 29--The most remarkable single aspect of this session of the Council of Foreign Ministers as it concludes three weeks of tedious but vital debate is the emergence of the body's newest member--United States Secretary of State Marshall--as its dominant personality.

THE arrival here last week from Germany of the first shipment of Automatic Rolleiflex and Rolleicord twinlens reflex cameras since the start of the war relieved a critical camera shortage. The immediate effect was to stabilize the price of the camera by giving it an official value and to point to a reduction in the price of used "Rolleis."

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head (estimated); total not given. Compared with week ago; weights under 260 pounds, 75 cents to $1 lower; hogs over 260 pounds and sows, 50 to 75 cents lower.

MR. ROBERT STANDISH, who is an old China hand and author of "The Small General" and "The Three Bamboos," has chosen the West Indies as the scene of his latest book and placed a solitary and isolated Chinese there to serve as his main character.

HERE is a well-knit presentation of the nation's housing problem, with a rather comprehensive historical outline and a broad list of suggestions which the author believes might atone for our past "failures" in this field.

THREE - YEAR - OLD Sandra tagged after her mother all day long, cried when her mother left the house, refused to play alone. Other children from other families--Jackie, Nancy, Philip, aged 2 to 4-- behaved much the same way.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The Congress of Industrial Organizations contended today that 1946 was a record year for industrial profits. It held, too, that most companies and corporations had a return on their investment "eight to ten times greater" excluding depression years, than in pre-war 1936-39.
The Unitarian Service Committee of 9 Park Street, Boston, made public here yesterday the names of sixteen displaced persons overseas and relatives whom they are seeking in this country.

NEW YORKERS today accept Grand Central Terminal as casually as sidewalks, virtually indifferent to the frenzied crush of immigration and the no-quarter battles of financial giants that made possible this railroad edifice. Yet it was scarcely two decades ago that Grand Central's spider web of rails was completed, the finishing touch to an almost miraculous engineering feat that took more than a quarter of a century and cost $35,000,000.

CAIRO. ANOTHER exodus is under way here. Under the Anglo-Egyptian agreement to evacuate Cairo by March 31. British officers are canceling the leases on their comfortable and long-inhabited apartments, putting their elder sons and daughters into boarding schools and taking their wives and babies to single rooms in the communal dwellings of the new British military headquarters at Fayid.

President Truman's appeal for lower prices was followed quickly last week by a statement from Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, urging everybody who has anything to do with setting the cost of living to cooperate to bring it down.
HAMBURG, Germany, March 28 --Consumer cooperatives prepared today to retrieve the importance in the German economy that they held before Hitler dissolved them.
AMERICA will soon begin living under new labor laws. A turbulent, dramatic, fateful decade in our industrial history is drawing to a close. One chapter ends. Another chapter begins.

SOMEWHERE about the hour all well-behaved readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES are putting out their lights tonight, "Oklahoma!" will be entering the last day of its fourth year at the St. James Theatre. One day later the press department of the Theatre Guild will be able to indulge in the neatest of theatrical semantics.

The eleventh annual Three Choir Festival was concluded yesterday morning at Temple Emanu-El. As in the past, the third and final program was worked into the regular morning service for the sabbath. The choirs sang from an invisible position in the loft behind the Ark.

SOMEWHERE about the hour all well-behaved readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES are putting out their lights tonight, "Oklahoma!" will be entering the last day of its fourth year at the St. James Theatre. One day later the press department of the Theatre Guild will be able to indulge in the neatest of theatrical semantics.

The eleventh annual Three Choir Festival was concluded yesterday morning at Temple Emanu-El. As in the past, the third and final program was worked into the regular morning service for the sabbath. The choirs sang from an invisible position in the loft behind the Ark.
JERUSALEM, March 30 -- British naval craft went to the rescue of a disabled ship crammed with 1,600 Jews bound for Palestine, removed 750 refugees and began towing the vessel to Haifa today.

Asparagus is not so inexpensive now as it may be later in the season, when supplies from local gardens are arriving in the market. Nevertheless its cost is unusually low and its quality very fine. To make the most of this so-typicalof-spring vegetable, we recommend use of the following recipes:

Employes of thirteen city departments, together with their dependents, will become eligible next month for complete medical care under the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York. Purchase Commissioner Albert Pleydell, general manager of the plan, announced yesterday that enrollment campaigns were making excellent progress in other city departments.

FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus, March 30 -- That German prisoners of war here appear to have more personal freedom than Jewish internees is resented most by sidetracked Jewish immigrants to Palestine who are interned in British camps in Cyprus.

Pious sentimentality and "flabby" emotionalism, in occasional attendance at church do not prove loyalty to the Christian faith, the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert said yesterday afternoon at St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street.

The remembrance of "Jesus the Indomitable" staking His life "on what He knew to be the will of God and calling us to remember Him and follow Him," is the challenge of Palm Sunday to all Christians, the Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill, pastor emeritus of the Brick Presbyterian Church, said yesterday in a guest sermon at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets.

Machine tools sent to Greece from War Assets Administration sources should be ready for immediate operation, Tell Berna, general manager, National Machine Tool Builders Association, stressed over the week-end in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES. He said:

Seven leaders in the field of international relations have organized the nonpartisan 1947 Foreign Policy Campaign "to awaken the American people to an awareness and fulfillment of their world responsibility in this time of crisis," the Foreign Policy Association announced yesterday.

IN the battle for cash and customers between the established National Football League and the newer All-America Conference the NFL has had one insuperable advantage, tradition. Not very long ago the AAC corralled one of the nicest chunks of tradition that the older circuit ever boasted, Mel Heim. Pro football's all-time center has just cast his lot with the Los Angeles Dons of the AAC where he will serve as line coach.

William Shirer, Columbia Broadcasting System news commentator, made his Sunday broadcast at 5:45 P.M. yesterday and after telling his radio audience that it was his last broadcast announced his resignation from Columbia.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., March 30 -- The eighteen-hole golf course of the former Woman's National Golf and Tennis Club on Cedar Swamp Road here is being whipped into shape after five years' disuse. Delegates to the United Nations are expected to be braving the course with brassie and niblick within a few months.
ROME, March 30 -- Walter Audisio, better known as the "Colonel Valerio" who "executed" Benito Mussolini, said at a public meeting today that the former Duce had not died a hero's death.
BERLIN, March 29 -- Americans here are in a state of fiscal frustration as the result of the Military Government's changes in German and American currency, and no end is in sight.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 30 -- Silas Skidmore Clark became Mayor of this suburban city of 45,000 fifteen months ago more or less by accident. He entered politics as a tyro, but learned the ropes fast. Now, in matters of municipal administration and planning, he is regarded as resembling a combined La Guardia and Moses, minus the fire of Fiorello and Robert but not their stamina.

Poland never can and never will become a Communist nation, Stanton Griffis, Ambassador-designate to Poland, declared yesterday. He contended that because they were "being guided by Catholicism the Poles will never become Communists."

PITTSBURGH, March 30 -- Even if John L. Lewis had not called a six-day work stoppage to honor the miners lost in the Centralia disaster, little coal would have been mined this week, it was stated today. There would have been only two full days of work, Monday and Wednesday.

OBERHAUSEN, Germany, March 30 -- Taking advantage of the Sunday lull in the Ruhr's food demonstrations, Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Social Democratic party, fired the opening gun today in the election campaign in Land [State] North Rhine Westphalia.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $53,897,800,937. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows: Apr. 1 -- 7/8% ctfs. of ind......... $2,819,694,000
BERLIN, March 30 -- The American Military Governor of Greater Hesse took sharp issue with criticisms of the treatment of inmates of the civilian internment camp in Darmstadt.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, its personnel problems settled, will grant its first loan in the near future, an authoritative source reported yesterday. France is to lead, with Denmark likely to follow as a successful loan applicant.

Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the New York National Guard, declared yesterday that the entire Guard program, calling for an ultimate force of 60,000 troops, was jeopardized by uncertainty over Federal financial support.

More than 260,000 days of free care and 391,315 days of partly paid care were provided in 1946 by twenty-four Catholic hospitals in the New York archdiocese, according to the annual report of Msgr. John J. Bingham, director of health of New York Catholic Charities, released yesterday.

Seventy-seven-year-old Tommy Connor, spry, measuring 5 feet 3 inches in height, and weighing 135 pounds, noted a milestone yesterday and paid no attention to it. The day marked the opening of his fifty-eighth year with the circus. He is the oldest employe.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Americans for Democratic Action pledged itself today to militant political action, from the grass roots right through to the national level, without turning into a third-party movement.

In a long, uphill struggle the New York Knickerbockers cut a 21-point deficit to a mere 2 points, but they could do no more and bowed to the Philadelphia Warriors, 76 -- 72, before 15,152 persons at Madison Square Garden last night.

Although sales and earnings of the United Aircraft Corporation in 1946 declined sharply, the company emerged in the final quarter of the year from what was described as the "most critical period in our history" to realize satisfactory results on the year's operations, according to the annual report to stockholders, issued for publication today.
CAMDEN, N.J., March 30 -- Mrs. Gladys Johnson, 40 years old, six of her fourteen children and a grandson were burned to death this morning when fire destroyed their home.

OTTAWA, March 30 (AP) -- Richard L. Button, 17-year-old ice artist from Englewood, N.J., and Miss Barbara Ann Scott, 18-year Ottawa star, added the North American figure-skating championship trophies to their large collections last night.

BOMBAY, March 30 -- The Committee of Ministers -- an advisory and policy-shaping body -- of India's Chamber of Princes recommended today the calling of a conference of representatives of the major political parties in India and of the Indian States to gauge the greatest measure of accord that could be obtained on defense, communications and foreign affairs.

Today is the twentieth anniversary of the appointment to the board of commissioners of the Port of New York Authority of Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the biState agency. Commissioners and executives of the Port Authority will honor Mr. Cullman at a dinner on April 7 at the Links Club, 36 East Sixty-second Street.

BOMBAY, India, Monday, March 31 -- Forty persons were killed and 137 were wounded yesterday in communal riots that broke out in four different sections of Bombay, the Provincial Director of Information announced today.

ATHENS, March 30 (AP) -- Athens newspapers said today that a fourday battle between Greek troops and about 1,500 guerrillas on Mount Vardusia, in central Greece, southwest of Lamia, was developing favorably for the Government.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 30 -- Facing National League opposition decidedly softer than that which they had been encountering in the recent jousts with the rugged Cardinals, the Yankees engaged Ben Chapman's Phillies today for the first time this spring and forthwith put on a polished and finished performance.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Secret testimony that Turkey, even more than Greece, is the key to any move to halt the spread of communism in the Mediterranean is before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

The concert of sixteenth and seventeenth century music which Edgar Varese directed last night with the New Music Society in the New School for Social Research was not the first of its kind that he has given in proof of his penetrating musicianship and his wide knowledge of noble music of these epochs.
Although the New York Central Railroad last year moved the greatest volume of traffic in any peacetime year, it had a net loss of $10,449,268, its annual report shows.

The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation will launch a large newspaper campaign this week through the country for its new 1947 models, it was announced over the week-end. Through local dealers, the company will offer its new line of reception and recording instruments, with models starting at $19.95.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander has expressed opposition to a resolution before the City Council requesting that the police permit overnight parking of automobiles on streets in residential areas, it was disclosed yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 30 -- For the second time in its history, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has entered into a distributing contract with an independent producer, the studio and Liberty Films having concluded an agreement by which Liberty will produce the screen version of "State of the Union" on the Metro lot for Metro release.

Revision of six major features of the national securities laws have been recommended by the committee of security regulation of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York and have been submitted to James J. Caffrey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was disclosed yesterday by Thomas Jefferson Miley, secretary of the association.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved last week into new high ground for this year. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 60 to 102 points.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Congress is permitting to go by without a decision tomorrow's original deadline for authorizing a program of economic and military aid to Greece and Turkey and will contend chiefly with domestic issues on the floor this week.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 30 -- Rebel planes from Concepcion made two attacks on the Campo Grande military barracks outside Asuncion in the last twenty-four hours. Government sources said three civilians had been killed in the second attack early today.

Secretary of the Interior Krug rightly refuses to debate responsibility for the terrible Centralia disaster with John L. Lewis. That must be determined by official inquiry. If the shocking tragedy had not occurred this would have been a quiet week in the coal fields.
PARIS, March 30 -- When useless political games are over and the Constitution is revised, the great masses of the French people will rally to their country, former President de Gaulle said today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30 -- An informal poll of the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission indicated today that it was not likely to adopt the United States proposal to leave United Nations representatives in Greece's troubled frontier areas while the commission and the Security Council debated the responsibility for past incidents.

SEATTLE, March 30 (AP) -- Coach Mike Peppe of Ohio State was the last man in the University of Washington pool last night, flung there fully clad by his gleeful team which had just rolled up 66 points to capture the National Collegiate A.A. swimming championship for the second successive year.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 30 -- Contrary to popular belief, Americans prefer the alcoholic beverages made in the United States to those imported from other countries, C.M. Strauss, Monroe, La., chairman of the board of Wines and Spirits Wholesalers of America, Inc., said in New Orleans today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The National Association of Commodity Markets and Allied Trades, Inc., said tonight that the United States was probably shipping abroad larger amounts of grain "than are safe for our economy."

CHICAGO, March 30 -- An English springer spaniel, Ch. Frejax Royal Salute, owned by Fred Jackson of Royal Oaks, Mich., won the best-in-show award at the close of the two-day all-breed dog show in the International Amphitheatre tonight.

Despite a chilling wind that reached a velocity of thirty miles an hou thousands of New Yorkers thronged to city churches yesterday for traditional Palm Sunday services. The high wind and low temperatures discouraged the usual pre-Easter style turnout, fur coats and heavy water clothing predominating.

William J. Albrecht, 22 years old, of 37-55 Seventy-seventh Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, was charged with homicide last night in the slaying, twelve hours earlier, of Fiske Dellinger, 24, son of a prominent Boston attorney, in a vacant lot in Elmhurst, Queens.

HAIFA, Palestine, Monday, March 31 (AP) -- The first explosion here early today was described by persons in the area as "a single earth-shaking boom," but other blasts followed quickly when the oil lines caught fire. A southwest breeze sent the flames into shrubbery around the Shell Oil Company office, which appeared to be doomed.

George Enesco, the eminent Rumanian violinist and composer, received the Grand Cross of the Order of Loyal Service from Mihai Ralea, Rumanian Ambassador to the United States, yesterday at the Hotel St. Moritz, for "making the music and soul of Rumania universally known throughout the world."

Archimandrite Anthony, rector of the Russian Orthodox Church of SS. Peter and Paul in Montreal, was consecrated Bishop of Montreal and Eastern Canada in a three-hour service yesterday in the Russian Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Virgin Protection, 59 East Second Street.

Representatives of eighteen major industrial classifications were named over the week-end as members of the industrial mobilization committee of the Navy Industrial Association. The committee was formed to assist the Army-Navy Munitions Board in the preparation of a national industrial mobilization plan at the request of Richard R. Deupree, chairman of the munitions board.

Trouble continued last week to trail the little bay steamer President Warfield, which sailed from Baltimore more than a month ago to run Palestine immigrants past the British blockade in the Mediterranean.

AUBURN, N.Y., March 30 (U.P.) -- A sitdown strike by convicts protesting Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's veto of three parole bills has involved more than 100 prisoners at Auburn State Prison and is still spreading, unofficial reports said tonight.

CENTRALIA, Ill., March 30 -- Robert M. Medill, State Director of Mines and Minerals, who is on duty at Mine No. 5 where 111 coal diggers died in an explosion last Tuesday, was preparing tonight to carry out orders from Gov. Dwight H. Green that any Illinois mine considered unsafe should not be permitted to reopen.

Consumers spent less freely than usual in 1946, but preliminary estimates indicate that their expenditures in the last quarter (on a seasonally adjusted annual rate basis) came to 88.5 per cent of disposable income for that period. This is revealed in an analysis of the pattern of consumer spending released over the week-end by the National Industrial Conference Board.
LONDON, March 30 -- With March already the wettest since 1856, the Air Ministry's weather forecast tonight offers nothing better than "cloudy with rain at times."

Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the Communist party in the United States, labeled by members of the House Un-American Activities Committee as an individual of many aliases, a draft dodger and a bail jumper, admitted publicly yesterday that he assumed his present name fifteen years ago.

After three weeks of preliminary labors, the Moscow Conference now approaches a stage demanding certain fundamental decisions which will determine not only its own future course, but also the whole question of whether or not the victors of the second World War can reach agreement on a settlement with their main enemy, Germany.

British and American business men in India expect continued growth of trade between India and the Western nations despite unsettled conditions and the impending severance from the British Empire, according to John M. Bradley, veteran shipping agent, who is here on a visit from the East.
AMSTERDAM, March 30 -- The Dutch index of wholesale prices, on the basis of 1938-39 as 100, rose again in January, reaching 267.4, against 265.9 for December.

Among the several follies committed by the House of Representatives in the pursuit of economy, chopping down the Conciliation Service in the Labor Department is one that calls for correction when the Senate takes up that supply bill. Edgar L. Warren, chief of the Conciliation Service, was the unhappy target of this axe-swinging.

Mayor O'Dwyer completed yesterday his study of the final draft of his executive budget for 1947-48, which will total about $1,000,000,000, a new high mark in the city's history. The total budget, to be submitted to the Board of Estimate at a special meeting tomorrow, will include a tax levy budget of not less than $824,000,000, forecasting a basic real estate tax rate somewhere between $2.90 and $3 for each $100 of assessed valuation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 30 -- As the United Nations prepared today to start polling its member countries -- probably early this week -- for their views concerning a special General Assembly session on the Palestine problem, Secretariat officials crossed their fingers against any decision favoring a full-dress affair.

LONDON, March 30 -- The Federation of British Industries called upon the Government today to import 10,000,000 tons of coal this year and to step up its production target from 200,000,000 to 220,000,000 tons. Any imports would presumably come from the United States.

NEW DELHI, India, March 30 -- India's lawmakers are busy these days looking into and after the morals of their constituents. Apparently they are determined to make drinking, gambling and other harmful pleasures unpopular with the masses.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 30 (AP) -- Two recent graduates from the amateur ranks, Cary Middlecoff, Memphis dentist, and George Schoux of San Francisco, representing the Winged Foot Club of Mamaroneck, N.Y., tied for the $10,000 Charlotte open golf title today with 11-under-par totals of 277.

Edward F. McGrath, 22-year-old Brooklyn star, captured the Eastern indoor tennis singles championship yesterday by defeating August Ganzenmuller of Sea Cliff. L.I. in the final round of play at the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx The score was 4 -- 6, 12 -- 10, 6 -- 3 3 -- 6, 9 -- 7.

ALBANY, March 30 -- Governor Dewey signed today a series of bills which end Oct. 1 the State program of child care centers as it now functions and greatly expand the program of the State youth commission against juvenile delinquency.

MEXICO CITY, March 30 -- The Mexican Confederation of Labor, or CTM, by ending the three-year tenure of Senator Fidel Velazquez, as secretary general, appears to have narrowed its losses to the defection of the group now formally organized as the CUTM.

For reasons best known to them, Paul Feigay and Oliver Smith went their separate ways after producing two musicals, "On the Town" and "Billion Dollar Baby." Subsequently, each did a play in association with a co-sponsor. Both plays were duds.

LOS ANGELES, March 30 -- Both communism and the extreme rightism of Gerald L.K. Smith are issues in Tuesday's municipal election for fifteen city couneilmen, four members of the Board of Education and ten judges.

President Truman and Secretary of the Treasury Snyder have expressed their concern over the high price level and indicated that they think industry should do something about it. In effect, this statement places the responsibility for the recent price spiral upon industry.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- All deliveries of corn futures sold last week at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade, with May at $1.88 1/4 at one time, highest since 1920. However, the completion of some foreign orders for cash corn resulted in a sharp recession from the top, with a subsequent rally when the Government resumed buying.
With the national telephone strike deadline only a week away, Federal conciliators made virtually no headway last night in efforts to avert a walkout.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am directed by the Postmaster General to refer, to the letter from John D. Harris, New York, dated Jan. 23 and headed "Food Parcels for Britain," which was published in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES and of which a cutting has been sent to this office anonymously.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)-- A speed-up in the rate at which foreign countries are using up the credits advanced to them by the United States was reported tonight by the Department of Commerce. The credits are composed of money loans and sales or property by the Government in return for promises to pay later.

The immediate need for 8,000 more public health nurses was stressed by President Truman in a letter to the National Organization for Public Health Nursing, made public yesterday. The organization will observe Public Health Nursing Week from April 20 to 26.

BERLIN, March 30 -- German selfishness and the failure to provide effective leadership were termed by Col. Hugh B. Hester, chief of the Food and Agriculture Branch of the United States Military Government, the primary causes of an inadequate food program.

LONDON, March 30 -- After a decline that had been going on almost without interruption for two months, the gilt-edge section of the stock markets has staged a rally. The persistent decline of the Government stocks and the many conjectures to which it has given rise has weighed almost as heavily on the markets recently as has the disastrous consequences of the severe winter.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period March 22 to 28 are given in the appended tabulation: The Senate On the bill to establish daylight saving in the District of Columbia, passed 56 to 17: YEAS

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred Zaharias of Denver, Col., won the Augusta women's titleholders golf tournament today with a 72-hole score of 304, shooting a one-under-par 74 in a rainstorm for the final 18 holes.

One of the more pleasing phenomena of the present century has been the slow but steady increase in political morality. Graft has not disappeared completely, nor will it until there is no one in any community who is willing to buy a favor. But those in government willing to dispense those favors, for a price, are fewer and fewer as the years go by.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I should like to commend THE NEW YORK TIMES for the leadership it is taking in behalf of the public library. It is indeed regrettable that the libraries of this city have suffered for so long the financial handicaps which result in the difficulties of which we now read.

MOSCOW, March 30 -- The Big Four deputies on Austria circulated among the delegates to the Council of Foreign Ministers today a preliminary and partial Austrian treaty draft. The draft proposed free Danubian navigation and special arbitration machinery to handle disputes arising from the peace settlement.

While total operating revenues of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., last year rose $23,385,000 over 1945, this was offset by an increase of $41,705,000 in total operating expenses, according to the 1946 annual report mailed to stockholders today.

CENTRALIA, Ill., March 30 (AP) -- Driscoll A. Scanlan, State Mine Inspector, said today that at least fourteen of the 111 miners who died as a result of an explosion in the Centralia Coal Company's No. 5 mine last Tuesday lived long enough to write notes to their families.
Every business executive has real weapon at hand to use against unethical speculators in raw materials, a high governmental official disclosed here yesterday.

The value of a broad general education in any career was stressed yesterday by speakers at the Elmira College Career Conference in the Biltmore Hotel. The seventy-five students attending also were warned not to let their studies "interfere with their education."

PARIS, March 30 -- The Popular Republicans defeated the Communists today in re-run National Assembly elections in the Drome Department which had to be canceled last fall because of voting irregularities.

Few out-of-town buyers were in the wholesale markets last week where apparel activity was holding up on pre-Easter business, which is tapering off, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Normal differences between teen-age children and their parents have been accentuated by the rapidity of change in this generation, according to Dr. Evelyn M. Duvall, executive secretary of the National Council on Family Relations.

Publishers of nineteen countries have signed agreements to produce and distribute a multi-lingual magazine to be circulated in thirty countries, Thomas H. Beck, chairman of the board of the Crowell Collier Publishing Company, announced yesterday.

LONDON, March 30 -- The Government faces tomorrow one of those little but sharp crises that now and then have plagued Labor party leaders. A bill to impose peacetime conscription is coming up for a two-day debate. With it is an amendment, signed by more than seventy Labor MP's, asking Parliament to reject it.

The board of directors of the National Association of Manufacturers is completely in accord with the general idea of an international trade organization. It was announced over the week-end. The board hopes that American industry will be able to approve the charter for an international trade organization that is soon to be discussed in Geneva, it was said.

LONDON, March 30 -- Ominous signs of a serious flight of private capital from Britain have begun to appear following revelations of weakness of the British economy brought forth by the winter's industrial crisis.

MADRID, March 30 -- Political circles here are much occupied today with a report that Generalissimo Francisco Franco will issue a startling proclamation Tuesday morning affecting his own position. Tuesday marks the eighth anniversary of the end of the civil war and is the day of the annual victory parade.

President Truman's proposal of $250,000,000 in aid to Greece was praised, but assistance to Turkey was condemned in a resolution unanimously adopted yesterday at a mass meeting of the Armenian National Council of America. A thousand persons attended the meeting, which was held at 100 East Seventeenth Street.
Philip D. Berenson has been named vice president in charge of sales for Art-Craft Briar Pipe Corporation, Brooklyn.

The annual report of the Bureau of Alcoholic Therapy, made public yesterday, said that of 126 men who took the full year of treatment 100 were cured by the city's bureau. However, 125 other men, who failed to take the complete treatment, were not included in the statistics.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A joint Army Air Forces-National Geographic Society expedition of scientists will leave for Brazil on April 1 to study "a dozen important problems of the universe" while the sun is in total eclipse on May 20, it was announced.

WARSAW, March 30 -- The Supreme Council of the Polish Peasant party [PSL] confirmed today the expulsion by Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of six leaders of the revolt against his leadership. The resulting split was inevitable after the party's crushing defeat in the January election.

A progress report on the current drive by independent retail grocers to meet the serious threat of post-war competition was presented yesterday at the board of directors meeting of the New York Food Merchants Association, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania, according to A.F. Guckenberger, executive secretary.

Elaine Rudnick, 22-year-old New York pianist, who has been heard in the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Brooklyn Museum, gave her first Manhattan recital last night at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Her program included Bach's Italian Concerto and selections by Scarlatti, Brahms, Chopin and Granados.

MOSCOW, March 30 -- The Soviet proposals on German exports and imports in the Coordinating Committee's report to the Council of Foreign Ministers would result, if adopted, in a cut in German ration levels to near starvation levels.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 30 (AP) -- A soldier who, tiring of routine garrison duties at West Point, left the Army, re-enlisted in the paratroopers under an assumed name and became a hero of World War II in France, has been declared a deserter by the Army, his attorney said today.

Something New Under the Sun Announcement that the new United Nations capital on our East River will be "unlike anything ever built before" and "an example of the new urbanism" is inspiring or alarming, as you happen to take it.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- J.A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, said tonight that he was preparing for Congress a full report on safety in the coal mines, but would not engage in a "controversy" over the recent catastrophe in Centralia, Ill., in which 111 miners lost their lives.

HAVANA, March 30 -- Victory finally came to the Montreal Royals today for the first time in six meetings with the Dodgers, but it took them three and a half hours and thirteen innings. The score was 6 to 5, with a single by Jack Jorgensen off Hank Behrman scoring Lew Riggs with the winning run.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, March 30 (AP) -- Dense clouds of ashes and fumes reaching a height of six or seven miles, poured out of blazing Mt. Hekla today, blacking out a wide area to the south.

TOKYO, March 30 -- The opinion is growing in some Japanese circles, as well as among certain high-ranking officers of the occupation forces, that new labor legislation providing for the democratic operation of Japan's new trade unions has become long overdue.

NEWCOMERSTOWN, Ohio March 30 (AP) -- Denton True (Cy) Young, greatest game winning pitcher that ever lived, was too moved emotionally here last night to say a word as 800 hill country neighbors, legislators and baseball figures paid homage to him on his eightieth birthday anniversary.

The international trade section of the New York Board of Trade, Inc., went on record over the weekend as advocating the complete elimination of export controls by June 30. The organization, in a resolution passed unanimously, endorsed the stand of Gen. Douglas Mac Arthur in urging their prompt discontinuance as an excellent way to place Japan on a self-sustaining basis.

NEWCOMERSTOWN, Ohio March 30 (AP) -- Denton True (Cy) Young, greatest game winning pitcher that ever lived, was too moved emotionally here last night to say a word as 800 hill country neighbors, legislators and baseball figures paid homage to him on his eightieth birthday anniversary.

SOME writers look upon the epic of America as a mighty drama filled with tremendous climaxes and clashing interests. For them interest and meaning center only in the Revolution, the Civil War, the conquest of the West and the march of industry. If they can't write about Valley Forge and Gettysburg and the gold rush they don't feel it worth while to write about the American past at all.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 30 -- Sweden's abrupt imposition without notice of drastic restrictions on all "nonessential" imports, which evoked sharp protests in Stockholm on March 24 from both Washington and Berne that the restrictions were a clear breach of existing trade agreements, aims at arresting the rapid shrinkage of the Riksbank's reserves of gold and foreign exchange.

BOMBAY, March 30 (Reuters) -- This was the picture tonight of riot-torn storm centers in India: Bombay -- Forty killed, 137 wounded; situation brought under control; curfew imposed. Calcutta -- Five killed and fortytwo injured.

PITTSBURGH, March 30 -- While declaring that incoming business continued at a high level, steel officials last week were nevertheless scanning the economic future for signs of a slackening in steel demand. The only thing discernible, it was said, was what some trade sources termed a "softening" in so-called black market or twilight market steel prices.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Civil Aeronautics, Administration today authorized the nation's scheduled airlines to land at airports under lower ceiling and visibility requirements when using the CAA-approved Instrument Landing System.
Defense materials and other cargo purchased from this country by Venezuela will be carried from New York to La Guaira soon on former Navy Landing Ships (Tank), it became known yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Refrigeration equipment manufacturers revealed today that, with improved material supplies and the industry well on its way toward supplying demand for conventional household and commercial refrigeration equipment, many innovations in equipment were on production lines and first shipments started.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., March 30 (AP) -- The high-scoring tempo continued in the American Bowling Congress tourney today, paced by Ernest Del Dotto, Merced, Calif., who soared into the lead in the singles division with a 690 series.

Electrical equipment, including motors, generators, transformers and switchboards, is among 150 schedules of surplus property offered by the War Assets Administration, Carl P. Malmstrom, the regional director, announced yesterday. The offerings originally were valued at $154,540,000.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Preoccupation with thes threat of Soviet expansion in the eastern Mediterranean diverts attention from the shifting political currents washing the western waters of that strategic tri-continental lake. Yet the largest Communist parties in Europe are in France and Italy.

Four young singers with fine, powerful voices were presented late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall by George Leyden Colledge, who promises similar quadrupleheaders in the future using the same general title of Aristo Artists.
The American South African Line will resume passenger vessel operations between here and South and East Africa by the end of this year, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Price fluctuations in the grain markets last week were extremely rapid and erratic, reflecting heavy operations in futures against cash transactions. It is estimated that possibly 25,000,000 bushels of cash grain of various kinds has changed hands in the last two weeks.
BERLIN, March 31 -- Almost two years after Germany's unconditional surrender weeds are beginning to sprout atop the towering piles of rubble lining the streets of scores of communities.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., March 31 -- Pinned beneath an overturned ten-ton tractor-tread vehicle Saturday evening in a wild section of Graphite Mountain, near Corinth, Peter J. McLaren, 32, of 433 West Forty-fourth Street, New York City, a business executive, was killed instantly and a companion, Ernest Way, 39, of New Haven, Conn., a safety manager, was trapped beside Mr. McLaren's body until discovered by skiers late yesterday afternoon, twenty-four hours after the mishap.

NEW ORLEANS, March 31 -- Practice of some whisky distilleries in taking over the function of wholesale liquor distribution is "regarded by temperance groups as a victory for the drys," whose present program is to take the profit out of liquor, Arthur Guyer of Los Angeles, said here today.

Indicating a sharp contest over the financial future of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, Victor McQuistion, president, warned holders of the company's adjustment bonds and common stock yesterday that recapitalization of the company at this time "would wipe out the common stockholders and benefit only the lawyers."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 31 -- Adopting eleven acts, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors made fiscal arrangement today for the collection of 10-cent tolls on the Hutchinson River and Saw Mill River Parkways and the discontinuance of tolls on the Cross County Parkway beginning June 1.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 31 (AP) -- Mark F. Ethridge, United States delegate on the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission, called upon the Bulgarian liaison officer, George Koulishev, today to explain an article in a Communist newspaper of Sofia that said Bulgarians would welcome "creation of a Macedonian State within the framework" of Yugoslavia.

ESSEN, Germany, March 31 -- In an effort to avert a general strike of Ruhr workers, including 300,000 miners, railway passenger services have been cut 75 per cent in the British zone. Every available locomotive has been pressed into service to rush food to this area from Bremen and Hamburg, Milltary Government officials disclosed today.

Ernest Bevin, British Foreign Secretary, was blamed yesterday for the present problem of Palestine by Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, president of the Zionist Organization of America, who arrived at La Guardia Field by plane from Cairo.

The third official search of the Collyer home at 2078 Fifth Avenue started at 8:30 A.M. yesterday. When work was halted for the day at 4:30 P.M., the police were certain that Langley Collyer was not in the basement library, one of the building's twelve rooms.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 31 -- The Yankees, who this spring have become accustomed to covering great distances, traveled only a short one today and for no purpose whatever, for their exhibition game with the Phillies was rained out after only one inning, and with that they went motoring back to their own training base at St. Petersburg.

Swelled by record flotations of public utility and State bonds, the $624,051,000 total of new bonds offered publicly here in March, representing thirty separate issues, was the largest for any month since May, 1946, when $636,286,000 in fifty issues was marketed.
MOSCOW, March 31 -- Several "exploratory" talks have been held on the subject of revision of the Anglo-Soviet treaty of 1942, it was learned today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a member of the Labor Research Advisory Committee to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, may I comment briefly on the action taken by Congress in regard to that bureau. If the decision to whittle down the BLS requests for funds by almost two-thirds is not overruled, it means the almost complete strangulation of a very vital government activity.

John G. Hagan, president of the City Tank Corporation, 53-09 Ninety-seventh Place, Corona, Queens, made a business trip to downtown Manhattan yesterday afternoon. He was passing the Municipal Building about 4 P.M. when he remembered he had a few telephone calls to make.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Although the administration, has stressed that part of its newly announced foreign policy which provides aid for the Greek people, and played down the aid to Turkey, which is much more strategic from a military standpoint, the attention of critics of the current government in Athens has not been diverted by this tactic.

Iola George, 22 years old, of 504 West Fifty-third Street, was a patient in the psychiatric division of Kirigs County Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday after she had been taken from the south walk of the Brooklyn end of Manhattan Bridge.

MOSCOW, March 31 -- Secretary of State Marshall flatly rejected today the Russian demand for reparations from German current production as the price of economic unity for Germany. He also told the Russians that the United States opposed policies that would make Germany a "congested slum or an economic poorhouse in the center of Europe."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 31 -- American troops in Germany get "good food, excellent living quarters and rather too much entertainment," A. Conger Goodyear concluded today after a two-week survey of military living conditions and morale in all parts of the zone for the War Department.

Sugar stocks in most of the retail grocery stores have been built up to the full allowable inventory, it was reported yesterday by the trade, in readiness for the validation today of Spare Stamp 11 -- the first ration stamp good for ten pounds of sugar.

The audience that gathered last night in Times Hall to hear the second and last of the programs that Georges Enesco is giving for the benefit of underfed children of Rumania had the advantage of hearing that extraordinary musician not only as violin soloist but as piano accompanist of his country -women, Pia Igy and Stella Roman, who sang two groups of songs as their contribution to the occasion.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in March totaled $68,766,000, the smallest amount for any month since November, 1943, when $31,063,000 was redeemed. The total compared with $95,421,000 for the preceding month and $140,480,000 for March, 1946.

Daisart Sportswear, Inc., of 99 Central Avenue, Newark, N.J., and three of its officers were charged yesterday with having diverted 3,500,000 yards of cotton piece goods into the textile black market at an illegal profit of $1,015,423.

President Truman's program of "unconditional aid" to anti-Soviet governments will "unite the world against America and divide America against herself," Henry A. Wallace declared last night as he denounced proposed United States loans to Greece and Turkey.

Store Sales Up 9% Here Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed a gain of 9 per cent over the like week of 1946, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Max Haupt of Chicago, father of one of the Nazi saboteurs electrocuted in 1942, must serve his life sentence and pay a $10,000 fine as a result of his lower court conviction for treason, the Supreme Court held by 8 to 1 today.
