An arbitration award providing wage increases of 21 1/2 cents an hour for 25,000 elevator operators and other service employes in 4,000 Manhattan office, loft and apartment buildings was made public yesterday by David Sullivan, president of Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union, AFL.

The establishment or fellowships through which young graduate rabbis could study psychiatry and psychoanalysis and thus equip themselves for more efficient work in counseling members of their congregations was recommended last night by Rabbi Joshua Loth Liebman of Boston.

A new move to end the use of proportional representation in City Council elections, by submitting a repeal referendum to the voters this fall, is under serious consideration, it was learned yesterday. The move has the support of the Democratic organizations in the five counties, at least the tentative support of Mayor O'Dwyer, and probably will be strengthened by a sympathetic attitude on the part of the Republican organizations in the city.

Cotten goods prices have hit their peak and further increases are deemed unlikely on the basis of current demand, according to trade observers in Worth Street yesterday. Sales volume of cotton textiles is leveling off, it was stated, although there is no doubt that business being booked is still very substantial.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A bill to maintain rent control through Feb. 29, 1948, without an "across-the-board" increase was unanimously approved today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Removal of export licensing control over about fifty items, including iron and steel manufactures, certain hides and leather products, automobiles and automobile tires and some chemical items was announced today by the Office of International Trade, Department of Commerce.

The Aluminum Company of America filed a petition in Federal court yesterday asking for a judgment declaring that the company "no longer has a monopoly of the aluminum ingot market and that, in consequence of the termination of such monopoly, competition has been restored in the aluminum industry."
Pedestrian and vehicular traffic at Herald Square and at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street was expedited yesterday as a new police rule barring auto turns went into effect.

"There are a thousand ways around the Condon-Wadlin bill. Men have been known to get sick on Mondays. Thousands more could get sick on Tuesday, and if there is a cat to be skinned we can skin it from both ends."

Today the New York City Cancer Committee begins the task of collecting $1,300,000, its contribution to the national fund of $12,000,000 that the American Cancer Society will raise. When we consider how little was done for those who were stricken by cancer earlier in the century -- even the word was hardly mentioned because of its connotation of agony and slow death -- the sum may seem large.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Government announced today a policy for bringing selected Germans and Austrians to the United States to study or work with private and governmental Institutions active in the fields of education, religion and molding of public opinion.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (U.P.) -- The Navy, in an effort to tighten its security regulations, has proposed legislation to make it a criminal ofense, subject to heavy penalties, for any Government employe to disclose secret, confidential coded information.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 31 -- With a rousing ninth inning against the aging right arm of Earl Caldwell, the Giants celebrated their return to the home base today by turning an apparent defeat into a spectacular victory in a pulsing battle with the White Sox before 1,874 fans.

PARIS, March 31 -- Former President de Gaulle was denounced as as "opponent of the republic" in a bitter statement issued today by the central office of the Socialist party, led by former Premier Leon Blum. The Socialists have never before so openly or so formally broken with M. de Gaulle.

AKRON, March 31 -- A three-point recommendation for the consideration of Congress in the writing of what he termed "America's long-term rubber insurance policy," was advanced here today by John L. Collyer, president of the B.F. Goodrich Company and former special director of rubber programs for the Government.

The Allegbany Corporation reported yesterday for 1946 a net income of $1,665,925 after charges and taxes. This is exclusive of an interest payment of $655,727 received on bonds of railroads in reorganization, which was applied to the cost of these securities, and a net profit of $2,007,597 from the sale of securities that was credited to earned surplus, account.

Next Sunday the Easter bunny will deliver baskets of chocolate eggs, candy chicks and many other traditional sweets that older children have missed for several years and that their younger brothers and sisters never have known. For the first time since the war, confectioners here are amply stocked for the Easter holiday.

The State of Illinois announced yesterday that it would offer for sale on April 29 an issue of $300,000,000 of veterans' bonus bonds. They will come due on May 1, 1949 to 1972. Interest is not to exceed 2 per cent.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- High feed costs, charged to "excessive speed" of Government grain buying, is curtailing poultry and hog replacements to such a degree that a scarcity of fowl and pork may result next fall, Walter C. Berger, president of the American Feed Manufacturers Association, warned today.

The mystery of the missing Bronx bus was solved yesterday with considerable help from the chief culprit, who drove the vehicle 1,500 miles to Hollywood, Fla., and then virtually advertised his whereabouts.

The trend toward lower price ranges in women's and misses' dresses has gained momentum, with various manufacturers expressing willingness to concentrate on garments in the $1.87, $2.25 and $2.87 wholesale brackets, it was learned in the trade yesterday.

Why People By-Pass The thing is not likely to happen, but in the "bypassing:" of the U.N. by President Truman's new Greek policy it would certainly be exciting if the White House put out a statement saying that this is exactly what Mr. Truman intended to do -- to by-pass the U.N.

Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d announced yesterday the signing of Mary Martin to star as Annie Oakley in the national company of "Annie Get Your Gun," one of Broadway's biggest moneymakers. According to present plans, the road duplicate begins its travels Oct. 4 at the Fair Park Auditorium in Dallas, Tex., appropriately enough Miss Martin's home state.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 31 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff, the Memphis dentist who passed up a berth with the Walker Cup team to give himself a two-year test as a professional golfer, won the Charlotte open tournament play-off today with a smashing 32 -- 32 -- 64, eight under par, to trim George Schoux, the San Franciscan who plays out of Mamaroneck, N.Y., by nine strokes.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 31 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg's proposal to give the United Nations power to halt the GreekTurkish aid program would be a welcome confirmation of United States support for the world organization, it is believed here.

In an effort to meet the misgivings of some and the propaganda of others, Senator Vandenberg has proposed an amendment to the President's program of aid for Greece and Turkey which neither adds to nor detracts from that program, but which may accelerate its adoption by Congress.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of March 26, "Transit Prospects," your interpretation of my letter to the Board of Estimate, published in THE TIMES on Feb. 10, is in error. Your editorial states: "Mr. Gross said at that time that $500,000,000 was needed for new construction and $150,000,000 for rehabilitation.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in March dropped to the smallest total of any month since November, 1944; it also was the dullest for a corresponding month since 1942. Sales crossed the million -share mark in only four sessions, the largest of which was 1,211,520 shares on March 7.

From gross revenues of $42,123,717, an increase of 55 per cent over the 1945 total, Eastern Air Lines, Inc., last year realized a record net income of $4,504,643, a gain of 112 per cent over the $2,126,294 earned in the preceding year, Capt. E.V. Rickenbacker, president and general manager, announced yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Grain markets turned downward today on the Board of Trade after a higher opening. There was a lack of the aggressive buying that was in evidence last week, and brokers reported no interest in either flour or corn for export.

A group of minority stockholders of the Cliffs Corporation, attacking a consolidation plan of the management as unfair, is seeking, in a letter to stockholders, to enlist support for a petition to the Securities and Exchange Commission for an advisory report on the management plan.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the interest of truth, some slight corrections of a historical nature are required in the comments of James E. Greer, executive director of the Council for Democracy, whose letter appeared in THE TIMES of March 25.

The deadlocked negotiations in the contract dispute between the American Union of Telephone Workers and the long-lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company were ordered moved to Washington last night as the Government intensified its efforts to avert a national telephone strike next Monday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 31 -- The United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, in a meeting that was at times baffling to some of the delegates themselves, agreed tonight to study Soviet amendments to the commission's original report.
HONG KONG, March 31 -- Sharp division in the Annamese forces resisting France in Indo-China has been indicated here.
MADRID, March 31 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco tonight announced to the nation the formation of a Regency Council under his direction.
MOSCOW, March 31 -- Jacques Rueff of France, president of the Inter-Allied Reparations Agency, was strongly criticized today by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Communist party of the United States, agitated over the recent trend in American foreign and domestic policy against communism, is attempting to organize a counter-attack.

Reporting on operations last year of the Philco Corporation, John Ballantyne, president, and Larry E. Gubb, board chairman, informed stockholders yesterday that a net income of $3,107,480, or $2.13 a common share, had been earned, despite an operating loss for the first nine months.

LONDON, March 31 -- The age at which a child may leave school in Britain will be raised tomorrow from 14 to 15 years. It will represent a big step toward the goal of a free secondary education for all.

ATLANTA, March 31 -- Gov. M.E. Thompson, fighting for control of Georgia's Democratic party machinery, today wrested the Jefferson Day dinner campaign from the forces of Herman Talmadge. At the same time he announced a purge of "bolters and deserters" from the State's payrolls and party ranks.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- About 35,000 bituminous coal miners "jumped the gun" today in advance of the midnight deadline for a week of mourning for the 111 miners who lost their lives it the Centralia (Ill.) mine explosion last week.
LONDON, March 31 -- Further improvement in British Government stocks, together with increased activity in base metal shares and Brazilian securities were the features of today's stock markets.

The American Abstract Artists group has opened at the Riverside Museum, Riverside Drive at 103d Street, its eleventh annual exhibition, which will continue through April 20. The museum is open daily, except Mondays, from 1 to 5.

FOR three days now I have been immersed in the pages of what I believe to be one of the most remarkable novels of our time. The experience has been exhausting, but enormously stimulating. Only one other novel which I can think of at the moment demands as strenuous intellectual concentration and rewards it so fully, although in a very different manner.
Fritz Kreisler, renowned viollnist and composer, and his wife Harriet, whom he married in 1902, have returned to the Roman Catholic Church, it became known yesterday.

TOKYO, March 31 -- The ninetysecond Japanese Diet, the last under the old Meiji Constitution, ended its deliberations and dissolved this afternoon. Thus ended the old Japanese parliamentary system that began in 1890.

MOSCOW, March 31 -- The American project for a four-power military alliance directed against Germany stood a considerably greater chance of success tonight when Foreign Minister Bidault pledged France's support for the idea.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- Taking the lead at the clubhouse turn and warding off a determined stretch challenge by War Watch, Bohn and Markey's Bill Ross whirled to a smashing triumph at Gulfstream Park today in the featured Ocala Purse, a test at one mile and a furlong in which seven measured strides.

The American Broadcasting Company will receive the National Radio Network Award as one of the five winners of plaque awards, which will be presented at the Third Annual Radio and Business Conference, April 22 and 23, sponsored by the School of Business and Civic Administration of City College, it was announced yesterday.

BERLIN, March 31 -- The Russians may be expected to complain shortly that the Americans are balking at granting the Germans what the United States consistently proclaims is one of humanity's most cherished rights -- that of freedom of the press.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- Robert Mitchum will play Billy Buck, the hired man, in the screen version of John Steinbeck's "The Red Pony," Republic Pictures announced today. The studio has borrowed Mitchum from David O. Selznick for the Charles K. Feldman Group Production, which is scheduled for the cameras in May.

Two young American composers received checks for $500 and heard performances of the orchestral works that won them the money last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music at the third annual Gershwin Memorial Concert of Victory Lodge of B'nai B'rith.

NEWARK, N.J., March 31 (AP) -- A bid of $75,000 for the purchase of the steamer Sandy Hook, owned by the Central Railroad of New Jersey, was entered today before Federal Judge Guy L. Fake by five residents of Hudson County.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 31 -- Marshal Tito told a joint session of the Yugoslav Parliament today that Greece had become a base for imperialistic forces of the United States and Britain that could imperil peace in the Balkans and in the entire world.

T.H. White, British author, whose new novel, "The Elephant and the Kangaroo," will be published on April 11 by Putnam, has written to his publisher about his difficulties with the American immigration authorities. He says: "At present I am having difficulty in transporting myself to America because, having been born of British parents in India, I am regarded by your laws, for quota purposes, as an Indian.

Smashed windows, bulging walls and plaster shaken loose in a sixstory apartment house at 45 East Sixtieth Street were caused yesterday, the police said, by the "apparent suicide" of Michael Greenwich, 58-year-old bookkeeper. He was accused of taking $50,000 from the trucking concern for which he worked.

CENTRALIA., Ill., March 31 -- Driscoll Scanlan, state mine inspector who says his reports of bad conditions at mine No. 5 near here were ignored by both the mine company and the State Department of Mines and Minerals, today accused Robert M. Medill, director of the State Department of Mines and Minerals, with being responsible for the conditions which resulted in the death of 111 miners last Tuesday.

Harold Kohon, who appeared in a program for the violin at Town Hall last night, has had wide experience as a solo recitalist as well as with chamber music ensemble and orchestra. His playing has admirable mechanical proficiency. His left hand is accurate; his tone is firm and warm; and he can manage with dispatch nearly all of the difficulties that face a violinist.

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 4,000 head, total 5,000; 50 to 75 cents higher than Friday; weight under 260 pounds moderately active and showing most advance; good and choice 180 to 260 pounds,

Outlining new concepts of convalescent care to aid patients in more rapid recovery from illness or injury and more continuous medical supervision, the Hospital Council of Greater New York recommended yesterday additional facilities for general hospitals.

Individual carpet manufacturers may be considering some price reductions, it was learned in the trade yesterday. Any downward revisions, it is understood, are predicated upon maintenance of labor and materials costs at current levels.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- Registration statements covering $45,000,000 of debentures. $6,300,000 of bonds, 1,197,898 shares of common stock, 150,000 shares of preferred stock and an unspecified number of subordinated income debentures were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by fourteen companies.
Workmen will begin today to tear down the two-story frame building that for more than 100 years has served as part of Public School 3, Hancock Street near Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.

More than 700 telegrams and letters from manufacturers all over the country have been received by Hearn Department Stores, evidencing interest and offering merchandise for its "lower cost of living" promotion, Leonard Ginsberg, president, said yesterday.

HAVANA, March 31 -- Branch Rickey, who directs the destinies of the Dodgers for better or for worse -- and nobody at the moment can say which -- sat in a box at Gran Stadium this afternoon and delivered himself of a few thousand words "touchin' on an' appertainin' to" his 1947 club.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Some of the Zionists have chosen to introduce the Palestine issue into the Greek-Turkish loan debate, with results they are not likely to approve.

In an effort to insure the presence of more trout in the stream than anglers on the bank, the New York Conservation Department has exceeded all past records in troutstocking in preparation for the 1947 season, which opens on April 12.

NEW DELHI, India, March 31 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi conferred today with Viscount Mountbatten, the Viceroy, on critical Indian issues. He remained for two and a quarter hours in the Viceregal Mansion, at first with Lord and Lady Mountbatten and finally for an hour alone with the Viceroy.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Truman signed legislation extending sugar rationing until Oct. 31, and named Cavendish W. Cannon of Utah to be Ambassador to Yugoslavia. White House callers included Representative John W. MacCormack, Stanley K. Hornbeck, Acting Secretary of State Dean Acheson and Senator Alben W. Barkley.

HONOLULU, March 31 (AP) -- The seagoing tug ATF114 towed the stern section of the broken tanker Fort Dearborn toward Pearl Harbor today after the Navy tug Lipan churned into port with a log that told of flashing lights and opened portholes on the supposedly deserted half-ship.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Warning that "never have the survival and advancement of democracy been so dependent upon education at every level." Willard E. Givens of Washington, D.C., executive secretary of the National Education Association, asserted here today that "our schools and colleges have important assignments in the restoration and maintenance of social stability."
MOSCOW, March 31 -- A nationwide "offensive" to overcome agricultural deficit and increase food production has been decreed by the Soviet Government and the Communist party.
PARIS, March 31 -- A revolt has broken out in Madagascar, according to dispatches from Tananarive, the capital.
LONDON, March 31 -- Official London is disturbed and mildly irritated by the latest wave of speculation about new United States financial help for Britain.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., March 31 -- The most colorful Mayor in Sullivan County, whose diminutive but dynamic figure often has brought a reference to him as "the La Guardia of the Catskills," ended a twelve-year tenure as chief executive of this widely known county seat today.
BOWIE, Md., March 31 (AP) -- The spring racing season will open in Maryland tomorrow with upward of 12,000 of the faithful expected to be on hand for the return of the thoroughbreds.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- An emergency bill authorizing the Government to halt by injunction strikes in transport, utilities and communications was introduced today by Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., chairman of the House Labor Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Government today asked the Circuit Court of Appeals at Richmond, Va., to overrule a Federal District Court decision that the United States illegally seized the soft coal mines. The Department of Justice filed a brief citing the Supreme Court's recent decision in the John L. Lewis contempt of court case, in support of its contention that the District Court at Wheeling, W. Va., erred in its ruling.

Competitive sales yesterday of four blocks of public utility company securities occasioned, in one instance, a high bid from a life insurance company for a $22,425,000 bond issue, and in another transaction, a tie between underwriters for $1,400,000 of preferred stock.
CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- The walls reverberated at the AllAmerica Football Conference meeting.

Severity-five candidates turned out for New York University's first football practice of the spring season yesterday on Ohio Field. The Violet's new coach, Edward E. (Hook) Mylin, and his line coach, Jim McGaughey, were in command.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 -- Abandonment of Korea by United States forces under the present conditions would have "serious repercussions in the Orient," Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge said here today.

CLEVELAND, March 31 (AP) -- Seventy-six trade unions, manufacturers and jobbers charged with restrictive trade practices and price rigging in the production of 80 per cent of the country's plumbing supplies were acquitted today by Federal Judge Robert N. Wilkin.

LONDON, March 31 -- Britain's Labor Government moved the second reading of its peacetime conscription bill in the House of Commons today with embarrassing support from the Conservatives and equally embarrassing opposition from within its own party ranks.

When and now does a deserter become a good soldier and a fighting hero? The question may be answered if the War Department consents to review a sentence of desertion, prison and dishonorable discharge just passed by a court-martial sitting on the strange case of James Minker of Syracuse.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Selective Service Act expired at midnight tonight Since Oct. 29, 1940, when it began to operate, 10,200,367 men were inducted into the armed services.

Uncertainty and concern were expressed by officials of public and private agencies yesterday over the effect of a series of bills signed by Governor Dewey that will end the State program of child-care centers on Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Comdr. Frank Slingluff, USN, retired, who saw service in both World Wars and was holder of the Navy Cross, died here today in Garfield Hospital after an illness of several weeks. He was 60 years old.

Two knitwear manufacturers, Ralph Mendelsohn, 47 years old, of 334 West Eighty-seventh Street, and Philip Plotnick, 52, of 121 Corbin Place, Brooklyn, were arrested yesterday on charges of tax fraud. They were said to have evaded State taxes on $1,000,000 of black market operations and to have concealed profits in sixty-one banks and fourteen brokerage accounts under fictitious names.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 31 -- Foreign Minister Oesten Unden, replying to the American protest against the Swedish ban on imports, suggested immediate consultations between Sweden and the United States on the principles and application of import control.

GLEN COVE, L.I., March 31 -- The Webb Institute of Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering, the oldest school of its kind in the United States, begins this week the task of moving from, the Bronx, where it was established nearly sixty years ago, to the former Herbert Lee Pratt estate on Long Island Sound here, purchased in 1946.

"The Mother of Us All," a new opera by Virgil Thomson and the late Gertrude Stein, will be given at four invitation performances during Columbia University's third annual Festival of Contemporary American Music, to be held May 12 to 18. Prof. Douglas Moore, head of Columbia's department of music and president of the National Institute of Arts and Letters, announced the festival plans yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 31 -- The emphasis placed on German reparations in the Moscow talks has come as a pleasant surprise to the delegates of eighteen nations assigned to the Inter-Allied Reparation Agency here. They had expected to be neglected.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 31 -- The Bureau of Police and Fire said today that charges against each of thirteen patrolmen suspended in the police department' second major scandal within two weeks would include immoral conduct and neglect of duty.

A flare-up of violence as the result of a feud involving control of hiring and firing dock workers was revealed yesterday when the District Attorney's office announced that three men had been arrested and charged with the fatal shooting of a 43-year-old boss stevedore.

CYPRUS, March 31 -- Lord Winster, the new British Governor of Cyprus, has dismissed four Greek members of his Advisory Council who boycotted the ceremonies on his arrival last week. The boycott was a gesture of solidarity with the movement for a union of Cyprus with Greece.

The 47-year-old steamship Meteor, which as the Chester W. Chapin was known to travelers of another era as a pleasure cruiser in Long Island Sound, once more may play host to New Yorkers -- this time as a floating hotel or night club.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today to grant prompt action to Eastern railroads on their petition for increases in basic coach and pullman fares.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Truman nominated Cavendish W. Cannon of Utah today as Ambassador to Yugoslavia, to succeed Richard C. Patterson Jr., who resigned last week. The nomination went to the Senate on a list with six other ambassadorial appointments.

Glaring disparities exist in every field of Negro health and welfare service, according to a study made for the United Negro College Fund, Inc., and made public yesterday. It declared that "Americans who would demonstrate practical democracy to the world must teach hope by helping to release our own minority groups from despair."

The annual report of the Corn Products Refining Company and domestic subsidiary sales companies showed yesterday a net income for 1946 amounting to $13,623,679, equal to $4.71 a share on the 2,530,000 shares of common stock outstanding. This compares with $8,633,393 or $2.73 a common share earned in 1945 after including a tax carry-back credit of $776,072.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Representative John Taber of New York, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, today assailed a decision of the Supreme Court as "unconscionable" and bearing "such an odor" that he opposed Congressional acceptance of the ruling.

The Selective Service Act expired at midnight last night, and from this point forward the United States must depend upon voluntary enlistment for the men to fill our Army, Navy and Marine ranks. The lapse of Selective Service will bring no immediate crisis. But what of tomorrow?

The most challenging comment in the current report of the Commission on Freedom of the Press, issued under the title of "A Free and Responsible Press," is that the dissemination of news and ideas is in danger of falling "under the control of fewer and fewer persons." This privately financed research group, largely composed of college professors under the chairmanship of Chancellor Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago, made no charge of monopoly.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The forty-nine-member policy committee of the National Federation of Telephone Workers will add some finishing touches to its strike strategy while awaiting the outcome of the "final round" of conferences to avert a nation-wide stoppage.

Underwriters here will place on the market today offerings of stock of industrial companies as follows: Plymouth Rubber Company, Inc. -- 300,000 shares of common stock at $13.50 a share, by F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., and E.W. Clucas Co.
PITTSBURGH, March 31 -- Scattered work stoppages marred what district offices of the Solid Fuels Administration described as an otherwise "normal" working day in the soft coal mines.

In its fourth production in two months the quixotic Experimental Theatre continues to be the most refreshing of Broadway's current activities, and Arnold Sundgaard's "The Great Campaign," acted at the Princess Sunday evening and yesterday afternoon, is the most original of the season's experiments.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 31 -- Joe Magaletti of 52 Ferris Avenue, this city, a former staff sergeant in the Army Engineers, brought back from the Rhineland battlefronts two huge stadium-type Nazi flags as war trophies. He cut off the ends, but his wife still thought they were too big for tablecloths.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The sale of the Pullman sleeping car business to a group of forty-three railroads for $75,000,000 was approved today by the Supreme Court.

ALBANY, March 31 -- At the requst of Mayor William O'Dwyer, Governor Dewey approved today a bill that permits New York City to spread over three years the redemption of $19,000,000 in budget notes authorized to finance payment of last year's pay increase for transit system employes.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 31 -- Colgate W. Darden Jr., former Governor of Virginia and chancellor of the College of William and Mary, was named president of the University of Virginia, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., rector of the university, announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Senator William F. Knowland, California Republican, warned the Senate today that the United States might be unable to recover its prestige if David E. Lilienthal and other interim appointees to the Atomic Energy Commission were repudiated.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 31 -- In an outstanding exhibition of sailing tactics Gem II, with Durward Knowles of Nassau as skipper, came from behind today to win the first of three races for the International Star Class spring championship.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 31 -- Colgate W. Darden Jr., former Governor of Virginia and chancellor of the College of William and Mary, was named president of the University of Virginia, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., rector of the university, announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Senator William F. Knowland, California Republican, warned the Senate today that the United States might be unable to recover its prestige if David E. Lilienthal and other interim appointees to the Atomic Energy Commission were repudiated.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 31 -- In an outstanding exhibition of sailing tactics Gem II, with Durward Knowles of Nassau as skipper, came from behind today to win the first of three races for the International Star Class spring championship.

Bids on Utility Issues Underwriting offices hummed yesterday afternoon with comment on bidding for four separate blocks of public utility company securities. The tie bids of Harris, Hall Co. and Otis Co. for 14,000 scares of Michigan Gas and Electric Company preferred stock was another "one for the book," recalling the margin of $14.75 that separated recent high bids for $5,000,000 of Delaware Power and Light Company preferred stock.

A miniature lend-lease program, similar in theory if not in scope to the international wartime program, was evolved yesterday in Flatbush Magistrates Court, Brooklyn. The program involves a chicken and its eggs, and all parties to the agreement made it plain that it is strictly a temporary one.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A statutory invitation to the United Nations to modify or halt completely the American $400,000,000 Greek-Turkish aid program at any time a majority voted its displeasure was proposed today by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg.
LOS ANGELES, March 31 (U.P.) -- The biggest surprise of the American Bowling Congress tournament to date was provided today by the performance of a 15-year-old bowler and his partner.

The principal need in the effort to raise the mental health of the nation is more money for trained personnel, Dr. Frank F. Tollman, Commissioner of Hygiene in the Ohio Department of Public Welfare, declared yesterday.
With the opening of its 1947 fund-raising campaign scheduled for today, the American Cancer Society asked the public yesterday for full support of its effort to raise at least $12,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- Fees totaling $2,485,000, to be paid out of the $15,000,000 settlement received by the Pennroad Corporation in legal action against the Pennsylvania Railroad, were recommended today for sixteen attorneys and three members of a stockholders' committee who took part in the litigation.

Simultaneous announcements yesterday disclosed that Joe Lapchick, after eleven seasons as basketball coach at St. John's University in Brooklyn, had been released from his contract to accept the headcoaching job with the New York Knickerbockers of the Basketball Association of America.

Back in 1914, when Andy Coakley took the job of coaching Columbia baseball teams, someone should have informed him that the post was, more or less, a permanent one. If it was security that Coakley wanted the gentleman must, by now, be convinced that he is on firm ground.

LONDON, March 31 -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Frederick E. Morgan, former chief of United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation operations in Germany, charged today that the relief agency had been and probably, still was, honeycombed with Soviet secret police agents.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- A District grand jury today indicted Howard Fast, an author, and sixteen others identified as members of the governing body of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee.
The Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, which has been operating with guest conductors for the last three seasons, has engaged Erich Leinsdorf as its permanent conductor.

For the first time since pre-war days, new and varied collections of lower - priced machine-made wallpapers are now available in stores here. Pattern books and fresh samples of these papers have just been distributed to decorating departments in several local stores where wallpaper services that were virtually suspended are being revived.

Stock prices drifted lower yesterday in dull trading. Final prices were near the lowest for the day, with the leaders off fractions to 3 points and selected issues 3 to 5 points lower. The threatened telephone strike and the coal mine holiday, along with doubts concerning earnings of the railroads, influenced the trend of prices.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Congress passed today and President Truman "with reluctance" signed legislation extending sugar rationing and price controls until Oct. 31.

TRENTON, N.J., March 31 -- Legislation that would have forced hundreds of New Jersey policemen and firemen and other State and municipal employes to retire on pension was returned to committee tonight by its introducer, State Senator Alfred B. Littell, Republican, of Sussex.

The 740 port patrolmen in this area who were dismissed last Friday as part of a Federal economy measure, received renewed hope for restoration of their jobs yesterday from Gilbert A. Chase, president of the Port Patrol Officers Association.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., son of the late President, called at Tammany Hall yesterday afternoon and conferred with the Tammany leader, Frank J. Sampson, at Mr. Sampson's invitation.

JERUSALEM, March 31 -- Taking a drastic step against terrorism, the Palestine Government decided today that the country's population, preferably the Jewish community, should pay for the damage, at least $1,000,000, caused by explosions and fires among oil installations and stores in Haifa.

State wood manufacturers, even though Mr. Herzog had told the House committee that "the board no longer makes decisions based on the Clark Brothers case, at least until there should be some further ruling from the Federal courts."

With improvement in availability of some materials, passenger car factory sales during February totaled 266,237, or 8 per cent higher, than the 247,130 sales in January, the Automobile Manufacturers Association announced today after an industry-wide survey.

Inspired by easier stock and grain prices, selling of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange increased yesterday, and final prices were at or near the lowest levels of the day, and 21 to 36 points net below Saturday's final quotations.

Baltimore County, Md., awarded $1,000,000 of Metropolitan District bonds due on April 1, 1948 to 1987, to Drexel Co. and associates. Their bid was 100.04 for a combination of interest rates representing a net interest cost of 1.694 per cent.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 1 -- Alexandre Parodi, French representative, proposed today that the United Nations Commission on Conventional Armaments concentrate on accelerating the withdrawal of occupation forces stationed in the territory of member nations without their consent.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio denounced this evening the AchesonLilienthal report, basis of United States policy for world control of atomic energy, as an instrument that would place Russians in charge of American atomic bomb plants.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A series of conferences, intended to bring national leaders of the Democratic party into closer touch and, it is hoped, sympathy with state Democratic organizations, was announced today by Gael Sullivan, executive director of the Democratic National Committee.

Mayor O'Dwyer, in two ceremonies at City Hall, swore in six appointees to municipal posts yesterday. Five of the new office holders, with salaries ranging from $4,500 to $11,000 a year, reflected the first patronage accorded Frank J. Sampson, recently elected leader of Tammany Hall.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As members of American Relief to Austria, may we call to the attention of the public the urgent need at this minute of the Austrian children. We know children all over the world are suffering, freezing, starving, but think perhaps after Poland no group of children are suffering more than those of Austria.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Immediate submission of the GreekTurkish aid problem to the United Nations for a showdown with Russia within that organization was proposed before a surprised Senate today by Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia.

HAVANA, April 1 -- Lippy Leo Durocher put in a very full day at Gran Stadium today and one result of his earnest application to his job was a bit of confusion -- nothing unusual in the Dodger history.

ALBANY, April 1 -- New York State ended its 1946-47 fiscal year with a $58,712,842 surplus, Frank C. Moore, State Controller, reported today to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey. It was the fifth successive year that the state has had a substantial excess of revenues over expenditures.

LITHONIA, Ga., April 1 (AP) -- Police Chief Edward L. Foster of De Kalb County said today that a Negro and his wife were taken from their home by Jour unmasked white men last night and flogged severely. The woman was shot in the foot.

Sam Snead, who won the British open golf title last year, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday from Johannesburg, South Africa, via Pan-American Overseas Airlines. Accompanying him was Arthur (Bobby) Locke, South African professional champion, who was Snead's playing companion on a six-week tour of that country.
More than 600 friends attended a simple funeral service for former Gov. Charles S. Whitman yesterday afternoon at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.
PARIS, April 1 - Victor Dimpault, Inspector General of the French colonies, left Paris today by plane for Madagascar to investigate the attacks on French troops that broke out Sunday and Monday.

Tom Smith, trainer for the Maine Chance Farm, formally was received back into the circle of official horsemen yesterday when the license committee of the Jockey Club granted a trainer's license to him at its regular meeting. Thus Smith, subject of a cause celebre of the American turf, was authorized to ply his trade again in this State, where all his troubles began, and automatically everywhere else in the nation.
NANKING, April 1 -- The reorganized Government that was scheduled to make its appearance by today has not materialized.

Eighteen thousand telephone operators in the metropolitan area have been called to two meetings in Manhattan Center today to vote on joining the national telephone strike at 6 A.M. Monday. The meetings, to be held at 2 P.M. and 7 P.M., were called by the Telephone Employes Association, which has already filed a formal strike notice with the Department of Labor.

NASSAU, Bahamas, April 1 -- C. Stanley Ogilvy's Whip, from Western Long Island Sound, won the second race of the first International Star Class spring championships since the beginning of the war today. Whip tied for the lead in points with Gem II for the series.

HONOLULU, T.H., April 1 -- Brig. Gen. Wayne C. Smith, commanding general of Schofield Barracks, today began an investigation into the attempted escape from the post stockade last night of thirty Army prisoners. During the outbreak, one prisoner was killed, an officer of the guard beaten unconscious, and four guards were held as hostages.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 -- Samuel Goldwyn today signed Howard Hawks to direct "That's Life," Danny Kaye's next film, which will go before the cameras in May. Hawks has just completed, his own independent production, "Red River," which United Artists will release.
RANGOON, Burma, April 1 -- Another stage was marked on Burma's progress toward self-government today. Beginning today, her currency is no longer linked with India's.

DETROIT, April 1 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs whipped the Detroit Red Wings, 4 to 1, at Olympia tonight before 14,496 fans to take a 2-to-1 lead in games in their four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup hockey semi-finals.

The instinct and practice of politicians and diplomats "to withhold the truth or sugar-coat it lavishly with untruths and evasions" is still heavily obstructing any real evaluation of events in foreign policy, Arthur Krock, chief Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told 500 teachers yesterday.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday all the early losses and closed at about the best levels of the day, 15 to 45 points net higher. The far months showed relatively greater strength than old-crop months.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1 -- Although it had been accepted as a foregone conclusion for some time that Don Johnson would be one of the Yankees' starting hurlers this year, it was not until today that this extraordinary young man from Oregon officially was removed from the roster of the Kansas City club and received a New York contract to sign.

Senator Harley M. Kilgore of West Virginia called last night for a curb against those who seek to "split America" by encouraging group dissensions, a phenomenon that is growing, he said, as it did after the first World War.

Deposits of the Chase National Bank at the end of the first quarter of this year were $4,488,156,000, compared with $4,495,304,000 on Dec. 31, 1946, and $5,140,087,000, on March 30, last year, according to the statement released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Eastern railroads piled up evidence today of the need for increased passenger fares on the second and final day of the hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission and continued to contend that the moderate nature of the increases would not cause loss of traffic.

JERUSALEM, April 1 -- The hope that all of the 1,200 or more Jewish immigrant children in Cyprus detention camps might be transferred in a body to Palestine for rehabilitation and training was voiced today by Mrs. David de Sola Pool in announcing plans for the construction of a u100,000 children's reception center near Haifa.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 1 -- Perturbed because they have no athletic field for their baseball team, 571 pupils at the North Tarrytown High School went on strike today. They refused to be lured back even by a Rockefeller offer of a temporary field.

New York business groups have been asked to contribute $1,000,000 more to the Greater New York Fund this year than last, according to a memorandum made public yesterday by health and welfare organizations.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 1 -- Plans have been completed by Miss Janice Sue Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold F. Miller of this city, for her marriage to James Douglas Freeman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Douglas Southall Freeman of Richmond, Va.

The imaginative skill of the French couture was evident yesterday at a showing of imports presented to the press at Bergdorf Goodman. Drapery manipulated with a seemingly simple but highly effective touch, a slim silhouette with fullness at the hips tapering in sharply at the hemline, a few skirts with fullness springing from the waist or a lower point at the hips, and deep shawl-like shoulder trims were a few of the nighlights.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Two years ago this month the Truman Administration was trying to devise ways and means of getting Senator Arthur Vandenberg's support for a strong and liberal international security organization at San Francisco.

FORT BENNING, Ga., April 1 -- Large-scale full-dress rehearsal of tactical cooperation between Army air and ground forces in the theoretical defense of the United States against an enemy which landed in Florida and secured the entire state began here today.

BERLIN, April 1 (AP) -- A fast, well-trained Czech Army team took the lead tonight in the opening round of the four-day Allied Forces championship boxing tournament in the Olympic Stadium Sports Club by scoring victories in five preliminary bouts.

Sunshine yellow set the theme for a fashion show of Henry Rosenfeld's spring and summer dresses at Russeks yesterday. Casual dresses and suits in a variety of fabrics were shown in varying shades of yellow, with yellow backgrounds, or in striped combinations that included yellow.

Acceptance by fifteen leading industrialists and business men of chairmanships in the $2,590,000 fund-raising project of the Thomas Alva Edison Foundation was announced yesterday by Harvey S. Firestone Jr., national chairman of the Thomas Alva Edison Foundation Fund.

MOSCOW, April 1 (AP) -- Prof. Eugene Tarle outlined in Izvestia today a definition of what may be considered the official Russian conception of Germany's future government, declaring that primarily Germany should be "a decentralized nation."

The large body of temporary laws passed in connection with the prosecution of the war fell into three broad categories -- those which were to last during the period of "hostilities," those associated with the states of "emergency" declared in 1939 and 1941, and those which were to continue until the "termination of the war."

Fewer Buyers' Arrivals Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 552, compared with 880 last week and 1,820 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- In the greatest turnout of voters in the city's history, Chicago today elected as Mayor the Democrat, Martin H. Kennelly, 59-year-old business executive and civic leader. The term is four years.

IT'S a rather significant development that Joe Lapchick calmly turned his back on a life tenure as coach at St. John's to accept a similar post with the professional New York Knickerbockers of the Basketball Association of America. "I'm just an old pro at heart," sheepishly admitted the one-time center of the immortal Original Celtics.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee today approved, 7 to 1, a bill extending a Government price-support program on wool through 1948.

With the use of radioactive substances increasing, doctors must see that the public becomes better informed than it is now about the great danger involved, Dr. Hermann P. Muller, Professor of Zoology at Indiana University, declared yesterday.

Ration stamps good for at least 24,000 pounds of sugar, and possibly for twice that amount, are being sent out every day from the New York ration issuance office to persons who say their stamps have been lost, stolen or destroyed, it was learned yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 1 -- The country's 400,000 soft-coal miners began today a six-day mourning holiday for the 111 mine dead of Centralia, Ill., on a warning, sounded in two widely separated areas, that may become the keynote for a revolt against returning to work next Monday.

DUISBURG, Germany, April 1 -- As Ruhr coal production dropped to the lowest figure since Jan. 21, this year, the North German Coal Control disclosed that it would apply sanctions against miners who absent themselves from work to participate in demonstrations that have been popping up all over this area in the last week.

Accompanied by a price reduction of $20 the Ford deluxe sixcylinder, three-passenger business coupe has been restored to the company's line of cars, J.R. Davis, vice president and director of sales and advertising, Ford Motor Company, announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 1 -- The completely nonpartisan aspect of United States policy as expressed in the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting here was emphasized today by John Foster Dulles, Republican delegate on Secretary of State Marshall's diplomatic team.

Mayor O'Dwyer's proposed budget of $1,029,120,314 was described yesterday as a blow to real estate, a threat to new business and proof that a ten-cent transit fare will soon be unavoidable. The new use tax of $5 on automobiles and $10 on trucks with which the Mayor proposes to balance the record budget was denounced as "extortionate" and imposing a "penalty for which there is no equitable basis."

LOS ANGELES, April 1 -- Formation of a nation-wide organization, to be known as "The Friends of Public Education," was proposed here today by Mrs. Eugene Meyer, wife of the owner of The Washington Post, as one way to improve the public school system.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 1 (AP) -- With a scorching sun beating down on the courts, play ran true to form today as the River Oaks invitation tennis tournament field was whittled to thirty-two.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 1 -- Like many an American city, this suburban community is bisected by a railroad cut that becomes increasingly ugly on the landscape as neighboring buildings are modernized and boulevards constructed.

George Neikrug, an Army veteran, made the 'cello a vehicle for adventurous program-making and playing at the Town Hall last night. He found some music for the instrument not played by every recitalist, and what he found he performed with the earnestness and devotion of a scholarly and imaginative mind.

The text of Mayor O'Dwyer's budget message submitted to the Board of Estimate and the City Council follows: To the Board of Estimate and the City Council: Gentlemen: I present herewith for your consideration the Executive Budget for the fiscal year 1947-1948.

CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- The AllAmerica Football Conference today signed three new players and a fourth, Claude (Buddy) Young, former University of Illinois halfback, indicated that he had come to terms with the New York Yankees.

Banks Closing Saturday All regular commercial and savings banks in the metropolitan area, Westchester, Rockland and Nassau Counties will inaugurate year-round Saturday closing schedules this week, according to the latest results of a survey recently undertaken by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

NEW DELHI, India, April 1 -- A report to the Inter-Asian Relations Conference from its committee on "national movements for freedom" has urged Asiatics to "take effective steps to bring a speedy termination to foreign domination over their countries."

One of the city's gas companies obtained yesterday from the Public Service Commission permission to refuse to accept new customers for home heating and two others obtained extensions until November of identical restrictions already in force.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Truman called on Congress today to extend rent control for a year beyond its present June 30 expiration date, to provide "proper protection" for millions of American families during the current "critical housing shortage."

Coming into Easter with coal sales lagging as the result of unfavorable weather conditions, outof-town stores are following the lead of New York retailers in slashing prices on spring merchandise, it was reported yesterday by resident buyers.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Registrars and admissions officers of a score of colleges and universities asserted today that every qualified applicant who sincerely wanted to go to college last fall was able to find a place to go. Their spokesman was Ronald R. Thompson of Ohio State University, chairman of the admissions study group of the National Education Association's higher education conference.

The House of Representatives overruled yesterday an action of its Appropriations Committee so irresponsible in its vindictiveness that it would have stood as a black page in the history of American constitutional government. The Committee's action consisted in refusing to honor a request for funds to meet a Court of Claims judgment which has been unanimously upheld by the Supreme Court.

The master agreement intended to encourage investment in new construction by stabilizing labor costs suffered a new setback yesterday, when 600 Brooklyn and Queens plumbers went on strike for wages higher than those fixed in the stabilization compact.

Three Brooklyn shopkeepers were in Flatbush Magistrate's Court yesterday because thoughtless children had fired cap pistols into the faces of blind veterans' guide dogs. The storekeepers, charged with violation of a recently enacted amendment to the firearms law that makes it a misdemeanor to have for sale cap pistols, firecrackers or caps, were held, for trial in Special Sessions.

BOWIE, Md., April 1 -- With the sun beaming and the weather mild, 14,952 persons crowded into the Southern Maryland Agricultural Association's unpretentious little track today to see the horses run and to do battle with the mutuels. This was the first day of Bowie's eleven-day meeting and also the initial session of the Eastern racing campaign.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Grains turned sharply upward in the late trading on the Board of Trade today after showing weakness early. Closing trades were at the top, with wheat gaining 1 1/2 to 7 cents. Corn rose 1/4 to 1 1/2 cents and oats were unchanged to 1 3/4 cents up.

An appeal to Governor Dewey to make funds available for the extension, of the child day care center program in New York City into the early months of 1948, will be made by the United Neighborhood Houses, which includes all the settlement houses in the city, it was announced yesterday.

Herman W. Steinkraus, president of the Bridgeport Brass Company and chairman of the committee on labor relations of the National Association of Manufacturers, last night "cross-examined" Robert R. Nathan, Washington economist and co-author of the CIO's "Nathan Report."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 1 -- The succession of Crown Prince Paul to the Greek throne may open the way for collaboration of all "democratic parties" in the country, Vassili Dendramis, chief of the Greek delegation to the United Nations and Ambassador to Washington, said today.

YONKERS, N.Y., April 1 -- Irving Gaines is a manufacturer of handbags and knows nothing about narcotics. But after last night's experience he may think twice before admitting men to his home who say they are from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

LONDON, April 1 -- Renewed buying of base metal shares following the rise in-United Kingdom prices together with further improvement in British Government stocks were the features of an otherwise quiet stock market today.
LONDON, April 1 -- The condolences of the British Government over the death of King George II of the Hellenes are being conveyed by the Duke of Gloucester, acting for the absent King George VI.

Despite protests, the Office of Alien Property, now in the Department of Justice, signed a, contract last week with Milton Shubert, nephew of Lee and J. J. Shubert, giving him the right to use material from the operas of Giacomo Puccini, it become known yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- New labor legislation is the only way to stop labor from depriving the country of prosperity in its quest for power, W.C. Johnson, vice president of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company or Milwaukee, told the Midwest Power Conference today.

Setting a precedent in the cigarette field by using daytime radio in an appeal to housewives, Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of Cecil Presbrey, Inc., for a radio campaign for Philip Morris cigarettes. Programs to be sponsored are "Queen for a Day" and "Heart's Desire."

"Tenting Tonight, Frank Gould's comedy, which arrives tonight at the Booth (the curtain will rise at 8:20), is the first of two new offerings to come along this week with a college background. The other is "Barefoot Boy With Cheek," a musical opening tomorrow night at the Beck.
Elmer A. Stevens has been named director of purchases of the B.F. Goodrich Company, effective July 1. He will succeed A.D. Moss, who will retire after forty-eight years with the company.

MADRID, April 1 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco's speech last night on plans for naming a possible successor was the main topic of conversation today, with interpretations varying widely. Monarchists appeared intensely annoyed.

MOSCOW, April 1 -- The Big Four agreed to tackle the problem of Germany's future government tomorrow after three and a quarter hours of blunt, indecisive and at times bitter discussion today of the level-of-industry and reparations questions.

The National Federation of American Shipping issued a statement yesterday opposing suggestions that the United States turn over seventy-five Liberty ships to German crews under American supervision to transport bulk foods to Germany.

The internal storm that raged through the National Maritime Union, CIO, at Monday night's membership meeting in Manhattan Center, which found NMU vice president Joseph Stack guilty of charges brought by Joseph Curran, president, gained in intensity yesterday.

New mortgage financing in the amount of $775,000 at 4 per cent interest for ten years has been obtained by the Elbeco Realty Corporation from a savings bank on the ten-story store and loft building occupying the blockfront on Hoyt Street between Livingston and Schermerhorn Streets, Brooklyn.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 11 per cent in March, compared with the same month last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The figure compares with a rise of 9 per cent in February.

Crown Prince Paul, who succeeds his brother as King of the Hellenes at the age of 45, is the sixth Greek monarch since the country was proclaimed a kingdom 117 years ago after having gained its independence from Turkey.

DETROIT, April 1 (AP) -- The Packard Motor Car Company had a factory operating loss of $6,539,062 in 1946, but offset it with profits from branch and subsidiary operations, tax refunds and reserves to achieve a $4,835,513 addition to earned surplus, the annual report showed today.

Okinawa Day, commemorating the second anniversary of the American invasion of that Japanese stronghold, was observed here yesterday. Speakers hailed that campaign as a demonstration that Americans of all races, creeds and colors could work together in time of war as they should work in time of peace.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Arthur Bliss Lane, who has retired as United States Ambassador to Poland to inform the American people through private writings of the situation in that country, charged at a news conference today that the Warsaw Government was a satellite of Soviet Russia.
PARIS, April 1 -- The inner Cabinet considered two problems tonight -- the meat supply and former President de Gaulle -- without apparently settling either.

The Provisional International Civil Aviation Organization, which will drop the "provisional" from its title on Friday and become permanent through ratification by thirty-four nations, has found no way to eject Spain from membership, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 26: Decreases of $563,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations, $204,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, $179,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted and $655,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

Mayor O'Dwyer broke two records yesterday when he submitted an executive budget for 1947-43 amounting to $1,029,120,314, with an indicated basic tax rate of $2.95 on each $100 of assessed valuation. Both figures set new high marks.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The United States Public Health Service disclosed today that Columbus, Ga., had been selected for a long range study of BOG vaccination for tuberculosis, widely used in both Europe and South America.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 1 -- The Soviet Union bluntly informed the United Nations Balkans Commission today that the Yugoslav Government has no intention of answering questions concerning its foreign policy toward Greece.

ROME, April 1 -- Britain agreed to convert u32,000,000 of the u33,000,000 standing to Italy's credit in London into dollars at the official exchange rate of $4.03 under the convention approved by the Italian Cabinet today.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A Congressional investigation of the status of outsanding loans made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was promised today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

NEW ORLEANS, La., April 1 -- The need of public relations in the alcoholic beverage industry was cited today by Ellis D. Slater, chairman of the executive committee of the Licensed Beverage Industries.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Earl G. Harrison, former Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, urged today that the United States amend its immigration laws and "assume leadership in providing new homes for the displaced persons" who are now in Europe.

LONDON, April 1 -- Britain's peacetime conscription bill passed the second reading in the House of Commons tonight without a division. But before that more than seventy Labor party members of Parliament had voted against their own Government and for a motion that would have rejected the bill.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, may have won his fight to prevent the appointment of James Boyd to head the Bureau of Mines, it was indicated today.
By a vote of 25 to 3 the Freedom House board of directors placed itself yesterday behind President Truman's policy of extending aid to Greece and Turkey.
ATHENS, April 1 -- King George II of the Hellenes died at 1:55 P.M. today of a heart attack. Six hours later his brother, Crown Prince Paul, was sworn in as the new Greek monarch.

An all-industry campaign to increase consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables was announced yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Council of the Port of New York at the Hotel McAlpin.

A statement made to the House Foreign Affairs Committee by the CIO Maritime Committee that it believes American-built merchant ships are being sold to Greek shipowners who subsequently transfer them to the Panamanian and Honduran flags has been categorically denied by the Greek shipowners' committee of New York, it was disclosed yesterday.

Five European orphan children, 2 to 4 years old, who were seized when they were infants by the Germans and assigned to "kultur" centers for training were among the 888 passengers who arrived here yesterday from Bremerhaven on the transport Marine Marlin.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 1 -- All roads led to Augusta today as the stragglers filed in for the eleventh annual Masters golf tournament which will open on Thursday. Many of the topnotchers, notably Ben Hogan and Byron Nelson, have been here for a week or more getting their games tuned up for the event that is a sort of testimonial to Bobby Jones' "grand slam" feat of 1930.

LONDON, April 1 -- A financial agreement by which Britain will waive her right under the peace treaty to seize Italian pre-war assets in the United Kingdom is almost ready for signature, it was learned today.

The interest rate pattern in this Federal Reserve District on last Nov. 29 ranged from slightly less than 1 per cent to 6 per cent, and the average rate charged on all business loans by all member banks was 2.3 per cent, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York stated yesterday in reporting the latest results of its recent survey of commercial and industrial loans.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 1 -- Vestibula Stable's Cash Reward turned the tables on a previous conqueror in beating Allen Strandlund's Bert, runner-up in the mile and a sixteenth feature at Gulfstream Park today. Cash Reward, second to Bert at a mile and seventy yards last week, was booted home by Jack Robertson in 1:44 flat, Woolford Farm's Leavenworth was third.
Stuffed toy bunnies, some in gay clothes, others with washable "fur" of mohair, appear more prolific this year than at any Easter in years, according to a survey yesterday of local toy departments.

J.H. Bleistein, former president of the American Fur Merchants Association for eight terms, has been named manager of the business of Motty Eitingon, Inc., mouton fur processors and dealers, it was disclosed yesterday at the meeting of creditors at the United States Court House.

The people of New York City were prepared to expect a larger expense budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1. Nevertheless it is sobering news that Mayor O'Dwyer has set this proposed figure at $1,029,120,314. Thus the executive budget passes the billiondollar mark for the first time in the history of the city.

The Philadelphia Orchestra completed its annual series of visits to Carnegie Hall last night with the tenth and final concert of its New York season. To commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the death of Brahms, which falls tomorrow, Eugene Ormandy played a program devoted entirely to that composer.
JERUSALEM, April 1 -- David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, belabored the British Government and Palestine terrorists with equal vigor today.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- For the first time in the present session, one of the top figures in the House Republican leadership, Chairman John Taber of the Appropriations Committee, sustained today several important setbacks when the membership overrode the recommendations of the veteran legislator from New York.

Taking advantage of distress situations to obtain almost fantastic prices for paper is a direct blow at the free enterprise system. E.W. Tinker, executive secretary, American Paper and Pulp Association, declared here yesterday.

An emergency bill framed by Representative Hartley, Chairman of the House Labor Committee, to halt by Federal injunction the national strike of telephone workers called for April 7 apparently stands little chance of being enacted into law before the walk-out is scheduled to take place.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 1 -- The task of determining what happened to a yachtsman who disappeared ten years ago while on a 3,000-mile Atlantic Ocean solo voyage faced Surrogate Charles H. Griffiths of Westchester County today.
Those who think the woodcock hunter is the most secretive individual in the world probably have never encountered a Long Island trout fisherman who knows where there are a few trout.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Through constant repetition, rumors that Yugoslavia has designs on the territorial integrity of Greece -- especially on Aegean Macedonia -- and is training Greek partisans in guerrilla tactics and hampering the Royal Greek Army in its warfare against guerrilla forces have come to be accepted in THE TIMES and elsewhere as statements of fact.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The revelations concerning Eugene Dennis of the Communist party made by J. Edgar Hoover in Washington served to recall an incident of importance in November of last year. This incident indicates the unscrupulous tactics of the Communists in assaulting anyone who tells the truth about the Moscow conspiracy against the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 1 - Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, an opponent of the Army-Navy unification bill, sought to imply today in questions asked Vice Admiral Forrest P. Sherman that White House "pressure" had forced the Army and Navy to alter their views, even after there had been agreement on the compromise of Jan. 16.

The nation-wide campaign of the American Cancer Society to raise at least $12,000,000 for the most concentrated attack on cancer attempted so far opened last night with a meeting at the Astor Hotel. Notables in many walks of life attended, headed by Cardinal Spellman, who pronounced the invocation.

The top officials of American tennis, headed by President Holcombe Ward, gathered on board the French liner Oregon yesterday for a luncheon given by the members of the French team on tour of the United States and Canada.

NEW DELHI, April 1 (U.P.) -- Speaking before the Inter-Asian Relations Conference today, Mohandas K. Gandhi called for the establishment of a permanent Asian Institute, which would meet regularly to discuss the problems of Asia, but "not to wage war with Europe and America."

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The House Labor Committee refused today to grant its immediate approval to an emergency strikecontrol bill by its chairman, Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican, of New Jersey, which had been eyed with reserve by the House leaders.

MOSCOW, April 1 -- The Austrian delegation waiting to present its treaty views to the Council of Foreign Ministers decided today to send an aide-memoire to the Soviet Government recalling that Premier Stalin had promised to support the integrity of Austria.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 1 -- The United States birth-rate is undergoing the biggest boom in its history, according to figures contained in the March issue of the United Nations Monthly Bulletin of Statistics, to be published tomorrow.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Within a very short time the United States Senate will consider ratifying a treaty with Canada concerning the creation of a joint commission to control the Great Lakes fisheries. The Senate will consider this treaty and pass its judgment on it, but only a relatively few thousands of people will have taken note of the action.
LONDON, April 1 -- A strong likelihood that the British Government would repudiate the threatened levy against Palestinian Jews to pay for yesterday's oil fire damage developed today.

CENTRALIA, Ill., April 1 -- Gov. Dwight H. Green this afternoon announced the resignation of Robert M. Medill, director of the State Department of Mines and Minerals, "for the good of the service." At the same time the Governor announced that Prof. Harold Leroy Walker of the Department of Mining and Metallurgical Engineering at the University of Illinois would succeed Mr. Medill on a temporary basis.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 1 -- With the most impressive pitching flashed by a Giant since the training campaign got under way, forkballing Bill Ayers today became the second of Mel Ott's pitchers to go the nine-inning route and the first to achieve a shutout.
Homer Collyer was buried yesterday in the family plot in Cypress Hills Cemetery, Queens.

With completion yesterday of the west rose window over the main entrance to St. Patrick's Cathedral on Fifth Avenue, a handsomely renovated unit of the background for this year's Easter parade was assured.

The death of King George of Greece has removed from the political scene one of the most controversial rulers ever placed by destiny in a key position. But it has added new uncertainties to the uneasy situation in the Balkans at a moment when the United States proposes to take its stand there against further Russo-Communist aggression.
Far and Wide Rationalization, as everybody knows, is the process of thinking up profound and high-minded reasons for liking what a person likes and disliking what he doesn't much care for.

BOSTON, April 1 (AP) -- With Billy Reay scoring four goals, the Montreal Canadiens gained a 3-1 lead in games over the Boston Bruins in their four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup hockey semi-finals with a 5-1 triumph tonight before a crowd of 13,909 at the Boston Garden.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Under the auspices of Lewis B. Schwellenbach, Secretary of Labor, representatives of the American Union of Telephone Workers and the long-lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, held their first conference in this city today and it was officially announced that no substantial progress has been made."

Owners of the Imperial Hotel, landmark at Broadway and Thirtysecond Street, began proceedings in Municipal Court yesterday to evict 200 permanent residents. The eviction notices are returnable April 9.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 1 -- Charges that the United States was employing a "strategy of hunger" to take advantage of wartorn countries that lack food and thus subordinate them to the American "monopolistic group" were played up in the Belgrade press today.

ATHENS, April 1 (AP) -- The accession of Paul to the Greek throne was automatic under the law. The third son of King Constantine took the scepter of Government less than seven months after his brother had returned from his latest exile in London.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (U.P.) -- Chairman J. Parnell Thomas of the House Un-American Activities Committee asked Tom C. Clark, Attorney General, today to begin prosecution of the Communist party and its officials for failure to register as foreign agents and for seeking overthrow of the Government.

Activity in the final hour of trading yesterday brought stock prices to a firmer close, with the steel and motor shares leading, after an irregularly lower opening. Transfers were slightly higher than during the previous session, at 770,000 shares, compared with 720,000 on Monday.

Securities valued at $43,582,776 will be placed on the market here today by underwriting managers as follows: Atlantic Refining Company -- 250,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative 3.75 per cent dividend preferred stock, at $100 a share, by Smith, Barney Co.

The Greek Government and the Greek rebels assert that the sudden death of the King will make no difference in the internal situation. Administration spokesmen in Washington say it will not affect the policy of aid to Greece. The brother of the ill-fated George II was immediately sworn in to take his place, so there is no change in the regime.

Scale constitutes the theme of an exhibition that opens today at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. Installed in socially arranged galleries on the third floor, it will remain through May 4. This unusual show was directed by Margaret Miller of the museum staff.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- A threat to boycott Panamanian ships in all American ports unless Congress, or the Maritime Commission, puts a stop to the transfer of United States-owned vessels to Panamanian registry was made today in a resolution adopted by the Maritime Trades Department, AFL.

CLINTON, N.J., April 1 -- Tip Top Soo, pointer bitch handled by Herman Smith of Hatchechubie, Ala., won the $1,000 Imperial open all-age stake, climax of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club's spring trials today.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., April 1 -- Dr. Joshua Loth Liebman, author of "Peace of Mind," called today for Congressional appropriations to carry out the provisions of the National Mental Health Act. The act, passed by the last Congress, authorizes funds for research and teaching in the field of mental health.

Gross sales of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation last year were $37,615,540, or about 15 per cent of the 1945 volume of $236,846,862, and only 11 per cent of the peak gross sales of $323,749,331 of 1944, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Leroy R. Grumman, board chairman.

AMSTERDAM, April 1 (Aneta) -- Profit taking, following yesterday's gains, accounted for the decline in prices on the Stock Exchange today. Trading was active, as this was the first day when yields from the sale of securities was completely free.

Mrs. Melville Irwin has been home-fashioning candy for fifteen years. She might have continued for another fifteen, and we would never have known, had it not been that we suddenly came on a tiny notice of her enterprise in a magazine we were thumbing through in a dentist's waiting room.

SPARTA, Greece, March 31 (Delayed) -- A substantial increase in the Government forces, combined with new methods of attack, appears to have brought about an early success in the military operations now in progress in eloponnesus.

Voting under Proportional Representation, a year and a half ago, the people of New York elected a City Council composed of twenty-three members -- of whom fourteen were Democrats, three Republicans, two acknowledged Communists, two Liberals and two American Laborites.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 1 -- An "international arcade," containing stores and small shops, may be established in the projected world capital in midtown Manhattan, it was learned today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 -- The American Locomotive Company of New York asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to withdraw a registration statement filed last July 18 covering a proposed public offering of 100,000 shares of $100 par value prior preferred stock and 100,000 shares of convertible second preferred stock, $100 par value.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Consumers can expect food prices to hold near present levels during the next few months, largely because of their own lusty demands, the Agriculture Department said today.

LONDON, April 2 -- The British have definitely decided not to relinquish their mandate in Palestine to the United Nations when the General Assembly meets to consider the Palestinian problem, it was learned in an authoritative quarter today.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 2 (AP) -- Sam Match of Los Angeles, boasting a great assortment of strokes and showing amazing strength on his back hand, defeated Bitsy Grant of Atlanta, 6 -- 3, 0 -- 6, 6 -- 2, in the feature contest of today's program in the River Oaks invitation tennis tournament.
