LONDON, April 2 -- The Labor Government's leaders decided today to reconcile themselves to the heavy vote of Labor Members of Parliament against their peacetime conscription bill in the House of Commons last night.
MOSCOW, April 2 -- The United States Government has informed the Soviet Union that the United States' once-powerful armed forces in China will be reduced to a total of 6,180 men by next June 1.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 2 (AP) -- Christopher T. Chenery's Hornbeam set a new track record today in capturing the seven-furlong Hollywood Handicap at Gulf stream Park. The 7-year-old gelding, who had lowered the six-furlong mark at Tropical Park in a previous outing, breezed in 1:22 3-5 under Jockey Wayne D. Wright to pay $5.50 for $2.

DETROIT, April 2 (AP) -- The nation's automotive industry, having turned out nearly a million and a quarter passenger cars and trucks in the first quarter of 1947, will try to equal or top that mark during the next three months.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The principle of the Vandenberg proposal for so bringing the spirit of the United Nations into the $400,000,000 Greek-Turkish aid program as to authorize that organization to halt the program at will has won almost unanimous, although informal, support of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, it was learned tonight.

Bach's "The Passion According to St. John" was presented by the Schola Cantorum, under Hugh Ross, last night at Carnegie Hall. The great masterpiece received a noble and reverent performance. All of the participants threw themselves whole-heartedly into an interpretation that was carefully detailed throughout and filled with vivid contrasts.

The stock market closed easier yesterday, with prices irregularly lower. The turnover was limited, although trading expanded in the final hour when about 220,000 shares changed hands. Turnover was 680,000 shares, the smallest in a week, compared with 770,000 on Tuesday.

JERUSALEM, April 2 -- Once again playing heavily upon the cost of terrorism to the people of Palestine themselves, the Government gave out the impression tonight that it might be years before the country's oil supply position would recover from the effects of the terrorist bombing of the Shell Company's installations at Haifa on Monday.

Legal Interest Announcement yesterday that Governor Dewey had signed the legislation amending the Banking Laws affecting interest rates on instalment loans of certain types, while not unexpected, was received with considerable relief and satisfaction in banking circles.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, disclosed today that the Government is preparing a revision of its budget estimate, which originally forecast a deficit of nearly $2,300,000,000 for the current fiscal year ending June 30.

With the signing in Trenton yesterday of three bills authorizing the Port of New York Authority to proceed with the development on lease of the Newark airport and marine terminal -- bills identical with those passed by the New York Legislature -- the Port Authority was described yesterday as ready to begin work on the regional airport development as soon as the draft of an agreement with the City of New York is signed.

Good Friday, the traditional anniversary of the crucifixion, will becommemorated widely tomorrow by churches of all faiths in the New York area. Almost all the leading churches in midtown Manhattan will hold a three-hour "agony service" in Observance of the three hours the Saviour hung on the cross of Calvary in Jerusalem. The day will be the most solemn in the religious calendar.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission heard argument today on an application of a group of railroads to pool the earnings of the Pullman Company's sleeping-car service and to acquire stock of the Pullman Company as a step in the pooling arrangement.

NANKING, April 2 (AP) -- The Chinese Government tonight confirmed that its troops had captured Taian and observers quickly speculated that the Government soon would open a major campaign to rout Chinese Communists from south of the Yellow River in western Shantung Province.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 2 -- A third union, the AFL-United Automobile Workers, today entered the field of groups seeking to be named bargaining agent for production workers at the AllisChalmers plant here.

Increasing illegal use of curb space for overnight parking by some garage owners who are getting high prices from hard-pressed motorists was charged by the Automobile Club of New York yesterday after a city-wide survey. According to club findings these garage owners accept cars when their buildings are filled to capacity, then place the excess vehicles on near-by streets for the night.

BOWIE, Md., April 2 (AP) -- Dashing over a sloppy track to his first victory of the year, George G. Gilbert Jr.'s Scholarship captured the $10,000-added Rowe Memorial Handicap today in a driving four-horse finish. With a crowd of 9,088 watching in the rain, Scholarship hit the wire a half length in front of Bobanet Stable's Aerial Song, while the Shamrock Stable's favored Air Patrol was third.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 2 -- Col. A. Roscher Lund, head of the United Rations secretariat attached to the Security Council Balkan Commission, reported today that published charges against Gustav Gottesman, his Polish assistant, either were "hallucinations" or a slanderous attack.

BOMBAY, April 2 (Reuters) -- As explosions shook Peshawar, capital of the North-West Frontier Province, today, twelve members of the Moslem League stormed the compound of Government House, residence of Sir Olaf Caroe, Governor of the province.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Representative Ploeser, Republican, of Missouri, chairman of the House Small Business Committee, said today thousands of small business men are protesting that they are unable to buy needed materials from the War Assets Administration.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (U.P.) -- The Senate Rules Committee upheld by a single vote today the right of a Senator to filibuster until he tires or two-thirds of his colleagues vote to silence him.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2 -- As rain today washed out the Yankees' final engagement in St. Pete, not to mention the concluding game of their series with the Cardinals, Manager Bucky Harris gathered with his aides to take up what eventually must become the Bombers' major problem of 1946.

The Stadium Concerts, Inc., which celebrates its thirtieth anniversary this year, will present the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in five concerts weekly during its season, which opens Monday, June 16, and closes Aug. 9, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America yesterday announced a group creditor life insurance plan to be offered to home loan borrowers, designed to pay off the open balance of a mortgage in the case of the borrower's death. The plan will be offered on a nation-wide basis, according to the company, which said that key personnel now is being trained.

The Aluminum Company of America had in 1946 a consolidated net income of $23,964,930 after taxes and all charges and after including $6,900,000 refundable portion of prior years' taxes arising from unused excess profits tax credit, the annual report said yesterday.

The factional struggle within the ranks of the National Maritime Union, CIO, continued yesterday, with the result that Joseph Stack now stands as a suspended but not ousted vice president of the union.
LONDON, April 2 -- Britain's housewives told the Government today they were "desperate" because of the acute shortage of household goods.

WARSAW, April 2 -- The Polish Government and the Vatican will Begin soon a new series of informal negotiations in Rome that may lay the basis for signing of a concordat and the re-establishing of relations between the state and the church in Poland, it was learned today.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 2 -- With fifty-seven of the world's leading club-swingers on hand, including the holders of the three major open championships -- the United States, British and Canadian -- the stage is now set for the eleventh Masters tournament, one of golfs choicest events.

Despite efforts of manufacturers to absorb increased costs, indications are that prices of men's fall clothing will advance about 5 to 7 per cent when lines are opened around the middle of this month. Higher prices for worsted fabrics and trimmings were cited yesterday in manufacturing quarters as the reason for the advance.

Alexandre Parodi, French delegate to the United Nations Security Council, said yesterday that the success of Air France, French National airline, was typical of the rate at which his country had recovered from the ravages of the war.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Responsible officials in the Truman Administration have proposed that the President consider Robert Moses, New York Park Commissioner, as director of the United States' plan to aid Greece and Turkey, it was learned today.

The City Planning Commission adopted yesterday its "conservative" plan for rezoning the area surrounding the permanent site of the United Nations headquarters, to be situated on the east side of Manhattan between Forty-second and Forty-eighth Streets.

Silk Plan Being Considered The plan for providing a fund for promotion of silk is still very much alive, according to trade sources yesterday. Government agencies concerned with the sale of Japanese silk now have under consideration the plan which calls for an initial expenditure of $300,000, and a decision is expected in the next few days.

FORT BENNING, Ga., April 2 -- In a simulated battle that had all the reality of actual conflict except confusion and casualties, American airborne troops landed behind the "enemy" on the Alabama side of the Chattahoochee River today to complete one phase of the ground-air cooperation maneuvers of Operation Wayside.

PARIS, April 2 (AP) -- Dispatches from Hanoi reported today that Col. Robert Marie Gufflet, French Chief of Staff for the Far East, and Col. Pierte Louis Debes, acting commander of French forces in Northern Indo-China, had been killed in a plane crash off the TongKing coast.

Babe Ruth and executives of Republic Pictures conferred "at great length" yesterday afternoon concerning plans for the filming of the home-run king's life story, it was announced by James R. Grainger, executive vice president of the motion picture company.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- An emergency bill empowering the Government to end by injunction such strikes as that now threaten on the national telephone lines was approved today, 16 to 3, by the House Labor Committee.

BERLIN, April 2 -- The Bavarian Minister of Agriculture delivered a speech at a meeting of the Munich Tuesday Club March 4 that has excited lively interest here. In that speech he opposed virtually every major policy of the United States or the bizonal agencies, and also expressed strong anti-Semitic sentiments.

VIENNA, April 2 -- Even with the projected financial aid from the United States, Austria is not going to get through the present year without running into another economic catastrophe, United States officials here predict.

A special decree imposing import licenses on commodities in the luxury and nonessential category was announced yesterday by the Brazilian Ministries of Treasury and Foreign Affairs, according to spokesmen for the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau.

The strange tale of a 15-year-old youth of a wealthy family, who stole his aunt's jewels and sold them for a song, came out yesterday when Arthur Shuarfc, 33, of 1 Lafayette Avenue, Suffern, N. Y., and his wife, Lena, also 33, were held in $5,000 bail each in the Rockland County Jail at New City, N. Y. They were charged with possessing, concealing and withholding stolen property.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2 -- Myrna Loy has been signed for the leading feminine role in the screen version of John Steinbeck's story, "The Red Pony," which Lewis Milestone will produce and direct as a Charles K. Feldman group production for Republic.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- John L. Lewis, who will give the House Labor Committee tomorrow his views of the Illinois mine explosion and the six-day mourning period he proclaimed, was accused by a Republican House member today of failure to do his part in safeguarding the miners' lives and of conducting a "mocking strike."

The Port of New York Authority will consider bids on April 15 for an issue of $8,500,000 of bonds maturing on Aug. 15, 1974. The issue is to be designated as the second installment of the eighth series and will bear interest of 2 per cent.

WARSAW, April 2 -- The official Polish press interpreted with one voice today United States Secretary of State Marshall's brief reference to Germany's former eastern lands as the formal opening of an Anglo-American campaign to restore the "regained territories" to Germany.

We are disappointed in Mayor O'Dwyer's failure in his proposed executive budget to give proper weight to the needs of public libraries. We are confident that this disappointment is shared by many New Yorkers, who see an inconsistent discrepancy in a budget that totals more than a billion dollars and allows only 55,695,635 to branch libraries to serve more than seven and a half million persons.

HAVANA, April 2 -- Jackie Robinson returned to first base tonight as the Dodgers and Montreal Royals met under the Gran Stadium lights, and that's where the Negro star will play in their four remaining games, according to President Branch Rickey of the Brooklyn club.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 2 -- The White Plains Hospital announced today that its school of nursing has established an affiliation with the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York that will permit student nurses here to study pediatric nursing at Babies Hospital in New York and orthopedic nursing at the New York Orthopedic Hospital.

A sharp revision of some of the Army's post-war plans and modification of the missions of the National Guard and Organized Reserves to add "civilian defense" to their duties are the indicated results of the studies of two War Department boards, it was learned in Washington last week.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- The first step toward universal higher education through Federal scholarship aid was taken today by a section of the National Conference on Higher Education of the National Education Association meeting. The program, providing $500 for tuition and fees and $40 monthly for subsistence will be presented at tomorrow's general session.

John M. Bess, executive vice president of Noma Electric Corporation's appliance divisions, announced yesterday a reduction of more than 20 per cent in the price of the Frigid-Freeze, twenty cubic feet, de luxe model commercial frozen food cabinet manufactured by the Refrigeration Corporation of America, a Noma division.

Harvard University alumni and undergraduate members of the Hasty Pudding - Institute of 1770 have enlisted the aid and sponsorship of many members of society here, in Boston and in Philadelphia, for the New York production of the Hasty Pudding Club's annual show to be presented tomorrow night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

A complete sanitary code, worked out by members of the New York Preservers Association in cooperation with city health officials, was formally presented last night at the annual dinner of the association at the Hotel New Yorker.

Although serving baked ham for Easter is a tradition well worth following, especially this year when the meat is abundant, there's no rule against innovating something in the way of accompaniments. Broiled fruit, for example, not only makes a colorful garnish, but contributes a delicious flavor, too.

An end to "nationalistic hostilities" and a "just accord between the Soviet Union and the West" were recommended as necessary policies for the reordering of Europe in a statement issued yesterday by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, 297 Fourth Avenue.

Another Busman's Holiday In view of what John Steinbeck has accomplished with a rickety nine - passenger wayward bus, there is no telling what dazzling effects he could have obtained if he had at his disposal William Cimillo's beautiful new forty-four passenger $18,000 red-and-green bus with a silver top.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Liquidation was under way today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, houses with Easter connections selling freely. With stop-loss orders uncovered, wheat broke 10 cents and corn 8 cents a bushel, at one time, the daily permissible limits.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (U.P.) -- Representative George A. Dondero, Republican, of Michigan, told the House today that he couldn't understand how the Army expected to rid itself of Communists when it advertised for recruits in "Communist newspapers."

PRINCETON, N.J., April 2 (AP) -- Dr. Ta Chen, Chinese delegate at Princeton University's bicentennial conference on Far Eastern culture and society, called today for the establishment of a national census to enable China to "enlighten herself as well as the other nations of the world" as to her true internal situation.

Retail merchants plan to buy art average of 68 per cent of women's fall apparel requirements in initial orders, according to Jos. Kraeler Frasca Company, manufacturer of coats and suits. The conclusion was based on a survey of 1,164 retail stores in all parts of the country.

The New York Board of Trade, joining yesterday in the protests of other business and civic groups against Mayor O'Dwyer's executive budget of $1,029,120,314 for 1947-48, predicted that it would result in a record-breaking flood of claims for reduced real estate assessments.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, accused Russia tonight of sabotaging the United Nations through an "obstructive policy of non-cooperation."

The Amerikai Magyar Nepszava, Hungarian language daily published in New York, has been banned from Hungary by the order of Laszlo Rajk, Hungarian Communist Minister of the Interior, according-to Paul Nadanyi, editor in chief of the paper.
MOSCOW, April 2 -- Solomon A. Lozovsky, head of the Soviet Information Bureau, invited foreign correspondents today to submit requests for any facilities during- their stay in Moscow.

MADRID, April 2 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco's declaration that Spain is a monarchy, with himself as chief, has put him further than ever from reconciliation with the Monarchists and probably destroyed all hope of agreement with Don Juan, according to a Monarchist source that is usually accurate.

A resolution asking the Department of State to protest to the Swedish Government on the imposition of import controls without sufficient warning to United States foreign traders, was approved yesterday at the April meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The failure of the President's diplomatic advisers, and of Mr. Truman himself, fully to anticipate the issue that has arisen over the relation of the United Nations to his proposal of political loans to Greece and Turkey, and to spike in advance the opposition on this point, is being highly illuminated by events.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman urged last night the assignment of unused immigration quotas to admit a "fair share of the victims of nazism" to the United States. He advocated this step in a pre-Passover broadcast, presented in cooperation with the American Jewish Committee, over the Mutual network.
Two major complaints were voiced yesterday against the new state bill that closes child-care centers in New York City on Oct. 1 but continues seasonal migrant camps until April 1, 1948.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown,. tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Statements of corporate earnings published in March generally Indicated "exceptionally prosperous" operations during 1946 for most of the manufacturing industries, the National City Bank of New York states in its monthly letter, issued yesterday.

Silo's, the city's oldest auction gallery, where the varied furnishings and fittings of hundreds of famous estates have gone under the hammer, will soon close its doors at Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, it became known yesterday.

Following a three-month test of newspapers by Dorland InternationalPettingell Fenton, Inc., Scandinavian Airlines System, Inc., has scheduled a campaign using forty newspapers in the United States, supplemented by direct mail and trade media.

TOKYO, April 2 -- "Unsatisfactory or partial implementation of the occupation's policies" are to blame for Japan's economic muddles, Dr. Sherwood M. Fine today told the Allied Council. Itical sphere and ask how Supreme Allied Headquarters could get a Japanese Government capable of enforcing-its policies.

The license granted to Milton I. Shubert, Broadway theatrical producer, by the Office of Alien Property to produce a musical play on the life of Puccini gives the composer's publisher the right to approve the completed score, it was disclosed yesterday in a statement issued in Washington by Attorney General Tom C. Clark.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 2 -- A new grist mill of identical design and on the same foundation as the one of 1683 vintage that inspired Washington Irving and Currier Ives was added today to the "Little Williamsburg of the North" being developed here in Sleepy Hollow with funds donated chiefly by John D. Rockefeller Jr.
PITTSBURGH, April 2 -- Steel makers were keeping their fingers crossed tonight, but feared the worst on the possibility of the soft coal mine holiday ending on schedule at midnight Sunday.

PARIS, April 2 -- Two friction points of the French Union, Indo-China and Madagascar today were the subject of grave preoccupations of the French Cabinet. It is obviously anxious to checkmate, as soon as possible, a movement that might be designed to break up France's world position.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- The Central Public Utility Corporation applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to undertake a plan for simplification of its holding company system through the divestment by its subsidiary, the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company, of control of the Atlanta Gas Light Company.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 2 -- The split in the Social Democratic party, formerly the Communist organization, was reported by the Espectador, which said that this virtually liquidated the party, which made a poor showing in the recent elections.

CENTRALIA, Ill., April 2 -- Members of a special committee of citizens appointed by Gov. Dwight H. Green to determine the causes of the blast which killed 111 miners here, returned late today from an inspection of the mine and reported they had seen evidence of a "windy" shot which possibly could have set off the blast.

The summary of the waterfowl situation made by, Ducks Unlimited, following the return of hundreds of questionnaires from all three shooting zones, indicates that the fall flights were down in numbers, but the hunter kill was approximately half that of the previous season.
Felix Edgar Wormser has resigned as secretary and treasurer of the Lead Industries Association to become assistant to the president of the St. Joseph Lead Company on May 12.

HONG KONG, April 2 -- Former Emperor Bao Dai of Annam, who has been approached by the French and has mustered the support of Right Wing Viet Namese independence groups, is now whiling away his time here waiting to be restored to the golden throne at Hue.The 34-year-old exiled monarch, who abdicated at the end of the war, spends virtually all his days in movie houses and many of his nights in dance halls.
WASHINGTON. April 2 (AP) -- A promise to retain a "skeleton force" of 421 patrol officers at eleven major seaports was made to Senators today by W.R. Johnson, Customs Commissioner.

MOSCOW, April 2 -- A high-powered Yugoslav delegation arrived here by train from Belgrade today determined to make a last-ditch drive to get a piece of Austrian Carinthia for Marshal Tito. The delegation also will try to extract $150,000,000 in reparations from Austria.

The rain pounded the pedestrians hard yesterday at the four corners of Thirty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue, but they stood fast and waited for the green light. Four husky policemen, one on each corner, (young, six feet one inch each, and photogenic) beamed: "A success," said one.

PEIPING, April 2 (U.P.) -- Several Peiping charity organizations were $199,000 richer today as a result of a donation of supplies, including 24,000 cases of beer, by the United States Army Post Exchange, it was announced today. The donation was made by the Army in preference to destroying the surplus commodities.The cost of returning them to it . United States was prohibitive.

Two women standing on the sidewalk at West 125th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue were injured yesterday morning, one seriously, when a bus, after colliding with a trailer truck, skidded on the wet pavement, mounted the sidewalk, knocked them down and then struck a bakery wagon that was lined up against the curb.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased 1,050,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 107,576,000 barrels, compared with 106,526,000 a week earlier and 104,297,000 on March 30, 1946.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The deliberations of Congress over the "Truman Doctrine" dominate all current action in Washington because the doctrine enunciates a new foreign policy and writes the first chapter in a continuing history, Arthur Krock, chief Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared tonight in a broadcast over WQXR.

Three steps to prevent future economic upsets should be taken by Congress, J.K. Javits, Representative from the Twenty-first Congressional District, New York, told members of the National Paper Trade Association convention at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

An exhibition and auction of paintings and sculpture by 100 contemporary artists has opened at the Barbizon-Plaza art gallery in honor of Picasso, who is honorary chairman of the Spanish Refugee Appeal, to which the proceeds will go. The display will continue daily, including Saturday and Sunday, through April 9.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio declared today that the United States plan for international control of atomic energy would undermine this nation's security and therefore should be withdrawn from the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- A series of speeches by President Truman, starting with one at the Jeferson Day Dinner here Saturday night, was announced at the White House today. The dinner, organized by the Democratic National Committee, will cost the guests $100 a place. The proceeds will replensh the party's treasury.

MOSCOW, April 2 -- Secretary of State Marshall of the United States and Foreign Secretary Bevin of Britain blocked today a Russian move to introduce the Communist-dominated "front" movements now flourishing in the Soviet zone of Germany into a German provisional government and the drafting of a new German constitution.

The Interstate Commerce Commission opened hearings yesterday on the application of a group of forty-six railroads to take over and operate the 80year-old Pullman sleeping-car service. Approval by the I.C.C. is now the only hurdle remaining in the consummation of this $75 million transaction, which successfully met the test of review by the Supreme Court earlier in the week.

Handwoven bedspreads and wall hangings in which sampler-like designs record the gaiety of a circus, the rhythmic pace of a neighborhood square dance, or the pride of prize-winning pigs at a county fair, went on exhibit yesterday at America House, 485 Madison Avenue.
LONDON, April 2 -- Reflecting the approach of the Easter holiday, the stock markets were on the quiet side today.

UPPERVILLE, Va., April 2 (AP) -- Sun Wonder, 12-year-old bay gelding owned and ridden by Beverley Byrd of Berryville, won the coveted Rokeby Bowl today at the annual Piedmont point-to-point races held on Paul Mellon's estate near here.
The New York Telephone Company began laying in cots and food yesterday to care for supervisory employes if its unionized operators, clerks and maintenance workers strike at 6 A. M. Monday.

PARIS, April 2 -- Most of the members of the Cabinet were amazed today to learn that Premier Paul Ramadier had been so angered by Charles de Gaulle's speech in Bruneval Sunday that on Monday night he had motored 150 miles east of Paris to argue it out with M. de Gaulle at the former President's country home.

CLEVELAND, April 2 (AP) -- The Cleveland Rebels came up with their best game of the year tonight to defeat the New York Knickerbockers, 77 to 51, in the opening game of the third-place play-off in the Basketball Association of America.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- A music industry program has been launched by a group of industry associations, William A. Milles, executive secretary of the National Association of Music Merchants, announced today. Dr. Albert Raring, professor of marketing, Indiana University, was appointed program consultant for the music industry.

STUTTGART, Germany, April 2 -- Dr. Fritz Eberhard, chairman of the German Office for Peace Questions, declared today that Germans felt they were "well represented in Moscow" in the person of United States Secretary of State Marshall.

The first appearance on the Metropolitan stage of Set Svanholm as "Parsifal" took place last night when the Wagner opera received its second performance of the season in that theatre. In this performance Mr. Svanholm only strengthened his position as one of the most accomplished Wagnerian tenors that the Metropolitan has presented the public in the decades of its existence

The barbiturate addict is just as much a danger to society as the narcotic addict, Dr. Charles Solomon of the King's County Medical Society declared yesterday at a hearing by the Board of Health on proposed legislation for the control of the sale of barbiturates, the sedatives known, commonly as sleeping pills.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 2 -- Great Britain formally asked the United Nations today to call an extraordinary session of the General Assembly on Palestine and promised to submit an accounting of her twenty-five-year guardianship of the Holy Land in the fall.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The State Department today assisted Dr. Syngman Rhee, leader of the South Korean Democratic League, to obtain passage to return to Korea by way of China after the War Department had told him there was no space for him on Air Transport Command planes.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 2 -- The United Nations has received the names of five governmental representatives to the seventeennation committee on the development of codification of international law, which is scheduled to meet May 1.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 2 (AP) -- A world record for rotational speed was claimed today by General Electric Company, which announced it had propelled a wheel at 123,000 revolutions per minute.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It would appear that the proposed amendment to the Constitution limiting the Presidential tenure was not validly adopted by the House of Representatives. Article 5 of the Constitution provides: "The Congress, whenever two-thirds of both Houses shall deem it necessary, shall propose Amendments to this Constitution * * *.

Failure to secure the required quantity of eighteen-ounce wool serge for Army uniforms has led to a decision to fill in with a special type of covert cloth with high breaking strength, it was announced yesterday by Col. L.O. Grice, commanding officer of the Quartermaster Purchasing Office, New York.

Pilot Press reports that it will issue on April 23 a novel by Ernst Wiechert. "The Girl and the Ferryman," which was published in Germany in 1932. Mr. Wiechert, who remained in Germany during the Nazi regime without ceasing to oppose it, was for a time in Buchenwald concentration camp and was personally threatened by Goebtiels.

PITTSBURGH, April 2 -- A wage increase of about 21 cents an hour is expected to be demanded by the United Steel Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, for its 850,000 members, it was indicated today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of March 20, "France and Germany." asserts that France proposes a policy which would "encompass the destruction of both Germany and Germans." You summarize the main points of this alleged policy as partition of Germany, destruction of her industry, reduction of her population through more or less forced emigration.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Democratic party will welcome support for re-election of President Truman from Henry A. Wallace, former Secretary of Commerce, from Senator Claude Pepper and "any others rallying to the cause" during the 1948 campaign, Gael Sullivan, Democratic national director, said today.
CALCUTTA, India, April 2 -- For a week now Calcutta has been in the grip of ruinous, fratricidal strife between Hindus and Moslems.
DETROIT, April 2 (AP) -- It looked more and more today like an allCanadian final series for the National Hockey League's battered but prized Stanley Cup.

The Masters golf tournament will get under way in Augusta today, and the most intriguing figure in it is bound to be Byron Nelson. Lord Byron has left The Fairway to get on the fairway, a distinction that seemingly is so fine it requires an instant explanation. But it's an important distinction.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 2 -- A United States proposal to place the former Japanese mandated islands in the Pacific under a United Nations trusteeship was approved unanimously tonight by the Security Council. The Council's acceptance of the agreement with no important changes came after Warren R. Austin had twice threatened to withdraw it rather than consent to amendments unacceptable to the United States.

A fifteen-year, several million-dollar program for developing Governors Island into a modern, efficient headquarters for the First Army was made known yesterday by Brig. Gen. George J. Nold, the unit's chief engineer.

The Port of New York Authority notified the City Planning Commission yesterday that its proposed $18,000,000 union bus terminal in midtown Manhattan, west of Eighth Avenue, would be ready for operation by June, 1949.

The English - Speaking Union opened yesterday a day nursery for babies of overseas war brides in its headquarters at 19 East Fifty-fourth Street. The excited chatter of young mothers and the happy coos of babies that penetrated the foyer of the clubhouse gave little doubt that the "new addition" was a success.

On the whole, Frank Gould's "Tenting Tonight," acted at the Booth last evening, may be described as too entertaining. With three war veterans as his chief cut-ups, Mr. Gould has made every line a gag and every situation clever; and Hudson Faussett, the director, has applied the slapstick to the seat of the pants of all the male actors.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Two Republican Senators renewed today before the Senate Armed Services Committee their attack on the national defense unification measure backed by the Army, Navy and the White House. The House Committee on Expenditures in Executive Departments started its hearings on the bill.

ATHENS, April 2 -- The Soviet Union's Ambassador in Athens, Rear Admiral Konstantine K. Rodianov, has asked for his passport to return to Moscow because he was "called by his Government," it was learned tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 2 -- United Nations officials who have been watching the organization's tight budget with some concern received a new financial problem here today. How much, they wanted to know, will it cost to hold a special session on Palestine?

Washington, April 2 -- A country-wide strike of telephone workers, interrupting domestic and international communications, will take place next Monday "as things look now," according to Joseph A. Beirne, president of the National Federation of Telephone Workers.

Underwriters headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and Mitchum, Tully Co. will offer today to investors $8,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent fifteen-year debentures and 70,000 shares of 3 1/4 per cent $100 par value cumulative convertible preferred stock of the Food Machinery Corporation of California, manufacturer of packing-house and canning equipment and of agricultural and automotive-service supplies.

Prison terms of five to ten years for bribery were imposed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit on David (Pete) Krakauer and Harvey Stemmer, while Jerome Zarowitz, the third "mastermind" behind Alvin J. Paris' football bribery scheme, received an indeterminate penitentiary term for conspiracy.
BERLIN, April 2 -- A full-scale Investigation into German bizonal agencies and state governments throughout the economically merged United States and British zones has been started.

First Flight, last year's queen of the 2-year-olds, arrived from Kentucky, and the Greentree string, headed by Blue Border, checked in from South Carolina. Assault is due today. Those were the chief items of news from the Long Island tracks yesterday, where all hands were busy preparing for the opening of the New York racing season at Jamaica on Saturday.

ALBANY, April 2 -- A bill that permits insurance companies to finance cooperative apartment building's for veterans was approved today by Governor Dewey. He also approved measures liberalizing the Veterans Scholarship Law and providing 240 additional scholarships for children of deceased veterans.

A motion to get a new trial for Mrs. Genevieve Rivera, sentenced to a year in prison for contributing to the delinquency of her 14-year-old son, on the ground that she was mentally incapable when she waived her right to counsel in court, was lost yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The House Banking and Currency Committee balked today over a proposal to permit a general 10 per cent increase in rents and voted to postpone a final show-down until April 16.

LONDON, April 2 -- Uneasines over the miners ability to live up to their promises to produce as much coal under a five-day week as they do in the present six was expressed by Emanuel Shinwell, Minister of Fuel and Power, in the House of Commons today.

SYLVIA TOWNSEND WARNER'S publishers have long since resigned themselves to seeing her compared to Jane Austen, James Stephens, Elinor Wylie and Katherine Mansfield. That seems a prudent enough position to take, since what they all have in common is mainly a tendency to look at the world's pomposities satirically and a habit of writing in English.

Ancient Fort Clinton in Battery Park, also known as the Aquarium, may be granted another reprieve from demolition, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday. He said that the Federal Government, through the Department of the Interior, was willing to take immediate title to what is left of the ancient building as a prelude to seeking a Congressional appropriation to pay for its restoration and preservation as a national shrine.

CINCINNATI, April 2 (AP) -- A motion for dismissal of an appeal in the original portal-to-portal pay suit was filed in the Sixth United States Circuit Court of Appeals today by counsel for the employes of the Mount Clemens Pottery Company of Mount Clemens, Mich.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 2 -- If it is true that coining events cast their shadows before, the Giants must be in for a great year. They had their first taste of National League opposition today and celebrated by burying the Cubs, 9 to 1, before 1,982 fans.
ESSEN, Germany, April 2 -- The greatest post-war threat to the recovery of German economy materialized today when miners representatives voted a one-day strike by 300,000 Ruhr miners tomorrow.

Settlement of a two-day-old plumbers' walkout in Queens and Brooklyn hinged last night on a meeting scheduled this afternoon between committees representing the Master Plumbers Association and the Building Trades Employers Association.

SPRINGFIELD, III., April 2 -- the Illinois Senate without debate today voted 42 to 0 for a legislative investigation of the Centralia mine disaster and of'the adequacy of present laws to protect coal miners.

As a new addition to its volunteer services to civilian hospitals, the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross yesterday announced a recreation program at Bellevue Hospital with weekly musicals for psychopathic wards, and organized play and entertainment for the adolescent boys' and children's wards.

NEWARK, N.J., April 2 -- Completion of a three-year municipal development survey by the Central Planning Board, which contemplates an expenditure of $250,000,000, of which the city of Newark's share would be $100,000,000, was announced today at a luncheon meeting by Franklin Conklin Jr., chairman of the planning board's citizens advisory committee.

OTTAWA, April 2 -- Newfoundland may join Canada as a tenth Province, it was indicated today by the appointment by the Newfoundland national convention of a delegation to visit Ottawa to study the possibility of federal union, and by the assurance given by Louis St. Laurent, Minister of External Affairs, that the Canadian Government would be "happy to receive delegations."

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, April 2 (U.P.) -- A southeast wind blew ashes from erupting Mount Hekla over hitherto unaffected areas today, threatening Reykjavik itself. Scientists said the volcano, which erupted last week, waa quieter today, but there was a possibility ashes would fall on the capital if the wind continued to blow from the southeast.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Robert T. Lansdale, State Commissioner of Social Welfare, today rejected a suggestion that state funds could be provided under existing law for the operation of child-day-care centers after Oct. 1. The proposal had been made by Stanley M. Isaacs, a New York City Councilman and president of the United Neighborhood Houses.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday with net losses of 68 to 84 points on the day, one of the most drastic declines in many weeks.

Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES expressed the belief last night that the public had the power to discipline bad newspapers, by refusing to read them. He replied to a wide variety of questions on journalism and related questions at a dinner of alumni of the Columbia School of Journalism.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Senator O'Mahoney said today that there is no reason to give financial aid to democracy abroad unless this country acts promptly to preserve democracy at home.

United States aircraft, engine and accessory manufacturers are neglecting a golden opportunity in the export field, it was said here yesterday by Maj. Gen. Thomas O. Hardin (Ret.) who recently returned from a three months survey trip to India in behalf of United Aircraft Corporation.

Brooklyn Trust The Brooklyn Trust Company reported as of March 31, total deposits of $222,142,604 and total assets of $239,722,102, compared respectively with $235,134,367 and $253,410,203 on Dec. 31, 1946. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $52,868,188, against $59,770,279; holdings of United States Government securities to $139,653,833, against $147,846,449, and loans and bills purchased to $32,571,329, against $33,633,509.

In his first statement since his resignation as Ambassador to Poland, Arthur Bliss Lane expressed views that make sense as applied to the delicate and difficult task of maintaining ties with nations whose governments were not elected in accordance with the solemn engagements signed by the Big Three at Yalta.

NEW DELHI, India, April 2 -- Asia must conquer the West with a message of love and truth, Mohandas K. Gandhi, leader of the Indian nationalist movement for nearly thirty years, told the concluding session of Inter-Asian Relations Conference today.
EXETER, N.H., April 3 -- Phillips Exeter Academy announced today a $500,000 gift from Thomas W. Lament toward a $5,000,000 scholarship and endowment fund.

ALBANY, April 3 -- The State Youth Commission, in a bulletin of information sent today to municipal officials, said that under the new system of state-aid for child day care, which will go into effect Oct. 1, new facilities would be established and additional families served.
Easter travel to and from New York began to gain momentum yesterday as carrier spokesmen predicted that the week-end rush would be about the same as or slightly greater than last year.

A country-wide telegraph strike was threatened yesterday by the Commercial Telegraphers Union, AFL, which filed a thirty-day Smith-Connally Act strike notice on behalf of its 50,000 workers employed by Western Union.

NASSAU, Banamas, April 3 -- The Whip, owned by C. Stanley Ogilvy of Hartford, Conn., annexed the international star class spring championship today with a total score of 25 points. Robert Coulson of Nassau served as crew.

Surely yesterday's vote in the Senate should bring to an early end the long filibuster against confirmation of the President's appointment of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission. It has been clear for many days that all the relevant (and a great deal of irrelevant) evidence was in.

PARIS, April 3 -- Estimates based on French Government figures indicate that France may have to spend $200,000,000 of her carefully hoarded supply of dollars to replace the wheat losses caused by winter freezes.

Consolidation of the Probation Department of the Kings County Court and the probation units in the other courts here was recommended in a report issued yesterday by Leonard Probst, vice chairman of the State Probation Department.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 3 -- A new application of radioactive tracers to biochemistry has resulted in the direct observation, for the first time outside the animal body, of the synthesis of proteins, the basis of growth and life, according to an announcement today from the University of California.

Over the long and loud objections of Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, the union's national council yesterday threw out last Monday's meeting which convicted Joseph Stack, vice president, of conduct unbecoming an officer of the union, and set another meeting for tomorrow at 11 A.M.

Heavy retail promotions, accompanied in some instances by the sharpest mark-downs in six years, will be relied upon to maintain volume in women's ready-towear in the post-Easter period, it was reported here yesterday. Provided weather conditions are favorable, however, the results may be better than pessimistic forecasts have indicated.

That talent for richly combining melodrama and comedy, which Writers Frank Launder and Sidney Gilliat so delightfully displayed in their scripts for Hitchcock's "The Lady Vanishes" and Carol Reed's "Night Train," has been deftly applied by those gentlemen to the writing, production and direction of their own film, a British honey entitled "The Adventuress," which opened at the Victoria yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- At least $700,000,000 will be needed to expand teaching facilities, laboratories and classrooms by 1950 to meet the doubling of pre-war enrollments expected by American colleges and universities. Half of this amount will be sought from Federal funds and is to be matched by $350,000,000 from philanthropy or non-Federal funds.

Edna Iles, English pianist, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Miss Iles, who has concertized abroad and appeared in her own country with important orchestras, was heard in a program containing the BachBusoni choral prelude, "Sleepers, Wake," Beethoven's "Waldstein" Sonata and two extensive groups devoted, respectively, to compositions by Medtner and Chopin.

All vacuum cleaner allocations to dealers, with the exception of one well-known quality brand, will be terminated within sixty days, a spokesman for a large national appliance distributor predicted yesterday. He reported some backing up at the distributive level in lesser-known brands but emphasized that the condition has not yet become serious.

TOKYO, April 3 -- Within about a month details of a plan for permitting private participation in Japan's foreign trade should be ready for publication. Not long after mid-year, the first foreign buyers should begin appearing on these shores.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The United States Government today authorized Gen. Douglas MacArthur to make some advance reparations transfers from Japan to four Allied powers for urgent relief purposes.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved the $400,000,000 Greek-Turkish aid bill by a 13-to-0 vote today.

Slowing Down on Cotton Buying Mill buying of cotton has eased somewhat although consumption continues high, according to trade sources yesterday. Mills are placing more emphasis on July futures, it was indicated, with an eye toward the new crop.

Assault, winner of the triple crown and a record-breaking $424,195 last year, and Better Value, Trainer Max Hirsch's chief hope for honors among the 3-year-olds this season, were among the thirtythree King Ranch color-bearers to join the equine colony on Long Island yesterday.

With the devotion of an old grad, George Abbott has been rounding up the freshmen and seniors again. "Barefoot Boy With Cheek," he calls his new class reunion, and it was put on at the Martin Beck last evening. An old hand at leading the college cheer.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 3 -- The United Nations Security Council has been "strangled" as well as "completely obstructed" and made "sterile and impotent" by the Soviet Union's use of the veto, Sir Alexander Cadogan, British representative, told the Council today.

Consolidated Edison Company's recent $100,000,000 financing operation was a major factor in increasing commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System by $76,000,000 last week.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3 -- The Yankees today engaged in their last workout of the year on AI Lang Field and but for the fact that it was the final drill Manager Bucky Harris could have found ample reason for viewing his 1947 prospects without a care in the world.

A reorganization plan equitable for both senior and junior investment interests of the St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., has been made possible by improved conditions, according to a statement of the corporation's directors embodied yesterday in the annual report.

Patricia Neway, dramatic soprano; Francine Falkon, contralto, and William Masselos, pianist, were the winners in the recent Young Artists Auditions held in this city by the New York Federation of Music Clubs for the National Federation.

SHANGHAI, April 3 (AP) -- More than sixty employes of the China office of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration charged today that the Chinese Government had kept all but 2 per cent of UNRRA supplies from Communist-controlled areas.

Random notes. Another reminder to those who have been trying to buy a bird dog: The annual breeders' sale of setters and pointers, held under the auspices of the English Setter Club of America, will take place tonight at the Medford Lakes Lodge, Medford, N.J. The sale begins at 6 o'clock.

BERLIN, April 3 -- Serious discussions are taking place among high Military Government officials here to release quietly from their personnel rolls those persons who have been citizens of the United States fewer than ten years, it was learned today.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 3 -- Prosecutor Matthew F. Melko announceed today that he would order the elimination, of all forms of gambling, including bingo and lotteries, in Middlesex County.

MONTREAL, April 3 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadians, defending champions, entered the final round of the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs tonight by defeating the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 3, in the second overtime period. Johnny Quilty's goal broke up the game and enabled the Flying Frenchmen to take the best-ofseven series, 4 -- 1.

Now, as the nation looks ahead to a housing boom, is the time to fight restrictions that would set up "ghettos" over the land, Charles Abrams declared yesterday. Covenants and practices barring people from neighborhoods on racial or religious grounds should be fought in the courts, the legislatures and by educating the people, he said.

BOWIE, Md., April 3 (AP) -- E.B. Lee's Orage emerged from the maiden ranks in her eighth start today to the tune of a $49.40 for $2 mutuel. Buddy Root booted the daughter of Pilate home four lengths in advance of High Ground Stable's Breakage, with Isidor Bieber's Chamade third.

Stock prices drifted lower yesterday in quiet trading. The telex phone strike threatened for Monday and the news in the coal situation were factors in the lack of interest. Leaders generally were down fractions to 2 points.

An answer in a suit for damages for $365,000 charging "overcrowding" and "negligent" operation, filed by fifty-nine passengers of the steamship Katoomba in Newark Federal Court on Jan. 21, was entered yesterday by the law firm of Kirlin, Campbell, Hickox Keating, acting for Capt. Stomati Polemis, master of the vessel.

Harry C. Beaver of Longmeadow, Mass., who was vice chairman of the board of directors of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation, Harrison, N.J., manufacturers of mechanical equipment, died of a heart attack on Wednesday night in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. His age was 70.

IN the year 1825 in the city of Taganrog the church bells tolled for the death of Czar Alexander I, grandson of the profligate Catherine the Great, son of the mad Paul I, sometimes himself called The Blessed. The histories and reference books still cite that year and place for Alexander's death, but they are wrong, says Leonid I. Strakhovsky in his biography, raphy, "Alexander I of Russia."

MOSCOW, April 3 -- A Russian bid to impose proportional representation -- the "list system" whereby the Communist party has risen to power in other nations -- upon German voters was frustrated in the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers today.

A banking group headed by the National City Bank won yesterday an award of $7,500,000 of municipal airport bonds of Los Angeles, Calif., with a bid representing a net interest cost of 1.5559 for obligations maturing from 1948 to 1967.
A young longshoreman prevented what might have resulted in severe damage in a freakish accident on the new Grace Line passenger -cargo vessel Santa Clara yesterday.

Parents and Children When people speak about the gulf between the generations, as Dr, Evelyn M. Duvall does in a pamphlet released by the Public Affairs Committee, there is a first temptation to say something bright and flip.

MOSCOW, April 3 -- A compromise formula to provide limited reparations from current German production was circulated among the Soviet, British and French delegations today by United States Secretary of State Marshall.

Marathon Homes, Inc., Sydney M. Siegel, president, has obtained seventy-two loans totaling $718,100 on a large group of one-family dwellings on the north and south sides of Sixty-first and Sixty-second Avenues, west of Marathon Parkway in Little Neck, Queens.

The following message of Christian charity came yesterday from the ministers of the Community Church, Park Avenue and Thirtyfifth Street, to an unknown guest who stole a pulpit Bible: The ministers are not angered with you, believing that either your spiritual or economic need was great; your act is not approved, but can be forgiven; and finally, "wear its pages well" if you still have the pulpit Bible you stole.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Capt. N.H. Collisson, Mines Administrator, sent the following telegrams today: To the operators of the 518 mines which are to be closed indefinitely: Review of Federal coal mine inspection reports indicates that while inspector did not find imminent danger in the above mine, safety conditions are apparently deficient and make operation hazardous.

Motorists hereafter may park their cars overnight on the city's streets without fear of police summonses, under a confidential order issued from Manhattan Police Headquarters last Monday, it was learned last night.

DOWNERS GROVE, III., Friday, April 4 -- At least one person was reported killed and forty-eight others were known injured late last night when the Twin Cities Zephyr, streamliner of the Burlington Railroad, crashed into an obstruction.

LONDON, April 3 -- The British peacetime conscription period is being reduced from eighteen months to one year in the National Service Bill, it was announced today. This is a surprise concession made by the Labor Government itself after the revolt earlier this week when seventytwo Labor M.P.'s voted to reject the bill.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Admiral J.F. Farley declared today that a $36,000,000 slash in Coast Guard funds for the next fiscal year might lead to ship losses which would far exceed that saving by Congress.
PEIPING, April 3 -- Negotiations for the release of Maj. Robert Rigg and Capt. John L. Collins, who have been held by Communists in Manchuria since March 1, will be opened shortly.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.T., April 3 -- Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris of Greece has informed the United Nations that Greek military authorities had to intervene to disperse "spontaneous unfriendly demonstrations" against Albanian and Bulgarian liaison officers attached to the Special Commission of Inquiry on the Balkans.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3 (AP) -- Merle Hapes and Frank Filchocl, New York Giants' backfield stars who became entangled in gamblers attempts to "fix" the Nations Football League's championship play-off last Dec. 15, today were suspended indefinitely in the latest chapter of the biggest sport scandal since the 1919 World Series.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- During the week ended April 2, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, member bank reserve balances decreased $118,000,000.

An Easter program, nearly all of it suggestive in one or another way of the season, was given by Leopold Stokowski and the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. One beautiful and familiar work followed another, such as the Bach ChoralePrelude, "Christ lag in Todesbanden," in "Mr. Stokowski's orchestration; the Beethoven "Pastoral" symphony; the Good Friday music from "Parsifal" and Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Russian Easter" overture.

MOSCOW, April 3 -- The Foreign Ministers deputies on the Austrian treaty resumed efforts today to reach an agreement on the dispoposition of German assets in eastern Austria. Although they made some small progress, an accord is still lacking on the key aspects of this complex and important problem.

Neither rough, seas nor snow nor ice stayed the Joint Distribution Committee from completing shipments of 6,000,000 pounds of Passover foods to Europe's Jews in time for the holiday, which begins today at sundown, it was announced yesterday at the committee's New York office, 270 Madison Avenue.
Charles R. Sherman has been named general manager of buying for the Sun Chemical Corporation and its divisions.

Asserting that international economic cooperation is the alternative to disaster in Europe, Dr. Paul van. Zeeland, former Prime Minister of Belgium, outlined yesterday the functions of a projected organization to be known as the Independent League for European Cooperation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 3 -- The financial troubles of the United Nations seemed headed for further difficulties by the disclosure here today that $1,000,000 would be needed to cover the activities ordered by the Economic and Social Council at its last session here.

Refusal by garment manufacturers to accept delivery of fabrics has brought about a sharp increase in the number of textile arbitration cases, it was learned yesterday. The arbitration department of the National Federation of Textiles alone has over seventy such cases pending, according to trade sources, and numerous others are up before other agencies designated in textile contracts.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The American Products Council, representing a broad group of American manufacturers, challenged today the validity of the twelve-nation tariff conferences called by the United States to meet at Geneva April 8, as violating the basic conceptions of the reciprocal tariff program.

During the war the official cost of living index did not reflect fully the rise which had taken place. Because of many complaints, particularly by labor groups, President Roosevelt appointed a Cost of Living Committee to examine the adequacy of the index. Two results stemmed from this inquiry.

The fascist threat to democracy is greater now than at any time since 1932, when Germany and Italy were under its control, O. John Rogge, former United States Assistant Attorney General, said last night at the Commodore Hotel. He spoke at a dinner of the New York and Bronx Physicians division of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York campaign for $65,000,000.

PRINCETON. N.J., April 3 -- Princeton University conferred honorary degrees on eighteen American and foreign educators, artists and scholars this afternoon at the institution's fourth convocation of the bicentennial year. Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, presided.

New York probably will not get its long-awaited smoke abatement campaign -- which Mayor O'Dwyer and Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein announced three months ago -- for at least a year, it appeared yesterday.

Commenting on Tallulah Bankhead's artistry at this late date seems to us as needless as adding fuel to a blazing fire. No matter what the ebullient star appears in, the cordiality of her reception often outweighs the merits of her vehicle.

The old German piers in Hoboken, N.J., wards of the Government since their confiscation during World War I, were the scene of considerable activity yesterday as the Port of New York Authority began a survey with a view to its possible acquisition and operation of the property by the bi-State agency.

Holiday Easter holidays will be observed with the closing of all principal domestic securities and commodity exchanges today, but banking institutions in most States will be open as usual. Livestock and dairy markets also will remain open for business.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, said today that the establishment by Congress of a ceiling on expenditures "lies dormant in the bosom of the Republican party."
Services in synagogues and temples, followed by seders -- or rituals -- at home, will start the Passover holidays at sundown tonight.

PITTSBURGH, April 3 -- The order by Secretary Krug temporarily closing a fifth of the country's soft-coal mines took both the steel and coal industries by surprise today. The Western Pennsylvania Coal Operators Association stated that it was "shocked" to learn that 157 of the 518 working's closed for safety purposes were in Pennsylvania.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 3 -- Spring was in the air today and Edward T. Townsend, veteran agent of the State Conservation Department, was doubtless the busiest man in Westchester County in answering 250 telephone calls to explain the vagaries of nature.

Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, yesterday set April 24 for the first proceeding under a new law authorizing the commission to compel reorganization of utility companies which may be insolvent.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The plight of the 30,000 Yugoslav refugees in Italy, many of whom fought on the side of the Allies, is an affair that involves the conscience and honor of the democratic nations who originally took them under their protection.
LONDON, April 3 -- Britons staggered today under five pieces of bad news in quick succession.

A single consultation in each case, costing only $5, is all that has been necessary to dispose of 70 per cent of the 695 cases brought before the Legal Referral Service in its first nine months, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, April 3 -- Premier Paul Ramadier today confirmed his secret motor journey late Monday night to visit Charles de Gaulle after the former Premier's attack on the French Constitution in Bruneval Sunday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.T., April 3 -- The Arab League, thrown into the center of the United Nations stage because of the call for a special General Assembly session on Palestine, was reported today to be facing a fight for representation on the proposed fact-finding commission for the Holy Land.

SINGAPORE, April 3 -- Lawlessness, political disaffection and economic dislocation are the legacies of war in Malaya. The British Government, which this week marked the first anniversary of the resumption of civil administration, has had little success in restoring conditions to normal.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Chauncey G. Farker, an investment banker of this city and a member of a nationally known firm, accepted today appointment as director of the administrative department of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

THE long-awaited decision of Commissioner Bert Bell of the National Football League on the attempted "fix" of the Bear-Giant championship play-off has finally been handed down. Frank Filchock and Merle Hapes each have been given an "indefinite suspension," which is merely a legalistic way of saying that the two culprits are barred for life.

The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company will be seized by the state at 6 A. M. Monday if al efforts to avert a strike of New Jersey telephone workers fail Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll announced in Trenton yesterday.

Ludwig Baumann Co. reported yesterday for the six months ended with last December a net income of $487,708 after taxes, $70,000 reserve for additional contingencies and $134,469 additional reserve for loss and collection expense on accounts receivable.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, April 3 -- Along with the great mass of displaced Jewish persons, Poles and Baits in the United States zone of Germany, the International Refugee Organization will inherit from UNRRA next June some 19,000 "others" whose problems are equally difficult but more curious.

Cotton textile mills are currently investing in new and improved equipment at the rate of $100,000,000 annually, according to a survey of the Cotton Mills Information Service. Cotton mill profits which are now comparable to those in other industries have enabled manufacturers to make expenditures for improvements as well as for research and educational projects for training textile technicians.

Both numerically and on a percentage basis the women of New York have outdistanced the men in their response to the Red Cross 1947 Fund of Greater New York, Mrs. Fergus Reid Jr., director of fund raising, announced yesterday.

The City College baseball team opened the metropolitan collegiate baseball season by registering a 10-1 triumph over the Brooklyn College nine yesterday. While a crowd of 700 fans sat in, the Beaver batters pounded the offerings of three Brooklyn hurlers.

As a result of the refusal of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee of 192 Lexington Avenue to produce its records, early last year before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, sixteen officials of the organization were arraigned yesterday in Federal court on indictments charging contempt of the House.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The State Department transmitted t the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today a document containing its replies to 111 questions submitted by Senators on the propose aid to Greece and Turkey.

Establishment by the states of one out-patient mental hygiene clinic for each 100,000 of the population is the ultimate goal of the United States Public Health Service, Dr. Robert H. Felix, chief of the mental hygiene division, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- In perhaps the most dramatic session of the Eightieth Congress, the Senate this evening refused to pigeon-hole President Truman's six appointments to the United States Atomic Energy Commission.
BERLIN, April 3 -- "Rave" reviews of a one-man show by Henry Koerner, Vienna-born American artist, have appeared in Berlin papers under the signatures of German art critics.
The executive committee of the Liberal party has adopted unanimously a resolution supporting President Truman's policy for immediate and adequate aid to Greece and Turkey.
CHICAGO, April 3 -- Connecticut and Washington, D.C., were named today grand award winners in the 1946 National Traffic Safety Contest, in which all States and 1,355 cities participated.

JERUSALEM, April 3 --Two more young Jewish terrorists were condemned to death by hanging today. The sentences were imposed in a Jerusalem military court one day before the eve of the Passover, Jewish festival commemorating the deliverance from death of Israel's eldest sons in Egypt during the time of Moses.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Average primary markets prices rose 0.3 per cent, with a rise of 0.2 per cent for foods, during the week ended on March 29, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher prices for agricultural products and some industrial commodities more than offset declines for a few non-agricultural articles.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 3 -- Calling Chiang Kai-shek's Kuomintang party "autocratic and reactionary," a noted Chinese scholar on a year's leave of absence from a Chinese university denounced his government here today, calling it a "mouthpiece of the vested interests bloc."
LONDON, April 3 -- Although business in stock markets today was influenced by the Easter holiday period most sections were cheerful and firm.
BERLIN, April 3 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, returned from Moscow late today "no less optimistic" than when he left Berlin nearly four weeks ago.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday recovered all early losses and closed at or near the best levels of the day, 6 to 30 points net higher.

With automotive again in the lead, total advertising in all New York newspapers during March increased 19.48 per cent compared with the similar period of last year, according to a compilation of Media Records figures. Financial again showed a loss -- 5.36 per cent.

BATAVIA, Java, April 3 (AP) -- The American Liberty ship Martin Behrman sailed empty today for Singapore from Tanjung Priok, Batavia's seaport, leaving behind the cargo confiscated by Netherlands Indies authorities.

A sanctuary globe formerly on the altar of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem has been reproduced with unusual fidelity by American craftsmen after no one could be found in Europe who was willing or able to perform the task, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- Short covering and commission-house buying based on a resumption of buying of wheat flour by the Government and disclosure that possibly 400,000 bushels of cash corn had been sold for export or bought by exporters late yesterday resulted today in generally higher grain markets on the Board of Trade.

On June 25, 1942, the Board of Estimate voted to demolish the old Aquarium down in Battery Park, which had once been Fort Clinton, then Castle Garden and later an immigration station. President Truman on Aug. 12, 1946, signed a bill that would permit acquisition of what remained after partial wrecking for a national monument.

GELSENKIRCHEN, Germany, April 3 -- Ruhr miners showed a solid front in closing down all but a few mines. More than 125,000 Germans attended demonstrations today in twenty-six cities to protest the food situation in the region of North Rhine-Westphalia.

LONDON, April 3 -- The Labor party's proposal to publish 600 local weekly newspapers throughout Britain was attacked today at the annual conference of the National Union of Journalists by Fred Treavett, retiring president.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- New York's "blue ribbon" jury system was criticized before 'the Supreme Court today by counsel for Joseph F. Fay and Jamas Bove, union officials who were convicted of extorting money from contractors.

Laymen are unprepared to do their part in public health work, Dr. Franklin Bobbitt, Professor Emeritus of Education at the University of Chicago, declared yesterday. He spoke on the closing day of an institute on public health at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

Food market conditions indicate a price-break within the next few months, spokesmen for wholesalers and retailers stated yesterday. Consumer resistance to prices are blocking trade channels, it was stated, and the food men themselves are seeking all possible means of getting prices down.

TOKYO, April 3 -- Heavy pressure by the Allied occupation through Japanese central and local governments is apparently about to result In the successful completion of the Japanese domestic food collection program for the first time since the war.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Truman hailed today the election of Martin H. Kennelly as Mayor of Chicago as the beginning of a national trend back to the Democratic party. This was the President's first partisan political statement since he pledged last Nov. 11 to conduct his office without regard to personal or party considerations.

In response to persistent reports that the corporation is contemplating price reductions on basic steel products, Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, declared yesterday that, until demands of the steel workers' union for a substantial wage increase are disposed of, "no real consideration can be given by us to the adequacy or inadequacy of our present steel prices."

PEARL HARBOR, April 3 -- A Japanese sailor, who had been hiding out for more than two years with half a hundred others on Releliu Island in the Palaua came out of the caves of Bloody Nose Ridge yesterday and surrendered to the United States Marines.

VIENNA, Austria, April 3 -- The strong opposition of the Austrian peasantry to the demand of the Ministry of Finance for a heavy capital levy has completely stalemated currency stabilization that is a prerequisite for a lasting economic recovery program.

LONDON, April 3 -- A British business man was fined L3,000 and sentenced to three months' imprisonment today because he had spent $5,000 more than he should have in New York to get $500,000 worth of orders for British industry.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Secretary of the Interior Julius A. Krug ordered 518 of the Government operated soft-coal mines closed indefinitely for safety reasons today. But John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, AFL, derisively termed Mr. Krug's order "a death-bed confession" and called for his ouster.

CHICAGO, April 3 (AP) -- Fortyeight Illinois mines ordered closed indefinitely today by Secretary of the Interior Krug produce at least half of the shipping- mine tonnage of the state, it was estimated from production records in the office of the Illinois Coal Operators Association.

Workers in the Mount Clemens Pottery Company, whose suit for back pay under the Wages and Hours Act set the pattern for similar court actions involving potential liabilities of between $5 billions and $6 billions, have asked for a dismissal of their appeal to the United States Circuit Court.

ATHENS, April 3 (AP) -- Greeks who lined the curbs ten to fifteen deep got their first glimpse of King Paul today since his accession as he marched unattended behind a gun carrier bearing the flag-draped coffin of his brother, George II, from the Royal Palace to Athens Cathedral.

BOSTON, April 3 -- More than 2,000 of Boston's 3,600 school teachers held a protest meeting this morning and later crowded into the State Capitol and its galleries, occasionally booing and cheering, as the Legislature cut their proposed wage increase from a $600 to a $420 maximum for 1947.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 3 (AP) -- Nedim Veysel Ilkin, director of the Turkish Press Bureau, said tonight that he had withdrawn the press card of Aslan Houmbaradji, local correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 -- "The House Above the River," a novel by Michael Foster which Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer acquired for the screen when it was published last year, will be filmed next fall, with Katharine Hepburn in the leading role, the studio announced today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 3 -- Another of Jolly Cholly Grimm's rookie hurlers collapsed here this afternoon and the Giants swamped the Cubs, for their sixth victory in a row and their third shutout triumph in that stretch. The count was 12 to 0.

With two of Europe's outstanding performers joining a brilliant array of native talent in the scramble for titles, the National A.A.U. indoor swimming championships, up for decision in Ohio State's pool tomorrow and, Saturday, shape'up as a partial preview of the aquatic program at the 1948 Olympics.

WASHINGTON, April 3-Lewis B. Schwellenbach, Secretary of Labor, said today that he would recommend to President Truman a veto of the pending portal to portal bill if it should come to him in its present form.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Following is the roll call vote by which the Senate defeated, 52 to 38, a motion to return the nominations of David E. Lilienthal and others for the United States Atomic Control Commission to the Senate Atomic Committee :

Clifford E. Paige, chairman of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday that "unless the $1,900,000 rate increase already sought is forthcoming soon, the dividend policy must be modified to meet conditions as the management finds them."

The writings of William Blake have been made the subject of a second large volume. Holt published late last year Mark Schorer's "William Blake: The Politics of Vision." The Princeton University Press will issue on April 14 "Fearful Symmetry: A Study of William Blake," by Northrop Frye, which interprets the longer poems, the "Prophecies."

PHILADELPHIA, April 3 -- In a unanimous decision, the Securities and Exchange Commission sanctioned today the East Coast Public Service Company's amended plan for merging the Tidewater Electric Service Company into the Virginia East Coast Utilities, Inc., recapitalizing the latter and then liquidating itself pursuant to Section 11 (E) of the Holding Company Act.

CHICAGO, April 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 4,000 head, total 7,000; weights 260 pound and down 50 to 75 cents higher than Wednesday's average; heavier weights very uneven, mostly 25 to 50 cents higher;

DETROIT, April 3 (AP) -- Making their few shots count heavily, the Toronto Maple Leafs moved within one victory of the Stanley Cup finals tonight by whipping the Detroit Red Wings, 4 to 1, to take a three-to-one edge in games in their best-of-seven series before 14,577 fans.

An organizer of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, was held yesterday in 550,000 bail as a material witness in the fatal shooting of Anthony Hintz, boss stevedore. The action was taken after Assistant District Attorney William J. Keating declared that he had valuable information about the killing and attempts might be made to intimidate him.
