Press Wireless, Inc. has renewed its efforts to obtain authorization from the Federal Communications Commission to handle all messages relating to the operation and business administration of press and radio organizations, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Maj. Gen. Lauris Norstad, the War Department's Director of Plans and Operations, declared today before the Senate Armed Services Committee that, without a single Secretary at the top, there could be no real unification of the Army, Navy and Air Forces.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Legislation to permit persons over 65 to earn up to $40 a month and still receive old-age insurance benefits was introduced today by Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican, of New York. The present law limits to $15 the amount a person may earn monthly and still receive the old-age insurance.

HAVANA, April 3 -- A 23-yearold college undergraduate today became the central figure in one of the strangest stories ever to come put of a major league baseball training camp. If the case were brought before a court of law, judge and attorneys would be strictly on their own, for there is no precedent.

A Brooklyn policeman was killed in a pistol duel with a robber in a grocery store at 1513 Fulton Street, near Throop Avenue in the Bedford -Stuyvesant district of Brooklyn at 1:25 o'clock this morning. The thug also was slain by bullets from the policeman's service revolver.

The program of aid to Greece and Turkey leaped its first and highest hurdle yesterday when the Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved it by a 13-0 vote. This is an impressive endorsement of the President's bold initiative in asking support for the independence of weak peoples against outside pressure.

WASHINGTON, April, 3 (AP) -- Seeking to prevent "unreasonable or unwarranted" price fluctuations, the Government today ordered a slash in maximum speculative holdings of cotton, futures by individuals.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (U.P.) -- The State Department has asked President Truman to seek permanent legislation authorizing it to discharge any employe without hearing when the "demands of national security" warrant, it was learned today.

The circus is coming to town! Opening Wednesday night in Madison Square Garden, this year's snow will feature a glittering parade of fairyland folk, culminating in the wedding of Cinderella. Two shows daily, at 2:15 and 8:30 P.M. Admission ranges from $1.20 to $6; children under 12 half price at matinees, except on Saturdays and Sundays.

When the Statue of Liberty on Bedloe's Island reopens to the public today for the first time since January 6, all lipstick marks that marred the 70,000 square-foot interior will have been removed, Charles S. Marshall, superintendent, declared yesterday.

The friction between the National Guard and the Organized Reserves and the resentment of both against the Regular Army was approaching the dimensions of a minor cat-and-dog fight in some areas of the country last week.
The city s basic real estate tax rate for 1947-48 will not exceed $2.90 for each $100 of assessed valuation and may drop below that figure, it was indicated last night.

With both the Easter and Passover seasons about to start, markets are busy today filling orders for housewives planning holiday dinners. Fortunately, supplies of most traditional foods are bountiful, though you do need a fat wallet, because prices remain high.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Federal seizure of the country's telephone system in the event of a strike at 6 A.M. on Monday is being considered by President Truman. He told a news conference today that he thought that he did not have authority to take over the telephone industry but was having the question investigated.

Randolph S. Churchill, son of the former Prime Minister of Great Britain, declined yesterday to carry out his radio appearance for Monday over Station WHN because Earl Browder, former American Communist party leader, would be a co-participant in the program.

PARIS, April 3 -- The French Government today dispatched to Madagascar Gen. Bornis Deabordes, charged with conducting a military inquiry and with organizing a possible defense plan similar to the mission carried out in Indo-China by Maj. Gen. JacquesPhilippe Leclerc.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Department store sales in the week ended March 29 were 10 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

ROME, April 3 -- The Cabinet Council today decreed a 50 per cent increase in the price for rationed bread. In future it will retail at about forty lire a kilo [about four and one-half cents a pound at the official rate of exchange.]

QUEBEC, Que., April 3 -- Record prosperity and enormous profit enjoyed by Canadian newsprint manufacturers may be a cause for gratification to security holders but it cannot be denied that some concern is felt here as to the long term wisdom of the industry's present price policy.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Ninety-six long, single-spaced, typed pages were required to list 111 questions growing out of the Truman Doctrine which members of Congress addressed to the State Department through the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. Therefore it is impossible in any reasonable amount of newspaper space to give a thorough summary of the results of the quiz which was suggested by Senator Vandenberg.

CENTRALIA Ill., April 3 -- Three witnesses, all of whom were in Mine No. 5 for several hours after the March 25 explosion which killed 111 miners, testified today that they noted no powder smoke, refuting the testimony yesterday by H.C. Niermnn, assistant superintendent of the mine.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I would like to draw attention to the forgotten factor in the unhappy situation in Palestine. We have been so distracted by the din of the rival claims of Zionists and Arabs that we seem to have forgotten the claims of the whole Christian world.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 29 were 829,412 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 14,629 cars or 1.7 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 20,270 cars or 2.5 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 6,588 cars or 0.8 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 3 -- Lift on the farm seems to agree with Byron Nelson. At least no ill-effects of his retirement eight months ago to devote himself to his cows and chickens down on his Texas ranch were in evidence today.

"Siamese twin" floor lamp with one base, two sources of light and two shades was among advancements in home lighting described last night at a joint meeting of the Residence Lighting Forum and the New York Section of the Illuminating Engineering Society.

Substantial support for increasing the appropriations for city libraries in the budget now under consideration was manifested yesterday at a conference of civic associations held under the auspices of the Citizens Union in Freedom House, 20 West Fortieth Street.

Three men, taken into custody yesterday morning at their homes in Brooklyn and Manhattan, were linked last night by Brooklyn police to gunplay in an attempted payroll robbery in Queens and to three. Brooklyn hold-ups in which $18,000 in cash and Government bonds were taken.

CINCINNATI, April 4 (U.P.) -- The sixteen major league ball clubs have adopted a life insurance and annuity plan for their players and will pay all the insurance premiums and three-fourths of the annuities cost, Commissioner A. B. Chandler announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- A sharply restrictive labor bill likely to embody in every essential the ultimate recommendations to be made by the House Labor Committee has been drafted in final form, it was learned today.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 5 -- The Japanese people went to the polls today to elect for the first time by a democratic process governors of their forty-six Prefectures. Up to now the governors have been named by the Central Government under imperial mandate.

His cover-alls grimy, his face smudged with dirt, Detective Joseph Whitmore sat wearily on the steps leading to the decayed Collyer "mansion" at 2078 Fifth Avenue yesterday and said: "This search is becoming a nightmare.

Secretary Krug's order closing 518 government-operated coal mines, the safety of which has been questioned, will be supported by public opinion throughout the country. It may prove to be a hard blow to miners, operators and industry alike, since it is estimated that it may throw 100,000 miners out of work temporarily and lower the daily output of bituminous coal by 26 per cent.

The New York office of the Securities and Exchange Commission filed yesterday with the Federal District Court here a complaint against Victor McQuistion, president of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, charging him with violation of the proxy rules.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 4 -- The list of more than eighty articles on which all rationing or control restrictions have been lifted was made public today by the new Government in its first statement on applied economics in Belgium.

An appeal for joint effort by manufacturers and retailers to lower prices to the consumer by reducing high-profit margins was voiced yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co., world's largest department store.

PITTSBURGH, April 4 (AP) -- Tomorrow's "dream school" is a reality today for the 1,000 pupils of the new Sacred Heart Elementary School. They study in air-conditioned classrooms sterilized by ultraviolet rays and write on green glass chalkboards designed to relieve eyestrain.
Beef badly needed in England was delayed in transit yesterday long enough to make a brief appearance in the Brooklyn-Queens Night Court.

Robert Louis Stevenson said, in "Virginibus Puerisque" if memory serves, that it is a blacker lie sometimes to say "I'm glad to see you" than to say "I was in Mozambique last night." The latter statement, he explained, is obviously fantastic. Yet a few days ago thirty-eight air passengers arriving in New York before sunset were able to say for the first time that they had seen the same sun rise over the Pacific.

A new novel by Erico Verissimo, Brazilian author, entitled "Consider the Lilies," with a sucessful Brazilian physician as the central character, will be published by Macmillan on April 15. Senhor Verissimo is the author of two previous books published in America, "Crossroads" and "The Rest Is Silence."

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Senator Walter F. George of Georgia bluntly shifted focus on the GreekTurkish aid program today from its relief and reconstruction aspects to its political implication. This he averred to be a positive policy "to check Russian expansion."

It all seemed very foolish at first. A perfectly sane man with two perfectly sane assistants went to the top of a building 100 feet above the street yesterday and began dropping eggs off the roof. A crowd began to gather. A fresh egg struck the ground and splattered.

PARIS, April 4 -- Intense activity was reported from Indo-China today. Motorized forces started sweeping clean-up movements around the suburbs of Hanoi. Viet Nam forces from ambush attacked French troops and trucks following behind tanks, showering them with grenades on a road southeast of the city.

MOSCOW, April 4 -- The Economic Committee appointed by the Council of Foreign Ministers to deal with reparations, the German level of industry and economic unity has not met since Tuesday and there is no prospect of its meeting in the near future.

Richard W. Ellsasser, 20-year-old concert organist, gave the entire Part 3 of Bach's "Klavieruebung," its third American and first New York memorized presentation, last night at Town Hall, under the auspices of the Bach Circle of Boston.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (U.P.) -- The thirty-five foot barrage balloon that broke away from its moorings here this morning and drifted northward as far as Wilmington, Del., came down in Chesapeake Bay tonight and floated ashore near Rockhall, Md.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with deep interest your editorial in THE TIMES advocating the appointment by Governor Dewey of woman to one of the newly created places on the Parole Board.
Principal issues in the threatened nation-wide telephone strike are wages and "self-defense demands" such as the union shop, seniority provisions, protection against layoffs and old-age security.

The extraordinary adventures of Alice in Wonderland will be recreated this evening at the International Theatre, where the Lewis Carroll fantasy will be revived under the auspices of Rita Hassan and the American Repertory Theatre.

The Statue of Liberty probably will be the only American girl in or near New York who will go without lipstick for Easter, Bedloes Island officials predicted yesterday. The statue was reopened for the first time after a "lipstickproof" paint job and a widely publicized appeal by Charles S. Marshall, superintendent, urging people to cease defiling Miss Liberty with lipsticked autographs.
Three cases of smallpox, the first found in New York City since 1939, were reported yesterday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 4 -- Bill Smith of Ohio State equaled his meet mark of 2:08 in repelling the challenge of France's Alex Jany in the 220-yard free-style.
It still was a moot question last night whether the police ban on all-night parking had been modified.
Jews throughout the world began at sundown last night the celebration of Passover, commemorating the deliverance of the ancient Hebrews from bondage in Egypt.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Investigations into the spectacular wreck of the Twin City Zephyr of the Burlington Railroad in near-by Downers Grove last night were centered today on how a twelve-ton farm tractor slipped off a moving freight train and into the path of the limited.

LONDON, April 4 -- British civil servants have decided to protest against a recent ruling that they must not publicly criticize Government policy as well as against being penalized for membership in "any" political party.

F. SCOTT FITZGERALD created the most famous -- and durable -- of all younger generations in fiction. It was so durable, in fact, that you can still find traces of it around, creaking a little in the joints, but rather resenting the efforts of succeeding generations to take over. One of these latter-day younger generations is the subject of Mark Saxton's thoughtful new novel, "Prepared for Rage."*

Wide Swings in Easter Trade Wide variations in showings of individual stores here marked the close of Easter shopping here this week. Figures ranged from gains of about 15 per cent to declines under a year ago of about the same amount.

PORT OF BEAUMONT, Palmer Land, April 2 (Delayed) -- HMS Trespassy, one of two small British ships here to visit the Ronne Antarctic Research Expedition, caught fire last night as she lay at anchor and was severely damaged before the flames finally were put out this morning.
ATHENS, April 4 (AP) -- New fighting broke out on several fronts of Northern Greece today between Government forces and leftist guerrillas.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Members of Congress and Government officials were told today that unless something is done to guarantee uninterrupted steamship service to Alaska, "80,000 citizens there will go bankrupt."

In its fight to maintain ninetysix day child care centers throughout the city, threatened with closing by Governor Dewey's decision to withdraw state aid in October, the City-Wide Child Care Center Parents Association, 201 West Eighty-ninth Street, announced yesterday it would question passersby in Times Square this afternoon on their opinion of the Governor's decision.

SEOUL, Korea, April 4 (U.P.) -- Maj. Gen. Archer L. Lerch, American Military Governor of Korea, promised today that American controls over Korean Government departments would be relaxed "as soon as possible" to achieve a "free and independent and united Korea administration by Koreans."

BOWIE, Md., April 4 (AP) -- Spanish Uhl, a 6-year-old who campaigned with success on the minor tracks last year, came through with a smashing victory in the featured Blenheim Purse today. Carrying the colors of M. Prickett, the son of Spanish Play led every stride of the way, winning by a half length.

MILWAUKEE, April 4 -- While Chicago and Milwaukee police mingled with the 1,200 delegates, the convention of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes International Alliance and Bartenders International League, AFL, got under way today.

SECAUCUS, N.J., April 4 -- Shot in the spine as he attempted to break through a cordon of police, a 21-year-old Jersey City gangster died early today, ending a six-year criminal career that included thirty arrests and a half dozen escapes from the police and penal institutions.

High food prices are a problem for everyone today, even the First Lady, according to a statement by President Truman reported in this paper yesterday. Describing their effect on the low-income family, Miss Lillian Anderson, director of the nutrition bureau of the Community Service Society, said yesterday that such households now must spend as much as 50 per cent of their weekly income on food alone.

ROME, April 4 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi today warned the Italian people against dictatorship. He declared that unless they cooperate with the Government to stem the domestic inflationary trend Italy might be plunged into dictatorship as a last resort to avoid social and financial chaos.

Spencer J. Drayton, executive secretary of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations, last night made public a transcript of a letter sent by Judge James E. Dooley, president of the T.R.A., to the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association, which recently went on record as refusing to accept the T.R.A.'s new code of standards for the operation of race tracks.

WESTPORT, Conn., April 4 -- School officials and Parent-Teacher Association leaders here are considering ways to prevent organization of a chapter of the American Youth for Democracy, called a part of the Communist party by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, following publication of an article in the Staples High School publication, "Inkling's," on the aims of the organization.

With at least 20,000 fully automatic firearms, most of them war trophies from overseas, still unaccounted for in this area, the Treasury Department started yesterday an accelerated drive to have them registered by their owners.

CENTRALIA, Ill., April 4 -- The disaster in the Centralia Coal Company's No. 5 mine which killed 111 miners last week was due to a dust explosion touched off by an overcharged blast in the narrow face of "First West," one and a half miles southwest of the main shaft, Driscoll Scanlan, State mine inspector, said tonight.

JERUSALEM, April 4 -- Another ship of Britain's deportation fleet for unauthoried Jewish immigrants has been damaged by a bomb, the second to be crippled by sobotage within the past three days, it was announced tonight.
LONDON, April 4 -- According to the calendar this is Good Friday, but for Britons who suffered under rain, sleet, snow and biting north winds it was more like a gloomy Christmas.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- A decision to proceed with legislation on tax reduction, if Senate-House conferees fail to agree soon on how much President Truman's 1948 budget should be cut, was reported to have been reached today by the Senate Republican policy committee.

Much time and ingenuity has been spent on the problem of how to provide new capital for small business; too little has been spent, perhaps, on the question of making it possible for small business to create capital through the retention of earnings.

Those planning an early trip to New Brunswick for the "black" salmon fishing will have to be patient, for the latest reports from there indicate that unusual ice and snow conditions in some areas have delayed the opening about two weeks.

Mrs. Agatha Parker, 22 years old, of 29 Crescent Street, Brooklyn, lost last fall the engagement ring she had received from her husband. To obtain the money to replace it, the police said, she embarked on a series of thefts that landed her in Felony Court yesterday, charged with grand larceny.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The appalling shortage in Britian's coal output is not due to decline manpower. If the miner attend his work with the same regularity in 1939 and exerted the same physical effort while at work, the national output of coal would be increased by less than fifty million tons per annu.

A United Easter Dawn service of one hour will be held tomorrow at 7:30 o'clock in the Radio City Music Hall before an anticipated audience of 6,000. The service will be conducted under the auspices of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.

Hoyt S. Haddock, executive secretary of the CIO Maritime Committee, issued yesterday a list of four vessels which, he said, had been bought by Greek shipping interests in the American surplus pool and transferred by them to the Panama flag.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The value of United States exports, led by a sharp increase in commercial shipments, rose to $1,153,000,000 during February, and probably set an all-time record for American export trade, the Department of Commerce reported today.

As increasing amounts of distressed woolen goods get into clothing production and into yard goods departments for over-thecounter sales, the market is emerging in stronger position, with prospects excellent for the remainder of the year, it was pointed out yesterday by trade sources.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- A demand that the airmail rate be increased to 6 or 7 cents an ounce to make the service pay its own way was made today by Senators Clyde M. Reed, Republican, of Kansas, and Kenneth McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Another communication system for radio transmission and reception, speedily and in secret, of messages intelligible only to authorized listeners, is offered by William W. Hansen of Garden City, N.Y., to whom was issued this week Patent 2,418,119, assigned by him to the Sperry Gyroscope Company of New York.

Arturo Toscanini regards the Office of Alien Property's decision to grant a license to Milton Shubert to make a Broadway musical play out of Puccini's music as unfortunate, it was learned yesterday. Though he has received a letter from Attorney General Tom C. Clark in response to his telegram of protest to President Truman, the maestro's opinion of the transaction has not improved, it was said.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Chesapeake Ohio and the Alleghany Corporation today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to release from the independent voting trust of the Chase National Bank of New York, into which the ICC required the two companies to place all stocks owned by them not of C. O. affiliated roads, of the 400,000 shares of New York Central stock recently acquired by the C. O.

PITTSBURGH, April 4. -- At least twenty-four Pittsburgh mines will be ready to reopen on Monday after passing safety tests here yesterday by joint union and management crews as a result of the drastic Krug interdict which placed 153 regional pits in the "unsafe" category.

Researched Retail Ads, a new bimonthly service prepared by the Meyer Both Company, has been sent to more than 500 stores that have signed as charter subscribers. The service is a series of advertisements that have been shopped for consumer response in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.

The New York Knickerbockers will be out to avenge the 77-51 drubbing they absorbed last Wednesday in Cleveland, when they meet the Cleveland Rebels in the second game of their thirdplace Basketball Association of America play-off series at Madison Square Garden tonight.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Thirteen thousand miners in forty-nine Illinois mines ordered closed Thursday by Secretary of the Interior J.A. Krug until they comply with safety regulations were ruled to be eligible for jobless pay today by the Division of Placement and Unemployment Compensation of the State Labor Department.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 4 -- The establishment of an appeals board to handle grievances of members of the United Nations Secretariat was announced today by Byron Price, Assistant Secretary General for Administrative and Financial Services.

Christian churches in the city were filled yesterday afternoon at three-hour services commemorating Good Friday. Thousands of worshipers attended these and special noon services lasting from forty minutes to an hour.
Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Airlines and arch conservative of the air-transport industry, has sounded another alarm for the domestic air carriers.

For a generation at least the creation of a federal department of health has been proposed, with a secretary of cabinet rank as its head. With each year the case for such a department gains in strength. Our numerous scattered federal health agencies should be merged and coordinated with our educational and security services.

Requests for the yearly pamphlet issued by the staffs of the New York, Brooklyn and Queens Borough Public Libraries, urging the public to promote their campaign for increased financial support from the city have been received in large quantity, it was learned from a library spokesman yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- President Truman will make "a strong speech" at the Jefferson Day Dinner here tomorrow night but will refrain from any direct commitment on the 1948 Presidential campaign, White House associates indicated today.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade state, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers.
The last of the nine felons in the break from Brooklyn City Prison on Jan. 2 was accounted for yesterday with the capture of Anthony Aiello.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Gen. Joseph T. McNarney discounted today the extent of Communist infiltration from the Soviet zone of Germany into the United States area.

CHICAGO, April 4 (U.P.) -- Ten children who would have had to go away to school at a state institution two weeks ago played happily today in one of this country's first public school kindergartens for the blind. The youngsters, all totally blind since birth, and doomed to a lifetime of darkness, entered the new class two weeks ago.

Automatic electric toasters will be the "last of scarce traffic appliances to meet with consumer price resistance," a traffic appliance buyer for a leading department store declared yesterday. He pointed out that despite some increases of close to 100 per cent, the bulk of merchandise still retails under $20 and added that "consumer price resistance is virtually nonexistent in this price category."

This is Holy Week for Christians and Jews. More people of all denominations attend religious services during these days than at any other time of the year. Human society has made as many revolutions through the centuries as the irreversible wheel of time. Twice in this century the world has turned upside down and come back with historic landmarks shattered and the weights shifted that hold the political structure in balance.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (U.P.) -- War Assets Administrator Robert M. Littlejohn was accused today of interfering with a $1,000,000 war surplus contract in a suit filed in Federal Court by the Palmer Bolt and Nut Company, Inc., Detroit.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Senator Glen H. Taylor, Democrat, of Idaho, said in an address prepared for the radio tonight that the President's program of aiding Turkey and Greece involved "an oil grab" in the Middle East.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 4 (AP) -- Two children perished today and seven others were burned, four critically, in a flash fire that swept a crowded five-room foster home.

Good husbandmen go forth to plow with faith in their hearts. Since that epochal day of long ago when man learned he could stir the soil, put in seed, and in due time harvest the grains, plowing has been an act of faith. When spring's miracle has come to earth and the higher-climbing sun has dried the soil enough, the soil is made ready for the seeds.
Daniel M. Dent has been appointed general manager of the manufacturing department, manufactured products division, the Borden Company.

DANBURY, Conn., April 4 -- This city's entire force of seventy-five regular and supernumerary policemen were on emergency patrol duty tonight as Mayor William J. Hannan and Police Chief George J. Schoen acted to prevent a possible repetition of a pyromaniac's activities which started at 9 P.M. Thursday and extended over a sixhour period until an early hour this morning.

CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- If the proposed amendment to the United States Constitution limiting the Presidency to two full terms or not more than ten years is ratified by the required thirty-six states, the task may take several years though it has been approved, so far, by eight states.

Acting on a tip from an anonymous source, ten detectives raided a cafe at 628 Grand Avenue, Brooklyn, at 10:30 o'clock last night, arrested Alfred Giordano, 53 years old, of 341 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, said to be the proprietor, on a charge of maintaining a gambling house, and twenty-two other men whom they charged with disorderly conduct.
What may be a significant step forward in the history of medical progress in this country was demonstrated yesterday in the homes of persons afflicted with cancer and other "long-term" diseases.
LONDON, April 4 (Reuters) -- Tens of thousands packed Great Britain's football stands for Good Friday features which saw Brentford in a losing battle to retain a foothold in the first division.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation reported yesterday for 1946 a consolidated net income of $27,607,645 after charges, taxes and reserves for depreciation and depletion, equal to $2.30 each on the 11,974,041 capital shares in the hands of the public.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Certifications required by the Government to reopen the 518 soft coal mines which it closed for safety reasons have begun to come in, the Coal Mines Administration reported today on the basis of scattered field reports.

Effete Buffalo Bill The question is whether Senator Morse of Oregon has a high opinion of the physical prowess of a plainsman or just the opposite. His words can be read in two ways. Senator Morse said to Senator Kenneth Wherry of Nebraska:

BOSTON, April 4 (AP) -- Marking the twentieth anniversary of the first Boston-New York commercial passenger flight, Ralph S. Damon, president of American Airlines, said today that "aviation can knit together the constructive interests of the peoples far more effectively perhaps than can the awful fear of the atom bomb."

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 4 -- The superintendent of the United States Military Academy today reduced to six months the two-year prison sentence in the case of the widely publicized deserter-war hero and suspended execution of a dishonorable discharge for him.

PARIS, April 4 -- France will join the United States in seeking substantial reductions in British Imperial preference tariffs at the negotiations for a reduction in trade barriers opening in Geneva next Thursday.

BOSTON, April 4 (AP) -- The Boston Wool Trade Association, voicing opposition to the Robertson wool price bill reported out by a Senate committee, asserted in a statement today that it would cost the taxpayers "at least $75,000,000 yearly."

PARIS, April 4 -- The newspaper Monde today published the text of a letter Charles de Gaulle wrote to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in January, 1945, to dissuade the then Allied Supreme Commander from evacuating Strasbourg.

VIENNA, April 4 -- Expert study of the military clauses proposed by the French for the Austrian treaty has convinced the Austrian Government they might prove almost as damaging to Austria's economy as the Soviet claims under the Potsdam clause.

ALBANY, April 4 -- Appointment of five members of the Barber Advisory Committee, which will advise him in the promulgation of rules and regulations for the barbering profession, was announced today by Thomas J. Curran, Secretary of State.

By unanimous vote the Security Council of the United Nations has now appointed the United States sole trustee of the Marshall, Caroline and Marianas islands, under the "strategic area" provisions of the Charter. These provisions give us the right to convert the, islands into fortresses in order to safeguard peace and our security.

The A.C.A. Gallery will open on Monday evening an exhibition entitled "Artists' Tribute in Memory of Franklin Delano Roosevelt," the result of a competition for which twenty-six artists submitted drawings illustrating outstanding speeches by Roosevelt.

PEIPING, Saturday, April 5 (AP) -- First reports of the Tangku ammunition dump attack said one marine tank was disabled by a land mine in the early fighting, which was punctuated by several explosions of stored ammunition.

MOSCOW, April 4 -- Implementing its promise to open more doors to correspondents -- at least during this Council of Foreign Ministers' session -- the Soviet Information Bureau has plunged visiting reporters into an extensive sightseeing program.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 4 -- The Giants said their farewells to Arizona today with a salvo of home runs that left the folks with something to remember them by. Resuming hostilities with the Indians and fighting an uphill battle all the way, the New Yorkers hammered their way to a 10-to-6 victory, their seventh in a row, to the satisfaction of 3,671 fans.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 4 (AP) -- A survey of opinion conducted by Cornell University with funds granted by the Carnegie Corporation and the Rockefeller Foundation indicates that the American people believe the United States should retain control of the atomic bomb.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 4 -- Public interest in the United Nations will reach its peak Monday when Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet delegate, is expected to comment on American foreign policy in the Near East, officials here predicted today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 4 -- John E. Cushing, president of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company for the last nine years, was made president of the Matson Navigation Company today. He succeeds Frazer A. Bailey, who resigned to become president of the National Federation of American Shipping, with headquarters in Washington.

MOSCOW, April 4 -- Foreign Minister Molotov has called for a renunciation of foreign -- that is, American or British -- "interference" in Greece, and expressed doubts that American policy would restore democracy there.
On May 6, Cleveland will offer $6,100,000 of various bond issues at rates not to exceed 3 per cent. The issues will be dated May 1 and will be redeemed on May 1, 1948 through 1972.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 4 -- Regular service from the Fairfield (Calif.) Air Base to Tokyo over the Great Circle route probably will be started in sixty to ninety days by the Air Transport Command, Brig. Gen. Archie J. Old, commander of the ATC's Eastern Pacific wing, said today.
A new joint labor-management meeting aimed at heading off the telephone strike in the area served by the New York Telephone Company broke up last night without success.

JERUSALEM, April 4 -- British soldiers, carrying rifles and machine guns, followed in the footsteps of the Prince of Peace through the Jerusalem Old City today in a traditional Good Friday procession. The procession took the Stony Road followed by Christ from his condemnation by Pontius Pilate to his burial in the Sepulchre of Joseph of Arimathaea.

For racing enthusiasts in this theatre of operations, spring begins officially at 1:30 P. M. today. That's the time when the horses will be at the post at Jamaica for the first race of the New York season.

MOSCOW, April 4 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark accused Fedor T. Gusev today of seeking to employ "unfair tactics" as the Soviet deputy opposed United Nations participation in disputes involving German assets in the eastern zone of Austria.

The Mayor has proclaimed a spring drive to clean up streets, vacant lots, city-owned properties and private building's as well. The Outdoor Cleanliness Association will head up the unofficial efforts to inspire New York's careless residents to do their duty and make the city a more decent place in which to live.

JERUSALEM, April 4 -- British soldiers, carrying rifles and machine guns, followed in the footsteps of the Prince of Peace through the Jerusalem Old City today in a traditional Good Friday procession. The procession took the Stony Road followed by Christ from his condemnation by Pontius Pilate to his burial in the Sepulchre of Joseph of Arimathaea.

For racing enthusiasts in this theatre of operations, spring begins officially at 1:30 P. M. today. That's the time when the horses will be at the post at Jamaica for the first race of the New York season.

MOSCOW, April 4 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark accused Fedor T. Gusev today of seeking to employ "unfair tactics" as the Soviet deputy opposed United Nations participation in disputes involving German assets in the eastern zone of Austria.

The Mayor has proclaimed a spring drive to clean up streets, vacant lots, city-owned properties and private building's as well. The Outdoor Cleanliness Association will head up the unofficial efforts to inspire New York's careless residents to do their duty and make the city a more decent place in which to live.

Hope that the city administration may approve plans to finance construction of 10,000 apartments to rent at $12.50 a room monthly was reported last night by Edmond Borgia Butler, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The first "wave" of United States delegates to the Geneva trade confererences commencing April 10 will leave the United States this weekend. Forty officials will go at this time -- half on Saturday by special airplane and half on the following day.

PEARL HARBOR, April 3 -- United States naval air bases in the Pacific west of Pearl Harbor have been consolidated and "rolled up" in the last eighteen months until only seven of twenty six are operating, Vice Admiral John Dale Price, commander of the Naval Air Forces in the Pacific, has reported here after a 16,000-mile tour of inspection.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 4 -- As the Yankees packed their belongings today for their final spring training maneuver, which virtually will be completed in a hop, skip and a jump, Manager Bucky Harris found it necessary to give utterance to a rather singular confession.
DETROIT, April 4 -- The incumbent left-wing leadership of Local 600 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, was swept back into power for another year today on the basis of complete tabulation.

Easter holiday travel from and into the city was so heavy yesterday that some transportation officials expressed surprise. Although most carriers reported traffic greater than on last year's Good Friday, none saw an Easter record.

HAVANA, April 4 -- All the Dodgers were given the day off today but Hugh Casey will have to add nine more off days before he can return to active duty, and Peewee Reese may have to rest even more than he has been doing for the past several days.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- The Justice Department told the president of Wayne University today that J. Edgar Hoover, F.B.I. Director, has identified the American Youth for Democracy as a Communist front organization.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Tom C. Clark, United States Attorney General, in a surprise announcement today, declared that President Truman had the authority to seize the nation-wide network of telephone lines if the employes go on strike as scheduled Monday at 6 A.M.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: News reports of Mayor O'Dwyer's willingness to allow the Federal Government to take title to and restore Fort Clinton have merely mentioned that the Mayor made this statement at a luncheon at Fraunces Tavern on April 2.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The debate on aid to Greece and Turkey has reached the "tired stage,'' and this is the stage when flagging minds think they have solved their problems when they haven't.

MINDEN, Germany, April 4 -- The Ruhr food demonstrations have had no effect on the Bavarian farmers and it is held highly unlikely that the Ruhr will fare better in the next ration period as a result of extra Bavarian efforts to alleviate the situation.

LA ROCHELLE, France, April 4 (Reuters) -- The British steamer Willodale sank in a storm fifteen miles off the French coast today with a loss of at least six lives. A French battleship and seaplane searched amid the mountainous waves of the Bay of Biscay for survivors of the crew.

Deacon has gone on the wagon. No more sly tippling for the loquacious crow of the Bronx Zoo, because beginning today he will be back in show business and can't afford to garble his lines. The order went out yesterday from Lee Crandall, general curator of the zoo.

Bubble gum or no bubble gum, American bobby soxers are veritable gentlefolk when compared to their British counterparts, according to Robert Taylor and his wife, Barbara Stanwyck. The film stars arrived on the United States liner America yesterday, still haunted by vivid memories of a half-hour tussle with hero-worshiping British youngsters.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 4 -- A terrific comeback by little Ben Hogan and a sensational round by young Cary Middlecoff, a Memphis amateur until a few weeks ago, highlighted today's second round of the eleventh annual Masters tournament at the Augusta National Golf Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 4 -- Brenda Marshall, who has been absent from the screen for four years, was signed today by Paramount to play the feminine lead, with Alan Ladd, in "Whispering Smith," the studio's projected remake of Frank H. Spearman's 1906 Western novel.

BERLIN, April 4 (AP) -- The Unitad States, Czechoslovakia and Belgium, each qualified four fighters for the championship round of the Allied forces European boxing tournament in the semi-finals tonight.

PEIPING, Saturday, April 5 -- Five United States Marines were killed and sixteen wounded early today when an unknown number of unidentified, armed Chinese attacked the First Marine Division ammunition dump three miles northwest of Tangku, near Tientsin, headquarters of the First Marine Division announced.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Dean Acheson, Acting Secretary of State, announced today that Henry F. Grady of San Francisco has been selected to be the first United States Ambassador to India.

SHANGHAI, April 4 (AP) -- The story of how Governor Chen Yi halted the demonstrations on Formosa last month "sounds as if it had occurred several centuries ago," American journalist John W. Powell says in an article that will appear tomorrow in his China Weekly Review.
ROME, April 4 (U.P.) -- Three men were sentenced tonight to thirty years in prison for the murder of Giacomo Matteotti in 1924.

SOME gardeners like to grow varieties of vegetables that are seldom seen on the market, particularly if they are new and promise to be improvements over older sorts. A number of interesting newcomers are on this year's lists.

UNTIL the last years of the nineteenth century Russia did not know philosophy as a science and as an intellectual discipline, as the West has known it for many centuries. Yet in Dostoevsky Russia possessed, in a deeper and more representative sense than any Western nation, a truly national philosopher who in his creative art and in his theoretical writing expressed the thoughts and longings, the drives and reactions of his people.

The testimony before the Interstate Commerce Commission last week on the application of the railroads in the East for an increase of 10 per cent in their passenger fares emphasized the difficulty that the roads are experiencing in meeting operating expenses.

Another sure sign the war is over was the definite decision last night that the Albany-to-New York outboard marathon would be resumed this spring. This May- time fixture, back in the days before Pearl Harbor, always represented one of the most fantastic and bizarre phenomena of the sports world.

"MAN EATERS OF KUMAON," the best selling book by James Corbett, will be, it is the hope of Monroe Shaff, who will produce the film version for Universal International release, "an honest story of an Indian Village and its people in the tradition of 'Chang' and 'Grass.'

WITH the best intentions, some of the care given to trees during spring does more harm than good. Wrong pruning can be worse than none at all. Any cuts an inch or more in diameter should be covered with tree paint and lopping off large limbs should be avoided unless necessary.

A total of 58,325,129 passengers used the Twenty-third Street stations of the subways, Third Avenue elevated and bus lines during the year which ended June 30, 1946, according to a report submitted to the Twenty-third Street Association by Thomas R. Cox, vice president and chairman of the organization's transportation committee.

Because hundreds of families would be forced out of slum areas they have occupied for generations, plans now before housing officials here call for postponement of some slum clearance, it was learned yesterday. The plans provide for the construction of at least one low- rent public housing development on vacant land in Queens or the Bronx.

TAPACHULA, Mexico -- To drive from Mexico to Guatemala is out of the question. Some people claim they have done it -- in taxis, motorcycles, jalopies and jeeps. But hotel men and officials in this border city wink at their tall stories and point to the railroad.

Activity centered yesterday on the buying of milady's bonnet and the little one's Easter bunny . . . not on securities. A mere 270,000 shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange in a listless session during which the ticker tape halted frequently.

When the cosmic rays were first studied systematically and intensively it was suggested that since they are even more penetrating than X-rays and pierce every human being on this earth on an average of more than twenty times a second, they may explain the prevalence of cancer.

Marked advances in residential building efficiency and economy appear to be in the making, judging by new construction materials and methods being submitted to the Federal Housing Administration for engineering tests, according to Raymond M. Foley, National Housing Administrator.

LETTER -- A reader, who has been following accounts of the Navy's junket to and from Antarctica, noted that six twin-engine planes, several bulldozers, tractors and other objects too bulky to be loaded in a hurry had been left behind.

SO many gardens are tended after the day's work is done that plantings which can be enjoyed in the dim light of evening as well as during the day are doubly valuable. When making new selections for the border this year flowers which are attractive after sundown might be considered.

As had been predicted following the victory of Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didriksen Zaharias in the women's national amateur golf championship at Tulsa, Okla., in September, 1946, the Denver golfer has proved to be the Joe Louis of women's golf.

CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) -- Strength in May wheat featured an otherwise dull grain market today on the Board of Trade. While most wheat deliveries eased, the May contract was firm on trade reports that the Army Quartermaster Corps will buy a large quantity of flour in the near future.
ALBANY, April 5 -- The bills paving the way for eventual construction in Albany of several new- State office buildings and a new executive mansion, were signed today by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey.

Forty railroad cars, emblazoned with red and yellow letters that proclaimed their contents as the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, rumbled into the Mott Haven yards in the Bronx early yesterday morning. Up on a trestle 9-year-old Timothy John Garrity listened eagerly for the muffled roars of lions and tigers from their wagon cages, lashed to flat cars and covered with tarpaulins.
MADRID, April 5 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco's gesture Monday in announcing a Council of the Realm and procedure for naming his successor has backfired with remarkable force.

-- NEW YORKERS Life for us everyday New Yorkers is one discouraging thing after another. For instance, the notion gets around that the place is just one mad, voluptuous Sodom and Gomorrah of pleasure seeking, and our Mayor has to remind the world that quite a few of us work for a livelihood and dwell in humble streets, where the only revelry to speak of is the dancing of kids around hand organs.

MOSCOW, April 5 -- After four weeks of meetings, it is evident that the Council of Foreign Ministers is not going to solve the German problem in Moscow. There is still hope, although it is less strong than it was a month ago, that an Austrian settlement will be agreed upon here.

MAN has seldom been more of a political animal than he is at present and his civic thinking has in this country quite naturally led to numerous books about democracy. We must, of course, be reasonable and not expect too much of these studies; experts, despite the thunder of their technical vocabulary, can be as confused as the ordinary citizen and as limited in breadth of view.
CHICAGO, April 5 -- Peter S. Lambros, former editor and publisher of The Greek Star, died today in Mercy Hospital after an illness of two weeks. He was 74 years old.

ONE of the brighter notes heard along the Main Stem last week was sounded by Irwin S. Chanin, head of the organization bearing his name. Mr. Chanin said he and his associates would go ahead with their plans for new theatres as soon as conditions settle, which, he thinks, should be some time next year.

I loathe it, I hate it, I despise it. * * * * * I am one of the unemployed who hopes to get his job back. Once, years ago, George II of the Hellenes uttered the first sentence about his kingly role. Later, while in exile, he spoke the second sentence.

HOLLYWOOD. SOMEONE has said with evil astuteness that the real artists in Hollywood never get in front of the cameras. They make no loud publicity noises, rarely are seen in fan magazines and never spy their names in lights.

Extension of export controls contained in the Second War Powers Act is the keystone of the Government's political loan program and is fundamental to a world trade financed by dollar gifts and loans, foreign traders stated last week. Without these controls, they said, foreign governments will have great difficulty in squeezing the required goods out of the already overworked American production machine.

PEIPING, April 5 (U.P.) -- The United States Marine Corps has proved that Chinese Communists killed five marines and wounded sixteen early today. The pre-dawn attack was made on an ammunition dump near Tangku.

WHAT is claimed to be a new idea in a radio network public-opinion poll program will have its premiere presentation, on Wednesday when WOR-Mutual offers the first installment of its "Opinionaire" series from 8:30 to 9 P.M.
The public has responded gratifyingly to the suggestion that those who have not been vaccinated since childhood be so treated immediately, Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein said yesterday.

HAVANA, April 5 -- A five-run outburst in the fifth inning that gave the Dodgers their eighth victory in ten starts against their Montreal farm cousins by the score of 6 -- 3, also threatened today to remove Jackie Robinson's much- discussed chances for promotion to the Brooks from the realm of speculation.

PARENTS want their children to play fair, to do unto others as they would be done by, and many parents think they've brought them up this way until a wave of religious or racial prejudice hits the neighborhood.

In presenting his annual report for 1946 to the Spies Committee for Clinical Research, Dr. Tom Spies of the University of Cincinnati dwelt on our ignorance of nutrition, for all the work that has been done by biochemists in discovering new vitamins. He holds that we do not know the chemical compounds that must be supplied to the human body in order to meet its requirements for growth and health.

HERE is a gardener's notebook for the year, full of hints, suggestions, comments and observations for any gardener -- city, suburban or rural. Much of the material comes from Miss Jenkin's weekly column on the garden page in the Sunday NEW York Times.

THE third edition of "A Cruising Guide to the New England Coast" brings up to date one or the most valuable volumes ever published for the East Coast yachtsman. It is safe to say that for those who sail for pleasure it is the best adjunct to the chart and Pilot available.

The critical shortage of certain types of office personnel in the metropolitan area has eased considerably recently and business organizations of all types will become increasingly insistent upon proper qualifications of applicants "from now on," Ernest De La Ossa, chairman of the New York Personnel Management Association, declared in an interview last week.

THERE is a strong general feeling among people closely connected with helicopters that rotary-wing aircraft have reached a stage of development where they can be considered a means of commercial transport. At the same time there is an equally strong opinion among some manufacturers of helicopters that it is about time the machines were produced in numbers and put to general use.

RICHMOND, Va., April 5 (AP) -- Paul Revere, a 7-year-old bay gelding from Paul Melton's Rokeby Stables, Upperville, had Lady Luck with him today and won the three- miles-over-timber Deep Run Cup race in the fifteenth annual running at the Atlantic rural exposition grounds at Strawberry Hill.

MR. LEWIS believes that Thomas Paine quite literally wrote the original draft of the Declaration of Independence; that "no ordinary man" (i. e., Thomas Jefferson) could have written it; and that the famous draft in John Adams' hand and the so- called Rough Draft in Jefferson's hand were both copied from the original written by Paine.

Stanley Grafton Mortimer of this city and Tuxedo Park, N.Y., one of the noted American amateur racquets players, died yesterday morning in his home at 18 East Seventy-ninth Street. He had been in poor health for more than six months, and suffered a heart attack on Friday.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, today added up the money to be laid out by the United States under its international commitments in the next fifteen months and announced a total of $7,043,100,000.

Last-ditch efforts are scheduled for today here and in New Jersey to prevent the threatened breakdown of telephone service at 6 A.M. tomorrow. Hours of discussion yesterday failed to produce a single sign of progress.

New York and Cleveland, principals in the third-place play-off series in the Basketball Association of America, will meet in the deciding contest here on Wednesday night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. This became a certainty last night when the local Knickerbockers, in command most of the way, recorded an 86-74 victory over the Rebels before 10,321 persons at, Madison Square Garden.

PARIS, April 5 -- The Viet Nam radio in a broadcast reported here today recognized that Emile Bollaert, new High Commissioner to Indo-China was endeavoring to make an objective study of the situation.
VIENNA, April 5 -- Austrian publishers of independent newspapers report that a new effort is being made to put all except party- owned newspapers out of business.

Joseph Stack, vice president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, was found guilty yesterday afternoon of charges preferred by Joseph Curran, NMU president, at a membership meeting in the St. Nicholas Arena, 69 West Sixty- sixth Street.

THE single-handed sailing of Marin-Marie has become somewhat of a legend among yachtsmen. His own story, held from publication by the war years, now reaches America in "Wind Aloft, Wind Alow." For the uninitiated, let it be explained that Marin-Marie, the pseudonym of the French marine artist, M.-M. Durand de St. Front, is the only yachtsman to have crossed the Atlantic, alone, both under sail and in a motorboat.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Some of the freedoms of speech which employers may use with impunity in dealing with union organizing in their plants were spelled out in a National Labor Relations Board decision issued this week.

NEW DELHI, India, April 5 -- Indonesian and Viet Nam delegates to the recently concluded Asian Relations Conference issued today a five-point program by which they suggested that Asian countries could take positive action to prevent the re-establishment of colonialism in Asia.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 5 (AP) -- Red Barrett rationed the Chattanooga Lookouts to four hits today as the Braves registered a 5-0 victory over the Southern Association club.

SEOUL, Korea, April 5 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, returning from conferences in Washington, said today that American efforts to strengthen democracy and economic development in South Korea would be intensified.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A fear that the home-building industry is headed for collapse as a result of overpricing and excessive costs is fast catching on among Government economists.

LOUISE VARESE has done a competent, witty translation of Lemarchand's "Parenthesis," and in spite of the "good guys" and "honeys" who crop up from time to time, some of the French flavor gets through alive. Certainly there are enough cocottes, stagnant canals and Gallic touches to keep a pre-war tourist satisfied.

HERE is a little book that is just what its name implies -- a primer, written for the land- lubber. And the authors. Rosemary and Steever Oldden, have done a very shipshape job. For the young in age and the young in spirit who are considering the acquisition of a small sailing boat it is an excellent starter.

The Maritime Commission's proposed new bareboat charter system for war-built merchant vessels, or which the Government agency asked for industry comment, has met unanimous opposition from local ship operators.

With secondary security markets still spellbound by the current play of conflicting economic forces, investment interest in recent weeks is being drawn increasingly toward the market for new capital. Here, for the first time in years, underwriting specialists are sweating out one pricing and selling job after another, with little to go by from the listed markets in the way of encouragement or guide.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The possibility that anti-trust charges could be brought against firms entering into agreements for lowering prices was foreseen today by several top-ranking legal authorities both in and outside the Government.
CENTRALIA, Ill., April 5 -- One Congressional and two state investigative agencies tonight had completed their inquiries into the Centralia coal mine explosion at the scene of the disaster.

The former Norfolk, Va., Army base is now being operated as a cargo terminal by the Norfolk Terminals Division of Stevenson Young, Inc., under a five-year lease from the Maritime Commission, it was announced yesterday by H.D. Stevenson, president.

MOSCOW, April 5 -- The Foreign Ministers' deputies dealing with the Austrian settlement met today and reached further disagreement on all the main points of the discussion on the property of United Nations nationals in Austria.
LONDON, April 6 (Sunday) (AP) -- Europeans prepared today to celebrate the rites of resurrection in the Protestant and Catholic churches and cathedrals of their ravaged continent.

THE unpleasant events of our time have deflected Mr. Cloete from fiction writing into sociological analysis. "Yesterday Is Dead," published in 1940, identified a ubiquitous yet somehow elusive man in the street with the man of good-will (who is only too eager to be moral and a Christian if circumstances permit) and gave him ventriloquistic credit for a good many author-inspired notions.

We recently expressed the view that orderly price reductions would provide a solution for many of our present problems. The difficulty is, of course, to get such a movement under way when it must be largely voluntary and in the face of the many very real obstacles.
HONG KONG, April 5 -- Now that the old treaty ports have disappeared with the end of extraterritoriality, Hong Kong is a conspicuous political anachronism.

EARL CONRAD holds an unusual position in American journalism. As Harlem bureau head for The Chicago Defender, a Negro newspaper of considerable influence, he has entry to intimacies that few Negroes disclose to a white man.

WHATEVER became of Jerry Osgood? He used to room with Bob Clement and Jim What's His Name in Winthrop House. He was a good guy, quiet, minded his own business. That last's no special commendation, though -- almost anybody could indifferently mind his business at Harvard in the mid-Thirties.

The strike of approximately 1,000 sandhogs that has tied up construction on the $84,000,000 Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel since March 20 was ended yesterday When members of Local 147, Compressed Air Workers Union, AFL, voted to return to work tomorrow morning without having obtained any changes in existing contracts with employers involved.

With the lifting of the Government's export controls on some fifty items last week, renewed inquiries from foreign countries for steel rushed into the American market again, but it is indicated that domestic steel mills will not alter their present allocations to foreign consumers substantially before 1948.

TOKYO. WHEN a ghastly painted Japanese actor playing a princess role recently winked at a samurai warrior and in Dixie fashion drawled "hel-lo" in the midst of a serious Kabuki classic, old Japan lands realized that even the Japanese theatre had been affected by the occupation.

With price again prime news in retailing after taking second place during the war years, retail advertising faces a real test in the period ahead, according to H.J. Kenner, manager of the Better Business Bureau of New York City.

NORTH WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 5 -- After suffering more from the indirect ravages of World War II than it did from cannon balls and grapeshot in the 1776 Battle of White Plains, Washington's headquarters here was nevertheless still upright today and will be re-opened to the public tomorrow.

WHEN Easter comes to Broadway this observer usually waxes benign and is moved to scan the holiday offerings with as much enthusiasm as discretion allows. This seems a fair conciliation toward both the buyers and sellers of films.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 5 (AP) -- Waters from Lake Chautauqua and its swollen tributaries brought flood conditions to southern Chautauqua County today, flooding cellars, blocking roads and filling the streets of Frewsburg with two feet of water.

Offering a series of improvements, the new spring model Lincoln cars were announced yesterday by T.W. Skinner, general manager of the Lincoln-Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company. Changes are shown in exterior and interior appointments.

ISIDOR SCHNEIDER'S novel is a strangely parochial or sectarian fiction intended to show members of the Communist party how disgusting Trotskyists and renegades are. The Trotskyists and renegades were originally Communists themselves, of course, and uninitiated readers who do not share the author's premises may have a difficult time keeping moral accounts straight in this atmosphere of psychopathia, fraternal hatred, suspicion and betrayal.
LONDON, April 5 -- In 1939 two Labor party MP's, Clement Attlee and A.V. Alexander, voted against conscription. That was as war approached, but the British labor movement had always been pacifist.

THE Johns Hopkins University has just announced the creation of a new Department of Writing, Speech and Drama which, beginning next fall, will offer a major in any one or a combination of these fields. This announcement calls attention once more to the role our colleges and universities have come to play in the present crisis in the American theatre.

Several theatre parties in aid of worthy causes have been arranged for the coming week. The Florence Crittenton League has taken over the evening performance on Tuesday of "The Importance of Being Earnest" at the Royale Theatre, the proceeds to be used to further its work among young girls needing help and guidance.

Dog show campaigners these days are mostly marking time. The indoor season has all but expired, the shows outdoors are still more than a month ahead, but the spring events are casting their customary shadows before.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- John L. Lewis' request today that all but two of the nation's soft-coal mines be closed has dramatically highlighted the problem of mine safety. Dangerous as coal mining is, there is at least some consolation in the fact that the country's record has been improving over the years.

LONDON, April 5 -- The Soviet Government has sent a note to the Greek Government holding it responsible for publication in Greek newspapers of a "faked interview" with Premier Stalin, the Moscow radio reported tonight.
MOSCOW, April 5 -- Ambassador Robert D. Murphy evoked an "I must apologize" from Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, in a Coordinating Committee meeting today.

Cook County, Ill., has one-fiftieth of the State's area, more than one- half of its population. Of the county's 4,063,342 residents, 3,396,808 live in Chicago. In the last four Presidential elections large down-state Republican majorities were canceled out by big Democratic margins in Cook County.

THIS is the third book to win the Norton Medical Award. Like the other two, "Doctors East, Doctors West" by Edward Hume, and Carl Binger's: 'The Doctor's Job," it is a book by a doctor about medical life -- in this instance the world of the surgeon and the operating theatre.
The life of crime on which he embarked twenty years ago -- juvenile delinquent in his teens, a murderer in his manhood -- apparently has left Anthony Aiello penitent.

TURBULENT love (or a reasonable facsimile) in the little old New York of hansom cabs and unaltered brownstone fronts is what the reader finds in this story of selfish, spoiled Vicky -- and the devoted spouse who grants her every wish.

Letter From America Dear Dr. Pangloss: You ask in your last letter what are people in this country chiefly thinking and talking about. Well, it is a big country with something like one hundred and forty million people and a corresponding number of interests and problems, some weighty and grave, some of lesser consequence.

LENINGRAD, April 5 -- Representatives of the United States, Britain and France are conducting negotiations in Moscow designed to give the French more coal and thus pave the way for French approval of United States and British plans for economic unity and an increase in production in Germany.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- In a time of general dissatisfaction, such as exists today in the United States, the political stocks of men in office fluctuate considerably and often, and that is what is happening in the Republican and Democratic parties. Since each controls one Government source of public action -- the Democrats, the Presidency, the Republicans, Congress -- the fluctuations affect both parties equally as they carry out their particular responsibilities.

CONTRARY to the usual custom, Easter week finds the dance schedule in a slump. Not a ballet company is around, and not even a recital is to be found in the Broadway district. Performances in the neighborhood houses, however, are as follows:

MOSCOW, April 5 -- Because of the free-press promise extracted from Foreign Minister Molotov by former Secretary of State Byrnes, the Moscow session of the Council of Foreign Ministers posed a most difficult problem to the Soviet newspapers.

In the planning of future shopping centers in suburban or potentially urban neighborhoods, ample parking space will be one of the factors making for success of these projects, in the opinion of Robert H. Armstrong, president of Armstrong Associates.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 5 (U.P.) -- Pauline Betz, champion woman tennis player of the United States, tonight admitted that her status was in doubt.

To the Drama Editor: While "The Eagle Has Two Heads" is not Cocteau's best, far from it, it is excellent theatre and melodrama. But, even more than that, it has something to say. For, in a period during which we have all learned to get acquainted with death, we find an author who dares to write of two human beings who are in love with death.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A "safety" strike of most of the country's soft coal mines next week appeared probable on the basis of John L. Lewis' demand today that the Government close all but two of the pits until they pass Federal reinspection.

TRANSLATIONS of Pindar are not published very often. There have been less than a dozen in the last fifty years or more, and the most interesting of these was an edition so sumptuous that it might as well not have been published at all.

VERY teasing to the mind is Robert Frost's assertion, quoted in today's Treasure Chest, that "the most exciting movement in nature is not progress, advance, but expansion and contraction." The remark has its roots, perhaps, in Emerson's famous essay on "Compensation."

PARIS, April 5 -- The hint put forth by Foreign Minister Georges Bidault's popular Republican organ Aube for an alliance of the Catholic Popular Republican party and the Socialists in France was rejected today by the official Socialist newspaper Populaire.

WHILE our writers, both practiced and fledgling, seemed to have covered and recovered practically every sociological phase of the last war -- from the home front to the battlefront and back home again -- they, nevertheless, left still one aspect of war unexplored.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES. Both in content and in timing the two reports on Germany submitted by Mr. Hoover to the White House have immense historic interest, bearing directly on the foundations of any hope for peace.

Most general contractors feel that the peak of construction costs has been reached in many sections of the country, according to a poll of opinion of 268 leaders in the business, conducted by the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

MOSCOW, April 5 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers emerged today from the doldrums of the past week and agreed upon the establishment of a German advisory council as a provisional government three months after the organization of central administrative agencies.

With the introduction of a bill in Congress to provide copyright protection for textile designs, trade groups in the textile industry last week backed the legislation to replace the "gentlemen's agreement" to respect fabric designs and constructions.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The end of Selective Service as a manpower agency for the Army and Navy leaves the military services singularly unruffled. The Navy and Marine Corps traditionally, and successfully, have relied on voluntary recruiting to fill their ranks, and the Army has not made a draft call since October.

TO THE EDITOR: Re Sidney Hook's "What Exactly Do We Mean by 'Democracy'?": The meaning of democracy as a word is very plain and very clear, but as a principle of government it is very obscure. * * * Democracy means simply this: majority rule in matters affecting the people collectively.

LONDON, April 5 -- Winston Churchill denounced today the British Government's decision to cut the proposed period of compulsory military service from eighteen months to one year as "another example of the policy of scuttle."

WHAT to do for the established lawn to keep it looking well is often a puzzling question. So much has been said and written about the dangers of too much fertilizer or fertilizing at the wrong time that the gardener is timid about doing anything at all for fear it might cause more harm than good.

Roosevelt College, which was formally dedicated less than a year and a half ago in Chicago by Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, will move from its present quarters in an old office building to a modern reconstructed center next fall.

New Yorkers face the prospect of attending Easter services and marching in Fifth Avenue's fashion parade today under threatening skies. The Weather Bureau predicted that the day would be cloudy and warm, with showers in the afternoon and possibly even in the morning. The winds are to be fresh to strong.
ANNAPOLIS, April 5 -- Behind the six-hit pitching and heavy hitting of Andy Frahler, the Naval Academy nine scored a 14-2 victory over Dartmouth today, for its third victory of the season.

AMONG the numerous "How to" books for freshmen business tycoons, those usually sell the best which give the successful formulae for obtaining that raise. Since Loire Brophy's latest book goes a step farther and tells also "How to Make One Good Raise Deserve Another," it probably will have an added allure for the aspirant to top management rating.

ATHENS, April 5 -- In the light of her record, it is difficult to see how Greece is to avoid inflation or import sufficient commodities to maintain a reasonable standard of living even with the proposed financial assistance from the United States.

NEW YORK'S avenues and cross streets offer exciting opportunities for adaptation of the technique of the picture story to an entire city street. Each street in the metropolis has its own peculiarities, its own characteristics and distinctive atmosphere.

WAR takes many forms. Perhaps those who know its essence are concentration camp prisoners, who endured brutality and hunger without the chance to hit back. Agnes Newton Keith's crisp, frank account of her internment in Borneo, where she, her husband and her son were taken captive when the Japanese arrived in 1942, mixes pathos and humor, and succeeds in being entertaining and good for you at the same time.

BOSTON, April 5 -- With spring in New England hearts, if not yet in this northern air, the question of whether billboards should be restricted was warmly argued in the New Hampshire Legislature at Concord, while all over the area people were again making arrangements for the tourist season.

A FEW months ago a small group of FM enthusiasts, who not only had learned to appreciate the noiseless-reception virtues of the new art but also that its furtherance required prompt and practical action, got together at Chicago and formed the Frequency Modulation Association.

CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) -- Executive machinery for the first national collegiate baseball tournament in June was completed today as Frank G. McCormick, chairman of the N.C.A.A. diamond group, named a tournament committee and selection units for the eight N.C.A.A. districts.

RICHMOND, Va., April 5 -- Britain's financial plight is of more than ordinary interest in the fluecured tobacco belt from Virginia to Florida, where a $6,000,000 slash in British funds available for purchases of American tobacco may have important repercussions.

Dr. W. Edwards Deming of the Bureau of the Budget, who has recently returned from Athens, reports that Greek scientists are half starved and in a pitiable condition. Yet they struggle on heroically. Many of them are civil servants who receive about $30 a month.

SANTA CLAUS, Ind., April 5 (U.P.) -- Postmaster Oscar L. Phillips, believed by thousands of children to be "the real Santa Claus" because he answered their Christmas letters, died today of a heart attack. His age was 57.

The Paumonok Handicap is getting to be a family affair. For the second successive year a son of Fighting Fox, who himself took top money in 1940, won the six-furlong sprint at Jamaica yesterday as New York's racing season got off to a thoroughly wet start.

IT was a strange itinerary. It started at a Broadway movie palace and ended a day later in a dingy, musty cinema on the Bowery. In between were visits to motion-picture theatres in Newark, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Forty-second Street.

NORFOLK, Va., April 5 (AP) -- The American Liberty ship Charles Nordhoff was escorted to an anchorage inside Hampton Roads today by the Coast Guard cutter Cherokee, which was sent to aid the vessel when fire broke out in her No. 4 freight hold yesterday.

Something new will be added to familiar old Coney Island this year. Now in construction, to be ready for assault by the thrill- seekers within a few weeks, are three different types of rides, namely, the "Cuddle-up," the "Flying Dips" and the "Gyroscope."

IN this year of limited ocean voyages, the inland water tour is gaining in popularity. Already the Canada Steamship Company, whose ships cruise the Great Lakes, the St. Lawrence and the Saguenay, is handling brisk bookings for early trips, the first scheduled for May 30.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The National Planning Association called upon the United States today to take the lead in supporting a non-political world trade program by reducing its own tariffs. It also asked the Government to offer assurances to other countries that the American economy is not headed toward a "price- boom and bust."

With rapidly mounting living costs and the ever - increasing shortage of beds, the hospitals of the nation are faced constantly with two serious problems. Hospitals must maintain, the necessary number of beds to meet the needs of their communities and still keep patient-day operating costs within budgetary limitations.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 5 -- The new Belgian tourist industry designed to provide the pleasures of travel at moderate prices, is being tested for the first time this Easter week-end.

TWENTY-ODD years ago two professional women from New York went to Connecticut and bought a tumble-down little house and several acres of hillside, marsh and gully. They wanted a retreat for week-ends and summers.

Industrial commodity prices generally have reached their peak and, if history repeats itself, a price decline in many important raw materials can be expected, industrial executives in key manufacturing industries disclosed here yesterday.

Blackpool capped a long uphill fight in the first division of the English Football League today by defeating third-place Liverpool, 3 -- 2, to gain the lead from the faltering Wolverhampton Wanderers.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Amid Republican gloom and Democratic jubilation, Chicagoans have been studying the results of Tuesday's election with an eye to its effect on the two major parties in the State and on the national political contests in 1948.

WILLOW HILL is any little American town with comfortable homes, an active women's club, a cherished basketball team, and easy talk about democracy. Into this quiet comes the race problem when the Government builds houses for Negro workers.

EVER since Jimmy Melton chose to lift his voice in behalf of farm machinery rather than gasoline the Star Theatre has had its hands full in putting together the half- hour at 9:30 Sunday evenings on CBS.

The United States intelligence services -- the country's "first line of defense" -- will soon receive the scrutiny of the Congressional committees now conducting hearings on the so-called "unification" legislation.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The predominant Congressional attitude toward the hundreds of thousands of displaced persons in Europe seems to be: something should be done about them -- by other countries.
