ALBANY, April 5 -- Governor Dewey today signed the Steingut Bill providing that the chairman of the New York City Housing Authority shall be appointed by the Mayor, and that the chairman must devote his whole time to the duties of the office. The appointive power takes effect July 1, this year, unless a vacancy in the office occurs before that date.

INCREASE in engine performance, which already has reached as high as 145 horsepower in new car models, is bringing the automobile industry an additional problem -- that of adequate braking power. Virtually all 1948 passenger cars are scheduled to have engines whose driving power far exceeds that produced by pre-war power plants.

TEMPORARY housing like the quonset huts to be seen near New York City has a bleak, bare look that fairly cries out for some kind of planting. Using just annual flowers which are quick to grow and abundant in bloom, and allowing not more than $3 for seeds and fertilizer, transformations can be made in the appearance of these small properties.

ONE of the gayest and most rewarding group shows of the season has opened at the Downtown Gallery. The pace is set by Jack Levine's "Magician," who is startling his observers by producing a rabbit in a tall hat. Reuben Tam's "Monhegan" -- a beautiful stark composition -- demonstrates that artist's rapid advance.

DETROIT, April 5 (AP) -- Weary, drenched refugees by the hundreds fled their homes today as Michigan's flooding rivers and streams neared all-time high levels with the fall of two to three inches of rain.
PROMPT -- A man came into a James- town, N.Y., bank and attempted to pay "the interest" on some United States war bonds he had purchased there a year ago.

TWO more books, by authors with widely different reputations, offer more material for the most deeply controversial question of our time. That is, whether Soviet socialism and American capitalism can coexist and peacefully share the world, or whether war to the death -- perhaps the death of both -- is inevitable.

BOWIE, Md., April 5 (AP) -- Shamrock Stable's Darby Dieppe made a sudden return to the form that had enabled him to run third in the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes of 1945 when he galloped off with the $10,000 added Bowie Handicap today.

The cornerstone of the Sloan- Kettering Institute for Cancer Research, central unit of the $15,000,000 Memorial Cancer Center that will occupy the block between York and First Avenues and Sixty -seventh and Sixty-eighth Streets, will be laid at 11:45 o'clock tomorrow morning.

THE beginning of April convinces us, as we never were convinced during winter, that gardens will flourish again and fruits and vegetables ripen for our satisfaction. We are re-entering the old cycle of sowing, growing, harvesting and -- yes, remote as it may seem now -- the time of food preservation. Which brings us to the question of home freezing.
PEIPING, April 5 -- A strong editorial denunciation of United States foreign policy was printed Thursday in the Tientsin Ta Kung Pao. The newspaper sees "antagonism." to the Soviet Union.

READERS of Miss Block's well- burnished, all-female melodrama (in slick paper and between book covers) will rejoice to hear that she has turned to the psychothriller. Miss Block's talents are perfectly suited to this type of fiction, and her admirers will be assured in advance that she can arrange a feral triangle with expertness and dispatch.

ATHENS, Sunday, April 6 (U.P.) -- Constantin Tsaldaris, Vice Premier and Foreign Minister, denied late last night that the Russian Government's protest concerning a spurious newspaper interview with Premier Stalin had been received in Athens.
PARIS. IN a drab little room on the third floor of a converted hotel not far from 1'Arc de Triomphe lies a plan for a great international musical revival.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I. -- Once a familiar haunt of pirates and then a flourishing center for sugar and rum, the Virgin Islands are now playing the new role of a vacation spot for those who like to take their holidays quietly.

IN current life, in his relations with his fellowmen, man must use his reason, but he will perpetrate fewer errors if he listens to his heart. Indeed, the sanest judgment is always questionable because it is impossible to assemble all the elements required to give it an absolute value.

IN 1843 Frederick Douglass, the celebrated Abolitionist orator, half-Negro, half-white, came to Pendleton, Ind., on a speaking tour. A pro-slavery mob from the strongly Democratic neighborhoods to the north and east of this peaceful Quaker farm town warned him off, closed all halls and churches to him, and when he spoke in a grove from a platform the Quakers had built, suddenly swarmed in, knocked him unconscious and rode away.

Miss Pauline Betz, American women's singles tennis champion, faces possible suspension when the United States Lawn Tennis. Association's amateur rules committee meets tomorrow to investigate charges against her, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

LOS ANGELES -- California is embarking on a great highway program to alleviate probably the worst State traffic problem in the country. Last year some 3,800 persons out of a population of 9,000,000 lost their lives in automobile accidents -- a worse death toll than those of New York and Pennsylvania combined, with two and a half times California's population.

Education for leadership and support of organizations opposing prejudices among various groups will aid establishment of world peace, according to pupils who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

Four weeks ago tomorrow, during a raging blizzard of a Moscow winter, the Foreign Ministers of the Big Four met to consider peace treaties for Germany and Austria. Today, with Moscow quickening to spring, there is no sign of agreement; instead, there are many signs of a stalemate that will be extremely difficult to break.
DETROIT, April 5 (AP) -- Price reductions ranging from $25 to $55 on Plymouth passenger automobiles were announced today by the Chrysler Corporation.

ATHENS (By Wireless). HIGH above Athens is the Acropolis with its Parthenon, gracious and majestic monument of an earlier age. From there the Sea of Salamis can be seen, a blue sheen under a pink dappled sky. All around are relics of the ancient past, pressing in upon one's consciousness as reminders of how much our Western civilization owes to Greece.

THERE are more than twelve million clubwomen in the United States and, considering their vast numbers and their avowed purposes, they are not sufficiently effective. It is possible that, in spite of their increasing activity, their influence is really diminishing. The signs point that way.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Government economists this week were busy studying the significance of national economic trends during the first quarter of this "year of decision."

The first session of the French Parliament under the Fourth Republic has ended on a note of suspense. None of the problems, domestic or foreign, which beset France has been solved. Nevertheless, it is possible to see more clearly certain trends.
With the opening last week of its campaign to raise $5,000,000, the Phillips Exeter Academy has embarked upon a far-reaching program to bring the school and the community closer together.

The allowance of deductions in determining taxable income, under Federal income tax laws, marks the difference between taxing gross income and net income. The courts have held that deductions are allowed not as a matter of right but by statutory grant.

WHILE the cops were poking around 2078 Fifth Avenue a few days ago, looking through the littered manse of the Collyer brothers for Langley Collyer, a departmental bibliophile was taking a gander at some of the 2,500 books that had been keeping the Collyers company all these years.
AKRON, Ohio, April 5 (AP) -- The American Professional Football League tonight announced formation of an expanded fourteen-team loop, subject to ratification regarded as routine.

Only partly successful in their efforts to have the Legislature lift the mortgage moratorium, savings bankers are planning to exercise the utmost caution and discretion in observing the law as actually amended, it was learned yesterday.

Editor New York Times Book Review: THERE appeared in your paper on March 9 a review by Mr. Lawrence Lee of Mr. Godfrey Blunden's "A Room on the Route." In the second column of his review you will find Mr. Lee writing:

E.E. CUMMINGS has the poet's faith that a whole idea will set us free. Hair of E.E. Cummings' whole idea is now in the public domain. It comes to us in books, in newspapers and over the air. The vogue is for advertisers to ridicule advertising, for generals to denounce war, for scientists to be appalled by their own cataclysms.

At least 1,000 Jewish refugees and displaced persons are engaged in work projects sponsored by the Joint Distribution Committee in the American occupation zone in Germany, Etta Deutsch, the committee's chief employment officer in the zone between November and last month, said yesterday.

ICELAND poppies are among the best of the more than one hundred poppy species found in Europe and America. Although often grown incorrectly and treated as annuals, they can be made to thrive and last for many years.

ON April 9, 1912, William Howard Taft, then President, signed the bill creating the Children's Bureau, the first governmental agency of its kind anywhere in the world. It received a small appropriation -- $25.640 for salaries and expenses -- and a large mandate.

DR. Johnson once remarked that as he grew older the biographical parts of literature attracted him most; and in the same spirit one can say that there is no such thing as a wholly dull autobiography. Any report on human life has a certain documentary value: and many such reports rise above documentation into vision and interpretation.

WE have had shows restricted to small paintings, but save for exhibitions of actual murals, I do not recall one, prior to last week's opening at the Museum of Modern Art, that was specifically confined to paintings the smallest of which must be "over six feet long."

FIFTH Avenue will see today another Easter Parade. We'll not undertake to tell you precisely how many it has seen before, but the count must go well up to a hundred. It must, because the first churches in the Avenue were built in the middle Eighteen Forties and in those days New Yorkers were church-going folk, made a formal ceremony of the proceeding, and dressed for it in their Sunday best even on ordinary Sundays.

HAVANA, April 5 -- Minister of the Interior Alfredo Pequeno suspended tonight the fifth congress of the Confederation of Workers after one Autentico leader had been slain and another wounded in a clash with Communists.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., April 5 -- The sudden shift from the sun- washed Arizona desert to the altitude of 5,279 feet here, had a distinctly unfavorable effect on the Giants today. Their seven-game winning streak ended, with a deafening bang, as the Indians mauled three of four New York pitchers tossed into the fray, and scampered off with a 15-to-7 victory.
ORLANDO, Fla., April 5 (AP) -- The Senators put on a four-run drive in the sixth today to defeat the Phillies, 6 --2.

The unanimous vote last week in the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations gives realtion for believing that the President's program of aid to Greece and Turkey will have the early and emphatic endorsement of both branches of Congress. In this vote we have had once more the reassuring spectacle of partisanship being put aside on a major question of foreign policy.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- he United States stepped into World War I thirty years ago on a Good Friday.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Idleness from, labor-management disputes in 1946 exceeded 1,000,000 man-days in each of the cities of Buffalo, Chicago, Cleveland, Detroit, Houston, Los Angeles, New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and San Francisco.

Joseph J. Brunetti, Hackensack builder who is completing a group of fourteen small garden-type apartment buildings at Maywood Avenue and Passaic Street, in Maywood, N.J., has assembled additional land in that neighborhood and has completed plans which call eventually for the erection of fifty- eight such buildings to accommodate nearly 700 families.

THE spotlight is focused early on rock gardens. From the time bold snowdrop appears above receding snow until the rapid succession of crocus, scilla, narcissus and primula blossoms is climaxed by the galaxy of late spring bloom on tiny perennials, the rock garden holds the limelight.

To the Drama Editor: THE time is approaching when the actors and actresses of America must make up their minds as to whether they will continue to perform in the theatre of the nation's capital so long as a large percentage of the population, asking nothing more than their rights as American citizens, are barred from admittance.

MR. BODLEY explains the purpose of his guest when he writes, "I was on my way to find that place or that person, that state of mind which would complete the pattern of my life and give me freedom." His search carries him through twenty-six chapters, during the course of which he visits Java, China and Japan, and records what he did, what he saw and what he thought.

After traveling together to and from the job for about 90,000 miles in cars, five long-time employes of the Ford Motor Company plant at Edgewater, N.J., yesterday claimed title to a record as "share the ride" participants. Their aggregate service with Ford is about 120 years and for more than fifteen years they have been motoring over the same route.

Nearly all the seats have been taken for the Blue Hill Troupe's twenty-third annual production, comprising performances of "The Gondoliers," on the nights of April, 23, 24, 25, and a special matinee for children on April 26. The performances will be given at the Hunter Playhouse in East Sixty- eighth Street and all proceeds over production costs will be donated to the Lenox Hill Hospital.

Two years ago the United States took the initiative in arranging the San Francisco conference which established the United Nations. At the signing of the Charter President Truman said "our thinking and all our actions must be based on a realization that it [the Charter] is only the first step."

Billy Nicholls put on one of his finest exhibitions of mallet-work this season as he led the New York Athletic Club into the final round of the national junior indoor pole championship tournament last night by beating Al Parsells' Ramapo Dodgers, 12 to 7, in the Squadron A Armory double- header.

Further data about the new World Council of Christians and Jews were announced yesterday by the New York headquarters of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, sponsor of the new organization.
A QUESTION that deserves consideration during these days of making out orders for seeds and plants is: How much seed and how many plants will be needed for the space?

CHICAGO. CHICAGO is an overwhelming enigma -- beautiful in its magnificent lake front, sordid in its slum districts that cover vast sections of the city, incredibly powerful in its rush and roar of production.

NANKING, China, April 5 -- The China Textile Industries Corporation, the Government's huge textile combine, has totaled up its accounts for last year and announces a profit of about $80,000,000 in United States money.
Today will begin nation-wide observance of Army Week, as designated by President Truman, The celebration is being sponsored by the Military Order of the World Wars, a veterans' organization.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 5 -- Plans to establish contact between the United Nations and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development have now been worked out. The World Bank is the only likely source of funds for an ambitious United Nations' program of help for war-devastated countries.

SOMEONE once pointed out that the charm of Colonial Williamsburg lies in its homogeneity. Everything there is of an era, one era. Its streets are among the few in America where all the buildings, public and private, are in complete harmony.

THE first five additions to the Broadway bookrack, as listed above, are in themselves a commentary on Broadway's current spottiness -- and Broadway's tendency to stutter as it repeats itself. "All My Sons" is the only entry whose emotion springs out genuinely from the printed page -- and its author's passion for scenery-chewing will repel more than one reader.
Headed by the annual varsity four-mile grind with Harvard on June 18, Yale University's 1947 rowing schedule contains thirty- two races for all crews, including the freshmen and 150-pound oarsmen.

THIRTEEN years ago in this Review -- and a glance at some of the titles may well make readers wish "the way it is" could be more like "the way it was": A life of Col. T.E. Lawrence, "The Man Behind the Legend," by Liddell Hart (integrating, wrote Charles Poore, "Lawrence's whole career as no other book has done.")

MRS. ROSALIND MAINGOT of London, one of the greatest of contemporary portrait photographers and one of the few women to be made a fellow of the Royal Photographic Society of Great Britain, will speak at the Master Theatre, 310 Riverside Drive, on April 22.

Dr. Helmut de Terra, who last February found in Mexico the skull and bones of a man believed to be the oldest inhabitant of North America, made known yesterday the discovery of finds that may cast a new light on prehistoric man and his culture.

EXHIBITIONS scheduled for May and June at the Albany Institute of History and Art include the twelfth annual exhibition of work by Artists of the Upper Hudson May 1 to June 1; prints by Rockwell Kent, May 1 to May 15, and from June 4 to Sept. 30, "Past Artists of the Upper Hudson."

Seven weeks ago Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson of New York City gathered estimates of budget needs from all city departments. With bureau chiefs and fiscal experts he screened the various estimates item by item. By mid-March, Mr. Patterson submitted a tentative budget to Mayor William F. O'Dwyer.
LONDON. BRITISH radio is almost back to pre-crisis form. The Third Program has been restored for serious-minded listeners and the Light Program has come back in the daytime for the flippant ones.

First editions and other literary property belonging to Edward Browning Jr. of Philadelphia and Richard A. Loeb of New York will go under the hammer tomorrow at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

PITTSBURGH -- English Courses With more than 8,650 students in English classes at the University of Pittsburgh, that institution has established a new record for the number enrolled in this subject, more than doubling the number of English students of a year ago.

MADRID, April 5 (U.P.) -- United States Charge d'Affaires Philip Bonsal today protested to the Foreign Office against action taken to withdraw the press credentials of Francis E. McMahon, correspondent in Spain for The New York Post.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee called today for the "earliest possible" action on the proposed aid to Greece and Turkey. A report by the group said "delayed action might prove more ineffectual than no action at all."

LOS ANGELES, April 5 (AP) -- Hank (Chesty) Lauman and Frank Mataya, members of the Herman Undertaker team of St. Louis which, scored a top 2,992 total last night, surged to the front of the American Bowling Congress doubles division late today with a 1,322 series.

IN the history of American thought, contributions from the academic campuses have tended to be less influential than the writings of humanistic essayists, novelists and the great reflective statesmen. Even in the flowering of technical philosophy in this country late in the nineteenth century and after men like William James, Charles S. Peirce, George Santayana and John Dewey were more than spokesmen for current philosophical disputes.

THE Coolidge Professor of History at Harvard has produced, at the behest of the former Secretary of State, Mr. Hull, a completely fascinating account of why and how Mr. Hull's State Department dealt with the Vichy regime of Marshall Petain from the fall of France to the assassination of Admiral Darlan.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Albert M. Day, director of the Fish and Wildlife Service, said today it probably will be necessary to curtail -- but not close completely -- the water-fowl hunting season next fall.

TORONTO, April 5 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs tonight joined the Montreal Canadiens in the final round of the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs by crushing the Detroit Red Wings, 6 -- 1, for their fourth victory in five starts in the best-out-of-seven semi-final series.

Deliverance of displaced persons from the camps of Europe for a new life in the promised land of freedom was urged by rabbis in sermons here yesterday, the first day of the Jewish festival of Passover, commemorating the liberation of the ancient Hebrews from bondage in Egypt.

Light steel and glass perimeter construction features the facade of the new twenty-one-story office building of the Tishman Realty Construction Company nearing completion in the blockfront on the east side of Park Avenue from Fifty-sixth to Fifty-seventh Street.

THE actual slave who served as the model for Harriet Beecher Stowe's sweet old Uncle Tom was a complex and not altogether admirable character. Josiah Henson was a good slave. In freedom he became an obsequious opportunist.

IN the industrial world there is a time lapse between the building of a working model of an automobile, airplane or refrigerator and the marketing of same to the public. During this lapse the product is tested to bring out its weaknesses.

MOSCOW, April 5 -- Edvard Kardelj, Vice Premier of Yugoslavia, demanded today that Austria pay to Yugoslavia $150,000,000 in reparations in the form of current production and the removal of industrial plants.

BERLIN, April 5 (AP) -- The United States Army team tonight won championships in three weight classes to take top honors in the Allied Forces European boxing championships which were concluded before more than 5,000 fans at the Olympic Sports Club.

DURING the good old days when I had nothing on my mind except the problem of convincing the stubborn producer that I was right about my script and that he was wrong, I used to participate in bull sessions, and explain what I would do if I were running a studio.

ALBANY, April 5 -- A shortage of doctors is threatening the success of the state health program, which has as a primary goal the elimination of tuberculosis in twenty-five years through intensive case finding methods and hospitalization, the Health Department revealed today.

Daniza Ilitsch established herself as an artist of high distinction by her superb work as Leonora in the performance of Verdi's "Il Trovators." presented at the final matinee of the season, yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The shadow of the great Middle Eastern pool of oil reserves, with its concomitant implications of military strategy, overhangs current deliberations on the Truman Doctrine.

This country, with the most complete, complex and vital communication system in the world, has never experienced a nation-wide telephone strike. It is threatened with one now. The time is dangerously short in which to avert it. The public cannot possibly realize how serious a disaster to our national economy it would be.

Activity in the financial comnunity was somewhat restricted last week by the observance of religious holidays. Security exchanges were closed on Good Friday and the banks began their first Saturday closing of the year. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was at a slow pace and the new investment market was not overworked.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard declined yesterday to grant an injunction staying eviction of residents of the Hotel Imperial, Broadway and Thirty-second Street. However, the court issued an order requiring the owners to show cause why they should not be enjoined from, closing the building.

MOST of the Gotham reviewers regard Konstantine Simonov's "The Whole World Over" as a pleasant, friendly and entertaining stage lark. In the opinion of two or three of the old contemptibles, of whom I am one, it is thin and artless, although the tone of the characterization is genial enough.

There is a certainty about beginnings that is inescapable. We see them around us now, as always when spring creeps across the land, beginnings and continuances that build the substance of faith and belief. Who can long have doubts when he stands beside a greening meadow, or walks through a woodland stirring with the slow vigor of spring, or even when he sees the complex beginnings of a daffodil thrusting up from a hidden bulb?

"You rod and gun editors break out with all sorts of ideas," one trout fisherman writes, "so why not suggest how a fly fisherman can put in his time profitably while sitting on the bank of a stream and waiting for conditions to get right?"

The writer of the following letter is a lawyer, and was formerly president of the American Society of International Law. He is the author of "Certainty and Justice" and of numerous articles on law and international relations.

EASTER, 1947, will probably go down into business history, according to present indications, as the turning point in retail trade. After the flashing increases of the war years and the immediate post-war period, holiday trade was a distinct disappointment, and so labeled by leading merchants here.

TOKYO, April 5 -- Continued national support for the conservative Government parties was indicated tonight after more than 20,000,000 Japanese had voted. It was the first general election for local officials since the surrender.

MARKING another step "toward closer linking of communication with the rest of the world" is "air letter" service which will be inaugurated on April 29 from the United States to all foreign countries, the Postoffice Department announced last week.
The champion United States team won the first annual Wilkinson fencing tournament last night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The chief underlying issue in the telephone dispute was said by the Twentieth Century Fund, the economic research institute, in a report tonight, to be that of "local versus national bargaining."

WASHTNGTON isn't the same without C. Powell Minnigerode to greet you when you arrive for a Corcoran Biennial. I forget how many years he directed the Corcoran Gallery, but it seems to me his total span of activity there extended over more than a half century.

Dr. Thomas Hendrick Russell, professor of clinical surgery and director of surgery at the New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital for the last eleven years, died yesterday in his home at 2 East Seventy-fourth Street, after a brief illness. His age was 61.

AT the turn of the year only the most incredible optimist could have said that the Democratic party can win in 1948, but it is highly significant that within little more than three months after the Republican Eightieth Congress first assembled on Capitol Hill, public feeling has begun a remarkable shift and at least one national political figure has placed himself, willingly, some distance out on a limb.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Republicans found much to criticize in President Truman's Jefferson Day speech tonight. This was in contrast to their reaction to his other addresses since the November election.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A bitter and probably a prolonged struggle over provisions of a sixty-two- page omnibus labor bill will begin at 10 A.M. on Monday when the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare opens discussions on a committee print to be available at that time.
WARSAW, April 5 -- The mass migration of Jews from Poland has finished.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 5 (AP) -- Navy and Holy Cross staged a surprise football scrimmage today, and at the end neither Coach Tom Hamilton of the middies nor John (Ox) Da Grosa of the Crusaders would reveal what they thought of the performance's.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5 -- Saved by his chipping irons, Jimmy Demaret, former Texas rainbow now registering from Ojai, Calif., today got past the "third-round jitters" in the Masters golf tournament to gain a three-stroke lead on the field coming up to tomorrow's final round of the eleventh Georgia classic.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va. -- Kenmore, the home of Col. Fielding Lewis and his wife, Betty, sister of George Washington, is celebrating this spring the twenty-fifth anniversary of rescue from the enterprising realtors who were going to make apartments of the fine old brick mansion, in the planning and decoration of which Washington had a share, and cut up the grounds around it into city lots.

LONDON, April 5 -- The British Government's foreign policy was heavily attacked today as one that placed "the people of Britain in extreme dependence on the United States." The charge was made at the annual conference of the Cooperative party in Llandudno, Wales.

Coal and Telephones During the first quarter of 1947 labor -management disputes reached a post-war low. The total man-days lost through strikes in the first three months of the year were about one- twelfth of the 58,000,000 man-days lost in the same period of 1946.

CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head (estimated): total not given. Compared with week ago: barrows and gilts 75 cents to $1.01 higher, sows 50 to 73 cents up.

Leopold Stokowski conducted his first children's concert in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning when he took over the sixth and final Young People's Concert of the season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York.

MARKING another step "toward closer linking of communication with the rest of the world" is "air letter" service which will be inaugurated on April 29 from the United States to all foreign countries, the Postoffice Department announced last week.
The champion United States team won the first annual Wilkinson fencing tournament last night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head (estimated): total not given. Compared with week ago: barrows and gilts 75 cents to $1.01 higher, sows 50 to 73 cents up.

Leopold Stokowski conducted his first children's concert in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning when he took over the sixth and final Young People's Concert of the season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York.
ATLANTA, April 5 -- Playing their first game in four days, the Yankees flashed no overpowering attack today as they opened a two-day visit with Kiki Cuyler's Atlanta Crackers.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 5 -- Government and Opposition members of Parliament exchanged blows in the Bulgarian Parliament last evening, the clash ending only with the expulsion of all the Opposition members from the Chamber.
TOKYO, April 5 -- The occupation troops paraded this morning as Gen. Douglas MacArthur proclaimed Monday as Army Day.
IN Moscow today, as at San Francisco, London, Moscow, Paris and New York before, statesmen of America and Russia, are making one more attempt to reach an understanding on the problems of the world.

JIMMY CONZELMAN is a droll character who works for another droll character, Charley Bidwell. The coach of the Chicago Cardinals and the owner of the Chicago Cardinals currently are sojourning in Miami Beach, dreaming bright dreams about the next football season. They are so tremendously confident of producing a championship winner that Bidwell probably has ceased being a secret Chicago Bear fan.
LONDON, April 5 -- The fifty or so nations planning to bid for world sports laurels in the 1948 Olympics in England can accelerate their preparations.

Seldom -- perhaps never before -- have career-seekers in Wall Street been so absorbed in learning what makes the securities industry tick. That is borne out by reports of those interested in personnel training programs since the war.

TOKYO, April 5 -- Because no Allied nation has yet indicated what materials it wants from Japan, the United States order authorizing Gen. Douglas MacArthur to begin reparations removals is unlikely to bring immediate action, occupation officials said today.

As recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, the text of President's Truman's speech at the Jefferson Day Dinner of the Democratic National Committee was as follows: Thank you very much, Thank you very much.

PROF. RAYMOND WEAVER'S pioneer work as biographer and editor of Herman Melville is still bearing fruit; and Mr. Olson's little book on Melville, "Call Me Ishmael," is the shyest and latest grape to hang on that vine.

LONDON, April 5 -- The "annexation" of the Pacific islands by the United States "under the polite but convenient guise of strategic trusteeship" was bitterly denounced today by the leading British liberal newspaper, The Manchester Guardian.

A great public debate over a new wage-price-profit policy for the nation's economy began to approach its climax last-week. With the crucial steel contract coming up for renewal on April 30, both sides made their bargaining positions clear.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The telephone labor dispute turned the attention of the country this week to the vast telephone system which it has come to accept as an essential part of its everyday life.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Truman strongly reaffirmed tonight this country's faith in the United Nations but insisted with equal firmness that it was our responsibility to resist oppression anywhere in the world.
Thaddeus Kozuch, Chicago pianist, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. He appeared both as composer and performer, for he introduced a Sonata he wrote last year.

PITTSBURGH, April 5 -- A complete shutdown of Western Pennsylvania's vast bituminous coal fields hinged today on the uncertain attitude of the individual miner and his interpretation of John L. Lewis' latest ukase.

PARIS, April 5 -- Pierre-Aime Touchard, inspector general of theatres in the Ministry of Arts and Letters and an authority on the classical and contemporary theatre, has been named administrator of the Comedie Francaise, it was announced today.

The head of the Russian Orthodox Church in North America has broken administrative relations with four prelates because they have announced their opposition to a reconciliation with the Patriarchate in Moscow, it became known yesterday.

There is nothing new about Easter. As a great and joyous and deeply religious Christian faith it is nearly two thousand years old. It falls in the same season with the Jewish feast of the Passover. All over the earth, as far back as history and legend go, the coming of spring or the time of the first planting or the first natural stirrings of new growth has been celebrated.

ATHENS, April 5 -- In the cortege for King George II of the Hellenes, who died Tuesday, there walked behind Archbishop Damaskinos and other dignitaries of the Greek Orthodox Church, the new King, Paul, and the 7-year-old Crown Prince, Constantine.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, and the State Department have agreed to revise the wording of the Senator's amendment of the Greek-Turkish loan bill to bring it into line with the United Nations Charter, it was learned today.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 5 -- Grand Coulee dam, key unit in the biggest water power system in the world, faced a crisis this week when a House subcommittee on appropriations threatened to slice President Truman's request for national irrigation funds from $130,000,000 to less than $24,000,000.

FOR the first time in the seventy-five years of its existence, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will put on next Thursday a one-man show of the work of a living artist. The artist is Ivan Mestrovic, a sculptor's sculptor, a craftsman who is recognized as a master by the members of his profession and an artist who is so filled with the sense of humanity that he has become the people's sculptor as well.

HAVING a part-score often affects a player's choice of bids, and this is particularly true in the case of preemptive bids. Any pre-emptive bid (opening bid of three or four) is an overbid. The bidder takes a chance on going down.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A telephone union spokesman said tonight that there appeared to be not the "slightest question" that there would be a country-wide strike at 6 A.M. Monday and declared he had been "assured" there would be no Government seizure.

THE third program of the Ballet Society, presented recently at the Central High School of Needle Trades, was of particular interest because for the first time all its ballets were new and by young native choreographers.

THE most impressive signs of virtue in the short stories of V.S. Pritchett are honesty and fullness of effect. These two attributes set the fourteen pieces collected in "It May Never Happen" considerably above the standard level of contemporary short fiction.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 5 -- Meet-record performances by Walter Ris, University of Iowa ineligible, in the 100-yard free-style and Ohio State's 300-yard medley relay trio featured the closing session of the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor swimming championships in the Ohio State University natatorium tonight.

ONE of the extraordinary men of New York," was Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's characterization of Samuel Bulkley Ruggles, whose life coincided with the first eighty-one years of the last century. Lawyer by training, business leader and realty promoter by inclination, public-spirited citizen by choice, Ruggles exemplified the finest qualities of each in a long career of remarkable accomplishment.

BROWSING through the remainder bin outside Bernard Quaritch's bookshop in Piccadilly one day in 1861 an unknown bargain-hunter noticed a pile of unprepossessing booklets, priced at a penny each and containing a poem called "The Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam," freely translated by an anonymous author.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 5 (AP) -- The Reds scored two runs in the bottom half of the thirteenth inning today to defeat the Red Sox 4 -- 3. A crowd of 5,543 fans witnessed the two-hour-thirty-one-minute seesaw battle.
BORROWER -- A woman living in Brooklyn, Mrs. Joseph Pearlman, has filed suit to make her 78-year- old stepfather return her copy of D.H. Lawrence's "Lady Chatterley's Lover."
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 5 (AP) -- Frank Leahy, one of the greatest exponents of the T-formation in football, took off his hat respectfully today to the master of the mall.

Henry Soffe Thompson, former Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, who was a founder and the first president of the Thompson-Starrett Company, builders, died yesterday in his apartment in the Hotel Berkshire, 21 East Fifty-second Street, after an illness of fifteen months.

DANVILLE, VA. THE Barter Theatre of Virginia -- the first State-subsidized theatre in America -- is concluding its most successful tour since it was organized in 1933 by Robert Porterfield as a means of keeping the body and soul of the "displaced" actor together during a famous depression.

Monopolistic privileges in the hands of labor unions and the "secondary boycott," used by some labor leaders in jockeying for further power are as dangerous to the public welfare today as business monopoly practices were before they were outlawed by the Sherjnan Anti-Trust Act, the National Association of Manufacturers held yesterday in a pamphlet titled "Americans 'Won't Stand for Monopolies."

The Musicians Emergency Fund has been requested by officials of the Veterans Administration to expand the fund's morale-building and rehabilitation program of musical instruction, it was announced yesterday. The plan is to aid veterans in all hospitals in this area, and eventually throughout the State.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York urged yesterday that the Government construct ocean liners for private operation when high costs make such undertakings by steamship lines prohibitive.

Few agencies of the Government enjoy confidence as widespread or as well based as the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Its men not only risk the special hazards of their calling but are under exceptional mental and physical strain in a service that knows no maximum hours of work and carries on around the clock.

HAVANA, April 6 -- Lippy Leo Durocher's regular center fielder and, in fact, his opening day lineup may have been put on display in today's farewell to Havana in a 6-to-0 shut-out of the Montreal Royals at Grand Stadium.

ATHENS, April 6 -- Greece is governed by a coalition of RightWing and Right-Center parties. Leftists and liberals, by a combiniation of circumstances largely of their own making, have little or no voice in shaping national policy.
The telephone strike scheduled for 6 A.M. today will affect a system that includes 31,600,000 phones and 116,660,000 miles of telephone wire.

Mayor O'Dwyer's 1947-48 exetive budget of $1.029,120,314 will be attacked today by citizens, taxpayers and business and civic organizations at the first of three public hearings before the Board of Estimate. The hearing, which will cover all city departments except education, higher eduction and libraries, will begin 10:30 A. M.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,070,078,937. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows: Apr. 10 -- Discount bills ..... ... $1,311,578,000

MONTE CARLO, April 6 (AP) -- Miss Pauline Betz, the United States and Wimbledon women's tennis champion, who faces possible suspension by the United States Lawn Tennis Association, won a mixed doubles match today wilh Budge Patty, who denied reports that the Loa Angeles star already had been suspended by American officials.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 6 -- Russians are throwing Swedish deliveries under the recent billion crown Russo-Swedish trade agreement back on the Swedish market with an 80 per cent increase over the Swedish invoice prices, the Stockholm newspaper Aftonbladet will charge tomorrow.

The Reynolds Metals Company registered last year record production and earnings "despite losses for the first six months of 1946 due to reconversion of our more than j fifty plants," R.S. Reynolds, president, reported in the annual statement being mailed to shareholders today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April, 6 -- Attention will be focused here tomorrow upon the United Nations Security Council as the greatest crowd in its history turns out to hear Russia's reply to President Truman's $400,000,000 anti-totalitarian program for Greece and Turkey.

A report of the Eighth Guam Congress, recently come to hand, offers convincing evidence of the ability of the people of that island to deal with public affairs in an orderly and competent manner. A joint session of the House of Council and the House of Assembly debated several controversial measures having to do with the rebuilding of Agana, including the allotment of land and the zoning for business and light industry.

Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market fluctuated irregularly last week as developments in Washington excited profit taking and liquidation and diminished trade-buying support. At the cessation of trading on Thursday, starting the holiday recess, active months on the New York Cotton Exchange were 41 to 82 points below the closing level of the previous week, for which net gains of 60 to 102 points had been registered.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., April 6 -- The master perfectionist was operating today. His name is Rapid Robert Feller, owner of the jet-propelled fireball, and he was Working in what amounted to midseason form. His Indian Tribe gave him two runs and that was all he needed.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The income tax collector, a tough customer sometimes, has won an argument with six waiters that 10 per cent of the check is about right for a tip.
WASHINGTON, April 6-- Officers of a Philadelphia teamsters' union were accused by a House committee today of "banditry" and "extortionate practices."

MARGUERITE BAY, Palmer Land, April 2 Delayed) -- The Antarctic social season is at its peak. The cove on which this expedition has its base is as crowded, relatively, as New York Harbor, and landing boats are going back and forth carrying social notes and invitations to luncheons and cocktail parties.

One of the major changes recently in business demands for funds from commercial banks has been the shift from short-term to medium and long-term credit, according to a report released today by the National Bureau of Economic Research.

FRANKFORT ON THE ODER, Germany, April 5 (Delayed) -- Col. Jakov Korsikov, commander in this city, which is one of the Soviet zone's chief centers of dispersal for German prisoners of war from Russia, disclosed today that there had been a lull recently in the release of captives.

The world of E. Phillips Oppenheim, the shadowy world of spies and intrigue, codes and ciphersand plain, hard work-will come under Congressional investigation soon when the Intelligence section of the new "merger" bill is considered.

Following is a summary, as reported by The Associated Press, of how the impending telephone strike is expected to affect service in states throughout the nation: Alabama, North and South Carolina, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi and Tennessee -- Dial-to-dial calls are expected to continue normally.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., April 6 -- The reappraising of the Town of Smithtown, which is expected to bring increased revenues into the town treasury besides providing a uniform method of establishing assessed valuation of real property throughout the town, is nearing completion, according to Anthony G. Psota, Clerk to the Town Board of Assessors.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 6 -- Coming almost simultaneously with the grave pronouncements from the highest official authorities on the precarious state of Italian finance, to cope with which a decree levying a heavy tax on capital has been issued, news of the exceedingly advantageous outcome of the Anglo-Italian finance negotiations in London was a welcome relief.

An offering of $2,800,000 worth of Packard marine engines, power units for the famous wartime PT-boats, is included in the sales program of the War Assets Administration, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, announced over the week-end.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 6 -- Despite strong appeals by Premier Recep Peker for a heavy vote, the polls were strikingly deserted in, today's by-elections for nine Parliament seats in four administrative divisions.

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- The railroads will propose a freight rate increase of four to 15 cents a hundred pounds on their transcontinental hauls as a solution to the competitive relationship between rail and water rates, a railroad attorney said today.

A national drive to reduce paper distribution costs for wholesale paper merchants has been opened here by the National Paper Trade Association, it was learned over the week-end. E. Jay Huss, industrial engineer, has been hired by the association to carry out plans developed by their committee on operating efficiency.

A week-end survey of key cities throughout the country showed a mixed response to the appeal made here by Jack I. Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co., to retailers and manufacturers to lower prices for the consumer by reducing highprofit margins.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On March 24 THE NEW YORK TIMES printed a letter from Harold L. Ickes complaining of an editorial favoring restoration of the name of "Hoover Dam."

Two teen-age boys had their first run-in with crime in the raw Saturday night, found it exciting and wound up as neighborhood heroes. The story of their exploit emerged yesterday in Queens Felony Court, when the husky young man they had overpowered was arraigned on a charge of burglary.

The cornerstone of the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research is to be laid today -- an event of the highest biological importance because the Institute will be the second unit in a Memorial Cancer Center. Even without this addition the Memorial Hospital is the oldest and largest institution in the world devoted exclusively to the treatment of cancer and to research in cancer.

LONDON, Monday, April 7 (AP) -- The Tass Agency said today that Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov had told Secretary of State Marshall that "participation of foreign armed forces in the civil war in China can but lead to the fanning of the civil war."
CLEVELAND, April 6 -- Vessel operators are preparing for one of the busiest seasons In Great Lakes shipping history.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 -- Although some member-manutacturers are cutting production this year to await a revision of the price structure, the California garment industry, encouraged by success of "the California label," is planning for a billion-dollar-a-year business by 1955.
H.J. Rainey, controller of the Kellogg division of American Brake Shoe Company since 1942, has been named vice president of the division.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- President Truman's program for assisting Greece and Turkey is scheduled to reach a final stage in Congress this week. Debate on the bill in the Senate will open Wednesday. Approval by a good margin in both Houses was forecast by most authorities.

LONDON, April 6 -- The weather made the biggest Easter news in Britain today. Everywhere it was cold, with strong winds much of the day, and nearly everywhere there were some hours of rain. One writer described it as "a muffler -and-mackintosh Easter for Britain's holiday crowds."
ROME, April 6 -- Italy's objections to the financial report of the Big Four commission on the Free Territory of Trieste will be submitted to the Council of Foreign Ministers in Moscow this week.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6 -- Playing with all the confidence in the world. Jimmy Demaret today won one of golfs most coveted honors --the eleventh, annual Masters tourney, yearly feature at the famous Augusta National Golf Club.
Radio talks by the civilian and military heads of the Army marked yesterday the opening of Army Week on the thirtieth anniversary of the entrance of the United States into World War I.

The local art season continues this week with a number of events of unusual interest on the calendar. On Friday the Metropolitan Museum will break its long-standing precedent to present a one-man show by a living artist -- in this case work by the Serbian sculptor Mestrovic, under the auspices of the American Academy of Arts and Letters.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 (AP) -- Additional revenues from rate increases in recent years have "fallen far short of meeting increased operating costs," Norfolk Western Railway said today in its fiftyfirst annual report.

A Great Day on the Avenue Yesterday, being Easter Sunday, there were on Fifth Avenue many people who are not seen there as often as many other people. Those who are seen there every weekday, engaged in shopping and window shopping or just going to and fro afoot or in buses, were also there in considerable numbers.

The first of 5,000 pickets began marching outside telephone exchanges in the metropolitan area at 6 A.M. today, after collapse of night-long negotiations to avert a walkout of 35,000 employes of the New York Telephone Company in New York City, Long Island and Westchester County.
HONG KONG, April 6 -- Talks with colonial administrators here indicate that Britain is determined to hold on to Hong Kong for commercial and strategic reasons.

The lucrative North Atlantic passenger trade, again rising toward peak level with the lifting of wartime restrictions on travel, will be completely dominated this year by British and Canadian-flag ships, a survey disclosed yesterday.
ALBANY, April 6 (AP) -- More than six and a half billion pounds of milk were hauled to market from New York State farms last year, the State Department of Agriculture reported today.

Clearing skies saved the day yesterday for one of the most festive and dressy Easter throngs seen in many a year. Park, Madison and Fifth Avenues were gay with a profusion of flower-trimmed hats. Style highlights were the new longer skirts and the predominance of black and navy as costume colors.

The two-story store and office building on a lot 25 by 75 feet at 3412 Bergenline Avenue, Union City, N.J., was sold by the Hudson Bloomfield Corporation to the Passaic Bergen Mortgage Corporation, Joseph Grossman, president, through the C.B. Snyder Realty Company, brokers, who said this was the fourth time they had negotiated a sale of the property.

In the presence of a congregation of 5,000, nearly half of whom were admitted to standing space after waiting in a line two blocks long, Cardinal Spellman celebrated the pontifical mass of Easter Sunday in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

TOKYO, Monday, April 7 -- A clean sweep for independents, running without party label but generally in support of the present Conservative Government of Japan, and a smashing defeat for opposition parties-Socialists and Communists -- are the results of this nation's first democratic elections for local offices, held under Allied supervision yesterday.
Principal issues in the threatened nation-wide telephone strike are wages and "self-defense demands" such as the union shop, seniority provisions, protection against layoffs and old-age security.

Moshe Shertok, chief of the political department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, last night denounced terrorist activities in that country and declared that those responsible were harming the Jewish cause.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee faces a decision this weeK as to how much value the United States Employment Service renders to veterans in particular and to other workers in general and how this service balances against the economy program of Congress.

MONTREAL, April 6 (AP) -- President Clarence Campbell of the National Hockey League announced today that the final round of the circuit's Stanley Cup playoffs between Toronto and Montreal will open in Montreal Tuesday night instead of Thursday as originally planned.

The impact of the nation-wide telephone strike was due to fall today on some ten million persons in the New York metropolitan area. Opinion in informed quarters differed as to the probable effect of the attempt to silence voice and, to a large extent, wire communication, and the results could not be forecast definitely.

FOR the first time in United States history our State Department has made it possible for the general public "to look at the record." The vociferous denunciation which our diplomatic relations with the Vichy Government of France unloosed in this country got under the skin of Cordell Hull, then Secretary of State. He couldn't defend himself at the time because of the secret necessities of the war.

Passover is a reminder of the ideal of a world In which opportunities for a full life will be free to all men, rabbis said in sermons here yesterday, toe second day of the Passover holidays, commemorating the liberation of the ancient Hebrews from servitude in Egypt.

The welfare of Protestant displaced persons in Europe is the responsibility of American Protestants, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared in a statement made public yesterday by the American Christian Committee for Refugees, Inc.

More than 7,000 persons attending Easter morning services at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday heard Christ's resurrection described as "the value placed on us and our doings for eternity." The sermon was preached by the Rev. Edward N. West, canon sacrist of the cathedral.

Collection of $255,914 was reported yesterday by the women's special gifts committee of the Red Cross 1947 Fund of Greater New York. The amount is 61 per cent of the committee's quota of $400,000. "While there has been a lag in the total dollar value and number of individual gifts," Mrs. Fergus Reid, director, explained, "it has been due to the fact that many prospects are just now returning from an unusually lengthy Southern season."

Experiments on white rats which, eat the same foods as humans, have shown that a normal diet plus extra Vitamin A lengthens the life span and extends the "prime of life," Dr. Henry Clapp Sherman, Mitchell Professor Emeritus of Chemistry at Columbia University, announced yesterday.

HOLYOKE, Mass April 6 -- James Laurence Tighe, consulting civil engineer, chairman of the municipal gas and electric commission, Hampden County engineer and member of the Massachusetts Public Health Council, died today in the Providence Hospital after an illness of several weeks.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed today that it start repaying the Government subsidy with which it started operations thirteen years ago.

JERUSALEM, April 6 -- Mingling with a polyglot throng of pilgrims, the American delegation to the conference of the Inter-Parliamentasy Union in Cairo made a hasty Easter Sunday tour of Christian holy places in Jerusalem.

BOSTON, April 6 (AP) -- Ten new entries, topped by that of Bill Steiner of the Maccabee A. C. of New York, were received today by the Boston Athletic Association for the fifty-first annual marathon to be run April 19. The B. A. A. now has received a total of eighty entries for the annual grind.

Ralph E. Dalton, a one-man committee to reform hoboes, leaned back comfortably in a chair and beamed as dozens of prospective converts drank coffee and ate sandwiches at a house-warming in his new headquarters, 108 East Fourteenth Street, yesterday.

The Rev. James J. Lynch, director of finance of New York Catholic Charities, declared in his annual report, made public yesterday, that in spite of many gifts the organization last year was "unable to meet the full financial needs of its member agencies."

There is something distinctly gruesome in the use John L. Lewis is making of the safety issue in the coal fields. The shocking Centralia tragedy gave him an unexpected opportunity to call a mine strike the Supreme Court had forbidden by designating it as a period of mourning.
Plans for the city's official reception to Miguel Aleman, President of the Republic of Mexico, on Friday, May 2, were announced yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer. The Mayor proclaimed the day as Mexico Day.

Deutsch Shea, Inc., in cooperation with 362 daily newspapers throughout the country, is preparing a "Report of Newspaper Merchandising Aids," listing the nature and extent of specific merchandising assistance offered by daily newspapers in cities of 50,000 and over.

PARIS, April 6 -- Speaking in Strasbourg today, former President de Gaulle said that "if a new tyranny should ever menace all or part of the world, we may be certain that the United States and Prance would be together to oppose it."
The century-old Village Presbyterian Church rang its new 500pound bell for the first time on Easter morning in the hope that a missing son and his mother might be re-united by hearing the chimes.

ATHENS, April 6 -- The Hellenic nation buried its dead King today. The coffin containing the body of George II, which since Thursday had rested in the dimly lighted Cathedral, was taken upon a gun carriage to the tomb at Tatoia, fourteen miles outside the city.

Second-hand steel drums are selling at a premium of from 75 cents to $1.75 over the price of new steel drums because of critical scarcities in containers, a survey of container prices and deliveries disclosed here last week.

TOKYO, April 6 (AP) -- Louis Saillant of Paris, General Secretary of the World Federation of Trade Unions, declared today that a delegation he heads had cut short its tour of Southern Korea because of "certain incidents which we considered insulting."

BUENOS AIRES, April 6 (U.P.) -- The Paraguayan revolt has spread from the north to the south and now threatens to encircle and isolate Asuncion, the capital. Today the garrison at Alberdi announced it would side with the insurgents.

The national council of the National Maritime Union, CIO, hag authorized the organization's national negotiating committee to take a strike vote, according to the latest issue of The Pilot, weekly publication of the NMU.

BOSTON, April 6 (AP) -- Mitttossing paratroopers of Uncle Sam's Eighty-second Airborne Division from Fort Bragg, N.C., loomed as the dark-horse team in the three-day National A.A.U. boxing cnampionships which get under way tomorrow at Boston Garden.

NANKING, April 6 (AP) -- The official Chinese Central News Agency said today that most of the Chinese Communist Armies in North Shensi Province had made good a retreat eastward across the Yellow River into Shansi Province but still were under firm Government pressure.

Arturo Toscanini conducted his final concert of this spring with the NBC Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Radio City with a program that in the instance of the Prelude and "Good Friday" music from "Parsifal" was appropriate to the season.
DETROIT, April 6 -- Flint and Lansing were put in a state of emergency tonight as they bore the brunt of wind-whipped flood waters rampaging over much of the lower peninsula.

The great fortresses of the Maginot Line lie buried under the hills in the vicinity of Strasbourg. Between the wars France wasted her substance building defense works on her eastern border that neither saved Alsace nor enabled the German conquerors to hold on to it.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands April 6 -- The first step toward a customs union has been taken by the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg. Bills for ratifying the customs agreement were submitted last week to the respective Parliaments.

While retailers tried to drain off some of their high inventories in pre-Easter sales, wholesale markets experienced a lull last week, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

In the spring of 1920 the country was witnessing the national demonstration that will be recalled as the "Buyers' Strike." "Overall clubs" were being formed, their members pledged to, buy no more wearing apparel until prices came down; one state proclaimed an "Old Clothes Day," and in April New Yorkers watched an "Economy Parade" march up Broadway.

Two pacifist organizations decided that Fifth Avenue at the height of the Easter fashion parade was a good place to discuss civil liberties with the police. Result: One pacifist found himself on the sidewalk and he and nine others were registered on a police blotter under the general heading of disorderly conduct.

The minimum United States program which will establish confidence abroad and permit the proposed International Trade Organization to accomplish its aims includes a substantial reduction of United States tariffs and assurance that the American economy will avoid a price-boom and bust, Dr. J.B. Condliffe stated in a pamphlet just released by the National Planning Association.

Brig. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick, chairman of the New York City Cancer Committee's 1947 campaign, announced plans yesterday for the support of organized labor in the campaign. William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, previously had urged support of the drive.

The whole philosophy underlying the new American foreign policy of aiding the free nations of the world against direct or indirect aggression has been set forth anew by President Truman in his speech at the Jefferson Day dinner. It is not a new philosophy. On the contrary, it is as old as the "United States, and goes to the roots of America's existence.

New York's theatre honored twenty men and women early today with the first presentation of the annual Antoinette Perry Awards for outstanding contributions to the current theatrical season. Twelve hundred persons, including many theatrical celebrities, cheered the winners at a midnight ceremony in the Waldorf-Astoria.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 6 -- France's Alex Jany and Sweden's Per Olsson each, left here today with a silver second-place medal as a memento of the National A. A. U. indoor swimming championships, which were completed in Ohio State's natatorium last night.

LONDON, April 6 -- The Government received renewed assurance of trade-union support today ii meetings and speeches throughout the country. However, there was ample evidence that Foreign Secretary Bevin's external policy remained the most controversial feature of the Government.

LONDON, April 6 -- The Easter holiday and the coming budget combined here to reduce financial activity considerably in the last few days, but on the whole the stock markets have stood up well to these brakes on business and initiative.

Favored by clearing skies in the early morning hours. Easter Dawn services sponsored by Protestant churches were held throughout the metropolitan area yesterday with a heavy proportion of young persons among the worshipers.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- New winter wheat is expected to appear on the terminal markets in Texas in about sixty days if weather conditions are favorable, and the prospect of a record yield this season is beginning to make itself felt in prices in the market for futures, especially on the May, which has been selling at a big premium over the July, a new-crop month.
Maritime unions are preparing to boycott and picket every merchant ship under the flag of Panama that enters American waters, they announced yesterday. The boycott may start in two weeks.
Sudden sunshine flooding Fifth Avenue in spring warmth yesterday brought out a record crowd that took part in an Easter parade paralleling the pre-war pageants.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 6 (AP) -- Jack Kramer of Los Angeles gave ample proof why he is national champion and the world's firstranking amateur today as he blasted Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla., in straight sets for the River Oaks tennis title.
LOS ANGELES, April 6 (U.P) -- Henry Peterson, a member of the Soporito Market five, Tucson, Ariz,, today bowled a 290 to register the best game of the American Bowling Congress.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- End of the six-day miners' mourning period will not restore quantity production tomorrow in the country's soft coal mines, observers here believe. Easter Sunday passed without development in the situation after the Government, which is now operating most of the mines, rejected last night the request of John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, that all mines except two be closed for safety reasons.

Reorders for women's suits and last-minute requests for Easter handbags highlighted wholesale activity here last week, according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

Dispatches from Washington recently told of a secret report prepared by the House Subcommittee on Monopoly dealing with the "increased economic concentration" as a result of the war and of post-war policy with respect to plant disposal.

Richard Strauss' "Ariadne auf Naxos" was presented by the New York City Opera Company, last night at the City Center, as the opening performance of its spring season. The fascinating work, which proved an outstanding success when produced by the company last fall, again met with a fervent welcome, and it is to be hoped that it will remain a permanent part of the organization's repertoire.
BERLIN, April 6 -- Again it was Easter. But no spring sunshine brightened today for Berliners. Throngs sloshed to the churches through widening puddles as chill rains dampened the city.

BOSTON, April 6 -- Kirsten Flagstad, the Norwegian soprano, got a welcome back to the concert stage today as she made her first appearance in this country in six years before an audience that filled three-quarters of Symphony Hall.

The materials situation is improving gradually and the availbility of certain items is "considerably eased," Harry L. Erlicher, General Electric vice president in charge of purchasing and traffic, asserted last week.

The Police Department paid a hero's tribute yesterday to Jack Chason, patrolman killed early Friday morning in a pistol duel with an armed thug. The full inspector's funeral was attended by nearly a thousand of Patrolman Chason's colleagues, most of them on their own time.
MOSCOW, April 6 -- Senior members of the United States and British delegations to the Council of Foreign Ministers here see economic unity for Germany postponed by at least six months.

The Rio Doce Valley in Brazil, with an estimated 12,000,000,000 tons of the highest grade iron ore, offers an Immediate solution to current fears by United States industrialists that top grade American deposits will be exhausted within the next few years, Jose Garrido Torres, director of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau, said last week.

American newspapers are the best and fairest in the world, Wilaur Forrest, president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, declared yesterday in a discussion of the recent report of the Commission on Freedom of the Press.
WASHINGTON, Monday, April 7 -- A nation-wide telephone strike became effective at 6 A. M. today with the passage of the deadline set by the National Federation of Telephone Workers.
BRUSSELS, April 6 -- The first important offer by an American concern to invest capital equipment in Belgium since the war has been rejected on the ground that there is no room for a competitor here.

It takes no second sight for us to say that many refrigerators today contain cooked meat of one kind or another. To predispose you in its favor, we purposely speak of it as "cooked" rather than "leftover." Some kitcheners are convinced that nothing good can come out of what is left.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6 -- Liberty Films has signed Claudette Colbert to play opposite Spencer Tracy in the screen version of "State of the Union," which Frank Capra will produce and direct for the company. The picture will be distributed . by Metro - Goldwyn Mayer, and will be filmed at the Metro studio this summer.

LOS ANGELES, April 6 (AP) -- Lieut. Dave Freeman of the Army Medical Corps retained his national badminton title last night by defeating Carl Loveday of Montclair, N. J., 15-8, 15-8, in the men's singles final of the national tournament.

OTTAWA, April 6 (AP) -- The Canadian duck hunting season will be shortened and the bag limit reduced from last year in the light of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service survey that there are only 54,000,000 ducks and geese on the North American continent, an official of the Wild Life Protection Division of the Mines and Resources Department said tonight.
The Sperry Corporation had a consolidated net income of $7,415,981 in 1946, equal to $3.65 a share on 2,031,565 shares outstanding, Thomas A. Morgan, board chairman, reported yesterday.

Net income of the Botany Worsted Mills last year increased to $3,802,548, after taxes and all charges, from $817.891 earned in 1945, according to the annual report to be issued to stockholders today by Col. Charles F.H. Johnson, president.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Former Federal Judge William Clark of Princeton, N.J., who left the Third Circuit Court of Appeals in 1942 to enter the Army, asked today that two judges of the Court of Claims disqualify themselves from participating in a case in which he seeks return to the bench.

As a lively discussion of high retail costs developed in wholesale and retail trades, spokesmen indicated yesterday that prices were causing increased consumer resistance and a few made cautious predictions of gradual price declines, even in processed foods.
After a poor start, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday recovered from the lowest levels of the day but closed 14 to 31 points net lower than on last Thursday.

The report of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service on the waterfowl situation, compiled following "the most complete annual inventory ever conducted by the service," shows a drastic decline in the duck population, but not sufficiently drastic to necessitate a closed hunting season this year.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- E.B. Van Horn, counsel for the Senate Committee on Expenditures in Executive Departments, said today the Customs Bureau's action in laying off port patrol officers was "mighty bad management -- almost caprice."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 7 (AP) -- Paul E. Richter announced today his resignation from the executive committee of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., and said he would not "stand for re-election as an officer or director of the company" at a meeting of stockholders on April 24.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., April 7 (AP) -- Stuart Allen, 16 years old, adopted son of a minister, was reported today by J. Croy Keller, Chief of Police, to have admitted the slaying of John Frank, elderly sexton at his father's church, on April 1.

From 80,000 to 90,000 Bell System workers in the metropolitan area stayed away from their jobs yesterday. However, maintenance of normal dial service kept the telephone strike from bearing too heavily on 90 per cent of New York telephone users and 40 per cent of the New Jersey subscribers.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A majority of the Senate Labor Committee agreed informally today upon proposed legislation to put down by Government injunction great strikes, such as that now silencing many telephones, where national health or safety was deemed imperilled.

BOSTON, April 7 (AP) -- A parade of bone-crushing heavyweights thrilled 5,533 fans by scoring speedy knockouts tonight as the fifty-ninth national A.A.U. boxing championships opened with a sixty-two-trial-bout program in the Boston Garden.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, April 7 -- Continued need of imperial defense preparations was emphasized here today by King George VI.

Business As Usual The financial community suffered yesterday no major setbacks as a result of the telephone strike. This was due to two factors. First, the volume of 630,000 shares on the New York Stock Exchange created no heavy demand on telephone equipment either in or between cities.

Reginald G. Coombe, president of the board of managers of Memorial Hospital Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases, handed a silver trowel yesterday to Alfred P. Sloan Jr., with the words: "I hope you will see the day when light will break forth from this institute to shine on the afflicted everywhere."

DETROIT, April 7 -- Henry Ford, noted automotive pioneer, died at 11:40 tonight at the age of 83. He had retired a little more than a year and a half ago from active direction of the great industrial empire he founded in 1903.

Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer have been invited to attend a maritime managementlabor meeting that may set a new style in industry relations. It will be a "break bread together" and a "pipe of peace" gathering scheduled for the St. George Hotel on May 14 by the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, and officials of private steamship companies.

Final Easter Sales Up 2% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week were 2 per cent above the like week of last year. The increase was well below expectations for the final week of Easter shopping. For the preceding week the rise was 8 per cent, while for the four weeks ended Saturday it was also 8 per cent.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 7 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, today appointed Dr. Gunnar Myrdal, Swedish Minister of Commerce, as Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

Alvin J. Paris, whose testimony as principal state witness was responsible for the imprisonment of the three "higher-ups" in the football "fix" scheme, was sentenced yesterday by General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit to a one-year penitentiary term.

Bush Terminal Net profit of Bush Terminal Company for the first two months of 1947 was $95,000, Irving T. Bush, president, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting. He said a net of $150,000 was indicated for the first quarter.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 7 -- Andrei A. Gromyko scored a triumph today with the crowd that set an attendance record for a United Nations Security Council meeting to hear the Soviet reply to President Truman's "stop communism" program.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Governor Dewey gave his approval today to bills providing for referenda this fall in increasing the State Public Housing Loan Fund by $135,000,000 and authorizing corresponding increases in annual state housing subsidies.

Vacation-bound fashions -- appealing also to the stay-at-home -- were presented yesterday at the St. Regis by the Tailored Woman. A white pique swim suit had a ruffled strapless top and trim of hand-painted butterflies gracing the bodice and skirt.

Earnings of Paramount Pictures, Inc., for the fifty-three weeks ended on last Jan. 4 are estimated at $44,040,000 after all charges, including provision for taxes, according to the report issued yesterday. The corporation's earnings for the fifty-two weeks ended on Dec. 29, 1945, were $17,952,432.

Two new cases of suspected smallpox were reported yesterday, bringing the total of possible and confirmed cases to six since the reappearance of the infectious disease here last Friday after a sevenyear absence.

Vera Zorina, dancer and actress, has been engaged by the PhilharmonicSymphony Society of New York to portray the role of Joan of Arc in one of the society's most ambitious offerings next season, it was announced yesterday.

Seven hundred and fifty children from all parts of the city rolled wooden eggs 23,400 yards yesterday in a contest sponsored by the Park Department. The prizes for the winners were provided by Arnold Constable Co.

VIENNA, April 7 -- A dispatch from Trieste to London and Austrian newspapers saying that plans were being considered for construction of a new railroad to Vienna via Ppntebba and Villach caused surprise here over the week-end.

MUNICH, Germany, April 7 -- The decision to merge the Communist party of Bavaria with the Socialist Unity party of the Russian zone was announced today at a mass meeting by Wilhelm Pieck and Otto Grotewohl, co-chairmen of the latter, and Fritz Sperling, chairman of the Communist party.

PARIS, April 7 -- Disavowing all desire to seek power through a personal plebiscite but again condemning the Constitution and the existing party system, former President de Gaulle called on the French people today to rally to form a republic that would identify itself with national "renewal."

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The Senate voted today to continue the Government's wool price support program through 1948 at not less than last year's level -- 41.6 cents a pound. The measure, passed on a voice vote, now goes to the House.

Foreign Minister Molotov's letter to Secretary Marshall implying that American troops are participating in the Chinese civil war and asserting that Russian troops completely evacuated Chinese territory almost a year ago is a bit of Soviet propaganda. Neither statement will stand examination.
