The manufacture, installation and distribution of Western Electric Company products were crippled yesterday in an off-shoot of the nation-wide telephone strike. Seventeen thousand workers were out at the company's main plant in Kearny, N.J., and at smaller plants in Clifton, Newark, Passaic, Bayonne and at 529 West Fortysecond Street here.
Comfortable construction and durable materials, as well as graceful lines, are incorporated in the summer furniture shown in Sloane's newly revamped department which opened yesterday.
George A. Arkwright, Public Service Commissioner, began yesterday a series of hearings on the application of the Long Island Rail Road for increases in passenger fares.
For the first time in almost sixty years men operated the switchboards of the New York Telephone Company yesterday.

When 340,000 telephone company workers walked off their jobs at 6 o'clock yesterday morning in the country's first major communications strike, the impact of that action on the nation's economy made a curiously eccentric pattern. Long-distance telephone service fell off to about 20 per cent of normal, but leased-wire services for press and radio were unaffected, as were dial telephones, which serve about 60 per cent of the country's telephone subscribers.
MOSCOW, April 7 -- The Big Four's deputies for Austria got into another involved debate over minor economic clauses of the Austrian draft treaty today.

The 1921 business depression brought the Ford Motor Company its most severe financial crisis, and served to demonstrate both Mr. Ford's antipathy to bankers, and his resourcefulness. When it became acute the company had obligations of $58,000,000 due between Jan. 1 and April 18, and only $20,000,000 with which to meet them.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 7 -- "Sorry, Wrong Number," a radio play by Lucille Fletcher, has been purchased for the screen by Hal Wallis, who will produce the film version for Paramount release next fall. Anatole Litvak will join Wallis as director and co-producer of the film and will reportedly share in the profits of the venture.

PEIPING, April 7 -- The next major Nationalist offensive in north China is expected to be launched soon from Tsanghsien, sixty-five miles south of Tientsin. Government forces plan to drive south along the railway to open the Tientsin-Pukow line for the first time since V-J Day.

Mutual understanding of each other's problems by management and employes and improved human relations in industry are more effective means of minimizing strikes and other labor disputes than attempts to evolve legislative panaceas to terminate them completely, Keen Johnson, Under-Secretary of Labor, declared yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 7 -- For the first time since 1939, the thirtysixth conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union opened here today with representatives of twentyfour nations.

Highlighted by the personal appearance of leading designers, a showing of California fashions was held at Bamberger's, Newark, yesterday. The manikins used the counter ledges as runways and moved at a lively pace high above the crowd.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- France, Italy, Norway, Germany, Belgium, Egypt and some Latin-American countries will benefit by emergency grain allocations announced today by the Department of Agriculture for April-May shipment.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Carroll Reece, Republican National Chairman, accused three major broadcasting companies today of helping President Truman raise his own campaign fund by providing free radio time for his address to the Jefferson Day dinners Saturday night.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Discussing "the latest technique for successful use of objective research in promotion" at the annual meeting today of the National Newspaper Promotion Association, Alfred Politz, New York researcher, termed as "justified" the "concern" occasionally expressed that "research is being misused for the sake of promotion."

ALBANY, April 7 (AP) -- Other bills signed by Governor Dewey today included: Permitting Board of Supervisors to grant to county officers and employes elected or appointed for definite terms cost of living salary increases of 15 per cent over the pay received in 1945.

The sentence in the President's Jefferson Day speech that stirred the longest, loudest and most spontaneous applause was his statement: "I am happy to be able to say tonight that for the present fiscal year, 1947, we shall balance the budget and we shall have a surplus."

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The Intercoastal Steamship Freight Association today filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission proposed rate increases on fifty commodities, designed to keep pace with suggested upward revisions of transcontinental railroad freight rates.

BOSTON, April 7 -- In a letter addressed to the National Catholic Edupation Society, which opened its convention here today, President Truman asked continued support of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

FRANKFORT ON THE ODER, Germany, April 6 (Delayed) -- Germany still has the power for a military resurrection, Col. Jakov Korsikov, Soviet commander, said at Russian headquarters here yesterday. He implied that the problem was as much one in which the four powers must watch each other, to prevent the German strength from being misused against any of the Allies, as to watch the Germans.

THE mad gallop toward the Run for the Roses will get under way at Jamaica today with the staging of the first division of the Experimental Handicap. Some of the 3-year-olds already have had their blankets removed, but the big unveiling will take place this week and the true objective is unmistakable, the Kentucky Derby on May 3.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- After nearly one year free of major disputes the industrial front was shattered today by two unprecedented major strikes. The White House was reported to be deeply concerned over the sudden change in the labor relations picture and its possible effects on the national economy and on international economic relations.

There was an easier tone in the stock market yesterday. Prices closed lower and steadier in quiet trading. The down-trend was attributed largely to the general concern over the telephone strike and the stoppage in coal production which may again disrupt industrial activity.

A joint study by newspaper advertising executives and retailers of advertising techniques, public opinion and research is nearing completion, Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 7 -- Bituminous mines represented by the Western Pennsylvania Coal Operators Association were producing today at only one-fourth of capacity, representing a general tendency of most miners to support continuation of last week's strike in protest against safety conditions in the mines.

Herbert F. Schroeder, a securities broker, was arrested yesterday on the complaint of State Attorney General Nathaniel Goldstein, who charged him with misappropriating $23,714 of a customer's money to trade with on his own account.
A telephonic blackout blanketed the suburbs and outlying sections of the city on the first day of the nation-wide telephone strike, but the dial saved the day for New Yorkers yesterday.
An English police sergeant with stanch faith in international amity was among the 2,274 passengers who arrived from Southampton on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth yesterday.

NANKING, April 7 -- Reforms in Formosa are awaiting decision by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, according to Gen. Pai Chung-hsi, Defense Minister. At a press conference today General Pai said the Generalissimo would decide whether Gen. Chen Yi would be removed as governor.

Sidestepping questions on the political outlook for 1948, former Vice President Henry A. Wallace confined himself chiefly to a discussion of the role of the United Nations in world peace before leaving La Guardia Field for London at 3:05 P.M. yesterday.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 7 -- Formation of a new type of cooperative stock corporation for employes of Thomas A. Edison Industries, to which, he is contributing $1,260,000, was announced today by Theodore M. Edison, youngest son of the late Thomas A. Edison.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Supreme Court of the United States threw out today the defense of a cannery in Florida that used the Federal anti-price discrimination laws to protect it from a state suit to collect $114,000 due on a contract for purchases of cans.
CHICAGO, April 7 -- Grains turned upward sharply today in the late trading on the Board of Trade, after an early break.

LISBON, Portugal, April 7 -- Don Juan, pretender to the Spanish throne, today issued a formal statement to all Spaniards vehemently condemning Generalissimo Francisco Franco's plan on succession as a violation of all principles of the hereditary monarchy.

ATHENS, April 7 -- Greece has the appearance of a democracy, but the appearance is deceptive. It would not be fair to describe her as a police state, but under the stress of domestic crisis and foreign threats a large measure of the freedom associated with a democratic state has been suspended.

Maritime unions of the American Federation of Labor are planning intensive organization drives to take advantage of internal difficulties currently experienced by unions in the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and of the present wave of anti-Communist sentiment among sea workers.
George Herman (Babe) Ruth is back in baseball again, in a role close to his heart and ideally suited to his unique standing in the diamond sport as the idol of American youth.

So much interurban communication was shifted yesterday to telegraph, because of the telephone strike, that the facilities, of the Western Union Telegraph Company were strained, messages were slowed, some additional personnel was hired and still more temporary workers were sought last night.

BARROWS DUNHAM, a Professor of Philosophy at Temple University, is a skillful writer, an able dialectician and a thoroughly confused individual. He can write with a flourish and argue with eloquence. But he sometimes doesn't know what he is talking about. He distorts history to fit the Procrustean bed of his Marxist convictions.

The United States Conciliation Service stepped in yesterday in an effort to forestall a threatened walkout of 50,000 Western Union Telegraph Company employes outside of this city. The Commercial Telegraphers Union, AFL, filed a strike notice last Thursday and two days later two other unions representing the Southwest filed similar notices.

PITTSBURGH, April 7 -- Unless there are unexpected developments before Friday in his negotiations with the United States Steel Corporation, Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, is expected to send out a call for a meeting next week of his national wage policy committee to prepare for a country wide strike May 1.

FORT SMITH, Ark., April 7 -- A couple of vagrant flies brought disaster to the Giants here today. Whitey Lockman misjudged a Wind-blown drive in the second inning that went for a double. Willard Marshall became confused under another in the seventh that fell for three bases.

BERLIN, April 7 -- The Deutsche Laenderbank, private banking house for I.G. Farbenindustrie, will be treated as an integral part of I.G. Farben's political-industrial empire and its assets will be disposed of accordingly, according to James S. Martin, American control officer for I.G. Farben.

LONDON, April 7 (U.P.) -- The preparatory committee of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment is scheduled to meet Thursday in Geneva, Switzerland, to open negotiations for an international economic set-up that envisages lasting peace through world prosperity.

Between 300,000 and 350,000 telephone workers walked out yesterday in the first country-wide strike in the industry's history. Workers in all except nine of the forty-eight states took part in the stoppage.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If Mayor O'Dwyer's proposed budget is adopted, the cost of New York City's government will have increased in the first two fiscal years of his administration by 30 per cent -- over $270,000,000 -- which is $17,000,000 more than the total cost of this city's government for 1919.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 7 -- The text of a statement by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative, at today's meeting of the United Nations Security Council follows: The statement made by the United States representative at the meeting of the Security Council on March 28th deals with an important question.

Maritime Commission regulation of the practices and charges of freight forwarders in New York and all other United States ports was urged yesterday by the Port of New York Authority at a hearing in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.

Gray iron foundries have undertaken a long-range program aimed at improvement of the industry, Raymond L. Collier, executive vice president of the Gray Iron Founders' Society, Inc., disclosed yesterday. With the full cooperation of industry members, a nation-wide survey of industry conditions has been undertaken.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Effective political opposition to passage of the Greek-Turkish aid bill is collapsing. It is generally agreed that the measure will go through both branches of Congress with a thumping majority. But never in recent history has there been such support for a program that inspired so many sincere doubts.

Harold V. Smith, president of the Home Insurance Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that most of the thirtyfive criticisms and recommendations concerning the company in the five-year report of the New York State Department of Insurance had been disposed of to the satisfaction of State officials and the management.

WARSAW, April 7 -- By act of her Parliament, Poland has created a State Council. It wields a power in the new republic that is greater than Parliament's although the same act decrees that Parliament is a sovereign body in the sphere of legislation.

The 4,867-ton, motor vessel Dumra, most recent of the twentyfive new Peninsular Oriental and British India vessels to be commissioned since the end of World War II, is re-establishing the Persian Gulf service from Bombay to Basra, via Karachi and other ports.

Late that same year Mr. Ford met his greatest industrial crisis. In 1924 the Ford company had manufactured about two-thirds of all the automobiles produced in this country, but by 1926 the Chevrolet car, manufactured by the General Motors Corporation, had become a serious competitor.

A resolution authorizing an increase in the common stock of the Johns-Manville Corporation from 1,500,000 shares to 4,500,000 to permit a three-for-one split will be voted upon by stockholders at the annual meeting on May 9, the company disclosed yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 7 -- A Soviet proposal that the German people decide by a plebiscite whether their future state have a centralized or a federal government was rejected today by the United States, Britain and France.

Rhubarb, which in grandmother's day ranked close to sulphur and molasses as a remedy for spring fever, has been in disfavor for the last few years because of the sugar shortage. This season, too, the demand is light, although plentiful supplies are arriving from hothouses in Michigan and up-State and from truck gardens in California.

LONDON, April 7 -- The "Truman Doctrine" for aid to Greece and Turkey was severely condemned by the influential Cooperative party at the close of its annual conference in Llandudno, Wales, today. The Cooperative party is an integral part of the Labor party for political purposes and has numerous Members of Parliament.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has donated $250,000 to the coming campaign here of the World Youth Fund of the Y.M.C.A., it was announced yesterday. Richard W. Lawrence, chairman of the advance and special gifts committee of the campaign, said Mr. Rockefeller's contribution was an advance gift to the World Youth Fund Campaign, which will be conducted in May in this city and Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
TRENTON, N.J., April 7 -- The New Jersey Legislature acted tonight on several controversial bills of the type usually deferred until final adjournment is approaching.

MOORESTOWN, N.J., April 7 -- Dr. Joseph Stokes, a physician in Moorestown for sixty-one years, who had also been prominent in local banking and civic affairs, died at his home today after a long illness. He was born here eighty-five years ago, a son of Dr. N. Newlin Stokes.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 7 -- Outhit nine to seven, Villanova's baseball team capitalized on six Princeton errors today and handed the Tigers their second defeat in three starts, 9 -- 2.

Keynote, the Wheatley Stable's gray daughter of Mahmoud, scored by a decisive margin in the Rose D'Or, feature event at the Jamaica race track yesterday. But for the great majority in the crowd of 42,405 on hand, the time that elapsed before the official flash went up must have seemed an eternity.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 7 -- The Soviet Union criticized the United States and Britain today for putting "artificial obstacles" in the path of a United Nations disarmament program, and he called for an end of "inflated" armies and military budgets.

The management of a Brooklyn apartment house abandoned yesterday an action to dispossess a war veteran tenant who had instituted a damage suit charging violation of Office of Price Administration regulations.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor paid a visit to the East Side Settlement at 540 East Seventysixth Street yesterday and received a rousing welcome from 225 youngsters.

The new all-automatic General Electric washer was shown here yesterday to 100 electrical appliance dealers from Westchester and the Bronx. They were told, during the first of a. series of dealer conferences of General Electric Appliances, Inc., that prices on all major appliances of General Electric have not advanced over last year and in a few items price reductions have been made.

Renting a one-story brick shed in Detroit, Mr. Ford spent the year 1902 experimenting with two-cylinder and four-cylinder motors. By that time the public had become interested in the speed possibilities of the automobile, which was no longer regarded as a freak.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Interpretations of President Truman's Jefferson Day address that see in his remarks an unconditional threat to veto tax-reduction measures were challenged today by Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Progress toward settlement of the long lines telephone dispute was reported by the Labor Department tonight in the unprecedented national strike of telephone workers.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 -- The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey filed an amended plan of dissolution with the Securities and Exchange Commission today. It will transfer all of its assets, upon consummation of the plan to a subsidiary, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark, N.J.

There is at least one clear deduction to be drawn from the local elections in Japan, the returns from which are now tabulated. That deduction is that Papasan and Mamma-san see more hope in the established order than in the economic and social revolution that was the choice offered them by the Socialists and Communists.

Three more teams have decided to join the fight for the National A.A.U. indoor water polo championship which will be contested in the pool of the New York Athletic Club next Friday and Saturday. This makes an unprecedented international field of nine entries for the first staging of this roughriding aquatic sport since 1941.

History's Mixed Company Speaking of de Gaulle, Petain, Weygand, Darlan, Laval, as many of us have been doing the last few days, it seems a great pity that governments engaged in fighting wars of liberation, either for themselves or in behalf of others, will seldom live up to the higher moral niceties.

Bids on bond issues of two school districts in Riverside County, Calif., will be received on April 14. Desert School District and Palm Springs Union High School District will offer $750,000 each. Dated May 1, 1947, both issues will come due May 1, 1948 to 1972.
NORFOLK, Va., April 7 -- Looks as though something will have to be done about this Yogi Berra and very soon the burden of the task will rest with the seven other clubs in the American League.

In a letter supporting the fourth annual drive of the United Negro College Fund, Inc., released yesterday by the fund, President Truman said that "where Negro veterans are concerned, the greatest burden and the greatest opportunity have fallen to the Negro college."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 7 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, charged today that the United States aid program for Greece constituted intervention in Greek internal affairs. He demanded that the United Nations Security Council establish a commission to see to it that United States help for Greece was administered exclusively for the benefit of the Greek people.
TORONTO, April 7 (Canadian Press) -- D.W. Ambridge, president of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., said today at the annual meeting of the company that no dividends would be

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 7 -- Three officials of the Venezuelan Government have accused Julio Cesar Vargas, former Inspector General of the Army, of having conspired with former President Eleazar Lopez Contreras to overthrow the Government.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., April 7 -- Four children were burned to death here this morning when a flash fire swept through the interior of a one and one-half story clapboard house at 114 West Main Street. They were trapped in the attic bedroom of their tiny home and died before the quickly summoned Fire Department arrived.

In the elegant atmosphere of the Hotel Astor Coral Room, 150 civic, business, military and professional leaders lined up with compartmented metal trays yesterday to buck a counterpart of an Army chow line for a GI lunch.

New Yorkers face the prospect of an immediate increase in their cleaning bills for suits, dresses and other apparel sent to neighborhood tailors, it was learned yesterday, as wholesale cleaners and dyers raised prices to retailers a reported 25 per cent.

Gilbert Dodds, the invincible miler who swept the boards in twelve races in his return to spiked-shoe competition, was voted the outstanding performer of the past indoor track campaign by the Track Writers Association yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Government plans to ask Federal Justice T. Alan Goldsborough on Thursday to restore, in view of stoppages in the coal mines, the full $3,500,000 fine against the United Mine Workers, it was learned today. The $3,500,000 was set by the justice last December in the contempt case.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 7 -- Fordham produced two runs in the eighth inning to trip Rutgers today, 6 to 5, for its second victory of the season. Jim Arbucho pitched the whole game for the Rams, limiting the Scarlet to eight scattered hits.

These policies were made feasible by the revoluntionary organization of production devised by Mr. Ford. Under the old factory system, a single workman constructed an entire spring, using several different tools and performing many different operations in the process.

The U.S. Lawn Tennis Association planted a time bomb yesterday under the world's top ranking woman star, Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles, and it appeared possible that the explosion might blow the tall redhead right out of amateur tennis.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The National Labor Relations Act is superior to the "Little Wagner Acts" of the states in labor-industry disputes, the Supreme Court held today.

The Associated Hospital Service enrolled 562,464 persona during 1946, a 37 per cent gain over 1945, Louis H. Pink, president of the organization, said yesterday in his annual report. This enrollment brought the total covered by the service to 2,788,987, or one out of four persons in the metropolitan area.

It is due to Monte Nelson, a young pianist who played last night in Town Hall, to say that his appearance was preceded by high praise of his talent from authoritative quarters. And it is due the reader to state that, attending this recital, we were grievously disappointed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We, the people of the United States of America, are now faced with these harsh but inescapable alternatives. The old Yankee fisherman had a saying that a man must "either fish, cut bait or go ashore."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, April 7 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler got most of his information about the United States from his own propaganda machine and it took quite a time to convince him that Americans would be anything but a pushover in the war, secret German files showed today.

Provision must be made by some coordinated group of city agencies for persons forced to vacate condemned slum property to make way for new construction, and houses held unfit for human habitation, Robert F. Wagner Jr., Commissioner of Housing, said last night.

No drastic price drops are impending in the major lines in hardware store. New York retail merchants reported here yesterday, since minor readjustments have been made steadily since shortly before last Christmas, according to several store managers.
JERUSALEM, April 7 -- Still another appeal on behalf of Dov Bela Gruner, doomed terrorist, failed in the High Court here today.

HAVANA, April 7 -- The Cuban Government intervened today in a effort to settle the controversy between Communist and anti-Communist labor groups. The dispute has already flared into open violence and has caused suspension by authorities of the Fifth Congress of the Confederation of Cuban Workers which had been scheduled to open yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg moved today to kill a "joker" in his amendment to align President Truman's Greek-Turkish aid program with the United Nations Charter.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Walter Morrow, president of the American Retail Federation, advised today all retailers to examine their price structures "item by item and category by category," to bring them to lower levels.

ALBANY, April 7 -- The McGowan Bill, that would have made anyone who writes obscene literature guilty of a misdemeanor along with those who distribute or offer to distribute such literature, was vetoed today by Governor Dewey.

MIAMI, April 7 -- Some misplaced Dodger batting eyes were located today as the boys whacked out a bevy of blows to bury the Browns beneath a top-heavy 12-4 score at Miami Field, before 2,500 fans who seemed extraordinarily enthusiastic in comparison to the Havana clientele.

Among the objections advanced against President Truman's program of aid for Greece and Turkey has been the charge that the governments of these two countries are not democratic and that in aiding them we would be aiding "Fascist dictatorships." That charge has been invoked so freely against so many countries, including the United States itself, that it needs some defining.

Pursers employed by the United States Lines and the American South African Lines have voted overwhelmingly in favor of the Staff Officers Association, AFL, as their exclusive bargaining agent in future negotiations with the companies, it was announced yesterday by Thomas Hill, East Coast representative of the association.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Historians and students of contemporary United States affairs are awaiting an event of July as eagerly perhaps as they have ever awaited a similar one. The event will be the publication of the private papers of Abraham Lincoln, including at least 108 items not to be found in the collection of Nicolay and Hay.

LONDON, April 7 (Reuters) -- The race for English Football League honors tightened today with five teams bunched within three points of one another following Easter Monday games watched by hundreds of thousands of fans enjoying the first sunny weather of the holiday week-end.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It would seem to me that there can be differences of opinion on Greece, Turkey, Great Britain, Russia and France. But I fail to see how there can be any differences of opinion among us about the importance and welfare of the children living in the United States.

On May 26, 1937, a group of UAW organizers, including Richard T. Frankensteen and Walter Reuther, were distributing organizing literature outside the gate of the Ford plant at River Rouge, when they were set upon and badly beaten.

Activities to be undertaken during the year, a review of the purposes of the organization and the election of officers, were on the agenda at the annual meeting of the corporate members of the American National Theatre and Academy held yesterday afternoon at the Princess Theatre, 106 West Thirty-ninth Street.

MOSCOW, April 7 -- The United States was accused today of creating strong naval and air bases in China. This charge was made amid mounting Soviet suspicion of American strategic policy in areas as widely separated as the Mediterranean and the Pacific.

Matthew G. Ely, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, warned the Board of Estimate yesterday against a possible return of the Bankers Agreement that strait-jacketed city finances fourteen years ago under Mayor John P. O'Brien.

Fred Pechter, formerly vice president in charge of personnel and industrial relations with Publix Shirt Corporation, has been appointed manager of all manufacturing facilities of the ExcelsiorVarsity Underwear Corporation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 8 --Andrei A. Gromyko put the Soviet Union on record today as agreeing to the principle of international atomic control from the mine to the plant but balked at permitting aerial surveys to detect secret operations.

Tax-Exempt Territorials The First Boston Corporation, in a progress report on the marketing of the recent $50,000,000 Puerto Rico Water Resources bond issue, tells how one incredulous buyer repeatedly questioned the advertised exemption of the bonds from Federal and State taxes before placing an order.

Here for a good-will tour opening at the Yankee Stadium on May 4 and which later will take them to Philadelphia, Baltimore, Detroit, Chicago, St. Louis, Los Angeles and San Francisco, the Hapoel soccer team of Palestine arrived yesterday on a Transworld Airliner at La Guardia Field after traveling by way of Cairo, Rome, Madrid and the Azores.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 8 --Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, has under consideration a proposal to investigate charges that some Secretariat employes are guilty of pro-Russian bias, it was learned here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 8 --Special limitations on the flow of information from the Trusteeship Council to the press, which could be more severe than those imposed by any other United Nations organ, were proposed today by Sayid Awni Khalidy, the representative of Iraq.

Low rate export cargo is piling up on the docks in increasing quantities because of lack of shipping space, it was reported yesterday. A number of complaints are being received from exporters who are unable to ship cement, flour and autos despite good market demand, Department of Commerce officials state.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)--A condensed text of the speech by Senator Vandenberg in the Senate today on the proposed aid program to Greece and Turkey: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has unanimously reported the bill entitled "To Provide for Assistance to Greece and Turkey."

Smallpox was established definitely yesterday as the illness in one suspected case at Willard Parker Hospital. The total since the outbreak was revealed here last Friday stands at four positive cases--one of which has proved fatal--and two suspicious cases.
ATHENS, April 8 (UP)--Railroad and public utility employes voted today to join the forty-eight-hour strike during its last twenty-four hours.

Most of us look forward to opening day at the circus, whether we attend or not. It means that better season has arrived or is immediately in the offing, when spring warmth makes life mellower and more tolerable. The month is one of children in midtown streets, and so a chance to renew youth.

WASHINGTON, April 8--Producers of building materials are making an intensive study of a voluntary price-cutting program as a means of checking the rising cost of housing construction, it was learned today.

NEWARK, N.J., April 8--Permission to use the Newark Airport for the take-off of a projected round-the-world flight by Milton Reynolds, pen manufacturer, was rescinded tonight, it was announced by Maj. Vincent Carson, assistant manager of the airport.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent leading editorial you stated: "It was the interest [of Great Britain] which inspired the Monroe Doctrine, which, though proclaimed by the United States as its own, was really made effective by the British fleet."

ALBANY, April 8--The growing of potatoes or tomatoes in a 3,000acre area centering around Hicksville, L.I., site of the only known golden nematode infestation in North America, can be barred by the State Department of Agriculture under a bill signed today by Governor Dewey.

Twenty-six districts, one more than a year ago, will be sites of qualifying rounds on Monday, June 2, for the national open championship, according to an announcement yesterday by the United States Golf Association. In addition to announcing that Memphis, Tenn., had been added to the qualifying points, the association declared that in seven instances the qualifying rounds had been shifted from one city to another.

PARIS, April 8--A new organization to systematize former President de Gaulle's campaign began to take form today under the name of the Reunion of the French People, taking its title from the phrase in M. de Gaulle's speech yesterday calling for such a reunion.

PITTSBURGH, April 8--Executive board members of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, were summoned today by Philip Murray to a special meeting here at the end of next week, April 1920, to discuss what the unions will do after April 30, when steel industry contracts expire.

Dr. L.M. Birkhead, founder of the Friends of Demoracy, Inc., 137 East Fifty-seventh Street, and coeditor of its semi-monthly bulletin, faced a criminal libel charge at a preliminary hearing yesterday before Magistrate Peter M. Horn in Mid-Manhattan Court.

The telephone strike had its light aspects--and its grim side, too. An alert emergency operator in Newark came in on a feebly flashing light yesterday morning, heard a man hoarsely mention "heart attack" and then caught a sound as of a body falling to a floor.

A price reduction averaging 18 per cent in the retail prices of infants', children's and teen-ager shoes was announced here yesterday by the Yankee Shoemakers, a division of the Sam Smith Shoe Corporation, Newmarket. N.H. The action was described as the first adjustment in the shoe trade conforming to President Truman's request for lower prices.

Everything seems to have been arranged for the London unveiling on June 2 of Broadway's sturdiest comedy, "Life With Father." So much so that Oscar Serlin, sponsor of the Howard Lindsay-Russel Crouse bonanza, will depart by clipper April 26 to supervise Firth Shephard's presentation on the other side.
MOSCOW, April 8--The Big Four deputies on Austria concluded their discussions of the proposed treaty draft with that country today widely separated on many critical issues.

WASHINGTON, April 8--Republican House leaders made firm preparations today to pass and send to the Senate before next week is out an omnibus bill basically altering the labor policy of the United States.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals took under review yesterday the criminal conviction of Henry Lustig, millionaire restaurateur, and two others on charges of having defrauded the Federal Government of $2,872,766 in income taxes owed by the Longchamps Restaurant chain.

Prices of men's fall clothing will be about 5 per cent higher, with representative manufacturers again forced to allot their output, according to the "open letter" to the trade, issued yesterday by Jerome I. Udell of Max Udell, Sons Co., manufacturers of Gramercy Park clothes.

WASHINGTON, April 8--A measure proposing the establishment of a Government system of export credit insurance was vigorously opposed today by the heads of the Export-Import Bank and the Federal Reserve System.

ROME, April 8--Unless funds are made available within the next eighty days to the International Refugee Organization, about 750,000 displaced persons will be in an extremely critical situation after June 30 when the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration closes its operations in Europe, Maj. Gen. Lowell W. Rooks, director general of UNRRA, said today.

Four of the five public pay station telephones in the lobby of the Henry Hudson Hotel at 353 West Fifty-seventh Street were put out of service for almost two hours yesterday evening when the receivers were cut from the coin-box instruments.

The Twentieth Century-Fox International Corporation and Paramount International Films, Inc., are jointly forming a corporation to distribute 16mm prints of their product in foreign countries. The new company will operate only in territories which, because of lack of theatres or insufficient population, are not now reached by the standard 35mm films.
Before the Fordham nine bowed to Brooklyn College, 14--8, in a Metropolitan Conference game at Flatbush Field yesterday, Ram Coach Jack Coffey said his principal problem this year is pitching.

Chief Police Inspector Martin J. Brown presented a check yesterday for $3,000, representing donations from members of the force, to 13-year-old Bette Jane Frankenfelder, official mascot of the Manhattan Red Cross Field Workers. The campaign was further enriched by gifts from Manhattan business and financial institutions totaling $417,681.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- Senator Herbert R. O'Conor, Democrat, of Maryland, said tonight that he would vote tomorrow for confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

ATHENS, April 8--Greek civil servants went on strike today. Employes of the Postoffice, Bank and other Government Departments quit because they did not get as large an Easter bonus as they thought they should have got.

The Electric Bond and Share Company filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission its plan II-B providing that it would pay no further amount of cash or other assets to holders of the certificates issued upon the retirement of its preferred stocks under plan II-A.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, April 9--Negotiations for an accord in the long-lines phase of the telephone strike continued early today with a background of assertions by officials of the Department of Labor that a "break" was near.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 8 --A spokesman for the Jewish Agency for Palestine charged today that the whole procedure of the United Nations might be brought into contempt if Britain refused to be bound by the General Assembly's recommendations for the settlement of the Palestine question.

New York continued to take the telephone strike in fairly easy stride yesterday. The dial system held up, and New York Telephone Company officials declared there was no reason to expect it to develop any major failure.

In the capitals of the world yesterday, as in the humble homes of the country, the passing of Henry Ford was sincerely mourned. British newspapers carried the story of Mr. Ford's death with streamer headlines, pointing out that the English Ford Company now employs many thousands in a huge plant outside London.

Governor Dewey, strongly urging pay-as-you-go policies in government, declared last night that unnecessary public borrowing and spending menaced the young people of this and future generations. He addressed 1,400 guests at the forty-third annual dinner of the Flatbush Boys Club at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On behalf of hundreds of thousands of A. T. and T. workers throughout the country I want to express to you their appreciation for the objective and factual news coverage which you have given to the telephone strike. Your editorial in the issue of April 8 is a clear and precise recital of the overall situation.

A sad story of twelve rabbits that died on Easter Sunday in the display window of a Brooklyn pet shop was unfolded yesterday in Flatbush Magistrate's Court. The two defendants tried to pin the blame on erroneous weather forecasts but Magistrate James F. Fawcett found that explanation unsatisfactory.

MONTREAL, April 8 (AP)--Paced by Billy Reay, who scored two goals, the Montreal Canadiens shut out the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6-0, tonight in the first game of their four-out-of-seven final series for the Stanley Cup, emblematic of world hockey supremacy.

Many retailers are trying to reduce prices, Lew Hahn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared yesterday. Their efforts should at least halt the rising prices that have brought increasing consumer resistance in many markets, he said.

He was a simple, in some ways almost naive, man, and it was in the quality of logical directness perhaps that his chief genius lay. To a peculiar degree he was the embodiment of America in the era of industrial revolution. Starting as a Midwestern farm boy, he became a mechanic, went into business for himself, and was finally one of the wealthiest men.

WASHINGTON, April 8--Representative Karl E. Mundt of South Dakota, ranking Republican member of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, outlined tonight a six-point program for curbing Communists in this country.

KINGS POINT, L.I., April 8-- Behind the four-hit pitching of Lester Baldersen, the Kings Point baseball team handed Manhattan a 7-to-3 setback today. It was the first game of the season for both teams.

VIENNA, April 8--United States quarters here have taken measures to clear up, from the standpoint of American policy, the confusion now prevalent in Vienna regarding the fate of the Austrian treaty at Moscow.

A bill authorizing jail sentences and fines for telephone strikers was rushed through both houses of the New Jersey Legislature last night as the second day of the walkout of 85,000 Bell System workers in the metropolitan area passed with no progress toward a settlement.

WASHINGTON, April 8--The Army emphasizing its contention that preparedness is the best and cheapest insurance against war, released figures today showing that four wars against foreign powers in the last 100 years have cost the United States $362,981,660,048 and 526,081 in dead.

Marking the first grant made by the Carnegie Corporation of New York in the field of nursing, a gift of $28,000 will be used to finance an intensive study of the registered nurse's real job and changes in education that are required, it was announced yesterday.

An exhibition pictorially commenting upon one hundred years of family life in America opened with a preview yesterday at Portraits, Inc., 460 Park Avenue. It has been organized as a benefit for the Homemaker Service of the Children's Aid Society.
TO THE NEW YORK TIMES: When are we veterans going to realize that we are no longer the pampered darlings of the American people but a part of the taxpaying citizenry itself?

HAMILTON, Ont., April 8-- Although the United States and Canada enjoy a standard of living unequaled by any collectivist state, there are many people in both countries who "do not appreciate our freedoms and are ready to throw them overboard," it was declared here tonight by Gwilym A. Price, president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

TOKYO, April 8--Opportunities to study American trade unionism on its home grounds could "salvage" the Japanese union leaders who have drifted into the Communist camp, according to Willard S. Townsend, vice president of the CIO, who is here as an American member of the World Federation of Trade Unions mission.

BATAVIA, Java, April 8 (AP)-- A.K. Gani, Minister of Economics in the Indonesian Republic, announced today a ten-year plan to change Java, Sumatra and the smaller islands of the Republic from a colonial to a semi-socialistic economy.

PITTSBURGH, April 8--A survey of mines in the soft coal fields indicated today that John L. Lewis may be planning to starve the steel industry of its coke supplies by keeping the captive mines shut, while permitting a gradual reopening of fuel-producing mines.
CHARLESTON, S.C., April 8-- Getting back on their native soil and hearing those familiar American boos and cheers must have given the Dodgers a shot in the arm.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8-- "Early Autumn," Louis Bromfield's 1926 novel, has been purchased for the screen by Benedict Bogeaus as a vehicle for Ida Lupino, the United Artists producer disclosed today. Bogeaus and Miss Lupino will produce the picture jointly on a profit-participation basis.

CHICAGO, April 8--Grain markets made a strong start and a weak finish on the Board of Trade today. General selling followed announcement that a special meeting of the Cabinet would be held in Washington tomorrow to consider the general price situation.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 8 (AP) --Stockholders of Bethlehem Steel Corporation voted today by an overwhelming majority to increase the minimum employe pension of $160 a year to $600 annually at the annual meeting. They voted also to lift a $25,000 ceiling in effect under the old pension plan.

If the Long Island Rail Road were permitted to increase its passenger fares, the company would spend $15,000,000 of its net income for the next three years on improvements, Walter S. Franklin, vice president, declared yesterday. He testified before Public Service Commissioner George A. Arkwright at a hearing on the road's application for additional revenues in 233 Broadway.

New York University, thwarted twice by rain in attempts to begin its defense of the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference championship, got away from the barrier yesterday and beat City College, 8--7, at Lewisohn Stadium. The Violet has won the Conference title the last four years.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8--The sixteenth annual packaging conference and exposition, featuring latest developments in container materials and machinery, opened today for a four-day stand in Convention Hall.

The document, described as revolutionary, was prepared specially for the legislative reference service of the Library of Congress, which is making a special study of the implications of atomic power for Congress.

BOSTON, April 8--"Russian propaganda is at present ruthless, imperialistic, dishonest and dangerous," Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, New York City, asserted today at the National Catholic Education Association's convention.

Accidents in American homes exact a greater toll every two years in killed or injured than the atomic bombs inflicted upon the Japanese, Maj. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, wartime commander of the atomic bomb project, declared last night.

Household fat salvage has increased since last October by 164 per cent, the American Fat Salvage Committee reported yesterday. The increase was attributed to more plentiful supplies of meat and greater conservation by housewives beecause of higher prices paid now for used fats and kitchen greases.

NANKING, April 8--Plans for the sale of many Governmentowned enterprises to private purchasers advanced a stage further today with the publication of regulations control the disposition of state properties.

Swamped by a selling wave in the final hour, prices of shares on the Stock Exchange broke 1 to 3 points yesterday in the broadest market in a month. The sudden avalanche brought the turnover to 1,020,000 shares, with 610,000 changing hands between 2 and 3 o'clock--practically equaling the entire day's business on Monday.

BOSTON, April 8 (AP)--For the second straight year well-balanced boxing forces from Hawaii dominated the National Amateur Athletic Union championship tournament while its bulky starting field of 130 was being reduced to the thirty-two semi-finalists tonight at the Boston Garden.

MUNICH, Germany, April 8-- Pour prominent German stormtroopers charged with organizing an underground movement to preserve the Nazi ideology and German militarism and eventually to seize power, pleaded not guilty before the Military Government's general court here today.

MUENCHEBERG, Germany, April 6 (Delayed)--This town, on the road from Berlin to Frankfort on the Oder, affords an interesting glimpse of life in this area of the Soviet zone. The Russians, for the most part, have gone, leaving only a small Military Government detachment.

WASHINGTON, April 8--A sixweek stay of the principal provisions of an anti-trust decree against leading motion picture producers and distributors was granted by Associate Justice Stanley F. Reed of the United States Supreme Court today.

A special study of magazine coverage in the Buenos Aires market, Argentina, has been approved by the research committee of the Export Advertising Association, Inc., G. Allen Reeder, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday.

The Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation in its annual report to stockholders yesterday, said drilling operations, pipeline runs, refinery output and sales in 1946 were greater than in any prior year. Production of crude oil was the highest since 1929, when allowables were not so restricted.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, today urged a new slash in funds for the Labor Department even as department officials testified that House cuts of nearly $14,000,000 would cripple their activities.

CHICAGO, April 8--Leo Heer, vice president of the National Retail Furniture Association, said tonight: "Retail margins between cost and selling price of home furnishings have been reduced by furniture stores generally on a nation-wide scale to lessen the impact of rising costs.
Tedoro Marquis, 58 years old, who was the victim of a $4,800 robbery, testified yesterday in Kings County Court that he had promised to share the money with a Brooklyn detective if he recovered it.

WASHINGTON, April 8--The Government reported a rise in softcoal production today but a curiously worded message from John L. Lewis to his district leaders threw considerable doubt on the prospects for early termination of the "safety" strike.

A campaign to end the practice of "production printing" of commercial work in public vocational schools throughout the State was announced yesterday by Ralph Wright, executive secretary of the Allied Printing Trades Council of Greater New York.

Intimations that a solution of the country-wide telephone strike might be reached within a few hours leaked out of negotiations in Washington last night as the strike of 340,000 employes of the Bell System ended its second day. The talks were continuing in the early hours today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 8--The War Crimes Court at Rabaul began the trial today of Lieut. Gen. Hatazo Adachi, who was commander of the Eighteenth Japanese Army in New Guinea, on charges of complicity in the war crimes of his subordinates.

In an address that summarized the arguments for American action, Senator Vandenberg yesterday urged Congress to approve immediate aid to Greece and Turkey. With this address he answered Mr. Gromyko, who had voiced the official Russian opposition the day before.

LONDON, April 8 -- The stock markets here today were quiet after the holiday and business decidedly was small. With the end of the account and the budget only a week away, observers said dealings are likely to continue restricted.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., April 8 (AP)-- Stuart B. Allen, 16 years old, the adopted son of the Rev. James S. Allen, rector of Christ Episcopal Church, smiled today as he was ordered held without bond for trial in Juvenile Court for the murder of John Frank, 59 years old, the sexton of the church.

A flight to London with an eye toward a possible opponent for Joe Louis was undertaken yesterday by Nat Rogers, matchmaker for the Twentieth Century Sporting Club. Rogers left LaGuardia Field aboard the Pan American Airways clipper Great Republic.

Events are forcing on Congress important decisions in the field of labor legislation. The winter's truce on the industrial front has been broken. A nation-wide telephone strike has dealt a heavy blow to the nation's business. Mr. Lewis has succeeded to getting most of his miners out of the mines despite a Supreme Court ruling forbidding him to do so.

WASHINGTON, April 8--President Truman withdrew from the Senate calendar today nineteen treaties which have been moldering in the pigeonholes of the Foreign Relations Committee for many years, one since 1910.

WASHINGTON, April 8--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 2, the Federal Reserve Board announced today: An increase of $101,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, decreases of $452,000,000 in holdings of Treasury certificates of indebtedness and $620,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and an increase of $121,000,000 in borrowings.

MOSCOW, April 8--The procedural log jam that had been blocking progress in the Council of Foreign Ministers was broken today by the diplomatic lumberjacking of Secretary of State Marshall of the United States and Foreign Secretary Bevin of Britain.
Lipstick marks made by visitors to the Statue of Liberty reappeared yesterday for the first time since the statue, coated with "lipstick-proof" cream-gray paint, reopened to the public last Friday.

Eleven American-built vessels that will fly the flag of India when that country becomes autonomous have been purchased in the United States for service between India and ports in North America and Europe, it became known here yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, April 8 (Aneta) --Trading was active, following the Easter holidays, and prices were irregular on the Stock Exchange. New highs were made by many of the industrials while Indies plantations issues declined sharply on rather pessimistic reports.
LONDON, April 8--Henry A. Wallace said on his arrival in London today that he had "come to England and Western Europe to discover those forces that must be united on behalf of peace."

HYDERABAD, India, April 8-- Hyderabad, largest and most powerful of the Indian States, envisions an "alliance with whatever Control Government emerges in an independent India," Sir Mirza Ismail. Hyderabad's Premier said today.

SAUGATUCK, Conn., April 8-- Seventy-five women -- "rich and poor, known and unknown"--began working on the manufacture of cable grips promptly at 10 o'clock tonight, in violation of a Connecticut law prohibiting women from employment in industry between 10 P. M. and 6 A. M.
Seeking to focus attention of educators on the function of wholesaling, the National Association of Wholesalers yesterday announced a $1,500 prize contest for outstanding articles on the subject.

Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Cooke, former women's national tennis champion, said yesterday that no decision on a possible appeal of the suspension handed her and Miss Pauline Betz by the United States Lawn Tennis Association would be made until word comes from Miss Betz, now in Europe, The Associated Press reported.

NORWALK, Ohio, April 8 (AP)-- Republican chairman Carroll Reece asserted tonight that President Truman had failed to carry out his promise to cooperate with the Republicans on most questions and has only "gone through the motions" of ridding the Government of subversive employes.

Reports from most of the popular Catskill streams indicate that angling conditions will be excellent on opening day this Saturday "if" the weather does not change drastically during the next three days.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 8 (AP)--An Aeropostal Venezolana two-engined plane crashed in a mountainous region twenty-five miles east of here today, killing all twenty - seven persons aboard. Twenty-one of them were high school students and three were their teachers.

Higher operating costs and increased demands for services from the 423 voluntary hospitals and health and welfare agencies will require more contributions to the campaign of the Greater New York Fund, public officials declared yesterday. The fund is asking $6,000,000 this year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Cigarette smoking, especially since women have taken it up, is becoming more and more annoying. Cannot something be done to prohibit smoking in public eating places? One cannot sit down to eat anywhere, even at fountains, without getting smoke all over one's food, down one's throat and in one's eyes.

WASHINGTON, April 8--Citizens who have been pointing out to the public authorities two seldom -used paths to orderly government in the general welfare are finding support for their position in the fact that telephone service in Virginia and Indiana has continued without interruption during the nation-wide strike of telephone workers.

WASHINGTON, April 8--The Interstate Commerce Commission has before it proposals of transcontinental railroads, ship lines serving Atlantic and Pacific Coast ports, and two ship lines serving Gulf and Pacific Coast ports, for an upward adjustment of their rates on about seventy commodities.

The economic policy of the United States is linked inescapably with its political policy, James Reston, diplomatic correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday in a radio forum discussion of "Must We Have Freer Trade for World Peace?"

After reading about his studies on the vitamin A requirements of whites rats, we called Dr. Henry C. Sherman, Mitchill Professor Emeritus of Chemistry at Columbia University, to inquire further about the significance of his research so far as human beings are concerned.
Prison terms of two to ten years were imposed yesterday by Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions on six East Harlem narcotics peddlers who were members of two of the nation's biggest syndicates.

Contrary to widespread belief, it was established last night that husbands can learn to cook. By donning aprons, ten men who never had cooked before demonstrated their ability to prepare a meal. They ate it, too.

MONTREAL, April 8 (AP)--The International Labor Office released today a survey of immigration regulations in twenty-three countries. The survey disclosed that the majority were facilitating the admission of foreigners whom they deem, "qualified to contribute" to their national economy.

Former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia was named yesterday as the winner of the 1947 One World Award for press and radio. Word of his selection was received by Mr. La Guardia in the high-ceilinged study of his home at 5020 Goodridge Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx.

For the third time since the event first was run in 1940, C. V Whitney's Eton blue silks were carried to victory in the Experimental Free Handicap at Jamaica yesterday when Bastogne led home a field of nine Kentucky Derby nominees before 32,769 witnesses.
ATHENS, April 8--Members of the Greek Government undertook today to refute some of the criticisms directed at the Athens regime since President Truman proposed United States aid to Greece and Turkey.

Leo Milito, 130, East Side, defeated Harry Diduck, 128, the Bronx, in eight rounds at the opening of the new Sunnyside Garden in Queens last night. A crowd of 2,800, including Borough President James A. Burke, was present.

Zino Francescatti, French violinist, whose reputation has been building steadily in this country since his debut here eight years ago, attracted a large audience to Carnegie Hall last night for his only recital of the season. It was not the violinist's first appearance of the season, however, for he has played already as guest soloist with both the New York Philharmonic -Symphony and the Philadelphia Orchestra.

Here and There One of the luckiest afterthoughts in recorded history must be the local weather man's remark on Easter eve, as reported in at least one newspaper. Predicting a chill and wet morning for the church parade, he hastened to add that the boys in the Weather Bureau make no claim to infallibility and the sun might come out, at that, in time for the new hats and suits.

ESSEN, Germany, April 8--In a severe speech reproaching miners' trade union leaders for permitting last week's coal strike, Sir Cecil Weir, president of the economic subcommission of the Control Commission for Germany, warned today that if the upward production trend was not resumed at once, "it will be a national disaster which will affect every German."

Henry Ford was once the hero of the Soviet Union. His death recalls a time in the late Twenties when the American visitor in Russia was proudly taken to factory shows designed to pump up enthusiasm among the workers for the techniques and tempos of the Machine Age.

Unless New York City receives additional financial help from the state it will be compelled to levy new local taxes to meet rising costs of city government, Mayor O'Dwyer warned yesterday at a public hearing on the recordbreaking $1,029,120,314 budget at City Hall.

Invitations for bids and specifications covering drydocking, repairs and limited conversion of the liner Washington, former United States Lines passenger vessel, have been sent to all ship repair yards, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 8--Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg opened debate on the Greek-Turkish aid bill today with a reply to the protests of Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister. He challenged Russia to prove, by deeds as well as by words, that the program was not necessary.

BOWIE, Md., April 8 (AP)--R. A. Connell's Agate, a non-winner for almost two years, dropped down the class ladder today and won the Carnival in Costa Rica claiming: purse before an estimated crowd of 11,000.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 8,500 head, total 12,000: market slow; $1.00 to $1.50 lower compared with Monday's average; closing trade a trifle more active than early; good and choice 180 to 260 pound

Home is the man who made bus riding in the Bronx an adventure and gave to bus passengers there the dream that the fare box may turn into a jackpot with a trip to Florida for a nickel if the right driver comes along.

"The Red Prussian: The Life and Legend of Karl Marx," by Leopold Schwarzchild, author of "World in Trance," has been scheduled by Scribner for May publication. It discusses how Marx developed his philosophy and to what extent Marxism is the result of the prejudices, private animosities and sufferings in one man's 'life.

ALBANY, April 8--At the solicitation of Mayor William O'Dwyer, Governor Dewey approved today a bill that authorizes New York City employes who are war veterans to retire at the age of 50 if they have completed twenty-five years of city service.

The national council of the National Maritime Union, CIO, yesterday chose Chester Young, Charleston, S.C., port agent, to fill the vacancy created by the ousting last Saturday of Joseph Stack as vice president. By an eight to two count, with six members of the council refraining from voting, Mr. Young was picked to serve until a special election is held.
Big brothers 2 to 6 years old escorted sixty-five sisters yesterday at the fifth annual Little Sisters Contest of the Harlem Boys Club, 28 West 134th Street.

MOSCOW, April 8--Under pressure of charges that Russian plans would create a police state in Germany, Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov made his first important concession in the Council of Foreign Ministers tonight. He withdrew "state security" from his proposed list of the powers of Germany's future central government.

Release by the United States Army of the partial minutes of wartime conferences of Hitler and his advisers shows one of the fundamental weaknesses of governments built around one personality: a self-delusion which none of the yes-men dares to dispel. Hitler was a captive of his own propaganda.

LONDON, April 8--Another of Britain's most important labor groups today adopted a resolution condemning the Truman Doctrine regarding Greece and Turkey. This came about at the closing session of the annual conference of the Union of Shop Distributive and Allied Workers in Blackpool.

The national council of the National Maritime Union, CIO, yesterday chose Chester Young, Charleston, S.C., port agent, to fill the vacancy created by the ousting last Saturday of Joseph Stack as vice president. By an eight to two count, with six members of the council refraining from voting, Mr. Young was picked to serve until a special election is held.
Big brothers 2 to 6 years old escorted sixty-five sisters yesterday at the fifth annual Little Sisters Contest of the Harlem Boys Club, 28 West 134th Street.

MOSCOW, April 8--Under pressure of charges that Russian plans would create a police state in Germany, Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov made his first important concession in the Council of Foreign Ministers tonight. He withdrew "state security" from his proposed list of the powers of Germany's future central government.

ATHENS, April 8 (AP)--The Official Journal said today that a contract had been signed between Finance Minister Demetrios Helmis and William Schmidt representing Mines, Inc., of New York, for lead and zinc prospecting and mining operations in Western Thrace.

WASHINGTON, April 8--A special meeting of his Cabinet was called by President Truman today to meet at the White House tomorrow morning to consider the country's price structure. The steady rise in most prices, which Mr. Truman fears may break into an inflationary spiral, has been increasingly occupying the President's attention for several months.

WASHINGTON, April 8--Harry D. White, one of the architects of the Bretton Woods Agreement, covering post-war currency stabilization, resigned today as executive director for the United States on the International Monetary Fund.

Business and other groups rather than the Government should take the lead immediately in driving home the necessity of expanded trade through a comprehensive public relations campaign, George L. Bell, associate director, office of international trade, Department of Commerce, declared yesterday.

Release by the United States Army of the partial minutes of wartime conferences of Hitler and his advisers shows one of the fundamental weaknesses of governments built around one personality: a self-delusion which none of the yes-men dares to dispel. Hitler was a captive of his own propaganda.

LONDON, April 8--Another of Britain's most important labor groups today adopted a resolution condemning the Truman Doctrine regarding Greece and Turkey. This came about at the closing session of the annual conference of the Union of Shop Distributive and Allied Workers in Blackpool.

Langley Collyer was found dead yesterday in his old brownstone home at 2078 Fifth Avenue. His body, wedged in a booby trap set to keep out intruders, was lying in the same room on the second floor where his blind brother, Homer, had been found dead on March 21.
Miss Pauline Betz, women's national tennis champion from Los Angeles, and Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Cooke of New York, former titleholder, have been lost to the amateur ranks.

The presentation of six medals and six certificates of the Boys Clubs of America Junior Book Award will be made to twelve books at a dinner at the Hotel New Yorker on April 17 at 6:30 P. M. The winning books were chosen from 130 that had been selected by forty-three publishers of juvenile books and sent to forty-seven Boys Clubs across the country.

A banking syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co., received yesterday the award of an issue of $2,158,000 of storm water drain and sanitary sewer bonds of Monroe, La., at a bid of 100.035 for a combination of interest coupons representing a net interest cost of 2.208 per cent.

DETROIT, April 8--The body of Henry Ford will lie in state for fourteen hours tomorrow in his beloved Greenfield Village so that thousands from every walk of life may pay homage to the man who more than anyone else helped to make Detroit the industrial heart of America.

WASHINGTON, April 8--Strong support for the War Department's expanding program to make Germany self-sufficient within three years by reviving her exports was given today by two highly placed department officials recently returned from Germany.

March shipments of rayon totaled 78,200,000 pounds, 4 per cent greater than a year ago, it was announced yesterday by the Textile Economics Bureau. For the first three months of the year shipments totaled 224,900,000 pounds, 8 per cent over the 1946 period.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 (AP)-- The Connecticut Light and Power Company, Hartford, Conn., registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission 336,088 shares of $2 preferred and 163,912 shares of $1.90 preferred stock. The shares have no par value and a stated value of $50 each.

The report of the Hoving Corporation and its subsidiaries, issued to stockholders yesterday covering the period from May 24, 1946, the date of its organization, to Jan. 31, 1947, shows a consolidated net profit of $665,919 after all charges.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP)--William A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, was re-elected today and predicted that within five years the nation's airlines "will be very close to all weather operations."

BALTIMORE, April 8--An epic spring exhibition tour, which had begun weeks ago and touched such sun-scorched outposts as Puerto Rico, Venezuela and Cuba, closed on a somewhat frosty but still triumphant note today as the Yankees flattened Tommy Thomas' Orioles, 7 to 3.

An error and Jack Kearney's double in the first half of the ninth enabled Hofstra College to defeat St. John's University, 3 to 2, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday. It was the opening league game of the season for St. John's.

The United States Lines Company yesterday raised the annual dividend rate of its common stock to $2 from $1 a share, announcing that its earnings for the first quarter of this year increased $1,125,883 over the corresponding period of 1946.

MOSCOW, Apirl 8--Anglo-Soviet negotiations on their bilateral treaty are proceeding slowly in the shadow of the Council of Foreign Ministers as part of a series of bilateral talks and dickerings on the sidelines.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- The Navy announced today that a force of carriers, cruisers and destroyers was tentatively scheduled to visit Sydney, Australia, next month.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 8--Representatives of twenty-four nations listened intently today as Senator Alben W. Barkley, leader of the United States delegation to the conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union, called for tolerance of shortcomings of the United Nations and for respect for the BigFive's right of veto.

Cotton, shantung, pure silk and crepe fashions brought a foretaste of summer yesterday to the Zachary Bogert Cotton Shop showing at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. Running the gamut from beach togs to evening wear, the summer fashions were generally marked with swishing fullness in the skirts and seen in crisp white, delicate pastels and vivid prints.
LONDON, April 8 -- Scotch whisky distillers will return to a pre-war rate of production, 30,000,000 gallons, next year, according to assurances from the Government, it was learned today.

SHEFFIELD, Ala., April 8--The Giants bounced back on the winning trail when they shut out the Indians today, 4 to 0, in the teeth of a gale that kicked up dust clouds on barren Reynolds Field, but they paid a tremendous price for the triumph.

Container Corporation Walter P. Paepke, chairman of the board of the Container Corporation, coupled a report of improved first quarter earnings with a note of caution at the annual meeting at Chicago yesterday. He estimated earnings at $3,182,000 compared with $1,032,000 for the comparable 1946 period.

Bulk of the merchandise price cuts to consumers thus far have reflected retail departmental promotions, clearances and renewal of store-wide sales practices such as dollar-day events, it was reported here yesterday in retail circles.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 9 -- Responsibility for the first phase of the United Nations disarmament work was referred to the five great powers today by the Commission on Conventional Armaments.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Production of frequency modulation radio receivers during the current year will run between 1,800,000 and 2,100,000, according to a report issued here today by a special committee of the Radio Manufacturers Association, based on a study of industry prospects.

An improvement in supplies of hot rolled steel sheet was reported here yesterday from, several industrial sources. A confidential memorandum of the Pressed Metal Institute contained assurances that there is likely to be a modification of the "present stringency" in hot rolled sheet, according to Tom J. Smith, executive vice president.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 9 -- With the Soviet Union and Poland abstaining, the United Nations Security Council voted today to refer the Corfu Channel mine disputs between Britain and Albania to the International Court of Justice. It is the first case referred to the court since it was re-established at The Hague one year ago next week.
Police for Peace To promote Anglo-American friendship Britain could send us no better qualified emissary than a member of the Yorkshire County Police, with the possible exception to be noted later.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 -- A drive for higher wages by its affiliates everywhere was endorsed by the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations, in a policy statement adopted at its biennial convention here today.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Mrs. Addison B. Green of Holyoke, Mass., president of the National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs, tonight defended her party against "the recent outcry of high 'Republican prices.'"

The nation-wide telephone strike grew out of union demands for higher wages, the union shop, increased pensions, longer vacations, shortening of the time required to reach top pay levels, and other concessions.

Leo Durocher, manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, yesterday was suspended for the 1947 season by Commissioner A.B. (Happy) Chandler in the most drastic action ever taken against a major league baseball pilot.

Independent apparel and furnishings stores were urged yesterday to cut mark-ups during the critical period of price adjustment, according to a statement by Henry Modell, head of Modell Stores. Such action by independents and smaller merchants, he said, would be the real starting point for general price reductions and in many instances will be the factor enabling the retailer to remain in business.

The Federal Public Housing Authority announced yesterday award of $25,260,000 of temporary loan notes in behalf of fifteen local housing authorities at bids ranging from 0.82 per cent to 0.86 per cent. Excepting $1,685,000 of Buffalo, N.Y., notes maturing Nov. 25, all notes will come due May 4, 1948.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is unfortunate that Delbert Clark's dispatch of March 27 and the accompanying headline printed on page 4 of your edition of March 28 should give the impression that American Military Government officials have allowed a Nazi to dominate the Bavarian educational system.

ALBANY, April 9 -- New York State's stand-by residential rent control law, which got a brief tryout last summer during the temporary suspension of the Office of Price Administration, is continued in force for another year under a bill approved today by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey.

NEWARK, N.J., April 9 -- New Jersey's achievements as the pioneer pottery state are indicated in an exhibition here of 250 examples of ceramic wares made in colonial days and the nineteenth century. The display opened today at the Newark Museum.

Twelve hundred Brooklyn children from the Red Hook and Navy Yard districts, including eighty orphans and crippled youngsters, were enthusiastic spectators yesterday at the annual Easter Week Carnival sponsored by the Police Athletic League at the St. George Playhouse, 100 Pineapple Street, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Describing preparedness as "our only sane insurance against war -- our first line of self-defense," T.P. Archer, vice president of General Motors Corporation and chairman of the Navy Industrial Association's committee on industrial mobilization, pleaded today for prompt and effective conversion of industry and its scientific talents to the needs of its armed services in the event of war."
BERLIN, April 9 -- Allied military forces, working with German police, suddenly started tonight a twenty-four-hour search throughout Berlin for "criminal elements."

William J. Boers Sr., a member of the composing room staff of The New York Post for sixty years before his retirement in 1942, died yesterday at the age of 87 in his home at 1115 Dorchester Road, Brooklyn.

Maintaining a higher percentage gain than other types of retail distributors, sales of leading mail order and chain store concerns increased 21 per cent during March, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
LONDON, April 9 -- More than 300,000 Britons are waiting to emigrate to the Dominions, according to figures disclosed here today by officials of Australia, South Africa, New Zealand and Canada.

Appointment of forty-four official delegates to represent American Lutheran churches at the meeting of Lutherans from twentyeight countries to be held at Lund, Sweden, June 30 to July 6, was announced here yesterday.
PARIS, April 9 -- The Count of Paris, pretender to the former throne of France, joined his voice of those of Socialists, Communists and Henry Wallace in denunciation of Charles de Gaulle today.

Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra is paying its respects to Brahms in its final New York concerts of the season this week. The occasion, of course, is that this year marks the fiftieth anniversary of Brahms' death.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, made the first argument today in behalf of the new Federal aid-to-education bill in a preliminary hearing before the Senate Subcommittee on Education.

Mayor O'Dwyer and his colleagues on the Board of Estimate basked yesterday in the sunshine of lavish praise from the same labor unions of city employes -- both CIO and AFL -- that last year served upon them aggressive and even truculent demands for higher pay for municipal workers.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Administration has lost its gamble on the quick passage of the GreekTurkish loan bill, and as a result of that gamble has placed one of the immediate purposes of the Truman Doctrine in jeopardy.
PARIS, April 9 -- In view of the disorders in varying degrees in several parts of France's overseas Union, the Cabinet acted today to increase the army by about 220,000 men.

MOSCOW, April 9 -- Secretary of State Marshall proposed today the revision of the pre-war GermanPolish boundaries to serve the needs of both Poland and the general economy of Europe.
