His proposal caused a sharp split in the Council of Foreign Ministers on one of the most important aspects of the question of Germany's future frontiers.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 4,500 head, total 7,500: market fairly active: weights 260 pounds and down opened strong to mostly 25 cents higher: later trade 25 to 50 cents above Tuesday's average:
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- A proposal for settlement of that part of the country-wide telephone strike which affects the 20,000 long-distance telephone workers was agreed to at 11:30 o'clock tonight.

The San Francisco Symphony Orchestra arrived in New York yesterday morning for its first visit since it was organized in 1911. Under the leadership of Pierre Monteux it will give a concert tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall.

We have received a number of letters soliciting our help in solving the problem of where to put an automobile in New York City when it is not in use. Some are irate over what they regard as profiteering by garage operators. Some want overnight parking in residential areas made legal.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- A bill proposing the establishment of a nine-man committee of publishers and newsprint producers, with power to act voluntarily to relieve the need of publications lacking sufficient newsprint supplies, was introduced today by Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican, of Indiana.

BOSTON, Mass., April 9 -- The right of parents to choose the teachers of their children must not be infringed, Archbishop Richard J. Cushing of Boston told the convention of the National Catholic Education Association tonight.
All along the line yesterday where dial service was available in the metropolitan area the telephone strike seemed to make no appreciable inroads on business or in the social scheme.

THE stories in "The Purple Testament"* were never intended for publication in the first place at all. They deal with all kinds of subjects and were written by all kinds of people. One is about a girl who could find no other lodging for the night but a cot in a jail. Another is about ranch life in Montana. Another is about a Sunday trip from California across the border into Mexico.

Eudice Shapiro, violinist, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. In a comprehensive program ranging from Beethoven to the moderns, the gifted artist held her performances on a consistently high level. Her playing was always sane, musical and intelligent, as well as technically secure.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- In a brief, anti-climactic action this evening the United States Atomic Energy Commission rode out months of stormy controversy and was confirmed in fact by the Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- Baldwin R. Bane, director of the corporation finance division of Securities and Exchange Commission, clarified, in a letter made public today, the circumstances under which warrants issued to underwriters and certain other persons may be registered under the Securities Act of 1933.

The driver of a stolen automobile was killed late yesterday in the New York-bound section of the Lincoln Tunnel when the car, traveling at high speed and zig-zagging through slower moving traffic in an effort to outdistance pursuing policemen, crashed into a wall of the tube and overturned.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate today confirmed David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission: FOR CONFIRMATION -- 50 Republicans -- 20
With trading moderately active, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 28 to 42 points net higher yesterday, slightly off from the best levels of the day.

PARIS, April 9 (AP) -- Miss Pauline Betz, barred from amateur tennis by the United States Lawn Tennis Association, arrived from Monte Carlo. While still undecided about future plans, she declared the suspension "sort of nudges me toward professionalism."

PITTSBURGH, April 9 -- Coal operators in western Pennsylvania and presumably mine operators in other areas have received word from the Coal Mines Administration that it has no plan for any immediate inspections of mines except the 518 declared unsafe by J.A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior.

LONDON, April 9 -- Henry A. Wallace, editor of The New Republic, warned today, at one of the best - attended press conferences ever held here, that "there is being established in the next three months a kind of pattern which, if it hardens, will lead to war."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 9 -- Byron Price, United Nations Assistant Secretary General for administrative and financial services, said today that the appeals board recently set up to hear the grievances of dismissed workers was only the first of several steps to improve troubled employe relations here.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- As a result of studies made by Task Forces Williwaw and Frigid under severe conditions in Alaska and the Aleutians, the Army has learned it must scrap much standard equipment and develop special new items for military operations in the Arctic.

Senator Brien McMahon of Connecticut, author of the Atomic Energy Act, declared last night that any nation that refused to enter into a fair and reasonable plan for atomic control -- and he indicated he felt the American plan was fair and reasonable -- was committing an actual act of aggression.

BOSTON, April 9 (AP) -- Taking over when the favored Hawaiians forces faltered, the Cincinnati and California delegations collected two individual championships each as the National Amateur, Athletic Union closed its most successful boxing tournament in history tonight before a crowd of 13,371 at the Boston Garden.

A major change in pricing grinding wheels, one of the principal lines in the industrial supply field, has been made by the Norton Company, Worcester, Mass., R.M. Johnson, vice president, disclosed yesterday.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 9 -- The twin villages of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown, long in the hands of entrenched Republican and Democratic machines, faced political housecleaning today.

TOKYO, April 9 -- Apparently the Allied "purge directives" will really do some purging. Broadened since Japan's election a year ago, they have begun to bite deeply into the ranks of those who plan to run this month for the Diet.

A striking telephone girl returned to one of the Newark exchanges yesterday to ask her chief operator: "Can I get every day off from 1 P.M. to 3 P.M. if I go back to my position?" The chief operator wondered why she needed all the time off.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The question raised by Secretary Schwellenbach with regard to measures against communism in this country is important. As all careful observers have come to know, the open activities of the Communist party in the United States are merely a screen behind which agents of the Comintern operate in efforts to slow up our industrial production by causing and envenoming labor disputes.

CINCINNATI, April 9 -- The text of Commissioner Chandler's decision suspending Leo Durocher, follows: On March 15, 1947, L.S. MacPhail, president of the American League Baseball Club of New York, Inc., placed in the hands of the commissioner a request for a hearing to determine whether:
VIENNA, April 9 -- Estimates available here indicate that the United States at Moscow offered to give Austria approximately $115,000,000.

NANKING, April 9 -- A spokesman of the Chinese Ministry of Information retorted with a complete denial tonight to a Tass [official Soviet news agency] dispatch alleging extensive United States military assistance to China since the end of the war.
Former Mayor F.H. La Guardia yesterday charged criminal negligence and timidity against the present city administration in the care of La Guardia Field and the development of Idlewild Airport.
Well-known New York stores will participate in the creation of a new streamlined shopping center on upper Michigan Avenue in Chicago, it became known here last night.

STUTTGART, Germany, April 9 -- Pale and thin, but bristling angrily, Hjalmar Schacht defied a German denazification tribunal to prove the charge that he was a "major Nazi offender." He declared he was proud to have taken part in four plots to overthrow Adolf Hitler.
The problems of an adequate intelligence system are major and many; not all of them can be discussed openly but all of them ought to be studied carefully by Congress.

The popular vacuum coffee pot has been made almost exclusively in glass. Recently, however, it appeared in aluminum, and today you'll find an excellent model at Gimbels in stainless steel. This can't break or crack or discolor, and may be handled in the dishpan as roughly as you please.

LONDON, April 9 (AP) -- Dai Rees and Charlie Ward, British professionals who returned recently from playing the United States winter golf circuit, were among the leaders today in the opening round of the British season's first big tournament.

Net income of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company was $27,726,780 last year after all charges, including $13,138,442 provision for taxes, according to the sixty-ninth annual statement, issued yesterday. The net was equal to $3.62 a share of capital stock.

An exhibition of Latin-American painting will open at the Knoedler Galleries with a preview on April 21 and to the public the next day and continue through May 10. While the exhibition does not propose toc over the Latin-American field, it will include fifty paintings.
MOSCOW, April 9 -- Ambassador, Robert D. Murphy of the United States commented indirectly today on the lateness of Soviet participation in the Japanese phase of World War II.

Contrasting with weakness in the closing hour on Tuesday, prices if shares yesterday on the Stock Exchange were steady and quiet through most of the session. Fluctuations were narrow and prices at the close erased part of earlier losses.

William Cimillo, the 37-year-old bus driver who abandoned his Bronx route on March 28 and drove an $18,000 bus to Hollywood, Fla., was described as a "bookmaker in debt" by Bronx Chief Assistant District Attorney Sylvester Ryan yesterday.

Wool Yarns More Plentiful Wool yarns in colors are in better supply, according to knitted outerwear manufacturers yesterday. Availability of these yarns will mean a more varied selection of both sweater and knitted bathing suits this season, it was indicated.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Panama, April 4 -- Study of aerial photographs aboard the homeward-bound ships of the Navy's Antarctic task force has indicated that retreat of the Antarctic icecap is far more advanced than had previously been believed.

ATHENS, Thursday, April 10 (AP) -- Greek Government troops, supplied and supported from the air, were reported today to be attempting the encirclement of a Leftist guerrilla force of about 3,000 men in the wild mountainous region separating Thessaly from Epirus.

The four-story building containing two stores and six apartments at 77-79 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, has been acquired by Manuel Fernandez from the estate of Tillie Levy through Meyer A. Leibow, broker.

HOLLYWOOD, April 9 (U.P.) -- Frank Sinatra was arrested in the middle of a tune today and hauled off to court, where he pleaded not guilty to a charge of hitting Lee Mortimer, New York columnist, outside Ciro's restaurant last night. The singer accused the columnist of insulting him.

BOSTON, April 9 -- With its Mayor, James M. Curley, under Federal sentence for mail fraud, Boston learned that the president of its City Council, John B. Kelly, was indicted today by a grand jury on charges of bribe solicitation and attempted larceny, together with another Councilman, Joseph M. Scannell.
Children no longer keep parents from getting divorced, Chester Rohrlich, president of the Jewish Child Care Association of New York, declared yesterday.

The urgent need for women to serve voluntarily as leaders of senior Girl Scout troops was announced yesterday as 500 senior Scouts, members of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, met for their third annual conference at the Needle Trades High School, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.

Strawberry-colored sawdust -- a new shade -- blanketed the arena. The three mammoth wooden rings blazed with bright golden leaves. Elephants by the dozens trumpeted joyous welcome. Up in the dome, young men and women in gaudy costume were more daring than ever; clowns leaped and tumbled, reveled and rollicked.
ALBANY, April 9 -- The adjutant general released the following National Guard orders today: Campbell. Maj. W.J., 106th Inf., to headquarters as S-3.

The former Army transport Sea Flasher, one of twenty-four ships bought by the Isthmian Steamship Lines from the Maritime Commission, is nearing completion of her reconversion in the Brooklyn plant of Todd Shipyards Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

Public Relations men should regard their job as a phase of management and cease referring to themselves as members of a profession, John C. Long, manager of publications, Bethlehem Steel Company, declared yesterday.

Joseph Pulitzer, whose fiery genius had a profound effect on American journalism, was born a hundred years ago today. He helped greatly to give our press two things on which it still builds a growing influence: mass circulation and a rugged independence of political or any other outside control.
ATHENS, April 9 -- Large-scale operations, with the whole army of the North and units of the navy and air force taking part, were launched against the Greek guerrilla bands today.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- John D. Goodloe today was elected chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, succeeding Charles B. Henderson, who resigned on the advice of his physicians. Mr. Henderson's resignation was accepted as to the chairmanship but not as to membership on the board of directors.
GENEVA, April 9 -- At 3 P.M. tomorrow the biggest horse-trading session in history will get formally under way.

Passenger shipping activity along the New York waterfront resem bled pre-war days yesterday as four liners, including two of the world's foremost luxury ships sailed from North River piers and a fifth vessel arrived.
CANADIAN, Tex., April 9 (AP) -- A tornado raked three Texas and Oklahoma towns tonight, killing an estimated fifty-two persons and injuring hundreds.

A steady rise in applications from Jewish war veterans who seek to become farm owners is noted in the forty-seventh annual report of the Jewish Agricultural Society, issued yesterday by Dr. Gabriel Davidson, its managing director.

Four New York newspapers suffered slowdowns or work stoppages in their composing rooms yesterday, apparently as the result of dissatisfaction on the part of members of Local 6, International Typographical Union, with an offer made Tuesday by the Publishers Association of New York.

There were some smiling baseball fans in Brooklyn yesterday but they were careful to consume beer, borsht or ice cream in the secrecy of their homes. For last night the taverns of Platbush Avenue, the matzoth-ball dispensaries of Pitkin Avenue and the confectionery shops of Fulton Street were no fit places for Giant addicts.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The welfare and retirement fund which the United Mine Workers won last spring after a two months' soft coal strike will start paying its first benefits within the next thirty days.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Progress of the housing program and other new construction is lagging far behind Government forecasts of last November and is not likely to reach the goal set for 1947, official figures revealed today.

Giordano's "Andrea Chenier," revived last night by the New York City Opera Company, is a work primarily for singing actors. It requires for its best estate a big stage, lusty voices and expert histrionism. Although the opera had not all these advantages last night, it was given, lustily and to a very responsive audience.

Langley Collyer was asphyxiated, probably smothered by debris that fell on him, Dr. Thomas A. Gonzales, Medical Examiner, reported yesterday after an autopsy. Dr. Gonzales said that Langley had been dead about a month and had definitely died before Homer.
A furniture department filling an entire floor at McCreery's with model rooms, new furniture and striking accessories was opened yesterday at a press preview.
A conciliation meeting, which resulted in no apparent progress, was held yesterday between the Western Electric Company and representatives of the striking Western Electric Employes Association.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the Communist party, defied a subpoena of the House Committee on Un-American Activities today and was at once cited for contempt.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- Proposals advanced by railroads to reduce loss from damage claims due to inadequate boxing are "fundamentally wrong," W.B. Lincoln Jr., technical manager, Inland Container Corporation, Indianapolis, Ind., declared here today.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and Gov. Robert F. Bradford of Massachusetts exchanged information on fiscal relations between States and municipalities, education, veterans' housing and labor management relations at a conference tonight in the Executive Mansion.

The series of conferences which gets under way today in Geneva, Switzerland, represents a definite and important stage in the evolution of a world program devised to breathe life into the philosophy of economic cooperation. This program had its origins in the Anglo-American agreement published Dec. 6, 1945, coincident with the announcement of the British loan.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- Owen C. Lavery, 35, of Wilkes Barre, Pa., an injured veteran of the Seabees, told the Federal District Court here today that he had spent almost two years doing odd jobs because his union suspended him three months after he entered the service for non-payment of dues.

Undaunted by a new state law providing jail sentences and fines for utility strikers, 12,000 striking New Jersey telephone operators remained away from their jobs yesterday. They were joined in their defiance by nearly three-quarters of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company's 2,500 accounting employes, but most of the 6,100 maintenance men and clerical workers returned to work.

Who is going to take over responsibility for 50,000 displaced persons when UNRRA ceases operating June 30? The International Refugee Organization, formed to assume this task, has been approved by twelve nations, including the United States, but so far none of the sponsors has appropriated funds to carry it out.
Cost of fabric in house dresses retailing for $4 or less represent more than 50 per cent of the total garment cost, Max J. Lovell, director -counsel of the House Dress Institute, asserted yesterday.
A record number of 10,000,000 stamps of the Joseph Pulitzer commemorative issue have been requested by the New York Postoffice for the first day sale of the stamp, according to Postoffice officials.

The Administration has shown marked concern during the past fortnight over the continuing upward trend in prices. The President expressed apprehension on this point in a press conference last March 26, and yesterday he summoned his Cabinet in a special session to listen to a report by Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, dealing with the situation and its possible implications.

NORFOLK, Va., April 9 -- With two holds flooded and a twenty-sixfoot gash extending almost to her main deck, the United States Lines freighter American Farmer made Hampton Roads this afternoon under her own power after being in collision with the collier Pittsburgh Seam in thick weather off Parramore Banks whistle buoy this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- The Philadelphia Electric Company contemplates a $200,000,000 expansion program, it was announced today by Horace P. Liversidge, president, at the company's annual meeting. Cash resources on hand, he said, make early new financing unnecessary.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 9 -- Sayid Awani Khalidy, Iraqi representative in the United Nations Trusteeship Council, and Francis B. Sayre of the United States, the Council's president, declared today in favor of ''the fullest measure of publicity" for the Council's meetings.

MOSCOW, April 9 (AP) -- The text of a statement by Secretary of State Marshall to the Council of Foreign Ministers: The time has now come for the Council of Foreign Ministers to examine the problem of the final determination of the Polish-German boundary.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 9 (AP) -- William M. Hickey, president of the United Corporation, recessed the company's annual meeting today until April 30, saying he wanted to allow time for the inspector of elections to count proxies to determine whether a quorum was present.

JERUSALEM, April 9 -- By legislative decree the Palestine Government conferred on itself today the powers of military dictatorship exercised by the British Army during the recent period of statutory martial law in parts of the country.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 9 -- Fourteen nations -- exactly half of the required majority of twentyeight -- have informed the United Nations that they are in favor of holding a special session of the General Assembly to appoint a fact-finding board on Palestine, Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today.

WALTERBORO, S.C., April 9 -- Marion A. Savage of Scotia, N.Y., a consulting engineer for the General Electric Company, who won the Lamme Gold Medal in 1938 for his work on large high-speed turbine generators, died here today at his birthplace, where he was visiting relatives.

Edward E. Watts Jr., attorney, was elected president of the Travelers Aid Society of New York yesterday at its forty-second annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He succeeeds Donald S. Stralem, who has been head of the society for seven years and will continue as a member of the board of directors.

Charges that the Government's seizure of the General Aniline and Film Corporation in 1942 as alien property was "improper" and that the Government is running the company to the detriment of the interests of minority stockholders were made yesterday at the annual meeting of the company by Eugene L. Garey, stockholder and lawyer.
DETROIT, April 9 -- More than 75,000 persons paid their respects to Henry Ford today as his body lay in state in the Recreation Hall in Greenfield Village.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- If the State Department, and also some persons who are sincerely devoted to the purpose of the Vandenberg amendment to the Greek-Turkish aid legislation, will allow its author to sit down quietly by himself and make the document express what he wants it to express, the amendment may finally be so worded.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- Howard Guttman, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, questioned today the authority of Helmer Hansen, attorney for the Standard Gas and Electric Company, to take part in a hearing on corporate simplification proceedings instituted against the Philadelphia company.

The suspension this season of Manager Leo Durocher of the Dodgers checked temporarily one of the most hectic careers in baseball, a career highlighted by great triumphs and bitter disappointments, by brawls and arguments, by fines and court actions.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 9 -- Darryl F. Zanuck, vice president in charge of production at Twentieth Century-Fox, announced today that his studio will produce a film dealing with Russian espionage in the United States and Canada under the title "The Iron Curtain."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 9 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, smilingly brushed aside today as "decidedly untrue" rumors that he might resign and that he had displayed partiality toward the Soviet Union. He announced that he was sending William H. Stoneman, his personal assistant, to Geneva to investigate "the origin" of other rumors regarding the secretariat assigned to the Balkan investigating commission.

Plans for the establishment of a cooperative, non-profit national film center to organize and expand the use and distribution of nontheatrical motion pictures on behalf of labor and civic groups were announced yesterday by Robert Delson, motion-picture and labor attorney and chairman of the provisional executive committee.
LONDON, April 9 -- No country in the world will be watching the results of the International Trade Conference that opens in Geneva tomorrow with more anxiety than Britain.
LONDON, April 9 -- The British Ministry of Supply confirmed today that nearly 500 British fighting planes of World War II types had been sold to Turkey and were in process of delivery.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department announced today that producer prices of fluid milk in four major northeastern marketing areas will decline the equivalent of 1 cent a quart May 1. The reduction will be effective May through June.
DETROIT, April 9 -- In identical moves, the Ford Motor Company and the Foremen's Association of America advised one another today that each was terminating its contract on May 9.

Almost anything can happen along that strip of sand known to surfcasters and Tar Heels as the "Banks," which stretches from "Thah to thah" along the North Carolina coast. And, according to Bill Sharpe, it usually does.

ALBANY, April 9 (AP) -- Former United States. Senator James M. Mead of Buffalo has started drawing a state pension that will pay him about $4,500 annually for the rest of his life. The State Employes Retirement System, which confirmed today that he had applied for pension payment, reported that Mr. Mead had contributed more than $22,000 to the fund.

LONDON, April 9 -- A month's study of Britain has convinced a delegation of the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union that there are many "influential individuals and groups" in Britain "irreconcilably hostile to the Soviet Union and other peace-loving countries."

Mindful of the success of Maurice Chevalier's one-man show, Allen Adler is planning a program of entertainment with Ethel Waters as the sole artist, it was learned yesterday. If the plan materializes, Miss Waters would be seen and heard in a cavalcade of songs tracing her thirty-odd years in show business.
The New York Knickerbockers made their way into the semi-final round of the Basketball Association of America's championship play-offs at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

The Furness Bermuda Line's hopes that it might soon get back into its pre-war luxury service between New York and Bermuda, which were hit so hard by the recent fire in England aboard the Monarch of Bermuda, were somewhat buoyed yesterday by the announcement that the British Ministry of Shipping had agreed to release the Queen of Bermuda, a sister ship, from Government service.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The War Department has spelled out a concept of a national intelligence service for the atomic age that would be designed to prevent an "atomic Pearl Harbor" which "might well cost us our life as a nation."

Securities Loot Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange once again have passed the word along to their customers' brokers and other employes to be on guard against "looted" securities, i.e., stocks and bonds obtained by illegal means from their owners at the time of the war in occupied or enemy countries of Europe.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., April 9 -- Byron Clark Jr., New York attorney and insurance company president, died here today in the United Hospital of the effects of gashes on his wrists and neck and an overdose of sleeping medicine. Dr. Amos O. Squire, County Medical Examiner, ruled tonight he had committed suicide.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The House Republican leaders approved today and substantially insured the final passage next week of an omnibus bill to smash the closed shop and industry-wide bargaining and arm the Government to put down by injunction "public interest" strikes.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 9 (AP) -- A secret stockholders' vote, in which two factions attempted to gain control of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, was held today in the First District courtroom here.

Fashions keyed to the month of June and the Lohengrin wedding march were offered by B. Altman Co. yesterday in a showing on Lts third floor. There were fashions for the bride and her attendants for a simple ceremony or a large church or garden wedding.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Everybody clamors for lower prices, but precious little is done about it. There have been sporadic attempts to readjust our far too high price level, but the results have been nil. Except in a few isolated instances, the inflated price line is stubbornly held, with consequences that are now becoming painfully apparent to all.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Truman was accused by House Republican spokesmen today of inconsistency in his Communist containment policy and of turning a deaf ear to national demands for corrective labor laws and tax reduction, as well as more economical government.

Total advertising in all New York newspapers during the first three months of this year aggregated 33,899,762 lines, compared with 28,422,371 in the similar period last year, or a gain of 19.27 per cent, according to a compilation of Media Record figures.

HICKORY, N.C., April 9 -- A two-run homer by Bill Rigney clinched a 7-4 verdict over the Cleveland Indians today at Lenoir Rhyne Field before a crowd of about 4,500, as the Giants continue the latest of Manager Mel Ott's spring experiments.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 -- With the way opened by a Supreme Court decision last Monday, R. Stanley Dollar said today that he and his group of stockholders in American President Lines would press an early fight in Federal District Court to try to prove that they are rightful owners of 92 per cent stock control now held by the Maritime Commission.
ATHENS, April 9 -- The new King, Paul I of the Hellenes, in an interview with this correspondent today, put the blame for his country's troubles on foreign intervention and Communist leadership.

The Democratic State Committee will give a dinner for Mayor O'Dwyer at the Commodore Hotel Monday evening, May 26, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State chairman, announced yesterday at a luncheon for newspaper reporters at the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Lewis B. Schwellenbach, Secretary of Labor, and Edgar L. Warren, director of conciliation, pleaded before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today for funds refused them by the House.

Stocks of gasoline in the nation last week declined 610,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 106,966,000 barrels, compared with 107,576,000 barrels a week earlier and 103,687,000 on April 6, 1946.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- For an hour and forty minutes today President Truman and his Cabinet discussed with the President's Council of Economic Advisers the economic situation in which the country finds itself today. Much of the emphasis was placed on the national price structure but no attempt was made to devise remedial action, it was stated.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses placed on display yesterday at City Hall a model of the Manhattan approaches to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel and the proposed development of Battery Park, at the southern tip of Manhattan. Members of the Board of Estimate had a close-up of the model at an executive meeting late in the afternoon.

MEXICO CITY, April 9 -- Gov. Hugo Pedro Gonzalez of the State of Tamaulipas has been removed from office, Minister of Interior Dr. Hector Perez Martinez announced tonight. An influential editor in that state was assassinated ten days ago.

City officials joined yesterday with philanthropists and Protestant leaders throughout the city in endorsing a campaign for $1,095,000 to meet the combined needs of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, Inc., and the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc.

THAT was a mighty drastic sentence that Commissioner Happy Chandler meted out to Leo Durocher yesterday. It almost seems as though Chandler, irked no end by steady criticism that inferred he was a lightweight in a heavyweight's job, decided to flex his muscles and show how strong he is. The penalty appears to be unnecessarily severe because it may result in Durocher's being read out of baseball.

HYDERABAD, India, April 9 -- It is a sign of India's political times that Sir Mirza Ismail, topranking "face-lifter" of the Indian Princely States has entered the service of His Exalted Highness, the Nizam of Hyderabad and Berar, who is said by some guessers to be the world's richest man.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- President Truman, in high good humor, received today his annual American League baseball pass. The southpaw Chief Executive, who is expected to throw the first ball at Washington's opening game against the Yankees Monday, also got a wallet in which to keep the pass.

The city Health Department and the United States Public Health Service joined yesterday in a widespread and difficult job of health detective work in connection with the current outbreak of smallpox in New York.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- John W. Hanes, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, predicted today that the Federal budget for the current fiscal year would be overbalanced by from $3,000,000,000 to $4,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Navy Department, it was learned today, believes that discoveries as revolutionary as the atomic bomb are necessary before atomic rockets can be flung across oceans in a "push-button" war.

The $12,000,000 national drive of the American Cancer Society received a welcome impetus yesterday afternoon when a check for $250,000 was presented to the society in behalf of the Damon Runyon Memorial Fund at a brief ceremony at the Stork Club, 3 East Fifty-third Street.
LONDON, April 9 -- Apart from the strength of Brazilian bonds and the weakness of British Government stocks, the stock markets today generally were dull and featureless.

MOSCOW, April 9 -- According to reliable diplomatic sources, the Soviet Government has proposed to the United Kingdom that a clause be included in the revised AngloRussian treaty that would effectively isolate that country diplomatically from the United States.

William Helis' 3-year-old End of Strife is no candidate for triplecrown honors, but he was good enough at Jamaica yesterday to beat three Kentucky Derby nominees in the same time marked up by the winner of the Experimental Handicap on the previous afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The $400,000,000 Greek-Turkish aid bill and the foreign policy behind it underwent sharp attack by three Republicans in the Senate today. However, only one, Senator Harlan J. Bushfield of South Dakota, announced that he would vote against the measure.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman voiced unequivocal support for the American plan to aid Greece and Turkey last night even as he asked that the United Nations be strengthened to make it an "effective and powerful weapon" for lasting peace and security.

ALBANY, April 10 -- New York University is entitles to receive from State Controller Frank C. Moore $2,226.72 which the City of New York awarded it in 1916 for the city's appropriation of five parcels of land in West 180th Street, between Aqueduct Avenue and Osborne Place.

Unless Americans help other nations in restoring their shattered economies and raising their, standards of living, there can be no lasting peace, no security for this country, Nelson A. Rockefeller, former Assistant Secretary of State, declared yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 10 -- Warren R. Austin told the Security Council today that the Vandenberg amendment, which gives the United Nations power to halt the $400,000,000 GreekTurkish aid program, was proof that the Government and the people of the United States had the "firm determination" to uphold the world organization.

Participation of most of the city's official departments in the forthcoming spring clean-up drive was promised yesterday to the members of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association during a reception and cocktail party at Matchabelli's, 711 Fifth Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., April 10 -- The creation of separate juvenile courts for the entire nation was recommended tonight as part of a program to combat child delinquency. Judge George W. Smyth of the Westchester County Children's Court, New York, said that these full-time judges must be specialists in their fields.
SECURITY COUNCIL Continued discussion of United States plan to aid Greece and Turkey, hearing statements by Warren R. Austin of the United States among others.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- During the week ended April 9, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, member bank reserve balances increased $394,000,000.

A total of 4,098 blind persons, including forty-eight veterans who lost their sight in World War II, were helped in 1946 "to live normal, useful and full lives" at The Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, it was announced yesterday.

Irwin S. and Henry I. Chanin, builders and realty operators. took title yesterday to the West Side car barns of the Third Avenue Railway System occupying the blockfront on the west side of Tenth Avenue, from Fifty-third to Fifty-fourth Streets.

Advertisers are entitled to a really effective standardized method of radio research rather than the many systems currently in force, Archibald Crossley, president of Crossley, Inc., said yesterday during a meeting of the radio luncheon group of the American Marketing Asosciation in the Hotel Sheraton.

Libby, McNeill Libby, food canners, had net earnings of $4,935,083 after taxes and all charges, in the fiscal year ended on March 1, Daniel W. Creeden, president, reported yesterday. The earnings equal $1.36 a share and compare with $3,882,270 or $1.07 a share reported for the previous fiscal year.

Random notes. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service will hold a series of public conferences in all "key" cities throughout the country between May 1 and June 2 to discuss waterfowl problems and hunting regulations with State officials, conservation agencies and sportsmen's groups.

Mayor O'Dwyer and his colleagues on the Board of Estimate listened yesterday afternoon to twenty-one speakers who asked higher wages and better working conditions in various city departments. It was the fourth day on which the board heard comment on the proposed city budget of $1,029,120,314 for the next fiscal year.

LOS ANGELES, April 10 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the American Society of Professional Automobile Racing said today they had received authorization from owners of twenty-eight racing cars to withhold their entries in the annual Indianapolis speed classic May 30 until ASPAR'S petition for increased prize money has been settled with promoters of the Memorial Day event.

Declaring that "no one does anything about the housing shortage," Municipal Court Justice Maurice A. Wahl granted yesterday a "final" two-week stay of eviction orders against tenants of the Murray Hill Hotel.
LONDON, April 10 -- News of increased coal allocations to industry cheered the stock markets today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Whether Iran will now fall within the orbit of countries receiving American aid to withstand the pressure of expansionist policies of the Soviet Union was a question raised by the arrival here today of an Iranian purchasing mission seeking surplus United States military equipment.

Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared yesterday that President Truman, "in his effort to place responsibility for reducing prices solely upon business, apparently ignores the responsibility of Government and labor to cooperate in the necessary and desired lowering of price levels."

The availability of a new relief package, containing seventeen yards of cotton goods suitable for garments, was announced yesterday by Paul Comly French, general manager of CARE, the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe.

LOS ANGELES, April 10 -- The Government charged today that the General Motors Corporation, the Standard Oil Company of California, the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and six other concerns had conspired to get monopolistic, control of a network of local transit facilities extending from Coast to Coast.

To the Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am one of those who over a lifetime have watched the public conscience toward decent working standards in American industry grow from the small voice of aspiration to firmly accepted government policy. I can scarcely believe Senate Republicans will find it politically wise to concentrate the strokes of their economy axe on funds for the Labor Department, which was created by a Republican Congress in 1913.
The Central States Power and Light Corporation, in its annual statement issued yesterday, showed a net loss of $10,389 for 1946, compared with one of $50,266 for 1945.

Production of steel by domestic mills during March established a peacetime record of 7,284,518 net tons, thereby making the first quarter's output of 20,919,055 tons also the highest for any peacetime quarter, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Charles H. Sanders, eastern sales manager of Benson Hedges, has been named sales manager and will be responsible for all sales operations.
Trained armed services are a concomitant of the United States' world position of responsibility, Gen. Courtney H. Hodges, commanding the First Army, declared yesterday.
Possibility of a revival of the National Recovery Administration was read into the anti-trust modification statement of President Truman by industrial circles her yesterday.

MONTREAL, April 10 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, in one of the roughest games of the season, hammered out a 4-0 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight to tie at one game apiece their finalround Stanley Cup play-off series.

ROME, April 10 -- The independent newspaper, l'Italia. Nuova, published today what purported to be secret instructions sent by the Communist party's headquarters to the secretaries, of provincial Communist federations in Sicily urging them to organize acts of violence and to accelerate the collection of automatic weapons and the creation, of armed bands Local elections are scheduled in Sicily for April 20.

Without consulting his two colleagues on the Board of Transportation, Commissioner William H. Davis has asked the unions representing employes of the city's unified transit system to submit to him all pertinent evidence of their numerical strength among the transit workers, it was made known last night.

The issuance of a "request for bids" for the construction of five combination passenger-cargo vessels for the American President Lines Round-the-World service has received formal approval of the Maritime Commission, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Truman called today for a general cut in prices to avoid inflation and Attorney General Tom C. Clark said that price-reducing agreements between business men would get special study from the Department of Justice.

Westchester County awarded yesterday issues of improvement bonds aggregating $4,826,000 and maturing from 1948 to 1962 to a banking group headed by Glore, Forgan Co. at a bid of 100.144 for 1s. Other bids were 100.129 for 1s, submitted by C.F. Childs Co., Inc.; and 100.2699 for 1.10s, submitted by the Bankers Trust Company.

WARSAW, April 10 -- Foreign Minister Zygmunt Modzelewski declared today that "nothing can make Poland abandon" the western territories she gained from Germany. He also assailed United States Secretary of State Marshall and British Foreign Secretary Bevin for using Poland as "a political pawn in diplomatic maneuvering."
CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

An exhibition of recent work by the famous Yugoslav sculptor, Ivan Mestrovic, opened with a members' preview yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum. It opens to the public today and will continue through next month.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended April 5 totaled 715,159 cars, the Association of Amercan Railroads announced today. This was 114,253 cars, or 13.8 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 71,515 cars, or 11.1 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 50,513 cars, or 6.6 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
The New York University base ball team was held to a 4-4 tie by Manhattan at Ohio Field yesterday in the Jaspers' first start in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference.

Irra P a took time off from the touring "Song of Norway" and returned to New York for a performance of "Carmen" last night with the New York City Opera Company at the City Center. It was her first appearance with the company, and her vigorous, animated Carmen gave impetus to a production not yet shaken down into a cohesive, consistently professional job.

ATHENS, April 10 (U.P.) -- Greek Commandos and infantry landed on Cape Platamon from the sea today and rapidly pushed inland in an attempt to encircle and wipe out guerrilla concentrations on Mount Olympus and Mount Ossa.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The late President Roosevelt wrote Pope Pius XII on Sept. 3, 1941. that the Soviet Union's dictatorship was less dangerous to humanity than Adolf Hitler's, a newly published book disclosed today.

LONDON, April 10 (AP) -- British movies and their stars have replaced the American product in the favor of British audiences during the last ten years, a survey among patrons of the Granada group of theatres in Britain indicated tonight.

The Standard Oil Company and the Texas Company have notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that they have jointly underwritten $15,000,000 in bank loans to the Overseas Tankship Company for the purchase of a fleet of tankers from the Maritime Commission, it was announced yesterday.

MADRAS, India, April 10 -- T. T. Krishnamachari was born into a Brahmin family 47 years ago. Today he is an agnostic. But he also is a Congress party politician and he admires Mohandas K. Gandhi, the devout Hindu. His son is studying chemistry and physics and hopes to finish his education in a school in the United States.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 10 -- Excerpts from a statement to the United Nations Security Council today by Warren R. Austin, United States representative, follow: There is a seeming inconsistency in the position of the Soviet delegate.

ALBANY, April 10 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey today signed a bill to permit physicians to practice in partnerships and to pool fees. He also approved a measure to allow the employment of physicians by non-profit medical indemnity and hospital service corporations to treat persons insured by them.

The 1946 report of the chief of the Forest Service, Lyle F. Watts, supports President Truman's Arbor Day warning that this nation faces "a very real forest problem." The report is an indictment of the way we are handling one of our most important natural resources. For three centuries we have slashed, burned and cut indiscriminately.

Fresh, vegetables may receive prominence in menus this weekend, for the Housewife will find when she does her marketing today that there is a wide variety from which to select at prices lower than those a week ago -- in some cases by as much as 6 or 8 cents.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 10 -- Amendment of State laws to include marriage counselors equally with doctors and lawyers among those privileged to hold in confidence data shared with consultants was advocated here today by John S. Bradway, director of the legal aid clinic of Duke University.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 10 (AP) -- Paul E. Fitzpatrick, State Democratic chairman, said tonight that New York State would be "safe for Truman in 1948."

Many retailers recognize that prices of electrical appliances are too high and are willing to reduce markups at least temporarily if manufacturers of fair-traded items give the "go-ahead" signal, it was learned yesterday. One leading retailer stated that some such move is necessary if the merchandise is to retain its dominant position.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- In annual "May Day -- Child Health Day" preparations, the Children's Bureau today made accident-prevention chief item on the 1947 child health program due to an analysis of mortality statistics.

MINDEN, Germany, April 10 -- Stocks of virgin aluminum having been exhausted. German economists and industrialists for the combined Anglo-American zones are seeking the Military Government's permission for the reactivation of aluminum plants, it was learned today.

Treasury Financing Possibly foreshadowing the policy which it plans to follow in the scheduled reduction of outstanding ninety-one-day bills, the United States Treasury announced yesterday a call on its War Loan Deposits under which the country's B banks will be required to provide $248,014,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 10 -- The United Nations decision to give up the Lido Beach Hotel this summer is being protested strongly by staff members who have been quartered there, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Justice T. Alan Goldsborbugh charged John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers today with failure to show "good faith up to this moment" in complying with the Supreme Court's order to end the coal strike.

PARIS, April 10 -- Sidi Mohammed, the Sultan of Morocco, today made a ringing defense of the Arab League and in doing so emerged as a new and potentially powerful factor in France's troubled overseas scene.
Two New York high-school seniors were among the 126 students throughput the United States who were declared winners yesterday in the third annual Pepsi-Cola college scholarship competition.

Facing five to ten years in Sing Sing, Joseph (Pip the Blind) Gagliano, head of an East Harlem narcotic peddling combine said to be one of the biggest in the East, committed suicide by hanging early yesterday in the Bronx County Jail.

There is little likelihood that vessels now in the Maritime Commission's laid-up fleet will be chartered to move low-cost cargoes as urged by exporters recently, it was reported by marine sources yesterday.

Jackie Robinson, 28-year-old infielder, yesterday became the first Negro to achieve major-league baseball status in "modern times. His contract was purchased from the Montreal Royals of the International League by the Dodgers and he will be in a Brooklyn uniform at Ebbets Field today.

The 165th Infantry Regiment became last night the first regiment of the New York National Guard to meet the War Department's requirements for Federal recognition. The last four units of the regiment were Inspected and approved by four First Army offiicers at the regiment's armory, 68 Lexington Avenue.
SEOUL, Korea, April 10 -- With the return of Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander, from Washington, there is an air of expectancy in south Korea.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is commendable that Senator Vandenberg is eager to meet the criticism that in adopting the Truman proposal for dealing with the Greek-Turkis crisis the United States would be acting unilaterally and by-passing the United Nations.

BERLIN, April 10 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay refused today to accept a suggestion that the end of this year might be set as a possible deadline before which the settlement of German unification might be anticipated.

Washington, April 10 -- In its first four-hour meeting the House Labor Committee formally approved today the first eight sections of the omnibus labor bill, including a provision to break up the closed shop in American industry.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 10 -- Amid gifts never opened and messages of cheer never read by him, Jerry Nichols, 6 years old, died today in the Orange Memorial Hospital in Orange. News of his death created a wave of sympathy that spread far beyond his home neighborhood.

Feeling that the last word in baseball's Yankee-Dodger "cause celebre" has not yet been said, Larry MacPhail called one of his famed press conferences yesterday at which he gave the impression that while he may have some regrets that his original bombshell caused so much general damage, he was by no means afraid to touch off a few more firecrackers.

The State Commission Against Discrimination has made a "good beginning," but must publicize its work further if it is to achieve maximum effectiveness, the Welfare Council of New York City said yesterday in a report approved by its directors.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -- Fire starting in an unused galley swept for several hours late today over a section of Treasure Island, man-made naval base in San Francisco Bay, causing damage estimated by the Navy at $500,000.
PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -- Registration statements covering new issues of common and preferred stocks were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by three companies.

Deposit of $1,500,000 in a special bank account, representing new capital provided by three lenders for Motty Eitingon, Inc., mouton fur processors and dealers, was announced yesterday at the meeting of creditors held at the United States Court House.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Senate, without opposition, wrote into the $400,000,000 Greek-Turkish aid bill late today an authorization to the United Nations to modify or halt the program at any stage.

ALBANY, April 10 -- Governor Dewey stated today that he would make two state-wide radio broadcasts next week to report to the people on the accomplishments of the recent legislative session. It will be the second time since he has been Governor that the report will be divided into two parts.

The school construction program of the Board of Education for 1947 is "in very good shape," with $1500,000 of rehabilitation work scheduled for completion, before the end of the year, the Board of Estimate was told yesterday by Anthony Campagna, Board of Education member in charge of the school building program.

Regulation W of the Federal Reserve Board controling consumer credit, has "outlived its usefulness and restricts demand, production and employment," the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York declared in a report adopted yesterday at its regular monthly meeting.

AMSTERDAM, April 10 (Aneta) -- Prices declined in light dealings on the Stock Exchange. Indies plantation issues and shipping shares closed lower. Industrials and bank stocks were irregular, while state bonds were steady.

The Axis Victims League, Inc., an association for the restitution and compensation of rights and interests to Axis victims, in a statement yesterday characterized as unsatisfactory the draft of the restitution law accepted a month ago by the Council of the German Laender in the American Zone, which it said was expected to be promulgated without change by the American military authorities.

A program of "sick-bed-to-job" training, instituted last November at the New York State Reconstruction Home in West Haverstraw, N.Y., to enable patients suffering from poliomyelitis and other disabilities to resume an active life, will meet its final test today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Congressional subcommittee which has jurisdiction over Panama Canal matters is inclined to let the controversial issue of how to improve the Canal "simmer" for at least a year, Chairman Fred Bradley said today.

Indicating that their current stocks of nylon hosiery are adequate, large retailers in New York and other metropolitan centers have passed up their April allotments of branded nylon hosiery, it was learned yesterday. Some stores began cutting back on women's hosiery inventory in March, according to trade sources.

Bishop Charles K. Gilbert of the Episcopal Diocese of New York appealed last night for aid in meeting the challenge presented by "a tired and disillusioned and despairing humanity that is losing faith in many of those human formulas and devices upon which men relied for world peace and security."
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Red Cross mobilized today its national staff of specially trained personnel from over the country to provide relief in the Texas-Oklahoma areas swept by a tornado.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Charges that Jesse H. Jones, former chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, condoned a "fictitious" and "fraudulent" bankruptcy proceeding by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad were aired today before the Senate Banking Committee. It was asserted that the RFC "is holding the bag to the extent of some $80,000,000" on a loan to the railroad.

Leaders in government, education and journalism paid tribute yesterday to the memory of an immigrant whom they acclaimed as a crusader for the democratic principles now facing a global test for survival.

Substantial Federal tax reduction, additional foreign loans and gifts as well as a balanced budget are perfectly feasible, Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the board of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- A record winter wheat crop of 973,047,000 bushels was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture. Its report, however, told of delays in getting spring crops planted in the eastern two-thirds of the country.

GDYNIA, Poland, April 10 (AP) -- United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration officials said today that ice formations in the Skagerrak and heavy seas were preventing forty-five ships laden with $50,000,000 of supplies from entering Poland.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -- In this country alone, waste attendant upon present methods of packing, shipping and distributing produce would be sufficient to "feed the hunger-ridden countries of Belgium, Holland, Greece and Czechoslovakia," A.L. Martin, director of research, Western Growers Association, Los Angeles, declared here today.

If the President's observations on prices yesterday had been intended deliberately to stiffen the back of union labor in its pending demand for a new round of wage increases they could hardly have been more admirably contrived, to accomplish that purpose. If, on the other hand, they were offered as a contribution to the public's understanding of the problem, then they might better have been left" unsaid.

Three top leaders of 12,000 striking New Jersey telephone operators were ordered arrested last night for defiance of a new state anti-strike law. Warrants for their arrest were issued in Newark after the national policy committee of the National Federation of Telephone Workers, meeting in Washington, had instructed the New Jersey union to challenge the law by staying on strike.

PITTSBURGH, April 10 -- An agreement between the Aluminum Corporation of America and the Alumimun Workers Union, AFL, on a wage increase of 10 cents an hour focused attention today or the money demand to be made here next week on the United State Steel Corporation by the United Steel Workers of America, CIO.

A coal company mechanic had an unexpected bath in molasses in a railroad tank car in Brooklyn last night while looking for a lost monkey wrench, and a police emergency squad got well-smeared in effecting the rescue.
The Hapoel team from Palestine will play before the largest crowd ever to attend a soccer match in New York when it opens its American good-will tour at the Yankee Stadium the afternoon of May 4.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Development of rail and water transport in China offers a profitable future, according to Arthur N. Young, former adviser to the Chinese Government.
DETROIT, April 10 -- The body of Henry Ford was interred this afternoon in a plot near the graves of his mother and father In Addison Ford Cemetery.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- With prices lower for agricultural commodities, average primary market prices declined 0.4 per cent in the week ended April 5, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The almost perpetual rail embargo on the port of New York is ruining exporters in this area, W. H. Lukens, R. M. Hollingshead Corporation and president of the Overseas Automotive Club, stated yesterday. Speaking at the monthly meeting in the Hotel Woodstock, he warned that inadequate facilities and racketeering at the port are rapidly jeopardizing the foreign trade future of this area.

Negotiations broke off yesterday between the strike-bound Westen Electric Company and the Association of Communication Equipment Workers. The United States Conciliation Service immediately began to bring both parties into conciliation.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Truman extended the olive branch today to the Democratic left-wing leadership of Henry A. Wallace and Senator Claude A. Pepper of Florida. He said he had no desire to read either man out of the party and predicted both would support the Democratic ticket in the 1948 campaign.
PARIS, April 10 -- Robert Piguet opens ,the mid-season with thirtyfive summer models.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 10 -- Ten members of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission today outvoted insistent Russian demands for immediate work on a convention to outlaw the atomic bomb.

For his final Thursday night Philharmonic-Symphony concert of the season last night in Carnegie Hall, Leopold Stokowski arranged an all-Russian program, performed it with his wonted virtuosity and elan and in so doing furnished morals to adorn a tale.

Senator Robertson of Wyoming showed a lack of understanding of the basic reasons for military unification when he seized on testimony before the Senate Armed Services Committee showing a saving of $55,000,000 by the Joint Aeronautical Board as proof that voluntary cooperation was just as efficient, or more so, than would be actual merger.

ATHENS, April 10 -- Government forces, estimated at about 15,000, were said by a military spokesman today to have made satisfactory progress against the guerrillas in main area of operations in the Pindus Mountains south of Metsovo.

Mrs. Walter S. Sullivan, whose husband was a former executive of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died at 1 P.M. yesterday after a taxicab in which she was a passenger was in collision with another cab at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 10 -- Guilty of unemployment insurance frauds against the State Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance, four women and two men were sentenced here today by County Judge Elbert T. Gallagher to penalties ranging from $350 fines to one year in jail.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- May wheat tightened as the result of commission house buying in small lots and closed 1 3/4 cents a bushel higher on the Board of Trade today, while the new crop months were weaker in expectation of a bearish Department of Agriculture estimate on the new winter wheat crop and closed with losses of 2 1/4 to 2 3/4 cents.

In a tour of the horizon that has so far served mainly to show up differences in the angles of vision, the Foreign Ministers at Moscow have at last come to the question of the German-Polish boundary. This is one of the hottest issues before the conference, for it involves not only the Big Pour but Poland.

Development of a market woodpulp industry in Alaska was endorsed yesterday by the Association of Wood Pulp Consumers, Inc. Its views have teen conveyed to the Secretary of Agriculture under whose direction the forests are administered and the Secretary of the Interior who supervises the development of territorial policy.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 10 -- Plans for the construction of an atom-smashing machine of unprecedented power at the Brookhaven National Laboratory for Atomic Research on Long Island were presented here today by Dr. Philip M. Morse, director of the Government-financed experimental center.

Decidedly, man is not the animal who learns lessons easily or remembers them very long. One would imagine that a world war which has cost a trillion dollars and scores of millions of lives would be enough to drive home a lesson so that it might be remembered at least two years.

WOODWARD, Okla., April 10 -- A tornado ripped through western Texas and Oklahoma last night killing 132 persons, injuring at least 1,305 more and leaving millions of dollars of property damage in its wake.

Hundreds of German Jews who managed to escape the Third Reich for exile in such distant points as Shanghai, India and Ethiopia now are seeking to return to the homeland that once rejected them, Eli Rock, head of the Berlin office of the Joint Distribution Committee, said yesterday.
TOKYO, April 10 -- Discussion in Japanese circles on the need for United States credit to this country has been capped by a highly optimistic proposal for a $1,000,000,000 loan.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The National Federation of Telephone Workers decided today to ask Lewis B. Schwellenbach, Secretary of Labor, to seek a top-level conference in order to settle the nationwide telephone strike on a national level directly with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

The opening of a new service between New York and Matadi, Belgian Congo, and Lobito, Portuguese West Africa, was made known here yesterday. The service will be operated by the Compagnie Maritime Congolaise, a recently formed corporation, with the Atlantic Overseas Corporation, with offices at 10 Pearl Street, as general agents in the United States.
LONDON, April 10 -- British opinion has begun to split on Henry A. Wallace and his stand against the "Truman Dootrine."
GENEVA, April 10 -- An atmosphere of urgency and a consciousness of the tremendous implications of its Work dominated the opening Session of the Geneva Trade Conference today.

An appeal for the collective wisdom of the nation's governmental and economic forces in helping perfect a program of action "aimed at enhancing our economy's dynamic productiveness and moderating its tendencies toward booms and busts" was made yesterday here by Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Committee for Economic Development and president of the Studebaker Corporation.

An ambitious goal of $1,095,000 in gifts has been set by the new Protestant Fund of Greater New York in its first campaign, which has just been put under way. This is an organization formed last September by the Protestant Council and the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies to coordinate and unify the financing of religious, educational and welfare services.

Screw Prices Withdrawn One of the principal sources of screws has notified distributors and hardware jobbers that prices have been withdrawn and that a new price list will be issued soon, a New York jobber reported here yesterday.

Net income last year of the Chicago North Western Railway Company fell $6,902,352 to $8,181,603 from the 1945 net of $15,083,955, according to the annual report signed by R.L. Williams, president, issued yesterday.

The Association of Stock Exchange Firms submitted yesterday to the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange two plans for increasing the commission rates on stock transactions. While taking no action at their meeting, the governors of the Exchange decided to consider both plans and set May 8 for another meeting to determine policy.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -- Describing the outlook for the American Merchant Marine as "very dark indeed," Albert W. Gatov, executive director of the Pacific American Steamship Association, asserted tonight that if water transportation was to regain its share of the freight-carrying business, "the traditional differential between rail and water rates must be preserved."

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Julius A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, declared before a Senate investgating committee today that United Mine Workers officials had refused to accept the opportunities and responsibilities of making the country's coal mines safer.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., April 10 -- Nine anthracite workers were killed and nine others were burned, three critically, today in a gas explosion in the Schooley Colliery at Exeter, which is about seven miles north of here on the west side of the Susquehanna River.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Truman took exception today to a forecast by John W. Hanes, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, that the Government would wind up the current fiscal year with a surplus of at least $3,000,000,000 and possibly save an additional $8,000,000,000 in the 1948 fiscal year.

Everyone knows that Mayor O'Dwyer is seeking additional revenue to make ends meet. Where it is coming from is not only bothering him but others as well. To extricate the Mayor from a dilemma, a prominent showman, who prefers to remain anonymous, volunteers the following suggestion: Increase the annual license fee for picture houses from $200 to $500, the sum paid by the so-called legitimate theatres.

MONTERREY, Mexico, April 10 -- An outspoken invitation to American small investors to buy Mexican Government bonds described "as safe and as secure as any in the world" was issued today by Ramon Beteta, Mexico's Minister of Finance, in a major speech before the twelfth annual meeting of the Texas group of Investment Bankers Association of America.
MOSCOW, April 10 -- The United States unequivocally supported today French claims for the separation of the Saar from Germany and its economic and financial integration into France without delay.

DANVILLE, Va., April 10 -- Rapid Robert Feller's preview today for the Indians' opening game next Tuesday was something less than adequate. By way of taking their farewell of the Iowa strong boy for 1947, the Giants hammered Rapid Robert for nine hits, two of them homers; stole bases in a manner reminiscent of Feller's earlier days and affected the firebailer so he walked six, forcing in a run with one of his passes.

Trading in the stock market yesterday was at a slow pace. Prices Kept within a narrow range and closed irregularly higher. Some of the leading issues sold off toward the end of the session, but the volume was the smallest since Monday at 680,000 shares, compared with 850,000 the day before.

PARIS, April 10 -- Premier Paul Ramadier, reviewing the situation in Madagascar at a press conference today, said that the recent outbreak had been traced to the instigation of elements within the Malagasy Renovation party.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted the New York New Haven and Hartford Railroad authority to increase Its basic oneway coach fare from 2.2 to 2.5 cents a mile, and its parlor and sleeping car fares from 3.3 to 3.5 cents a mile, with a minimum fare of fifteen cents.

BERLIN, April 10 -- Trade union leaders throughout the American zone of Germany have served notice on United States Military Government representatives that they cannot maintain calm much longer among the dissatisfied hungry and ill-clothed workers.

In two articles, the first of which is published today in this newspaper, Winston Churchill again offers one of those searching surveys of the troubled international scene which made him a powerful spokesman of the Western World during the war. Today's article is of special interest and importance at this moment because it sheds new light on the situation in Greece and the Middle East.

MOSCOW, April 10 -- As the Council of Foreign Ministers commenced its second month of deliberations here today, two basic facts were apparent: The Big Four as such are still stalemated on the fundamental issues involved; but the three Western powers have drawn more closely together and harmonized their views on many questions.

It is barely a year since I spoke at Fulton at the desire of the President of the United States. I read over again last night what I then said, I was surprised that such mild, mellifluous, carefully shaped and guarded sentiments should have caused so much commotion, not only in America and in my own country but elsewhere.

BOSTON, April 10 -- A charge that the National Education Association was blocking Federal aid to education by refusing to support a bill which would bring $242,500,000 to the public schools and "a mere $7,500,000 to private schools" was leveled at the closing session of the National Catholic Educational Association here today by the Rev. William E. McManus, assistant director of the educational section of the National Catholic Welfare Conference.

URBANA, Ill., April 10 -- What the home economist can contribute to better housing research was outlined here today at the University of Illinois by J. Lita Bane, head of the Department of Home Economics, and Deane G. Carter, Professor of Agricultural Engineering.

Total shipments of hosiery during February amounted to 12,528,718 dozen pairs, an increase of 3.6 per cent over the corresponding month in 1946, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. Shipments of women's full-fashioned hose totaled 3,326,229 dozen pairs against 2,893,737 dozen pairs in February, 1946.
King Dorsett, en route to victory at 7 to 10 in the $6,500 added Sgt. Byrne Handicap at Jamaica yesterday, almost scraped some paint from the rail turning into the stretch.
DUBLIN, April 10 -- Ireland today is facing the most critics food and fuel crisis within living Memory.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Representative Margaret Chase Smith of Maine today advised Republican women leaders from ten Eastern States to take a cue from the soap operas and win women through "daytime radio serials based on everyday life."
After holding steady most of the day, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 10 to 16 points net lower.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Total orange production for the l946-'47 season was estimated today by the Department of Agriculture at 115,200,000 boxes, compared with 100,300,000 in 1945-'46 and 109,200,000 in 1944-'45.

The appointment of Rear Admiral James Fife Jr. as Commander of Submarines, Atlantic Fleet, succeeding Rear Admiral John Wilkes, was announced last night during a special television program marking the forty-seventh anniversary of the Navy's first submarine, the Holland.

The Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway Company went yesterday before the Public Service Commission to seek permission to raise monthly commutation fares by $2.50 for a sixty-two-trip ticket and to increase monthly and weekly school fares by 20 per cent.

DETROIT, April 10 -- The United Automobile Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations served its sweeping wage demands, amounting to more than 30 cents an hour, upon the General Motors Corporation today.

BERLIN, April 10 -- Although no official figures were given out, it was estimated today that close to 2,000 persons -- not all of them Germans -- were arrested in the surprise twenty-four-hour sweep of Berlin by the Allies in search of criminal elements.

A miniature Hollywood premiere, in which thirty disabled persons of all ages saw themselves for the first time on the screen, was staged yesterday at Bellevue Hospital at a preview of "The Forjotten Casualty," a documentary film that will open in the New York area movie houses on April 14.

The United States Trotting Association yesterday barred Dale Ellis of Chillcothe, Ohio, and Britton, S.D., for life and suspended Drivers Harry Bedell of Glen Rock, N.J., and Norman Phillips of Hackettstown, N.J., for the 1947 season as the outgrowth of an investigation of a questionable race at the Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., last Nov. 1, The Associated Press reports.

THE Leo Durocher suspension left Brooklyn fans, players and officials still stunned yesterday, and for that no one could blame them. Yet the more you think it over, the stronger the impression grows that the Lip's congenital inability to keep his mouth shut led to his downfall. One of his most irritating qualities was his needling tendencies.

MOSCOW, April 10 -- A French proposal that there be two kinds of members on the Information and Consultative Committee on the German peace treaty failed to bridge a gap between the Big Four deputies today.

Leo Durocher is down, but he cannot yet be counted permanently out of the Brooklyn baseball picture. In fact, intimation that Durocher might return to manage the Dodgers at the end of his oneyear suspension was given last night by Walter O'Malley, vice president of the club.
Many dinners will be given tonight before the Bassinet Ball, annual benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, which will take place in the ballroom of the Ritz Carlton.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 11 -- The owners of Centralia Coal Company Mine No. 5, the State Department of Mines and Minerals, and Driscoll O. Scanlon, State Mines Inspector, share the responsibility for the explosion which killed 111 miners, a special committee concluded today.

JERUSALEM, April 11 -- While waiting for the United Nations consideration of the Palestine problem, British policy here appears to be that of sparing no effort to enforce law and order and maintain the existing political status.

The fifth and final play of the Experimental Theatre's current membership series will be given tomorrow evening at the Princess Theatre under the sponsorship of the American National Theatre and Academy. It is "Virginia Reel," a play by John and Harriet Weaver.

Voluntary action at all levels of production is the first step in bringing about lower price levels and preventing controls or extreme price deflation, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared last night.

In a refinancing of the six-story apartment house at 321-329 West Twenty-fourth Street, the original first mortgage of $160,000, which had been reduced to $138,021, has been paid off at par and a new first mortgage of $120,000 has been obtained from the North River Savings Bank, according to Henry Weiner, attorney for Samuel R. Firestone, trustee for the benefit of certificate holders.

In behalf of the executive committee of the Lead Industries Association of New York, a representative of lead miners and consumers for the last eighteen years, F.E. Wormser, secretary of the organization, filed yesterday with the House of Representatives Committee of Public Lands a statement opposing the proposed $100,000,000 subsidy on production of thirtyeight metals.

LONDON, April 11 -- A new challenge to the Communist International -- a Liberal international -- was formed in Oxford tonight. Its objective is "to win general acceptance of liberalism throughout the world and to foster a free society based on freedom and personal responsibility and to provide a means of collaboration between men and women of all countries who agree with these principles."

Martin Kainz, an artist of repute, whose paintings are in American and European collections, made his first public appearance as a tenor, in a recital given last night at Times Hall. He was assisted by Irene Koscinski, soprano, in a program of solos and duets.

Apparently seeking a $6,000 payroll, burglars broke into the Medallic Art Company, at 210 East Fifty-first Street, early yesterday and after ripping two of the concern's six safes got $150 petty cash, scrap gold worth $300 and some commemorative coins valued at $1,000.
