TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter published March 22 Mihail Ralea, who represents the Groza regime in the United States, claims that private enterprise enjoys in Rumania "unfettered freedom." What are the facts?

BUFFALO, April 11 -- Buffalo Forge Company and its subsidiary, Buffalo Pumps, Inc., announced today firm prices on all lines of fans, blowers, power plant equipment, air conditioning lines, units heaters and pumps, effective immediately. Edgar F. Wendt, president of the company, issued the following statement:
ALBANY, April 11 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey vetoed the Desmond bill which would have established the machinery for confinement of sexual psychopaths until they no longer were a danger to society.

BOWIE, Md., April 11 (AP) -- Cedar Farm's Git, unsuccessful in Florida last winter, regained winning form in the feature today. The 4-year-old, ridden by Jockey Carson Kirk, forged to the finish line two lengths in advance of Gal Ann, with Betty's Bobby third in the field of seven.

Hopes of retail liquor store men that mandatory enforcement of fair trade agreements on all packaged goods will prevent sharp reductions in liquor prices are illusory, trade sources stated yesterday. With competition now breaking out at the distiller level, they said, liquor prices are going to decline, regardless of enforcement action planned by the State Liquor Authority.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The United States has informed the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and China that 239 Japanese combatant surface vessels of destroyer tonnage or less would be available for equal division among them. It said 140 of them were ready for delivery.

Two Chicago teams will meet for the National A.A.U. indoor water polo title at the New York Athletic Club tonight. The Illinois A.C., winner of the crown in 1941, last year the tournament was held, and the Beilfuss Natatorium gained the championship bracket by winning their semi-final tests last night.
TRENTON, N.J., April 11 -- Uncertainty over the actual number of favorable votes cast in the New Jersey Assembly for a municipal sales tax bill today apparently had doomed it to an executive veto.
MOSCOW, April 11 (AP) -- The text of Secretary of State Marshall's letter on Korea to Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov follows:

JERUSALEM, April 11 -- A Jew who entered the Mosque of Omar, one of Islam's most sacred shrines, was beaten to death by a Moslem crowd today in the first religious slaying in the Holy City since 1929. Another Jew escaped with minor injuries.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The House Labor Committee approved overwhelmingly today a sharp omnibus labor reform bill. The Senate committee at the same hour overmastered Senator Robert A. Taft's leadership to vote a further softening of an already far less restrictive Senate measure.

The nation-wide telephone strike grew out of union demands for higher wages, the union shop, increased pensions, longer vacations, shortening of the time required to reach top pay levels, and other concessions.

Public hearings on Mayor O'Dwyer's proposed $1,029,120,314 executive budget for 1947-48 have produced little expectation of any substantial change. The budget is so large and our additional taxing powers are so limited that few have had the temerity to suggest, except for the record, any large increases.
NEWARK, N.J., April 11 -- One of the three "willing guinea pigs" arrested today to test the validity of New Jersey's anti-strike law plans to go on her honeymoon Sunday, strike or no strike.

TAKE the oceans as your province and you can discuss almost anything on your mind under the tide-linked moon. And that's precisely what Ferdinand C. Lane does in his garrulous and entertaining new book, "The Mysterious Sea."* He talks affably about pirates, trade routes, wars, fishes, empires, ocean currents, ships and shipwrecks, mutineers, deeps and argonauts -- among many, many things concerning the seas and their histories.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- May wheat showed no congestion in the early trading on the Board of Trade today and advanced 10 cents a bushel, the daily limit, before the demand was satisfied. The action of the May carried the new crop deliveries higher, but late in the session a report that cash wheat premiums at Kansas City had declined 1/2 to 5 1/2 cents led to general selling.
Percie Ovenden, with the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria since its opening, has, been appointed purchasing steward, succeeding Roland Pierce, who has resigned to enter private business.

Ten good 3-year-olds and true -- well, reasonably true -- have been named to start at Jamaica today in the $20,000 added Experimental Handicap No. 2, and when the numbers go up at the end of the mile-and-a-sixteenth run a great deal more is expected to be known about who's who in the division.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 11 -- Telephone service throughout Indiana continues uninterrupted because of the new state law making arbitration compulsory in all management-labor disputes involving public utilities. The law was enacted by the State Legislature last March.

MOSCOW, April 11 -- The Voice of America, the nightly radio program from the United States to the Soviet Union, was bitterly attacked today by Ilya Ehrenburg as the voice of "American reaction" and as a program that might have been written by Hermann Goering or Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels.

The "safety shutdown" in the coal fields, decreed by John L. Lewis to coincide with a strike which the Supreme Court had forbidden him to call, now seems to be backfiring against Mr. Lewis himself. The reason for this was put in plain terms by Federal Judge Goldsborough, refusing to remit at present the $2,800,000 fine imposed on the United Mine Workers for contempt of court.

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 11 -- As the Geneva Trade Conference wound up its second day the dominant note in the speeches and in the private discussions of delegates had become the urgency of forestalling a new world depression.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- The hidden hoard of two South Side recluses who lived in squalor in a basement flat mounted to $151,020 today as public authorities found $109,910 in cash, securities and bank accounts in two downtown banks.

TOKYO, April 11 -- The registration of candidates took place today for the first of Japan's two forthcoming national elections -- that for the House of Councilors which will replace the old herediatary peers under the new Constitution, effective next month.

Charles P. Gross, chairman of the Board of Transportation, announced yesterday his disapproval of the labor relations plan for the city's 33,000 civil service transit workers, as drawn by his associate on the board. William H. Davis, at the request of Mayor O'Dwyer.

MONTREAL, April 11 (AP) -- Montreal's crippled Canadiens suffered another blow today when President Clarence Campbell of the National Hockey League suspended Maurice (The Rocket) Richard for one game and fined the high-scoring right-winger $250 for his display of temper in last night's Stanley Cup play-off game against the Toronto Maple Leafs here.

A man dies of smallpox in a New York hospital. Immediately there is set in motion city, state and federal apparatus to search out every person who had even a momentary contact with the victim on a bus ride of thousands of miles from the Mexican border to New York.

MOSCOW, April 11 -- Because of the failure of the United States-Soviet Joint Commission in Korea the United States has decided to act independently in its zone, comprising the southern half of that country. Without delay Washington intends to take steps toward establishing the eventual independence of that area.

ATHENS, April 11 (AP) -- A Greek Army of 15,000 supported by aircraft, tanks, artillery and parachutists, has encircled 1,500 square miles of mountainous guerrilla country in Thessaly and is drawing the net tighter on an estimated 2,500 men in Leftist bands in the area, a Greek General Staff spokesman reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 (AP) -- Opening the defense of his 165-pound title, Doug Lee of the Baltimore, Md., Y.M.C.A. today threw Loran Deming of Southwestern Tech, Weatherford, Okla., in a first-round match of the National A.A.U. wrestling championships. The time was 1:41.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 11 -- Stanley B. Cofall, Ohio Director of Liquor Control, issued an order today abolishing all rationing of liquor sales in State monopoly stores. There has not been any rationing in sales by the drink in private establishments catering to the public.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 11 (AP) -- Babe Ruth, who admits that he's still a "mighty sick man," went out today and caught a fifty-pound, 6-foot 8-inch sailfish after a thirty-minute fight.

Not Very Serious Lipstick inscriptions on the Statue of Liberty have not been eliminated by the new coat of anti-cosmetic paint and a wire guard around the spiral staircase, Barred from access to the framework of the statue, the bobby-sox visitors have taken to writing their names and telephone numbers on the steps themselves.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The end of the current fiscal year on June 30 will complete a two-year period in which the United States will have put $16,788,091,000 into foreign assistance or relief.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 -- A goal which would make the basic six-hour day a "living reality" through the fixing of a wage by which "a man can make a living in six hours" was established by the International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, at the closing sessions of its biennial convention here today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved yesterday over a moderate range and closed 1 point higher to 12 points lower than the day before.

SURABAYA, Java, April 11 (ANETA) -- The longest transoceanic tow ever attempted by non-oceangoing tugs -- 16,690 sea miles -- was successfully completed with the arrival here late yesterday of three Dutch tugs towing the 4,000-ton floating drydock Juliana, with a giant floating crane riding inside the drydock.

The opening in this city of the House of Italian Handicrafts with a ceremony in which Italy's Foreign Minister, Count Carlo Sforza, spoke from Rome and Mayor O'Dwyer voiced the good wishes of New York inaugurates a laudable private effort to help a devastated and impoverished country to help itself.

WOODWARD, Okla., April 11 (AP) -- The grind of machinery clearing away the rubble today replaced ambulance sirens as Woodward, still mourning eighty-four dead, turned to rebuilding its shattered city.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Commissioner Ugo Carusi told the Senate Expenditures Committee today a saving in supervisory staff could be made if the border patrol work of the Immigration Service and the Customs Bureau were under one agency.

With Jackie Robinson, first Negro with a major league club since 1884, playing nine innings at first base flawlessly, the Dodgers overwhelmed the Yankees, 14 -- 6, in their exhibition contest before 24,237 persons at Ebbets Field yesterday. The 28-year-old Robinson, whose contract had been purchased from Montreal on Thursday, received a pleasant reception from the fans and the players.

Franklin D. Roosevelt has now receded two years into history: far enough to give us some perspective on him, not far enough to be a cold figure on a monument. We remember some of his lighter aspects -- the cockily tilted cigarette in its long holder; the genial give and take of some of the press conferences; the boyish interest in the sea; the almost squally boyish zeal for politics considered as a game.

MOSCOW, April 11 -- Four French appeals to the Soviet Union to join the United States and Britain in agreeing on the integration of the Saar into France's economy were rebuffed by Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov today in a dramatic meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

Port congestion in South America and ice in the Baltic Sea are keeping thirty-nine of the Moore-McCormack Lines' vessels immobilized, Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of the company, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The national telephone strike entered a new and bitter phase today when the National Federation of Telephone Workers rejected a tentative agreement covering 20,000 long lines telephone workers employed directly by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

BERLIN, April 11 -- Polish officials disclosed today that the chief Polish liaison officer in United States headquarters in Frankfort on the Main had been removed, presumably because of his violent anti-United States attitude.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., April 11 (AP) -- Visitors from many parts of the country will gather tomorrow before the portico of the Roosevelt family home to commemorate the second anniversary of the death of their wartime leader, Franklin D. Roosevelt.

In the drive to obtain at least 30,000 enlistments a month, the First Army has established in its area, which includes New England, New York, New Jersey and Delaware, 280 recruiting booths and stations, seventy-five of which are on a part-time basis, it was made known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- A hood for oxygen therapy, designed to obviate many of the disadvantages of the large oxygen tent, is one of the 362 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

BOSTON, April 11 (AP) -- Tex Hughson pitched the first five innings with the form he showed last season ,in winning twenty games as the Red Sox defeated the Braves, 3 -- 0, today in the first of a three-game city series.

New Capital Market Telephones permitting, the underwriting community stands to do a lot of business next week, compared with that in the week now ending, during which public financing was confined to three municipal bond issues and one issue of railroad equipment-trust certificates, all totaling $12,009,000.

CHICAGO, April 11 (U.P.) -- Substantial price cuts on clothing and other items were announced by a few department stores across the nation today in response to President Truman's warning against high prices.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 11 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council began today to write the questions each administering power must answer in its annual report to the General Assembly on how far the trust territories have progressed toward self-government or independence.

BERLIN, April 11 -- Thousands of employes of the Siemens plant in the British sector of Berlin are debating a ten-minute strike Monday as a protest against the acquittal of Wolf Dietrich von Witzleben, formerly chairman of the board of Siemens and Halske, and Siemens and Schuckert.

A campaign against unemployment insurance chiselers, begun by the State Division of Unemployment Insurance last October, has reached a high point with 700 cases currently being examined for suspected fraud, it was declared yesterday.

A two-hour rally to raise funds toward the $1,300,000 quota assigned to the New York City Cancer Committee in the American Cancer Society's campaign for $12,000,000 was conducted yesterday in Times Square with Army recruiting officials and stage and screen stars participating.

When he went to Yale College as a young man Wilbur L. Cross, who had been born in a "nice little rural place close by Hartford," found the Yale of 1881 a good place. His professors were, in retrospect, "a delightful and noble race of men." So, by thousands of Yale men and students in Yale Graduate School who knew him as professor or dean, is Wilbur Cross remembered with affection and respect years afterward.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Comoission today dismissed proceedings aimed at revoking the brokerdealer registration of Charles A. Massie, doing business as Charles Massie Co., New York.

A fight in the lobby of the Palladium Dance Hall at 1698 Broadway ended early yesterday in the arrest of five youths at Polyclinic Hospital, where they had gone for treatment. In the emergency room when the suspects walked in was Thomas Morton, manager of the hall, who identified them as his attackers.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Sir John Boyd Orr, director general of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, warned today that the world food emergency was not over.

BERLIN, April 11 -- The complete results of the four-power round-up in Berlin, during which an estimated 800,000 persons were asked to identify themselves, remained a secret today, although three of the four powers reported that together they had apprehended 2,023 suspects.
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 11 -- Dr. Frank P. Corrigan, United States Ambassador to Venezuela, walked out of a meeting of the Venezuelan Constituent Assembly this morning.

LONDON, April 11 (AP) -- Former British open champion Alfred Padgham put on a stirring finish today to win the $5,000 Silver King professional golf tournament with score of 285 for the 72 holes. Sam King of Widernesse was runner-up with 289.

To provide efficiently trained steward personnel aboard American merchant vessels, the Maritime Commission, in cooperation with operators of passenger vessels and the seamen's organizations with which they have labor contracts, is setting up a standard training program, it was made known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- R.R. Sayers, director of the Bureau of Mines, said today that the inspector who examined the Centralia, Ill., mine five days before the explosion occurred, exercised "reasonable judgment" even though he had found very hazardous conditions and did not request the closing of the mine.

With the city laboratories working overtime to meet the demand for vaccine, Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein appealed yesterday to physicians and non-municipal hospitals to buy at least part of their supply from commercial manufacturers during the current immunization campaign against smallpox.

LONDON, April 11 -- Three more Britons pleaded guilty and were fined today for unwitting participation in what is proving to be an international monetary scandal. The name of Max Intrator, which was mentioned in another case yesterday, figured in all three cases.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 11 -- The establishing of a United Nations police force is being delayed by the inability of the Military Staff Committee to agree on quotas. The committee has not found how each great power can supply a contingent exactly equivalent to those of the four others.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- A broad program for educational reform in Japan has been communicated by the Allied Far Eastern Commission to Gen. Douglas MacArthur. The decision came in the form of a directive and was announced today.

Under the auspices of Trinity Episcopal Parish, the Bethlehem Bach Choir of 250 voices will sing the Bach B Minor Mass tomorrow in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The music will start a 5 P.M. with an hour's intermission at 6:30. The sacred recital it being presented "as a token to the people of New York of the consistent support by Trinity through the years of the best in church music."

Mayor O'Dwyer asked the Citizens Budget Commission yesterday to undertake a survey to determine the advisability of combining into a single public safety unit the functions of the Police and Fire Departments. He also asked for a study of the possibility of using 954 supervisory officers of the Department of Sanitation as peace, officers within the new unit.

Putting on a tremendous display of batting power, the St. John's nine crushed Brooklyn College, 19 to 3, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference test at Brooklyn College Field yesterday. The victors tallied in every inning, except the seventh, and pounded four Kingsmen hurlers for 19 safeties.

LONDON, April 11 -- Britons spent more last year then in any previous year, but taking into account the higher prices, shortages of goods and quality changes they got less for their money than before the war. This was revealed tonight in the annual White Paper on the national income and expenditure.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 11 -- The extraordinary session of the United Nations General Assembly on Palestine will probably begin on Monday, April 28, it appeared today after twenty-four countries had given their consent to the meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The Commodity Credit Corporation, huge Government food and farm agency, cost the taxpayers $1,969,287,425 for loan, purchase, resale and subsidy operations from its creation in 1939 to March 1 this year.

As the climax of the observance of Army Week, the annual Army Day parade, sponsored by the Military Order of the World Wars, will be held on upper Fifth Avenue today. The advance echelon, followed by junior and senior divisions, will step off at Ninety-fifth Street at 2 P.M. and march to Sixty-second Street.
Memorial celebrations were held yesterday by several organizations to commemorate the second anniversary of the death of former President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Published on the second anniversary of his death, the letters written by Franklin D. Roosevelt to Pope Plus XII throw an interesting light on the mind and character of the late President as well as on the purpose that inspired his rather bold initiative in appointing a personal representative to the Holy See.

PARIS, April 11 -- The Communist newspaper Ce Soir spread over its first page today an interview with Henry A. Wallace in which he was quoted as referring to "the group in the United States that presses for war."

NANKING, April 11 -- New orders will be issued to end Nationalist attacks on relief shipments to Communist areas of China. New promises of non-interference have come from Gen. Chen Cheng, chief of staff, to officials of UNRRA.

WARRENTON, Va., April 11 -- The marriage of Miss Sarah Marshall Warren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Mack Warren of this community, to the Rev. Joseph Blunt Tucker of Montrose, Va., son of Dr. and Mrs. Augustine Washington Tucker of Shanghai, China, took place this afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church here.

With all three principal roles in excellent hands, Verdi's "La Traviata" received a highly commendable performance by the New York City Opera Company last night at the City Center, where it was presented for the first time in the spring season.
