WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Truman's stern emphasis yesterday on the need for "cooperation" by business, rather than regulation of it, was received today as additional evidence of the new approach being taken generally by the Administration toward private enterprise.
MOSCOW, April 11 -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky suggested today that a German Government "adequate fop the purpose" be allowed to express its opinion at ths peace conference.
The Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary this year, yesterday announced a schedule of twenty-four senior tournaments for the outdoor season.

Active and alert, Charles Evans Hughes, former Chief Justice of this United States, spent his eighty-fifth birthday here yesterday with his three children and nine grand-children in a quiet family gathering.
TO THE EDITOR OF NEW YORK TIMES:

PITTSBURGH, April 11 -- Owing mainly to the closing down of most of the coal mines, in western Pennsylvania, business in the Pittsburgh district last week dropped to the lowest level reported in 1947, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

MONTERREY, Mexico, April 11 -- An eleven-point program, aimed at increasing the possibilities of United States citizens' investments in Mexico, was placed before the convention of the Investment Bankers of America, Texas Group, which closed its business sessions here today.
Brooklyn's celebrated case of Leo Durocher simmered down yesterday to little more than a guessing contest involving his successor as Dodger manager for 1947.

The first of 685 apartments being built in Queens for United Nations personnel was inspected yesterday by Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett and more than 150 bankers and city, state and foreign officials.
A vigorous community program of education to combat the rise of venereal disease throughout the city was urged yesterday by Dr. Israel Weinstein, Commissioner of Health.

Vincent Astor, whose family has been prominent in the industrial and social life of this city for generations and who was christened William Vincent Astor, won a Supreme Court injunction yesterday preventing Vincent Astor Williams from doing Business as the Vincent Astor Purchasing Company.

LONDON, April 11 -- Rumors that Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Dalton may make special income-tax concessions to holders of British Government securities lifted the prices of those issues in the stock markets here today. As soon as business started a general increase of up to 3/8 point was seen.

BERLIN, April 11 -- The long-awaited eruption of the city's politics developed this afternoon when a disputatious four-hour session of the Berlin Assembly terminated in a vote of no confidence in the Magistrat. The ballot was 80 to 25, with one member abstaining.

A rural program that in addition to urging families to stay on farms will organize committees in each rural Baptist Church to provide information on rural employment opportunities was announcecd here yesterday by the Department of Town and Country Work of the Northern Baptist Convention.

BOSTON, April 11 -- The lumber industry has reached the point where it can do its full part toward supplying housing needs, but the day of low-cost homes still remains somewhere in the future, C. Arthur Bruce, president of the National Lumber Manufacturers' Association, said today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 11 -- Zoning ordinances that restrict much of the Purchase area of Harrison Township to private estates of five or more acres were called old fashioned and unconstitutional today by Robert E. Dineen, State Superintendent of Insurance, in a Supreme Court suit filed here to have the ordinances vacated.

LOS ANGELES, April 11 -- Gen. George C. Kenney, Chief of the Strategic Air Forces, disclosed today that an aerial robot-guided missile with an 5,000-mile range had been planned down to actual unit production cost, but warned the nation against exaggerating "push-button warfare" notions into a fatal "Maginot Line" psychology.

TRANS-JORDAN, April 11 -- Nuri as Said Pasha, President of the Iraqi Senate and former Premier, said in an interview last night that in his opinion a revision of the British-Iraqi treaty, which gives Britain military and political privileges in Iraq, would not soon be undertaken.

MADRID, April 11 (AP) -- Estaban Bilbao, president of the Cortes [Parliament] announced today the membership of a committee -- heavily weighted with Falangists -- that will consider Generalissimo Francisco Franco's proposed "law of succession" for restoration of Spain's monarchy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 11 -- Sally Benson, author and scenarist, has come to the coast to write the book for a projected musical version of Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice," which Arthur Freed will produce late next year at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

Slower movement of rayon piece goods from converters to manufacturers has resulted in a perceptible curtailment of finishing operations, it was learned in the trade yesterday. Despite the campaign to advance showings for the fall season, it appears that converters, and mills which do their own finishing, have not made decisions on designs and patterns, textile men said.

RICHMOND, Va., April 11 -- The Giants closed their spring road trip with an outburst of round-trippers today that sank the Cleveland Indians for their fourth victory in a row, 6 -- 2. The triumph moved Mel Ott's band three games in front of the American Leaguers, clinching the interleague series.

In this morning's newspapers the box score of the exhibition game yesterday at Ebbets Field between the Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Yankees carries the above name in the Brooklyn line-up. If Robinson had been a white man the name would have been there long before this, for he was the prize rookie last year of the Montreal club, of the International League, which is owned by the Dodgers.

After a nation-wide and scientific search for a football coach, during which thirty-eight candidates were subjected to a written examination and other tests of gridiron instructional ability, City College came up yesterday with a mentor who had been on the campus all the time and had not gone through the mill.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 11 -- The Truman Administration takes cognizance of remedying "some infractions of mercantile law" through "mass education and cooperative assent rather than by lengthy litigation against single companies," Federal Trade Commissioner Lowell B. Mason said today.

The Dramatists Guild has sent a wire to President Truman protesting the contract signed by the Office of Alien Property with' Milton Shubert, Broadway producer, wherein the latter may use Giacomo Puccini's music for a musical play or operetta, it was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 -- A proposal that the longshore contract on the West Coast, due to expire June 15, be extended to Sept. 30 to avoid the "series of disastrous and unnecessary strikes which tied up shipping last fall" was made today by Frank P. Foisie, president of the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast.
ALBANY, April 11 -- New York contractors proposed a solution today for the "bottleneck" which is slowing down the state's big post-war highway construction program.

PARIS, April 11 -- On the eve of the second anniversary of Franklin D. Roosevelt's death, Leon Blum, writing in Agence Economique at Financiere tomorrow, will pay eloquent tribute to "a man whose vacant place no one can fill." M. Blum will tell how, in captivity two years ago, he learned through a clandestine radio broadcast of the President's death.

Trade Declines Here in Week With comparisons made against the peak week of Easter volume last year, retail trade here declined this week. Most department stores here had sales decreases under last year, the drop in some cases ranging to 15 per cent.

A nation-wide advertising program to promote the sale and consumption of fish and fish products was discussed yesterday in an allday meeting of the national advertising committee of the National Fisheries Institute, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The San Francisco Orchestra, Which Pierre Monteux, in his ten years as its conductor, has made a symphonic body to be reckoned with, nationally, made its New York debut last night in Carnegie Hall. The orchestra was greeted by a packed house, and immense enthusiasm.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday denied Rocky Graziano's application for a boxing license. Declaring that there had been nothing new in the matter since the fighter suffered revocation of his license at an open hearing two months ago, Chairman Edward Eagan advised Graziano that the board would not consider his application to box in this state.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The office of the Housing Expediter today ordered full investigation of what it termed "unauthorized construction work" on race track stands at Churchill Downs, Louisville, Ky.
WARSAW, April 11 -- Peasant party leader Stanislaw Mikolajczyh joined today the unabated Polish outcry against the proposal to revise the Polish-German frontiers.

DACHAU, Germany, April 11 -- The United States Military Tribunal today began the trial of thirty-one Buchenwald concentration camp guards and doctors. It started by asserting its competence to try them even though the camp is now in the Soviet zone.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Chairmen of the Senate and House committees having jurisdiction over price control legislation agreed today that the peak of inflation had passed.

Easter comes tomorrow for approximately 150,000 New Yorker. They are members of the Eastern Orthodox Church, whose Julian calendar differs somewhat from the Gregorian, which most Christians follow. Each of the heritages they represent, Russian, Greek Syrian, Bulgarian, Yugoslav, Rumanian and others, has its own set of customs for this great spring feast.

The State of New Jersey lost ground yesterday in its efforts to force striking telephone workers back to their jobs through the application of criminal and civil penalties under the state's drastic new utility strike law.

Trading in stocks on the Stock Exchange yesterday followed a pattern similar to that of previous sessions this week, when the concentration of buying or selling took place in the final hour. An easygoing selective recovery during the first four hours ran into selling pressure, and although strength appeared before the close, prices were lower on the day.

PITTSBURGH, April 11 -- An overnight change of policy on the part of some district officials of the United Mine Workers, AFL, made possible today a resumption of regular production in the bituminous fields on Monday. The end of the safety strike was foreseen with the reopening this morning of seven of the biggest captive mines of the United States Steel Corporation.
Today is the day!

A "good feeding" ship is a good fighting ship, according to Comdr. Kenneth G. Schacht of the Submarine Trumpetfish, anchored at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn. He made this observation to a group of women visitors specially invited aboard for a luncheon and inspection tour on the forty-seventh anniversary of the day on which the United States Navy purchased its first submarine.

Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle ordered a survey yesterday of 1,200 hotels in the city to make certain they conform with the provisions of the recently enacted State legislation covering safety in the hotels. He said 425 hotels had been notified since last December to eliminate fire hazards or accept summons for court action.

Boys and girls have poured into Teen Canteens in the last three or four years, enjoying the freedom and share in planning. Many centers have flourished, others have slumped, and community feeling about these ventures is still strongly pro and con, according to a new study by Hazel Osborn.

Dr. Joshua L. Liebman, radio clergyman and author of "Peace of Mind," will speak in Town Hall Wednesday at 11 A.M. on "The Road to Inner Serenity" Dr. Liebman is Visiting Professor of Jewish Philosophy and Literature at Andover-Newton Theological Seminary and is believed to be the first raboi appointed to the faculty of a Christian theological seminary to teach Judaism.

Increases in calf leather prices during the last month to six weeks may be rescinded as a result of the 10 1/2 to 12 cents a pound decline in prices of April calfskins in sales by packers on Thursday, it was reported in trade circles here yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., April 11 -- The supervision of boys' clubs, summer camps and similar group activities were declared today "not to be a function of the police department." Inspector Lawrence Morrison, director of the crime prevention division of the Houston, Tex., department, said that group work programs were putting too great a strain on already inadequate departmental budgets.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The marriage of Senorita Argentina Copello, daughter of Senora Argentina de Soto de Copello of this city and Santiago, Dominican Republic, to Robert Whittier Dudley of Washington and Hanover, N.H., took place this afternoon at the Sulgrave Club. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. W. Louis Quinn of St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral.

OKLAHOMA CITY, April 14 (AP) -- This city was without street-car and bus service for twelve hours today when employes of the owners, the Oklahoma Transportation Company, refused to cross the picket line of another union. Service was resumed in mid-afternoon, after a court order prohibiting the picketing had been issued.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 12 -- Bob De Coppet, with his boat Zotom, and Arthur Knapp Jr., with the Agony, tied at 83 points each today in the Interclub Class at the end of the first session of the national dinghy championships at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- In the view of many observers here the Republicans seem to be polishing up the silver platter upon which the Democrats gave them the election in 1946 for the apparent purpose of returning the compliment in 1948.

In choosing Rouen as the French Terminal of the Maersk Line's new trans-atlantic service, the Moller Steamship Company, Inc., opeators of the line, have selected a port that has suffered relatively minor war damage and now has little shipping congestion, M.M. Moller, president, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- Corn dropped for losses extending to around 3 cents a bushel at times today on the Board of Trade, the deferred deliveries leading the downturn. Wheat and oats, while weak at times, recovered toward the session's close.

AT this late date, some measure of a business recession can scarcely be avoided. Or at least the means by which it could have been done are no longer practically available. Present levels of prices are higher than can be sustained with currently earned incomes plus remaining reserves of savings, and buying consumer durables on credit needs in most lines to slacken rather than to expand.

IT'S refreshing, just for a change, to switch from a rowdy sport like baseball to a sedate, gentlemanly pastime such as boxing. But the Manly Art of Modified Murder will be in the news again on Tuesday when those two reluctant dragons, Bruce Woodcock and Joe Baksi, battle in bonnie England for the dubious distinction of meeting Joe Louis in June.

The Working Girls' Vacation Society will benefit from the evening performance of "Finian's Rainbow" on Thursday at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. Mrs. Frederic W. Ecker is chairman of the benefit committee and Mrs. Henry W. Warner honorary chairman.

The nation-wide telephone strike grew out of union demands for higher wages, the union shop, increased pensions, longer vacations, shortening of the time required to reach top pay levels, and other concessions.

BERLIN, April 12 -- Oberbuergermeister Dr. Otto Ostrowski ignored today a communication from the Magistrat requesting that he submit his resignation as a result of yesterday's vote of no confidence by the Berlin Assembly.

To the Drama Editor: WHAT is an experimental theatre? Strictly defined, perhaps it is a theatre where plays are produced which depart from the accepted conventions of playwriting or production methods and the author and other artists concerned have a chance to see how acceptable or effective their departures are.

AN AMERICAN correspondent was discussing with a Soviet consular official in Manchuria the apparent Soviet attitude of aloofness toward China, especially the closed Siberian border across which nothing was moving in either direction. Surprise was expressed that the Soviet Union was not taking an active part in helping the Chinese Communists in the civil war with the Nationalist Government of Nanking.

T. H. WHITE, memorable for "The Sword in the Stone" and "Mistress Masham's Repose." has not done it again. The present novel is a satirical fantasy set in Ireland: its heavy atmospherics roll in on the reader with all the cloudy ponderosity of a Galway sky.

The tramp, tramp, tramp of marching feet on upper Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon brought Army Week to a close. It was the annual Army Day parade, sponsored by the Military Order of the World Wars, in belated observance of the anniversary of the entrance of this country into World War I. It was also New York's salute to the motto of Army Week that "A Strong America Is a Peaceful America."

AMONG the most discussed proposed improvements for the motor car of the future, possibly even for some 1948 models, is direct injection of gasoline into the combustion chambers. Already much research has been devoted to this development, the chief aim being to reduce the cost.

In a letter to Mayor O'Dwyer, made public yesterday, the Citizens Budget Commission expressed approval of the Mayor's insistence that $92,000,000 of cost-of-living pay rises for city employes be kept on a temporary basis in the 19471948 executive budget of $1,029,120,314.

A sinister upswing in drunken and reckless driving, resulting from the heavy increase in spring motoring, was forecast yesterday by John S. Cuthbert, Eastern representative of the National Safety Council, unless drastic curbs are applied immediately.

STUTTGART, Germany, April 12 -- The bizonal economic agencies of the merged United States and British zones are developing into going concerns this spring with effects -- both economic and political -- that are beginning to be felt.

ALBANY, April 12 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey signed today bill mandating minimum salaries for classroom teachers ranging from $2,000 to $5,325. He said the bill, passage of which was marked by controversy, will provide "the highest state-wide schedule of teachers' salaries in the nation."

Curtailment of domestic demand for women's apparel has stepped up efforts of coat, suit and dress manufacturers to expand their exports. Despite numerous obstacles, such as lack of foreign exchange and stiff tariff barriers, all signs point to a record year in finished wearing apparel, a survey of the trade indicated last week.

MANY gardeners who would not think of being without a vegetable garden and a row of strawberries seem to think that raspberries are too difficult or too much trouble. Raspberries require less care and last far longer than a strawberry patch, which must be replanted every second or third year at the latest.

Qualified approval of President Truman's policy in the Mediterranean was expressed yesterday by the Council for Social Action of the Congregational Christian Churches of the United States, which sent its recommendations to members of Congress.

The domestic cotton trade, the Government and international diplomatic officials are manifesting increasing concern over the future course of American cotton exports as factors tending to limit shipments of the staple abroad continue to develop.

PARIS, April 12 -- Charles de Gaulle appeared to have re-entered French politics with a flourish of trumpets this week. His speech at Strasbourg was regarded by some as historic for this reason. Others, including some of his most ardent devotees, found it was merely a disappointing reiteration of his familiar ideas.

Forty-seven women from sixteen countries will be brought to the United States for advanced study and special training through the $2,100,000 round-the-world reconstruction fund campaign now being conducted by the Young Women's Christian Associations.

NINETEENTH-century American paintings appear in two of the current exhibitions. At the Kennedy Gallery three of Albert Bierstadt's paintings are among the highlights, one of them being a huge Sierra Nevada morning panorama and another the picturesque "Multnomah Falls."

STUTTGART, Germany, April 11 (Delayed) -- The economically merged United States and British zones are facing a grave crisis that makes maintenance of the present ration questionable. This was disclosed today at the close of the three-day bizonal food conference of Allied and German officials.

MANCHESTER, England, April 12 (AP) -- Mr. Wallace today called President Truman's proposal to aid Turkey and Greece a commitment "to rush to the aid of every dictator who hoisted the anti-Communist Skull and Bones."

William F. Smart, shorthand expert, who was for twenty-five years official reporter of the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., died on Friday in the Polyclinic Hospital, of a cerebral thrombosis and terminal pneumonia after an illness of six weeks. His age was 72.

THE first and most important step in a garden operation is preparing the soil for planting. Whether the project at hand is the building of a new flower border, the replanting of an established area or preparing a new vegetable or flower garden, time and careful work are needed.

MADRAS, India, April 12 -- The story of Communist expansion in South India is one of shrewd organizational tactics exploiting a general economic discontent. Its success may be judged by the acute fear of communism that exists in conservative Hindu society.

LONDON, April 12 -- Denouncing as "deplorable" a statement issued yesterday by the British catering industry advising tourists not to come to Britain until 1948, Sir Alexander H. Maxwell, chairman of the British Tourist Board, declared today that Britain wanted as many visitors as possible this year.
Capricious April acted just that way yesterday with a record high temperature for the date of 75.3 degrees here at 1:35 P.M. and an unseasonable cold spell covering the Midwest.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 12 -- The seventy-fifth observance of Arbor Day, the holiday dedicated to tree planting, finds the Pacific Northwest, the principal lumberproducing area of the country, engaged in a far-reaching controversy over the effectiveness of a reforestation program undertaken in recent years by the lumber industry.

Messages from President Truman and Governor Dewey hailing City College as an example of "democracy in action" and praising its "superb contribution" to the city and state were made public yesterday as the college prepared for City College Centennial Week which will begin today.

THE wistful little fellow with the smudge of mustache, battered derby and baggy trousers has had his day in the sun and has wandered off in his upturned shoes, jauntily swinging that wonderfully flexible bamboo cane, to a land whence there is no returning.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- In reply to a charge made at the convention of the National Catholic Educational Association in Boston on Thursday, the National Education Association today denied that it was blocking Federal aid to schools.

The aid of the Federal Government and parent-teachers associaations should be invoked to improve conditions in the teaching profession, according to pupils who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

WITH the final Sunday afternoon subscription concert this afternoon the Philharmonic-Symphony Society completes its 105th New York season. This is not, however, the end of the season's activities for the orchestra.
LONDON, April 12 -- Miss Clemence Dane's new play, "Call Home the Heart," was well received by the critics on Friday after its opening performance at St. James' Theatre Thursday night.

SIX of the country's orchestras will be under different heads next season. The New York Philharmonic will have Bruno Walter as its musical adviser. Artur Rodzinski, who left the Philharmonic, will lead the Chicago Symphony.

THE locale for Polan Banks' period novel is New Orleans during the carriage, gaslight and French opera era of the Nineties, when the Vieux Carre was the haunt of proud Creole families rather than of antique shops, bars and budding authors.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 3 to 25 points net lower than on Friday, with a moderate volume of business.

OMAHA, April 12 -- Sternwheel towboats, a throwback to more romantic days on the Missouri River, were suggested this week as one means of transporting the embarrassingly large holdover stocks of corn on Midwest farms.

In taking up directly with Foreign Minister Molotov the question of a settlement in Korea, Secretary Marshall has taken the only course that gives any hope for breaking the deadlock prevailing there for a year between the United States and the U.S.S.R. The problem of Korea is one that can be settled only on the Moscow-Washington level.

Twenty-four hours are not nearly enough for the pleasure boat skipper's day now that April and fitting-out chores are here. The horny-handed yachtsman who is already growing more callouses, what with scraping, sanding, painting and varnishing, may have been a jovial, easy-going lazy gent during his winter week-ends, but if he appears jittery, excitable, impatient during the next month his family, in-laws and neighbors must be tolerant. He is not to blame.

TOKYO, April 12 -- Local eletions for Japanese prefectural Governors, Mayors and members of town and village assemblies came and went this week. Japanese political analysts, busily checking the results, have now arrived at some fairly clear answers on the attitude of the national electorate eighteen months after surrender.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 12 -- Here at the little white chapel where Franklin D. Roosevelt last attended church services, 300 villagers and polio victims in wheel chairs participated in memorial services today for the late President, who called this his second home.

LIKE monopoly at home, international cartels are symptomatic of the economic disease which Thurman Arnold has aptly labeled "hardening of the commercial arteries." Between the two wars there was a marked trend toward further concentration of industrial and financial power all over the world, and the same motives of self-enrichment and self-protection that led to the "stabilization" of competition nationally inspired the formation of cartels on an international scale.

UNTIL a very few years ago the physician maintained a graceful and mutually rewarding relationship with his patients and neighbors. The twentieth century has ripped this comfort from us. It is no longer profitable, either to patient or physician, for medical practice to exist entirely on an individualistic basis.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 12 -- President Truman began his third year in office today by paying tribute to his predecessor, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, as a "great humanitarian." His eulogy was delivered over the radio here, on the second anniversary of Mr. Roosevelt's death.

THE Literary Life: A gentleman with, so to speak, a gift for letters, is writing as follows to publishers: "I specialize in autographing books for authors in exact facsimile of their handwriting. Expert workmanship is assured and prices are reasonable."

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Negotiations in the telephone strike reached a virtual standstill today when the American Telephone and Telegraph Company rejected a proposal for conferences with the union on an industry-wide basis.

Wages and Prices Again The Presidential press conference is a unique institution. It gives the nation's press and radio correspondents an opportunity to query the President directly, often forces him to state his position on questions that heads of states like to duck.
MORE and more women in the United States may be divorcing their husbands, but as far as the war brides now in this country are concerned, the American male is a marital blue-ribbon winner.

Strauss: Don Juan. The National Symphony Orchestra conducted by Sidney Beers. (Decca FFRR, two twelve-inch records.) This is a British ensemble, not the orchestra of the same name of our own capital. The music is brilliantly recorded, and the performance is forthright and sonorous.

The same methods used in measuring the heat of stars millions and millions of light-years away are applied by General Electric engineers in devising rockets that will outdo the German V-2. Before such an improved rocket can be produced the searing heat and the supersonic velocity of gases must be measured.

ALL those who grow garden peas successfully agree on several primary points. The importance of early planting -- March 15 to April 15 in this area -- and a rich, friable soil to a depth of twelve to twenty inches are basic factors.

LONDON. IT is becoming increasingly difficult to win money at bridge. Or at any rate enough money. That is why there are very few bridge professionals, in my meaning of the word, playing today. There are a large number of would-be professionals, but that is quite another matter.

A collection of prints that includes historical portraits, naval subjects and Audubon birds from the estate of the late Mrs. Walter B. James and others will be auctioned tomorrow at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WHEN Mr. Robinson's great snow is at its height, the whole northeastern quadrant of the United States is menaced with extinction: New York, as the focal point of this super-blizzard's wrath, is blanketed to the first step-backs of its skyscrapers. * * * When the storm abates at last, and spring melts the drifts into the rivers, 800,000 are dead.

ST. LOUIS, April 12 -- Solution of world ills and the establishment of a global government to eliminate war were impossible, the Rev. B. Frank Hall, Pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Clayton, declared today, unless America leads the world back to the political philosophy of the Eighteenth Century.

IT may be unjust to say so, but I have an idea that James Reid Parker is a personable man who can mix a salad dressing with just enough of a whiff of garlic to give it tone without letting the garlic dominate. In a way, this statement verges on the libelous, but it derives honestly from a reading of the twenty-four pieces which make up this book.

ALMOST everything about this novel smacks of the borderline. The setting, somewhere near the head of the Gulf of California, straddles the American - Mexican boundary. The characters exist in a limbo especially contrived for them out of Mr. Waters' extensive knowledge of the region.

THE world-wide conference to draft recommendations for simplification of passport and visa requirements and for speeding of customs border examinations will convene tomorrow in the Palace of the United Nations at Geneva.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Women's National Press Club today announced its annual awards for outstanding achievements by women. President Truman will present the awards at a dinner on April 19.

Stock prices weakened 1 to 2 points yesterday and closed at new low levels of the year as trading broadened to the largest volume for an abbreviated session since March 8. The turnover was 630,000 shares.

GENOA, Italy, April 12 (AP) -- Charles "Lucky" Luciano -- called "the boomerang" here because of his second enforced return to his native land -- was taken off the deportation ship Bakir by ten policemen today and lodged in jail.

THERE is some very pretty writing in "House of Mist," and a kind of engaging breathlessness of manner, as if the story simply couldn't wait to be told. At the same time there is a good deal of tricky and involved narration, and a reliance upon certain old and somewhat worn devices.

A recent announcement from the Soil Conservation Service of the Department of Agriculture emphasizes two important points. First, efforts to save the nation's topsoil are making progress; second, we still have a considerable distance to go. The statistics of the past are sober reading.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 12 -- The United Nations' building plans for its permanent site may be submited at the coming special session of the General Assembly instead of at the regular session next September, Benjamin A. Cohen, Assistant Secretary General in charge of public information, said today.

AMONG the one-man shows of the week is one of work by Philip Malicoat, at the gallery of Jacques Seligmann. The artist, a resident of Provincetown, paints in a manner closely analogous to that of Edwin Dickinson, most notably so in an impressionist landscape and two portraits; and the "Sonata Players," his most ambitious picture, strangely recalls the memorable canvas by Dickinson which was once given a prize by the Academy and hung upside down.

VIENNA, April 12 -- Having compelled the once-dominant Small-holders party to amputate by stages its own parliamentary majority, Hungarian Leftists are trying to force Premier Ferenc Nagy to repudiate Anglo-American efforts to save the cause of democracy in Hungary.

London Visitor In his Madison Square Garden speech on last Sept. 12 the then Secretary of Commerce, Henry A. Wallace, sharply criticized American policy toward Russia and warned against following "British imperialistic" policies in the Middle East.

SINGAPORE. AMERICAN motion picture agents in the Orient report that the earnings of Hollywood productions are surpassing pre-war boxoffice records throughout the Far East. American films encounter "no competition" from British films, even in British territory, where restrictions and discriminations operate against American entertainment enterprises, according to representatives of the major American companies.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 12 -- New and severe controls are to be imposed on the already tightly rigged economy of the Netherlands. It is affirmed that too many persons are indulging in the folly of luxurious living.
London. The following are stories now making the rounds in the British capital: A KINDLY Food Ministry has recently decided that whale meat shall be made available to the public through fishmongers.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Here are the provisions of the sweeping Republican union-control bitt prepared by the House Labor Committee: NATIONAL LABOR RELATIONS BOARD The present board would be abolished and in its place the bill would set up a three-member labor -management relations board.

LIVING costs, as we all know, alas, are at record levels. In January, 1946, the consumers' price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 129.5 (100 being the 1935-39 average). In February, 1947, the index had risen to 152.8.

D.C. SOMERVELL has performed his chosen task -- a labor of love -- extremely well. He has condensed the six bulky volumes of Toynbee's monumental work on the rise and fall of civilizations into a single book that challenges comparison with the one-volume edition of Frazer's "The Golden Bough" -- and is no less remarkable an achievement.

THE theme of this book might be said to be that what democracy and the free enterprise system need is more oldstyle "git-up-and-git." Mr. Teague, who is by profession an industrial designer and collaborating author of "Design Thia Day: The Technique of Order in the Machine Age" (1940), seems for the purposes of his present argument to have mastered nearly all the arts and sciences.

TO THE EDITOR: Apropos the article, "Babies Are Puppies, Puppies Are Babies," by Lawrence K. Frank: The high love of the dog held by many of the present day is an atavism. Eras ago the human needed the dog for protection against other humans and against unfriendly beasts.

IT is a significant commentary on our time that the phrase "men of good-will" has come to be used with contempt. The cynics and the so-called realists utter it with a sneer when they wish to dismiss those whom they regard as well-meaning meddlers.
Brooklyn fandom, hardly recovered from its shock over the banishment of Manager Leo Durocher, may soon be rocked by another.

MONKTON, Md., April 12 (AP) -- Stuart S. Janney Jr.'s long-winded gelding Winton pulled clear of a three-horse pile-up at the final jump of a three-mile steer 'se to win My Lady's Manor point-topoint race before 7,000 spectators today. It was the third straight victory for Janney aboard the 13year-old Winton in the annual timber classic through the rolling Maryland countryside.

Spring, as Chaucer pointed out some centuries ago, is the time when folk long to go on pilgrimages. In other and more normal years a tide of tourist travel to Europe would be setting in about now. But this year Europe, usually so anxious to entertain us, seems a doubtful host.

A prosaic but historical bodyremoval permit, issued in this city eighty-two years ago, has just changed hands here. It recalls the period of deep mourning in New York over the death of President Abraham Lincoln. The anniversary of his assassination is tomorrow.

The text of President Truman's address on the Franklin D. Roosevelt memorial broadcast yesterday, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES. was as follows: My Fellow-Countrymen: One year ago today I stood in silence beside a newly built tomb in the Rose Garden at Hyde Park.

The program has been completed for the annual convention of the American Institute of Architects, to be held in Grand Rapids, Mich., April 29 to May 1, James R. Edmunds Jr., president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Senate majority conference voted 21 to 7 today to combine labor reform proposals in an omnibus bill and thus confront President Truman squarely with a choice between a single Republican formula for regulating unions and no restrictive legislation whatever.

LONDON, April 12 (Reuters) -- Results of football games in the British Isles today: INTERNATIONAL SOCCER England 1. Scotland 1 (at Wembley). F.A. CUP SEMI-FINAL REPLAY Burnley 1. Liverpool 0 (at Manchester).

Dr. Wesley C. Mitchell, Professor Emeritus of Economics at Columbia University, urged intensified use of modern research techniques to solve world economic problems in a report issued yesterday by the National Bureau of Economic Research.

To add a touch of the suburban atmosphere to urban housing the builders of the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment structure at 20 East Seventy-fourth Street are providing an individual balcony or terrace for nearly every suite in the house.

ONCE upon a time (war is a strange taskmaster) I was assigned to study that massive work "The Oceans" (by Sverdrup, Johnson and Fleming). The reasons for my assignment were at the time almost as mysterious as the sea itself, but I soon discovered, to my interest, that the ocean is not just a lot of salt water housing fish and shrimp.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., April 12 -- The second anniversary of the death of Franklin Delano Roosevelt was commemorated with a memorial service at his birthplace here today.

With final details for the purchase of three Victory-type vessels from the Maritime Commission completed, the flag of the Union of South Africa will soon be seen for the first time in "deepwater" trading, it was announced here yesterday.

LIVESTOCK -- America's animal kingdom is shrinking. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics reports that, though the total value of livestock in the nation is at an all-time high of $11,252,000,000, the number is lower than last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 -- West Coast longshoremen at a caucus today refused to accept a proposal of Frank P. Foisie, president of the Waterfront Employers' Association of the Pacific Coast, that the present longshore contract, signed Nov. 17 and expiring on June 15, be extended to Sept. 30.

Under the impetus of economic unrest, financial markets reacted nervously last week. A telephone strike, continuation of the coal stoppage and conflicting opinions concerning price levels confused the general business picture. In addition, the lack of progress on labor and tax legislation contributed to the uncertainty.

JUST thirty-five years ago this week in this Review: Page One is shared by Lady Gregory's "Irish Folk-History Plays" and Johannes Jorgensen's "St. Francis of Assisi." Of Lady Gregory, the reviewer writes, "She is known more appreciatively for her fostering of the Irish drama rather than for her achievement in it.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 12 (AP) -- Rokeby Stables' Paul Revere, winner last week of the Deep Run Hunt Cup in Richmond, won the Louie Leith Cup today at the twenty-sixth spring meeting of the Middleburg Hunt Racing Association before a crowd of 6,000.

Amid a preliminary fanfare such as has rarely, if ever, been seen before, the 1947 major league baseball season is about to get under way and among the game's millions of fans it is quite possible the prevailing opinion is the inaugural isn't coming any too soon.

COLUMBIA -- Teachers College A record number of students from outside the continental United States -- 168 men and 194 women from fifty countries -- is now attending Columbia University's Teachers College. The largest groups represent Canada, China, Puerto Rico, Hawaii and India.

"CALL ME MISTER," Broadway's ode to the separation center, will be eligible Friday for the Good Conduct Ribbon, a trinket the Army used to hand out for twelve months of service unmarred by heinous crimes.

Beethoven's Ninth Symphony was presented by the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, under Leopold Stokowski, at the organization's Pension Fund benefit concert, last night at Carnegie Hall. For good measure, this gigantic masterpiece was prefaced by the Bonn master's Eighth Symphony, the two highly contrasted works forming an unusually noble and impressive program.

HISTORY holds few success stories to compare with that of Joseph, eleventh son of Jacob, the slave boy who became master of the world's mightiest empire. The biblical story of Joseph is told in a few pages of Genesis. Its writer, who used words more sparingly than most modern story-tellers, left much to the imagination.

Charles M. de Forest of 135 West Sixteenth Street, executive vice president and a founder of the American Provident Society, died yesterday in St. Petersburg, Fla., according to word received here last night by an officer of the society.

THE dispute in Washington over fluids for Customs Service personnel focuses attention on a problem that affects the entire field of foreign travel as well as thousands of American tourist and business travelers; the annoying delays at customs and immigration barriers at the piers and international airports.

KILKENNY, Ireland, April 12 -- In no part of Ireland are the farmers battling against greater odds to get in their wheat crops than in the country around this picturesque medieval Leinster town known as "the marble city," a name associated with the black marble quarries around it.

NOT the man to avoid the topical or controversial subject, Producer Jerry Wald next month will start filming the tentatively titled, "Up Till Now" for Warners, a picture which may turn out to be as controversial as any, according to the producer.

THERE is nothing particularly novel about a single or a series of attacks upon the movies for badly influencing the public's mores and morals. Such attacks have been frequent and familiar in the history of the screen, and the industry has come to regard them as hazards of the game.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 12 -- Dave Carpenter pitched and batted Princeton to a 5-4 victory over the Naval Academy nine today. Carpenter collected three hits in four chances, including a triple in the eighth inning, that sent the winning run across.

The Metropolitan Golf Association will open the 1947 tournament season with a one-day medal-play event over the Glen Ridge Country Club, Glen Ridge, N.J., on May 20, it was announced yesterday by Theodore G. Law, chairman of the tournament committee.

THE growling wrangle about the relative importance of the nation's lawmakers and balladeers is an old one, but the latter win hands down so long as Frank Sinatra is around to sing the product. For Mr. Sinatra is The Voice; he is the spokesman for that humble third of a nation which is pretty young but fiercely intense; he is "An American Phenomenon."

THIS pint-size biography of America's Edgar Wallace will undoubtedly interest the millions of Gardner mystery fans (6,104,000 books, including 25c editions, sold in 1945). It doesn't tell so much how Gardner turns out such a large and successful product as it relates what he experienced in order to be able to do it.

THE mail in response to the Le Gallienne "Alice in Wonderland" has been terrific. Two letters arrived at this desk on the same day. One from a petulant gentleman offers a solution to the inaudibility mentioned in the first night review:

THE background for this tale of mystery and murder is the Greenwich Village Outdoor Art Show, and most of the characters are artists or other Villagers. Jane MacDevitt, a reporter, goes to interview Andrina Manderson, a writer of mystery stories, and is present when the body of Sue Marvin, sometimes known as "The Torso," is discovered, fully clothed, in Mrs. Manderson's bathtub.

MANILA, April 12 -- Maj. Gen. George F. Moore, commanding the Philippines-Ryukyus Command, who last November assumed one of the Army's most ticklish jobs in the Pacific theatre, now finds himself more or less seriously embarrassed. In full blast is a newspaper expose of graft and corruption in the disposal of Army supplies and surplus property totaling an estimated $500,000,000 during the last two years.

PARIS, April 12 -- The Communist Party organ, the newspaper Humanite, linked today, the anniversary of the late President Roosevelt's death, with the forthcoming visit to Paris of Henry A. Wallace. An article in the paper said that Mr. Wallace represented the spirit of the late President as opposed to the foreign policy of President Truman.

A tale of the activities of helicopter planes in the Antarctic and the caring for a group of fifty-four seasick penguins was told yesterday by Coast Guard Lieut. David Gershowitz of 368 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, the first member of the Byrd expedition to reach New York.

Competitive bidding, a formality commonly required by local governments and by railroad and public utility companies in selling bond issues to underwriters, is to be tried out in the field of industrial securities within the next few weeks.

HOLLYWOOD. TWENTY-SEVEN pages of demands, tactfully described as "proposals," were issued last week by the Screen Actors Guild as a preliminary move in the negotiation of a new employment contract with film producers to supplant the present agreement, which expires May 15.

THREE years ago a certain neighborhood out in Queens was a mixed community where few people mixed. Not one of the city's best areas, and not one of the worst, its people were not getting along well together. They were mostly Negro, with a minority of Italian, Irish and Jewish origins.

IN "Hotel Vesuvius," besides the text, the illustrations are the handiwork of the author. Mr. Fabricius' drawings, which are numerous, remind one of a cross between modern language textbook decorations and wax crayon color-ins for the kiddies.

IT is enlivening for the American reader to hear about Latin America from an English historian, especially from one who can write with such grace, compactness and insight as does Robin A. Humphreys, Reader in American History in the University of London.

BANFF, Alberta -- Spring skiing on the treeless slopes of the Canadian Rockies at from 1,000 to 10,000 feet is now attracting enthusiasts from all over North America to this popular mountain resort, itself nearly a mile above the sea.

An eighth-inning error by Lehigh's second baseman, Geza Molnar, permitted New York University's baseball team to defeat the Pennsylvanians, 6 -- 5, yesterday before 300 people at Ohio Field, for the Violets second victory of the season.

Substantially 75.18 per cent of the trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange originates in the states bordering on the Atlantic seaboard, it was disclosed yesterday on the basis of reports covering a week's business of 350 member firms.
IT is easy to grow midget roses from seed. The supply of seeds is low, but once they have been obtained the rest is as simple as raising a zinnia.

BREWSTER, N.Y., April 12 -- A light rain dampened the clothing but none of the ardor of a record number of anglers who thronged the watershed lakes and streams of Putnam and Westchester Counties at daybreak this morning, and although the sun broke through at 10 o'clock the trout refused the cooperation that would have made opening day a success.

SO long as ambitious writers continue to seek dramatic themes in the annals of our nation's history, the battle of Gettysburg will be an inspiration and a challenge -- and a frequent literary ambuscade. For the lore of this great and grim engagement in the Pennsylvania hills between the armies of Lee, sweeping northward, and the uncertain forces of Meade conceals a vast host of enigmas ready to put the unguarded writer to rout.

NANKING, April 12 -- Foreign Office sources said today that a new Soviet note on Dairen had been received. The Soviet message was concerned with the occupation of Dairen by Chinese Government civil and military authorities. Officials refused to disclose the contents of the note.

THERE is no question in the world that Joe Louis is a more interesting fellow than the book called "My Life Story" would have you believe. I have read a good many "autobiographies" of heavyweight boxing champions.

PITTSBURGH, April 12 -- The steel industry, which three months ago assumed the lead for labor peace in 1947, faces the prospect of an unexpected strike growing out of a failure of wage contract negotiations to resolve a single issue among the fourteen demands made by the United Steelworkers of America, CIO.

THE first green spears of perennials are beginning to push through the warm, brown earth. They should be the harbingers of an everchanging succession of flower pictures made by careful selection and arrangement of perennials, annuals, and bulbs.

New ideas for homes and housing equipment, model plans and a sample house are included in the metropolitan home show which will open at noon next Saturday in Grand Central Palace. The exhibit will be open to the public for a week, closing at 10 P.M. on April 26.

ESTORIL, Portugal, April 12 -- Don Juan, Pretender to the Spanish throne, declared here today that any compromise with Generalissimo Francisco Franco on restoration of the monarchy was unthinkable. But he said he expected a new move soon from the Franco side and was convinced that pressure inside Spain would force the dictator to step out of the picture.
Dartmouth's baseball team had no trouble with a wobbly Columbia nine and won, 11--2, in the opening Eastern Intercollegiate League game for both teams before 1,000 at Baker Field yesterday.

Bosses for the Atom On Oct. 28, 1946, President Truman named a five-man, all-civilian United States Atomic Energy Commission to control all atomic energy activities within the nation. Last week -- after eighty-four days of Congressional wrangling -- the longest fight on a Presidential appointment since 1941 -- the Senate confirmed the nominations of the commission members.

The "automatic teller," a comparatively new mechanical development in banking, which involves scrapping the traditional pass book, is receiving renewed attention from bankers now eagerly seeking improved methods and the utmost in mechanization to offset rising costs of operation.

With a flight plan calling for a journey around the world in two and one-half days, the Reynolds Bombshell, converted high-speed military plane, took off from La Guardia Field yesterday at 5:11 P.M. but ran into delay two hours later.

IN "The Amboy Dukes," Mr. Shulman illumines the problem of juvenile delinquency during our hectic war years. His style is fervid, yet terse; his understanding genuine. He writes not to shock, but to clarify.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- The beginning of an era of "rejuvenated government," in which "men in public service are going to have to conduct themselves so as to merit public respect," is promised by Martin H. Kennelly when he succeeds Mayor Edward J. Kelly at the City Hall on Tuesday.

ONLY those who nave had the experience can fully appreciate the quickening of the pulse that comes to the student of history as he stumbles upon some long-hidden document whose existence historians have suspected and for which they have searched unsuccessfully. When that document happens to be a part of so famous a monument of political and literary history as the Declaration of Independence, the tug at the emotions can only be described as violent.

Youth was served last night as a Beilfuss Natatorium team, averaging only 22 years in age, dethroned the Illinois Athletic Club's veteran combination as National A.A.U. indoor water polo champion at the New York Athletic Club.

Eighty-one-year-old David Mannes will wield a baton over his sixty-five piece symphonic ensemble for the last time this afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. With the downward beat for the finish of Strauss' "Tales From the Vienna Woods," Mr. Mannes will have completed thirty seasons of conducting.

TEN years ago Wilfred E. Binkley published his "Powers of the President," an outstanding analytic history of the relationship of Congress and the President, the classic on this important and now timely subject.
LONDON, April 12 (Canadian Press) -- In scenes reminiscent of colorful pre-war days, England and Scotland today battled to a 1-1 draw in the annual international soccer match at Wembley Stadium.

Elliott Roosevelt, son of the late President, said last night that President Truman's domestic policies were leading to "a depression that is almost upon us" and that the Administration's foreign policy made the threat of war a "menacing possibility."

EVERYTHING about mankind is paradox. He who strives and conquers grows soft. The magnanimous man grown rich becomes mean. The creative artist for whom everything is made easy nods. Every doctrine swears that it can breed men, but none can tell us in advance what sort of men it will breed.

NOT all the bidding systems in the world, and not all the logic, will ever talk bridge players out of some bids that they make instinctively. This fact may be the answer to an argument that is under way in the pages of The Bridge World magazine.

MOBILE, Ala. -- Warming in the April sun, Mobile looks back on a season in which her azaleas bloomed for a record number of visitors, and forward to developments which are calculated to bring her more tourists. Some of these developments are under way and others are spoken of with confidence.

Tributes were paid yesterday to Franklin D. Roosevelt on the second anniversary of his death at Passover memorial services in synagogues. The Passover festival, commemorating the deliverance of ancient Hebrews from bondage in Egypt, ended last sundown for conservative and orthodox Jews. Reform Jews ended the observance Friday at sundown.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 12 (AP) -- Led by their double winners, Herb Barten and Charles Fonville, the University of Michigan Wolverines upset a favored University of California team, 71 1/2 to 59 1/2, today in their track and field meet which opened the outdoor season before 8,500 spectators.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- Aided by the slugging of Hank Lequear, Pennsylvania defeated Cornell in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game today, 12 -- 7. Lequear made three hits, including a homer with two on base in the eighth.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 -- From every state capital on the West Coast has come more than the usual number of stories of lobbyist activities in the Legislatures this year; but anyone outside Sacramento gets the impression that the lobbies in the California capital are working overtime.

The City College baseball team toppled Hofstra from Metropolitan Conference leadership by defeating the Long Islanders, 9 -- 7, at Macombs Dam Park yesterday. The Beavers thus achieved their second league victory in three starts, but only after a see-saw battle in which a last-ditch rally by the losers just failed to tie the count.

Debutantes of next season, headed by the Misses Hope Auchincloss and Mary Lathrop Brown, will sell flowers at the annual spring festival and bazaar of St. James Episcopal Church to be held on Friday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

THERE is no enthusiast so enthusiastic as a lightplane owner and no devotee so zealous as the lightplane pilot. With such people the business of owning and/or flying a small private plane is a state of mind, a way of life, an obsession.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- Putting on a blistering rally in the final quarter, the Philadelphia Warriors gained the jump over the Knickerbockers in the semi-final play-offs for the Basketball Assoiation of America championship by defeating the New Yorkers, 82-70, tonight in the opening game of the series.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- One way of looking at John L. Lewis' exploits of the last two weeks is to measure the soft-coal production that was lost. It probably amounted to 17,000,000 tons.

TO THE EDITOR: Jacob Viner's article, "In Defense of Dollar Diplomacy," is timely in view of President Truman's recent advocacy of American aid to both Greece and Turkey. But this context does not give license to print with it a photograph of Greek children receiving food from American sources.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- General Motors' offer of a 10-cent hourly increase is not acceptable to the leaders of the two largest unions to which it was made.

DETROIT, April 12 -- General Motors Corporation offered its hourly rated production employes who are members of three CIO unions a cost-of-living wage increase of 10 cents an hour with the provision that the rise would be subject to re-examination in August.

GLENWOOD LANDING, L.I., April 12 -- Three Bronx boys, including two brothers, were drowned late this afternoon in Hempstead Harbor after their auxiliary rowboat had capsized. Two other youths and the father of the brothers were rescued by a tug, but the older man's condition is critical.

SEOUL, Korea, April 12 -- The general belief in this city today is that the long-dormant Korean problem is on the way to settlement. This belief arose as a result of United States Secretary of State Marshall's letter to Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov calling for the immediate reconvening of the Joint Commission on Korea to implement the Moscow agreement.

A work stoppage demonstration, in New Jersey that may embrace a million members of all labor unions in the state was planned last night in support of the striking telephone workers. Meanwhile, there were no signs here or across the Hudson of a break in the walkout that began last Monday.

BOWIE, Md., April 12 (AP) -- Gorget, from the Art Dale Stable of Mrs. George Smith of Newark, Del., surprised a closing-day crowd of 19,108 today by galloping to a five-length victory in the $10,000added Southern Maryland Handicap.

PARIS. AN increasing number of American students are coming to Paris to study. Already more than 500, the largest number since 1936, are registered at Paris faculties and academies great and small. House of the Cite Universitaire, International Student Center in the far reaches of the Left Bank, where life leans to the simple and rugged. In a few days the National League will launch its seventysecond baseball campaign. From all indications this promises to be one of the most successful in the league's history.

CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- The White Sox, with three pitchers hurling superbly after Johnny Rigney's shaky start, defeated the Cubs, 3-2, today to take a clinching 4-to-2 margin in their spring city series before 11,282 fans in 34-degree weather at Comiskey Park.

THIS seems to be open season for complaints about floors. Adventurous couples who have solved their housing problems by moving into coldwater flats or similar down-atthe-heel abodes report success in coping with problem walls, windows and "inside" bedrooms, but confess they are stumped by the ugliness of a long-neglected floor.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- A substantial decline in meat prices and concerted action by the country's retail grocers to bring about lower food prices were reported today by the leading trade associations of the two industries.

CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 300 head (estimated); total not given. Compared with week ago: all weights and sows. $1.50 to $1.75 lower. CATTLE

BOSTON, April 12 -- A political explosion has been building up in Boston for some time. It came this week when a grand jury indicted the President of the City Council and Acting Mayor John B. Kelley and another Councilman, Joseph M. Scannell, on charges of bribe solicitation and attempted larceny.

THE season of 1946-47 may yet become known as the year of the "comeback." Back last fall Jack Benny confounded the pundits of Radio Row by climbing up again to the top of the comedy brackets. Now, as the formal program semester nears a close, another veteran showman, Al Jolson, has caught the public's fancy anew.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- With its major affiliates locked in wage disputes, the Congress of Industrial Organizations will rally its forces tomorrow to fight pending labor measures which would impair its bargaining strength or threaten its striking power.

THE farther an Irishman travels the more nostalgic he becomes. Regardless of the affluence he may achieve in the land of his adoption he remains in his own mind an exile from Ireland. But oftentimes when the dream comes true and the exile returns to the long-remembered haunts of former days, the charm and beauty are swept away before the realities of country life.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn. WITH an outward and deceptive serenity, Oak Ridge basks in apparent well-being in the warm spring sunshine of this Year 2 of the Atomic Age. The dross and debris of its chaotic beginnings have pretty much been cleared away. Its neat white and green houses stand in prim array along paved streets and greening grass plots.

Fall merchandise lines to be opened in the wholesale markets during the next two to six weeks will reflect much of the current trend toward lower prices, it was reported here last week. Indications were that many manufacturers are planning to step up quality, revise price lines downward and absorb costs wherever possible to stimulate greater unit turnover.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- After a particularly tedious session of the first Council of Foreign Ministers in London in 1945 a cynical diplomat commented, "The world simply must not have another war because we cannot afford to have another peace conference."

FRANCE and the French, and what Americans have succeeded in making of them, have been eternally delightful subjects for our writers -- from Benjamin Franklin and Thomas Jefferson to James Thurber and Francis Steegmuller.

ONE might say that these United States are too well lighted and too new to make a milieu favorable to the ghost story. Ghosts don't flourish under fluorescent lighting. And much of America is so newly settled that ghosts have hardly had time to shake off the mold and get going.

A dog that has not won a blue ribbon at a licensed American Kennel Club event prior to Jan. 1, 1948, will not be eligible for the next Westminster Kennel Club show. The rule will apply to all but those entered in puppy classes.

There has often been discussion of the "right" tempo of the opening movement of Brahms' Third Symphony, which began the final New York concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the end of its Brahms observances of the season, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

WELLESLEY, Mass., April 12 -- Plans for a Seventy-fifth Anniversary Fund drive to raise $7,500,000 for Wellesley College maintenance and improvements were announced today by President Mildred McAfee Horton. The college will observe the seventy-fifth anniversary of its founding in June, 1950.

The present difficulties in the coal industry have not yet affected the export movement of coal to continental Europe, Capt. Granville Conway, President Truman's coordinator of emergency export programs, said yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 (AP) -- Dr. M.A. Northrup, three times national champion, came close to defeat in the first 165-pound semifinal bout today before outpointing Leland Merrill of the New York A.C. in a 4-3 thriller in the national A.A.U. wrestling tourney.

IF your child is under 16, if he has poise, an ability to think quickly, a fund of general information, originality, a sense of humor, a good voice and modesty, he is a possible quiz kid. At least, that's according to Eliza Merrill Hickok, whose sesquipedalian press release, "The Quiz Kids," might be considered a handbook on the birth and growth, the care and feeding and the give and take of pint-sized pundits.

THIS is the time of year when Broadway, adopting an old Brooklyn custom, begins talking about next season. The departmental scout, conceding that much of the conversation may add up to so much palaver, feels duty bound, nevertheless, to report that Richard Aldrich entertained Betty Field at lunch last week for reasons other than picking up the check.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Dark clouds loom on the labor horizon, threatening industrial trouble in vital sectors of the national economy.

A THREE-CENT stamp "honoring the doctors of America" will be issued on June 9, it was announced last week by Postmaster General Robert E. Hannegan. Specifically, this postal item will commemorate the founding of the American Medical Association a century ago.

ST. LOUIS, April 12 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns, who finished seventh in the American League last year, upset the world champion Cardinals in the first of their two-game spring series today, 2 to 0, before 12,000 fans.

CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- The American League has a real baseball treat ready for its fans this season.

The day of the "stunt flyer" in sales management is past and the executive with the steadiness of the airline pilot is here to stay, Wesby R. Parker, national sales manager of the General Foods Corporation said yesterday during an address before an association of manufacturers' representatives at Harrisburg, Pa.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 12 -- Prospects for the ultimate establishment of international atomic control are again at a low ebb because of renewed uncertainty over the question whether the Soviet Union is willing to accept effective international inspection.

THE amateur photographer may have to change his techniques if manufacturers of enlarging cameras adopt the Western Union Telegraph Company's new concentrated arc, or zirconium, lamp. This possibility was raised at a meeting of the Technical Section of the Photographic Society of America, at which William J. Robinson Jr., engineer physicist of the company, discussed photographic applications of the new light source.

PARIS, April 12 -- Faced with restlessness among Kabylie tribesmen in eastern Algeria, the French Government has issued an order forbidding Messali Hadj, Moslem extremist, from addressing meetings in the region, it was learned in Paris today.

IVAN MESTROVIC, the great Yugoslav sculptor, now living in this country and teaching the Syracuse University School of Fine Arts, is having a oneman show of recent work at the Metropolitan. Installed in the Mogan Wing, this impressive exhibition was arranged under the Joint sponsorship of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

NEWARK, N.J., April 12 -- The Yale trio, runner-up in the National Intercollegiate Indoor Polo championship, rode to a 13-7 victory over Princeton tonight before 2,000 at Essex Troop Armory. The game featured the final Newark program of the season.

As an unusual answer to the problem of providing adequate modern housing for hospital employes in the face of a shortage of living accommodations, the Edward S. Harkness Memorial Hall is under construction at 168th Street and Broadway.

ALBANY, April 12 -- Acting at the request of Mayor William O'Dwyer and the State Health Department, Governor Thomas E. Dewey vetoed today the JohnsonBerge bill which would have prohibited, after July 1, 1949, the dumping of garbage, rubbish or refuse, except residue from incineration, on landfills within New York City.

BOSTON, April 12 (AP) -- Two Boston Red Sox rookie pitchers, Lefty Mel Parnell and Harry Dorish, thrilled a crowd of 18,741 fans by holding the Boston Braves to three hits today while the American League champions were gaining their second straight city series shut-out by a 2-0 margin at Braves Field.

At sea level, where the pressure of the atmosphere is 14.6 pounds to the square inch, water boils at 212 F, but on top of a high mountain it boils at a temperature so much lower that it is difficult to cook potatoes.

MANCHESTER, April 12 -- For the first time in its long history Britain's cotton piece goods industry centered here is shopping in foreign markets for cotton cloth.

IF divorces continue to increase at the present rate, the day may come when there will be more divorces than marriages. The latest statistics indicate that the rise in divorce rates -- whatever the cause -- is a world-wide trend.

With a single, typical thrust of his bludgeon yesterday, Johnny Mize brought a 3-to-1 victory to the Giants over the Indians to thrill a gathering of 12,227 that flocked to the Polo Grounds for the preview of Mel Ott's 1947 machine.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 12 (AP) -- Few fishermen were expected to return home today with tales of luck such as that told by W. Gordon Donahoe of Buffalo. He cast into Erie County's railroad pond, near Protection, and pulled out a 14-inch, 1 1/2-pound rainbow trout at 12:02 A.M. (EST), one minute after the season opened.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 12 -- With twenty-six favorable replies received, United Nations officials were standing by tonight for the two approvals necessary before the special session of the General Assembly on Palestine can be called officially.

Bringing up Jackie Robinson to the Dodgers may turn out to be a master stroke by Branch Rickey. The Negro player, endeavoring to win his spurs in the Majors, yesterday delivered his first hit, a single, that drove home Pete Reiser and saved his new team-mate from the embarrassment of a shutout by the Yankees at Ebbet Field.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, April 12 -- The Administration's program of assisting eastern European countries to resist Communist expansion was endorsed by the Young Republican Western States Conference in a resolution today.

MEXICO CITY, April 12 -- The determination of President Miguel Aleman to avoid any inflation, caused by an increase in circulation through Government expenditures, has led him to turn down Government departments that have been insisting that they required additional funds to carry out their programs.

THE author of this biography, which deals solely with General Marshall's Army career and does not go into his more recent services as special envoy to China or as Secretary of State, appears to be exceptionally wellinformed.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 -- Legislation in each state to restrict the practice of social work "to persons designated as qualified practitioners by an appropriate agency" was recommended today at the conference of the American Association of Social Workers.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- In a special press conference today Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky of the Soviet Union implied today that his country could never accept a German peace treaty that did not satisfy Soviet requirement on reparations.

"I die of new books, or the ever-lasting talk about them," he said again and rather than become a follower of the "insatiable monster of modern reading" "would forswear his spectacles, play at put, mend pens, kill fleas, stand on one leg, shell peas, or do whatsoever ignoble diversion you set," etc.

PITTSBURGH, April 12 -- District leaders of the United Mine Workers, AFL, were authorized personally today by John L. Lewis, the union president, to send their men back into the bituminous pits on Monday.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 12 (AP) -- Asserting her superiority in the last sixteenth of a mile, Cosmic Missile captured the $10,000 added Ashland Stakes, for 3-year-old fillies, at Keeneland Park today before a crowd of about 12,000.

THE first of the new Pacemaker Speed Graphics and Crown Graphics, the latter without focal plane shutter, are now available in the 2 1/4x3 1/4inch size. The 3 1/4x4 1/4 and 4x5 sizes will follow later this year, according to the Graflex, Inc., announcement.

"FINGERPRINTING" DIAMONDS -- Some day it may be possible to identify diamonds as readily as fingerprints. W. Waters Schwab, New York diamond expert, says that there are no absolutely perfect diamonds. What is loosely called a "perfect" or flawless diamond is one, according to Federal authorities, which is without imperfection visible through a 10-power loupe (magnifying glass).

Paul D. Converse, Professor of Marketing at the University of Illinois, in a communication last week to THE NEW YORK TIMES, challenged the figures used by Fenton B. Turck, industrial engineer, in his address before the National Marketing Conference of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States last month.

IN time, the "feel" of a large community tends to get into the bones of its residents. But it also gets under their skins and makes them hypercritical and/or cynical about local civic virtues and defects. Rare indeed is the New Yorker (or Clevelander or Chicagoan) who doesn't think that his own home town is probably the dirtiest, most machinebeset, etc., in all the land.
