Bringing up Jackie Robinson to the Dodgers may turn out to be a master stroke by Branch Rickey. The Negro player, endeavoring to win his spurs in the Majors, yesterday delivered his first hit, a single, that drove home Pete Reiser and saved his new team-mate from the embarrassment of a shutout by the Yankees at Ebbet Field.

THERE is more truth than fiction in Percy Winner's first novel, because the locale -- Fascist Italy -- is real, and so is the protagonist, who is only thinly veiled under the name of "Dario Duvolti." The politics and the history are accurate, for Winner lived in Italy during those critical years and had a special gift for penetrating behind the scenes.

President Truman's emphasis on the responsibility of business for reducing prices because it urged the end of price controls, without mentioning the responsibility of either labor or the Government, in his press conference last Thursday, evoked strong protest from the business community.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- What to do about the dangerously high level of prices continues to hold first place on the Government's agenda of domestic affairs. Judging from developments this week it may stay there, unanswered, for some time.
Congressional debates on the Greek-Turkish loan program emphasized last week some of the risks of the aid policy but also underlined the imperative nature of its need.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 (AP) -- Sam Chapman and Eddie Joost hit home runs, the former with two on base in the second inning, to lead a thirteen-hit attack on Charley Schanz, Dick Mauney and Lou Possehl as the Philadelphia Athletics recorded a 12-to-2 victory over the Phillies in the first of a two-game city series today before 13,813 fans.

PARIS, April 12 -- In a speech published today by l'Aube, newspaper of the Catholic Popular Republican movement, Francois de Menthon declared his party opposed Gen. Charles de Gaulle's attitude toward the Constitution and the party system.

AT the New York Botanical Garden two courses start this week. "Botany for Beginners" will be taught by Dr. E.E. Naylor on six Mondays, starting tomorrow. This class is from 3 to 4 P.M. "Field Botany," a series of seven trips around the grounds to study wild plants, will be conducted by Dr. E.L. Wittrock on Saturdays at 1:30 P.M.,

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 12 -- Leslie MacMitchell of the New York A.C. won the first running of the Boardwalk Mile today in 4:14.8, breaking the tape on the straightaway course 20 yards ahead of Tommy Quinn of Elizabeth, N.J.

THIS book deals with the improvement of one's human relations through better voice and speech. Written by a well-known teacher who received her training from recognized coaches and at Teachers College, Columbia University, it is reliable without being technical.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Lord Inverchapel, the British Ambassador, declared on the radio tonight that politically, Britain welcomed the American move "to join the task of preserving peace and the cause of liberty in parts of the world where hitherto we have been alone."

IN learning to walk or to talk, in learning to read or to behave politely at the dinner table, a child learns most easily and quickly when he is "ready" for the learning, according to the developmental point of view.

Grocery manufacturers fully share the desire of President Truman to reduce the cost of living and will do all they can to help, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc. said yesterday.

HAVANA -- Tourists seldom get into the interior of Cuba. Accommodations for luxurious vacationing are not numerous there. Transportation, except by air, is crowded and rugged. And Havana makes a valiant effort to entertain American visitors adequately within its metropolitan confines.
PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, established by Alexander Cummings, who later founded The New York World, reached its 100th birthday today.

ONCE again dance devotees will have to go out of the Broadway district for performances this week. One of the most interesting events on the schedule promises to be Mura Dehn's jazz program this evening, in which she will be assisted by an all-Negro dance group and a quartet of jazz musicians.

TORONTO, April 12 -- Toronto took a 2-to-1 edge in games in the National Hockey League Stanley Cup play-off finals tonight by leading virtually all the way to defeat the Montreal Canadians, 4 to 2, at Maple Leaf Gardens.

DR. Harold Thomas Hyman, a former teacher of medicine and now a distinguished consultant and general practitioner, has written a five-volume opus which took six years to prepare with the collaboration of a dozen able physicians and surgeons.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- Agreements on land reform and the destruction of Germany's primary war plants were all that the Council of Foreign Ministers could produce today after four hours and twenty minutes of discussion. Disagreement on a score of other items, ranging from the composition of the peace conference to basic human rights, balanced the minor progress made on the two subjects.
THE pots of bulbs, hydrangeas, azaleas and other plants that were Easter gifts remain attractive from two days to two weeks, depending upon the care given them. Their future then is the question.

LONDON, April 12 -- Henry A. Wallace's first public speech in Britain was sharply criticized today by two of the country's leading newspapers. The press generally gave full and prominent reports of Mr. Wallace's speech in London last night.

SHALL women be ordained as ministers? Tomorrow at its annual meeting the New York Presbytery will vote on that question. And next month at the General Assembly in Grand Rapids, Mich., the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. will decide by the vote of its 276 Presbyteries whether women shall be ordained as regular bishops and pastors.

The National Association of Manufacturers in a statement yesterday urged the United States delegation at the current Geneva Conference to support the elimination of cartels and international commodity agreements in the proposed International Trade Organization.
A unique experiment, designed to help veterans get a college education although they do not possess the traditional academic requirements, has proved successful at Brown University, Providence, R.I.

ALBANY, April 12 -- Robert T. Lansdale, Social Welfare Commissioner, said today that the state bad started a new system of advance allotment of state aid for public assistance to the county and city public welfare districts.

HOLYOKE, Mass., April 12 -- Nathan P. Avery, school committeeman, former Mayor of this city and past president of the Massachusetts Bar Association, died in this sleep this morning at his home. His age was 77. He had been suffering from a heart ailment and recently had spent several weeks in a hospital.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- President Truman's sweeping order to purge Communists and "disloyal" employes from the executive branch of the Government and screen all new job applicants may cost close to $50,000,000.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, reported today that a Senate-House conference was "near agreement" on measures to outlaw portal-to-portal pay claims.

PROFESSOR THOMAS of Connecticut Junior College is a doughty opponent of all dualisms. Presumably he would reject Emerson's statement that there is a crack in everything God has made not because of manifest error but because of its apparent contentment with dualism.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 12 (AP) -- E.W. Edwards Son said today that it would slash prices Monday in its three up-state department stores and urged other concerns to take similar action, "to avert a depression."
Builders and prospective home buyers alike are awaiting with interest the outcome of President Truman's effort to bring prices down.

Riding to the front in the first period and holding its advantage until the final bell, the New York Athletic Club captured the national junior indoor polo championship last night by halting the Ramapo Freebooters, 11 to 8, at the Squadron A Armory.

Never in the history of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association has there been such intense organization activity in order to produce the soundly planned schedule just received from the hardworking tournament chairman, Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr., of the Crestmont Golf Club.

Retail trade figures covering last week suffered by comparison with the high pre-Easter volume of 1946. Department volume decline by as much as 15 per cent or more in the case of individual stores, with typical declines ranging from 5 to 10 per cent, it was estimated.

LONDON, April 13 -- "American imperialism" and "domination of the dollar" were loudly denounced in a joint statement issued tonight by the Communist parties of Britain, Canada, Australia and South Africa.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra completed its 105th New York season yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall and immediately began to prepare for travel, for at 12:55 P.M. today the group leaves for Baltimore, the first stop of its 4,000-mile tour.

Charles A. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I set forth my views in regard to the policy formulated recently by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development ?

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senator Claude Pepper of Florida today rejected Henry A. Wallace's suggestion that he might head a third party. He pledged that he would stay in the Democratic party as long as it was "truly liberal."
Mildred Duryea of this city was re-elected president of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., yesterday at its final meeting for the season in the Hotel Astor.

With its old store at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street closed after business on Saturday, Best Co. began yesterday the task of moving to its new home at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, north of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Recent testimony before a Senate subcommittee calling for Government assistance for United States imports was made public here yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 13 --Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, accused "big business" today of seeking to force strikes in the nation's great industries by withholding wage increases necessary to offset a rise of 20 per cent in living costs in the last nine months.

Ten recipients of the first sixteen post-war awards of "Jeffersons" for promoting democracy and tolerance accepted them last night at the annual dinner of the Council Against Intolerance in America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Two hundred and fifty persons attended. "Jeffersons" are small statues of Thomas Jefferson, the "Father of the Declaration of Independence."

Prices of cotton continued to decline steadily last week. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 73 to 97 points under the final levels of the preceding week, when net losses of 41 to 82 points had been registered.

FRENCH LICK SPRINGS, Ind., April 13 -- American bankers, in common with other business men, must "nationalize" their thinking and consider the effects of their individual operations on the whole economy, if the trend toward nationalization of industry by Government is to be checked, Joseph M. Dodge, vice president, American Bankers Association, stated here today.
Private charitable agencies such as New York Catholic Charities are needed to prevent establishment of an "omnicompetent state" here, Edward B. Rhatigan, Welfare Commissioner, declared yesterday.

Vivian Rivkin gave yesterday afternoon at Town Hall a piano recital devoted entirely to music by Brahms, in commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the death of that master. The elaborate program contained the "Klavierstuecke," Op. 76; "Three Intermezzi," Op. 117; "Two Rhapsodies," Op. 79; seven of the "Waltzes," Op. 39, and the infrequently presented Sonata in F sharp minor, Op. 2.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I suppose even THE TIMES has to be wrong some of the time, but it is cause for genuine regret to see it lining up with old-line politicians against the civic forces of the city on so fundamental an issue as the representation of the people.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Senate this week will probably pass the $400,000,000 authorization for Greece and Turkey to resist communism. Likewise the House will make important progress toward passage of its sweeping omnibus labor bill.

The National Society for the Prevention of Blindness reported yesterday that its broadened campaign to protect eyesight was receiving the support of physicians, nurses, public health officials, social workers, educators and safety engineers throughout the country.

The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation announced yesterday the award of 122 fellowships valued at $310,000. The awards are given annually to scholars and artists to provide opportunities for them to continue work in their chosen fields.

LOS ANGELES, April 13 -- A running current of West Coast complaints against economic "strangulation" by the East has reached a climax in charges that a conspiracy is afoot to "kidnap" the West's freight cars.

Press-model Speed Graphic cameras, 8x10 view cameras, 16 mm. 24-volt electric-powered gun cameras, lenses of various types, still projectors, 16 mm. sound and silent projectors; screens, cases, tripods, washers, dryers and other photographic equipment are featured in War Assets Administration surplus this week.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Truman declined to comment today on the possibility of Federal intervention in the telephone strike.

ST. LOUIS, April 13 (AP) -- The world champion Cardinals squared the two-game city series with their American League rivals with a one-sided 8-to-1 victory over the Browns today. About 17,500 fans turned out, despite chilly weather.

PITTSBURGH, April 13 -- Many coal mines owned by steel companies in this district and else-where were shut last week because of the overnment-union controversy over safety measures, but the steel ingot output for the country was barely affected and no sharp drop is anticipated this week.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The division within the Congress of Industrial Organizations on the issue of communism was sharply emphasized today in the organization's meeting to protest against labor bills pending in Congress.

Davis Shuman, trombonist, was heard in probably the first full-length recital for the instrument ever presented, late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. He was assisted by Mischa Mischakoff, violinist; Leonid Hambro, pianist, and a string ensemble in a lengthy and varied program, throughout which he made a deep impression by his expert musicianship and full command of the trombone's resources.

Price advances have averaged only 18 per cent since the depression year of 1938 compared to an increase of 73 per cent in wages, but earnings of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company in the March quarter of this year were comparable to the most productive prewar periods because of the high level of operations to meet the sustained demand for glass and plastic products, John D. Riggers, president, reported to stockholders yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- The Santa Fe Railway Company today filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission a brief in support of the railway's application to enter St. Louis, Mo., and provide the Chicao, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company with shorter routes between Chicago and Kansas City and St. Louis and Kansas City.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 13 (AP) -- The Pirates first-string first baseman, Elbie Fletcher, suffered a badly sprained right ankle today in an exhibition game with the Columbus American Association Club.
The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx will be the laboratory in a new research program for drugs to cure infantile paralysis and other virus diseases, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The 1947 baseball season opens tomorrow, and the nation's No. 1 fan will be right there to see that everything goes off properly.

PITTSBURGH, April 13 -- The return of the coal miners yesterday shifted attention to the wage talks scheduled this week between the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, and the United States Steel Corporation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -- "The Saxon Charm," a forthcoming novel by Frederic Wakeman, author of "The Hucksters," has been purchased by Universal-Inter-national in a deal by which the author will reportedly receive 10 per cent of the gross revenue from the film adaptation.
Life Stirs in the Sycamores Buds are out on the sycamore trees in Bryant Park. A mist of green clothes the privet that hedges the place about. The grass plot in the middle is really green.

The Moscow Conference is expected to reach its climax today when it takes up discussion of the American proposal for a Four-Power alliance to keep the Germans disarmed for forty years or as long as is necessary to convert them into an orderly and democratic nation.
LOS ANGELES, April 13 (AP) -- Two torrid five-man teams and two new doubles combinations banged their way into the upper brackets if the American Bowling Congress tournament standings today.

KARACHI, India, Monday, April 14 -- Milton Reynolds, Chicago manufacturer, who is attempting a 'round-the-world record flight in his converted A-26 bomber, the Bombshell, arrived here from Cairo early today.
PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- Delegates from ten Eastern Protestant Episcopal seminaries ended a conference on the church and labor and rural problems today at the Philadelphia Divinity School.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Application of the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946 has resulted in a rash of subcommittees in Congress, with an accent on specialization.

A new proposal for settling the week-old strike of 35,000 employes of the New York Telephone Company will be placed before company and union representatives today by Commissioner J. R. Mandelbaum of the United States Conciliation Service.
New decoration courses planned to help homemakers refresh their homes by summer are now opening in local schools as well as in a museum.

The Polish liner Batory, popular in pre-war trana-Atlantic and Caribbean cruise service, will complete her first post-war passenger crossing when she arrives here this morning from Southampton with 853 passengers.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Preponderant support by a large cross-section of organizations for the International Trade Organization being discussed in Geneva was claimed today by the State Department here. It released an official consensus of hearings held in various cities in the United States prior to departure of the American delegates to Geneva.
The War and Navy Departments joined the City Health Department yesterday in its drive Here to prevent the spread of smallpox.

Thousands of communicants of Eastern Orthodox churches, Greek, Russian, Rumanian, Ukrainian, Syrian and Serbian, crowded houses of worship for two to four hours after midnight yesterday and celebrated Easter in the tradition of their religion.

THERE is no accounting for taste in books, any more than in anything else. One might think that madness and alcoholism, would be of somewhat limited appeal, but anyone who did think so would be completely ignorant of the modern reading public's appetite for vicarious horrors. Themselves inhabitants of a frenzied world where catastrophes in bulk are common-places, readers in droves seem to find solace and pleasure in the private, individual disasters of personal self-destruction.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- The market for corn was unsettled last week, showing strength at times, but it dropped to a new low for the week in the late trading after an estimate by the Department of Agriculture that farm reserves on April 1 were 1,295,000,000 bushels, or 262,000,000 bushels larger than a year ago and well above the average of recent years.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor today announced that $250,000 is being set aside for the development in 1948 of a program to aid juvenile victims of cerebral palsy those cases known as "spastics."

A two-year study of how efficiently public libraries are serving American communities and whether libraries should become future custodians of non-commercial radio, films and television will be financed with a grant of $175,000 by the Carnegie Corporation of New York, Robert M. Lester, the secretary, announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- Despite the slow death of a committee appointed two years ago by the Securities and Exchange Commission to protect the country's small investors from fraud, there are more safeguards for the "little men" today than ever before, according to officials of the SEC.

CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- The Cubs salvaged the final game of their spring city series today by defeating the White Sox, 5 to 3, before a crowd of 16,008 that defied 32-degree weather. The White Sox won the series, 4 -- 3.
MINDEN, Germany, April 13 -- Little hope is held here that the German steel industry will be able to contribute much toward current reparations for at least another eighteen months.

With the gray-uniformed choir of the United States Military Academy providing the music, massed colors of patriotic societies at the altar, and a major general to make the address, a special service was held yesterday afternoon at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Ninetieth Street and Fifth Avenue.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Lard and edible oil markets showed a much weaker undertone last week, said to reflect buyers resistance to paying high prices to obtain supplies rather than any material pressure of offerings. Cash lard on the Board of Trade was quoted yesterday at 29 cents a pound, off 3 1/4, cents from a week previous, and loose lard was down 2 cents at 27 cents.

The City of New York turned over several tracts of land along the East River to the United Nations yesterday. In a formal ceremony the future world capital was consecrated as a "temple of peace" and the "center of the hopes, the aspirations and the ideals of all mankind."
JERUSALEM, April 13 -- For the second time since her 1946 arrest, Geulah Cohen, 21-year-old terrorist broadcaster and gungirl, escaped today.

A down-to-earth trend in shoe prices made itself felt yesterday at the Shoe Manufacturers Fall Opening at the Hotel New Yorker. A manufacturer of low-price women's shoes announced a price cut of 21 per cent, which he said should bring the retail price from $5 down to $3.69 and $4.

The 3,131-ton Norwegian freighter Belpamela, which left New York on April 5 for Cherbourg, France, was sunk on Friday 1,200 miles east of Norfolk, Va., when rolling cargo burst her sides, the Coast Guard reported last night.

Unemployment within the metropolitan area has shown a perceptible "though certainly not alarming" increase recently and employers are becoming more insistent on adequate qualifications for job applicants, M. Joseph Tierney, metropolitan director, New York State Employment Service, disclosed in an interview last week.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (AP) -- The Athletics blanked their National League rivals, the Phillies, 2 -- 0, today before 20,419 to record their second Shibe Park victory in a row and wind up the annual springtime city series all even at two games each.

"I'm considering last season as my rookie season in big league ball. That's the one when I had to remove all the kinks and wrinkles.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 13 -- The full membership of the United Nations was summoned today by Secretary General Trygve Lie to an extraordinary session of the General Assembly April 28 to consider the Palestine problem.

A throng of 6,200 persons filled the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon and evening for the performance of Bach's 3 minor Mass given by the Bach Choir of Bethlehem, Pa., as part of the 250th anniversary celebration of the founding of Trinity Church.

LONDON, April 13 (AP) -- A majority of London's boxing writers predict that Joe Baksi of Kulpmont, Pa., will defeat British Heavyweight Champion Bruce Woodcock in their ten-round fight at the Harringay Arena Tuesday night.

Consolidated retail sales of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., for the twenty-six weeks ended on Feb. 1, increased 18 per cent to $152,537,000 from the $129,508,000 volume for the similar period of the previous year, according to the semi-annual unaudited report of Jack I. Straus, president, being mailed to stockholders today.

Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president emeritus of Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday in his first sermon since returning from a seven-month lecture tour of the Philippines, China, Siam and India.

ALBANY, April 13 -- Governor Dewey has approved a bill sponsored by Robert E. Dineen, State Superintendent of Insurance, providing for creation of a security fund to guarantee payment of automobile liability insurance claims in the event an insurance company becomes insolvent.

The Giants were spared the strain of carrying a long winning streak into the National League campaign when they dropped an 11-to-6 decision to the Indians in the ten-inning finale of the exhibition series between the clubs at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

When an American citizen who has been honored by his country with high public office goes abroad for the purpose of organizing foreign sentiment against the policies of his own Government, it is not surprising that there should be protests in the Senate and elsewhere, and even demands in certain quarters for the cancellation of the traveler's passport.

Watched by members of the visiting Hapoel soccer team from Palestine, who were getting a line on prospective opponents for the first game of their tour at Yankee Stadium on May 4, the New York Americans, who acted as hosts, lost their Lewis Cup match to the Baltimore Americans at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, before a crowd of 3,200 fans yesterday, 1 -- 0.

Strikes or lockouts in industries or services essential to the health or safety of the public are intolerable, the labor committee of the Twentieth Century Fund declared in a report on "Strikes and Democratic Government," made public yesterday.

TOKYO, April 13 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's request to the Allied Council for Japan for a study of the question of a wage-price policy has underlined the virtually complete breakdown of economic controls established since the surrender of Japan.
The old alibi about mistaking the fire alarm for a mailbox went into the judicial scrap heap yesterday and another explanation almost as old was used. It did not make much headway in court.

BOSTON, April 13 (AP) -- Smarting from two straight shut-offs, the stubborn Braves nullified home-run slugging by Ted Williams and Rudy York and battled the Red Sox until darkness ended their game in a sixteen-inning tie, 7 -- 7, in the city series wind-up today before 30,884 at Fenway Park.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 13 -- Sudeten Germans expelled from Czechoslovakia into Bavaria In the United States zone of Germany are refusing to accept their expulsion as definitive, according to stories reaching Prague from Usti in northern Bohemia.

Among the outstanding art events of this week will be the Brooklyn Museum's fourteenth biennial international water-color exhibition which opens to the public on Wednesday. On Wednesday also the Museum of Modern Art will open an exhibition of drawings from, the permanent collection and will show kodachromes and architectural plans of two groups of buildings designed by Frank Lloyd Wright.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 13 -- Hyperthyroidism, or toxic goiter, a disease that afflicts millions of persons throughout the world, has been brought completely under control through a aeries of powerful new drugs, it was announced here today.

Mayor O'Dwyer's 1947-48 executive budget of $1,029,120,314, to be considered by the Board of Estimate at a closed session this morning, will be increased by about $5,000,000, it was indicated last night.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The 204th anniversary of Thomas Jefferson's birth was celebrated today by the Unitarian Church at the Jefferson Memorial in the midst of the capital's springtime cherry blossom festival.
LONDON, April 13 -- The impending budget has reduced financial activity here, particularly the Stock Exchange business, to its lowest ebb in a long time.

This month marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of the death, as a young man of 18, of John Simon Guggenheim. He was the son of the late Senator Simon Guggenheim and Mrs. Guggenheim, who, three years after his death, set up as a memorial the foundation that honors his name.

A strike of workers in the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges land in major Wall Street brokerage houses appears certain, M. David Keefe, president of the United Financial Employes, AFL, said last night.

Taking official cognizance of abuses stemming from lack of off-street storage space fop automobiles, the city administration has suggested public hearings on proposed legislation to regulate and supe gaag s and parking lots, it was learned yesterday.

John L. Lewis' decision to call off his "safety work stoppage" in the coal mines was made under two compelling pressures. The first was that Federal Judge Goldsborough still held the power to impose a fine of $2,800,000 on the union for a strike called in contempt of the court, and seemed likely to impose it.

The second game of the semi final play-off between the New York Knickerbockers and the Philadelphia Warriors for the Basket ball Association of America championship will be played tonight at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. The Warriors took the opener of the best two-out-of-three-game series in Philadelphia Saturday night, 82 -- 70.

They say that quiz program participants often are stumped by the question, "What is veal?" Beyond answering that it's some sort of meat, they can't go far in their definitions. There's good reason for it. Veal is the meat least eaten by Americans, and hence the most unfamiliar. Why? Because it's the hardest to select, the most difficult to cook.

TOKYO, April 13 -- The development of the Truman policy of apparently offering the help of the United States to nations that prove barriers to the spread of communism is lifting the hopes of, many Japanese for further benefits from America.

Apparel prices are predominantly under the control of the retailer and textile concerns that receive 85 cents of every dollar spent by the consumer for such goods, according to Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association.

The floor of the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street, as knee-deep in wadded newspapers yesterday afternoon as exhibitors in the New York Antiques Fair unpacked their wares and made ready their booths.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The National Federation of Telephone Workers will not appeal to President Truman to seize the country's telephone lines, according to a statement tonight by Joseph A. Beirne, the NFTW's president. The union will probably urge the Chief Executive to arrange a meeting for industry-wide bargaining with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

GENEVA, April 13 -- Conference leaders are delighted at the large number of official observers attending the Geneva meeting of the Preparatory Committee of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 (AP) -- Wrestlers from little Cornell College, Mount Vernon, Iowa, carried away the bulk of the honors at the national A.A.U. senior wrestling championships, concluded early today at the San Francisco Olympic Club.

The nation-wide telephone strike grew out of union demands for higher wages, the union shop, increased pensions, longer vacations, shortening of the time required to reach top pay levels, and other concessions.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Soft coal production is officially expected to reach 90 per cent of normal tomorrow, but the Federal Bureau of Investigation will make an undercover check to determine whether the United Mine Workers union faithfully complies with the Supreme Court order ending the coal strike.

TOKYO, Monday, April 14 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur said today that United States-occupied South Korea had made its "greatest step forward in the democratic processes of self-rule" after the opening of the interim Legislative Assembly last December.
AMSTERDAM, April 13 -- Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck's note on the financial and foreign exchange situation has been postponed until next week because of his wish to make it comprehensive.

For the last time David Mannes led his sixty-five-piece symphonic orchestra yesterday afternoon in the balcony of the Great Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The concert was the final one in the season's schedule of four, but for Mr. Mannes it also brought to a close thirty years of conducting at the museum.

Companion labor reform bills were assuming definite shape in the two Houses of Congress last week. In each case the stated underlying purpose of the legislation was to strengthen collective bargaining by equalizing the positions of labor and industry.

Hard-pressed passenger agents and their equally harried assistants, striving mightily to arrange transatlantic bookings in a market where applications exceed accommodations by at least ten to one, said yesterday they had encountered almost every conceivable variety of an "emergency."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 13 -- Arthur Knapp Jr., oft nicknamed the last of the Mohicans because he was one of the originals in cold-weather dinghy racing back in January, 1932, when the frail craft were taken out to buffet blows and ice cakes, finally came into his own today.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- The volume of orders for Diesel motors indicates that a record number of units will be produced this year, accompanied by a record dollar volume, a spokesman for the manufacturers stated today.

The plan for improved labor relations on the city's unified transit lines, as drawn by Transportation Commissioner William H. Davis and approved by Mayor O'Dwyer, appeared last night to be doomed to rejection by the two other members of the Board of Transportation.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, April 14 (AP) -- A Russian private was under treatment at an American Army hospital here today for minor gunshot wounds, and a Russian major was also reported wounded In a Korean constabulary clash just south of Soviet-occupied North Korea.

A record sum of $889,488,000 was spent by newspaper readers in the United States and Canada to buy daily and Sunday papers in 1946, according to estimates released over the week-end by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

For the first time within the memory of officials of St. Patrick's Cathedral the Catholic Cadet Choir of the United States Military Academy sang solemn mass in the cathedral yesterday and its members acted as servers and acolytes in the sanctuary.
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- Western Conference basketball coaches today recommended a twenty-two game over-all schedule for 1948 and a sixteen-game round-robin Conference schedule for 1949.
LIVERPOOL, England, April 13 -- Henry A. Wallace defied American critics today to muzzle him in his criticism of United States foreign policy and called for "a new deal for the world."

MOSCOW, April 13 -- United States Secretary of State Marshall will seek Soviet agreement in principle on the United States proposal for a four-power treaty against German aggression when the Council of Foreign Ministers meets tomorrow.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, April 14 (AP) -- A Russian private was under treatment at an American Army hospital here today for minor gunshot wounds, and a Russian major was also reported wounded In a Korean constabulary clash just south of Soviet-occupied North Korea.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (U.P.) -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Producers Association of America, is going to Europe soon to try and break through two "iron curtains" which are blocking American films in many countries.

Public schools here are failing to teach the rudiments of simple English grammar, it was charged yesterday. As a result supervisory personnel of the city's business houses are only "two jumps ahead of a nervous breakdown."
Fleets of multi-jet bombers soon will be carrying the cockade of the Army Air Forces into the sky at speeds approximating those of the world's best jet fighters.

The stock market was subjected yesterday to the most serious assault on prices since late 1946 under a barrage of liquidation unmatched this year. Three waves of selling struck the share list before the pressure lifted and left values reduced 2 to 7 points at the close although some of the pivotal industrials managed to recoup some of the losses during the late trading.

THE conversational part of the baseball season is at an end and for that we can't be too thankful. Starting this afternoon everyone will be playing for keeps as the major league season begins. Opening Day always is a distinctive occasion because it brings with it the culmination of months of ardent anticipation by those incorrigible optimists, the baseball fans.

CINCINNATI, April 14 (AP)--The Reds, emphasizing youth and a new manager, will take high hopes into the ball field tomorrow for the opening game of the season against the experienced, star - studded, world champion Cardinals.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., April 14-- Mortgage lending operations by banks in many sections of the nation have been considerably curtailed in recent weeks, according to a sampling of opinion among bankers now meeting here. The bankers are among some 300 from all parts of the United States attending the executive council meeting of the American Bankers Association.

WASHINGTON, April 14--Business profits for the past year, although considerably varied, indicate in general "considerable ability to hold the price line or even reduce it," according to a report submitted to the Congressional Joint Committee on the Economic Report.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 14--The sale of 7,000 pigs to Switzerland made during the first two months of this year was against Marshal Tito's orders and without his knowledge, it was stated here today.

Signing of an agreement between New York and the Port of New York Authority for completion and operation of the city's airports by the agency under lease is expected before Mayor O'Dwyer leaves for a vacation on the West Coast, it was learned yesterday.

BERLIN, April 14--Some 70,000 trade unionists among Berlin's 500,000 staged a ten-minute work stoppage today in protest against a denazification court's reinstatement of Wolf Dietrich von Witzleben as director of the Siemens und Halske plant in the British sector.

CHICAGO, April 14 (AP)--With Hank Greenberg a last-minute installation at first base, the revitalized Pirates will launch their National League season against the Cubs tomorrow before an expected crowd of 35,000.

After ignoring five earlier promptings from our Government in the matter, Russia has agreed to undertake a settlement of Lend-Lease accounts. Discussions to this end will soon begin in Washington. The total amount of direct American Lend-Lease aid to Russia was somewhat in excess of eleven billion dollars.

The New York apartment house television antenna situation, which has plagued many potential set owners and manufacturers for two months, may be settled soon--at least tentatively--it was announced yesterday at the opening sessions of the Television Institute at the Commodore Hotel.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 14-- Residents of this suburban village found a question of high finance posed for them today in an unprecedented sixty-page booklet distributed by the village trustees. The question was: "Do you want to use cash or credit in paying for $1,066,000 post-war improvements?"

Excursion Into Linguistics Mr. Wallace in Liverpool, according to The Associated Press, said the time is not ripe for a visit to Russia, "but I have a hunch if I could speak Russian Mr. Stalin would let me speak to the common people there just as I am speaking to you today."

Return of fine woolens and worsteds for men's clothing will feature the style show tonight to be held under sponsorship of the New York Custom Tailors Designers Club at the Hotel Roosevelt. A preview of the twenty-four models was held yesterday afternoon at the offices of the International Wool Secretariat.
Wouldn't you like to know that a baby in Europe, pinched by hunger since birth, has had a couple of good square meals all because of you?

OFFENBACH, April 14 (AP)-- This region's once thriving leather industry is beginning to play an important role in reviving Germany's foreign trade, American Military Government officials reported today.
Future prices on the New York Cotton Exchange continued downward yesterday and closed 24 to 38 points net lower.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 14--Administrative officials of the United Nations computed carefully this afternoon the possible costs of the extraordinary Palestine session of the General Assembly, beginning two weeks from today, and discovered with some dismay that $552,799 might have to be taken from the organization's tight budget.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)-- The State Department stood by its text of the 1945 Potsdam declaration today in the face of a Moscow contention that it omitted a paragraph on German reparations.

For its fifth and final production of the season, the Experimental Theatre offered "Virginia Reel," put on at the Princess Sunday evening and yesterday afternoon. It is the least interesting of the Experimental's scripts--conventional in form and point of view.
WASHINGTON, April 14--Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg urged the Pan American Union today, during the celebration of its fiftyseventh anniversary, to offer membership to the Dominion of Canada.

TORONTO, April 14 (AP)--The future held a rosier tint today for the Montreal Canadiens, confident that the return of Maurice Richard is all they need to tip the scales in their favor in the best-of-seven Stanley Cup final with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

ALBANY, April 14 (AP)--Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today the New York City Housing Authority could not let housing rehabilitation contracts in excess of $10,000 on a "costplus" basis.
For the first time since 1940, when the population of the New York metropolitan area was computed at 8,707,666, the censustaker began ringing doorbells again yesterday.
BOSTON, April 14 (AP)--Johnny (Grandma) Murphy, veteran righthanded relief pitcher, who was quietly cast adrift by the New York Yankees last Saturday, today was signed by the Boston Red Sox.
A loudspeaker blared the news yesterday at the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 West Twenty-ninth Street, that its six-day seventeenth annual boys' fair was under way.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 14--The atomic boiler of the Clinton Laboratories at Oak Ridge, Tenn., operated for the Atomic Energy Commission, by the Monsanto Chemical Company, is now producing tritium, the super-heavy water containing a hydrogen three times the mass of ordinary hydrogen.

PARIS, April 14--Archibald MacLeish resigned today as a member of the executive council of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. Milton Eisenhower, head of the UNESCO national commission in the United States and president of Kansas State College, was unanimously elected to succeed him at the closed session this morning.
ROME, April 14--Italians were startled today by a Tass report from Stockholm that American troops had suspended their departure from Italy and are preparing to stay for an indefinite period.

MOSCOW, April 14 (Reuters)-- Tass, official Soviet news agency, today accused American, British and French news sources of having resorted to "direct blackmail" and of lacking "objectivity" by allegedly overplaying the difficulty of reaching agreement in the Moscow meetings of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

NANKING, April 14--President Chiang Kai-shek turned prompt attention to the problem of Government reorganization following his return here this afternoon from a ten-day visit to his native district of Fenghua in Chekiang. It was predicted tonight that a revamped administration, in which the Kuomintang would share positions with members of the Social Democratic and Young China parties and nonpartisans, would be announced in a few days.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 15-- The 85,000-ton liner Queen Elizabeth, en route from New York with some 2,200 passengers and a crew of 1,200, ran aground last night on the Brambles, a shingle bank at the entrance to Southampton harbor.

LONDON, April 14--Britain's budget will be presented to Parliament by Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, tomorrow afternoon. There is no measure and no day of the year that means more to the average Briton than budget day, for it will affect the pocketbooks of every man and woman in this country.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 14-- There is a conflict between two world concepts of living that has entered the stage of "acute social and political warfare" and passed the phase of academic speculation or pious feeling, the Rev. John LaFarge, S.J., editor of the weekly religious magazine "America," declared today in the annual Dudleian Lecture at Harvard University.

VIENNA, April 14--The first congress of Austria's majority party, the People's party, will be featured by a demonstration of solidarity with parties in other countries that have similar Catholic orientation and are essentially anti-Communist.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14-- Drastice changes in our economic, social and industrial life have seriously "dislocated" the aged, Miss Rose J. McHugh, chief of the special standards section, Social Security Administration, said today. She declared that history has increased the numbers of the aged, but has made increasingly insecure their place in society.
Partners of member firms of the New York Stock Exchange may pressed into service as clerks on the floor of the Exchange in the event of a strike next week, it was reported yesterday.

The occupation, administration and reformation of Japan under the command of General MacArthur has been one of the outstanding achievements of the post-war period. Now, however, events beyond MacArthur's control are beginning to precipitate a crisis in Japan. This crisis is the result of a progressive economic breakdown and exhaustion, to which MacArthur and his aides are calling attention with increasing urgency.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (U.P.)-- James C. Petrillo has been subpoenaed to tell the House Labor Committee about the operations of the American Federation of Musicians, Chairman Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican, of New Jersey, said today.

DALLAS, Tex., April 14-- Whispers of rebellion stirred the American Association of University Women today at the opening of its fiftieth general session. Controversial issues that have been simmering for six years, during which time no conventions were held, rose to the surface as delegates met, eager to exchange news and views.

Jack Frye, former president of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., was elected yesterday chairman of the board of the General Aniline and Film Corporation and its sales agent, the General Dyestuff Corporation.

PEIPING, April 14--Shihkiachwang, 172 miles south of Peiping, is reported under Communist siege with the Peiping-Hankow railway cut above and below the city. The Government is said to plan to send supplies to the garrison by air.
PHILADELPHIA, April 14-- Registration statements covering a total of 200,738 shares of common stock were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by two companies.

Senator Vandenberg's declaration on Pan American Day that Canada should be a member of the Pan American Union of twenty-one American republics is as open an invitation as has been extended to the Dominion to occupy the twenty-second chair at future Pan American Conferences.

For its second Carnegie Hall concert devoted to music of the twentieth century the Juilliard School of Music turned to choral works last night. The school's chorus and orchestra, aided by a number of soloists and conducted by Robert Shaw, presented works by Charles F. Bryan, composer from Tennessee, Paul Hindemith and Arthur Honegger.

WASHINGTON, April 14--Standing out against their seven colleagues, Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson and Justice Robert H. Jackson denounced today a New Jersey township annual license fee on a storage warehouse as "more dangerous in the end" than a tax levied by New York 160 years ago against importation of firewood.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, April 14--In searching for evidence of new trends of thought among Germans in the United States and British zones, this corespondent has found only pessimism.

Fifteen thousand mouton skins or 1 per cent of the outstanding contracts will be delivered this week to contract holders by Motty Eitingon, Inc., fur processors in reorganization, it was announced yesterday. The announcement was made at a meeting of dealer and manufacturer contract holders at the offices of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers.

GENEVA, April 14--The announcement that the United States is prepared to get right down to work on tariff bargaining was the opening message today of Clair Wilcox, acting head of the United States delegation to the plenary session of the Preparatory Committee of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment.

DETROIT, April 14--The General Motors Corporation settled its wage differences today with the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, with a 15-cent increase. Of this, 11 1/2 cents will be paid as direct, hourly salary advances and 3 1/2 cents as adjustments for paid holidays and other economic factors.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 5 there was a report of an address by Dr. Claude W. Munger to the CarolinasVirginias Hospital Conference under the heading "Nurses Fail in Trust." Such a statement coming from a responsible hospital administrator should arouse protest from patients who have experienced nursing care, and especially from doctors who have worked with nurses and known their devotion to their profession.

Declaring that builders seemed satisfied with the rental ceiling arrangements of the Federal Housing Administration, Clyde L. Powell declared yesterday that the Federal Housing Commissioner was allocating $1,000,000,000 of mortgage insurance authorization to that field.

The Board of Transportation adopted a resolution yesterday repudiating the action taken on April 8 by Transportation Commissioner William H. Davis in writing to four of the transit employe groups and requesting them to submit evidence of the number of employes represented by each.

Walter P. Reuther, international president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, here for a four-day session of the union's executive board at the Hotel Picadilly, declared yesterday that the 15-cent hourly increase to the corporation's 30,000 electrical workers "is public proof that the extremely favorable profit position of General Motors enables it to grant a still larger wage increase."

HAVANA, April 14--Patricia Schmidt, young American dancer who has confessed to the shooting of John Lester Mee, Chicago lawyer who died yesterday morning, will be charged with homicide tomorrow at 11 A.M. Bond will be denied, Dr. Santiago Mencia, judge of the First Instruction Court, said this afternoon.

With local Catholic and public high school teams slated to see action, a program of scholastic baseball games has been arranged for the Polo Grounds this season, it was announced yesterday by Vice President Charles S. Feeney of the Giants.

Mayor O'Dwyer's letter to the Citizens Budget Commission outlining possible consolidations of city departments and increased mechanization of city services follows: April 14, 1947. Col. Harold Riegelman, Counsel, Citizens Budget Commission, 420 Lexington Avenue, New York City.
ROME, April 14--The Italian Government estimates that the deficit in the balance of Italy's international payments during the second half of the present year will amount to $300,000,000.

The New York Antiques Fair opened yesterday afternoon at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, with 90 per cent of its exhibitors showing American pieces. The fair will be open daily from 1 to 11 P. M. through Friday.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 14 (U.P.) --A conference between Indianapolis Motor Speedway officials and representatives of twentyeight race drivers who demanded more 500-mile race prize money broke up tonight "without an agreement."

A challenge to American initiative exists in opportunities for development of fisheries in the Pacific, Secretary of the Interior Julius A. Krug told 800 members of the National Fisheries Institute during their second annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 14--In a decision potentially affecting hundreds of thousands of veteran and non-veteran employes, the Supreme Court ruled today that the Selective Service Act does not guarantee indefinitely a veteran's seniority on his old job.

BERLIN, April 14--As gently as possible, United States applied pressure once more today to induce the 500,000 displaced persons in its zone to return to their homes. In a proclamation issued here and in Frankfort on the Main and Vienna, Gen. Lucius D. Clay warned of the uncertainty of further assistance from the United States or through an international organization.
Realistic literature was defended yesterday in Midtown Magistrates Court by a literary critic, an author, a professor of English and a minister.
The New York Knickerbockers were eliminated from the Basketball Association of America playoffs last night when they bowed, 72-53, to the Philadelphia Warriors at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)-- H.F. Worley, president of the National Customs Service Association, asserted today that port collectors were "deadwood" and that their removal would bring "considerable savings."

MOSCOW, April 14 (AP)--Following is the transcript of a discussion on censorship between Prime Minister Stalin and Harold E. Stassen, as made public today by Mr. Stassen: Mr. Stassen--Some problems have arisen between us in the past because of a lack of desire on your part to exchange ideas like the censorship of our foreign correspondents in Moscow.

Two attractions have been added to the roster of stage offerings due to open on the main stem next month. They are "Portrait in Black" and the twin bill of "The Medium" and "The Telephone." Theatregoers can count on at least five openings during May, a traditionally slow period in the theatrical season.

WASHINGTON, April 14--A bipartisan coalition bent on moderating the Senate labor bill made fresh major advances today, while House Republican members were giving overwhelming sanction to a far more restrictive House measure.

It will be "Play Ball!" on eight major league fronts today, with the Yankees and Dodgers dominating the local opening-day scenes at the Stadium and Ebbets Field, respectively. Unless the weather forces postponement, as it did yesterday in Washington, the 1947 diamond campaign will get away winging at 2 P.M. here.

WASHINGTON, April 14--William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, today denied assertions that the West is being discriminated against in the distribution of freight cars, as asserted in a Los Angeles dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Retail food prices in this city have not gone down, with a few exceptions, since President Truman called for general price reductions a few weeks ago, a survey among merchants and housewives showed yesterday. Some prices, in fact, have increased.

TOKYO, April 14--Behind Gen. Douglas MacArthur's request to the Allied Council to help establish a new wage-price policy for Japan lies what W. MacMahon Ball has called "a disquieting record of eighteen months of continuous failure to take necessary steps to restore Japan's economy and avoid economic collapse."
The Brooklyn Museum will open its fourteenth biennial exhibition of water-colors with a preview this afternoon and to the public tomorrow. It is to remain through June 8.
Charles Chaplin said yesterday he was not a Communist, that he had done a "great deal" of unpublicized war work and that he had never become an American citizen because "I am not a nationalist."

PARIS, April 14--Former President de Gaulle announced today that he would assume the leadership of the movement called the Reunion of the French People, founded in his name last Tuesday after his Strasbourg speech.

A return match between middleweight champion Tony Zale and Rocky Grazianc, the licenseless larruper from New York, will be held early this summer, probably in Cleveland or Chicago, Sam Pian, Zale's manager, told The Associated Press yesterday.

CHICAGO. April 14 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture Follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 9,000 head; total, 13,000; market slow: weights under 240 pounds opened 75 cents to $1.00 lower; later trade on all weights, $1.00 to $1.25 lower compared last Friday's

WASHINGTON, April 14--Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, back from the Antarctic, declared flatly here today that he never had requested the United States to stake out any polar territorial claims and insisted he did not consider the Antarctic strategically useful for military operations.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, April 15--A proposal to end the weekold national strike of telephone workers through a decision by a five-man arbitration board was made just before midnight last night by Lewis B. Schwellenbach, Secretary of Labor.
A proposal that women be admittted to the Presbyterian ministry was approved overwhelmingly yesterday by the Presbytery of New York. The vote was seventysix to twenty-one.

An agreement by the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company to abide by the compulsory arbitration requirement of the state's drastic ne wanti-strike law failed last night to end the eight-day-old strike of 12,000 New Jersey telephone operators.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., April 14-- Chief Justice Clarence E. Case, in an order signed today at the Hudson County Court, restrained three Hudson Manhattan Railroad election inspectors from announcing a decision in the company's annual election of directors.

Shoe retailers must look for lower prices in two directions-- lower legitimate costs of manufacturers and correct relative pricing of products which got out of line during the war years, L.E. Langston, executive vice president of the National Shoe Retailers Association, said yesterday.

The whistles of harbor craft saluted the Gdynia America liner Batory yesterday as the trim 14,287 -ton motorship moved slowly up the North River to her West Fortyeighth Street berth on her first commercial voyage in seven years.

JERUSALEM, April 14--After a gunfight at sea, a vessel bearing more than 2,700 unauthorized Jewish immigrants was being towed into Haifa tonight by two British destroyers. The ship is expected to arrive tomorrow morning.

Robert P. Boylan, a floor broker who has his office at E. F. Hutton Co., has been nominated for chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday. If the nomination is approved at the annual election on May 12 he will succeed John A. Coleman, who is retiring from the chairmanship.

Freeport Sulphur Plans of the Freeport Sulphur Company to expand its exploration for sulphur and other minerals were discussed yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders held at Wilmington, Del. George Gordon Battle, New York attorney, who presided in the absence of Langbourne M. Williams Jr., president, said he was unable to report on first quarter earnings before the board meeting which will be held on April 23.

The Armenian Students' Association, which presented a program of compositions by Alan Hohhanes as its first musical venture two years ago, last night furthered the career of a second young Armenian -American. It presented Neure Jorjorian, soprano, in a debut recital at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 14--The Soviet Union has agreed to negotiate its lend-lease indebtedness to the United States, the State Department announced today. Discussions will start as soon as Ambassador Novikov returns to Washington from Moscow.

Public opinion must impress on Congress the necessity for allowing immigration of displaced persons above quota limits, Dr. Maurice R. Davie, chairman of the Sociology Department of Yale University, declared yesterday.

Important advances in the study of congenital heart ailments, especially in young children, have been made through the passage of a catheter into the chambers of the heart, according to papers presented last night before the annual scientific session of the New York Heart Association.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., April 14-- The improvident buyer has been "shaken out" of the market for United States savings bonds, and the current rate of increase in sales over redemptions, amounting to $1,000,000,000 for this year, probably will be maintained, it was asserted here today.

CHICAGO, April 14--Scattered liquidation was on in the grain markets in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, with May wheat off 7 1/2 cents a bushel at one time. But pressure on the distant deliveries let up later and with commission house buying and short covering, a strong rally came at the close.

WASHINGTON, April 14--Today marked the fifty-seventh anniversary of the founding of the Pan American Union. Simultaneously, efforts of considerable importance were being made to close the breach between the United States and Argentina so that the idea of Pan-American unity could mean more than it had in the past year.

Running smoothly in the second spot for the greater part of the journey the Jaclyn Stable's 4year-old Inroc stepped into the lead position exactly at the proper time yesterday to win the Calverton Handicap, the feature race on the card at the Jamaica race track.
Without advance notice, Best Co., specialty apparel store, opened yesterday at 2:40 P. M. its new twelve-story building at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, April 14-- Five hundred nineteen diamonds, thirteen emeralds and seventeen assorted semi-precious stones were laid out on a table in a dingy Japanese court room here today a Col. Edward J. Murray went on trial before a public court martial.

Circulation figures of weekly newspapers, now required to be filed with the postoffice, are published for the first time in the 1947 directory released yesterday by the American Press Association. All figures in the new directory are either postoffice sworn or Audit Bureau of Circulation figures.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., April 14 --For three hours tomorrow, eleven relaxed United Nations diplomats will sit in the sun in the Bronx, watching eighteen determined athletes race around in an American game called baseball.

MOSCOW, April 14--Prime Minister Stalin and his Government "do not see any big difference" between Republicans and Democrats in the United States, the Soviet leader told Harold E. Stassen, who is a candidate for the Presidency in 1948, during their conversation in the Kremlin on April 9.

WASHINGTON, April 14--Bipartisan demands that the passport of Henry A. Wallace be revoked and that he be prosecuted for his activities and utterances abroad arose in the House of Representatives today.

MOSCOW, April 14--Secretary of State Marshall asked the Council of Foreign Ministers this afternoon to decide in principle whether a four-power treaty to prevent German rearmament should be written. He recommended that, if such a general agreement could be obtained, special plenipotentiaries be designated to negotiate a final treaty text.

Oscar Williams of the Harlem Boys' Club of New York hung up two new high run marks yesterday by winning three engagements to gain the final round in the senior division of the Boys Clubs of America national pocket billiard championship tournament at the Madison Square Boys Club.

The rising rate of unemployment in the needle trades indicates that the industry is reverting to a seasonal pattern of operations, it was learned yesterday. State employment agencies and the unions, however, while concerned over the situation, said that the employment picture in the New York garment industry was not alarming.

WASHINGTON, April 14--Henry A. Wallace, once Vice President of the United States, has gone abroad to build up opposition to the Truman Doctrine in the British Isles and on the Continent, the task being supererogatory in Soviet Russia and areas controlled from Moscow.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., April 14 --An autopsy revealed today that Herbert O. Barnes, 74 years old, publisher of the trade magazine Textile Age, 381 Madison Avenue, New York, died of "several" fractures of the skull mysteriously received.

Mayor O'Dwyer embarked upon a broad program of consolidation of city departments and full mechanization of city services yesterday when he asked the Citizens Budget Commission to work with city officials on large-scale surveys in both fields.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 14--A special criminal court sat today in Pretoria to open the first of three cases of high treason, in which Douglas Cecil Mardon is indicted on six overt acts of treason.
WASHINGTON, April 14--They had everything for an enthusiastic opening of the 1947 major league baseball season today except the ball game.
Owners of the three major league baseball clubs in the city enlisted police aid yesterday in a drive aimed at ridding their ball parks of professional gamblers.

The weather man carried out his threat over the opening week-end, and apparently several of those "fronts" he discusses met right over the Catskills, for it doomed the majority of the fly fishermen to more exercise than trout.

W. Arthur Nickel, central figure in the swindle that cost the Mergenthaler Linotype Company in Brooklyn $780,000, pleaded guilty yesterday in Kings County Court as he and two others were scheduled to go on trial.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)-- The Bureau of Mines said today that forty-four of the 111 men killed in the coal mine explosion at Centralia, Ill., March 25, might have saved themselves.
Spring football workouts under an all-new coaching regime began yesterday for City College. Forty candidates reported for the initial drill in Technology Gymnasium.

The ever-increasing need for Pan-Americanism was stressed by speakers at the Pan American Society's annual dinner, held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night to honor the city's Latin-American consular corps.

Store Sales Off 4% Here Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed a decline of 4 per cent under the corresponding week of last year, according to the "flash report," issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 14 (AP)--Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias of Denver, tabbed as the favorite, and Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill, seven-time winner of this tournament, tied for medalist honors in the North and South women's golf tournament today with 76's in a pouring rain.
SEOUL, Korea, April 14--Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander in Korea, reported today on his mission to Washington to ninety members of the South Korea Legislative Assembly.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will start next Monday its plan, based on competitive bidding of cooperating appliance dealers, to promote sales of gas space heaters and gas water heaters to owners of one and two family houses at minimum cost for equipment and installation, Brig. Gen. E. F. Jeffe, vice president in charge of sales, disclosed yesterday.

ALBANY, April 14 (AP)--A bill which would have authorized halfmile tracks for flat and steeplechase races up-State was vetoed today by Governor Dewey at the request of the State Racing Commission. Racing Commission Chairman Ashley T. Cole advised Dewey that such tracks open the way to "cheap racing."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 --Leo McCarey announced today that he will film "Good Sam," from a photoplay by Ken Englund and John Klorer, as his next Rainbow Production for RKO release. The producer - director has engaged Gary Cooper to play the leading role in the film, which Englund and Klorer wrote from McCarey's own screen story.

WASHINGTON, April 14--The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has asked the Baltimore Ohio Railroad to defer consummation of a plan for reorganization of the road with the aid of an RFC loan extension. The propriety of the loan and the circumstances surrounding it have been under investigation by the Senate Banking Committee.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis starts today an extensive educational campaign to distribute a message of advice and reassurance to the nation's parents.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Usually the great NEW YORK TIMES has its facts about right. But may I call attention to the editorial on "The Telephone Strike" in your issue of Sunday, April 6, in which you say, "The company which operates the American telephone system is a monopoly under state and government regulation."

HARTFORD, April 14--The United States is not about to be "edged out" of Latin-American markets by European competitors, James S. Carson, chairman of the education committee, National Foreign Trade Council, declared here today.

Support for the City College drive for a $1,500,000 student war memorial came yesterday from two of the college's most prominent alumni--Bernard M. Baruch of the class of '89 and Supreme Court Justice Felix Frankfurter, '02.

Attacking communism last night, Capt. E.V. Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Airlines, declared that "although no bombs are dropping or cannon roaring, we are, for all practical purposes, at war, the war of nerves." He spoke at a dinner of the Notre Dame Club of New York in the Hotel Commodore.
LONDON, April 14--On the eve of the publication of the budget, the stock markets maintained a firm front today.

MOSCOW, April 14 (AP)--The text of Secretary of State Marshall's statement to the Council of Foreign Ministers on a four-power treaty to prevent German aggression: A year ago, at a meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in Paris, Secretary Byrnes presented a draft of the treaty whereby the four principal Allied powers would undertake to work together to keep Germany disarmed for twenty-five years or more.

LONDON, April 14--Henry A. Wallace abandoned today his tendency to treat lightly American attacks on his speeches in Britain against the Truman Doctrine. He issued a special statement defending his position.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 14 --For three hours today Andrei A. Gromyko answered a cross-fire of questions on the Soviet Union's atomic policy and insisted that Moscow would support an international agency for the control and inspection of atomic energy.

ALBANY, April 14--The feasibility of operating a radio network without the use of telephone lines to link individual stations was demonstrated here today at the first regional meeting of the newly formed Frequency Modulation Association.

WASHINGTON, April 14--The Chesapeake Ohio, the Alleghany Corporation and the Nickel Plate today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve purchase by the Nickel Plate of 115,369 shares of prior lien stock and 1,658 shares of preferred stock of the Wheeling Lake Erie now owned by the C. O., and 54 shares of the W. L.E. prior lien owned by the Alleghany Corporation.

CHICAGO, April 14--Chicago railroads in 1946 were well to the top among the country's leading carriers in their ability to keep costs down in relation to the total revenues received from the public, a compilation of operating ratios showed today.

Another case of smallpox was reported in the city yesterday, bringing the total to eight cases and two deaths here since the first case was found on April 4. In addition, four cases in Millbrook, N.Y., are directly traceable to the contagion in New York.

OMAHA, Nebr., April 14--Attorneys general and assistants from twelve states today attended the first session of a closed twoday conference on problems involved in litigation growing out of anti-closed shop measures.

Stockholders of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. at the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., approved yesterday a resolution authorizing an increase in the number of preferred shares from 3,000,000 to 4,000,000. The increase will become effective on April 25, permitting issuance of the 1,000,000 shares of a new series of preferred stock registered last Thursday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Emerson Radio Phonograph Corporation announced yesterday to the trade reductions in list prices on nine table radio and table radio-phonograph combinations ranging from three to twenty dollars, Benjamin Abrams, president, disclosed at a press conference in the company's main offices at 111 Eighth Avenue.

LONDON, April 14 (AP)--With a shot at Joe Louis' world heavyweight title awaiting the winner, Britain's Bruce Woodcock and Joe Baksi of Kulpmont, Pa., meet in a ten-round scrap tomorrow night and both camps predicted victory on the eve of the international elimination.

IN the fifteenth century the known world was small and dangerous, surrounded by water which froze into mountains of ice in the north and which boiled fiercely in the south. Monsters and demons churned the mysterious depths of the Atlantic Ocean. The Viking voyages had been long forgotten and only a few learned men knew that the world was round.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Alexis de Tocqueville more than one hundred years ago wrote: "The press is the chiefest democratic instrument of freedom."

YOKOTA ARMY AIRDROME, Japan, Tuesday, April 15--The record-seeking, around-the-world airplane of Milton Reynolds of Chicago took off at 9:24 A.M. today (7:24 P.M. Monday, Eastern standard time) for Anchorage, Alaska--a 3,000-mile flight.

WASHINGTON, April 14--President Truman was reported today to have virtually ready for issuance an order transferring the administration of rent control from the Office of Price Administration to the Office of the Housing Expediter.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 14 --Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative, today violently attacked the Vandenberg amendment to the $400,000,000 United States program for Greece and Turkey. He declared it was "a mark of scorn vis-a-vis the United Nations and undermines its authority."

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 14 (AP) -- The ponies and about 12,000 racegoers returned with the rain at Havre de Grace's 1947 inaugural today, while Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' Natchez and Glen Riddle Farm's The Shaker capured split divisions of the Harford Handicap.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)-- Gerhart Eisler, alleged Communist leader, was indicted today on a charge of making "fraudulent and fictitious" statements when he sought a permit to leave the country in 1945.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of $3,000,000 of city school district bonds of Akron, Ohio, on a bid of 101.033 for 2s. Other bids for the same interest coupon ranged from 100.826 to 100.60.

Missionary Work World Bank officials, preparing the groundwork for the expected issuance of the institution's debentures, are now busily engaged in the usual missionary work before such an event, it was reported yesterday from French Lick Springs, Ind., where the American Bankers Association is holding its executive council meeting.
All work on the Brooklyn end of the Brooklyn-Battery tunnel was halted yesterday by a strike of timekeepers, checkers and other office help.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14-- Segregation of children of Mexican descent by officials of four school districts in Southern California was ruled unconstitutional today by the Ninth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

ALBANY, April 14--Gov. Thomas E. Dewey has approved the Young-Demo Merit Rating Bill, enabling employers in New York State whose payrolls are stable to get $140,000,000 in tax credits this year to be applied against their liability to the unemployment insurance fund next year.

WAREN, Germany, April 9 (Delayed) --The average estate in this typical Mecklenburg farming district, in the Soviet occupation zone, formerly measured 620 acres. Under the zone-wide land reform program it is twenty to twentyfive acres.

Mayor O'Dwyer has called in the Citizens Budget Commission as a consultant on certain specific proposals for economy, including reorganization of departments with a view to more efficient use of manpower and machinery. He suggests the greater mechanization of some city services and a study of present civil service classification with a view to making changes, a project long overdue and which the commission has been urging for some time.

Eleven holders of the Congressional Medal of Honor were honored yesterday by the Veterans of Foreign Wars in a luncheon at the Hotel Astor. The event marked the opening of the VFW's campaign to raise $300,000 in New York State for rehabilitation services to disabled veterans and their families.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 15 -- An economy-minded team of experts is undertaking a complete streamlining of all departments of the United Nations, it was learned here today.
City College students and alumni continued yesterday with their celebration of centennial week and their efforts in behalf of the drive to raise $1,500,000 for a student war memorial building.

WARSAW, April 15 -- The Polish Sejm [Parliament] reconvened today, facing as its main task the passage of a 174,000,000,000-zloty budget for 1947. The total was more than twice that of last year's budget.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- With certain conditions, the Securities and Exchange Commission today granted Middle West Corporation an extension until June 14 in which to divest itself of its common stock holdings in Central South West Corporation.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, proposed today that business firms with excessive profits reduce their prices regardless of competition or the absence of it.

A committee of holders of securities of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation yesterday made known the make-up of a slate of directors proposed to unseat the company's present management at the annual meeting on May 14.

CLEVELAND, April 15 (AP) -- Fireball Bob Feller's pitching: wizardry failed him today and the White Sox defeated Cleveland, 2 to 0, before 55,014 fans and behind the masterful hurling of Ed Lopat, long-time jinx of the Indians.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- A decided change in sentiment developed in the grain markets overnight, with a subsequent slackening in aggressive selling on the Board of Trade today. Commission houses and shorts, however, were active buyers at times, and prices ranged higher with the finish about the top.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 15 -- The appointment of Paul de Rodzianko of Britain to be secretary of the United Nations Appeals Board, set up recently to hear staff grievances, was announced today by the office of Secretary General Trygve Lie.
The city's huge vaccination campaign against smallpox was just getting into full stride yesterday when it ran into a shortage of vaccine and virtually stopped dead.
