Securities valued at $26,615,000 will be placed on the market here today by underwriting managers, as follows: Port of New York Authority -- $8,500,000 of 2 per cent general and refunding bonds due in 1974, priced at 101 to yield 1.95 per cent, by Drexel Co. and Glore, Forgan Co.

Need in television for more and better studio programs to cope with the growing acceptance of "naturally attractive" sports items as video subjects was stressed yesterday at the final meetings of the Television Institute, closing a twoday program at the Hotel Commodore.

A study now is being made in New York's public high schools to determine the quality of instruction being given in English classes, it was announced yesterday by Frederic Ernst, associate superintendent in charge of the academic high school division.

One seeks an explanation of the formidable program and its insufficient results at the hands of Leo Sirota, pianist, who gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Sirota elected to play some of the tallest compositions in the piano repertory -- a list of works that would challenge any master at any stage of his career.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The condition statement of weekly re porting member banks in 101 lead ing cities the Federal Reserve Board announced today shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 9: Increases of $145,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, $341,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Re serve banks, and $461,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and a decrease of $161,000,000 in borrowings.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark defended President Truman's program to bolster Greece and Turkey in a speech tonight. Alluding to Henry A. Wallace, he said that anyone "who tells the people of Europe that the United States is committed to a ruthless imperialism and war with the Soviet Union tells a lie."

SQUANKUM, N.J., April 15 -- Although the stream, conditions were about normal for an opening day and a record turnout gathered on the banks of the upper Manasquan and Metedeconk Rivers, the successful anglers did not seem as numerous as in other years.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Formal Congressional censure of Henry A. Wallace was proposed by Democrats on both sides of the Capitol today. But developments indicated that Congress would, instead, register its reactions to the former Vice President's speeches in Europe through votes on the GreekTurkish aid bill, which seeks to put the Truman Doctrine into action.

A blaze in one of the luxurious suites of the Waldorf Tower, 301 Park Avenue cast the Duke of Windsor in the role of volunteer fireman last night. Working with a will for about five minutes, he helped an emergency crew of WaldorfAstoria Hotel employes stretch hose along a thirty-sixth floor corridor to the endangered apartment, occupied by the Baron and Baroness Egmont van Zuylen of Holland.

The transport Marine Flasher, which last week was reported in distress about 840 miles east of Halifax, arrived here yesterday after a fifteen-day voyage from Havre, Southampton and Cobh. The Ship docked at Pier 95, North River, with 833 passengers, including United States citizens, refugees, war brides and children.
MYSORE, India, April 13 -- Deep in the heart of South India a pure Yankee voice called out before our railway compartment, "All right, you fellows, get that stuff in there. Don't be wasting my time."

Steel castings have advanced the least in price, and copper fabricated parts the most, a survey by the purchasing department of a large manufacturer covering the period since Jan. 1, disclosed here yesterday.

William H. Davis, Commissioner of the Board of Transportation, reported to Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall last evening on the status of the labor formula affecting five employe organizations on the New York City Transit System.

Delegates to the United Nations Security Council suspended international discussion yesterday to take in the Athletics-Yankees opener. But after the demonstration put on at the Stadium, the diplomats decided by overwhelming vote that any other game -- soccer, cricket, jai alai and maybe even American football, to mention just four specific examples -- makes considerably more sense than baseball.

JERUSALEM, April 15 -- Burton Hull, president of the Transarabian Pipeline Company and builder of the "Big" and "Little Inch" lines in the United States, has left the Levant without deciding on the terminus for the proposed pipeline from United States oil fields in Saudi Arabia to the Mediterranean coast.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 15 -- Msgr. Joseph Tiso former President of the autonomous Slovak State set up as a German protectorate, was found guilty today of high treason against the Czechoslovak Republic and sentenced to be hanged.

A cautious approach was taken yesterday toward the stock market, which proved full of cross currents, in view of the sharp losses suffered on Monday. While further new lows were reached at one interval during the session, some recovery appeared in the afternoon, which left the list no worse than irregular at the close.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 15 -- The Columbia baseball team gained its first Eastern Intercollegiate League victory of the season, 7 -- 6, today, holding a Princeton ninth-inning rally scoreless in spite of loaded bases with only one out.

ATHENS, April 15 -- Confidential reports to the Western Allies assert that a superadministration of the Balkans decides territorial questions, supervises military operations across the Greek border and directs political thought in Rumania, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and Albania.

LONDON, April 15 -- Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, stunned Britons today with his announcement of a 50 per cent increase in excise taxes on tobacco. That feature of the budget address overshadowed the income tax reductions for several millions and all the other features of the Chancellor's program.

The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. Buyers' Arrivals Gained Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1.339, compared with 721 last week and 1,052 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

GENEVA, April 15 -- A United Nations Balkans investigating subcommittee reached a surprising, if tentative, agreement today on the main issues with which the full commission's report to the Security Council must deal.

Germany is and long will remain "our No. 1 international problem," Robert H. Jackson, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court and chief American prosecutor at the Nuremberg trials, declared here last night.
MOSCOW, April 15 -- The Soviet Union was accused of withholding coal for general allocation within Germany by Secretary of State Marshall today.

LONDON, April 15 -- Britain's budget for 1947-48 is more than balanced, Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today. There will be a surplus of about L270,000,000 in a budget totaling nearly L3,500,000,000.

Prime Minister Stalin has now added his quota to the current discussion of freedom of the press. His answers to the questions of former Governor Stassen are characterized by a frankness and geniality that distinguish the interviews of the Soviet leader from those of Mr. Molotov or other official spokesmen of the Government.

JERUSALEM, April 15 -- Palestine's Jews shut up shop and left darkened city streets tonight in a silent protest against the deportation of some 2,500 immigrants whose blockade-running ship, caught by the British Navy, was towed into Haifa this morning with the bodies of two slain men on board.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Senator Irving M. Ives of New York, whose election last November was hailed by Republicans as the capture of a vital New DealDemocratic stronghold by the national GOP is becoming established as a leading party irregular in Congress.

Brookmeade Stable's Liberty Road qualified handsomely for Saturday's Wood Memorial -- if Trainer Preston M. Burch decides to send him a mile and a sixteenth twice in a week -- when he captured the $4,500 Canarsie Purse at Jamaica yesterday before 27,306 witnesses.

The round-the-world flight of Milton Reynolds and his crew in the Bombshell is one more graphic demonstration of how fast our planet is shrinking. Our fathers marveled when Jules Verne dared to send his fictional hero around the world in eighty days, a dash of dizzy speed soon bettered in actual practice.

Working men and women in Manhattan have contributed $404,278 to the Red Cross 1947 Fund of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. George Harding, chairman of the employe gifts committee.

Net income of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for the three months ended with March amounted to $48,145,000, equal to 52.33 a share, compared with $46,525,817 or $2.30 a share for the first quarter of 1946, the report disclosed yesterday.

Left and Right Senator Pepper has gratefully but firmly put aside Mr. Wallace's offer of the leadership of a third party. But in the course of his remarks the Senator has laid down certain dicta about American history which cannot be allowed to pass without challenge.

They opened the American League baseball season at the Stadium yesterday under a clear blue sky, a fact to which 39,344 paying eyewitnesses readily will attest. Unfortunately, under the stress of perhaps greater MasPhailian activities, nobody thought to apprise the Yankees of the event.

In 1875 about 2,000 died of smallpox in what is now the city of Greater New York. Though vaccination had been introduced, its efficacy was then still flouted. Today we have a different story to tell. The few cases of smallpox that have appeared have all been isolated.

Milton J. Reynolds' twin-engined converted Army bomber flown by three civilians streaked over the boundary of La Guardia Field at 12:06 this morning to be timed for a record-breaking 'roundthe-world flight of 78 hours 55 minutes and 12 seconds.
The Thomas Alva Edison Foundation will provide for the late inventer's successors the key to future scientific discoveries and developments. Dr. Charles F. Kettering predicted yesterday.

By flying above and around storms, airplanes on the North Atlantic route actually can take advantage of bad weather, A. K. Ohashi, navigator of American Overseas Airlines, declared yesterday in the company's offices here.

BOSTON, April 15 (AP) -- Just as a year ago, the Red Sox launched their American League pennant drive today by offsetting Tex Hughson's wabbly opening-day pitching to gain a 7-6 victory over the Senators before a crowd of 30,822.

Two deepwater piers at Fifth and Sixth Streets in Hoboken, N.J., have been acquired by the Holland America Line from Webb Knapp, New York real estate investors, it was announced yesterday by Frederik R. Wierdsma, general manager for the line.

Ignoring for the second time Commissioner A.B. Chandler's edict imposing silence on all principals involved in the by now celebrated Leo Duropher case, President Larry MacPhail of the Yankees yesterday dropped another surprise bombshell.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., April 15 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine announced here today that it would ask the General Assembly session on Palestine to declare an "open door" policy on Jewish immigration until a final solution had been found for the Arab-Jewish controversy.

The New York Giants, in their opening home game with the Brooklyn Dodgers at the Polo Grounds on Friday, may face a problem the schedule makers had not taken into consideration. A charge of unfair labor practices was filed yesterday with the State Labor Board against the National Exhibition Company (the Giants), and a union spokesman threatens a picket line at the ball park Friday to prevent merchandise deliveries.

MONTREAL, April 15 -- Describing reports concerning newsprint supply, price and distribution published recently in the United States and Canada as "distorted and incomplete," R. M. Fowler, president of the Newsprint Association of Canada, issued tonight a statement defending the industry's price policies.

The 8,750-ton cargo vessel Asia, first of five new Cunard White Star ships to be built since the end of the war, entered North Atlantic service yesterday when she left Liverpool for Montreal, it was announced here by H. P. Borer, general manager of the line.

Stores, particularly those of the smaller type, should drop their spirit of pessimism and adopt an aggressive attitude, it was advised last night at a meeting of about 300 members of the smaller stores division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- The only thing wrong with the opening of the baseball season at Shibe Park today was the way the Grants booted away the game, bowing to the Phillies, 4 -- 3.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias of Denver, three under fours for the twelve holes, defeated Mrs. William Hockenjos of Hopatcong, N.J., 7 and 6, today in the first round of the North and South women's golf tournament.

Net income of the Gillette Safety Razor Company for the first quarter of this year amounted to $2,904,662, equal to $1.28 a share on 1,998,769 common shares outStanding, Joseph P. Spang Jr., president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Boston.

Morris Neiberg, 17-year-old New Yorker, made his debut as a violinist at the Town Hall last night and established that he has talent. His technique, while not impeccable, was generally dependable, and his tone was clean and vibrant. His interpretations had refreshing modesty and sanity: they indicated that the young fellow was beginning to make music out of a personal feeling rather than imitate someone else.

MOSCOW, April 15 -- The deliberations of the Council of Foreign Ministers reached a critical stage this afternoon as discussion of the United States' proposal for a fourpower treaty to keep Germany disarmed wandered down tortuous blind alleys.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- President Truman proposed today that Congress delete from the nation's statutes the legal concept of compulsory neutrality, written into law three times in the years preceding the outbreak of World War II.
JERUSALEM, Wednesday, April 16 -- An official announced today that Dov Bela Gruner and three other convicted members of the Irgun Zvai Leumi organization were hanged at Acre Prison at dawn.

LONDON, April 15 -- Joe Baksi, Pennsylvania heavyweight boxer, put himself right in the front line as a challenger of Joe Louis for the world heavyweight title by completely outclassing Bruce Woodcock, British heavyweight champion, at the Harringay Arena tonight. Referee Moss DeYoung stopped the figrht after one minute and twelve seconds of the seventh round.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach carried to the American people tonight his fight to have the disputants in the nation-wide telephone strike accept his arbitration proposal.

Fresh fruit and vegetable price can be reduced and much food spoilage eliminated by joint action on the part of growers, receivers, wholesalers, jobbers and retailers. Edward A. Kausman, executive secretary of the Allboro Retail Fruit Association, said yesterday.

The friendly argument between Rear Admirals Byrd and Cruzen over the strategic value of the Antarctic region and the problem of its future sovereignty poses some interesting questions. Development of the airplane, in which the United States has played a major role, and two world wars in which we have taken part in less than a quarter of a century, have changed our thinking as a nation.

GCA, the Ground Control Approach radar system which can "sea" a plane in the thickest fog and talk its pilot down to within a few feet of the runway for a safe landing, was finally flight-tested at La Guardia Field yesterday. The tower operator received authority from the Civil Aeroneautica Administration to use the set in his discretion.

WOODWARD, Okla., April 15 (AP) -- Justine Ruble, chairman of the Woodward telephone workers' local, said today that telephone operators here would resign from their union because they were instructed not to return to work after last Wednesday's tornado.

RIO DE JANIERO, April 15 -- The first step in what may be a campaign directed by Moscow to boycott United States products in Latin America was launched in Congress yesterday by Communist Deputy Jose Crispim. Deputy Crispim said Brazil should raise barriers against the entry of United States products.

Manufacturers who accept unjustified cancellations or return of orders are in clear violation of the Robinson-Patman act, Representative Wright Patman (Democrat, Texas), co-author of the act, declared last night. Those who permit such practice are allowing special concessions, the loss on which must be borne by the seller's entire clientele, he pointed out.
Seven thousand veterans filed yesterday past a square black box on the floor of the Ninth Regiment Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street, and each picked a number.

European countries are definitely beginning to show resistance to American prices despite their needs for United States goods, William R. Martin, export manager, Publicker Industries, Inc., stated yesterday. Speaking at the meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania, he said a recent trip to Europe showed that foreign business men are becoming increasingly selective in their purchasing as their governments become more selective in the granting of import licenses.

FRENCH LICK. Ind., April 15 -- Except for scattered "adjustments of excesses," already under way, there is no evidence that a period of economic recession may be expected at any time in the immediate future, according to a group of top banking executives from six key areas of the nation.

The Board of Superintendents approved yesterday a course in automobile driver-training for New York City public high school students. If it is found to be successful after a trial in a Brooklyn vocational high school, the program will be introduced in other city schools.

Before Secretary Marshall's visit to the Kremlin yesterday, hope that the Moscow Conference might take some decisive step to speed final peace had been reduced to the vanishing point. The conference had been unable to agree even on the principle of the projected forty-year alliance of the Big Four to keep Germany disarmed.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 15 -- The right of the Yonkers Common Council to investigate the alleged misconduct in office of some of the city's foremost, officials, especially in connection with "protection" of a reported $130,000-aday international horse-race bookmaking ring, was challenged in Supreme Court here today.

LONDON, April 15 -- At high tide tonight sixteen tugs pulled the Queen Elizabeth, the world's largest passenger liner, off the Brambles sandbank, outside Southampton harbor, where she had been stuck fast for twenty-six hours.

LONDON, April 15 -- Prime Minister Attlee defended tonight as "essential" the right of the press to the "utmost freedom of expression," but he warned journalists that in criticizing the Government they should not run down the country itself.

ALBANY, April 15 -- Governor Dewey signed without comment today the two Stephens bills that continue for another year, until July 1, 1948, the commercial rent controls, now in effect in New York City. One relates to office and business space and the other to industrial space.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, April 16 -- Secretary of State Marshall conferred with Premier Stalin in the Kremlin last night less than two hours after the Council of Foreign Ministers had split over the United States' proposal for a four-power treaty to prevent German aggression.

Isolationists are attacking the International Trade Organization plan of the United Nations and are trying to weaken this nation's reciprocal trade program, William L. Batt, president of the S.K.F. Industries, Inc., of Philadelphia, declared yesterday.

TORONTO, April 15 (AP) -- Capt. Syl Apps overtime goal enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 2 -- 1, tonight and shot the scrappy Leafs into a 3-1 lead in their four-outof-seven Stanley Cup hockey playoff finals.

Asserting that "the vast majority of people are against the Franco regime in Spain," Dr. Francis E. McMahon, New York Post correspondent whose press credentials recently were withdrawn by the Franco Government, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday aboard the Trans-World Airlines Constellation Star of Dublin.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -- Unless industry brings its competency in human relations to the level of its prowess in technical development, it faces the possibility of mass desertion from the present system of industrial organization, it was declared here tonight by Alvin E. Dodd of New York, president of the American Management Association.

Fashions from the Muriel King custom salon, originals by Harriette Harra and costumes from the ready-to-wear departments were presented yesterday by Stein and Blaine in a spring-into-summer fashion showing at the Ritz-Carlton.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -- The American program for the reeducation of three conquered nations can be defended with "modest pride," Dr. T.V. Smith, former member of United States Government educational missions to Japan and Germany, and for eighteen months, Director of Education for the Allied Control Committee in Italy, said tonight at the National Conference of Social Work.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The House Committee on un-American Activities warned today that the "specter of communism stalks our college campuses masked under the cloak of the American Youth for Democracy."
CHICAGO, April 15 -- A countrywide program to reduce substantially the annual average toll of 7,000 deaths by drowning was announced here today.

SIX HUNDRED AND EIGHTY pages devoted almost solely to a peculiar and generally frustrated love affair of two months' duration! Only a Frenchman would write a novel like that. The Frenchman who has is Louis Aragon and the novel is "Aurelien."*

Between 200 and 300 drawings from its permanent collection were shown by the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, at a preview for members held yesterday afternoon. The admirable and attractively arranged exhibition opens to the public today, scheduled to remain through next month.

BALTIMORE, April 15 (AP) -- The Baltimore Ohio Railroad today notified the Reconstruction Finance Corporation it could not comply with an RFC request to delay the railroad's multi-million dollar reorganization.
The public in its demand for more reasonable prices may stop buying all but actual necessities, Lew Harm, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, warned yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets in Chicago by the Department of Agriculture follows. HOGS Salable hogs 6,000 head, total 11,500, weights 260 pounds and down 25 to 50 cents lower, compared with Monday's average: heavier weights steady to 25 cents lower:
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Settlement of the lend-lease account with the Soviet Union may involve unprecedented disclosures concerning Russian economy. Negotiations for a settlement will begin soon.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 15 (AP) -- President Eurico Gaspar Dutra, in a move against the spread of communism in Brazil, today suspended the activities of the Communist Youth Union.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Federal Government has sold $150,000,000 worth of surplus army clothing, much of it for foreign relief, and still has $139,000,000 worth to offer, the War Assets Administration reported today.
PARIS, April 15 -- It is understood on high authority that the French Government will avoid anything remotely resmbling official honors for Mr. Wallace when he visits Paris about April 22.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The United States Government is now urgently engaged in preparing its case for the special session of the United Nations General Assembly on Palestine. This case is not yet completed, but the tendency at the State Department is to favor a short session devoted primarily to the creation of a "neutral" factfinding United Nations commission to study the Palestine problem.

PANAMA, April 15 -- The question of the occupation of defense sites in the Republic of Panama by United States armed forces for the protection of the Panama Canal was further complicated today by a statement by President Enrique A. Jimenez.

THE little man who wasn't there would have been proud of his Dodgers yesterday as the Brooks rallied to batter down the Boston Braves in the opening day festivities at Ebbets Field. Leo Durocher was missing but he was present in the minds and hearts of the Flatbush faithful. Some of them even wore their hearts on their sleeves -- or at least buttons on their lapels, which boldly proclaimed, "We .Want Leo."

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A Congressional study to determine whether the atomic bomb has made universal military training unnecessary came up with the answer today that a "conscript" army would provide the best insurance for peace for the next five years.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 15 -- The Soviet Union is now ready to take an active part in discussing possible choices for a Governor of the Free Territory of Trieste, it was learned today.
Gerhart Eisler, describing himself as "a German Communist who wants to get back to Germany," declared yesterday that he was not an "atom spy" or any other type of foreign agent.

A banking group headed by the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association won yesterday the award of $1,085,000 of bonds of the Modesto School District, Stanislaus County, Calif. The bid was 100.026 for 1 1/2 s, 1 3/4 s and 2s, due from 1948 to 1972.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Gen. A.A. Vandegrift, commandant of the Marine Corps, Announced today that he was reorganizing the two fleet Marine forces into more flexible units "to provide for the possibility of atomic warfare."

Glass cooking utensils, perhaps because we were able to get them during the war, have not been receiving as much attention lately as the newly returned stainless steel and aluminum. Now, however, Corning Glass Works is bringing its Pyrex products to the fore again with two new dishes, one a so-called utility platter, and the other a square cake dish.

WAREN, Mecklenburg, Germany, April 10 (Delayed) -- A few miles from this market town in the Russian zone is a huge rambling castle. Windows are broken and doors hang loosely on hinges. The aroma of boiling cabbage floats out through the great front door.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Senate Labor Committee by another close vote rejected today proposed restrictions on industrywide bargaining and swept aside an attempt of Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, to outlaw the closed shop and its variations.

BERLIN, April 15 -- An angry article in today's issue of the United States-licensed Tagesspiegel criticizes the Berlin City Assembly for the passage of a decree disposing of the extensive holdings of war criminals and Nazi activists.

World Bank Outlet With little fanfare, considering the important role which it will play in the financing of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the office of Director of Marketing, under the direction of E. Fleetwood Dunstan, was opened here yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- President Truman referred to Cordell Hull, former Secretary of State, as the "father of the United Nations" in conferring the Medal for Merit on him today. The President drove to the Navy Medical Center at Bethesda, Md., to pin the decoration to the lapel of Mr. Hull's coat.

CINCINNATI, April 15 (AP) -- The three-hit pitching: of Ewell Blackwell and the hitting of Eddie Miller, Bert Haas, Rookie Frank Baumholtz and Bobby Adams were too much for the world champion St. Louis Cardinals today and they went down to defeat before the Cincinnati Reds in the season opener, 3 to 1.

NEW DELHI, India, April 15 (AP) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, spiritual leader of the Hindu-dominated Congress party, and Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the rival Moslem League, issued a joint declaration tonight calling upon all Indians to refrain from acts of violence and disorder.

Vaccinations and cream puffs don't mix, seven 'teen-age culinary artists in the cooking class of the Madison Square Boys Club at 301 East Twenty-ninth Street decided yesterday. Competing in the twentyseventh annual cooking contest being staged as part of the program for the club's seventeenth annual boys' fair, held this week, several of the boys remarked that the itching of their brand-new vaccinations interfered with the stirring of batter.

Arrest or prosecution of New Jersey telephone strikers under the state's drastic new anti-strike law was prohibited last night in a temporary restraining order issued by Federal Judge Guy L. Fake. The prohibition will hold at least until next Wednesday, when a threejudge statutory court will meet in Newark to pass on constitutionality of the new law.
The cotton futures market yesterday closed 1 to 24 points net higher, after a day of moderate business.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 15 -- The atomic fire now burning in the Tennessee Valley is producing new elements, of incalculable importance to civilization, in quantities from a thousand to a million times larger than formerly could be produced with the cyclotron.
LONDON, April 15 -- Having read the Logan Act, Henry A. Wallace is "satisfied that he need pay no more attention to talk in the United States of legal action," it was said tonight on his behalf.
Even without Skipper Leo Durocher the good ship "Dodger" proved yesterday that it could sail safely into port, although slightly storm-battered in the process.

The city's billion dollar budget was discussed yesterday at a meeting of the New York City League of Women Voters at the New York Historical Society building, 170 Central Park West. What the appropriations will and will not pay for in the fields of education, public welfare and housing were outlined by committee chairmen.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- Big Hank Greenberg belted only one hit in his National League debut, but it was a screaming double that enabled the Pirates to nip the Cubs, 1 -- 0, and settled a stirring season opener mound duel between Truett (Rip) Sewell and Hank Borowy before 29,427 thoroughly chilled fans at Wrigley Field today.

PITTSBURGH, April 15 -- Agreement between General Motors and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, on a wage rise of 15 cents an hour has been interpreted in labor circles here as an encouraging development, but does not necessarily lay out a pattern for a money settlement between the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, and the steel industry.

BOMBAY, April 15 (AP) -- Henrik Shlpstsad, former Republican Senator from Minnesota, said today that he planned to tell the United States State Department that the Netherlands' seizure of the cargo of the freighter Martin Behrman was a violation of American property without due process of law and merited official American intervention.

The habitat of the duckbilled platypus, one of evolution's leftovers, is the rivers of Australia and Tasmania. The habitat of a certain tribe of earthworms has been the basement of the lion house at the Bronx Zoo.

BERLIN, April 15 -- A most significant reversal in the migrating tendencies of Polish Jews, huge numbers of whom illegally left their native land because of antiSemitism and assumed the status of displaced persons in Germany, was disclosed today by Polish and Jewish officials.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It seems to me that from the account of Eugene Dennis, alias Francis Waldron, in your paper March 31 the general secretary of the Communist party in the United States has convicted himself and his party of unAmerican activities in his explanation of his and their war records.

Top leaders of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, moved yesterday to head off acceptance of the 15-cent wage increase granted by the General Motors Corporation to electrical workers as a pattern for wage settlements in industry.

Confidence that the United States and India are heading toward a goal of "mutual confidence, mutual sympathies and understanding" was expressed here last night by William Phillips, former Under-Secretary of State. He spoke at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore given by the India League of America in honour of Asaf Ali, first Ambassador of India to the United States.

Radio in this country has been an outstanding business success, but it still has not measured up to its potentialities, Clifford J. Durr, member of the Federal Communications Commission, said yesterday.

With the showing yesterday of a new two-reel technicolor film on the development of rayon, the American Viscose Corporation announced its new consumer service program to give educators and consumers useful information on the fiber.

American Water Works Earl S. Thompson, president of the American Water Works and Electric Company, said yesterday that the company is awaiting the clarification of tax questions by the Treasury Department before going ahead with its recapitalization plan recently confirmed by court action in the course of the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: President Truman's recent attempt to blame price increases largely upon greed for profits should be compared with the views of an economist often regarded as the spiritual father of the New Deal. That economist wrote in 1919 concerning the then post-war inflation:

SCHENECTADY, April 15 (AP) -- The General Electric Company reported today to stockholders at their annual meeting a net income for the quarter ended on March 31 of $16,763,650, equal to 58 cents a share, against a net loss of $13,701,580 in the first quarter of last year, when principal plants were closed for nine weeks by strikes.

DALLAS, Tex., April 15 -- High school and college graduating classes were called on today by Dr. Harold E. Snyder, executive secretary of the Commission for International Educational Reconstruction, to memorialize themselves by giving money for urgently needed education reconstruction abroad.

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 15 -- The first skirmish at the Geneva Trade Conference is taking place over the effort of most of the other countries present to bargain with the United States on tariffs before bargaining with each other.

STUTTGART, Germany, April 15 -- At his first meeting with the German Council of States since his return from the Moscow conference, Gen. Lucius D. Clay predicted today the possibility of a "relatively tremendous German industrial revival" in the next six months.
MOSCOW, April 15 -- A gradual improvement in the general economic situation in the Soviet Union in terms of industrial output was evident during the first quarter of 1947.

The Taft-Ellender-Wagner housing bill now before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee was sharply criticized yesterday at the closing session of the regional "clinic" of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Contract negotiations of the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, with the Bethlehem Steel Company were broken off yesterday. This development increased the possibility of a strike in the mills of the nation's second largest steel producer when the contract expires on April 30.

The annual report of the Republic Aviation Corporation, issued yesterday by Mundy I. Peale, president, disclosed a net loss of $7,406,113 for 1946 after all charges, including $3,000.000 provision for contingencies and including also $6,600,000 estimated tax carry-back credit.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 15 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has acquired optional screen rights to "NonFrat," an unpublished short story by George Tabori dealing with the American occupation of Germany, as a prospective vehicle for Walter Pidgeon.

LONDON, April 15 -- Sustained strength of British Government funds and industrials in the stock markets today before the budget was announced indicated the City's quiet confidence in Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Dalton's forth coming tax proposals.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Federal Communications Commission tentatively granted today five applications for new Class B FM broadcasting stations and four applications for television stations in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area.

Pointing to a loss of $7,659,942 in operating passenger service in 1946 as its reason, the Central Railroad of New Jersey announced yesterday that it had filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission and the New Jersey Public Utilities Commission tariffs setting up a new rate structure for commutation fares on its various lines.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Under-Secretary of War, pleaded today with the Senate Armed Services Committee not to run the risk of "reopening old sores" between the Army and Navy by injecting changes into the proposed compromise bill on unification.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With reference to the report of Charles E. Egan from London on Scotch whiskies, this report sets forth a certain amount of information, but the pertinent information which he failed to include in this report is: that the British Government -- the British bond or excise -- does not permit the release and sale of Scotch whiskies for human consumption until at least three years old.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- The Kingdom of Norway filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for a bond issue to be marketed publicly here by a group of investment bankers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 15 -- An extraordinary appeal to members of the United Nations to join the International Refugee Organization has failed and prompt action by the United States Congress offers the last hope that the international organization can be established, it was learned today.

Leaving a dog alone in an apartment all day may be cruelty to the neighbors, but it is not cruelty to the animal, according to Miss Anne L. Carmody, chief clerk in the humane work department of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

Billing protocol (an extremely touchy subject among players of high and low degree) isn't bothering Mady Christians and Miriam Hopkins, each a star in her own right. In "Message for Margaret," opening tonight at the Plymouth, both are co-starred.

The usually routine annual meeting of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company here yesterday was converted into a strike forum in which management officials, union representatives and company stockholders bitterly debated issues responsible for the national telephone strike.

Expanding Its Record Section Ludwig-Baumann has undertaken a 20 to 25 per cent expansion of its phonograph record department, a store spokesman disclosed yesterday. The move is in line with recommendations of the National Retail Furniture Association to its members to either expand or install such departments.

PARIS, April 16 -- In response to an inquiry as to why he had apparently joined other French leaders in signing a telegram inviting Henry A. Wallace, American politician, to visit France, Edouard Herriot said today that he had not been consulted about it.

MOSCOW, April 16 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov asked today that up to a quarter of Germany's coal production be used for export and reparations and that a four-power coal committee be established to control production in the Ruhr.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter from Elinor S. Gimbel concerning the future of the Child Day Care program in this state, which appeared on your editorial page on April 8, reflects the kind of approach to vital problems which does little to add to their solution.

The 36,000-ton Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam, now being reconditioned in Rotterdam, will be ready for service in early November, and after two North Atlantic trips, probably will enter the winter cruise field about Christmas time, Frans C. Bouman, managing director of the line, said yesterday.

NANKING, April 16 -- A Government spokesman virtually admitted here today that the Soviet refusal to permit Chinese Government troops to take control of Communistdominated Dairen was blocking the transfer of the city to Government hands.

The annual budget presented to the British people by Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, serves as a fresh reminder of the almost paradoxical character of Britain's new economic "radicalism." The British Labor party, which is The Government in Britain today, is Marxian socialist in its philosophy, with its, to us, alien concept of public ownership of the means of production.

With the possible exception of the late Wiley Post's solo flight around the world in 1933, the feat of Capt. William Odom in flying the Reynolds Bombshell to a new record sets a mark for personal endurance in the air. This became apparent yesterday as the participants in the flight discussed their experiences, before taking off for Washington at 4 P.M. to be received by President Truman.

The opening by Best Co. of their new store on Fifth Avenue at Fiftyfirst Street is something more than a milestone in the career of an old friend; it is, as far as we know, the first postwar completion of new quarters by a large specialty or department store, and so a good augury.

Recent reports of operations of many of the largest commercial banks and trust companies here for the first quarter of the year compared unfavorably with results shown for the same period in 1946, an analysis of their statements for March 31 disclosed.

With the arrest yesterday of three men, agents attached to the Special Investigations Branch of the Sugar Rationing Administration of the Department of Agriculture announced that they had broken up the nucleus of a nationwide sugar swindle ring.

David H Knott, chairman of the New York County Democratic Committee, began yesterday to mail to the 17,000 members of the County Committee notice of a call for a meeting to revise the committee's rules to make way for the ousting of Bert Stand as secretary and Clarence H. Neal Jr. as chairman of its committee on elections.

The newly organized Artists Equity Association announces the opening of permanent headquarters at 39 East Thirty-fifth Street. The association, organized to protect American artists, will hold its first regular membership meeting on April 30 in the auditorium of the Museum of Modern Art.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Government moved today to bring together operators and miners in the soft coal industry in a resumption of collective bargaining.

A threat to call a Strike at noon tomorrow against 250 of the 750 gasoline filling stations in Brooklyn was made yesterday by John Burke, president of Local 917, Gasoline Station Attendants Union, affiliate of the International Teamsters Union, AFL.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 16 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine will ask the United Nations General Assembly to provide for the representation of Jews when the Assembly opens its special session on Palestine on April 28, a spokesman said today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP) -- With Joe Fulks dropping in 37 points, 29 of them in the second half, the Philadelphia Warriors whipped the Chicago Stags, 84 to 71, tonight in the opening game of the Basketball Association of America's final play-off series.

First indications of the industrial effects of consumer resistance to bakery and confectionery prices was indicated by the price reduction on bulk sugar made yesterday by Sucrest Corporation, sugar brokers said. Effective today, Sucrest has reduced its price from $8.25 per hundred pounds as established by Department of Agriculture price control, to $8.20.
Administrative officials at the Board of Education are sharply divided on the question of whether conscientious objectors to war have the right to teach in the New York City public school system.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The American Red Cross made an initial appropriation of $250,000 today to aid victims of the Texas City explosion.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
LONDON, April 16 -- The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth docked at Southampton shortly before 10 o'clock tonight -- fifty hours behind her scheduled time.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The National Federation of Telephone Workers insists on a wage increase now because "millions of workers" have received such increases in recent months, according to Joseph A. Beirne, president of the federation. The "pattern" has been set in industry, he said.

Handsome furs, designed with a knowing fashion hand and quiet good taste, were presented by Dein-Bacher of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday in a spring and summer collection. Favoring mink and broadtail for their light weight and sleek elegance, this shop showed several trends prophetic of the autumn.

PARIS, April 16 -- More than an hour at today's Cabinet meeting was devoted to a statement by Marius Moutet, Overseas Minister, on the situation in Madagascar, which give rise to heated discussions with Communist Cabinet members.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Agricultural spokesmen from both the Republican Congress and the Democratic Administration today made emphatic statements that the farm price support program was not responsible for current high food prices.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 16 (AP) -- Col. Matt J. Winn, president of Churchill Downs, said today that decorations would be completed for ten new boxes at the horse racing plant here but that other construction work had been halted.
The Greek-Turkish program deserves, and will have, the support of the American people.
K.E. Staley has been promoted to assistant manager of Chevrolet's Atlantic Coast region, with headquarters in New York.
GENEVA, April 15 -- Will Clayton, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, arrived here tonight to assume leadership of the United States delegation to the Geneva trade conference.

Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, issued yesterday a statement in which he said that he was "astonished that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York should associate itself with Marriner Eccles" in his credit policy.

LONDON, April 16 -- Dismay over the staggering rise in the prices for tobaccos was the dominant reaction of Britons today to their new budget. For them it is obvious that nothing in the budget that Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced yesterday counted so much as the 50 per cent increase in tobacco duties.

The Student Board of Columbia College has requested in a letter to Columbia trustees that Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of the university, be made permanent president. The students say that it is the unanimous belief of their board that Dr. Fackenthal has proved capable and has won the support of the college.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd expressed his opposition today to control of the Antarctic by the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Mr. Willis was ordered home on March 20 for "consultation and termination of service," the State Department announced today, after an exchange of letters in January and February between Ambassador Smith and William Benton, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Tobacco distributors, almost all of whom also distribute candy, were given first-hand information today on the reasons for steadily rising confectionery prices. Speaking before the annual convention of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors, Philip P. Gott, president of the National Confectioners Association, traced the increases to higher costs of candy ingredients.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Organized labor today linked the National Association of Manufacturers to the pending Congressional measures dealing with labor.
Huntington, L. I., Union Free School District No. 3 awarded yesterday $3,200,000 of bonds due May 1 from 1948 to 1962 to C. J. Devine Co. at a bid of 100.085 for 1.20s.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- For the last quarter of 1946, 1,270 of the 1,395 American listed corporations reported net sales aggregating $21,640,721,000, representing an increase of 16.9 per cent over thirdquarter sales for the same companies of $18,517,549,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

GENEVA, April 16 -- Mounting sentiment for the creation of a free port at Salonika was reported today among the members of the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission. The theory was advanced that such a free port would relieve an important cause of friction in the Balkans, which, like Danzig, could threaten world peace.
TOKYO, April 16 -- The trend toward the conservative Japanese parties and independent candidates of conservative outlook, evident at the local elections of April 5, was again manifest today.

There was never a moment in the history of the world when nursing was so needed as it is today, or when the profession had so promising a future before it, Miss Annie W. Goodrich, founder of the Army School of Nursing and the Yale University School of Nursing, told 300 alumnae of the Cornell UniversityNew York Hospital School of Nursing yesterday.

Industrialization of the housing industry -- through prefabrication and otherwise -- was discussed before members of the National Committee on housing yesterday by experts in that field. The committee met at the Hotal Commodore.

The carpet industry must act now to exploit the mass market rather than concentrating on consumers in higher income brackets, Dr. Lawrence C. Lockley, Professor of Marketing, New York University School of Retailing, said yesterday.

JERUSALEM, April 16 -- All of Great Britain's forces in this tumultuous country were alerted tonight against reprisals by the Jewish underground for the hanging of four convicted terrorists at Acre today. By a new decree, military justice was made supreme in the land.

With its supplies of vaccine low, the city got a new smallpox scare yesterday morning when a Pan American Airways plane arrived at La Guardia Airport with a suspected case among the passengers taken aboard at Karachi, India, where the disease is epidemic now.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Demands that President Truman take "affirmative action" toward reducing prices as a probable deciding factor in the 1948 elections were voiced at Democratic National headquarters today by party leaders conferring on strategy for the forthcoming Presidential campaign.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 16 -- Members of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission began working on the details of an international control plan today, and as their first task decided to make sure they all were talking about the same things.

FORT WORTH, Tex., April 16 -- Men and women of this nation were urged today not to join the "scare-mongers" but to play their full part in "waging peace" by improving their understanding of Russian problems and Russian ways of thinking, even to learning the Russian language and corresponding with Soviet citizens.

Retail credit conditions continue basically favorable although total Volume has slipped from the peak reached at the close of last year and collections on charge accounts are somewhat slower, it was reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The War Department was accused today of rejecting "the keystone" of needed reforms in the military justice system by favoring continued control by commanding officers over courts martial.

Brave Days of Old Our city scout has been around looking at parades. It's not the way it used to be, he says, when they marched up Fifth Avenue from Washington Square to the Plaza, between sidewalks banked with people and tiers of windows serving as boxes for more people.

Prices need to be reduced wherever profits make it possible to avoid or mitigate a business recession, but further price rises now seem certain, Alfred P. Sloan, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, declared last night.

The executions of the four convicted Jewish terrorists in Palestine yesterday were a "deliberate provocation by the British on the eve of the opening of the special session of the United Nations to discuss the Palestine issue," Dr. Sidney Mark, executive director of the Zionist Organization of America, declared yesterday at an impromptu protest meeting called by the staff of the national headquarters of the group here.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 16 -- Bernard M. Baruch said here today that the world "can get going only if men work" and that "if we accept the challenge to preserve civilization, it means greater effort than that exerted during the war."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16 -- Universal-International announced today that Dan Duryea, Yvonne de Carlo and Edmond O'Brien will play the leading roles in "Black Bart," a photoplay by Luci Ward and Jack Natteford dealing with the adventure of an American highwayman in the midnineteenth century.

OTTAWA, April 16 (Canadian Press) -- The Dominion's Foreign Exchange Control Board issued today a brochure designed to explain why the Canadian dollar is selling in the unofficial market in New York at 7 3/8 per cent below the United States dollar and at par in Canada.

The weather gods, who had smiled so benignly on the league's opening day, apparently regretted that consideration yesterday. Their copious weeping made baseball hereabouts only something to which one could look forward as seven of eight big league games were rained out.

WARSAW, April 16 -- Polish Foreign Minister Zygmunt Modzelewski told Parliament today that the chain of treaties between Poland, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and Russia in effect "fix the border of all Slav countries on the Oder and Neisse [Rivers]."

ALBANY, April 16 -- Governor Dewey, in a review of this year's legislative record, emphasized tonight that his administration was committed to the pay-as-you-go policy with respect to public expenditures and believed that local public officials should be held accountable at home for the way they raised and spent money.

NANKING, April 16 -- Party and non-party political leaders cleared the way for the formation of a coalition government of China here tonight with the signature of a twelve-point statement of common policy. Gen. Chang Chun was chosen to be the new Premier.
Efforts to settle the ten-day-old strike of 35,000 New York telephone workers were deadlocked last night over union demands that a general wage increase or a "down payment" precede a return to work.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- Relieved that his Giants had been divested of their opening-day jitters, Manager Mell Ott planned today to go back at the Phillies with the line-up which dropped yesterday's inaugural. But the elements altered this plan.

TEXAS CITY, Tex., Thursday, April 17 -- A chain of explosions set off by the blowing up of a nitrateladen ship smote this Gulf port yesterday, killing hundreds and injuring thousands. It was the worst American disaster in ten years.

Edgar M. Queeny and William M. Rand, chairman of the board and president, respectively, of the Monsanto Chemical Company, left New York by private plane at 8:30 o'clock last night for Texas City, according to a representative of the company here.

The Board of Estimate, meeting yesterday in executive session, endorsed a proposed "definitive agreement" between the city and the Port of New York Authority, under which the bi-state agency will take over all city airports by June 1, under a fifty-year lease.

Just who will fight Joe Louis in June is a matter that is causing the Twentieth Century Sporting Club officials considerable anxiety these days. Sol Strauss, acting director of the organization in the absence of Mike Jacobs, was rather certain yesterday morning that he had Joe Baksi of Kulpmont, Pa., all lined up for the heavyweight king's next title defense.

The Railroad Retirement Board is seeking the widows or other heirs of 2,000 railroad employes as possible beneficiaries under the Federal Railroad Retirement Act it was said here yesterday. Revision of the law last year made many additional families eligible for payments.

A letter to President Truman criticizing Gen. Lucius D. Clay, commander of the United States forces in Europe, for suggesting that displaced persons return to their countries of origin was released here yesterday by the Refugees Defense Committee.

TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 16 -- I flew over the Texas City disaster area today -- over waves of black smoke which bid all but five huge clusters of licking flame. A rectangle roughly a mile long and a half mile wide along the waterfront was a mass of twisted steel structures and charred debris.

The traditional view that bringing up the children is entirely up to Mother and that all Dad does is "bring home the bacon" has been "blasted to pieces by the findings of psychiatry," Dr. Luther E. Woodward, field consultant, National Committee for Mental Hygiene, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Most of the Congressional delegation returning today from the InterParliamentary Union Conference in Cairo said the trip had impressed them with the necessity of aiding Greece and Turkey.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The $400,000,000 Greek-Turkish aid bill was approved formally by the House Foreign Affairs Committee today.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 16 (U.P.) -- President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla swore in tonight a new cabinet consisting of eleven Radical party ministers and one Democrat.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Grain markets showed a strong undertone generally on the Board of Trade today, with buying of May wheat said to reflect sales of flour to France and of May corn against further sales of that grain to the Government having considerable influence on the near-by deliveries.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Any remaining doubt that the first legislation under the Truman Doctrine -- the GreekTurkish aid bill -- would pass Congress by emphatic majorities has been removed by Henry A. Wallace. As so often before, he lent great assistance to a project he opposed.

BANGALORE, India, April 16 -- Sir Chandrasekhara V. Raman, noted Indian scientist and winner of the Nobel award for physics in 1930, said today that he had turned to the study of minerals to probe the unsolved mysteries of what goes on within the world's solid matter.
HICKSVILLE, L.I., April 16 -- Farmers in the heart of Nassau County's potato lands expressed today fear of a major problem as a result of drastic state measures to curb the spread of a golden worm.

The best come-back in about three weeks was made yesterday by the stock market with an average recovery of slightly more than a point. There were wider increases in some of the high-price issues. The rally was accomplished on comparatively light volume, however, as transfers on the Stock Exchange fell to 990,000 shares, against 1,450,000 shares on Tuesday, with the heaviest business in the final hour after four hours of irregular price movements.
Striking office help picketed the Manhattan end of the BrooklynBattery Tunnel yesterday morning, shutting down all work on the tunnel except by operating engineers.

Jet Pilot kicked mud at eight other 3-year-olds, won the $15,000 added Jamaica Handicap with a minimum expenditure of energy, and thus, before 22,057 onlookers at rain-drenched Jamaica yesterday, gave Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham's Maine Chance Farm its third bullseye in three shots at New York purses during this brand-new racing season.

The tenor and outcome of the meeting between Premier Stalin and Secretary Marshall remain closely guarded secrets, but this very fact suggests, as does other evidence, that the two men have been unable to break the deadlock between Russia and the West. There remains some hope that the conference may still produce a treaty for Austria.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 16 (AP) -- The field for the Memorial Day 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway began to fill up today despite the hold-out of a group of owners and drivers demanding a bigger purse, now $75,000, or a share of the gate.

MOSCOW, April 16 -- Armond D. Willis, former cultural attache at the United States Embassy here, left the Soviet Union this morning after charging that "anti-Soviet members" of the embassy staff had tried to prevent him from seeing Ambassador Walter Bedell Smith and had otherwise impeded his work.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- The development of giant cyclotrons, like the one recently operated at Berkeley, Calif., will make possible scientific study in the laboratory of particles of energies approaching those of cosmic rays, Dr. Enrico Fermi of the Institute of Nuclear Studies at the University of Chicago, declared here tonight at the annual Medal Day dinner of the Franklin Institute.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- An economic analysis prepared for Congress disputed today the basic contentions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations with respect to the sources of corporate profits last year.

Marketing Delays There has been much conjecture whether or not the curtailment of long-distance telephone facilities would affect adversely the flotation of new issues. If there was still any doubt about it, the fall in the stock market has made the point academic.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission dismissed today proceedings instituted more than eight years ago against the Transamerica Corporation, San Francisco, largest bank-holding company in the country, questioning the accuracy of a company registration statement and subsequent annual reports.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- J.A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, told a House Territories Subcommittee today that negotiations for establishment of a newsprint mill in southeastern Alaska were nearing completion with a large company.

Steel warehouses have reached a turning point in meeting shortages of supplies, Walter S. Doxsey, national president of the American Steel Warehouse Association, Inc., told the New York Chapter at the annual meeting yesterday at Hotel New Yorker.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's broadcast tonight reporting on accomplishments of the recent legislative session: Once again I have the pleasure of reporting to the people of New York on the results of the session of the Legislature and most of the things I shall talk about tonight deal with the children of our state.

PITTSBURGH, April 16 (AP) -- Five officials of the Texas City Tex., plant of the Republic Oil Refining Company, which has its main offices here, are missing in today's ship explosion, company officials said tonight.

As farmers in New Hampshire, Vermont and up-state are harvesting the final run of sap in their maple orchards, reports indicate that the crop already has reached from 50 to 85 per cent of the normal production. Equally cheering is the news that the quality of the syrup is excellent.

Greatly daring, the young artists of the New York City Opera Company essayed last night their first production, under the direction of Laszlo Halasz, of Richard Strauss' "Salome," and were conspicuously successful in this difficult task.

A three-year program for development of the proposed civic center in downtown Brooklyn was approved yesterday at an executive meeting of the Board of Estimate. It calls for the expenditure of $14,850,000 and was purepared by Borough President John Cashmore and Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator.

Two abnormal conditions separated by thousands of miles -- one in the Baltic area and the other in ports of South America -- have upset shipping schedules in the Port of New York, causing revision of cargo sailing dates for many of the lines by as much as two months.
The cotton futures market turned stronger yesterday and closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 32 to 41 points higher than the day before.

TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 16 (U.P.) -- The state of Texas, assisted by the Red Cross, the armed services and veterans organizations, mobilized its resources tonight to handle the big job of relief in this blasted city.

Freeing of India from its colonial status means opening up a huge potential market for United States foreign trade, Asaf Ali, newly appointed Indian ambassador, told the Far East-American Council of Commerce and Industry, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

The Arvid Samuelson A Cappella Singers sang last night for the first time in Carnegie Hall. In the past they have given their annual New York concert in smaller auditoriums. They were led by Arvid Samuelson, who founded the chorus twelve years ago.

A master plan for hospitals and related facilities here, a project undertaken three years ago, has been completed and will be made public next Tuesday by the Hospital Council of Greater New York at a dinner at the Commodore Hotel, Dr. George Baehr, president of the New York Academy of Medicine, announced yesterday.

So that City College students a hundred years from now may know what the college was like in 1947, student members or the college's Alpha Phi Omega fraternity are preparing a time capsule to be buried in the center of the St. Nicholas Heights campus, 139th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

Olga Paul, mezzo-contralto, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. With Otto Janowitz at the piano, Miss Paul presented a program consisting of arias by Lully and Campra; English songs by Robert Johnson and Thomas Brown; German lieder by Beethoven, Schubert, Brahms and Strauss; folksongs of varied origin, and a final group of offerings by Chajes, Weiner, Sarah Levi and Gorochoff.

BOSTON, April 16 (AP) -- Bob Murphy, whose efforts to organize big-league ball players a year ago went somewhat awry, said tonight he had filed unfair labor practice charges against the Eastern Racing Association, Inc., operator of Suffolk Downs horse track.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 16 -- Miss Katharine F. Lenroot of the United States, former chief of the Children's Bureau of the Labor Department, was elected chairman of the United Nations' temporary Social Welfare Committee at the first meeting of the committee's second session today.

The International League opens its 64th consecutive season today and President Frank Shaughnessy of the triple A circuit expects a great race and another banner year at the gate. Shaughnessy said: "Competition should be keen and there should be a battle royal for the four play-off spots.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Henry Wallace continues to talk in England. We here understand him and make allowances for him. But abroad, where he is not so well known, he is dangerous.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., April 16 -- The apathetic New Jersey anglers who waited until the second day to avoid the opening-day crowds were a sad and wet group strung along the Raritan and Musconetcong yesterday. Few of them had enough trout for a hungry man's lunch.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Among the diseases that afflict this political capital is one that may be called acute division of the brain. Under the influence of this disease officials of the Executive and members of the Legislature tend to see only one thing at a time, the vision is narrowed, the eyes focus on the specific and seldom on the general, and in the process, the part sometimes seems greater than the whole.

Some potent acting and some elegant garments for ladies are being squandered on some oldfashioned clap-trap in "Message for Margaret," which was put on at the Plymouth last evening. It is the work of an English writer, James Parish; and in London it has a London setting.

Steaks, hams and huge beef roasts will be standard equipment for the United States Walker Cup team when it invades the British Isles next month -- an innovation which no doubt will come as a pleasant surprise to hard-pressed British ration boards, The Associated Press reports.

Supplies of industrial chemicals continue, in general, to be insufficient to meet requirements, L.L. Horch, New York regional director, Department of Commerce, announced here yesterday on the basis of an April industry report on chemicals and drugs.

The prestige of National Boys Club Week declined yesterday when two girls and their pets walked off with honors at the dog obedience contest staged at the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A bill for the establishment of a women's Army corps "as an integral component of the Regular Army" was introduced in Congress today, the War Department reported.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The House rejected today two major efforts to soften the Hartley omnibus labor bill and substantially assured its final passage tomorrow by a big majority.

LONDON, April 16 -- A crudely made time bomb believed to be the work of Jewish terrorists was found in the Dover House offices of the Colonial Office shortly after 6 A.M. today. Dover House in Whitehall is within 200 yards of 10 Downing Street, official residence of Prime Minister Attlee.

Nineteen Americans who manned the yacht Ben Hecht in an unsuccessful attempt last month to run the British blockade and carry Jewish passengers from Europe to Palestine returned here yesterday on the transport Marine Carp.

The storm over Mr. Wallace continues in Congress, and it is variously proposed (1) to prosecute him under the Logan Act, (2) to cancel his passport, and (3) to subject him to a vote of Congressional censure. Not one of these three courses, in our judgment, is either wise or warranted.

PEIPING, China, April 16 -- A full-scale Communist offensive is going on in southern Shansi Province today. It is generally regarded in informed military quarters here as indicating that the Communists have decided to establish their new headquarters in the Shansi mountains, following the loss of their capital, Yenan, in adjoining Shensi last month to Chinese Government troops.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Senate-House Committee on the Economic Report decided today to seek the counsel of leaders from all segments of the economy as it undertook an examination of the current price structure and the general economic situation.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 -- Addressing a sectional meeting of the National Conference of Social Work devoted to veterans' problems, George W. Ebey, California State Chairman of the American Veterans Committee, today called upon social workers to pay attention to a wave of intolerance which he said had already made its appearance on the West Coast.

Staff accountants for District Attorney Frank S. Hogan studied yesterday the financial records of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club in connection with the grand jury investigation into alleged links between prize-ring figures and underworld interests.
Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding the New York National Guard, recommended yesterday general principles to be followed in organizing civilian defense for major emergencies.

Several years ago John Wildberg transferred with suspicious results from Harlem to the Forties the American Negro Theatre's production of "Anna Lucasta." Mr. Wildberg, it was learned yesterday is now thinking of trying the Broadway wheel of fortune with still another ANT offering.

BERLIN, April 16 -- The economically merged United States and British zones of Germany and the Swedish Government formulated but did not conclude a trade agreement following week-long talks ended yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the tragic death of Mrs. Walter S. Sullivan, New York City has lost not only a good citizen but one of its finer women. She had the rare talent of being able to combine an intense interest in her home and family with an active participation in community affairs, bringing to both a continuing enthusiasm, an inspiration to all who worked with her.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Under a new law, approved by Governor Dewey today, the state industrial commissioner is empowered to declare a state of emergency which will permit contractors on public works projects to employ their workers more than forty hours a week.

The sharp decline in profits of large advertising agencies through 1945 may now be catching up with agencies in the medium-size bracket, according to preliminary figures of the American Association of Advertising Agencies released yesterday.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Under a new law, approved by Governor Dewey today, the state industrial commissioner is empowered to declare a state of emergency which will permit contractors on public works projects to employ their workers more than forty hours a week.

The sharp decline in profits of large advertising agencies through 1945 may now be catching up with agencies in the medium-size bracket, according to preliminary figures of the American Association of Advertising Agencies released yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 16 -- No break in the deadlock in the Council of Foreign Ministers on a German settlement is indicated, despite the conference last night between Secretary of State Marshall and Premier Stalin.

We have long believed that the most satisfactory unification of the military services would be one worked out by the services themselves. That end finally was achieved. Such a plan, approved by Army, Navy and Air Force leaders, is now before Congress. The Senate Armed Services Committee is holding hearings on the bill.
LINDEN, N.J., April 16 -- The Standard Oil Development Company of New Jersey demonstrated here today the oil industry's answer to the potential competition of atomic energy.

The nation's stocks of gasoline last week decreased 745,000 barrels, according to the estimate of the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend they totaled 106,221,000 barrels, against 106,966,000 barrels a week earlier and 102,118,000 on April 13, 1946.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, April 16 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay barred today "new applicants" -- meaning Jewish persons from Poland -- from admission to displaced persons camps in the United States zone beginning April 21.

Formation of a charitable foundation in memory of James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, was announced yesterday at a luncheon in the Astor Hotel attended by thirty persons prominent in political and business fields.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 16 -- Georg Branting, Swedish Senator who helped the defense in Boston's Sacco-Vanzetti case and the Reichstag fire trial in Berlin, has been named by the Soviet Union as its candidate for the Governorship of Trieste, it was learned today.

TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 16 -- Explosion after explosion ripped through this teeming oil city today, killing hundreds of persons and injuring hundreds more, and setting chemical plant, oil tank and ship fires that sent clouds of poisonous gas fumes across the devastated area.

Twenty-five brand names, which have compiled a combined record of 1,918 years of service, will be awarded certificates of public service at a meeting of the Brand Names Foundation tomorrow in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Four will be awarded centennial certificates.

CINCINNATI, April 16 (AP) -- The vaunted sluggers of the world champion Cardinals came to life in the eighth inning today to push over four fast runs and defeat the Red, 4 -- 1, before a chilled crowd of 3,410.

MOSCOW, April 16 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers agreed today to hold its first morning session tomorrow to hear Marshal Tito's Yugoslav delegation present its claims against Austria. Austrian Foreign Minister Karl Gruber and his group of experts will be present while Yugoslav Vice Premier Edvard Kardelj is making his statement.

In one of the longest meetings ever held by the New York section of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, 33 West Thirtyninth Street, 350 engineers heard the results of the institute's nation-wide poll, which indicated that 84 per cent of the 15,000 engineers who answered were in favor of "exempting professional employes from provisions of the Wagner Act."
The appointment of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer as director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N.J., was announced last night by Herbert H. Maass, its president.

TORONTO, April 16 (AP) -- The same roster which has brought the Toronto Maple Leafs to the very rim of the Stanley Cup will play out the championship series with the Montreal Canadiens, barring injuries, Conny Smythe, managing director of the Leafs, said today.
LONDON, April 16 -- All British land forces are being withdrawn from Iraq, it was officially announced tonight.
LONDON, April 16 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Dalton's budget proposals generally were well received in City circles, and this was reflected by increased activity in the stock markets today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 16 (AP) -- A People's Court composed mostly of Communists and other Leftists sentenced three persons to death by garroting today for allegedly having plotted to overthrow the freely elected Hungarian Government.

Several hundred members of society have subscribed to the annual Gay Thirties Dinner Dance to be held tonight in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. As in past years, the proceeds will aid the maintenance of the Boys' Club of New York, which is concerned with the welfare of more than 6,000 youthful members who use the organization's two clubhouses, respectively at 287 East Tenth Street and 321 East 111th Street.

Coro, Inc., manufacturer of fashion jewelry, had a record net income of $2,172,251 in 1946, nearly 280 per cent larger than the $586,668 earned in 1945, the annual report to stockholders revealed yesterday. The earnings equaled $4.53 a share on 478,515 common shares outstanding, compared with $1.22 a share in 1945.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- Hank Greenberg's first National League homer, plus six unearned tallies on shortstop Len Merullo's two errors in the seventh, swept the Pirates to a 7-1 triumph over the Cubs before 9,749 fans at Wrigley Field today.
LONDON, April 17 (U.P.) -- The organizing committee for the Olympic Games today sent out fifty-three invitations for the Fourteenth Olympiad to be held in London from July 29 to Aug. 14, 1948.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, April 17 -- The British will blow up the fortifications on the island of Helgoland tomorrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -- Harry R. Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, accused West Coast shipowners today of aiming at forcing the longshoremen to agree to changes in the Coast contract between the union and employers or to "face a lockout next June 15."

This is the season for Long Island ducks. If the housewife wishes to serve something special for Sunday's dinner, she might choose one of these birds, for they are available in stores throughout the city at about 39 cents a pound --4 cents less than their price last Friday.

The stock market settled back yesterday into a corner with an irregular drift throughout the session and closing prices moderately easier in the key sections. Alterations of more than a point were few and the composite rate was reduced about 1/4 point.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., April 17 -- Pat Dunn of New York and Mrs. Margaret Wagar of Atlanta led the sixty-two-entry field at the halfway mark of the mixed pairs event in the Southwestern championship bridge tournament.
