The Board of Estimate adopted unanimously yesterday a budget of $1,031,961,754 for 1947-48, exceeding by $2,841,440 the $1,029,120,314 executive budget submitted by Mayor O'Dwyer on April 1. The budget now goes to the City Council, which has the power to decrease, but not to increase, specific items.
Arthur N. Hosking Jr. has been appointed director of sales and promotion of Prestige, Inc., manufacturers of women's and men's hosiery.

ALBANY, April 17 -- In an effort to avert a strike by dairy farmers supplying the New York City area, C. Chester Du Mond, State Commissioner of Agriculture, today invited producers and dealers to meet with him on Monday to consider the payment of "premium prices" on milk delivered to the metropolitan zone after May 1.
Brooklyn College registered a 10-to-7 victory over the Kings Point nine on the Flatbush diamond yesterday, paced by the fine pitching and timely batting of Mario Suarez.

ONCE upon a time the New York Giants were the only baseball team in town. The Yankees, or Highlanders, were nobodies. The Dodgers were viewed with condescension everywhere except among the more rabid of the Flatbush Faithful. The Giants were the team of teams and John J. McGraw was the Giants. This was the best franchise in the sport, but more recently it has become slightly frayed around the edges.

William L. Shirer, who recently resigned from the Columbia Broadcasting System after a dispute with the network, received top honors yesterday for "outstanding reporting and interpretation of the news" at the seventh annual presentation of the George Foster Peabody Radio Awards in the Hotel Roosevelt CBS also shared in the award.

BERLIN, April 16 (Delayed) -- The extent to which the ideological war is being fought over the stillwarm corpse of nazism is illustrated by a heavily falsified attack by a Soviet-dominated newspaper here on the denazification program in the United States zone.
Half a million New Yorkers were vaccinated yesterday as a temporary shortage of vaccine, which was delaying the city's three-week program of protecting the population against smallpox, was overcome.

LONDON, April 17 -- The Southampton Harbor Board will call a meeting next Thursday to investigate charges made by Commodore Harry Manning that the port facilities at Southampton are "disgraceful" and "primitive."

Breaking up the industrial combinations that aided Hitler so effectively in the prosecution of the war, although so far limited to the giant I.G. Farbenindustrie cartel, is progressing with surprising effectiveness. James S. Martin, chief of the decartelization branch of, the American Military Government in Germany, stated yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 17 -- Leaders of the big three unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations have been summoned here for a meeting tomorrow to bring up to date the status of their negotiations with the steel, automobile and electrical industries.

Two City College professors with a combined total of sixty-seven years of teaching at the college have contributed $2,000 each to the school's Centennial Fund, Jacob Schapiro, chairman of the fund committee, announced yesterday.
The outlook for the American shipbuilding industry is darker today than at any time in its history, H. Gerrish Smith, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Average primary market prices decreased 0.5 per cent during the week ended on April 12, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Agricultural prices continued to decline. At 148.1 per cent of the 1926 average, the Bureau's index of commodity prices in primary markets was slightly below the level of four weeks ago and 35.5 per cent above last year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 17 -- The United Nations today enlisted the aid of 100,000 amateur radio operators throughout the world to spread information about the activities of the international organization.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade were erratic today, May wheat having a range of 5 cents, advancing 4 1/2 cents a bushel early to $2.63, or 17 1/2 cents above the low of last week, but the deferred months were inclined to easiness in sympathy with feed grains.

PEORIA, III., April 17 (U.P.) -- The 18-month-old strike of thirteen railroad brotherhoods against the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, the country's oldest labor dispute, was settled today, the unions and company announced.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 12 were 6 per cent below sales for the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Tempers broke today as the GreekTurkish aid program spent its eighth day before the Senate.

NANKING, April 17 -- The political program, organic laws and membership of a new coalition government were announced tonight. The new regime will come into being tomorrow on the twentieth anniversary of the establishment of the first Kuomintang National Government.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 17 -- The new increased interstate single-trip fares of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad became effective today and suburban communities in the New York area prepared for a fight-tothe-finish against prospective increases in intrastate and commutation rates.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 12 were 758,166 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 43,007 cars, or 6.0 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 108,868 cars, or 16.8 per cent, more than for the same period last year, and 88,847 cars, or 10.5 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Fall buying of women's ready-towear by retailers will assume a more normal pattern with respect to deliveries and advance commitments, according to reports in merchandising circles here yesterday. Indications were said to be that initial commitments may average around 60 per cent of the early volume last year, with reliance placed on open-to-buy as the season advances.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- A bill designed to encourage longterm loans to "small" business men today received the endorsement of Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve System.

The world has no place to turn today for regeneration except the United States, said Bernard M. Baruch in an address before the State House of Representatives at Columbia, S.C. "But," he added, "if we are to accept the challenge to save civilization it means greater effort than that exerted during the war."

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Warriors made it two straight over the Chicago Stags in the final play-offs of the Basketball Association of America tonight, pulling away in the final minutes for an 85-to-74 victory before a crowd of 7,604 at the arena.

After twenty years of one-party rule and almost as long a period of twoparty war, China is to have a multiparty government under terms of a statement signed by Chiang Kai-shek, members of two small parties and some liberal nonpartisans.

If any man can turn the monstrous trick of giving Frenchmen a reputation for gloom, it will be Jean-Paul Sartre, apostle of the dour creed of Existentialism. But in the Existentialist showpiece, "The Flies" -- as put on last evening at the President by the enterprising Dramatic Workshop of the New School -- M. Sartre demonstrates that he also has a talent for vital theatre.

A year-long controversy was brought to a climax yesterday at Queens College when the faculty voted 55 to 42 to sustain a recent student council decision revoking the charter of the campus chapter of the American Youth for Democracy.

SINGAPORE, April 17 -- Warehouses in Java may contain 800,000 tons of sugar, most of which will be exported to help relieve the world shortage, according to Dr. Pieter Honig, general economics adviser to the Netherlands Indies Government.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Holding that a broadcast of defamatory remarks read from a script constitute libel, rather than slander, the Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that George W. Hartmann, former Columbia University professor and chairman of the "Peace Now" movement, had a cause of action against Walter Winchell, radio commentator.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, of New York, struck out tonight at "selfish forces" who have "seized upon this time of confusion to increase their power and wealth at the expense of the laborer" in the passage of new laws dangering- "social gains."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, April 17 -- Two thousand Jewish displaced persons today marched on the British consulate at Munich in a demonstration against the execution of Dov Bela Gruner and three other convicted Jewish terrorists in Palestine.
SECURITY COUNCIL Meets today at 10:30 A.M. to resume discussion of United States plan to aid Greece and Turkey (open).

CINCINNATI, April 17 (AP) -- Behind rookie Kent Peterson's superb relief hurling, the Reds unlimbered their home-run bats four times today against the Cardinals to score a 9-4 victory and take the opening series from the world champions, 2 -- 1. Peterson, a lefthander, went to the relief of Everett Lively with one out in the opening frame and held St. Louis to three hits the rest of the way.

Electrically heated ceilings that distribute radiant warmth by the same principle as that by which the sun warms objects in the path of its rays are receiving considerable attention from home heating engineers. In an experimental house in Knoxville, Tenn., according to an announcement by the United States Rubber Company, a study is being made of electrified ceilings containing a heating element of conductive rubber sandwiched between two thin layers of plastic.

Determined not to be "starved into submission" in their fight with the Bell System, striking telephone workers in the metropolitan area appealed yesterday to the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations for financial and picketing assistance.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Settlement of the nation-wide telephone workers' strike on the basis of a $6 wage increase and arbitration of the remaining demands was set forth today as a way of breaking the deadlock, according to officials of the National Federation of Telephone Workers.

Arrangements have been completed for using the former home of Max Reinhardt, Castle Leopoldskron, in Salzburg, Austria, for the Salzburg Seminar in American Civilization to be conducted by the Harvard Student Council July 15 to Aug. 31.

PARIS, April 17 -- In the bitterest attack it has yet made on the Western powers, the Communist party's political bureau accused "American reaction" today of backing former President de Gaulle, the Americans and British of frustrating France's efforts to get more German coal and "foreign imperialisms" of stirring up trouble in the French Empire in order to weaken and dominate France.

CLEVELAND, April 17 (U.P.) -- Baseball Commissioner A.B. (Happy) Chandler, without making a direct reference to the suspension of Leo Durocher, tonight defended his action in a forceful speech to the Cleveland chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said yesterday that a general European recovery is dependent on a broad program of credits in which the United States must take a leading role.

LONDON, April 17 -- Scotland Yard is investigating the possibility that funds from the United States financed the planting of a bomb in the Colonial Office's Dover House in Whitehall yesterday, it was disclosed tonight.

Bill Rate Money marketers are awaiting the outcome of the scheduled meeting in Washington today of Secretary of the Treasury Snyder, Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve System, and Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Prospect of an early upward revision of the Treasury bill rate undoubtedly will be a major topic of discussion.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -- The presence of 3,000,000 "inebriates" among the 50,000,000 American citizens over the age of 15 who use alcohol in some form, is a major problem that must be approached "unemotionally," Dr. George S. Johnson of the Stanford University School of Medicine told the National Conference for Social Work today.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 17 (AP) -- The number of long distance telephone operators here was cut from 197 to ten tonight, officials of the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company and the Telephone Workers Union stated.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- J.A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, issued a report today condemning a majority of bituminous coal-mining communities controlled by the companies as "a menace to healthful living." He recommended a joint State government-management-labor program for their improvement.
BOSTON, April 17 (AP) -- Taking a 4-0 lead in the first two innings. The Boston Red Sox today defeated the Washington Senators, 4 -- 1, behind Joe Dobson.
Helen Keller made an impassioned plea yesterday for national support of the American Foundation for the Overseas Blind.
ROME, April 17 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza was beaten today in a demonstration against the Government by a thousand unemployed workers.

The impressive quiet of an otherwise orderly meeting of 2,000 persons in Manhattan Center commemorating the fourth anniversary of Warsaw's ghetto uprising against the Nazis was shattered last night with a demonstration of antipathy toward the present Polish Government.

When Kate S. Chittenden was 6 years old she had two ambitions -- to play the organ and to teach piano-playing. Yesterday as she celebrated her ninety-first birthday in her studio, 853 Seventh Avenue, she looked back on seventyfour years of uninterrupted teaching, thirty-one of them as head of the piano department at Vassar College.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the current discussion concerning the unprecedentedly heavy cut made by the House of Representatives in the 1948 budget of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, attempts have been made to justify the action of the House by references to the "spectacular" growth of the bureau in the past nine years.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $40,000,000 of twenty-year 2 5/8 per cent debentures of the United States Rubber Company. The debentures are priced at par.

Time Study and Methods Conference sponsored by Society for the Advancement of Management and Management Division, American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Hotel Pennsylvania, 9:30 A.M. Luncheon, 12:15 P.M. Afternoon session, 2:15 P.M. Dinner, 7 P.M. Continues tomorrow.

The Federal Public Housing Authority will receive bids on April 29 on issues of temporary notes aggregating $24,872,000 in behalf of fifteen agencies. All notes will be dated May 20, 1947, and will come due May 25, 1948.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 17 -- Deborah Kerr, whom Metro-GoldwynMayer brought over from England for the feminine lead opposite Clark Gable in "The Hucksters," will make her second American film apperance in "If Winter Comes," with Walter Pidgeon, the studio announced today Miss Kerr, who was seen in the English film, "Vacation from Marriabe," has just completed "The Hucksters" and will begin work in "If Winter Comes" in June.

Manufacturers must step up output of quality fabrics and new designs to overcome consumer resistance, according to speakers yesterday at a luncheon-meeting of the Textile Salesmen's Association in the Hotel Astor. Fashion merchandising, they said, can do more than any one other factor to increase consumer purchases of apparel, but it must start with the yarn and fabric.

The Whitney Museum of American Art will close today for installation of the centenary exhibition of paintings by Ralph A. Blakelock, which opens to the public on Tuesday afternoon and will continue through May 29.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- As tourists in a spring influx like that before the war walked through the downstairs rooms of the White House today, Mrs. Truman's secretaries announced to women reporters an unusual burst of activity scheduled for the First Lady.
HELSINKI, Finland, April 17 -- Harold E. Stassen arrived in Helsinki today from Moscow. He will go to Stockholm, Sweden, tomorrow.

The Port of New York Authority will take over the city's three major airports on June 1 under a 50-year lease contract signed yesterday afternoon at City Hall by Mayor O'Dwyer and Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the bi-state agency.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 17 -- Nation-wide cooperative action by Federal and State Governments and industry to halt the "gross pollution of rivers and streams on which 50,000,000 Americans rely for drinking water" was urged here today by Surgeon Gen. Thomas Parran of the United States Public Health Service, at the meeting of the American Chemical Society.
A local catastrophe like the Texas City fires and explosions was viewed by Municipal and Federal officials yesterday as unlikely in New York

The development of "a liking for reading among boys" is necessary for building good citizens in America, David W. Armstrong, executive director, Boys' Clubs of America, declared here last night. He spoke at the first annual Boys' Clubs of America junior book award dinner in the New Yorker Hotel.

The twenty-seven-man crew of the ocean-going tugboat Great Isaac, which sank Wednesday night after it was struck by the Norwegian freighter Bandeirante, five miles south of Barnegat Lightship in a dense fog, arrived aboard the Bandeirante at Pier 6, East River, at 4 P.M. yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 17 (AP) -- The Moscow News, the Soviet Union's English language newspaper, said today Russian inventors had developed a "combination mechanical miner" that constituted a "technical revolution" and would do the work of thirty skilled mine workers.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- President Truman extended his congratulations today to Milton Reynolds, William P. Odom and T. C. Sallee on the successful completion of their flight around the world in 78 hours, 56 minutes. He received them briefly at his desk in the executive offices.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is with painful surprise that I read two articles about Greece written by your correspondent Raymond Daniell I hope you will not mind if I call these articles unfair and unjust, and harmful to Greek interests, especially at this crucial moment.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Republican party and Carroll Reece, its national chairman, were accused of threatening the existence of a free radio and interfering unduly with the managerial discretion of broadcasting chains in a letter sent to the heads of three major companies by Gael Sullivan, director of the National Democratic Committee.

JERUSALEM, April 17 -- Less than forty-eight hours after the hanging of four convicted terrorists and while Palestine is still in a state of high tension, the British commanding general confirmed tonight the death sentences of two other terrorists.

Philip D. Reed, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company, called on the American people last night to make free enterprise work better than ever before to insure its preservation in a world where the post-war trend has been toward totalitarianism.
CLEVELAND, April 17 (AP) -- A fence that would cut an enormous chunk from the Cleveland Stadium outfield area was ordered today by President Bill Veeck of the Indians as an aid to his Tribe sluggers.

LOBATSI, Bechuanaland, April 17 -- Echoes of King George VI' s visit to Lobatsi in this protectorate began to reverberate this afternoon. They are likely to reach New York by the time the United Nations General Assembly meets in its regular session next September.

Maine Chance Farm's winning streak ended yesterday, but not until half an hour after War Date had made the record four for four at the Jamaica meeting by scoring an easy triumph at 7 to 10 in the $7,500 added Minerva Handicap.

Supporters of the Red Cross throughout the nation must have felt much satisfaction yesterday when they read how that organization responded instantly to the heart-wrenching disaster at Texas City. On the same day this tragedy occurred national headquarters set aside $250,000 for aid and promised more money if needed.

LOS ANGELES, April 17 -- California Institute of Technology officials today announced receipt of a $300,000 fund from the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis for a five-year program of research into "the structure of organic proteins" in an effort to learn how the poliomyelitis virus destroys human nerve cells.

PARIS, April 17 -- Insisting strongly on the gravity of the national emergency, Premier Paul Ramadier emphasized today the need for all groups of opinion to subordinate their private or party aims to national interests.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 17 -- Albania appealed today to the United Nations' Security Council against four alleged violations of her territorial waters by Greek vessels. The incidents were said to have occurred during the first week of April in the Corfu Channel, where two British destroyers hit mines last October.

The Index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials Gillespie Varnish Cuts Prices The Gillespie Varnish Company. Jersey City, manufacturer of paints, varnishes and enamels, has reduced prices on a number of items, ranging as high as 25 per cent, it was announced yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 17 -- The most important trial in Belgium for economic collaboration with the enemy has ended in the acquittal, on appeal, of Baron Emmanuel Janssen, Gustave Fauquet, Jean Washer and Charles Semal, directors of the Fabelta artificial silk concern.
An appeal to the citizens of the United States to support a United States of Europe was issued here today by eighty-one prominent Americans.

The six-story store and apartment building on a lot 26.8 by 125 feet at 128 Second Avenue was bought by a client of Joseph Cohen and Arnold T. Milton, brokers, from Frederick Brown, who recently bought the adjoining parcel at the southeast corner of Second Avenue and St. Marks Place and resold it to a chain-store organization for improvement with a one-story taxpayer.

ST. LOUIS, April 17 (AP) -- A long single to center by Rookie Paul Lehner, a pinch-hitter with the bases loaded and two out in the tenth inning, gave the Browns a 4-to-3 victory over the Tigers today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The relief facilities of all Federal agencies were promised by President Truman today to the sufferers of the explosion in Texas City, Tex. He telegraphed this message to Mayor J.C. Trahan: "I know that the Red Cross is ministering to your stricken city and I have asked every Government agency to cooperate in relief activity.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 17 -- Frederick Osborn, deputy United States representative on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, warned today that the nations of the world were already traveling the road of atomic rivalries.

LONDON, April 17 (AP) -- A wellinformed source said today that negotiations had been completed for the publication of former Prime Minister Winston Churchill's war-time memoirs in Life Magazine and THE NEW YORK TIMES.

TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 17 -- Under a sky blackened with gigantic pillars of dense smoke from nine separate fires that cast a withering heat over a large area, the residents of this war-boom town claimed late today a costly victory over the catastrophic forces that brought them untold dead and injured. Property damage has mounted into millions of dollars.

LONDON, April 17 -- Defending his drastic increase in the tax on tobacco, Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons tonight that this budget measure was the "first shot in a campaign for the reduction of dollar expenditure."

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, denied before a Senate committee today that he had instructed mine safety committees of union members not to cooperate in speeding the reopening of soft coal mines two weeks ago.

ALBANY, April 17 -- A total of 908 new laws had been added to the statute books this year when Gov. Thomas E. Dewey approved at 4:26 P.M. today the last of the bills left with him by the Legislature when it adjourned on March 18.

A new spun glass material that diffuses a soft light when used in lampshades and floor screens and provides a washable fire-resistant covering for walls was shown yesterday at Elizabeth Maher Associates, 424 Madison Avenue. The textured material, made of Fiberglas and set with plastics is being manufactured by Polyplastex United, Inc., of Elmhurst.

While the deadlock between Russia and the Western World continues at Moscow, a resolution to rally American support for a project which is the logical answer to that deadlock has been introduced in both Houses of Congress by Senator Fulbright and Representative Boggs.

The new Pendleton collection, which includes three groups of furniture plus carpets, fabrics, and lamps to go with them and background paints to set them off, will be presented on the seventh floor of Wanamaker's Home Store starting Monday morning.

The covenant on airports signed yesterday at City Hall makes secure for many years the pre-eminent position of New York as an aviation center. Mayor O'Dwyer and Howard S. Cullman for the Port of New York Authority by their signatures seal a partnership of faith in the future of air transport and this city's share in it as a crossroads of the world.
MOSCOW, April 17 -- Yugoslav Premier Marshal Tito's special envoys staked out before the Council of Foreign Ministers today claims for southern Carinthia and $150,000,000 in reparations from Austria.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Leaders of seventy-nine lay organizations held round-table discussions at the National Education Association today on "how citizens can help get and keep good teachers," a curtain-raiser to Capitol Hill hearing's on Federal aid to education.

While coping with sharply rising costs, hospitals today also are beset with problems of adequate training for internes and residents, the future of the general practitioner and a growing disparity between demand for and supply of staff personnel, leading physicians reported yesterday. They urged the establishment of formal education programs in the nation's hospitals.

IN Italy they have been talking about "the problem of the South" for generations. And nowhere in the South is the problem more acute than in Lucania, that barren, desolate, primitive region just north of the arch of the Italian boot. It was there in 1935 that Dr. Carlo Levi spent a year in exile as a political prisoner after his release from the infamous Regina Coeli jail in Rome.

It was the sad duty of Stanley Gilkey, Barbara Payne and Henry Sherek, sponsors of the newlyopened "Message for Margaret," co-starring Mady Christians and Miriam Hopkins, to read a unanimous set of adverse reviews yesterday. Without further ado, the management decided to close the attraction after its fifth performance tomorrow night.

In recognition of their contributions "to widening the arc of understanding and appreciation in America for art in its varied forms," four $1,000 awards were presented yesterday to leaders in the fields of music, the motion picture, modern art and the dance.

NEWARK, N.J., April 17 (AP) -- With a home run by Joe Collins opening the firing and Al Clark's three-run circuit serving as the finale, the Newark Bears shelled three Rochester pitchers for eleven hits and an 11-5 triumph before 13,779 opening-day fans today.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 17 (U.P.) -- The tragedy of Texas City overflowed into Houston's block-square City Auditorium today, filling it with heartaches.

Streptomycin, contrary to much popular belief, is not a cure-all for tuberculosis sufferers, Dr. Paul A. Bunn of the Streptomycin Committee of the Veterans Administration warned 200 physicians and welfare workers yesterday at a luncheon in the Towers Hotel, 25 Clark Street, Brooklyn.

Winners of the annual Edgar Allan Poe Awards, given for the best first novel, criticism, film and radio show with mystery as the subjects, were announced yesterday by Hugh Pentecost, president of Mystery Writers of America, national organization of 200 authors.

MONTREAL, April 17 (AP) -- Maurice Richard kept the Montreal Canadiens in the Stanley Cup hockey play-offs tonight by scoring two goals to pace the Flying Frenchmen to a 3-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs. The Leafs now lead the Canucks by three games to two in the best-ofseven series.

MOSCOW, April 17 -- A continued deadlock on Germany in the Council of Foreign Ministers would force United States and British authorities to embark on a separate program in the two western zones. This program would raise the level of industry in the two zones, boost their exports and gradually transfer political responsibility to the Laender Governments.

Roy A. Hunt, president of the Aluminum Company of America, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the stockholders of the company that the time is fast approaching "when we'll have to beat the bushes for orders." However, he added, Alcoa's business this year, in comparison with 1946, is "very good."
ALBANY, April 17 -- The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that a race track operator, without reason or excuse, may bar any person from attending its races.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 5,000 head, total 8,000: weights, 250 pounds down, opened 25 to 50 cents lower; later trade on all weights 50 to 75 cents lower than Wednesday's average: scattered

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Thurman Arnold, former Assistant Attorney General, accused the International Typographical Union today of "totalitarian" methods and "make-work" practices that jeopardized the welfare of small newspapers.

OVER TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 17 -- In four years of war coverage I have seen no concentrated devastation so utter, except Nagasaki, Japan, victim of the second atom bomb, as presented today by flaming Texas City.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., April 17-Maj. Gen. George E. Stratemeyer, wartime commander of air forces in India and Burma and now charged with the development of National Guard and reserve flying, declared here today that cuts in funds had reduced the United States to the point where its impotence in the air invited attack.

The New York County Democratic Committee at its meeting next Thursday evening in Haaren High School is scheduled to adopt a resolution to change the party rules to make re-election of assembly district leaders and co-leaders in districts having multiple leaderships more certain than under the present rules.

Sentiment favoring the employment of an independent, paid president for the New York Cotton Exchange is growing among the membership, it was found yesterday. A decision on the matter, however, is not expected to be made until the installation of the new board of managers on June 2.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- A two-base hit that caromed off the left field concrete above the head of Clint Hartung at Shibe Park today was the big blow in a bewildering succession of events which sent the Giants crashing down to defeat for the second time at the hands of the Phillies.

A program preliminary to the start of a comprehensive campaign to promote understanding of the American system of free enterprise has been completed by a joint committee of the Association of National Advertisers and the American Association of Advertising Agencies and submitted, for approval and administration of the Advertising Council.

With Sandy Silverstein going the route for the first time this season, the New York University baseball team defeated St. John's University at Dexter Park yesterday, 4 to 3, in a well played game. It was a rare college contest in that only one error was committed.

TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 17 -- Terror-stricken Texas City was a gray ghost town today. House after house stood in splintered silence, deserted in destruction. In the shadow of the raging fires a lone cow munched away at scrubby grass, no one to care for her milk. The only other moving thing in that torn land was a red apron that waved on a washline in an abandoned backyard.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Insurance to be paid for the loss of lives and property in the Texas City disaster may run from $50.000,000 to $100,000,000, according to insurance men acquainted with conditions in the stricken seaport. One of the largest single items will be some $15,000,000 in fire insurance on the vast plant of the Monsanto Chemical Company, it was said.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A colloquy between Senators Vandenberg and Pepper, which appears in today's Congressional Record but was crowded out of most news reports by more dynamic matter, illustrates better than any written reservation to the Greek-Turkish aid legislation that the bill is being supported by many in Congress on the specific understanding that it does not initiate an unlimited policy or a fixed method of enforcing it.

A call was issued yesterday for a conference next month at which plans will be made for an Emergency World People's Congress, designed to bring public thinking "to grips with common tasks essential to survival in the Atomic Age."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The terrible explosion at Texas City comes as a terrific shock to the nation. The worst feature of this disaster is that most of the horror wrought, including the hundreds of lives lost, was, in our opinion, entirely unnecessary, because it is a well-known fact that the loading of ammunition and explosives should be confined to a separate port area.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The House Ways and Means Committee will begin hearings early next month on general revision of the Federal Tax Code, Chairman Harold Knutson of Minnesota said today.

Harper reports that it has acquired the American book rights in James F. Byrnes' personal record of his experiences as Secretary of State. As yet untitled, Mr. Byrnes' book will deal mostly with his part in the formation of our post-war foreign policy, from the accession of President Truman to early 1947.

A revised plan of reorganization for the Childs Company, operator of restaurants, has been prepared by John F.X. Finn, trustee, for submission to the United States District Court here on Monday, it was announced yesterday.It calls for a preferred-arid-common-stock capitalization, instead of the allcommon-stock capitalization set forth in the previous proposal.
LONDON, April 17 -- Changes in the British Cabinet were announced tonight following the resignation of Lord Pethick-Lawrence, Secretary of State for India and Burma.

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System now appear to be tapering off, registering declines for the second consecutive week, it was disclosed yesterday. According to the report for the week ended on Wednesday issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the loans declined $59,000,000 to $4,168,000,000.
MILLVILLE, N.J., April 17 (AP) -- Mr. Ball purchased the Millville Glass Manufacturing plant early this year. The plant produces battery separators, pill bottles, vials, glass novelties, etc.

Two jurors were selected yesterday in Kings County Court for the trial of Julius Lobel, alias Jimmy Collins, and Irving Cohen, both charged with grand larceny and forgery in the swindle of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Responsibility to print unbiased, objective news is a part of the price which the public expects of the press in return for its basic guarantee of freedom, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared today in an address to the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

In the hope of taking some of the weight off Glenn Dobbs' shoulders next fall, the Brooklyn Football Dodgers yesterday announced signing of Elmore T. Harris, known to track and field followers for his feats on the Madison Square Garden boards and elsewhere during the past few seasons.

LONDON, April 17 -- Official sources let it be known today that Foreign Secretary Bevin was expected to start back for London from Moscow next Tuesday or Wednesday. They also confirmed (what was already known) that negotiations for Anglo-Soviet nonaggression pact had bogged down.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 17 -- The United Kingdom was reported today to favor excluding the Big Five as well as the Arab League from the proposed special United Nations commission of inquiry on Palestine.

One swallow does not make a summer, nor does one defeat lose a pennant. Two setbacks, however could be the start of a costly habit and the Yankees were on the road to their second straight defeat by the Athletics yesterday at the Stadium.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- During the week ending April 16, member bank reserve balances increased $53,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

TOKYO, April 17 -- The political parties in Japan are widely divided on the question of a controlled economy, with the most conservative strangely aligned with the Socialists, according to an editorial in Asahi Shimbun today.

GENEVA, April 17 -- William H. Stoneman, special assistant to United Nations Secretary General Trygve Lie, wound up today his investigation of charges of bias and incompetence directed against the Secretariat of the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A new Federal code to govern labormanagement relations, including a thorough overhauling of the Wagner Act, was approved by the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee today. The vote was 11 to 2.

Random notes: A wire has been received from the water watchers at Roscoe reporting that the Beaverkill is clear and about normal, with the water temperature hovering around 42 degrees. What more can the anxious trout fisherman ask?

Spindly-legged Johnny Jorgensen had himself a "day" as the Dodgers, capturing their second straight decision over the Braves at Ebbets Field yesterday, vengefully assaulted Mort Cooper, the pitcher who kept them out of the 1946 world series.

Snubbing the Euator Round the world by air is a flexible term. For this reason it is gratifying to see that the Reynolds Bombshell's round-the-world trip was not only faster than Howard Hughes' flight nine years ago by twelve hours but approximately 5,000 miles longer.
There will be a familiar face on the Bronx Gun Hill Road bus today. He has not been seen in those parts since March 28, when he made a slight detour and ended up in Hollywood, Fla.

Support for the fourth annual United Negro College Fund campaign, during which it is hoped to raise $1,300,000, was both promised and recommended to others yesterday by John D. Rockefeller Jr., Harvey S. Firestone Jr., and Andrew W. Robertson, Westinghouse Electric Corporation chairman.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The House with exultant shouts passed by 308 to 107 today a bill embodying the sharpest restrictions on labor unions ever attempted since collective bargaining became a powerful factor in American industrial life.

Three sets of baby lamb twins have arrived at the Children's Zoo of the Bronx Zoo. Born two weeks ago, the lambs are lovable playmates for young visitors. Another favorite diversion there is the Wishing Seat, a natural rock formation, where boys and girls stop a moment to make a wish.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy laid plans today for working in a spirit of friendly cooperation with the Atomic Energy Commission headed by David E. Lilienthal.

GENEVA, April 17 -- The removal of trade barriers and the creation of a world trade organization are "herculean tasks" but the American people are behind the effort, William L. Clayton, Under-Secretary of State, said today. He made the first public statement since his arrival to head the United States delegation at the Geneva Trade Conference.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 17 (AP) -- Mayor Frank Hague, who had a Washington appointment with President Truman, wasn't on hand to see it and it was too bad because his Jersey City Little Giants put on a real show before 37,281 fans in Roosevelt Stadium as they slugged out a 11-5 victory over the Buffalo Bisons in their International League baseball opener.

American Rolling Mill Charles R. Hook, president of American Rolling Mill, announced that stockholders at the annual meeting held yesterday at Middletown, Ohio, had approved amended articles of incorporation to extend for five years from July 15, 1947, to July 15, 1952, the time during which the preferred stock must be converted into common stock, and also to permit the directors to authorize the purchase of shares of any class issued by the company.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 17 -- All American missions abroad have been instructed to inform foreign governments that the United States strongly supports the establishment of the International Refugee Organization, it was learned today.
A detailed proposal for gaining two years' time in the construction of two low-rent housing projects was advanced yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority.
LONDON, April 17 -- As was to be expected, business became much quieter in the stock markets today after the activity that followed the announcement of the budget.

LONDON, April 17 -- Before leaving Britain for Stockholm today Henry A. Wallace, American politician, issued a statement expressing "surprise" at "the confidence and ability to meet problems" that he found among members of the British Government.

Adam Hat Stores. Inc. and Subsidiaries -- For 1946: Record consolidated net income of $651,127, equal to $1.54 each on 421,299 common shares outstanding compared with $518,175 or $1.24 each on 417,299 shares for 1945 which included a net capital gain of $129,281.
Recovering from early lows, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 2 to 18 points net higher.

Fifteen hundred Democrats, attending the Jefferson Day Dinner of the National Democratic Club last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, heard Senator Tom Connally and Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman virtually place President Truman in nomination to succeed himself in 1948.

TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 17 -- The new ship explosions today that sharpened the sorrow and misery of this stricken city looked like giant sky rockets, coming: as they did thirteen hours after twin blasts took hundreds of lives and injured thousands.

Retailers are preparing to abandon their traditional policy of marking up prices to make more profit, John E. McCarthy, director of central training activities, Gimbel Brothers, Inc., declared yesterday.
LONDON, April 18 -- Great Britain is "being driven to ruin" and the empire "scattered and squandered," Winston Churchill said today in his gloomiest attack yet on the Labor Government.

Resistance of manufacturers to overpriced rayon piece goods has resulted in extensive reductions by secondary sellers, it was learned in the trade yesterday. The socalled "white" market, successor to the black market of OPA days, has practically disappeared, textile men said.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- It may come as a surprise to some citizens that our Chief Executive is ambidextrous. At least, he was today when he officially launched the local season by tossing out the first ball, after which the Yankees behind Allie Reynolds proceeded to whitewash the Senators, 7 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Three experts, commissioned by the American Federation of Labor Building Trades Department to recommend techniques for avoiding jurisdictional strikes, prescribed a five-year plan today.

BERLIN, April 18 -- S.N. Rostowski, leader of the Soviet trade union delegation to the second annual congress of the Free German Trade Union, praised by implication today the British Military Government's handling of the Ruhr coal mine strike. Mr. Rostowski was a member of the delegation to the World Federation of Trade Unions that recently toured Germany.

Two alert youngsters, one a vegetarian and the other "almosta-vegetarian," received silver cups yesterday at Bellevue Hospital as the "healthiest boys" in the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street. The cups were presented to the boys by Dr. William F. Jacobs, superintendent of Bellevue.

One out of five New Yorkers, in contrast to the widely-publicized one out of eight throughout the country, is doomed at present to die of cancer, Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick, chairman of the New York City Cancer Committee campaign, told 125 civic leaders yesterday in a luncheon at the Hotel Towers, 25 Clark Street, Brooklyn.
PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (AP) -- Home runs by Ted Williams and Bobby Doerr paced the Red Sox to a 9-to-3 victory over the Athletics today to mar Philadelphia's American League opener before 8,782.

Dr. Willie Melmoth Bomar, who charges she was dismissed from the faculty of Girls High School, Brooklyn, because she served on a Federal court jury, asked the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday to decide "whether she must forego the privilege of American citizenship in order to teach the fundamentals of citizenship to school children."

DETROIT, April 18 -- The General Motors Corporation offered today a wage bonus of about $5,000,000 to the United Automobile Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in order to effectuate an immediate pay adjustment on the basis of 15 cents an hour.
David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, last night denounced the anti-labor bill voted by the House Thursday.

There are many anglers who continue to remain calm despite the opening of trout seasons in various near-by states, and brazenly announce their preference for the more contemplative forms of angling, such as flounder fishing.

ALBANY, April 18 -- Some form of cancer was developed by at least two out of every 1,000 residents of New York State last year, Dr. Morton L. Levin, Director of Cancer Control, said today in a report to Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., State Commissioner of Health.

PITTSBURGH, April 18 (AP) -- The Pirates today opened their home season with all the fanfare of a Hollywood premiere -- including a movie star -- and brought the festivities at Forbes Field to a happy conclusion for an overflow, record crowd of 38,216 by downing the Reds, 12 -- 11.
TOKYO, April 18 -- Registration ended today for candidates of the House of Representatives, the lower house of the new Japanese Diet [Parliament], with 1,604 men and women seeking the 466 seats.

Pianism of the highest order prevailed throughout the recital given by Robert Casadesus last night at Carnegie Hall, before a capacity audience. The program, composed of works of Rameau, Liszt, Chopin and Debussy, was excellently devised, and every offering it contained received a masterly and illuminating performance.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (AP) -- H.W. Lay Co., Inc., Atlanta, Ga., food products' manufacturer, today registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission 16,000 shares of $50 par 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock and 15,000 shares of $1 par common.

Labor and business must demonstrate "economic and social statesmanship of the highest order" if an industrial recession is to be avoided, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, warned yesterday in his annual report as president of the Union Labor Life Insurance Company.
LONDON, April 18 -- Although business remained on a small scale in stock markets today, the general tone was cheerful.

The Mayor's occasional vacations always offer a good opportunity for taking stock of work done and what lies ahead. We have little doubt that they are so used by him while he is taking a deserved rest. It is also a useful occupation for those left behind.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES. In the death of Ernest Flagg, American architects and architecture have lost one of the most valuable and original creative artists that this country has produced. While an energetic and forceful personality, he did not seek notoriety and therefore is not as well known as some practitioners in "modern" architecture whose work is brought to the attention of the public more insistently.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Heated clashes over whether the Truman Doctrine would point to peace or war developed among Republicans as they took over Senate debate today on the bill to bolster Turkey and Greece. The galleries seemed divided on the issue.

The vacancy created at the Plymouth Theatre tonight by the departure of "Message For Margaret" will be filled by "A Young Man's Fancy," it was announced yesterday. The Harry ThurschwellAlfred Golden comedy, which Henry Adrian is producing, will arrive at that playhouse on Tuesday evening, April 29.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In reference to the letter of C.G. Couvaras which appeared on March 28 regarding the status of the guerrilla band Edes, led by General Zervas, and the opposition forces Elas, I find it necessary to make several corrections.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday from the early lows and closed irregular, 20 points higher to 15 points lower than the day before.

PITTSBURGH, April 18 -- An agreement on "economic issues" amounting to a fifteen-cent-anhour increase was announced in a joint statement today by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 18 -- Ernest L. Van Wagner, retired New York police inspector and past president of the St. Petersburg Shrine Club, died here yesterday in a hospital. His age was 71. He retired fifteen years ago.

The following books of a religious or inspirational nature have been published recently: THE GOSPEL OF JESUS CHRIST, by Pere M-J Lagrange, O.P. Two volumes. Translated by the English Dominican Province. Westminster. $7.50 the set -- A narrative of Christ's birth, ministry, death and resurrection, as narrated in the Four Gospels and accepted by Christendom.

LITTLE FELDBERG, Germany, April 18 -- The scientific recordings here of the explosion on Helgoland, 275 miles away, were "beautiful." That was the enthusiastic judgment of Dr. John V. Atanasoff, chief of the acoustics division of the United States Naval Ordnance Laboratories.

A "most gratifying" response to City College's $1,500,000 Centennial drive for a student war memorial has been received during the past few days from New Yorkers in all walks of life, Leo Eisen, a member of the college's Centennial Fund committee, announced yesterday.

William Masselos, 26-year-old New York pianist, and Joan Brainard, 22-year-old soprano from Hamden, Conn., were the winners in the national finals of the 1947 Young Artists Auditions of the National Federation of Music Clubs, held yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall.

The system for merit-rating public school teachers adopted by the last session of the Legislature was termed "impracticable and unworkable" by a three-quarter majority of twenty-three school superintendents yesterday at the opening session of a New York University educational conference, held in the School of Education.

The special Saturday film programs for children begun six months ago with the establishment by the industry of the Children's Film Library have proven so successful that several hundred prints of additional pictures will soon be added to the library, it was announced yesterday by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association.

CUXHAVEN, Germany, April 18 -- Helgoland, Germany's North Sea Gibraltar, was effectively demilitarized today. The British Navy set off 3,500 tons of high explosives stored in the island's intricate eight and a half miles of tunnel system.

One of the most effective forces in the community in gradually breaking down the ancient enmity between the boys in the street and the cop on the corner has been the Police Athletic League, a police-sponsored recreation organization which provides physical, social and cultural pursuits for hundreds of thousands of boys and girls.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Net profits after taxes earned by United States national banks totaled $495,000,000 in 1946 a rise of $5,000,000 over the previous year, and a rate of 9.61 per cent of capital funds, Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, announced today.

A strike of 1,900 employes in the city's financial district, scheduled to begin at 10 A.M. Monday, appeared a certainty last night when officials of the United Financial Workers, AFL, admitted that they saw "little hope" for a settlement and when the New York Stock Exchange and the Curb Exchange failed to indicate any intention of yielding to union demands.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 18 -- Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts declared today that he had not expected the American demand for a large lendlease cash payment. The Prime Minister's statement was made during discussions in the House of Assembly on the recently concluded settlement of lend-lease transactions between South Africa and the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Air Coordinating Committee, President Truman's top aviation policy board, announced today its opposition to a pending Senate bill calling for a single airline to fly international routes for the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -- Despite its failings, there is every indication that the United Nations will succeed in bringing peace to the whole world. Dr. E.N. Van Kleffens, Netherlands representative on the Security Council, and Sir Alexander Cadogan, permanent United Kingdom representative in the United Nations, said here tonight.

Eugene Cardinal Tisserant, Secretary of the Sacred Oriental Congregation and only non-Italian Cardinal in the Vatican Curia, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday by plane from Rome. He was met by Cardinal Spellman, whose guest he will be for a visit during which he will receive honorary degrees from both Princeton and Fordham Universities.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 17 (Delayed) -- The Czechoslovak Government today introduced a bill in the National Assembly to provide a paid annual holiday for all workers not in the civil service.

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation established a new high sales and earnings record in the fiscal year ended with, last January, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Robert J. McKim, president. Net sales for the year totaled $141,950,574, an increase of 22 per cent over the previous annual volume of $116,353,703.

ALBANY, April 18 -- The Board of Regents authorized today the appointment of a five-member temporary advisory committee to assist the State Education Department in a study of the status of guidance and counseling programs in the public schools.

Guaranteed Loans The executive council of the American Bankers Association has reaffirmed its opposition to "governmental or semi-governmental lending or guarantee of loans," it was announced yesterday. The council, in a resolution just released, states flatly that with the return to more normal conditions, such war-time methods of financing business present "serious dangers"; are in effect "subsidies favoring certain groups of borrowers" and "encourage unsound and inflationary lending."

Representatives of more than 700 apartment houses in the New York City area have rejected in effect the plan submitted recently by the Television Broadcasters Association to obtain at least a temporary settlement of the apartment house video antenna situation, it was learned yesterday.

Though this is the time of peak production, relatively few eggs are being stored now against the period next fall when hens will be laying at a low rate. Heavy Government purchases have something to do with this. Enthusiastic consumer acceptance is another factor, for the public is buying as many eggs as it did when meat was in short supply.

MIAMI BEACH, April 18 -- Twenty-five of Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle's Tokyo raiders had arrived here today for the opening of the three-day reunion of the American fliers who lifted this country's hopes for victory when they roared off the flight deck of the Carrier Hornet five years ago and headed for Japan.

Under a canopy of fleecy white clouds the Giants yesterday opened their 1947 championship season at the Polo Grounds. And they did it with such an extraordinary display of vim, vigor and vitality that they all but blasted their ancient rivals, the Dodgers, clear out of the arena.

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 18 -- The Balkang Investigating Commission of the United Nations held two heated sessions in public today. They were marked by charges that documents had been stolen and efforts made to suppress "the real truth about Greece" and a refusal by the commission secretary to tell the full group the names of his contacts with the Greek guerrilla leader, "General Markos."
MOSCOW, April 18 -- A western European economic union is growing in importance in the minds of United States delegates as the deadlock in the Council of Foreign Ministers grows more pronounced.

Sale of Japanese cotton goods by the United States Commercial Company to twenty-six countries throughout the world has brought marked reduction in demand for American cottons in such markets, it was learned yesterday from exporters. In the Philippines alone, exporters said, sales have dropped more than 75 per cent since the first of the year.

PITTSBURGH, April 18 -- Little Change was reflected in the level of business in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. There was a fairly large gain in freight shipments and a slight increase in industrial production, owing to a sizable rise in bituminous coal output, but these gains were a little more than offset by a substantial drop in trade after allowance for seasonal changes.

Hunter College opened defense of its women's intercollegiate fencing championship by defeating Panzer College of East Orange, N.J., 7 to 2 as first-round matches were completed in New York University's East Building gymnasium last night.

GALVESTON, Tex., April 18 (AP) -- Samuel F. Muecke, Deputy Collector of Customs here, testified today before a Coast Guard board investigating the explosion of the Grandcamp that a manifest revealed the ship carried sixteen cases of ammunition.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- A State Department memorandum to the Senate reported today that the United States sold Russia $233,000,000 worth of supplies -- chiefly machine tools and industrial equipment -- from V-J Day to last Dec. 31.

Even 3,500 tons of British explosives couldn't blow the little island of Helgoland off the map. But as a strategic menace it ceased yesterday to exist. The steel and concrete pens from which German submarines crept out in two wars are gone. Every semblance of the massive Nazi fortress has vanished.
Reflecting the great demand for transatlantic travel accommodations, two European-bound liners sailed from North River piers yesterday with virtually every berth occupied.
PALERMO, Sicily, April 19 -- Leaders of all national parties and 800 candidates for deputy today ended their campaign for the regional parliamentary elections Sunday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 18 -- Two elements long since vanished from the earth are being recreated in relatively large quantities in the giant atomic energy furnaces at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Hanford, Wash., it was reported here today before the clossing sessions of the 111th national meeting of the American Chemical Society.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The newest mechanical hopes for war veterans who have lost arms or legs were demonstrated by amputees here today under the auspices of the National Research Council.

Unwittingly operating an automobile, the controls of which had been re-located for use by a onelegged man, a restaurant doorman last night fatally injured a woman pedestrian and then collided with a moving taxicab and a parked car.

ALBANY, April 18 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., in the keynote speech tonight at the opening session of the organizing conference of the New York State Branch of Americans for Democratic Action, assailed Governor Thomas E. Dewey's record during the recent legislative session.

JERUSALEM, April 18 -- Palestine's most militant underground organization, Irgun Zvai Leumi, declared today its intention to keep on fighting any regime other than "a Hebrew authority" that the United Nations might sanction in Palestine.

The nation-wide telephone strike grew out of union demands for higher wages, the union shop, increased pensions, longer vacations, shortening of the time required to reach top pay levels, and other concessions.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 18 (AP) -- Governors of the Rumanian National Bank were reported reliably today to have approved a loan of $7,000,000 granted by the Chase National Bank of New York.

ATHENS, April 18 (U.P.) -- Diplomatic quarters reported tonight that the Greek Government's nine-day offensive to crush guerrilla resistance had failed of immediate success. Up to 20,000 guerrillas were said to be concentrating in the north to establish a new front along the country's borders.

Private builders started construction of only 2,440 dwelling units in this city during the first three months of 1947, against 5,210 in the corresponding period last year, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.
PARIS, April 18 -- Premier Paul Ramadier presided today at a special meeting of governmental and military experts, at which problems of the French Union and the French colonial policy were examined.

NEW ORLEANS, April 18 (AP) -- Representatives of the Southeastern, Southwest and Missouri Valley Conferences discussed today their openly recognized programs of aid to athletes in the light of the proposed "purity code" of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- Senator Homer Capehart, Republican, of Indiana, proposed today that the United States ask for more newsprint as a condition on any additional loans to European countries.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Office of Price Administration, which currently is in charge of rent control, was reported today to be planning soon to decontrol at least fifty rental areas and drop 750 of its rent personnel.

If the Associated Playwrights in Grand Street never do anything else, they will still deserve a speck of glory for producing "Our Lan'." It is clearly the best of the plays put on during the season at the Henry Street Playhouse, and it is one of the best of the Gotham season in general.

Darkening clouds on the labor wage horizon and the call for a strike on Monday of union employes against the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges and member firms involved in the disputes, invited yesterday a resumption of selling on the stock market.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- -- West Coast ship lines advised the Interstate Commerce Commission today that they believed their rates should, as a general proposition go up 50 per cent from the levels of June, 1946.
JERUSALEM, April 18 -- In broad daylight the Jewish underground opened its counteroffensive against the British forces today in apparent reprisal for Wednesday's hanging of four convicted terrorists.

Laura Sherry of Milwaukee, who founded the Wisconsin Players and was a leader in the experimental theatre, died yesterday in the Beverly Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Fiftieth Street. She was the author of a book of poetry about her native Prairie du Chien, Wis., and edited two volumes of Wisconsin plays.

John L. Strohm, who travelled 4,000 miles through Russia with Stalin's sanction, has finished a book describing his experiences that will be published by Scribner on May 12. "Just Tell The Truth: The Uncensored Story of How The Common People Live Behind the Russian Iron Curtain" contains sixty-four pages of pictures taken by the author.

NANKING, April 18 -- The State Council of the new Government will hold its first meeting and formally take office next Wednesday. The appointment of Ministers to complete the roster of the new regime will await the assumption of office by members of the Council.

DUBLIN, April 18 -- Ten days ago the food position of Ireland looked very serious. Not a third of the wheat crop had been sown and the people were anxiously talking of a prospective famine. Now, after a spell of fine, sunny weather, the situation has materially changed and this country's prospects of getting a fair share of its food next winter from the soil are brighter.

Asserting that prices for the great majority of goods must reflect the cost structure, the Tanners Council of America in a bulletin issued yesterday said that "if profits were entirely eliminated in manufacturing industries it is doubtful whether cost of living indexes would be cut by as much as 5 per cent."

VIENNA, April 18 -- Peter Krauland, chief Austrian expert on German property in Austria, flew back to Moscow today with Austrian Cabinet instructions for Foreign Minister Dr. Karl Gruber and the Austrian delegation there.

Jamaica's final preview of the May classics for 3-year-olds -- the Wood Memorial -- is on the program today. It'll be a double dress rehearsal for the doings at Louisville and elsewhere, for when the names of twenty-two horses went into the entry box it became necessary, for the third time since the initial running of the Wood in 1925, to split the field into two divisions.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The aid of the American Society of Newspaper Editors in helping to get increases in the pay of teachers was sought by Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, today.

On the heels of demonstrations abroad, forty young men and women "occupied" an ante-room of the British Consulate here for about an hour yesterday in a protest against the execution of Dov Gruner and three fellow Irgun terrorists in Palestine. They left only when threatened with arrest by Sir Francis Evans, British Consul General.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 18 -- Educators and business leaders joined today in an indictment of the traditional women's college for their failure to prepare students either for careers or for full development as individuals.

DUBLIN, April 18 -- This country is going to experience great difficulty in financing purchases abroad when the present dollar arrangement with Britain ends in July, James Dillon said today in the Dail Eireann.

DETROIT, April 18 -- Henry Ford left the controlling share of the voting stock of the Ford Motor Company to his four grandchildren and the bulk of his personal fortune to the Ford Foundation, it was revealed today with the filing of the will of the motor pioneer.

TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 18 -- Teams of rescue and salvage workers wearing gas masks and employing bulldozers, cranes and winches pushed into the explosion-shattered plant area of this city's waterfront today for the first time since the disaster struck Wednesday morning.

DALLAS, Tex., April 18 -- The $2,500 Achievement Award of the American Association of University Women was presented tonight to Dr. Barbara McClintock, investigator in the Department of Genetics of the Carnegie Institution, New York, at the final session of the national biennial convention.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 -- Thirty-one Japanese-manned Liberty ships leased to the Japanese Government for returning soldiers and Japanese nationals to their homeland from Pacific island an the Asiatic mainland after Japan's surrender are due here for "repatriation and decommissioning" during the next five months, according to Brig. Gen. N.H. McKay of the San Francisco Port of Embarkation.

TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 18 -- Texas City stirred today out of shock and started to grope for life. With fear of further explosions removed, many of the residents who fled to near-by cities returned to their wrecked and battered homes.

The modern family physician, described as having little in common with the old-time general practitioner, was hailed yesterday as the quarterback of a team of specialists devoted to safeguarding the community's health.

Several dinner parties will be given before the Bal Blanc du Ballet to be held Tuesday evening in the Terrace Room of the Plaza under the auspices of Ballet Associates. Proceeds of the fete will augment a scholarship fund to train needy and talented students of the dance.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Local wage settlements by affiliates of the Bell System may be the formula that will end the countrywide telephone workers' strike, in the view of leaders of the National Federation of Telephone Workers.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Robert Woods Bliss collection of Indigenous American Art, which was opened to the public today at the National Gallery of Art, has the intimate charm of one assembled slowly with personal interest and pleasure by the collector, as indeed it was.

BOSTON, April 18 (AP) -- With both teams scoring most of their runs in a wild inning and a half, the Boston Braves today opened their home season by outscoring the Philadelphia Phillies, 10 -- 7, before 4,552 fans who braved a cool wind and threatening skies.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Grain markets fluctuated erratically today on the Board of Trade with corn developing independent weakness as the result of hedging sales against large purchases of cash corn for shipment from the country and from other markets.

PEORIA, Ill., April 18 -- Paul Robeson, the singer, came to Peoria tonight after the city had indicated he would not be welcomed. At a late hour, however, Mr. Robeson had not emerged from the home of a local CIO leader to make his promised sidewalk speech.

Trade Shows Slight Gain Here Retail trade here made a better comparative showing this week than last. Despite the handicap of rainy weather, several stores showed an increase over last year. Estimates indicated that the average for department stores is tending to show a slight increase over 1946 figures.

THOREAU sits near Walden Pond, watching the trains go by. Emerson's house burns. A man who owns a sporting goods and automobile accessories store is in wide demand at convention picnics because of his hilarious impersonations of Theodore Roosevelt. Farmers chase the British Redcoats down the lane. Franklin Pierce is nominated for President and Hawthorne is asked to write his campaign biography.

NEWARK, N.J., April 18 (AP) -- A Seton Hall prep team toured Newark Schools Stadium's 440yard cinderpath in 44.9 seconds today to add the Eastern States diadem to its growing list in the first-day program of the Seton Hall College relay carnival.

When the House of Representatives adopts a severely restrictive labor bill by the decisive margin of three to one, with even a majority of the Democrats voting for it, it will not do for the leaders of the American trade-union movement to interpret this result merely as a plot of Big Business, a political trick or a sudden case of jitters in Washington.

TRENTON, N.J., April 18 (AP) -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today signed into law the record appropriations bill of $155,723,345, and the administration measure doubling state road aid to municipalities. The two bills were among fifteen receiving the Governor's signature.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 18 -- Capt. Frederick W. Egen of the Police Academy, New York Police Department, said today that police officials and parole authorities in the nation must increase their efforts and mutual assistance because of the increase in crime, particularly among the young, and the greater difficulty of supervising young offenders.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The two much-heralded articles by Winston Churchill in THE NEW YORK TIMES do not, in spite of their elouence, provide for a better understanding of the grave situation in Greece and Turkey. Indeed, there are several misstatements and contradictions that I feel should be made known.
ROME, April 18 -- After yesterday's disorders, in which Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza was attacked and beaten, several minor incidents occurred in various parts of Rome this morning.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is prepared to extend its facilities to those peoples who are willing to aid their own recovery through cooperative effort and thus create an expanding world economy. John Jay McCloy, president of that institution, declared yesterday in his first public statement on its program.
The New York City Housing Authority has a housing problem of its own, it was learned yesterday, and so has the United Nations.

Oil as Stigma Any day, perhaps, some resolute, not to say reckless, individual may yet take his life in his hands on the subject of Oil. He hears the Truman plan for Greece and Turkey airily dismissed in one word, Oil.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Herbert Hoover said today that the Allies were "busy as bees" destroying the capacity of Europe to produce fertilizer while the whole Continent was "gasping for food."

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Dean Acheson, Acting Secretary of State, today reiterated the hope that Congress would authorize the sending of equipment still in the lend-lease pipeline to ten countries, including the Soviet Union. He pointed out that after V-E and V-J Days the United States had contracted to deliver this equipment for purchase either through cash payment or on credit arrangements.

Brand names represent a vital force in the American economy as "the heart of free and active competition," speakers said yesterday at the Brand Names Day meeting of the Brand Names Foundation, Inc., in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The National Coal Association estimated today last week's bituminous production at 7,045,000 tons and commented that "the Lewis safety strike or slowdown was in effect during the entire week."

DETROIT, April 18 -- Following is the text of the will of Henry Ford, filed for probate today: I, Henry Ford, of "Fairlane," Dearborn, Michigan, do hereby revoke all instruments of a testamentary nature heretofore made by me, and do hereby make, publish, and declare this to be my last will and testament, in a manner and form following:

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The goal get by the Allies for a standard of living in Japan is one "substantially" equivalent to that of Japan in 1930 to 1934. A policy decision of the Far Eastern Commission to that effect was communicated to Gen. Douglas MacArthur in a directive on Jan. 23 and was announced here today following study and agreerment by General MacArthur.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 18 -- Henry A. Wallace today appealed to the Scandinavian peoples to take an active part in the work for peace in view of their exposed position as a probable battleground for a third World War.

LONDON, April 18 -- Under the slogan, "We're up, against it ! We work or want -- a challenge to British grit," Britain's Labor Government plans to call upon its citizens for extra effort to help the nation out of the "serious economic crisis."

An agreement averting a threatened strike of 50,000 Western Union employes in all parts of the United States, except New York, was reached at 3 o'clock this morning, whereby the employes will receive a wage increase of 5 cents an hour and other benefits, instead of the 25-cents-an-hour increase originally demanded.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 -- The veto certainly has been "abused," from the standpoint of "many member states" of the United Nations, but not the "morality" but the "judgment" of those who are invoking the veto so frequently is susceptible of criticism.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 18 -- Alberta Latta, president of Textiles, Inc., Gastonia, N.C., predicted today that yarn prices will continue to remain high because of scarcities and elevated costs.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 18 -- Judge August Ziegener in Hudson County Common Pleas Court sentenced today eighteen defendants in the $1,235,000 Western Electric Company conspiracy case to serve a total of thirty-five years in prison and fined each of five companies involved $1,000 and costs.
The thirteen-day-old strike of telephone workers remained deadlocked yesterday but on two different sectors of the metropolitan area conciliators worked to bring about a settlement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 18 -- "Midnight Lace," a new novel by McKinlay Kantor which will be published next fall by Random House, has been acquired for the screen by Universal-International, the studio announced today. The story deals with a traveling milliner of 1900.

The transition of the Netherlands Indies from colonial status to a mutually respected, dominion-like place within a Dutch Union appears to be making orderly and peaceful progress. A plan for Dutch-Indonesian exploitation of the rich islands' economy was announced a few days ago.
ST. LOUIS, April 18 (AP) -- A threerun third inning against Johnny Schmitz carried the Cardinals to a 4-to-1 victory over the Cubs before 11,863 persons in the world champions' home debut today.

MOSCOW, April 18 -- United States Secretary of State Marshall accused Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov today of seeking to impose on Austria treaty conditions making her a puppet state. He warned Mr. Molotov that the United States "could never cooperate" in a treaty of that sort.

BOSTON, April 18 (AP) -- Three months after his disqualification in a similarly dedicated race at Tropical Park, the 6-year-old F.B. Eye, owned by Sam Garfield of Lynn, Mass., breezed to a sixlength triumph in the $5,000 Damon Runyon Memorial Purse before an opening day crowd of 20,375 at Suffolk Downs.

Gains of frozen food products have been at the expense of fresh vegetables rather than canned goods, according to a survey just completed by Dr. F.D. Geise, chief agronomist for the American Can Company. Despite the phenomenal percentage increase in production of frozen vegetables during the ten-year period 1936-1945, the report showed that canners' gains in volume were almost five times that of frozen vegetables.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 18 -- Byron Price, Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations in charge of administrative and financial services, received executive responsibility today for the development of the future world capital.

LONDON, April 18 (AP) -- The House of Commons tonight passed, 179 to 72, the Government-sponsored bill to continue the system of bulk buying of raw cotton by a state commission which replaced the privately operated Liverpool Cotton Exchange during the war.
TOKYO, April 18 (AP) -- One young American soldier was sentenced to be hanged and four others received life terms today for the murder of five Japanese during a wild drinking bout Jan. 31.

With a terse announcement that read "Burton Edwin Shotton has accepted the management of the Brooklyn Dodgers and will take charge of the team today," Branch Rickey yesterday ended speculation as to the immediate successor of Leo Durocher, suspended for a year by edict of Baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler.

Relations between local steamship operators and labor may not always have been smooth in the past, but the labor legislation passed by the House of Representatives on Thursday is not going to do anything to improve them in the maritime industry, a survey of local shipping men showed yesterday.
