Portland, Me., will offer an issue of tax notes totaling $800,000 on Tuesday. Dated April 25, the notes will come due Oct. 7.

Prayers for the Russian people and "Millions living in Sovietdominated lands" will be offered on May 1, by "millions of Catholics throughout the United States, Hawaii and Canada," according to an announcement yesterday.

Kent Cooper, executive director of The Associated Press, said in his annual report yesterday that censorship of foreign news had remained a problem and that new kinds of barriers to the free flow of international information had been raised in the first full postwar year.

The first test case to bar an increase of more than 15 per cent in private passenger car garage rentals was started here yesterday with the backing of the Automobile Club of New York. It was prompted by widespread complaints that some garage operators have been gouging pleasure car owners because of lack of offstreet parking facilities.

CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- Tony Zale, world middleweight champion, will risk his title for the second time against his fiery challenger, Brooklyn's Rocky Graziano, in a return 15-round match in Chicago late in June or early in July.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Senate Republican leaders began drawing together today to stiffen the labor bill, which came only yesterday from committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., April 18 -- The United Nations Security Council rejected today a Soviet proposal that it send a supervisory commission to Greece to insure that the proposed $150,000,000 in economic help from the United States was used "only in the interests of the Greek people."

ALBANY, April 18 -- For vessels with a draft of less than twentyone feet, pilotage rates in New York Harbor will rise very sharply as a result of new rates fixed in the Pilots Bill signed by Governor Dewey. The increase, however, will be smaller, proportionately, for the deeper draft vessels.

Eddie Giosa, Philadelphia lightweight, boxed his way to a cleancut triumph over Julio Jimenez of Mexico City in the main ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Giosa scored steadily with lefts to the head, and consistently avoided Jimenez's returns.

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 18 -- A frustrated little conference is struggling through the agenda on passports and frontier formalities in a smaller salon of the Geneva headquarters of the United Nations.
TOKYO, April 18 -- Attempts to obtain adequate supplies, of Australian wool for Japanese industry have hit a brick wall of Australian anti-Japanese feeling.

DETROIT, April 18 (AP) -- Home runs by Roy Cullenbine and Pat Mullin settled a pitchers' duel in 50-degree temperature today as the Tigers treated 46,111 fans at their home opener to a 2-to-0 shutout of the Indians.

LOS ANGELES, April 18 (AP) -- Andy Varipapa, national match game titlist, and his teammates of the Brunswick Mineralite five of New York held the American Bowling Congress team lead today with a score of 3,023.

Edward E. Rhatigan, Commissioner of Welfare, said yesterday he planned to submit to the State Youth Commission program for the continuance of the present schedule of child day-care centers through the use of state funds to supplement city finances.
If the boys of Otis Junior High School have anything to say about it East Harlem is going to be a community recognized for its merits and not notorious for its defects.

PITTSBURGH, April 18 -- Offthe-record talks were reported to have taken place today between representatives of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, and the United States Steel Corporation. The wage contract between the two expires April 30.

MADRID, April 19 -- The feeling aroused by the recent exchanges of views on the restoration of Spain's monarchy produced some disorder in Madrid this morning. Several hundred pro-Franco students tried to stage a mock funeral of Don Juan, the Pretender.

The United States made millions of tons of high explosive during the war, yet such was the system of control in production and in transportation by land and sea that there was no serious mishap. Now comes the appalling disaster of Texas City to make us wonder whether that system of control was relaxed or whether we were simply lucky during the war.

Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Committee for Economic Development, said yesterday that reports from four regional representatives indicated that no business recession had started in the United States and that if one did occur it need not develop into a serious depression if government, business, labor and agriculture would act sensibly, and if the public did not get panicky.

The New York Central Railroad yesterday mailed to stockholders a proxy statement disclosing the nomination of William H. Vanderbilt, a former Governor of Rhode Island, and Joseph M. O'Mahoney, secretary of the company, for election to the board of directors.

War reporters who have seen Texas City are inevitably reminded of Nagasaki after the atom bomb, or some European town laid waste in one of the climactic air raids that finished the war. The horror and devastation experienced by nearly every other belligerent country in the late conflict came to the United States for the first time in the awful disaster on the Gulf Coast.

A merchant seaman from New York was taken to a hospital with smallpox yesterday when his ship docked at Bremerhaven, Germany. The United States Public Health Service said the patient was a Porto Rican mess steward aboard the Army transport M.B. Stewart.

MADRID, April 19 -- The feeling aroused by the recent exchanges of views on the restoration of Spain's monarchy produced some disorder in Madrid this morning. Several hundred pro-Franco students tried to stage a mock funeral of Don Juan, the Pretender.

The United States made millions of tons of high explosive during the war, yet such was the system of control in production and in transportation by land and sea that there was no serious mishap. Now comes the appalling disaster of Texas City to make us wonder whether that system of control was relaxed or whether we were simply lucky during the war.

Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Committee for Economic Development, said yesterday that reports from four regional representatives indicated that no business recession had started in the United States and that if one did occur it need not develop into a serious depression if government, business, labor and agriculture would act sensibly, and if the public did not get panicky.

CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox scored their second straight shut-out victory today, a 1-0 triumph over the St. Louis Browns, as Johnny Rigney staged a successful pitching comeback and rookie Outfielder Dave Philley belted a triple, double and two singles in four trips.

SEEDING of root crops should be started this month. The list of kinds is long, but perhaps the most frequently grown ones are carrots, beets, radishes, turnips, onions, witloof chicory, salsify and potatoes. They are not as easy to grow as most of the leaf and fruit vegetables.

ART, at last has begun flowing freely from the other side of the Atlantic. This revived influx is indeed a welcome development, and the Brooklyn Museum's first post-war watercolor biennial, fourteenth in the important international series, deserves large attendance.

BUTLER, Md., April 19 (AP) -- The great Winton failed in his usual late drive today and Clifton's Duke won the Grand National Steeplechase. Winton's chances to repeat his grand slam of 1946 thus were spoiled.

MADISON", Conn., April 19 -- Opening day conditions on the Connecticut streams in this area were on a par with those of New fork and New Jersey, although several of the streams were but slightly higher than normal. The success ratio seemed to be about the same as the other two states, which is not an unusual condition when the great number of openingday anglers is considered.

Rare first editions, French illustrated books and other literary material collected by the late H.A. Fortington of Poughquag, N.Y.; Dudley Orcutt, New York, and other owners will be auctioned at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, tomorrow afternoon and evening and Tuesday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Donald R. Richberg assailed today what he called "weak-minded 'liberals'" who would swallow anything that carried a union label.

PARIS, April 19 -- Gen. Jacques Philippe Leclerc, hero of Bir Hacheim and the liberation of Paris and leading French specialist in motorized warfare, was today appointed inspector of land, naval and air forces in North Africa.
PINEHURST, N.C., April 19 -- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias of Denver scored her fifteenth straight tournament triumph today but only after one of the

IN today's Treasure Chest there is a quotation from Andre Gide which seems to me to have a. particular application to our time. Gide's imaginary interviewer has expressed his surprise that Gide, earlier in their conversation, should have drawn an apparent distinction between the "heart" and the "mind."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 19 (U.P.) -- Racked by tuberculosis, Charles H. Treat, 47 years old, onetime All-America football player of Princeton University, plunged to his death from a ninth floor hotel room early today.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was nervous and erratic yesterday, and final prices were 49 points higher to 16 points lower than the day before.

The task of officials of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development -- preparing the market for the bank's debentures and acquainting business and the public generally with its aims, purpose and operation -- is no easy one, it became evident last week.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Senate War Investigating Committee directed former Senator Burton K. Wheeler today to look further into the Navy's purchases of Arabian oil.
MADRID, April 19 -- The Police authorities blocked a pro-Franco demonstration scheduled for today because they feared that street fights between Monarchist and Falangist elements were inevitablp.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 19 -- The recovery of world tin production is going to be slower than has been anticipated, according to a statement issued at the close of the first meeting of the Tin Study Group yesterday.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System has cleared a full hour of "choice" listening time on Tuesday night from 9:30 to 10:30 and plans a new weekly series of dramas adapted from contemporary books and stage plays.
PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- Princeton helped Pennsylvania open the rowing season on the ruffled Schuylkill River today by winning four of the five races before a crowd of 5,000 spectators.

THIS book is a representative selection from Thomas F. Woodlock's daily column which ran in The Wall Street Journal between 1930 and 1945. His "thinking over" was always that of a complete person. Sociologist, philosopher, economist, he was something of all these, yet exclusively none of them.
Management and labor must cooperate to the fullest extent possible to insure full industrial productivity in this country, representatives of both groups declared yesterday.

MOSCOW. AT present I am working on my Sixth Symphony, begun in 1945. The symphony, in E-Flat Minor, has three movements. The first movement, of agitated character, is lyrical at times and austere at others; the second movement, largo, is brighter and full of song; the finale, rapid and major, is in character close to my Fifth Symphony except for the austere reminiscences of the first movement.

WEATHER CHEMISTRY -- Why does New York City feel colder when the temperature is around freezing than does an inland city where the air is dry and the temperature even lower? Dr. J.A. Babor of the College of the City of New York answers the question.

-- GIANTS Talk in the papers about the huge growth of big-business combines since the war sends us to the bookshelf to look up giants. They've never been popular, it seems, and most of them have come to bad ends, from Goliath and the sons of Anak right on down the line.

ALTHOUGH a chronological record, this book of gentle remembrances is not intended as an autobiography. Rather has Dr. Parker jotted down those items which he likes to recall now, in the autumn of his life. Not all were especially significant.

NOTRE DAME -- Criminology A graduate curriculum in correctional administration to prepare college men for the fields of probation, parole and prison administration will be started in September at the University of Notre Dame. The new curriculum, instead of emphasizing social work, will stress criminology, penology, criminal law, psychiatry and character education.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Everybody made up and shook hands today after a pre-game meeting of the Washington Senators called by Manager Ossie Bluege to iron out the affair of a kidding (or was it taunting?) telegram from team-mates to Pitcher Bobo Newsom.

Barring a last-minute reversal, and Irrespective of any partial accomplishments that may be credited to it, the Moscow Peace Conference has failed in the principal task for which it was called. It has not been able to draw up a preliminary text of a German peace treaty, an achievement which appeared to be doubtful from the start.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 19 -- A serious rift in French-Swiss economic relations has been threatened as a result of Swiss anger over the proposed terms of settlement for Swiss holdings in the nationalized French electric power industry.
Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri cut a ribbon shortly after noon yesterday to mark the opening of the metropolitan home show in Grand Central Palace.

A SINCERE attempt to prove that little good painting has been done since 1860, this book would achieve its purpose except for the fact that it is dull, wordy, repetitious and based on false premises and unwarranted conclusions.
The writer of the following letter is president of the Institute of Ethnic Affairs.

Taking steps to meet the crisis in American education, State Legislatures and city officials in various sections of the country have granted salary increases to teachers and have provided more money for the support of the public schools.

DIRECTORS of the Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra have been negotiating for some time to bring the Netherlands' most famous orchestra to this country. Negotiations began last year when Dr. G. De Koos, a representative of the orchestra, came to New York to consult with Arthur Judson, president of Columbia Concerts, Inc.

THE combination, delphinlum and lilies, is classic in the many gardens where both plants are grown. For the gardener soon realizes that they are even more beautiful planted together than where they appear alone.

Death in Texas Texas City, hugging Galveston Bay, was once called an "obscure country cousin" of Galveston, ten miles away. In the Twenties and Thirties the city grew slowly as a Gulf port. By 1940 its population was 5,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., April 19 -- American migrant workers are being denied the right to lead a normal life, Miss Jane Hoey, of the Social Security Administration, said at the National Conference of Social Work here today. They are citizens, she said, and "they should be accorded by public and private agencies, all their rights, even if special legislation is required."

A week from Tuesday morning will see an Influx of more than five hundred women golfers of the metropolitan district teeing up for a aeries of newly formed interclub team matches. These matches, known as a "Cup Series" patterned after the system that has been so successful in the Philadelphia district, have attracted the largest number of women golfers ever to take part in the opening season competition.

"HOW'S that new baby of yours now? Getting cuter every day, I'll bet!" A disarming character, Pierre the Louisiana Pelican, delivers this line in the first of a series of leaflets newly prepared and distributed monthly since January to parents of first-born babies throughout the State of Louisiana.

BOSTON, April 19 (AP) -- Hopping on Charlie (Red) Barrett for five runs in the opening inning, the Phillies today won the second game of a Patriots Day doubleheader, 9-2, after bowing, 9-3, to'Boston's Braves in the opener. Ken Raffensberger checked the Tribe with six singles in the nightcap.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Retail prices of consumers' goods, rents and services rose about 2 per cent between mid-February and mid-March, according to preliminary data issued today by the Department of Labor. The consumers' price index hit a new high above 156.

Bernard M. Baruch put his finger on the crux of the world economic problem in his speech in South Carolina last week when he called on Americans to unite in getting back to work for maximum production as the basis of domestic security and international reconstruction.

THIS extraordinary narrative, written in robust first-person detail by an author who has understandably chosen a pen-name. Harold Maine, could be called the story of an alcoholic's long struggle to salvation. As such, it might be considered of unusual interest even at a time when the life and mores of the compulsive drinker have been so exploited as to leave the general public slightly anesthetized.

IT is impossible to believe for a moment that Horace Walpole would canonize a dull saint, and she was his "Dear Holy Hannah," not at all in satire but only in regret for all "that beadroll of virtues" which kept her, in his shrewd as well as elegantly urbane opinion, from being one of the cleverest of women instead of one of the best.
CHICAGO, April 19 -- Charles W. Bidwill, well-known sports promoter, died today of bronchial pneumonia and a heart ailment in St. George's Hospital. He was 51 years old.

Life begins at 65 years of age and more, as far as hobbies are concerned, according to Mrs. Grace Cohagan of the aged division at the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, 122 East Twenty-second Street.

THE S.S. Alcoa Cavalier, sailing from New York on May 2 on her maiden voyage to the Caribbean, promises to be an important addition to the West Indies cruise trade. The ship was open for inspection by the press at her North River pier last week.

The American Chemical Society, several thousand strong, met at Atlantic City last week to report on their recent activities. Most of the reports dealt with technical procedures, which are of more interest to chemical engineers than to the public. Yet enough was said to make newspaper readers realize that what goes on in the research laboratories has its effect on daily life.

MANAGEMENT and labor drew closer together last week in spite of the legislative effort in Congress to pull them apart. The Wesinghouse settlement following on the General Motors agreement, foreshadowed peace for the electrical equipment industry.
THE travel season is abooming and the plaint of the passport applicant is heard in the land. The plaint, of course, is directed at those peculiarly unflattering likenesses called "passport photos."

A question that bobs up periodically among railroad men -- the effect of subsidies for airlines and other forms of transport on railroad operations -- bounded back into the limelight last week to receive more than its usual measure of attention.

WITH the production of "Virginia Reel," by John and Harriett Weaver, the Experimental Theatre has completed its first season of five new plays. "Virginia Reel" is a routine, untalented drama that contributes nothing to the theatre in general or to the ET in particular.

There is an intense public demand for land and housing in the Western states, particularly California, according to C.T.S. Keep, president of Previews, Inc., who has just returned from a trip to the company's branch offices in Los Angeles, San Francisco and Denver.

NUREMBERG, Germany, April 19 -- The first trial of German industrialists before the United States military tribunal opened today. The prosecution accused Friedrich Flick, German steel manufacturer, and five associates of having committed, in the conduct of their business, crimes involving slave labor, plunder of occupied territory, "Aryanization" and the support of or membership in the Elite Guard.

HAMBURG, Germany, April 19 (AP) -- Germans in the British occupation zone will elect deputies for three provincial parliaments tomorrow. The Communists are expected to run a poor third despite their recent exploitation of a critical food situation.

Climaxing a week in which many records were established, financial markets terminated on a recovery note, but it was the third successive period of declining prices. Concern over labor troubles, with indications that they are swiftly coming to a head, brought the worst break in stock prices this year, the broadest market in the history of the New York Stock Exchange, and the registering of many new low prices before the week closed.

HOLLYWOOD. THE film industry's interest in the academic world as a source of creative talent has frequently been expressed, but never effectively implemented. This spring, however, the Rev. Gilbert V. Hartke, head of the Drama department at the Catholic University of America in Washington, came to the Coast and obtained promises of cooperation which appear likely to bear fruit at the university's playwriting festival next summer.

Paul Kempf, who was widely known as an editor and publisher of musical periodicals, died here yesterday in a hospital. His age was 64. He had served on the newsediting staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES from 1930 to 1940, when illness forced him to retire.

MOSCOW, April 19 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov requested the Council of Foreign Ministers this afternoon to award to Yugoslavia that portion of Austrian Carinthia claimed by Marshal Tito and to study Belgrade's demand for $150,000,000 in reparations from Austria.
Daylight-saving time, which will become effective in New York next Sunday at 2 A.M., will be somewhat less generally observed in other sections of the country than last year.

DURING the years between the Bolshevik Revolution and the outbreak of World War II there was a considerable volume of publication concerning Russia, but most of it was of the catchpenny variety, written by celebrities, near-celebrities and journalists, or by unrepentant emigres, either damning or exalting the "Soviet experiment."

IN "Ladies of Literature" Laura L. Hinkley reviews a century marked by woman's participation in a sphere of endeavor which had largely belonged to man. The dates enclose a perfect round -- from 1778 when "Evelina" burst upon an astonished but soon delighted world, to 1879 when George Henry Lewes sent "Theophrastus Such" to the publisher for the woman who signed herself George Eliot.

GENEVA, April 19 -- If there is any lingering doubt in anyone's mind that President Truman's description of the United States as the giant of the economic world was an apt characterization, the opening moves at the Geneva trade conference should have helped considerably to dispel it.
ATHENS, April 19 (U.P.) -- Communist sources said today disagreement had broken out within their party that imperilled guerrilla operations mpre than did the Greek Army's 60,000-man offensive.
JERUSALEM, April 19 -- Depth charges were set off in Haifa harbor late today to prevent an attack by "frogmen" of the Jewish resistance forces on three vessels of the British deportation fleet.

Those Elusive People A full generation ago the late Alice Duer Miller wrote a militant pro-suffrage book with a clever fighting title which has since been widely imitated. She called it "Are Women People?" Up to the present there have been any number of books, magazine articles and public speeches In behalf of any number of good causes which have asked the same question, and the original challenging effect has by no means worn off.

For years to come New York will suffer from a serious shortage of teachers, Dr. Jacob Greenberg, associate superintendent of schools, declared yesterday. He spoke at the sixth annual conference of the Association of Teachers of the Social Studies in the City of New York.
An ex-convict sought for ten months for the shooting of a police sergeant was captured yesterday after a cordon of policemen had sealed off a five-block area of East Harlem.

FOR almost a year Wenzell Brown wandered among the Caribbean islands, talking to people in all walks of life, but especially to the poor, and tracing information to its sources. In a delightful travel book highlighted by reports of internal politics and attitudes, he has clearly set forth the basic conflicts that make these areas both attractive commercially and a potential source of conflict.

THROUGHOUT the United States today school administrators are bracing themselves, none too happily, for the advent of the "war babies" -- the children whose birth in 1941, 1942 and 1943 nearly overwhelmed hospitals and doctors as the nation experienced a sharp rise in the birth rate.

The second unit of the United Fruit Company's passenger fleet, the Antigua, will re-enter the peacetime cruise service with a departure from New Orleans on Friday, company officials announced yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 19 -- Laying down an eighteen-hit barrage off the servings of two hurlers, the Army baseball team registered its seventh straight triumph of the season today by downing Brooklyn College, 11 to 7. With Glenn Davis, Charlie Mackmull and Larry Ogden setting the' pace with three blows apiece, the cadets clinched the game with a six-run drive in the seventh inning.

PITTSBURGH, April 19 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates racked up their fourth straight victory today to keep their unbeaten pace atop the National League, combining timely hitting with Nick Strincevich's three-hit pitching to brush aside the Cincinnati Reds, 6 -- 1, before a windswept crowd of 21,891.

THIS book is a biography of the Rev. Pierre Bernard Hill, a famous figure in the Southern Presbyterian Church. The story follows a classic pattern, but the details are of considerable interest. Hill was born in Richmond, Va., in 1877; his boyhood was normal, and he was fortunate in being well loved by a sound family.
NEWBURYPORT, Mass., April 19 -- Retailers of this city announced today development of a plan for an immediate 10 per cent reduction in the prices of their services and goods.

MOST gardeners consider that fall is the season for transplanting shrubs. Experience has shown, however, that there are exceptions to this rule as to every other, and better results may be had when certain varieties are moved in early spring.

SPRING is the season for planing chrysanthemums. The new plants available at the time are rooted cuttings about six inches high. These, with proper care, will grow into large are vigorous clumps by fall.

BERLIN, April 19 -- Only official stamps are lacking at the moment to return the renowned conductor Dr. Wilhelm Furtwaengler to the podium after his acquittal as a Nazi collaborator. This formality, it is expected, will not be delayed beyond the beginning of next week.

THERE are going to be lowerpriced tickets on Broadway next season. According to a survey conducted by this department last week, there are producers and managers along the Main Stem who feel that the time has come for the "break."

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- Department store sales last week in Third Federal Reserve District were 7 per cent below a year ago. In the four weeks ended April 12 they were 8 per cent above the like 1946 period. In Central Philadelphia department store sales last week were 8 per cent below last year, but gained 8 per cent above during the 4 weeks period.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 19 (AP) -- The weather man put a damper on the twenty-second running of the Kansas relays today as most of the favorites in a field of 700' athletes failed to pass the test on a sloppy track and in a cold, drizzling rain.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Political pressure on the President has increased in proportion to his gains in public approval, reported in test-polls and other samplings among the people. The additional pressure is almost visible as Mr. Truman awaits the legislation from Capitol Hill designed to restrain union labor's excesses and eliminate its economic monopoly.

THERE have been all sorts of "Salome" performances here since the American premiere of that opera, given by the Metropolitan Opera in 1907, with the scandal which ensued, and such horrendous results in the publicity line that the Metropolitan didn't dare to put the work on its stage again for twentyodd years.

GENEVA -- In 1914, when trains were slow and motor cars were still in their infancy, and there were no airplanes, the European business man could decide to make a journey from, one capital to another and accomplish it in a matter of hours.

The experts are puzzled by the explosion of a cargo of ammonium nitrate at Texas City, with consequences so tragic that they have shocked the world. So insensitive is the compound that it has to be detonated on the battlefield by a special primer when it is mixed With TNT or nitroglycerine.

Retail trade here made a somewhat better comparative showing last week. A number of stores had fair increases over the like week of 1946. The city-wide average for department stores was held likely to show a slight gain, against a 4 per cent decline for the week ended April 12.

Despite the nation's network of newspapers, radio, magazines and other educational media, only a minority of our population can be considered actively conversant with contemporary world problems. This is a conclusion reached in a survey conducted recently by Cornell University under a grant by the Carnegie Corporation and the Rockefeller Foundation.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 -- Fears have arisen once again that racial intolerance and discrimination against minorities are rising on the West Coast. A Federal Circuit Court opinion here this week condemning as unconstitutional the segregation of several thousand Mexican-American pupils in separate schools of southern California highlighted these unwholesome conditions.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- With accumulating evidence that most major wage disputes were being settled peacefully, the leader of the striking telephone workers suggested today that the Government ought to use "pressure" to get a wage offer from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

AN efficient extravaganza, a social comedy in a comicopera setting, this felicitous first novel by Susan Kerby proves that she shares with other English writers the gift of the light touch. She writes a brisk, crisp prose that may be a legacy from her days as an account executive in a London advertising agency; her gaze is cool and unwavering.

A backlog of potential expansion purchasers and an ever-increasing list of new customers for good factory space presage a continuing firm market in industrial properties, according to Frank B. Morrell, vice president in charge of the industrial division of the Charles F. Noyes Company.

OSLO, April 19 (U.P.) -- Henry A. Wallace charged tonight that Winston Churchill, Conservative leader in Britain, "dare not confess publicly the private conviction of his group that war is inevitable."

SOCIAL ADVANCE -- We never expected to note a scientific improvement in the old-fashioned apple pie, but here it is: According to the Department of Agriculture, experimenters have succeeded in "firming" the tastier but softer, more perishable varieties of apple (Mclntosh and Gravenstein) for use in commercial pie-making.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head (estimated). Compared with week ago: Hogs were generally $2 lower, sows and some extremely heavy butchers, $2.50 lower.

WHETHER or not they claim to be gardeners, few homeowners fail to plant roses somewhere. It may be only a Paul's Scarlet climber beside the kitchen door or the favorite dozen offered in a nursery catalogue along a driveway.

IT is gratifying news, indeed, that Charles Weidman has received a Guggenheim Fellowship in the list of awards made last week by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation. In the more than twenty years that the foundation has been functioning Martha Graham is the only other dancer (unless we include the mime-painter-writer, Angna Enters, who touches other fields perhaps more closely than she does the dance) who has been so honored.

Intervention by the City Administration, after other mediation efforts had failed to resolve a labor-management dispute, resulted yesterday in at least temporary postponement of a threatened strike of 1,900 brokerage house employes in the financial district that had been set for 10 A.M. tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- No one likes to lose, least of all Bucky Harris, who has fallen heir to the managerial headaches of the Yankees. However, even in defeat the pilot found something to smile about as the Senators handed the Yankees a 4-2 setback before 15,482 fans at Griffith Stadium today.

SAIGON, Indo-China. SAIGON is a city which once offered travelers and resident whites some of the finest living to be found in the Far East. Its fine cafes, smart French shops and chic women, its airy spaciousness and generally exotic personality won it the appellation "the Paris of the Orient."

The Russell Sage Foundation has spent in the forty years of its existence more than $21,000,000 for improvement of social and living conditions in this country, Shelby M. Harrison, general director of the Foundation, pointed out in a statement released last night.

THE Colony of Georgia was envisioned primarily as a paradise for man, and only secondarily as a commercial venture and a military buffer against the Spanish and French. The Utopia would be lightly governed by a Board of Trustees, which included the best of England's statesmen, philanthropists, country gentlemen, clergy and such, and the imperialism which animated it had ecclesiastical overtones.

MIAMI, April 19 -- Florida's longpending Everglades project, which would convert 1,800,000 acres of subtropical land and water into the third largest national park, may be created within a year. Secretary of the Interior J.A. Krug has accepted a deed to 1,000,000 acres at the southern curve of Florida; and the State Legislature this week passed a bill appropriating $2,000,000 to acquire the remaining privately owned land through condemnation proceedings.

A six-run seventh-inning uprising enabled City College's nine to hand the Manhattan College charges of Kenny Norton a 12-to-7 setback in a Metropolitan Conference clash at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium yesterday.

In addition to the current orders for custom-built homes in the Winston Associates developments at Skyline Lake, in Pompton Lakes, N.J., and Continental Village, in Peekskill, N.Y., Norman K. Winston announced yesterday that the company plans to expand its building operations by erection of several new groups of small homes.

NEWARK, N.J., April 19 -- Manhattan's runners triumphed thrice today to annex the lion's share of the honors in the Seton Hall relays, first major test of the outdoor track season in the East, at the Newark stadium.

Two million dollars for the 1947 fund appeal of Catholic Charities in the Archdiocese of New York will be sought in a drive to be started today in all parishes. The cost of maintaining services and facilities increased in 1946, according to an illustrated booklet covering the work of the Archdiocesan Catholic Charities organization.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Presidential veto of pending tax reduction legislation wag predicted today by Republican National Chairman Carroll Reece in a letter to 10,000 Republican office holders, party officials and leaders.

ROME, April 19 -- An editorial in the Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano expressed regret today that Czechoslovak authorities had missed an opportunity for furthering spiritual union between the Czechs and Slovaks by granting a pardon to Msgr. Josef Tiso, who was executed yesterday morning.

DISTINCTIVE characteristics of each season are revealed in its plant material, and the flower arranger has an opportunity to select containers and accessories which will enhance these different qualities. The sizes, colors, patterns and textures of various blossoms will suggest suitable accessories.

KEYPORT, N.J., Sunday, April 20 (U.P.) -- The nude body of an attractive woman was found last night in a big steamer trunk in the center of a side road near here. State police said she apparently had been strangled to death with a leather dog leash that still was around her neck.

CAIRO in wartime was a rendezvous where all sorts of refugees converged; but Clement Woodlee, Johann Kreutzer and Madame Anastasia Propocoglu had all come to escape something more than physical destruction.

A low edging for the rose bed helps immeasurably to define the straight lines of a formal border or the graceful sweep of a more naturalistic planting. Hemming the bed with a ribbon of dwarf flowers or one of solid green or gray foliage is a decision to be made.

THE State Department having stamped a priority "C" on their visas, two hundred American Youth Hostelers are preparing to work and tour Europe this summer. While applications are pouring in daily to meet the May 1 deadline, AYH has announced that it will be unable to accept more than two hundred because of limited shipping space.
Adolf Dehn, the painter-lithographer who dropped his print-making from 1936 to 1945, is again having an exhibition of his graphic work at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue.

THE impetus given the documentary film by the war has not slackened with peace. And four veteran, topflight fact-film makers -- Willard Van Dyke, Irving Jacoby, John Ferno and Henwar Rodakiewicz, who have been quietly working this last year as Affiliated Film Producers, Inc. -- now are ready to release their first four offerings.

EVER since Capt. William Kidd was hanged at Execution Dock in England in 1701, for acts of piracy and murder, he has been a legend, a symbol and a historical problem. Prof. Willard Hallam Bonner of the English department of the University of Buffalo has gone to a great deal of pains to separate the few undeniable facts from the imaginative fiction.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- If, as appears likely, Congress adopts President Truman's recommendations of last Tuesday to repeal the main section of the Neutrality Act, the United States will have completed a whole cycle in its efforts to keep out of war.

ITHACA. N.Y., April 19. -- With the temperature in the low forties, Princeton defeated Cornell in an Eastern Intercollegiate League double-header today before 1,200 spectators on Hoy Field. The scores were 12-11 and 4-3.

WALLACE STEVENS continues to exhibit the fecundity which has made the last decade more prolific for him than all the rest of his previous career. Until 1936 all his published poems were included in "Harmonium," but since then he has added "Ideas of Order," "The Man with the Blue Guitar."

Quests of Perfection -- THE sifting of human creations! -- nothing less than this is what we ought to mean by the humanities. Essentially this means biography; what our colleges should teach is, therefore, biographical history, that not of politics merely, but of anything and everything so far as human efforts and conquests are factors that have played their parts.

Eddie Arcaro, the master bootin' man, astounded a crowd of 50,840 at Jamaica yesterday, and earned its acclaim, by riding five successive winners -- two of them in the divisions of the $40,000 added Wood Memorial, New York's double-feature dress rehearsal for the Kentucky Derby.

PARIS, April 19 -- Revolt in Madagascar in the wake of the loss of Syria and Lebanon and the prolonged guerrilla war in Indo-China has brought France squarely before the problem of the survival of her former empire.

FEW artists can have had the serene good fortune of Florine Stettheimer. She painted exactly as she pleased. Her carefully wrought but seemingly effortless pictures were assured or a rapturous reception. The close circle of intimates who were permitted to see her work greeted each picture with tender exclamations of delight.
New York University's nine blanked Williams College, 9 to 0, yesterday at Ohio Field in the Bronx.

Marshall Sees Stalin George Catlett Marshall arrived by plane in Moscow six weeks ago today -- just forty-seven days after taking the oath of office as Secretary of State. He came to take part in the Big Four conference of Foreign Ministers on peace treaties for Germany and Austria.

Police precincts and the city's general hospitals will continue vaccinations today as usual from 9 A.M. to 10 P.M., except for the clinic in the Health Department building, 125 Worth Street, which will close at 5 P.M., Dr. Israel Weinstein, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday.

ATHENS (By Wireless). THE twilight of liberalism has come to Greece, ancient birthplace of democracy, just as it has to so many other countries of Europe. It is dusk already but it is not yet night. There is still hope that Greece can be saved or can save herself from dictatorship of the right or left.

To the Music Editor: Since there have been a number of charges and counter-charges in the pages of the Sunday TIMES concerning the Hungarian composer, Erno Dohnanyi, I should like to present the facts of the case, as determined by thorough investigations of the Information Control Division and Information Service Branch, United States Army, European Theatre.

AS a lad in Presbyterian Sunday School listening to an occasional missionary who had returned from some far corner of the earth, the present reviewer used to wonder what kind of time these soul-savers' children had. Did they -- the small boy's eternal question -- have any fun, perhaps go riding on a camel's back or even on an elephant now and then ?

LONDON, April 19 -- Sweden, eager to clear the air on the question of "broken time" so that a decision may be applicable to the Olympics of 1948, has offered a motion to alter amateur status rules at the specially called Congress of the International Amateur Athletic Federation in London on June 9.
OSLO, Norway, April 19 -- In three speeches, one of them broadcast, Henry A. Wallace grave to Norwegian audiences today his version of what was going on in the United States.

Apparently aroused by the news of the disaster in Texas City, New Yorkers have given $356,996 to the Red Cross in the last two days, it was announced yesterday. The contributions brought the local 1947 fund to $5,014,817 or 81.2 per cent of its quota in the national campaign for $6,000,000.
TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 19 -- Facing the setting sun, 1,500 survivors of this city's tragedy stood in the local football field this evening attending a memorial meeting for their dead.
Work has been started on Fifth Avenue's largest multi-family building-a nineteen-story apartment house at the north corner of Sixty-ninth Street.

WHEN a visitor to the Capitol Building of Texas walks Into the rotunda, he sees at its opposite entrance the marble figures of two state heroes, Sam Houston and Stephen F. Austin. When he crosses to look closer, he discovers that the maker was Elisabet Ney.

BOSTON, April 19 -- The small and wiry Yun Bok Su, a 24-yearold student at the University of Korea, out ran a brilliant international field of 156 today to win the Boston A.A. Marathon by twothirds of a mile from Finland's Mikko Hietanen while setting a new course record of 2 hours 25 minutes 39 seconds.

WASHINGTON. WE were standing around in an old corridor at The Pentagon the other day when a mysterious figure wearing a mustache and the uniform of a United States Army officer came up to us and whispered: ...

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 19 -- Coach Bob Giegangack's Yale track forces won their first meet of the outdoor season by dominating the field events at DeWitt Guyler Field today to defeat Columbia, 78 1-5 to 56 4-5.

NANKING, April 19 -- The reaction to the new Chinese Government outside official circles has been cautious. The average Chinese hopes the new Government means a more liberal, efficient administration but is inclined to be skeptical.

SPRINGTIME in radio brings a veritable deluge of prizes. None has achieved the stature of the Pulitzer Prizes or even the "Oscars" of Hollywood, to be sure, but those that there are do perform the useful function of calling attention to the positive accomplishments of the folk engaged in broadcasting.

THE printed matter on the dust cover of "Aurora Dawn" comes right out and says in so many words that Herman Wouk, the author, "has boldly set at defiance the entire modern barebones school of writing derived from the early Hemingway."

The return of the Byrd expedition to the United States last week concludes the most active winter of Arctic, Antarctic and sub-Arctic military operations and experimentation in which this country has engaged in peacetime.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States announced today that it would mark its thirty-fifth annual meeting by starting a program designed to give the public a better understanding of the American economic system.

THIS novel from Brazil is partly the internal melodrama of a man's lifelong flight from a humiliated childhood. It is also a parable of the choice between worldly ease and humanitarian drudgery. And partly it is a slickpaper romance about the choice between a beautiful wife and a beautiful memory.

America's outstanding post-war contribution in world affairs is the charitable spirit in which she has sent aid to desolated Europeans, Cardinal Tisserant, secretary of the Sacred Oriental Congregation, declared here yesterday. He arrived from Rome last Friday.

A COMPREHENSIVE picture of travel conditions in the next few years will be presented May 5-10 by the International Travel Exposition at Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Forty-sixth Street. The show will be the first of its kind to be held in New York since 1933.

A YOUNG writer, grappling with her first published work, Sally Jones has chosen a specialized and adumbrated slice of life. Capably armed with talent and courage, she has attacked the problem of a widowed mother attempting to give her Children a normal upbringing in a bourgeois society in spite of a cloud that hangs over the family.

Reports that a wage agreement had been reached by the United States Steel Corporation and union negotiators charged trading on the New York Stock Exchange with new life yesterday, reversed early weakness there and swelled the turnover for a brief Saturday session to 690,000 shares, largest in six weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (U.P.) -- Secretary of War Robert P. Paterson said tonight the demotion of Col. William L. Lee from brigadier general "has no connection" with the fact that he slapped John Maragon, a personal acquaintance of President Truman, in Rome last year.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The grim facts of what may happen to the United States -- and the world -- as a result of the discovery of the atomic bomb were forcefully presented to the American Society of Newspaper Editors here today by four of the top scientific, military, civilian and political authorities of the country.

BERLIN, April 19 -- The continuing -- and tightening -- deadlock of the Foreign Ministers at Moscow has inevitably set the speculation mills in Berlin working. With the master minds agreed on virtually nothing but the fact of disagreement, the prime question in all minds here is:
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 19 -- The decision of the United Nations General Assembly last fall to establish an International Refugee Organization was hailed as one of its most important achievements.
Equity in real estate is held by the United States Supreme Court not to be "property" either for the purpose of computing depreciation or for determining gain or loss resulting from its sale.

Robert Menga, 12-year-old violinist from Fall River, Mass., gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon. Those interested in his career apparently believed in starting in a big way, for the auditorium was Carnegie Hall and his program included two full concertos.

Aid to Britain should be limited to the economic and financial fields and should not include the military or political, according to pupils who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 19 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen, aspirant for the Republican Presidential nomination who has been making a fact-finding tour of Europe, declared today, "It is not proper to discuss the foreign policy of the United States in a foreign country."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 19 -- An intensely hot fire, fed by a shipment of cork waste, damaged the Maritime Commission freighter Honduras Victory today at an American Export Lines pier just north of the busy Exchange Place ferry terminal opposite Cortlandt Street, New York City.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. ENLIGHTENED democracy is still in search of a form and has no great official building it could honestly call home. Like the cuckoo, it nests in homes devised by its adversaries.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Congress will have the opportunity next week to implement President Truman's plan to discover and fire disloyal Federal employes.

ST. LOUIS, April 19 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs, who had scored but two runs in their first three games of the season, finally found their batting eyes today and pounded out a 7-to-l victory over the Cardinals.

Columbia and Fordham, two oldtime diamond foes, whose rivalry dates back to 1884, yesterday battled eleven innings to a tie in their annual clash at Baker Field, the game being called as darkness impended with the count 2-all.

A nation-wide walkout of 50,000 telegraphers coming on top of the curtent telephone strike would have been a grievous blow to our already crippled communication system. Happily, it now seems to have been averted for at least six months. The most encouraging feature of the tentative agreement announced by both parties to the dispute is that it was reached through the orderly process of collective bargaining stimulated by federal conciliation.

To the Music Editor: IT would be nice, of course, if Milton Shubert decided not to distort or change or adapt any of Puccini's music to the kind of Broadway holiday we have come to expect from Broadway producers, intent on achieving a commercial success with but a passing glance at artistic musical standards.

MOSCOW, April 19 -- The stalemate in the Council of Foreign Ministers on the economic unity of Germany and the allocation of that country's resources has brought about a tri-power agreement on the division of Germany's coal resources.
MEXICO CITY. TEATRO AMERICANO, that brave and unprecedented venture on the part of three young New Yorkers, has come to life again, after the usual transfusion of cash required in such cases.

THIS book -- third of a trilogy by the same author about Russia at war -- is the moat complete and, on the whole, probably the best account yet published in English of the Soviet Union's "black summer" of 1942.

The War Department announced yesterday that its Corps of Engineers had completed designs for a new type of temporary Army housing, readily convertible into permanent structures with few alterations and a minimum additional expenditure.
TORONTO, April 19 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs won the Stanley Cup, emblematic of the world hockey championship, by defeating the defending world champion

PALERMO, April 19 -- All parties plan to bring to the polls the greatest possible number of followers for tomorrow's election of the regional autonomous Parliament. They abstained from public speaking in accordance with the Government ban on political mass meetings on the eve of the elections.
PHILADELPHIA, April 19 (AP) -- Dom DiMaggio's single with two out and the bases loaded in the tenth gave the Boston Red Sox a 4-to-2 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics before 12.718 fans today.

Seventh of a series of reports on a motor tour of Latin America. SAN MARCOS, Guatemala -- World unity takes another beating at the Mexican-Guatemalan frontier. If you reach the Mexican customs point at noon, you wait two hours until officials return from lunch and siesta.

MR. SEWALL was one of those ingratiating personages who had the good fortune to be loved and cherished by many of the great and the near-great. To Dr. Webb and Mr. Powell must go the credit of writing the memoirs of this American physician whose name today is not a household word in spite of his many talents and obvious culture.

ALBANY, April 19 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, in a broadcast report to the people on accomplishments of the recent legislative session, declared tonight that he was willing to risk political reprisals for his sponsorship of the Condon-Wadlin law providing for automatic dismissal of any public employe who goes on strike.

CALLA lilies will grow in damp spots. But these flowers are not often seen growing naturally. We associate them so completely with the florist's single cut stalk, bought by half dozens or dozens, that it is hard to get away from the idea of a stiff, formal blossom, good for a "modern" flower arrangement and not much else.

CONGRESS has been spending much time debating labor issues. In the process, members of both houses are bandying about terms that are not always clear to the public and perhaps not even clear to the Congressmen.

AMERICA was never better served than by the foreignborn, foreign-trained soldiers who fought for the Union during the Civil War -- men like de Trobriand, Duffie, Krzyzanowski, and a host of others exemplified by Jean de Merac, hero of "The Scarlet Patch."

TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 19 -- An official tally made by the State Public Safety Department, which is correlating statistics concerning the explosion disaster in this refinery port city, listed the number of known dead today at 377.

PITTSBURGH, April 19 -- The "shot in the arm" that Pittsburgh has been seeking may be in the offing. The Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company, largest coal firm in the world, plans to switch over a vast, untapped western Pennsylvania soft coal tract to the manufacture of high-octane gasoline, gas, oil and alcohol.

NEW DELHI, India, April 19 -- Discussions between India's new Viceroy and political leaders are still in the consultative stage. It appeared today that down-to-earth negotiations to settle the conflicting views on this country's future as an independent nation would not come for another week or two, if at all.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., April 19 -- The Military Staff Committee of the United Nations Security Council has decided to limit the proposed international police force in size to one that can handle only disputes among small and medium powers, it was learned today.

PARIS, April 19 -- The French Communists charged today that Charles de Gaulle had been inspired by President Truman to reenter French politics and that his bid for power enjoyed the support of the White House.

IT'S all pretty trite. Neil Campbell is a young Scot seeking his fortune with the Northwest Fur Company. He also seeks his father, whom he has not seen Since childhood. Then there is Julie, a half-breed girl, sought by both Neil and the evil factor at Buffalo Lake.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 19 -- For the first time the United Nations will hear petitions from private citizens this week.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 19 -- Rutgers swept the four weight events today to overcome Fordham in a dual track meet, 72 1/4 to 62 3/4.

THE Elizabethan Age was golden by any sensible man's touchstone, and its writings are so various that even their customed reader is always finding something new there. It is the ideal period to browse in, and this makes it bonanza for the anthologist.

Following is the complete text of Governor Dewey's broadcast last night completing his report to the people, begun in a broadcast Wednesday, on the legislative session, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Wednesday night I reported to you on the great steps we had taken at this session of the Legislature to insure better education and opportunity to the children of our state.

DEATH is no respecter of persons and strikes everywhere, at any time. Yet it still comes as a tremnendous shock to hear that Benny Leonard is dead. He went out the way he'd have preferred to go out, in a boxing ring and active in the sport he loved until the very moment he died. But the "final knockout came much too soon for him. The age of 51 seems too young to die.

WHEN the British Government bought the copyright to Basic English for use as an administrative language, its inventor, C.K. Ogden, received u23.000 ($93,000) for 600 nouns, 150 adjectives and 100 "operators," or verbs, prepositions and the like-all indispensable in everyday human relations.

TO THE EDITOR: Some time ago THE TIMES carried an article on domestic service by Frieda Miller of the Women's Bureau of the U.S. Department of Labor in which there was a bad mistake. Since the article evidently started repercussions in various parts of the country -- I cite at this time only those in the Vassar Alumnae Magazine -- I hope that you will allow me to make the correction.

More than a score of scientists, headed by Hugh W. Terhune, war time Coordinator of Fisheries at Seattle, will leave San Francisco in May for the Philippine Islands where they will undertake the job of reviving and modernizing the islands' fisheries industry, it was announced yesterday.

Suppliers of materials to foundries will be asked to deliver better and more useful qualities of coke, pig iron, sand and other basic raw materials, L.E. Roark, executive vice president, the National Founders Association, disclosed in an interview.

Ten vacant building sites in Bellerose, Queens, are among fourteen parcels of Manhattan, Bronx, Brooklyn and Jersey City real estate which will be offered at auction on April 29 by Joseph P. Day, Inc., in the Vesey Street salesrooms.
LONDON, April 19 (Reuters) -- Football results throughout the United Kingdom today: ENGLISH LEAGUE first Division Bolton o. Wolverhampton 3. Charlton 2. Arsenal 2. Chelsea 1, Huddersfleld 0.

Barnard College's forty-fifth annual Greek Games, a contest between freshmen and sophomores in the form of an ancient Greek festival, were dedicated yesterday afternoon in the Barnard gymnasium to the honor of Dionysius, Greek god of wine, before an audience of 500 spectators.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 -- William A. Ross, who entered the steel industry as an office boy and rose to the presidency of the United States Steel Corporation's western subsidiary, died of a heart attack today in St. Luke's Hospital. His age was 68.

MECHANICAL features of passenger cars being under constant scrutiny with a view to improvement, particular attention is now being given to bumpers and headlights. The Automobile Manufacturers Association, mindful of the annoyance of interlocking bumpers, has outlined a standard height for these appliances.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Organized labor has few listeners on Capitol Hill these days. Those who are willing to listen have scarcely any influence.

LONDON, April 19 -- The puzzle Of Palestine becomes the United Nations' problem a week from Monday when the General Assembly, at the behest of Britain, convenes at Lake Success to discuss that troubled area. What solution the world organization may achieve, if any, and whether Britain will abide by the ultimate proposals are questions which time alone will answer.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., April 19 -- Two members of the train crew were killed and eighty-seven persons, many of them from Chicago, were injured day when the Illinois Central Railroad's Chicago-toMiami streamliner, the City of Miami, was de four miles north of this city.

Stout-hearted friends of air transportation were apparently right when they declared that the recent slump in plane occupancy was a passing phase. Planes are now operating at high-load factors on most airlines, and the curtain has been lifted on many new comforts to be provided for post-war long-distance travel.
DETROIT, April 19 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, issued a "wages-prices-profits" brief today supporting its demand for industry-wide wage increases aggregating more than 30 cents an hour.
TO THE EDITOR: Re A.H. Raskin's "Report on the Communist Party (U.S.A.)": We have nothing to fear from communism provided our democratic objective is human justice.

ON the twenty-seventh floor of the RKO building of Rockefeller Center is the workroom of a group of men of many nationalities. Their surroundings are commonplace and incomplete, but the men are oblivious of them. They are working hard -- and in haste.

CARLO LEVI, an Italian in his middle forties, is a doctor by training -- an unusual doctor, I happen to know, and one who, like Chekov, practices only "when he is really needed." By profession he is a painter, ranking with the very best ot his generation. He is a political leader who fought fascism under and above ground for' twenty years, paying more than his toll of prison and "internal exile."

A STRAW, rather heavy, in the querulous wind: With excitement still in the atmosphere over the $3.50 price one publisher has put on novels, another firm -- Houghton, Mifflin -- will raise the ceiling still higher in the late summer when it brings out Ben Ames Williams' "House Divided."

BERLE BUCKLEY, head of the Studio School of Photography, will conduct a seven-day photographic tour to Williamsburg, Va., and "the Old South" starting from New York on June 9. The tour will be under the auspices of Camera Journeys, Ltd., 51 East Tenth Street, and will be made by train, ship and motor coach.

MOSCOW, April 19 -- The definition of American foreign policy as it is applied in relation to Germany, Europe's primary problem, is at this juncture and from the standpoint of the United States, the most satisfactory result of the Council of Foreign Ministers meeting here.
TRUDI SCHOOP makes two appearances at the Ziegfeld Theatre today, her first to what is known as the Broadway district (though this happens to be up on the Avenue of the Americas) in eight years.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 10 -- The Soviet Union, in effect, is waging a war of attrition against the present Turkish regime.

AN American visitor to India these days is likely to go through three stages. The first is surprise -- at India's resemblance to a Hollywood version of the Orient. There are the veiled women in long, clinging saris, the halfnaked beggars covered with sores, the perspiring pukka sahibs in sun helmets, the weird Oriental music, the monsoon.

The new industry-engineered housing developed by building material producers and retail material dealers to aid in the reduction of housing costs will fit in with any type of masonry construction, Roy A. Shipley, president of the Structural Clay Products Institute, reported yesterday.

TWO Canadians, Ray Darby, author, and Morris Surdin, composer, are the authors of the program titled, in fairy-tale fashion, "Once Upon a Tune." Now heard at 8 o'clock Saturday evenings over the Columbia Broadcasting System, it is one of radio's rare ventures into the realm of fantasy and, as such, probably one of the unique ethereal successes of the season.

Washington, D.C. Paintings and etchings of old and new transportation subjects, by Peter Helck, make up the special exhibition which has opened at the Smithsonian Institution. It is being held in the Arts and Industries Building and may be seen Sundays and weekdays from 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. through April 27.

FEW books on journalism have more explicit application to the technique of the reporter than this work by the assistant managing editor of The St. Louis Globe-Democrat. It has the authority and detail of a textbook and should not be overlooked by any aspirant to the city room.

FOR the first time in railroad history, "dawn-to-dusk" service between the Great Lakes and the Gulf of Mexico will be established when Illinois Central's new all-coach speedliner, City of New Orleans, begins daily operation next Sunday.

The upward trend of prices is now being widely debated. Here is one view of the significance and causes of that trend. The author was head of the Office of Price Administration from July, 1943, to February, 1946, and Director of Economic Stabilization from then until his resignation last June.

The great motor company that bears his name, and which was founded in 1903 with only $28,000 in cash, remains in the family under the will of Henry Ford. This is in keeping with the character of its founder, who prized independence from the influence of "outsiders" and who, as long ago as 1919, bought up all stock not owned by his family and made it an exclusively Ford property.
LONDON, April 19 -- Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Hugh Dalton, presented his people with a budget in surplus this week. As a sign of health and vigor it was applauded.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Louis Rodolph de Steiguer died today in Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 79.

IMMIGRATION during the bubbling days of the American melting pot was a regular enough subject for novelists. Now (by virtue of decreased immigration and a shift of contemporary historic accent in fiction) the problem of first-generation aliens about to become first-generation Americans has been neglected, if not completely ignored.

DETROIT. IN many of the nation's big cities the task of absorbing whole new populations -- especially the volatile and ebullient Negro masses from the rural South -- is an urgent social problem. During the war urban Negro communities doubled and tripled in size as the tide of emigres flowed northward to fill industrial war jobs.

Letters in this space on two recent Sundays have supported the President's program of aid to Greece and Turkey. The writer of this letter in opposition to that program is Associate Professor of English at Villanova College.

ATLANTA, April 19 (AP) -- Georgia's "solid" Democratic Party was split in rival factions tonight as Gov. M.E. Thompson summoned a State convention to wrest party leadership from the forces of the late Eugene Talmadge.

ALBANY, April 19 -- The New York State organizing conference of Americans for Democratic Action went on record today in opposition to the proposed $400,000,000 state soldiers' bonus, which will be voted upon by the people in November.

Conditions for the ocean race from Newport to Annapolis in June were announced yesterday at the New York Yacht Club, along with an advance batch of entries' of craft of various types that made practically certain the contest will be the largest deep-sea one in number of contestants ever held. A tentative list" of prospects covers more than sixty yachts.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 19 -- Restrictive and narrow college entrance requirements have seriously hampered the development of broad and adequate secondary school curricula, Mrs. Millicent Carey McIntosh, headmistress of the Brearley School and dean-elect of Barnard College, charged here today.

IN 1718, as today, women were forbidden upon any craft of the Royal Navy -- as Lieutenant Robert Maynard knew when he took pretty Molly Molloy aboard the cutter when he was ordered to deliver important dispatches to Captain Woodes Rogers, anchored off Spithead.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- President Truman predicted today that the Federal Government would end the current fiscal year June 30 with a surplus of $1,250,000,000.

The elimination of the market for industrial construction will result from any substantial increase in current building costs, according to A. Kingsley Ferguson, president of the H.K. Ferguson Company, industrial engineers and builders.
The signers of the following letter are distinguished members of the Harvard University faculty in the fields of the natural sciences, the humanities and the social sciences.

A complete revision of the rules and standards for obedience and trucking competition has been finished and will be included in the May issue of The American Kennel Gazette. In sending out advance proofs, John C. Neff, new executive secretary of the American Kennel Club, pointed out that the rules would become effective on Oct. 8 and until then all obedience activity would proceed under the old rules.

ON the night of Aug. 18, 1908 -- it is reasonable to believe that it was pretty warm since air conditioning was then but a glint in an engineer's eye -- there occurred a theatrical phenomenon that has no parallel in our stage annals though we backtrack to the days when the Hallams were jousting on John Street.

THE annual exhibition by members of the Society of Illustrators at the organization's clubhouse is always a colorful event. I wish it were more animated. Technically proficient most of the work certainly is. But as one walks about there grows on him a sense of disappointment because so much of the work seems tableau -- movie suddenly stopped.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan declared today that remaining lend-lease shipments to Russia should be held up until she settled her $11,000,000,000 account with this country.

By way of demonstrating that their sudden flair for belting home runs was something more than an opening-day flash in the pan, the Giants touched off two more gaudy shots at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The Hunter College fencing team, consisting' of the Misses Estelle Osher, captain; Margo Wolf, Mary Beausoleil and Alice Levitt," retained the women's intercollegiate fencing championship without the loss of a match on the strips of the East Building gymnasium of N.Y.U. yesterday.

SURELY you remember Kit Storm, the artist who doubles as detective, and his wife, Sherry, who tells how he does it. Kit's method is to make sketches at the scene of the crime, thus preserving his first impressions of what he sees.

SCAKSDALE, N. Y., April 19 -- Peg's Pride, winner of the American Horse Shows Association totalpoint ' jumper championship last year, gained honors during the first two sessions as the Boulder Brook annual spring fixture opened in the club's indoor arena today.

The city-backed measure to curb abuses in the operation of garages and parking lots provides for a maximum fine of $500 and sixty days in jail with revocation of license for flagrant offenders, it was learned yesterday.

NANCY KENDALL'S novel is a story about Mamma Dean. It is distinctly not another Mamma story, following the popular mold of those recalled through nostalgic mists and warm tenderness. Mamma Dean is a menace, a "good" woman who looks for evil in all things and is pleasurably excited when she finds it.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 19 (AP) -- Lefty Max Lanier, whose sudden jump to the Mexican League early last season had a direct effect on the much-soughtafter improvement of player conditions in the major leagues, said tonight that he was through dickering with the powers-that-be in Mexico.
The improved position of Manhattan real estate is emphasized in the latest figures on distress coneyances of property.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 19 -- Scarlet-tipped oars swept the Raritan today as Rutgers led Columbia home in varsity, junior varsity and freshman races that opened the rowing season for both universities.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 19 -- Ronald Burton, backed by effective fielding, fashioned a brilliant three-hit pitching performance as the Navy nine defeated Yale, 2 -- 1, before a crowd of 3,500 today.

LOS ANGELES, April 19 (AP) -- A. Los Angeles bowler, Joy Stras, toppled the pins for a 699 series to take fifth place in the individual standing's for the only change today among the leaders in the American Bowling Congress tournament.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 19 (AP) -- Although riderless Alexis led the way under the wire, Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' Natchez sped to a new track record today in capturing the first running of the $20,000-added Edward Burke Handicap before a record-breaking crowd of 23,500.

AS everyone in Scotland knows, the pen name of "Hugh MacDiarmid" lightly disguises Christopher Murray" Grieve, a Border-Scotch poet whose books of prose and verse since 1925 have alternately delighted and distressed both his fellow-countrymen and his British critics.

Loans made in 1946 by New York State savings and loan associations to finance homes totaled $258,200,000, which was an increase of 116 per cent over the amount advanced in 1945, according to Harold Lee, governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System.

A significant chapter in the chronicle of postwar international finance is likely to unfold on Thursday with the offering to investors of privately underwritten bonds of a European nation for the first time in a decade. The offering consists of a small issue of obligations of the Kingdom of Norway, which has not borrowed in the private capital market here since before the war.
The fifth International Congress of Pediatrics will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel July 14 to 17, it was announced yesterday.

THE water gypsy who is lucky enough to have a canoe, a hatchet and a set of aluminum camping dishes is holding on to them for dear life this year. Camping equipment is in such short supply, and prices so high for most of the available items, that the expected post-war rush to the pseudo-primitive but comfortable life besides river and lake seems to be off until 1948.

Wages and Legislation The problem of labor relations dominated the nation's domestic affairs last week. There were important developments on two fronts: first in labormanagement relations, and second in legislation.

Corporate profits in 1946 and early in 1947 were at record high levels. On several occasions labor spokesmen have attributed this rise in profits to increases in prices. The Legislative Reference Service of the Library of Congress has recently completed an analysis which shows that price increases were only a minor factor in the attainment of these profits.

MOSCOW, April 19 -- The Soviet Union considers that its treaties with other powers, such as the Anglo-Russian treaty now under revision here, must exclude participation "in all blocs or actions" against one of the parties concerned.

The nation-wide telephone strike grew out of union demands for higher wages, the union shop, increased pensions, longer vacations, shortening of the time required to reach top pay levels, and other concessions.

DR. ODUM has devoted his life to the study of Southern resources (both human and physical) and the most productive means of employing them. In an unused sense of the term, therefore, he is a professional Southerner. His investigations, conducted from that stronghold of the Southern academic conscience, the University of North Carolina, have made him one of the great men of American sociology.

A considerable number of buyers were in the New York wholesale market last week to pick up additional summer merchandise, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for the NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 19 -- The $150,000,000 annual Alaskan trade, a Seattle monopoly almost since the first prospector trudged across Chilkoot Pass half a century ago, was sought this week by two other communities. Portland promised a shipping service to the Far North, and the British Columbia seaport of Prince Rupert began active participation in the bustling commerce with such Alaskan points as Juneau and Skagway.

THE question of the rights and privileges of the amateur photographer was raised recently when a woman phographer standing on the sidelk of a midtown street tried to take a picture of a saleswoman playing jewelry in a glassless op window.

Missing from Boston since Friday afternoon, 3-year-old Nancy Ryan, was found asleep beside Caroline Howard, 19, a friend of the child's family, in the waiting room of the Grand Central Terminal at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

HERBS are so easy to grow -- they lend themselves so readily to diverse tastes -- that it is small wonder to see their cult increasing. Anybody can raise herbs if the soil is only moderately good. Some plants, like rue, even prefer poor earth.

Smallpox In mid-February, Eugene La Bar, 50, an American silver and leather importer, left Mexico City by bus for Laredo, Tex. On Feb. 25 he left Laredo by American bus for New York. The bus stopped at Dallas, Tex., St. Louis, Mo., Pittsburgh, Pa., and arrived in New York City on March 1.
CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- A late rally developed today in grains on the Board of Trade with deferred deliveries of corn and oats pushing above the preceding close.

BY way of celebrating: its fiftyfifth anniversary, the Macbeth Gallery has arranged a Whistler loan exhibition. Nearly fifty oils, water-colors and pastels have been secured, lent by American museums and from private collections.

A NEW speed record for roundthe-world flight was set last week when a stripped down version of a standard Army Air Forces twin-engine attack bomber circled the globe in 78 hours 55 minutes and 12 seconds.

CUXHAVEN, April 19 (U.P.) -- The four basically military objectives of the Helgoland demolitions have been attained. The "targets" effectively demolished were: The German submarine shelters at the southern end of the island; the two main coastal batteries, protection, and a number of smaller batteries; eight miles of underground fortifications lined with concrete, and the upper galleries of these fortifications on the western side of the island.

LONDON, -- It looks as if the last word in the wild controversy as to whether tourists ought to be encouraged to come to England this year has been spoken by a Scot. "No American whose presence is worth attracting here is likely to come looking for caviar or hot dogs," was the way Thomas Johnston, chairman of the Scottish Tourist Board, summed up the situation.

Dutchman's-breeches are in bloom on stony hillsides where the sun has begun to warm the soil beneath the leafless trees. The little white breeks tipped with gold sway on their slender stems, and the gray-green foliage feathers out around them as graceful as fresh fern fronds.

THE flute of the title represents the note of hope that wavers through this somber story of tenement life in Montreal. To Florentine Lacasse, a waitress in the five-and-ten, it means romance; to her mother, the welfare of her large brood; to the men of Saint-Henri, embittered and demoralized after almost ten years of depression, it means steady work.

LONDON. THE best news about the London theatre is that if has recovered from its acute attack of frostbite. Once more it is possible to sit comfortably in a playhouse without overcoat and gloves and again in consequence plays are beginning to run healthily.
OMAHA, April 19 -- State Governments involved in present labor litigation are likely to present a unified legal front as the result of a meeting held here this week.

HERE is another semi-clinical romance for the psychiatric set. It avoids the usual Freudian jargon, leaving label-minded laymen to supply their own assortments of ids and psychoses. Movie-going analysts, it is clear, particularly of the feminine gender, will delight in it.
