Marshal Stalin told Mr. Stassen that the reason Russia maintained censorship was that some foreign correspondents sent erroneous reports which were regarded as unfriendly to the Soviet Union and its Government. This had happened, the Marshal said, when Moscow had lifted censorship and as a result of the inaccurate reports the censorship had to be restored.

BALTIMORE, April 19 -- Gerald Webb Jr., of Middleburg, Va., noted hunt rider, was fatally injured in an accident at the running of the Worthington Valley Steeplechase races today at Butler. He died at Union Memorial Hospital soon after 8 P.M.

Nearly eighty years ago a fortuitous coincidence, which some might term fate, laid the basis for what is known today about multiple sclerosis, a common disease though one of the most baffling and devastating in existence. At that time a servant girl in the home of the great French neurologist, Jean Marie Charcot, developed symptoms of involuntary movement of the eyeballs, tremors in parts of the body, and scanning speech.

OF one thing there seems little doubt. The musical theatre in America is becoming a vital medium of dramatic expression. This doesn't necessarily imply that operetta and musical comedy are through. It just means that a form called the "musical play" can be added to the list.

EVERYONE loves Charles Chaplin -- or rather, everyone loved him once, when he still answered to the name of Charlie and stuck faithfully to his little Tramp. But now, with his latter-day endeavors to move on from that quaint, submissive role and to use his great talent for expressing something more than the pathos of life, a great many former admirers are cooling conspicuously toward him.

ALL Gaul is divided into three parts on any subject other than Jean-Louis Barrault. While hero-worshiping of movie stars is considerably less of a national pastime in France than in this country, the star of "Les Enfants du Paradis" is being unanimously proclaimed as the outstanding dramatic personality this year.

PITTSBURGH, April 19 -- An executive board meeting of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, was postponed today in favor of further negotiations between the union and the United States Steel Corporation. This move gave strength to reports that the union would have a contract by Monday.

Inventory reserves set up by a number of retailers will assist greatly in cushioning any price decline which develops in the months ahead. Whether they will prove adequate depends on the rate of merchandise turnover and the speed and depth of the recession in the price level, it was pointed out last week.
Federal efforts at conciliation to break the deadlock in the telephone strike continued yesterday as the New York Telephone Company considered several suggestions for a solution.

To the Drama Editor: THE controversy as to racial discrimination in the National Theatre in Washington has been participated in by Actors' Equity, the Dramatists' Guild, a number of playwrights and actors personally, and on the other side by the theatre owner.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Henry Agard Wallace, some of his closest friends in the capital opined this week, should take to heart a brand new maxim which they have coined for his especial benefit. It is, "He who throws boomerangs should learn to duck."

Bonds to be issued by the Port of New York Authority in developing the city's airports will be secured for perhaps ten years or longer only by revenues from operation of the airports and by the project's rated share of the Authority's general reserve fund.

THE death of George II, King of the Hellenes, has been commemorated in stamps. On April 6, the date of his funeral, a mourning series was released. These comprise stamps bearing his portrait, 1-drachma green, 3d red-brown and 8d deep blue, released originally in 1937, now reissued with a black border surrounding each, and with new values surcharged; respectively 50d, 250d and 600d.

FOURTEEN years ago this week in this Review: a couple of months after Hitler took power in Germany, and you wouldn't guess it from the books under investigation. "A Memoir of Un-Common Charm" is the Page 1 heading for Nora Waln's "The House of Exile," the record of a Quaker girl's years in China.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Soft coal operators of the country are deeply conscious of the importance of a decent physical environment for miners' families, said John D. Battle, executive secretary of the National Coal Association, in a statement today, and he added:

By the end of last week over 2,000,000 New Yorkers had heeded their Health Commissioner's advice and had presented themselves for vaccination against smallpox. Not for years had the metropolis been so stirred by an issue of public health.

How many motored pleasure boats in the country? Goodness knows.' In pre-war days Ira Hand and other expert guessers were wont to get up Into the realm of, maybe, 1,500,000, counting the inland lakes, rivers and creeks where no Federal supervision is maintained and where boats are not required to carry Federal registration numbers.

Demands for lower prices from large wholesalers have created cutbacks in production among small plants producing metal products in the New York industrial area, factory executives disclosed here yesterday. This is only one of six new trade conditions which, combined, have started a serious recession in output, they revealed.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 19 (AP) -- A summons and complaint have been served on Father Divine in a legal action seeking about $350,000 damages and to prevent the Negro cult leader and several co-defendants from disposing of nearly $600,000 left to them under the terms of a will, Philip L. Zenner, lawyer, for plaintiffs in the case, said today.
President Truman will address the annual luncheon of The Associated Press in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at 2 o'clock tomorrow afternoon. This will be the chief event of a busy Newspaper Week program.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., April 19 -- The Arab League has decided to isk the United Nations for an immediate decision on Palestine and will move to throw open the whole controversy at the extraordinary session of the General Assembly, it was disclosed officially today.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Washington society and politicians jumped through "the hoops" tonight for President Truman, Mrs. Truman, Miss Margaret Truman, and about 500 other guests as the Women's National Press Club staged its "National Circus."

IN 1838 Emerson made an entry in his journal concerning the Rev. Ezra Ripley, his step-grandfather and Concord's massive patriarch: "Dr. Ripley prayed for rain with great explicitness on Sunday, and on Monday the showers fell.

Newspaperman Stalin The Russian view of the rights of the press was expressed by Nicolai Lenin in these words: "Why should freedom of * * * the press be allowed? Why should a Government which is doing what it believes to be right allow itself to be criticized?

THE Fourteenth International Salon of Photography, sponsored by the Pictorial Photographers of America, opened last week in Education Hall of the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street.

DETROIT, April 19 (AP) -- Breaking out with a flurry of extra-base hits, including four doubles and Pat Seerey's home run, the Cleveland Indians whipped the Detroit Tigers, 5 to 3, here today for their first victory of the American League season.

Public Health Nursing Week, which begins today, marks the seventieth anniversary of this vital service in America and gives a grateful people the opportunity for tribute to the work of the nation's 20,672 public health nurses. From a mere handful of pioneer women who began visiting the sick in their homes in this city in 1877, the movement has grown to become the hub around which much of a community's well-being revolves.

After weeks of painstaking investigation the police yesterday smashed an Italian lottery combine with a weekly "take" estimated at $5,000,000. In a series of raids on homes and printing establishments in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, seventeen men were arrested, including three "bankers," and plates, lottery books and thousands of printed results were seized.

Week Ended April 18, 1947 The Canadian free dollar, after a show of fair strength in the preceding week, slumped off sharply last week in a dive to 91.12 cents, a new low since it was adjusted to parity with the American dollar last July. Foreweek trades were reported at 93.75 cents, but Friday's final of 91.50 cents revealed a loss of 1 5/8 cents from the preceding week.

KEYPORT, N.J., April 20 -- An autopsy performed today on the body of a nude woman found in a trunk on Bethemy Road last night confirmed the fact that death was due to strangulation. It was a virtual certainty, officials said, that the murder weapon was the brown leather dog leash still wound tightly around her throat when she was found.

A BASEBALL fan is the most insatiable of all sports followers. He'll watch game after game, talk endlessly about his favorite pastime and read avariciously every scrap of information he can get. The real figure filberts will find the new Official Baseball Guide, which is published by The Sporting News, as satisfying a morsel as deep-dish apple pie.

TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 20 -- Plans to rebuild the multi-milliondollar industrial waterfront which was devastated in Wednesday's explosion disaster have been discussed informally between city officials and representatives of the companies which suffered the principal damage.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (U.P.) -- The War Department said tonight that the Japanese people were showing "unfailing trust" in the leadership of Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, April 20 -- RKO has announced cancellation of plans for producing the screen adaptation of "The White Tower," James Ramsay Ullman's novel about Swiss mountain climbing, because of failure to fill the six major roles in the film with players of adequate virtuosity.

U. S. NAVAL AIR MISSILE TEST STATION, POINT MUGU, Calif., April 20 -- This 5,000-acre promontory recently frequented by artists sketching the quaint ways of fisher folk is now a center for some of the country's most advanced experimentation in weapons of the future.

BOSTON, April 20 -- The adage that "it never rains but it pours" had to be revised today in the land of the bean and the cod. Up here it never rains but it snows -- and that's why at least 35,000 fans were keenly disappointed.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 20 -- District Attorney James N. Gehrig announced today that Anthony Papa, 27-year-old war veteran, had confessed slaying Rose Marie Fusco, 6, who was found in her home with her throat slashed late last night.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 20 -- Smiley Quick of Los Angeles was the star in an exhibition match for the benefit of the near-by House of St. Giles the Cripple at the Garden City Country Club today.
SALONIKA, Greece, April 20 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris said today that American assistance would assure a victory over communism in Greece.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 20 -- Tempers are flaring, doorbells are ringing and forums are convening in a sequence of wrangles that threatened White Plains and New Rochelle today with the loss of $8,500,000 in state housing funds and the disintegration of municipal undertakings to decrease slums and increase housing.

Leader of a betrayed, enslaved and afflicted people under German occupation, Christian X of Denmark kept the spirit of freedom alive. He would have been a popular monarch in any country. He was a good soldier in a peaceful land, an ardent sportsman, a happy husband and father.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Announcement of the 15-cent wage increase agreement in the steel industry failed to raise any hopes today of an early settlement of the nation-wide telephone strike, which goes into its third week tomorrow.

The unprecedented demand for gas and electricity experienced last year by the Long Island Lighting Company would have been offset by higher operating costs, but the elimination of excess-profits taxes permitted the company to achieve a satisfactory earnings record in 1946, Edward F. Barrett, president, notes in the annual report being sent to stockholders today.

Functional construction and natural colorings of wood are stressed in furniture made by the Kagan Woodcraft Corporation, 340 East Forty-fourth Street. Since Yllya Kagan, head of the company, has been working with woods all his life, and his son Vladimir is studying architecture, their designs combine craftsmanship with contemporary designs.

A 15-year-old girl was fatallY beaten with a crowbar early yesterday morning by a burglar with whom she struggled in her Brooklyn home. Her brother, 9, who came to her aid, was knocked unconscious with the same weapon.
PARIS, April 20 -- Maurice Thorez, Communist Vice Premier, charged today that friendly powers were eagerly waiting to supplant France in her colonial possessions.

LONDON, April 20 -- The reactions of the financial markets to the Government's budget have been neither violent nor unexpected because, apart from the severe increase in the tobacco tax, nothing violent nor unexpected was proposed.

Sixteen thousand dollars to build a new children's home in Palestine was raised yesterday at the annual donor luncheon of the Junior Mizrachi Women's Organization of America. Eight hundred women attended the affair at the Riverside Plaza Hotel, 253 West Seventythird Street.
LONDON, April 20 -- Princess Elizabeth will be 21 tomorrow, and it is a birthday that she must share with many millions of British and Commonwealth citizens throughout the world.

For many years it was regarded as a trait peculiar to the business community that it was the last to recognize the need for self-reform, and that when such reform was finally undertaken by others, it showed little zeal for cooperation.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan agreed today to accept an amendment specifying that the bill for assistance to Greece and Turkey include no commitment to support private American oil agreements in the Middle East.

Dr. Norman D. Newell, professor of geology at Columbia University, will head an expedition from Columbia and the American Museum of Natural History into the Andes Mountains in Peru to study the fossil remains of prehistoric marine life.

The post-war world is not the one that was promised, Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, declared last night at the fortieth anniversary dinner of the Free Synagogue in the Hotel Biltmore.

WITH a brazen fanfare of advance publicity, confidently labeled "a modern comic classic" by its proud publisher, greeted with raptures by the Book-of-the-Month Club, whose co-selection it is, a mildly amusing novel is published today. It is called "Aurora Dawn,"* and it is the work of Herman Wouk, a clever and erudite young man who was once a favorite pupil of Irwin Edman and once a favorite gagwriter for Fred Allen.
ST. LOUIS, April 20 (AP) -- Two home runs by Big Bill Nicholson, who batted in six runs today, enabled the Chicago Cubs to make it two out of three from the St. Louis Cardinals, 7 to 4.
The next suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York is likely to be one of two rectors of Manhattan parishes, it was learned yesterday.

There may have been neater apartments in Brooklyn than the six rooms occupied by Patrick MeEvinney, 57 years old, at 827 Quincy Street, but if so it was only because he was busy last night, and a little excited.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association, obviously ready, willing and anxious to grasp complete control of boxing from the New York State Athletic Commission and ailing Promoter Mike Jacobs, today gave its formal "blessing" to Jersey Joe Walcott, Camden, N.J., veteran, as an opponent for heavyweight champion Joe Louis.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 -- Figures on post-war transportation needs of Alaska and the revenues required to maintain adequate service between West Coast and Alaskan ports on a strictly private basis will emerge, ship operators in this area believe, from an experimental project approved by Congress for adaptation until July 1, 1948.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 20 (U.P.) -- Union leaders tonight mobilized their membership for a statewide demonstration tomorrow against a bill now before the state Legislature which would outlaw the closed shop.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 20 -- A blustery East wind canceled the final session of dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club today, and the cold-weather sailing season ended.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 20 (AP) -- Henry A. Wallace differed with Winston Churchill tonight over the causes of the second World War and declared: "I deny that heavy armaments are the road to peace."

Business men from India and countries of the Near East are now coming into the American market in increasing numbers in anticipation of the trade freedom as a result of loosening of sterling bloc restrictions in July, foreign traders reported last week.

As retail inventories decreased last week, reorders began to arrive in the wholesale market, while manufacturers, to shape up their stocks, reduced prices on floor goods, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Now that the tumult and shouting have died, and the pickets with their Quisling chorus outside and the fanatically enthusiastic audience inside Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon are things of the past, the truth may be told about the artistic merits of Kirsten Flagstad's New York recital.

Sgt. James Bute, attached to the Bay Ridge Precinct in Brooklyn, was named yesterday as the first winner of the Catherine O'Dwyer Medal for Life Saving, in general orders issued by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

Mayor O'Dwyer was reported yesterday to be "cooling off" toward the proposal to levy an automobile use tax of $5 a year on passenger cars and $10 a year on commercial vehicles. His financial advisory staff was said to be restudying the city's billion-dollar budget for 1947-48 to find out whether the new taxation could be avoided.
BOMBAY, India, April 20 (Reuters) -- At least two persons were knifed to death and seventeen others injured here today in communal rioting, which continued until dusk.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- The F. Wayland Ayer Cup for excellence in typography, make-up and presswork has been awarded to The Rutland Herald of Rutland, Vt., it was announced today.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,932,591,417. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Four hundred doctor-nurse teams will start today the vaccination of 200,000 students in the city's public and parochial high schools, Dr. Israel Weinstein, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday. By the end of the week it is hoped 1,000,000 school children will have been inoculated against smallpox.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 20 (AP) -- Crown Prince Frederik, who exchanged his title of Regent for that of King Frederik IX late today at his father's death, is the first of Denmark's thirty-eight monarchs to be trained by the Navy.

With few exceptions, foreign governments will be receptive to U.S. advertising efforts within their borders, Carroll Rheinstrom, president of Macfadden Publications International Corporation, said over the weekend. Although political conditions, in some cases, remain uneasy, he said, there is a general feeling that advertising of American products will have a constructive effect on public morale.

MOSCOW, April 20 -- Senior members of the United States delegation were nurturing a faint hope tonight that the Soviet delegation would make last-minute concessions on German reparations tomorrow or Tuesday. Such concessions would enable the Council of Foreign Ministers to end its deliberations with some progress on the most important problem on its agenda.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 20 -- The treaty of friendship and mutual assistance between Czechoslovakia and Poland, which was ratified by the Polish Parliament last week and brought a Polish trade delegation to Prague on Friday, has been viewed by many observers as the penultimate step in the formation of a "Slav bloc."
The cost of handling cargo in the Port of New York is mounting steeply, with shippers paying uncounted thousands of wasted dollars every week for the movement of their goods, both export and import.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 -- The high steel operating rate, the decline in prices of scrap metal and the heavy volume of shipments of finished steel were obscured some last week by the steel labor picture.

About 2,500 policemen have been assigned to guard President Truman's route on his visit to New York today to address the annual luncheon of members of The Associated Press in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Arrangements for the President's protection were announced at Police Headquarters yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (U.P.) -- The Labor Department reported tonight that 14,800,000 workers were covered by union contracts and listed thirty-four fields in which 80 to 100 per cent of the industry had been unionized.

The Council of Economic Advisers is reported to have told the President that purchasing power and consumption have begun to sag slightly. Buying has been maintained, according to this report, only because of an expansion in consumer credit, a shrinkage in wartime savings, and a reduction in the present rate of savings.

To remove tenacious city soot from Venetian blinds, new equipment and new services have been devised to simplify the job this season. A laundry calls for home blinds and washes them in a mechanized plant. New mitts, brushes and chemicals for cleaning stubborn stains are available.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- A proposal that landlords and tenants be enabled to agree on a 15 per cent increase in rents under continued Government control was made today by Senator Albert W. Hawkes, Republican, New Jersey.
CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -- More cities are putting taxes on sales, tobacco, liquor and gasoline for additional revenue to offset mounting costs.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 20 -- The troubling question of King Leopold may soon be clarified with the publication of a report assembled by an impartial commission instructed to study "the attitude of the King since 1936." The best informed persons expect a mild statement clearing his name of the gravest charges against him while at the same time implying that the only solution lies in his abdication.

ALBANY, April 20 -- Governor Dewey announced today that Henry C. Turner of New York, chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination, has resigned to return to the full-time practice of law. The Governor said he accepted the resignation with "profound regret."

The Giants and the weather cooled off almost down to the freezing point at the Polo Grounds yesterday and the resultant exhibition was one from which 13,655 shivering onlookers scarcely derived any pleasure.

Among the "war babies" now ready for school some have safely weathered family pressures and upsets. Others have been hard hit and will need special help from teachers in kindergarten and first grade, according to James L. Hymes Jr., Professor of Education at State Teachers College, New Paltz, N.Y.

TOKYO, Monday, April 21 (AP) -- A wind-driven fire that raged through the inland city of Iida, 100 miles west of Tokyo, was extinguished by rain early this morning after it destroyed almost 4,000 homes and left more than 17,000 persons without shelter, the United States Eighth Army announced.

BERLIN, April 20 (AP) -- Spring has brought an encouraging industrial recovery in the United States zone of Germany, but the food situation remains precarious and in some respects the ration is the lowest since the beginning of the occupation, the American Military Government said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 20 -- An immediate survey of the relief programs now being carried out in at least six European countries will be undertaken by the International Children's Emergency Fund, it was announced here today.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Grain markets fluctuated in an uncertain manner on the Board of Trade last week, with rapid price changes reflecting conflicting news. Sentiment at the close of the week was more bearish than of late, especially on corn. This was under pressure from cash interests, the lowest prices in several weeks being made yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Prices of frozen foods are continuing downward and are coming in line with those of fresh fruits and vegetables, but as long as the price of raw commodities remains high, the cost of frozen foods will not drop to the low levels expected by the industry, Charles E. Wurm, president of the Quick Frozen Food Association of Chicago, said today.

KANSAS CITY, April 20 -- Asserting that the Communists were not a political party but rather an international conspiracy to destroy representative government, Carroll Reece, Republican National Chairman, declared today that Republicans in Congress would cooperate with President Truman to purge Communists and other subversive persons from the payroll of the Federal Government.

Charity Sunday," marking the opening of the twenty-eighth annual house-to-house parish appeal of New York Catholic Charities, was observed yesterday with special sermons and prayers, in all Catholic churches in the Archdiocese of New York.

Operations last year of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company resulted in a net income of $23,838,612 before depletion, equal to $2.75 each on 8,674,332 capital shares outstanding, according to the annual report to be issued to stockholders today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The War Department aims to arm the National Guard with virtually every weapon used by the regular Army, in contrast to the wooden guns and tanks with which the pre-war Guard had to train.

A two-year wage agreement has been reached between the United States Steel Corporation and Philip Murray for the CIO United Steel Workers. If the National Wage Policy Committee of the union ratifies the settlement, as it is expected to do, it would be the most cheering news this country could hear at this critical moment in our domestic affairs.

The revolution in human affairs caused by modern science has no parallel in history, Dr. James T. Shotwell, director of the division of economics and history of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, declared yesterday in his report to the endowment trustees.

Newspaper publishers and other executives, here for the annual Newspaper Week meetings, said yesterday that business and industry throughout the country generally were still flourishing despite fears in some quarters of a recession.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Individual savings in the United States dropped from an "abnormally high" $33,000,000,000 in 1945 to about $19,000,000,000 in 1946, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Two young singers made their debuts yesterday afternoon at the City Center in the New York City Opera Company's second presentation of its spring season of the double bill , "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci."

In experiments to determine the cause of arteriosclerosis, the disease has been produced in dogs by Dr. Alfred Steiner and Dr. Forrest Kendall of the Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Welfare Island, it was announced yesterday by the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation.

JERUSALEM, April 20 -- Terrorists' scattered attacks injured a dozen soldiers today. Two cunningly contrived road-mines, one of which may have been intended for the British High Commissioner, were discovered and dismantled before they could do any damage.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 20 -- Urging full support of the United Nations by the World Council of Churches, Bishop Gustaf E. Aulen of Sweden said today that the Council could aid in promoting peace by "stimulating the consciousness of justice in different parts of the world."

Spring brings such pleasant things as baseball, sidewalk cafes and flowered hats. And then, of course, there are fresh ducklings. At this season they come to market in sizable numbers from Long Island, tender and young, no more than twelve weeks in age.

Further recruiting in the Naval Air Reserve is urgently desired by the Navy Department. Of some 60,000 wartime Navy pilots more than 50,000 are now civilians. The Reserve program is intended to keep the hard-won skill of these men available. The plan calls for twenty-two Naval Air Reserve units and air stations which will devote their week-ends to the program of continuous training.

DETROIT, April 20 (AP) -- A wage pattern in the automobile industry, with alterations to fit individual cases, appeared virtually cut out tonight after a two-year steel agreement was reached in Pittsburgh.

Even Christ's sacrifice on Calvary will not be enough to save an indifferent humanity if it does not replenish its spiritual heritage, the Rev. Dr. Benjamin B. Hersey, minister of the Church of the Divine Paternity, Fourth Universalist Society, Central Park West at Seventysixth Street, said yesterday.

Museum events, benefits and annual exhibitions are interspersed in another crowded week of the local art season. The Whitney Museum will open tomorrow a centennial exhibition of work by the American painter, Ralph Blakelock.
The newly renovated parochial school of St. Patrick's Old Cathedral, Mott and Prince Streets, was blessed and rededicated yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Sharp criticism of military interference with economic affairs in Germany was expressed yesterday by some business men with investments in that country. Their criticism reflected the repeated objections of foreign traders to military control over Germany's international trade."

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 20 -- King Christian X, who ruled his Danish subjects for thirty-five years and was acclaimed a hero for his guidance of them during five bitter wartime years of German occupation, died tonight of a heart ailment.

Trudi Schoop and her comic ballet, who have been touring for the last few weeks, dropped into New York for two performances yesterday at the Ziegfeld Theatre before sailing next week for their European headquarters: The vehicle this year is called "Barbara," and is described as a dance-comedy in nine scenes.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, April 20 -- About 70 per cent of the 14,000,000 eligible voters went to the polls today to install new Landtage [state assemblies] in the British occupation zone.

Details of a four-day visit to the city next month by Miguel Aleman, President of Mexico, were made public yesterday from Mayor O'Dwyer's office at City Hall. The first day, Friday, May 2, will be marked by the city's official reception at City Hall at 12:30 P.M.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Far be it from an Englishman to question the judgment of your diplomatic correspondent Mr. Reston when he asserts that good manners would ruin baseball. In fact, "gentlemanly baseball" might ruin the country, too, robbing it of one of those safety valves without which human societies are transformed into crowds of robots, ripe for exploitation by the first dictator who comes along.

VIENNA, April 20 -- The Soviet Union and the Western Allies suddenly opened a propaganda battle here today to convince the Austrians that each side would be blameless if a treaty were not drafted in Moscow.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Allocations of lard for export in the second quarter of the year were issued late last week and proved to be much below trade expectations. They aggregated 89,000,000 pounds, compared with 138,000,000 pounds in the previous quarter, and were less than half of the allocations in the same period last year.
TOKYO, April 20 -- Light voting was recorded today as Japan went to the polls to elect members of the House of Councilors, which will replace the old House of Peers.

JERUSALEM, April 20 -- Through their ministers in Washington the five Arab states that belong to the United Nations are asking its secretariat to place on the assembly's agenda their demand that the British mandate for Palestine be abolished and Palestine be proclaimed an independent state.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important rollcalls during the period April 12 to 18 are given in the appended tabulation: The House On the passage of the Labor Bill, passed 308 to 107:

KANSAS CITY, April 20 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York seemed to have more support for the nomination for President in 1948 than any other aspirant as members of the Republican National Committee gathered here today for the meeting tomorrow at which a time and place for the Republican national convention will be selected.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 -- New contract benefits amounting to slightly better than 15 cents an hour for 142,000 production employes of the five principal operating subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation were announced here today.

A small radar beacon for light-houses, designed to supplement and in time perhaps to replace the conventional lighthouse light, has been perfected by the General Electric Company, it was announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, April 20 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers agreed today that Austria's responsibility for her participation in World War II should be specified in the peace treaty.

While sixty pickets, carrying placards, paraded in front of both entrances of Carnegie Hall in protest yesterday afternoon, a packed assemblage indoors gave Kirsten Flagstad, Norwegian soprano, an ovation at her first post-war appearance in this city.

Plans of the Maritime Commission, if realized, will improve living conditions aboard the ten C-4 type vessels being operated by the commission on emergency passenger services, it was learned over the week-end.

Princess Elizabeth of Great Britain is 21 years old today. She is far away from England winning new friends in South Africa, but she was never closer to the loyal hearts at home. They love her as a woman and look forward to the day when she may rule them as their Queen.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 (AP) -- After dropping the first game of a double-header to Cincinnati, 13 -- 5, the Pittsburgh Pirates blazed back today to take the five and one-half inning nightcap, 7 -- 3, before 40,784 fans.

The first official clue to the effect of the steel "wage pattern" on the two-week-old telephone strike will be revealed this afternoon when the New York Telephone Company notifies a Federal conciliator whether it is prepared to alter its previous refusal to grant a full or "down payment" wage increase to 35,000 striking telephone workers in the metropolitan area.

Given to encourage new playwriting talent, this year's Sidney Howard Memorial Award of $1,500 will be turned over to the Experimental Theatre. The announcement was made yesterday by the Playwrights Company, administrators of the annual prize.

Members of Local 6, International Typographical Union, AFL, voted yesterday, 1,592 to 211, to accept a proposed contract providing pay increases of 16 to 20 per cent for 4,000 employes in the composing rooms of twenty-seven newspapers in this city.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 19 -- A crucial stage in European post-war production has beer reached. That is the conclusion to be drawn from the balance sheets and annual reports for 1946, published this week by leading Swiss industrial undertakings.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Walter Masterson's three-hit pitching checked the winning streak of the Boston Red Sox today as Washington pounded Mel Parnell for three runs in the first inning and a 3-1 victory before 28,433 fans. The loss was the first of the season for the Sox after four triumphs.

CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -- The Chicago Stags, after almost blowing a 13-point lead in the last quarter, hung on to beat the Philadelphia Warriors, 74 to 73, tonight and send the Basketball Association of America championship play-off series into the fifth game.

Scout, the K-9 veteran, came out of hiding yesterday and is now a free dog. The springer spaniel returned to his owners after the Health Department ruled that the animal was a second offender because the third person it was alleged to have bitten was only scratched.

Scout, the K-9 veteran, came out of hiding yesterday and is now a free dog. The springer spaniel returned to his owners after the Health Department ruled that the animal was a second offender because the third person it was alleged to have bitten was only scratched.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 20 -- The United States and Britain were prepared today to merge voting strength in a fight against the Arab League's move to open full-dress debate on Palestine at next week s special session of the United Nations General Assembly.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On April 6 a news story appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES under the headline, "Orthodox Church Ousts Four Prelates."

SHANKS VILLAGE, N.Y., April 20 -- An exhibit of art works by former soldiers, sailors and marines who are living here while attending Columbia University and other New York colleges was opened this afternoon in what was once the Officers Club of Camp Shanks.

ARMONK, N.Y., April 20 -- Shores Frank Doone, owned and handled by George M. Rogers of Mount Holly, N.J., won the open all-age stake, and Tarhellias Lucky Jake captured the amateur all-age stake for Dr. J.E. Miles of Brooklyn as the three-day field trials of the Southern New York Field Trial Club were completed today.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 20 -- Holle Jo, Donald Sutherland Ill's 7-year-old chestnut mare, bought for him by his father while Don was spending thirty-three months in the Army, including infantry service in the European theatre, romped to her first conformation hunter championship tonight.

King Christian X of Denmark on V-E Day emerged out of two years' imprisonment in his own country, the idol of his people, because of his fearlessness and refusal to compromise during the Nazi occupation.

Cotton prices here turned firmer last week after early weakness. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes for the week ranging from an advance of 121 to a decline of 5 points, compared with losses of from 73 to 98 points in the previous week.

Old Hand on the Job The visitor looked like an elderly but very spry college professor. "Pray, pardon the intrusion," he said, "but my name is Plutarch. You may remember a book of mine in which distinguished persons are arranged in pairs for purposes of comparison.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Senate having agreed to vote next Tuesday on the $400,000,000 program to help Greece and Turkey resist aggression, and passage being assured, Congressional interest has turned to two controversial domestic matters which may run into Presidential vetoes when they reach the White House.

An internal controversy over charges of Communist infiltration into the American Council of the influential Institute of Pacific Relations will come to a climax at a special meeting of the Council tomorrow afternoon.

NEW ORLEANS, April 20 -- The Rev. James W. Courtney, assistant pastor of the Jesuit Church of the Immaculate Conception here, was stabbed four times and seriously wounded today by a man to whom he was about to administer Holy Communion during a High Mass.

Scarce nails and fence posts, steel-wire rope and automotive lubrication equipment are listed among the 134 offerings, valued at $156,108,000 in acquisition cost, scheduled for sale this week by the War Assets Administration, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, announced over the week-end.

PEIPING, China, April 20 (AP) -- Chinese newspapers reported today that 9,000 Chinese Communists had begun an attack on Government positions at Pulantien, forty-five miles northeast of Russianoccupied Dairen.
TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 20 -- This Sunday is different from all other Sundays in Texas City.

Dr. Lillian Wald Kay, instructor in psychology at New York University, and twenty undergraduate students are gaining practical experience in psychology through a new teen-age program conducted by them at Prescott House, 247 East Fifty-third Street.

President Truman's warning that prompt preventive steps were necessary to "prevent" an "economic cloudburst" took the zest yesterday out of the stock market which earlier had been encouraged by the United States steel wage agreement.

The Musicians' Guild of New York, which has proved a welcome addition to the city's musical life, completed its first season last night when it presented its fourth program of old and new chamber music at Times Hall.
"There's so much bustle here. It's not at all like it was back home."

The memory of the 1933 bank holiday has not faded, so accumulated earnings of banks probably will not be taxed as excessive by Federal authorities, the National Association of Bank Auditors and Controllers was told yesterday.

GENEVA, April 21 -- An agreement on procedure in tariff bargaining satisfactory to the United States delegation was reached this morning at a meeting of heads of the seventeen delegations attending the Geneva Trade Conference.

GALVESTON, Tex., April 21 -- Testimony indicating a strange conflict of scientific knowledge on the explosive qualities of ammonium nitrate fertilizer, the substance which is believed to have caused the explosion disaster in Texas City, was given today at the Coast Guard's inquiry into the events leading up to the tragedy.

Felix Witzinger had bad luck in February when he journeyed from Northfield, Minn., where he is on the music faculty of Carleton College, to play a piano recital in New York. Before he could give his recital, he was stopped by something worse than a music critic; he caught the measles.

Julius Lobel, alias Jimmy Collins, alleged key figure in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle, was described alternately yesterday as the receiver of more than $250,000 for his part in the embezzlement and as a "high class messenger boy."
SINGAPORE, April 21 -- Two religious cults from the jungles of Indo-China have taken opposing sides in the conflict between France and Viet Nam.

An issue of $2,750,000 of 2 per cent school bonds of Warren, Ohio, will be offered for sale on May 13 to the highest bidder. Dated June 1, 1947, the bonds will mature on June 1 and Dec. 1, 1948 to 1971.

In a decision hailed by union counsel as a "milestone in the defense of American labor against Communist deceit and treachery," Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer upheld yesterday the suspension of four leaders of a Communist faction from membership in the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Senate today approved a twoyear suspension of the 4-cent-perpound tariff on copper in a move to build up this nation's depleted stockpile of the metal.

TWA Situation On the verge of bankruptcy three months ago and strife-ridden in the top executive level, Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., is operating on a stable basis as the annual meeting of stockholders on Thursday approaches observers said yesterday.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, April 21 -- The first state governments to be set up freely since the republic will be composed of delicately balanced coalitions in the British zone as a result of the unexpected strong gains in yesterday's voting by the small Communist and conservative Center parties.

ALBANY, April 21 -- Representatives of dairy farmers serving the New York City area, striving to prevent a possible milk strike, designated a common bargaining agent today to negotiate with the dealers for premium prices on May and June fluid milk.
Butter and cheese prices were reduced yesterday in most grocery and dairy stores here as prices in the wholesale markets slumped for the second successive business day.

ANSONIA, Conn., April 21 -- This city's 110 public school teachers carried out their threat of a mass "resignation" today, remaining away from their desks in six elementary schools, two high schools and one junior high school and providing an unscheduled holiday for 2,300 pupils.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 21 -- Egypt formally called on the United Nations General Assembly tonight to consider the independence of Palestine and the terminating of the twenty-five-year-old British mandate at its coming extraordinary session.

The survival of the United States is dependent upon our maintenance of a first rate military establishment, Gen. George C. Kenney of the Army Air Forces said last night. He spoke at a dinner of Sigma Delta Chi, journalistic fraternity, in the Midston House, Madison Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.

A 22-year-old mother and her 11-month-old son were burned to death yesterday morning in their home at 779 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx. They were found, the baby clutched in his mother's arms, a few feet from a window on the second floor.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 21 -- The United States and Britain turned down today the Soviet Union's proposal for the appointment by the United Nations Security Council of Georg Branting, Swedish lawyer and diplomat, as the first Governor of Trieste.
ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., April 21 -- Passenger-boat service from the Battery, New York, to this gateway to North Jersey shore resorts, is scheduled to be resumed June 15.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The first direct and major Democratic attack in the Senate on the House tax reduction bill was made today on the eve of the opening of Senate committee hearings on the measure.

Many agencies working for safety in the field of traffic have advocated practical driver training in the schools. A commendable first step in this direction for New York has now been taken, with the approval by the Board of Superintendents, of a program to be tested in Brooklyn.
Although another snowstorm swept over Boston yesterday to make the Dodgers two-day visit there a fruitless one, it developed today that the sun never has shone brighter for Pistol Pete Reiser.

THAT new outfielder on whom Bucky Harris has been banking so strongly made his debut in Philadelphia on Sunday and will be formally unveiled at the Yankee Stadium this afternoon. The kid looked good in his first start, hitting a three-run homer, and he may be a big help to the Bronx Bombers before October brings the world series.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 21 -- Princess Elizabeth, heir-presumptive to the British throne, today marked her twenty-first birthday by dedicating herself to the empire.

NUREMBERG, Germany, April 21 -- How some German industrialists squabbled over the spoils from occupied countries was illustrated in documents introduced by the prosecution today in the trial of Friedrich Flick and other leaders of Nazi industry before a United States tribunal.

President Truman took the occasion of the annual luncheon of The Associated Press yesterday to discuss a subject which he had already touched upon informally in two recent press conferences -- the subject of mounting living costs.

Allotments by the better known manufacturers are the rule as men's clothing lines for fall are opened this week and next, it was reported here yesterday. Confirming previous indications, prices are even with to about 5 per cent higher than for the spring season.

PITTSBURGH, April 21 -- The new contract between the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, and the United States Steel Corporation was hailed today by Philip Murray as a model guide to industrial stability which might well be followed by unions and companies in other mass production industries.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 21 (AP) -- The Connecticut State open champion, Felice Torza of Hartford, playing out of the Southern Pines (N.C.) Country Club, won the medal in the qualifying round of the forty-seventh annual North and South amateur golf championship at the Pinehurst Country Club today with a par 72 for the 6,879yard No. 2 course.
LONDON, April 21 -- The reputation of the Port of Southampton was defended today against criticism that navigational facilities in the approaches to the port were inadequate.

The Jewish Daily Forward, a nonprofit newspaper devoted to Americanization and general advancement of the immigrant, as well as to social democracy and liberalism, will begin today a three-month celebration on its fiftieth anniversary.

The opening session of the annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, a feature of the Newspaper Week program, will be held today, beginning at 10 A.M., in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Coming along in the stretch at just the right rate of speed, Frank Frankel's Petrol Point pounded home to victory in the Whitestone Purse, the Class C allowance race that enjoyed top rating at Jamaica yesterday.

A gift of $1,509,389 from the late Frederic Bancroft, librarian, lecturer and author, will be devoted to expanding Columbia University's resources for research in American history, Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia, announced yesterday.

The National Orchestra Association, which, under Leon Barzin's baton, gave its fourth and last concert of the season last night in Carnegie Hall, is not only a training orchestra for young players, but, frequently, an agency for contemporary music.

Henry Ford II, president of the Ford Motor Company, announced yesterday that assets of the Ford Foundation, Inc., amounted to $108,913,234. His statement was made after the annual meeting of foundation trustees, of which he is one, at the National City Bank of New York, 55 Wall Street.

MOSCOW, April 21 -- The history of World War II will certainly have to be rewritten as the result of Nikolai Werta's scenario for the Battle of Stalingrad, Part I, a film now being produced in the Union.

CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- Henry Wyse, veteran curve-ball pitcher, throttled Cincinnati's high-geared offense by setting the Reds down with only three hits for the Cubs' first shut-out victory of the season, 3 to 0, before 6,699 chilled fans today.

MOSCOW, April 21 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers got down to brass tacks on the Austrian treaty this afternoon, meeting in secret session for two and onequarter hours in an effort to break the deadlock on critical points.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 21 -- The first hope in several months for peace in the jurisdictional strike of studio workers which has been hampering motion picture production for seven months appeared tonight as representatives of the ten major producers prepared to treat with officials of the International Brotherhood of Carpenters, AFL.

NEWARK, N.J., April 21 -- Senior Federal District Court Judge Guy L. Fake received today a plan of reorganization that would divide into three separate companies the Central Railroad of New Jersey, which has been in bankruptcy since October 30, 1930.

JERUSALEM, April 21 -- If his health permits him to go to New York, Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, Secretary General of the Arab League, will be the principal Arab spokesman at the special session on Palestine, Emile Ghoury, secretary of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee said today.
LAKE SUCCESS, April 21 -- The right of enemy aliens to petition the United Nations Trusteeship Council was established here today.
TOKYO, April 21 -- Although Japan has adopted the outward symbols of democracy, she is not abandoning the old Japanese tradition of rule by violence.

THE trees that grow in the Saint Henri quarter of Montreal aren't very different from those of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. Neither district has very good soil for trees, nor very good surroundings for people. Unemployment, poverty, dirt, hunger and fear can do much to blight the lives of people anywhere; but anywhere, too, people will endure them and continue to live with as much hope and courage as they can muster.
CHICAGO, April 21 -- Trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade today was at a much slower pace than last week with rapid price fluctuations at times.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 21 (AP) -- Circuit Judge W. Scott Miller here today issued a restraining order against striking telephone workers, unions limiting pickets to two at each telephone building wherever the Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company operates in Kentucky.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Secretary of State Marshall sent word from Moscow to the Senate today that the program to bolster Greece and Turkey against totalitarianism was "indispensable."

JERUSALEM, Tuesday, April 22 -- In a cell of the central prison in the last hours before they were due to be hanged, two terrorists blew their hearts out last night with explosives that had been smuggled in to them.
PARIS, April 21 -- The threepower agreement on German coal announced in Moscow today by no means solves the French coal problem, in the opinion of French officials and experts.

ALBANY, April 21 -- The Court of Appeals, reversing the lower courts, has ruled unanimously that $107,508.33 in interest must be added to the $350,000 damages awarded Donald Flamm last June in his suit against Edward J. Noble for fraud and duress in connection with the alleged forced sale of Radio Station WMCA in 1941.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 21 -- After hearing that acute alcoholism is increasing in Westchester and that churches and communities face no social problem more difficult of solution, the clergy committee of the County Mental Hygiene Association voted unanimously today to join in a psychiatric, medical and legislative drive to curb the "disease."

Promptly at 1:45 P.M. yesterday, Mrs. Harry S. Truman and her daughter, Margaret, arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to hear President Truman speak at the Associated Press luncheon in the grand ballroom. As they swung through the revolving door at the Fiftieth Street side entrance leading to the tower apartments, Secret Service men and policemen were on the alert.

The nation-wide telephone strike grew out of Union demands for higher wages, the union shop, increased pensions, longer vacations, shortening of the time required to reach top pay levels, and other concessions.

Thousands of New Yorkers stood in the rain yesterday to catch a glimpse of President Truman as he passed through the city streets on his way to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where he addressed the annual luncheon of The Associated Press.

Letters of tender offering 15,000 finished mouton skins have been sent to contract holders in accordance with the weekly Schedule as set up, George J. Beldock, attorney for the dealer group, reported yesterday in Chapter XI reorganization proceedings affecting Motty Eitingon Co., fur processors, at a meeting held in the offices of Referee Irwin Kurtz.

Weather such as we have had during the past two days would have filled the hearts of last season's duck hunters with joy, but the average trout fisherman took one look outside and spent his time tying up some fly patterns that were in short supply.

Ralph Blakelock was born a hundred years ago this year (Oct. 15, 1947) and to celebrate the event the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, has arranged an exhibition of the American painter's work, preparing it in collaboration with City College, which also marks this year the hundredth anniversary of its existence.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., April 21 (AP) -- David E. Lilienthal said tonight that proof was still lacking that the nation's atomic energy project would succeed and he declared that, under present world conditions, it must be kept surrounded by secrecy.

Of the 1,000,000 European refugees and displaced persons whose names are on file with the Central Location Index 15 to 20 per cent have been reunited with their families overseas or relatives and friends in the United States, Canada and South America, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A Swedish trade delegate here for talks with the State Department declared emphatically today that his country's foreign exchange position permitted no alternative to the recent restrictions which Sweden has imposed on imports.

Col. Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, called on members of the News Publishers Association at a meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday to support the passage of the Mason bill in Congress to amend the anti-trust laws so as to permit press associations to choose their own members.
NANKING, China, April 21 (U.P.) -- Premier Chang Chun is reported to have named two Young China party members to posts in his Cabinet as the first non-Kuomintang Ministers.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 21 -- Great Britain has told New Zealand that retention of the unqualified imperial trade preferences arrangement is not practicable because of the Bretton Woods and Washington loan agreements. She has indicated that preferences must go, no matter what tears are shed.

HYANNIS, Mass., April 21 -- Dr. Malvern B. Clopton, a leading St. Louis surgeon, died today at his summer home in near-by Wianno after an illness of nine months. He was born in St. Louis seventy-one years ago.
MOSCOW, April 21 -- A tri-power agreement under which France will receive larger amounts of Ruhr and Saar coal as production rises has been signed here by France, the United States and Great Britain.

CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 5,000 head: total, 7,500; weights under 250 pounds and sows moderately active, fully 50 cents higher compared with last Friday's average; weights 250

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 21 (AP) -- Joe McCarthy, fully recovered from the illness which forced him to quit as manager of the New York Yankees, today observed his sixtieth birthday with a determination to "forget baseball."
TRENTON, N.J., April 21 (AP) -- Scores of bills were grinding through the legislative mills at a quickened pace tonight as the lawmakers drove toward adjournment.

The life of Simon I. Patino, the Bolivian Tin King who has just died in Buenos Aires, illustrates dramatically the extremes of wealth and poverty that constitute a continuing problem for much of South America.
The deadlock in the telephone strike remained unbroken yesterday as all Bell System units stood pat in their refusal to make a wage offer to their striking employes.

VIENNA, April 21 -- By the time final deliveries are made early this summer, Austria will have received from the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration the equivalent of $19.50 in goods for every person in the country.

MOSCOW, April 22 (AP) -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov proposed in a letter to Secretary Marshall, made public today, that the joint Russian-American Commission on Korea convene in Seoul on May 20 to resume its work.

DETROIT, April 21 (AP) -- Chicago's surprising White Sox maintained their unbeaten pace today with a ten-hit attack that beat the Tigers' ace, Hal Newhouser, 6 to 4, and kept them on top of the American League standings.

PELELIU, Palau Islands, April 21 (AP) -- Finally convinced that the war was over, twenty-six Japanese soldiers and sailors formally surrendered to the Americans on this Pacific island today, two and onehalf years after it had been secured by the United States Marines.

Different English Phrase We commented the other day on Henry A. Wallace's remark, early in his European tour, that if he only knew the Russian language he felt sure Mr. Stalin would allow him to lay his views before the common men of the Soviet Union.

Wage increases averaging 10 per cent will be sought for construction workers here by the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York, it became known yesterday. The American Federation of Labor organization has notified the Building Trades Employers Association of its desire to negotiate wage rises to become effective June 30.

The Public Service Commission's investigation into the application of the Kings County Lighting Company for an increase in its gas rates brought out yesterday that the new schedule would cost the average residential consumer 13.5 per cent more than he now pays.

Off the Jersey banks of the Hudson, with the skyscrapers of Manhattan across the river and the George Washington Bridge almost over our heads, we sat in a motorboat yesterday and watched fishermen haul in nets loaded with shad. This was the peach blossom run, or the first big school of the glistening fish to come up the river in their search for fresh water spawning grounds.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson proposed today a longrange farm program of abundance -- in bad times the Government would boost the food-buying power of the poor rather than pay farmers to produce less.
ROME, April 21 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi said today that continued and increased American participation in European and Mediterranean affairs would be "a guarantee against a new war."

With group practice by physicians on the upswing, the general practitioner of the future may become a field worker whose services are integrated into a new hospital system. Such a plan would provide a share of his remuneration from a financial pool derived from the Blue Cross Hospital Plan and prepaid medical insurance plans, hospital experts asserted yesterday.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 21 -- The Iowa House of Representatives voted 75 to 30 today to refuse to kill a bill banning the closed shop, while an estimated 15,000 men and women members of organized labor milled in and around the State Capitol in a demonstration of labor's opposition to the measure.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- A survey of selected income data reported by manufacturing corporations in annual reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission from 1936 through 1945 was made public today.

The wife exerts an influence in from 42 to 67 per cent of all decisions to buy consumer goods, such as electrical appliances, even in cases where the husband's influence is greater, according to a survey in the Wage Earner Forum, released yesterday by Macfadden Publications, Inc.
Sharp and unexpected increases in patronage and in future reservations on both foreign and domestic airlines during the last thirty days were reported yesterday.

Reflecting the record world-wide demand for petroleum products, crude oil production, refinery runs and sales by affiliates of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) were the largest in history, the annual report of Eugene Holman, president, and Frank W. Abrams, chairman, showed yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES of April 9 carried a report of an address I gave before the American Catholic Educational Association in Boston. The account is on the whole factual, but I regret that the headline attributed to me a degree of bellicosity which on this occasion at least I lacked.

MOSCOW, April 21 -- The United States is attacked for paying the "hangman's salary" in Greece and helping the "friend of von Papen" in Turkey by Ilya Ehrenburg, in the latest issue of Culture and Life.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 21 -- The working committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission discussed today for the fourth time Russia's amendment requiring that international control and inspection be put into effect "immediately" after a convention is signed.

KANSAS CITY, April 21 -- In an atmosphere optimistic of Republican success in next year's Presidential election, the Republican National Committee today voted to hold the 1948 Republican National Convention at Philadelphia during the week beginning Sunday, June 20.

President Truman called yesterday for national unity in support of his program of reducing prices to avoid a depression and of keeping taxes up and continuing rent, credit and export controls until the country is "over the hump" of inflation.

CINCINNATI, April 21 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner A.B. Chandler today turned down a request by Branch Rickey, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, and Ford Frick, president of the National League, that he reconsider the case of Dodger Manager Leo Durocher, whom he suspended for the 1947 season.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Negotiations between John L. Lewis, United Mine Workers president, and a majority of soft coal mine operators, deadlocked since last May, will be resumed here April 29, Capt. N.H. Collisson, Federal coal mines administrator, stated tonight.

PARIS, April 21 -- On the eve of the arrival in Paris of Henry A. Wallace, leaders of the Popular Republican party followed Edouard Herriot of the Radical party in disclaming responsibility for the former Vice President's visit here or his speeches.

The draft-evasion trial of Serge M. Rubinstein, international financier, was attacked in Federal Court yesterday as a conspiracy on the part of some Government officials to put Rubinstein in jail "on evidence that wouldn't hang a dog."

The city's special committee named to mediate differences between the United Financial Employes Union, AFL, and brokerage firm representatives in the financial district in an effort to avert a strike, conferred yesterday all day with union and management spokesmen without reaching any definite conclusions.

The text of President Truman's address yesterday at the annual luncheon of The Associated Press at the Waldorf-Astoria follows: Freedom, in the American tradition, is always coupled with service. The American press -- a free press -- must never forget its obligation to the American people.
DETROIT, April 21 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, has agreed to a wage settlement with the General Motors Corporation on the basis of an increase of about 15 cents an hour.

Arthur Miller's "All My Sons" was selected as the best American play of the season yesterday by the New York Drama Critics Circle. Eugene O'Neill's "The Iceman Cometh" was runner-up, although "All My Sons" led from the start of the balloting.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In reference to the dispatch from Dana Adams Schmidt which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 17 under the heading "Clay Halts Entry to Refugee Camps," may I, in order to obviate a misunderstanding which might mislead American public opinion, point out the following:

CHICAGO, April 21 -- The purpose of government in labor relations is to insure conditions in which free collective bargaining may flourish, for free collective bargaining is the only road to industrial peace.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 21 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's royally bred In The Pink showed a liking for the soft going today and made it two in a row over this track today -- the only two victories of her brief career.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The National Bureau of Standards announced today that it has taken over the last of seven wartime "radio propagating stations," the American segment in an international network of fifty-eight stations which maps the ionosphere in forecasting radio communications conditions.

The four-story building at 751 McDonald Avenue, Brooklyn, containing two stores and fourteen apartments, and an adjoining vacant lot, 20 by 85 feet, have been sold by P. Walker Morrison, Isidor Wasservogel and Leon Leighton, as trustees of Series B-K, to a Client of Albert A. Perlmutter, attorney.

A new organization, La Maison de France, Inc., aimed at improving economic and business cooperation between France and the United States, was announced yesterday by Philip Cortney, president, Coty, Inc., at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- Early advances in prices of electric kitchen appliances were predicted today by Leonard C. Truesdell, vice president in charge of marketing of Hotpoint, Inc., manufacturer of ranges, dishwashers and other appliances.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 21 -- Officials of the United Nations are seeking revision of their yearold arrangement to take over 912 apartments in two housing developments now being built by the Metropolitan and the New York Life Insurance companies, it was learned today.
The Community Service Society of New York aided 29,077 families in its last year, an increase of 2,000, according to the annual report yesterday.

A good illustration of the use of one coordinated group of furniture throughout a house may be seen in the full-scale model home built on the floor of Grand Central Palace for the Metropolitan Home Show, which will continue for the rest of the week.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- In an unprecedented slash, the House Appropriations Committee recommended today a 47 per cent reduction in the funds for the Interior Department that were requested in President Truman's budget for the 1948 fiscal year.

Members of The Associated Press paid tribute yesterday to Frank B. Noyes, 83-year-old president of The Washington Evening Star. At their annual business meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel they adopted a resolution praising his fifty-four years of service on the board of directors of the AP and its predecessor, the old Illinois Corporation.

An issue of $10,000,000 of Northern Natural Gas Company serial debentures was awarded at competitive bidding to a group of underwriters headed by Blyth Co., Inc., yesterday. The bid was 100.2005 for a 2 1/2 per cent coupon and the bonds, dated May 1, 1947, will be due serially May 1, 1957 through 1967.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- After four months of arm's-length correspondence, the American Federation of Labor today invited the Congress of Industrial Organizations to confer on a plan to merge.
Norman Rubio of Albany took the unanimous decision over Wayland Douglas of Brooklyn in the main ten-round bout in the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Each weighed 148 pounds.

Brunswick-Balke-Collender Earnings of the BrunswickBalke-Collender Company in the initial three months of this year were $260,485, compared with $36,636 a year ago, R.F. Bensinger, president, told shareholders at their annual meeting held yesterday in Chicago.

The text of the report of the board of directors of The Associated Press to A.P. members at their annual meeting yesterday follows: The report of the Executive Director for 1946 vividly portrays the scope of the Association's operations in a year marked by economic and political upheavals.

A total of nearly $3,000,000 in grants for cancer research was distributed during 1945 and 1946 to finance 240 research projects in forty-eight universities, hospitals and other institutions, it was announced yesterday by the American Cancer Society at a press luncheon at the Hotel New Yorker.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Basil O'Connor, chairman of the American Red Cross, today called "astonishing" the criticisms of Red Cross relief activities attributed to Mayor J.C. Trahan of Texas City.
This city, with more than half its population vaccinated in the last fortnight, got another false alarm of smallpox yesterday -- this time from Staten Island.
DETROIT, April 21 -- Two persons were injured and twenty-two were arrested today as rioting broke out at the Michigan Bell Telephone Company.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- What to do about tax rates and appropriations is always influenced by partisan politics and the concern of office-holders to keep their jobs. The methods by which business men arrive at their fiscal policies are subordinated to these factors when government deals with the same problem.

The five-story store and loft building at 248-50 Pearl Street and 186 Water Street and the four-story warehouse at 190 Water Street have been purchased for investment by Harry W. Watts, commercial photographer, from the Battery Park Realty Corporation, of which Thomas H. Hindle is president.

PITTSBURGH, April 21 (AP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced today that "while some lines of apparatus will require some price increase due to recent wage increases, no price advance on home appliances is contemplated at this time."
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 21 -- Frederik, elder son of King Christian X, was this afternoon formally proclaimed King Frederik IX of Denmark, following upon the death of his father last night.

PARIS, April 21 -- Counsel for Jacques Lemaigre-Dubreuil, director for an important French oil firm, today asked 1,000,000 francs in damages from Andre Geraud, journalist widely known as Pertinax, charging that libelous statements were made in his book "The Grave Diggers of France."

ROME, April 21 -- The Provinces of Trento and Bolzano -- Upper Adige -- are to have two regional Parliaments, according to an agreement between Premier Alcide de Gasperi and a delegation from the German-speaking population of the region.

STEWART MANOR, L.I., April 21 -- Mrs. Nancy Jackson, 30 years old, of 171 Van Buren Street, Franklin Square, L.I., was beaten and robbed of $15 in the parking field of the Long Island Railroad station here at 12:10 P.M. today.
Tiny copies of period furniture, some made as toys or collectors' items, others as designers' study models, went on exhibit yesterday at Manor House, 383 Madison Avenue.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Reporting on the FAO report in THE TIMES recently, your correspondent, Thomas Hamilton, states that I have formulated on behalf of the Greek Government "some reservations on certain points" of the report. I want to clarify that these reservations were on rather secondary questions and that the general opinion of the Greek Government is that the FAO mission to Greece has done an inspired and excellent work.

An appeal for a boycott of Britain and a call to American Jewish youth to join the underground resistance movement in Palestine was made last night to 2,400 persons attending a meeting in Manhattan Center, held as a memorial to the four men executed by the British as terrorists.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Labor Department officials were busy today studying the steel wage agreement in order to ascertain whether it could be applied to the dispute which has resulted in a strike of 330,000 telephone employes. The strike entered its third week today.

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 21 -- The United States circulated among the ten other members of the United Nations Balkan investigating commission today a proposed summary of the evidence on the Macedonian issue. This summary tends to prove that Yugoslavia and Bulgaria interfered in Greek internal affairs so as to win Greek Macedonia for Yugoslavia and western Thrace for Bulgaria.

Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was on a large scale yesterday and prices were firm on old-crop months, but barely steady on newcrop months. The close was 65 points net higher to 21 points net lower than Saturday's final levels.

DETROIT, April 21 -- The United Steelworkers' 15-cent wage settlement does not cover the 1,100 nonbasic steel companies, which employ 350,000 union members, a spokesman for these companies announced today. Only separate negotiations on a plant-by-plant basis are acceptable, the announcement said.

Rained out of their scheduled meeting with the troublesome Phillies yesterday at the Polo Grounds, the Giants headed for Boston last night. They open a three-game stand at the Hub today, leaving the local scene to the Yankees and Dodgers, who will be entertaining, respectively, the Red Sox and Phillies.

After a debate which has provided ample opportunity for discussion on every argument in opposition, President Truman's program of aid for Greece and Turkey is expected to come before the Senate for a final vote this afternoon. It carries the specific and unreserved endorsement of Secretary Marshall.

BOSTON, April 21 (AP) -- Weston W. Adams' Flag Drill, a 7-10 favorite, reveled in the sloppy going at Suffolk Downs today to win the six-furlong feature from Sam Garfield's Respire by two lengths. Mr. Chairman was third, two and a quarter lengths back of Respire.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 21 -- Vanguard Productions, the David O. Selznick company, today announced plans for a screen version of Henrik Ibsen's "A Doll's House," to be produced late this year, with Dorothy McGuire as Nora. The play, which was first published in 1879, is in the public domain in the United States, and Selznick has cleared the Norwegian and other unexpired European rights at a reported cost of $16,000.

BERLIN, April 21 -- The intense German interest in the Moscow conference is reflected here in the revival of rumors of the western Allies' impending departure from Berlin. The interim since Secretary of State Marshall's interview with Premier Stalin has generated a flurry in the food black market in consequence of their reported failure to achieve any progress in major German problems.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- John K. Norton, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, urged a Senate labor and public welfare subcommittee today to "get rid of the slum areas of education" by making Federal aid available to the states.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 21 -- Supervisory employes of the GraceNew Haven Community Hospital fired the boilers in the laundry powerhouse of the hospital's New Haven unit today to maintain essential laundry services after the resignation of forty-six maintenance and powerhouse workers earlier in the day halted laundry work.

LONDON, April 21 (AP) -- The ext of Princess Elizabeth's birthday address to the British Commonwealth: On my twenty-first birthday I welcome the opportunity to speak to all the peoples of the British Commonwealth and Empire, wherever they live, whatever race they come from and whatever language they speak.

Flowers, veils and ribbons figure largely in a man's idea of what a woman's hat should be, according to veterans at the Naval Hospital, St. Albans, who took part yesterday in a millinery fashion show and hat trimming contest at the hospital.

Sales Off 1% Here Showing a decline for the second consecutive week, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week were 1 per cent under those for the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.
LONDON, April 21 -- Week-end consideration of the budget brought in buyers of selected industrials in the stock markets today. The turnover in other sections was smaller than expected.

Old-line, standard and reliable manufacturers of hardware have had the foresight to realize that they could not increase their prices to a point where consumers would not buy their goods, H.E. Masback, executive vice president, Masback, Inc., wholesale hardware merchants, disclosed in an interview yesterday.

New York is a physically deteriorated port. A canvass of executives in industries using harbor facilities and harbor personnel resulted in this composite conclusion: The port retains its supremacy by the weight of its influence and geographical advantage, not by its efficiency.

Pushing across a run in the twelfth inning, Hofstra defeated Manhattan, 4 -- 3, in a Metropolitan Baseball Conference test at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. It was the longest game thus far this season in league play.

Walter Tyrie Stevens, who was identified with the export trade here for many years, died last night at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Stevens Bobst, 1215 Fifth Avenue. He had been ill for several months. His age was 79.

The Board of Estimate is scheduled to act soon on a proposed amendment of the city Zoning Resolution relating to Article V, Section 21-C, which would exclude the Board of Standards and Appeals from jurisdiction over site and general building plans for large-scale residential and other developments to be constructed on an area of 75,000 square feet or more.
