There was no faint resemblance between Hal Gregg and the weather at Ebbets Field yesterday as the tall young Californian held the Phils to one hit and pitched the Dodgers to a 1-0 triumph -- not to mention hurling them into second place in the National League.

VIENNA, April 22 -- Austria must import a total of $123,000,000 in food this year, according to an estimate of the Ministries of Food and Agriculture made public today by the semi-official Austrian press agency. These imports are apart from those obtained through the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, which is now ending its work.

A banking group headed by the National City Bank won the award yesterday of $1,800,000 of bonds of Columbus, Ga., maturing from 1948 to 1977, at a bid of 101.42 for fixed interest of 2 per cent, an interest cost of 1.903 per cent. The next highest bid was 101.415, submitted by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc.
Reduction of this city's huge bonded indebtedness is vital if taxes are to be cut or municipal services expanded, Frank C. Moore, State Controller, told the Chamber of Commerce of Queens last night.

The stock market made some further upward progress yesterday, but the advance was painfully slow and gains of a point or more were scored by only a few key issues. The price average rose 0.64 point, but the session was the narrowest in more than two weeks.

CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- Shortstop Eddie Miller smashed a homer in the second inning and then singled across the run that gave the Reds a ten-inning 7-to-6 victory over the Cubs today before 5,484 spectators.

Public information activities of commercial and industrial trade associations can be profitably Increased, four panel speakers agreed in discussions here yesterday before the Trade Association Executives organization at a luncheon meeting at the Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The House overwhelmingly approved today citations for contempt against Leon Josephson, described in debate as the leader of a Communist fraudulent passport ring, and Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the Communist party.

A new collection of plastic-coated printed fabrics and slipcovers introduced at Macy's offers a stainresistant surface along with a conventional appearance. A thin and virtually invisible plastic coating has been applied to decorative cotton yardage now available for draperies, bed covers, tablecloths, upholstery, and cushion covers.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 22 -- The struggle between the conservative political parties that wish to regain their influence in Czechoslovakia's labor union organization and the Communist elements that dominate it has been boiling over in the Prague press and in speeches and broadcasts.

LONDON, April 22 -- A proposal that the United Nations should frame a declaration of human rights, including freedom of religion, was endorsed today by the spring meeting of the British Council of Churches.

Zenon Tuczynski, 13 years old, gave a piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall. He is a well set up lad, and he performed valiantly in the presence of an audience which contained many another little boy and little girl whom it was hard to make sit still, while fond mammas looked at the stage, and then at their offspring, and, dreamed of empire.

SINGAPORE, April 22 -- British colonial officials in Malaya have ordered the registration of secret societies. This regulation is aimed at the Chinese Communist organization, which is alleged to have caused labor disturbances in Malaya.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 -- Edward G. Robinson is expected to play the leading role in Paramount's "The Night Has a Thousand Eyes," a screen melodrama based on a novel by Cornell Woolrich, it was learned today. The story was published last year under Woolrich's pen name, George Hopley, but the studio had acquired film rights to it in a pre-publication deal in December, 1945.

CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- Officials of the American Society of Professional Automobile Racers tonight assembled to discuss with several Midwestern and Eastern racing promoters the possibility of holding a Memorial Day race for "name" drivers who have refused to compete in the 500-mile race at Indianapolis.

The taboo of the vacationminded vice-president, which silenced Fred Allen at the outset of a broadcast three days ago, laid its blight of silence last night on two other radio comedians, Bob Hope and Red Skelton.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 22 (AP) -- The Centaur, British light aircraft carrier, was launched amid strict security regulations today by the Duchess of Kent, sister-in-law of King George VI. In London, the Admiralty said the Centaur's construction was begun during the war and that she was along the lines of the Colossus class, which has a displacement of 14,000 tons.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A charge that the Federal Government appropriates far more money for farm animals, and even for trees, than it does for the education of children was made before the Senate Subcommittee on Education today by George J. Hecht, publisher of Parents' Magazine and School Management.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- President Truman was urged today by Chester Bowles, his former price administrator, to activate his price cutting appeal by appointing a businessmen's committee to work with the Government in negotiating downward price revision.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee made public today a heretofore unpublished list of more than eighty persons associated in some way with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation during the chairmanship of Jesse H. Jones who have since "gained key positions" in the control or management of large private companies.

LONDON, April 22 (U.P.) -- The Cunard-White Star liners Aquitania and Mauretania and the battleship Warspite reported today that storms at sea had injured passengers, snapped a towline and shaken the big ships.

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind ruled yesterday that Dr. Karl von Kleczkowski, former German Army spy, and his wife, Stella, who turned to the Allied cause in 1943, were not entitled to a sanctuary in the United States and were subject to an order deporting them to their native Austria or Turkey.
LONDON, April 22 -- Yesterday's spurt of trading pace was not maintained in the stock markets today and business was on a small scale.

Progress toward an agreement between General Motors and Walter Reuther's CIO automobile workers follows closely on the completion of a contract between Philip Murray's steel workers and Big Steel. Mr. Murray not only extols this contract as a mode of its kind, but lets it be known not too obliquely that in his opinion it would make an excellent pattern for the other mass-production industries to copy.

Unless the Brooklyn Union Gas Company is permitted to increase its rates to consumers, it will be unable to finance a $23,000,000 expansion and construction program except at inordinate costs, according to testimony yesterday before the Public Service Commission at 233 Broadway.

The greatest effectiveness of the Bureau for the Suppression of Theft and Pilferage can come from the devising of ways and means to prevent the thefts which cost this port "staggering" annual sums, Edward E. Conroy, executive vice president of the bureau, declared yesterday.

LONDON, April 22 (AP) -- The text of Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov's letter to Secretary of State Marshall about Korea, as transmitted by Toss in English from Moscow: May I inform you of the following in reply to your letter of April 8 regarding Korea:

PARIS, April 22 -- For the first time in months, long lines of purchasers were turned away breadless today from bakeries here and in a large part of France. In several sections of the city bakers displayed notices that they had not received their regular flour rations.

Buyers' Total Above '46 Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,209, against 1,339 last week and 990 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., April 22 -- The United States has proposed two new names in the sixmonth-old contest to select a Governor of the Free Territory of Trieste. The two new candidates are Count Carl August Ehrensvard, a major general in the Swedish Army, and Maj. Gen. Otto Ruge, former commander in chief of file Norwegian Army.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., April 22 -- This city with a population of slightly more than 15,000 became a national test tube of the value of cutting retail prices 10 per cent when 157 of its 172 stores cooperated in reducing sales prices by this amount today on the heels of President Truman's speech yesterday requesting such a cut.

Secretary Marshall's letter of April 8 to Foreign Minister Molotov regarding a resumption of negotiations for establishment of a unified and democratic Korea has brought results much more quickly than has been the rule in dealings with the Soviet. Mr. Molotov suggests the Joint U.S.-U.S.S.R. Commission resume its sessions in Seoul on May 20 and report its progress to the two occupying Governments not later than August.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Industry was warned today to "stop leaning on government for its virtue and develop some moral self-reliance of its own," while at the same time government bureaus were criticized for their method of enforcing the law through "hit and miss individual prosecutions."

The first five members of the New York City delegation to file International Boy Scout Jamboree to be held at Moisson, France, about sixty miles outside Paris, next August, have been selected by the International Jamboree Committee of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, it was announced yesterday by Col. Sigurd J. Arnesen, chairman of the committee.

Those who have been waiting for the big channel bass to arrive at the mouth of Oregon Inlet on the North Carolina banks can pact their duffle and be on their way for bass up to 55 pounds have been taken during the past week.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted to the Virginian Railway Company the right to oppose at ICC hearings a plan to set up interlocking directorships for the Chesapeake Ohio and the New York Central Railroad Companies.

Youth and War The young people of the British Commonwealth whom Princess Elizabeth singled out in her birthday greeting are of her own age class. In the main the young men must have been untouched by the war in the sense of coming under fire on the battlefield.

What's going on here? Last week Kermit Bloomgarden, producer, announced that the Lillian Hellman play, "Another Part of the Forest," would end its engagement May 3 at the Fulton. It won't. The closing date has been moved up a week to Saturday night.

The New York Telephone Company officially slammed the door yesterday on acceptance of the 15cent-an-hour steel wage increase as a pattern for the determination of telephone wages. Similar action was taken by Bell System affiliates throughout the country on the sixteenth day of the national telephone strike.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Senate, by a vote of 67 to 23, nearly 3 to 1, today passed the $400,000,000 bill to bolster Greece and Turkey against communism.

The Senate has approved President Truman's program of aid to Greece and Turkey by a larger majority and a more decisive bipartisan vote than it has given to any other major controversial measure in the whole field of American foreign policy since the outbreak of the war in Europe.

DACHAU, Germany, April 22 (AP) -- August Ruhnke, former deputy commander of Kaufbeuren concentration camp, was sentenced to death today by a United States military court for his part in the mass killings of thousands of camp prisoners.
JOE DIMAGGIO climbed up the dugout steps, stopped and shuddered. "Where," he exclaimed, "are the penguins? Gosh, it's cold. Operation Baseball has become Operation Frostbite."

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 22 -- The dates for ninety-six of the 120 tariff negotiations that must take place before the Geneva Trade Conference finishes its work here were announced by the secretariat today. The United States will be the first country to start negotiations with all other countries.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A demand that the Marine Corps should have its status specifically defined under any plan of unification of the armed services was made today by Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, Marine Corps commandant.
With millions of sore arms in New York these days, the New York County Medical Society broadcast some helpful advice yesterday on what every citizen should know, and do, about his vaccination.
LONDON, April 22 -- Making his first public address as United States Ambassador to Britain, Lewis W. Douglas tonight defended and explained the Truman doctrine of aid to Greece and Turkey.

D URING the German occupation of France two books written by men active in the resistance movement became internationally famous. One of them was a novelette called "The Silence of the Sea," by Vercors. The other was a collection of short stories called "Army of Shadows," by Joseph Kessel.

COLUMBUS, Ga., April 22 -- Eight officers of the Delta Air Lines and a private flier were killed here today when two planes were in collision thirty feet above the Muscogee County airport runways and crashed in flames.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Government intervention in the pricewage problems of business appeared unlikely to a broad section of Government spokesmen who expressed their views here today. It was made clear that persuasion would continue to be applied, but there was no indication of any kind of action which might be called a positive Government program.

The Airlines Terminal Building, occupying the west blockfront on Park Avenue from Forty-first to Forty-second Street in the heart of the Grand Central zone, was reported yesterday to have passed into new hands.

Commuters using the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad voiced strong opposition to a request made by the line to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a 20 per cent increase, in its interstate commutation rates.

Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson's proposed plan to increase food buying power rather than cut food production was greeted as a more realistic approach to the surplus problem by leaders of the food industry yesterday. They warned, however, success of the program and the degree of support it will receive from tine food industry will depend on how it is implemented.

If the millinery trades hope to increase their output to 100,000,000 hats per year, they will have to concentrate on in-between season selling, Walter K. Marks, head of the company bearing his name, and president of the Eastern Women's Headwear Association, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A national advertising campaign will be sponsored by the American Petroleum Institute to help inform the public of the "progressive character" of the oil industry, it was announced today. John M. Lovejoy, chairman of the institute's public relations operating committee, said that the campaign, which is on a limited basis, will be handled by Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell Bayles, New York.

Russell A. Firestone's 4-yearold colt Degage, hustled along from the start by Conn McCreary, ran the speediest six furlongs of the Jamaica meeting yesterday in winning the Blackstock Handicap, a $5,500 added sprint.

The Northern States Power Company of Wisconsin awarded yesterday at competitive sale $19,000,000 of first mortgage thirty-year bonds to an investment banking group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and White, Weld Co. at a bid of 100.6811 for designated interest of 2 5/8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The National Federation of Telephone Workers charged the Bell System today with "reaching a new low" by demanding that locals of the NFTW refuse to submit to the top union policy committee agreements they formulated with twenty-five Bell affiliates.

A local law designed to help prevent passport fraud such as were committed during the war by Communists and Nazis and other misuse of birth certificates was passed yesterday by the City Council. The law, if signed by Mayor, O'Dwyer, will make it "unlawful for any person to make a photostatic copy of a record of birth, stillbirth, marriage or death, or of a certification of birth, issued by the Department of Health."

Reporting on operations last year of the Creole Petroleum Corporation, A.T. Proudfit, president, informed stockholders in the annual report issued yesterday that oil production in Venezuela in 1946 set a new record high, with Creole's production averaging 545,390 barrels daily, or 20 per cent more than in 1945.

DETROIT, Mich., April 22 -- A meeting between representatives of the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, recessed at 11 o'clock tonight. Walter P. Reuther, president of the UAW, accused the company of rejecting four attempts by the union to reach a wage agreement based on an increase of fifteen cents an hour.

American women, richest in material privileges, are the most unhappy women in the world, Dr. Marynia F. Farnham, psychiatrist and author, said yesterday in a forum discussion of the topic: "Is Modern Woman Overprivileged?" "They have no grasp of the real privilege of being happy, integrated and having some kind of consummate life," she said.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 22 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine requested the United Nations today, "as a matter of simple justice," to allow it to represent the Jewish people without a vote at the General Assembly's special session on Palestine.
ROME, April 22 (U.P.) -- A mob of 4,000 war veterans fought through a cordon of police today and sought to enter Montecitorio Palace, where the Constituent Assembly was in session.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today passed and sent to the House the bill for aid to Greece and Turkey: FOE THE BILL -- 67 Republicans -- 35 Alken Ferguson Reed

Threats against the life of Alvin J. Paris for having turned informer against the convicted trio of "masterminds" in last December's professional football "fix" scheme has caused his transfer from Rikers Island penitentiary to the Tombs, it was learned yesterday.
Prices of steel scrap in the Pittsburgh district declined yesterday $5 a ton, the sharpest decrease for a single day since the downward trend developed on March 17.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (U.P) -- William Benton, Assistant Secretary of State, told a House Executive Expenditures Committee today that Russia was spending "enormous sums" on foreign propaganda, possibly more than the rest of the world combined.

PARIS, April 22 -- Henry A. Wallace declared tonight in a broadcast here that the first step toward a durable peace should be a "nonpolitical loan" by the United States for the relief of the devastated areas of Russia. This should be made through the mechanism of the United Nations, he said.

In its first collection of shoes since the war, presented at the St. Regis Hotel yesterday, Saks Fifth Avenue brought together shoe styles from here and abroad. There were handmade. fashions by Ferragamo of Florence, shoes by Mabel and Charles Julianelli and a group of exclusive designs.

The Guardian Life Insurance Company of America has sold the five-story and apartment building at 2808-2820 Hudson Boulevard, corner of Sip Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., to the Tribune Realty Corporation. J.I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

Recent dismissals by radio networks of "liberal" commentators were not caused by objection to political views but by the loss by the commentators of much of their wartime audience, A.A. Schechter, vice president of the Mutual Broadcasting System, said last night at the opening session of the third annual Radio and Business Conference of City College.

Nearly 200 Connecticut residents have contributed to "The New Connecticut Cookbook," compiled by the Westport Woman's Club and published today by Harper's. It succeeds "The Connecticut Cookbook," issued in wartime to give helpful suggestions on ways of meeting food shortages.

The United States, greatest creditor and lending nation of the world, must increase the volume of its imports to enable other nations to pay for the goods and credits they receive, William C. Foster, Under-Secretary of Commerce, stated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Executive Committee of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization in effect has rejected the World Food Council proposed here last winter by the FAO Preparatory Commission, it was learned today.

Two obviously pointed references to Baseball Commissioner Albert B. (Happy) Chandler were made by Branch Rickey, president of the Dodgers, last night in the course of his address at the second annual all-sports dinner honoring Nat Holman and City College athletes at the Hotel Astor.

MOSCOW, April 22 -- The formula for control of the Ruhr and other major European industrial areas by an international group representing all directly interested nations is "the most important development" of the Moscow session of the Council of Foreign Ministers, according to John Foster Dulles.

The next question we face in Greece concerns our attitude toward the regime. In what manner and to what extent does the program in support of Greek independence commit us or entitle us to intervene in internal politics? One thing we cannot do is to impose on the Greeks a government of our choosing.

At the organization meeting of the directors of the, American Smelting and Refining Company, held here yesterday, Roger W. Straus, president, was elected chairman to succeed Francis H. Brownell, who had asked that, because of age, he be relieved of the chairmanship.

New York's public school teachers are beset by "fear and suspicion" regarding interpretation of the new state education law as it affects opportunities for promotional increments, the Teachers Guild, AFL, charged yesterday.

The American Automobile Association has urged the Department of State to transmit to the United Nations a request to use its influence in lowering barriers to travel. There exists today a bewildering procedure of passports and visas, entry and departure permits, health and vaccination tickets, police permits, photographs, tax certificates and the like.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Warriors tonight won the Basketball Association of America's first championship, defeating the Chicago Stags, 83 to 80, to take the final play-off series, four games to one.

Air travel to Europe has experienced a boom greater than that of domestic United States airlines. Providing more than 2,000 seats a week -- more than the accommodations available on surface ships of comparable comfort -- the three United States and four foreign airlines serving New York are booked fully into July.

Representative W. Kingsland Macy of Suffolk County and his entire administration slate of candidates scored a five-to-one victory last night over their opposition, headed by City Councilman Edward Rager, in the annual election of officers of the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

GALVESTON, Tex., April 22 -- Testimony that firemen fighting the blaze on the French freighter Grandcamp, which exploded last Wednesday and devastated the refinery port area of near-by Texas City, were not informed of the pending blast although, it was anticipated by the ship's officers, was given, today at the United States Coast Guard's inquiry.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 22 (AP) -- Felice Torza of Hartford, Conn., the medalist, led the way into the quarter-finals of the North and South amateur golf championship with a second-round victory over Dr. J.P. Kenrick of Bethesda, Md., at the twentieth hole today after being three down at the ninth.

WASHINGTON, April 22 --The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 16: A decrease of $161,000,000 in loans, and increases of $518,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities and $546,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

Fiscal Agent While officials of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development continue their efforts to determine the method by which the bank's debentures will be offered for subscripiton, it has been decided that the Federal Reserve Bank will handle "at least the mechanics of fiscal agent," it was reported yesterday.

A bill for the licensing, supervision and regulation of garages and parking lots, submitted to the City Council yesterday by Council members Bertha Schwartz of the Bronx and L. Gary Clemente of Queens, was sent to committee pending public hearings on the measure.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- John T. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, indicated today that the Administration expected the national income to drop about $8,000,000,000 If industry lowered prices in accordance with President Truman's "moral persuasion."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the interest of free speech we must expect to suffer much uninformed discussion regarding international matters, but surely we are hearing more misstatements of fact and of history in connection with the loan to Greece and Turkey than is reasonable.

HAVRE DB GRACE, Md., April 22 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm colors continued to roll to victory today as two daughters of the sire Bull Lea ran one, two in the featured six-furlong Leonardtown Purse. They were Twosy, a campaigner during the winter, and Maud Lea, making her first start of 1947.

ROME, April 20 (Delayed) -- Leading lawyers who defended Msgr. Aloysius Stepinatz, Archbishop of Zagreb, in his trial last October, were thrown into jail an otherwise victimized by the Yugoslav authorities, it was declared today by one of them, who escaped and found refuge on Italian soil one jump ahead of the Ozna, the Yugoslav secret police.

LONDON, April 22 -- Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, has thus far achieved his objective of reducing the consumption of American tobacco, according to the testimony of members of the National Organization of Tobacconists.

REHOVOTH, Palestine, April 22 -- Terrorists killed eight persons, including a 3-year-old boy, by blowing up a military and civilian passenger train outside Rehovoth today. The boy's mother, Mrs. Shaki Balladi, a Turkish citizen, was one of the forty-one injured.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The State Department was represented by Dean Acheson, Acting Secretary of State, today as standing unchanged in its attitude that the United States should deliver nearly $17,000,000 of post-war lend-lease supplies to the Soviet Union.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 22 -- Current high prices are more dangerous to free, private enterprise than the Communist party of the United States ever has been, Alf M. Landon said today. He suggested a four-point program for the Federal Government to check the inflationary spiral of prices and wages and to clear the way for cooperation between management and labor for full production.
Tammany Leader Frank J. Sampson gave his endorsement yesterday to Surrogate James A. Delehanty for re-election this fall, a move that appeared to insure the sitting jurist another year on the bench.

A strike by which employes of the Stock Exchange and the Curb Exchange, with the backing of workers in brokerage offices, had threatened to halt the activities of the nation's financial center was averted at 12:10 A.M. today by an agreement to arbitrate.

An appeal to American parents to provide educational supplies for parentless, homeless children held in detention camps on Cyprus was made yesterday by Mrs. David de Sola Pool, who just returned from a visit to Palestine and Cyprus as a representative of Hadassah.

By a vote of 1,163 to 66, the American Council of the Institute of Pacific Relations defeated yesterday a proposal by Alfred Kohlberg, an importer, for an investigation by a committee of outsiders into charges of Communist bias in its publications and professional staff.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 22 -- The Republican National Committee today unanimously adopted a resolution authorizing Carroll Reece, its chairman, to appoint the committee of arrangements for the Republican National Convention and its committee on rules and contests.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 22 -- Dr. W.A. Visser 't Hooft, general secretary of the World Council of Churches, said today that the impression that the council was "largely a Western and, more specifically, an Anglo-Saxon organization" was a major problem confronting its future relations with Eastern "Orthodox churches.

Classroom study of devices such as crutches, hearing aids and artificial limbs was advocated yesterday by Dr. Howard A. Rusk, associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, to allay youthful curiosity on the subject and save the wearers of the devices embarrassment.

An increase in the use of aluminum in home building and the extension of the utility core principal to include a complete prefabricated kitchen-bathroom-utility unit were among the developments discussed last evening by Harold R. Sleeper in a talk at the Metropolitan Home Show in Grand Central Palace.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- As the owner of 32,850 shares of convertible stock of the Eastern Utilities Associates, Roger W. Babson, the economist, appealed today for permission to participate in the "death sentence" proceedings instituted against the holding company and its subsidiaries by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The possibility of a court-directed dismissal of the charges against Julius Lobel, alias Jimmy Coliins, and Irving Cohen in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle case became apparent yesterday. The two men are being tried in King's County Court.

PARIS, April 22 -- This correspondent has just spent a few days in Warsaw with a definite purpose: To ascertain the true nature of the current Polish Government; whether it must be regarded as a tool of the Soviet Union or as a body of patriots exclusively intent upon safeguarding the country's independence.

Early buying of fur garments for next season is comparatively light, with caution being shown by both retailers and manufacturers. Sample lines are now being completed and broader buying activity by retailers is due about the middle of next month.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 22 -- Charles J. Boyle, retired executive vice president of Paul Block Associates, newspaper advertising representatives, died here yesterday morning at his home, the Chatsworth Gardens Apartments, after an illness of several years.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Many aspects of the vote in the Senate today on the Administration's bill to buttress Greece and Turkey against imported political communism must have been gratifying to the President -- among them, the number who voted in its favor, the more than 2-to-1 support by the Republicans and the small Democratic defection.

PALERMO, Sicily, April 22 -- Sicily swung sharply to the Left in the Parliamentary election Sunday and Monday. A nearly complete count shows the Socialists and Communists won an impressive victory over the centrist Christian Democrats and the Right Wing Qualunquists in the first regional Parliamentary elections in this century.

Serge M. Rubinstein, Russian-born financier charged with draft evasion, and two other men accused of conspiring with him in his efforts to avoid military service, were found guilty on all counts against them at 10:10 o'clock last night by a jury in the Federal Court here.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor authorized today a $1,500,000 "educational and publicity" campaign to combat Federal labor legislation. It asserted in a statement that Congress was "rushing headlong into one of the worst legislative blunders in history."

MOSCOW, April 22 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers agreed today to get its great experiment -- the Free Territory of Trieste -- off to a good start. The Big Four will request the United Nations to make available to the state's Governor up to $5,000,000 to finance its initial period of existence.

BERLIN, April 22 -- Brig. Gen. Robert A. McClure is reported to have protested against the forthcoming production of a play in the Russian sector as anti-American propaganda violating the Potsdam agreement. The protest appeared today in the Neue Zeitung, the American Military Government's paper.

A truck drove up to a New York pier at 11 A.M. on a recent day and the driver climbed down and presented his delivery order to the receiving desk. He had five tons of freight for a ship then loading for foreign ports.

The national retail summer millinery week got under way yesterday when the trade promotion committee of the Millinery Stabilization Commission presented the first of a trio of luncheons this week at the Hotel Pierce in the Cotillion Room.

Attention was centered on two main problems at the opening meetings of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday -- the newsprint shortage and labor relations.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Col. Ben C. Limb, Korean chairman of the Korean Commission here, declared today that Mr. Molotov's proposal for the resumption of Soviet-American conversations in Korea would make that country "a Communist puppet state, controlled by Moscow."
PARIS, April 22 -- In its first meeting, the new Representative Assembly of Madagascar adopted two resolutions today calling for action to suppress the uprising and adjourned.

JERUSALEM, April 22 -- The explosives with which the condemned terrorists, Moshe Barazani and Meir Feinstein, committed suicide last night were smuggled into the death cell in hollowed-out oranges, British police authorities said.

After a visit to their proposed training camp near Highland Mills, N.Y., the Hapoel soccer players from Palestine returned to New York City yesterday and will continue to make their headquarters at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn until their first game against a picked metropolitan eleven at the Yankee Stadium on May 4.

The Hospital Council of Greater New York unfolded its master plan for hospitals and related facilities at a dinner last night at the Commodore Hotel where the plan was acclaimed by leaders in the field of health and hospital service.

High bids aggregating $633,250 were listed for the seventeen properties offered at auction yesterday through Joseph P. Day. Inc., at the Hotel Commodore. The Manhattan and Queens parcels attracted lively bidding. Daniel J. McElveney Jr., conducted the sale.
Strict supervision of New York waterfront facilities is being maintained daily to prevent fires and explosions, such as those that devastated Texas City last week, it was learned yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, April 22 (AP) -- A couple of local keglers, Charley Darrington and Dick Hall, scoring a 1,284, moved into fifth place in the doubles event of the American Bowling Congress today, 72 points behind the leaders, Ed Doerr Jr. and Len Springmeyer of St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (U.P.) -- Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, tonight reaffirmed industry's pledge to aid President Truman's campaign to cut prices, but he said the Government "must do its part of the job if we hope to win this battle."

Miss Pauline Betz, Women's national tennis champion, arrived a La Guardia Field from Paris yesterday and hopes to come to a definite decision shortly as to whether or not to go through with her projected professional tour with Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Cooke.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 22 -- The corridors in the New York City Building at Flushing Meadow were mopped clean today, furniture was pushed into place, desks were dusted and lights tested. At the gates security guards were on duty.

PITTSBURGH, April 22 -- The settlement of a two-year wage contract with the United States Steel Corporation demonstrated that there is no need for restrictive labor legislation, Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, said today in a telegram to all United States Senators.

Hugh Baillie, president and general manager of The United Press, reported yesterday that the number of clients served by that news agency had reached a record total of 2,689 newspapers and radio stations. This figure, he said, excluded such special clients as magazines, radio commentators, steamships and executive offices.

The forms and methods used by official agencies in reporting bank earnings are antiquated and tend to confuse the public, members of the National Association of Bank Auditors and Comptrollers were told yesterday. Addressing the group's regional convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania, M.A. Schapiro, bank analyst, of M.A. Schapiro & Co., Inc., sharply criticized these data-collecting methods and also urged a greater uniformity in the preparation of statements by the banks themselves.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Aggressive buying of July wheat attributed to a professional trader, combined with reports that seeding of spring wheat was being delayed seriously in parts of the American and Canadian Northwest, gave that market a strong undertone today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (AP) -- Robert V. White, president of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting today that the company would not accept any reduction in the rental of the Lehigh Susquehanna Railroad as proposed in the reorganization plan filed for the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Few members of the Senate voted specifically today for President Truman's broad doctrine that "it must be the policy of the United States to support free peoples who are resisting attempted subjugation by armed minorities or outside pressures."

LONDON, April 22 -- A rash of unofficial strikes had Britain's labor leaders in a quandary today. The strikes have made several thousand workers idle and tied up transport, mining and production activities in a number of places.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 22 -- Freedom of the press here received another setback today when the Government indefinitely suspended two important opposition newspapers for publishing a speech by a Deputy criticizing the administration. The Government acted under the martial law still in force in six provinces around Istanbul -- theoretically, at least, because of the danger of foreign aggression.

The Army is concerned with clothes for the Arctic regions, and it is important for the textile industry to continue its development of apparel that will keep men warm in cold climates, Maj. Gen. Thomas B. Larkin, Quartermaster General, declared yesterday.

W.S.S, Rodgers, chairman of the Texas Company, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting here that charges made by James A. Moffett that the Arabian American Oil Company and the California - Texas Oil Company, Ltd., had defrauded the United States Navy in the sale of fuel oil and other products were "absolutely false."

Robert McLean of The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin was reeleeted president of The Associated Press yesterday by the board of directors. The board met at AP headquarters in Rockefeller Center. Six directors had been elected at the annual meeting of members at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Monday.

The nurses' residence to be built by the Helene Fuld Health Foundation of New York at 1830 Madison Avenue will cost $150,000, according to plans filed yesterday by York Sawyer, architects, with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

In active trading, the cotton futures market yesterday closed 37 to 74 points net higher than on Monday, led by the May and July, 1947, deliveries. It opened with gains of 1 to 12 points and worked upward under heavy price-fixing both for domestic and foreign, mills, augmented by commission house support.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, April 22 (AP) -- A special train bearing $25,000,000 worth of silver and art objects removed by the Germans from Hungary sped toward Budapest under heavy guard tonight, in a new gesture of American friendship toward Hungary, where the majority Smallholders party is under Communist pressure.

Twelve thousand workers assembled in Madison Square Park yesterday and gave vociferous support to a resolution calling on Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, to set aside a day for a nation-wide demonstration against the antilabor bills pending in Congress.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The war fraud trial of 'Andrew J. May, former chairman of the the House Military Affairs Committee, got off to a fast start today with selection of a jury in two hours.

MOSCOW, April 22 -- The Soviet Union has agreed to a revival of the joint Soviet-American Commission on Korea and an examination of its work by both Governments this summer. This has been disclosed in a letter received by Secretary of State Marshall from Foreign Minister Molotov and made public today.

A proposal that the nation's general hospitals provide special facilities for chronic or long-term, diseases was advanced yesterday by Dr. Vlado A. Getting, Commissioner of Public Health for Massachusetts.

"Paris Was Our Mistress: Memoirs of a Lost and Found Generation," by Samuel Putnam, an account of his seven years spent in Paris between wars, has been scheduled for May 2 by the Viking Press. Mr. Putnam, who has just received the Brazilian Pandia Caolgeras Prize for Literature and History for 1946, has been elected as a corresponding member of the Brazilian Academy of Letters, the number of which is limited to twenty.
ALBANY, April 22 (AP) -- Charles Garside, a lawyer of New York City, was appointed today by Governor Dewey as a member and chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Senate agreed today to begin tomorrow its great debate on labor legislation as its Labor committee filed divided and subdivided recommendations clearly foreshadowing a formidable controversy.

KALAMBAKA, Thessaly, April 23 -- Some 4,000 square kilometers of rebel-held territory, reaching from the east-west KalambakaMetsovo line southward nearly as far as Karpenisi, has been redeemed by the regular Greek Army since the full-scale operations began on April 9.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 23 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie declared today that any of the nine men suggested for the Trieste Governorship by Britain. France or the United States would be "well qualified."

VIENNA, April 23 -- The Austrian Socialist party, in its central organ, the Arbeiter Zeitung, called attention today to the circumstance that the leader of the Hungarian Socialists, Arpad Szakasitz, had issued an announcement at the Danubian Socialist Congress in Budapest that was contrary to decisions taken by Socialist party leaders in Prague.

W. Arthur Nickel, self-confessed "inside" man in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle, described himself yesterday as a "bewildered man," whose difficulties began when he followed the "instructions of other people."

In an ultimatum without precedent, the Actors Equity Association warned Washington's National Theatre yesterday to end its rule against Negroes in the audience within twelve months after June 1 or face an Equity-imposed ban that would keep all actors off its stage.

Although prices in industry generally are "clearly too high," banking "prices" for many services are at the lowest point in history and will have to be increased, Prof. Raymond Rodgers of New York University's School of Commerce asserted last night.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The nation-wide program of the newly organized National Association for the Employment of the Handicapped was outlined tonight by Maj. Gen. Graves B. Erskine, USMC, Federal Retraining and Re-employment Administrator, at a dinner session opening of the seventh annual meeting of the Women's Supreme Council of B'nai B'rith.
DETROIT, April 23 -- The Packard Motor Car Company produced its millionth car here today, a 1948 super eight convertible. Its first automobile was built in 1899.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Chairman J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, of the House Committee on Unamerican Activities, formally asked President Truman today to order Attorney General Tom C. Clark to prosecute Communists as "criminals and conspirators."

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Internal Revenue Bureau raised the objection of administrative difficulties and complicated tax return forms today to the House-passed bill for reduction of personal income taxes.

The first sessions of the fifth annual Conference of the Committee on Art Education, sponsored by the Museum of Modern Art, will take place today at the museum. The conference will continue through Sunday. Some of the meetings are open to the public on payment of an admission fee.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The National Retail Liquor Package Stores Association, Inc., 11 West Forty-second Street, New York, has been prohibited from conspiring to fix prices in the sale of liquors, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 23 -- The British Government is considering individual appeals to each of the United Nations to stop ships bound for Palestine with unauthorized Jewish immigrants, it was reported today.

Pull productive effort as demonstrated in the output of cotton textiles during 1946 and the first quarter of 1947 are the only antidote to inflation, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, stated yesterday.

The strike of 35,000 telephone workers in the metropolitan area reached the show-down stage yesterday, with the New York Telephone Company setting Saturday as the deadline for union acceptance of a plan for arbitration of all disputed issues, except the union shop and pensions.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 23 -- Dr. J. Hutchinson Cockburn, director of reconstruction and interchurch aid of the World Council of Churches, urged the Christian church today to expand and accelerate its work among European youth because "communism cannot be argued down, it must be lived down."

MOSCOW, April 23 -- United States Secretary of State Marshall proposed today that the Austrian peace settlement be submitted to the United Nations as the Council of Foreign Ministers' Moscow session neared its close in an atmosphere of sharp disagreement.
BERLIN, April 23 -- Charges and countercharges of meddling in Berlin's internal politics involved the Russian and American Military Governments at city levels in another squabble today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 23 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which has long refused to traffic with independent film producers, today announced the signing of its second contract for the distribution of an independently-produced picture within a month.

The victory of the slate headed by Representative W. Kingsland Macy in the fight for control of the National Republican Club was taken yesterday as an indication that the club would be united behind the candidacy of Governor Dewey for the Republican Presidential nomination.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned weak yesterday and closed 50 to 81 points net lower.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 23 -- The common headache in a large number of cages is due to the high tension of life in the modern world, Dr. Frank D. Carroll, associate in ophthalmology, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, declared today.

LONDON, April 23 -- The possibility that unionized British workers participating in unauthorized strikes would have their union cards canceled loomed here tonight as labor leaders sought means to check the current wave of outlaw stoppages.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Collaboration talks between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations appeared assured today although the time is still indefinite.

Considering the "awful beating" mothers have taken from the childcare experts, there is a temptation to "talk turkey to fathers," but reassurance is needed by parents, not blame, Dr. Carl Binger, Professor of Clinical Psychiatry, Cornell University Medical College, declared yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23 -- Harvard scored its second straight Eastern Intercollegiate League victory today at Soldiers Field, routing the Columbia nine, 13 -- 6.

LONDON, April 23 -- A fierce southerly gale from the Atlantic covered the whole of the British Isles today and, accompanied by heavy seas, played havoc with shipping around the coasts, especially in the English Channel and the North Sea.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- In an order made public tonight the Federal Communications Commission took action against the Broadcasting Service Organization, Inc., because of prolonged and continuous "wilful misrepresentations "regarding the stock ownership and financing of its Station WORL in Boston.

Reflecting an increase of $2,986,739 in sales of Franklin Simon Co., Inc., its net profit for the fiscal year ended with January exceeded the previous year's net by $409,691, according to the annual report yesterday by J. Howard Denny, president.

Maintaining their perfect record at Ebbets Field, the Dodgers made it two in a row over the Phillies yesterday. The 5-2 score fails to reflect the tension of a finish that almost, but not quite, thawed out the 8,812 frozen spectators.

Two new issues of foreign government dollar bonds aggregating $15,000,000 are among offerings of securities totaling $42,195,600 in par value to be made by underwriting managers here today. The offerings of foreign obligations are:

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Opposition to compulsory arbitration and support of labor's "right to strike" was voiced Today by Cyrus S. Ching, director of industrial and public relations of the United States Rubber Company, in an address at the final session of the National Wholesale Druggists Association in mid-year convention.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Administration's program to provide $350,000,000 in relief to distressed peoples in liberated countries ran into a determined demand in the House today that Russiandominated nations be barred from receiving such aid.
Seven-year-old Peter Boris Petroff, a polio victim, saw his first circus yesterday -- not at Madison Square Garden, but in the polio ward at Knickerbocker Hospital.

PARIS, April 23 -- A 7 per cent cut in the outlays of the ordinary budget was approved by the Cabinet today after a review of the financial situation by Finance Minister Robert Schuman, who declared a balanced budget would be necessary to avoid an emergency.

Several debutantes of this season are aiding members of the executive committee in the arrangements for the talk on contemporary art to be given by Roland McKinney this afternoon in the Crown Room at 711 Fifth Avenue in behalf of the Frontier Nursing Service.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 23 -- Mrs. Mary Chase Stratton, owner of the Pewabic Pottery Company, Detroit, tonight was awarded the 1947 Charles Fergus Binn's Medal for outstanding contribution to the ceramic industry.
War against high prices and inflation raged on a nation-wide scale yesterday.

PARIS, April 23 -- In three speeches in Paris today Henry A. Wallace cited a probable depression in the United States in the next few years as a factor that might make for war. He also gave a lengthy qualification of the charge he had made in Britain that the present United States foreign policy was imperialistic.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Wheat developed independent strength on the Board of Trade today and advanced cent 3/4 cents to 2 1/4 cents a bushel, July leading as the result of buying attributed to mills and commission houses. Closing trades were at about the top.

Despite the newsprint shortage, newspapers set new records last year for circulation and national advertising revenue and now "represent the largest mass product in existence today." Alfred B. Stanford, national director of the bureau of advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Spanish Prisoner racket, designed to fleece the gullible, is spreading throughout the United States again.

A brilliant pitching and hitting performance by Sandy Silverstein enabled New York University's baseball team to defeat Brooklyn College, 6 -- 4, yesterday at Ohio Field, and maintain undisputed possession of first placp in the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference with three victories and no defeats.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 23 (AP) -- Setting a world rerord. Stanley Sagner's Saggy today won the $5,000 added Aberdeen Stakes, a 2-year-old fixture. Turning on speed that sent Cedar Farm's Brandy Punch, an odds-on favorite, into defeat by four lengths.

The stock market made little headway yesterday and the close was narrowly mixed. Business again shrank, and to such an extent that the results of the session carried little meaning. There was slight bulge in a few key issues but the composite rate showed a rise of only 0.18 point.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- By a vote of 7 to 6 the Senate Banking Committee decided today to bring out for floor action the Taft-ElLender-Wagner long-range housing bill.

LONDON, April 23 -- Complaining that prices in the proposed fiveyear international wheat agreement were "excessive," Great Britain declined today to subscribe to an agreement worked out here in the last three weeks by the international wheat conference.

Reading the debates and following the maneuvers of the rival parties in Washington these days on taxes and the budget, the onlooker may be pardoned for wondering from time to time whether these are regarded primarily as matters of fiscal policy or of political strategy.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- A New York CIO delegation, here to oppose pending labor legislation, declined to discuss the matter with an aide or Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York, today because "all members" of the group were not permitted to be present.

TOKYO, April 23 -- More than 80 per cent of the votes cast last Sunday in the first of Japan's national elections have been counted tonight. Although complete results may not be known before Friday, it is now possible to get a fair picture of what the nation's new Upper House will be under the new Constitution.

Alliance Ware, Inc. Directors of Alliance Ware, Inc., have called a special meeting of stockholders for May 15 to vote on a proposal to split the common stock, two shares for one, it was announced yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, April 23 (U.P.) -- A veteran of twenty-four consecutive American Bowling Congress tournaments, 49-year-old Freddie Breckle of Detroit today went into first place in the singles with a 738 series.

BOSTON, April 23 -- Little hope for a halt in rising prices at this time is held by Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. On the contrary, the NAM executive said some are bound to go upward as a result of the recent round of wage increases.

JERUSALEM, April 23 -- For the first time since January, David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, visited the British High Commissioner, Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan Cunningham, for a political conference today. A special meeting of the agency's executive was summoned immediately afterward.

AVALON, N.J., April 23 -- Miss Edith M. Greenan, the only woman mayor in New Jersey, is now conducting a vigorous campaign for re-election. Her plea for votes rests on her administration's fiscal policies.

To regain the public prestige it has lost in the last few years, radio must stop appeasing "vocative" minority pressure groups and educators and serve the majority of its listeners, James D. Shouse, president of the Crosley Broadcasting Company declared yesterday afternoon in an address before the third annual City College Radio and Business Conference held at the Pauline Edwards Theatre, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Truman directed today that the Office of Temporary Controls be abolished June 1. The office was established Dec. 12, 1946, to administer vestigial remnants of the Office of Price Administration.

GENEVA, April 23 -- The practical job of reducing the barriers to world trade got off to a poor start today as dissatisfaction over the terms of the new French tariff spread among the other delegations at the Geneva Trade Conference.

Twenty members of the "Steinbugler clan" gathered in the home of Mrs. John Steinbugler, 88-yearold matriach of the family, at 94 Lenox Road, Brooklyn, a few nights ago, to celebrate the fact that their "maid-companion" had been with them for fifty-five years.

Declaring that "food prices generally have reached or passed their peak," Clarence Francis, chairman of the General Foods Corporation, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday that he considered the present trend a corrective one rather than a recession.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Senate's debate on labor legislation was opened today by Senator Robert A. Taft, of Ohio, with a declaration that a reduction in union power was the basis of the program to which he was pledged.
LONDON, April 23 -- Business in the stock markets today was light and conditions generally were dull.

The 180 tenants who are living rent-free at the Imperial Hotel will continue to do so for a while so far as Municipal Court Justice John M. Lewis is concerned. The court yesterday dismissed proceedings for eviction of the residential tenants, while continuing trial of similar action against business tenants occupying space on the hotel's two lowest floors.

NANKING, April 23 -- The organization of the new Chinese Government was completed today -- except for a few minor details -- with the appointment of twenty-six members of the Cabinet or Executive Yuan.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Registration statements covering $75,000,000 of debentures, $2,686,000 of bonds and 31,200 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two companies. A third withdrew a proposed public offering of 500,000 shares of capital stock.

BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, April 23 -- After more than six months of discussions, a four-power agreement has been reached on five steps in the drastic reform of Germany's financial structure, it was learned today.

The Port of New York Authority is preparing to take over on June 1 the New York airports and possibly the Newark Airport, it was announced yesterday. Its legal department has already sent to airlines holding leases from the city at Idlewild a form of release, to which, it was said, they have raised no substantial objection.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- The Cubs scattered their errors a little more harmlessly than the Reds today and took the rubber of their three-game series, 7 to 1. It was a loosely played contest that was marred by seven errors, the Reds having a 4-3 edge in the misplays.

Since the end of the war, New York City has lost more dwellings through demolition than have been provided through permanent new construction, figures of the City Department of Housing and Buildings showed yesterday.

Newspapers reduced their driving accident rate for delivery trucks in 1946 despite an increase in the national accident record, it was announced at yesterday's meeting of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it had a change of heart in its running feud with Fred Allen on the subject of vacation-minded vicepresidents in radio. It wanted, said NBC, to forgive and, especially, to forget.

MADRID, April 23 -- The Government of Generalissimo Francisco ranco has launched an offensive against Don Juan, pretender to the Spanish throne, both through efforts to restrict his supporters' political activities and through propaganda.

PALERMO, Sicily, April 23 -- One of the first measures that the Communist party in Sicily will sponsor when the regional Parliament opens in May will be the allocation of land to farmers, Girolamo Licausi, its leader, said today.

BOSTON, April 23 -- The Giants functioned today like a powerful machine harnessed to nothing at all. The result was another inelegant drubbing that left Manager Melvin Ott in a complete state of stupefaction as he pondered the answer.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is discouraging, to say the least, to have the President declare that if business doesn't voluntarily cut prices, he will support a rise in wages. The White House seems to ignore the root causes of the rise in the cost of living and good sense fails to let one grasp how an increase in wages is going to offset this rise.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Commerce announced today that American business, exclusive of agriculture, expects to spend about $13,900,000,000 this year for construction of a new plant and the purchase of new equipment, compared with $12,000,000,000 in 1946 and $6,600,000,000 in 1945.

Pointing out that much of the loss suffered between 1930 and 1940 could have been avoided by application of simple economic measures, Raymond Rubicam, chairman of research and policy of the Committee of Economic Development, called yesterday for improved market research to solve economic problems.

ST. LOUIS, April 23 (U.P.) -- The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company accepted tonight the Labor Department invitation to resume negotiations in Washington for a strike settlement, but said that it was "with the explicit understanding that no cash offer will be made."

Facing the Illinois Bonds With the record-breaking $300,000,000 State of Illinois veterans' bonus bond issue less than a week away, the confident temper of the current municipal bond market offers a striking contrast to the backing and filling and final retreat that marked its winter approach to the $200,000,000 Michigan bonus issue.

Much of the greatness and prosperity of New York City rests on the seaborne commerce that passes into or through its harbor. It is estimated that one of every ten workers in the 1,500square-mile port area earns his living directly or indirectly from harbor activities. The city is greatly blessed by its unique geographical affinity to sea and rivers.

LONDON, April 23 -- The Marquess of Queensberry married here today Mrs. Mimi Gore Chunn at Caxton Hall Registry Office. The ceremony was performed without a ring because the bridegroom had left it in his apartment. He put it on his bride's finger directly after they returned from the civil ceremony.
PARIS, April 23 -- Molyneux chooses the palest shrimp and lobster tones, the suave combination of lichen and lilac for midsummer prints, but for linen suits and frocks turquoise takes the lead.

In 1935 the United Hospital Fund surveyed the hospital resources and needs of the city and published its findings in a notable three-volume report. It turned out that we had no unified hospital system. Municipal hospitals, voluntary hospitals, private hospitals, institutions were scattered over the boroughs.

The Advertising Council annonced yesterday a nation-wide educational advertising campaign to promote public understanding of the American system of free enterprise and its advantages to every economic group.

The Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, hardware manufacturers, has entered the appliance field with an automatic electric iron known as "Tip Toe," it was announced yesterday. To support the retail sale of the iron the company will use national trade and consumer papers and, through cooperative advertising with retailers, local papers in all markets.

Textron, Inc., in its report for 1946, released for publication today, shows consolidated net earnings of $6,475,000 after excluding minority interest, earnings of subsidiaries prior to acquisitions and after a contingency reserve of $1,000,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of March 3 you published a report from your special correspondent in Prague according to which the Czechoslovak Government was considering a plan "to turn over the elaborate hotels and bathing establishments of the Czechoslovak spas to Czechoslovak social institutions as recreation centers for workers, mothers and ailing children."

LOS ANGELES, April 23 -- Kenyon J. Scudder, superintendent of the California Institution for Men, said today that environment, and not race and religion, determine social behavior and explain the history of crime.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am a Second World War veteran and a patient at the Bronx Veterans Hospital.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, made a start today toward fulfillment of his prediction of last week by making public two statements from industrial concerns announcing price reductions and promising conformity with President Truman's campaign against the high cost of living.

Hats of distinctive and individual character made up the second showing this week of the Millinery Stabilization Commission. It took place yesterday noon in the Cotillion Room of the Hotel Pierre. Each of the eight exhibitors entered three models.
PARIS, April 23 -- The United States maintained its dominant role of supplying large French imports in the first quarter of 1947, according to official customs figures issued today.

Not to Raise Fall Prices Shirt and pajama manufacturers will cooperate with President Truman's program by not raising prices for fall 1947 above present levels, it was resolved yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers.

The nation's food industry was called upon yesterday by one of its leaders to reduce and stabilize prices through industry-wide regulations or else accept a return of Government controls to avert "disorder and chaos."

Glass yarn is used instead of textile fabrics in the carcass of a new type of industrial hose announced at the Park Central Hotel yesterday by W.C. Winings, manager of the mechanical goods division of Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, Akron, Ohio.

James Lyons, a senior at the Boston University Department of Journalism and a contributor to THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review, won first prize yesterday in the sixth annual journalism essay contest conducted by the American Newspaper Publishers Association in cooperation with the American Council on Education for Journalism.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Republican Congress completed approving action today on a bill requiring that the great dam on the Colorado River in Black Canyon be called "Hoover Dam" and not "Boulder Dam," as at present.

John F. Ryan, executive vice president of the Newspaper Guild of New York, who had been labeled a Communist by Milton Murray, president of the national union organization, was one of fifteen delegates elected to represent the New York local at the American Newspaper Guild's national convention in Sioux City, Iowa, in June, according to official incomplete returns made public today at New York Guild headquarters, 40 East Fortieth Street.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Dismayed but not discouraged by the defeat of their candidate for Mayor of Chicago, Illinois Republicans are optimistic over the prospect of carrying the state in next year's Presidential election and are expected to put forward a "favorite son," probably Gov. Dwight H. Green.

BOSTON, April 23 (AP) -- Bel Reigh, Mrs. T. Christopher's 6year-old, romped to an easy victory in the feature race at Suffolk Downs today, defeating Oran Lodge Stables' Alberto D. by two lengths before a crowd of 14,516. R.B. Carroll's Winsome Lad finished third.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (AP) -- Relief Pitcher Tom Ferrick struck out Sam Chapman with two men on in the ninth to cut short a rally by the Athletics and give the Senators a 4-to-3 victory today over the Mackmen, who suffered their sixth straight setback.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The State Department's entire program for broadcasting the American way of life to the world has been doomed by an Appropriations subcommittee of the House of Representatives, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Labor Department began today a new and possibly final effort to end the strike of 330,000 telephone workers which began April 7.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., April 23 -- Soviet representatives on the United Nations Military Staff Committee want to have its report kept secret even after it is delivered to the Security Council on April 30, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Maritime Commission ended today a "pause" since February in the sale of surplus merchant ships to foreign buyers, resuming the program on a note of caution.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Senator Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire, whose investigation of a loan made to the Baltimore Ohio Railroad by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is developing into an inquiry into the whole record of the RFC, seeks always to be on the side of the angels.

THE trouble with John Fischer as a Russian expert is that he has been there. This, of course, is not an absolutely insurmountable hazard. But it is bound to put him at something of a disadvantage in facing the swarms of people who can tell you all about Russia and what our attitude toward her should be, unhampered by any cluttering first-hand evidence whatever.
W. Newall Wyatt has been appointed division sales manager in charge of dry cleaning specialties and industrial solvents, Westvaco Chlorine Products Corporation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 23 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, said today that he was reserving judgment on "some particular features" of the secretariat attached to the Balkans Investigation Commission.

MOSCOW, April 23 (AP) -- The text of United States Secretary of State George C. Marshall's statement on Austria at the Foreign Ministers' Conference: I should like to turn again to the matter of the Austrian treaty. I think we must decide now whether we can or cannot conclude an Austrian treaty here.

DETROIT, April 23 (AP) -- Loosing a broadside of five homers -- three of them in succession to tie a major league record -- the Tigers handed their first loss of the season to the White Sox today, 7 to 4.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Army and Navy circles were weighing today the possible effect of the testimony given yesterday by Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift. Marine Corps commandant, on the unification bill before the Senate Armed Services Committee.
PITTSBURGH, April 23 (AP) -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations signed what he regards as a two-year steel industry peace treaty today.
WARSAW, April 23 -- Official Poland is in the midst of celebrating the second anniversary of the Polish-Russian alliance.

Strong opposition to the return of Government controls and rationing of newsprint during the present shortage was expressed by speakers at yesterday's general session of the sixty-first annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Raising of undue hope among blind persons that their sight may be restored simply by corneal transplants was criticized yesterday by Miss Grace Harper, director of the State Commission for the Blind of the Department of Social Welfare.

The field of medical care was pictured yesterday as an experimental battleground with the nation's health at stake in a duel between protagonists of its advancement under a "free society" or a totalitarian system of government.

Morty Phillips makes cheesecake the way Pauline Betz plays tennis. We told you last November what a master of that dessert he is. Now he's branched out with something else, a superior sort of fruit tart, and we think he had spring entertaining in mind when he did it.

The state charged yesterday in Lower Manhattan Summons Court that the architectural concern of Thomas W. Lamb, Inc., which designed Madison Square Garden, the old Hippodrome, the Strand and Capitol Theatres and scores of other well-known buildings, was "illegally practicing architecture."

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Truman exercised his first veto against the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress today, and it appeared tonight to have been a mistake. The bill from which he withheld approval would have conferred special powers on the counsel for the Senate War Investigating Committee, of which he was chairman for most of World War II.

An early fall opening of a new production, "I Gotta Get Out," was announced yesterday by Herbert I. Harris and Lester Meyer, who have joined forces to form a new reducing partnership. Joseph fields and Ben Sher are the authors of the "comedy about racetrack characters."

A string of weather stations across northern Canada and the islands to the north, the construction of which has already been provided for, is to be the first step in strengthening America's new Arctic "frontier."

A recommendation for the creation of a national intertrade arbitration panel composed of members of the retail and ready-to-wear trades will be made to the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association by the vendors' relations committee of that organization, it was announced yesterday.

THERE were not many in sports who knew Charlie Bidwill, the owner of the Chicago Cardinals of the National Football League. In fact, not many had even heard about him until a couple of months ago, when he whisked the greatly sought Charlie Trippi of Georgia out from under the noses of Larry MacPhail and Dan Topping.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 23 -- Dr. William A. Holla, Westchester Health Commissioner, charged this afternoon that some physicians in the county were so interested in collecting private fees that they were uncooperative in the department's campaign to give free clinic vaccinations to residents during the current smallpox emergency.

General Vandegrift of the Marines has testified before a Senate committee that the Unification Bill approved by his Navy superiors and the Army leaves the future of the Marine Corps in doubt and subject to the prejudices of whoever is appointed Secretary of National Defense.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Pennsylvania gained its third straight Eastern Intercollegiate League victory in four starts by defeating Princeton, 7 to 4, today.

Serge M. Rubinstein, a man accustomed to having his own way and to overcoming problems beyond the imaginative scope of the average person, came four-square yesterday against an obstacle with which, temporarily at least, he was unable to cope.

Labor conditions on New York's 700-mile waterfront are causing untold waste and limiting the effectiveness of the port as a funnel through which vast quantities of foreign commerce pour, transport executives charge.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined 629,000 barrels, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the week they amounted to 105,592,000 barrels, against 106,221,000 a week earlier and 100,672,000 a year ago.

Lewis E. Lawes, for twenty-one years Warden of Sing Sing prison, said of himself that he believed "neither in coddling nor brutality." His philosophy, however, was tipped always on the side of humanity. More than any other man who served this state he brought its prisons out of medieval darkness into institutions that give erring men a chance to redeem themselves.

BOSTON, April 23 (AP) -- Associated Factory Mutuel Fire Insurance Companies, Inc., said today it expected to pay close to $950,000 for losses suffered by the Ludlow Manufacturing and Sales Company in the Texas City, Tex., disaster. The loss was partly reinsured, Associated said.

DETROIT, April 23 -- The General Motors Corporation will give its answer tomorrow morning to a proposal by the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, that apportionment of a 15 cent hourly wage increase be submitted to arbitration.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Andrew J. May, wartime chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee, plans to take the stand in Federal District Court to deny that he took bribes to obtain munitions contracts.
Proving the Obvious President Truman is apparently among those unmoved by our recent almost tearful protest against this free-enterprise America being asked to "prove" things that everybody knows.
ST. LOUIS, April 23 (AP) -- The last-place Cardinals fell before powerful Pirate bats today, 8 to 5, in a game that saw three home runs and seven pitchers, five of the hurlers for the Redbirds.

VIENNA, April 23 -- Allied figures disclosed today that all zones of Austria had exceeded their quotas of food deliveries for the first quarter of 1947 from domestic production except the Russian zone, which was far below its quota.

LONDON, April 23 -- The British Government's determination not to carry out any United Nations policy on Palestine of which it does not approve was put on record in a notable debate on Palestine in the House of Lords today.

Chilled by the weather, but thrilled by the magnificent 2-hit pitching of Allie Reynolds, a banner midweek crowd of 30,729 persons at the Stadium yesterday saw the Yankees blank the Red Sox 3 -- 0. It was the second successive shutout twirled by Reynolds, who whitewashed Washington, 7 -- 0, before President Truman last Friday.
FUSAN, Korea, April 22 (Delayed) -- This principal port of the United States zone of occupation in Korea is preparing to receive increasing amounts of shipments from the United States.

Increasing interracial and interreligious conflicts in the Boulevard -Prospect area of the East Bronx have been indicated by a threefold increase in juvenile delinquency there. This was reported yesterday in a survey made public by the Mayor's Committee on Unity and the Political Science and Sociology Departments of Hunter College.

Five eastern railroads carrying thousands of commuters in and out of the metropolitan area every day appealed yesterday to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a substantial increase in their commutation fare rates. Their representatives testified before a fourman ICC board headed by Burton Fuller at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.

Although net sales of Standard Brands, Inc., and its domestic subsidiaries in the first quarter of 1947 were 21 per cent higher than for the comparable period of last year, net income for the period declined from $3,667,555 to $3,188,135. James S. Adams, president, announced yesterday.

Low water temperatures continue to make life unhappy for the fly fishermen, although reports from some of the Catskill streams indicate occasional mid-day hatches, with a few anglers managing to take trout on the dry fly. Reports from Connecticut, New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania streams are about the same.

A message asserting that Henry A. Wallace's visit to France will set a "pattern in this One World for the free interchange of opinions between the leaders and the peoples of all nations of good-will was dispatched yesterday to the leaders of the major French political parties by more than seventy Americans.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- American educators have been converted to Federal aid for education by facing the hard facts about United States schools as disclosed by research, Dr. George F. Zook, president of the American Council on Education, told a Senate Education subcommittee today at a hearing on four Federal aid bills.

Fortune Gallo's San Carlo Opera Company opened its annual twelveday spring season with a performance of Bizet's "Carmen," last night at the Center Theatre. The ever-welcome masterpiece received an animated, smoothly moving presentation, that held the attention well and evoked marked enthusiasm from the large audience in attendance.
