LONDON, April 23 -- The Earl of Listowel, the new Secretary of State for India, assumed his post at the India Office today. It is a position in which he has the commiseration as well as the congratulations of his colleagues.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 23 -- Comparing the world today with Europe in the seventh and eighth centuries, when there had been "a period of barbarian aggression not unlike that which we have recently been through," Prof. C. Rufus Morey, cultural attache for the State Department in Rome, warned 100 scholars at the Princeton Graduate College tonight that we are heading for a humanistic depression.

Financial advertisements, for the most part, are "sober, pompous, polysyllabic," and generally ineffective, Mrs. Bernice Fitz-Gibbon, advertising director for Gimbel Bros., Inc., asserted yesterday at a meeting of the Financial Advertisers Association of New York at the Lawyers Club.

Gerhart Eisler, who has been called the Communist "mastermind" in the United States, asserted here yesterday that his release on $20,000 bail after ten weeks of imprisonment was tantamount to a "confession of guilt" by the Department of Justice.

Gregory V. Stadnik, 42 years old, a member of the Ukrainian delegation to the United Nations, who was wounded in a delicatessen store hold-up here last Nov. 21, is still a patient in Roosevelt Hospital, it was learned here yesterday.

Summer fashions for both day and evening were the theme of Arnold Constable's showing yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Majoring in styles for the sun and surf, they presented a complete group in a clear, bright shade of yellow.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 23 (AP) -- The Navy said today it was in the process of holding courts-martial for four Marine guards and two prisoners accused of abusing inmates in the North Severn brig at the Naval Academy.

Rallying for three runs in the top half of the sixth, Fordham's baseball team registered its first Metropolitan Collegiate Conference victory in three starts yesterday by topping St. John's University, 4 to 3, at Dexter Park, Woodhaven.

Despite the failure of certain business groups to support the present Salvation Army drive for $1,000,000, because of its withdrawal last year from the Greater New York Fund, $923,000 has been collected to date, it was reported yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the advisory board in the Wall Street Club, 40 Wall Street.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 23 (AP) -- A proposal went before the National Association of State Racing Commissioners today to form a bureau to collect and disseminate data about applicants for racing licenses.
MOSCOW, April 23 -- The Big Four agreed today to repatriate about 2,000,000 German prisoners of war before the end of next year.

Enraged at the sexton of Congregation Sheveth Achem, 551 East 169th Street, the Bronx, who had prevented their attempt to steal sacred silver objects, one of two youths returned and brutally beat him yesterday.

A vacancy has existed since November on the United States District Court bench for the Southern District of New York. There have been many reports of candidates under consideration for this lifetime position, and various considerations, chiefly political in character, have been assigned to the reported candidacies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today announced the purchase of screen rights to "Command Decision," a novel by William Wister Haines, as a future vehicle for Clark Gable. The story deals with political interference in the United States Army Air Forces during the war, and was acquired by Metro at Gable's request, according to the studio announcement.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Department of Justice objected today to proposed legislation to allow steamship companies to operate overseas airlines, saying it might lead to "monopoly and restraint of competition."

The stock market was unable yesterday to retain the slight margin of advantage obtained earlier in the week and, while the composite rate fell only about 1/2 point, there were a few wider losses in some key issues. A few of the recently depressed stocks, such as Schenley, found support but elsewhere interest contracted to a minimum, with frequent lags on the ticker tape.

Concern over the reported elimination of funds for the State Department's information and cultural activities, including the Voice of America program, was expressed yesterday by Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick and Dr. George Shuster at a seminar in The New York Times Hall, 240 West Fortyfourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The proposed merger of Northwestern Electric Company with Pacific Power and Light Company together with related transactions was sanctioned today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, subject to the usual terms and conditions.

LOS ANGELES, April 24 (U.P.) -- Leo Rollick of Santa Monica today dropped his American Bowling Congress singles title when he could muster only a score of 615, not sufficient to place him among the first 20 in that event. Rollick also failed to finish among allevents leaders as he chalked up a score of 1,843, compared with the 1944 mark hung up by Hank Lauman of St. Louis, leader in that class.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- Showing a conciliatory approach toward Hollywood's long labor unrest, the major motion picture studios today reversed previous policy and invited the International Brotherhood of Painters, AFL, leading element of the seven-month studio strike, to take part in discussions aimed at settlement of the conflict.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Labor Department completed plans for an intensive series of conferences in Washington tomorrow with a view to settling the strike of 330,000 telephone workers.

If and as manpower becomes available, there is a civic need that requires attention over wide areas of the nation. Since the beginning of the war little attention has been paid to the roadside improvement program that was making progress in the latter part of the Thirties.

Acts of terrorism in Palestine will only mean retaliation and eventual destruction of the Palestine economy, Mrs. David L. Isaacs, vice president of the Women's League for Palestine, declared yesterday at the organization's annual luncheon in the Hotel Astor.

Plans of the State Housing Commission said the City Housing Authority to erect public housing on virgin vacant land were condemned by George H. Gray, President of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board, at the board's April luncheon and conference yesterday at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.

Calling for vigorous leadership on the part of the United States with respect to its foreign policy, particularly in the Middle East, Sosthenes Behn, president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, backed President Truman's program of immediate aid to Greece and Turkey in his annual report to stockholders for 1946 issued for release today.

JERUSALEM, April 24 -- After his political conference yesterday with David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, the British High Commissioner, Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan Cunningham, made a flying visit today to British Middle East Military Headquarters in Fayid, in the Suez Canal Zone.

Following a spending spree in which the police say he went through $15,000 that had been obtained by fraudulently cashing in fourteen tickets for flights to distant points, Larry Stokes, 28-yearold former airlines reservation clerk, was held yesterday in $1,000 bail by Magistrate Philip Thurston in Felony Court for a hearing May 1 on a grand larceny charge.

Expansion and strengthening of the State Department's overseas information program rather than its curtailment was urged in a petition forwarded yesterday to the House Appropriations Committee as well as to leaders of both parties in Congress.

Tibor Serly conducted a string orchestra of twenty-four players last night at Town Hall, in the first of several concerts which he plans to present in this city, under the sponsorship of song writers, arrangers and radio conductors from the commerical music field.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 24 (AP) -- The blast which Ohio State football mentor Wes Fesler fired at southern coaches and colleges a couple of weeks ago has proved somewhat of a boomerang.

The Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation had a consolidated net profit in 1946 of $12,187,805 after $7,390,000 provision for taxes, or double the 1945 net of $6,031,085, after $5,740,000 tax charges, the annual report of N. Peter Rathvon, president, showed yesterday.

The Republican leadership in Congress has fumbled some of its opportunities. On the paramount issue of union labor correctives enough Republicans have broken away in the Senate committee to water down these correctives considerably. But, as between the administration and the majority leadership in Congress, the latter has held to what in November, 1946, was clearly the overwhelmingly popular side, while the administration has continued to hold to the other.

A gloomy picture of economic conditions in Europe in terms of inflation, flight from national currencies, continued food shortages exhaustion of coal reserves and growing Russian influence in trade was described yesterday by Joshua B. Powers, president, Joshua B. Powers, Inc., international publishers representative.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- During the week ended April 23, member bank reserve balances decreased $167,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Earmarking of $500,000,000 for teachers' salaries in annual Federal aid to education of "not less than a billion" was urged today by the American Federation of Labor before a Senate Education Subcommittee.

AMSTERDAM, April 24 -- The necessity of restricting imports to help adjust the Netherlands' adverse balance of trade was emphasized by Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck in a foreign-exchange statement published today. The Government has set up a "priorities committee" under Mr. Lieftinck to revise the entire imports program.

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department ot Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 6,000 head: total, 8,500; market fairly active. 50 cents to $1 higher; mostly 75 cents to $1 up on weights under 250 pounds; sows around 50 cents higher, but most hogs over 300 pounds old late with advance lost; ...

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., April 24 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and five other American civic groups joined today in an appeal to the United Nations to keep Britain and the Arab states off the proposed commission of investigation on Palestine.

LONDON, April 24 -- Navigational facilities in Southampton harbor were defended today by M.G.J. McHaffie, chairman of the Works and Harbor Committee. The chairman declared at a meeting of the Southampton Harbor Board that the grounding of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth, was not due to lack of navigational aids.
Bernard Schachter, for the past four years head of the boys' department at Abraham Straus, has been appointed merchandising director and buyer of the boys' division of Bond Stores, effective May 26.

Those Fatal hours The five-day work week is still so new and so short of universal application that it is much too early to say what the effect of increased leisure will be on crime. Old-fashioned folk, of course, will recall that Satan finds work for idle hands, but this smacks strongly of bias.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Gordon R. Clapp was confirmed today by the Senate, 36 to 31, to be chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, succeeding David E. Lilienthal.

Many plays, both here and abroad, have borne Ferenc Molnar's imprint. Even when he was the cynosure of Alt Wien or Budapest, rarely a season went by -- or so it seemed -- without one of his plays making the overseas trip to Broadway.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- Liquidation developed in corn futures on the Board of Trade today, and with stop-loss orders uncovered closing trades were at losses of 1 1/4 to 2 3/4 cents. Wheat was affected by the action of corn and finished 1/4 to 1 3/4 cents lower, with May leading.

PARIS, April 24 -- France "must remain a democratic republic -- free of dictatorship aspirations -- not only in the interests of her people, but in the interests of the world," Henry A. Wallace told the French people tonight.

When the housewife stops at the fish counter while doing her weekend marketing today, she'll notice a greater variety than there has been for some time. Boston mackerel, shad and strawberry bass (alias croakers) are making their spring appearances while old standbys such as cod and flounder are also plentiful.

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- Pat Seerey and Don Black blended their talents in behalf of the Indians today as the Tribe scored its fourth straight victory with a 1-0 decision over the White Sox. Black threw a four-hitter to gain his second pitching success on a margin supplied by Pat Seerey's secondinning home run.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 24 -- There was a touch of sadness on both sides this afternoon when, after a ten-week visit to South Africa, the British royal family stood on the turret of the battleship Vanguard as she slipped her moorings and steamed out of Table Bay, then out of sight.

Reporting on operations of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended with last January, Bernard F. Gimbel, president, in the annual statement to stockholders, announced that sales rose for the eighth consecutive year, to $293,352,489, a volume greater than that of any previous year in the company's history, and an increase of $63,257,490, or 27.5 per cent over the previous fiscal year.
With about 5,000,000 New Yorkers vaccinated, the city planned yesterday the gradual shutdown of its free, public immunization stations.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 24 -- China announced today that she would become a member of the International Refugee Organization and share in its budget.

Good news for prospective summer excursionists on Long Island Sound came yesterday from Todd Shipyards Corporation's Hoboken division, which is preparing the familiar Americana and the recently purchased Naushon for passenger service between New York, Rye and Bridgeport.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- A threat of a 1944 campaign fund expose "involving high Democratic party officials" came today from the defense at the war fraud trial of Andrew J. May, former House Military Affairs Committee chairman.

Frank J. Sampson's plans for the reorganization of Tammany Hall won approval yesterday afternoon, without opposition, at a meeting of the Democratic executive committee and at a night meeting of the full county committee at Haaren High School, Tenth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Merchants in scattered cities climbed yesterday aboard the bandwagon of the "Newburyport Plan" for an across-the-board cut of 10 per cent in prices, but there was little if any sign of immediate price cuts at sources of production.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Creation of a small group of private citizens to advise this Government on foreign policies, and thus avoid many pitfalls, was suggested tonight by Charles Cheney Hyde, president of the American Society of International Law.

The Book-of-the-Month Club reports it has selected for July Natalie Anderson Scott's "The Story of Mrs. Murphy." The novel, chronicling the decline and fall of an alcoholic, will be published by Dutton. The Club also has taken as reserve selections "The Money Man," by Thomas Costain, to be published by Doubleday, and "The Red Danube," by Bruce Marshall, which will be published by Houghton Mifflin.
BOSTON, April 24 -- The Giants hit four gorgeous home runs today, three by big Jawn Mize, the fourth by Walker Cooper, but the Braves played a far craftier game.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Against a mounting background of Marine Corps opposition to the proposed Army-Navy unification bill, Senator E.V. Robertson. Republican, of Wyoming, anti-unification leader, demanded today that various so-called "secret" papers alleged to be aimed at establishing Army dominance be produced at the hearings.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Grainimporting nations of Western Europe are appealing to the United States, Canada and Australia for extra shipments of wheat to avert a bread crisis before the new crops of the Northern Hemisphere are harvested, it was revealed today.

LONDON, April 24 -- A five months' ban on the use of gas or electricity for heating purposes will be invoked for all British homes on May 5, Emanuel Shinwell, Minister of Fuel and Power, announced in the House of Commons today.

Special Sessions Justice Matthew J. Troy of Brooklyn called yesterday on the State Legislature to repeal the ban on off-the-track betting on the ground that the anti-bookmaking law was unenforceable and worked a hardship on returned war veterans who want to gamble a few dollars on the horse races.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Approximately 200,000 Jews in Germany and Austria must migrate elsewhere, with Palestine and the United States offering about the only alternatives, in the view of one official spokesman who returned to Washington today.

Walter S. Franklin, vice president in charge of traffic on the Long Island Rail Road, yesterday promised his company would spend an additional $675,000 for improvements to the railroad's property in Suffolk County if its petition for increased fares was approved by the Public Service Commission.

PITTSBURGH, April 24 (AP) -- Andy Pafko and Phil Cavarretta did the distance hitting for the Cubs today, but it was Don Johnson's single which defeated the leagueleading Pirates, 6 -- 5, before a chilled Ladies' Day crowd of 8,891.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- A Democratic minority moved up to the line and into the redoubts today against the Taft Senate labor bill, which already was drawing formidable support from Southern conservatives.

Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, announced last night that his three railroads -- the C. O., Pere Marquette, and Nickel Plate -- are embarking on a $100,000,000 program of capital expenditures.
TRIKKALA, Greece, April 24 -- This is a hard battle that is being waged against the rebel forces here in the rocky heart of Continental Greece.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (AP) -- Despite the potent presence of Herb McKenley, one of the world's greatest quarter-milers, Illinois may find the running tough in defending its 1946 laurels against Manhattan and New York University in the annual Penn Relays tomorrow and Saturday.

MUNICH, Germany, April 24 -- The Central Committee of Jews in the United States zone and a council composed of 219 representatives of 211 Jewish camps and communities today begged the United Nations to open the gates of Palestine.

There is a possibility that the first really good week-end for the fly fisherman is now coming up, for streams are dropping and water temperatures rising, and the happiness or despair of thousands of anglers now rests with the weather man.
MOSCOW, April 24 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers concluded its Moscow meeting at 7:45 o'clock this evening after forty-four sessions of largely fruitless discussion.

LONDON, April 24 -- Refusal of the United States to pay more than 20.4 cents a pound for natural rubber was criticized by F.D. Ascoli, chairman of British Rubber Growers Association, at the organization's annual meeting today.

TO THE EDTIOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: What price our recent world war catastrophe, when, at this point in time, April 20, the report of Thomas J. Hamilton in THE NEW YORK TIMES on the million displaced persons in Europe is headlined "Fate of Refugees Still Unresolved."

MOSCOW, April 24 -- The Big Four agreed today to cut the strength of their occupation forces in Germany. This signal victory for the United States policy was embodied in a directive to the Allied Control Council in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to uphold the validity of the Lea Act under which the Government sought to convict James C. Petrillo of coercing a radio station into hiring "stand-in" musicians "not needed to perform actual services."
Shortages of radio operators for American merchant ships were reported here yesterday by two maritime unions.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Specific recommendations for handling the Greek economic situation were made today in a comprehensive report by the European representative of the American Federation of Labor. He urged that the federation has a basic responsibility toward assisting the Greek workers to create a united, free, tradeunion movement.

The Question House at the Bronx Zoo opens tomorrow, ready for any poser from young visitors. Boys and girls are invited to take their questions to the experts. Open weekdays from 1 to 5 P.M., Saturday and Sunday, 1 to 5:30. The hundred millionth visitor to the Zoo is expected to pass through the turnstiles some time this week-end.

The cargo-passenger vessel African Glade will leave Thirtythird Street, Brooklyn, this evening, marking the initial departure in the American South African Line's new service to West Africa. Until now the company has been identified only with the South and East African route.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Truman made it clear today that he planned no stronger action calculated to lower prices and indicated that if manufacturers and businessmen insisted on pricing their products out of the market it would be their own funeral.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 24 (AP) -- Bring on the Derby crowd. Louisville is all set for it.

The outlook for settlement of the eighteen-day-old strike of 35,000 New York telephone workers dimmed last night when union leaders complained that a company approved arbitration plan was so vague they could not tell whether it merited serious consideration.

The annual series of Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Memorial Concerts by the Goldman Band, under Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, will be presented from June 13 to Aug. 10, Harry F. Guggenheim, president of the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The House Republican leadership headed tonight into what promised to be its major test on the prime party issue of budget-slashing.

CLEVELAND, April 24 (AP) -- The Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company today elevated Edward B. Greene from president to chairman of the board and indicated in a proxy statement that he would serve as chairman of a proposed $90,000,000 concern to be formed by a merger of the company and the Cliffs Corporation.

The annual exhibition of work by junior members and non-members of junior age has opened at the National Arts Club and will continue through May 18. Included in the show are ninety-two paintings, fourteen black-and-whites and seventeen pieces of sculpture.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Papers of a scientific, historic and cultural nature were presented at the opening sessions today of the annual general meeting of the American Philosophical Society.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 24 -- The marriage of Miss Jean Caroline Manice, daughter of Mrs. Dorothy J. Manice of this city, to Edward Kirkley Holland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward I. Holland of New York, took place this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary's-on-the-Hill.

A fashion show with popcorn, pink champagne and spun sugar candy was held yesterday in the executive dining room of Macy's in celebration of its "circus fantasies." These were amusing and refreshing summer cotton and spun rayons fashioned after the original circus costumes designed by Miles White for the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.

MOSCOW, Friday April 25 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, Republican adviser to Secretary of State Marshall, said today that the United States had hammered out in the Foreign Ministers conference "specific policies which in the long run should accomplish more than agreements which inevitably would have involved much compromise."

Bringing to a close a series of shows, the Millinery Stabilization Commission and Millinery Fashion Bureau presented hats of eight designers yesterday in the Hotel Pierre. Marked by lightness and a prophetic trend toward size, the hats represented the talents of Lilly Dache, John-Frederics, Sally Victor, Anita Andra, Emme, Lenesta, Mary Goodfellow and Mago Hayes.

Provision in the Robinson-Patman Act which makes it unlawful for a seller to grant any privilege to some purchasers unless he offers it to all, leaves no doubt that unjustified returns are in violation of the act, Samuel Blumberg, counsel to the Textile Fabrics Association, declared yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 24 -- Two hundred New York patrolmen and twenty-five members of the old Allen and Bomb Squad will be on duty with fifty United Nations guards at next week's Palestine debates of the special General Assembly.

GENEVA, April 24 -- The United States has officially expressed its astonishment at the "skyscraper" levels of duties proposed in the new French tariff. This sentiment was conveyed by William L. Clayton. United States Under-Secretary of State, to Pierre Baraduc, acting head of the French delegation to the Geneva Trade Conference.

AS the sporting world moves along through its second post-war year, it becomes increasingly evident that 1946 was the "Year of the Ruptured Duck," an extra season that returning service men required to shake loose from their GI jitters and get back to the form of their pre-war days. We noticed it in basketball and we are noticing it more and more every day in baseball.

A first-class pitching effort by young Frank Shea in his debut as a starter was nullified by the eve more brilliant performance of Tex Hughson, with the result that the Yankees dropped the final game of their series with the Red Sox yesterday.

Total sales of frozen poultry, fish and meat will quadruple 1946 sales to consumers within the next five years, Carl Kolb, president, Eastern Frosted Foods Association, said yesterday. This total offers a potential volume of $300,000,000 for the industry, he said at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Continuing declines for agricultural commodities caused a decrease of 0.6 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended April 19, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Representatives of thousands of commuters using the Delaware, Lackawanna Western and Erie railroads raised strong objections yesterday to the attempts of the two lines to win from the Interstate Commerce Commission major increases in their commuter fare rates.

BERLIN, April 24 -- There are 370,000 displaced persons in camps in the American zone and the UNRRA's director here, Paul Edwards, asked today: "Who is going to get breakfast for them on the morning of July 1?"

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- When Secretary of State Marshall returns to Washington this weekend from Moscow, he will have a new policy planning staff to assist him in preparation for the "second round" with the Russians next November.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association took a stand yesterday in favor of arbitration for the settlement of labor-management disputes and received a committee report opposing industry -wide bargaining and nationwide standardization of contracts as destructive to competition and the welfare of small newspapers.

Minimizing the threat of inflation "if some people in Washington stop throwing wrenches into machinery they know nothing about," Lewis H. Brown, chairman of the board of the Johns-Manville Corporation, said yesterday that "90 per cent of the American people are now and will continue to be relatively better off than in the past."

Private Placements The register of 1947 private placements publicly reported is still short of that for the last quarter of 1946 in aggregate of capital involved, but not in number of transactions. So far more than twenty negotiated placements of $1,000,000 or more have been reported totaling more than $220,000,000.

DETROIT, April 24 (AP) -- The Browns' only winning pitcher, Jack Kramer, handcuffed the Tigers with three singles today for a 6-to-1 victory that was his -- and the Browns' -- second triumph of the season.
PARIS, April 24 -- Former President Charles de Gaulle's policy in the present world emergency coincides with President Truman's, he declared today at a press conference.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 24 (AP) -- George P. Mahoney, due to be replaced July 1 as chairman of the Maryland State Racing Commission, drew a vote of confidence today from the National Association Of State Racing Commissioners. The group named Mahoney third vice president.

Joe Louis will be seen in ring action only two more times, and then the Brown Bomber will hang up his gloves. In a conference yesterday with Sol Strauss, acting head of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, the heavyweight champion decided to forego a fight this June, expressed himself in favor of a September outing, another some time in 1948, then retirement.

ALBANY, April 24 -- A court action against the city of Albany was threatened today by Arthur J. Harvey, counsel for the Carver Cultural Society of the Israel Methodist Church, following cancellation by the Board of Education of permission for use of the Philip Livingston Junior High School auditorium for a recital by Paul Robeson, Negro singer.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Government today formally lowered its estimate of the volume of new construction and home-building which will be completed this year.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 19 were 865,846 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 107,680 cars, or 14.2 per cent more than for the preceding week, 215,003 cars, or 33.0 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 1,146 cars, or 0.1 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 24 -- Prof. Dmitri V. Skobeltsyn, member of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, attacked what he called the United States, "monopoly" in atomic energy today as the most dangerous factor in the international atomic picture.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 24 -- From a maze of Westchester parkway and throughway plans being drafted by State and local governments, county officials sorted out today twenty-six miles of construction scheduled for early contract and eighty-four miles of other work that is needed but not so urgently.

KANSAS CITY, April 24 (AP) -- Lamotte T. Cohu of Hawthorne, Calif., was elected president of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., today by the board of directors, succeeding Jack Frye, who resigned recently following differences over management with the principal stockholder, Howard Hughes.

Displaying a bit more pugnacity but no more run-making talent, the Phils yesterday completed a three-game losing cycle at Ebbets Field, having counted only two runs in twenty-seven innings of abortive effort.

DETROIT, April 24 -- The wage dispute involving 220,000 General Motors workers was settled tonight on the basis of an 11 1/2-cent hourly increase as the way was pointed to the auto industry's new pay pattern for 1947.
Price reductions in the wholesale markets here have been "spasmodic" and so far do not represent any broad movement toward lower levels, resident buying offices here reported yesterday.

Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio said last night he did not see why President Truman should veto a labor bill enacted by Congress in the "reasonable" spirit of the present Senate bill and that he regarded the President as "absolutely illogical" in opposing tax reductions while urging that mass purchasing power be kept up.

DETROIT, April 24 -- More than 250,000 Detroit automobile and allied workers left their jobs here this afternoon in response to a call from the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, to attend a union mass meeting in Cadillac Square in front of the City Hall to protest pending labor legislation.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., in the first quarter of this year had estimated net earnings of about $19,000,000 after charges and taxes, B. Brewster Jennings, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting held here yesterday.

KWANGJU, Korea, April 24 -- This South Korea city of 120,000 took a holiday today to greet Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander in Korea. He is on a week's inspection tour of military installations in the United States occupation zone.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Robert M. Littlejohn, War Assets Administrator, asked Congress today to end by Dec. 31 the Government's priority system for disposal of all surplus property except real estate.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- Representative Clifford R. Hope, Republican, of Kansas, chairman of the House Committee on Agriculture, called tonight for a national policy with respect to agriculture. He urged more cooperation between farmers and business men and emphasized the need for a free economy that would eliminate monopolies in business, labor and agriculture.

America is equipped to outdo war production in the decade 1950 to 1960 and thus provide people with more goods and services than at the wartime peak and with fewer hours of work, according to a Twentieth Century Fund economic survey, three years in the making, which has just been completed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: President Truman recently issued an executive order prescribing procedures for administering an Employes Loyalty Program. The Council for Democracy emphatically agrees with the purpose of insuring full loyalty to the United States on the part of federal employes and providing protection against "infiltration of disloyal persons."

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 24 -- Britain's contribution to relief and rehabilitation already has reached $3,000,000,000, Lord Inverchapel, British Ambassador to the United States, asserted here today in a luncheon address to the Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce.

LONDON, April 24 -- The largest conference of the British Liberal party in thirty years, at its opening meeting in Bournemouth today, repudiated Henry A. Wallace's foreign policy ideas and, after a lively debate, endorsed the new Truman Doctrine.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 24 -- Providing the best possible medical care for children and adults in low-income families is the paramount problem facing the medical profession today, it was reported at the closing session here today of the 181st annual meeting of the Medical Society of New Jersey.

Under the apt title of "Unfinished Business," the New York Community Trust has published its report for 1946, proving again that its services to scores of deserving charities are limitless and that its business is indeed, in the most humanitarian sense, unfinished. Last year the Trust, whose total resources available for philanthropic work now amount to $17,543,536, gave $580,059 to some 130 charitable organizations.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Truman declined to give ground today on yesterday's veto of a bill to confer special powers on the counsel for the Senate War Investigating Committee. It was the first veto message he has sent to the Republican-dominated Eightieth Congress.
LONDON, April 24 -- Business in the stock markets today again failed to show any signs of expansion.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The House Banking Committee approved today a bill continuing rent control without a general increase until Dec. 31, 1947, or until March 31, 1948, if the need for the threemonth extension were certified by Presidential proclamation.

Another New York landmark was prepared for oblivion last night, as the Murray Hill Hotel officially closed. The closing was "official" because, actually, several dozen persons were spending a last night in the hostelry that since 1884 had served the city's most famous residents and visitors.

Human characteristics to which the industrial system accords little or no recognition can be used by both labor and management to develop living standards higher than those of the past and providing more economic security for all H. F. Willkie, vice president, Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., Louisville, Ky., declared yesterday.

AT NATIONALIST-COMMUNIST FRONT LINE, on the Sungari River, Manchuria, April 24 -- Maj. Robert B. Rigg and Capt. John W. Collins were freed today by the Chinese Communists after fifty-five days in captivity.

I was very much shocked to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 23 the article by Pertinax, representing the North American Newspaper Alliance, in a dispatch from Paris dated April 22, concerning his talk with the Premier of the present Polish Government, M. Joseph Cyrankiewicz.

Six signatory officers of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company, all of whom signed checks that allegedly were cashed by Julius Lobel, alias Jimmy Collins, testified yesterday in Kings County Court that it has been customary for them to write checks after a superficial examination of supporting data.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 24 -- The Provisional Committee of the World Council of Churches recommended a program today which would limit press representation at some sessions of the council's first assembly and bar reporters from certain other meetings during the international conference.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 19 were 6 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Soviet policies and their effect on the United States future foreign program are expected to be subjected to an intense review by Secretary of State Marshall after his return to the capital.

Employment in the advertising field currently is better than average, according to Walter A. Lowen, head of a placement agency bearing his name. He stated yesterday that his agency has more than 500 open orders for all types of advertising personnel which includes 108 jobs paying $7,500 or more annually.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed barely steady, 60 points lower to 17 points higher.

Bridal Flower, who was generally regarded as the queen of the 3-year-old fillies last year, made a triumphant return to the races at Jamaica yesterday, when she gained a last-stride decision in the $6,000 added Swivel Handicap.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- John W. Hanes, former UnderSecretary of the Treasury, predicted today that favorable Congressional action on tax reduction and budget-cutting would arrest the stock market decline.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., April 24 -- The United States wants the impending report of the United Nations Military Staff Committee published as soon as it is circulated to the Security Council, the American delegation here announced today.

Actors Equity Association served notice yesterday on the League of New York Theatres, organization of theatre owners, operators and producers, that unless the League agrees to conform with Equity's policy against racial discrimination at the National Theatre in Washington there will be no basic agreement between the two groups.

E. G. Grace, chairman of the board, announced yesterday that the Bethlehem Steel Corporation had granted a wage increase of 15 cents an hour to employes. In disclosing that his company had followed the pattern set by the United States Steel Corporation, Mr. Grace asserted that the increase places the steel industry in a precarious position, has precluded any reductions in steel prices and has aggravated "the inflationary spiral."

AGAWAM, Mass., April 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Fanny Dixon Welch, former Democratic National Committeewoman from Connecticut, died here today at the home of a daughter. She had been in ill health for some time. She had lived in Columbia, Conn., for forty years.

Every time a home owner adds a wing to his house or even a dormer window he is producing architecture, Thomas H. Creighton, editor of Progressive Architecture, said last night. He urged that home builders stop being afraid of architecture and learn to make full use of good design to solve individual living problems as well as the broad social housing problem.

Francis D. Quimet, vice president of the United States Golf Association and non-playing captain of the American Walker Cup team, refused yesterday to make any predictions as to how his charges will fare in the international matches at St. Andrews.
Despite a threat by dairy farmers serving this area that they may strike if the price of milk drops still further, major milk dealers here announced a 1-cent-a-quart reduction yesterday.

Dr. James Alexander Miller, leader in the fight against tuberculosis, received the Academy Medal last night at convocation ceremonies marking the termination of the New York Academy of Medicine's centennial celebration.

David W. Howe of The Burlington (Vt.) Free Press was elected president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association at its annual meeting yesterday. Other officers named were Vice president, Edwin S. Friendly of The New York Sun; treasurer, William L. Fanning of The Yonkers (N.Y.) Herald Statesman, and secretary, J.L. Stackhouse of The Easton (Pa.) Express.

LONDON, April 24 -- A private Member's measure calling for a new Bill of Rights was introduced in the House of Lords today by the Marquess of Reading with the backing of the Liberal party. Its progress undoubtedly will arouse keen debate and interest because the rights of the individual have become a vital problem since the Labor Government took office.

PARIS, April 24 -- To check a panicky run on bakeries and cries for bread throughout the country, the Government announced a national wheat crisis today and imposed restrictions that, it was said, must be enforced for more than a year.

More than 200 industrial designs ranging from a teacup to a jetpropelled monorail "commuter car" were displayed yesterday at the first exhibition of work by junior and student members of the American Designers Institute. The showing was held at the studio of Scott Wilson and Fritz Foord, 4 East Fifty-third Street, in connection with the institute's annual convention.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- A refund of $2,800,000 of the $3,500,000 fine he imposed last Winter against the United Mine Workers for contempt of court, was ordered by Federal District Court Justice T. Alan Goldsborough today. During the same procedure in court, the UMW paid the $700,000 fine assessed by the Supreme Court in March, as a reduction from the original Goldsborough penalty.

CAIRO, April 24 -- The Egyptian Government is preparing its case for presentation to the United Nation Security Council next month. It will demand the immediate evacuation of British troops from Egypt and Sudan and declare the present Sudanese condominium illegal.

The Gramercy Park Asosciation presented its first "neighborhood" flower show yesterday at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street. The exhibit was like a friendly reception in a home.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Five hundred members of the Alumni Association of what is perhaps the oldest and largest institution of its kind in the United States -- the Boys' Club of New York -- are deeply shocked by the sudden death of their boyhood friend and fellow-alumnus, Benny Leonard.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The Cities Service Company program for simplification of its corporate structure, involving the retirement of $100,488,300 of 5 per cent debentures and elimination of preferred and preference stocks with divided arrearages approximating $49,000,000, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Officials of the Newspaper Guild of New York said yesterday that the local delegation to the national convention of the American Newspaper Guild, CIO, appeared to consist of eleven supporters of the New York administration and four of the opposition.

ROME, April 24 -- L' Osservatore Romano strongly attacked the Communist leader, Palmiro Togliatti, today for having successfully opposed the insertion of a clearcut statement that marriage is indissoluble in the new Constitution. This Leftist victory, the Vatican's newspaper ruefully admitted, may make easier the attainment of one of the Socialist-Communist aims, which is the establishment of divorce in Catholic Italy.

A forty-year odyssey through 850 miles of water, fighting the currents of streams and rivers, ended yesterday at the Fulton Fish Market. Strangely, the voyagers doubled their weight by the time they reached their destination. Their trip apparently agreed with them.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 24 (U.P.) -- Faultless, the Calmuet Farm's Kentucky Derby hopeful, won a driving neck victory in the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland today, but his triumph was far from impressive and failed to boost his stock in the run for the Roses a week from Saturday.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 24 -- Harold Weismann, Gestapo chief in Kladno, and five other Gestapo members who were responsible with him for the massacre in Lidice were hanged here today.

PARIS, April 24 -- Mr. Wallace said the differences of view between President Truman and himself were not very great. He declared that "Mr. Truman favored a non-political loan to Russia the last time I talked with him, but I do not know whether he still does."

Better coordination between government and voluntary agencies for the aid of the mentally and physically handicapped through employment was advocated yesterday by Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service.

MOSCOW, April 24 -- Prime Minister Stalin raised his vodka glass to propose the health of President Truman and Secretary of State Marshall toasted the future success of the peacemakers tonight. This occurred as the Council of Foreign Ministers session ended in a gale of cordiality at a banquet in St. George's Hall of the Kremlin.

In spite of an understanding between the Flatbush Boys Club and the Flatbush Day Nursery, Inc., which has used the top floor of the boys' club at 2245 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, for the last twenty years, a group of mothers staged a peaceful demonstration in front of the club yesterday afternoon to protest the closing today of the nursery.

The management of the St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., of Montreal, a paper-mill holding company, yesterday reached a compromise agreement with the stockholders' committee that has been attempting to obtain control of the corporation's directorate.

Declining somewhat more than seasonally, and dropping for the third consecutive week, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System were $88,000,000 lower during the week ended on Wednesday.

BALTIMORE, April 24 (AP) -- The school where George Herman Ruth learned the game and the team with which the Babe broke into organized baseball just twenty-five years ago are joining hearts to honor the Sultan of Swat in his home town of Baltimore.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company asked the Board of Estimate yesterday for leave to increase the basic average rental at Stuyvesant Town from $14 to $17 a room a month. It also asked that the average basic rental at Riverton Houses be raised from $12.50 to $14 a room a month.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 24 -- Mrs. Albert J. Eldon of this community has made known the engagement of her daughter, Patricia, to William Carpenter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Carpenter of Pittsburgh.

MUNICH, Germany, April 25 -- The fall of the Bavarian Government headed by Minister President Hans Ehard was expected today after the State Legislature voted down the Social Democrats and effectively neutralized the socialization provisions of the Bavarian Constitution.
Two new printed wallpapers designed for children's rooms, and treated with DDT to kill flies, mosquitoes and moths, are now available at Gimbels.

A tested formula for reducing manufacturing costs through improved control of production and purchasing was described to 1,000 management executives attending the second day of the production conference of the American Management Association at Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

Hospitals exploit student nurses, Lawrence K. Frank, director of the Institute of Human Development, declared yesterday at a National Nursing Council workshop conference at the Visiting Nurse Association of New York, 262 Madison Avenue.

American ports cannot serve as models for projected improvements in Swedish harbors, according to members of an official delegation from the port of Goeteborg who sailed for home yesterday. The harbor experts said the heavily congested American ports, particularly New York, had offered them little, if any, ideas for bettering conditions at home.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 25 -- Joe E. Brown, whose only film appearance in the last five years was a brief role in "Hollywood Canteen" in 1944, will return to the screen next summer to play the leading character, a Protestant clergyman, in "The Tender Years," which Edward L. Alperson will produce for Twentieth Century-Fox release, Alperson's company announced today.

LONDON, April 25 -- Strict limitations upon the periodic fuel purchases permissible for the average householder were imposed by the Ministry of Fuel today. This was done in announcing allocations of coal, coke and similar products for the twelve months beginning May 1.

DETROIT, April 25 (AP) -- Parlaying six hits into as many runs with the aid of nine passes, the Tigers swapped eighth-inning rallies with the Browns today and finished on top. 6 to 5, to split their two-game series.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 25 -- Fine performances marked the running of the amateur derby that opened the three-day meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Association today on the grounds of the Verbank Fishing and Hunting Club.

To benefit men competing today in an examination for promotion to sergeant, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced yesterday that departmental merit awards had been granted to 547 members of the force.

Shifting price movements, accompanied by a slight increase in business, led the stock market yesterday to the lowest levels of the week. The list closed at the approximate level of last Saturday with major losses for the day in several key issues and the composite rate down a point.

Women yacht sailors are to have their full innings, especially along this coast, the coming summer. The North American Yacht Racing Union and the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound both made decisions yesterday to hold their foremost racing events for fair skippers and crews.

HARRISBURG, Pa., April 25 (U.P.) -- The Pennsylvania Industrial Union Council, CIO, after a bitter floor fight over communism voted today to ban Communists, Fascists, Nazis, members of the Ku Klux Klan and other "hate-disseminating institutions" from holding any of its twelve offices.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Albert S. Goss. master of the national grange, proposed today revision of the farm parity formula to include farm labor costs and reflect "existing conditions."
TOKYO, April 25 (AP) -- Sunday will be "Babu Rusu Day" in Japan 'in honor of the great American I hitter of "homu runs."

ALBANY, April 25 -- Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein issued an order at Troy today directing the Albany Board of Education to show cause why it should not be restrained from interfering with the use of the Philip Livingston Junior High School auditorium on May 9 for a concert by Paul Robeson, Negro singer.
LONDON, April 25 -- More good dividend announcements brought in fresh buyers of industrials in the stock markets today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 25 -- Women should become a rallying force for inculcation of universal faith in the work of the United Nations, Mrs. Ruth Bryan Rohde, former Minister to Denmark, told the Westchester County Federation of Women's Clubs today at its annual conference in the Contemporary Club here.

The Index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. Trade Shows Rebound Retail trade here rebounded from the decreases of the last two weeks, despite unfavorable weather conditions.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Justice Department, declaring railroads overcharged the Government on wartime military freight, announced today that proceedings would be filed on Monday to obtain refunds.

PITTSBURGH, April 25 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week recovered sharply from the low levels prevailing in the first half of April, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Resumption of coal production was soon reflected in increased electric power output, in higher blast furnace Operations, and in heavier freight shipments.
MOSCOW, April 25 -- The honeymoon ended tonight for Moscow newspaper correspondents. Special facilities connecting Moscow freely with the world on conference stories came abruptly to an end.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Clifford A. Swanson said today that the plan of the Army's Surgeon General for a single medical system, for the armed forces was "unworkable or fundamentally defective."

Newspaper advertising In fifty-two cities during March totaled 167,384,190 agate lines, a grain of 14.2 per cent over the corresponding month in 1946, according to Media Records. All classifications of advertising' showed gains for the month, except financial which dropped 8.8 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A fire-escape apparatus to remove trapped individuals from the windows of burning buildings, has been patented by Henry Richard Harms Ludeles of Grosse Pointe, Mich.

Another week should find the weakfish moving into Peconic and Great South Bays in the first echelon of the big migration. Reports from commercial fishermen indicate that the schools are beginning to appear.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Frank Costello, New York gambling figure, was asked today to testify at a Congressional investigation into wartime operations of a reputed "non-profit" corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Illinois started to establish its anticipated dominance of the fifty-third annual Pennsylvania Relays by capturing two of the three major tests today, but a tall, bespectacled New York University freshman stole the thunder of the Orange and Blue stars in the opening session of the two-day carnival.

New Capital Market A market schedule of record proportions so far as volume is concerned lies ahead of investment bankers next week. Commitments running beyond a half billion dollars are involved in major bond and preferred stock transactions, topped by the state of Illinois $300,000,000 veterans' bonus bond issue, which is scheduled for sale on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Alaskan officials planned today a fight to prevent Alaska steamship companies from increasing rates on service to the Territory an average of 35 per cent.
WARSAW, April 25 -- The twomonth Polish amnesty was to end at midnight tonight. More than 50,000 "conspirators" had surrendered to amnesty commissions.

Leading advocates of the repeal of Regulation W, war-time initiated control on consumer credit, have temporarily suspended their activities, it was learned yesterday. In view of widespread efforts to reduce prices of consumer goods, attempts to promote repeal of the regulation at this time would be unpopular as well as unwise, these leaders believe.

TOKYO, April 25 -- Only one major difficulty remains for settlement before the Occupation announces its plan for the resumption of the private Japanese export trade. This is the housing of foreign buyers.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 25 (AP) -- Horse racing returns to Louisville tomorrow for a nineteen-day session at Churchill Downs.
Formal rejection by the unions yesterday of the arbitration plan approved by the New York Telephone Company, left the nineteenday-old strike of 35,000 telephone workers here deadlocked last night.

TRIKKALA, Greece, April 25 -- Of the many members of guerrilla bands captured by the Greek Army and gendarmerie, or who have surrendered to Government units, and whom the writer has interviewed in this Thessalian area, none has yet professed himself to be a Communist.

Hearings that may affect the fare rates paid by hundreds of thousands of commuters on twelve Eastern railroads serving major metropolitan areas were ended yesterday at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today chat final figures showed last year's cotton crop totaled 8,640,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I understand fully Professor Foerster'; wish, confirmed by Mr. Tetens in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 8, to have the leaders of the Weimar Republic kept silent. If they were, those gentle men would have a better chance to make their statements without being confronted with the facts.

LONDON, April 25 -- With an eye to the possibility that they might have a share in power after the next elections, the British Liberals today turned down a strong minority demand that the party oppose peacetime conscription.

NANKING, April 25 -- Under the heading, "Notices by Chang Chun," the new Premier of China inserted two items in the advertisement columns of the official Kuomintang Central Daily News this morning. The first notice read: "Chang Chun, being of inferior talent, is now given a very unsuitably tremendous burden and is afraid of his inability to shoulder it.

John Gielgud, now appearing on Broadway in "The Importance of Being Earnest," has drawn the assignment of staging "Medea," the play which will star Judith Anderson and return her to the local scene after an absence of five year. Contracts between the British actor and the team of Robert Whitehead and Oliver Rea, sponsors of the project, were signed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Clearing Committee for Women's Organizations, with nineteen women's groups represented, protested today the House version of the emergency wool bill as undermining the trade agreements program.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 26 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida and six members of his Cabinet were elected to the Lower House of the new Japanese Diet while early returns appeared to indicate victory for the present conservative Government.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter in THE TIMES of April 3 regarding the interrelationship between the Communist party and Russia, Alexander Kerensky sharply distinguishes between the Soviet Government of the U.S.S.R. and "the international complex of revolutionary Communist parties.''

BERLIN, April 25 -- A strong denunciation of the growing power of the state throughout the world -- comparable to the development that brought Germany to her present plight -- was voiced this morning by Bishop Otto Dibelius, ranking Protestant prelate in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Senate Expenditures Committee charged the Customs Bureau today with "gross incompetence" and recommended requiring it to live within a House-approved $32,500,000 appropriation for the year beginning July 1.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 25 -- Representatives of the five great powers conferred today with Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, to fix the procedure necessary to get the special session of the General Assembly under way Monday.

Strenuous opposition to imposition of mandatory fair trade enforcement under powers now granted to the State Liquor Authority was expressed yesterday by spokesmen for the American Wine Association, which represents 80 per cent of the wines handled in New York State.

CLEVELAND, April 25 -- Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations Security Council, outlined here tonight an eight-point program that this country must pursue to achieve collective security through the U.N.

Mme. Elizabeth Zoltan Tildy, wife of the President of Hungary, arrived at La Guardia Field last night by plane from Budapest. She has been, invited to visit this country for two weeks as the guest of the Order of the Eastern Star and American - Hungarian Reformed Church organizations.

For sixty years the Riverside Community House, at 239 West Sixty-ninth Street, has been serving the boys and girls and some of the adults, of the West Side. Yesterday, in celebration of its anniversary, the house threw open its doors and invited the community as a whole to come in and look it over.

Three men accused of stealing fur coats worth $60,000 from a truck owned by Revillon Freres Company, of 684 Fifth Avenue, waived examination yesterday before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter and were ordered held for grand jury action.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A bill drastically curtailing the Interior Department's appropriations for the 1948 fiscal year was passed by the House tonight, 307 to 30, and sent to the Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Dr. Arthur H. Compton, chancellor of Washington University, told the American Philosophical Society today that cooperation between nations in scientific research was an important step toward a peaceful adjustment of world society.

Health officials expressed pleasure yesterday that a threatened Smallpox epidemic in New York had been "miraculously" curbed. With 5,265,000 persons vaccinated in the city since the first public report of smallpox here on April 5, the vaccination campaign was drawing to a close.

Senator Raymond E. Baldwin, Republican, of Connecticut, said last night that new legislation should not seek to destroy labor's gains and that industrial peace could be achieved by equalizing the obligations of labor and management.

GLYNDON, Md., April 25 (AP) -- For the fifty-first time the Maryland Hunt Cup will be run over rolling Worthington Valley tomorrow, and the committee says that fourteen of the finest timbertoppers in the business will be out there trying to take a $100 challenge cup and the glory that goes with winning the nation's premier cross-country race.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 25 -- The American Council for Judaism will ask the United States to oppose any move by the Jewish Agency for Palestine to become a non-voting representative at the United Nations General Assembly session on Palestine, it was announced today.

Willa Sibert Cather did not tailor her writing to passing tastes. Her works were, like herself, sturdy, simple and charged with the vitality of the pioneer days of Nebraska, where she grew from childhood to womanhood. "A painter or writer," she once said, "must learn to distinguish what is his own from what he admires."

Substantial improvement in the quality of shoes being turned out was reported here yesterday by W.W. Stephenson, executive vice president of the National Shoe Manufacturers Association, as a preliminary to the National Shoe Fair, which opens here Monday.

DETROIT, April 25 -- With last night's wage agreement between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, expected to set the pattern, a settlement of the union's three-month-old wage dispute with the Chrysler Corporation was looked for today.

Figure Puzzle Expert Sarah Wambaugh, plebiscite expert under the old League of Nations and adviser to the head of the American group of observers in the last Greek election thinks it "extraordinary" the way people will use words contrary to their ordinary meanings and make statements flagrantly contrary to facts.

Paint manufacturers here are taking immediate steps to help dealers meet a current recession in sales, L.D. Eldot., president, New York Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association, revealed yesterday in an interview. Plans include expansion of community "Clean Up and Paint Up" campaigns and distribution of a basic book on sales methods just released by the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association, Inc.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Contrary to what is stated in Anne O'Hare McCormick's column in THE NEW YORK TIMES, April 12, the appointment of Myron Taylor as personal represenative of the President to the Pope with the rank and honors of an Ambassador, and with an embassy stafi at the Vatican, is a violation of the principle of separation of church and state written into our Constitution.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 25 -- A wide search extending to Canada was on tonight for an 18-year-old high school student of Great Neck who is sought as the youth who attacked and robbed Mrs. Nancy Jackson at the Stewart Manor railroad station last Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, expressed confidence today that American business men would take the "statesmanlike" view and respond to President Truman's appeal for lower prices.

Senator Robertson, who apparently has constituted himself a one-man task force to scuttle unification, selects a brittle stick with which to attack the agreed-on plan when he speaks darkly of "secret documents" in Army, Navy and Joint Chiefs of Staff files purporting to show nefarious designs by one service on another.

Thomas Bracken has been a member of the staff of this newspaper, man and boy, for fifty-five years. Now he is retiring at the age of 70 to pass his winters in a new home in Florida and his summers at his cottage in the Berkshires near Sheffield, Mass., where his nine grandchildren will come to visit their grandparents.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Current steel production may be slowed down unless government agencies accelerate their sales of scrap to Industrial firms, John R. Steelman, assistant to President Truman, warned today. He said that consumer stocks of scrap iron and steel have dropped more than 1,700,000 tons since March 31, 1946.

GUATEMALA, April 25 -- The Congress of Guatemala has just passed the so-called "Law on Expression of Thought," which, according to the official newspaper Diaro de Centro America, is "necessary to safeguard our democratic life."

The "Newburyport Plan" for a 10 per cent reduction of retail prices gained new adherents in scattered communities of the country yesterday but with little indication of reductions on the wholesale or producer level. In New York City the Department of Markets reported food, prices pretty much unchanged from last week.
NANKING, April 25 -- The Communist radio station in northern Shensi denounced the new Central Government today as a "reactionary, traitorous regime," organized to turn China into an American colony.

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- The bulletin of the atomic scientists said today that the policy of the United States in Greece and Turkey "will not solve the central problem of our security -- that of atomic weapons."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 -- A demonstration of 2,000 striking employes of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company was broken up in the Central City district today by police. Fourteen men and thirteen women were arrested. They were released in $20 bail each on charges of violating a city ordinance against demonstrators blocking a thoroughfare.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 25 -- Dairymen representing 90 per cent of the farmers who produced milk for New York City and vicinity decided today that Federal supervision of their industry is no longer desirable.

WEIRTON, W. Va., April 25 (AP) -- The Weirton Steel Company today granted to its 12,000 independent union production workers an across-the-board wage increase of 12 1/2 cents an hour. Its minimum basic hour rate was raised from $1 to $1.16 1/2.

Baseball faced what was generally forecast as another reverberating explosion yesterday when it became known that Commissioner A. B. (Happy) Chandler had summoned President Larry MacPhail of the Yankees for a hearing to be held in the commissioner's Cincinnati office next week.

An exhibition of printed textiles designed by Ludwig Bemelmans, Salvador Dali, James Reynolds and Marcel Vertes was opened yesterday at the Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration. Original sketches and finished piece goods are displayed side by side.
DES MOINES, April 25 (AP) -- Jerry Thompson, University of Texas junior, back from a fouryear hitch In the Navy, today resumed his role as one of the nation's outstanding distance runners.

PARIS, April 25 -- Maggy Rouff's important midsummer collection is a bouquet of coloring, shell pink crepes, cotton prints in palest cyclamen and white. A soft ferngreen satin sash swathes the midriff of a delicate chartreuse print.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Officials of the National Federation of Telephone Workers said tonight that they considered that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had refused their offer to settle the strike for a wage increase of $6 weekly.
CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- The White Sox scored a run in each of their first three innings against the Indians and then coasted to a 3-2 victory today.

There are signs in the windows of city markets these days saying "Tongue -- 45 cents a pound" (or a little more in some cases). It's an actual kindness on the part of dealers to call the attention of consumers to this particular cut of meat.

Builders' hardware distributors were urged yesterday to expand and take over distribution of their lines to retail stores to Improve marketing efficiency by H.T. Bourne, general sales manager of Sargent & Co., hardware manufacturers, New Haven, Conn.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange continued active yesterday. Final prices were 14 to 41 points net higher.

Elaborate plans for observance of Babe Ruth Day in the Yankee Stadium tomorrow were announced yesterday, along with details of an extensive radio broadcast of the occasion over a coast-to-coast hook-up of the Mutual network.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- An, increasing demand for civilian specialists to fill key positions in Japan and Korea was reported today by spokesmen for the Civil Affairs Division of the War Departraent.

Social security program under public auspices and private welfare programs both are needed to provide adequate care for aged persons in a democratic society, Miss Rose McHugh, official of the Standards and Program Development Division of the Social Security Administration, declared yesterday.

ANDOVER, Mass., April 25 -- Mr. and Mrs. John Sedgwick Barss of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Sedgwick, to David B. Weden, son of Mrs. David B. Weden of Wellesley, and the late Mr. Weden. The wedding has been planned for June.
MOSCOW, April 25 -- The Foreign Ministers of the three big Western powers ended their sojourn in Moscow today on a note of optimism and hopes for the future.

VIENNA, April 25 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark sharply criticized the Soviet stand on the Austrian treaty on his return from Moscow tonight. He said that to have agreed with the Russians "would have been tantamount to setting up an Austria with her sovereignty so restricted and her economy so burdened that her chances of survival as a free and independent state would have been slight."

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- In a joint application, the Louisiana Power and Light Company and its parent, Electric Power and Light Corporation, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to sanction a proposed transaction through which the subsidiary will obtain part of the funds required to finance an expansion program.

Representatives of two of the three check-cashing agencies that cashed checks involved in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle identified Julius Lobel, alias Jimmy Collins, yesterday as the man who presented them for payment.

Three processions will enter the Cathedral of St. John the Divine at 2:30 P.M. today as the opening feature of the induction, investiture and Installation of the Right Rev. Charles Kendall Gilbert as the eleventh Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York.

PARIS, April 25 -- French comment on the close of the Moscow conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers -- with the exception of the extreme Left press -- deplores its negative results, and fears that the prospects for agreement may diminish rather than improve before the next session in November.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The House was told by its Foreign Affairs Committee today that the Greek-Turkish aid bill, which the committee has approved for floor action, "constitutes an affirmative promotion of peace."

GALVESTON, Tex., April 25 (AP) -- Rear Adm. Gordon T. Finlay, chairman of the Coast Guard board investigating the Texas City disaster, charged today that some of the witnesses who appeared before the group "lied in their testimony."

The National Association of Women Artists will open the fiftyfifth anniversary exhibition of work by members with a members' preview and reception in the galleries of the National Academy at 8:30 o'clock tonight. Miss Iika Chase is to present the awards Beginning tomorrow and continuing until May 22 the exhibition will be open to the public.

FALMOUTH, England, April 25 (AP) -- The American ocean-going tug Farallon reached port today after having strained through a hurricane that churned up 100-foot waves, smashing her bridge and navigational equipment and injuring the captain and some crewmen.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 25 (AP) -- Former Mayor Roger L. Putnam announced tonight that he and two associates would start publication of a newspaper in this partly strike-bound city early in June.

College rowing, which got off to a limited start last week, swings into full stride today in three major regattas that will bring four crews into the picture for the first time. Those making season debuts are Navy, Yale, Harvard and M.I.T.

Any lingering fears about the seaworthiness of the giant Cunarder Queen Elizabeth resulting from her recent fifty-hour grounding on a Southampton reef were effectively dispelled yesterday after her arrival at Pier 90, North River, with a cosmopolitan list of 2,272 passengers.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Warren R. Austin, the United States representative in the United Nations, and his alternate, Herschel V. Johnson, will be assisted by a staff of advisers and others at the General Assembly session.

LUXEMBOURG, April 25 -- Aloyse Meyer, president of a prewar steel cartel and manager of the Arbed works since 1912, was unanimously elected chairman of the board of directors of that steel empire at the annual meeting today.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- A witness today related that he palled out of a wartime lumber deal with Andrew J. May, then House Military Committee chairman, because "I decided there was something wrong."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 25 -- The United Nations military staff committee adopted today a tentative recommendation that the Security Council make public its first report on principles for the establishment of an international police force.
Stymie, fresh and fit, begins his 1947 campaign -- and his stretch drive to top Whirlaway's world money-earning mark -- in today's $20,000 added Excelsior Handicap at Jamaica.
LOS ANGELES, April 25 (U.P.) -- Leaders in the American Bowling Congress remained unchallenged today despite assault by four full squads.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today it would lend $3,000,000 to the Preferred Accident Insurance Company of New York.

Nothing is so miraculous about "Miracle in the Mountains" as the fact that Ferenc Molnar wrote it and staged it. For in the past Mr. Molnar has written imaginative drama with the caution of a cafe scribbler -- avoiding at all costs the mawkish and the maudlin.

MONTREAL, April 25 (AP) -- Choirs and bands from eight Canadian and United States schools today took part in the second concert of the three-day International Festival of School Music, in which 12,000 children from eighty cities and towns are participating.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 25 (AP) -- A thrilling battle to the wire and a disqualification marked the Seneca Purse, the best offering on the final Friday program of the first meeting here.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Witnesses representing religious organizations at a Senate hearing endorsed in the main today Federal aid to education, but differed on permitting Federal funds to assist private and church schools in states which give such aid.

Our way of life in America, our hopes and our ideals are broadcast daily by radio and through other media to sixty-seven countries through a group of activities in the State Department. It is a program that attempts to tell the story of how democracy works and thinks, and to thwart with factual information the misrepresentations abroad of our intentions.

Don't put all the blame for juvenile delinquency on the movies, the radio and the comic books -- some rests on conditions that exist in the home. That was the general verdict of seven girls and six boys who debated the effects of entertainment thrillers on American youth at a forum held yesterday in Public School 65, Eldridge and Forsyth Streets.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Republican regular and liberal wings of the Senate came to grips today in fundamental disagreement on the labor bill. Senator Irving M. Ives of New York denounced from the floor as "definitely anti-labor" the first of four stiffening provisions sought by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

PARIS, April 25 -- Henry A. Wallace said today that although he opposed "political strings" to loans, the loan he had urged for Russia should be conditional upon an understanding regarding Germany "and perhaps other points."

Fifty-five years ago THE NEW YORK TIMES, then at 41 Park Row, took on a new office boy. He was a shy, blue-eyed towhead from semi-rural Aatoria in Queens and he was only 16 years old. His name was Thomas Bracken.
E.J. Schiffer has been made general traffic manager for Gulf Oil Corporation. He succeeds the late J.C. Beck.

Experience in treating a single child, or in handling family difficulties, does not always imply the ability to understand the behavior of a group of children. Lack of this experience is a major problem in professional training, according to findings of a special study in nursery, guidance made public yesterday by the New York City Committee on Mental Hygiene of the State Charities Aid Association, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

AMSTERDAM, April 25 (ANETA) -- Trading was active and prices moved upward, with many stocks reaching new highs, on the Stock Exchange. The statement issued Thursday by Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck on economic conditions did not depress the market, as might have been expected.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The basic conflict between organized labor and industry on the issue of tax reduction was presented to the Senate Finance Committee today by representatives of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the National Association of Manufacturers.

Believed to be the largest family that has flown the Atlantic to settle in the United States, Mr. and Mrs. Sybrand van der Dussen of Rotterdam and their eleven children arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon aboard a Royal Dutch Airlines plane from Amsterdam.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Republican labor may "take a walk" in 1948, according to reports here today. The reports resulted when it became known that a committee of the American Federation of Labor had encountered heavy going in seeking to convince Senator Robert A. Taft to moderate some of his views on labor legislation.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The State Department has renewed its request that Yugoslavia relinquish the nine Italian vessels, including the former luxury liner Rex, that she seized after the ships were beached near Trieste.
