One of 200 stockholders attending the fifty-seventh annual meeting of the North American Company here yesterday asked Edward L. Shea, president, whether the company planned to remain in the utility business or "will it be liquidated?"

Cardinal Spellman accepted a Certificate of Achievement from the Navy yesterday at ceremonies in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to mark the formal closing of the recreational and welfare center operated for six years by the National Catholic Community Service at 17 East Fifty-first Street.

The Board of Transportation rejected yesterday, by a vote of 2 to 1, the Davis-O'Dwyer plan for improving labor relations on the city's unified transit system. The plan was drawn by Commissioner William H. Davis, former chairman of the National War Labor Board.

Allocations of quality aluminum cooking ware will be terminated in from three to six months, a spokesman for one of the major producers said yesterday. He predicted that many war-born producers who entered the field immediately following cessation of Government contracts for fabrication of aluminum airplane parts and other war work shortly will be forced out of cookware production and will have to turn their facilities to other products to survive.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 25 -- The trials and persecutions of these last years were cited today by the Provisional Committee of the World Council of Churches as evidence of the failure of the Churches of Christ to prevent "man's disorder."

BERLIN, April 25 -- Disappointment that the Foreign Ministers conference in Moscow had not produced an Austrian peace treaty was expressed by Secretary of State Marshall during a two-hour pause here enroute to Washington. Secretary Marshall added he had never expected a German treaty to result from the discussions.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 25 -- Yugoslavia warned the United States and Britain tonight that unless they surrendered persons considered by Belgrade to be war criminals she would raise the matter with the United Nations.
LONDON, April 25 -- The normally mild-mannered Prime Minister Attlee went for Winston Churchill today like David setting out to slay Goliath.

Considerable interest has developed in the 10 per cent price cut initiated by retailers in Newburyport, Mass. Other communities are reported to have joined the campaign, which is being hailed as a "war against inflation." It would be more appropriate to call this a "war against high prices" and to recognize that the actions in Newburyport are merely skirmishes rather than full-fledged battles.

A group of 200 businessmen has been invited to attend a conference on foreign economic, political and cultural policies of the State Department June 4 to 6, inclusive, in Washington, D.C., it was disclosed yesterday. The businessmen, representing national organizations and other interested groups, were invited to attend the threeday meeting by Francis H. Russell, director, Office of Public Affairs, Department of State.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The railroads told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that overland carriers "should be free, as they have been in the past, to make any necessary adjustments in rail rates as conditions may warrant."

The three buildings at 1333, 1337 and 1343 Merriam Avenue, the Bronx, accommodating seventyeight families, have been sold by Remy Estates, Inc., to the Mancur Realty Corporation, represented by M. Robins, attorney. Schimmer, Kerner Feder were the brokers.

In his toast at the Kremlin dinner ending the Council of Foreign Ministers, Secretary Marshall spoke of the United States as a young and impatient country. "In our impatience," he is quoted as saying to the tired men around the groaning board, "it will perhaps be understood that we are most anxious for an early peace and prosperity in Europe."

BOSTON, April 25 (AP) -- Undaunted by a five-run deficit, the Athletics pecked away today in the rain until they were only one run down and then rallied for five in the ninth to defeat the Red Sox, 11 -- 7.

The Maritime Commission's request for legislation that would extend most of its ship charter and operating powers until June 30, 1949, was viewed with general favor here yesterday by shipping men. While most of those in the industry apparently would like to see the Government get out of the business, they also feel that the time is not yet right for such a step.

A sculpture entitled "The Lovers" that won for Mitzi Solomon, its creator, one of four prizes in that class awarded by the National Association of Women Artists, has been barred from the annual show that opens to the public tomorrow in the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 25 -- "The Home" was the subject of an address by Mrs. Doris C. Maxwell of Springfield, Mass., today before more than 100 delegates to the second annual conference of Girls Clubs of America, Inc., in the Sheraton-Biltmore Hotel here.
LONDON, April 25 -- The Communistcontrolled Government in Rumania has launched a campaign to tighten the Communist grip on the country, according to authoritative reports received here.

WASHINGTON. April 25 -- The American Federation of Labor reported today a new high membership of 7,551,370 and said the affiliation of the International Association of Machinists, with more than 600,000 members, was expected in the next few months.

JERUSALEM, April 25 (U.P.) -- Simultaneously with the Sarona blast, mines exploded in Jerusalem when military vehicles passed along a road at the foot of the Mount of Olives. No one was injured. Sirens also sounded in Jaffa during the morning, but there were no immediate reports of underground violence.

Columbus, Ohio A banking group headed by the Bankers Trust Company bought at competitive sale yesterday $2,050,000 of various purpose bonds of Columbus, Ohio, maturing from 1948 to 1972, at a bid of 100.099 for l%s, a net interest cost of 1.49 per cent.

The marriage of Mrs. Nancy Tenney Lloyd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rockwell Campbell Tenney of this city and Washington, to Robert Spalding Coleman, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Coleman of Lake Forest, Ill., took place yesterday afternoon at Sherry's. Msgr. Joseph F. Flannelly of St. Patrick's Cathedral performed the ceremony.

KORN WESTHEIM, Germany, April 23 (Delayed) -- Maria Spreche, a matronly housewife and long-time Communist, told tonight how she had written a letter to Premier Stalin beseeching him to release a friend's son from Russian imprisonment.

JERUSALEM, April 25 -- Two Jews drove a stolen postoffice truck laden with explosives into one of the most heavily guarded police compounds in Palestine today. Twenty minutes later a shattering blast killed five British police officials and wounded six others.

A new system of dimensional proportions that may be applied to the design of anything from the smallest household object to a large city planning project was demonstrated yesterday by Charles Le Corbusier, French architect, in the auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Any move in the Senate to restore the State Department's foreign information program, which has been doomed in a House Appropriations subcommittee, will face extremely tough sledding, it was established today.

DR. CANTOR writes rather breezily about cancer, now the second cause of death. According to him cancer can always be "cured" if it is diagnosed in time and the standard surgical and radiological procedures are followed -- a conclusion that is true of superficial cancers but not always true of deep cancers which, in fact, too often escape early detection.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Wage settlements in the steel industry and General Motors Corporation have suddenly changed the overcast industrial relations skies.

When the Queen Elizabeth left her berth at Pier 90 yesterday, bound for Southampton, England, she carried a group of American amateur golfers on their way to St. Andrews, Scotland, in search of the Walker Cup, and then to Carnoustie to compete in the British amateur championship.

CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP) -- Bob Feller, Cleveland Indians' fireball artist, hung up his second straight shut-out victory today, a three-hit 6-to-0 triumph over the Tigers and beat his arch pitching rival, Hal Newhouser, in the process.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from a Polish journalist, forwarded from Moscow through Earl Browder, regarding the dispute over Poland's western border. The letter summarizes all the historic, legal and practical grounds usually advanced in justification of Poland's claim, but is silent on the real reason for it.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Senate Republican policy committee acted today to press the labor control bill through the Senate during the coming week, with the Taft program for additional curbs on unions to be tested in the meantime by a poll of Republican Senators.
The New York Mandolin Symphony Orchestra, consisting of fifty-five players conducted by Ignace Strasfogel, gave its twentythird annual concert last night at Town Hall. There was an audience of 1,500.

Louis F. Budenz, former editor of The Daily Worker who was reconverted recently to Catholicism, delivered an attack on the Communist "fifth column" last night when he spoke at the centenary dinner of Xavier High School in the Astor Hotel before an audience of more than 1,000.

Social scientists studying Industrial sociology were warned yesterday by Dr. Wilbert E. Moore, Aassistant Professor of Sociology at Princeton University, to avoid random problem-solving, undisciplined research, inadequate theoretical frameworks and the failure to formulate problems in ways that can be tested.

Virginia C. Gildersleeve, retiring dean of Barnard College, was honored yesterday by the Governments of France and the United States and by 1,000 alumnae who attended a luncheon at the Waldorf -Astoria Hotel.
First place in the National League is not a mirage nor a typographical error for the Dodgers.

After an irregularly lower opening prices of shares in the short session on the Stock Exchange yesterday firmed a bit, with a few issues showing more than a fractional improvement. Trading dropped to the second smallest volume of the month for a two-hour session, or since April 5.

The latest about the Morris and Essex Kennel Club show at Madison, N.J., on May 24 is that entries are arriving at a rate that indicates they will reach or surpass 2,500. That would make it equal in numbers with Westminster, limited to about 2,500, with the important difference that Morris and Essex will draw all its entries from thirty-four breeds.

THE best show in radio was not on the air last week. It was, of course, the almost incredible series of incidents which started last Sunday when NBC cut off Fred Allen for twenty -five seconds, continued with the silent treatment also being doled out to Bob Hope and Red Skelton, and ended with NBC blandly saying, "Oops, sorry."

STRAWBERRIBS are one of the easiest crops to grow Many of us have sentimental, inaccurate memories of the wonderful flavor of wild berries and are loath to try cultivated fruit. Actually, tame varieties of strawberries provide more shortcakes, pies, jams and desserts than most other fruits, and fully ripened berries have a delicious flavor when picked a short time before eating.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., April 26 -- When John E. Swanson, middle -aged hardware merchant of this old colonial seaport, read in the paper that President Truman had called for a general price reduction, he immediately went into action.

The statement by Carl Whitmore, president of the New York Telephone Company, on the rejection by the unions of Commissioner J. R. Mandelbaum's proposal to end the telephone strike, follows: The four unions representing our employes in the metropolitan area have repeatedly stated to the press that they are independent of any other unions and are in a position to make final settlements of the strike issues.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Members of the advisory board of the Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion, representing labor, management, agriculture and the public, agreed in a report to President Truman today that such a representative group could be an asset to the Government even in times of peace.
SINGAPORE, April 26 -- Many troubles of Asia today can be traced to the shortage of rice, the staple food of the Orient's millions.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- The Rutgers varsity crew remained in the Eastern collegiate undefeated ranks when it nosed out Pennsylvania by three feet on the Schuylkill River today, one of the closest finishes seen here in years.
LOS ANGELES, April 26 -- Are the wild horses of the Western ranges being killed off? That was a burning issue this week in this metropolis of a State in which there are virtually no wild horses.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- This energetic metropolis, noted for its fierce pride in boasting the biggest and the best, has been considering for the past few days the prospect Of a $200,000,000 building program for upper Michigan Avenue, which would make the eleven - block stretch from the Chicago River to North Oak Street "the most modern mile in the world."

The writer of the following letter, now representing the American Friends Service Committee in Frankfort-onMain, was formerly rector of St. George's Church in New York City. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: To read your comments on Germany from my Quaker desk in the Public Welfare Department of the City of Frankfort is a different experience from reading them in my study in New York.

SOME current of revolt charged through the veins of Russell Cheney. Yet this quiet Connecticut painter subscribed to none of the more established patterns of New England nonconformity. He did not flout the community, like the early Abolitionists, nor did he dive into some solitary retreat like a hermit.

WINNING photographs in the seventh annual Scholastic Photo Awards contest for high school students, 15 to 18 years old, will be exhibited at Rockefeller Center starting Friday. Continuing throughout May, the show will be called the National High School Photographic Exhibit and will comprise 125 award winners and other prints selected from the contest.

IT has long been felt in art circles that something ought to be done about Ralph Blakelock. There has appeared a tendency to underrate this American painter, the centenary of whose birth is now being observed. Perhaps it isn't so much that Blakelock has gone unappreciated as that we have lacked opportunities to see his accomplishment as a rounded whole.

An apparently crazed fortypound black-and-gray mongrel dog was killed by a patrolman on the shore of the Seventy-second Street lake in Central Park yesterday afternoon after the animal had bitten two children and the policeman.

Authorities in the housing field expressed general agreement yesterday that the present housing emergency would become permanent unless the public demanded advanced thinking and planning on the part of Government and private industry.

AGAIN, at the risk of being labeled a plugger for British films, we are going to raise more sabbath clatter about three recent pips from Albion. They are Carol Reed's melodrama, with James Mason, "Odd Man Out"; Frank Launder's and Sidney Gilliat's "The Adventuress," and Noel Coward's "This Happy Breed."
BALLET THEATRE'S first season at the City Center opens tomorrow evening, to continue for three weeks through May 18.

THE Nuremberg trials lasted less than a year. However, the tons of incriminating records that were piled up in the dusty court rooms -- Justice Jackson's staff alone screened over 100,000 documents -- covered the whole twelve years and twelve weeks of the Third Reich.

TOKYO, April 26 -- Japan's newly organized Socialist party emerged today as the largest single political grouping in the second general election held since the occupation. It failed, however, to break the grip of the Conservatives, headed by Premier Shigeru Yoshida.

LOUISVILLE, KY. SOME 125,000 racing fans will see the Kentucky Derby next Saturday by courtesy of the greatest "crowd engineer" in America. He is 44-year-old Andy Frain of Chicago, a barrel-chested Irish-American who has converted mass ushering into a science and transformed a former piddling racket into a legitimate $11,000,000 business.

This is not going to be a cheerful column, so those in search of optimism and light would do well to climb the attic stairs and search for some time-yellowed copy of an old sporting magazine, written during those days when fish and game were plentiful and hunters and anglers few.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 26 -- Following is the agenda of the first meeting of the special session on Palestine of the General Assembly, which will begin in Flushing Meadow on Monday at 11 A.M. (the explanatory notes were supplied by the United Nations Secretariat):

With the suspension for two years of the United States import duty of 4 cents a pound on copper now virtually assured, the opinion has been expressed in some quarters that similar action should be taken with respect to zinc. However, the situation existing in zinc is quite different from that in copper.

The protection of the country against subversive activity is an increasing concern of the Federal Government. But in the accomplishment of this essential objective Congress should be careful not to restrict the limits of legitimate freedom or to imperil in any way the basic liberties of the American way of life.

EVERY experiment must have its trial and error, and the establishment of Theatre Incorporated, certainly an experiment on the Broadway scene, has tasted its share of ups and downs. But the results of this experience of mistake and correction in our first two years have provided lessons which proved invaluable in the past and will prove more so in Theatre Incorporated's years to come.

Unsolved problems, Which still haunt the nation's economy, were reflected in the action of the stock market last week. Although many situations were clarified, in its present mood the market practically ignored the remarkable firstquarter earnings, corrective labor legislation or tax bills under consideration.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 26 -- Making its first start in defense of its Eastern Intercollegiate League title, the Yale baseball team defeated Dartmouth, 8 -- 3, today.

MORE than fifty-five years ago Cesare Casella, a 'cellist well known in Europe, brought me his nephew, Alfredo, a somber and timid child, who appeared greatly gifted. He entered the Paris Conservatoire as a pupil of Diemer, an excellent pianist, and several years later studied with Gabriel Faure, winning all the prizes obtainable.

Wholesale markets last week saw little activity as stores continued to operate conservatively, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers. There was however, a bit of business on some promotional items, the report said.

An unprecedented, far-reaching campaign to encourage outstanding students to enter the teaching profession and at the same time raise the standards of public school education is now under way in this country.

Samuel Rudin and his sons, Jack and Lewis, are completing one of the few new rental housing1 projects being undertaken by private interests in Manhattan -- an eighteenstory and penthouse building at the southeast corner of Second Avenue and East Fifty-seventh Street.

The Grace liner Santa Paula, after undergoing more than ten months' reconversion work, comes back to this port this morning in "civilian clothes" for the first time since Pearl Harbor. She will join her sister ship, the Santa Rosa, in the Caribbean cruise service with a departure from here on Friday.

FRAGRANCE is to us one of the most appealing attributes of our garden. We were astounded to hear, and found ourselves emphatically denying, a rose grower's statement, "Fragrance in a rose is of secondary importance."

AMONG the quietly intrusive personages of literary legend, the daemon king Oberon has been one of the moat persistent. According to one tradition (the veracity of which is open to question) he was the son of Julius Caesar by an immortal lady of the kingdom of the fays.
THE great question in industrial relations is: "What does one do when a strike or lockout imperils the public health or the public safety?"

-- RESISTANCE Last week we asked Professor Ensykle to circulate around and look for some of this consumer resistance the economists talk about. In the very first block he saw a flashily dressed consumer struggling to escape from the clutches of a jewelry merchant who was holding him by the coat-tails and yelling for the police.
NANKING, April 26 -- Major Robert Rigg and Capt. John W. Collins today told the story of their fifty-five days' captivity in the hands of Chinese Communists in Manchuria.

Chester Bowles, former OPA Administrator was wrong by more than 60 per cent in his statement last Sunday in the TIMES Magazine that prices of drugs and pharmaceuticals are up 67 per cent since last June, according to F.J. Griffiths, executive secretary of the National Association of Chain Drug Stores.

With Walt Hajek and Red Tellefsen turning in steady mound performances, Columbia's baseball team took both games of an Eastern Intercollegiate League doubleheader, 5 -- 2 and 5 -- 3, from the University of Pennsylvania at Baker Field yesterday.

Retail trade here rebounded quite sharply last week, following the volume declines of the two preceding weeks. Department store volume was estimated at close to 15 per cent ahead of the same week last year, with some stores having gains ranging to 30 per cent. April as a whole is likely to show a slight increase.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Truman today ordered the transfer to China of an unspecified number of surplus ships and floating drydocks. He also ordered that they be accompanied by a limited complement of naval personnel and technical advice.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Federal mediation in the telephone strike operated in high gear today but apparently came to naught.
"ONE of the greatest gifts you can give a child is confidence. * * *" "Have fun with children. Let them know you enjoy being with them."

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 26 -- Magistrate Anna M. Kross of New York, speaking here today at the closing session of the second annual three-day conference of Girls' Clubs of America, Inc., said that "behind every male criminal there is a woman who has not given him the proper home."

The special session of the United Nations Assembly which will open tomorrow at Lake Success has not been asked to solve the problem of Palestine. Its agenda merely requires it to consider the appointment of an investigating: commission which will present findings and recommendations at the regular meeting in September.

CHONJU, Korea, April 25 (Delayed) -- A survey of the food situation in south Korea has revealed here a paradox as far as the ability of the richest agricultural province of south Korea is concerned.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 26 -- The warring Thompson and Talmadge political forces are engaged today in another all-out battle. Control of the Georgia Democratic party and of the State's delegation to the 1948 national convention is at stake.

The sculpture "The Lovers" continued to be a storm center yesterday. Two more sculptors resigned from the National Association of Women Artists in protest against art "censorship." Hobart Nichols, president of the National Academy of Design, issued a statement denying he had any "personal responsibility" in the barring of the sculpture from the art show.

Prospects of an all-year peace in the nation's steel industry were dimmed yesterday with the announcement by an official of the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, that negotiations between the union and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation had bogged down.

An offer by the Dutch Government of Surinam to the Freeland League for Jewish Territorial Colonization to open territory in South America for 30,000 homeless European Jews will be discussed here by the national executive committee of the league next Saturday and Sunday.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Secretary of State Marshall returned this morning from the Moscow conference of Foreign Ministers. He was greeted at the national airport by President Truman and other ranking officials, plus a cheering crowd of several thousand.

MEXICO CITY, April 26 -- President Miguel Aleman will leave for Washington some time after midnight Monday with the process of setting this nation's economic house in order considerably advanced since he took office.

Plans completed here yesterday for the official visit of President Aleman provide for a City Hall reception at noon on Friday, the conferring of an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws at Columbia University on Friday afternoon and a dinner by the Pan American Society at the Waldorf that evening.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., April 26 -- The boom of Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, for the Republican nomination for President in 1948 is scheduled to gain impetus after his return from Europe. Undismayed by the admitted present lead of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26 (AP) -- Two of the fancier Kentucky Derby dandies -- Double Jay and On Trust -- had their local "unveilings" today, but when the lid was pried off about the only thing to pop out was a possible surprise starter in next week's Derby field.

To the Drama Editor: SOME TIME ago I bought a magazine with the seating plans of the various theatres and went to the box office of a hit show to buy two seats. I pointed to a certain location on the map and said I wanted those particular seats.
Richard King, 45 years old, of 793 Jennings Street, the Bronx, shot and killed two women in that borough yesterday afternoon, went to Manhattan and killed a man and then shot himself fatally.

NEW DELHI, April 26 (Reuters) -- A spokesman at the Viceroy's House stated today that "it is not impossible that Gen. Lord Hastings Ismay and Sir Eric Mieville, senior members of Viceroy Mountbatten's staff, may go home to report to the British Cabinet, or that the Viceroy may convene a roundtable conference in May."

PRINCETON, N.J., April 26 -- Two sharp singles by Glenn Davis and effective pitching by Jack MaeMull gave Army's baseball team its ninth straight victory of the season today as the Cadets downed Princeton, 4 -- 1, on University Field.

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 26 -- A series of recommendations calling for a reduction in passport and visa formalities and for the easing of foreign exchange control for travelers has been adopted in the final report of a meeting of experts of thirty-three countries who ended work in Geneva yesterday.
"THE inexperienced player loves to make finesses," observes Charles C. Plaat in a book of advice to bridge players, recently published under the title, "Better Your Bridge."

IMPROVED riding comfort, with a view to eliminating that tired feeling experienced by motorists after a long trip, is ranked among the leading objectives of research by automobile engineers. Although specific design work is a closely guarded secret, the basic goal generally is known.

ALGIERS, April 24 (Delayed) -- A certain amount of acute political unrest is present in Algeria today. A special representative of the United States is here to make a discreet survey of the situation.

ISTANBUL (By Wireless). TURKEY stands at the crossroads of the world. She is the guardian of narrow waters which wash oriental and occidental shores. Below her on the map lie all the riches of Iran and India, to the west all the lands of the Mediterranean. She is at once a dam against further Soviet expansion westward and an outpost of the West.

HERKIMER, N.Y., April 26 (AP) -- State Supreme Court Justice Abram Zoller today dismissed an action brought to prevent a $600,000 estate from going to two "heavens" of Father Divine, Negro cult leader.
Elimination of the State Department's information service and the American broadcasts to foreign nations would be a "terrible mistake" in the opinion of Robert E. Sherwood, playwright.

Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, announced yesterday that a survey of its members in the last three weeks has shown that onefifth have reduced prices on one or more of their products this year.

MICHAEL OLIVER was still an undiscovered young American artist when he settled with his wife, Margaret, his daughter. Lisa, and his inseparable Bohemian friend, Harold Bierstund, in an old villa overlooking a small fishing village on the French coast.

Completing a consecutive double for the Greentree Stable, the 5year-old gelding Coincidence provided a mild surprise at Jamaica yesterday by winning with not the slightest difficulty the fortieth running of the $20,000 added Excelsior Handicap.

THE transatlantic passenger trade is taking a long time to recover from the effect of the war years and today only a handful of luxury liners worthy of the name are plying the North Atlantic lanes to European ports.

"MARGUERITE REILLY" is an unusual book. For readers whose conception of the distaff side of British fiction is somewhere between the refined stream of consciousness of Virginia Woolf and the refined gaiety of Angela Thirkell, this grimly objective novel will be a total surprise.

THE recent paintings by Esther Williams, at the Kraushaar Gallery, constitute her best and most diverse exhibition thus far. Persuasive color and well worked out compositions have always characterized her work. Most of the new work has gained over that earlier seen in a new freedom of brush work; and in several examples there is a basically abstract approach.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 -- Inadequate housing, not job discrimination, appears to be the main worry of Negroes here, and leaders accuse real estate interests and the Federal Housing Administration over policies which they say provoke irritation and racial outbreaks.

The United States Treasury Department's decision to redeem the third $200,000,000 block of its bills on May 1, accompanied by the series of calls on its war loan deposit accounts in banks, indicates an important development in the elimination of the pattern of wartime Government financing, informed observers asserted last week.

Of the 6,000,000 persons who are sick in the United States every day, fewer than 1,250,000 are in hospitals. Invaluable assistance in the care of many of the remaining 4,750,000, who are treated in their homes, is given by the 20,000 public health nurses, who make 16,000,000 visits each year to one of every six families in the nation.

MARTHA SCOTT, screen actress, will play the featured role in "I Have Seen the Children," a radio drama about the displaced children of Europe, to be presented over WQXR from 9:30 to 10 P.M. on Tuesday.
CHICAGO, April 26 (U.P.) -- Eighty-five executives saw today what can happen to an overworked heart.

HERE is a popular-style romance covering the reconstruction of a young Army woman returned from the wars. Mrs. Seifert sets out to scotch all those rumors about women in the service. Her Rosalind is a pretty girl who worked with a United States Army hospital in England and is engaged to the head of her hospital unit.

Henry A. Wallace left Europe yesterday to return to the United States after a busy seventeen-day speaking tour that had carried him to five western European countries. He had traveled as a private citizen, but his trip had stirred more discussion than any of his previous travels as a Government official.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 26 -- The apparently irreconcilable claims of Jews and Arabs to the control of Palestine will be brought before the United Nations when a special session of the General Assembly opens at Flushing Meadow, Queens, on Monday at 11 A.M.

The proposed billion-dollar outlay by Government and public sponsors on airports in the next seven years may be "an investment in deathtraps" unless industrialists, local and State agencies and planners support the Civil Aeronautics Administration in its efforts to create safe airport zoning regulations, according to Ralph G. Schwebemeyer of Newark, president of the Society of Industrial Realtors.

ZANE GREY'S books of the West would fill several fivefoot shelves. This latest was published serially in 1927 as "Open Range" and is now appearing in book form long after its author's death. It departs from the conventional Grey pattern only in introducing its hero.

THE new work which Martha Graham will present for the first time in Boston on Saturday in the Symposium on Music Criticism sponsored by Harvard University has been entitled "Night Journey." It deals with the legend of Jocasta and Oedipus and becomes thus the third work in succession by Miss Graham on classical Greek themes.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean, a leader in Washington society for many years and owner of the famous Hope diamond, died tonight at 6:15 in her home here. She was in her sixtieth year.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Government has flatly rejected for the fourteenth time in two years the United States appeal to let fifteen Russian wives of American citizens join their husbands in this country.

FROM time to time this department has commented on the excursions of Ivor Brown into the natural history of words. What innocently began as "A Word in Tour Ear" was tentatively prolonged by "Just Another Word."
LONDON, April 26 (Reuters) -- Results of football games in Great Britain today: ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division Arsenal 5, Grimsby 3. Aston Vill 1, Liverpool 2. Blackburn 0, Stoke City 2.

The Greater New York Fund's tenth annual campaign on behalf of hospitals, health and welfare agencies will get under way on Tuesday with a dinner in the Hotel Astor that will feature a week of activities. Senator Irving M. Ives will be the principal speaker at the dinner.

THIS is reportedly the first novel by a citizen of the Philippine Republic to be published in America. The author, Stevan Javellana, is a 29-yearold law student who fought with the Philippine Army and later with the guerrillas.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 26 -- Yugoslavia is investing more than $5,500,000,000 in her five-year plan and must attain its goals, Marshal Tito told Parliament tonight. "We cannot be dependent on capitalistic countries," he said.

BASEBALL will pay tribute to Babe Ruth today with special services at the various parks. But even in the Yankee Stadium, the "House that Ruth Built," the ceremonies are not expected to be overly elaborate. The Sultan of Swat is still a mighty sick man and the thought behind the occasion is more important than the festivities themselves.

IN one small garden maroon primroses are in bloom with the first daffodils. Yellow, lavender and coral ones add their colors when the narcissus display is at its height. A tall pink kind appears with the pastel tulips, and lingers after them.

Buyers' resistance to high prices has concentrated the attention of manufacturers upon practical steps toward meeting their customers on their own buying levels, industrial executives disclosed here during production conferences which ended yesterday.

THE post-war scene in Japan presents all sorts of curious goings-on, suggesting in many instances that the influence of the mysterious West is making the mysterious East even more mysterious than usual.

GLYNDON, Md., April 26 (AP) -- Stuart S. Janney Jr. rode his champion hunter Winton to victory today in the fifty-first Maryland Hunt Cup race. Winton clinched the title of the free state's top steeple-chase hunter.

THEY say that all comedians have a secret yearning to play Hamlet. Eddie Albert admits to no such desire. But he has a very purposeful perspective on life, and he is not content to sit back and just philosophize, which he could afford to do on his earnings as an actor.

Within two months of the marketing of Michigan veterans bonus bonds, the municipal bond market again is face to face this week with the challenge of recordbreaking investment supply. The issue to be placed with investors this time is the $300,000,000 State of Illinois Service Recognition bonds, which will come up for sale on Tuesday in Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- Exploration of the possibilities of international administration of the world's airways and oceans, including the Polar regions, was urged today by Miss Emily Greene Balch of Wellesley, Mass., 80-year-old winner of the Nobel Peace Prize for 1946.

JUST thirty-six years ago this week in this review: Books and Authors, on Page 1, is devoted to a discussion of "Shakespeare: Poet or Impostor?" No contemporary reader can fail wistfully to appreciate the fine hand and skilled logic of the Times columnist:

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Democratic geographers who have been trying to map party strategy for 1948 have lately identified an unhappy hollow on the national political scene and named it Woodrow Wilson Valley.
BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, April 26 -- The British Military Government is seriously concerned over a new threat to the already precarious stability of the mark.

THE fifty-fifth annual exhibition of work by members of the National Association of Women Artists opens to the public today in the maze of galleries of the National Academy. This is one of the liveliest exhibitions the organization has put on and despite the size -- there are about 300 entries -- it has been exceptionally well installed.

BERLIN, April 26 -- Two Russian correspondents of Tass, who made an informal tour of the United States zone last week, restated their earlier charge that the United States Military Government was tragically mishandling denazificaton.

Syphilis is usually diagnosed by a Wasserman test. If the result is negative, it does not mean that the patient is free from syphilis. There are also occasional false positive results after upper respiratory infections (severe colds), malaria, mumps and other diseases and various types of vaccinations.

NEW ORLEANS -- For the eighth consecutive time Cajun families from the Barataria section will vie with one another in a pirogue race on Bayou Barataria near Lafitte on Sunday, May 18. What Mardi Gras is to New Orleans and the Derby is to Louisville the pirogue contest is to the Cajun.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) -- Harry (The Cat) Brecheen, who has tormented the Cubs for years, found his match in Bob Chipman today and the St Louis Cardinals lost to the Cubs, 4 to 1, for their fourth straight defeat before a crowd of 34,922.

Some people are like ants. Give them, a warm day and a piece of ground and they start digging. There the similarity ends. Ants keep on digging. Most people don't. They establish contact with the soil, absorb so much vernal vigor that they can't stay in one place, and desert the fork or spade to see how the rhubarb is coming and whether the asparagus is yet in sight.

The British Government's reservation of the right to disregard any unfavorable United Nations decision on the Palestine issue places Britain in "an immoral position," Rabbi David H. Panitz said yesterday in a sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway.

DURHAM, N.C., April 26 (U.P.) -- Alert armed guards patrolled grounds and buildings of the sprawling Duke University Hospital tonight in search of an elusive pyromaniac who has started eight fires in the institution in three days.

THERE'LL be a flurry of openings on Broadway this week -- three entrants are going to the post and, in a season of assorted oddities, each will be adding something to the book. Most interesting, perhaps, from the artistic standpoint, is the double-bill to be offered at the Barrymore Thursday.
Tomorrow at Flushing Meadow -- in the first special session of the United Nations General Assembly -- the representatives of fifty-five nations will take up the problem of Palestine.

Although they heartily subscribe to President Truman's thesis of increased productivity for lower prices, New York garment manufacturers last week pointed out that the fashion industry must, as a matter of self-preservation, curtail its activity in a market where prices are sifting slowly, to lower levels.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (U.P.) -- Jess Larson, acting general counsel of the War Assets Administration, testified today before a House committee investigating surplus property sales that the Government lost a considerable sum in the sale of surplus nuts and bolts under a contract that bordered on "the unconscionable."

A strike of 6,000 brewery workers that had been set for last midnight was called off yesterday pending meetings of union locals in Manhattan and Brooklyn today. An attempt will be made to negotiate wage agreements with individual brewers rather than the Brewers Board of Trade.

IN 1939, at the outbreak of the European war, President Roosevelt entered relations with leaders of the Protestant, Jewish and Catholic faiths with the declared purpose of making possible joint action between political and religious authorities for the alleviation of suffering during the war and the eventual re-establishment of peace.

VIENNA, April 26 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark repeated today previous statements of the United States delegation in Moscow that the Soviet Union had moved much farther away from the other Allies on German assets in Austria during the Big Four conference.

Yesterday was the last day for persons to receive vaccinations at police precincts. In announcing the closing of this service, Commissioner of Health Israel Weinstein said that mass vaccinations would be given in Health Department centers tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday from 9 A.M. to noon and from 6 to 9 P.M.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Senate War Investigating Committee redrafted a bill today to meet objections which had prompted President Truman's first veto since the Republicans took control of Congress.

"Unrealistic thinking and boondoggling by both the Government and property owners are betraying the housing interest of the American public," and war veterans in particular, in the opinion of Fred Berger, president of the Fred Berger Company, Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- An estimate that the Army's ground combat strength was only about 200,000 men and an assertion that our occupation forces abroad could be "destroyed by a major power" were made tonight by two Congressional specialists in national defense.

IT is rather difficult to estimate such a book as Margaret Osborn's first novel, "The Ring and the Dream." In spite of her careful and sensitive writing, the novel is weak in its construction. She has built out of the effect of wealth and its environment on two differing people a series of remembrances from varied sources, rather than a straightforward dramatic novel.

OTTAWA, April 26 -- Hemispheric union and the St. Lawrence Seaway have bobbed up again in the Canadian Parliament and the newspapers this week as matters for comment with something of the seasonal recurrence of the first robin and the Loch Ness monster.

THIS is the story of post-World War II Czechoslovakia, of the land and its people, of its domestic and international life. Mr. Hindus describes it as a most interesting and challenging country, staging a revolution by evolution, instead of evolution by revolution.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 (AP) -- Despite all the new medical weapons against disease, this country can remain free of the socalled great plagues only by eternal vigilance, Dr. Rodney R. Beard, Stanford University public health expert, said in a lecture last night.

THE three-day Symposium on Music Criticism which will be held Sanders Theatre, Cambridge, under the auspices of Harvard University on the first, second and third of May, has an impressive program. The opening meeting will be chaired by Dr. Archibald Davison of the Harvard Music Department.
The national economy was under intense scrutiny last week in three areas -- prices, wages and labor legislation.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable receipts. 200 head (estimated): total 3,200 (estimated). Compared with week age Hogs weighing under 280 pounds.

The famous "touchdown twins," Glenn W. Davis and Felix A. (Doc) Blanchard, and seven of their Army teammates will play on the 1947 College All-Star football squad to meet the New York Giants, Eastern professional champions of the National League, in the Polo Grounds Wednesday night, Sept. 3.

It was not only the terrific heat generated by the explosion of atomic bombs in Japan, the blast and the resultant violent wind that brought death and destruction to Hiroshima and Nagasaki, but the deadly rays that were given off. Because these rays killed sometimes white and sometimes red corpuscles in the blood stream, many persons died days and weeks after the bombs were dropped.

The war-learned lesson of the importance of self-sufficiency as an instrument of protection in times of international hostilities and as a basis of national prosperity is being applied by several South American countries in the establishment of integrated steel industries within their own borders, it became known last week.

DO women really change? It is the general impression that during the last few generations women have become leggier and slimmer -- but have they? Most people would say more and more women are entering professions such as medicine -- but are they? Women are as much interested in fashion as ever -- but do they have the same attitude toward it?

CHICAGO, April 26 -- Chances of Illinois having a State Fair Employment Practices Commission this year, similar to one operating in New York, were lessened this week when the Legislature for the second time in two years rejected two similar bills that would have outlawed job discrimination because of race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 26 -- Following is a series of basic questions and answers on the Palestine situation, which comes before the special session of the United Nations General Assembly tomorrow: (1) What is the present status of Palestine?
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Department of Commerce reported a drop today in the rate at which the national economy has been expanding.

For ninety minutes yesterday morning it was circus of highly hilarious variety in Times Hall. The packed house included 507 youngsters and not a few adults. From the Big Top -- Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus -- came, a splinter of madcap clowns, jugglers and Vargas with his trained chimpanzees to evoke cheers, whistles and applause.

ANY time Jean Treister strolls into a department store -- and she does so a lot these days when department stores are cutting prices regularly -- there is a pretty good chance she will attract the attention of the store detectives.

The library of Paul Francis Webster of Beverly Hills, Calif., will be auctioned tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. The collection contains a large number of first editions, autograph letters and manuscripts.

THE pattern of urban living always has held a peculiar fascination for Guy Greer. Giving up his chosen profession of mining engineer after World War I for international economics and finance, he gradually turned his hobby of studying community planning into a full-time career after serving with the Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Housing Administration during the depression years.

PARIS, April 26 -- Negotiations are soon to begin to coordinate the trade of France and her zone in Germany with that of the two other Western zones. These talks will be the first step in what is expected to be a complete revision of French foreign policy as a result of the Moscow conference.

BOSTON to Yarmouth steamship service will be resumed on May 29, when Eastern Steamship Lines puts the newly refurnished steamship Yarmouth onto the Nova Scotia run. The first trip will coincide with the Apple Blossom Festival, May 30June 1, in Annapolis Valley.

CINCINNATI, April 26 (AP) -- A two-run outburst in the eighth inning gave the Cincinnati Reds a 3-2 victory today over the frontrunning Pittsburgh Pirates, who thrilled a crowd of 11,316 with the first triple play of the major league season.

WITH considerable beating of the drums, Decca has issued an album called, Our Common Heritage (eight ten-inch records). It contains sixteen poems commemorating "milestones in the history of America," read by glamorous names like Bing Crosby, Brian Donlevy, Walter Huston, Fredric March, Agnes Moorehead and Pat O'Brien.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 26 -- Eighty to 100 fellowships are being provided by the United Nations to enable twelve war-ravaged countries to train social welfare workers abroad. The grants are part of the project to carry on the training program of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.

P.G. Wodehouse, whose preoccupation with Psmith, Jeeves and their contemporaries led him into a tactical error when the Germans overran France, arrived here yesterday hoping that America would give him credit for good intentions.

Most of the housing measures adopted at the recent session of the State Legislature and signed by Governor Dewey are "clearly favorable to housing progress in New York City," the committee on housing of the Community Service Society declared in its annual legislative review, made public yesterday.

Leading concerns in three major industries, the General Electric Company, the Chrysler Corporation and the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, reached agreements yesterday calling for wage increases approximating 15 cents an hour.

THE familiar moss pinks have already opened in sheltered corners near New York. With blossoms so closely packed together that their foliage is inconspicuous even at a short distance, each brilliant patch resembles a small gay rug rolled out like a royal carpet to greet the spring.

Editor New York Times Book Review: MR. HARRY LEVIN, in his recent review of the "Columbia Dictionary of European Literature" in your columns, pointed out some merits of the volume and, as becomes a discriminating scholar, its omissions and shortcomings.

Possibilities of reducing the cost of building will be the major topic at the spring meeting of the Producers Council, national organization of manufacturers of building materials and equipment, opening in Grand Rapids, Mich., tomorrow.

MOSCOW, April 26 -- The primary conflict at the meeting of Foreign Ministers which ended here this week was that between the urgent economic needs of the present and the requirements necessary for a stable and enduring peace.

OLD-LINE pictorialism was much in evidence here last week during the Third Annual Dassonville Print Competition, when salon prints were judged for cash awards in the only contest of its kind. Although characterized by print quality of a rather high order, particularly for entries in a prize contest, the general run of exhibits offered little relief from the monotony and lack of vitality so often encountered in contemporary salons.

"WHEN I joined the Century." wrote Henry Holt in his reminiscences, "it was unquestionably the most active center of culture in New York." He had joined it in 1870, when "there was in the city hardly a man of eminence in literature, art or science who did not belong to the Century."

LONDON, April 26 -- Despite the Yugoslav threat to bring the matter before the United Nations, the British Government will not recede from its refusal to hand over several hundred Yugoslav refugees sought by Belgrade as war criminals, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

A preference for motion pictures that portray "average people" rather than those that "exaggerate life" was expressed yesterday by several participants in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast from the studio of WQXR at 730 Fifth Avenue.

Republicans and Democrats both have national committee headquarters in Washington, with big staffs to turn out publicity, publish party newspapers, collect funds, write speeches and arrange dates for party orators to deliver them. Basically the national committees exist for one purpose -- to try to elect a President.

IN this sober-sided year of 1947, a bright necktie is enough to draw stares. Back in 1770, at Copenhagen, a gentleman of fashion might appear in sapphire coat, embroidered waistcoat, black satin smalls, pink silk stockings and high red heels, and draw only a bill from his tailor.

Editor New York Times Book Review: WHY lump Holmes (Oliver Wendell Holmes), an authentic humorist in verse and prose, with the far from merry Whittier, Emerson and Longfellow?" asks Franklin P. Adams in a review of "Native American Humor," by James R. Aswell, in one of your recent issues.

An interesting aspect of the GI home ownership program is revealed in the end-of-the-year survey by the United States Savings and Loan League made public yesterday. While in some parts of the country, notably in the West, the veterans are using as much and sometimes more of their GI borrowing power to build new homes as to buy old ones, the characteristic experience for the nation as a whole is to the contrary.

BECAUSE Wake Island remained a legend long after it ceased to be a battle, it became something of a moral victory outweighing our military defeat. There is no telling how many thousands of young men went from seeing the Hollywood film story of the battle to their nearest recruiting station, but their numbers were undoubtedly considerable.

HARDY chrysanthemums will benefit by breaking up the old clumps for division this spring. Good use may be made of the new bottom growth for fresh plant material. The strongest plants are propagated from root divisions, not from cuttings.

UNLIKE most recent treatments of life in the Orient, this book is primarily neither analytical nor political in intent. But, being the work of an alert mind, it impinges on actual conditions in China, including the present war, and evaluates them as they appear.

General Foods Corporation has adopted a comprehensive personnel program aimed at establishing an adequate reservoir of replacements for top or general management executives, Gordon Van Ark, manager, personnel development division, personnel administration department, disclosed in an interview last week.

World markets are beginning to show definite signs of resistance to United States prices despite unsatisfied and continuing demand for American goods, foreign traders stated last week. Reports of declining prices in the United States have resulted in so many cancellations of orders in numerous consumer goods lines that one large foreign trade group has warned its members not to ship until they get late confirmation on long standing orders.
A national drive to solve the low-cost home problem by encouraging the construction of new "industryengineered" homes is soon to be started by joint action of two important trade associations.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Representative Harold Knutson of Minnesota, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, accused President Truman today of "playing partisan politics with the tax situation." In a statement distributed by the Republican National Committee, the author of the House-approved bill to cut personal income taxes from 10.5 to 30 per cent asserted:

DES MOINES, April 26 (AP) -- Two track marks were ground into the cinders at the thirty-eighth Drake Relays today and another was tied as the record-breaking field of 2,000 athletes ended a carnival unmatched in performance in the past five years.

TAKE from the misty fables of the Middle Ages a lion and a unicorn; set them down, semidisguised, in Victorian England in a legend-haunted castle; introduce them to Maria Merryweather, an elfin miss from London and to a shepherd boy who, like Peter Ibbetson, dreams true, and you have the chief ingredients of Miss Goudge's new book.

NORWAY'S achievements across three centuries are reflected in designs of an eleven-stamp series received on a cover by Scott Stamp and Coin Company last week. The group commemorates the tercentenary of the establishment of Norway's postal system.

AS the weather turns springlike, trailer owners grow increasingly restive. Like boat skippers, they want to get their craft out of "drydock" and head for the open. Those anchored to desk jobs have become more and more wistful as luckier fellow fans escaped to Florida and other Southern centers during the cold months.

Secretary Marshall has come back from Moscow to a united people deeply grateful for his firm stand on their behalf. His return is no retreat. In fact it is notification to the world, and especially to the Soviet Government, that we will no longer retreat from those high principles for which we fought the war.

ATHENS, April 26 (AP) -- Nicholas Zachariades, secretary general of the Greek Communist party, who has had freedom of movement throughout Greece, was threatened for the first time today with being declared a fugitive.

LONDON, April 26 (Canadian Press) -- Abbreviated fixture lists were the order of the day today as English soccer clubs, knocked out of the cup competition earlier in the season, battled to hold their positions in the league standings.

Letter From America Dear Dr. Pangloss: We have our labor and industry problems in the United States, but you must not let yourself be carried away by scare headlines. It simply is not true that American wage-earners are in an ugly mood when on strike.
ANNAPOLIS, April 26 -- Yale came back to the water with a sweeping triumph today to open its first full-scale season of rowing since 1942.

MUNICH, Germany, April 26 -- In the swarming Jewish displaced persons camps of the United States zone this spring there is a great deal of talk about a "a march on Palestine" but very little marching.

MRS. LANGLEY, whose "Dark Medallion" won a Friends of American Writers award in 1945, has written her newest novel in the form of a whimsical allegory. God is her chief protagonist, the not unreasonable Deus in her suburban machina.
Steadiness prevailed in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closing prices were 15 to 24 points net higher, led by strength in the May, 1947, delivery.

RANDOM HOUSE, the other day, sat down and wrote a letter to Senator Bilbo: In his new novel, Sinclair Lewis discusses a problem of intense interest to every American. I know that it is also of special importance to you, and I am therefore sending you a copy of "Kingablood Royal" [which deals with the Negro problem in a small American city].

THE technique of "high-key" photography was described here last week by Mrs. Rosalind Maingot, Fellow and only woman member of the Royal Photographic Society of Great Britain. Speaking at the Master Institute Theatre under auspices of the Metropolitan Camera Club Council, Inc., Mrs. Maingot illustrated her talk with slides of some of the portraits and other subjects that have made her one of the most famous of English woman photographers.
To the Screen Editor: I do think you were hard on "Smash-Up," and I'm taking the liberty of saying so because I know a little about the history of this picture.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., April 26 -- Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the New York Guard, announced today that field training encampments for 16,000 state troops, in quotas of not over 2,000 at a time, will open in Camp Smith, Peekskill, on June 21.
URBANA, Ill. EARLY in June, dedication ceremonies will be held at the University of Illinois for a fiveand-a-half room house that has just been put up on the campus.

THIS will certainly be a banner summer for music festivals in America -- and most of them will feature contemporary music. There are so many lined up that a man with a private plane could probably attend a festival every night of the summer and his flights would take him back and forth across the continent several times.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (Religious News Service) -- President Truman's proposal to aid Greece and Turkey has been endorsed by the board of directors of the National Council of Catholic Women, it was announced here today.

Delegates to the American Newspaper Publishers Association convention, which closed with a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last Friday, went home aware that New York's hotels have returned to pre-war balance.

With the departure from here on Saturday of the motor vessel Newscarrier, the Davie Transportation Company, Ltd., will open its tenth consecutive season of operation of a freight service between New York and Montreal along the inland route via the Hudson River and Lake Champlain, it was announced yesterday by the Aqua Shipping Company, agents for the operators.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The story of American democracy, which the State Department has been telling to the world, was threatened this week with an abrupt ending.

Climaxing a series of recent developments indicating a Congressional shift away from the Government's pro-public power policy, the House of Representatives approved by a voice vote on Friday a $13,370,200 cut in appropriations for the Bonneville Power Administration and at the same time approved a slash in the Department of Interior's budget for the fiscal year beginning on July 1 to $161,413,513, or 45% less than the Presidential recommendation.
Babe Ruth will come home today.

Expressing the view that depth of any decline in retail sales volume during the months ahead can be controlled to a considerable degree by close adherence to a calculated buying plan, a large buying organization here last week emphasized four major principles for store guidance in operating on such a plan.

The 1947 edition of the national sports on parade, an exhibition of Jewish athletes participating in various sports, was held at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night under the auspices of the United States Maccabi Association with the cooperation of the Manhattan Zionist Region.
THE end of the Moscow Conference means the return of censorship on all news sent from Russia. After approximately two months of freedom, correspondents will once again write with the censor in mind.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 26 (AP) -- The Hollywood Turf Club today recommended returning to the public all breakage in pari-mutuel betting, and, in an announcement that may produce nation-wide repercussions in racing circles, said it had worked put a method to solve mathematical problems in the plan.

LONDON, April 26 -- A crowd of 99,000 fans from all parts of Britain saw London's Charlton Athletic battle to a 1-0 victory over the Burnley Lancashire club in the final for the Football Association's Cup at Wembley Stadium today.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- The American Medical Association, a nonprofit organization of 131,590 members and 72,243 fellows, whose wide scope of activities directly or indirectly benefits the public health, will be 100 years old on May 5.

LONDON, April 26 -- British Liberals today called for the immediate adoption of "a workable over-all plan," including a national wages and profits policy, to solve Britain's economic crisis. This decision was reached at the closing session of the annual party conference in Bournemouth.

ATLANTA, April 26 -- Deprived of needed revenues to fulfill a party program of expanded services, Gov. Melvin E. Thompson, as Director of the Budget, has allocated almost half of the State's income for the operation of schools.

NANKING (By Wireless). IN the development of relations between China and the West, modern medicine has been perhaps the greatest single agency for good-will. For nearly thirty years the foremost instrumentality through which Western medicine has drawn the Occident and Orient together has been Peiping Union Medical College.

NGAIO MARSH is getting too good at her job to be properly appreciated by addicts -- though her name on a book cover, as always, is a tocsin to whodunit maniacs. Ahead of them lie certain assured items of perfection.

BOSTON, April 26 (AP) -- For the second time in as many days the lightly regarded Philadelphia Athletics today rallied in the ninth to defeat the Boston Red Sox. This time they scored four runs after two were out to win, 5 -- 2. In yesterday's drizzling rain the Mackmen came up with five runs in the ninth to beat the American League champions, 11 -- 7.

THESE three books are the first of the more thoughtful works on the atom bomb, written in each case by a man who has some right to ask a hearing, and who is willing to concede that twenty months is not too long a time in which to conceive a book, plan it, draft it, write it, edit it, and see it through the press.

AFTER Paris was liberated in the summer of 1944, the Resistance was so proud and powerful that many people invented Resistance records for themselves to get an article published or to stay out of trouble. A year later it was not uncommon to hear the bitter joke that Resistance veterans were beginning to invent more "respectable" records for the same reasons.

PRINCETON, N.J. -- To many New Yorkers spring means escape from metropolitan sidewalks to quiet, wooded paths where a biker can step back into the nineteenth century, free of crowds and safe from automobiles.

WHEN Francisco Vasquez de Coronado, first tourist to the American Southwest, made his jaunt through the region he was looking for gold and a shining city. The gentleman withdrew frustrated, for he was some four hundred years ahead of time.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- New York University was thanking its lucky stars tonight for a bad break that pushed Coach Emil Von Elling's pupils into the most sensational triumph of the fiftythird annual Penn Relays.
ST. LOUlS, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The White Sox regained undisputed possession of first place in the American League today with a 2-to-0 victory over the last-place Browns.

Many New York apartment tenants agree that their landlord is having a difficult time, what with frozen rents, higher operating costs and the prospect of higher taxes, according to William J. Demorest, president of William A. White Sons, realty brokers and agents for residential buildings.

The first real indication of price reductions in commodities in months was disclosed in the current report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. Their conclusions were based on the composite opinion of purchasing agents in a wide variety of lines of manufacturing who reported that prices are "almost static, with a slight downward trend."
Critical 48 Days In the past forty-eight days there has opened a new chapter in the postwar history of Russian-American relations.

IT'S no wonder that Americans who have been brought up on dinners of lamb chops and peas sometimes smile politely when the comment is repeated that cooking is a great art. What skill is there to lighting the oven, broiling the chops, applying the salt and pepper, transferring the meat to a platter and carrying it to the table?

HOLLYWOOD. THE Warner Brothers, who have a reputation for timeliness in making pictures, last week got on the film, industry's new bandwagon by announcing that the forthcoming picture, "Up Until Now," will expose "the effects of Communist and Fascist influences on American democracy."

THERE is a strong possibility that within the next few weeks Newark Airport will join La Guardia Field, Idlewild Airport and Floyd Bennett Field under the operating guidance of the Port of New York Authority.

To the editor: Regarding "Report on the Communist Party (U.S.A.)," by A.H. Raskin, on the question whether the American Communist party is really a legal political party, in the accepted sense, or a conspiracy, I would like to present a few facts and some data from official Communist publications.

TO THE EDITOR: H.E. Salisbury's article, "Russian Fallacies About Us -- and Vice Versa," gives the totally misleading impression that "basic misunderstanding" between the American and the Russian people is about equal.

AFTER a lifetime spent in reading and writing, one may become suspicious of literary effects and find it difficult to indulge in quick enthusiasms. All the more reason that; when one comes upon such a book as these three short novels by Vercors, he should feel deeply stirred -- and even indulge in enthusiasm.

PARIS, April 25 -- Having fired warning shots from Bayeux, Barle -Duc, Bruneval and Strasbourg, Charles de Gaulle came to Paris this week to elucidate at a press conference the aims of his new movement called the Reunion of the French, People.

Fifty local unions representing 30,000 workers, which withdrew recently from the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union, CIO, announced yesterday their new affiliation with the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO. John Driscoll, chairman of the Provisional Metalworkers Council, made the announcement at a convention of 155 delegates of the council at the Park Central Hotel.

A CITY considers itself fortunate when it has a symphony orchestra, a stock company, a flower show or a big league baseball team. But between 1918 and 1946 in Boston there were many citizens who wondered how lucky they were in having the Red Sox, for in those twenty-seven years the Red Sox did not once win a pennant.

At a time of great economic change in the world, economists of the Twentieth Century Fund, a non-profit, non-partisan research foundation endowed by the late Edward A. Filene of Boston, have made a study of the likely trend of the national economy in the United States during the remainder of the post-war transition period, estimated to end by 1950, and the ensuing "real" post-war decade from 1950 to 1960.

LUNGA POINT, Cape Gloucester, the Matanikau, Gavutu, Ie Shima, Suribachi, Makin, Pelellu, Saipan, Tarawa! Four years, three years, two years ago, they were familiar names to all Americans. How many could identify them today -- except the United States Marines, who fought for them and took them?

To the Art Editor: YOU are certainly right. The stopping of the State Department's traveling exhibitions in Europe and Haiti definitely is a cultural crisis. It challenges every cultural progressive in the country and should challenge even those neutrals in the war of ideology between modern and academic art who believe in fair play through a showing of both schools.

NEW DELHI, India, April 26 (AP) -- Indications that the predominantly Hindu Congress party might be making preparations for possible talks on the partition of India to meet the Moslem League demands for an independent Moslem State came today from a reliable informant within the Congress party.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert was installed as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York in a ceremony of ecclesiastical dignity and splendor yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

ONE of the earliest and most generous of American philanthropists and civic benefactors was Judah Touro (a son of the first minister of the Newport, R.I., Jewish congregation), whose extensive fortune was largely accumulated by mercantile, shipping and other activities in New Orleans.
DETROIT, April 26 -- The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, announced tonight a two-year agreement providing for a wage increase of about 15 cents an hour.

The New York Telephone Company served notice yesterday on the four metropolitan telephone unions, whose membership of 35,000 workers has been idle for nearly three weeks, that it would not be bound by any formula or settlement that may be reached in Washington.

BROADCASTING, after the feverish spending of the war years, is settling down to a more realistic fiscal diet. Its people, particularly upper-bracket talent, are becoming uncomfortably aware of a growing coldness by many sponsors to the fancy prices put on their services.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., April 26 -- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, suggested here today that universities were being misused under the veterans' education program and urged that in the future a large share of post-high school education be shouldered locally.

MOSCOW, April 26 -- The United States and Britain are collecting enormous amounts of reparations from current production in Germany while refusing to approve the Soviet Union's request for them, an article in the Moscow Bolshevik charged today.

"A LITTLE TREASURY OF GREAT POETRY" is a successor or rival to Palgrave's "Golden Treasury" and QuillerCouch's "The Oxford Book of English Verse." and falls about midway between them in length and in the number of poets included.

ROME, April 26 -- The regional election held last Sunday in Sicily resulted in a sweeping victory for the Left-wing parties which successfully stormed what hitherto had been considered a citadel of conservatism.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Prospects for the extension of rent control beyond June 30 without any general increase were considerably strengthened this week, but only after a spirited behind-thescenes battle in the ranks of the Republican Congressional majority.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 26 -- Hungary has applied for membership in the United Nations in the first move taken by a former Axis country for admission to the world organization, it was announced today.
New recruits to the retail-price reduction plans that are spreading across the country were announced yesterday, but in other quarters there was head-shaking and expressions of dissent.

CEILOMETER -- The ceilometer is an automatic electronic device which accurately and continually measures the heights of clouds. A pulsating light source throws a beam, invisible to the human eye in the daylight, vertically into the sky. A unit 1,000 feet from the projector detects the "scatter energy" produced on cloud layers.
On Friday and Saturday in Dallas, Tex., an interesting group of champions will try to retain their National Amateur Athletic Union gymnastic titles.

ON the surface, nothing could be more deceptively slight than this fine short story (though it is offered to the reading public on its own, it is hardly more than that in length). The Breadwinner, a coastwise British trawler assigned to anti-aircraft patrol

BY old academic tradition, it ought to be news when the president of Harvard University lectures to a Yale audience. It is, President Conant has presented the reader with a clear and winning account of the tactics and strategy of science.

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 26 -- The Geneva conference has absorbed the shock of the first batch of tariff offers without springing any large leaks. The meeting seems less endangered by any unreasonableness of the initial exchanges of the proposed duty reduction schedules than by the threatened undermining of the United States' bargaining position by Congressional action.

IN the 160 years since the founding of the Republic there have been some 300 attempts by Congress to change the Constitutional provision for Presidential tenure and re-eligibility. Now, mirabile dictu, one of these attempts has been successful -- at least so far as the Congress is concerned -- and State Legislatures have the opportunity of passing on an amendment limiting Presidents to two elective terms.
A crowd of 30,017 baseball fans left Yankee Stadium yesterday convinced that 20-year-old Don Johnson justifies many of the extravagant things that have been said about him.

THE latest "biggest thing to hit Broadway in years" arrives at the Cort Theatre on Friday. There's nothing startling about the play, "Heads or Tails," farce about a diplomat. But behind it is a new producing unit, Your Theatre. Inc., which modestly claims credit for a revolutionary idea in backing plays -- you buy a ticket and thereby become a backer.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 (AP) -- Mort Cooper, making his second start of the year, held the Phillies to four hits and pitched the Braves to a 7 to 1 triumph in the first of a three-game series today before 10,597 fans.
Riverdale Country School, which will celebrate its fortieth anniversary on Wednesday, is to become an institution for the development of citizenship "both of the country and of the world."

BOSTON, April 26 (AP) -- After finishing first by a neck, the Highland Stable's Laboulaye was disqualified and placed third behind the Reynolds Brothers' Mr. Chairman and Spangled Game, in the 10,000 added Governor's Handicap today before 32,243 fans at Suffolk Downs.

THE Horticultural Society of New York will hold its annual narcissus show in the clubrooms, 598 Madison Avenue, on Tuesday and Wednesday. This is the event that was scheduled for April 24 and 25, but it is being held this week instead because cool weather has delayed flowering.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Truman's campaign for lower prices bore some fruit this week. Tradesmen of many types, from manufacturers of chemicals and cables to retailers of canned goods, announced price cuts.

THE girl of the title is Marte Grotjohann, a personable young peasant, whom the author occasionally (and not quite convincingly) presents as a simple, intense, dramatic madonna. The ferryman is Jurgen Doskocil, a great, bulky, bear-like man, very good, honest and long-suffering; but he, like Marte, is not convincing as a figure of saintliness.

THE fifty-three authors of this collection of wartime reminiscences are all disabled veterans, some of them double amputees. Their stories were written as ordinary themes in a course in English composition taught by Don M. Wolfe at some unnamed university in Washington, D.C.

THE housing situation is not solely a residential matter, what with the dearth of available first-run film showcases hereabouts. So it is pleasant to report that a new theatre will be constructed on Forty-second Street.

TODAY, although streamliners hurtle over the Lucin Cutoff, airliners wing over its waters and a transcontinental highway taps its shores, the Great Salt Lake remains a difficult body of water to explore. Boatmen rarely venture into its shallows: only the gulls, celebrated in Utah history, are frequent visitors to its northern reaches and mountainous islands.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 26 (AP) -- Racing up from last place, Virginia-bred Bullet Proof from the stable of Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Whitney closed with a tremendous rush today to win the $30,000 added Chesapeake Stakes and establish himself as a threat for the Kentucky Derby next Saturday.

WILLA S. CATHER: On April 24, at New York City, age 70. Onetime managing editor of McClure's Magazine. Born in Virginia, she lived much of her life in Nebraska. When she began writing she drew upon her experience in the Middle West for the inspiration and background for many of her novels.

The writer of the following letter is a consulting economist, wrote "Labor and Reconstruction in Europe" helped to organise the Amalgamated (Labor) Bank and is a member of pro-labor organizations. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Government officials express concern about a decline in business.

TO the eyes of some business observers last week the situation began to look like a combination of 1920 and 1937. President Truman repeated his indictment of high prices and later made it clear that he would stop at "moral suasion."

It has often been said that the "soak the rich" policy of taxation continued throughout the second World War period. That this policy permeated the Federal income tax system for nearly a decade before the war can hardly be denied.
