We probably had more experimental taxation in that period than we had up to that time and since the incidence of the income tax.

Behind an airtight defense and the three-hit pitching of Jerry Brown, the St. John's University baseball team stopped City College, 13 -- 3, in a Metropolitan Conference game before 300 spectators at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.

A young singer of exceptional charm, skill and intelligence made her appearance late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. She was Mariko Mukai, Japanese-American soprano who was born in Seattle and who came East in 1941 where she received four successive fellowships at the Juilliard Graduate School.

The Philadelphia Bach Festival Chorus, under James Allan Dash, presented Verdi's "Requiem" last night at Carnegie Hall. Neither the choral body of more than 300 voices, nor its conductor, had appeared before in this city, and their initial performance here attracted a large gathering.

PEIPING, April 26 -- Six Communist divisions, totalling 50,000 men, are concentrating at Chienkochi on the Lesser Sungari River, 100 miles northwest of Changchun, Manchurian capital. Nationalist commanders expect a Communist offensive against Changchun within four weeks.

The Truman doctrine of aid to Greece and Turkey is a domestic political maneuver to keep the Democratic party indefinitely in power, Frederick Schuman, Woodrow Wilson Professor of Government at Williams College, asserted yesterday.

JERUSALEM, April 26 -- A.E. Conquest, Deputy Superintendent of Police, was fatally shot by underground gunmen, in Haifa today. His death in the hospital brought British police casualties to six killed and five injured as a result of terrorist action since yesterday.
DAYLILIES are among the best of perennials. Their merits, if described, would sound as exuberant as a seed catalogue.
Although there has been some slackening of the dizzy pace of Manhattan realty trading recently, the prices being paid by buyers are being maintained at a level well above a year ago.

THE torrent of books about Russia which is now pouring off the American presses inescapably reminds one of the fable of the blind men and the elephant. There is so much disagreement in these reports on Russia -- and so much of it is fundamental -- that there are times when it hardly seems possible that the writers are speaking of the same country.

AT a cocktail party at the Algonquin this afternoon Arthur Miller will be knighted by the New York Drama Critics Circle for his current drama, "All My Sons." It is the critics' choice as the best new play of the season.

NOW that the days are longer and the sun's rays more intense, everything in the greenhouse seems to be growing with leaps and bounds. Snapdragons, calendula," fragrant stock and sweet peas, along withgardenias and lilies, join together to make up the grandest greenhouse show of the year.

When H.H. Nininger talks about moonstones he doesn't mean gems but literally rocks that came from the moon. He holds that the stones called tektites have been chipped from the moon by big, fast meteorites. Nininger happens to be one of the American authorities on meteorites, which is the reason why anything that he says about them commands attention.

MISSISSIPPI -- Engineering The School of Engineering at the University of Mississippi has modified its curriculum to meet demands "for permanent and modern services to students planning to enter the engineering profession." The Bachelor of Science degree in general engineering has been changed to a degree in engineering administration and will include, in addition to basic courses, study in accounting, economics and business organization.

LONDON, Monday, April 28 -- Fear that the United Nations General Assembly might recommend a policy for Palestine that Britain could not carry out alone was expressed in an editorial in today's Times of London.

Raw cabbage salad, one of the richest sources of Vitamin C, may be served to advantage in virtually every home right now, for the vegetable is abundant and relatively inexpensive. A considerable loss in nutritive value will result, however, if the salad is not prepared properly, according to a recent report from the United States Department of Agriculture.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 (AP) -- The, Chinese Communist radio highly praised Henry A. Wallace today and assailed the Truman Administration as "a reactionary clique," which it said was operating "in the old Hitlerite way."
A more basic and permanent reduction in prices than the "Newburyport Plan" was demanded yesterday by consumers and some business leaders here and in Washington.

Our Founding Fathers Our city scout said he'd read a while ago a book by Frederick L. Collins, who has devoted some time to the chronicles of this metropolis. It was called "Money Town," meaning New York and especially that part of it toward the tip of Manhattan.

PITTSBURGH, April 27 -- With, the steel labor picture expected to be bright for some time to come, emphasis here last week was on steel production. Steel ingot output for the country was up onehalf a point to 95 per cent of rated capacity.

Wherever organized baseball was played yesterday Babe Ruth was honored. Ceremonies at the Yankee Stadium, where the Babe was given the greatest ovation in the history of the national pastime, were broadcast throughout the world, and what Ruth and others had to say was piped to other ball parks.

MOSCOW, April 27 (Reuters) -- Pointers as to the possible Russian attitude at Monday's special session of the United Nations General Assembly when the Palestine problem will be discussed were given today in Soviet press comment.

The stimulation and revival of German industry without further delay was strongly urged by the National Foreign Trade Council in a statement communicated to Acting Secretary of State Dean Acheson, Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg and Representative Charles A. Eaton.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 27 (U.P) -- The probable field for the seventy -third annual running of the Kentucky Derby next Saturday was narrowed down to an even dozen horses tonight with C.V. Whitney's Phalanx still the betting favorite.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Despite reports earlier in the day that three groups of negotiators in the telephone strike were making "good progress," their meetings adjourned tonight without decisive result. The Government-sponsored conferences will be resumed at the Labor Department tomorrow morning.

A carillon of twenty-six bells presented to the First Presbyterian Church of Stamford. Conn., as a symbol of gratitude and friendship by Nestle's, the chocolate manufacturing concern, was turned over to the Rev. Dr. Donald F. Campbell, the pastor, in a ceremony at Pier 61, North River, yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 27 -- The United Nations General Assembly must eventually consider three fundamental and mutually contradictory issues in deciding the future of Palestine: (1) Whether Britain, which has administered the country under a League of Nations mandate since 1922, shall be allowed to retain control.
BERLIN, April 27 -- Two Russian correspondents were visibly disturbed by what seemed to them to be an uncalled-for number of Germans bearing arms during their recent tour in the United States zone.

LONDON, April 27 -- In a long broadcast in English over the Moscow radio today the "Analyzer" said that the Truman Doctrine of aid to Greece and Turkey was highly unpopular in the United 'States. The commentator contended that Henry A. Wallace was right and newspapers in the United States were wrong on this subject.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 27 -- Now that the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration is terminating its operations, the question mark that hangs over Czechoslovakia's future is whether she will receive the $250,000,000 loan for which she applied to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

two days of celebration commorating the centenary of the nding of the Society of St, Vint de Paul in the Archdiocese o New York culminated last night a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria tel attended by 600 members friends.
A corps of United Nations interpreters will be on hand today for the opening of the General Assembly's special session at Flushing Meadow.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 27 -- Shortages of raw materials and of parts, plus labor relations problems, still are thwarting the attainment of peacetime production goals of industrial plants here, a survey revealed today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- An attitude of "watching and waiting" on the part of buyers highlighted the opening of the National Housewares and Major Appliance Show today before 5,000 persons in Convention Hall.

American Airlines opened its high-speed DC-6 services between New York and Chicago yesterday, setting a commercial record for the distance by three minutes. Planes carrying officials left each city at noon aboard the flagship New York and the flagship Illinois.

ST. PAUL, April 27 (AP) -- Gov. Luther W. Youngdahl disclosed late today that the Northwestern Bell Telephone Company had offered its striking workers a $2.50a-week increase in wages for settlement of the telephone strike in five Midwest states.

Several thousand worshipers attended the annual St. George Day service late yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in honor of England's patron saint. Sponsored by the American Order of the Sons of St. George, Independent Order of the Daughters of St. George, the Order of the Daughters of St. George and associated societies, the service was preceded by a parade of thirty-eight participating organizations.

AMSTERDAM, April 27 -- Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck's note on foreign exchange, published on Thursday, has made the seriousness of the nation's economic situation fully clear and its frankness has impressed the population.

The Senate-House Committee on the Economic Report, under the chairmanship of Senator Taft, has announced plans to make its own study of the question of high prices and the rising cost of living. One encouraging feature of the proposed inquiry is that it places chief emphasis where it properly belongs, namely, on farm and food prices.
Francis Cardinal Spellman delivered the invocation that opened the ceremonies at the Yankee Stadium yesterday on "Babe Ruth Day."

TRENTON, N.J., April 27 -- State highway officials took a survey of the road construction work now going on in New Jersey, or soon to be authorized. Then they announced that within fifty years the state would be criss-crossed with freeways and parkways to take the irritating red traffic light from express highway travel and speed motorists on their way to distant points.

Variety is indicated in the art exhibitions on the calendar this week with both group and one-man shows in formidable numbers. The openings today include work by four artists at the Durand-Ruel Galleries-Daly, Harris, Schwartz Smith.

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 27 -- There is a growing belief among the economic experts at the Geneva Trade Conference that the present intransigent phase of Russian policy is largely explainable by Russia's expectation of a grave economic collapse in the United States.

The Princess Theatre, which has housed the season's five offerings of the Experimental Theatre, Inc., placed its stage yesterday in the service of a revival -- but a revival that probably departs more markedly from the conventional theatrical pattern than any of the last five tenants.

On the completion of 125 years of service to children of this community, the Jewish Child Care Association of New York has the satisfaction of knowing that it has earned an enviable place in the roster of organizations and groups dedicated to aiding the neglected and underprivileged.

NANKING, April 27 -- Chinese press dispatches today said that the Communists had recaptured the important Shantung base city of Taian at 10 A.M. Saturday, dealing a disastrous blow to Government hopes of ending the civil war in three months.

In the first three and a hall months of this year three United States and three foreign airlines flew 8,000 passengers and 1,250,000 pounds of mail and express eastbound over the Atlantic. Traffic figures, unofficial but believed to be accurate, show that the three American lines carried about 75 per cent of the entire load.
NORWALK, Conn., April 27 -- A grass roots movement to strengthen the United Nations to the point where it actually can outlaw war, particularly atomic warfare, was started here today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27 -- RKO has revived one old story property and has purchased another for production by William Pereira, who signed a new term contract with the studio at the week-end.

ALBANY, April 27 -- Dr. Harold G. Thompson, director of the division of examinations and testing, State Education Department, announced today that May 1 and 2 have been selected for the Regents examinations on which the university and Cornell scholarships will be awarded.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 (AP) -- If the athletes that competed in the Drake and Perm relays last Friday and Saturday had been on the same field; the Drake performers would have won hands down -- as far as the winners' records go.

VIENNA, April 27 (U.P.) -- Foreign Minister Dr. Karl Gruber, in a radio broadcast to the Austrian people on the Moscow conference, said today that the question of German assets in eastern Austria was the problem that prevented a Big Four agreement on an Austrian treaty.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 (AP) -- Four psychopathic patients, pretending that they needed medical aid, overpowered four medical corpsmen at the Army's Letterman Hospital at 2' o'clock this morning, seized keys to doublelocked doors and fled with one corpsman as a hostage.

VIENNA, April 27 -- A warning has been sent to Washington by high military authorities here that $60,000,000 worth of raw materials and key industrial equipment at least must be furnished to Austria as soon as possible.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Corn futures on the Chicago Board of Trade last week were as weak as wheat futures were strong. Heavy hedging sales and expectations that a liberal movement of the grain would continue for some tune were the chief factors.
LOS ANGELES, April 27 -- Lamotte T. Cohu, new elected president of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., tonight quietly enunciated a "back to fundamentals" philosophy on air passenger service.

A fine of $50, with the alternative of ten days in jail, was imposed yesterday on Mrs. William F. Jensen, 39 years old, for having turned in a false fire alarm at 4:20 A.M. to summon help when five men were beating and robbing her husband, a well-to-do Seattle business man.

Cotton prices in the domestic market fluctuated irregularly during most of last week, with swings in each direction pronounced on near-by futures. However, at the end of the period, the market displayed a rather firm tone. At the close on Saturday active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 7 to 70 points, with the current May and July deliveries showing the greatest advances.

President Harry S. Truman, in a letter to the Advertising Council, released yesterday, praised the role of business in using advertising to help solve public problems. The use of advertising in newspapers, radio, magazines and other media to give the public information on social problems "is a highly significant new development in American life," the letter stated.
The Dodgers ran their winning streak to five games BY outscoring the hapless Giants, 9 -- 8, before another banner crowd of 31,675 at Ebbets Field yesterday.

CINCINNATI, April 27 (AP) Frankie Baumhpltz's twelfth-inning single, which scored Augie Galan from second, gave the Reds a 2-1 victory over the Pirates in the second game of a double-header today, after the Reds had won the opener, 6 -- 1. A crowd of 36,961 -- probably the largest in Crosley Field history-saw the twin bill.

PARIS, April 27 -- France's major problems, which, some quarters believe, threaten the Cabinet's existence, were the subject of weekend speeches and important meetings of leading party organizations today.

Governor Dewey endorsed yesterday the Greater New York Fund's tenth annual campaign, which will be opened tomorrow night with a dinner at the Astor Hotel. Senator Irving M. Ives will be the principal speaker.

Sales volume declined more than 20 per cent in machinists' supply lines here in the last three weeks and small shops have substantially curtailed buying, industrial supply distributors have disclosed.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- With full-page advertisements in tomorrow's editions of 110 newspapers from coast to coast, the American Federation of Labor is opening its 51.500,000 "educational and publicity drive" against labor relations legislation pending in Congress.

Yankee Stadium, "the house that Ruth built," held the greatest crowd of the major league season, 58,339, yesterday They came to pay homage to the Babe, and it was a truly great tribute. The Yankees tried hard for the victory that would have made it a perfect day, but went down, 1 -- 0, before the Washington Senators.

MONTSERRAT, Spain, April 27 -- More than 50,000 pilgrims crowded the slopes around this spectacular mountain shrine near Barcelona today for the ceremonies of enthroning the ancient image of the Virgin of Montserrat on its new $450,000 gold and silver throne.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period April 19 to 25 are given in the appended tabulation: The Senate On the passage of the GreekTurkey Aid, Bill, passed 67 to 23:

How to press a man's shirt in four and a half minutes by "sitdown ironing," a technique developed to save a homemaker's energy, will be demonstrated this week at the National Housewares Show, which opened yesterday in Philadelphia's Convention Hall.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- The world champion Cardinals suffered their fifth straight defeat today, losing, 3-0, to Johnny Scnmitz, a southpaw, and the Cubs before a chilled crowd of 36,839 that braved 37-degree weather.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 27 -- Culminating the 36th Orange County Field Trial Club meeting, the shooting dog stake was judged today by Dr. Wallace Vail of Greenwich and Frank Ash of Fulton. The winner was Granite State Hipower, pointer dog owned and handled by Harold J. Hustis of White Plains.

Coinciding with the opening of a special session of the United Nations Assembly to consider the problem of Palestine, the Jewish Agency in Jerusalem launches today a full-dress propaganda campaign against political terrorism. This attempt to call a halt on the reign of violen'ce follows an interview between David Ben-Gurion, head of the Jewish Agency, and Sir Alan Cunningham, British High Commissioner.

WEST HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., April 27 -- Physically disabled patients, especially infantile paralysis victims, will save months and in many instances years in returning to normal activities as the result of a new physical education program developed at the New York State Reconstruction Home, Dr. A.J. Canning, superintendent of the institution, declared today.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday for 1946 a consolidated net income of $58,284,830 after charges, taxes and reserves for depreciation, depletion and amortization. This is equivalent to $6.42 each on the 9,076,202 capital shares outstanding.
For the most part, wholesale merchandise markets were on the quiet side last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK times by leading resident buying offices.

A letter advocating that the Rev. H. Ross Greer, the rector for the last seventeen years of Grace Church, Millbrook, N.Y., be elected the new Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York has been sent to every clergyman in the diocese.

Fordham University awarded an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws to Eugene Cardinal Tisserant, secretary of the Sacred Oriental Congregation of Vatican City, at a special convocation yesterday afternoon in Keating Hall on the school's Bronx campus.
PARIS, April 27 -- Lanvin's blues, delphinium, periwinkle, cornflower and powder, combined with chalk white in striped or flowered shantungs, are truly midsummer.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,716,878,417. They consist Of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

ROME, April 27 -- About 100 teen-age Fascist students assembled in the Church of St. Mary of the People in the center of Rome this forenoon and sang a Fascist song while the mass was being celebrated. They wound up by shouting, "Long live Mussolini!"

Officials of the four striking metropolitan telephone unions met with executives of the New York Telephone Company in joint and separate sessions for three hours yesterday at the Gramercy Part Hotel. The only report given to the public on the progress, if any, of the discussions was "no comment."

CORONADO, Calif., April 27 -- Delegates from 165 Junior Leagues in the United States, Canada, Mexico and Hawaii registered here today for the twenty-fifth annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America.

In the first round of the National Challenge Cup competition under the auspices of the United States Football Association of Hawthorne Field yesterday, Brooklyn Hispano gained the verdict over the New York Sport Club, 3 to 2.

The American Brake Shoe Company had record shipments of $27,692,944, including $702,000 by Canadian subsidiaries, in the first quarter of this year, the report disclosed yesterday. Exclusive of Canadian subsidiaries, shipments that were limited by strikes and material shortages, amounted to $15,751,535 for the corresponding three months of last year.

LONDON, April 27 -- The stock markets here have settled down well after the announcement of the Government budget by the Chancellor of the Exchequer. This probably is because, apart from the tobacco impost, the tax changes were much as had been expected.

Gerhart Eisler, the so-called Communist "master-mind" in this country, has evidently not mastered the difference between an accused person's rights in our courts and those he would enjoy, were the situation reversed, in the Russian courts. Mr. Eisler is convinced that his release on $20,000 bail, after ten weeks' imprisonment, amounts to a ''confession of innocence" by the Department of Tustice.

The Mayor's Committee on Unity has called a hearing at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, for 8 o'clock tonight to "determine the causes and underlying problems of the Greenwich Village section as they affect intergroup relations." it was announced yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mental illness is the most vital medical problem in the United States today. There are, throughout the country, more than 600,000 persons incarcerated in mental hospitals. In New York State alone there are close to 100,000 patients in the state's mental hospitals.

The Playhouse hasn't had any luck to speak of this season. "Miracle in the Mountains," Ferenc Molnar's "legend" (the author also directed it), which passed in review on Friday night, was the seventh attraction of the season to be inspected there.

Washington will hardly seem, the same gay city without Evalyn Walsh McLean. Her hospitality, exercised on a truly regal scale, gave it a verve it will not easily find again. As the years passed, with the lights of "Friendship" almost constantly aglow, she became the mythical hostess.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Stocks of wheat in all positions in the United States on April 1 aggregated 310,000,000 bushels, or 22,000,000 bushels less than a year previous, according to estimates by the Department of Agriculture, which looks for the carry-over on June-30, the end of the current crop year, to be around 100,000,000 bushels, or about the same as in 1946.

A message from Pope Pius XII was delivered yesterday by Cardinal Spellman, presiding at a ceremony in St. Francis Xavier Church, 30 West Sixteenth Street, to mark the 100th anniversary of the founding of the church and school.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 27 -- Miss Verenne Mitchell of Scarsdale was the outstanding equitation performer throughout the fourteenth annual Hutchinson spring horse show at Teddy Gussenhoven's spacious Hutchinson Farms today.

IN the seventy-eighth year of his age David Fairchild looked back upon his long life and found it good. A distinguished botanist and plant expert, he was for more than twenty years head of the Department of Agriculture Division of Plant Exploration and Introduction. Many thousands of plants now grow in this country because of his efforts.

Week Ended April 25, 1949 A renewal of the selling of Canadian free dollars, interrupted for the once a fortnight ago when it firmed slightly, depressed the value of that unit to 89.62 cents last Friday. This was the lowest since October, 1945, and canceled all of the advantage acquired when it was lifted to parity with the American dollar last July.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 2 -- The thirty-first annual Samples Fair that closed last week in Basle surpassed all predecessors for variety and quality of manufactured goods offered, for the number of exhibitors and for the registration of buyers. As against 2,055 exhibitors last year, there were 2,171 this time. Several hundred applicants for space had to be refused.

The steamship Panamanian, a 43-year-old vessel that has sailed the seas under three names, is to end her career soon at a Shanghai scrapping dock. Her passing is expected to stir many old-time seagoing men as well as a large number of landlubbers who take a "professional or romantic" interest in ships and nautical affairs generally.

PITTSBURGH, April 27 -- Pittsburgh industrialists are viewing the settlement of the wage issue in the steel, automobile, electrical and rubber industries as a major gain toward stability in production, but they recognize that one unsolved factor remains in the coming soft coal negotiations.

When Secretary of State Marshall broadcasts his report on the Moscow Conference tonight, the world will be able to obtain an even clearer picture than already provided of just what the differences between Russia and the West really are, and what the United States proposes to do about them.
In tribute to "the world-wide ministry being conducted through Church World Service," the Protestant church of New York held an Ecumenical service last night at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The United States Commercial Company announced today that henceforth private buyers would be allowed to bring Japanese cotton piece goods to this country for finishing and re-export to other countries.
ST. LOUIS. April 27 (AP) -- The Borwns knocked the White Sox out of first place in the American League today by trimming Chicago in both games of a double header, 4 to 2 and 4 to 3.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIME: Your editorial suggesting that New York City motorists solve their own problems by forming cooperatives prompts us to respond with a hearty amen, and to hasten to add that this is not a new device for motorists, even those in a metropolis, to use effectively.
MOSCOW, April 27 -- An editorial in Izvestia said today that significant progress on the German question had been made at the recent sessions of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The passing of Charles Seymou Whitman signifies something more than the end of the career of one of the outstanding figures in recent American history. His life and public services mark the commencement of an era of political morality, for much of which he "could rightfully claim credit."

The fifty-fifth anniversary exhibition of the National Association of Women Artists opened to the public yesterday at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, minus "The Lovers," Mitzi Solomon's forbidden sculpture. A third sculptor announced she was resigning from the association in protest against the barring of the work as indecent.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 (AP) -- Jim Tabor's home run in the last of the ninth gave the Phillies a clean sweep of a double-header with Boston before 34,835 fans today to end a four-game losing streak. Both contests were decided by identical 5-4 scores.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (U.P.) -- The National Federation of Small Business charged today that big bustness is responsible for "artificially high" price levels, and called upon President Truman and Congress for more effective antitrust laws and enforcement.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Secretary of State Marshall told President Truman and Congressional leaders tonight that this country must persist in its effort to obtain peace treaties enabling Germany and Austria to survive as independent nations in a Europe threatened by Communist domination.

TOKYO, April 27 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur, in a public statement today, called the new Japanese general election a decisive repudiation of communism and an overwhelming choice by the Japanese people of "a moderate course," divorced from the extremes either of right or left.

Speakers at a meeting of the Citizens' Housing Council on Saturday seemed to be in agreement that while finding a home was uppermost in the thoughts of countless American citizens there was no real popularly supported housing movement in this country. The reason may be that though the need is evident and simple the remedies are not.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Republican leaders of the Eightieth Congress have now made such progress with their own "must" legislation that they are in a position to take a short breather and at the same time assay public reaction.

BOSTON, April 27 (AP) -- With a packed crowd of 34,693 in the stands, a sudden and heavy rainstorm washed out a scheduled doubleheader while the Red Sox and Athletics were in a 6-6 tie after nine innings of first-game action today at Fenway Park.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Capital completed plans today to give President Miguel Aleman of Mexico one of its greatest receptions when he arrives Tuesday for a nine-day visit.

Warnings of the dangers of Communist and fascist doctrines and pleas for support of religion of all faiths were made yesterday at the second annual communion-consecration breakfast of the metropolitan districts of the New York State Grand Lodge of the Masonic Order.

Debut and Encore Concerts closed its third season late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, where it presented three artists in a joint recital. Frances Lehnerts, mezzosoprano, and Jay Karlin, 16-yearold Brooklyn violinist, were the debutantes.
ROME, April 27 (AP) -- A convicted murderer, repentant and his prison sentence ended, attended the, beatification today of his victim, 11year-old Maria Goretti.

TOKYO, April 27 (AP) -- The text of General MacArthur's statement on the Japanese elections: With the recently held series of elections, the last preparatory step necessary for inauguration of the new Japanese Constitution has been accomplished.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Charles P. Taft today foresaw a spiritual and economic revival in war lands of Europe, due to the voluntary aid and human rehabilitation techniques which went beyond bread and butter requirements.

A drive among clothing manufacturers on behalf of the $1,000,000 Sidney Hillman Foundation in memory of the late president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America will open at a luncheon tomorrow in the Hotel Brevoort, Fifth Avenue and Eighth Street, it was announced yesterday by the union.

Beginning Wednesday what is perhaps the oldest sneeze in the world -- and the most unusual, too -- will have its first public audition at the Bronx Zoo. It's a weird noise that begins with a hiss and wheeze and winds up like a small firecracker.

Industrial furnaces, marine supplies, Army clothing, tires and tubes and drugs are the major lines offered currently by the New York regional office of the War Assets Administration, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, disclosed over the veek-end.

NEW DELHI, India, April 27 (Reuters) -- A plan for a sovereign state of Bengal, enlarged by adding territories from neighboring Indian Provinces, was put forward today by H.S. Suhrawardy, Moslem League Premier of Bengal Province.

ONE of the main difficulties in writing about Babe Ruth is that a chap suddenly finds himself bumping into the bottom of the column before he's even had a chance to warm up. Such was the case in this space yesterday and the special tribute which has just been paid to the Bambino affords a chance to toss in a few more pitches about the most colorful ballplayer that the game ever has had.

ATHENS, April 27 -- George Papandreou, head of the Republican Socialist party and Minister of the Interior in the Government of Premier Demetrios Maximos, stated last night that he had questioned the Governors of Greece's forty-six Departments concerning Right-Wing bands in their areas.

NAVY ORDNANCE TEST STATION, Inyokern, Calif., April 27 -- This 1,000-square-mile reservation, the Navy's largest center for the development of "secret weapons," has achieved something far transcending in importance any of its technical projects.

LONDON, April 27 -- Winston Churchill defended himself today against the bitter personal attack launched on him by Prime Minister Attlee on Friday. Mr. Attlee had accused Mr. Churchill of having been the "most disastrous Chancellor of the Exchequer of the century" and had ascribed some of the present troubles, including the fuel shortage, to Mr. Churchill's past career.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 -- Officials of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union at Long Beach were accused yesterday of "betraying" labor and management in the shipping industry and keeping sixty-nine dockside gangs from their jobs at the Saturday time-and-a-half rate and sixteen ships in idleness at the wharves.

Canadian National Steamships, Ltd., in 1946 operated twice as many voyages as in 1945 and had a profit of $1,709,888, according to the annual report of R.C. Vaughan, president. He said operating revenues rose 51 per cent above those of 1945, while operating expenses went up 74 per cent.

The special session of the General Assembly to study the Palestine situation, which opens today at Flushing Meadow, Queens, will confront the United Nations with a series of critical decisions on the future of the eastern Mediterranean region.

NANKING, April 27 -- Li Huang, one of the leaders of the Young China party, announced today in Chungking that he would not accept his appointment as Minister of Economic Affairs in the reorganized multi-party Government.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Finding that the forces underlying business expansion "have lost their upward drive," the United States Employment Service tonight predicted a slowdown in hiring.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 27 -- The royal visit here ended only three days ago, but already it is becoming a mere memory and observers wonder what influence, if any, it will have.
LONDON, April 28 -- Although week-end orders were on the small side cheerfulness was general in the the stock markets today.

LOS ANGELES, April 28 (AP) -- Louis B. Mayer, motion picture producer, was divorced today by Mrs. Margaret Shenberg Mayer, who receives a cash settlement of $3,250,000. They had been married for 43 years.

Impressive progress has been made by American occupation forces toward the economic rehabilitation of Germany, considering the magnitude and diversity of the problems involved, Harvey D. Gibson, banker and 1947 national chairman of the Red Cross Fund, reported yesterday.

In a pronouncement which sets a new precedent in the relations between conquerors and conquered, General MacArthur has just paid tribute to the Japanese people for rejecting the totalitarian philosophies of both right and left and setting out firmly on the path toward their own liberation in a new democracy.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (U.P.) -- Mr. Wallace's press conference was recorded for a radio broadcast tonight, although he kept the microphone under his left foot.

Five is the key number, so far as the local baseball set-up is concerned. That number will figure prominently at the Polo Grounds and Ebbets Field today, when the Giants and Dodgers open their respective home stands against the west.

Forty years ago young Charlie Funk drove a team of mules on a fresno or scraper, out West. His partner on the fresno was about to take a position as an instructor of English at the University of Colorado and the two drivers practiced their English on the mules.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Democratic and' irregular Republican opposition to the Taft labor program accused Senator Robert A. Taft today of insistently risking, if not inviting, a veto by President Truman.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 28 -- The Communist party seems to be trying to use the hanging of Father Josef Tiso -- as Hungarian Communists have used the trial of alleged conspirators against the Hungarian republic -- to force the Democratic party in Slovakia to commit political suicide after the manner of the Hungarian Smallholders.

SEATTLE, April 28 (AP) -- A strong, well-balanced Chicago Town Club team gave an East vs. West title tattle tinge today as the nation's top women swimmers began arriving for the week-end National A.A.U. meet.

Because the presiding magistrate "was not fully aware of all the facts at the time," Chief City Magistrate Edgar Bromberger reversed yesterday the conviction of Mrs. William F. Jensen of Seattle, Wash., for turning in a false alarm early Sunday.

DETROIT, April 28 -- The British Government was accused tonight by Rabbi Uri Miller of Baltimore, president of the Rabbinical Council of America, of adopting a form of "brutal nazism" while gathering its might "to crush the remnants of our people and our hopes."
VIENNA, April 28 -- The American charitable organization CARE, which signed a contract with the Hungarian Government on Feb. 4, still cannot get Russia's permission to operate in Hungary.

President Aleman of Mexico will be reminded anew when he steps out of his plane in Washington today and again on Friday, when he visits this city, with what warm friendship the American people regard him and his people. There remain between our two countries, as President Truman admitted during his March visit, some "areas of disagreement," but there are no areas of discord.

Guaranteed Loans Opposition by the American Bankers Association to the Tobey bill, which would broaden the power of the Federal Reserve banks to underwrite business loans made by commercial banks is expected to be intensified.

With prices holding firm for the most part, buying by retailers was cautious at the National Shoe Fair which opened here yesterday under joint auspices of the National Shoe Retailers Association and the National Shoe Manufacturers Association.

A subcommittee of the Mayor's Committee on Unity began hearings last night on racial tension in the Greenwich Village section, with emphasis on attacks by young hoodlums on Negroes in that area in recent months.

Ballet Theatre came back to town last night for a spring season of three weeks, this time at the City Center. After some of the ballet that recent months have offered us, it is a pleasure to see once more what a first-rate company looks like.

Understanding of traditions and lore of various nationalities, particularly in communities culturally mixed, is necessary to develop friendliness among neighbors. This theme was stressed yesterday at an assembly of pupils of Public School 165, 109th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue, by a group of pupils of different nationalities who visited one anothers' homes to discuss their backgrounds.

TOKYO, April 28 -- Plans for the resumption of private trade with Japan gradually are taking shape, and within two months occupation officials expect to be able to invite foreign nations to send their buyers here.

The Palestine controversy that forced the United Nations to call its first special General Assembly session has been a three-sided conflict among the Arabs, the Jews and the British ever since the country was taken away from. Turkey by the victorious Allies after the first World War.

SEOUL, Korea, April 28 -- Military officials here today received word that Dr. Philip Jaisohn, Media, Pa., physician and aged Korean patriot who is an American citizen, would be unable to journey to Korea to assist in the stabilization of the country's political scene.
JERUSALEM, April 28 -- Sixty thousand Jewish inhabitants of Jerusalem breathed freely tonight when it was announced that the curfew had been lifted.

WARSAW, April 28 -- The amount of reconstruction and change to peacetime conditions that has taken place in the Soviet Union during the almost two years since the war with Germany ended is difficult to gauge.

"I Have Seen the Children," a radio drama about Europe's displaced children, will be broadcast from 9:30 to 10 o'clock tonight over Station WQXR. Martha Scott, screen player, will play the leading role.

Stock prices yesterday dragged through the second slowest trading session in nearly a year, fluctuating within a narrow range and closing irregularly lower. Except for a few leading issues, price changes were limited to small fractions.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Current discussions on profits, wages, cost of living index, reduction of taxes, etc., imply that we do not realize the opportunities and responsibilities individual citizens of this country must meet successfully if the United States is to fulfill its role in world affairs.

The popular conception that the parent "is glad to dump his child anywhere" is a fallacy, Clara M. Allen declared yesterday in a report on day-care centers for school children, published by the Child Welfare League of America, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 28 (AP) -- Harvard University and the city of Providence will be able to proceed with their division of the estate -- in excess of $2,000,000 -- of Charles H. Smith as the result of an out-of-court settlement of the suit by Mrs. Daphne Eugenic (Smith) Cameron for possession.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- James J. Reynolds Jr., a member of the National Labor Relations Board, in an unprecedented proposal today, suggested that a union be regarded as an "employer" in a closed-shop proceeding before the board.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Senator George D. Aiken, chairman of the Senate Education subcommittee, said today that by Friday, with fifty witnesses heard, his group would go into executive session "to try to work out a Federalaid-to-education bill that will meet objections."
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- House voting on the $350,000,000 relief program for liberated countries was blocked for a second time today as argument focused on two new restrictive proposals.

American film distributors through the Motion Picture Association have protested the worldwide distribution of new and old German-made films as recently arranged by the Anglo-American Military Government in Germany. This was made known yesterday by Joseph H. Seidelman, vice president and foreign distribution head of Universal Pictures, who returned on Friday from a six-week trip to London and Paris.

CORONADO, Calif., April 28 -- Delegates to the national conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America were told tonight that as representatives of "a portion of the nation's social and cultural leadership" they bore a special responsibility in the quest for international understanding and global peace.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Leaders of United States industry began, here today discussions of the forwarding of business under the private enterprise system with meetings simultaneously on two fronts.
GENEVA, April 28 -- The date for opening what is hoped will be the final round of discussion on the charter of the International Trade Organization has been advanced from May 15 to May 5.

Following is the text of Secretary of State Marshall's broadcast from Washington last night reporting to the nation on the justconcluded conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28 -- Churchill Downs, America's racing capital for this one week during the year, tomorrow will be the scene of the tenth running of the Derby Trial, last of the long series of preliminaries to Saturday's bigmoney number.
CHICAGO, April 28 -- Liquidation was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, with the May deliveries leading.

JERUSALEM, April 28 -- Political expectations from the special session on Palestine of the United Nations General Assembly are more pronounced among Arabs than among Zionists, it. appeared today from the tone of local press comment.

On a tour of inspection of the Manhattan Beach and near-by Maritime Veterans Emergency Housing projects, State Commissioner of Housing Herman T. Stichman announced yesterday that a 400-foot bathing beach and a 50,000-square-foot playground for children would be made available for the 1,200 veterans' families who are tenants at the projects.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- The increase in psychiatric disorders presents "a major challenge to American medicine," Dr. William C. Menninger of Topeka, Kan., psychiatrist and consultant to the Surgeon General of the United States Army, said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 28 -- Edward Gross, Broadway producer of "Chicken Every Sunday" and "St. Louis Woman," today announced the purchase of screen rights to "Mrs. Mike," a novel by Nancy and Benedict Freedman, for $200,000 plus an unspecified percentage of the prospective profits from the film version.

The United States can win world peace for at least a generation if it remains strong and follows wise and humanitarian policies, Harold E. Stassen declared yesterday on his return from a European tour that took him through sixteen countries.

BUENOS AIRES, April 28 (U.P.) -- All communications with Paraguay were broken off today shortly after the Government of Dictator Higinio Morinigo had announced a new revolt had been squashed in Asuncion, the nation's capital.

PARIS, April 28 -- All three leading political parties were lined up together today, on the eve of the reconvening of the National Assembly, against participation in former President de Gaulle's reform movement, but neither or the other parties would agree to any participation in the Communistsponsored vigilance committees, formed to combat M. de Gaulle.

Paul James Duncan, who fought in two wars as an officer of the Imperial Russian Army and rose to the rank of lieutenant colonel, died yesterday in his home at 562 West 144th Street, after a long illness. His age was 67.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Department of Justice formally asked 964 railroads today for refunds on wartime military and naval freight handling involving many millions of dollars.

MILWAUKEE, Wis, April 28 -- Two hundred and fifty persons from all parts of the country, including many official representatives of community planning bodies, heard speakers today at the Citizens Conference on Planning advocate unification of the governments of metropolitan areas, improved legislation for the assembly of land for public use and creation of municipal parking authorities.

The United Nations' first debate on the issues of the Palestine case will begin'at 11 A.M. today in the key general committee of the special General Assembly. The Arab League is expected to make an all-day fight for discussion of its demand for independence of the Holy Land.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 28 -- Strong competitive forces, long absent from the market, again are at work to force down the costs of building, regardless of any pressive or persuasive action such as President Truman's plea for lower prices, according to Tyler S. Rogers, president of the Producers Council, National Association of Manufacturers of Building Material and Equipment.
WILDWOOD, N.J., April 28 -- More homes will be occupied in Cape May County as a result of the abolition of rent ceilings here, officials declared today.

Jeanne Behrend, who appeared in recital at Times Hall last night, placed Aaron Copland's sonata in the choicest spot on her program. This is one of Mr. Copland's finest compositions and one of the best produced by an American composer in recent years.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 28 -- Rabbi Morris S. Lazaron of Baltimore, speaking tonight at an open meeting of the New Haven Chapter of the American Council for Judaism, advocated "the use of restraint and statesmanship on the Palestine situation."

ST. PAUL, April 28 (AP) -- The general board of the Northwest Federation of Telephone Workers today rejected the $2.50 weekly wage increase offered by the Northwestern Bell Telephone Company. Further meetings of the negotiators were put off until 9 A.M. Thursday.

DETROIT, April 28 -- Disciplinary action has been taken against thirty-eight employes of the General Motors Corporation for their activity in leading participation by thousands of workers in a union rally here last Thursday to protest labor bills pending in Congress.
New York operators of excursion boats are rushing reconditioning and modernization work on the city's steamboat fleet for the opening of the excursion season next month, a survey yesterday showed.

Dr. Carol P. Cori of Washington University Medical School, St. Louis, famous biochemist, received last night the second intermediate Sugar Research prize of $5,000 for his achievements in the field of human metabolism.

Claims in excess of $4,000,000 were filed yesterday at the first meeting of general creditors of Motty Eitingon; Inc., held before Referee Irwin Kurtz in the United States Court House. Among the largest claims were those filed by the Public National Bank and Trust Company, the Edmund Wright Ginsberg Corporation, and James W. Talcott.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A stormy telephone strike conference today apparently presaged a break in the strike situation by the end of the week.

NANKING, April 28 (AP) -- Communist capture of the important Shantung Province base of Taian was acknowledged today by sources in the Government Ministry of Defense, but they added, "Look for surprising developments in Shantung within two weeks."

A professor of English at Smith College and a naval historian have collaborated on a book about eating (not a cook book, please note), which Henry Holt Co. published yesterday. To promote "A Man and His Meals," as the little work is called, Hoit asked half a dozen People from the press to a lunch yesterday in the directors' dining room.

General Electric Company announced yesterday list price increases of from 6 to 17 per cent on several electrical appliances in keeping with a recent statement by Charles E. Wilson, president, that wage increases would necessitate raising prices an average of 7 per cent.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- The International Harvester Company today offered eleven unions, representing 62,000 employes at twenty-one plants, wage increases totaling 15 cents an hour, and soon afterward one of the unions, the United Farm Equipment and Metal Workers Union, CIO, accepted the offer.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 28 -- A controversy over the advisability of establishing the city's first subsidized public housing in a three-block area of the Post Road shopping district reached a climax this afternoon when the City Council approved the $5,500,000 project and authorized the Municipal Housing Authority to proceed with construction.

Random notes: A sweeping check-up on Eastern New York and Connecticut trout streams over the week-end revealed that the fishing was fair but the results poor, although several of the streams checked were clear and only slightly higher than normal.
Historic Temple Beth-El at Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street is being demolished to make room for an apartment house.
TRENTON, N.J., April 28 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll signed into law today ten of the more than 400 bills passed in the closing days of the State Legislature.

PARIS, April 28 -- Manikins in bare feet are an amusing innovation against the background of Christian Dior's sumptuous salon, but most appropriate for the display of his beach and country models, picturesque in their simplicity.
Leaders of the Jewish Agency for Palestine made it a point yesterday not to attend the opening meeting of the General Assembly's special session on Palestine at Flushing Meadow.

The telephone strike went into its fourth week yesterday with officials of the four metropolitan unions and the New York Telephone Company continuing their silence-shrouded conferences. These will be resumed at 1:30 P.M. today.

Herbert Hoff, manager of the Playland Arcade, 1580 Broadway, a shooting gallery and skill game emporium, was at the open safe in his office at 9:45 A.M. yesterday when a shadow fell across the window.

The United Mine Workers' District 50 lost its last foothold in train service unions yesterday when brakemen and ticket takers of the Long Island Rail Road voted to rejoin the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.

After having completed its organization work with record speed and harmony, the United Nations General Assembly decided yesterday to postpone the opening' of full-dress debate on the Palestine question until tomorrow. Organization procedure marked the opening of the special session on Holy Land problems, held at Flushing Meadow, Queens.

Jimmy Carollo of Corona outpointed John Thomas of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., at the St. Nicholas Arena last night, gaining the unanimous decision. Carollo tipped the scale beam at 200 and Thomas at 192 for the 10-round bout.
The prosecution in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle completed its case late yesterday afternoon in Kings County Court.

"A Young Man's Fancy," first of the week's trio of new offerings, will be presented tonight at the Plymouth Theatre under the auspices of Henry Adrian. It is a comedy by Harry Thurschwell and Alfred Golden set in a summer camp and dealing with "progressive education" as applied, particularly, to a precocious youngster who tries to repair a romance between two counselors.
The Greater New York Fund delivered yesterday its first orange and blue campaign flag to Acting Mayor Vincent B. Impelletteri at City Hall.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 28 -- Lew Hahn, New York City, president, National Retail Dry Goods Association, said today American business men are facing the fact that prices will have to come down despite the views of many manufacturers, whose sincerity cannot be doubted, that prices cannot be lowered because of the current cost of production.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 28 (AP) -- Dr. C. Charles Burlingame, psychiatrist in chief of the Institute of Living, said today that the emphasis now being placed on psychiatry was causing a "dangerous" situation in which "people in all walks of life are being instilled with the belief that they need psychiatric attention to save their minds, if not their souls."

An exhibition of canvases and water-colors by Canadian woman painters opens to the public today at the Riverside Museum, Riverside Drive and 103d Street. It will continue through May 18. This show was organized by the Fine Arts Committee of the National Council of Women of Canada and comes here upon the invitation of the National Council of Women of the United States.

A hospital orderly who at first claimed to have been the "lookout" during the burglary in which 15year-old Selma Graff was fatally beaten in Brooklyn on April 20, was said by the police to have admitted later that he had concocted the story.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Secretary of State Marshall, back from the clamorous atmosphere of the peace arena, tonight offered the American people a word of comfort and advice from Premier Stalin.

While it is unlikely that cotton textile prices at primary sources will show any change in the next sixty days, slower purchasing for the third and fourth quarters indicate reductions of about 10 percent for the last half of the year, according to a survey yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- A bill demanding greater publicity for campaign expenditures but making possible the revival of financial "angels" in Federal primaries and elections was ready today to be introduced in the Senate.

CHICAGO, April 28 AP -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 7,000 head, total 9,000; market opened slow with few sales steady to 25 cents lower than Friday but later trade and general market fairly active and steady with Friday's

BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 28 (AP) -- "The Woman in Red," who led John Dillinger into an FBI trap that resulted in the killing of America's Public Enemy No. 1 in Chicago thirteen years ago, died last Friday in a quiet town in southwestern Rumania, the Timisoara newspaper Vestul said today.
CHICAGO, April 28 -- A warning that "a little knowledge in international understanding is a dangerous thing" was voiced here today by Dr. Chih Meng, director of the China Institute in America.

In line with the growing trend of the nation's railroads to replace steam-driven locomotives with Diesel-electric units, the New York Central System has, placed a $12,000,000 order for seventy of the latter type engines with four manufacturers, it was announced yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There has been much criticism in recent days of present practice in Federal Government offices in handling official correspondence classified as confidential. In this connection our public officials have frequently been blamed for carelessness in handling or for actual thievery of such official documents.
Representatives of thirty nations attended the opening session of the International Meeting on Marine Radio Aids to Navigation in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, April 28 (U.P.) -- Two top Congress Party leaders opened the third session of the Indian Constituent Assembly today with warnings that partition of India into separate Moslem and Hindu areas might be just around the corner.

Hearings on the application by the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company, whereby the rate to consumers would be increased by $225,000 annually, were resumed yesterday by the Public Service Commission. The company is one of three serving consumers in Brooklyn now petitioning the commission for higher gas rates.

From Distant Pulpits Contrary to the general impression, it has now been shown that an opposition candidate is free to campaign for the highest office in the gift of the people in countries like Russia, Poland, the Balkans and wherever else the rigid one-party system prevails.

WARSAW, April 28 -- Auguste Cardinal Hlond called on the people of Poland this week-end to oppose the "modern heathendom" that is trying to "replace the worship of the Creator with the cult of the creature and worldliness."
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee upheld today a subcommittee cut of more than $14,000,000 in Federal grants to states for United States Employment Service operations.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 28 (AP) -- General Railway Signal Company will show a small profit for the first quarter, but its income is still affected by orders taken at former OPA price levels, Paul Renshaw, president, told the annual meeting today.

CLEVELAND, April 28 (AP) -- The Indians' new outfield fence was displayed for the first time today, but Dizzy Trout of the Tigers really fenced in the Tribe by hurling a five-hit 3-to-0 shutout and slamming a home run. The Tiger right-hander retired the side in order in five of the nine innings and drove in two of the three Bengal tallies.

Three retail chains cut prices 10 percent on soaps and soap products yesterday as housewives and merchants throughout the nation experimented with several plans for checkmating the rising cost of living.

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 28 -- The United States is proposing to the United Nations commission investigating the Balkans the acceptance by Yugoslavia, Bulgaria, Albania and Greece of the Pan American convention sealing frontiers in the event of civil war.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 28 -- Chronic shortages of urgently needed zinc compounds were stressed as the major obstacle now confronting die casting plants, galvanizers and pain manufacturers, according to three speakers at the twentyninth annual convention of the American Zinc Institute, Inc., which opened here today.

BALTIMORE, April 28 (AP) -- One horse dropped dead after the race, jockeys were spilled and only three of eight starters managed to finish in the opening steeplechase of the Pimlico track season today. Bill Hill, owned by Mrs. Daniel Shea, died while being taken to his barn after the hectic event.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Henry A. Wallace carried on his fight against the Truman Doctrine today with the assertion that it had brought France to the verge of civil war and would divide the world into warring factions.

A campaign in which every New Yorker has a deep interest begins today. The Greater New York Fund is making its tenth annual appeal, acting this year in behalf of 423 hospitals, health and welfare agencies whose services are available if needed to residents of the city and, in emergencies, to the many thousands who make their living here but live beyond the city borders.

CINCINNATI, April 28 (AP) -- Larry MacPhail, president and general manager of the New York Yankees, has a chat scheduled at 11 A.M. Thursday with Baseball Commissioner A.B. Chandler, and the betting (if such a word may be used in a baseball story) is that the voluble red-head will be listening instead of talking this time.
CALLAO, Peru, April 26 (Delayed) -- When we set sail Monday to drift in the path of Kon-Tiki's men, we shall be equipped as nearly as possible in their way.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- The "hot potato" middleweight title bout between Tony Zale, champion, and Rocky Graziano will be held at Wrigley Field on Wednesday, July 16 -- if it can hurdle a brewing state legislative challenge.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, urged Congress today to merge all American overseas airlines to meet mounting competition from foreign Government-owned carriers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial comment upon the failure of New York's Library Service to provide books for disabled persons unable to visit the public libraries voices a need which we who are continuing our volunteer war work in hospitals are aware of constantly.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP) -- In reports to the Security and Exchange Commission, made public today, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company of New York, reported that W.S. Gifford, president and director, was paid $209,650 last year.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The President's Advisory Committee on the Merchant Marine began its studies today by holding a daylong session with the Maritime Commission.

The supply of domestic help has increased appreciably in the last few weeks, but wages remain close to wartime levels and families with children still have trouble finding help, a survey of employment agencies showed yesterday. Wages run 75 to 85 cents an hour, $30 to $35 a week and up where special skills are required.

Complaints about comparativeprice claims and qualities of advertised merchandise have been increasing, according to a statement yesterday by the Better Business Bureau. Claims of "worth," "value," "made-to-sell-for," "manufacturer's price" and "regularly" are viewed by complainants with increasing skepticism, the report says.
TOKYO, April 28 -- The conservative coalition Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida decided today against resigning soon because of Friday's general election.

ALGIERS, April 26 (Delayed) -- A Constituent Assembly of the Algerian people to determine their own form of government was demanded today by Messali Hadj, Arab nationalist leader. As the French National Assembly prepared to take up a statute for Algeria, he made it clear that his party was completely uninterested in what he considers half-measures.

LONDON, April 28 -- The Government is going to be under strong pressure from its rank-andfile to follow a policy more favorable to the Jews in Palestine, it became evident today when the agenda for the annual Labor party conference were published.

Concerted action by any business group to reduce prices is 'clearly illegal" and subject to anti-trust suits under the Sherman and Clayton acts by non-ooperating competitors of such group even if the Government refuses to bring suit, Ernest S. Meyers, partner in the law firm of Isseks, Meyers Verdon, said yesterday.

It was hardly the time to be discussing hockey, what with the sun shining warmly outside and Babe Ruth, Happy Chandler, the Kentucky Derby and other, more seasonable topics on most every sports-minded person's lips. But there was Prank Boucher, manager and coach of the New York Rangers, surrounded by sports writers at a luncheon table at Toots Shot's yesterday, in the mood for hockey, ice hockey, that is.

A display of custom order fabrics from fifteen studios throughout the country went on exhibition yesterday at Georg Jensen where it will remain through Saturday. The collection includes a variety of prints -- hand blocked, hand screened or airbrushed.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States gave its support today to the House-approved tax reduction bill as an "insurance" for the maintenance of high levels of economic activity and national income "through encouragement to incentive and by tax reduction."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 28 -- The facade that has separated Harvard and Radcliffe Colleges into two institutions for sixtyseven years may be eliminated permanently within the next six months, making co-education within sacrosanct Harvard Yard the rule rather than a phenomenon, it was learned today.

THE largest financial award in the world of letters, the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer $150,000 prize, is 150 times as large as the Pulitzer Prize and more than three times as large as the Nobel Prize. But, unfortunately for its prestige, it is restricted to novels which have the obvious makings of commercially profitable screen versions.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- J.A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, is expected to request bituminous coal operators and the United Mine Workers of America, who open negotiations here tomorrow, to confer at once and work out a contract taking the mines out of Government operation.

LONDON, April 28 -- British housewives booed John Strachey, Minister of Food, tonight, giving him a foretaste of a mass demonstration at the House of Commons that 20,000 to 30,000 women plan to stage on June 6.

The first post-war theatrical auction here opened yesterday at the United Service Organization-Camp Shows warehouse at 8 West Sixtysecond Street. With 4,012 costumes and 2,000 miscellaneous clothing items valued at $200,000 placed on sale, Thomas Burchill, auctioneer, said this auction was bigger than the last large one held here before the war, when the theatrical effects of the late Florenz Ziegfeld were sold.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Democrats said today they plan an extraordinary effort to recapture the Senate in next year's elections.

MOSCOW, April 28 -- An intensification of the class struggle and great economic and political crises are predicted for the United States and Britain in Pravda, official newspaper of the Communist party.
MEXICO CITY, April 28 (AP) -- President Manuel Aleman reiterated today the importance of the press as he prepared for his departure for Washington at dawn tomorrow.

CLEVELAND, April 28 -- Manmade lightning flashes, designed to send a guiding beam up to weatherbound planes through 1,000 feet of heavy fog, were demonstrated for the first time tonight at Cleveland airport by the Westinghouse Electric Company.

Net earnings of the Industrial Rayon Corporation for the first quarter of this year were reported yesterday to be $2,579,353, equal to $1.70 a share of common stock. This compares with $1.58 a share in the preceding quarter and with $1,862,535, or $1.15 a share, in the initial three months of 1946.

ATHENS, April 28 (U.P.) -- Press reports from Crete said tonight that more than 400 guerrillas were theatening the capital and seaport of Canea and that an increasing number of Cretans were moving to the hills daily to take up arms against the Government.
An inspection of Idlewild Airport in Queens showed yesterday that, with three minor exceptions, it was ready for occupancy by airlines.

Devotees of sport in Venezuela soon will get a drastic lesson in the problems of port operation if a recent proposal is put into effect, A.J. Pasch, chairman of the United States Atlantic and Gulf-Netherlands West Indies and Venezuela Conference, asserted yesterday.

LONDON, April 28 -- The India Office here denied today that Lord Mountbatten had made up his mind to support Pakistan -- a separate Moslem State -- in India. It is also denied that Gen. Lord Ismay, the Viceroy's senior staff officer, who will come here this week-end, is bringing any plan with him.

Store Sales Up 8% Here Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 8 per cent over the like week of 1946, according to the "flash report" yesterday of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Mrs. Philomena Gentile of 6812 Thirteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, was fined $15 and received a suspended sentence of thirty days in jail in Bay Ridge Court, Brooklyn, yesterday for turning in a false alarm of fire. Mrs. Gentile pleaded guilty but explained to Magistrate Frances W. Lehrich that she pulled the alarm to summon help because her husband was beating her.
Mrs. Mary S. Harkness, widow of Edward S. Harkness, the philanthropist, yesterday laid the cornerstone of the Edward S. Harkness Memorial Hall, at 165 Fort Washington Avenue.

HONOLULU, April 28 -- Twelve Army prisoners, accused of participating in an attempted break from Schofield Barracks stockade on March 31, will face charges of violating four articles of war that carry the possible death penalty. Brig. Gen. Wayne C. Smith, commander of the post, stated today.

PESHAWAR, North-West Frontier Province, India, April 28 -- Imagination on the part of the Viceroy and self-restraint on the part of rival political parties helped to avert a threatened clash during the Viceregal visit to Peshawar today.

LONDON, April 28 -- More than 10,000 of London's 24,000 dockworkers went on strike today, holding up work on about half the shipping in Britain's busiest port. Members of the Stevedores and Dockers Union and of the Lightermen's Union went out in sympathy with the 4,000 dockworkers of Glasgow, who are on strike to protest dismissals.
CHICAGO, April 28 -- Mental illness is as great a threat in rural areas as in cities, according to a recent study cited by the American Public Welfare Association.

BERLIN, April 28 -- During their tour of the American zone two Russian correspondents for Tass visited factories in Munich and Stuttgart. They displayed special interest in working conditions and the workers political inclinations. They asked questions on production and marketing.
Mme. Elizabeth Zoltan Tildy, wife of the President of Hungary, unofficially visited the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow yesterday and pledged her country's full cooperation to the United Nations.

MONTREAL, April 28 (Canadian Press) -- Terms of the settlement of a three-month-long proxy fight for control of St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., were ratified at the company's annual meeting of shareholders here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 28 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council today approved Britain's administration of the trust territory of Tanganyika. It decreed that no action was needed on the Tanganyika petitions from German and Italian residents, appealing against repatriation.

IT is time to pause for station identification. The baseball season has been in progress for a fortnight and today marks the first switchover point. The Eastern teams in the National League start to entertain the brothers from the hinterlands while the American Leaguers from along the Atlantic Seaboard head out where the West begins.

OTTAWA, April 28 (AP) -- The Foreign Exchange Control Board said today that Canada bought from the United States last year $603,000,000 (Canadian) more than she sold there. It was a record trade deficit.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Evidence that Andrew J. May feared getting "in debt so badly I can't get out" developed today at the Government war fraud trial of the former Representative, who headed the House Military Affairs Committee during the war.

BOSTON, April 28 (AP) -- Taking over in the back stretch when Mrs. T. Christopher's Rustle Broom ran wide, R.B. Carroll's Belrate brushed off all challenges and defeated C.C. Boshamer's Teddy Tarn by two lengths in the mileand-seventy-yard feature event today at Suffolk Downs.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Studies on how the embryo, animal and human, receives its food through the placenta, the mammalian "eggshell," have been obtained for the first time by tagging atoms with heavy water and with radioactive isotopes produced by atomic energy, it was reported here today at the meeting of the Nations Academy of Science, leading scientific body in the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., April 28 -- The war of nerves between manufacturers and buyers continued today at the national housewares and major appliances show in Convention Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- If the Republicans really want to transmute their campaign pledge to reduce taxation into a law instead of a mere legislative gesture, Senator George of Georgia has now shown them the most likely way to achieve it. He will join them, he said, on a bill to lower taxes as of July 1, 1947, but only when they have proved "they mean what they say about reducing [government] expenditures."

Cencerro of the Jayess Stable stepped down in front to win the Atlantic Handicap, the Class C race that topped the card at Jamaica yesterday. With Ted Atkinson in the saddle, the 5-year-old son of Equestrian seemed not at all bothered by the top weight of 122 pounds as he scored by a full length over Walter P. Chrysler's Reckon.

LIMA, Peru, April 28 (Reuters) -- Six young Scandinavian scientists left the Peruvian port of Callao this afternoon on a fifteen-ton raft in the hope of drifting 4,000 miles to the Society or Marquesas Is lands, halfway across the Pacific.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and closed 61 to 69 points net lower on the day, with a moderate volume of business.

Behind the effective six-hit hurling of Nick Thornton, Manhattan captured its first Metropolitan Baseball Conference contest yesterday, downing Brooklyn College, 7 -- 2, at Van Cortlandt Park. It also was the Jaspers' initial victory of the season.
The Kingdom of Siam was formally admitted to the United Nations yesterday as the fifty-fifth member of the international organization.

A formidable cordon of security police, consisting of 165 city policemen, United Nations guards, city detectives and two patrol cars, was on hand yesterday for the opening of the special session of the United Nations General Assembly on Palestine at Flushing Meadow.

Not only are anti-social street gangs in New York growing in number, but gang warfare is being carried on "not with snowballs but with Luger pistols," G. Howland Shaw, president of the Welfare Council of New York City, declared yesterday.
CLEVELAND, April 29 (AP) -- The Athletics scored a gift run in the ninth inning to defeat the Indians, 4 to 3, today in the opener of a two-game series.

NEW DELHI, India, April 29 -- India's Constituent Assembly, discussing the Fundamental Rights Committee's report, today adopted this provision: "Untouchability in any form is abolished and the imposition of any disability on that account shall be an offense."

PARIS, April 29 -- Delicate detail is a feature to be admired on the Bruyere midsummer models. Minute sequins are so sparsely scattered on gentian blue or cinnamon printed cottons that they add life rather than glitter.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Two Democrats of the House Banking Committee, in a minority report, maintained today that the rent control bill reported out of the committee last week "falls far short of the desired goal to achieve effective rent control."

HELSINKI, Finland, Apr. 29 (AP) -- Although the great names of yesteryear have been erased by the war or age, Finland plans to send a strong team to the 1948 Olympics to carry on the nation's reputation as the land of great long distance runners.
Cotton trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was heavy yesterday. After a sharp break, the market closed steady but 18 to 47 points net lower than on Monday.

BREWSTER, N.Y., April 29 -- A thorough round-up of just about every part of the Putnam-Westchester watershed area today revealed a scarcity of both fishermen and fish. The strong wind made for rather uncomfortable fishing on the larger lakes.

Twenty-eight student nurses, who began their studies three years ago during the stress of war, received diplomas last night at the forty-eighth graduation exercises of the Roosevelt Hospital School of Nursing. A reception for friends of the graduates followed the ceremonies at the Henry Hudson Hotel, 331 West Fifty-seventh Street.

LONDON, April 29 -- With more than fifteen months' stocks of raw cotton on hand, Great Britain this year will be a "tough" buyer in world cotton markets, according to officials charged with her purchases of the staple abroad and who have replaced the Liverpool Cotton Exchange brokers in buying cotton for the Lancashine mills.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 29 -- Miss Margaret Brooks, 17 years old, a pupil of the West Lake School for Girls at Beverly Hills, Calif., arrived in the East by air today in contemplation of elopement. But she landed in police headquarters here instead of at an altar because she had related her plans to classmates who could not keep the secret from her father.

Gala Occasion at the Bijou: On Saturday night, June 14, Howard Lindsay and his wife, Dorothy Stickney, who endeared themselves to countless theatregoers for their inimitable portrayal of Father and Mother in "Life With Father," again will go on in the roles they created.

Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday upon his return from an elevenday vacation in California that he would ask the City Council to adopt local legislation imposing an annual tax of $5 on pleasure automobiles and $10 on commercial motor vehicles.

CORONADO, Calif., April 29 -- Junior Leagues were among the first groups to recognize the new problems of channeling activity of wartime volunteers into peacetime interests, delegates to the conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America were told today.

Julius Lobel, alias Jimmy Collins, had his day in court yesterday. He described his role in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle as that of "errand boy" and attributed his affluence to his success as a gambler and to a lucrative black market in nylon stockings.

THE New York Giants are currently entrenched behind their Polo Grounds barricades, striving to repel the invaders from the West.
