Generalissimo Melvin Ott is deploying youthful and inexperienced troops against the seasoned hordes from the hinterlands, and the battle will depend greatly upon how they stand up under fire.

BERLIN, April 29 -- Driving through rich fields in Bavaria, two Russian correspondents of Tass, touring the American zone, pointed out what they said were vast improperly used lands. One of them said to me: "Those grazing grounds, those untilled fields are why the Americans must import billions of dollars' worth of food for German consumption.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 29 -- The seventeenth annual festival of American music of the Eastman School of Music, Dr. Howard Hanson, director, got off to an auspicious start tonight before a large audience in the Eastman Theatre.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A suppressed War Department report revealing that the Army and Navy needlessly wasted hundreds of millions of dollars on the procurement of war supplies, has been obtained by the Senate Armed Forces Committee.

Six lengths separate the top and bottom teams in the National League standings. In the order of their appearance they are the Dodgers and the Cardinals and even at this early date -- pennants are won and lost in April, too -- the lead of the Brooks over the world champion St. Louis club is no trifling matter.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Southern Coal Producers Association firmly declined today to take part in any industry-wide bargaining conference with the United Mine Workers (AFL), but offered to negotiate a separate wage contract with the union.
LONDON, April 29 -- The Labor Government faced the distasteful necessity tonight of bringing in troops to assure food supplies threatened by strikes.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A new bronze statue of Thomas Jefferson stands watchfully facing the White House today from its pedestal in the Jefferson Memorial across the Tidal Basin.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., April 29 -- Knocking out seventeen base hits off the combined offerings of two or the three Hofstra hurlers, N.Y.U. continued undefeated in Metropolitan Collegiate Conference play by downing the secondplace Flying Dutchmen, 12 to 7, at Bethpage State Park today.

WARSAW, April 29 -- The planned economy of the Soviet Union is almost certainly hoarding bread grain. The rationing system has cut distribution and the word has been spread that this was necessitated by last year's drought. Workers and peasants are accepting this move and its explanation courageously and philosophically.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The first experimental evidence that cancer may originate as the result of a change in the hereditary make-up of some cell in the body, a change (mutation) that may be caused by any one of a great variety of factors, physical or chemical, external and internal, was presented here today at the annual spring meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.

The arbitration bureau of the National Federation of Textiles has received almost 200 cases since the beginning of 1946 to date, according to Irene Blunt, secretary of the association. The greatest bulk of them have come in during the last three months, she said, and the bureau is working at full schedule of four cases a day to clear the calendar.

JERUSALEM, April 29 -- With only a few feet of masonry separating them from freedom, about thirty Stern Gang and Irgun Zvai Leumi terrorists were surprised today in the act of tunneling their way out of Jerusalem's Central Prison.

NUREMBERG, Germany, April 29 -- Twenty-four executives of I.G. Farbenindustrie, headed by Carl Krauch, Hermann Schmitz and George von Schnitzler, will be charged with preparing and participating in aggressive warfare in an indictment to be filed with an American military tribunal next Saturday, it was reliably learned today.

BOSTON, April 29 (AP) -- Under a clever ride by George Hettinger, Cherry Oca Stable's Magellan, a 9-2 shot, defeated Sam Garfield's F.B. Eye by a neck in the feature race today before a crowd of 13,038 at Suffolk Downs. Weathercock finished third, a length and a quarter behind F.B. Eye.

The controversy over the exclusion of Mitzi Solomon's prizewinning sculpture, "The Lovers,' from the annual show of the National Association of Women Artists will be brought up tonight at the organization's annual meeting.

The fastness of New York's fashion world was invaded yesterday when a representative group of styles by St. Louis fashion creators were shown at the Ritz Carlton Oval Room at the luncheon, hour. Many of New York's fashion experts were present.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Even well-to-do cities, which pay teachers high salaries, are nearing the tax-saturation point and need Federal aid, Benjamin Epstein, speaking for the Newark, N.J., Emergency Council of Teachers Organizations, today told the opening session of House hearings on eleven Federal aid-to-education bills.

Still operating under a selfimposed blackout on information to the public, representatives of the New York Telephone Company and 35,000 striking telephone workers met last night in the first evening negotiating session since the walkout began April 7.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Ever since the rumor arose that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York had counseled the Senate Republicans not to put Senator Irving M. Ives on the committee that was to deal with labor legislation, some suspicion has existed in Republican ranks that the Governor is engaged in very complicated political strategy.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The White House announced a list of 76 guests for the dinner tonight in honor of President Aleman of Mexico.

Price mark-downs on radio sets, canned food, furniture and many other goods continued to spread through the nation yesterday, but New York housewives found their dollars didn't buy any more of such necessities as fresh vegetables, fruits and meats.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP) -- Hank Greenberg's big bat, which had not been too potent this spring, provided the margin of victory as the Pirates defeated the Phillles, 6 to 2, in the first game of the Western invasion of the East at Shibe Park today before 7,386.

DOVER, Del., April 30 -- The resumption of common stock dividends and a large-scale expansion of the Cities Service Company's oil and gas interests appeared a certainty after completion of the corporate simplification orders under the Public Utility Holding Company Act, W. Alton Jones president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here today.

BATAVIA, Java, April 29 (U.P.) -- Political sources said tonight, without confirmation, that Western Java had split off from the Indonesian Republic and that heavy fighting between large local forces was going on in the isolated Central Java area between Cheribon and Blitar.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Truman tonight hailed the presence of President Miguel Aleman at a White House state dinner as an evidence of western hemispheric solidarity and as an example for the nations of the eastern hemisphere with whom he said the United States wanted to be no less a good neighbor.

DETROIT, April 29 (AP) -- Stopped by the four-hit pitching of Virgil Trucks and Hal White, the Red Sox took an 8-to-3 pasting from the Tigers today in their first Western appearance of the season. It was Boston's sixth setback in eight starts.

The Artists Equity Association announced yesterday that Hudson D. Walker, president of the American Federation of Arts, has been appointed executive director of the association and will address the membership "official coming-out" meeting to be held this evening at 8:30 o'clock at the Museum of Modern Art.

STOCKHOLM, April 29 (AP) -- Swedish tennis officials today named Lennart Bergelin and Torsten Johansson to open the nation's Davis Cup bid against Czechoslovakia in the first round of European zone play May 2-4.

Chambers of Commerce representatives from twenty-five of the country's largest port cities and delegates from ten national groups will meet in Washington today to discuss co-ordination of efforts to promote an adequate American merchant marine.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A bill killing most of the portal-to-portal suits now totaling about $5,000,000,000 and authorizing the compromise of the remainder was approved today by a Senate-House conference committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 29 -- Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, American physicist who headed the New Mexico atomic bomb laboratory, told United Nations scientists today that research on the destructive powers of the atom must be continued by an international control authority.

LONDON, April 29 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin returned from Moscow this morning and in his few remarks to the press proved more cautious and a little more optimistic than Secretary of State Marshall. However, it is safe to say that behind the scenes, British opinion on the Moscow conference is very much the same as that expressed by the chief United States delegate.

Direct Purchase Power The so-called "Direct Purchase Bill" which President Truman has just signed, permitting the Federal Reserve Banks to buy up to $5,000,000,000 of securities directly from the United States Treasury, is not likely to be used with any frequency, informed banking spokesmen said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Army today ordered the demotion of 640 colonels to the rank of lieutenant colonel, effective July 1, in a move to reduce the top ranks in accordance with its shrunken size.

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 29 -- The Soviet Union and Poland fought a desperate but unsuccessful rear-guard action today in an effort to prevent effective scrutiny of the troubled Balkan border area between Greece and Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania between now and the Security Council's decision on the Greek complaints.

Kept out of last Saturday's Excelsior Handicap which was to have been his 1947 debut, Stymie, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' one-time plater and now one of the all-time wonders of the turf, will make his initial bow of the season today when he runs in the $6,500 added six-furlong Snark Handicap at Jamaica.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 -- For the sixth time in eight 1947 starts the Calumet Farm's colt Faultless was a winning favorite today -- but only by the margin of his handsome head.

ALBANY, April 29 -- Supreme Court Justice William H. Murray signed an order today directing the Secretary of State, Thomas J. Curran, to show cause why he should not be restrained from enforcing the Wilson-Pakula Law. This measure, signed three weeks ago by Governor Dewey, is designed to prevent "raiding" of a party's primary election by members of other parties.

MANILA, April 29 -- Goaded by Congressional disclosures and a barbed press, President Manuel A. Roxas, after a meeting of his Cabinet today, ordered the suspension and investigation of numerous Filipino Government officials and employes.

State and Commerce Department officials have agreed to take up with Indian authorities problems created for American exporters under the recent imposition of severe import restrictions by the Indian Government, it was reported yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., April 29 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll moved today into a labor dispute that has been crippling a $40,000,000 building program in northern New Jersey through sporadic strikes during the last two years as the result of jurisdictional fights among opposing American Federation of Labor unions.

When Prince Wan Waithayakon of Siam took his seat in the United Nations Assembly the most democratically inclined and the only free country in southeast Asia assumed its rightful place at the council table of the world. And one of the most troubled areas of the Far East gained an independent spokesman.

As interesting as anything in the Marshall report on the Moscow conference is the light it throws on the character, mind and method of the new Secretary of State. Mr. Marshall did not have time to reveal himself before he went to the Foreign Ministers Council.

Michael Sinutko, 5 years old, of 568 Ninth Avenue, and Lucille Green, 5, of 130 West 132d Street, were named king and queen of health yesterday in the annual Child Health Day contest of the Children's Aid Society.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Following are the texts of President Truman's greeting to President Aleman of Mexico and the latter's reply.

Support of the $800,000 drive of the United States Committee for the Care of European Children, and revision of immigration quotas to expedite the removal of warmade orphans to private homes here, were stressed last night in WQXR's presentation of the drama, "I Have Seen the Children."

WASHINGTON, April 29 (U.P.) -- The Army and Navy today put before the House a war plant leasing program which they said would save money and time "which in a future war might spell the difference between success and disaster."

In case you wish to observe a parcel of adolescent boys behaving normally, your attention is directed to "A Young Man's Fancy," which was put on at the Plymouth last evening. To judge by the bedlam on the stage, Harry Thurschwell and Alfred Golden, the authors, knew how terrifying life can be in a summer camp when the boys are in good health and voice.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Baltimore Ohio Railroad categorically denied today allegations of impropriety in the carrier's reorganization under bankruptcy with the aid of an $80,000,000 loan extension by the agency.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 29 -- After weathering seventeen years of attack as an "economic white elephant," the County Center on the Bronx River Parkway here suddenly has come of age by balancing its operating budget for the first time, the Westchester Recreation Commission reported today.

UNITED STATES NAVAL ORDNANCE TEST STATION, Inyokern, Calif., April 29 -- This $50,000,000 desert "secret weapon" development center, where the Navy has successfully welded 10,000 civilians and service scientists, engineers, technicians and their dependents into a smoothworking unit, has paradoxical features of want in the midst of plenty.

Rocco Rossano, 145, Brooklyn scored a technical knockout over Davey Cohen, 146, Bronx, in 2:22 of the sixth session of the scheduled feature bout of eight rounds last night at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, before a crowd of 4,000. The loser was outclassed and suffered lacerations of each eye when Referee Harry Gleischer halted hostilities.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 29 -- The twenty-fourth Eastern States Antiques Fair opened here this afternoon with the 100 exhibitors' booths overflowing onto the stage of the Westchester County Center's auditorium. The fair will be open daily from 1 to 11 P.M. except for the last day, Saturday, when the doors will close at 6 P.M.

A new line-up and the salubrious atmosphere of the Polo Grounds seemed to work wonders for the Giants yesterday. Reacting vigorously to the change in personnel and the shift in scene, Mel Ott's charges swarmed all over the Cardinals for a 7-2 triumph before 12,784 paying spectators.

Various Building Types The Yankee Stadium, where Babe Ruth received national acclaim last Sunday in the House That Ruth Built, was not the only house erected in the United States during the period sometimes described as our era of glorious nonsense twenty years ago.

Japanese cottons offered by the United States Commercial Company to private traders here for re-export will be disregarded, downtown exporters asserted yesterday. Price and conditions of sale, they said, make the goods unattractive in the face of continuing opposition to products from Japan.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 29 -- A 21-year-old mother beat up two males here today. She thought they had kidnapped her children.

The U.S.S. Gato, a 1,500-ton submarine that was commissioned three weeks after Pearl Harbor and piled up an impressive record in thirteen war patrols in the Pacific, was turned over to the Naval Reserve yesterday in formal ceremonies at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 29-- Congressman Fred A. Hartley Jr. of New Jersey, chairman of the House Committee on Education and Labor, said today that "Labor is sick and won't take any medicine for itself, so it remains for Congress to give it some."

Supplementing the report on the Moscow Conference submitted by Secretary of State Marshall, John Foster Dulles, his special Republican adviser at Moscow, has now submitted his own report on that Conference for public judgment. It is symbolic of the harmony established between the two parties in foreign affairs that his report is practically identical with that of Secretary Marshall in respect to all facts and interpretations.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The House voted tentatively today to slash to $200,000,000 the Administration's $350,000,000 program for the relief of distressed peoples in liberated countries. It also adopted reservations, aimed at Russiandominated areas, that American missions would watch the distribution of supplies all the way through to local communities.

MARYVILLE, Mo., April 29 -- A tornado ripped through the tiny farm town of Worth today. It leveled every building along the near-by community's Main Street, but left miles of green rolling fields in every direction almost untouched.

Confirmation of the long delayed spring came to this city yesterday when the Horticultural Society of New York opened its annual twoday narcissus show at its headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue. The exhibit, to which the public is invited, may be seen today from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.

Plans for a nineteen-story office building at 720-34 Third Avenue at an estimated cost of $2,500,000 were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The 720 Third Avenue Corporation, of 285 Madison Avenue, is the owner, and Sidney Goldstone is the architect.

America is still a land of promise, Senator Irving M. Ives declared last night at a dinner in the Hotel Astor opening the tenth annual campaign of the Greater New York Fund. He said that it was "still a better place than all the totalitarian regimes that were ever dreamed of in the crooked philosophies of the dictators."

DETROIT, April 29 -- The Rabbinical Council of America adopted tonight a resolution calling upon the United States to exert its influence in the United Nations to safeguard Palestine as the last haven in the world for Jewry.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Henry Ford 2d told the United States Chamber of Commerce tonight that the American public expected results from business management, not explanations of its problems.

Planned economy has become an integral part of business life in Britain and will result in rapid recovery from post-war difficulties, L.P. Thomas, president L.P. Thomas Company, and a director in several building material concerns, stated yesterday.

Heading in a general westward direction, with "airports of call" dependent upon the consignments of various air cargoes it finds, the world's first international air tramp departed from La Guardia Field shortly after noon yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 29 -- Production at Metro-GoldwynMayer, which has been slack since the war and which has decreased sharply in recent months as a result of the studio's retrenchment program, will reach a new high level this summer, it was announced today.

VIENNA, April 29 -- The Communist party's Volksstimme warned the Austrian people today that Austrian prisoners were being held in Russia as hostages for a change of Austrian policy away from its alleged pro-American and anti-Soviet orientation.

While good teaching of world affairs undoubtedly exists in many schools, there is need for improvement and planning on a city-wide basis, the Board of Education's Committee on the Teaching of World Affairs in the Schools reported yesterday.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 29 -- William Wilson, 59-year-old staff engineer of the New York Telephone Company, was killed this morning when he stepped into an elevator shaft in the telephone building on Fulton Avenue here. He plunged five floors to the basement.

The principal distortions in the price structure probably will not be corrected primarily by direct and purposeful action but by the lapse of time and the operation of natural forces, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York says in its monthly "Survey," issued yesterday.

LONDON, April 29 -- Members of the Chemical Workers Union engaged on the Government's atomic- energy projects are suffering from a number of baffling ailments, the May issue of the union's journal, The Chemical Worker, charged today.

A trend toward more emphasis on silhouette and less on decoration in women's fall shoes is indicated by exhibits at the Nations Shoe Fair being held this week at the Commodore, Biltmore, McApin and New Yorker Hotels. Close toe and heel dress shoes, close versions of sandals and casual types, and high or asymmetry vamps are among the fashion high lights.

John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy adviser, urged last night a revival of the economic potential of the BritishAmerican zone in Germany, particularly the Ruhr, to help solve the problems facing Western European democracies and to demonstrate the efficacy of free institutions.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 29 -- Hudson County Quarter Sessions Judge John Drewen denied today a motion by New Jersey State Senator Edward J. O'Mara to quash conspiracy indictments brought against Mayor Bernard N. McPeely and ten other Hoboken city and police officials.

The proposed change in rules that would perpetuate a wartime system under which women at Radcliffe are permitted to go to Harvard instead of having Harvard professors go to them seems to be one more step in the emancipation of the female, who was long considered above or beneath the need for higher education.

Herschel V. Johnson, deputy United States delegate to the United Nations General Assembly, led the fight yesterday against acceptance of the Arab demand that the special session on Palestine place on its agenda a proposal for the termination of the British mandate and the immediate independence of Palestine.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- The Inland Steel Company prepared today for a strike at midnight tomorrow by Locals 1010 and 64, United Steel Workers, CIO, which represent 14,350 employes of the company's Indiana Harbor and Chicago Heights plants.

WARSAW, April 29 -- The American Embassy has dismissed a Polish employe who declared herself recently to the security police as a participant in the political underground. Under the amnesty, she will not be prosecuted.
LONDON, April 29--The strike of dock workers here and the fact that it was the last day of the account kept business down to a minimum in the stock markets today.

How much should be budgeted for food by the many persons in this city who must eat all their meals in restaurants? Of course, with unlimited money to spend there's no difficulty. But for those with moderate incomes the problem of getting the right food at reasonable prices is not easy.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 (AP) -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation reported today at its stockholders' annual meeting that its consolidated net income for the first quarter of 1947 was $6,337,132, equal to $1.41 a common share, compared with $813,246, or 13 cents a share, for the first quarter of 1946.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio rejected strong public pressure today from two Republican colleagues to have him abandon efforts to stiffen the omnibus labor bill, but he is prepared to make one concession.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Advances in the treatment of pneumonia, malaria and tuberculosis were described today by medical scientists at the annual convention of the American College of Physicians. About 4,000 delegates from all parts of the country are at the sessions.

Some very strange animal life is found in Australia, but none stranger than the platypus. The first British settlement of the land down under was only a dozen years old when a stuffed specimen of this mixed-up beast was carried home to England, in 1799. Scientists there were frankly skeptical.

JERUSALEM, April 29 -- Science from the medical school in Palestine will make its unique contribution to the welfare of all the peoples of the Middle East, James G. McDonald, a member of the AngloAmerican Committee of Inquiry, said today in a speech delivered at the site of the projected Institute of Biology building.

Net income of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and its subsidiary companies for the twelve, months ended on March 31 was $33,064,204 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, the company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, warned today in a statement that "we cannot wait too long for a peace program which at least unites those who can agree."

Hiram Edward Manville, retired chairman of the board of the Johns Manville Corporation, who died June 27 last left a gross estate of $14,499,540, and after payment of debts and administration expenses a net of $4,906,450, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday by Deputy Estate Tax Commissioner Charles W. Ferry.

When the Board of Education meets this afternoon it will call upon the Board of Estimate for an additional allotment of $1,500,000 to be used in modernizing old public school buildings, it was learned yesterday.
PEIPING, April 29 -- Communist armies battled Government troops on many fronts in North China today while commodity prices in Nationalist areas soared to new highs.

Consolidated sales in the first quarter of this year increased to $71,500,000 from the $53,000,000 volume transacted in the corresponding three months of last year, Thomas J. Hargrave, president of Eastman Kodak Company, reported yesterday to stockholders at their annual meeting in Flemington, N.J.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Gov. Dwight H. Green and the Illinois Service Recognition Board cleared the way today for payment of the State veterans' bonus by awarding a $300,000,000 bond issue to finance the bonus to a nation-wide syndicate of banks and dealers headed by several Chicago companies.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The State Department announced today that the United States had recognized the independence of the Himalayan kingdom of Nepal and established diplomatic relations with it through the conclusion of an executive agreement of friendship and commerce at Kathmandu, the capital.

ROME, April 29 -- Political circles displayed both regret and tempered satisfaction today over Secretary of State Marshall's speech to the American people. Their regret stemmed from the fact that he dispelled whatever slim hopes were entertained here for an early peace in Europe, without which, they felt the economic reconstruction of ormer belligerents will inevitably be retarded and in any case much more difficult.
Eight speakers presented reports yesterday at the International Meeting on Marine Radio Aids to Navigation at the Hotel Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Doubling of pre-war box board output by early next year has some members of the box-making industry worried, C.B. McClain, vice president of Atlas Boxmakers, Inc., declared today. He addressed the annual industrial packaging and materials handing forum sponsored by the Industrial Packaging Engineers Association of America.

The only mammals that can have a gay time every night and not develop bags under their eyes will show New Yorkers today how it is done without the aid of beauty parlors. This is the day that the platypuses will make their public debut at the Bronx Zoo.

MOSCOW, April 29 -- The Soviet Union's delegation to the Council of Foreign Ministers session here fought consistently for realization of the Potsdam and Yalta decisions as they had been agreed, against United States and British attempts to change these decisions.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 23, the Federal Reserve Board announced today: Decreases of $110,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural oans, $169,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, $255,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and $462,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks and an increase of $334,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- Buying gained momentum at the national housewares and major appliance show in Convention Hall today when buyers failed to find a definite crack in the price line and began asking for order blanks.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- The Long Island Lighting Company applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to borrow $5,000,000 from four New York banks to pay outstanding bank loans and to finance present construction.

JERUSALEM, April 29 -- The objectives of the Jewish Agency's representatives to the United Nations were outlined today in cablegram from New York read to correspondents by an agency spokesman. They are: To obtain Zionist representation in the Assembly.
With the glamour and confusion of its season's opening behind it, Ballet Theatre got into its regular stride at the City Center last night and proved once more what an admirable company it is.

Marking the return of more competitive conditions, allotments of boys' clothing are disappearing from the merchandising picture as fall lines are opened, it was reported here yesterday. Prices rule unhanged to slightly lower for the new season.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 6,500 head: total, 10,000; market fairly active, mostly 50 cents higher; some sales 75 cents higher on hogs over 260 pounds; sows unevenly 50 cents to $1 higher; top $24

ST. LOUIS, April 29 -- Rain today upset plans for the Yankees' first game against the Browns at Sportsman's Park and brought to light a revision of Manager Bucky Harris' pitching order. Bill Bevens, who was to have taken his regular turn, was indisposed as the aftermath of his smallpox vaccination and temporarily sidetracked.

New techniques for determining reader interest in farm publications were described yesterday to the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association. Alcuin W. Lehman, managing director of the Advertising Research Foundation, told members that in a survey of fifteen rural Ohio counties interviewers discovered that pictures obtained greatest reader interest.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Despite his many recent laudable moves, President Truman's opposition to any tax reduction right now is so indefensible that the action can only be considered political, as stated by your capable Arthur Krock.

On the eve of today's meeting of the United Nations Security Council, called to consider the application of Hungary to join the United Nations, Stephen Borsodi, counselor to the Hungarian Legation in Washington, said Hungary would forswear her pre-war boundaryrevisionist policy.

The Jewish Agency for Palestine protested yesterday that the first general committee meeting of the special General Assembly had heard only "one side of the question" and the Zionists' cause had not been represented.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Having spent the last forty-seven years as lawyer, judge and enlisted man in the Army, I think that the lawyers who are trying to take the court-martial system away from the officers have no idea of what they are doing.

Negotiations looking toward a deal on the three Supreme Court Justiceships to be filled at the November election in the Second Judicial District are under way, it was revealed yesterday. The district includes Kings, Queens, Richmond, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

Leading manufacturers of men's clothing in the New York market paid warm tribute to the memory of a labor leader yesterday as they contributed $142,300 toward the $1,000,000 Sidney Hillman Foundation established last fall as a memorial to the former president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (U.P.) -- The House Appropriations Committee approved today $95,458,658 in deficiency appropriations to enable some Government departments and agencies to operate until the current fiscal year ends June 30.

Leading manufacturers of men's clothing in the New York market paid warm tribute to the memory of a labor leader yesterday as they contributed $142,300 toward the $1,000,000 Sidney Hillman Foundation established last fall as a memorial to the former president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (U.P.) -- The House Appropriations Committee approved today $95,458,658 in deficiency appropriations to enable some Government departments and agencies to operate until the current fiscal year ends June 30.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 29 -- The first report of the United Nations Military Staff Committee, which, according to authoritative sources, reveals that the prospect for establishing an international police force are exceedingly remote, will be submitted tomorrow to the Security Council.
Nurses from all corners of the world met yesterday and agreed that the public must be educated to a true appreciation of their profession if it is to receive adequate nursing service.

Real lace and fine stitches on the finest of table linens are back again for this year's brides. Yesterday Lord Taylor presented its first post-war collection of imports from France, Belgium and Italy. There is embroidered Bisso linen and silk organdy from Italy, some of it accented with elaborate onepiece insets of lace.

Following are the texts of speeches by Dr. Fadel Jamali of Iraq, Herschel V. Johnson of the United States, Dr. Charles Malik of Lebanon, and Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union in yesterday's meeting of the General Committee of the United Nations General Assembly:

Net income of the United States Steel Corporation in the first quarter of 1947 was $39,234,511, equal to $3.78 a common share, Irving S. Olds, chairman, reported yesterday after the quarterly meeting of directors. The board declared the regular dividend of $1.75 a share on the preferred stock and $1 on the common.

OTTAWA, April 29 -- After declaring a surplus of $352,000,000 in revenue over expenditure during the last fiscal year, Finance Minister Douglas C. Abbott today announced a reduction in Canadian income tax rates that will bring them below the present levels in the United States.

Now that the excitement has died down about the "wayward bus" that went to Florida, a story developed yesterday about a "wayward truck." Due to arrive by midmorning at the Greek War Relief Association at 420 East Fiftyfourth Street with 500 pounds of seeds donated by the National Junior Vegetable Growers, the truck never appeared.

BOSTON, April 29 (AP) -- Lefty Warren Spahn gave only four singles today to win his second game of the year as the Braves blanked the Cincinnati Reds, 4 -- 0. It was the first shut-out of the season for a Boston twirler.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 29 -- An international competition, considered one of the most significant of its kind ever conducted, probably will be held for the design of buildings for United Nations headquarters, members of the American Institute of Architects were informed at the opening of their convention here today.

Buyers' Total Lower Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,149 compared with 1,209 last week and 1,951 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The question of art or utility along the East River in Queens aroused more discussion yesterday. United Nations planners desire advertising signs removed from the shore frontage directly opposite the United Nations site in Manhattan, and the Board of Estimate has under consideration a resolution restricting Queens business signs that face the world capitol.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Liquidation continued in the grain markets early today on the Board of Trade. Prices reached new lows for the current downturn with corn leading. The May delivery of corn was off 5 3/4 cents a bushel at one time and down 33 1/4 cents from the high of a month ago as the result of heavy selling attributed to professional traders who were closing spreads with July and on hedging pressure.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The diplomatic reports summarizing the Moscow conference are beginning to come in. For the most part they merely illustrate the accuracy and completeness of the press reports on the peace negotiations in Moscow but they do comment with some interest and surprise on the tactics and personality of Secretary of State George C. Marshall.

The text of John Foster Dulles' report on the Moscow meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers broadcast by him on the Columbia Broadcasting System network last night follows: Eight weeks ago, I went to Moscow with Secretary Marshall.

The United States could contribute to liberal political principles throughout the world by another large loan, or gift, to Great Britain, in the opinion of J. Raymond Walsh, economist and radio commentator. Dr. Walsh advocated this procedure yesterday to tide Great Britain over her current period of difficulty during which, he said, "she is striving to find a new economic basis for her life."

The question of art or utility along the East River in Queens aroused more discussion yesterday. United Nations planners desire advertising signs removed from the shore frontage directly opposite the United Nations site in Manhattan, and the Board of Estimate has under consideration a resolution restricting Queens business signs that face the world capitol.

Talks were opened at Washington yesterday between John L. Lewis and the bituminous mine operators with a view to working out a contract for taking the mines out of Government operations. Seized on May 22, 1946, after a fifty-nine-day strike, the properties must be returned to their owners by June 30 next.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Imminent wage overtures to end the strike of 330,000 telephone workers were predicted today by Henry Mayer, counsel for a group of telephone workers unions.

WILLIAM HARDY McNEILL, a young historian who served as a United States Military Attache in Greece for twenty crucial months, from November, 1944, until June, 1946, has none of the facile skill of a crack feature writer; but he has many of the fundamental requirements of a good historian, including industry, thoroughness and detachment.

A midday wave of selling on the New York Stock Exchange produced yesterday some sharp inroads in key issues but a late recovery saw most, and in many instances all, of the losses recovered and the composite rate off only 0.20 point on the day.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The diplomatic reports summarizing the Moscow conference are beginning to come in. For the most part they merely illustrate the accuracy and completeness of the press reports on the peace negotiations in Moscow but they do comment with some interest and surprise on the tactics and personality of Secretary of State George C. Marshall.

The text of John Foster Dulles' report on the Moscow meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers broadcast by him on the Columbia Broadcasting System network last night follows: Eight weeks ago, I went to Moscow with Secretary Marshall.
A wholesale meat house, supplying 300 butcher shops in Brooklyn, Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens, became early today the first major purveyor of food in this city to reduce all prices 10 per cent.

An Arab proposal to place the question of the independence of Palestine on the agenda of the special session was rejected last night by the General Committee of the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow. The vote was 8 to 1, with five abstentions, including that of the Soviet Union.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
LONDON, April 30 -- The stock markets today made a bright start to the new account, the more favorable news of the dock strike bringing in buyers.

IF you can stand one more anthology -- which is about as moot a point as can be raised these days -- here is a pretty lively one. It is called "The Holiday Reader"; it is edited by Bernard Smith and Philip Van Doren Stern, and it is full of all kinds of short pieces by all kinds of authors, from Ernest Hemingway and Archibald MacLeish to Bennett Cerf and Shakespeare.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- John L. Lewis and his United Mine Workers kept the door open today to a wage conference without the participation of the Southern Coal Producers Association, but the miners' leader insisted on knowing, virtually to the last ton, where every operator stood.

The Riverdale Country School, marking the fortieth anniversary of its founding, reviewed yesterday its history and accomplishments as one of the first "country schools" in the United States and looked also to the future when it will become a "world school," training its students for world service and citizenship.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- Television images in good color, projected on a small theatre-size screen using an all-electronic system, had their first public showing here today fresh from the laboratories of the Radio Corporation of America.
A four-run uprising in the eighth inning enabled New York University's baseball team to beat Temple, 6-2, yesterday at Ohio Field, and remain undefeated in nine starts this season.

Simple vases, made for specific types of flower arrangements, by the Newcomb Art School of Tulane University in New Orleans were placed on exhibition yesterday at America House, 485 Madison Avenue. The pottery stresses the school's theory that vases always should be designed for a definite purpose rather than as empty table-top ornaments.

More than 300,000 free tickets to baseball games at the Yankee Stadium constitute the initial endowment of the Yankee Juniors, which came into being yesterday. The new organization, whose purpose is to combat juvenile delinquency by encouraging interest in sports, is sponsored by the New York Yankees.

The salt water fishing has improved considerably during the past few days, with really big flounders reported from several fishing ports, and the weakfish are due to arrive in Peconic in large numbers any day. The first catch of mackerel was made on Tuesday off Manasquan, N. J.

Long Island University, which has been in bankruptcy reorganization since 1943 in Federal Court, Brooklyn, is expected to have its present financial structure approved today by Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Representatives of the Port of New York Authority, the city, and the Navy Department held what was described today as a "very satisfactory" conference on the question of transferring a New York lease on a part of Floyd Bennett Airfield to the Port Authority.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Nearly a score of witnesses urged the Senate today to reject, soften, or delay ratification of the Italian peace treaty, asserting it was a harsh agreement that played into the hands of the Soviet Union.

Reflecting greater production in the first quarter of this year by contrast with a year ago when the rate was seriously reduced by the, steel strike, earnings of five large steel companies showed great gains over those of the corresponding three months last year, according to their reports announced yesterday.

Business loans and corporate earnings have expanded recently, but demand deposits of individuals, partnerships and corporations in all commercial banks in this district at the end of February had declined $335,000,000, or 1.6 per cent, since July, 1946, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Representatives of 35,000 New York Telephone Company employes signed an agreement yesterday to settle their twenty-four-day-old strike for a wage increase of $4 a week, but there were strong indications last night that few local workers would return to their jobs until strikes involving long-distance operators and Western Electric employes had ended.

LONDON, Thursday, May 1 -- Despite stubborn delaying tactics by a small group of Opposition members, the Labor Government finally succeeded early today in pushing through a "gagged" House of Commons its bill nationalizing all the inland transport in Britain.
Cotton futures closed somewhat irregular yesterday after a strong opening. The list on the New York Cotton Exchange ended 19 points higher to 12 points lower than the day before.

Frank J. Sampson, leader of Tammany, announced yesterday the selection of C. Mott Shavers as Tammany leader of the Fourteenth Assembly District to fill the vacancy caused by the death of James M. Pemberton.

Alfred Wallenstein, conductor and music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, will be this year's recipient of the Alice M. Ditson Award of $1,000, presented annually at Columbia University to an American conductor for distinguished services to American music, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of the university.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN Germany, April 30 (AP) -- Col. Jack W. Durans was sentenced to fifteen years at hard labor and cashiered from the service today as the United States Army wound up its prosecution of the "principals" in the theft of the $1,500,000 Hesse crown jewels.

GENEVA, April 30 -- The Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization convenes in Lausanne tomorrow with establishment of that agency regarded as a virtual certainty as a result of China's unconditional surrender yesterday on the IRO constitution.
Korea, directly under Japan's heel beginning in 1910 and influenced indirectly before then, emerged as a potential Olympic contender in its new status as a free nation yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: BOTH THE TIMES and The Washington Post hail Molotov's answer on Korea as hopeful. These editorials will no doubt be read with satisfaction by Mr. Molotov, but an American may be pardoned for having doubts.

Swelled by the largest retirement of public utility bonds in eight months, the total of $194,422,000 in bonds called before maturity for payment in April was the largest for any month since last September, but slightly smaller than in April, 1946.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP) -- The Pirates unlimbered their bats against Tommy Hughes and Blix Donnelly today for fifteen hits, including Clyde Kluttz's first home run of the season, and defeated the Phillies, 11 to 4.

Reductions of as much as 22 per cent in return air fares to Latin America were announced yesterday by Pan American Airways. Described as vacation fares, good until Sept. 30, they are expected by Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American, to result in the carriage of a million passengers this year by his company and its affiliate, Pan American Grace.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Negotiations for a settlement of Russia's $11,000,000,000 lend-lease account were formally opened today when Nikolai V. Novikov, the Soviet Ambassador, met with Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.

Consolidated net sales of the May Department Stores Company for the fiscal year ended with last January reached a record total of $330,331,000, according to the thirty-seventh annual report issued to stockholders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The significance of a flower, "lily white in color" and "seductive in fragrance," beguiled the Senate Banking Committee today as it continued its investigation of the propriety of an $80,000,000 loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Baltimore Ohio Railroad.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The list of guests at the dinner given by President Aleman tonight at the Mexican Embassy follows: The President of Mexico.

Favorable developments in various wage controversies throughout the nation found immediate response yesterday on the stock market, where the widest gains of the month were recorded. Advances of 1 to 3 points helped materially to bolster sentiment in Wall Street and an absence of pressure enabled the list to recover with comparative ease.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 30 -- Checking a ninth-inning rally that produced two runs and had the tying and winning runs on the bases, the Army baseball team defeated Yale, 4-3, today. It was the tenth straight collegiate triumph of the season for the undefeated Cadets.

HAMBURG, Germany, April 30 -- As the British zone faced another major food crisis, Maj. Gen. W.H.A. Bishop, deputy Chief of Staff of the British Control Commission, largely blamed the Germans themselves today.

PITTSBURGH, April 30 (AP) -- The United Steel Workers of America, CIO, announced tonight that virtual agreement had been reached with the Aluminum Company of America on a 1947 contract providing for the "more than 15-cent-anhour wage increase package."

Estimated income of the Pan American Airways Corporation in 1946 was $2,983,000 after provision of $2,420,000 for Federal income taxes, the company announced yesterday. In 1945 the net income was $7,565,580.

How the Princess Doris Farid es-Sultaneh, former wife of the Kresge chain stores owner and also of a Persian prince, lost jewels worth 599,500 to a "master swindler," who deceived her both in business and love, was told yesterday by State Attorney General Nathaniel S. Goldstein.
COPENHAGEN, April 30 -- With traditional ceremonial the body of King Christian X was borne today from Copenhagen to Roskilde Cathedral, where through the centuries all Danish kings have been buried.

JERUSALEM, April 30 -- While anti-terrorist Jewish labor organizations were beginning to celebrate May Day, two home-made mines full of rivets, nuts and bolts were discovered on the outskirts of Jerusalem today, ready for firing.

Treasury Surplus According to present indications, the United States Treasury's surplus for the current fiscal year will be even larger than the $1,250,000,000 forecast by the latest revision of budget estimates, informed banking spokesmen asserted yesterday.

Failure to avert thousands of traffic accidents over the country was attributed yesterday to inadequate driver examinations, neglect of periodic motorist and vehicular tests and lack of coordination among prevention groups. These factors were emphasized at a meeting of the National Committee for Traffic Safety in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A seven - year controversy over the proper basis for converting English pounds into American dollars for the purpose of assessing customs duty has been settled by a decision of the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals, Washington, D.C., it was announced yesterday by United States Assistant Attorney General Paul P. Rao, in charge of the customs division.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The most interesting aspect of the roll-call in the Senate today on the motion to split pending labor legislation into four separate measures was the solid Republican front and the large Democratic break against it. Never has a plain political scheme been advanced in an atmosphere of greater piety.

PARIS, April 30 -- France has proposed the opening of negotiations here next week to reach an accord on commercial exchanges between France and the economically merged United States and British zones in Germany, an official announcement said today.
LONDON, April 30 -- Strong support for the United States plan of atomic energy control was voiced in the House of Lords today.

Harvard remained unbeaten at the top of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League by defeating Columbia, 9 -- 7, at Baker Field yesterday. The victory, second over. Columbia and third in a row for the Crimson, dropped the Lions to a third-place tie with Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Republican Senators, concerned by what Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio called "an attack in the West on the Republican party," pledged "complete consideration" today to the reclamation needs of that area.

Intense dissatisfaction with present Congressional proposals for "liberalizing" pension benefits for postal employes was expressed here yesterday by representatives of 24,000 postal workers in this area.

As an aid to ocean navigation Loran already has proved its value on the United States liner Amerca, this country's largest passenjer vessel, Commodore Harry Manning, master of the ship, declared yesterday
The Arab League has "shockingly" misrepresented the position of Jews in Arab countries, the Jewish Agency for Palestine charged yesterday.

LONDON, Thursday, May 1 -- The Theatre Guild's production of "Oklahoma!" took London by storm last night. Presented at the famous Theatre Royal in Drury Lane, it won such applause that at the end the audience refused to go until the company sang some of the songs over again.
PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- Three companies filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission registration statements covering preferred and common stocks.

With a parting word of thanks to the American people for their kindness during his fourteenmonth assignment here, Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, Minister Without Portfolio in the Netherlands Cabinet and former Dutch representative to the United Nations, sailed for home yesterday aboard the Holland America liner Westerdam.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Eugene Dennis, secretary of the Communist party in the United States, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on a charge of contempt of Congress and a warrant for his arrest was ordered by the District Attorney.

MACON, Ga., April 30 -- Georgia Democrats received a new party faction today that immediately put in a bid for national political recognition by pledging its delegates to the 1948 Democratic national convention to vote for the nomination of President Harry S. Truman.
PARIS, April 30 -- Schiaparelli stars cotton. She gives an air of summer to a black wool tailormade by pocket flaps, gloves and blouse in cyclamen and white printed cotton.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The May issue of the Reserve Officer, organ of the 140,000 members of the Reserve Officers Association of the United States, will charge tomorrow that the attitude of the Regular Army toward civilian components is "anything but encouraging to the civilian soldier."

BERLIN, April 30 -- By caring for displaced Ukrainians and Balts through the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, the United States is harboring war criminals who fought against the Soviet Union, in the opinion of two Russian correspondents for Tass, and they confirmed this belief during a trip in the American zone last week, they said.

AMSTERDAM, April 30 (Aneta) -- Prices moved lower in moderately active trading on the Stock Exchange. Shipping issues went counter to the trend and closed higher. The increase was attributed to the proposal by the Royal Dutch Steamship Company of a six-year 30 per cent dividend, twothirds of which is to be in new shares.

ATHENS, April 30 (AP) -- A United States director of the Greek National Airline, founded by Trans World Airlines, was forcibly removed from the company's office today by an Athens police under a court order that vested control of the line in a fiveman commission.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Dr. Alfred Newton Richards, Professor of Pharmacology at the University of Pennsylvania Medical School, today was elected president of the National Academy of Sciences, the highest office in American science, for a term of four years.

TOKIO, April 30 -- Answering Russian charges that public health conditions here are appalling, Col. Crawford F. Sams told the Allied Control Council today that Japan in eighteen months since the surrender had made as much progress in public health as had other modern nations in eighteen years.

Commenting on the city's first expense budget to pass a billion dollars, Mayor O'Dwyer remarked some days ago: "I look over this budget and I wonder sometimes where the city is going." New York City is not alone in its concern over the rise in cost of municipal government.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Truman signed today a bill changing the name of Boulder Dam to Hoover Dam. He used four pens in signing the resolution and sent them to Lawrence Ritchie, secretary to Herbert Hoover.

The traditional May 1 migration in New York City is falling short again this year of the activity that was associated with it in pre-war days. In addition to the shortage of living and business quarters, the telephone strike of the last three weeks was a contributing factor this year.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (U.P.) -- The Hope diamond, valued at $2,000,000, whose supposed ill-luck followed society leader Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean to her deathbed last Saturday, was removed from circulation today -- perhaps forever.

HAMBURG, Germany, April 30 -- A step preparatory to the ultimate establishment of a German advisory council that would guide the activities of a central German administration was taken today when Lieut. Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Deputy Military Governor, announced the reorganization of the zone's advisory council along political lines.

While hopeful on retail sales prospects for the coming fall, most retail shoe chains are adopting a "watch and wait" attitude before placing the bulk of their fall commitments, it was reported yesterday following the annual meeting of the Popular Price Shoe Retailers Association at the Hotel Biltimore.

Larry MacPhail, who fully expects, that he will be called upon to answer charges of "insubordination" when he stands on the carpet before A.B. Chandler in Cincinnati today, will not meekly submit his wrist to be slapped by the baseball commissioner.

The Consolidated Edison Corporation of New York, Inc., executed yesterday the second step of a $290,000,000 bond refunding program by awarding at competitive sale an issue of $100,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds to a syndicate of seventyeight underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley Co.
LONDON, April 30 -- Nationalization of the Bank of England today produced its first visible effect. For the first time since its establishment in 1694, the bank issued an annual report.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Immediate United States financial aid to Greece to the extent of $300,000,000 until June 30, 1948, was recommended by the American economic mission in its final report to Secretary of State Marshall.

Directors of the American Cyanamid Company have voted to submit to stockholders a financing plan calling for the redemption of the present preferred stock and the issuance of a new convertible preferred series to provide funds for expansion, W.B. Bell, president, announced yesterday.
WARSAW, April 30 -- What might be called the "political reconversion" of the post-war Soviet Union is of equal importance to its economic readjustment.

A single issue of state veterans' bonds, the largest of its kind in history, featured an otherwise quiet month of new bond financing in April. New bonds publicly offered totaled $459,459,000, representing thirty issues, compared with $624,051,000 for the same number in the preceding month and $667,001,000 for thirty-one offerings in April, 1946.

Hats in Ring As of day before yesterday, Tuesday, April 29, 1947, this column finds itself contemplating an excellent ticket for the 1948 election to which one or both of the major parties might well give serious consideration. First place would go to Senator Claude Pepper of Florida.

By the overwhelming vote of 333 to 66, the House has finally approved a $200,000,000 appropriation for foreign relief after slashing some 43 per cent from the sum asked by President Truman and prescribing strict American control over any aid going to countries under Russian domination.

A new issue of $71,400,000 of $3.5O dividend preferred stock of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. will be placed on the market here today by an investment syndicate of 172 underwriters and 317 dealers headed by Morgan Stanley Co.

In this country today "we've got the raw materials for a lost generation," Gardiner Howland Shaw, president of the Welfare Council of New York City, declared yesterday at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue. He made this assertion in accepting the tenth annual award of a gold medal from the Boys Exposition for outstanding service in the prevention of delinquency.

A one-word summary of the international trade picture for the coming year is "tough," Joshua B. Powers, who was re-elected president of the Export Advertising Association, Inc., told the tenth annual meeting of that organization at a luncheon at the BelmontPlaza Hotel yesterday.

Concerned over increasing pressure by retailers for what they describe as unfair trade advantages, representatives of three New York dress trade groups met yesterday to discuss preliminary steps for protection of the industry.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- There was a let-up today in the aggressive selling of May corn, which has featured trading in the last few days on the Board of Trade. Shorts took the buying side freely, and with less pressure from hedgers the market developed a firmer undertone.

LONDON, April 30 -- Condemnation of exhibitions such as the British Industries Fair, which opens here and in Birmingham next Monday is contained in the report of the Wool Working Party named a year ago to study the wool piece goods industry here.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week dropped 1,732,000 barrels, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the week they amounted to 103,860,000 barrels, compared with 105,592,000 a week earlier and 99,320,000 a year ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 30 -- Two independent motion-picture financing deals were announced today. Sam Bischoff, United Artists producer, disclosed that he has obtained $5,000,000 credit from the Bank of America here for the production of four pictures, the first of which, "Intrigue," a George Raft film, is already before the cameras.

Thousands of Roman Catholics in the New York area will join with others of that faith in 400 communities of this country on "May Day," today, in prayers "for the Russian people and for the millions living in Communistdominated lands."
GENEVA, April 30 -- The United States and the Soviet Union opposed today a British attempt to impose the tightest secrecy on the deliberations of the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission.

BOSTON, April 30 (AP) -- Clubbing Cincinnati pitching for fifteen hits, the Braves today submerged the Reds, 10 -- 3, for their sixth victory in seven home games. The winners' Johnny Sain struck out ten and gave up six hits as he registered his second triumph.

SEOUL, Korea, April 30 -- In anticipation of the resumption of the Joint United States-Soviet commission discussions here at the end of May, the South Korean political factions have once again drawn their lines.

One opportunity after another slipped from the hands of the Giants yesterday but they fastened firmly to their last chance and rode it to a thrilling eleventh-hour 4-to-3 triumph over the Cardinals. It was the second straight setback at the Polo Grounds for the 1946 world champions, who have lost seven games in a row.

Two-year contracts, including wage benefits of slightly more than 15 cents an hour, were signed here yesterday by the Bethlehem Steel Company, Republic Steel Corporation, Crucible Steel Company of America and the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation with the United Steelworkers of America, CIO.

In a criticism of State Department "neutrality" on the Palestine problem, Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Palestine Foundation Fund, and a member of the Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, charged last night 'that Britain had no intention of heeding United Nations rulings and that the present meeting of the world organization is a "farce."
"UMT," or universal military training, is the next "hot potato" that will be handed to Congress.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 -- With the big doings at Churchill Downs only three days away, the Phalanx rooting and marching society is adding to its membership roster hour by hour.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- Outfielder Bob Kennedy proved Pitcher Johnny Rigney's good little helper today as the White Sox defeated the Senators, 5 -- 2, in the only game of the series. Kennedy punched out two doubles to drive in three runs and scored another himself as Rigney posted his second triumph.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was slightly larger than the total for March, but it was the smallest for a corresponding month since 1944. Sales crossed the million-share mark in only four sessions. The market was the broadest on record on April 14, when 1,111 issues were dealt in on a turnover of 2,196,660 shares; this was the largest day's business for the year.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Willard E. Givens, executive secretary of the National Education Association, put the weight of 2,000 local teacher organizations today behind the Taft bill for Federal aid to education on an equalization basis.

LONDON, Thursday, May 1 (U.P.) -- Gen. Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Minister of Armed Forces and Deputy Premier, told the Russian people in a May Day Order of the Day today that their armed forces must constantly maintain "fighting preparedness" and would begin summer maneuvers in a few days.

CHICAGO, April 30 (A.P.) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 6,000 head: total 11,000; market fairly active and 50 to 75 cents higher on weights under 280 pounds; heavier weights only moderately active and extremely uneven, 25 to
New York's biggest welcome mat will be laid down tomorrow, with large "Bien Venido" written across it for President Miguel Aleman of Mexico.

NEWMARKET, England, April 30 (AP) -- Unbeaten Tudor Minstrel stretched his victory string to six races today when he romped home by eight lengths in the Two Thousand Guineas, Britain's first race classic of the season, on Newmarket Heath.
Without advance warning, Australia suddenly reopened yesterday the fight to give the General Assembly greater power in the seating of new members in the United Nations.
Andrew G. Clauson Jr., president of the Board of Education, is expected to be re-elected for a second term when the board meets on May 13, it was learned yesterday.

The first-night contingent will trek this evening to the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, where Chandler Cowles and Efrem Zimbalist Jr., in association with Edith Lutyens, will present the Ballet Society's production of "The Telephone" and "The Medium," a program of two musical plays having book, music and lyrics by GianCarlo Menotti.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The House of Representatives gave Secretary of State Marshall a strange homecoming present today. Just when he had about made up his mind that the main hope of an effective and positive foreign policy lay in trying to strengthen the non-Communist forces of Western Europe, the House slashed his European relief bill by nearly 43 per cent.

NEW DELHI, India, April 30 (Reuters) -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, declared today that the Congress party's demand for the partition of the Punjab and Bengal Provinces was "a sinister move activated by spite and bitterness."
GENEVA, April 30 -- The British have advised the French that tariff negotiations scheduled to begin next Monday cannot proceed on the basis of the proposed new French tariffs.

India's Constituent Assembly, framing a Constitution for an independent India, has accepted a recommendation from its Committee on Rights, that the Indian Constitution contain the provision that the institution of untouchability shall be forever abolished in India, and that its recognition will be an offense.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The House, by a vote of 333 to 66, passed its bill for relief of distressed peoples in liberated countries today, but with the original $350,000,000 authorization slashed by 43 per cent to $200,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Hemisphere solidarity was the dominant theme of every public utterance today by President Miguel Aleman of Mexico on the second day of his official state 'visit to this country. At a special meeting of the board of the Pan-American Union held in his 'honor, he called for even closer unity among the nations of the hemisphere and declared that the fulfillment of Bolivar's ideal was at hand.

Bad Bill Nicholson, a veteran, and Doyle Lade, 25-year-old righthanded pitcher, collaborated perfectly at Ebbets Field yesterday to shatter Brooklyn's six-game winning streak and move the Cubs within one game of the leagueleading Dodgers.

Delayed for half an hour by a heavy shower, the test game between the picked eleven from the four metropolitan clubs in the American Soccer League, which will face the Hapoel team from Palestine at Yankee Stadium Sunday, and the German Americans was played before 2,500 at Sterling Oval last night. The German Americans won, 3-1.

MOSCOW, April 30 -- Counting the blessings of the Soviet Union on the eve of the May Day celebrations, an article in Pravda, Communist party newspaper, said today that not the least of these was its growing number of "sincere friends" in the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Lionel Edie, New York investment adviser and economic analyst, predicted today an "orderly adjustment" of the country's economy within the next eighteen months to a level considerably below that of the present.

Cancellations of orders for copper and brass have been "enormous" but merely represent elimination of duplicated orders placed by buyers to protect future delivery needs, industry spokesmen disclosed here yesterday. In terms of percentage of total tonnage on order, they represent only a small amount, it was revealed, and no falling off in actual demand.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Fair-minded people must agree with Secretary Marshall in his criticism of Russian obstruction of the Austrian treaty of peace and of the Four Power Pact to keep Germany unarmed.

TORONTO, April 30 (AP) -- Sales of nickel in all forms amounted to 201,103,234 pounds in 1946, compared with 201,572,987 pounds in 1945, Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., told the annual meeting today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- In a supplement order, the Securities and Exchange Commission today sanctioned Illinois Power Company's plan for use of the $11,300,OOO it is to receive in settlement of claims against North American Company and the latter's subsidiary, North American Light and Power Company.

PARIS, April 30 -- On the eve of a big May Day demonstration, mainly under Communist auspices, Premier Paul Ramadier appealed to the workers tonight to maintain law and order and thus insure the stability of the republic, which "has hardly emerged from the provisional stage."

John S. Sumner, secretary of the New York Society for The Suppression of Vice, backed by one at, his agents and by three detectives, raided the offices of Random House, the publishing house, at 457 Madison Avenue yesterday afternoon. They confiscated ten copies of "The Blue Hen's Chickens," a book of poems by Vincent McHugh, and left two summonses.

BUENOS AIRES, April 30 -- Vittorio Mussolini said today that he had arrived in Argentina "clandestinely" a month ago and expressed the hope he would be permitted to remain in this South American country and bring his family from Italy so he could live and work "in peace."

LOUISVILLE, April 30 -- The rain sifted down gently from the leaden skies this morning in a steady drizzle, but the Churchill Downs track still was in excellent shape as most of the Derby horses went out for a spin on the oval, where one of them is destined to get fame, glory and a large chunk of folding money on Saturday.

Russek's Fifth Avenue assembled a collection of summer clothes, ranging from bathing suits to dance dresses, in "sail white" to offer as a fashion presentation at luncheon in the Sert room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. The styles looked frosty and cool as a long drink.

Blow not, blow cold tactics were attributed to Mayor O'Dwyer in dealing with the proposed $5 city use auto tax yesterday by William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York. He accused Mr. O'Dwyer of a weathervane attitude and said, "this offagain, on-again Finnegan act makes automobile owners even more determined to resist the confused and ill-advised proposal.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A special "port city" group of the United States Chamber of Commerce today named a tripartite committee of shipping specialists "to work with the President's Advisory Committee on Merchant Marine for the development of a program to strengthen the country's maritime industry.

DETROIT, April 30 -- Urging labor and management to exhaust every means of preventing strikes in the future, the Rabbinical Council of America also called on the Federal Government today to provide the machinery necessary to insure lasting industrial peace.

Westinghouse invited the press to lunch at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday to tell about a novel new kitchen and laundry planning service that will tie offered in some retail stores in this area after June 15. A dealer trained in this service will be able to present a homemaker with a detailed plan for a new or remodeled kitchen within fifteen to thirty minutes after she gives him the dimensions.

DETROIT, April 30 (AP) -- Getting classy four - hit pitching from rookie southpaw Mel Parnell, the Red Sox scored their first victory in five starts today. They chased Hal Newhouser to his third straight defeat with an eleven-hit assault that beat the Tigers, 7 to 1.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- George D. Stoddard, president of the University of Illinois, said tonight that the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization would be a potent force for peace if it used the weapons of free thought, free speech and a free press to carry to all men a knowledge of what was going on in the world.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was interested in the letter from Mr. Hallett, secretary of the Citizens Union, on Proportionate Representation. Like him, I was surprised to see the TIMES opposing P R in the city. 1 should rather have seen THE TIMES supporting its extension throughout the state.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Federal Government should keep out of the country's labor controversies, Henry Ford 2d told the National Press Club here today. In reply to a series of three questions, the motor manufacturer gave his position as follows:

ALBANY, April 30 -- The Health Preparedness Commission, in a final report today to Governor Dewey and the Legislature, urged the state to establish 1,500 hospital beds as part of a concerted drive against chronic diseases, which are responsible for 70 per cent of the deaths in New York State.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- No settlement will be made by an affiliate of the National Federation of Telephone Workers before a wage increase of $6 a wreck is granted, according to union officials and counsel for some of the affiliates.

Sidor Belarsky, basso, whose frequent appearances in this city have won him an enthusiastic following, gave a recital before a large audience last night at Town Hall. The program he presented contained offerings in eight languages, and featured novelties by the Palestinian composers, Gorochoff and Zeira, and a new South American song, "Voce," by Siqueira.

The Magistrates' Courts in New York City are to a peculiar degree courts of the people. The number of cases handled in a year runs into the hundreds of thousands. Many of these are traffic cases, but all types of crime, including felonies, misdemeanors and violations of departmental regulations, also arrive for either summary disposition or referral to grand jury on the way to other tribunals.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Senate upheld Senator Robert A. Taft, 59 to 35, today in the first great test vote on the omnibus labor bill, a vote in which eleven Southern Democrats went over with the regular Republican majority.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., April 30 -- Mayor Harley E. Knox said today that this city needed a positive program to meet a coming crisis in social and economic relations with 21,000 unemployed.

The 1947 appeal of New York Catholic Charities reached a total of $1,622,240 yesterday in contributions obtained by house-to-house solicitation in the New York Archdiocese and through the efforts of the special gifts committee. These figures were announced by George J. Schaefer, assistant treasurer of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, at a general report meeting in the Empire State Club.

The failure of Stymie in his season's bow, a brilliant triumph of Claud C. Tanner's Nearway in the Youthful Stakes, a triple for Eric Guerin and a $135.60 pay-off were among the features witnessed by the throng of 27,024 who went out to Jamaica yesterday.
A goal of $60,000,000 for 1947 and 1948 for overseas relief was approved yesterday by representatives of sixteen Protestant denominations.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The House swung into action today on a bill to extend rent control by giving its approval to provisions in the measure to terminate emergency housing controls over the allocation and distribution of building materials.

Behind the effective twirling of John Weiss, St. John's crushed Brooklyn College, 13 -- 0, in their Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game yesterday at Dexter Park. In pitching the Redmen to their third decision in six starts, the sophomore held the Kingsmen in check with six hits while striking out as many.
Starting today, the housewife who buys sugar or rice will know exactly the ceiling price.

The authority of the United Nations as well as the fate of Palestine is involved in the debate on the agenda of the special session of the Assembly. The session was convened for a special purpose; to appoint a committee to study the question in all its aspects and report its findings and recommendations to the regular meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The first duty of the United States is "to meet our responsibilities to ourselves," Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman told the United States Chamber of Commerce here tonight.

Prices Cut on Kitchen Towels In line with President Truman's request for price reductions, Excello, Ltd., Chicago, announced yesterday a reduction of 7 to 8 per cent on its entire line of kitchen towels. Harold W. Shaw, vice president of the company, pointed out that the cut was the second to be taken during 1947 and the total decrease for the year amounted to as much as 16 per cent.

A complaint of unfair labor practices against the Yankees, Giants and Dodgers has been issued by the State Labor Relations Board, the Rev. William J. Kelley, chairman of the board, announced last night. The complaint followed preliminary investigation by the board of charges filed by Robert Murphy of Boston, labor relations director of the American Baseball Guild.

LOS ANGELES, April 30 -- The Government in a civil suit described by Attorney General Tom Clark as aimed to help "restore competition" in both oil production and marketing today accused the Richfield Oil Corporation of violating the Clayton and Sherman Anti-trust Laws by making exclusive agreements with "independent" service stations in eight Western states.
