A broad survey of the city's health needs and facilities that may require a year to complete was recommended yesterday to the Health Council of Greater New York through Bailey B. Burritt, co-chairman of its program committee and president of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.

NANKING, April 30 -- The economic situation in China threatens to break completely out of control again. The new Government of Premier Chang Chun is thus confronted with a crisis of the gravest proportions.

LONDON, April 30 --The Bank of England issued its first annual report today, but this new departure for "The Old Lady of Threadneedle Street" showed clearly that she has lost none of her modest reticence since becoming public property.

ST. LOUIS, April 30 -- The Yankees' first invasion of the West was celebrated at Sportsman's Park today with a noisy clatter of base-hits, but most of the hitting and all of the celebrating was done by the Browns. The result of it all found the Yanks knocked off their perch atop the American League.

TRENTON, N.J., April 30 -- Despite the intervention of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, there were no signs of a return to work today of several thousand building trade workers made idle by jurisdictional disputes, principally in north Jersey.

The RCA International division of the Radio Corporation of America has nearly completed installations of radio broadcasting facilities in several Latin American countries representing expenditures of between $3,000,000 and $4,000,000, a spokesman for the division disclosed yesterday.

New York's second post-war May Day parade will take place today, under what appeared to be completely left-wing auspices. The paraders, estimated in advance to number more than 100,000, will leave Columbus Circle at 1:30 P.M., and march down Eighth Avenue, and thence to Union Square, where there will be a reviewing stand.
As the tenth annual campaign of the Greater New York Fund entered its second day, approval was received yesterday from Secretary of State George C. Marshall and other members of the Cabinet.

The RCA International division of the Radio Corporation of America has nearly completed installations of radio broadcasting facilities in several Latin American countries representing expenditures of between $3,000,000 and $4,000,000, a spokesman for the division disclosed yesterday.

New York's second post-war May Day parade will take place today, under what appeared to be completely left-wing auspices. The paraders, estimated in advance to number more than 100,000, will leave Columbus Circle at 1:30 P.M., and march down Eighth Avenue, and thence to Union Square, where there will be a reviewing stand.
As the tenth annual campaign of the Greater New York Fund entered its second day, approval was received yesterday from Secretary of State George C. Marshall and other members of the Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- George C. Blohm of Chicago, representing about 800 newspapers, asked Congress today to safeguard freedom of the press by "making it clear that news-gathering agencies may choose their own membership without violating the anti-trust laws."

Riding high on the crest of another explosive home run by Johnny Mize, the Giants yesterday completed their share of what currently has become a most extraordinary fashion in the National League -- the trampling underfoot of the world champion Cardinals.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States called today, by resolution, for labor legislation about parallel with the more conservative sentiment in the Congress.

JERUSALEM, May 1 -- A young man in a tweed jacket and sports trousers, looking no older than a college boy and handsome enough to be a bobby-soxer's hero, described today how it felt to receive an acclamation as an orchestral conductor in Palestine second only to that of the great and venerable Arturo Toscanini.

DETROIT, May 1 -- Nearly every building project, domestic and commercial, in Wayne and four surrounding countries stood idle today as a result of a wage strike of about 17,000 building trade workers headed by 9,000 carpenters.

ALBANY, May 1 -- Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., 69, resigned today as State Commissioner of Health, to which office he was appointed in 1936 by former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman. He had served nearly thirty years in the Health Department.

CHICAGO, May 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hags, 8,500 head, total 15,500: market very slow, end uneven: 75 cents to $1.25 lower with most decline on weights under 300 pounds: practical top. $23.75; around one

Fine English Prose Textbook writers in the field of English composition and their associated anthology editors will have to go very far indeed before they find anything written or spoken in our day to set by the side of John Foster Dulles' broadcast on the Moscow conference, as a model for their students.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: An editorial appearing in your April 3 issue was of great interest to me. In it you spoke for the inclusion of a woman in the membership of the State Parole Board, to fill one of the two newly established positions there.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 1 -- Opposition to any new Westchester taxes for school support and to the granting of county construction contracts requiring union labor was expressed today by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach in a special message to the Board of Supervisors' Committee on Budget and Appropriations.

Continuing the seasonal trend, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System have declined for the fourth consecutive week, falling $12,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday.

ALBANY, May 1 -- Of the 480 applicants for admission to the bar, only 189 passed the examinations conducted March 5 and 6. The names of 127 of the law students passing have been certified to the Appellate Divisions. The remaining sixty-two will be certified as soon as they have filed proof of full compliance with the rules of the Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The revitalized Army-Navy Munitions Board is putting the final touches to an industrial mobilization plan, which will propose far-reaching war powers for the President. It will outline specific actions for the Army, Navy and industry to take the moment a genuine "cloud" to world peace develops, it was learned today.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 1 (AP) -- Stating that there was a surplus of brass goods in Connecticut, the State Development Commission laid before Secretary of Commerce Harriman today a request that a survey be taken to determine if export restrictions on such products could be lifted.
The answer to the question of whether or not Miss Pauline Betz, women's national tennis champion, will join the professional ranks appears to be in the affirmative.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- On the last day of his state visit to Washington, President Aleman of Mexico, in addition to addressing a joint session of the United States Congress, sailed down to Mount Vernon on the Presidential yacht Williamsburg with Secretary of State Marshall as his host.
PITTSBURGH, May 1 (AP) -- A rash of strikes blemished production in steel today but with wage settlements reached for more than 375,000 workers the industry's general condition appeared good.

GENEVA, May 1 -- The lastminute arrival of a strong Russian delegation has given a big boost to the already considerable importance attached to the meeting of the Economic Commission for Europe, which opens here tomorrow.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 1 (U.P.) -- Dr. Leonardo Arguello, 75 years old, was inaugurated today as President of Nicaragua for a six-year term. He succeeded Gen. Anastasio Somoza, who had ruled the country for the past ten years.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- During the week ended April 30 member bank reserve balances increased $6,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Six representatives of the United States and one from the United Kingdom delivered reports yesterday at the fourth session of the International Meeting on Marine Radio Aids to Navigation at the Hotel Roosevelt.

LONDON, May 1 (AP) -- Half a dozen tennis teams will touch off the first fireworks tomorrow in the opening round of the European zone Davis Cup shuffle aimed at finding a challenger for the historic trophy now held by the United States. Two other teams are to begin hostilities on Saturday.

Random notes. Unless the weather makes a rapid change for the better, not even an otter will get much in the way of trout fishing over the coming week-end, at least so far as the Catskill streams are concerned.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 -- RKO today announced plans for 1948 production of a picture dealing with the trans-continental expedition of Meriwether Lewis and William Clark which opened the Oregon territory in 1805. The studio has engaged Ernest Pascal to write the scenario and has named Stephen Ames to produce the film in Technicolor under the title "Lewis and Clark."

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Senate, struggling through its sixth day of debate on the omnibus labor bill in a thinly attended session, agreed late today to vote tomorrow on the first of the stiffening amendments demanded by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

A complete list of commodities which are subject to Brazilian import licenses under a regulation dated March 27, 1947, was released yesterday by the Consulate General of Brazil in this city. Because of excessive importations of luxury and non-essential items, Brazilian consulates may no longer legalize documents on the list unless they are accompanied by the required licenses, effective immediately, the release stated.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The proposed peace treaty with Italy, accepted by former Secretary of State Byrnes as "not the best which human wit could devise," is before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

The Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday the zoning program recently adopted by the City Planning Commission to protect the permanent home of the United Nations on the East Side of midtown Manhattan. The general area, now more restrictively zoned for height, use and area, extends north from Thirtyfourth Street to Fifty-ninth Street between Second Avenue and the East River.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Thomas C. Boushall, speaking for the United States Chamber of Commerce, today opposed Federal aid to education on the grounds that the states have by no means exhausted their own resources.

Education of parents and proper marriage counseling for youth as early as high school are essential "if we are to break the vicious circle of unhappy parents producing unhappy children," Mrs. Rustin McIntosh, incoming dean of Barnard College, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- In two reorganization plans submitted to Congress today, President Truman sought to maintain the administrative grouping of a number of Government agencies along lines he thinks proved satisfactory during World War II.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The White House announced today that Rear Admiral Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter would become Director of Central Intelligence, succeeding Lieut. Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, who is returning to the Army Air Forces as the designated deputy commander.

WHEN Boone Caudill was 17 he had had about all he could take from his pap. Seems like the meanness in the old man just come on to boil good when he got enough drinkin' liquor in him to make another man happy. So that time when his pap really went for him was one too many. Boone grabbed a stick of firewood and fetched his pap a lick that mighty nigh killed him.

In a major shift in policy, the United States delegation to the United Nations is seeking legal means to have the Zionist viewpoint on the future government of Palestine presented to the General Assembly. This became known yesterday as a wave of protests against apparent American determination to bar presentation of the Jewish position in the Assembly reached the White House and the State Department.

Returning yesterday morning from a visit to her fiance, an ex-GI attending Lafayette College at Easton, Pa., an attractive 20-yearold bookkeeper plunged to her death from the eighty-sixth floor observation deck of the Empire State Building.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The State Department announced today the signing of an aviation agreement with Argentina.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, asserted today there would have been no agreement with Russia on an Italian treaty if its terms had not included Italian payment of reparations.

CULVER CITY, Calif., May 1 -- A small, simple radar warning device that will prevent airplanes from having collisions in the air or crashing into mountains or buildings in bad weather was demonstrated today by Howard Hughes, plane designer and pilot and majority stockholder of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc.

The 1947 May Day parade, completely under Communist or extreme left wing auspices, took place yesterday afternoon without untoward incidents of any kond. Capitalism and fascism were damned, the Truman Administration condemned and the virtues of peace and nonintervention were preached in songs, chants, placard and floats by 30,000 marchers, who made the trek from Columbus Circle to Union Square, along Eighth Avenue and then Seventeenth Street.

Settlement of the $6,450,000 suit brought by Konrad Bercovici, Hollywood writer, against Charles S. Chaplin, motion picture actor, was announced unexpectedly yesterday by Federal Judge Harold S. Burke, who aided the litigants in reaching an agreement. The cost of the settlement to Mr. Chaplin was $95,000.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A national program to protect civil rights was presented by Dr. John Slawson, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee, to the President's Committee on Civil Rights today. This program included plans to deal with violations of the basic privileges, and also to resist group dissension, race and religious discrimination, and bigotry of all kinds.

BABYLON, L.I., May 1 -- The Long Island State Park Commission is moving along with its 1947 parkways and parks construction program for which approximately $10,500,000 is available. The total on the commission's post-war program for parkways is $15,075,000, while for parks it is $2,749,800.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Attorney General Clark announced today the filing of new criminal informations against nine corporations and nine individuals charging conspiracy to restrain and monopolize the production and distribution of chlorinating equipment.
TOKYO, May 1 -- Independents and conservatives were far ahead tonight in the last of Japan's elections.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- President Truman and President Miguel Aleman of Mexico today announced jointly that they will stabilize the exchange ratio between the peso and the dollar, and that the Export -Import Bank will finance certain projects for which the Mexican Government has requested funds.

Broadening its charges to include practically all of the fair trade practice regulations of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimmings Manufacturers, rather than those confined to discounts and "memo" or consignment selling, the Federal Trade Commission yesterda opened its hearing on the complaint against the association at its offices here.

BUENOS AIRES, May 1 (AP) -- President Juan Peron told Congress today he intended to modernize the Argentine Army. "Our pacifist tradition of respect for all peoples is not sufficient, and a minimum of foresight is necessary in the midst of an armed world," he explained.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Trailerships, Inc., a newly-formed corporation of New York City, today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to transport truck trailers in two LST vessels between New York City and Albany, making one trip a day each way.

The month-long campaign of the World Youth Fund of the Y.M.C.A. was opened last night with a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, at which Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, permanent Representative of the Republic of the Philippines to the United Nations, cited the need for reconstruction of "Y" buildings devastated in the war.

Oriental cherry trees are in blossom around the small lake in Central Park at Seventy-ninth Street, making lovely vistas for a spring walk. Newark boys and girls may enjoy seeing the spring flowers and fruit trees blooming in the garden of the Newark (N.J.) Museum.

Hosiery Prices Reduced Julius Kayser Co. has reduced its prices on nylon hosiery from 8.5 to 22 per cent, according to an announecement yesterday. New wholesale prices on 42 gauge, 40 denier regulars and extra longs are $9.75 and $10.35, respectively; all 45 guage, 30 denier with regular tops, $10.75; 51 gauge, 30 denier, $12.50; 51 gauge, 15 denier, $14; 400 needle seamless, 30 denier, $9.75; 42 gauge, 6-thread silk, $10.75.

The quarterly statement of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and its wholly owned subsidiaries, issued for publication today, shows the net income for the first three months of this year amounted to $30,833,673 after providing $17,790,000 for taxes on income and $5,200,000 for excessive construction costs.

The only woman among the delegates at Blushing Meadow, Dr. Maria Z.N. Witteveen, Netherland alternate delegate to the special session of the United Nations General Assembly, does not feel that women are taking a back seat in directing the work of the United Nations.

The New York Chapter of Hadassah not only met its quota of $400,000 toward the nation-wide Hadassah goal of $4,000,000, but also fulfilled its pledge to raise $250,000 for the new Hadassah Hospital and Medical School, Mrs. Sol Boneparth, chapter president, reported at the annual donor Huncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Overnight rains and penetrating cold caused a postponement of the opening game of the series between the Yanks and White Sox at Comiskey Park today and, under advice from President Will Haridge of the American League, the contest has been scheduled as part of a doubleheader here Saturday.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- President Truman, jointly with President Aleman of Mexico, announced the granting of credits to Mexico along with a plan for stabilization of the peso. President Truman signed a $2,835,61,509 deficiency appropriation bill, appointed Rear Admiral Roscoe Hillenkoetter to be director of U.S. Central Intelligence and submitted a Government reorganization plan to Congress.

Absorptive The $200,000,000 aggregate of new securities placed on the market here this week in the wake of the $300,000,000 Illinois veterans' bonus bond issue seems to have been absorbed without straining the distribution machinery of securities underwriters and dealers.

Julius Lobel, alias Jimmy Collins, and Irving Cohen, defendants in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle case, were convicted early today by a jury in Kings County Court of grand larceny charges. Both were remanded to jail to await sentence, but no date was set for the sentencing.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 1 -- Dr. Hugo Eckener, German dirigible expert who arrived at the Naval Air Station here yesterday by air from Germany, announced today in an interview that his contract with the Goodyear Corporation in Aferon, Ohio, called for his helping the company improve their lighter-than-air craft.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- A House Expenditures subcommittee dug out information today that the Government hired a large construction company to sell surplus war supplies of every description.
George H. Wilkens has been appointed sales manager of Schick, Inc., maker of the Schick Electric Shaver.

HUNTINGDON, Pa., May 1 (AP) -- Two huge steel plates jutting from a freight train ripped like a giant can opener into a passing Pennsylvania Railroad flier early today, killing five passengers and injuring forty others.

MOSCOW, May 1 -- More than a million soldiers, sailors and workers tramped through Red Square and more than two hundred war planes swept over it today in a great May Day outpouring of homage to communism and its leader, Joseph Stalin.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- New observations on the behavior of mesons, the all-penetrating particles born through the collision of primary cosmic rays from interstellar space with atoms in the upper atmosphere, offer a serious challenge to the fundamental theory about the forces that hold the nuclei of atoms together, according to reports presented here today at the meeeting of the American Physical Society at George Washington University.

MONTREAL, May, 1 (AP) -- Four members of the National Hockey League champion Montreal Canadiens and one each from the Boston Bruins and the Chicago Black Hawks comprise the circuit's 19461947 all-star team announced tonight.
Despite renewed Arab appeals, the United Nations General Assembly refused yesterday to place on its agenda a proposal to discuss termination of the British mandate and the independence of Palestine.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores in April showed no change from those of the same month a year ago, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In March there was an increase of 12 per cent over the 1946 volume.

More than 1,200 persons attended a solemn high mass of requiem for the Very Rev. Dr. William J. Mahoney, president of St. John's University, Brooklyn, yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Baptist, Willoughby and Lewis Avenues, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The text of the address by President Miguel Aleman of Mexico before a joint session of Congress today was as follows: Mr. Speaker, Mr. President, Members of the Congress of the United States:

An increase of $176,140,720 in sales for the first quarter of 1947 over the corresponding three months of 1946 enabled the Chrysler Corporation to operate profitably this year, despite substantially larger taxes and expenses, the company's report disclosed yesterday.

The economic-political philosophies of former Vice President Henry Wallace were attacked by Clare Boothe Luce, author and former Republican Representative from Connecticut, in an address yesterday afternoon before the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street.

Down a path made smooth by the liberality of the opposing hurlers, the Dodgers sauntered to a 5-2 triumph over the Cubs at Ebbets Field yesterday in the rubber contest of their first series with a Western rival.
NANKING, May 1 -- Gen. Chang Chun, Premier of the reorganized Government, went before the Legislative Yuan this morning with the Ministers of his Cabinet and reported on his plans.

Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the American Jewish Committee, took issue yesterday with Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Palestine Foundation Fund, who had charged that the Palestine proceedings before the United Nations are a "farce."

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A Democratic National Committee statement that President Truman was directing a concentrated publicity campaign through Cabinet officers "to put the heat on basic manufacturers as the real culprits" behind prices boomeranged today in a flood of telephone calls to the White House and committee headquarters.
The Jackson Heights plan to lower prices in its stores for three days literally opened yesterday with flying colors, although consumer and merchant reaction to its success was mixed.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 1 -- Miss Betty Gallowhur, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Gibson Gallowhur of Braeloch, this place, was married to George Newell of London this afternoon in the home of her parents. The Rev. Arthur Ketchum of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Bedford, N.Y., performed the ceremony in the presence of immediate relatives.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Senate War Investigating Commitee, turned down by President Truman in a request to comb the files of Franklin D. Roosevelt for documents bearing on its Arabian oil inquiry, tonight invited the executors of the estate to appear before it.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Loading's of revenue freight for the week ended on April 26, 1947, totaled 893,776 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 27,930 cars, or 3.2 per cent more than for the preceding week; 233,512 cars, or 35.4 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year, and 6,174 cars, or 0.7 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
Cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were again extremely irregular yesterday. Final prices were 13 points lower to 18 points higher than the day before.
Eight hundred and eighty additional copies of Vincent McHugh's poems have been added to the stock seized by the Society for the Suppression of Vice, it became known yesterday.

WARSAW, May 1 -- Although a disastrous depression will engulf the world within a relatively short time, it will not destroy the Western capitalist system. Capitalism and communism can survive side by side, at peace in this ideologically turbulent era.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, said today America's policy of helping other nations halt Russian expansion will fail unless backed up by a boom in foreign trade.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The House tonight by a vote of 204 to 182 approved a bill extending rent controls to Dec. 31, 1947, or to March 31, 1948, if the necessity for further continuance is proclaimed by the President. Earlier, it defeated by 135 to 119 an amendment for a rent increase of 10 per cent.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I should like to try to correct the impression made by your report in THE TIMES of April 20 of my speech at Smith College.
GENEVA, May 1 -- Little progress on the negotiation of new trade agreements can be made at the Geneva Trade Conference until the United States position on its wool tariff becomes clarified.
Babe Ruth, who always "had a way with kids," gave some batting tips yesterday to 13-year-old Danny Williams, a Jackson, Miss., orphan and an admitted "weak hitter."

CINCINNATI, May 1 (AP) -- Leland Stanford (Larry) MacPhail, president of the New York Yankees, and Baseball Commissioner A.B. (Happy) Chandler set a longdistance conversation record today and then told sports writers they "had nothing to say."

LONDON, May 1 -- Attacking pessimistic views of Britain's future, Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council, said tonight that the nation must "discard its willingness to make the best of poverty."

JERUSALEM, May 1 -- Tens of thousands of members of Jewish, Socialist, Communist and labor organizations paraded in Palestine's principal cities today celebrating May Day. Slogans against Jewish terrorism were among those displayed and chanted by marchers.

The diversion of 5,000,000 pounds of sugar into the black market with the aid of employes of the Office of Price Administration, whose duties were to enforce the sugar rationing program in New York was disclosed yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

American Bakers Association, Chicago, has announced that the start of national advertisements in the baking industry's new $1,500,000 program would probably reach regular consumer channels in the fall. A planning committed representing all branches of the industry will meet in the near future.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 26 were 14 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

LONDON, May 1 -- This correspondent's report of the suppression of two Turkish Opposition newspapers noted in the opening paragraph that the Government had acted under martial law decrees in the Istanbul region.

The necessity of understanding "the other fellow, his language and his way of thinking and living," was stressed yesterday by Gen. Henry H. Arnold at a luncheon held in his honor by Columbia University in the Men's Faculty Club, 400 West 117th Street.

In show business anything is apt to happen. Two years ago H.J. Lengsfelder became smitten with an idea for letting the public in as partners of a theatrical production. With Ervin Drake, Mr. Lengsfelder had written a farcecomedy bearing the prophetic title of "Heads or Tails," a script in which they placed a great deal of faith.

The calm, serene atmosphere of the house of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, is today matched in spirit by its members' artistic work on exhibition for the second successive year.

BERLIN, May 1 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay has issued a directive outlining the basic principles and concepts of the United States Military Government and the manner in which its objectives are to be achieved.

Doubt over the advisability of grouping countries whose foreign trade remains in private hands and nations which conduct foreign trade by means of governmental agencies within the same international trade organization, was expressed in a study released yesterday by the International Chamber of Commerce.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 1 -- The Westchester division of the Professional Golfers Association opened the metropolitan area's competitive season with a one-day pro-amateur event at the Knollwood Country Club today. A pair of home clubbers, finishing near the end of the field of thirty-five teams, won best-ball honors by a stroke.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Professional traders took a stand on the bull side of the May grain deliveries on the Board of Trade today and found offerings light. In wheat the bulls had the assistance of mills, which are said to have been removing hedges against sales of old-crop flour for export.

Later reports from Batavia indicate that the "political sources" that last Monday spoke of large-scale civil war between rebellious Sundanese and Republican forces in Central Java were doing some wishful thinking.

We are accustomed to the legitimate labor union practice of trying to assure workers of a weekly pay envelope that will not fall below a certain dollar level of income. It may come as a surprise to some people, however, to learn that unions may also decide the maximum that their members shall earn.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- President Miguel Aleman of Mexico told a joint session of Congress today that "democracy, if not backed by force, whets the appetite of dictators."

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman called last night for the fulfillment of "sacred pledges" to Jews who wish to settle in Palestine. He declared it was the responsibility of Jews of America to help their European brethren.

Twenty-one reporters from all sections of the country will attend the sixth and final seminar for general reporters given by Columbia University's American Press Institute, starting Monday, Floyd Taylor, director of the Institute, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, Senate Minority whip, conceded today that the Senate would pass a tax reduction bill over Administration opposition.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 30 (Delayed) -- Vice Premier Mumtaz Okmen charged tonight that erroneous new on Turkey was spread "by certain foreign correspondents in our country who very often cannot grasp the thoroughly essential laws of Turkey's administration or whose views are unable to reach the depths of the political currents within the country."

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Committees of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations talked for five hours today about joining hands to face a future of uncertainties for labor leadership.

Copperweld Steel The wire and steel division of the Copperweld Steel Company are booked for capacity operation for the remainder of 1947, S.E. Bramer, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Pittsburgh yesterday.

Housewives shopping for the Sunday dinner will find a spotty price situation as a result of price cuts yesterday by some food merchants. Among butcher shops, particularly, the price spread was widened as some retailers reduced prices up to 15 per cent while others in the same neighborhoods held to last week's prices.

ALBANY, May 1 -- Mayor Erastus Corning 2d, stood pat today on his refusal to agree to the use of the Philip Livingston Junior High School auditorium, May 9, for a concert by Paul Robeson, Negro singer.

TUCSON, Ariz., May 1 -- Skeletons of a herd of mammoths, a prehistoric horse and an antelope have been discovered near Springerville, Ariz., by a group of scientists headed by Dr. Charles A. Reed of the University of Arizona, it was disclosed today.

PARIS, May 1 -- Premier Paul Ramadier will ask Parliament for a vote of confidence tomorrow as a result of the Communist Ministers' refusal in a Cabinet meeting tonight to stand by the Government's policy of freezing wages until July. Since a day of grace must intervene, the vote will probably be taken on Sunday.

New York's traditional welcome will be accorded to the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania when the newly reconditioned vessel arrives here at 3 P.M. today on her first commercial Atlantic crossing in more than seven years.

In a move designed to place responsibility for vice enforcement in the hands of local commanders, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced last night that the eight plainclothesmen of his confidential squad had been transferred to various divisions in the city.

Further substantial progress was made yesterday by prices on the Stock Exchange under the leadership of the oil issues, but profittaking in the final hour left the list only irregularly higher at the close. The steels and motors were hard pressed to retain early advantages, although some major aditions remained for many key stocks.

Things went completely askew in the feature race at the Jamaica track yesterday. First of all the field, originally comprising five starters, was reduced by one while the horses were still in the starting gate. Next a rearrangement of the pool bad to be made to reduce the wagering to only win and place.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 1 -- Short one member and 1 per cent of the required minimum budget to assume active status, the Preparatory Commission for the International Refugee Organization convened here today just two months before the date it must assume responsibility for the care of 834,950 refugees and displaced persons in eleven countries.

Having been certified by the music critics as first-quality opera last February, Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Telephone" and "The Medium" turned up at the Ethel Barrymore last evening. On the word of their public relations counselor, they are to be judged in the theatre district as music drama.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- To discover the probable reasons why the House of Representatives yesterday by an overwhelming majority cut the relief appropriations for war-devastated countries from $350 millions to $200 millions, and prescribed certain conditions of disbursal, does not require the services of Sherlock Holmes or a brace of bloodhounds.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 1 -- Wesley Engquist, the determined young infantile paralysis victim who arrived in this town by wheel chair from his home town of Fremont. Neb., last January, walked out of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation today on crutches.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 1 -- Wesley Engquist, the determined young infantile paralysis victim who arrived in this town by wheel chair from his home town of Fremont. Neb., last January, walked out of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation today on crutches.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 -- Following a thunderstorm in the morning that left the inner half of the Churchill Downs racing strip looking like a vast batch of caramel custard, the talk in Derbytown today was chiefly of the mud and how it would help or hinder the contenders in Saturday's seventythird Kentucky Derby.

President Aleman of Mexico comes to this city today after a welcome in Washington that must have warmed his heart. That the friendly relations between this country and Mexico are not limited to parades and kind words is shown by the joint statement of the two Presidents yesterday.

The United Telephone Organizations, representing 12,000 repair men employed by the New York Telephone Company, formally repudiated last night the $4-a-week strike "settlement" signed at dawn Wednesday by its president and the heads of three other New York phone unions.
The Mayor's Traffic Committed recommended yesterday the establishment of off-street parking facilities under municipal operation.

Miss Phoebe Meredith Frey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. W. Guernsey Frey Jr. of Forest Hills, Queens, and West Cornwall, Conn., has completed plans for her marriage on June 25 to William Bancroft Anderton Bentley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Bentley of Lawrence, L.I. The ceremony will be performed in St. James Episcopal Church here.
The Mayor's Traffic Committed recommended yesterday the establishment of off-street parking facilities under municipal operation.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Two Government witnesses gave support today to charges that munitionsmakers Henry and Murray Garsson tried to "cover up" alleged bribes to Andrew J. May, wartime chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee.

President Truman's personal automobile, formerly President Franklin D. Roosevelt's, rolled into New York from Washington yesterday under State Department guard, to be used by President Miguel Aleman of Mexico today, when he will be the city's honored guest.

NEW DELHI, India, May 1 (U.P.) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi came to New Delhi today in answer to an urgent summons from the Congress party's Working Committee and began deliberations that may be the most decisive in the party's sixty-one-year history.
LONDON, May 1 -- More good dividend announcements plus professional buying stimulated the industrial section of the stock markets today. Other sections, however, were quiet.

The "pop" concert is an amiable contrivance to lessen the strain of listening to music for those who find it a strain to listen to full symphonies, tone poems and operas. Boston has had its "pop" concerts for many years following the regular symphonic season and now New York is developing its own series.

LONDON, May 1 -- By an unusually small majority of 86 votes the House of Commons today approved the Labor Government's plans for building up Britain's coal stocks this summer. The plans include the ban on the use of gas and electricity for heating homes and on all non-residential heating from May 5 until the end of September.

Throngs rivaling those that crowd into St. Patrick's Cathedral on Easter Sunday and for the Christmas Eve midnight mass were there at 5:30 P.M. yesterday for a special May Day service to pray for the Russian people, their leaders and "millions living in Communist -dominated lands."

Banking institutions under New York State supervision were released yesterday from any further obligation to observe recommendations made a year ago by the State Superintendent of Banks to curb payments of inducements intended to attract mortgage business.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Declines in eight of ten major commodity groups lowered average primary market prices 0.3 per cent during the week ended April 26, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

Describing the present generation as a "battlefield of contending faiths" -- that of communism on one hand and liberty, democracy and the Christian way of life on the other -- Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor emeritus of the Riverside Church, yesterday declared it would be "the greatest tragedy in the world" to defeat communism through physical warfare.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Congress approved finally today its legislation to outlaw nearly all of the pending portal-to-portal backpay lawsuits demanding an estimated $5,000,000,000, and to block similar actions in the future.

Through the use of a placard constructed in relief, the importance of the symbol of the Greater New York Fund's Tenth Annual Campaign poster was described yesterday to the blind at a meeting held at the Lighthouse, New York Association for the Blind, at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

The United States is facing a painful dilemma in regard to atomic energy, David E. Lilienthal said last night to his first public appearance here since his confirmation as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.
CHICAGO, May 1 -- The United States is in a period of high incidence of infantile paralysis, which apparently strikes in cyclical waves, it was said here today.

Ballet Theatre last night revived Antony Tudor's "Dim Lustre" at the City Center after a lapse of some three years. It is an engaging little piece which should not be allowed to languish so long again.

A collection of modern abstract wallpapers designed by William Justema to serve as continuous and unified backgrounds have inspired room settings in a new exhibit to be opened today by Katzenbach Warren, 49 East Fiftythird Street.

Mr. and Mrs. George M. Adrian of 441 West End Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Therese Maria, to John A. Albert, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Albert, formerly of this city and Liberty, N.Y.

Richard T. Frankensteen, a founder of the United Auto Workers, CIO, who was battered by company police when, with Walter Reuther, he organized Ford workers, and who directed organization of the aircraft industry, is now on the other side of the fence, it became known yesterday.

Barnard College's faculty and 1,286 undergraduate students paid their respects to retiring Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve yesterday afternoon, with a pageant in Barnard Hall and a tea on the north lawn of the campus. Miss Gildersleeve, who will retire on June 1 after fifty-two years spent at Barnard as student, instructor and dean received a tribute from the student body, delivered by Gertrude Rosenstein, undergraduate chairman of the tea.

PRAGUE, May 1 -- The Communist party of Czechoslovakia -- the only European country except France where communism was returned with the largest vote in a free election -- selected May Day to claim a large increase in membership, particularly among women and youth.
LONDON, May 1 -- Cut Britain loose from the United States' apron strings -- this is the gist of advice offered by fifteen of the Labor party's Parliamentary rebels to a pamphlet issued today.

Richard T. Frankensteen, a founder of the United Auto Workers, CIO, who was battered by company police when, with Walter Reuther, he organized Ford workers, and who directed organization of the aircraft industry, is now on the other side of the fence, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Friday, May 2 (U.P.) -- Negotiations on which hopes for an early peace in the telephone strike had been pinned broke up early today in a complete deadlock after more than three hours of futile bargaining.
NEWARK, N.J., May 1 -- A capacity crowd greeted the return of the twenty-first renewal of the Essex Troop horse show, which opened a four-night stand at the Essex Troop Armory tonight.

ST. LOUIS, May 1 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns cut loose with their heavy artillery for the second straight day, piling up twenty hits -- three of them home runs -- in a 14-to-5 victory over the Washington Senators today.
NEW ORLEANS, May 1 -- The foreign trade zone of the Port of New Orleans was officially opened today.

There is need for overall planning by public and private agencies to alleviate many of the problems faced by the youth of this city, Dr. Arthur Swift, member of the staff of the Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday at a forum under the auspices of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Barnard College's faculty and 1,286 undergraduate students paid their respects to retiring Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve yesterday afternoon, with a pageant in Barnard Hall and a tea on the north lawn of the campus. Miss Gildersleeve, who will retire on June 1 after fifty-two years spent at Barnard as student, instructor and dean received a tribute from the student body, delivered by Gertrude Rosenstein, undergraduate chairman of the tea.

Tardy evidences of spring are to be seen in the vegetable stalls today, where receipts from gardens close at hand, or relatively so, are 50 per cent greater than a few weeks ago. This season's cool, wet weather has discouraged shipments from near-by areas to such an extent that this is really the first week the local office of the United States Department of Agriculture has been able to report any arrivals of note.

PRAGUE, May 1 -- The Communist party of Czechoslovakia -- the only European country except France where communism was returned with the largest vote in a free election -- selected May Day to claim a large increase in membership, particularly among women and youth.
LONDON, May 1 -- Cut Britain loose from the United States' apron strings -- this is the gist of advice offered by fifteen of the Labor party's Parliamentary rebels to a pamphlet issued today.

BALTIMORE, May 1 (AP) -- Saggy, Mrs. Stanley Sagner's 2-yearold Flash who established a world record for four and a half furlongs at Havre de Grace last week, made it four in a row at Pimlico today by winning the Ral Parr Stakes at the same distance.

In the Displaced Persons Camps of Germany and Austria, in the deceptively serene hillside villages of the American zone and the shelled barracks that once housed the SS, and in the Allied Commission Camps of Italy, live the new race of DP's, as the euphemism goes, people who once had a country.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, May 3 -- A conference seeking to lay a possible basis for general settlement of the national telephone workers' strike was under way early today at the Department of Labor.

James Lewis Kraft, founder of the Kraft Foods Company, has written an account of his experiences in following his hobby, entitled "Adventure in Jade," which will be published by Holt this month. Mr. Kraft has included the story of the discovery of jade on this continent and the symbolism jade has had for the Chinese since ancient days.

LONDON, May 2 -- It will be many months before the British position in consumer goods recovers from the effects of the recent fuel crisis, Sir Stafford Cripps said at his weekly press conference today. In his review of economic affairs, the president of the Board of Trade stressed the coal situation.

New systems of navigation developed during World War II will not eliminate the continued need for the present radio beacon system. These new aids will supplement rather than replace the older systems of navigational aids, Rear Admiral Earl G. Rose, USCG, Chief Operations Officer, Coast Guard, declared yesterday.

While all civilizations now know that they can perish, all peoples are beginning to understand that what cannot die is the universal striving after freedom. President Miguel Aleman of Mexico said when Columbia University conferred upon him an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws yesterday afternoon.
The college rowing season reaches flood tide today with the sweepswingers of Cornell, Syracuse, Manhattan and Boston University entering into the action for the first time.

A drive to enlist the cooperation of forty leading producers of foundry coke for improvement of the quality of the product for gray-iron foundries has been started to reduce costs and rejects. R.L. Collier, executive vice president, Gray Iron Founders' Society, Inc., disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., May 2 -- Sale of The Evening Courier and The Morning Post in Camden, N.J., was announced tonight by Richard W. Slocum, general manager of The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, which acquired the properties along with The Philadelphia Record after they suspended publication last Jan. 31.
Delayed by bad weather and half hidden by mist over the harbor, the 35,677-ton Cunard White Star liner Mauretania arrived New York late yesterday with 1,128 passengers.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Army, which is striving to work harmoniously with the Navy in the interests of unification, is currently embarrassed by a "leak" of a report from its supply chief, Lieut. Gen. Le Roy Lutes, telling how hundreds of millions of dollars could have been saved by joint Army-Navy wartime procurement.

New Capital Market The market for new capital, following its half - a - billion - dollar workout this week, now faces in contrast an uneventful interval. Next week the only corporate bond issue slated for marketing is the issue of $15,000,000 of Cudahy Packing Company first mortgage twenty-year bonds, up for competitive bidding on Monday.

A traffic patrolman was killed and four other persons were injured yesterday morning as the result of an accident involving four vehicles -- a fire engine, a poultry truck, a bus and a taxicab. The collision occurred at Seventh Avenue and Thirty-first Street, about a half hour before President Miguel Aleman of Mexico was scheduled to emerge from Pennsylvania Station.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced yesterday that under an agreement signed on April 11 with the United Steel Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, its employes will receive $17,000,000 in back pay.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, today told the Senate Education Subcommittee that children "by the millions are sitting in school by the hours, learning nothing, progressing not one bit in their understanding of the world."

One of the major criticisms of documents such as the widely publicized Nathan Report (which based its conclusion on how large a wage increase "industry" could grant on estimates of how much "industry" would show in the way of profits) has to do with their emphasis on global figures.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 2 -- Better programs of education for young children will come only "when the man in the street knows they are worth the money," Frederick H. Bair, executive assistant to the New York State Commissioner of Education, declared today.

Two years of increasingly cordial relations among the young people in the lower East Side area of the Metropolitan Vocational High School were celebrated yesterday with the presentation of a tree to the Jacob Riis Settlement House.

Narrowing of profit margins to absorb increased costs was urged upon fabric mills and other suppliers of materials for men's and boys' clothing to enable lower prices in a statement issued yesterday. The statement was issued following a joint meeting of the retail relations committee of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A. and the manufacturers' relations committee of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers at the Hotel New Yorker.
CHICAGO, May 2 -- The Yankees marked their first appearance of the season here today with a 5-2 victory over the White Sox. The triumph sent Bucky Harris' troupeack to the American League lead.

DETROIT, May 2 (AP) -- Pat Mullin's two homers and timely single brought the Detroit Tigers from behind today to stop the Philadelphia Athletics, 3 to 2, breaking the Mackmen's three-game winning streak.
PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- Registration statements covering bonds and shares were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

SEATTLE, May 2 (AP) -- Miss Ann Curtis of San Francisco's Crystal Plunge tied the accepted world record and bettered the American record for the 100-yard free-style today in winning the second preliminary heat at the start of the women's national senior indoor Amateur Athletic Union swimming and diving championships.

The Maytag Company, Maytag Atlantic Company, its metropolitan district distributor, and 1,146 dealers in New York City and out-oftown communities, Northern New Jersey and one county in Connecticut, will break a cooperative advertising campaign in 109 daily and weekly newspapers within the area at the end of this month.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 2 -- Four American warships arrived off Istanbul this morning in the third visit of United States naval forces to these waters in a year. The vessels were the aircraft carrier Leyte, the cruiser Dayton and the destroyers Purdy and Bristol.

Eight departmental and municipal subdivisions of the Republic of Colombia are considering resumption of debt service on about $40,000,000 of unrepatriated dollar bonds in default for fifteen years. Terms under study would reduce interest to 3 per cent from rates ranging from 6 1/2 to 7 1/2 per cent and would settle interest arrears by the issuance of a new 3 per cent bond for $200 to cover all accumulated arrears on every $1,000 bond.

Lester B. Pearson of Canada, who heads the United Nations General Assembly's important Political and Security Committee, said bluntly yesterday that he would try to prevent any debate on the heart of the Palestine case and avoid any necessity of hearing from Palestine's Jews or Arabs.

Not to be outdone by New York and other states which are going ahead with ambitious post-war road programs, New Jersey has embarked on a long-range fifty-year construction plan which, when completed, will gird, the state with a modern system of freeways and parkways.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- The telephone strike in Illinois was settled at 10 o'clock tonight subject to ratification by the three striking unions. If approved by union members, as expected, the workers will return to their jobs at 6 A.M. Monday with a $4-a-week wage increase.

Retail lumber yards in the metropolitan area have been forced to reduce gross mark-ups from 20 to 30 per cent because of failure of the expected large-scale housing program to materialize and stiff price resistance, a spokesman for the New York Lumber Trades Association disclosed yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 2 -- An impressive array of ministerial talent from the Netherlands and Luxembourg gathered here today for a two-day conference with the Belgian Cabinet on the subject of Benelux, or a customs agreement among the three countries.

KANSAS CITY, May 2 (AP) -- Democrats in President Truman's home county joined a politically inexperienced war hero's lead today to purge themselves of factionalism, particularly the Pendergast label, as they eyed the 1948 national election.
ROME, May 2 -- Nearly 200 Deputies battled on the floor of the Constituent Assembly today. It was said to have been the worst incident of the sort in Italy's parliamentary history.

Business office employes of the New York Telephone Company voted yesterday to accept a $4 wage rise and return to work on Monday. Substantial groups of operators and maintenance workers, however, turned down the same settlement, making impossible any restoration of normal phone service in this area.

After a brief interlude during the Moscow Conference, the Soviet Government has again rung down the Iron Curtain, and the vast expanse of the Russias, comprising one-sixth of the earth's land surface and containing some 200,000,000 people, has again become a dark continent -- a mystery to the outside world as the outside world is a mystery to it.
Benefits of memorandum or consignment sales of fur garments were termed "problematical" yesterday by John Hahn, secretary and general manager of the Retail Fur Council.

Official papers of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt relating to the Navy's purchases of oil products in Saudi Arabia will be extracted from the Roosevelt collection at Hyde Park and sent directly to President Truman, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Three businessmen of Dallas, Tex., were elected today to the board of directors of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad in a proxy contest which caused a recess of the road's annual stockholders' meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Peace committees of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations agreed today that unity in the American labor movement was desirable, but failed to agree on the means of achieving it Each found the other's blueprint unacceptable.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 3 -- With the dawn of Constitution Day today, Japan received the right to fly her Rising Sun flag without restrictions over the nation's Government and Palace buildings.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Grain markets were strong in the early trading on the Board of Trade today but turned weak and more than lost the advance. They closed around the low marks of the day, with wheat futures off 1/2 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel.

Peace reigned once more in the ranks of artists who make up the National Association of Women Artists, as "The Lovers," spurned sculpture group by Mitzi Solomon, was returned yesterday for exhibition in the galleries of the National Academy O. Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue.

CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP) -- Henry A. Wallace said tonight that the recent conference of foreign ministers at Moscow "ended in deadlock and failure," and that any hopes for its success "were shattered when President Truman announced his $400,000,000 antiSoviet crusade."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 2 -- A former marine, angered at being ejected from a tavern at 368 Summit Avenue, went across to a vacant lot tonight, turned and opened up on the place with a 30-calibre Springfield rifle. A dozen or more bullets were fired into the building and three persons were wounded, one fatally.

With the handing up yesterday of a fifteen-count mail fraud indictment, postoffice inspectors revealed that a country-wide search was underway for George McBride, 47 years old, said to be the operator of a fake export business, who is charged with having defrauded the public of $22,000 in funds sent to him for overseas food packages.
With a moderate volume of business, prices for cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 19 to 30 points net higher.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- An improved educational program, designed to provide better health services, eradicate illiteracy and raise school standards would help build national defense far more than compulsory miltary training, Dr. George F. Zook, president of the American Council on Education, declared today.

HEMPSTEAD. L.I., May 2 -- An Army A-26 twin-engined bomber attempting to land on the rain and fog obscured runways at Mitchel Field crashed into a vacant lot about a mile from the field this afternoon killing the pilot and flight engineer.
MOSCOW, May 2 -- During the last six weeks, the Soviet Union has been the scene of a nation-wide campaign to increase farm production, insure the food supply and eventually end rationing.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The goal of self-support for the United States and British zones in Germany by the end of 1949 was outlined here today by M.S. Scymczak, Director of the Economic Division of the United Office of Military Government.

No less than sixteen highly responsible organizations were represented at a recent meeting here of the National Committee for Traffic Safety. Their spokesmen agree that unless there was an intensified safety drive by national, state and community organizations, this summer would see a new high record of death and injury on the roads and streets.

American Airlines, Inc., in its statement of operations covering the first three months of this year, reported yesterday a net loss of $3,073,636 after expenses incurred in transition to peacetime commercial operations, but including $2,220,000 Federal income tax credit.

The week beginning tomorrow will be observed as Family Week in churches of the city. The general theme will be "Christian Living Begins at Home." The observance will be held under the sponsorship of the International Council of Religious Education, the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America and the United Council of Church Women.

A group of holders of stock of the Cliffs Corporation, headed by Stephen Carlton Clark, president of the Clark Foundation of this city, began yesterday solicitation of proxies from shareholders of the Cliffs Corporation to prevent its proposed consolidation with the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Navy asked Congress today to authorize the use of $55,580,000 to convert fifteen ships for a new type of warfare with emphasis on submarine and Arctic operations.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Secretary of State Marshall accepted conditionally today the proposal of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Molotov, for a resumption of joint negotiations in Seoul May 20 on the establishment of a provisional Korean Government.

Three Maritime Commission transports departed from New York within four hours yesterday carrying 2,000 passengers for European ports. The ships, which sailed from North River piers, were the Marine Falcon and the Marine Flasher, both bound for Cobh, Havre and Southampton, arid the Marine Shark, headed for Naples and Palermo.

TOKYO, May 2 -- Buddhist, Christian and Shinto leaders will join in the all-Japan religious peace conference to be held for three days starting. Sunday in Hongan Temple here. The meeting will end with a parade to the Imperial Palace and the simultaneous ringing of every temple, church and shrine bell in Japan.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- The second world's invention exposition opened a ten-day session here today with a display of about 600 inventions, ranging from the eccentric to the practical, and showing drawings of others too bulky or too nebulous for the inventors to send on the finished product.

Political affiliation is not a matter to be considered in fixing bail, Federal Judge William Bondy ruled yesterday in denying the request of United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey for the relatively high bail of $10,000 each, in the cases of two Communists under indictment for contempt of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

VIENNA, May 2 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark's departure, set for Sunday, is taking place amid misunderstandings that are undermining United States prestige and Austria's capacity to resist foreign pressure, sources within both the People's party and the Socialist party said today.

AUGUSTA, Ga., May 2 (AP) -- Senator Maybank, Democrat, of South Carolina, said today that the supplying by the Government of funds to develop foreign industry and agriculture to compete with "our own" is a "highly questionable venture."

President Miguel Aleman of Mexico was made an honorary citizen of New York City at an official welcome ceremony in City Hall yesterday afternoon. In a brief reply to Mayor O'Dwyer's welcoming address, the Mexican. President described New York as a "stimulating example of tireless, dynamic activity."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In connection with the abolishment of untouchability in India you mention in your editorial that "within the Hindu community the only way these unfortunates could free themselves from the religious taint that clouded their lives was by conversion to Islam, Christianity, Buddhism or Parseeism."

PIMLICO, Md., May 2 (AP) -- Warren Wright's Pep Well and Jockey Al Snider were the winning combination in the nineteenth running of the Jennings Handicap today. The Boswell colt saved ground along the rail to catch the pacesetting Rippey, from the W.G. Helis' stable, and go on to win by a length.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Senate Republican policy committee is expected to decide at a meeting tomorrow when to take up for floor action the bill to continue rent controls, which was reported out of the banking committee about five weeks ago.

Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Rothschild of 21 West Eighty-sixth Street have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Barnett, to Joseph Sanford Coons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Coons of Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that the question of attempting to apply the 15-cent hourly wage rise pattern to the steel fabricating industry was being left to union negotiators.

A total of five Supreme Court Justices will be elected in this city this fall, two of them in the First Judicial District, which includes Manhattan and the Bronx, and three others in the Second Judicial District, which includes Kings, Queens, Richmond, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
PARIS, May 2 -- The French National Assembly decided today that it would vote Sunday on the question of a vote of confidence in the Government, demanded by Premier Paul Ramadier.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- A largely hostile House Rules Committee, by the close vote of 6 to 5, released the $400,000,000 Greek-Turkish aid bill today for floor consideration to start Monday.

United Nations officials completed preparations last night to receive President Miguel Aleman of Mexico today at the special session of the General Assembly being held at Flushing Meadow. The occasion marks the first time for a visiting Chief of State to make a formal appearance during a United Nations meeting.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The roll call vote by which the Senate added today to the general labor bill an amendment prohibiting union coercion of labor follows:
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Senate accepted today by sixty to twenty-eight the first of the stiffening amendments to the Omnibus Labor Bill for which Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio is campaigning.

The city had President Miguel Aleman as its luncheon guest yesterday. With Mayor O'Dwyer as host and Grover Whalen as toastmaster, more than 1,500 guests at the Commodore Hotel heard Nelson A. Rockefeller say that the visit here by Mexico's Chief Executive marks "a turning point in the history of Mexican-American relations."

ROME, May 2 (AP) -- A United States Army court-martial today absolved Pvt. Walter Florek of publicly insulting the Soviet flag in a Belgrade bar last August, but fined him $25 for disorderly conduct. The verdict made no mention of a charge that he also insulted the Yugoslav flag.

MANILA, May 2 -- President Manuel Roxas announced today that the Philippine Government would open to foreign purchase hundreds of thousands of tons of scrap iron. The iron is scattered over the Philippines in residue from the war.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 2 -- "The Homecoming of Ulysses," Clark Gable's next picture, will be Mervyn LeRoy's first directorial assignment under his new contract at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the studio announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- President Truman listed navigation and flood control today among "important activities" on which prosperity depended.

Newburyport, the Massachusetts city that started the nation-wide wave of 10 per cent retail price reductions, has decided to continue the experiment indefinitely. Meanwhile the plan continued yesterday to spread to other communities. But in many places consumers were skeptical and the response was not as satisfactory to the merchants as it had been in the place of origin.

For five hours yesterday one million New Yorkers, more or less, cheered, applauded and showered ticker tape on Mexico's President Miguel Aleman. Spider-web mist hid skyscraper towers and fine drizzle swept against Senor Aleman's face as he stood in an open car to receive the accolade, yet he never lost his smile.
PARIS, May 2 -- There is originality in Marcel Rochas' cotton beach ensembles in that they are draped as one would expect only afternoon and evening gowns to be.

NEWARK, N.J., May 2 -- Peter Packard of Hackensack, N.J., showed deft, smooth handling as he won the featured A.S.P.C.A. horsemanship event in the second night's performance of the fourday Newark horse show at the Essex Troop Armory tonight.
SINGAPORE, May 2 -- Within the past week French troop ships carrying more than 5,000 soldiers have paused at Singapore en route to Indo-China.

Enforcement of safety regulations and maintenance of safety in New York State factories, mercantile establishments, places of public assembly and construction projects reached a new high for excellence during 1946, Charles E. Durr, director of the State Labor Department's Division of Industrial Safety Service, reported yesterday.

The history of Christianity as well as the history of Armenia demonstrates beyond any doubt that ideas and ideals, truth, liberty and justice are irresistible forces, the Rev. Dr. M. T. Kalaidjian, vice president of the Armenian Missionary Association of America, declared here yesterday.

The five-story building altered for ten families at 128 West Seventy-seventh Street has been sold by Katerine Marmor of Los Angeles, Calif., to Max Rosenblum through Slawson Hobbs, brokers, who arranged a new first mortgage of $30,000 with the Broadway Savings Bank.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial, "An Alternative Policy," which appeared in your issue of April 17 is interesting, but a careful reading of it would lead one to the conclusion that we are heading toward another war.

Hank Greenberg's debut in a local National League park, delayed a day by the weather yesterday, will be made this afternoon at the Polo Grounds when the Pittsburgh Pirates will tackle the revivified Giants under Coogan's Bluff.
MOSCOW, May 2 -- There is still an edge to the wind, but the Russians are enjoying this two-day holiday in the springtime.

In the current hearings on the Italian treaty before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Vandenberg told opponents of ratification, headed by Adolf Berle and former Governor Poletti and including his Republican colleague from Michigan, Senator Homer Ferguson, that he expected the treaty to be pushed through the Senate as rapidly as possible.

Through the appeal for funds of Goodwill Industries of New York, Inc., contributors are offered the opportunity to assist an organization that helps the handicapped, not by charity, but by giving people jobs and job training. At the Industries' plant at 123 East 124th Street about 125 men and women may be found at work at any time reconditioning clothes and upholstery, repairing appliances, operating switchboards, selling merchandise and doing many other jobs.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Chinese Government has agreed to begin negotiations soon looking toward settlement of its outstanding war accounts with the United States, the Secretary of State, George C. Marshall, announced today. The aggregate is more than $2,000,000,000.

LOS ANGELES, May 2 -- The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced today plans for a $15,000,000 "medium price" rental housing project accommodating 1,300 to 1,400 families in the southwestern section of this city.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The text of a letter from Secretary of State Marshall to Soviet foreign Minister Molotov regarding Korea follows: Dear Mr. Molotov: I have considered your letter of April 19, 1947, in which you accept our proposal to reconvene the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Joint Commission and suggest that the commission resume its work on May 20, of this year.

CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 5,000 head: total, 8,500 head. Market opened slow but later trade active on most sales, steady to 25 cents lower: full decline on hots under 250 pounds: top, $23.50

Much of modern girl's beauty and charm is fabricated in test tubes. From shoes to rouge these beauty bids depend largely upon "organic syntheses, reaction kinetics, and energy levels," according to a speaker at the twenty-fourth annual meeting of the American Institute of Chemists last night at the Hotel Commodore.

A sum of $101,000 has been provided to present a large-scale program of free concerts, which will be initiated tomorrow at 2:30 P.M., at the Bronx Veterans Hospital, Kingsbridge Road, by Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, it was announced yesterday by Richard McCann, president of the local.
Gregory McKee has been promoted from assistant to associate manager of radios and phonographs and manager of records and accessories at L. Bamberger Co.

A drive to revise 32-year-old legal restrictions preventing the use of time-study methods in plants of war material contractors has been opened in Congress, industrial sources disclosed here yesterday.

Through a recent report on social conditions in the city -- this one covers the East Bronx -- runs a note of caution and warning that no one can read without misgivings. The warning is that juvenile delinquency, on the increase since 1940, lies at the root of many other evils in congested urban districts.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The United States has proposed a farreaching amendment to the constitution of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, the State Department announced today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 -- With every sign pointing to fulfillment of Col. Matt Winn's prediction that upward of 125,000 will jam their way into Churchill Downs tomorrow, all is in readiness for the seventythird Kentucky Derby.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP) -- An injunction and damage suit against the National Maritime Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations, its president, Joseph Curran and five other union officers, was filed today in United States District Court by owners of the cargo ship Robert.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- There is "grave danger" that we may commit the same fatal errors which caused Germany to lose her lead in the development of an atomic bomb, also costing her the chance to win the war, Professor S.A. Goudsmit, Northwestern University physicist, told the meeting of the American Physical Society here today.

DAVID DODGE decided to get out of the Navy and see the world. He is a writer and reformed tax expert who spent the war years, he says, polishing his dress blues in a swivel chair anchored at San Francisco. That was all very well as a line of simple duty. But when peace broke out he was ripe for far-wandering and peril and adventure.

PORT MOUTON, N.S., May 2 (Canadian Press) -- All members of the British freighter Wicklow Head's thirty-three-man crew were accounted for today after a daring rescue operation. The 2,888ton freighter ran aground at nearby Port Joli Head in a thick fog last night.

The commander of Irgun Zvai Leumi, Palestine underground force, should be called to testify before the special session of the United Nations General Assembly, Joseph Clark Baldwin, administrative chairman of the Political Action Committee for Palestine, said yesterday.

The marriage of Mrs. Catherine Bruce Kitchel, daughter of Mrs. Paul Abbott of 123 East Fiftythird Street, to John Revere Chapin Jr., also of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chapin of Brookline, Mass., took place yesterday in the Unitarian Church of All Souls here.

Sidney Levine and Sol Bergstein sold the six-story apartment house at 800 Greenwood Avenue, Brooklyn, accommodating sixty-five families, to the 800 Realty Corporation, represented by Joseph A. Michel, attorney.
HANOVER, N.H., May 2 -- The potent bat of Ben Gulla spoiled Dartmouth's inaugural home game today and gave Pennsylvania a 7-5 Ivy League triumph over the Indians.
LONDON, May 2 -- The long arm of United States economic penetration has stretched to Burma and it aroused criticism during a debate in the House of Commons today.

Negotiations are under way with Ben Hecht for a dramatization for fall production of "Aurora Dawn," the new best-selling novel spoofing the radio advertising business, it was disclosed yesterday by the author, Herman Wouk. If the theatrical version jells, it will be put on by Carly Wharton, who produced Irwin Shaw's "The Assassin" last season.

For two years H.J. Lengsfelder, co-author of "Heads or Tails," has been developing a plan by which the ticket-buyer can share in the profits of Broadway productions. According to the program at the Cort, where the first production opened last evening, 142 church and civic organizations have invested in this easy plan, and more than 3,000 individuals.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 (AP) -- Here is the field for tomorrow's Kentucky Derby, showing post positions, horses, owners, jockeys and probable odds:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One can only view with alarm the wild claims for additional pay now being made. With prices and taxes as high as they are, almost any person can show that he has great difficulty in meeting the expenses of living in the way he desires or in the way to which he is accustomed.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 2 (AP) -- Decision was reserved today in a Supreme Court action brought to prevent the Albany Board of Education from interfering with a recital by Paul Robeson, Negro baritone, in an Albany high school next Friday.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Dean Acheson told Congress today that a proposed merger of the United States' international airtransport operations might be interpreted by other countries as evidence of " 'imperialistic' activity."
NANKING, May 2 -- Military headquarters announced tonight the capture of Suiteh in northern Shensi. This city became an important Communist base after the fall of Yenan and Wayaopao.

Faced with a $100,000 deficit in contributions, the Federation of the Handicapped, Inc., announced yesterday that twenty-one of its 125 orthopedically handicapped employes had been laid off while the others had agreed to a 10 per cent reduction in pay.

Trade Here Gains in Week Despite adverse weather conditions, retail trade here made a good comparative showing this week as customers responded to special prices on a wide variety of goods. Some department stores here had gains ranging from 20 to 25 per cent over last year.

Welcomed to New York yesterday as the symbol of a new era in relations between the United States and its good neighbor to the south, President Miguel Aleman promised last night that American investors would have ample room for initiative and opportunity for a fair profit in the economic development of Mexico.

The angler who quits fishing and races for the nearest taxidermist with a four-pound rainbow will have some idea of the fever that mounted in C.L. Shepherd of Opportunity, Wash., who celebrated May Day by taking a 36-pound Kamloops rainbow at Pend Oreille Lake, Idaho.

The United States joined Britain yesterday in defeating a proposal that the United Nations General Assembly let the Jewish Agency for Palestine state its views at a plenary session. The vote in the General Committee, which met in Flushing Meadow, Queens, was 8 to 3.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Senate Finance Committee completed tax-reduction hearings today and a majority apparently was prepared to report out the Houseapproved bill next week with only one major change.
With the relay phase of the campaign out of the way, college track and field athletes will swing into significant pre-championship individual competition in a widespread program of major meets today.

Favorable corporate developments spurred individual issues yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, and a further technical recovery in other sections enabled the stock market to reach more favorable ground. Prices generally closed only about a point higher on the day, due to profit-taking in the late afternoon, although several individual stocks managed to make greater increases.

LONDON, May 2 -- The feature of generally dull stock markets a here today was the weakness of gold-mining shares. Their persistent decline of the last few days was increased by selling from the Cape, while another factor in the fall has been the employment of floating speculative money in the London market in the industrial section.

Miss Ann Hochschild, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hochschild of 1200 Fifth Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon in the home of her parents to Richard Gerrit Poole, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Poole of Lake Forest, Ill.
