The Rev. Dr. Emmet Fox performed the ceremony in the presence of immediate relatives.

Bernard M. Baruch, who was chairman of the Rubber Survey Committee appointed by former President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1942 to meet the crisis in rubber at that time, accepted yesterday a souvenir sample from the tenmillionth bale of synthetic rubber made at the government - owned plant at Institute, W. Va.

The text of Mayor O'Dwyer's address at New York City's official reception yesterday to President Aleman of Mexico in the Council Chamber at City Hall and the latter's reply follow: Today the great City of New York is extremely proud and happy to pay tribute to a most distinguished visitor, President Miguel Aleman of the Republic of Mexico.

Mrs. Leroy S. Edwards of the Urban Club of Brooklyn was elected president of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs by delegates representing 250,000 clubwomen at the 133d convention of the organization yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

GENEVA, May 2 -- The Economic Commission for Europe held its first meeting today amid warnings that the victorious allies must not delay too long Germany's economic rehabilitation, or else all European countries would suffer.

The United Nations -- at least its subdivision that worries about the site and associated ceremonies -- learned yesterday that it is difficult to get out from under a fiftyton boulder. The saga of the boulder is something the United Nations would like to forget.

HIAWATHA, Kan., May 2 (NANA) -- John Milburn Davis, the enigma of Hiawatha, has been buried in the $750,000 memorial he constructed to the memory of his wife and which aroused the ire of nearly everyone in this town.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP) -- A $100,000,000 backlog of orders, representing about one year's business, was reported today by the Baldwin Locomotive Works. The orders, the company said, are well distributed among its various departments, except for steam locomotive shops.

Supply and Demand From an address delivered at Hartford the other day by a leading psychiatrist and reported by The Associated Press, it is not altogether clear whether we have too few psychiatrists or too many.

Herbie Kronowitz, Coney Island middleweight, gained the decision over George (Sonny) Horne of Valley Stream in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The victor weighed 160 1/4, to 161 for his rival.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (U.P.) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee recessed today its hearings on the Italian peace treaty until next week, when Secretary of State Marshall and former Secretary Byrnes will make their recommendations for or against early ratification.

Last week we reported that mocha coffee from Arabia is available again for the first time since before the war. Today it may be said that Java coffee is back, too. When blended together, mocha and Java are a team as good and as famous as scallops and tartar sauce, whisky and soda, ice cream and cake.

Last week we reported that mocha coffee from Arabia is available again for the first time since before the war. Today it may be said that Java coffee is back, too. When blended together, mocha and Java are a team as good and as famous as scallops and tartar sauce, whisky and soda, ice cream and cake.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- J. Albert Dear Jr., editor of The Jersey Journal, told Congress today that rising operating costs, rather than competitive conditions, caused a decline in recent years in the number of daily newspapers.

GENEVA, Switzerland, May 2 -- Yugoslavia and Albania served notice tonight that they would not appoint liaison representatives to serve with the subordinate group of the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission that is being sent back into northern Greece.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 2 -- Despite recent charges of Turkish censorship, no representative of a foreign newspaper has been expelled for any expression of adverse criticism. None has been barred from re-entry, even though his record may show his approach was unsympathetic or even hostile.

Reaffirming the policy of renominating competent judges who have served full terms regardless of political considerations, the executive committee of the New York County Republican Committee last evening designated Surrogate James A. Delehanty, Owen W. Bohan, General Sessions judge, and Samuel C. Coleman, Rocco A. Parella and Henry S. Schimmel, City Court justices, for renomination in the Republican primary.

CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP) -- Bob Feller of the Indians came within an eyelash again today of entering baseball's Hall of Fame for the third time as he stopped the Boston Red Sox with one hit and recorded his third straight shut-out, 2 to 0.x

HONOLULU, May 2 -- Forty-five hundred Hawaiian Catholics paid tribute today to the memory of Father Damien de Veuster, leper priest of Molokai, at a solemn mass in his honor at the Honolulu Auditorium.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- The summer season in the Great Smokies region began on May 1, a month earlier than usual, to take care of the expected rush. White dogwood, silver bell and redbud are starting to bloom on the hillsides, and in June and July the purple rhododendron and mountain laurel hold their spectacular displays.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 3 -- The Big Five are still divided on most of the fundamental principles required for the establishment of an international police force, it was disclosed today by the first report of the United Nations Military Staff Committee.

IN this latest book of his, composed of four lectures delivered at Yale last spring, Herbert Read continues to investigate the relations between art and society. As before, a high instinct leads him to the very center of the main problem.

OBERLIN, Ohio, May 3 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, speaking here today at special ceremonies marking the inauguration of William Edwards Stevenson as eighth president of Oberlin College, emphasized the importance in safeguarding the independent college's integrity "in an increasingly collectivistic society."

The projected wing of the Catholic Seamen's Church Institute of Brooklyn, 653 Hicks Street, will come one step closer to realization is the result of the ninth annual dinner-dance of the Rudder Club of Brooklyn on Saturday in the Hotel St. George.
TORONTO -- Summer travelers with somewhat more than the usual time to spend can find many different kinds of vacations in eastern Canada.
A full-fledged college training program in international relations, which is expected to pioneer an approach to wider education in that field, is being tested at Stanford University.

HANOVER, N.H., May 3 -- With George Palmer and Dave Carpenter holding Dartmouth to six hits, Princeton's Tigers put together fifteen safeties for an 8-2 Eastern Intercollegiate League victory over the Indians. Toby Fullerton led the Tiger attack with four hits, including a pair of doubles that drove in five tallies.

LAKE SUCCESS -- The visitor to New York City who puts the United Nations on his list of sights and makes his way out to the interim world headquarters here, will be startled to discover how colorfully international this former gyroscope factory has become.

With the threat of a labor strike averted at the eleventh hour, industrial peace seemingly assured for another year and banner firstquarter earnings as a buttress, the domestic steel industry should now be riding the crest of a wave of optimism.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 3 -- Edward M. Day, senior member of the law firm of Day, Berry Howard and long active in corporation law, died here last night at the age of 74.

LONDON. MUCH interest has been aroused in Britain by the news of the invention of a new game in the United States, passing by the name of golf. This news has given rise to widespread comment, and a certain mild resentment, in Scotland. It seems that the promoters of the new game in the United States have taken, without acknowledgment, the name of a game invented in Scotland rather more than two centuries ago.

TIME was, not too many years ago, when the more particular traveler shunned the long-haul bus as a motorized torture chamber, preferring to pawn the family silver so that he could buy better transportation.

The National Association of Manufacturers announced yesterday that its board of directors had approved financial aid to Greece but had urged that it be extended in the form of a gift and not "disguised as loans or credits." If aid is given to Turkey also, it added, this should be on a loan or credit basis because of her superior economic position.

"AMERICA is the best half-educated country in the world." Everyone can recall this pungent saying of Nicholas Murray Butler. The saying is true. The high schools and colleges do not turn us out fully educated men and women. We are lucky if we can boast a sound halfeducation when we receive our bachelor's degrees.

TRENTON, N.J., May 3 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll signed today a bill limiting municipalities to the issuance of one tavern license for each 1,000 of population and one package store license for each 3,000. Present license holders will not be affected by the law.

LONDON, May 3 -- In a major move to isolate detained Palestinian terrorists from the community the British Government has decided to deport them to camps in Kenya, it was learned today. Kenya was formerly used for Italian prisoners of war.

ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP) -- The Washington Senators ganged up on Southpaw Sam Zoldak in the seventh and eighth innings today to overcome a four-run deficit and edge out the St. Louis Browns, 5 to 4. The defeat ended the Browns' four-game winning streak.

As amateur photography looks forward to its second postwar summer, it is becoming quite apparent that the number of camera owners who will not have a chance to shoot their vacation trips, picnics and seashore outings in color will be few indeed.
MAPPING routes, shopping, packing are the least of European travelers' worries these days. The big problems are first, catching your reservations and second, complying with inoculation requirements.

HONOLULU -- Plans are big but progress is slow in Hawaii's reconversion into a tropical tourist capital. Elsewhere in the Orient the situation is the same, except that many former tourist havens have not yet reached the point where they can start to plan the resumption of pleasure travel.

The Jewish Museum, said to be the first of its kind in the United States and probably the largest in the world, will be opened to the public Thursday under the auspices of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America. The museum is housed in the former home of Mrs., Felix M. Warburg, who presented the six-story building at Ninetysecond Street and Fifth Avenue to the seminary in 1944 for the museum.

OTTAWA, May 3 -- When he introduced his budget last Tuesday Finance Minister Douglas C. Abbott told his countrymen frankly that the reduction of the income tax by an average of 29 per cent, which he proposed, must not be interpreted as an indication of easy times ahead.

THE atmosphere of the art world remains, as I write stormy, a condition aggravated by the recent unpleasantness up at the National Academy, where the National Association of Women Artists is holding its annual.
BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, May 3 -- The British Military Government is studying methods whereby German editors would devote more space to subjects on which the Germans base their "persecution complex."

REYKJAVIK -- Sitting on the edge of the Arctic Circle up in the North Atlantic is a rugged little volcanic island decorated with majestic glaciers and dotted with steam-spouting hot springs. The island is Iceland and it is waiting for the summer when it expects its second "invasion" by Americans in the last seven years.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 (AP) -- Silent Tom Smith knew it all the time -- but he didn't tell anybody. The tgiht-lipped veteran trainer, who had just watched Jet Pilot triumph in the Kentucky Derby, insisted: "After it rained I was pretty sure we'd win it.

The French Cabinet, headed by Socialist Premier Paul Ramadier, is supported by an uneasy parliamentary coalition of Communists, Socialists and Popular Republicans -- the three largest parties. Since it took up its tasks as the Government of the Fourth Republic last Jan. 22, the Cabinet has frequently been close to collapse because of sharp differences in the coalition.

OLEAN, N.Y. May 3 (AP) -- The "St. Bonaventure Railroad" is now rusting on the scrap heap, all 300 yards of it thus ending an era of free passes on other, bigger railroads for the Very Rev. Thomas Plassman, O.F.M., president of St. Bonaventure College.

VANCOUVER, B.C. -- For the first time in history the American motorist will be able this summer to travel overland to Alaska. If his car is "roadworthy" and if he has equipment and supplies for the long journey ahead, the Canadian Government will admit him onto the Alaska Military Highway, the fabulous 1,519-mile wilderness road constructed during the war as an emergency route to the American Army's bases in the Far North.
Department store sales by reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table which gives percentage comparisons with a year ago:

The widely heralded Hapoel soccer team of Palestine will make its American debut this afternoon when it faces a New York select pro eleven at the Yankee Stadium starting at 3:30 o'clock. A capacity throng, which will be a record crowd for soccer attendance in this country, will be on hand.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 3 -- Missouri's powerful track team, invading this territory for the first time, made a show of four Eastern Ivy League rivals in a pentagonal meet here today.

While scattered localities continued experiments with the so-called Newburyport Plan of a 10 per cent reduction of retail prices the effect was sporadic and there was little indication that in general the housewives' dollars had gained any elasticity since President Truman made his appeal for lower prices.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col. -- The vast and brilliant vacationland of the Rocky Mountains, sweeping southeast for 1,200 miles from Montana's Glacier National Park to the hot sands of New Mexico, is confidently awaiting a record 4,000,000 visitors between June 1 and Oct. 15.

WRITTEN in wartime exile by one of Germany's bestknown dramatists, this novel makes clear to our minds the time of troubles we are living through. Fritz von Unruh sees the issue not in terms of a struggle for power, but against it.

The adjournment of the United Nations General Assembly's meeting last night left eight more speakers to be heard from on the question of Zionist representation in the Palestine case. This is expected to delay the Flushing-toLake Success moving day.

A GLIMPSE of what tourist, conditions may be like this year and in years that follow will be offered by the International Travel Exposition of 1947, which opens tomorrow at Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Forty-sixth Street.

THOUGH Gericault was one of the great emancipators of nineteenth-century French art, he died so young that a full century was required for his stature to emerge from the mists. Not until 1924, the centenary of his death, when the Duke of Trevise organized a massive show of his paintings and drawings at Paris, did he at last start to stand out in all his power.

THE appearance of a new book by Aragon could not be expected to cause the same stir in America that it does in France, where his mere name breeds controversy. A fervent Dadaist in 1920, he was one of the founders with Andre Breton of Surrealism, but he abandoned even that advance -guard poetic movement soon after his first trip to Russia in 1930 and his conversion to communism.
THE National Council of State Garden Clubs will hold its eighteenth annual meeting at the Mayo Hotel, Tulsa, Okla., on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.
The return of Manhattan College to intercollege rowing after an absence of five years was spoiled yesterday when Boston University took both the varsity and jayvee races on the Harlem River.

BERLIN, May 3 -- Konstantin Simonov's play, "The Russian Question," designed to educate the Russian and German public in the United States attitude toward the Soviet Union, fell with a soft flop on the stage of Max Reinhardt's Deutsches Theatre this afternoon.

The interview which Harold E. Stassen had with Generalissimo Stalin nearly a month ago, of which only a small part dealing with censorship was published immediately, is today released to the public in full. Taken at face value, it is encouraging. It appears to open up new possibilities for breaking the deadlock between Russia and the West not only in respect to the peace treaties but also in respect to other outstanding issues.

A NEW kind of tourist will be seen on the boulevards and the strade of Europe in the next few years. Like the man that broke the lyrical bank at Monte Carlo, he will walk the streets with a familiar and independent air, although there is small chance that he will be mistaken for a millionaire.

DREAMS, their origin, significance, and possible prophetic character, have always engaged the mind of men. Yet, until the advent of Freud and his remarkable studies in the interpretation of dreams, nothing of any practical scientific value had been accomplished in this field.

Evidence of the dearth of suitable mortgages available to institutional investors under current conditions has received official recognition in the latest decision of the State Superintendent of Banks, Elliott V. Bell. In a sudden move last week, the superintendent conceded that certain lenders, in their scramble for mortgages, were offering excessive premiums to brokers and builders, and hence it was desirable to withdraw the obligation that he previously had imposed on the more conservative operators.

TECHNICAL education sometimes prepares people for astonishing careers, as witness the case of Michael Kidd. For three years he studied chemical engineering at City College (working nights as a copy boy on The Daily Mirror to support himself), and was apparently pretty good at it.

ONE of the most significant events of late 1948 will be the first visit to America of the famous Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam. The visit will be made with the blessing of the Dutch Government. This is not the first celebrated European orchestra within the memory of the generation to visit America.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Soviet Union wants to cooperate with the United States to effect world peace and hopes this country is similarly disposed since "if one party does not wish to cooperate then the result will be conflict and war," Prime Minister Stalin told Harold E. Stassen, Republican Presidential candidate, in a Kremlin interview April 9.

MEXICO CITY -- Mexico expects to hold her own in the increasing competition for tourists this summer. While last summer's record -- a 70 per cent increase over the preceding year is not likely to be matched, there is every indication that American visitors will again comprise one of the country's major industries.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Opening hearings before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations this week focused on the Italian peace treaty. Senate approval of peace pacts with three Axis satellite states -- Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania -- also is to be considered.

CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head; total 3,500 (estimated). Compared with week ago; market steady to 50 cents Higher, with most advance on hogs under 250 pounds; sows, 25 to 50
HOLLYWOOD. BENNY GOODMAN, whose usual association with records is confined to waxing precise classical music or hot swing, has joined, albeit in absentia, the ranks of the disk jockeys.

Americana, color plate books, first editions and other literary material from the estate of the late Mrs. Walter B. James of New York, and other owners will go under the hammer tomorrow and Tuesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

LOS ANGELES, May 3 (AP) -- Southern California's Trojans overwhelmed the invading Illini today, 73 to 49, and Troy's sprint star, Mel Patton, exploded to a decisive victory over Illinois' National Collegiate A.A. Champion Herb McKenley in the 220-yard dash as a crowd of 29,879 sat in on the best dual track and field meet of the season here.

TORONTO -- All records for tourist travel in Canada were broken last year and 1947 looks even better. The Canadian Government's Travel Bureau at Ottawa reports that inquiries for holidays in Canada this summer have been pouring in since the beginning of the year at an average of 1,100 a day, twice the amount ever before received.

THOSE who write of guns and gunning know well that their efforts are directed to a hypercritical audience and that no reader protests more loudly than the gun crank when he detects, or thinks he has detected, an error.

THIS book, like any book written by Professor Corwin of Princeton University, deserves attention. His scholarship has a wide range (even if, surprisingly, he ascribes to Bertrand Russell the invention of the phrase, a "universe of discourse"); he uses a keen and witty mind courageously to criticize judicial decisions and executive behavior; he does not fear to state forthrightly the grave problems confronting our people.

TOKYO, May 3 -- Barring the unforeseen, Gen. Douglas MacArthur intends "to see the occupation through," a spokesman said today in reply to reports circulated in Washington. His health is excellent, the statement stressed.

AMESTERDAM. FRANCE had her Alfred Cortot case, Norway her Kirsten Flagstad and this month musical Holland will be rent asunder when Willem Mengelberg returns from Switzerland to seek revocation of his lifetime disbarment from Dutch musical activity for wartime collaboration with the Germans.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- After less than three weeks in office, Mayor Martin H. Kennelly's campaign promises to clean up Chicago, to eliminate waste and provide improved municipal government are showing evidence of fulfillment.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Having recently returned from Nuremberg, I am struck by certain ironical contrasts between our Government's prosecution of Nazi criminal organizations at Nuremberg and our parallel proceedings here against socalled disloyal American organizations. It would seem that we are providing American justice for Nazis, but Nazi justice for Americans.

TWO consecutive WJZ-ABC public service programs scheduled to be heard from 9:30 to 10 P.M. and from 10 to 10:30 P.M. on Tuesday, May 20, will examine America's slum problem and suggest remedial action.

MADRID -- Spain's tourist centers are looking forward hopefully to a revival of travel. Few countries have more picturesque cities to visit and the Spanish Government tourist office -- the Direccion General de Turismo -- is making every effort to make them easy to reach and to provide comfortable hotel facilities wherever these have been lacking.

A professor of English or of history does not usually cherish the illusion that his students are all potential novelists and poets or authorities on feudalism or eighteenth century liberalism. Literature, history, philosophy are taught as cultural subjects. In science it is otherwise.

LET it be stated at once: an extraordinary and powerful new naturalistic talent herewith makes its debut in American letters. But let it be added immediately: Chicago's Mr. Motley has a deal of graduate work to do in literature's school of realism before attaining all the honors of his craft.

MR. WATTS is almost certainly an inspired and inspiring teacher, but when he attempts, in the first four essays of the ten here reprinted, to give a reasoned basis for the inspiration that has carried him through thirty years of teaching, he becomes both confused and confusing.

BROADWAY will have an ear cocked tomorrow in the direction of Morningside Heights, where Columbia's trustees will perform their annual ritual of endowing one of the season's offerings with the Pulitzer Prize.

DUBLIN -- Ireland is one of the few countries in Europe in which an American can spend a vacation this summer or fall and be assured of good food in reasonable quantity, a wide variety of first-class hotels to choose from, ample facilities for sight-seeing and plenty of sport, whether it be golf, fishing or racing.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas, chairman of the House Un-American Activities Committee, called on heads of the armed services today to take action against uniformed persons who took part in Thursday's May Day parade in New York City.

WOKING, England, May 3 -- Stanley (Ted) Bishop, United States amateur golf champion from Dedham, Mass., won the 36hole Goldsmith Cup open amateur tournament today as members of the United States Walker Cup team steadied their sea legs with their first competition on British

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of April 13 you published a letter from Otto Nathan criticizing Herbert Hoover's report to the President which advocated revival of German industrial production.

ALTHOUGH it is always fashionable to pretend that a theatrical season is dull, there is room for a little argument here. Is this a dull season, for example? Not to me, if you want to get personal about it. Beginning on Oct. 10 with the memorable performance of Eugene O'Neill's "The Iceman Cometh," it has produced about twenty interesting theatre works-old and new dramas and musical plays.

In behalf of the Generosity Thrift Shop, Inc., a garden party and tea will be held on the afternoon of May 13 at the home of Mrs. Seth M. Milliken, 951 Madison Avenue. Guests have been requested to bring packages of rummage suitable for resale later at the shop, as a partial payment of admission.
The George Junior Republic, an institution for delinquent juveniles, will be the beneficiary of the formal reopening for the summer of the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria on May 15.

UP to the end of last week it looked very much as if the ballet around here was a dead duck, or at least a seriously sick one. Though the season has contained more performances than any previous season on record, the artistic accomplishments have fallen to a new low, and there have been more empty seats at every company's performances than ever before.

In a week of debate, not a single member of the United Nations -- apart from the five Arab countries -- has given the slightest public intimation of its views regarding the ultimate status of Palestine.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- John L. Lewis is warming up for a new joust with the soft coal industry, but he is keeping one eye on Congress. So are the operators, or at least those of them who want some legislative help.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 3 -- A special committee of the American Institute of Architects will study and report soon on the proposal that the institute underwrite the cost of an international competition for the design of one or more building's for the United Nations headquarters in New York.
Peacetime universal military training, soon to be submitted to Congress, stands or falls on its military utility.

THERE was a much discussed bridge hand several years in which one player held a Yarborough -- a nine - high hand -- and yet voluntarily raised his partner to a slam. The bidding had been: South. West. North. East.

PARIS -- France, once the leading tourist center of the world, is trying hard to recapture her place. She is confident that the job she has done thus far will assure her of more than 500,000 visitors this year -- not all from America, of course.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 3 -- Harvard's varsity crew, green but good, slammed down a mile-andthree-quarters Severn River course for a hair-raising victory over Navy today in a quadrangular rowing regatta that also involved M.I.T. and Penn.

Rabbis in sermons yesterday, which was designated United Jewish Appeal Sabbath by the Synagogue Council of America, stressed the needs of Europe's 1,500,000 Jewish survivors and offered prayers for success of the $170,000,000 United Jewish Appeal campaign for the relief, rehabilitation and resettlement of Europe's homeless and destitute Jews.
REPORTS on the subject of children's interests reach us from grown-ups now and then. Thanks to a new study of day-care centers for school children we now have a report, "As the Children See It."

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 -- The wartime migration of more than 75,000 Negroes into this city and the East Bay area, with the prospect of many more, has posed here, as elsewhere, the problem of housing and unemployment, many leaders said today.

The role of the newspaper in shaping the political, economic and social structure of the United States was described as "enormous" yesterday in the first of a series of short-wave round-table discussions to be beamed to foreign nations over the State Department's international broadcasting facilities.

LISBON -- Portugal's little strip of the Iberian peninsula is generally regarded by the American tourist as just a way station on the route to Spain or elsewhere. Actually it is a beautiful country well worth a visit from the traveler interested in scenery or world history.

HOUSEKEEPING is housekeeping, whether it is done in a 1 1/2-room kitchenette apartment, an ocean liner, a train or in a four-engine, 300mile-an-hour transatlantic airplane. Which explains why a corner of Pan American World Airways' lofty hangers at La Guardia Field is equipped with an electric laundry machine and a clothes line.

Peace-loving people have long dreamed of an international police force which would make war impossible. The men who drew up the Covenant of the League of Nations played with the idea and dropped it. The bitter experiences of World War II led the authors of the United Nations Charter to go further.

HUGO LEICHTENTRITT'S valuable new book on Serge Koussevitzky is not so much a biography of the Boston Symphony Orchestra's conductor as it is a well-deserved tribute to the great musician as a devoted champion of the American composer.

The immediate construction of 116 new ships, aggregating 900,000 deadweight tons, is necessary to meet the urgent needs of the postwar American merchant marine, a study of a report now before President Truman's special advisory committee on the merchant marine showed yesterday.

A SYMPOSIUM on flower photography in the current issue of The Camera finds four experts in agreement on the essential techniques in this field. Dom Chiesa works by daylight indoors; Louise K. Broman prefers photographing wild flowers in the field;

ATLANTA, May 3 -- An 8,000acre Franklin D. Roosevelt memorial area in and around Warm Springs, Ga., which thousands will visit annually from all parts of the nation, was visualized this week following announcement by Gov. Melvin E. Thompson that the name of Pine Mountain State Park had been changed to Franklin D. Roosevelt State Park.

WARRENTON, Va., May 3 (AP) -- Never Worry, 13-year-old chestnut mare by War Whoop out of Sparkling Day, today romped home eight lengths ahead to win the four-mile Virginia Gold Cup, the Old Dominion's top steeplechase, in eight and one-half minutes over a rain-soaked turf.

Wild trilliums are in bloom, if you know where to find them, the purplishred wake robins, the shy-nodding trilliums with white petals and long sepals, the dwarf whites which were the first to bloom, and the relatively rare large-flowering trillium. They are lilies, all of them, kin of Solomon's seal and bellwort and adder's tongue or dogtooth violets.

EARLY along in this grab-bag of stereopticons of New Orleans in the decade after Appomattox, which Frank ("Foxes of Harrow") Yerby has shuffled between covers and labeled a novel, we were reminded of one of S.J. ("Crazy Like a Fox") Perelman's better spoofs of a Hollywood story-conference.

ONE never ceases to admire the skill with which French writers are able to construct a tight narrative, agitated by suspense, told in vivid, muscular prose, and enlivened by characterizations that are subtle, yet sharp. "In "Sirocco," the popular French novelist Joseph Kessel has displayed all those talents so long identified with tradition.

TO vacationists who must operate on a low budget of time and money the American Grand Tour -- from coast to coast -- has always seemed to be at the end of the travel rainbow. Despairing of adequate time or of being able to afford either sleek airliners or Pullman trains, they put the travel folders away and resign themselves to another season at the near-by seashore.

SEATTLE, May 3 -- Dr. Walter C. Woodward, noted physician and surgeon, who was known as "the Will Rogers of the medical profession" because of his wit, died here this afternoon in Swedish Hospital after an illness of two weeks. His age was 70.

IF were a labor leader today I would call the members of my union together for an off-the-record discussion. I would present some facts and ask some questions. I would not underestimate their intelligence.

Significant problems facing America's schools and colleges were considered in Washington this week as the nation's foremost educators, college presidents and school administrators met in the thirtieth annual conference of the American Council on Education.

AMATEUR photographers are expected to shoot more film this summer than at any time in the history of photography. Many new enthusiasts have entered the uncounted ranks of the nation's No. 1 hobby in the last few years.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The drive to effect lower prices gained modestly in momentum this week, bringing slender but persistent hope to some Government economists that a formula for avoiding a full-scale business recession had at last been discovered.

THE outdoor summer concerts start next month. There will be plenty of them, with all the old series going strong and a few reviving after being abandoned during the war. One of the series being revived is that of the Essex County Symphony Society at the City Schools' Stadium in Newark.

IF I were an employer today my business would probably be larger and much more profitable than ever before. We would be in a seller's market except for a few luxury or poor-quality items. There would be some difficulty in procuring a continuous flow of materials and components of the quality and types most desired.

NOW that the shooting is over, and we know the answers to several of yesterday's headlines, it seems impossible to write about the recent war without including a detailed analysis of the flowering of love as it rears its head amid the grime and gore of battle.

Thirteen distinctive urban, gardens, planted adjoining homes in residential districts, will be opened to the public under the auspices of the City Gardens Club on Tuesday and on May 13 from 2:30 to 6 P.M.

Lack of garaging facilities here was designated yesterday as one of the major contributing causes for the upswing in car theft insurance rates by the National Automobile Underwriters Association, 99 John Street. Data collected over the last year indicated that cars left in streets unattended at night were being stolen in increasing numbers.

A total of 486 applications for multiple-family dwelling site approvals have been received by the New York district office of the Federal Housing Administration from Jan. 5, when the intensive drive to promote rental housing began, up to March 31, Thomas G. Grace, New Tork State director of the FHA, announced yesterday.

FOR THE WEEK: Place brush support for peas, and also thin sweet peas to stand six inches apart. When they are six inches tall, sprinkle bone meal or nitrate of soda along the row. . . . Watch for aphids and if the infestation seems severe spray or dust with a nicotine mixture. . . . Dust delphinium plants with sulfur or rotenone and spray peonies with bordeaux mixture.

The 20,000-word indictment against the twenty-four executives of the I.G. Farbenindustrie in Germany places them on a par with Hermann Goering and others tried before the International Military Tribunal in Nuremberg.

Although proponents of increased credit aid to small business continue to rage, it is evident that regular commercial banks have been making such aid available in ample volume under current conditions, banking spokesmen asserted last week.

Delegates of fifty-five nations, representing 1,617,000,000 people and two-thirds of the world's land area, met last week at New York's Flushing Meadow for the first special session of the United Nations General Assembly. They had gathered to consider the problem of a single country the size of Vermont, with a population smaller than that of Manhattan.
PARIS. IT is clear that many of the new names launched since the Liberation owed much of their eclat to non-literary factors. Very few now give promise of permanent value or of continued production.

THE gardener who looks ahead and plans for the future is certain to have masses of blossoms throughout the year. Planting roots of hardy asters now will bring immeasurable enjoyment of fall flower color.

PANAMA, May 3 -- Foreign Minister Ricardo J. Alfaro today revealed the position of the Government of Panama in respect to the occupation of sites in Panama by the United States Army for the defense of the Panama Canal in a statement to the press.

NOW that shortening has returned to grocery shelves, homemade pastry can come to dinner again. The family will rejoice, though the cook may not. Pastry is the bane of every bride, and often it remains so, long after the bride has graduated into the fullfledged housewife class.

THE little biography on the jacket of this collection of occasional writings reveals the fact that the author is no ordinary essayist. Joseph Needham, it tells us, is a fellow of the Royal Society. He reads Chinese in the original, he translates Polish -- a language with seven declensions -- and studies Aztecan philology to relax.

WASHINGTON, May. 3 -- The effect of the Swedish import restrictions of March 15 on American goods has been eased through an agreement regarding their application, the State Department announced today.

What this world needs is more experience in cooperation. Elder statesmen are not usually effective cooperators, partly because of the nationalistic pressure to which they are subjected, partly because their habits of thinking are fixed. Cooperation ought to begin in childhood.

Federal authorities in Washington are studying evidence pointing to sabotage in the burning of the liner John Ericsson at her West Fiftieth Street pier on March 7. according to authoritative information received by shipping men here.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Truman was urged by members of Congress today to use this country's influence to gain unlimited immigration for Jews into Palestine and a hearing for the Jewish Agency for Palestine in the United Nations General Assembly.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- One of the easiest and most rewarding overland journeys in South America is the trip from Caracas, Venezuela, to Bogota, over the Simon Bolivar Highway (a leg of the Pan American Highway).

WITH several million new automobiles added in the last twelve months to those already in service, vacation travel by car this year will attain peak volume. More motorists will be driving East and West and an increasing number of vacationists will take their cars abroad.
Since George C. Marshall took office as Secretary of State last Jan. 21, a new American foreign policy has been in the making. The lines of the policy have been drawn in three major developments.

NEW DELHI, India, May 3 (U.P.) -- Leaders of the Indian Labor Service Organization (Hindustan Mazdoor Swak Sangh) broke off from the Communist-dominated All-India National Trade Union Congress today in a move designed to break the Communist hold on Indian labor unions.

AMSTERDAM -- The immaculate beauty of the Netherlands will be admired this summer by the limited number of tourists who are lucky enough to gain access to the spotless, serious realm of Queen Wilhelmina. The one great restricting factor to foreign travel in this country will be the seasonal shifting of the Netherlanders.

To protect the American public against unreasonably high prices for natural rubber and as a defense measure, the United States Government should dispose of its synthetic rubber plants to private industry only with the understanding that they will be operated or maintained in a stand-by position.

A ground - breaking ceremony next Tuesday will signal the start of work on one of the latest largescale rental housing developments for war veterans in New Jersey. The project, known as Boulevard Gardens, will occupy an area covering two square blocks from Forty-ninth to Fifty-first Street on Hudson Boulevard in Bayonne.

FOR the past several years Arthur S. Link, as a student and as a member of the Department of History at Princeton University, has been working on a new biography of Woodrow Wilson. The first volume is now published, and it is an imposing and important contribution to American history.

Many manufacturers have yet to make a real contribution to lower prices on new goods, and the test of their position will come during the fall buying period in the weeks directly ahead, according to views expressed in retail circles last week.

ALTHOUGH the ocean-travel picture has improved since last summer, with a score of liners entering or resuming service in pre-war finery, the travel-hungry American faces the prospect of remaining landlocked for at least another year.

WASHINGTON -- Of the various fields of veterans' services, there is none that has received more widespread approval from both the public and the veterans than the medical services of the Veterans Administration. Though characterized as the "backwash of medicine" less than two years ago, the remarkable improvements made in this service since its reorganization have gained for it the unqualified support of the medical profession at large.

ROCHESTER -- Engineers' Jobs Practical experience combined with opportunities to learn at first hand the opening's offered by industry will be provided for engineering students at the University of Rochester this summer when they will be given jobs in eight of the city's leading manufacturing plants.

ROME, May 3 -- Hints at the possibility of civil war were heard today as Communist leaders harangued meetings of 6,000,000 workers who struck throughout Italy in protest against the May Day massacre of eight peasants in Sicily.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Truman praised today the "fine response" of the wholesalers' trade organization to his plea for lower prices, but simultaneously he called upon "all segments of the economy" to be constantly aware of the national price problem.

RUTLAND, Vt. -- Motorists who don't care particularly whether they drive on second or third class highways provided they are historic may ride this summer along stretches of two military roads of great interest. The first of these is the Crown Point Military Highway, built in 1759-60 by the British to help move men and supplies in the French and Indian War.

LOS ANGELES -- California, with its variegated beaches, deserts, mountains and cities, is looking forward, as it does each year, to its biggest tourist season in history. And there seems no particular reason why this may not materialize.
LONDON, May 3 (Reuters) -- Results of football games in Great Britain today: ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division Brentford 0 Blackburn 3. Chelsea 1. Sheffield United 4. Derby 1. Huddersfleld 0.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., May 3 -- The Council of Bishops of the Methodist Church, in annual session at the Riverside Inn today, took under consideration proposals for special church activities to commemorate the centennial of Methodist missions in China in 1948.

From widely separated parts of the country came news last week of the progress made in solving the riddle of cancer. Especially important was the paper read by Dr. Milislav Demerec of the Department of Genetics, Carnegie Institution of Washington, on the changes that occur in cells and their relation to the growth of tumors.
LONDON, May 3 (AP) -- The Admiralty broadly hinted today that it may try to develop an atompropelled battleship.

Four firemen were injured and two others were overcome by smoke late last night and early today while fighting a stubborn five-alarm fire in a six-story brick warehouse at 16 to 20 Skillman Street, at Flushing Avenue, in the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn.

THIS newest volume of poetry by the director of the Frick Collection shows Mr. Clapp constantly developing and refining his individual and highly intellectual poetic idiom. "The Seeming Real," like "Against a Background of Fire," is the expression of an intelligent, speculative and detached mind, which finds in the language of science -- notably of astronomy -- the only fitting symbols for the present chaos and future nothingness.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 -- More than a century and a half ago, wine growing was introduced into California by some Franciscan priests and about forty years later Jean Vignes, a Frenchman, set himself up as the first commercial grower of wine grapes west of the Sierra Nevada.

A two-story living room with a fireplace and a balcony master bedroom will feature the houses which Gordon B. Roth, builder, now has under construction at Long Beach, L.I., on the west side of Riverside Boulevard between East Fulton and East Hudson Streets.

PARIS. SPRING seems less a mockery in Paris this year than at any time since the war. Even the cynics admit that today things are a little better, or at any rate slightly different, or at least barely any worse. Then too the trees are greening and the air and sun give a welcome lift to the spirits.

THE little Princess Theatre, on West Thirty-ninth Street, was the scene of an important event in the annals of the American theatre last February. No brass band marked the event, no dignitaries took bows from flag-draped boxes, yet the opening of the Experimental Theatre's first play marked the initial theatrical undertaking of the American National Theatre.

WHEN the frustrated motorist of gas-rationing days consoled himself with dreams of a fabulous post-war car, the man behind the gas station pump, with practically nothing to sell, dreamed of fabulous post-war service stations.

The 15-cent-an-hour wage increases in the mass - production industries seem to be setting the pace for the nation's 1947 wageprice-profit structure. Generally speaking, they conform pretty closely to the wage theory put forward last fall by Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation.

THE truth of the old saw about the goose and the gander (you may substitute "turn about is fair play" or any similar cliche that Would gladden Frank Sullivan's heart) has quietly but effectively been proved this last year by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Unless teachers are paid a minimum of $2,400 a year, and receive greater tenure and security provisions, they will continue to leave the classrooms of this country in increasing numbers, speakers attending the conference of the American Council on Education warned today.

Sweeping changes in the areas rimming the East Side site selected for the United Nations were seen in the announcement yesterday that realty investment interests had assembled more than a score of properties adjacent to the proposed home of the world skyscraper capital.

In an unprecedented step by a utility company looking to a simplification or broadening of capital structure preparatory to financing a construction program that will cost over $75,000,000, the Southern California Edison Company, Ltd., will seek on Tuesday approval of stockholders of a refunding program involving the issuance of more than $95,000,000 of new securities.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Beginning with the San Francisco Conference, and continuing through the recent Moscow Conference, the Russian Government has obstinately pursued a policy of obstruction, intimidation and aggression. Her demands for territory, reparations and unfair preferment are directly responsible for the almost total failure of every conference of the Big Five.

LETURE-DEMONSTRATIONS by prominent photographers and a variety of opportunities for shooting pictures will be offered to amateurs at the Photo Carnival to be held May 16, 17 and 18 at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue.

CLEVELAND, May 3 -- A new bill is before the Eightieth Congress with the imposing title, the "Business, Employment, and Security Insurance Act." Old-timers all over the United States, who pay annual dues of 25 cents to national headquarters in Cleveland, know the bill by its more popular name, the Townsend Plan.

MADRID, May 3 -- A drastic decree, effective today, establishes the death penalty automatically for chiefs of guerrilla groups and a minimum of life imprisonment for anyone convicted of sabotage, kidnapping or armed hold-up. All offenses are to be judged by military courts, and the "most summary procedure" is ordered.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (NANA) -- The Secret Service is streamlining its protection of the White House and the President of the United States back to peacetime basis.

JERUSALEM, May 3 -- Pleading for "Arabism" and the independence of Palestine, the Arab bloc in the United Nations is now meeting the most critical test of its strength and influence. The test is crucial because the Palestine issue is the most important one on the program of the Arab League.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The United States, its prime military attention focused on the polar cap, is planning a second winter of Arctic troop training.

NORWALK, Conn., May 3 -- This bustling lower New England community of 45,000 persons has returned a decisive 2-to-1 majority so far in a referendum in favor of a strong United Nations capable of gruarding the world from the twofold threat of atomic warfare and international conflict on a lesser scale, a survey disclosed today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 -- Jet Pilot, Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham's big, handsome, 3-year-old colt, scored what amounted to a portalto-portal success in the seventythird Kentucky Derby today.

CALL 1947 the year of the re-discovery of America. Countless vacationers will learn anew that the greatness of their country can the measured not only in terms of mammoth industry and military effort but equally in terms of natural grandeur and picturesque loveliness.

CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- Trends were mixed in grain dealings on the board of trade today. While deferred wheat contracts slumped following a private forecast of a winter wheat crop of more than one billion bushels, the May contract displayed independent strength at times as a result of supplemental flour allocations to foreign countries.

SANDBURG supplies the text: "Let the gentle bush dig its roots deep and spread upward to split one boulder." This long, ambitious novel by Barbara Giles is a complex working out of Sandburg's metaphor of the living and the non-living.
Fifty thousand city employes received orders from Mayor William O'Dwyer yesterday to put aside their customary tasks for the next two weeks in favor of spring house-cleaning.

ONE of the first building materials to become associated with the general conception of modern architecture was glass block. Unhappily, it soon acquired the less pleasing tag of "modernistic," thanks to the antics of designers who slapped it up everywhere with more enthusiasm than common sense.

IT looks as if "all the comforts of home" -- once considered the finest offer that any hotel could make to a finicky traveler -- will soon be superseded by justified claims of "all the comforts you never dreamed of at home."

WALLOWA, Ore. SPRING is the season of the waterfall. The still beauty of the ice-cone, towering against the cliff in the riverbed, has given way to plumes and rockets which-shoot down and dissolve into mist and spray. The farther the descent the more vaporous becomes the column. Yet always in the dark pool at the bottom the stream is renewed and now it goes coursing toward the sea.

BABY chicks are almost as tempting at this time of year as baskets of pansies and other seedlings to be found in the stores. But it has to be said, nonetheless, that most keepers of poultry have too many hens for their needs.

With several deep-water tournaments scheduled for this summer, the horse-mackerel (thunnus secundodorsalis to the Websterian) anglers should find plenty to occupy them up and down the coast, from the Soldiers Rip in Nova Scotia to Brielle on the New Jersey shore.

THE tug of war between retailers and manufacturers on prices is reaching a point of high strain on both sides. Last week there were a number of concessions on the part of producers but nothing that rated as too important -- merely a little give here and there.

HOLLYWOOD. RUPERT HUGHES is credited with the observation that, unfortunately for a lot of people in Hollywood, the camera photographs people's minds as well as their faces. This may be the secret of the success of Deborah Kerr, who, as Hollywood's latest sensation, is towering considerably above the multifarious sensations that form the warp, woof and meow of the burg.

HERE is a problem novel that doesn't behave like one, the story of a crime of passion told without benefit either of sensational journalism or pedantic pontification. The problem is the one which society today has labeled "juvenile delinquency," but which becomes, when expressed in an act, not a lapse or a delinquency, but a transcendent, selfdestructive kind of criminality.

RECENTLY, I spent eight weeks in Vienna, conducting at the Opera and several concerts with the various orchestras there. I was greatly impressed by the vitality of musical life and equally shocked by the complete absence of "new blood."

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Labor's prestige in legislative halls has fallen to a new low, yet its potential political influence has never been greater than today. This apparent paradox is illustrated by the lawmakers' disregard of labor's wishes since the 1946 elections, at a time when trade unions have reached their highest membership levels in the country's history.

"MY FRIEND IRMA," presented by CBS at 10:30 Friday nights, is a farce of more than passing promise. Concocted out of about three parts "My Sister Eileen" and one part "You Can't Take It With You," it tells the hectic consequences which come from knowing a young lady who has more heart than brains.

PANAMA -- A trip to the Central American tropics to escape the heat of midsummer in the United States may sound strange. Yet it is true that even as close to the Equator as Panama is, summer weather can be cool and comfortable, especially at night.

FOR the first time since, prewar days, an almost unlimited early season choice of hotel accommodations, summer cottages and beach bungalows is available for the prospective summer visitor in many of the New Jersey coast resorts.

Following are the articles of the United Nations Charter regarding the use of an international police force: ARTICLE 42 Should the Security Council consider that measures provided for in Article 41 would be inadequate or have proved to be inadequate, it may take such action by air, sea, or land forces as may be necessary to maintain or restore international peace and security.

PRIMARILY, the resort hotel or inn keeper is father and mother to a houseful of pleasure-loving, grown-up children. It's his job to make them comfortable, tuck them into bed so they get a good night's sleep, and be up all night long so that early next morning he can hang out the sun, roll out the carpet of green over the golf course and set out a blue sky high over the lake.

THE Lasker volume is a new edition of a classic first published more than twenty years ago and makes available again one of the most interesting books on chess ever written. It is a characteristic product of a past world champion who was also one of the game's greatest personalities.

BETWEEN this Tuesday and the end of May, a parcel of late spring entries will be coming off the presses, these being a few of them: Fiction "Presidential Mission," by Upton Sinclair; "Devil at Westease,"
ALTHOUGH wartime restrictions on picture-taking in New York City no longer hamper the amateur photographer's activities in public places, a few peacetime "don'ts" still exist.

With fall apparel lines ready for presentation to store buyers who will arrive later this month, New York manufacturers of dresses have been unable to make final determinations on price, it was learned last week. After figuring and refiguring costs, manufacturers said it appears that the only alternative to operating at a loss is to close down shop until conditions become more settled.

BECAUSE Dorothy James Roberts is a gifted story teller and keen student of the human race, she can take a seemingly far-fetched situation and make it moving and believable. She does this in her story of a walk over a mountain -- a stark, gruelling experience shared by three people on a sweltering August night.

JASPER just couldn't pay attention. There was always something else in his mind. He spoiled his piano lesson by pounding on the keys as if he were beating a drum. At church he put the singers of the gospel choir off the tempo by drumming with his feet on the pew ahead.

THE British royal family's tour of South Africa has brought a bonanza to one New York business firm. Burrelle's, the large clipping service, has a lucrative order to snip every reference to the junket which appears in the American press.

ALBANY, May 3 -- Warning that we no longer have "the security of isolation," Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, war-time head of the Office of Strategic Services, emphasized tonight the importance to our security of an independent Korea.

ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S two private secretaries, John G. Nicolay and John Hay, finished the "official" ten-volume life of their dead chief in 1890. Fifteen years later they compiled a twelve-volume "Complete Works of Abraham Lincoln."

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Fall perhaps the pleasantest season of the year, is now here in its fullness as spring advances in the United States, and it is upon the fact that it is winter in these parts when the summer heat is at its worst in the States that South America is basing its hopes for the largest tourist season since the war.

BERMUDA continues to be a favorite spot for the short holiday. Formerly thought of as a spring and winter playground, the island now draws a year-round crowd. Many, in fact, prefer Bermuda in warm weather. For the outlander goes to the coral isle to enjoy the outdoor life.

Walter Kirby Higbe, Dodger pitching star, yesterday became a Pirate in the biggest financial major league deal of the year, announced jointly by Prank McKinney, Pittsburgh club president, and Branch Rickey, Brooklyn president.

WASHINGTON. IN my office there is a small black cylinder of pure uranium weighing about two and one-half pounds. It is harmless. Five years ago no man had ever seen even this small amount of pure uranium -- not that it was rare, but simply because it was of little importance.

Many reservations have been made for "May Days in Gotham," the annual luncheon-fashion show, on May 15 in the grand ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop and its affiliated charities. Miss Louise Edgar, who is in charge of the arrangement, is chairman also of the Nearly New Shop, located at 916 Eighth Avenue, where donated articles are sold for the shop and its affiliates.
The two rectors who have been mentioned most prominently for election as Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York withdrew jointly yesterday as "possible nominees."

Alert business organizations in virtually every field recognize that pre-war haphazard selling resulting from hit-or-miss training is not feasible in the current intensely competitive period, A.L. Nickerson, director of the SoconyVacuum Oil Company, Inc., in charge of domestic marketing, said in an interview last week.

AFTER a winter that saw most of them operating at alarmingly low revenue volumes, airlines of the United States look forward to this summer and what they hope will be swarms of travelers. The airlines of other nations, which don't have to worry so much about balancing the books because they are in the main national corporations, also look forward to a lush summer season.

For the second straight day the extraordinary session on Palestine of the United Nations General Assembly was deadlocked yesterday in debate on the problem of representation for the Zionist side of the case.

THE impressive circumstantial evidence that Alexander I arranged his own "death" in 1825, retired to Siberia and led a life of religious expiation for his acquiescence in the murder of his father, is assembled for the first time in English by Dr. Leonid I. Strakhovsky, lecturer in Slavic at Harvard University.

Letter From America Dear Dr. Pangloss: This is the second week in succession that you are being asked to devote a few minutes of your valuable time to the subject of advertising. There are two reasons.

QUITO -- Think of Latin America in terms of contrasts. There are cities as go-getting as New York, and more modern. There are villages as primitive as any on earth. There are pensions where frugal travelers live well for less than $2 a day. There are hotels and cabarets where the prices of steak and and Scotch reach Andean heights.

GENEVA, May 3 -- France informed the Economic Commission for Europe today that she favored progressive reconstruction for the German economy because of its importance to the economy of all Europe and because a "cancer" should not be left in the center of the Continent.

A day-long celebration of the 100th anniversary of the chartering of City College will be held Wednesday, with students, faculty, alumni, public officials and 175 delegates from other colleges and universities of the world participating.

MANY people read about garden -making in the spring, scan the newest seed catalogues and build beautiful mental picture of a colorful flower border that will fill the house with bloom until winter. Then comes a sigh and the conviction that the budget will just not permit the planting of a border or flower garden this year.

When President Truman went abroad last March for the first time since his return from Potsdam in 1945, he said he wanted to "visit my next-door neighbor first." He went south of the border to Mexico, was feted, given ovations. Last week the "next-door neighbor" repaid the call.

CAIRO, May 3 -- Egypt's swing toward ultra-nationalism is worrying even some Egyptians, and is a source of apprehension to the British and Americans. It is no longer comfortable to be a foreigner in the land of the Pharoahs.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Following is the transcript of Harold E. Stassen's conference with Premier Stalin made public by Mr. Stasser tonight: STASSEN (After introductions) -- Generalissimo Stalin, on this European trip I am particularly interested in studying conditions of an economic nature.

MANY parts of Europe, despite a host of difficulties, are again extending a cordial welcome to American tourists who can obtain transatlantic passage. For the first time in eight years the Old World is once more able to think in terms of tourism, formerly among its leading and most cherished industries.

A memorial service for Henry Monsky of Omaha, president of B'nai B'rith, Jewish fraternal order, and chairman of the interim committee of the American Jewish Conference, will be held today at 2:30 P.M. in Temple Emanu-El.

THREE well-known sculptors are jointly exhibiting recent work at the Grand Central (Vanderbilt Avenue) Galleries. Cornelia Van A. Chapin is represented by animals, birds and insects in a variety of materials from terra cotta to volcanic rock.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A five-point program of "must" legislation for action between now and adjournment was adopted today by the Senate's Republican Policy Committee.

JUST thirty-two years ago this week in this Review: Page 1 carries "An Interpretation of the Russian People," by Leo Wiener, and if our anonymous reviewer was interpreting Professor Wiener correctly, the professor was ignoring some mighty historymaking by Nicolai Lenin and his stout band of Leftists.

NANKING, May 3 -- Publication by the official Central News Agency this morning of "Communist plans for subversive activity in Government areas" is viewed with apprehension in liberal and Leftist circles.

For many weeks, business me from one end of the country to the other have been sufficiently concerned about prices to take concrete and effective action to bring them down. There are already evidences that the area of price reduction is widening as individual businesses find particular prices that are out of line from the point of view either of profit or of slackening demand.

As an actor and independent producer, no longer in bondage to either the Warner Brothers or Metro. John Garfield may feel "free for the first time in seven years," but his moments for dawdling seem numbered. For, as he was casually explaining the other day, there are such matters as "Look Homeward Angel," "Volpone," "Gentleman's Agreement," "Moonrise" and "Body and Soul," his first independent venture for Enterprise, all occupying slots in his film file.

ADDRESSED "to enterprising young men," an advertisement in The Missouri Republican on March 20, 1822, sought adventurers willing to ascend to the source of the Missouri River and spend one to three years there trading with the Indians and trapping beaver. That was one of the most momentous items ever to appear in an American newspaper.

VIRTUALLY every leading British collector, King George VI not excepted, is sending some of his best stamps for display at the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition at the Grand Central Palace here on May 17-25.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- W. Frank Marshall, Receiver of Taxes, disclosed today that the city plans to collect its 1 per cent wage tax from major league baseball players on earnings from games played at Shibe Park, home grounds of the Athletics and the Phillies.

RESUMING its prewar activities in the interest of promoting international goodwill, the Fine Arts Committee of the National Council of Women of the United States invited the similar Canadian organization to arrange a group show.

American resistance to Soviet expansion will not work in the long run "unless we do something more than try to keep the lid on the pot of the Middle East while Russia builds more fire under the pot," Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, Professor of Government at Columbia University, declared yesterday.

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- From the Pocono Mountains to Presque Isle State Park, from the New York border to the Maryland state line, Pennsylvania is busy with the preparations required of a host to vacationists of all ages and interests.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (NANA) -- The American Congress, like the average American taxpayer, is caught in a rising price squeeze that is lifting the cost ot government 100 per cent.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned irregular yesterday and closed 13 points higher to 19 points lower than the day before. The old crop months were strong.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The Government was reported tonight to have proposed a "package" raise of $5.14 a week to settle the long-lines part of the telephone strike, but the American Telephone Telegraph Company turned down any such formula.

GENEVA, Switzerland, May 3 -- Faced with what seems to be a challenge to the authority of the United Nations Security Council to investigate incidents that could lead to war, the United Nations' Balkan Investigating Commission today called a special closed meeting Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Moscow radio broadcast this "news" on the night of April 21: "New York -- Certain conservative Senators, just as the progressive ones, admit that the greater part of the American people are against Truman's proposal of aid to Greece and Turkey."

Mail orders for cotton wash goods, hosiery and knit underwear last week were heavy, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

The newly organized Malson de France, Inc., presently sponsoring exchange scholarships between the United States and France for young trainees in industry, will give a fete entitled "La Nuit de France" on May 12 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
NEWARK, May 3 -- A colorful crowd jammed the Essex Troop Armory tonight to watch the second half of the third day's events of the Newark Horse Show. The fixture will end tomorrow.

Assault turned on the speed in the stretch to win the Grey LagHandicap at Jamaica yesterday. The King Ranch's 4-year-old, who swept through to take the Triple Crown of racing last season, signalized his first start of the 1947 campaign by moving into the lead in the final 25 yards to beat the Sunshine Stable's Lets Dance by a head in the $40,000 added mile and a furlong fixture.

Gloomy reports on economic conditions in Europe brought back by business men and the sobering statement of Secretary of State George C. Marshall that the European patient is sinking while doctors deliberate have stirred talk that the Government may be considering some kind of economic organization of Western Europe as an immediate remedy, foreign traders stated last week.

WHEN you are intrigued this summer by changing cloud formations sweeping across the sky, try accelerating the slow pace of the clouds by operating the singleframe button on a movie camera. With the camera pointed toward an attractive patch of sky and cloud make single exposures at regular intervals of one second, two seconds or longer, depending on how fast the movement is to be shown on the screen.

LONDON, May 3 -- After a winter which brought more discomfort to a greater number of people than any of the war years, Londoners these last few days have been basking in vagrant and fickle sunshine. Tulips and jonquils are pushing their stems through the earth, until recently encrusted in frost or covered with snow, and pink and white hawthorns are in bloom.

A vastly improved Columbia University eight, which refused to yield any part of the way, brought an end to its own losing streak and the victorious skein of Rutgers by winning the triangular regatta on the Harlem yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- With no more preparation than a perfunctory run around rain-soaked, fogcloaked Comiskey Park, the Yankees were ill - equipped for their double-header here today. So, before 16,402 fans who shivered in a 43-degree temperature, they dropped both games to the White Sox and skidded into fourth place in the American League standing.

HOLLYWOOD. THERE are two major schools of thought about Hollywood. One asserts that movies create and mold public opinion, set the styles, whether in plumbing or hair dress, and by their example, are responsible for everything from juvenile delinquency to the jumping divorce rate.

PARIS, May 3 -- On the eve of the Assembly's vote on the question of confidence tomorrow, the Communist Central Committee reiterated today its support of demands for a workers' production bonus. Premier Paul Ramadier already had agreed to a bonus, stipulating, however, that it must not be a disguise for wage increases.

Lack of loyalty in many homes in the nation and a paucity of ideals among the young were cited yesterday as "weak spots" in our opposition to foreign ideology by Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy at Catholic University, Washington, D.C., in an address in which he advocated "a revolution of the spirit" to combat communism.
Renewed interest in the acquisition of vacant land in Queens was indicated in reports yesterday of sales by brokers in that section.

THIS year the country celebrates the seventy-fifth birthday of Yellowstone National Park. It is our first national park, and it inaugurated a system of 169 such distinctive and far-flung playgrounds for the nation.

Leaders of striking New York telephone operators will decide this afternoon on a recommendation that will either send their membership back to work tomorrow or reject in its entirety the recently negotiated $4 weekly increase with the New York Telephone Company.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 3 (AP) -- The president of the country's camp fire girls today termed radio programs for children "unforgiveable exploitation of childhood."

BRUSSELS -- Belgium has just about everything to offer tourists even in this year 1947. They will come from England in search of soul satisfying food, rich and plentiful, from Norway and Sweden for the easy going gaiety of this capital, from France and the Netherlands to buy those simple treasures that make life worth the living -- toys, electrical gadgets for the home and clothing.
WARSAW, May 2 (delayed) -- The Communist-dominated Warsaw Government is now engaged in a final effort to stamp out the oppositionist Polish Peasant party.

A sad-eyed youngster pulled a huge, shaggy dog almost as big as himself around the judging hall at the Boys Club of New York annual pet show yesterday, held in the clubhouse at Avenue A and Tenth Street. Of the seventy-two boys who entered pets in the competition, seventy-one were smiling.

WALL gardens invariably excite admiration wherever they are seen. A simple and pretty kind is the type to be found on properties where there is a drop of a foot or two somewhere on the lawn, at the edge of the terrace, or between lawn and driveway.

ON every high tide, from every boatyard on Long Island Sound these spring days, sleek, little craft gleaming in new paint are sliding down the ways. More boats than ever before, for this will be the biggest yachting season that has churned up the waters of the old Sound since Adriaen Block of Holland explored it in 1614.

As Kipling said, "The Liner, she's a lady." The Mauretania, welcomed back to our port after her grim years of war service, remains every inch a lady, though, as ships go, verging now on middle age. She returns redolent of happier days before the world plunged into catastrophe.

LONDON -- Dazzled by the possibilities of a golden stream of tourist dollars, Britain this year is "all out" for a new source of revenue. The money is needed to replace pre-war income she drew from investments overseas and from her merchant marine.

PLASTIC PILL -- Swallow a harmless synthetic resin or plastic pill if you have stomach ulcers is the advice of Dr. Manfred Kraemer (Presbyterian Hospital, Newark, N.J.) and Drs. Mary Spears and Mildred Pfeiffer (Women's Medical College, Philadelphia, Pa.).

MOTORISTS eager to indulge once again in the American national pastime of "seeing the country" will find conditions this summer favorable for their travels. Highways are in good repair, restaurants and gas stations have reopened, even detours are to be smooth and painless.

If the question of an immediate income tax reduction could be submitted to a referendum of the people, there would be little doubt as to the outcome. A very large majority would undoubtedly express themselves as being in favor of tax reduction.

SEATTLE, May 3 (AP) -- Miss Ann Curtis of San Francisco and Miss Brenda Helser of Los Angeles renewed their free-style duel today as each won her preliminary heat in the 440-yard event, and Miss Victoria Draves of Pasadena, Calif., sprang a minor upset in high board diving at the women's National Amateur Athletic Union indoor swimming and diving championships.

WARSAW, May 3 -- To clear up "misunderstanding's about the food situation" the Food Ministry said today that, unless Poland would make up a grain deficit of 180,000 tons, rations would have to be reduced to 1,000 calories daily by August.

BOSTON, May 3 -- There has been a slight increase in employment in segments of the New England woolen industry and a degree of let-down in women's shoe and garment manufacturing. Consequently, New England is taking new interest in its unemployment compensation laws, passed at the height of the New Deal.

BARRING an extraordinarily excessive demand, the supply of rollfilms for amateurtype cameras will probably hold up this summer, judging by the current rate of replenishment of dealers' stocks. Filmpacks and sheet film, however, will continue in short supply and flash lamps will be doled out in small quantities, as at present.
CONSTANTINE, Algeria, April 28 (Delayed) -- Tanks and armored cars are patrolling the Kabylie region, the danger spot of Algeria.

THE fifth annual nation-wide observance of Religious Book Week, sponsored by The National Conference of Christians and Jews and designed to stimulate the reading of books of spiritual value, is being held this week. The Conference was established in 1928 "to demonstrate that those who differ deeply in religious beliefs may work together in the American way toward mutual goals."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 3 -- The United States indicted twenty-four top officials of the I.G. Farbenindustrie today, charging them with fomenting and waging aggressive war, mass murder and plunder and spoliation.
LOS ANGELES, May 3 -- California, whose population jumped during the war by 30 per cent to more than 9,000,000 people, faces an immediate need of $200,000,000 worth of additional hospital facilities.

MISS ABEL, who is the author of an impressive, if not widely read first novel, "Victory Was Slain," and of a striking novelette called "The Bus That Had No Sign," has produced in "The Lake" another fresh, semi-experimental piece of work.

WHEN, in the fall of 1883, Prof. William Waterman Sherman, lately of San Francisco, was found adrift in the Atlantic Ocean, clinging to the debris of twenty balloons, all America rocked with curiosity, especially as he refused to tell his story until he had reported to the Western American Explorers' Club.

LONDON. SINCE discussion of the weather amounts to a national pastime in this country, bringing strangers together in train carriages and providing an endless source of good and bad jokes ("I missed summer last year: I was taking a nap that afternoon"), it is not too remarkable that a favorite stock item in book stores here is "British Weather," by Stephen Bone, published by Collins.
Through every available medium the month of May will be heralded as "Greater New York Fund Month."

A SPECIALIST in child portraiture by sunlight outdoors, Walter Scott Shinn has succeeded in overcoming the annoying problem of squinteyed expressions by using the techniques of backlighting and foliagefiltered sunlight.

WATERLILIES are among the easiest flowers to grow. With them there is no back-breaking digging, no hoeing, no tiresome weeding and the returns in enjoyment are great. Among the rewards are flowers of any color of the rainbow -- not only every day but also every night, for there are many night-blooming kinds to be enjoyed during long summer evenings.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Studies of the behavior of objects traveling at supersonic speeds are bringing to light a strange Alice-inWonderland world in which, among other things, a miss is much better than a hit, it was disclosed here today at the closing sessions of the meeting of the American Physical Society.
