VICTORIA, B.C. -- The land which Kipling called "Our Lady of the Snows" renounces white with the arrival of spring, and appears for the oncoming summer in a cloak of forest green. The timber of western Canada is pocketed with blue lakes and streaked by whiteriffled rivers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 3 -- The Yale and Army baseball teams played to a 3-3 tie today in a game halted by rain at the end of the sixth inning. The Elis lost the opportunity of handing the cadets their first collegiate defeat of the season by leaving two men on the bases in their final turn at bat.
Democratic orators, looking ahead to the 1948 election, praised President Truman last night as "a great President" and accused Republicans of bungling and promise-breaking.

GRANVILLE, Ohio, May 3 -- Three hundred friends, associates, and leaders in business and education honored today Col. Edward A. Deeds, chairman of the Board of Directors of the National Cash Register Company of Dayton, for his activities on behalf of Denison University here.

Although President Truman continues to give major emphasis to the desirability of reductions in industrial prices, what happens to food prices will largely determine the extent to which the pressure of higher living costs will be relieved. This is necessarily so because the rise in food prices has accounted for about 70 per cent of the increase in living costs since the beginning of 1946.

A RECENT advertisement of a transpacific passenger carrier describes the Far East as "the most interesting place in the world." It is -- but right now it is not for civilian tourists with limited amounts of money and time to spend on a vacation.

FREUD'S psychoanalytic interpretation of Leonardo da Vinci's mysterious personality is the first classical example of what has become a literary fashion -- and, sometimes, even a tiresome cliche of biographical writing.

ALONG Storyville's sordid streets about thirty-six years ago a coal wagon rolled dally. Atop it perched an 11-year-old boy, and as the wagon stopped before every second or third house, the boy stood up and chanted between his cupped hands: "Stone coal, ladies, 5 cents a water bucket!" Ten years later that same throaty, exciting voice sang out another chant.

HEAVY vacation rail travel this summer, especially to the Far West and to the National Parks, is indicated by all reports from railroad traffic officials. Their optimism is based on the fact that advance inquiries and bookings are 50 per cent ahead of last year.

MOSCOW, May 3 (AP) -- An article in the New Times, the Soviet magazine in international affairs, said today that some people in the United States "spread organized slander about our country through their hirelings in editorial offices of numerous papers and magazines."

Industrial peace, which is taking place finally in vital fields, brought a firmer tone to the stock market last week. There was a feeling of relief over the settlement of major wage disputes and, although some concern was expressed on the "profit-wage" ratio facing industry, a more hopeful attitude, nevertheless, prevailed in the financial community.

BERLIN, May 3 -- The two Russian correspondents who toured the United States zone recently said that what they considered one of the greatest failures of the United States Military Government had been in remolding German attitudes.
The long expected buyers market in durable goods lines is now definitely under way, officials of more than ten large manufacturing companies agreed here yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, May 3 -- There is not the slightest doubt that when President Miguel Aleman returns from the United States some time before midnight Wednesday he will be greeted as the greatest hero in the saga of modern Mexico.

DERBY, Conn., May 3 -- In a tremendously exciting finish, Princeton barely fought off Cornell's challenge in the varsity race to complete a sweep of the triangular rowing regatta with Yale today on the rain-swept two-mile course of the Housatonic.

Speaking as the first visiting Chief of State to address the United Nations General Assembly in formal session President Miguel Aleman of Mexico made a solemn plea yesterday for speed in writing the peace treaties.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 -- The Kentucky Derby crowd undoubtedly is the most amazing to American sports. The Derby draws more customers who have not the faintest chance of seeing the big event than any other. And it also draws a considerable number who hustle out to the sprawling Churchill Downs track with the express purpose of not even taking one curious gander at the Run for the Roses.

Speaking as the first visiting Chief of State to address the United Nations General Assembly in formal session President Miguel Aleman of Mexico made a solemn plea yesterday for speed in writing the peace treaties.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 -- The Kentucky Derby crowd undoubtedly is the most amazing to American sports. The Derby draws more customers who have not the faintest chance of seeing the big event than any other. And it also draws a considerable number who hustle out to the sprawling Churchill Downs track with the express purpose of not even taking one curious gander at the Run for the Roses.

ABOUT a year ago this department commented on a passage from G.K. Chesterton in which he spoke of the fear of sentimentality as "the meanest of the modern terrors." I remarked at the time that this fear had become so intense that it had even blurred the line between sentimentality and sentiment.

VIENNA -- Southeastern Europe is looking forward hopefully to another invasion. "The sweets of liberation, in this still thundery postwar atmosphere, have begun to go slightly sour. The region would like to be overrun once more by foreigners, but foreigners in slacks and sports coats instead of high boots and uniforms, and carrying pocketbooks instead of guns.

Capturing four first places and collaring a number of other positions, Bishop Loughlin Memorial High's athletes won the open team laurels with 34 points at the first Brooklyn College interscholastic track and field meet, which was held at Brooklyn College Field yesterday.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N.Y., May 3 -- More than 1,200 student veterans attending New York City colleges, all residents of this Federal Public Housing Authority project, protested today an increase in monthly bus commutation rates from $13 to $17.25.

Prices of shares generally held firm in the short session yesterday on the Stock Exchange. The opening was quiet and changes in quotations were mixed, but at the end of the first hour a mild improvement got under way and continued to the close.

MEMPHIS, Tenn. LLOYD T. BINFORD, chairman of the Memphis and Shelby County Board of Censors, rounded out April by outBostoning Boston. In one month he banned six movies, the latest of which, a serial in thirteen episodes, he refused to view.

THE best meal I ever ate was cooked not in the stainless steel kitchen of restaurant or luxury hotel but under a roof of Ponderosa pine branches, which swayed gently in the breeze from off Eagle Cap's granite dome. No gourmet would have called it an elaborate meal.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The first major revolt against President Truman's foreign policy came last Wednesday when the House of Representatives cut from $350,000,000 to $200,000,000 funds to be expended for "relief assistance to the people of countries devastated by war."

SEATTLE, Wash -- This region is as far north and west as Americans can journey in their own land. It is close to nature and nature has already seemed to smile beneficently on its hopes for a big tourist season. One of the mildest springs in the history of the Pacific Northwest brought forth flowers, blossoms and wild grasses many weeks earlier than usual.

Understanding Youth YOUTH is sharp-sighted and incorruptible. It hangs together and presents an impenetrable front against grown-ups. It is not sentimental, one may approach to it, but one cannot enter into it. Who has been evicted from that paradise can never get back.

AMERICANS are on the move again. They have thrown off the shackles of winter and are listening eagerly for the call of summer. Many of them have already begun their vacations; in a few weeks the tide of travel will be booming. This year, if the pundits are not mistaken, the volume will be far greater than that registered in the years immediately before the war.

Two traditional fixtures always mark the month of May in red letters on the pleasure boat calendar. Yacht clubs get things ship-shape, clear away the winter's accumulation of dust and cobwebs, generally slick up, get out their flags and pennants and, to the accompaniment of music, saluting cannons and high jinks, hold the formality of "going-intocommission-day."

"THE NAVAHO," by Clyde Kluckhohn and Dorothea Leighton, is an effort to provide orientation in regard to an Indian group numbering 55,000 and occupying 18,000,000 acres of mountain, mesa and plain in two of the largest American States, Arizona and New Mexico.

In its first public appeal for funds, the Dug Out, Inc., 235 East Fifty-second Street, servicemen's club through two World Wars, announced yesterday that unless financial help is forthcoming, it probably would have to close its doors in June.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 3 -- Aided by firsts in six of seven field events, Yale's track forces downed Princeton today, 76 -- 59, in their forty-second meeting.

SKY HOG -- Sweden -- or, for all we know, the civilized world -- was recently privileged to consider its first traffic case involving a helicopter. The AmericanSwedish News Exchange reports that the pilot, one Olof Sefeldt, was arraigned for "careless navigation of helicopter" because he suddenly halted his craft above the Vaster Bridge in Stockholm.

BERLIN, May 3 -- Fourteen top business executives of the United States concluded today a two weeks' tour of the key cities of Germany and Austria. They made the trip at the request of Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson to study German industry and the Military Government's industrial program.

FIVE of the eleven stories in this collection have to do with ecclesiastical characters within the Roman Catholic Church. Perhaps the most successful of the group is the title story, a life-sized portrait of a spiritually bankrupt priest.
BISMARCK, N.D., May 3 -- Don C. Matchan's first newspaper job paid him $22 a week and he found it hard to get along on that income. His political convictions have been on the liberal side ever since.

DETROIT, May 3 (AP) -- Taking their second one-run decision in two days, the Detroit Tigers swept a two-game series from the Philadelphia Athletics with a 2-to-1 victory today back of Paul (Dizzy) Trout's five-hit pitching.

Despite adverse weather conditions, retail trade here was active last week. Consumer response to specially priced offerings was brisk. Some department stores had increases ranging around 20 to 25 per cent, with the average increase for the city put at 10 per cent.
Saturday night is for parties. Among those planned for last night was one by the Communist party, U.S.A., Seventh Assembly District, 2744 Broadway, near 105th Street.
FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., May 3 -- An all-night race riot at the Army disciplinary barracks was quelled today after one prisoner was killed and six other prisoners and five guards were injured.

EVER since sound was invented (as an adjunct to movies, that is), the Hollywood wizards have been trying to figure appropriate ways of giving both, tone and illustration to classical music on the screen. At least we assume they've been trying, although we are frankly forced to observe that, despite a variety of presentations, they haven't shown much progress in this line.

CLEVELAND, May 3 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians' new outfield fence paid off its initial dividends today as the Tribesmen smacked four home runs to smother the Boston Red Sox, 9 to 3, and sweep the two-game series.
IN spite of the presence of Ballet Theatre at the City Center, the week is a busy one for recitalists, as the list below will indicate.
MOSCOW, May 31 -- The principles of free trade and equal opportunities have been condemned as spearheads of imperialist penetration by a foremost Soviet expert on international affairs.
WITH sea cruises available to only a fraction of the applicants for them this summer and fall, the Great Lakes and other inland waterways should be more popular than ever.

The All Veterans Orchestra, under Sascha London, its young American conductor, grave a concert yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, with Lola Monti-Gorsey, soprano, as soloist. As its name implies the organization consists entirely of ex-service men, who were active in the second World War.

OCTAVE AUBRY died just as he was to be formally inducted into the French Academy. A tragically ironical end to an ambiguous career: it was his destiny to be an almost. He started with slight, neat and competent "romanced chapters of history," the most ingenious being "The Lost King" and the least convincing "Caspar Hauser."

JOHANNESBURG -- The airplane has placed South Africa on the tourist map for all the 12,000 miles of water between New York and Capetown. This spring Pan American World Airways established twice-a-week mail and passenger service between La Guardia Field and Johannesburg, making the trip in forty-four flying hours.
BERLIN, May 3 -- The United States Military Government balked today an attempt of the Russiansponsored Socialist Unity party to penetrate the western zones.

The key to success of the United Nations is the training of international, democratic-minded leaders in the civil and professional fields, Lithgow Osborne said yesterday as he was installed as head of the American - Scandinavian Foundation.

ROME -- Passport restrictions and the dislocation brought about by the war and by the presence of Allied fences of occupation have so far prevented visitors from coming to Italy in any considerable numbers. A slight trickle is just beginning to arrive, and it is hoped that the trickle may swell into a stream before many months are past and into a river in the course of the next few years.

NEW YORK STATE is bounded at one corner by New York City, itself one of the wonders of the world, and at the western border by Niagara Falls, a honeymoon and tourist attraction that seems never to lose its appeal.

CHICAGO -- The Midwest has a two-way appeal to summer vacationists. Thousands small lakes and fishing streams, and vast areas of virgin timberland make it a sportsman's paradise. And for the millions who plan their holidays to escape the cities during the ha fever season, the northern areas offer relief from ragweed as well as from the heat.

GENEVA, Switzerland, May 3 -- Two years after the victory over Hitler the Balkan peoples still know no peace. Their mood is one of uneasiness and insecurity amounting in many instances to actual fear. For many of them the war has never ended.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (NANA) -- Weather forecasts in "pictures" instead of word predictions are being developed by the United States Weather Bureau.

NANKING, May 3 -- Politics has been called "the science of the possible." If this be true, the recent reorganization of the Chinese National Government was politics in its most characteristic manifestation. Given the narrow social basis and the oligarchic bureaucratic nature of the ruling groups in Kuomintang China, the administration resulting from the reorganization is the best that could have been produced under the circumstances.
BOSTON -- From Cape Cod west to the New York border and north to Canada, paint brushes and hammers are busy as New England prepares for what it hopes will be a great tourist summer.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 3 -- When the insurrection broke out against French rule in Madagascar on March 29 the rank and file of the "Democratic movement of Malagasy renovation" was induced by its leaders to believe that help would be forthcoming from overseas, notably from the United States.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 3 -- When the insurrection broke out against French rule in Madagascar on March 29 the rank and file of the "Democratic movement of Malagasy renovation" was induced by its leaders to believe that help would be forthcoming from overseas, notably from the United States.

HESITATION about planting a vegetable garden for fear that the weeds will outgrow the crop plants is not justified in actual practice. Weeds need not be a problem. In a wellcultivated garden, weeds never even get a start, and thus backbreaking hours need not be spent under the summer sun.

NEAR Buried Hatchet, Okla., according to Mr. George Milburn, the earth is good; and the folks who walk and work it, if not perfect, are abundantly human. What's more, they're the salt. With this in mind (and it's a reassuring thought, though subject to recurring doubt), "Flannigan's Folly" sets out, through pages neat as a new plowed field, to demonstrate Felix Flannigan's quest after new land to cultivate.

Justice of the Domestic Relations Court, City of New York. "THE MARRIAGE READER" suggests that in the marital relationship neither should be master. Domination by one partner to a marriage relationship blocks happiness and the democratic way of living.
THE writer of this article was in China in 1937 when the Japanese army invaded. He has been in China again in the last year. The contrast is mournful.

In the first report of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad Company, successor in reorganization to the Seaboard Air Line Railway Company. Legh R. Powell Jr., president, said that operations of the road in 1946 resulted in revenues of $112,403,393.

WATERBURY, Conn., May 4 -- Eighty-three delegates to the 155th convention of the Connecticut Medical Society at New Haven last week unanimously approved the Alsop Birth Control bill, but a battle lies ahead in the State Legislature.

Toward the tail end of the season, closings become more plentiful. Some attractions leave because their limited engagements expire, a situation which applies to next Saturday night's previously announced departures of "Joan of Lorraine" and "The Importance of Being Earnest."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The hope which sustains most supporters of the U.N. is that it will be strengthened and transformed into a federal world government with powers adequate to prevent war. This can only be done by the governments of the nations of the world, in response to insistent popular demand.

CLEVELAND, May 4 -- Bent upon charting new pay demands and strengthening their foothold in the controversial field of the guaranteed annual wage, nearly 400 delegates representing 200,000 workers in the United States and Canada assembled here today for the fourth constitutional convention of the United Packinghouse Workers of America, CIO.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 4 -- Radio in America is not living up to its responsibilities or potentialities, particularly for inspiration and education, three participants in a round table broadcast declared here today. It was presented at a meeting of the seventeenth Institute for Education by Radio.

NANKING, May 4 -- An American loan is essential for the economic rehabilitation and reconstruction of China, Gen. Chang Chun, the new Premier, declared in a statement today. He simultaneously proclaimed a policy of "self-help" in dealing with the budget deficit.

The Swedish - American liner Gripsholm is scheduled to arrive here today with 1,225 passengers, among them twenty Swedish bus transportation executives, who will make a three-weeks, coast-to-coast tour of this country's automotive and allied industrial plants.

Legislation to provide more adequate fire protection in apartment hotels, studio apartment buildings and similar types of multiple dwellings not covered by existing laws will be introduced in the City Council tomorrow, Robert F. Wagner Jr., Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 4 -- Although business remains subnormal, there recently has been some reawakening of interest, with flashes of animation and strength. The behavior of the stock markets as a whole since the Government's budget was announced by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Hugh Dalton, has, with the exception perhaps of the gilt-edged group, been contrary to most forecasts.

LONDON, May 4 -- The winter fuel crisis caused a falling off of British exports to the value of u200,000,000 [about $800,000,000], Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade, said today at a Labor Party May Day rally in Bristol.

SEATTLE, May 4 (AP) -- Miss Ann Curtis, statuesque San Francisco mermaid, who has been making headlines for seven seasons, earned the biggest front page type last night by cracking a world mark in the 440-yard free style final. But today she was faced with a threat to the individual title she has taken in Seven straight women's national AAU indoor swimming championships.

Events of diverse interest in the art world are on the calendar this week, including the opening of the new Jewish Museum at Fifth Avenue and Ninety-second Street. The institution will be formally dedicated Wednesday evening and will open to the public on Thursday with a display of textiles, ecclesiastical objects, frescoes and modern paintings, ancient coins and other material.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 4 -- President Mariano Ospina Perez sent a message today to A.J. Rasch of the Grace Line, requesting reconsideration of the 25 per cent freight increase to Colombian ports. He asked that the increase be deferred while Colombia sought to decrease the cost of living.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,505,244,417. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows : May 8 -- Discount bills .......... $1,309,934,000
WASHINGTON, May 4 (U.P.) -- The Department of State is aiming at July 15 as the date on which foreigners may resume private trading with the Japanese, informed sources said today.

Incorporation of a downward escalator clause in contracts with exporters has resulted in a sharp increase in inquiries and orders, H.A. Allison, president, Allison Plastics Company, stated yesterday. The policy has had the added effect of eliminating restrictive and protective clauses which, of necessity, have been incorporated in such contracts, he said.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- A group of industrialists and business men called on industry today to show "economic statesmanship" in revising the price structure downward and thus save the country from a serious slump.

With the country's chief labor disputes in basic industries being settled on the basis of wage-rate increases, both labor and management agree that their principal task now is to restore normal conditions in the economy by achieving full production.

The bill to unify the armed forces is "one of the most important peacetime forward steps ever proposed in our military history" and is "admirably designed to meet and resolve the problem," Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War in World War II and also under President William Howard Taft, declared in a letter to the Senate Armed Services Committee.

LONDON, May 4 -- Top secret discussions on the influence of new weapons on combined operations will begin tomorrow at the Staff College, Camberley, Surrey. The last of 180 senior officers of the British Army, Navy and Air Force, who will take part arrived today.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Eightien Congress hopes to pass two milestones this week in its legislative drive toward adjournment about July 31.

James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, has turned to the field of literature. Harper plans to publish in October his account of the part he played in the formation of American foreign policy from the time President Truman took office until early in 1947.

MOSCOW, May 4 (AP) -- Tass, Soviet news agency, quoted Foreign Minister Molotov today as having said that Russia was "advancing in spite of the malice and intrigues of our foes -- the foes of communism."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 4 -- Czechoslovakia's system of bilateral alliances with Russia, Poland and Yugoslavia is not "an exclusive system," is aimed solely at a possible recurrence of German aggression and is open to western nations willing to undertake similar obligations, Premier Klement Gottwald said today.

Another of the annual battles between the city and the Transport Workers Union, CIO, over wages, hours and working conditions of the 29,000 operating employes of the municipal transit system was in the making yesterday.

Emma Foos, German mezzosoprano, was heard in her first New York recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. With Paul Meyer at the piano, Miss Foos presented a program containing the arias, "Divinites du Styx," from Gluck's "Alceste," and "O Don Fatale," from Verdi's "Don Carlos;" Wagner's "Traeume" and "Schmerzen," and Lieder by Beethoven, Schubert, Schumann, Wolf, Cornelius and Strauss.

PARIS, May 4 -- The Communist Ministers were ousted from the Cabinet tonight and, for the first time since the war, France had a coalition Government of center parties excluding both the extreme Left and the extreme Right.
President Miguel Aleman of Mexico began his last full day in New York the way millions of New Yorkers begin theirs -- he took a subway ride.
CHICAGO, May 4 (AP) -- The post-war shrinkage of the Federal payroll has been offset in part by expanding state and local Government payrolls, a Civil Service Assembly survey showed today.

JERUSALEM, May 4 -- Zionist terrorists blasted open the ancient and formidable walls of Acre's central prison today, liberating 251 Jewish and Arab prisoners in one of the biggest jail breaks in history. Some of the eighty convicted terrorists imprisoned there escaped.

Our lookout man at the United States Department of Agriculture, who keeps us informed of developments in fresh produce, remarked the other day that he had seen more water cress in the city during the last six months than during the entire war.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Union leaders accepted and company officials today rejected a Government proposal to settle the wage dispute in the Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company with an average wage increase of $5.14 a week for the 20,000 long-distance workers.

NANKING, May 4 (AP) -- A series of Communist victories across North China from Shansi to Shantung was acknowledged by pro-Government sources tonight. This was coincident with the disclosure that Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek had made a secret trip to the front to rally his commanders.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 4 -- Well-informed political circles in Ankara report a large-scale reshuffle within the Turkish Foreign Ministry, "aiming to reinforce" Turkey's representation in Washington and the United Nations.

Increases in fire insurance rates that range up to 30 per cent, with an average rise of 8.7 per cent, will be effective today in New York State. The new rates affect twenty-five out of seventy-eight classes and sub-classes in New York City and twenty-nine out of 104 classes and sub-classes in the remainder of the state.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter appearing in your issue of April 19 Maurice Orbach declares that the problems of the world will not be solved by leveling charges and calling names. At the same time, he makes several serious charges against one of the great statesmen of today, Winston Churchill.
PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) -- The Phillies swept a double-header from the Reds today, 5 to 3 and 10 to 5, before a crowd of 18,522.
The first World Armenian Congress appealed yesterday to the United Nations for a settlement of Armenia's territorial claims against Turkey.

NEWARK, N.J., May 4 -- Eclipsing his triple triumph of yesterday, Skipper Schroeder of Summit, N.J., came back today to win four blue ribbons and dominate the junior horsemanship classes as the Newark Horse Show concluded its four-day run.

The French Communist party, by precipitating a Cabinet crisis that is ending the present Coalition Government, evidently plans to test Communist strength not only in France but in western Europe. The maneuver which brought this about was the refusal of the five Communist Ministers and all their deputies to support an Assembly vote of confidence in Premier Ramadier's program to stave off an inflationary spiral in wages and prices.

BERLIN, May 4 -- Removal of the barriers to personal contact between foreign and German business men and prompt exchange stabilization were urged today by fourteen leading American industrialists who have just completed a tour of the United States and British zones.

The Workmen's Circle Chorus, which was organized in 1915, gave its annual concert yesterday afternoon at Town Hall before an audience pf 1,300. Again It was led by Lazar Weiner, who is celebrating his fifteenth anniversary as conductor of the group.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 4 -- The key to Yugoslavia's five-year plan appears to be heavy industry, the basis of which is iron ore. A total of 613,000 tons was mined in 1939, most of it for export. According to official reports more than 100,000 tons of crude iron was produced here on the eve of the war.

BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, May 4 -- More than one-third of the Germans in the British zone have no respect for nationals in the local governments and no respect for property rights in times of shortage, according to a British survey made available today.

A couple of Tasmanian devils showed up at the Bronx Zoo yesterday, much to the discomfiture of other animals who had never read the zoological report that the creatures were not as terrifying as they sounded, nor as mean as they looked.

Advertising in all New York newspapers during April aggregated 12,263,735 lines, compared with 10,919,862 in the similar month of last year, or a gain of 12.31 per cent, according to a compilation of Media Records. All classifications showed gains except financial, which dropped 28.46 per cent.

By uninhibited use of the standby hedging transactions demonstrated last February in the United Air Lines financing, under-writers of a $2,286,800 issue of Pitney-Bowes, Inc., convertible preferred stock said last week that they were enabled to make a success of what otherwise would have been a marketing flop.

Cotton prices in the domestic market dropped rather sharply during the early part of last week, and they subsequently recovered only a part of their early losses. At the close on Saturday, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 44 to 107 points.
DETROIT, May 4 -- The Yankees waded through a miserable afternoon today to complete their 1947 debut at Briggs Stadium, and wound up with nothing more than a Mexican stand-off with the Tigers.

If charges filed in Nuremberg on Saturday are sustained the United States, through its chief prosecutor in Germany, Brig. Gen. Telford Taylor, will have brought to the bar the most sinister group of business men in all human history. These are the twentyfour top officials of the I.G. Farben industrie, once the most powerful chemical combine in the world.

ALBANY, May 4 (AP) -- The State Reserve Officers Association today elected Lieut. Col. Robert W. Parks of Binghamton, president, and adopted resolutions favoring universal military training and unification of the armed forces.

Alfred Hitchcock, the film director, will stage his first theatrical production in this country in the summer during the initial season of La Jolla (Calif.) Playhouse. Gregory Peck, one of five actors sponsoring the summer theatre, will star in the play, Patrick Hamilton's "Rope," which will be filmed in the fall.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- A billion-bushel crop of winter wheat is in sight for this year's harvest, by far the largest on record and 127,000,000 bushels in excess of last year's production, according to an estimate by a Chicago statistician. The average winter wheat crop for the 1936-45 period was 654,000,000 bushels, while production of both winter and spring wheat for the same period was 844,000,000 bushels.

Two items in the week-end news, one spectacular, one relatively minor, illustrate to what extent prejudice still stalks the world. A race riot took place in the Army disciplinary barracks at Fort Leavenworth. White and Negro prisoners had been segregated in different cell blocks.

An experimental program of visual education, for school children, through display of motion pictures in licensed neighborhood theatres in school hours, has been operating since Feb. 21, License Commissioner Benjamin Fielding reported yesterday.
OAKLAND, Calif., May 4 -- The war-time influx of Negroes to this side of the Bay Cities area has produced the same problems that are occupying students of the situation in San Francisco.
WARSAW, May 4 -- Shakespeare has been recruited by the Poles to support their ethnic, geographic and economic claims to the "regained territories" on the Oder and Niesse Rivers.

Stop watch chronometers, electric clocks and heavy jungle cloth trousers are among the consumer goods offered in the new sales program announced yesterday by Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director of the War Assets Administration.

French Line plans for the famous old liner Ile de France, which entered the St. Nazaire shipyards April 24 for long months of grooming preparatory to her return to commercial service early in 1948, contemplate a reduction in accommodations from the pre-war total of 1,600 passengers to 1,384, it was learned yesterday.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey will offer any of its facilities, knowledge and files to the United States Government to aid in the prosecution of the twenty-four top officials of I.G. Farbenindustrie of Germany, who have been indicted for fomenting and waging aggressive war, mass murders and plunder.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 -- Steel ingot production reflected last week the renewed emphasis on productivity and uninterrupted operations when the rate jumped 1 point to 96 per cent of capacity. Most major companies were operating close to capacity.

BATAVIA, Java, May 4 (U.P.) -- The Pasoendan party, claiming to represent 12,000,000 Sundanese, today proclaimed the independent state of West Java with its capital at Bandung and asked the Dutch for military protection in trade for the return of Dutch factories and plantations to their prewar owners, Bandung dispatches said.

MANILA, May 4 -- Three hundred Japanese war prisoners, including fifteen generals and a rear admiral, will be turned over for trial to the Philippines Government soon, posing a thorny legal and social problem.

In an analysis of the causes behind the general rise in prices, the National City Bank of New York has singled out as the primary cause the "tripling of the money supply as a result of the wartime expansion of bank deposits and currency in circulation.

JERUSALEM, May 4 -- To be ready for a possible appearance before the United Nations, David Ben-Gurion, Chairman of the Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, will depart by plane for New Tork tomorrow, the Agency announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee declared today that the Taft-Ellender-Wagner Housing Bill "will make possible the construction, of more housing, more quickly, at lower cost and, for more income groups than otherwise can be produced."

Retail stores last week reported that the new items arriving at attractive prices found ready consumer response, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading, resident buying offices. Incoming buyers, reports added, were busy finding desirable values and in some instances "close-outs" for promotional events while re-orders continued from many quarters for summer and sheer goods.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Consumer resistance to high prices for hog products continues in evidence, and the price of refined lard declined 2 1/4 cents a pound last week. Nevertheless, the market showed more stability late in the week than for some time past, suggesting to some brokers that the end of the almost straight decline had been reached.
HAVANA, May 4 -- Dr. Manuel Fernandez Supervielle, Mayor of Havana, committed suicide with a borrowed police revolver this morning in his home in the Miramar residential district.

The United States watches with anxiety the periodic flare-ups on the political fever chart of France. Our concern is prompted by two considerations. One is that France is the chief exemplar of free government on the European Continent; in the rises and falls of her temperature throbs the fluctuant pulse of democracy.
HARRISON, N.Y., May 4 -- A four-seat amphibian plane crashed this afternoon on the links of the Century Country Club here, killing the pilot and causing serious injuries to his two passengers.

CLEVELAND, May 4 (AP) -- The Senators pasted Bob Feller in the seventh inning today, punching across four runs for a 6-3 victory over the Indians and an abrupt halt to Bob's scoreless - inning string.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Whalers hauled oil-rich carcasses valued from $100,000,000 to $125,000,000 from waters around the South Pole during the December-April season, an official estimated tonight, but American whalers were not among them.
Acting with a perversity that may set a record of some sort, the weather yesterday for the third successive afternoon held baseball at a standstill in the metropolitan area.

The United Nations should adopt and implement a plan for the development and political control of Palestine during the present session of the General Assembly, a 133-page document submitted to the President of the Assembly and the delegations by The Nation Associates declares.

In his recent address in this city on price inflation, President Truman pointed out that government, as well as business, had certain responsibilities in combating the rising cost of living. However, when it came to particulars, he confined himself largely to voicing his opposition to a reduction in the income tax.
This time it is a "cake and white elephant sale" slated to be held tomorrow that has the parents of Brooklyn's Public School 241 up in arms.

NEWARK, N.J., May 4 -- A charter plane returning from the Kentucky Derby overshot the 7,000-foot runway at Newark Airport in the murk this afternoon and crashed into a covered sewage ditch on the edge of the field. All thirteen persons aboard were injured and removed to hospitals.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 -- That was a magnificent hoss race Col. Matt Winn staged at Churchill Downs yesterday, and the Kentucky hardboots who will argue at the drop of a hat -- especially a derby hat -- are embroiled in heated discussions. As you probably know by now, Jet Pilot, Phalanx and Faultless finished under a blanket (a very small blanket, too), and yet there is no clear-cut evidence of superiority.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank and president of the International Chamber of Commerce, made public over the week-end a report by a special committee of the latter organization urging that immediate steps be taken to enable Germany to achieve economic recovery and thus constitute less of a financial burden on the occupying powers.

A 5 per cent discount heretofore allowed employers on medical bills of $15 or more in workmen's compensation cases when paid within thirty days will be abolished as of June 1, it was announced in an order released yesterday by Miss Mary Donlon, chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board.

The current Palestine crisis is just as much a "Christian problem" as it is a Jewish one, the Rev. Dr. Charles T. Bridgeman, former canon of St. George's Cathedral, Jerusalem, said yesterday in a sermon at Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

Delegates to the international meeting on marine radio aids to navigation, who convened here last week, departed yesterday for New London, Conn., on the United States Maritime Service training ship American Sailor. The vessel left Pier 73, East River, at 7 A.M.
Employes of four city departments attended communion breakfasts yesterday in the midtown area.

Belmont Park will open its spring season today with the $20,000 added Toboggan Handicap occupying the feature spot. With many improvements made under the direction of the recently appointed general manager, Alex M. Robb, the Nassau County Park promises to enjoy one of its best sessions since it was founded in 1905.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -- United States Pictures, Warner Brothers' producing subsidiary, has borrowed Dane Clark from Warners for the leading male role, with Lilli Palmer, in "Ever the Beginning." Lionel Houser and Allen Boretz have written the scenario from an unproduced play by Lucille S. Prumbs and Sara B. Smith dealing with a woman of central Europe, who emigrates to the United States in 1905.

BERLIN, May 4 -- German-born employes of the United States Military Government will not be subject to automatic discharge when their contracts expire, according to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, military governor. General Clay flatly contradicted widely published reports to this effect in a conversation with this correspondent.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Liquidation was on in corn early last week on the Board of Trade, with May selling at $1.55 a bushel at one time, off 33 1/4 cents within a month. However, the market rallied later on buying induced by the failure of cash grain to be tendered on May contracts, and also buying of May against sales of July attributed to spreaders.
CHICAGO, May 4 (AP) -- The White Sox, current American League leaders, defeated the Athletics twice today, 8 to 7 and 1 to 0, for their second double-header sweep in two days.

ROME, May 4 (U.P.) -- Left Wing denunciation of American aid to Italy, new hints of the possibility of civil war and criticism of Government policy by Right Wing elements combined today to head Premier Alcide de Gasperi and his Cabinet toward a crisis.

About a year ago D.W. Brogan, Professor of Political Science at Cambridge University, was writing from London: "There is no question that the man in the British street is looking across the Atlantic with more doubt in his heart than he has known since 1939 and since he has a great deal to worry him besides, the doubt leads easily enough to irritation and sourness."

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., in a letter to Representative Paul W. Shafer, Republican, of Michigan, chairman of the subcommittee of the House Committee on Armed Services, went on record today as opposing the "blanket extension of export controls" as "both unnecessary and undesirable."

The failure in the last two weeks of several retail price-cutting drives to force down manufacturers' and farm prices on most cost-of-living items indicated last night that consumers would pay again full prices this week for many necessities.
A tomb for a soldier of World War II, of unknown identity and unknown nationality, may be erected in the future world capital of the United Nations as a spiritual symbol, it was learned yesterday.

The International Air Transport Association reports on the fine safety record of international airlines in its first compilation of world air transport statistics. During 1946 sixty member airlines of the association operating in all parts of the world, flew a total of 8,346,000,000 passenger miles, or enough to carry the whole population of Greater London to North Africa.

BOSTON, May 4 -- As the final event in a three-day "Symposium on Music Criticism" under the auspices of the Department of Music of Harvard University, Martha Graham and her company gave the world premiere here last evening of a dance work entitled "Night Journey," in the auditorium of the Cambridge High and Latin School.
The United Nations General Assembly will be asked to rule today whether the Jewish Agency for Palestine should be allowed to state its case before the Assembly's Political and Security Committee.

The United States Lanes has accepted delivery of twenty-five of forty C-2-type cargo vessels purchased from the Maritime Commission and the remaining fifteen vessels are expected to be turned over by September, it was disclosed in the company's annual report issued last week.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 4 -- Lockwood Barr, former managing editor of The Wall Street Journal and one-time public relations chief of the General Motors Corporation, is a man of many hobbies. One of the more original was proving so contagious today that self-appointed collaborators were aiding him from many parts of the world.

BOSTON, May 4 -- As the final event in a three-day "Symposium on Music Criticism" under the auspices of the Department of Music of Harvard University, Martha Graham and her company gave the world premiere here last evening of a dance work entitled "Night Journey," in the auditorium of the Cambridge High and Latin School.
The United Nations General Assembly will be asked to rule today whether the Jewish Agency for Palestine should be allowed to state its case before the Assembly's Political and Security Committee.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Two of three striking telephone unions in Illinois voted today to return to work tomorrow under the terms of an agreement reached Friday night which grants them a $4 weekly wage increase. The third and largest union, the Illinois Telephone Traffic Union, apparently had rejected the agreement.

Almost all the 37,000 striking employes of the New York Telephone Company in this city, Long Island and Westchester County are due back at their jobs today, ending a four-week tie-up and permitting restoration of normal local and suburban service.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Commenting on the economic crisis in Japan, a NEW YORK TIMES editorial of April 15 presents several misconceptions which could do a good deal of damage if they won widespread acceptance. That the editorial was only quoting General, MacArthur in substance makes this no less true.

Leaders of the Liberal party have asked Adolf A. Berle Jr., former Assistant Secretary of State and Ambassador to Brazil, to become State Chairman to succeed Dr. John L. Childs, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Berle has the invitation under serious advisement and is expected to accept.

TRENTON, N.J., May 4 -- Champion Twin Ponds Belle, a great little Welsh terrier owned by Mrs. Edward P. Alker of Great Neck, L.I., completed a perfect week-end today by taking best in show at the eighteenth annual event of the Trenton Kennel Club.

ST. LOUIS, May 4 (AP) -- Returning to Sportsman's Park, where they lost the world series to the Cardinals last fall, the Red Sox pounced on the Browns with a vengeance today, winning both games of a double-header, 3 to 2 and 8 to 1. The crowd of 25,735 was the largest of the season here.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 (AP) -- The parade to the Preakness began today -- with nine gee-gees packing their bags and heading for next week's $100,000 -- and one and all agreed it may be a different story for Derby winner Jet Pilot, if it doesn't rain.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Navy announced plans today to send a submarine around treacherous Cape Horn for the first time in its history.
Anticipating rigid controls of garages and parking lots within sixty days, operators have raised their rates again, it was learned yesterday.

In St. Patrick's Cathedral, where he was consecrated four years ago, the Most Rev. William T. McCarty celebrated a farewell pontifical mass yesterday before leaving for Rapid City, S.D., where he will be installed as Coadjutor Bishop on Thursday.

LONDON, May 4 -- Condemning the "disgraceful folly" of unofficial strikes, Attorney General Sir Hartley Shawcross warned today that a breakdown of the Labor party's Government would lead to totalitarianism. He said unofficial strikes undermined democracy.

NEW DELHI, India, May 4 (U.P.) -- Orthodox Brahmin priests and Sadhu ascetics squatted outside the residence of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru in relays today, waving their yellow flags marked with the sacred swastika of Hinduism, and chanting:

By reason of the importance of the automotive industry in our economy and its fabulous accomplishments of production in both war and peace, one is apt to forget how young it really is. We have grown so accustomed to the conveniences, economies of distribution and pleasures of being a nation awheel that we can hardly realize that the whole development of powered vehicles on the American roads goes back less than seventy-five years.

The Hapoel soccer team of Palestine, starting its good-will tour of the United States, made an impressive debut yesterday, defeating a selected professional eleven, 2 -- 0, before 43,177 persons at the Yankee Stadium.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A year ago, when the fight for continuation of OPA for another inflationary year was on, we heard a great deal about the flood of goods that would keep prices down if only price controls were removed.

PEIPING, China, May 3 (Delayed) -- The Chinese civil war was reported to be still growing in intensity today as Government forces battled Communist troops lodged firmly astride North China's three principal north-south railways.

More than 2,000 persons filled Temple Emanu-El yesterday afternoon at a special memorial service for Henry Monsky, international president of B'nai B'rith and chairman of the interim committee of the American Jewish Congress. Mr. Monsky died on Friday in the Hotel Biltmore at the age of 57, while attending a meeting of the future organization committee of the conference.

VIENNA, May 4 -- A political crisis resulting from the Big Four failure to write an Austrian treaty in Moscow is expected to develop next Tuesday and Wednesday. The first clash is expected to occur at the Socialist party caucus Tuesday and the second at the formal meeting of Parliament Wednesday when the Government will report on the Moscow session.

LONDON, May 4 -- Rarely if ever before has any currency forced itself as much on the attention of the British public as the United States dollar now is doing. Every newspaper and every periodical is commenting about it one way or another.

SEOUL, Korea, May 4 -- Reports reaching here of protracted exchanges of correspondence between Secretary of State Marshall and Foreign Minister Molotov are diminishing hopes for an early reconvening of the Joint United States-Soviet Commission for the settlement of Korean questions.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 -- The Allegheny-Ludlum Steel Corporation signed today with the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, what was reported here as the first agreement with a basic steel producer calling for a company-financed health and welfare insurance program.
Church memorial services were held yesterday by four organizations of war veterans.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 4 -- Speaking before 500 Vassar College alumnae at the final session of the first of five reunion week-ends, Miss C. Mildred Thompson, Dean of Vassar, urged college-educated women today "to put everything they've got" into getting America to take its place in the community of the world.

The modern trend to smaller bedrooms, with beds pushed into corners or alcoves, is apt to cost homemakers more energy and time in making beds, according to home economics students at Pratt Institute, Brooklyn. Results of their research and fatigue studies were released yesterday.

Retailers' reluctance to place orders well in advance of the season will mean a substantial dollar volume loss in both men's and boys' heavy outerwear departments, Jules Goldstein, eounsel and director of the National Heavy Outwear Association, warned yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 4 -- Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, Premier, admonished Egyptians tonight to cease their undue ultranationalism and to receive courteously all foreigners, regardless of race, nationality or creed.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 5 -- Finance Minister Pedro Luis Correa e Castro said today he Relieved Brazil bad passed the worst phases of inflation. Measures already in execution and others under study would avert any crisis, he stated in an interview.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 5 -- The revolutionary system of people's Courts in Czechoslovakia ended today. This became the first country in eastern Europe, from he Baltic to the Aegean Sea, to return to a normal system of judicial trial and procedure.

The United Nations General Assembly, holding its last full session at Flushing Meadow for the time being, instructed its Political and Security Committee yesterday to give the Jewish Agency for Palestine a hearing on the British proposal to establish a committee of inquiry into the Palestine question.

CLEVELAND, May 5 -- An "antidepression" program, keyed to a thirty-hour week and a guaranteed annual wage, was outlined today by Ralph Helstein, president, at the opening session of the Fourth Constitutional Convention of the United Packing-House Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Alfred Wallenstein, the third American conductor to receive the $1,000 Alice M. Ditson Award of Columbia University for distinguished services to American music, arrived in New York yesterday to conduct the NBC Symphony Orchestra in a series of concerts.

The "white elephant sale" to be held in Public School 241, President Street near Classon Avenue, Brooklyn, was defended vigorously by parents who will participate in it despite the criticisms of one of the founders of the Parents Association.

Arnold Hardy, an amateur photographer whose lens caught a woman plummeting to her death in the disastrous Winecoff Hotel fire in Atlanta, Ga., was announced yesterday as the winner of the Pulitzer Prize for the year's outstanding example of news photography. It is the first time a Pulitzer award has gone to an amateur.

Let's have a barbecued chicken for dinner tonight-bronzed from the spit, the skin crisped by heat the flesh moist with delicate juices, the whole permeated with that outdoor flavor that a barbecue always suggests.

A Fifth Avenue diamond merchant was knocked unconscious in his office yesterday by two men, who escaped with uncut diamonds and rings. The thugs overlooked diamonds valued at several thousand dollars secreted on the dealer's person.
GENEVA, May 5 -- Delegates from Russia, the Ukraine and White Russia warned the Economic Commission for Europe today against efforts to use economic aid to devastated areas for political ends.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor said today that William Green, president of the organization, had issued an "interpretation" of a union committee's decision aimed at settling the seven-month jurisdictional strike in Hollywood movie studios.

IT was a long time in coming and, when it happened, it didn't happen in the big leagues, unfortunately. But Tommy Bridges pitched himself a no-hitter not very long ago for the Portland Beavers out on the Pacific Coast. And baseball men the country over smiled with satisfaction and remarked delightedly, "I'm glad that Tommy finally made it."

PARIS, May 5 -- The next hurdle in the political crisis is tomorrow's special meeting of the Socialist party's National Council, which will be asked to back the action of Socialist Premier Paul Ramadier in dropping Communist Ministers from the Cabinet.

MOSCOW, May 5 -- Moscow's newspapers celebrated Press Day In the Soviet Union today with vigorous attacks on capitalist newspapers. Press Day is also the thirty-fifth anniversary of the founding of Pravda, official organ of the Communist party, in St. Petersburg [Leningrad].
CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) --Today's report of the livestock markets by the Department of Agriculture follows:

A shipload of 13,500,000 pounds of potatoes, marked for starvation relief in Germany, was unloaded yesterday in Jersey City after spoilage and rot had set in on the trip from Texas. The Army, it was learned, has sold the shipment to a domestic company, thereby drawing criticism from potato dealers who did not have a chance to make a salvage Bid.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- In its first vote on a regular appropriation bill since the Republicans gained control, the Senate approved tonight by voice vote $1,676,198,080 in appropriations for the Labor Department and Federal Security Agency for the next fiscal year.

A public hearing on the proposals to license and supervise garages and parking lots will open today in Police Headquarters. As fifty organizations and individuals have asked for time to defend or oppose the measure, it was held likely that the hearing will last through tomorrow.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- The plastics industry now is a billion-dollar-a-year business, it was declared here today on the eve of the opening of the tenth anniversary conference. It will be held by the Society of the Plastics Industry, and marked by the second national plastics exposition at the Coliseum.

The report of Paramount Pictures, Inc., for the fiscal year ended Jan. 4 is issued for publication today by Barney Balaban, president. It shows earnings of $44,042,106, after all charges, and includes $4,843,000 that represents the company's interest as a stockholder in the combined undistributed net earnings for the year of partly owned non - consolidated companies.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 -- A recommendation that the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, CIO, go on strike June 15 in the event no contract with shipowners was agreed on by then was made to the union's biennial convention at its opening session here today by Hugh Bryson, the president, on behalf of the national officers.

For the forty-fifth, consecutive year, the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Bailey Circus played host to the city's underprivileged children yesterday morning. Fourteen thousand poured into Madison Square Garden -- with the blessing of Mayor O'Dwyer -- from 200 schools, hospitals, orphanages and other institutions.

GENEVA, Switzerland, May 5 -- Yugoslavia and Albania bluntly informed the United Nations' Balkans Investigating Commission today that they would not permit its subsidiary group to enter their countries to investigate alleged interference in Greek affairs.
Mayor O'Dwyer appointed a committee of twelve shipping executives yesterday to serve in the development of the Port of New York.

DETROIT, May 5 -- The gradual return of Joe DiMaggio to hitting form and the impending debut of Yogi Berra as a catcher were the topics in the Yankee camp today when rain and the soggy conditions at Briggs Stadium postponed the scheduled clash with the Tigers.

No clearer exposition of the case for unification of the armed services of the United States has been made than that by Henry L. Stimson in his letter to Senator Gurney, published in this newspaper Sunday. Although twice a Secretary of War, Mr. Stimson's bona fides as a far-sighted American are too well established to make possible the charge of partisanship in his case.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Mme. Zoltan Tildy, wife of the President of Hungary, held a press conference today in Blair-Lee House, where she is a guest of the United States. Mme. Tildy spoke, through an interpreter, as a former newspaper woman herself.

The momentum generated last week by the stock market lost a considerable degree of its force yesterday, although interest held at a high level in the motors. Monting gains ranged as high as 3 3/3 points in Chrysler, but a leveling off of bidding shaded most extreme increases so that the composite rate only showed a rise of 0.25 point at the close.
Fur wraps and raincoats vied with mellowed tweed and gabardine classics where fashionable women gathered at the Belmont Park opening yesterday. The traditional fashion display was rained out.
AUGUSTA, Me., May 5 (AP) -- Maine, the birthplace of prohibition, took a step today toward return of the old "brass rail" bar.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, the Veterans Administrator, who soon must justify to Congressional committees an annual appropriation of $7,000,000,000 requested for the Veterans Administration, has informed his subordinates that the VA must sharpen the efficiency of its services.

New York millinery manufacturers will resist pressure of retail buying syndicates to get inside or preferential prices on women's headwear, Sam Finkelstein, executive administrator of the National Council of Millinery Associations, declared yesterday.

BUFFALO, May 5 -- Dr. Louis H. Bauer of Hempstead, L.I., president of the New York State Medical Society, called on the medical profession today to assume a militant leadership in guiding the public toward an improved and wider national health program.

JACKSON, Miss., May 5 (AP) -- The Mississippi Supreme Court, in absolving a Negro convicted in connection with a shooting last autumn, held today that a Sheriff making an arrest without a warrant must have good evidence that the person taken into custody was guilty.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior J.A. Krug told a Senate appropriations subcommittee today that House cuts in his department's budget would mean postponement of the development of more than 1,300,000 acres of irrigated land and 350,000 kilowatts of hydroelectric power.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 5 -- Objections to Westchester's parkway toll procedure and to the suggested sales taxes for school aid resulted today in a turbulent meeting of the County Board of Supervisors, which finally was adjourned in the evening.

STONINGTON ISLAND, Marguerite Bay, Antarctica, May 1 (delayed) -- We awoke this morning aboard the ship Port of Beaumont to see the initial freeze of the Antarctic winter beginning over the cove. Provided suitable weather conditions continue and there are no high winds, the ice should be strong enough to bear our weight in five days.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 6 -- Federal conciliators were pressing early this morning for a compromise to break the deadlock in the strike dispute involving the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Long Lines Department and the American Union of Telephone Workers.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 5 -- Attempts to set a trial date for thirty-one white men accused of lynching a Negro developed a legal contretemps here today. The county prosecutor took the witness stand to defend himself against charges that he had led defense counsel to believe that a postponement could be obtained at this term of the court.

BERLIN, May 5 -- The threatened resignation of Dr. Viktor Agartz, chairman of the Executive Committee for Economics of the fused occupatibn zones, has brought to focus a fundamental disagreement, on policy between the British and United States Military Governments.

Robert Casadesus, pianist, and Zino Francescatti, violinist, are virtuosos, each in his own right, but when they joined forces in a program of sonatas at the Town Hall last night they established an atmosphere that belongs with chamber music.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Legislation designed to clarify the status of newspapers and press services under the anti-trust laws was opposed by Thurman Arnold today as "class legislation which in effect endows them with the powers of private government."

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The House Appropriations Committee cut $162,893,515 more from Presdent Truman's budget today in a bill carrying funds for the State, Commerce and Justice Departments and the judiciary. The cut in the estimates was 23 per cent.
LONDON, May 5 -- Britain's great labor experiment with the five-day-week for coal mines got off to a bad start today.

Harold McLeod Turner, textile commission merchant and vice president of the cotton goods firm of Turner, Halsey Company, 40 Worth Street, died yesterday in the New York Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 65.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Over-subscription by 25.5 per cent of the 1947 Red Cross Fund Appeal for $60,000,000 was announced today by Harvey D. Gibson, national chairman of the campaign. He reported total contributions, to date, of $75,322,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The test of good labor relations legislation is whether it encourages peaceful settlement of difficulties by the employers and unions themselves, with due and responsible regard for the rights of individual employes, employers and the public.

The international travel exposition, in which major air, rail and ship lines and travel agencies of fifteen countries have exhibits, was opened to the public yesterday at the Grand Central Palace. It is expected that the colorful displays in the show will be seen by 200,000 persons before the exhibition closes Saturday night.

CONSTANTINE, Algeria, May 1 (Delayed) -- The permanent relationship between France and Algeria is expected to be established during the present National Assembly session, which will adopt the Statute of Algeria.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- The North American Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to distribute two and one-half shares of the Wisconsin Electric Power Company's $10-par-value common stock for each 100 shares of North American outstanding.
LONDON, May 5 -- Although week-end orders were not on a large scale the stock markets today generally were cheerful.

The N.Y.U. fencing team, undefeated in eight dual meets this season and newly crowned National Collegiate Athletic Association champions, will be facing one of its stiffest tests in many seasons in the international collegiate match with Havana in N.Y.U.'s East Building, 239 Greene Street, on Saturday.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 5 -- Ten workers who are threatened with loss of their jobs because they do not belong to a union, and who are unable to join the union because it is closed to all but sons of members, were denied a temporary injunction today restraining their employer from firing them because they were not union members.

A grant from the Kellogg Foundation of Michigan to advance a three-year program to develop and improve practical nursing was announced yesterday by Alias Hilda M. Torrop, R. N., president of the National Association for Practical Nurse Education.

BOSTON, May 5 -- Either a reduction of the national debt or a vast expansion in national wealth must be achieved if the savings in the banks of America are to be kept from "withering," Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank of New York, declared here today.

Return of many welfare services by the Federal Government to State and local authorities is revealing "dangerous tendencies," C. M. Bookman, chairman of the executive committee, Community Cheat of Cincinnati and Hamilton County, Ohio, said yesterday.

In an atmosphere clouded by new threats of controversy, the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly will meet at 11 A.M. today at Lake Success to name and instruct a committee of inquiry on the future government of Palestine.

India and other Asiatic countries have become afraid of the United States as a result of the proposed loan to Greece and Turkey, Sirdar J.J. Singh, president of the India League of America, declared here yesterday at its office, 40 East Forty-ninth Street.
VIENNA, May 5 (U.P.) -- A shouting, brick-heaving crowd of 5,000 milled for two hours in front of the Federal Chancellery today in a Communist-inspired hunger demonstration.
BOSTON, May 5 (AP) -- Leading at every pole, S.A. Weidman's Late Time, 6 -- 1, today won the featured six-furlong race by two and a quarter lengths over Mrs. C.J. Gamble's Hyhustle at Suffolk Downs.

Perhaps the reason that keeps the Pulitzer Prizes at the top of the list of various rewards for journalism and the arts is that they are so soundly and broadly based. This year the index is not inferior to the best tradition of the awards. They are given both to institutions and individuals.

The Bermuda honeymoon of Frederick J. Kirch, 37-year-old former Army captain, was interrupted over the week-end by Secret Service agents who returned him to New York by plane to face a charge of having raised a Government mustering-out pay check from $100 to $28,000.

ROME, May 5 (U.P.) -- Communist leaders, threatened by the likelihood that their attacks on Premier Alcide de Gasperi would bring a Cabinet overthrow that would eliminate them from the Government, shifted then tactics today.

Plans for using motion pictures for educational purposes in India were discussed yesterday by representatives of the motion-picture industry of India and American producers of documentary movies at the opening of the India Film Conference.

LONDON, May 5 (U.P.) -- Beautiful models in "practical" clothes and glittering gowns paraded along an s-shaped, flootlit runway today to display styles Britain is counting on to capture foreign, and especially American, currencies.

That musical by Betty Comden and Adolph Green, which they are creating for the firm of Paul Feigay and Oliver Smith, is beginning to shape up as a fall prospect. It now bears the title of "Gold Diggers of 1898," according to an announcement made yesterday, and Saul Chaplin has received the commission to compose the music.

A 500-pound safe stolen Saturday morning from Local 39 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, at 141 Dwight Street, Brooklyn, was recovered yesterday after one man probably was drowned and the police captured another man.

Just as man has achieved the age-long dream of flight, he can achieve the age-long dream of a peaceful, stable world, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower told members of the Wings Club at a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night.

MUNICH, Germany, May 5 -- In true democratic tradition, Dr. Wilhelm Hoegner, Deputy Minister President of Bavaria, as a representative of the civilian population, tonight held up a mirror to an American audience and cited several contributing factors behind the increasing restlessness of Germans under the occupation.

Chicago awarded an issue of $4,000,000 of water works revenue certificates of indebtedness due from 1951 to 1963 to a banking group headed by the First Boston Corporation at a bid of 100.05 for 1 3/4s yesterday. Other bids, for 2s, ranged from 102.64 to 101.43.

Mrs. Janet Kaufman, 37 years old, of 5401 Clarendon. Road, Brooklyn, was robbed of $13,000 to $25,000 worth of jewelry by two armed men who entered her bedroom about 9:30 A.M. yesterday. A third bandit, who remained in the kitchen, knocked out Mrs. Kaufman's maid when she struggled, hitting her on the head with the butt of his pistol.

Buzfuz, the Sunshine Stable's 5-year-old gelding, found conditions exactly to his liking at Belmont Park yesterday and splashed home to a decisive triumph in the Toboggan Handicap, the fixture that served as the feature of the opening day card.

The "Jackson 'Heights Plan" came to an end yesterday when retail merchants in the Queens community admitted that their three-day experiment in price-cutting had failed to force down manufacturers' and wholesalers' prices to a point where general markdowns for retail could continue.

CHICAGO, May 5 (U.P.) -- Fred Corcoran today was relieved of his job as tourney manager for the Professional Golfers Association and was named promotional director to open a publicity office for the group in New York immediately.

Initial fall buying commitments during the next four weeks will be conservative, ranging around 50 to 60 per cent of last year, it was reported here yesterday by executives of retail buying organizations. This will leave "open-to-buys" during the course of the season extremely heavy.
Sketches of the winners of the Pulitzer awards follow:

The State Department's cancellation of its touring exhibition of modern American paintings was protested last night at an "Artists Action Meeting" in the Hotel Capitol. The meeting was held under the joint sponsorship of Artists Equity, American Group, Artists League of America, the Audubon Society, the New York Society of Women Painters, the Serigraph Society, the Art Division of the Progressive Citizens of America and the Sculptors' Guild.

JERUSALEM, May 5 -- Terrorists expended sixteen lives to liberate only twenty-one Jewish prisoners yesterday when they blasted open Acre's Central Prison, a recount of casualties disclosed today. Meanwhile, British Army units and police patrols were making an intensive search for those who escaped and a thorough official inquiry into the mass prison break was undertaken.

MOSCOW, May 5 -- United States Secretary of State Marshall was charged here today with "distortion, evasion" and "misinforming the American public" in his radio address to the United States last Monday.

For the first time since 1941, members of society who attended the opening day program of the Westchester Racing Association's spring meeting at Belmont Park yesterday were able to have luncheon and tea in the historic Turf and Field Club.

Old-crop months, the May and July, 1947, deliveries, on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 33 to 34 points yesterday. New crop deliveries, or those from October onward, declined 10 to 23 points net.
The Inwood Country Club team of Long Island, Baltusrol of New Jersey and Century and Winged in Westchester are leading the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's newly organized interclub series.

ATLANTA, May 5 (AP) -- Miss Louise Suggs swept the 6.500-yard East Lake Country Club course today with a two-under-par 70 to take top honors in the qualifying round of the Southern women's golf tournament -- six strokes ahead of her nearest rivals.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Repudiation by Congress of the Truman Doctrine will be sought by opponents of the $400,000,000 bill to brace Greece and Turkey against communism, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Supreme Court, deciding an overtime pay suit against owners of a New York loft building, held unanimously today that hourly rate formulas in employe wage agreements must provide for "regular" hourly rates and for at least time and one-half for overtime.

Wholesalers are waiting for substantial reductions in heavy underwear before making fall commitments, according to Worth Street sources yesterday. Mill efforts to get goods moving have not been strong, it was learned, indicating that producers are watching all factors that might bring a break in prices.

United Gas Improvement Stockholders attending the annual meeting of the United Gas Improvement Company in Philadelphia yesterday heard W.W. Bodine, chairman of the executive committee, say that while sales and revenues of companies in the system "are holding up very well," expenses were up "all along the line."
DETROIT, May 5 -- A walkout or seventy-two plant protection men forced a shutdown today at the plant of the Hudson Motor Car Company and caused 8,000 production workers to be sent home.

ROME, May 5 -- The lira, which has been slipping rapidly in the last few weeks, dropped to a new low of 860 to the dollar on the free [black] market today. It came nearest to this figure last Dec. 2, when it reached 815 to the dollar, but it recovered shortly afterwards and was below 600 by the end of January.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The Virginian Railway Company contended today that any consolidation of the Chesapeake Ohio and the New York Central rail systems would adversely affect other carriers operating in the area between Chicago and the Eastern seaboard.

SEATTLE, May 5 (AP) -- Fifteen new records, seven of them the property of Miss Ann Curtis of San Francisco, were in the books today and Crystal Plunge of San Francisco owned the team crown in the women's national senior indoor A.A.U. swimming and diving championships.

Another of Manhattan's fast-dwindling surface-car lines will be motorized May 18, it was announced yesterday by Victor McQuistion, president of the Surface Transportation System. Buses will operate from Park Row to 190th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

LONDON, May 5 -- The Labor Government's bill for the nationalization of all inland transport passed its third reading in the House of Commons tonight. The bill now goes to the House of Lords, where it is expected to be much amended so Hit will have to come before the House of Commons again before becoming law.

The Organization of Rehabilitation through Training will undertake the vocational education of 30,000 displaced persons in camps in Germany, Austria and Italy during 1947, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Maurice Finkelstein, president of the Women's American ORT, at a luncheon given yesterday by the national board of the organization in the Stockholm Restaurant.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 5 -- Declaring that there can be no profit now in name-calling or crying over spilt milk, Charles G. Pyle of New York City, managing director of the National Electrical Wholesalers Association, warned today that the nation's economy stands at a cross-roads.

The port of New York must be modernized to eliminate existing delays and congestion, James A. Farrell Jr., newly elected president of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, declared here yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- May wheat and oats acted tight and prices ranged higher on the Board of Trade today. At no time was there any material pressure on the two grains, but professional sentiment was inclined to the bear side on the new crop deliveries of wheat owing to favorable weather and crop comments.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 5 -- The opening Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro tournament of the season brought out a total of sixty-one teams despite the inclement weather, and at the end three teams finished in a deadlock for top honors at 67, three strokes below par figures, at the Fresh Meadow Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Justice Henry A. Schweinhaut temporarily excused Secretary of State George C. Marshall today from appearing as a witness in the war fraud trial of former Representative Andrew J. May.

Maj. Gen. Thomas F. Farrell, chief engineer of the State Department of Public Works and a veteran of both World Wars, will become the new chairman of the New York City Housing Authority on July 1. Mayor O'Dwyer announced at City Hall yesterday.

The Central Railroad of New Jersey is trying deliberately to discourage short-haul commuter traffic to near-by points in northern New Jersey, William Wyer, chief executive officer of the railroad, declared yesterday.

Architecture awards for the best residential and non-residential construction in the United States in 1946 were presented last night to six winners at a dinner tendered by the magazine "Progressive Architecture," which was sponsored for the competition.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Ellis Island, first stopping place in America for thousands of immigrants, may be closed to save the Government $300,000 a year.

Atom Experts, All It is so easy to understand the atom, after Hiroshima and Nagasaki and Bikini; and yet so hard to understand. One of the reasons why it is so hard to understand the atom's significance today and in the immediate future is that we have had so many self-constituted expounders on the subject of whom not very many are technically or temperamentally qualified, to put it bluntly.

Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., author of the omnibus labor bill passed by the House of Representatives, described the measure yesterday as a "bill of rights" for the rank-and-file of the labor movement.

LONDON, May 5 -- The British Government has decided to ratify the Anglo-Polish financial agreement winding up Poland's wartime debts to Britain, Foreign Secretary Bevin announced in the House of Commons today.
