The Peirce Wire Recorder Corporation, producers of a new combined wire transcriber-recorder, in cooperation with twenty-nine dealers in selected cities, will break a newspaper campaign on behalf of the device in these areas in the next few weeks, Charles P. Peirce, president, disclosed in an interview in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Harold E. Stassen condemned President Truman's global communism-resistance policy today as a "negative" approach to world peace. However, he endorsed the component program of aiding Greece and Turkey because he said it represented bi-partisan foreign policy.

MONTREAL, May 5 -- The Soviet Union, which pressed in the United Nations General Assembly last fall to exclude Spain from the International Civil Aviation Organization, may find itself formally deprived of direct participation here when the first assembly of the permanent intergovernmental body of the air meets tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A 5-4 ruling by the Supreme Court today was vehemently denounced by the dissenters as effectively destroying the constitutional guarantee against unreasonable search and seizure in instances where persons are arrested in their home.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Secretary of State Marshall was reported by sources in the State Department to have received no encouragement today in his efforts to save its short-wave radio broadcasts and cultural activities abroad.

LOS ANGELES, May 5 -- Los Angeles civic circles are in an uproar tonight over the attempt of its harbor community of San Pedro to "secede" from the municipality and thereby, cause nominal loss to the city of the nation's fourth largest port.

The United States already has entered the much-heralded "recession," which actually amounts to nothing more than resumption of normal, competitive, pre - war economic conditions characteristic of a traditional buyers' market, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance, New York University, declared yesterday.

Local telephone service returned to normal yesterday for 9,000,000 persons in metropolitan New York as almost all of the 37,000 employes of the New York Telephone Company came back to work after a four-week strike.

New Yorkers have managed to carry many strange bundles through subways, but three boys with a bulging canvas bag and a pail looked suspicious to a transit policeman at 3 A.M. yesterday. His suspicions were well founded. The bag contained seventy pounds of pennies -- $112 worth -- and the boys had quite a story to tell.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 5 -- Commissioner Robert H. Freer of the Federal Trade Commission, declared today that the present high price level can be attributed to the influence of increased mergers of corporations, due to the concentration of many products into a comparatively few manufacturers' hands.

BOSTON, May 5 (AP) -- A bill to tax newspapers, radio stations and magazines was killed today by the Legislature's Rules Committee, the approval of which was necessary because the measure was introduced after the deadline for filing. Several representatives of publishers and broadcasters appeared before the committee in opposition to the proposal, terming it "unjust and discriminatory."
Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles, national women's tennis champion, and Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Cooke of New York, former title-holder, definitely left the amateur ranks yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5 -- The on-ano-off deal whereby Paramount mount take over Liberty Films, the William Wyler-George Stevens-Frank Capra-Samuel Briskin producing company, reportedly in return for $5,000,000 worth of Paramount common stock to be divided among the four partners, has been revived and will probably be closed this month, it was learned today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 5 -- President Miguel Aleman of Mexico today presented to the United States Military Academy a Mexican flag from the cadets of the Colegio Militar de Mexico and declared that the fondest hope of both the United States and Mexico was for "a state of peace with dignity which will justify the faith of all men in justice and enable civilization to enhance its heritage."

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, asserted today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had played "power politics with Wall Street in its assistance to almost a dozen bankrupt carriers" that, in consequence, "have been grossly, almost criminally, mismanaged."

BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP) -- The rain, Jet Pilot and four other contenders for the $100,000-added Preakness hit town together today while Trainer Tom Smith appeared confident that next Saturday's classic was in the bag -- rain or shine.

The first move' to celebrate a Golden Jubilee for Greater NewYork was made yesterday. The Jubilee will mark the fiftieth year since Manhattan, Bronx, the old city of Brooklyn and outlying towns and villages on Long Island and Staten Island were consolidated into the Greater City.

The Rev. Dr. Horace W.B. Donegan, rector of St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, was agreed upon yesterday afternoon by the most prominent leaders in both the high and the low church groups as their candidate for Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- A record increase of $8,600,000,000 in the inventories of American corporations during 1946 was reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission in its quarterly analysis of working capital. The increase boosted inventories to a new high of $35,300,000,000.
L.L. Sheets, formerly city manager for Eastern Air Lines in Philadelphia, has been appointed traffic and sales manager for the company in New York.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (U.P.) -- Communist penetration into virtually every, field of industry, in the United States is growing because for every party member there are ten sympathizers ready to do their work.

Sooner or later the sun will be shining over Flatbush. The Dodgers and their followers hope it will be the former, or, to be more specific, this afternoon. For today the Dodgers cross paths with the Cardinals for the first time this season, and, since everyone has been taking a crack at the world champions, Burt Shotton's league leaders would like to break into the act.

PIMLICO, Md., May 5 (AP) -- Mrs. E. duPont Weir's Christmastide and Eireann dominated the $5,000 Pimlico Breeders' Stakes today, the pair finishing a length apart and in the order named at the end of the dash of four and a half furlongs for 2-year-old fillies.

NANKING, May 5 (U.P.) -- Chinese Communist forces attacked Tolun, Manchuria, today and intensified their activities in north China and Manchuria. Government sources said the Communists were attempting to open a 1,000-mile corridor from north China to Harbin.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., May 5 -- Mrs. H. Townsend Bradley Martin, 36 years old, wife of the polo player and racing stable owner, died here early today of an overdose of sleeping pills at her home, Twelve Furlongs, on Wilton Road East. Dr. Joseph Sloane Bell, Ridgefield Medical Examiner, gave a verdict of suicide.

TOKYO, May 5 -- The Japanese Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida, which resigns tomorrow as a result of the last general elections, wrecked itself over its attempt to follow the Allied order requiring it to force grain collections from farmers, according to many political observers here.

QUEBEC, May 5 (AP) -- George S. Dudley secretary of the Canadian Amateur Hockey Association, said today at the association's thirtieth annual meeting that "it might be that We will not have a hockey team at the next Olympic Games." He did not elaborate.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with amazement that the office of the Alien Property Custodian and the Department of Justice are reported to have consummated a contract giving an American citizen, resident in New York City, the right to use the music of Giacomo Puccini for commercial purposes.

"Big Steel" Meeting The annual meeting of stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation in Hoboken yesterday produced two unusual developments. One was the starting of the meeting with a prayer by Joseph E.J. McGee, lay reader and verger of the Cathedral Church of Christ, Roxborough, Philadelphia.

New York would not be the city it is, for visitor or those who live here, without its electric lights. But there is a place for everything. We agree with Commissioner Moses and others who have been trying to build a site of dignity and beauty for the United Nations in eastern midtown Manhattan that commercial advertising display has no appropriate place in that picture.
The National Urban League will place increasing emphasis upon vocational guidance for Negro youth, the social work agency's annual report said yesterday.

Random notes. Despite the "inclement" (this term was the mildest used in the reports received) weather of the past week-end, quite a number of trout fishermen tried the Catskill streams, and a few of them took nice fish.

The United States will ask the special United Nations General Assembly to appoint a neutral committee of investigation for Palestine, without representation of the Big Five or the Arab League, it was reported yesterday.

TOKYO, May 5 -- A women showed less enthusiasm than men for the new Constitution, the newspaper Jiji Shimpo said today it would be quite understandable. Men received tea cigarettes and a special ration of sake (rice wine) on Saturday to celebrate the new charter Women got three cigarettes and no sake.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (U.P.) -- Plans to give Congress a closer check on the United States atomic energy program, nationally and before the United Nations, through special agents operating independently of other Government agencies, were revealed tonight.
A showing of brightly colored fashions by Hollywood designers was presented by Lane Bryant yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. Made of nonfading fabrics, the fashions were mostly casual in feeling.

LONDON, May 5 -- The British Industries Fair, which opened today in London and Birmingham for the first time since 1939, gives visible proof of Britain's desire to expand world trade generally, Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade, said tonight.

With a full-scale colonial war in progress in French Indo-China, something more than conciliatory statements by French High Commissioner Emile Bollaert and President Ho Chi Minh of the insurgent Viet Nam Republic is needed to bring an end to the fighting.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The latest Soviet press attack on the United States and its officials -- this time by Izyestia -- was comparatively mild by Russian newspaper standards. But it was not written with the restraint counseled by Generalissimo Stalin in his interview with ex-Governor Stassen when he observed:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 5 -- The United States is expected to propose that the United Nations send a commission to guarantee the good faith of the Greek Government in offering amnesty to guerrilla forces now hiding in the hills, it was learned today.

Information provided by the newspaper reporter's "receptivity and ceaseless quest" for it is as important to human relations as Dr. Albert Einstein's theory of relativity is to science, Carl W. Ackerman, dean of Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Prices of radios will not drop "to any appreciable extent," M.F. Darling, president of Local B-1031 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (AFL) predicted today in a monthly report to 16,000 radio un on stated that material costs and wage levels were up and apt to stay up for some time.

Tommy Quinn, Joe Nowicki, Roy Cochran and Ed Conwell have been selected by the Amateur Athletic Union to represent the United States in the Bank Holiday Games in London on May 24 and 26, it was announced yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris.
Burton Fuller, sitting yesterday as examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, urged the railroads carrying commuters to New York to study a uniform rate system.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The first maternal and child-health training course arranged under the Federal-State grants-in-aid programs will open this Summer at Harvard University. The Children's Bureau said today that this specialized training was one of several new ventures made possible by an added appropriation of $5,500,000 for maternal and childhealth services and $3,500,000 for services to crippled children.

The people of the United States have learned to abandon political isolationism but many still cling to economic isolationism, a form of international thinking that can lead to a world economic collapse and war instead of peace. Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, said last night.

BERLIN, May 6 - While the British and the Americans in Military Government agree on a "federal" governmental system as the best for Germany, their definitions of "federal" differ radically. This is one of the prime reasons why bi-zonal unity exists largely on paper for Germans and not at all for the Allies' personnel.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 6 -- Measures to blend the economies of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg have been adopted in all three countries, it was announced today.

The first large deal in imported copper by domestic consumers since the 4-cent-a-pound tariff was suspended by Congress in April was reported here yesterday, with the price believed to be 24 cents a pound, Connecticut Valley base. This price was described as the equivalent of the 23 3/4 cents set by the British Ministry of Supply for foreign-produced copper.

Rabbi Morris Max, executive vice president of the Rabbinical Council of America, said yesterday that a headline in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Thursday contradicted the spirit of a news story it covered concerning a resolution on labor the council adopted at a Detroit meeting.

During "Tribute to Women Week," that will begin on Sunday, Mother's Day, the New York Infirmary will start its spring drive for $5,000,000 for a new hospital to be built on York Avenue between Sixty-second and Sixty third Streets.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- American steamship companies asked Congress today to take Sown what they, termed "bureaucratic barriers" now blocking their participation in international air transportation.

Another large passenger vessel departed from New York in a prewar setting yesterday when the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania left Pier 90, North River, at 5 P.M. with 1,141 passengers for her first post-war commercial eastbound crossing.

Despite a hardening deadlock with Russia in the Atomic Energy Commission, the United States will press to obtain an international atomic control agency plan from the United Nations by September, when the next regular General Assembly meets here.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation in the first quarter of this year had estimated net earnings equal to about $1.90 a snare on the capital stock, E.T. Stannard, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting held here yesterday.

BALTIMORE, May 6 (AP) -- Another Preakness candidate stepped front and center today when Cedar Farm's Mityme -- pronounced "Mighty-Me" -- proved just that as he turned back the favorites to win the Survivor Stakes at Pimlico. Mityme, owned by John S. Bromley of Philadelphia, ran a brilliant race under the cool handling of Carson Kirk, and earned a shot at the $100,000-added Preakness Stakes Saturday.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- William G. Chandler of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, denied today that the purchase of paper mills by large publishers had deprived any newspapers of newsprint.

Trinity Church, Broadway at Wall Street, celebrated yesterday the 250th anniversary of its founding on May 6, 1697, with a special 12:30 P.M. service arranged for the downtown banking community. In the evening members of the New York Historical Society and their friends attended a preview of an exhibition of historical treasures of the church, held at the society's building at 170 Central Park West.

NEW DELHI, India, May 6 (London Times dispatch) -- For the first time since September, 1944, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, and Mohandas K. Gandhi, spiritual leader of the predominantly Hindu Congress party, conferred here this evening.

DETROIT, May 6 -- One authoritative stroke by Eddie Lake of Antioch, Calif., frustrated the Yankees at Briggs Stadium this chilly afternoon and sent Bucky Harris' troupe crashing to defeat at the hands of the Tigers, 3 to 2, before 12,652 hardy fans.

CHICAGO,May 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 8,500 head, total 12,000; market opened slow; later trade moderately active, unevenly 50 cents to $5 lower; mostly 50 to 75 cents off: top $23.T5; bulk of good

Two possibly troublesome questions arose yesterday in connection with Mayor O'Dwyer's choice of a new chairman for the New York City Housing Authority. One concerned the residential eligibility of the appointee, Maj. Gen. Thomas F. Farrell of Albany.

ALBANY, May 6 -- Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein issued an injunction today restraining the Albany Board of Education from interfering with a concert by Paul Robeson, Negro baritone, Friday night in the auditorium of the Philip Livingston Junior High School.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Senate crushed by sixty to seventeen today an effort to put aside the Taft omnibus labor bill for a ten-day armistice.

The Riverside Museum will present Canadian motion pictures at 8:15 o'clock this evening and tomorrow evening in connection with the exhibition of work by Canadian women artists. The film, in color and sound, is about the life and work of three artists -- Emily Carr, Tom Thomson and A.Y. Jackson.
Although many teachers are doing an inferior job, the answer to the question "Is College Teaching a Failure?" is emphatically "No," Dean Harry J. Carman of Columbia College said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (U.P.) -- A larger, faster and more luxurious "Sacred Cow" than his present private plane will be delivered to President Truman in midsummer in time for him to fly to Alaska and the Pacific Northwest.

Five hundred stockholders at the twenty-eighth annual meeting of the Radio Corporation of America in Radio City yesterday heard David Sarnoff, president, say that the annual dividend of 20 cents a share on the common stock might be increased "before long."

LONDON, May 6 -- The unofficial strike by winding engineers of the north of England's coalfields continued today. All other mine workers who yesterday began their long-sought privilege of a five-day week are so infuriated that probably for the first time in Britain's trade union history the miners are acting as strikebreakers.

PARIS, May 6 -- Considerable labor restlessness, which spread to customs guards at ports and frontiers, appeared today. Although seemingly uncoordinated, except in the metal trades, the incidence of strike movements gave the impression of an incipient labor offensive against the Government's wage-freezing policy.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A Government check-up shows 73 per cent of the soft coal tonnage mined by the United Mine Workers is ready to enter national wage negotiations, it was learned today, but dissenting Southern operators said that figure was too high.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 6 -- The resolution approved this evening by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations Assembly follows: The first committee resolves: (1) To grant a hearing to the Jewish Agency for Palestine and the Arab Higher Committee of Palestine;
The Parks Department has set out 2,100 trees on city-owned property so far this spring planting season, it was reported yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 6 -- That Czechoslovakia is occupied or controlled in any way by the Soviet Union is absolute nonsense. President Eduard Benes declared today in an interview with this correspondent.

EDDIE DYER now has seen every team in the National League, the soft-spoken and eternally pleasant manager of the Cardinals completing his study of the opposition at Ebbets Field yesterday. He's been considerably impressed by the general rise in the caliber of the play but is still convinced that there's nothing so wrong with his Redbirds that more rugged hitting and slightly better pitching can't cure.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The bill to authorize assistance to Greece and Turkey to ward off totalitarianism has been made more urgent by the recent meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, Secretary of State Marshall said today as the House of Representatives opened debate on the measure.

VIENNA, May 6 -- Vice Chancellor Adolf Schaerf offered to Russia today guarantees that western capital would be forced out of every significant position in the Austrian economy by nationalization and socialization.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 6 -- The battle over representation on the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine will begin here tomorrow. The General Assembly's Political Committee will be faced with a choice between excluding the Big Five or insisting that the major powers share responsibility for the investigation.
The "troublesome question" of licensing garages and parking lots was aired yesterday at a six-hour public hearing of the Mayor's Traffic Committee in Police Headquarters.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 6 -- As joint beneficiaries of the Truman doctrine, Turkey and Greece are strategically alike in facing pressure from the north, but their needs are vastly different.
PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) -- Trailing by one run going into the seventh inning, the Cubs jumped on Tommy Hughes and Schoolboy Rowe for two runs to defeat the Phillies, 3 -- 2, today.

A bill to revise the country's labor laws has been passed in the House by the decisive majority of 308-107. In the Senate a companion measure, somewhat more moderate in tone, has reached the stage of debate on the floor and is expected to come to a vote shortly.

Many business executives and consultants, interviewed recently in a survey of management and labor information about "featherbedding" in industry, expressed the conviction that "make-work" and "stretch-the-work" practices were widespread in most of the country's mass-production factories.

The Round-the-World Reconstruction Fund campaign of the Y.W.C.A. is well on the road to success, Mrs. Arthur Forrest Anderson, president of the national board, announced yesterday. She reported gifts of $1,904,612, or 90 per cent of the minimum goal of $2,100,000.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Extension of Government export controls beyond June 30 was urged today to insure capacity operations in United States flour mills during the 1947-48 crop year. Atherton Bean of Minneapolis, vice president of the International Milling Company, informed the Millers National Federation in convention here that heavy shipments of flour abroad would be assured, at least for the next year, if controls were continued.

Shipping containers are now available in better supply and some fiber drum manufacturers are now soliciting new business, promising deliveries on schedules better than pre-war quotations, industrial purchasing agents disclosed here yesterday.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., May 6 -- Ten infants were under treatment at Somerset Hospital here today for infectious diarrhea, which thus far has taken the lives of six other babies. Dr. Carl Weigele, medical assistant in the State Department of Health's division of maternal and child health conferred yesterday with staff physicians in an attempt to check the outbreak.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Russia has proposed, and the State Department has accepted, a plan for the exchange of five meteorologists in what may prove to be the beginning of a cultural exchange program of wide proportions, it was learned authoritatively today.

GENEVA, May 6 -- Tariff negotiations at the Geneva trade conference have reached an extremely delicate stage. As had been expected, the critical set of the negotiations has turned out to be a triangle of the United States, Britain and Australia.

ATLANTA, May 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill, N.C., defending champion, moved into the second round of the thirty-second annual Southern Women's golf tournament at East Lake Country Club today by beating Mrs. J.C. Wright of Atlanta, 9 and 7.

Sacred Picket Line As the city's telephone strikers went back to work day before yesterday, some of them, according to this newspaper's account, "avoided the eyes" of the picketers representing the long-line workers who remained on strike.

WASHINGTON, N.J., May 6 -- Two hundred pickets from labor unions marched outside the local Elks club this afternoon as Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., of Kearny, defended before the local Kiwanis and Rotary Clubs what he termed the "Hartley bill of rights for labor."

Twenty-five New York business men met yesterday to form the Business Men's Advisory Council for the George Junior Republic, a self-governing organization near Freeville, N.Y., for maladjusted youths. Plans were begun for a five-year $6,000,000 program to extend the facilities of the Republic.

CLEVELAND, May 6 -- Charging that the Republicans and Democrats offer to voters nothing more than a choice between tweedledum and tweedledee," the United Packinghouse Workers of America, CIO, broke today with both major parties.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 30: Increases of $181,000,000 in loans and $222,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted and a decrease of $139,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 6 -- Trial of thirty-one white men accused of lynching a Negro was set for May 12 by Judge J. Robert Martin Jr. today in a decision overruling all defense motions seeking delays, a severance of trial and even permission to withdraw from the case.

As Edwin A. Salmon disclosed yesterday that he would quit his post as chairman of the City Planning Commission on Sept. 1, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University announced that Mr. Salmon would become director of the New York UniversityBellevue Medical Center.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The way of the transgressor is a primrose path compared to that an economizer in Congress must tread, and Representative John Taber of Auburn, N.Y., provides the most prominent current illustration of that fact.

Buyers' Total Lower Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 849, against 1,149 in the previous week and 1,808 in the similar week last year, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, new United States representative on the United Nations Military Staff Committee, called yesterday for a mobile, compact and effective world police force ready to handle spot emergencies but not designed to wage war against a major power.

A banking group headed by Lazard Freres Co. won yesterday the award of bond issues of Cleveland, Ohio, aggregating $6,100,000 and maturing from Nov. 1, 1948, to Nov. 1, 1972. The high bid was 101.286 for interest of 1 3/4 per cent, a net interest cost of 1.654 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -- In a memorandum opinion the Securities and Exchange Commission today approved the Electric Bond and Share Company's proposal to sell 448,408 shares of common stock of the Carolina Power and Light Company at competitive bidding, including up to 25,000 shares which Bond.

A twenty-two page illustrated campaign brochure was released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute, disclosing that all forms of media will be used in its efforts to acquaint the public with the petroleum industry. It contains advertisements, radio commercials, suggested mailing pieces and other promotional matter.

Steamship companies are "not entirely blameless" for the congestion in this port, L.W. Byrne, chief of the port promotion bureau of the Port of New York Authority, asserted yesterday. Their poor timing in the scheduling of truck deliveries of cargo for export has contributed toward the present situation, he said.

Orgranized anti-semitism was less successful in 1946 than before the war because of greater resistance by potential recruits and positive counter action by an informed public, according to a survey by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai Brith that was made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Differences as to the propriety and relevancy of a question as to an individual's "real identity" brought on a clash today between two Republican members of the Senate Banking Committee.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady, 6 to 18 point net higher than the day before.

Practically all allotments of worsted and gabardine suits in men's fall clothing lines have been taken up by retailers, according to a survey of orders placed thus far for the new season. Caution is being shown on other types of garments, particularly woolens, for which retailers have little appetite.
BUFFALO, May 6 -- A new way of treating fibrositis, the inflammation of fibrous tissue, was reported today at the annual meeting of the New York State Medical Society.

Owners of passenger automobiles weighing more than 3,500 pounds and registered in New York City will be called upon to pay a use tax of $10 a year under local legislation introduced in the City Council yesterday with Mayor O'Dwyer's backing.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., May 6 -- Arthur Percy Fitt, son-inlaw and former associate of Dwight L. Moody, noted evangelist and founder of schools, died last night at Green Pastures, his home here. His age was 77.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- The Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that a discharged soldier returning to work for his former employer is entitled to the specific job he held before his war service, though the company organization may have changed and the income from the job greatly increased.

WINTER PARK, Fla., May 6 -- Mme. Louise Homer, noted contralto, who thrilled Metropolitan Opera audiences as Amneris in "Aida" and in other famous roles, died here this afternoon of a heart ailment at the age of 76. She had been in ill health since the death of her youngest daughter, Joy, on Oct. 23.

Symbols of Jewish culture through the ages, with particular emphasis on them of the Torah -- the Five Books of Moses -- and the Ten Commandments marked a preview last night of the Jewish Museum's first exhibit.

CHATTANOOGA, May 6 -- President Miguel Aleman of Mexico spent today studying dams and steam electric generating plants of the Tennessee Valley Authority's system. He explained his intense interest in the project by saying, "In Mexico we have a similar problem to the one you had here before TVA."

JERUSALEM, May 6 -- A few of the Arab prisoners liberated Sunday when terrorists blew open the Acre Central Prison were straggling back to captivity today, but according to the latest official count, 166 Arabs were still at large and twenty-one Jews seemed to have made a clean getaway.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Joseph M. Dodge, Detroit banker and former financial adviser to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, American Military Governor in Germany, was appointed today to head the American delegation to the four-power commission that will meet in Vienna next Monday in an effort to adjust differences among the Big Four over the Austrian peace treaty.
GENEVA, May 6 -- The Economic Commission for Europe ran into its first real trouble today over the future of the joint effort to solve Europe's post-war internal transportation problem.

CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) -- The Athletics used a combination of Bill Dietrich's air-tight pitching and Bingo Binks' potent hitting to beat the White Sox today, 3 -- 0. The loss smashed the American League leaders' four-game winning streak.

Because of lack of dollar credits in the United States, a substantial backlog of industrial construction in foreign countries is being created, according to O.F. Sieder, executive vice president and general manager of the H.K. Ferguson Company, industrial engineers and builders.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In reporting my address before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee yesterday, in THE TIMES, The United Press correspondent made it appear that in the questioning after my address, Senator Tom Connally charged that I had at one time "advised" the late Benito Mussolini, and that I had admitted that I had communicated with the dictator.

The local joint executive board representing 60,000 hotel and restaurant workers in Manhattan and the Bronx has obtained a Supreme Court order restraining its parent union from appointing a trustee to run the local group and reorganize its affairs, it became known last night.

The 100th anniversary of the chartering of City College will be celebrated today with a morning convocation, a reception and luncheon for 175 delegates from universities throughout the world. Special afternoon events will also be held.
Cooperation on the tenth annual campaign of the Greater New York Fund was planned yesterday by leaders in the financial district at a luncheon in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

More than seventy-five representatives of fifteen national business associations interested in management of business offices met yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria to establish committees for developing the first nation-wide voluntary standards for 25,000 items of office equipment and supplies.

It would be pleasant to live in the world envisioned by the Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives when it eliminated from the budget the funds for the State Department foreign cultural relations program, including the "Voice of America" broadcasts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6 -- Warner Brothers today announced the purchase of screen rights to "The Two Worlds of Johnny Truro," a novel by George Sklar published last February. The studio would not disclose the price paid for the property, but Henry Blankey was named as the producer of the screen version.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- The second national plastics exposition opened here today with some disclosures of new developments in the field, and a statement of its growth in production capacity and invested capital.

New furniture and serving accessories to enhance outdoor dining were put to practical use yesterday during a garden party given by Designed for Living, 131 East Fifty-seventh Street. Green wrought iron sofas with high spring cushions, plus wrought iron tables and chairs in which the metal was curved to form simple frames, served as background.

BERLIN, May 6 -- Maj. Gen. William H. Draper, economics adviser for Gen. Lucius D. Clay, disclosed today an American proposal at the Moscow conference to declare a moratorium on foreign investments in Germany. The proposal, he said, was turned down by Foreign Minister Molotov because "it would have brought the Soviet A.G. under discussion."
Britain's shipbuilding prospects are bright despite a recent slight recession in that industry, Sir Thomas Brocklebank, deputy chairman of Cunard White Star, Ltd., declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter from President Truman to Secretary of State Marshall on the peace treaties being considered by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee: My Dear Mr. Secretary: Since your return, you and I have carefully canvassed the existing situation regarding the ratification of the Italian and the three satellite treaties now pending before the Senate.

LONDON, Ont., May 6 (AP) -- Miss Barbara Ann Scott, world figure skating champion, said today that Sydney Dawes of the Canadian Olympic Committee had notified her that she would have to give up the car her native Ottawa gave her as a gift if she wanted to be a member of the Canadian Olympic team in 1948.

BOSTON, May 6 (AP) -- Johnny Sain pitched a masterful four-hit shut-out tonight as the Braves trounced the Pirates, 6-0, before 29,631 fans in the first night game of the major league baseball season. The Boston victory was scored over Kirby Higbe, who made his first start since Pittsburgh acquired him from the Dodgers last Saturday.
Running its undefeated string to nine games, New York University's baseball team beat Kings Point, 7-1, yesterday at Ohio Field, in a non-Conference clash.

An underwriting syndicate of thirty-eight investment houses headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will place on the market today a new issue of $15,000,000 of Cudahy Packing Company first mortgage 2 5/8 per cent bonds, due May 1, 1967.

LONDON, May 6 -- Britain served notice today on her creditors that she refused to take on "fantastic commitments" of war debts amounting "nominally" to more than u3,000,000,000 and insisted, that this "unreal, unjust and unsupportable burden" must be "very substantially scaled down."

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A difference of 78 cents a week separates negotiators seeking to wind up the long-lines strike of American Telephone and Telegraph Company employes. Announcement to this effect was made by Federal Conciliators Peter J. Manno and William N. Margolis as a session of the negotiators recessed just before midnight.

LONDON, May 6 -- Britain is a nation slowly dying of starvation, Dr. Franklin Bicknell, member of the Royal College of Physicians and noted nutritionist, asserted today in an article in The Medical Press, one of the major organs of the medical profession.

Mayor O'Dwyer paid high tribute at City Hall yesterday to Bernard Baruch as he gave the elder statesman the annual award of the Metropolitan Conference of Temple Brotherhoods for outstanding public service.
LONDON, May 6 -- Queen Mary, the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester, the Duchess of Kent and the Princess Royal today toured the Earl's Court Exhibition branch of the British Industries Fair.
Coming together for the first time this year at Ebbets Field yesterday, the first-place Dodgers am last-place Cardinals drew farther apart than ever.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Fleet Admiral Ernest J. King opposed today before the Senate Armed Services Committee the Administration's program for unification of the Army and Navy and proposed a plan or his own in which a National Security Council with the President as ex-officio chairman would control the country's armed forces.

Walter P. Chrysler's dark bay Caltha, a daughter of Bahram, won yesterday's $11,275 Fashion Stakes at Belmont Park, but it was a Maine Chance Farm aptly named colt, Royal Blood, about whom, the majority of the 23,883 racing fans present were raving.
WARSAW, May 6 -- The United States, Britain and France asked the Polish Government today to investigate the source of the gold that Portugal is scheduled to pay for Polish coal.

A small group of interested sportsmen and conservationists attended the conference and open forum conducted by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service at the Hotel Shelton yesterday. Albert M. Day, director of the service, and other officials outlined the present waterfowl situation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: David N. Fields' letter in your issue of April 28 is obviously well meant and like much of the current thinking by dilettantes in public affairs, assumes that dollars alone will cure anything, including the mental health situation over the nation.

The stock market suffered a severe sinking spell yesterday but a partial come-back in the late trading reduced extreme losses of 3 points by two-thirds. While it vas the widest sell-off since midApril, the halt in the recovery failed to attract heavy liquidation.

Increasing responsibility for the actual bedside care of chronic "patients must be assumed by practical nurses, Dr. A.P. Merrill, superintendent of St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases, declared yesterday.

STUTTGART, Germany, May 6 -- A consolidation of the bi-zonal agencies now administering the combined British and American zones from six different headquarters, will probably develop as a result of conferences now in progress, Gen. Lucius D. Clay disclosed today. The likeliest candidate among the communities capable of absorbing their 6,000 to 7,000 employes, he added, is Frankfort on the Main.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Navies of the future may fight their battles in the era of atomic warfare with ships so changed in design that not a man will be in sight at battle stations, W. John Kenney, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, predicted in a speech here today.

The facts brought out in the Supreme Court decision in Mineola, L.I., which, involved a closed shop and a closed union should be required reading for anybody who wonders why Congress is determined to reform the labor laws. The Rockaway News Company of Valley Stream, distributors of newspapers, has a closed shop agreement with the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 6 -- Law was divorced from politics in Czechoslovakia today. The decrees under which summary justice had been meted out for the past two years by people's courts and national courts expired last midnight. Reviewing the application of this "retribution law," as it was called, Czechoslovakia was of two minds about its merits.
VENICE, May 6 (AP) -- Field Marshall Albert Kesselring, who directed the German retreat in Italy in 1944, was sentenced by a British Military Court today to be shot for war crimes.

MOSCOW, May 6 -- Izvestia, Soviet Government newspaper, charged today that there were airdromes and radio stations in Turkey staffed by United States and British officers and "practically inaccessible" to the Turks.
Under a steadily clearing sky, the Outdoor Cleanliness Association held its fourteenth annual flower mart yesterday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Pounding six pitchers for twelve hits and aided no little by amateurish fielding efforts of the Giants, the Reds opened a three-day stand at the Polo Grounds with an 11-to-6 victory yesterday.

DETROIT, May 6 -- It appears evident that retailers have succeeded in stopping the upward movement of prices and from this point it should be possible gradually to bring about a reduction, Lew Hahn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said today at a meeting here of the Retail Merchants Association of this city.

Federated fund raising, the "communization" of fund drives, is "unsound and un-American and spells ruination for all private health and welfare activities," Basil O'Connor, chairman, central committee, American Red Cross, and president, National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 6 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly decided today to give a hearing to the Arab Higher Committee, as well as to the Jewish Agency for Palestine, on the British proposal that the Assembly establish a committee of inquiry on the Holy Land.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 6 -- The course that will be pursued by the Arab Higher Committee of Palestine and the Jewish Agency for Palestine became a matter of conjecture tonight as the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly extended a formal invitation to both to be heard on the future government of the Holy Land.
PARIS, Wednesday, May 7 -- Premier Paul Ramadier's decision of Sunday to drop Communists from his Cabinet was upheld by the Socialists' National Council in a close vote early today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -- The Tucker Corporation of Chicago, organized last July to produce a "radically different" rear-engine passenger automobile, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 4,000,000 shares of $1 par value, Class A common stock.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (U.P.) -- Government attorneys sent a parade of high-ranking, active and retired Army officers to the witness stand in Federal court today and got testimony from one that former Representative Andrew J. May interceded with the War Department in an effort to get "a nice big contract" for the Garsson munitions combine.

LONDON, May 6 -- Brazilian rail stocks again fell sharply in the stock markets today because definite information is lacking regarding take-over prospects. All-round losses of as much as 5 points were recorded. Elsewhere conditions were quiet.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Corn futures showed a strong undertone on the Board of Trade today as the result of aggressive buying combined with reports of the cash article tightening up. Wheat after, being firm early turned downward in the late trading.

NANKING, May 6 (U.P.) -- The Chinese Communists' campaign to open a 1,000-mile corridor between Harbin, Manchuria, and North China gained momentum today when they captured five more towns in Shansi, a Government military communique reported.

Lippy Leo Durocher returned to Brooklyn yesterday for the first time since Commissioner A. B. (Happy) Chandler banned him from the game for this season, and said he had "never been happier" than he has been during that suspension. He also said he had every intention of resuming his managerial post with the Dodgers when the suspension is over.

When George White, whose fame as a showman rests on his glittering series of "Scandals" revues, is released Saturday morning from a San Diego (Calif.) County prison camp after serving eight months and sixteen days on a hit-and-run charge of killing a newlywed couple, he will have a pretty good outline of what his next "Scandals" is to be.

MADRID, May 6 (U.P.) -- Twentyfive thousand Basque workers in Bilbao defied Generalissimo Francisco Franco's ironclad no-strike law today at the risk of imprisonment and extended their general strike into the second day.

ST. LOUIS, May 6 (AP) -- Ted Williams and Jeff Heath showed off their home-run swings today but Williams had the advantage as the Red Sox topped the Browns by 6 to 5 in an eleven-inning contest in which big Ted scored the tying and winning runs.
Food writers lunched yesterday it the Astor Hotel with about 175 members of the American Spice Trade Association, who today wind up the organization's forty-first annual three-day convention.

BOSTON, May 6 -- United States loans to Greece and Turkey are "non-economic" operations and not the type the new World Bank will handle, Robert L. Garner, vice president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, told the nation's mutual savings banks executives today at their twenty-seventh annual convention in the Statler Hotel.

Mayor O'Dwyer has made an excellent appointment in selecting Maj. Gen. Thomas F. Farrell to be the first paid chairman of the New York City Housing Authority. General Farrell on taking office July 1 will have behind him a broad experience in engineering, in construction and in getting big things done without undue delay.

Broadcasting will be more sharply supervised and controlled by the Government as the industry continues to grow in importance as a necessity in everyday life, former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia asserted yesterday at a meeting of District 2 of the National Association of Broadcasters in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MONTREAL, May 6 -- The first permanent assembly of the International Civil Aviation Organization, meeting here today, acclaimed substantial accomplishments in the technical and economic fields, but viewed seriously two political problems laid in its lap.

The fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Compagnie Maritime Belge, S.A. (Belgian Line) was marked last night by the staff of the Atlantic Overseas Corporation, 10 Pearl Street, general agents in this country for the line, at a gathering in the Hotel St. Regis.

Ninety-five hundred striking long-distance telephone workers in this city will not cross Western electric picket lines even if Washington conferences bring a settlement of their own month-old walking. George S. Myerscough, chairman of the central strike committee for the metropolitan district, asserted last night.

CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) - -A reduction in minimum initial margin requirements, except for May contracts, was announced today by the directors of the Chicago Board of Trade, who set wheat margins at 30 cents a bushel, corn at 18 cents and oats at 12 cents.

GWYN THOMAS, like Richard Llewellyn of "How Green Was My Valley" fame, is a Welshman who knows the mines and miners of South Wales like the back of his hand. Both men are blessed with a fine Celtic ear for the odd rhythms and curious twists which the English language takes in Wales. But Mr. Thomas, in spite of his obvious literary gifts, is not yet the novelist that Mr. Llewellyn is.

In the face of a shortage reported more acute than it was a year ago, and with Manhattan estimated to be able to absorb 75,000 to 100,000 new apartments, builders and housing investors in this borough have gone on a "buyer's strike."

ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 -- The 1,500 members of the National Electrical Wholesalers Association today turned their attention to technical discussions of the group's four-point program to sell 50 per cent more goods and services than before the war.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Truman, Secretary of State Marshall and James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, urged on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today immediate ratification of the peace treaties with Italy, Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania.

The National Institute of Arts and Letters, through a handwriting expert, has traced to one of its members the unauthorized mailing in the institute's name of "antiSemitic propaganda of a virulent and scurrilous nature," Douglas Moore, president, announced yesterday.
BUFFALO, May 6 (AP) -- Dr. Edward R. Baldwin was listed among 400 physicians to be honored tomorrow night by the New York State Medical Society for having practiced fifty years or more.

The Graham-Paige Motors Corporation reported yesterday a net loss of 54,364,568 for 1946 in contrast with a profit of $1,030,571 in the preceding year, but estimated also that income before taxes for the first quarter of 1947 will be about $372,500.

Jerry Brown registered his third straight mound success in hurling St. John's University to a 12-3 victory over Manhattan's nine yesterday at Dexter Park. Brown also excelled on the offense, getting a pair of safeties in three chances and scoring twice.

BOSTON, May 7--President Truman and Congress were urged to "double their efforts to reduce expenditures drastically so that substantial debt and tax reduction will be possible" in a resolution adopted today by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks at the close of a three-day conference here.
PARIS, May 7--The Radicals decided today to continue their support of Premier Paul Ramadier's new center Government despite their misgivings over its rigid economic controls.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The State Department is preparing to take over administration of occupied areas from the War Department, according to indications by Secretary of State Marshall at a news conference today.

Some of the patrons of Trefner's Restaurant, 619 Lexington Avenue, at Fifty-third Street, have been going there regularly ever since the place was established nineteen years ago. Though the cheerful, home-like atmosphere is one of the nice things about the establishment, it's the moderate price of the food that is the big attraction.

Dean Hughell E. W. Fosbroke of General Theological Seminary, an Episcopal institution at Ninth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, was guest of honor last night at a dinner at the seminary. A chapel service of thanksgiving for his thirty years' service, which will end with his retirement at the end of the present school year, preceded the dinner.

FRANKFURT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 7 (U.P)--Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, pictured today in a VE-Day anniversary message a new Germany led to democracy by its youth and aided by young American soldiers.

LONDON, May 7--From two important sources in Britain today came statements emphasizing the economic aspect of the new United States foreign policy, combined with heavily veiled but transparent hints that this American "lendlease in peace" might in the future mean aid to Britain.
MEXICO CITY, May 7--As a symbol of the greatest prestige ever attained by this country, President Aleman returned tonight from, his visit to the United States.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined an additional 355,000 barrels, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they amounted to 103,505,000 barrels, compared with 103,860,000 at the close of the preceding week and 98,196,000 on May 4, 1946.

Although the salt water fishing has been rather late in getting under way this season, the pollock are now off Montauk in fair numbers, striped bass have made an appearance in Shinnecock Bay and weakfish are showing in both Shinnecock and Gardner's Bays.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Mayor O'Dwyer directed John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, yesterday to make an immediate inquiry into charges that policemen were accepting money to permit garage operators to park automobiles in the streets overnight.

"The Mother of Us All," an opera in three acts with a text by Gertrude Stein and music by Virgil Thomson, received its premiere last night in Brander Matthews Hall, the Columbia Theatre Associates putting on the performance in cooperation with the music department of the university.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 7--By a vote of three to two, the Supreme Electoral Tribunal tonight outlawed the Brazilian Communist party.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- The Veterans Administration figures the hardiest veteran of the first world war will live 48 more years, and gives the healthiest participant in World War II another 83 years.
WASHINGTON, May 7--The House, after two days of debate, squared off tonight for its decision on the bill to authorize $400,000,000 of American aid to Greece and Turkey to ward off totalitarianism.

CHICAGO, May 7--The plastic industry received today advice on what it ought to do for its own good, mingled with praise for the control it has exercised over its own pricing and its product standards.

Two years ago today the greatest and most devastating war that has ever torn the Western World apart came to an end with the unconditional surrender of Germany. War in the Far East was to continue for three more months, and some of the fires it lit are still smoldering.

CINCINNATI, May 7--City planning in New York "has been one of the best-kept secrets of our time," C. McKim Norton, executive vice president of the New York Regional Plan Association, told the American Society of Planning Officials here today.

The stock market drifted narrowly yesterday and into a stagnant condition with further emphasis on the lower side. Only a few scattered issues showed major changes and the composite rate declined 0.34 point on the day. Activity increased in the late trading, but the turnover on the Stock Exchange was only 600,000 shares, one of the smallest this year.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- Oswald Ryan, vice chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said today that the board still believed that development of air transportation "independent of other transportation interests is a sound policy and should not be abandoned."

Letters are now being sent to 5,000 former Waves in the Third Naval District as the first step in a campaign to enlist them as members of the Inactive Reserve, Lieut. Comdr. Laura C. Geddes, district director of Wave personnel, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 7--Officers of the International Typographical Union (AFL) defended the so called make-work rules and apprenticeship practices of their craft before a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Small Business Problems today.

ST. LOUIS, May 7 (AP)--Dick Fowler's tight pitching and a tworun homer by Hank Majeski helped the Athletics vacate last place by defeating the Browns, 6 to 1, tonight in the American League's first night game of the season. St. Louis fell into the cellar.

WESTPORT, Conn., May 7-- Seeking a master plan for the community that will preserve its "rural character," citizens of this town had their first glimpse tonight at preliminary proposals for a shopping center, community and civic center, planned zoning and adequate recreation facilities.

Musicians employed in the key stations of the four principal radio networks in this city will receive wage increases ranging from 16 to 28 per cent under the terms of a contract reached late yesterday afternooon by representatives of the networks and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL.
City College regained undisputed possession of second place in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference by defeating Brooklyn College, 13--6, yesterday before 500 fans at Lewisohn Stadium.

The Clarence Derwent Awards for the best supporting performances by an actress and actor during the current season have gone to Margaret Phillips and Tom Ewell. The former was adjudged the best actress for her performance as Birdie Bagtry in "Another Part of the Forest," while Mr. Ewell won the honor for his portrayal of the marrying GI in the comedy, "John Loves Mary."

Normal operations in a large segment of the garment market can be resumed only upon liquidation of the large surplus of soft woolens at their true value, Leo C. Safir, president of the Safir Plan, Inc., manufacturers of bathrobes, declared yesterday.

The Nathan M. Ohrbach collection of Painting's of Contemporary New York will be shown at the Museum of the City of New York beginning today when a private preview for members will be held. The exhibition includes more than sixty oils, water-colors and drawings by ten American artists.

Record department store sales last year were 23 per cent above those for 1945, while the number of transactions rose 8 per cent, according to the Departmental Merchandising and Operating Results Report to be issued within the next few days by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, May 7--A special mission of Government experts will fly from Washington to Tokyo tomorrow to study vital factors in the economic condition of Japan, the War Department announced here today. Included in the group will be representatives of the State, War, Treasury and Commerce Departments and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the United States Commercial Company.

Mayor O'Dwyer faced last night, for the fourth time since he took office on Jan. 1, 1946, a potential crisis based upon the demands of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, for improved labor relations for the 29,000 operating employes of the city's unified transit system.
PARIS, May 6 (Delayed)--His Paris garden on a May afternoon was the charming setting for Jacques Fath's picturesque collection.

Despite the criticism leveled at parents today, mothers are keenly aware of their parental responsibilities. This was the verdict reached yesterday at the Children's Aid Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street, by judges of a Mother's Day contest conducted among mothers' clubs in its seven children's centers.
KANSAS CITY, May 7--President Miguel Aleman of Mexico received a Colorful welcome from this city today as well as an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from the University of Kansas City.

LONDON, May 7--Great Britain faces a food crisis as critical as the coal shortage that crippled her industrial power last winter, Lord Woolton, Minister of Food in the wartime coalition Government, warned in the House of Lords today.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The Senate rejected today a stiffening amendment to the Taft omnibus labor bill which would have struck hard at the power of national unions by restricting industry-wide bargaining. Forty-four Senators voted against the amendment and forty-three for it.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 7 -- Battering two of the three Columbia pitchers for fifteen hits and capitalizing on five errors, the defending championship Yale nine gained its second Eastern League triumph in two starts by overwhelming the Lions, 15--3, today.

BOSTON, May 7 (AP)--Rookie Earl Torgeson's eighth Inning homer, his fourth of the season, gave the Braves a 3-2 victory, over the Pirates tonight before a chilled crowd of 11,175. Manager Billy Herman, who was chased by Umpire Artie Gore in the ninth, held down first base for Pittsburgh as Hank Greenberg nursed an ailing right elbow.

CHICAGO, May 7--Increased passenger rates to and from the Pacific Coast on Western railroads, which have been approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission, were announced today by Hugh W. Siddall, chairman of the Trans - Continental - Western Passenger Associations.

BOSTON, May 7--About 800 textile operators were thrown out of work without warning yesterday afternoon when the mills of the Cocheco Woolen Manufacturing Company at East Rochester, N. H., and the Gonic Manufacturing Company in the Gonic section announced that they were closing at once for an indefinite period.

The American Writers Association, formed last fall to oppose an American Authors Authority plan advanced by James M. Cain and other writers, denounced the "socalled Cain plan" yesterday as "dictatorial and monopolistic and the brain child of Communists and their fellow-travelers."

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Army Chief of Staff, reaffirmed today his endorsement of a single civilian head in the proposed unification of the armed services. Retired Admiral William F. Halsey and Gen. Merritt E. Edson, Marine Corps commander, raised several objections and reservations.
BUFFALO, May 7--The three principal causes of maternal deaths, sepsis, toxemia and hemorrhage, are to a great degree preventable, Dr. James Knight Quigley of Rochester, N. Y., declared here today.

Josephine M. Meyer sold the twenty-family apartment house at 265 East 176th Street, the Bronx, to the H. E. Realty Corporation. The property, assessed at $60,000, was sold subject to a new mortgage of 535,000 for ten years placed with the North Side Savings Bank by the Eugene J. Busheri Company, also the broker in the sale.

LONDON, May 7--Replying to a Moscow broadcast associating him with a revival of fascism in Britain, Sir Oswald Mosley said today that "the reason for the Moscow excitement is that my publications are exposing Communist methods and aims."

Louise Homer was a shining figure in the Golden Age of opera. A native American, she matched her voice with the best in the world, and none privileged to hear her can ever forget its rich magic. Her career dates from the beginning of the century, and for more than thirty years she moved as an equal among such musical contemporaries as the de Reszkes, Caruso, Melba, Nordica, Schumann-Heink and Fremstad.

GRAMMARIANS will tell you that one never should end a sentence with a preposition. In other words, prepositions are bad to end sentences with. Just like that. Some times it's just as improper to conclude a column with a question, as was done in this space yesterday. The decent thing to do is to supply an answer. And we left unanswered, more or less, Eddie Dyer's query about figuring out the soundness of any trade.

CHICAGO. May 7 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows. HOGS Salable hogs 5.500 head. total 7:000 market active and $1 higher on weights under 250 pounds: weights over 250 pounds moderately active, uneven. 50 cents to $1 higher, mostly 75 cents up: sows around 50 cents higher: bulk of good and choice 170 to 250 pounds.

Five hundred retail merchants in Brooklyn pledged themselves yesterday for an average of $2,000 each to erect a $10,000,000-housing development as a new approach to the nation's economic problem. They hope to get Federal loans of $9,000,000 against their own $1,000,000, and believe the new homes may be ready for occupancy in eighteen months.

With sales of non-vehicle products "at an abnormally high level for peacetime years" in proportion, to total sales of $804,853,209, the General Motors Corporation in the first quarter of 1947 realized a net profit of $65,818,019, according to the report issued yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board, and C. E. Wilson, president.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 7 --The Jewish Agency for Palestine informed the United Nations today that it was "pleased to accept" the invitation of the General Assembly to be heard at the current special session on the future government of Palestine.

Freed from the need for clearing agreements with the policy committee of the National Federation of Telephone Workers, telephone unions made rapid progress toward locaL agreements in many parts of the country yesterday.

JERUSALEM, May 7--Contact has been made with the Soviet Union with a view to sending a delegation of Palestine Arabs to Moscow, Jamal el Husseini, vice chairman of the Arab Higher Committee, stated today. So far no reply has been received from Moscow, he added.

In a blithe ballet mood, Franklin Simon's fashion experts offered Mabs of Hollywood's newest bathing suit collection for inspection yesterday afternoon in the third floor sports department. The pretty little manikins, swaying and dancing, wore net Degas ballet skirts over the slender figure-fitting suits.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 7 --Faced with the threat of an Arab boycott of its proceedings regarding the Palestine question, the United Nations General Asembly held an emergency session this afternoon and gave recognition to the Arab Higher Committee corresponding to the recognition previously accorded to the Jewish Agency for Palestine.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Development of atomic power for naval ship propulsion has been made the mission of three new sections established in the Bureau of Ships, the Navy Department announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 7 --Warren R. Austin, the United States representative, began debate over the terms of reference for the proposed Palestine committee of inquiry in the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee today.

Observance of the second anniversary of V-E Day today must be tempered by the realization that most of Europe's Jews "still know no peace," leaders of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York said yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At the College Forum of April 26 on American-Soviet relations, Richard Lauterbach observed that misrepresentation of the Soviet Union in the American press and of America in the Soviet press was due in part to the propensity of all reporters to feature controversies and conflicts at the expense of undramatic instances of concord and understanding.

CHICAGO, May 7--Corn led the grain markets into higher ground today on the Board of Trade, the former closing about the top with grains of 1 3/8 to 4 cents a bushel, May leading. The latter was 12 1/2 cents above the low of last week. Wheat waa 1 to 2 cents higher and oats up 3/8 to 1 5/8 cents.

The New York State Department of Education is studying possibilities for increasing the time that students must spend in the city's public high schools to be graduated, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Harry V. Gilson, associate state commissioner of education.

Fleet Admiral King is consistent in his opposition to unification of the armed services. He has been envisioning the proposed Secretary of National Defense as a "man on horseback" ever since it was first suggested that the Army, the Navy and the Air Force be combined in one department.

There was a time at Ebbets Field yesterday when the umpire could have called off the game between the Dodgers and the Cardinals on account of rain, we grounds, fog or darkness. They did, in fact, enforce a 40-minute delay during the fifth inning, but so far as 11,435 Brooklyn fans and the Dodgers, themselves, were concerned, they didn't wait long enough.

OAKDALE, L. I., May 7--Theodore J. Knapp, stockbroker and president of the Queens County Jockey Club, which owns and operates the Aqueduct race track, was found shot dead in his room at the South Side Sportsmen's Club here today.

unemployment in this city has risen more than one-quarter since the middle of March, according to figures made public yesterday by the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The Senate Finance Committee received staff estimates of prospective Federal revenues today which policy-makers regarded as a virtual clincher of the case for personal income tax cuts beginning July 1.

The truck-driving members of the International Union of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers, AFL, who between 1938 and 1946 fluffed up "featherbedding" in the trucking industry into a $1,000,000-a-year racket, are earning their money nowadays on the iron-spiked pallet of hard labor.
NANKING, China, May 7 (AP)-- The Government today ordered the licensing of food merchants and prepared to lift wage ceilings in its newest assault on its growing economic problems.

LONDON. May 7 -- Spring warmth and sunshine descended today like a curse on London's City which has now gone ten days without street cleaning because of an unofficial strike. In the neighborhood of Billingsgate fishmarket London smells as it has not smelled in centuries.

Sugar continued to pile up yesterday in Eastern seaboard warehouses as Cuba harvested a record crop under favorable weather conditions and refiners there raced each other to fill the quota of imports allowed by the United States Sugar Act of 1937.

PARIS, May 7.--The ousting of the Communist Ministers coincides with a firmer orientation of French policy toward the United States. That trend to the west was not decided mainly on the ground of domestic policy. It was, above all, the outcome of a one-and-a-halfhour talk between Premier Stalin and Foreign Minister Bidault in Moscow on March 17.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was glad to see your mild defense of American radio in the April 20 Topics of The Times. Not that I am so devoted to the programs offered that I keep the radio turned on all the time. Like a good many listeners, I am a little tired of the radio, but why blame the broadcasters for our being somewhat fed up?

VIENNA, May 7--The Austrian Parliament today adopted two resolutions asking the Allied powers in effect to end the occupation before the peace treaty is signed and to withdraw their control over internal Austrian administration.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 7-- Universal-International today announced the signing of an agreement with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to borrow William Powell from that studio for two pictures this year with an understanding that the deal may be extended next year for additional films.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange gained strength as the session progressed yesterday, and final prices were 31 to 45 points net higher than the day before.

LONDON, May 7--American film producers who are anxious to prevent any change in film quota requirements here have won a friend at court in the Board of Trade, it became known today. The British film industry, which is now enjoying the biggest domestic and export business boom in its history, is understood to have relaxed much of its pressure for added restrictions against American films.

DOUGLAS, Ariz., May 7 (AP)-- Constantino Vincent Riccardi, facing extradition on an indictment in New York on charges of the theft of $97,000 in jewelry and fraudulent sale of mining stocks, sold today a block of 1,000,000 shares of stock in the Southwestern Mines, Inc., to John H. Betts of Long Beach, Calif.

In the double-edged challenge of communism to the democratic world, the decision of the French Government to try ruling without the Communist party may be as important a development on the internal side of the struggle as the Truman policy of aid to Greece has proved to be on the international side.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., May 7 --Mrs. Louis N. Burns, 62 years old, a housemother for unadjusted boys at the Children's Village here for the last ten years, will step into Cinderella slippers on Friday for a week-end in New York.

ST. LOUIS, May 7--Warned in its opening session today that the historic wall between church and state was being undermined, the Southern Baptist Convention will vote tomorrow on a recommendation that it oppose any Federal aid to education involving application of public tax money to church schools.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., May 7 (AP)--A large-scale expansion program, expected to cost approximately $300,000,000, is being carried on by the General Electric Company.

LONDON, May 7--After throwing the House of Commons into a violent uproar by accusing the Government of "levity, opportunism and panic-stricken cowardice," Winston Churchill and his Conservative followers voted under protest tonight in favor of twelve months conscription for Britain in peacetime.

BALTIMORE, May 7 (AP)--Racing fans here appeared more concerned today not over who would Win the Preakness Stakes Saturday, but over who would be the favorite, Jet Pilot or Phalanx. It was the main topic of conversation on the street corners and in the bars and beauty parlors, overshadowing even possible withdrawal of Double Jay, best 2-yearold colt of 1846.

William Hunt Diederich indicated yesterday that he was surprised, though not particularly concerned, over the announcement by the National Institute of Arts and Letters that it was taking steps to expel him for unauthorized use of the organization's name in the mailing of anti-Semitic literature.

TRENTON, N. J., May 7 (U.P)-- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today approved a bill for increasing the state's share of revenue from three New Jersey race tracks by an estimated $1,000,000 in 1947. The measure, which applies to Atlantic City, Garden State Park and Monmouth Park, provides a new formula affecting both the state's share of the 10 per cent take on pari-mutuel betting and on breakage.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which has not yet made a loan, ended its first nine months of existence on March 31 with a deficit of $680,176, it reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 7--In today's press conference at the State Department, Doris Fleeson, an alert reporter with a facility for making difficult questions sound innocent, asked Secretary of State Marshall whether he thought this country still had a firm bipartisan foreign policy.

FORT BELVOIR, Va., May 7-- The Army Engineers gave the first public demonstration here today of how pipeline for carrying fuel can be dropped by helicopter in jungle, forest or other inaccessible places, eliminating the necessity for carrying out roads.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The Interstate Commerce Commission today permitted the city of Norfolk, Va., to become a party to proceedings involving a plan for the ultimate merging of the New York Central and the Chesapeake Ohio Systems.
ATLANTA, May 7 (AP)--Favored entries in the thirty-second annual Southern Women's Golf tournament advanced to the quarterfinal round of the championship flight today with exception of one mild upset.

CINCINNATI, May 7--Dr. Nelson Glueck, internationally renowned archeologist, educator and author, was elected president of the Hebrew Union College, America's oldest Jewish seminary, by the institution's board of governors here today, effective July 1 of this year.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 7 (AP)-- Drivers holding out for more prize money in the 500-mile Indianapolis motor speedway race appeared tonight to be doomed to an idle Memorial Day after a series of conferences among themselves, the speedway management and the American Automobile Association's contest board.

WASHINGTON, May 7--W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, forecast today a return to "the dark ages of business knowledge" if the budget requested for his department were slashed by the amounts proposed by the House Appropriations Committee.

Lamp Prices Tumbling A wave of wholesale price cuts is sweeping the lamp market both in quality and low-end merchandise, a retail representative reported yesterday. He said that some of the reductions come to as much as 25 per cent. The outcome at the retail level may be seen by sales of one quality item formerly retailing at $59.98 for $21.98, a 60 per cent reduction.

Award was announced yesterday of an issue of $2,000,000 of State of New Mexico State Highway debentures, due April 1 and Oct. 1, 1957 to 1960, to an underwriting group headed by Otis Co. The bid was 100,187 for 1 1/2s, an interest cost of 1,484 per cent.

Few stowaways ever have been subjected to as thorough and microscopic an investigation as Government agents have turned on the golden nematode, yet the Department of Agriculture admitted yesterday that it still was baffled on how the potato pest came from Europe to Long Island.

The first woman to receive the annual award of the Park Association of New York City, Mrs. Eliot Tuckerman, former president of the International Garden Club, was honored yesterday in recognition of her work in the preservation and restoration of the Bartow Mansion in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx.

The honor justly paid yesterday to Mrs. Eliot Tuckerman by the Park Association of New York City for her work in preserving and maintaining Bartow Mansion in Pelham Bay Park as a museum naturally turns back our thoughts to the era in which that fine old country house was built.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 7--A total of 879,950 displaced persons in Europe and the Middle East will continue indefinitely to depend on some international agency for part or total support. Definitive figures were presented today to the International Refugee Organization Preparatory Committee in session here.

OTTAWA, May 7--Miss Barbara Ann Scott's canary-colored automobile, presented to her by her native city of Ottawa when she won the European and world figure skating championships last spring, has become an international affair and today got mention in the Canadian House of Commons.

Patterns of living for American youth are being increasingly formed by competitive advertising, while the influence of "professional educators" is constantly decreasing, Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, declared yesterday at the opening session of the four-day National Conference on Health in Colleges at the New Yorker Hotel.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The heading on the Paris dispatch published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on April 22, "Pertinax is charged with libel in book," misrepresents the facts of the case. May I be allowed to state them as objectively as possible?

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 7--A flourish of guns between two members of the state Legislature and at least two shots on the floor of the state Senate caused Senators, employes and visitors to take cover under desks or run for exits here today and left a Senator with a bullet wound in his left hip.

Investors Sulking? The heavy spring weather isn't the only thing about Wall Street that is uncomfortably sticky, according to talk in the bond houses. Of the late April flotations of public utility issues, not all the new bonds have found permanent placement at the public offering prices.
