NEW DELHI, India, May 7 (London Times dispatch)--After conferring for several days with five Moslem League leaders from the North-West Frontier Province, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the League, said today he could not advise them to call off their civil disobedience movement.

Dr. Helgi P. Briem, consul general in New York for Iceland, has purchased the twostory dwelling on the north side of Ingam Street, west of Roman Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, from Fred E. Katzner. A first mortgage loan of $9,000 was obtained from the Continental American Life Insurance Company on the property, which is assessed at $14,500.

President Truman was charged yesterday by John J. Lamula, national organizer of the Committee for a Just Peace for Italy with trying to stampede the United States into ratification of the peace treaty with Italy.
LONDON, May 7--British shipbuilding costs are two and one-half times those of pre-war days, the Mercantile Marine Service Association's annual report said today.

WASHINGTON, May 7--Beginning its long-awaited examination of the price situation, the Congressional Economic Committee today issued a questionnaire on prices to be distributed to some 600 leaders of industry, trade, agriculture, finance and labor.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 7 --The United States and Great Britain will demand that the Yugoslav and Albanian Governments admit a special United Nations subcommission set up to keep an eye on border trouble in the Balkans, it was learned here today.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., May 7-- The first tactical unit of the Army Air Forces to be equipped with the new Republic Aviation Corporation jet plane, the P-84 Thunderjet, will be the Fourteenth Fighter Group of Air Defense Command based at Dow Field, Bangor, Me., it was announced here today.

At a reconvened hearing yesterday on the Brooklyn Union Gas Company's application to the Public Service Commission for increases in rates amounting to $1,900,000 annually, two consumers, asserting that they represented more than 1,500 gas customers, urged the commission to reject the petition.

RANGOON, Burma, May 7 (AP) --The loss of the 1,030-ton ship Sir Harvey Adamson, which disappeared in the Andaman Sea off the Burma coast three weeks ago with 250 persons aboard, was written off today as another "unsolved mystery of the sea."

A statement declaring it would be "tragic" to American foreign policy if Voice of America broadcasts were discontinued was issued yesterday on behalf of 150 war veterans who are employed by the State Department here.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, acting through an advertising agency, has undertaken a novel "test" of the market for its proposed securities issue, it was learned yesterday. According to leading bankers who have already been approached, the bank is submitting a list of five questions to potential buyers of its securities, inquiring as to the extent of their knowledge of the institution, their attitudes regarding its prospects, and their further needs for information.
The American Academy and the National Institute of Arts and Letters announced yesterday fifteen $1,000 grants to non-member composers, artists and writers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 7 --The United Nations will be deprived of its major overseas broadcasting facilities if Congress decides, for economy purposes, to silence the programs sent abroad by the State Department, it was learned here today.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., May 7--The Council of Bishops of the Methodist Church, the largest Protestant sect in the country, today accused the Roman Catholic Church of political activities in this country and abroad, which the council said amounted to bigotry and denial of religious liberty.

CLEVELAND, May 7--The United Packing House Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, adopted unanimously today a statement of policy which avoided any direct reference to Communists or any other group but made it clear that it rejected the interference by any group not identified with the trade-union movement.

DUBLIN, May 7--When Finance Minister Frank Aiken presented his budget to the Dail Eireann here this evening, he told the Chamber that Ireland's taxpayers would face expenditures totaling more than L60,000,000 in the current fiscal year.

A philatelist's paradise will be opened Saturday, May 17, in the Grand Central Palace, when stamps insured for $2,000,000 will go on exhibit at the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition. Marking the 100th anniversary of the issuance of the first United States postage stamps, the exhibition will contain the personal collection of King George VI of England and displays of thirty foreign governments.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- Levin H. Campbell, former Army ordnance chief, testified today that former Representative Andrew J. May exerted "pressure" for the Garsson munitions makers during the war and that this tended to hamper the Army munitions program.

Increasing freedom for women has taken them out of slavery, brought them additional unhappiness, made working imperative and brought increased need for understanding of the spiritual, speakers declared last night at the annual dinner forum of the National Board of the Y. W. C. A., 600 Lexington Avenue.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Tom C. Clark, Attorney General, proposed today a three-point program of education and law-enforcement as a means of combating the national fire menace.

MONTREAL, May 7--The two controversial questions before the assembly of the International Civil Aviation Organization--the expulsion of Spain and the multilateral air agreement--were referred to committees today for action probably tomorrow.
CLEVELAND, May 7--The Yankees tomorrow will make their season's debut against the Indians In the huge Municipal Stadium on Lake Erie's shore with a revamped batting order, if the weather permits.

There are times when statistics should galvanize a lethargic people into averting great human and property loss in the nation. Such an occasion presented itself at the opening of the President's Conference on Fire Prevention and Mr. Truman was ready with the figures.

Underwriting managers here will place on the market today issues of preferred stock of industrial companies, as follows: Suburban Propane Gas Corporation -- 40,000 shares of $50 par value 5 per cent cumulative dividend preferred stock at $50 a share, by Eastman, Dillon Co.

Bringing to a climax a year of centennial observance, City College, this nation's oldest publicly owned institution of higher learning, began its second century yesterday with special ceremonies commemorating the chartering of the college on May 7, 1847.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 8--Spurred on by Federal conciliators who declared that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long-lines wage conference was "on its last legs," negotiators plugged away early today at a "non-stop" session in an effort to wind up agreement to end the strike for 22,000 long-lines employes by midnight.

There were well-deserved cheers for Alicia Alonso at the City Center last night in her first appearance this season in the title role of Ballet Theatre's "Giselle." Technically she has never danced it half so brilliantly before, with flashing speed and fabulous extensions and suspensions.

World history has shown that peace, happiness and good neighborliness depend on the supremacy of moral law, Nelson A. Rockefeller said last night at dedication ceremonies of the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and Ninety-second Street.
MOSCOW, May 7--The new democratic governments of eastern Europe are withstanding intensified attacks by reactionary groups within those countries, Pravda said today.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)--The Association of American Railroads urged the Government today to liquidate immediately its Federal barge lines.

Tuesday's attack by Basil O'Connor, chairman of the central committee of the American Red Cross, on federated fund drives as "communization" and "un-American," was characterized here yesterday as "ill-advised and ill-considered" by James G. Blaine, a director and former president of the Greater New York Fund.

Russian Press Freedom Thirty-five years ago there occurred in the city now known as Leningrad an event which a writer in the Moscow Pravda the other day described as the most important milestone in the history of the printed word since Gutenberg set up his press.

BALTIMORE, May 7 (AP)--The Glenn L. Martin Company announced today that more than 2,000 employes had been laid off for "an indefinite period" and others will be made idle this week. A spokesman said the layoffs began Continued on Page 41, Column 7

Edward E. Rhatigan, Welfare Commissioner, told board members of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc., yesterday that the city was preparing to provide additional facilities for 1,300 dependent and neglected children. It will act under the program conducted by the Commission for the Temporary Care of Children, recently established by the Mayor's committee for this purpose.

Heaviest spender for advertising space in United States newspapers in 1946 was the War Assets Administration, which paid out $2,510,173 to move surplus war materials, according to Printers' Ink, out today. Data was compiled by Media Records from 338 daily newspapers in 108 cities, and covered all national or sectional advertisers who invested $5,000 or more in newspaper space last year.

Going to the front shortly after the start of the seven-furlong dash; Mrs. John D. Hertz's Owners Choice won the $17,500 Swift stakes yesterday at Belmont Park. Under adverse conditions of sky and track, the dark bay son of Blenheim II finished in 1:25 2/5 as he led Jaclyn Stable's favored I Will home by four lengths, with Walter P. Chrysler's Brabancon third and Deering Howe's Donor fourth.

Noel Coward, the playwright, sold a volume of one-act plays for $80,000, but when he got through paying income taxes on the transaction to the British and United State Governments he was poorer by $8,362.

BALTIMORE, May 7 (AP)--Pimlico staged its annual special race today for nine women jockeys who battled for a silver cigarette case in a morning gallop that was feminine in every detail except for the horses.

The American Spice Trade Association, representing more than 150 American spice manufacturers, importers, dealers and brokers will register an "immediate and strenuous" protest through all Governmental and trade channels against recent action by the colonial Government of Granada, British West Indies, establishing a virtual monopoly of distribution of nutmegs and mace, William Archibald Jr., an association director and partner in Van Norden Archibald, spice brokers, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 7--Few advocates of the cultural relations program of the State Department, few critics of those members of Congress who would not appropriate for it at this time or would sharply reduce its proposed budget, have probably taken the trouble to read the hundreds of pages of testimony before the House subcommittee.

MADRID, May 7--Bilbao has been having during the past week the most serious strike troubles seen in Spain since the end of the civil war. And the situation is still unchanged, according to reports reaching here.

LONDON, May 7--British funds and industrial shares displayed increased strength in the stock markets today, sentiment being brightened by the "strong line" taken by Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Dalton on the necessity for scaling down Great Britain's sterling war debts.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7--As a step in compliance with an order of the Securities and Exchange Commission dated May 7, 1942, the United Gas Improvement Company submitted today to the commission a plan for dissolution of the Connecticut Gas and Coke Securities Company, a subsidiary, by July 1.
BERLIN, May 7--Two years after the end of the war in Europe, the British and American Military Governments face the worst food crisis in the history of the occupation of the two zones.

"All of us agree that additional taxes are not accepted very cheerfully," said Mayor O'Dwyer on April 1, as a preamble to announcement that he would ask for a use tax on automobiles to balance his billion-dollar budget. There will, of course, be much opposition from motorists, but we believe that the Mayor has made a wise choice among the alternatives available.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 7 (AP)-- The Government has moved

Representatives of retail druggists throughout the city protested strongly yesterday to the Board of Health against stricter regulations the board proposes to place upon the sale of barbiturates, or common sleeping potions.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- A five and one-half per cent budget cut for the War Department was said today to be in prospect.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 8 (AP) -- Skee Riegel of Glendale, Calif., took his first look at the long "old" links at St. Andrews today and whipped out a threeunder-par 70 to show watchful natives that he'll be a power to reckon with in next week's renewal of the Walker Cup matches.

Even without Stan Musial, who was confined to his hotel nursing a pain in the side, the Cardinals made it two straight over the Dodgers last night at Ebbets Field. Harry (The Cat) Brecheen, 1946 world-series hero, barely missed handing the Brooks their first shut-out.
SINGAPORE, May 8 -- Rice allocation officials of sixteen countries, meeting in Singapore, today predicted seriously shortened supplies of Asia's staple food in the next six months.

PARIS, May 8 -- A combined celebration of the second anniversary of victory and of Saint Jeanne d'Arc's Day began today. There were ceremonies in Paris and in Orleans, which Jeanne d'Arc liberated in 1429.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Senate's 48 to 40 roll-oall vote today to prohibit union control of health and welfare funds and the involuntary check-off of union dues follows: FOR THE AMENDMENT -- 48 Republicans -- 33

PARIS, May 8 -- Having taken the chief responsibility for the removal of the Communists from the Government, the Socialists seem likely to reward themselves with a dozen of the twenty-five Cabinet posts.

LOS ANGELES, May 8 -- The CIO Fishermen and Allied Workers Union Local 36, thirteen of its officers and an international representative of the union were convicted last night after an elevenweek trial in Federal Court of conspiracy to violate the anti-trust laws in a recent campaign to fix prices of fresh fish sold to dealers.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., May 8 -- The Women's New Jersey Golf Association inaugurated its 1947 season with a great turnout of 79 players over the hilly, windblown fairways of the Forest Hill Field Club here today.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The bill to help Greece and Turkey ward off communism weathered its initial voting tests in the House of Representatives today, and moved into an apparently safe position.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Prominent in every current indictment of Soviet Russia is the charge of "aggressive imperialist expansion" through the wholesale seizure of smaller neighboring countries or parts of such countries and their incorporation with the territory under direct Soviet rule.

LONDON, May 8 -- Britons are not "dying of starvation or anything like it," Viscount Addison, a Government spokesman, insisted tonight at the conclusion of the lively two-day debate in the House of Lords on this nation's food supplies.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended May 3, 1947 totaled 882,684 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

BILBAO, Spain, May 8 -- The Spanish Government has broken the most powerful demonstration against it that has been achieved by any labor group since the civil war, it appeared tonight. Bilbao workers began returning in large numbers to industrial plants today.

LONDON, May 8 -- After a twenty-one-hour all-night session that set a record for this session of Parliament, the House of Commons tonight defeated, 261 to 36, a Labor party move to cut the duration of the Government's peacetime conscription law from five years to two.
UTICA, N.Y., May 8 -- The League of Women Voters wound up its three-day convention here today announcing re-election of officers, but some with different titles.

MOSCOW, May 8 -- The revival and expansion of Anglo-Russian trade is confidently expected by Harold Wilson, head of the British trade mission here that left for Britain today after three weeks of discussion with the Foreign Trade Ministry.

The Board of Estimate unanimously rejected yesterday the City Planning Commission's proposal to enlarge its jurisdiction over zoning with respect to large-scale building projects involving sites of 75,000 square feet or more. The action, taken on motion of Mayor O'Dwyer, was based on the belief that the zoning amendment recently adopted by the planning agency was unnecessary at this time.

Everett E. Pierce, general passenger agent for the New York Central Railroad, told Public Service Commissioner George A. Arkwright yesterday that passengers on the railroad making short trips would suffer more financially than those making long trips if the proposed increases were granted.

Declining for the fifth consecutive week, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans by the New York City reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell $64,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday.

In giving her former Fifth Avenue home to the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Mrs. Felix M. Warburg has performed a service both to the community and to the nation. For in the spacious house, well adapted to the purpose, a museum has been established in which may be preserved and shown examples of the various arts associated, today and through the ages, with Jewish culture.
PARIS, May 8 -- Jacques Heim scores with his gypsy frocks. Yard upon yard of printed cotton must be involved in these picturesque swinging skirts, cut circular and gathered besides.

Approximately fifteen per cent of all college students are in need of some kind of psychiatric consultation or care, it was agreed yesterday by the Committee on Mental Health of the Third National Conference on Health in Colleges, now in session at the New Yorker Hotel.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday. Closing prices were 13 to 32 points net lower, with near months relatively stronger than distant.

GENEVA, May 8 -- The United States and Great Britain circulated among the other members of the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission today separate drafts of formal recommendation designed to restore peace and harmony on Greece's troubled northern frontier.

No matter what the season is, one can count on Sonja Henie and Arthur M. Wirtz to supply Radio City's Center Theatre with an ice show. Purveyors of that brand of entertainment at low admission prices, the partners have reaped handsome dividends since they introduced the first of a steadily mounting series there in 1940.
LONDON, May 8 -- Street cleaners of the city of London, who have been out on an unofficial strike for eleven days, decided this afternoon to return to work tomorrow.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 8 (AP) -- Lew Worsham, Oakmont, Pa., and Jim Ferrier, San Francisco, mastered the 7,421-yard Memorial Park links today to set the pace for the first eighteen holes of the $10,000 Houston open golf tournament, posting three-below-par 69s.

SEOUL, Korea, May 8 -- The arrival of increasing amounts of supplies and equipment here is forcing down the prices of consumer goods and food and is effectively stabilizing markets, it was announced yesterday by Military Government authorities.

Mayor O'Dwyer took a hand yesterday in another dispute between the Board of Transportation and the Transport Workers Union, CIO. He directed Edward C. Maguire, director of the city's Division of Labor Relations, to make a preliminary investigation of a TWU complaint that motormen and conductors on the IND division of the subway had been treated unfairly in connection with "picks" and assignments on a new schedule of train runs, to become effective Sunday morning.
Mayor O'Dwyer made public late yesterday afternoon a revised bill for license fees for parking lots and garages as written by his traffic committee headed by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.
LONDON, May 8 -- "The dangers to world civilization from another world war are greater today than they were between the wars," Prime Minister Attlee warned today.

ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics handed the St. Louis Browns their sixth straight defeat tonight, 5 to 3, before a small crowd of only 2,703. Eddie Joost doubled and scored Pete Suder in the eighth inning with what proved to be the winning run.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 8 (U.P.) -- Army and police officials are ready to face any emergency that may result from yesterday's outlawing of the Communist party by the Supreme Electoral Tribunal. The task of closing down Communist party headquarters and local cells was virtually completed.

CLEVELAND, Miss., May 8 -- In the lack of success of the recent Moscow Conference, the United States must "push ahead" with the reconstruction of Germany and Japan without waiting for Big Four agreement, Under-Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today.
LONDON, May 8 -- Winston Churchill today expressed emphatic agreement with the recent demand for the scaling down of Britain's war debts, voiced by Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

NATURAL BRIDGE, Va., May 8 -- American industry needs a better and broader understanding of human relations and real business statesmanship if the free enterprise system is to succeed and survive, Joseph L. Eastwick, president of the James Lees Sons Co., declared here tonight at a celebration marking completion of his company's new carpet mills in nearby Glasgow.

An advertising budget of $1,750,000 for three pictures has been announced by Enterprise Productions, Hollywood, Calif. "Arch of Triumph" will have the largest appropriation, $900,000. "Body and Soul" has a $450,000 budget and "The Other Love," $400,000.

Congress seems to think it has a good excuse not to consider universal military training at this session in the failure thus far of the President's committee to report to him its conclusions. The President's assurance that the report will soon be made and that he will again try to obtain Congressional action indicates that this excuse soon will be shot out from under our national legislature.

After a heated eight-hour meeting, the national executive board of the American Union of Telephone Workers voted last night to end the thirty-two-day-old strike of 20,000 long-distance telephone workers, but called on its members to respect the picket lines of Bell System unions still on strike.

* * * Price of Spry Again Cut 2c The price of Spry, vegetable shortening, has again been reduced 2 cents a pound by Lever Brothers Company, it was announced yesterday. This cut is in addition to the similar reduction announced on April 10 and follows the over-all 10 per cent reduction in the price of all major Lever Brothers' soap products made on April 23.

LONDON, May 8 (AP) -- The Moscow radio said today that "a number of deliberate alterations and unprecise points" appeared in the text of the recent conversation of Prime Minister Stalin with Repubican leader Harold E. Stassen, as issued by Mr. Stassen and pubished by the American press.

Antony Tudor's "Dark Elegies" was presented last night at the City Center by the Ballet Theatre for the first time in some three years, and gave the season one of its most distinguished events. Set to Gustav Mahler's song cycle, "Kindertotenlieder," it is a work of extraordinary beauty which becomes more impressive with the passage of time.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 8 -- After deliberating one hour and forty minutes this afternoon a jury here in County Court convicted Morton B. Blumenstock, vice president in charge of national advertising for Warner Brothers Pictures Distributing Corporation, of drunken driving and third-degree assault with an automobile.

DETROIT, May 8 -- Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, addressed an appeal to Ford foremen today not to call the strike which the Foremen's Association of America has threatened for May 17.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 8 -- Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said today that the Big Five should shoulder their responsibility for the fate of Palestine through all stages of the United Nations work on the problem. He argued that there was "no justification" for the United States and Britain's opposition to being included in the peace organization's Palestine inquiry committee.

The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, in furtherance of its educational program in the field of foreign affairs, was urged yesterday by Alger Hiss, its president, to direct its program in the immediate future, "for the support and assistance of the United Nations."

Cooperation among all Christians was urged yesterday afternoon by Mme. Zoltan Tildy, wife of the President of Hungary. She spoke in Hungarian through an interpreter at a luncheon at the Hotel Plaza under auspices of the United Council of Church Women and Church World Service, after greeting listeners in English.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Senate Finance Committee completed the preliminaries today and prepared to start voting tomorrow on personal income tax reduction. Chairman Eugene D. Millikin of Colorado said that he expected a final vote by the end of the day after disposal of a number of proposed changes in the bill approved by the House.

The stock market was forced yesterday to surrender more of last week's gains, as further pressure was applied against the motors and steels. Heaviest losses were in a variety of industrials, with the composite rate off 0.83 on the day.

The trout fisherman who has decided to wait for weather and stream conditions to become just right before planning a trip to the Catskills is going to do more waiting than fishing, but at least it reduces the fishing pressure on many of the popular streams.

IN a strictly military sense Jet Pilot and Phalanx are a couple of thousand years apart. In a horse racing sense they are only a head apart -- or at least they were at Churchill Downs last Saturday. And just a head farther back came Faultless in a three-horse finish which was a ring-tailed wow.

Asserting that there must be much in the laboratories with which to enrich and beautify the musical art for greater service to man, Dr. Howard Hanson, director of the Eastman School of Music, charged yesterday that too little of such progress as yet had found its way into practice.

New York University's baseball team tightened its grip on first place in the Metropolitan Conference by nosing out City College, 11 -- 9, at Ohio Field yesterday. It was the Violets' sixth conference victory.

Holding that pessimism over fall ready-to-wear prospects has tended to be overdone, Charles G. Nichols, executive vice president and general manager of the G.M. Mckelvey Company, Youngstown, Ohio, said yesterday that he looked for new styling and sharply expanded fashion interest to prove stimulants to consumer buying.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Efforts of the Senate War Investigating Committee to comb the files of Franklin D. Roosevelt in connection with its inquiry into wartime Arabian oil deals were balked today by the executors of the late President's estate.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- The foreign market for plastics is world-wide and is growing, but so is competition, for world trade, with Great Britain emerging as our chief competitor, the tenth anniversary conference of the Society of the Plastics Industry was told today by C.C. Concannon of the Department of Commerce.
PARIS, May 8 -- Insurrections are brewing in both Tahiti and Algeria, the National Assembly was warned today during the debate on the Madagascar rebellion.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Senator Scott W. Lucas, Democrat, of Illinois, reproached the Republican Congressional majority today for inaction in laying down a legislative position with respect to the budget recommendations by the President for the 1947-48 fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The American Mission in Bucharest informed the State Department today that Rumania, in response to Russian demands, was about to deliver 400 freight car loads of wheat flour for use of the Soviet forces of occupation in that country.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a member of one of the delegations to the United Nations General Assembly, I am writing you to request THE TIMES to focus the attention of the proper authorities on a very unpleasant situation which could -- and should -- be corrected.

One can imagine, if Rudyard Kipling were alive, how he would relish the saga of the Port of Sydney and her sister converted bombers which have begun a tramp plane service on a global basis. He would have had to rewrite in the tempo of wings his famous poem on the liner and the cargo ships:

ATHENS, May 8 (U.P.) -- Reliable informants said tonight that a strong movement had developed to organize a new Greek Government with a "neutral, democratic" premier who would cooperate closely with United States advisers on the spending of the proposed United States loan and help establish a fair and supervised amnesty plan for guerrillas.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 -- A drive for joint action among all maritime groups in preparation for what was described as an inevitable "lockout", was called for today by delegates to the biennial convention of the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Order of the British Empire will be bestowed here tomorrow by the British Ambassador, Lord Inverchapel, upon Lieut. Col. Raymond R Camp, writer of a rod and gun sports column for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 8 -- The United States State Department has the opportunity in this former capital of Greek Christianity to thrust a spoke into the wheels of Soviet Russia's propaganda machine, fed by political communism and pan-Slavism.

New York builders, whose extensive post-war projects already have been sharply curtailed by a record 100 per cent rise in construction costs over pre-war levels, face the prospect of still higher costs when the so-called master agreement in the building trades is reopened within a few weeks at the request of the unions.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 8 -- Goldbeck, veteran Mount Kisco Country Club pro, and Fred E. Wright, the oft-time Leewood Club champion, were victors over twenty other pro-amateur teams in the Westchester P.G.A. bestball event today at Dunwoodie.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- The prosecution at the May-Garsson war fraud trial today traced two $1,000 checks to former United States Representative Andrew J. May despite May's threat to "expose high Democratic party officials."

Although held to two infield hits by a trio of Fordham hurlers, Manhattan captured its second Metropolitan Baseball Conference contest in five starts yesterday by defeating the Rams, 5 -- 3, at Van Cortlandt Park.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Action of May wheat and corn dominated the grain markets on the Board of Trade today and prices ranged higher. Closing trades, although under the best prices due to profittaking, showed gains of 3/4 -cent to 2 1/4 cents a bushel on wheat; 3/4 cent to 2 1/2 cents on corn and 1/8 to 1/2 -cent on oats, May showing the most strength in all instances.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Average primary market prices decreased 0.1 per cent during the week ended May 3, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor. At 146.7 per cent of the 1926 average, the lowest level since early March, the bureau's index of commodity prices in primary markets was 33.5 per cent above a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Senate accepted today by fortyeight to forty another sharpening amendment to the Taft omnibus labor bill, a provision to knock out the involuntary check-off of union dues and to put limitations about employer contributions to union welfare funds.

BUFFALO, May 8 -- The use of hot baths at a temperature of 104 degrees Fahrenheit for fifteen or twenty minutes, repeated three to five times daily is more effective in the treatment of poliomyelitis than the Sister Kenny hot pack method, Dr. Arnold Gurewitsch of Columbia University Medical Center reported today at the meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York.

Three 10-year-old parochial school pupils and a patrolman were bitten yesterday by a large mongrel dog that terrorized 400 children in the Sacred Heart schoolyard, at 449 West Fifty-first Street, before it was shot and killed.

Old Class Echoes Elderly school memories were stirred by two dissenting opinions in the Supreme Court's 5-to-4 decision the other day on the question of domiciliary search. One of the minority judges said that to permit a citizen's home to be ransacked without a search warrant was to bring back the "writs of assistance" of Revolutionary fame.

Lower prices will depend upon efficiencies developed by manufacturers and distributors, both national and private brands, it was emphasized last night by John Lawrence Wood, president, Affiliated Retailers, Inc. At present, he said, it is impractical to expect cost adjustments from labor and raw materials "under Governmentmaintained prices."
LONDON, May 8 -- Still under the stimulating influence of Chancellor Dalton's declaration on the sterling debt, the stock markets were cheerful today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 8 -- Dr. Harold Taylor, 32 years old, known during his two years at Sarah Lawrence College here as the youngest college president in the country, was attracting attention today in various states as a crusader against compulsory courses and racial discrimination in higher education.

Labor relations in the city's transit system have been in a troublesome state for years. On Oct. 1, 1946, the Board of Transportation assigned to Commissioner Davis the task of specializing in these relations, and he developed the present plan. The Mayor asked some very searching questions of Mr. Davis as they went along.

Broader understanding among nations and individuals throughout the world and sentiments opposing war were voiced by representatives of the United Nations, affiliated organizations and the schools at exercises yesterday commemorating the second anniversary of V-E Day.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Truman believes lasting world peace will be attained and that the United States has the greatest Government in the world, he declared in a birthday statement at his news conference today. His impromptu observations occupied most of the quarter of an hour he devoted to receiving newspaper and radio correspondents.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 8 -- Lauren Bacall, Who is now in Mexico, has declined to return to Hollywood for a role in "Romance in High. C," at Warner Brothers, it was learned today from a representative of Michael Curtiz, who will produce and direct the picture.

BALTIMORE, May 8 (AP) -- Overwork -- fear of it on the one hand, the result of it on the other -- whittled two starters from the possible Preakness Stakes entry list today, but stretch-flying Phalanx checked in with a personal report that he was all set to get even for his Kentucky Derby defeat.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox chalked up their fourth straight victory by defeating the Chicago White Sox, 3 -- 0, today and thereby provided the American League with a new leader. The idle Detroit Tigers moved into the top perch, twelve percentage points ahead of the displaced leaders.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- "Legalistic thinking" has produced a "mess" in the toilet goods demonstrator cases, Philip Cortney, president of Coty, Inc., said in oral argument here today before the Federal Trade Commission.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 8 (AP) -- The anthracite industry was urged today to develop new uses for hard coal if it wishes to protect its market.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 8 -- International obligations to insure development of a Jewish national home in Palestine must be the "basic and irreducible" consideration in any inquiry there, a spokesman for the Jewish Agency for Palestine asserted today before the United Nations Assembly's Political and Security Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (U.P.) -- More than 500 Communist veterans of World War II opened their first annual encampment today with a pledge to build their party into a "powerful" national force and to defend the United States against "atom-bomb fascism."

The first exhibition of contemporary American paintings to be shown in the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, had its preview yesterday in the galleries, newly painted for the Nathan M. Ohrbach collection of New York scenes.

If present plans to cut the appropriation of the Department of Commerce are put into effect, the Department's district offices in Albany, Rochester and Syracuse will be closed by June 30, L.L. Horch, regional director, Department of Commerce, said yesterday.

Martin L. Straus 2d, chairman of the board and president of Eversharp, Inc., said in the annual report of the company, to be mailed to stockholders today, that net income for the year ended on Feb. 28 was $4,213,902 after inventory revaluation and all other charges, and a provision of $2,708,499 for Federal income and other taxes.

One of the chief obstacles to full production by American industry is feather-bedding, the practice by which labor limits its own output. Originally confined to the craft unions, a survey made by this newspaper shows that it is now spreading through the mass industries.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7,000 head, total 11,000: some early sales of weights under 240 pounds 25 to 50 cents lower; general market these weights active and around 25 cents lower; hogs weighing

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board Issued new regulations today governing the operations of two groups of air carriers heretofore referred to as "non-scheduled." The new rules substantially increase the measure of control over the non-certificated field, the board said.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Why worry about a possible war with Russia when we now have a fullscale war here at home, without the proper settlement of which we will be in no position to go to war with any great Power? This war is that between labor union management, on the one side, and industrial management and the American people, on the other.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- During the week ended May 7, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, member bank reserve balances increased $51,000,000.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 8 -- The United Packinghouse Workers of America, CIO, closed its fourth constitutional convention today with a blanket demand for a pay increase of 15 cents an hour, linked with a thirty-hour week and a guaranteed annual wage.
MONTREAL, May 8 -- Franco Spain, to all intents, disappeared from the International Civil Aviation Organization today.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Chairman Walter G. Andrews of the House Armed Services Committee indicated today he would try to rescue the Army's universal military training proposal from inaction.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A simulated bombing attack on New York City and other eastern metropolitan centers will be staged later this month by a formation of approximately 125 B-29 Superfortresses, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The International Emergency Food Council has asked the Argentine Government to "exert every effort" to bring grain exports to hungry Europe up to a million tons a month for the next three months.

PITTSBURGH, May 8 (U.P.) -- Margaret Truman, daughter of the President, will make her national recital debut in Pittsburgh on Tuesday, May 20, it was announced today by Thomas P. Beegle, manager of Beegle Concerts. Mr. Beegle, who received Miss Truman's signed contract today, said her recital at the Syria Mosque here would be the first of a series of personal appearances throughout the country.

SOUTH ST. PAUL, Minn., May 8 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen said today that the "American press as a whole deserves high commendation for its fair and thorough manner in handling the story" of his recent Moscow interview with Prime Minister Stalin of Russia.

The Newburyport Plan and the variations adopted in other localities have led many people to believe that retail stores can cut the prices on everything they sell by 10 per cent or more and still make a profit. It is clear, however, that unless retailers in turn can buy goods more cheaply, such uniform price reductions can only be temporary.

The Board of Commissioners of the Port of New York Authority approved yesterday the purchase of $744,000 worth of automotive and operational equipment needed for La Guardia, Idlewild and Floyd Bennett Airports. The authority will take over the New York fields on June 1.

New York's particular status as a city of many racial strains and religions set the tone last night for the formal opening of a campaign to raise $1,500,000 for the building of an Interfaith Community House and Synagogue at Seventh Avenue and Fortieth Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 -- Plans to build $30,000,000 worth of electrical and steam equipment in its Sunnyvale (Calif.) plant in 1948 and $40,000,000 worth the following year were announced last night by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Several critcisms of Senator Taft that have been confidently made by opponents of his methods and mentality will have to be modified or withdrawn by the time Congress has finished with labor legisation. Among these criticisms are that Mr. Taft as a slow thinker, a die-hard and a bumbling tactician.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The President's Conference on Fire Prevention urged state Governors today to appoint state-wide committees for continuing study and orgamzaion of fire-prevention campaigns.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., May 8 -- Chile's busy nitrate roadstead at Tocopilla is called one of the world's toughest ports by Otho J. Hicks of the United Seamen's Service, who is on an inspection tour of seamen's clubs in Latin America.

Several thousand persons bound for Queens were delayed for as long as two hours early last evening when a four-car BMT local train was stalled by a short circuit in the Long Island City entrance of the Sixtieth Street tunnel under the East River.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 8 -- The text of the statement made for the Jewish Agency for Palestine by Dr. Abba Hillel Silver before the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee follows: I should like to say at the outset that were Mr. David BenGurion, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, here this morning, he would be making this statement.

Passage of the Taft-EllenderWagner bill would do much to encourage private enterprise to take its proper part in building the homes needed by moderate-income families, Edward Weinfeld said yesterday at a forum in St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church auditorium.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs, using a different method in each game, swept aside the Philadelphia Phillies in both ends of today's double-header. They won the first, 2 -- 1, in a pitching duel, and then slugged out an 8-7 conquest in the nightcap.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 8 -- The foreign relations of Czechoslovakia are complicated by the reluctance of the Western World to get too chummy with the "Slavic bloc" at this time. They also are complicated by traditional quarrels with neighboring states within that "bloc," and by special conditions affecting working arrangements with the Soviet Union.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 8 -- The Soviet Union moved today to open debate on Monday on the United Nations' authority to continue its on-the-spot investigation of Balkan border warfare.
CONNERSVILLE, Ind., May 8 -- Finly H. Gray, picturesque Indiana Democrat, died here today at the age of 83.

In reply to Governor Dewey's two radio speeches on the record of the last session of the Legislature, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, attacked last night the Condon-Wadlin law to outlaw strikes of civil service employes as "yellow dog legislation."

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 8 -- Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts made a promise today to enact legislation giving "some measure of responsibility, some executive authority" to elected representatives of South Africa's colored races.
It was chilly at Belmont Park yesterday and those in the crowd of 22,927 who shivered the most were the ones who backed odds-on favorites.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- William McC. Martin, chairman of the Export-Import Bank's board of directors, testified today that the bank's uncommitted funds for loans have dwindled to $800,000,000, of which $500,000,000 is earmarked for China.

New Treasury Call Coincidentally with its decision to retire $100,000,000 of the ninetyone-day bills maturing on May 15, the United States Treasury announced yesterday a call on its War Loan Deposit accounts. The call, on the B banks, requires 10 per cent of deposits as of the close of business on May 7, payable on May 15.

GENEVA, May 8 -- The United States proposed today that all European countries except Spain, whether members of the United Nations or not, be invited to participate in the discussions of the Economic Commission for Europe.

BOSTON, May 8 (AP) -- A. thirteenhit barrage against three Pittsburgh pitchers, including Rookie Earl Torgeson's third homer in as many games, today enabled Johnny Beazley to win his first start as a Boston Brave with a 12-5 decision over the Pirates.

PARIS, May 8 (UP) -- French customs officers who went on a twohour "zeal strike" on Tuesday -- enforcing to the letter every customs regulation -- were so highly pleased with the results that they are going to do it again.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 3 were 12 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

Long Island ducklings are available in the stores today at the lowest price they have been this season, with one chain, the A. P., featuring them at 29 cents a pound. In a spot check of stores throughout the city, the Department of Markets found that the most common price of the birds is 35 cents a pound, 2 cents below last Friday's tariff.

THE Vitanuova Club at Kubla Beach did not exactly shut down during the war, but it certainly wasn't what it had been with all those dances for service men, those raffles for the British, the French, the Greeks and the Chinese and a hundred other dreary distractions. But now the war was over and the most exclusive resort in the money belt of south Florida was itself again.

Legally, the term "for the duration of the war" refers to a period that terminates at the time of a formal proclamation by the President and Congress, the Appellate Division. Second Department, has held in a four-to-one decision governing the validity of a lease, it was disclosed yesterday.

Six more events in the series of programs arranged by the School Art League are announced for tomorrow at 10:30 A.M. These lectures and demonstrations dealing with various aspects of fine and commercial art comprise the eighth in the series of nine weekly programs for the benefit of students in the city's high schools.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commistion authorized today the sale at competitive bidding of 60,000 shares of new $100 par value preferred and 408,000 shares of new $20 par value common stock of the California Oregon Power Company.

Babe Ruth yesterday put into concrete form his oft-expressed desire to "do something for the kids of America," whose continuing idolatry has kept him in the forefront as a baseball figure for more than three decades.

A 10-weeks-old green monkey is stealing the show at the Central Park Zoo. Just big enough to hop and scamper, he is always under his mother's watchful eye and is most amusing when he tries to climb the cage wire.

OTTAWA, May 8 (AP) -- Prime Minister Mackenzie King advised the Commons today he had cabled J.C. Patteson, Canadian representative to the International Olympic Committee, to do "all possible" to protect the interests of Miss Barbara Ann Scott.

The United States liner America sailed at 4 P.M. yesterday from Pier 61, North River, with 971 passengers for Cobh, Cherbourg and Southampton. The ship, largest in this country's merchant marine, bore a fresh coat of paint received during a recent semi-annual survey at the yards of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Far Eastern Commission, in a policy decision announced today, ruled that property owned by nationals of the United States in Japan might be removed and destroyed in the disarming of that country.
RAPID CITY, S.D., May 8 (AP) -- Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York today was initiated into the Oglala Tribe of the Sioux Indian nation under the name of Wambli Ohitika, Chief Brave Eagle.

MOSCOW, May 8 -- The American and British Governments are pressing France to merge her zone of occupation in Germany with theirs in a new step to further their plans for the partition of Germany, it was charged here today.

The city of Boston awarded at competitive sale yesterday serial and term bond issues totaling $11,090,000 to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. The successful bid designated an interest cost of 1.617 per cent for $9,250,000 of serial bonds maturing from 1948 to 1968 and an interest cost of 2.306 on $1,840,000 of term bonds maturing in 1992.

Despite a year of intensive and productive work by the city and private welfare agencies, the present situation in shelter care for children is worse now than it was a year ago, Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan yesterday told members of the Women's City Club.

Eight hundred supporting members of the Palestine Lighthouse school and home for the blind in Jerusalem, paid tribute yesterday to its founder and president, Mrs. Samuel D. Friedman, at a twentieth anniversary celebration at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A paint brush, wax paper, and tissue paper should be included in the ironing equipment of every woman who sews and presses her family's clothing, Lee Enis, stylist for Butterick Patterns, declared yesterday. Miss Enis demonstrated correct ways to iron various materials and garments at Gimbels' Sewing Center.

BERLIN, May 8 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay confirmed today that he was ready to use troops, if necessary, to prod German farmers into action in the current food crisis in the American and British zones. At the same time he emphasized that the major portion of the food shortages resulted from the failure of food shipments from the United States to arrive here on schedule.

After yielding an early lead, the Giants unleashed a savage late attack to overtake the Reds at the Polo Grounds yesterday. By virtue of the 7-4 triumph, Mel Ott's charges gained an even break in the abbreviated series with Cincinnati and moved up two notches into fifth place in the league standing.
GENEVA, Switzerland, May 8 -- Discussions on disputed sections of the proposed international trade charter began today in the Geneva trade conference.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Two efforts to save Willie Francis from being sent to the electric chair in Louisiana again tomorrow failed today in the Supreme Court, but the justices held that the 17-yearold Negro could present "grave new allegations" to the State courts.

ST. LOUIS, May 8 -- Dr. Louie De Votie Newton of Atlanta was re-elected president of the Southern Baptist Convention today and Dr. C. Oscar Johnson, pastor of the Third Baptist Church here, was elected a vice president.

HANOVER, N.H., May 8 -- Three Dartmouth seniors were killed early this morning when their speeding car crashed into a ten-ton truck near North Hartland, Vt. The three, who were driving to New Jersey to pick up their guests for the Green Key, Spring Promenade, at Dartmouth, this week-end, included Frederick T. Sillars, 24, of Pittsfield, Mass.; Charles K. Long, 22, of Camden, N.J., and John Lopez, 22, of Lodi, N.J.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Robert R. Young, railroad executive and chairman of the recently organized Federation of Railroad Progress, made several charges against bankers, lawyers and the Government today in a continuation of his attack on "the railroad lobby."

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- For the last eight weeks the Truman Doctrine has been discussed primarily in strategic, political and ideological terms. But today both Secretary of State Marshall and his chief assistant, Under-Secretary Dean Acheson, set Mr. Truman's words to a new tune.

With output for April estimated at 7,048,767 net tons, domestic steel production during the first four months of 1947 amounted to 27,991,561 net tons, compared with 17,631,866 tons in the corresponding period of strike-affected 1946, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

With colleges and universities bursting at the seams, the danger is becoming increasingly more apparent that the standards of education may be lowered. The heavy demand placed upon the four-year institutions, caused in part by the unexpectedly large influx of veterans and in part by the normal upward trend in college enrollment, has placed almost superhuman demands upon the colleges.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (Science Service) -- Chemicals that create a bright glow when dropped on water, of great possible usefulness to seamen and trans-ocean flyers, are the subject of Patent 2,420,286, just issued to three chemists working in the laboratories of the American Cyanamid Company of New York, Dr. H.T. Lacey, H.E. Millson and F.H. Heiss.

ST. LOUIS, May 9 (AP) -- Joe Gordon's eleventh-inning single, scoring Manager Lou Boudreau, gave the Indians a 4-3 victory over the Browns tonight with fireball Bob Feller limiting St. Louis to four hits. It was the seventh straight loss for the Browns.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 9 (AP) -- Skee Riegel of Glendale, Calif., maintaining a torrid pace that ordinarily would be good enough to win the open championship on St. Andrews "old" course, gave the Scots something more to fret about today as the United States Walker Cup golf team continued its tune-ups for the international matches.

The argument that airpower is the spearhead of security today does not need to be elaborated. It is admitted on all sides. Last year the Air Coordinating Committee declared, after a careful study, that we should procure not less than 3,000 military airplanes annually if the state of the world's peace was settled, not less than 5,180 such aircraft if settlement was still postponed.

ATHENS, May 9 (AP) -- A high Government official said today that Mark F. Ethridge Jr., United States member of the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission, had proposed to the Greek Government that the United Nations supervise the Cabinet's program of amnesty for guerrillas.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- A Democratic minority threw in tonight a sudden, eleventh-hour and general counter-offensive against the Taft omnibus labor bill, and all plans of the Republican leaders for an early final vote were cast into doubt.

Alleged irregularities in the renting of city piers under short-term permits have been under investigation for several weeks by John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, Mayor O'Dwyer disclosed yesterday. The Mayor said he expected to receive a report from Commissioner Murtagh in a few days.

BUFFALO, May 9 -- A statewide network of centers for the conservation of hearing with a program patterned along the one used by the Army and Navy, was proposed today at the closing session of the meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York.

The first day of the General Sessions trial of Mariano Abello, suspended radio car patrolman accused of fatally strangling a woman last July 4 along "Slaughter House Row" on First Avenue, near Forty-second Street, ended at 6:45 o'clock last night with eleven jurors selected.

Useful Weather Observers Our State Department has accepted a Soviet proposal for an exchange of five meteorologists between the two countries. It is hoped in Washington that this might be the beginning of a much broader program of cultural reciprocity, such as we have proposed to Moscow without success so far.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- In a move designed to reduce its annual interest and dividend charges, the Kentucky Utilities Company, a subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation, applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to undertake a refinancing program.
In the midst of the housing shortage, carpenters, bricklayers and painters in some cities are idle for lack of work, a survey by The United Press showed.

BILBAO, Spain, May 9 -- Thousands of striking Bilbao workers returned to their jobs today with what finally appeared to be the first strike victory won by workers under the Franco Regime, according to information from sources of high reliability.

Fifty-five blue candles symbolizing the United Nations were lighted yesterday at a ceremony in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in honor of Mrs. Frederick G. Murray of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, selected as the American Mother of 1947 for the observance of Mother's Day tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- It took the Phillies three hours an eleven innings tonight to knock the Dodgers out of first place, but they finally made it and sent a half-frozen crowd of 22,680 fans home happy.

A program for college health services, designed to maintain students' health and to increase student knowledge of healthful living, was recommended yesterday in a committee report at the Third National Conference on Health in Colleges, meeting in the New Yorker Hotel.

The Kingdom of the Netherlands registered yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission an issue of $20,000,000 of ten-year 3 3/4 per cent external sinking fund bonds. A registration statement of more than 50,000 words and more than fifty pages of statistics described the economic structure of the borrowinng nation and the effects of five years of enemy occupation, estimating the extent of recovery achieved since.

MILLBROOK, N.Y., May 9 -- State Senator Frederic H. Bontecou announced today that he had resigned as a member of the State Senate, effective June 1. He said he was retiring to make way for a veteran of the second World War.

By unanimous vote the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations recommended yesterday final ratification of four of the first five peace treaties to follow the Second World War. They are the treaties with Italy, Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania. The fifth treaty, that with Finland, lies outside American jurisdiction, since the United States was never at war with that country.

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox moved back to the top of American League standings by defeating Detroit, 2-1, today. It was the eleventh Sox victory in eighteen games. Orval Grove pitched a seven-hitter for Chicago.
Cornell, Yale and Princeton will be the hosts for today's three big college rowing regattas, leading up to the Eastern sprint championships on Carnegie Lake next Saturday.

LONDON, May 9 -- The House of Commons heard today one of the most alarming pictures yet drawn of the crisis in book publishing caused by the lack of paper. This situation has been receiving increasing attention in Britain.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (U.P.) -- Former Judge Thurman Arnold knows how it feels to carry the Hope diamond around in his pocket like a piece of loose change.

Threatening letters of anonymous origin have been received by Jackie Robinson, first baseman of the Dodgers, it was revealed yesterday. This disclosure followed on the heels of a report that a strike of opposing players against the Negro ballplayer had been spiked.

Louis Bergen wore a wrist watch in his restaurant yesterday for the first time since he received it five years ago on his sixty-fifth birthday. That was proof that one of the best-known personalities in the "theatre" was retiring and that West Forty-fifth' Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, would never be quite the same again.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The State Department is refusing to issue passports to Americans to travel in Yugoslavia because of dangers there and has rejected a recent Yugoslav protest against this ban, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Following is the vote by which the House of Representatives today passed legislation authorising a $400,000,000 loan to Greece and Turkey:

JERSEY CITY. N.J., May 9 -- Mrs. Mary Peselli, 29 years old, carried her 4-year-old, crippled son to safety as a two-alarm fire raced through her home here at 9:30 A.M. today, but her 6-month-old daughter, Ellen Theresa, sealed in her bedroom, by insurmountable flames, perished in her crib.

COLUMBIA, Mo., May 9 --William L. Laurence, science writer for THE NEW YORK TIMES, stated here tonight that an atomic cloud hangs over the "common man" and over the capitals of all nations. "It darkens the conference rooms at Moscow, London, Washington and New York," said Mr. Laurence who addressed 650 students and visitors at the University of Missouri at a session of "Journalism Week" here.

Stockholders of the Johns-Manville Corporation approved a threefor-one split-up of the common shares at the annual meeting here yesterday. The split will be effective for stockholders of record at the close of business on Monday.

ALBANY, May 9 -- Justice Isidore Bookstein of the Supreme Court reserved decision today on an application for an injunction restraining the Secretary of State from enforcing the Wilson-Pakula bill, enacted this year to prevent a member of one party from "raiding" another party's primary elections.

A 21-year-old college girl missed death or serious injury by a scant fifteen feet yesterday morning when she was pushed in front of an oncoming BMT subway train in the Canal Street station by a man recently paroled from a mental hospital.
To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: I must take issue with the statement in the letter of Hugh Nash which you published on May o that the Truman Doctrine is a blow at the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- By a bandwagon vote of 287 -- 107, the House passed tonight its bill to authorize $400,000,000 of direct economic and indirect military aid to Greece and Turkey in warding off Communism.

Two suspected burglars, believed by the police to have entered a dozen apartments in the East Eightieth and East Sixty-sixth Street district, between Fifth and Park Avenues, in the last six months, were in the hands of the authorities early today after a detective had shot one of them, wounding him slightly in the left leg with one pistol shot.
Plans for the full-scale study of rheumatic fever in the lower East Side District of New York were made known last night by officials of the New York University College of Medicine.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 9 -- About 2,000 captains, deck officers and wireless operators of the Swedish Merchant Marine will strike tomorrow, following the rejection by the shipping companies of demands for higher wages and collective bargaining rights.
"Casey Jones," the locomotive engineer so devoted to duty that he faced death sticking to the throttle, is being joined today in American folklore by the "feather-bedding" railroad worker.

With the discovery yesterday that Stan Musial, their slugging first baseman, faced an immediate operation for appendicitis, the world champion St. Louis Cardinals left town in a chastened mood despite their triumph over the Dodgers Thursday night in the rubber contest of a three-game series.

A storm of protests arose yesterday from New York City's teachers' organizations when it became known that many of the teachers who were expecting salary increases this summer would not get any rise until July 1, 1948.

A new definition to meet the controversial issue of "proportionately equal" as applied to the purchase of promotional services and facilities on retailing cosmetics will be among regulations to be presented at the trade practice rules conference on Monday for the perfume, cosmetics and other toilet preparations industry, it was learned here yesterday.

SHANGHAI, May 9 -- There is a widespread feeling in Chinese and foreign circles here that the National Government may be compelled by circumstances to renew efforts to negotiate peace with the Communists.

Serge M. Rubinstein, international financier, who on April 23 was sentenced to two and a half years in prison and fined $50,000 after his conviction on charges of having made false statements to his draft board, filed a petition yesterday with Federal Judge J.F.T. O'Connor in a move to prevent his deportation.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today, without reservations and without a dissenting vote, the treaties of peace with Italy, Rumania, Hungary and Bulgaria. Chairman Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, announced that approval had come after a "long discussion" of the terms of the treaties by the committee.

A Coast Guard helicopter crashed and burned yesterday afternoon at Floyd Bennett Field during a three-hour air show staged for 250 high school newspaper reporters and photographers from New York and New Jersey. No one was injured.
LOS ANGELES, May 9 -- Members of the House Un-American Activities Committee opened ten days of closed hearings today on communistic activity in Hollywood.

The House of Representatives has given a generous approval to President Truman's bill for aid to Greece and Turkey. The measure now goes to a conference at which differences between the House and Senate versions will be reconciled. Since these differences are not large, it may confidently be expected that within the next few days a final draft of the bill will be offered to the President for his signature.

Mother's Day Buying Active Despite unfavorable weather conditions, buying for Mother's Day aided retail trade here in showing an average increase here this week. Department stores, it was estimated, would show an increase of about 5 percent over the like week of last year.

The suspensions of Marty Servo, former welterweight champion, and his manager, Al Weill, were lifted yesterday by the New York State Athletic Commission. Servo gave up the title soon after he was suspended in September for refusing to defend against Ray Robinson, the current champion.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Adolph N. Rosenthal of New York, whose wartime developed "secret television" and "skiatron" systems are being turned to account in the solution of peacetime problems in television and radar, is represented in this week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office by two of the 356 inventions on which patents were issued.

A race that had its inaugural in 1891 heads the program at Belmont Park today when the Metropolitan handicap will be run for the 54th time. A one-mile burst for 3-year-olds and upward, the Metropolitan is worth $25,000 added and has attracted a field that includes a number of the best runners in training.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent issue of THE TIMES William H. Zinsser, president of the Lenox Hill Hospital, is quoted as saying that "the spirit of Florence Nightingale has been somewhat dimmed by the eight-hour day."

George Bernard Shaw will figure prominently in the production plans of the Theatre Guild this winter, according to Lawrence Langner and his wife, Armina Marshall, both of whom returned from England yesterday on the Queen Elizabeth.
PARIS, Saturday, May 10 -- The World Bank's loan of $250,000,000 to France has long been awaited here as an important contribution toward filling the deficit in the balance of payments for this year.

A shift to firm price sales policies on practically all lines of electrical apparatus has been made by the two largest electrical equipment manufacturers, General Electric Company and Westinghouse Electric Corporation, it was disclosed here yesterday.

HOUSTON, Texas, May 9 (AP) -- South African Bobby Locke, Californian Ellsworth Vines and Ohioan Herman Keiser posted 138s, four under par to deadlock for the 36-hole lead in the $10,000 Houston Open Golf Tournament today. They displaced Lew Worsham and Jim Ferrier, who had led with 69s yesterday after the first round over the par 36, 36-72 layout.
The world price of wool will be bolstered by organized wool interests in the event of any price weakness, Dr. Edgar Booth, world chairman of International Wool Secretariat, declared yesterday.

GENEVA, May 9 -- The United States advised the Economic Commission for Europe today that regardless whether the four-power German control authorities will cooperate in the Commission's work, the United States control authorities will do so on economic matters handled on a zonal basis.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior, objected before a Senate Judiciary Subcommittee today to the nomination of former Representative Jed Johnson of Oklahoma to be a judge of the United States Customs Court, calling him "unfit" for the place.

The Municipal Welfare Department said yesterday that it had paid $500 for rent and food through the month of December, 1946, for a Bronx father and mother and their four children who had been evicted from their home in November for failure to pay rent while on home relief.
After having scaled two parapets on the Empire State Building, a middle-aged man plunged fifty-five stories on the Thirtythird Street side at 6:30 o'clock last evening.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The first billion - bushel winter wheat crop in the nation's history was predicted today by the Department of Agriculture in a report that said, however, that prospects for spring-sown crops are still dimmed by a backward season.

CINCINNATI, May 9 -- The United States in 1975 will have three times as many persons who are 50 years of age or older than this country had in 1920, Victor Roterus, resident director social science research project of the University of Michigan told the Association of State Planning and Development Agencies here today.

Spring lost out again yesterday as the mercury slid down to 33.8 degrees at 6 A.M. to set a new low reading for May. It was the second successive day that a cold record for the date had been listed in the city.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial entitled "Food Prices," in your issue of May 4, prompts me to call attention to the substantial contribution which has been made by milk producers and milk dealers in the New York metropolitan area in helping to "correct the unbalanced price relationships which have been causing so much concern."

BERLIN, May 9 -- A bizonal economic capital for the merged United States and British zones definitely will be established at Frankfort on the Main. Announcement of this decision, which was indicated by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, at Stuttgart Tuesday, and word of which leaked out at Frankfort yesterday, probably will be made within the next five days.

Mrs. Louis N. Burns, "Ma" to more than 500 boys during the last ten years, came to town yesterday from Dobbs Ferry, where she is a cottage mother in the Children's Village for boys who have been in trouble. It was her "night out."

The International Monetary Fund will begin actual effective operations within a few weeks, it was disclosed yesterday. Camille Gutt, managing director and chairman of the executive board, made the disclosure in a press conference at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- William A.M. Burden, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Air, has submitted his resignation to Secretary W. Averell Harriman and is expected to depart by July 1. The Secretary said today that he had requested Mr. Burden to reconsider his decision but friends of the latter said he was anxious to return to the aviation industry as soon as a successor could be found.

J. J. Clune, formerly with the National Union Radio Corporation, Newark, has been appointed merchandise manager of Air King Radios, made by the Air King Products Company, Inc., division of Hytron Radio Electronics Corporation.

Advertising in all New York newspapers for the first four months of the year totaled 46,163,461 lines, compared with 39,342,233 in the corresponding months last year, or a gain of 17.34 per cent, according to a compilation of Media Records' figures. All classifications showed gains except financial, which dropped 15.37 per cent.

LONDON, May 9 (AP) -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today that Britain welcomed the proposal by Under-Secretary of State Dean Acheson that the United States increase imports to bolster international trade. He said the Under-Secretary's analysis of the world's economic problems was both "farsighted and wise."

The Civil Aeronautics Administration renewed yesterday for a sixty-day period the permit for Ground Controlled Approach (GCA) landings at Gander, Nfld., by the three American-flag airlines flying the Atlantic. GCA is wartime radar equipment which makes it possible for planes to land safely when weather conditions are extremely poor.

New Capital Market Bond marketing this week lagged far behind the total of $426,115,000 for seven issues -- including the $300,000,000 Illinois bonus issue -- the week before. Of five issues totaling $38,190,000 put out this week, four were municipal; the other was industrial.

MONTREAL, May 9 -- The final expulsion of Spain from the International Civil Aviation Organization met an unexpected delay this afternoon when the executive committee could not agree on the precise number of states entitled to vote.

CINCINNATI, May 9 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs made Johnny Vander Meer's first start of the season an unhappy one today as they clubbed his offerings for five hits and four runs in the sixth inning and added another marker in the eighth to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 5-1.

STUTTGART, Germany, May 9 -- It is understood that considerable quantities of uranium are now being mined under joint Czechoslovak-Russian supervision at Jachymov [Joachimstahl], north of Karlovy Vary [Carlsbad], near the German border.

BALTIMORE, May 9 -- These were the chief developments today at old Pimlico, America's racing capital for this one week-end during the spring: (1) Eleven 3-year-old colts, including the first five finishers in last Saturday's Kentucky Derby and two others that participated in the scrimmaging at Churchill Downs, were named for tomorrow's fifty-seventh running of the $100,000 added Preakness Stakes.

TOKYO, May 9 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's denial yesterday that he had pledged that the United States would defend Japan continued to be discussed by the few Japanese who are aware of the situation. Some of them think Japan has been advised that their delegation to the peace conference must press for an international security guarantee.

Winners in a competition for woven textile designs held by the Moss Rose Manufacturing Company, Philadelphia textile house, were announced yesterday. The contest, open to students of industrial and textile art schools, drew almost 200 entries from forty-five Institutions.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady, 10 to 32 points net higher, led by old-crop months.

BUFFALO, May 9 (AP) -- The first chemical that temporarily halts one type of cancer-like tumor by going like a messenger only to those tumors was reported today by Dr. I. Snapper of Mount Sinai Hospital, New York.

New York University's championship -bound baseball team made it ten victories without a loss by crushing last-place Brooklyn College 13-1 in a Metropolitan Conference contest on the Flatbush diamond yesterday. In annexing their seventh league triumph, the Violets handed the Kingsmen their seventh straight loss.

Fred Connors, 58 years old, who, according to the police, feigned blindness and panhandled, was charged with homicide yesterday after his partner, Edward Trudeau, 69, was pushed from a subway platform in front of a train and killed.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 9 -- With the arrival at United Nations headquarters today of David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, the Zionist high command started preparations for the question-and-answer battle that is scheduled for the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee on Monday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 -- A revival of world trade depends not alone on the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, but also on "a free flow of private credit closely related to the movement of goods," Charles C. Pineo, the banks loan director, asserted today at the second Bay Area Institute of World Trade.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The World Bank began operations today by lending $250,000,000 to France to assist that country in its reconstruction and development of post-war economy. This was the first loan made by the $8,000,000,000 institution set up under the Bretton Woods Charter as an adjunct of the United Nations.

The Army Air Force, in need of trained meteorologists, has assigned 125 officers to five colleges in the United States to study weather forecasting and its relation to flight operations, it was made known here yesterday.

Most radio listeners have a keen ear for music, and prefer to hear it in a full and natural range despite oft-repeated assertions to the contrary, Dr. Harry F. Olson, director of acoustical research at the RCA Laboratories, told several hundred scientists and sound experts yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Henriette Michelson, pianist, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. She presented a lengthy and exacting program containing the Bach-Busoni chorale prelude, "I Call to Thee, Lord"; Bach's seldom played "Toccata and Fugue" in G minor; Schumann's "Toccata"; Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 111; Bartok's "Hungarian Peasant Songs"; two Mazurkas and the "Ballade" in F minor of Chopin, and Brahms' "Variations and Fugue on a Theme by Handel."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 9 -- Following is the text of a draft reported to the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee today by Subcommittee 6 as a basic for discussion of the proposed Palestine inquiry committee.

Seton Hall scored four runs off Fordham in the first inning and went on from there to defeat the Rams, 12-2, at Fordham Field yesterday. The loss was the second in tow days for the Maroon, while the Pirates gained their fifth triumph in six starts.
Unscathed in eighteen months' combat service with the Coast Guard, George Duelfer, 22 years old, was injured critically at 3:50 P.M. yesterday in a freak accident.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Irritated at criticism of Congressional economies, Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, suggested today that postmasters at Boston, Holland, Mich., and other points be fired or put in prison unless Post Office heads here can control them.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The United States District Court was asked today to dismiss charges that eighteen persons on the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee conspired to keep their records out of the hands of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

With Ambassador Paul McNutt back in Washington, winding up the last details of his mission to Manila, the appointment of a new Ambassador to represent the United States in the Philippines becomes an order-of business for the President.
