WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Senate's 65-to-26 roll-call vote on an amendment by Senator Taft to the labor bill to permit employers to sue unions for damages resulting from jurisdictional strikes and secondary boycotts follows:

DETROIT, May 9 -- Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, defied the Foremen's Association of America today to proceed with its plans for a strike if it thought by such action it could coerce the company into an ''unworkable" agreement or could prove that foremen had no management responsibility.
PARIS, May 9 -- With the Communists abstaining, the new majority of the Center today voted confidence in the Government toestablish order and punish those responsible for the revolt in Madagascar.

Only a handful of operators returned to work yesterday in the fourteen principal stations of the long-lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, holding up the restoration of normal long-distance telephone service.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Continuation of the telephone strike in many large cities and in smaller communities was threatened today by spokesmen for two unions of 42,000 employes in the Western Electric Company, an affiliate of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of April 23 a correspondent calls attention to what he describes as an inaccurate citation by another correspondent from the report of the Anglo-American Committee of Inquiry with reference to the immigration of 100,000 refugees into Palestine.

Shares of a few of the motor companies managed yesterday to edge into higher financial ground on the Stock Exchange, but the main portion of the market shuttled back and forth in uneven trading to produce a close slightly lower than on Thursday.
ATLANTA, May 9 -- The antiJewish, anti-Negro Columbians are attempting to renew their activities in Atlanta, Solicitor General Paul Webb of Fulton County charged today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9 -- Universal-International today announced the purchase of screen rights to "Come Be My Love," a forthcoming magazine serial by Robert Carson, described by the studio as a romantic comedy. Robert Montgomery will star in the film version and will direct it after he completes "Ride the Pink Horse," which is now being filmed on location in New Mexico.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- President Truman has until midnight Wednesday to make a decision whether to sign or veto the legislation to outlaw suits for "portalto-portal" pay and the problem was discussed at his Cabinet meeting today.
MOSCOW, May 9 -- Today the Russian people celebrated the second anniversary of the defeat of the Third Reich.

TOKYO, May 9 -- Leaders of Japan's four major political parties at a conference today agreed to attempt to form a coalition Government as the first administration of the nation under the new democratic Constitution.

MANILA, May 9 -- Lieut. Gen. George F. Moore, commanding United States Army forces in the Philippines, personally called a press conference today to give his version of Army losses here through pilferage and black market operations.

LONDON, May 9 -- A British official spokesman insisted today that Britain could adhere strictly to the provisions of the United States loan agreement requiring her to make sterling balances created by current trade after July 15 readily convertible into any currency, including dollars.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 9 -- Delegates of Arab League states fought hard today against a Zionist plea to the United Nations to base a solution for the Palestine controversy on the homelessness of Europe's displaced Jews.

Charles E. Gillham, for eleven years biologist for the United States Department of the Interior, stationed in the Northwest, has written an account of a trip from Alberta to the country above the Arctic Circle and south through Alaska.

PARIS, May 9 -- Premier Paul Ramadier's Cabinet, filled out by the addition of one Popular Republican and three Socialist Ministers to replace the Communists, won something of a victory today when the strikers at the Renault motor works voted to resume work on the Government's terms.

LONDON, May 9 -- The similarity of the goal sought by Russian communism and British socialism was affirmed by Premier Stalin in a talk with the Labor party's goodwill mission in Moscow last August, it was revealed today. The annual report of the National Executive of the Labor party, issued today, contains an extensive account of this mission.

ALBANY, May 9 -- Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein todays denied an application for an order directing the Secretary of State to certify that a District Attorney must be elected in Kings County next November.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 9 -- The second anniversary of the end of the war in Europe was marked in Yugoslavia today by military parades and an order of the day from Premier Tito. He bade the armed forces to stand on guard against what he called the warmongering of the American and British capitalist profiteers.
LONDON, May 9 -- Although the stock markets here were generally bright today business still was on the small side.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved the House tax reduction bill today, 8 to 5, with two principal changes.

PARIS, May 9 -- Hope for an agreement for the exchange of prisoners between the French and Viet Nam and for peace negotiations was expressed today in Hanoi by Red Cross and consular representatives, reporting on their interview with Viet Nam Foreign Minister Giam on Wednesday.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 9 (AP) -- Tennessee tore up Robert R. Neyland's coaching contract today, signed him to a new five-year one at an unannounced increase in pay and thereby assured itself of precision, power-packed football through 1951.

JERUSALEM, May 9 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, who may resume the role of world Zionism's chief spokesman when the United Nations debates the future of Palestine in the autumn, entertained the British High Commissioner, Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan Cunningham, at lunch today.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission opened bids today for conversion of six vessels into peacetime cargo ships. The ships, apparent low bids and working time specified are as follows: Former cargo ship Tate -- With drydocking, Waterman Steamship Corporation, Mobile, $537,445 and ,80 days; without drydocking, Constable Hook Shipyards, Inc., Bayonne, N.J., $698,000 and 78 days.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Two top wartime generals said today that former Representative Andrew J. May of Kentucky asked them to help Garsson munitions firms which the Government contends held the wartime House Military Committee chairman in their pay.

GENEVA, Switzerland, May 9 -- A massive report transmitted by General Markos, the Left-Wing Elas guerrilla leader, to the United Nations Balkans Investigation Commission" laying responsibility for the Greek civil war directly on Britain, was made public by the commission here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 9 -- The text of the statement made before the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today by Henry Cattan, a member of the delegation of the Arab Higher Committee for Palestine:

The recent statement of a British physician that the British nation was "dying from a lack of crude calories" received corroboration in part yesterday from the Right Rev. Dr. John William Charles Wand, Lord Bishop of London, who arrived on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- A bipartisan group of legislators today introduced measures to authorize construction of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Census Bureau statisticians said today that unemployment figures show no sign of a business recession.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store organizations showed a rise of 18.1 percent in April, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In March the sales increase was 21 percent.

First of the 1947 Chevrolet station wagons have been placed on display by some dealers in this city, the Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation announced yesterday. Each will sell for about $1,785 with four-ply tires and about $1,805 with five-ply tires, exclusive of sales tax.

Neighborhood butchers and supermarkets are offering beef kidneys for 23 to 35 cents a pound and pork kidneys for 23 to 29. You know without our saying it how low this is compared with other meats and poultry -- chuck steak at 43 to 55 cents a pound, bacon at 59 to 79 cents and roasters at 47 to 59.

Educators from thirty nations will meet in Paris, beginning July 21, for a six-week summer seminar sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Social and Cultural Organization, it was learned yesterday.

Mother's Day will be observed in the city's churches tomorrow. The day when men and women wear carnations in honor of their mothers will mark the climax of Christian Family Week. Sermons in virtually every pulpit in the city will emphasize the Christian duty of honoring parents.

Although it suffers under such derogatory names as "slink" and "black," the interest in the "spring" salmon, which is quite plentiful in New Brunswick, has shown a big increase this year, and many anglers formerly satisfied with trout are beginning to exhibit the malady known as "itching foot."

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 9 -- Competing in an unfavorable brisk wind, Henry T. Bullock of Vineland, N.J., captured the double targets title with a score of 92 as the three-day amateur trapshooting championships of America started at Travers Island today.

The Business Committee on National Policy of the National Planning Association places "squarely up to business" the responsibility for leading the country out of its present price problems. This position is taken despite the committee's recognition "that business men are not alone responsible for the price situation that has developed during the past few months."
ST. LOUIS, May 9 -- Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, told delegates to the Southern Baptist Convention today that he did not agree with their stand on two issues.

Continued restriction of production because of shortages of materials caused the Packard Motor Car Company to lose $1,148,173 in the first quarter of 1947, compared with a deficit of $247,449 in the comparable period of last year, George T. Christopher, president, reported yesterday.

PARIS, May 9 -- Adopting the trompe I'oeil technique, the decorators' art of painting drapery and scenes in perspective, Carven applies the paint brush to linen play suits and evening frocks that ought to be a delight to teen-agers.

MANILA, May 9 -- The Philippine House of Representatives today approved the Administration's 240,000,000 peso ($120,000,000) appropriations bill for the fiscal year 1947-48. It is still far short of making ends meet.

In the furore created by the brilliant pitching debut of Clint Hartung, the fact that the Giants finished on the short end of a 6-2 score in their series opener against the Braves was virtually overlooked by the 5,894 paying spectators at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today, with some pressure on wheat in expectation that the estimate of the winter wheat crop by the Department of Agriculture, to be issued late in the day, would show a record yield.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 9 -- A, deputation of the National Peasant party members of the Rumanian parliamentary Opposition handed tonight to Burton Y. Berry, United States diplomatic representative in Bucharest, a memorandum appealing for American aid to restore democratic liberty in Rumania.

ST. MARTINVILLE, La., May 9 (AP) -- Willie Francis made his second trip to the electric chair today. The same chair that spared his life through a mechanical failure a year ago took it this time -- quickly, and apparently painlessly.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 9 -- Britain's mandate in Palestine died with the League of Nations, Henry Cattan, spokesman for the Arab Higher Committee of the Holy Land, declared today in an impassioned appeal to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Taft amendment to permit employers to sue labor unions for damages in jurisdictional strikes and secondary boycotts written into the labor bill by the Senate today:

Completely reversing the acute sugar shortage situation of the war and post-war periods, sugar men are now seeking all possible ways to stimulate the sale of the product, it was reported yesterday. Price resistance by industrial and consumer users and excellent prospects for the record Cuban crop that is now coming into the country have presented sugar men with at least a temporary surplus problem, it was stated.

William Hunt Diederich, 63-year-old sculptor of Tappan, N.Y., was arraigned yesterday before Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell on a complaint filed by a postoffice inspector charging him with having sent scurrilous and anti-semitic matter through the mails.

BY bringing his two brief operas, "The Telephone" and "The Medium," into the heart of the theatre district, Gian-Carlo Menotti upsets the balance of power. Last February he offered them as musical events at the Heckscher Theatre where the music critics and the musical public admired them.

AMONG the many thoroughly admirable traits to be found In Bob Feller are his frankness, sincerity and honesty. All of them are particularly evident in his autobiography, "Strikeout Story," a most engrossing baseball book which has just been published by A.S. Barnes Co. It sounds so completely Bob Feller that one never notices the sepulchral figure of Frank Gibbons, his oversize ghost, lurking to the background.

The former Navy tanker Neosho is being restored to her original condition at the Todd Shipyards Corporation's Hoboken Division, it was announced yesterday. The vessel was built in 1942 for the Socony Vacuum Oil Company and requisitioned by the Navy for war service is soon as she was completed.

FOR a business which makes so much pretense of being explicitly moral and which proudly polices its members with a pious Production Code, the motion picture business has been pulling some mockeries of late. Meekly, this sideline observer would like to ask who's kidding whom?

When you scratch an angler on a hunter there is no way of telling what will show up under the skin, and the letters which flowed in as a result of our recent stab at the drowsy followers of these sports were extremely interesting.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Republican economic machine has gained considerable impetus in the last two weeks, but it is still far from the original goal. Cuts of from 47 to 23 per cent in the President's budget requests in the last bwo bills to be ground out by the House Appropriations Committee have set new records for the Eightieth Congress and produced groans of agony from the Federal agencies affected.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The House Appropriations Committee disclosed this week its reasons for refusing the entire appropriation of the foreign broadcasting and cultural activities of the State Department.

DANA FARALLA, in weaving a tale of a boy's resolute dreams for his horse, has delivered a regulation saddle-soapand-silks-opera which is saved from mediocrity mainly by a wee bit of a brogue and a pageanttinted introduction to the migratory horse-traders of the South.
MOSCOW, May 10 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, has accepted American proposals to broaden Korean participation in planning that country's future government.

WHEN I apologized to Carlo Levi for coming at an inopportune time (he had a train to make, he was packing his valises), he waved his hand. "All work will get done," he said. "Everything, I work in the deadline of time."

LINDENHURST, L.I., May 10 (AP) -- Because she was born of Protestant parents she never knew, 5-year-old Patricia Dennon may be taken away from the woman she has called mother ever since she began to talk.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Official diplomatic records published by the State Department tonight on the peace-making more than a quarter of a century ago carried a warning from Herbert Hoover that the Western Hemisphere could not indefinitely supply the deficiencies of Europe and that Europe should not become economically enslaved to the Western Hemisphere.

TOO often the history of a college is perpetrated by an emeritus professor of English who writes through a veil of tears. "Columbia: Colossus on the Hudson" is no such history, nor is Horace Coon, the author, a mistyeyed retired teacher on a binge of nostalgic remembering.

BILBAO, Spain, May 10 -- Civil Governor Genaro Riestra reafirmed today that all workers coming back after the Bilbao industrial strike must accept the loss of all seniority rights. He emphatically denied reports by workers that the question of penalties had been dropped.
WHAT Communists do in the trade unions of any country vitally affects the welfare and security of its entire people, and not merely its organized labor movement.

Sparked by Pat O'Brien's scintillating showing in the half-mile run, Bishop Loughlin Memorial High's track team won its third outloor meet within the space of eight days by taking the open laurels at the ninth annual Eastern interscholastic games sponsored by Boys High of Brooklyn at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday that as part of the campaign to recruit additional students for the Department of Hospital's six professional nursing schools, open house ceremonies will be held beginning this afternoon and continuing during National Hospital Week, ending next Saturday.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 10 -- Delegates to the World Telecommunications Conference from sixty -nine countries began to arrive here today. Headquarters are in the Ambassador Hotel.

THE Germans, a people known for their musical and scientific proclivities, managed to combine both these talents during the war by inventing a deadly noisemachine, a Chicago physicist recently disclosed.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, May 10 -- Egypt lowered her bars against the foreign military in uniform and welcomed here today about 3,500 officers and enlisted men of the United States Mediterranean Fleet. For the first time since the British left Alexandria and Cairo in March under their general evacuation scheme, uniformed men from abroad were seen on the streets of a major Egyptian city.

NEW JERSEY -- College Needs New Jersey colleges will enroll 50,577 by 1950, or 6,339 over the present college capacity. The institutions will need 1,000 more teachers during the next five years. These forecasts have been made by Dr. John H. Bosshart, State Commissioner of Education, who placed the present capacity of the colleges at 44,238, adding that this was made possible by the construction of temporary buildings and by larger classes and longer schedules.
Out of a clear blue sky that quite unexpectedly is helping folks forget the still lingering cold wave, the Giants, it seems, are suddenly receiving some equally surprising pitching.

BOTH these books were planned primarily for children of 10 and up but their readers are by no means restricted to juveniles. Certainly they will be a boon to parents embarrassed by questions about the United Nations.

PARIS, May 10 -- There was more than national interest and more than national significance in the removal this week of the Communists from the French Cabinet where they had sat ever since the liberation except for the short interval of Leon Blum's all-Socialist Government.

Despite the dramatic success of penicillin and streptomycin, it is not likely that the sulfa drugs will be displaced in the treatment of infections. But the sulfa drugs are hard on the kidneys, and they are hard because they tend to deposit crystals that block urinary tubules.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Asserting that housing had become "a political football in Congress," Louis E. Starr, Commander-inchief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, urged easier credit terms today for veterans, builders, and producers of factory-built homes.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- An error by Eddie Joost, Philadelphia shortstop, opened the way for a seventh-inning two-run rally by the Washington Senators, who came from behind to defeat the Athletics, 4 to 3, today.

ST. LOUIS, May 10 (AP) -- Snapping a losing streak at seven straight, the Browns sent three Cleveland pitchers to the showers in the seventh inning with a sevenrun rally and walloped the Indians, 8 -- 3, tonight.
BERLIN, May 10 -- German writers celebrated today "the day of the free book" on the spot where, fourteen years ago, books of writers of all nations were burned by the Nazis.

LONDON, May 10 -- Following is the text of foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov's letter to Secretary of State George C. Marshall on the resumption of work of the Soviet-American Commission for Korea as transmitted from, Moscow today in English by Tass, Soviet news agency, and recorded in London by the Soviet Monitor, an affiliate of Toss:
BERLIN, May 10--Twelve German Army generals were charged with wanton murder, plunder and terrorization in Norway, Greece, Yugoslavia and Albania in indictments filed today at Nuremberg.

OTTAWA, May 10 -- Parliament and press have been busy this week examing from every angle the budget proposals introduced by Finance Minister Douglas G. Abbott last week and the picture he presented of Canada's present prosperity.

HAVANA, May 10 -- Communist Leader Lazaro Pena was re-elected Secretary General of the Confederation of Cuban Workers tonight in a Congress attended only by delegates of the Communist party and their sympathizers.

BOTH group and one-man shows of the week seemed to present more than the normal contrasts. "Landscapes of Four Centuries," at the Koetser Gallery, is an exhibition which abounds in contrasts. It opens with Carracci's late sixteenthcentury "Landscape With Bather" and closes with "Blue Hour" by Werner Drewes -- an abstract arrangement which requires some faith on the part of the visitor for inclusion under the title of the event.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 10 -- Power in the field events enabled Cornell's track team to defeat Princeton and Syracuse in dual meets today. Princeton fell by 69-65, and Syracuse bowed, 71 2/3 to 63 1/3.

Active buying for Mother's Day increased retail sales totals here this week. The rise for department stores was put at about 5 per cent over the like week of last year. Main-floor accessory and gift items, including hosiery and candy, were outstanding.

PITTSBURGH, May 10 -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation disclosed here today that it is building equipment for 200 new subway cars for New York City that will provide quicker stopping and smoother, quieter rides.

LONDON, May 10 (Reuters) -- Results of soccer matches in Great Britain today: ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division Aston villa 2. Blackburn Rovers 1. Bolton Wanderers 1, Brentford 0. Charlton Athletic 1, Liverpool 3.

A change in international policy "to overcome the European disaster" has been urged by Pastor Martin Niemoeller in a letter to an independent group of Protestants who recently organized themselves to help German Protestants. It was learned here yesterday.

EXCURSION trips catering to camera enthusiasts are scheduled for this spring and summer by railroads, bus lines and other organizations. Some of the railroads have already announced trips and others have the matter under consideration for later in the season.

NATURAL BRIDGE, Va., May 10 -- The carpet industry is planning an intensive program of basic consumer research in addition to its greatly expanded advertising program, Merrill A. Watson, president of the Carpet Institute of America, New York, told 100 representatives of the press and radio here yesterday.
LONDON. "OKLAHOMA!" hit London like a cavalry charge and London surrendered. The news has no doubt reached you by now, and I shall not describe the victory all over again.

PARIS, May 10 -- France's new Cabinet, reorganized without the Communists, today threw off the lethargy induced in the past by its internal discords and took action on the pressing problems that it has been facing.

LITTLE more than a week ago Howard Hughes, designer, builder and flier of airplanes and largest single stockholder in Trans-World Airlines, demonstrated some airborne radar equipment designed to help prevent mid-air collision of planes and crashes into mountain tops.

EVE TRIEM'S "Parade of Doves," a volume that received the 1946 annual award of the League to Support Poetry, is for this reader by and large a well-deserved prize winner. The advisory board of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism at a recent meeting considered suggestions that the scope of the Pulitzer Prizes be broadened to include radio and motion pictures, Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the school and secretary of the board, announced yesterday.

DAISIES from South Africa are sure to become more popular as gardeners realize their immense variety and great beauty. To most people, the African daisy means just one plant, the gerbera or Barberton daisy.

By SHEPARD STONE THERE is a fairly widespread assumption in this country that any word of recognition or praise for individual Germans or groups of Germans is part of a propaganda campaign to exonerate Germany and to obtain a "soft peace" for her.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Commemorating the centennial of the historymaking exodus of Mormon pioneers to the West, a group of their descendants will start from Nauvoo, Ill., this summer and follow the route of the early Mormons to their haven in Salt Lake City, Utah.

PITTSBURGH, May 10 (AP) -- Lefty Fritz Ostermueller pitched six-hit ball today as the Pirates opened a long home stay with a 3-to-0 shut-out victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. A crowd of 12,579 turned out as the Pirates made the most of four hits collected from two Cardinal hurlers.

To the Drama Editor: THIS season I have seen "Annie Get Your Gun," "Finian's Rainbow," "Another Part of the Forest" and "Dream Girl," all by the following technique: About an hour before curtain time I drop by several box offices of shows I want to see.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- United States citizenship for the natives of Guam and American Samoa has been recommended by a Special Civilian Committee appointed by the Navy Department to study the situation. Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal, who released the report today, said he concurred in the recommendation and stated that Congress would be asked to take action.

Larry MacPhail, Yankee president who has a penchant for getting into and out of scraps--his latest was with Baseball Commissioner A.B. (Happy) Chandler-- yesterday found himself in another trying situation, this time with the Bronx's chief panegyrist, Borough President James J. Lyons.

DETROIT, May 10 -- The United Automobile Workers-Congress of Industrial Organizations Policy Committee today accepted the General Motors Corporation's action in laying off as a disciplinary measure about 500 workers who left their jobs to take part in a labor rally here last month.
A significant new home center is taking shape rapidly on land along the Hempstead Turnpike which previously was utilized as a Long Island farm.

IN the flowering of modern chemical science, gases from coal have yielded up such disparate products as medicines, dyes and artificial rubber. The same gases yield also components of the most powerful explosives and the bases for the most poisonous gases.

ST. LOUIS, May 10 -- Threat of a boycott of undesirable motion pictures by 6,000,000 members of the Southern Baptist Convention through rating agencies was contained in a resolution adopted unanimously today by the convention at its closing business session at Kiel Auditorium.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 10 -- Conservationists along the Pacific seaboard have renewed an old battle to save trees which symbolize this region to the world. In northern California and southern Oregon, intensive campaigns are under way to bring about protection of the historic redwoods.

Scoring heavily in the sprints and jumping events, Pennsylvania defeated Columbia, 87 to 53, in a dual track and field meet at Baker Field yesterday. Bill Vessie, the Lions' ace high jumper, took individual honors with his third record -breaking performance of the current season.

Work has been started on the footings and foundations for the colonial-style shopping center in Huntington, L.I., which is scheduled for completion in about four or five months. The site, at West Neck Avenue and Main Street, was purchased from the Wood estate and was one of the Huntington landmarks since 1756.

CHUMAYA, Japan, May 10 -- The Allied nations will be lucky if they collect only a small fraction of the reparations claims against Japan, experts now touring Japan with Brig. Gen. Patrick H. Tansey, headquarters' civil property custodian, concede.

ANOTHER group of revivals in Victor's Heritage Series makes available the vocal art of further outstanding figures of one and two generations ago. Jeanne Gerville-Reache can be heard in the Habanera from Carmen and in Chanson du Tigre, and her magnificent contralto voice comes through in recordings made in 1910 and 1911.

A New York apartment builder yesterday proposed revival of the plan for partial tax exemption or new housing construction to help owners to offer apartments at lower rates, and a broker suggested ten-year tax benefits for veterans on homes they purchase.

The American-Scandinavian Foundation, 116 East Sixty-fourth Street, announced yesterday its awards of annual fellowships to deserving American students desiring to further their studies in Scandinavian countries

ITHACA, N.Y., May 10 -- Harvard, the lone varsity eight remaining undefeated in the East, and Wisconsin took the wake of another crew for the first time of the rowing season as Cornell won the quadrangular regatta on Cayuga Lake early this evening.

Plans already approved by the Maritime Commission call for the substitution next year of five P2SE2-R2-type vessels for the C4SA-3 ships now being operated as emergency passenger ships for the Government under general agency agreements, it was learned yesterday.
THIRTY examples of a documentary photographer's excursion into the realm of creative photography are on view through May 17 at the Egan Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street.

JUVENILE delinquency, a not inconsiderable civic cancer, has, for a long time, been troubling Hollywood's film makers and the Motion Picture Association, with the result that two pictures on that theme are slated for production.

BALLET THEATRE begins its final week at the City Center Tuesday, but there will be novelties, if not premieres, on the schedule nevertheless. Tonight will see Jerome Robbins' "Fancy Free" with its original cast.

Two sections of Premier Stalin's statement to Harold E. Stassen acquire special significance when studied in juxtaposition against the background of American and European economic history and in the light of current economic problems in the domestic and international spheres.

BERLIN, May 10 -- Breaking a week long blackout on comment by Briitsh officials on the food situation in the British zone, Lord Pakenhara, Miinster to Germany and Austria, confirmed today the severity of the crisis. Conditions in the Ruhr, he said, are "as bad as anything in the world."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 10 -- The United States led the fight today against instructing the proposed United Nations inquiry committee to bring in proposals for the ultimate or immediate independence of Palestine.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 10 (AP) -- Gerald Micklem, recent winner of the English amateur championsnip, today was named with eight other top British simonpure golfers to defend the Walker Cup against the United States team, May 16-17.

As a new low temperature record was set here yesterday for the third successive day, the weather man cautiously predicted that seasonable weather would probably emerge this week. But he made no positive forecast after the mercury registered 37.5 at 6:45 A.M. to erase the previous low of 37.7 set in 1900.

DAFFODILS, springlike and sunny though they Are when considered singly, sometimes disappoint the gardener when he looks at them in the garden. Lacking the masses of foliage and other blooms that give background to later flowers, daffodils may look a little lost and forlorn in the bleak scene.
