Today it is reverently defined in encyclopedias, lectured upon in genteel feminine circles, dissected by grave professors.

LONDON, May 10 (AP) -- Most of the attention of Britain's soccer fans was directed toward Glasgow today, where Britain defeated the European All-Stars, 6 -- 1, but in England, vital promotion and relegation matches were fought.

Architectural plans are nearing completion for Gov. Alfred E. Smith Houses to be erected on the lower East Side of Manhattan, Edmond B. Butler, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, announced yesterday.

To the Drama Editor: HAVING painstakingly confided the error of its ways in Richard Aldrich's recently published "confession," we wonder if Theatre Incorporated now feels purified and absoved of sin and that all is forgiven.
HANOVER, N.H., May 10 -- Capitalizing on a walk and a single for two runs in the ninth inning. Yale snatched victory from Dartmouth today, 7-6.

An indication of the potential additional housing facilities in sight for New York City is shown in twenty-five large-scale projects now materializing or proposed which will afford accommodations for approximately 143,470 persons, according to Lee Thompson Smith, president of the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York.
LONDON, May 10 (Reuters) -- The South African cricket touring team, on its first appearance in London today, was dismissed in two hours ten minutes by Surrey at the oval for a modest 83 runs.

With better values more plentiful in different markets retail buying hesitation diminished, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers. Customers were proving the existence of both "needs" and "buying power" by their favorable response to these better offering's, the report stated.

WILL "There Was a Time" cause a rift between Taylor Caldwell and her everloving public? Will that public (who storm the book stores in the hundred thousands to demand her annual contribution to the best-seller lists) mind that she has slapped their wrists in this semi-autobiographical novel about a young writer who forsakes thunderous chronicles of villainous financiers to write from his heart?

ST. LOUIS, May 10 -- Plans for a world fair here in 1953 -- to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the Louisiana Purchase -- have now reached an advanced stage, with some 115 local civic, educational, professional, social, industrial, business and labor organizations already committed in favor of the observance.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 10 (AP) -- Dr. Louis Kaufman Anspacher, New York writer and lecturer, died of a heart attack in a hotel room here today while returning from Los Angeles on a vacation motor trip. His age was 69. He and his wife had stopped at the hotel overnight and were to have left for New York this morning.

Vermont's adoption of the Uniform Stock Transfer Law, just announced, completes the list of forty-eight states, the District of Columbia, and Alaska, in which such legislation has been enacted. Earlier this year, Iowa and Kansas, among the last of the "holdouts," took similar action, so that the campaign directed toward the state Legislatures back in 1909 has now reached its culmination.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Members of the International Association of Machinists will vote next month whether to go back to the American Federation of Labor, and if they take their president's advice they will vote "no."

NEW LONDON, May 10 -- The International Meeting on Marine Aids to Navigation adopted at concluding sessions yesterday conclusions and recommendations which will have both immediate and long range impact on the maritime interest of the world.

A feminist movement aimed at acquainting the women of the nation in more detail with the news, functions and meaning of corporate undertakings preliminary to an attempt for wider placement of women on boards of directors and in the higher echelons of management of all kinds of domestic industries began in earnest last week.

BECAUSE of safety factors and influence on car design, the procedure of licensing automobile drivers is of increasing importance throughout the country. A survey by the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators reveals that in many states the examinations follow patterns devised more than twenty years ago, while in others only sketchy tests are given before the motorist obtains a license.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows. HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head: total 3,500 (estimated). Compared with week ago: Market $1 to $1.75 higher: most advance on hogs under 260 pounds; sows 50 cents higher.

Readjustment of the nation's economic structure is materializing slowly, with more and more labor wage agreements being completed. As the process evolved last week, a cautious attitude developed in the security markets, resulting in an easing of prices after two weeks of rallying tendencies.

The results of the recent conference of Foreign Ministers at Moscow were considered favorable to peace by a majority of pupils who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

The Schwab mansion on Riverside Drive--one of the most magnificent private homes ever built in New York--has been sold and will make way for a modern apartment center. After having remained empty for more than eight years, the stately granite chateau and the entire block in which it stands have been acquired by the Prudential Insurance Company of America for a residential project which may accommodate as many as 600 families.

MILWAUKEE, May 10 -- A petition asking for an inquiry into alleged "mishandling" of the affairs of District 32 of the Congress of Industrial Organizations United Steelworkers' Union, and demanding the suspension of Meyer Adelman, its director, was sent to international headquarters at Pittsburgh today.

BOTH lyric poets and prosaic gardeners speak of May as the month of flowers. From the earliest forsythia and Japanese cherries to the late lilacs and shrub roses, there is never a day when a glance from the house windows, a walk around the neighborhood, or a stroll in the country, does not show masses of bloom.

HORSE RACING Faultless won the fifty-seventh Preakness Stakes by a length at Pimlico yesterday, earning $98,005 for the Calumet Farm of Warren Wright. On Trust ran second, with Phalanx, 11-to-10 favorite, third, and Jet Pilot, Kentucky Derby victor, fourth in a thrilling race watched by 40,222 persons.

JUST why the Pulitzer judges failed to select a play for the season probably is destined to remain one of those guarded secrets. Still, in the wake of last week's disappointment one sidelight and a couple of headaches did turn up in which the Sardi set could take more than passing interest.

AN ARCISSUS fanciers look for varieties of bulbs that have new and refreshing beauty, resistance to disease and longevity. Certain varieties of narcissus have a distinct character and personality while others are noted for their spectacular and almost blatant quality.
Plans are being made for excavation of the buried palace of King Nestor, one of the best-known rulers of Homeric Greece, it was learned yesterday.

The Federal Government should turn away from its policy of aiding speculative builders to sell homes, and should concentrate on aiding communities to build large-scale rental housing projects, Nathan Straus, former head of the United States Housing Authority, said yesterday.

Two days of intensive negotiations brought an agreement last night between the New Jersey Bell System and 12,000 striking operators but the mechanics of membership ratification precluded any restoration of regular telephone service before Tuesday at the earliest.

MISS JAMESON, in this book, is on what is for her familiar ground. Here are intrigues (criss-crossed but not woven) among the ruling and intellectual class. Here is an England that is curiously cold, remote, and unrealistic, even though the dateline is 1939.

HAKATA, Japan, May 9 -- Across northwestern Kyushu lies an industrial band that seems to be a single city, but it is a city of plumeless smokestacks. Fukuoka Prefecture, despite its eighty-eight coal mines, has a coal shortage. Factory output is below 30 per cent capacity and 300,000 persons are on relief.

A plan to refund food retailers to compensate for any price cut originating with manufacturers was proposed yesterday by J.J. Akston, president, and Emanuel Ebin, treasurer, of Dorset Foods, Ltd. The price-cutting plan, which is now being studied for action by members of Congress, the statement said, proposes a voluntary reduction by manufacturers of at least 10 per cent in food prices.
THE latest twist in contract bridge is "schneider bridge," a scoring device borrowed from gin rummy: If the losers of the rubber have not scored a point, the winners' score is doubled.
LONDON, May 10 -- An unusually severe winter that killed early crops and flooded wide areas of arable land has left Europe in a precarious position, so far as food supplies are concerned,
CHICAGO, May. 10 -- George Alfred Maney of near-by Evanston, Professor of Structural Engineering at Northwestern University since 1928, died today in Evanston Hospital at the age of 58.

THIS book, chiefly the fruit of Mr. Creekmore's experience at our naval base in New Caledonia, offers fresh testimony to the fact that poetry in these confused, disastrous times cannot be good without representing the intellectual and emotional complexity of our situation.

LIKE the champagne which he saw consumed by thousands of quarts (but which he seldom drank himself), this biography of the late Maury Paul sparkles and bubbles with intimate tales of New York's social world during the lavish Twenties and the thrifty Thirties.

CAIRO (By Wireless). AS a result of post-war readjustments in the international balance of power, the question of the necessary cooperation between the Arab States and one or more of the great powers has been reduced to a choice between Britain and the United States on the one side and the Soviet Union on the other.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 10 -- Republican chairmen from seventeen Midwestern and Western states today called on the Government to be mindful of the "inroads" of communism at home while considering expenditures to contain it abroad, and asked President Truman's cooperation with a Republican Congress to clear Government payrolls of all "subversive" persons.

IN the death of Sidney Keyes English poetry suffered its greatest evident casualty of the recent war. Although Keyes was not yet 21 when he died on the North African front he had already won himself a place with his volume "The Iron Laurel," published in 1942, and with the later fugitive pieces which were to be gathered together posthumously in "The Cruel Solstice."

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Western Electric Company and two unions representing striking employes continued contract negotiations inconclusively today, but a report of satisfactory progress came from one of the meetings.

CHARLES DICKENS was a reporter before he was a novelist, and when he turned to fiction he remained a great reporter of pre-Victorian and early Victorian England and its people. His penetrating eye and graphic pen gave the world perhaps the most complete portrayal of an era that literature has produced.

MOSCOW, May 10 -- Konstantin Simonov's "The Russian Question," the play that paints the American press black, was presented in Berlin only after the opposition of American "reaction" in Berlin had been overcome, according to Yuri Korolkov, writing in Pravda today.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- In a spirit of relaxed meditation on Friday night, a studious Congressman undertook to illustrate the significance of the vote on the GreekTurkish loan with a story about Mark Twain.

PRAGUE, May 10 -- That the United States and the Soviet Union should not be getting on as well as they ought to be is awkward, nerve-racking and costly to the hundreds of millions of citizens of those two nations. But it is a positive tragedy to central and eastern European countries which lie along Europe's broken backbone.

A bell rings every three hours. The huge doors of a 300-foot long conveyor room open outward. Two 26-foot trim, white cruisers emerge on separate steel cradles that have been inching along a moving assembly line. Two cruisers every three hours mean one every ninety minutes.

ERICH LEINSDORF'S article which appeared in THE TIMES music section of last Sunday, concerning the opportunities which the Vienna Opera now offers young American singers, has received a host of replies. The nature of the replies clearly indicates the intense desire of young American artists to get the stage experience and the education in music-dramatic interpretation which they cannot find in this country.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor sailed for England yesterday afternoon on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth.
LOS ANGELES, May 10 -- Los Angeles was abruptly confronted this week with the possible corporate loss of its whole waterfront.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 10 (AP) -- A U.S. Army Air Force plane piloted by one of America's most widely known World War II aces and carrying three American passengers was reported missing today in southeastern Africa. Four Royal Air Force planes immediately began a search.

THE formula for the historical novel is supposedly fixed. Its central characters are, traditionally, fictitious; real persons are restricted to subordinate roles. Only thus, we are told, can the novelist avoid tampering with the facts and attributing to his personages words and actions inconsistent with the record.

Plans by Robert R. Young and Robert J. Bowman, chairman and president, respectively, of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, to become directors of the New York Central Railroad, with the view of eventually consolidating the two roads, involve a complete upsetting of previously held ideas of competition among carriers in the Eastern territory and their groupings in any consolidation plan.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The grim reports of the food situation in Europe were a reminder this week of America's plenty. They bore a suggestion, too, that United States foodstuffs would probably be costly for a long time to come.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- President Truman and 500 other dinner guests were informed by the Gridiron Club tonight that even the Cannibal Kingdom of Darkest Africa has learned that the best way to get a loan from Uncle Sam is to introduce communism into its country.

A NEW museum was opened to the public last week: one devoted to a single theme, which it presents with opulent distinction. This is the Jewish Museum, now permanently established at Ninety-second Street and fifth Avenue occupying the former home of Mr. and Mrs. Felix M. Warburg.
BOSTON, May 10 -- The full scale reshuffling to which Bucky Harris subjected his lineup paid victory dividends today at Fenway Park.

The main issue in the choice of a suffragan Bishop af the Episcopal Diocese of New York next Tuesday will be whether the candidate comes from New York City or from the suburban area of the diocese. Whether he is "high," "broad" or "low" church will not be a factor, it is said.

During the recent war one of the earliest drives to keep our service men happy while overseas was the quest for books. The campaign proved successful and established many a new friendship. Now it seems that another drive is in order, a drive to obtain books for Britain.

THE arrival in New York of three duck-billed platypuses, those odd little Australian animals that represent some of the confusion of nature's efforts to turn out a mammal, has emphasized again that the big continent "down under" possesses some of the queerest creatures on earth.

Any effort to stop the decentralization of our cities and towns would be a waste both of time and money, according to Guy Greer. The forces which started decentralization are not only as strong as ever but are growing stronger, he declared.

LONDON. "GOING to the dogs" is what he ockneys call it, and "going to the dogs" is what the M.P.'s thundered in the House of Commons recently when they pondered the bad influence of mid-week sports in general, and greyhound racing in particular, on Britain's short supply of manpower.

NEWBUEYPORT, Mass. ON the lawn of the church of the first religious society in Newburyport stands an illuminated, oversized bulletin board which displays, with frequent changes, pious and ethical maxims designed to jolt the thoughts of passers-by. Last week's quotation was from a Chinese proverb: "The man who removed the mountain began by carrying away small stones."
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California said today that the Federal Government should make a substantial payment on the national debt before cutting taxes.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 -- Hoodlums were ordered banished from San Francisco today by Charles Dullea, chief of police, as the slaying here of Nick De John, a former Chicago gangster, was described by Edmund G. Brown, District Attorney, as "a signature murder, which bears all the marks of a gang slaying."
GENEVA, May 10 -- The Economic Commission for Europe decided today to extend its sessions in an effort to break out of the impasse that has developed on nearly all major issues.

Three major developments in engineering design of underground factories for future war plants require specialized knowledge for successful use of the new science of "protective construction," Guy B. Panero, head of Guy B. Panero, engineers, 420 Lexington Avenue, disclosed yesterday following an announcement by the Corps of Engineers, United States War Department, that he had been retained to complete a $150,000 survey of new underground plant sites.

PARIS, May 10 -- A great Paris fair eclipsing any held in Europe this year and demonstrating a resurgent French economy opened its doors today at Porte de Versailles on the southwestern outskirts of the city.

IN the summer of 1934 a young actress, 17 years of age, born in Ireland of English parents, sailed to New York from London and went to Hollywood under contract to Universal. Her name was Valerie Hobson. A few weeks later a huge actor, born in England of Irish ancestry, arrived in New York from London, and like Miss Hobson, proceeded to Universal City.

The first Alexander Hamilton Award, a Tiffany bronze medal given annually to a Columbia College alumnus for "distinguished service and accomplishment in any field of human endeavor" by the Alumni Association of Columbia College will be presented to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president emeritus of Columbia, Frank J. Hogan, District Attorney of New York County and president of the association, announced yesterday.

Possibly the Terry lectures "On Understanding Science," delivered last year at Yale by President Conant of Harvard, may have had something to do with Yale's decision to give a humanistic science course for undergraduates in the liberal arts -- undergraduates who are not majoring in science.

The report of the special civilian committee appointed by Secretary Forrestal to study the present Naval Government on Guam and American Samoa, which is made pnblic today, recommends that citizenship be granted immediately to the peoples of those islands and that organic acts for their governance be drawn and submitted to Congress.

THE first-class personnel director is a man with a double mission in life. He interprets management's views to the workers and the workers' views to management. He may spend all morning arguing with top management to put forward a compromise offer and all afternoon arguing with the union to accept it.

A timely double by Johnny Brescia, in the last half of the seventh inning enabled New York University's baseball team to beat St. John's, 4 -- 3, yesterday at Ohio Field. It was the Violet's eighth consecutive Conference victory and N.Y.U. remains unbeaten in twelve games.

France's Communists In most of Europe Communist parties emerged from the war with increased strength and until last week held Cabinet posts in nine countries. In France they made spectacular gains, winning the largest number of Assembly seats (182 out of 618) in the last Nov. 10 election.

THIS is a light and unpretentious little tale about one of London's numerous colorless and uncomplaining cockneys who suddenly finds escape from the dreary realities of life through dreams. Henry Perkins doesn't have vague, wishy-washy daydreams.

THE vacationist who includes photography in his plans is in a position similar to that of the professional who has received a photographic assignment out of town or out of the country. Although modest when scaled against the professional's, the amateur's preparations should be pretty much along the same general plan.

PEARL HARBOR, May 10 -- The first scientific survey of an atomicbombed battleship, the war-scarred New York, has been completed here, but results of eight weeks of investigation will remain a military secret

UNSUNG in the world of journalism and among the general public, but of consuming interest to a certain select body, a very special magazine this spring is celebrating its first anniversary. It boasts no more than 2,000 readers, but they are avid readers and include some of the brighter luminaries of the business and professional worlds.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 10 -- Yale University will offer a new course, "The Development of the Sciences," starting in the fall term. President Charles Seymour said today that it was designed to aid in "the closer integration of the sciences and the humanities in the college curriculum and to emphasize the contribution of the sciences to liberal education."
PITTSBURGH, May 10 -- The National Jewish Welfare Board received tonight at its opening meeting here a twenty-one-point program of recommendations as a guidepost for future policies.

PELHAM GRENVILLE WODEHOUSE glanced out the window overlooking Radio City and said New York looked twice as big as he remembered it last time he was here, ten years ago. Mr. Wodehouse, we might add, looks twice as big as we had imagined him.

D.W. Figgis, president of the American Can Company, said yesterday that he has accepted the position as chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers' Development Committee for the Metropolitan New York Area, because of the "enlightened philosophy" of the present NAM administration.

Additional evidence of the "buying strike" of housing investors was presented yesterday in statistics given out by the regional office of the United States Department of Labor. Private builders started construction of only 630 dwelling units in the City of New York during April, against 1,120 in the preceding month and 2,650 in April, 1946, according to Robert R. Behlow, the regional director.

The formation of the Carnegie Hill Association, Inc., the purpose of which is to protect, improve and beautify the area between Eighty-sixth and Ninety-sixth Streets and Fifth to Lexington Avenues, inclusive, was announced yesterday by Carleton W. Betts, who has been named secretary and managing director of the organization.

THE one trend revealed by surveys conducted at the International Travel Exhibition last week in Grand Central Palace was that the American people have a great desire to travel and that they intend to satisfy that desire soon.

Autograph letters and manuscripts, first editions and other literary material belonging to Paul Zuckerman and the Baron and Baroness Carl von Seidlitz of New York will be auctioned tomorrow and Tuesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 10 -- Bobby Locke of Johannesburg, the South African champion, dropped a four-foot uphill putt on the eighteenth green for a two under par 70 and the 54-hole lead in the $10,000 Houston open golf tournament today.

THE general construction of "The Rimless Wheel" will possibly prevent it from rolling to best-sellerdom. But the discriminating reader will none the less delight in what it offers, and even hail its writer as a discovery. His publisher was first in so saluting him, having given him one of its Centenary Awards in its contest for members of the armed services.

PRAGUE (By Wireless). THE biggest hurdle in the path of world peace is that of Russo-American relations. If that can successfully be surmounted it should be possible to fit all fragments of the post-war puzzle into place. Burning lesser issues, such as those of Palestine, India, Germany and Greece, could easily be resolved by the joint determination and cooperation of the two greatest powers in the world.

LONG before she died, Willa Cather's place in American literature was secure. No American novelist was more purely an artist. This, the most obvious fact about her, was not sufficiently understood by the rigidly socialminded critics who, in her later years, reproached her for retreat from the contemporary world.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- A selling movement developed in grains in the latter part of trading today on the Board of Trade and prices broke under the leadership of May wheat. Numerous stop-loss orders were touched off on the decline.

TUNIS, Tunisia, May 8 (Delayed) -- Hoping to profit by France's political difficulties at home and her exhausting struggles in Indo-China and Madagascar, Tunisian Nationalists are expected to call a one-day nation-wide general strike on Monday.

With few exceptions, seeded players experienced little difficulty in advancing as the Eastern tennis championships for private day and boarding schools started yesterday at the Boulevard Gardens Courts in Woodside, Queens. The competition is sponsored by St. John's University.

IN DECEMBER, 1941, Doris Rubens was teaching at the University of the Philippines and doing a news broadcast on the side. She had been a newspaper woman in China during the years that Japan was overrunning most of that country, and her dispatches had not endeared her to the architects of Asia's co-prosperity sphere.

ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 10 -- Dr. Edward Fuller, president of Bard College and former administrative aide of the Manhattan atomic bomb project, warned today that man's progress in science may lead "to self annihilation."

In an effort to end suicides from the observation tower of the Empire State Building, Gen Hugh A. Drum, president of Empire State, Inc., announced last night that an additional barrier would be constructed around the present breast-high parapet.
OF all our garden flowers the annuals are easiest and quickest to grow. They spring up from seed, develop to maturity, flower, produce seed, and die, all in one garden year.

The anemones are blooming in the woods, late this year with a late, cool spring. Those who shy at botanical names may insist on calling them wind flowers, which is a good enough name. But if you trace the botanical name back to its origins, you come out at the same destination.

JERUSALEM, May 10 -- Those Zionists who have been invited to appear before the United Nations Political Committee are the Cabinet Ministers and Ambassadors of what is in effect a shadow government for Jewish Palestine.

In five years the Pacific Northwest, which means Oregon, Washington, Idaho and western Montana, has been transformed by electric power. Where once the lumberman's axe rang and farmers raised crops on irrigated soil there are now huge plants that produce aluminum, magnesium, ferro-alloys, heavy chemicals, airplanes, ships and plutonium.

WARSAW, May 10 -- The Polish Government believes that Britain will withdraw her opposition to the ratification of Poland's new western boundaries at the London meeting of the Foreign Ministers in November. As a result of recent developments, Poland expects the United States to stand alone in seeking revision of the OderNeisse frontier.

THE voluntary phase of price reduction last week began to take on the shape of involuntary action. Mill and factory shutdowns previously were accounted for by labor trouble and material shortages. Now there is an outcropping of curtailment due to the normal reason that supply has outdistanced demand.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Describing present courses of stury as obsolete and inadequate, more than 100 of the country's leading authorities in secondary education called today for immediate and far-reaching changes in the nation's high schools.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, was called upon yesterday by the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, CIO, at its biennial convention to start recall action against John Green, head of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, as national CIO vice president.
THE Columbia Broadcasting System is planning extensive alterations in its program schedule to accommodate the considerable new business which has come its way.

Puerto Rico has a great need for American-trained teachers who do not have "a feeling of superiority," but are sympathetic with the people, according to Dr. Edward G. Seel, president of the Polytechnic Institute of Puerto Rico.

Premier Ramadier's decision to grasp the nettle of French communism by ejecting his Red Ministers from the Cabinet appears to be strengthening the Government as well as the nation. His bold action brought dire forebodings on what Communist opposition outside the Government might do to France.

In the belief that it is important to understand vital issues of the day, New York City teachers have embarked upon a far-reaching project to determine the most effective way to utilize newspapers and periodicals in the study of world affairs and current events.

KARLOVY VARY, Czechoslovakia, May 9 (delayed)--As recently as last week on the second anniversary of the liberation of Czechoslovakia, President Eduard Benes told the world that his country had expelled its Sudetan Germans for good.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 10 -- Following are excerpts from statements made today before the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly by the United States, Soviet and Yugoslav representatives on the preparation of terms of reference for the Palestine Inquiry Committee:

PARIS. THE waiting lines in front of the movie houses were never so long. From the big, firstrun palaces on the boulevards to the humblest neighborhood house out by the Nation they're packing them in.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 10 -- Following is the text of a draft submitted today to the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly by the Philippines to consolidate and amend the terms of reference proposed by the Soviet Union and India for the committee of inquiry on Palestine:

NEW DELHI, India, May 10 (AP) -- The Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten, announced tonight that he had summoned representatives of the Congress party, the Moslem League and the Sikhs to meet him a week from today to hear the British Government's plan for transferring power to Indian hands in preparation for full independence next year.

LONDON has never had the reputation of being especially hospitable to opera, so the London Opera Company, which plays at the Cambridge Theatre, is feeling pretty proud of itself. It has established a new record in the British capital.
PARIS, May 10--With splendid military ceremony, Winston Churchill was decorated with the Medaille Militaire today by Premier Paul Ramadier in the Court of Honor in the Invalides.

BOSTON, May 10 -- Governor Robert F. Bradford of Massachusetts has called upon the state Legislature to pass extraordinary taxes in some key fields. Simultaneously, the Maine House has passed a 2 per cent sales tax and sent to the Senate a bill providing for a 1 to 6 per cent income tax.

Industry -- almost every segment of it -- is decentralizing for the purposes of more economical location, availability of labor and climate, according to a survey of the nation's big power and light companies, completed last week.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 10 -- The Harvard varsity track team defeated Yale at Dewitt Cuyler Field here today by a score of 71 1/2 to 63 1/2. The Eli yearlings triumphed over the Crimson cub team, 68 1/2 to 66 1/2.

To the Screen Editor: THE opinion that our movie industry has come to regard attacks on it for badly influencing the mores and morals of our people as "hazards of the game," which was expressed by Bosley Crowther in a recent article, "Blame the Movies," carries with it powerful implications.

The continued listlessness of the stock market in the midst of inflationary pressures, long a discouragement to the recruitment of new equity capital, is now confounding economic thought generally, especially in the littleexplored field of functional finance.

INGRID BERGMAN had performed that same piece of stage business in scores of other performances of "Joan of Lorraine." It was just a matter of seating herself on a bench. But on the night in question the audience watched an actor's nightmare come true.

FOR the American GI, the fighting part of the war was always very confused and confusing. This book, designed as a grim, very modern kind of family album for the grim, modern family of Americans who fought the fighting part of the war, does not clarify the confusion. It does not aim to.

LONDON, May 10 -- Incomplete returns from Britain's coal-mining areas indicated tonight an upward trend in production during the first five-day week experienced in the industry. The reports indicated also that absenteeism was the lowest in years.

JERUSALEM -- There was a picturesque ceremony this afternoon in the Council Ball of Government House as Sir Herbert Samuel took the oath of office as High Commissioner o Palestine. The stringent precaution taken throughout Palestine maintained order * * * Palestine police are marching through the streets.

HOLD onto your hats! Booking managers are unanimously agreed that, barring unforeseen circumstances, the new season will be considerably larger than the record -breaking one that only now is beginning to abate.

WEST POINT, May 10 -- Army's undefeated baseball team staged an eighth-inning rally to defeat Fordham, 4 to 3, thus enabling the Cadets to gain an even break in today's major athletic competition against metropolitan rivals.

More than a score of New Jersey communities having the commission form of government will hold elections on Tuesday. Among the larger cities are Bayonne and Hoboken, Hudson County industrial centers, and Passaic, Trenton and New Brunswick.

HERE at last is a truly dispassionate account of the Greek civil war. It is written, moreover, by a professional historian who was an eyewitness to much of its development. Before the war, the youthful author of this volume was an assistant professor of European history at Cornell University.

WHEN Oliver LaFarge went to Santa Eulalia in 1932, he found that the native Indians believed that World War I had threatened to wipe out mankind, and that in spite of the Virgin Mary's intervention it had brought enormous harm to the world.

LIKE his redoubtable contemporary, Dr. Samuel Johnson, with whom he had many characteristics in common, George Frederick Handel fought the long, weary battle from dependence on the patronage of nobility and wealth to a position of economic self-respect and independence.

MICHAEL SALTER falls in love with a girl he has never seen except as a picture in a torn newspaper. He knows that her first name is Lorelei, and that is all. There is no reason to hope that he will ever meet her but he does.

THE little blossoms of spring bring a certain heart-warming pleasure that is never equaled by the large and showy flowers that appear later in the border. The scillas, grape hyacinths and spring snowflakes, now blossoming so generously, even outweigh the excitement of the first snowdrop, capped in green last January.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 10 -- Historic First Presbyterian Church in the heart of this city's business district was wrecked by fire early this morning, with a loss tentatively estimated at more than $160,000.

THIS volume is a reprint, without change, of the Clark lectures which Mr. Forster delivered twenty years ago at Trinity College, Cambridge; to read it again is to have confirmed one's original impression of charm, insight and unpretentious wisdom.

GENEVA, May 10 -- The United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission, now in Geneva writing a report to the Security Council, found itself confronted this week-end with a serious issue that may raise, a challenge to the very authority of the United Nations.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 10 -- The biggest lynching trial in the history of the South is scheduled to get under way in the County Court Building here Monday, with thirty-one white men charged with the mob murder of a Negro.

HAWTHORNS in bloom this month are a beautiful sight. The small trees, twenty to twenty-five feet tall, are attractive anywhere, but especially suited to properties where about twenty feet of space can be given to them.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 10 (AP) -- An Army general announced today that a budding plot against the Government of President Enrico Gaspar Dutra had been smashed with the arrest of several sergeants.

BOSTON, May 10 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark pledged today that there would be no "witch hunts" in the elimination of all elements subversive to our form of government. In a speech before the second national conference on citizenship he asserted:

The Newburyport Plan and similar community-wide price reduction programs will not work in the New York area, in lines of tools, hardware, mill supplies, light machine tools, optical goods, instruments and power equipment, distributors revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Dramatic clashes in Congress on labor legislation this week have focused the attention of the nation on one of the most controversial subjects before the people since the New Deal was inaugurated fourteen years ago.

Physicians and college administrators should share the blame for lack of health departments and broad student health programs, Dr. Alexander G. Ruthven, president of the University of Michigan, declared here yesterday before 450 educators attending the final session of the Third National Conference on Health in Colleges.

An important improvement in supply of durable goods is taking place, D.J. Walsh Jr., a partner in Sanderson Porter, engineers, 52 William Street, disclosed in an interview yesterday. Five new developments were cited by Mr. Walsh to show major changes in the market for heavy equipment, which have been revealed by inquiries for quotations on future industrial requirements.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 10 -- A three-hit pitching chore by Bob Wolcott shut out Harvard today, 1-0. Princeton pushed a man across the plate in the first inning for the only tally against the Cantabs on University Field.
MEXICO CITY, May 10 -- The question of just what President Miguel Aleman accomplished in the United States is coming to the fore here as the excitement of his homecoming dies down.

PAUL WEISS, now Professor of Philosophy at Yale, enjoys double distinction of being one of the most brilliant students of the late Morris R. Cohen and probably the ablest disciple of Alfred North Whitehead. He was co-editor of the Harvard edition of the "Collected Papers of Charles S. Peirce"; his previous volume, "Reality," developed various themes of Whitehead's metaphysics with marked originality.

Excessively high income tax rates in peacetime invariably have the effect of discouraging incentive to produce income. Diminishing returns naturally follow, particularly as to taxpayers in the higher surtax brackets. But a balanced budget may be accomplished in spite of reduced revenues -- by cutting Government expenditures.

HOLLYWOOD. THE recession in motion-picture activity, which has gradually been accepted as fact by labor and management alike, can be demonstrated by the compilation of production figures for the first eighteen weeks of 1947.

VIENNA, May 10 -- Clemens Krauss, famed director of the Munich opera in Nazi days, conducted the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra today after an absence from the concert halls of nearly two years. He conducted the last concert of the Philharmonic in Vienna just before the fall of the city to the Russians and the first concert immediately after the liberation.

TO THE EDIOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In considering the various proposals to declare the Communist party of the United States an illegal organization, it would appear valuable to note the experiences of Canada with this problem.

JUST twenty-six years ago this week in the Review: On Page One Blasco Ibanez writes on "The Future of the Novel," and concludes: "The war has upset the equilibrium of Europe. Life seems to be in flux again. Everything now is possible.

The tenth annual campaign of the Greater New York Fund, which seeks at least $6,000,000 as "business's share" of the $32,000,000 needed by 423 organizations and institutions participating in the campaign, enters its third week today.

To the Drama Editor: CONTRIBUTORS to your "Drama Mailbag" appear to be pretty definite in their opinions about box office treasurers. Either they condemn these worthies outright or else they seek to justify their lapses by pointing out some of the less attractive traits frequently displayed by the public.

MANILA, May 10 -- With Russia the only large nation that has not recognized the Philippines diplomatically, the Department of Foreign Affairs has authorized a prohibition on Russian immigration here, effectve immediately. It has instructed various Government agencies to begin a nation-wide check on Russian nationals to determine which ones have a legal right to remain.

THE Little Gardens Club of New York City will hold a tour of gardens and penthouse terraces in Greenwich Village on Wednesday and Thursday from 2 to 6 P.M. Seven will be shown both days, one on Wednesday only.

IN 1887 an English gentlewoman named Isabel Randall wrote, under the title "A Lady's Ranche Life in Montana," one of the most keenly observant memoirs of western frontier life ever produced. But Mrs. Randall was a snob.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- Aided by Ed Armstrong's heavy batting, the Naval Academy defeated Penn here today, 6-0. The middies second baseman hit a home run in the first inning, doubled in a tworun spurt in the third and had a single. Earlier today Penn went over to University Field at Princeton and defeated Harvard, 3-2.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 10 -- Long Island Sound's warm-weather season of sailing started today with the "eye opener" regatta, first of the pre-championship events at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 10 -- A group of nurses from Great Britain, here to attend the Ninth Congress of the International Council of Nurses, today disagreed with reports that the food situation in England was extremely critical.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 10 -- Willard B. Spalding, who recently resigned as superintendent of local public schools, said today that "the refusal of the State Legislature to pass legislation that would make it possible for homeless citizens, and those who do not own their property to vote upon school finance matters, has precipitated our school crisis."

WHAT is probably the largest collection of postage stamps ever shown under one roof will be on display Saturday when the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition opens in Grand Central Palace here.

Voices About America In a normal world it would not be necessary for this Government to spend thirty million dollars on Voice of America to broadcast to foreign nations a true picture of our way of life.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange lost all early gains yesterday, and closed barely steady, 10 to 23 points net lower.

MODERN application of aluminum as a building material is shown in the home utilizing aluminum clapboard and aluminum shingles which is being built on Crooked Mile Road in Westport, Conn., for George Peabody Jr.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers took over first place from the Chicago White Sox in the American League race today, defeating the pale hose, 5 to 2, before 10,249 onlookers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of April 26 answering the letter of Boris Izakov of the Moscow Pravda (who, incidentally, is a Russian and not a Polish journalist), you raised several points and made a aeries of statements which, in our opinion, require rectification.
SAN FRANCISCO. NOT since the period from Oct. 28 to Nov. 3, 1945 -- between the departure of "Adam Ate the Apple" and the arrival of "The Only Girl," has the Geary Theatre here had a dark week.

If the Truman Doctrine were exemplified solely by the $400,000,000 we are about to advance to Greece and Turkey there might be reason for the fears some well-intentioned persons have expressed over it. We are providing $250,000,000 for military uses alone. All of Turkey's 5100,000,000 will be for defense.

The integrity of the United States Government is being tested by its attitude on the Palestinian problem before the United Nations, Rabbi Israel Goldstein said in a sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eigthy-eighth Street near Broadway, yesterday.

Department store sales by reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table which gives percentage comparisons with a year ago: 4 Weeks Year 1 Week Ended Ended to

Quiet trading featured the stock market in its short session yesterday. Fluctuations generally were small and prices at the close were mostly firm. Turnover on the Stock Exchange amounted to 240,000 shares, the smallest since July 29, 1944, compared with 250,000 on the preceding Saturday.

THOUGH the State Department's cultural activities now seem certain to escape complete extinction at the hands of Congress, its international short-wave programs apparently will have to be presented under a drastically curtailed budget.
Continued activity in housing developments and a commercial deal in Hawthorne highlight the real estate market in New Jersey, according to the latest information from brokers in that area.

BERLIN. EVERY day in the week except Sunday groups of British, French, Russian and American officials and assistants sit at lunch or over a snack bar in the Allied Control Authority Building in Kleist Park, Berlin, and thrash out the differences which have arisen in meetings, in general proving that, over a luncheon table at least, cooperation between the Allies is no myth.

WASHINGTON, May 10 --The State Department was not prepared today to comment on the letter received by Secretary of State Marshall from Foreign Minister Molotov. The letter, received late yesterday, concerned a resumption of American-Soviet negotiations on Korea.

THE usual family-album snapshot of the picnic, the hiking party, the family reunion or other group events can be improved simply by giving a little more thought to arrangement. The ordinary shot of this type is the boring record of a bunch of people who happened to be gathered in one spot rather than a picture of a grpup of persons interested in each other and having a wonderful time being together.

THE American Theatre Wing school for professional veterans has extended the scope of its dance department so that it now includes special work in choreography and supervised rehearsal for concert work. Its tenweek summer course, which begins May 26, will include virtually all phases of dancing, scaled to all levels of experience.

CINCINNATI, May 10 (AP) -- Ewell Blackwell pitched fivehitter today for his third victory of the year, as the Reds downed the Cubs, 5-1, in a game featured by Cincinnati's timely hitting and snappy fielding.
NOVELISTS like Miss Graham have done a great deal to familiarize the average reader with the customs and the recent history of China.
ATHENS, May 10 (U.P.) -- The Greek Government agreed tonight "in substance" to the American suggestion of an internationallysupervised general amnesty for Greece's estimated 15,000 guerillas.

ROCHESTER -- Rochester, "The Flower City," already decked in tulips, hyacinths, and jonquils, is impatiently awaiting the peak of its spring season, the Lilac Festival, when the gentle slopes of Highland Park, Cobbs Hill Park, and hundreds of private gardens will burst into bloom.

LONDON, May 10 -- The battleship Vanguard bringing home King George, Queen Elizabeth and the two Princesses from their tour of South Africa entered the English Channel tonight and is due to enter Portsmouth Harbor at 6 P.M. tomorrow.

Zoning in Queens has taken a "great stride forward" with the creation of the new "G-1" district designed to protect dozens of communities now built up with onefamily homes, in the opinion of Borough President James A. Burke of Queens.

SPURRED by the advancing season the tight little buds of flowering almond, Prunus glandulosa, are prodded into awakening. Deep pink, coral-tinged beads studding the dark branches expand quickly into dainty pale pink rosettes.

WITH all the jocularity of a clambake getting started in bare feet and shallow water, a crew of performers skylarked through a robust performance borrowing impartially from vaudeville, burlesque and backporch conversation last week before a Radio City audience.

BRUNSWICK, Me., May 10 -- Declaring that the foundation of our foreign policy was the recognition of the rights of the people of every nation to enjoy the same privileges which we claim for ourselves, Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, Senate minority leader, expressed the hope tonight that we might by our example, power and persuasive influence, finally bring the world to recognize that in war there are no winners, but all losers.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Senate fiscal leaders planned today to appeal directly to Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. for assistance in effecting a settlement of differences between House and Senate budgetcutting resolutions.

LIDDELL HART, plausible and brilliant writer, has long been known for his unorthodox military theories and his biting commentary about the methods of modern war. As military critic for The London Times and author of various British General Staff manuals, Capt. Liddell Hart was at one time the best known and the most respected of England's military writers (save in certain army circles where his name aroused violent controversy).

NANKING, May 10 -- Following yesterday's decision to raise the salaries of military men and civil servants, Government leaders today bowed to the demands of striking Shanghai workers and voted pay increases. The Government returned to the old system of adjusting wages to meet the upward trend of the cost of living.

The Graybar Electric Company, Inc., has adopted its first formal sales training plan for appliance salesmen as a necessary move to meet competition in the near future, G.T. Bryant, national manager of major appliance sales, disclosed in an interview last week.

The rayon weaving industry may be heading into a heavy inventory position and a possible serious price reaction, it was pointed out last week by industry observers. Examination of the past record of the industry, they said, reveals that weavers have been prone to disregard danger signals until too late.

Work is nearing completion on the 144-family cooperative apartment building which the Harwil Building Corporation, headed by William Kalker, is putting up on the east side of Eighty-fifth Street, between Thirty-fourth and Thirtyfifth Avenues, in Jackson Heights, Queens.

Mayor O'Dwyer has invited the delegates and Secretariat of the United Nations to be the city's official guests at the "I Am an American Day" celebration to be held on the Mall in Central Park next Sunday afternoon, it was announced at City Hall yesterday.
UPPER MARLBORO, Md. "SIXTY dollar bid, sixty dollar bid, sistabidabidabidbdbdbd, one bid, onebid, wunbidwunbidwunnawunnawunnabdbd bd bd bd."

THIS new book by V. SackvilleWest, poet, novelist, biographer, writer on travel and sundry other subjects, is a whodunit, complete with murder, police, unofficial detective and a romance. It is, as might be expected, very well-bred, with sustained suspense, a subtle and original turn of plot, and a fine literary flavor, qualities with which mysteries are not too often blessed.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 10 -- The Secor Farms Riding Club opened its two-day horse show today with twenty-three classes completed during morning and afternoon sessions. Another twenty -five events will be staged tomorrow, capped by awarding of five championships.

THIS honest, clinical novel will be compared with Charles Jackson's "The Fall of Valor" as surely as "The Fall of Valor" was compared with "Death in Venice," if for no better reason than the fact that we have so few novels of homosexuality in English.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A comprehensive report on the steel industry that may have far-reaching effects on future wage and price negotiations and the national economy is nearing completion by the Department of Commerce, it was learned today.

GOP and Labor Labor unions in America have as members 15,000,000 working men and women. Last week Congress neared final action on a bill that would fundamentally change the national labor laws under which unions achieved this strength.

Salary increases to about 10,000 New York City school teachers will be deferred until July 1, 1948, so that approximately $1,000,000 of the $3,900,000 in the budget for teacher pay rises can be spent for rehabilitation of some of the city's old school buildings, it was indicated yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- Backing up Joe Hatten's six-hit pitching with some flawless support, including three double plays, the Dodgers were back on the beam and in first place again today, beating the Phils, 4-2.

BLAST -- The number of steel-making furnaces in the United States on Jan. 1 was 1,170, including 924 open-hearth furnaces, 29 Bessemer converters and 217 electric furnaces, an inventory by the steel industry shows.

DERBY, Conn., May 10 -- After Yale's oarsmen took the measure of Pennsylvania and Columbia in the freshman and junior varsity races as the Derby Day regatta was renewed today on the Housatonic River, Coach Allen Walz's Eli varsity crew made it a clean sweep against these rivals by driving to a clean-cut triumph in the main event.

IT is strange that a book containing an adequate study of the music of Tchaikovsky should not appear until more than half a century after his death. Yet, despite all that has been written about him and his music, a reasonably complete survey of the whole of his creative output is here presented for the first time in English.

SHANGHAI, May 10 (U.P.) -- Eight hundred thousand Shanghai workers, faced with famine unless the price of rice came down or wages go up, today threatened to call a general strike at noon Monday. They demanded the Government raise their wages, stabilize the cost of living, "soak the rich" and demobolize the army.

nOT long ago a home builder could take his choice between two kinds of windows -- one that slid up and down or one that swung in or out from a vertical hinge or pivot. More than likely the frame would be made of wood.

Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade and Dr. William Jansen, who is to succeed him in September, were guests of honor at a luncheon yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel sponsored by the New York Principals Association and attended by 1,900 members of the organization and of the school system.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 10 -- Dr. Theodore Sullivan Cox, dean of the School of Jurisprudence at the College of William and Mary, died today at the McGuire Veterans Hospital in Richmond. He was 53 years old.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 10 (AP) -- A reliable informant quoted a leader of remnants of the separatist Azerbaijanian militia today as having said that they planned to start a campaign in the North against the Iranian Government this summer "exactly as the partisans are now fighting in Greece."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 10 -- An Antarctic gust blew up suddenly today in the crowded chamber of the Political and Security Committee where United Nations delegates were discussing terms of procedure for the proposed committee of inquiry for Palestine.

Expanding at the average rate of over $255,000,000 monthly during the last twelve months, total consumer credit has now surpassed former peaks and stands at an alltime high well above $10,000,000,000.

Stymie ran his race yesterday, and his race was good enough to earn $21,650 for his owner, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs. Competing in the fifty-fourth Metropolitan Handicap, tradition-laden mile race for 3-year-olds and upward, the 6year-old son of Equestrian let the others do the running until the race was about half over.
BALTIMORE, May 10 -- The first four horses in last Saturday's Kentucky Derby were the big four of the fifty-seventh Preakness Stakes at old Pimlico today, but the order was scrambled.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 10 -- Navy's varsity and jayvee crew came through with surprise victories in a triangular regatta on Lake Carnegie today. On the strength of previous performance, the Princeton boats were favored to take premier honors but the Orange had to be content with triumph in the freshman race, a two-shell affair.

THE flower arranger welcomes the appearance this month of blossoming shrubs, for they are a welcome change from the evergreen materials and stark branches with which she has been working. She can now get away from the rather studied and deliberate effects created with flowerless branches and design more lavish and spontaneous compositions that will contrast refreshingly with what has gone before.

ON the outskirts of Dante's Inferno there was a section reserved for the "trimmers," for those mean souls who had lived "on themselves intent," shifting for every advantage, playing all the angles in such a constant, petty selfishness that not even hell could with dignity admit them.

BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) -- Clem McCarthy, widely known sports announcer who specializes in horse-race events, became confused today during the running of the Preakness and announced Jet Pilot as the winner although Faultess actually won.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- Guatemala is first and second gear country. Once across the Salvadoran border, you go into high. Not even volcanoes -- commonplace as ant hills in this tiny, quivery land -- fray these ribbons of smooth macadam.

COOKBOOK authors are legion. They write volumes about herb cookery, about soups, about the French and the Chinese and the Russian cuisines. But in all that's been done little of value has appeared on Swedish food, and this despite the fact that almost everyone enjoys the adventure of the smorgasbord in a Swedish restaurant.

BOSTON, May 10 (AP) -- An old local favorite, Mrs. C.P. Amodies' Dinner Party, came with one of his typical stretch finishes before a crowd of 31,311 at Suffolk Downs today to capture the $10,000 added Puritan Handicap by a neck over D.F. Harrington's Weathercock and reward his backers with a $40.80 pay-off.
EAGLE BRIDGE. HOW do I Paint? well first I get a frame, then I saw my masonite to fit the frame. Then I go over the board with Oil, Then give the board three coats of flat white paint.

But in all that's been done little of value has appeared on Swedish food, and this despite the fact that almost everyone enjoys the adventure of the smorgasbord in a Swedish restaurant.

Amodies' Dinner Party, came with one of his typical stretch finishes before a crowd of 31,311 at Suffolk Downs today to capture the $10,000 added Puritan Handicap by a neck over D.F. Harrington's Weathercock and reward his backers with a $40.80 pay-off.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 10 -- Joseph Hiestand of Hillsboro, Ohio, shorn of his doubles crown yesterday, came back in splendid

LONDON, May 10 -- On April 29 in New Delhi the Constituent Assembly, which is composed mainly of Congress party Hindus, adopted this clause for the proposed Indian Constitution: "Untouchability in any form is abolished and the imposition of any disability on that account shall be an offense."

America's Policy President Truman, just two months ago tomorrow, proclaimed his historic "doctrine" aimed at containing the expansion of Soviet communism. He asked the Congress for immediate authority to extend $400,000,000 in economic and limited military aid to Greece and Turkey.

Erasmus Hall High School, defending all three championships, made a strong showing as the seventh Eastern interscholastic tennis championships, sponsored by Columbia University, got under way yesterday at the Sunrise Courts in Sunnyside, Queens.

In selecting college graduates for employment, the 1947 employer puts more emphasis on personality, including leadership and ability to get along with people, than he does on scholastic standing. This was one of the facts brought out in a new survey of employment experience of college placement departments made by the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company, Minneapolis.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES has consistently and forthrightly emphasized the need for a free press to preserve our democratic form of government. No better illustration of the necessity for such emphasis is required than the present political campaign for the city commission in Hoboken, N.J.

Just to show they haven't by any means lost their flair for bounding from the sublime to the ridiculous, the Giants yesterday regaled a banner throng of 51,840 at the Polo Grounds with a varied assortment of their gifted talents.

Five four-story and one fivestory apartment houses with stores at 151-57 East 124th Street and 2049-53 Lexington Avenue have been sold by Ann McCarthy Cushen to an investing client of Eugene O. Hussey in a transaction negotiated by the Leonard S. Gans Company, brokers.

COATESVILLE, Pa., May 11 -- More than 1,500 Texas steers arrived at the Buck and Doe Run Valley Farms during the week-end and another 1,500 are expected soon. They Will be fattened and sold in the fall as an experiment in supplying Eastern markets with beef raised near by.

The New York Black Yankees and New York Cubans split their first Negro National League twin bill of the season before 10,000 fans in Yankee Stadium yesterday. The Black Yanks won the opener, 4 -- 3, in fourteen innings, while the Cubans took the seven-inning nightcap, 7 -- 0, behind Luis Tiant.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 11 (U.P.) -- German officials in the Westphalia-Rhineland area have telegraphed British authorities refusing to be responsible for maintenance of health and security unless their hungry people get more food at once, the American-licensed Dena news agency reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Philadelphia and Washington split a double-header today before a crowd of 22,811. Bob Savage scattered ten hits to win the first game for the Athletics, 4 -- 0, while the Senators captured the nightcap, 2 -- 1, behind the seven-hit pitching of Walter Masterson.

The supply of Scotch on the market has eased to the point where tie-in sales are now completely reversed, liquor retailers reported yesterday. Price declines to near Office of Price Administration levels and reports of renewed production for export in Scotland have made some brands obtainable on an immediate-delivery basis, one large retailer said.
MOSCOW, May 11 -- The United States and Britain are charged with blocking the repatriation of displaced persons from the western zones of occupation.

All signs pointed yesterday to a sweeping shake-up of the executive staff of the New York City Housing Authority when Maj. Gen. Thomas F. Farrell, its new chairman, takes office on July 1. He will succeed Edmond Borgia Butler, who resigned.

THE trouble with Eddie Arcaro is that he's a bit too free with his advice. It's quite possible that Faultless never would have won the Preakness at historic Pimlico on Saturday if Heady Eddie had kept his opinions to himself. But the crack little jockey is an outspoken citizen and he spilled out his thoughts to Doug Dodson as soon as the Kentucky Derby was over.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- This was a gay day for the Phillies and a record crowd of 40,952 fans but, despite the sunshine and comparative warmth, a gray day indeed for the Dodgers in old Shibe Park.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Truman observed Mother's Day today by flying to visit his ill mother, Mrs. Martha E. Truman, at her home in Grandview, Mo. The journey and the return trip took nearly nine hours in all, giving him three hours at her bedside.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a former naval officer who was stationed in Trieste for almost a year, and served through the length and breadth of Italy before that, I should like to answer some of the letters and news items appearing in your newspaper regarding the supposed harshness of the peace treaty with Italy.

MARGUERITE BAY, Palmer Land, Antarctica, May 6 (Delayed) -- Our scientific work is already well under way at and in trips from this base. A recent geological field trip suggests the possibility of commercially exploitable deposits of various minerals, notably iron and copper, in the region of Neny Island.

MONTREAL, May 11 -- An attack on the multilateral air agreement on commercial rights, to be discussed by the International Civil Aviation Organization this week, was circulated among the delegates here today.
Group prejudice, particularly prejudice against Jews, was decried yesterday by Robert J. Boyle, a member of the board of governors of the Knights of Columbus.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., in the fifty-two weeks ended on Feb. 1, had sales of $265,412,038, and net profits of $11,858,768, or $4.82 a share on the common stock, according to the report released for publication today by Fred Lazarus Jr, president.

Unnecessary workers hired only because some union requires it and who usually do nothing more than stand by while others are hard at work appear on thousands of payrolls, and on many outside the entertainment industries.

LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- A few weeks ago you could have bought Britain's interest in the Walker Cup for its measure in tea, but they're getting downright cocky now about keeping the golf mug in the old country cupboard.

Almost 19,000,000 men are under arms throughout the world and about forty nations are spending at least $27,400,000,000 a year on armaments, a world military survey conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES shows.
PARIS, May 11 -- In Mme. Gres' midseason collection, guimpes with short puffed sleeves give a youthful, naive look to flared frocks.

LONDON, May 11 -- If the Conservatives win the next election in Britain, they will not attempt to denationalize the Bank of England, the coal mines or the railways, according to the official statement of the party's industrial policy issued tonight.

A partnership resumed three weeks ago after one of the members escaped from Federal custody was halted again yesterday when a special police detail prowling the Jamaica Estates section of Queens seized a man and a youth.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 11 -- The Greek border controversy, which came up in United Nations debate five months ago, is scheduled to be heard again tomorrow before the Security Council. The Council will meet here at 5:30 P.M.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 11 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton, announced today the plans for the final sessions of the university's year-long bicentennial celebration from June 14 to 17, at which time President Truman will receive an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws and deliver a major address.

The Arc Container Company, recently organized to trade in new and used containers and for distribution of drum equipment, has purchased the twoand-a-half story structure formerly occupied by the Harco Steel Construction Company at 1180 East Broad Street, Elizabeth, N.J.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Justice Meier Steinbrink of the New York State Supreme Court proposed today at a convention of B'nai B'rith a five-point legislative program for preventing discrimination against minority groups, and for improving the enforcement of civil rights laws.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 11 -- A pioneer woman in the fight for higher salaries for nurses in Sweden declared here today, as newly elected president of the International Council of Nurses, that there was "only one way" for nurses to improve salaries and working conditions.

BUENOS AIRES, May 10 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The already serious congestion in this port is growing steadily worse and as a result the 25 per cent surcharge on freight rates imposed by American shipping companies on May 1 will be increased to 35 per cent on June 1, shippers said today.

CLEVELAND, May 11 -- Although adverse weather conditions will reduce this month's ore movement by several million tons, shipments from May 1 to June 1 will eclipse those for the same period last year by more than 5,000,000 tons, operators of Great Lakes vessels predicted today.

Sale of the old Schwab chateau on Riverside Drive for replacement by apartment houses marks the end of an era. It is the last of New York's private palaces still standing in melancholy grandeur on an entire city block. An altered economy makes it unlikely any will ever be built again.

An increase of 6 1/2 to 15 per cent in passenger rates to and from Pacific Coast points on Western railroads will go into effect on June 1, but will not affect tickets bought before that date, it was announced here yesterday.
Senator Claude Pepper of Florida declared last night that the United States should take a firm stand against any proposal by Great Britain and the Arab states to end the Palestine mandate.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- With the first billion-bushel crop of winter wheat on record about to be harvested, members of the grain trade are paying more attention to the statistical position of that grain likely to prevail in this country, and also the prospective needs of Europe and the Far East.
Spring returned to New York and its suburbs yesterday after three days of unseasonable cold.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 11 (U.P.) -- Albemarle County of Virginia, birthplace of Thomas Jefferson, began observing today the first Community Atomic Energy Week in history.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 11 -- A housing policy that tends to keep most Negroes in segregated areas and a lack of employment opportunities retard Negro development here, according to persons familiar with conditions. The city now has about 12,000 Negroes.

When the Rev. Dr. Horace W.B. Donegan, for the last fourteen years rector of St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, is put in nomination tomorrow for the office of Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, the nomination will be seconded by the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent of St. Bartholomew's Church.

More American-flag vessels must participate in foreign trade than heretofore if the United States is to have an adequate merchant marine, a spokesman for the American Merchant Marine Institute asserted yesterday.

WARSAW, May 11 -- Communist Vice Premier Wladyslaw Gomulka's call for a final merger of the Communist and Socialist parties has brought into the open the tension between the two major parties of the governing bloc.

A plan for new piers and warehouses on the East River in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, described as offering partial solution to the need for expansion of the Port of New York, has been prepared by Charles F. Giraud, Inc., consulting engineers for the Bronx Chamber of Commerce.

The city's streets were the background for a vast fashion show yesterday as women turned out in their best outfits to celebrate Mother's Day. Flowers and corsages were the order of the day and many women wore new gift earrings, bracelets, wrist watches and other ornaments.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, May 11 (U.P.) -- Col. Chesley G. Peterson, World War II air ace missing since Friday in a flight over the African bush country, was reported safe today. His plane, with three other American fliers aboard, had made a forced landing in the remote southwest corner of Tanganyika Territory, east of Lake Nyasa.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A dynamic foreign policy involving intensive research into trade and tourist business without reducing United States tariffs was proposed today by Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, who will introduce this week a bill to set up a foreign trade board.

BERLIN, May 11 -- Unless the food crisis of western Germany is solved quickly, the economic merger of the American and British zones is doomed to failure within half a year, in the opinion of the highest authorities of the two military governments.
HOUSTON, Tex., May 11 (AP) -- Bobby Locke, with the help of great putting, won the $10,000 Houston open golf tournament today with a 72-hole total of 277 -- 11 under par.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The archives of educational institutions throughout the country contain the names of many successful business men who have contributed actively and financially to the establishment, growth and development of educational programs so that the youth of this country would be better prepared to face the problems of life and to further the cause of democracy.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Greece and Syria, as well as six LatinAmerican nations, were among purchasers of surplus United States munitions from stocks abroad, the State Department disclosed in a periodic report of its Foreign Liquidation Commissioner.

Worried over the recent sharp decline in residential construction in New York and other areas throughout the country, the Federal Government will relax sharply some of the remaining major controls over building work within a few days, it became known yesterday.

In the present-day struggle between "the forces of Christ and the forces of anti-Christ" Christianity cannot be sufficiently strong without prayer, the Right Rev. Dr. John William Charles Wand, Lord Bishop of London, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, Broadway and 155th Street.

GENEVA, Switzerland, May 11 -- The new French tariff, as it will emerge from the current bargaining in the Geneva Trade Conference, will be considerably less a barrier to American exports to France than the pre-war system of French protection.

CAPE MAY, N.J., May 11 -- Four men were Killed when a fourmotored Lockheed Constellation of Trans World Airline exploded and crashed at 8:45 A.M. today in the middle of the Delaware Bay Ship Channel, about ten miles north of here.

LONDON, May 11 -- Rarely has Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Dalton been as enthusiastically aclaimed by the City as he was or his forthright statement on Wednesday about the necessity for a substantial scaling down of sterling debts that accumulated against Britain during the war and which now amount to more than three billion pounds.

King George and the royal family are home at last from their 10,000-mile jaunt through South Africa. The public is already speculating about a royal marriage. But in Downing Street, and no doubt in Capetown, too, the results of the King's mission are still being carefully weighed.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 11 -- Turkey will use for military purposes most, if not the entire sum of the $100,000,000 in aid voted to her recently by the United States Congress. Military authorities have declined to state publicly their specific requirements.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, who has been elected president of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary, reported yesterday that 20 to 30 per cent of Protestant churches were without ministers because of the "despiritualization" in American homes.

The State executive committee of the Liberal party is scheduled to elect Adolf A. Berle Jr., former Assistant Secretary of State and Ambassador to Brazil, State chairman at a meeting this evening in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel New Yorker.

CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers gained a game and a half first place lead in the American League today by sweeping a double-header from the Chicago White Sox, 10 to 0 and 6 to 1, on two three-hit performances before 45,755 fans.

Sophia Vembo, Greek contralto, made her American debut before an enthusiastic audience yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall in a recital given on behalf of the Greek War Relief Association, Inc. In a program devoted to popular songs of her country and recitations, the richly gifted young artist immediately made a deep impression.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman declared tonight that an expansion of trade among all nations was indispensable to the world's long-run recovery from the war.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 11 (AP) -- Misfortune hit the United States Walker Cup golf team again today and put Smiley Quick on the shelf.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 11 -- More than 600 graduates of classes from 1915 through 1919 and from 1934 through 1939 returned to Vassar College this week-end for the second of five reunion week-ends which this month are bringing back all classes to the campus.

Late in 1945 the physicists of the country protested against the veil of military secrecy that had been drawn over research. The protest made some impression on Congress, for the McMahon Act, which creates the United States Atomic Energy Commission, calls for the dissemination of scientific information.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 11 -- Tracing the struggles of those who planted the first permanent English settlement in America at Jamestown Island, enduring "every conceivable discouragement, pain and suffering," Paul Green, Carolina playwright, spoke at exercises today in the old church at Jamestown commemorating the 340th anniversary of the landing of the first group of settlers on May 13, 1607.
BRUSSELS, May 11 -- The collection of art treasures from the Imperial Museum at Vienna, now on public View here for the first time outside of Austria, is being sought for display in New York.
DETROIT, May 11 (AP) -- Unionized foremen of the Ford Motor Company today approved a strike but set no date for it.
NANKING, May 11 -- The National Government faces a social and economic crisis that will soon test its capacity to rule non-Communist China.

The city's emergency program to safeguard its inhabitants against a smallpox epidemic resulted in the vaccination of 6,350,000 persons in a single month, according to a report submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer by Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein and made public yesterday.

Replying to the last letter of Secretary of State Marshall regarding resumption of negotiations on Korea, Foreign Minister Molotov has declared his willingness to accept as a basis for these negotiations certain American proposals summarized by him for broader Korean participation in the planning of that country's future government.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Republican program in Congress is so well defined that interest has shifted to what action President Truman will take on two bills, those to revamp the labor relations laws and to reduce individual income taxes.

Despite uncertainties of price policies, a heavy influx of buyers is expected in the New York garment market to view fall lines of women's apparel in the four weeks beginning May 19, resident buying offices reported last week.

In an article which appeared on this page on May 8, George A.
