Mooney, THE TIMES banking specialist, reported that an advertising agency, acting on behalf of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) had recently circulated a questionnaire among potential banker-investors in the proposed debentures of the IBRD.

MIAMI, Fla., May 11 (AP) -- Miss Doris Hart, who overcame childhood infantile paralysis to become one of the South's leading women tennis players, will leave here June 5 in quest of tennis honors formerly held by her best friend, Miss Pauline Betz, it was learned today.

CINCINNATI, May 11 (AP) -- Len Merullo doubled, scoring Don Johnson to break a 3-3 tenth-inning tie and give the Cubs a 4-3 victory over Cincinnati in the second game of a double-header after they had won the opener, 6 -- 3. The twin victory moved Chicago into undisputed possession of first place in the National League.

The Transport Workers Union, CIO, has won the first skirmish in its battle to get the Board of Transportation to reconsider conditions under which 2,000 motormen and conductors on the IND division of the city subway system may exercise their "pick" of train runs, it was learned yesterday.

The commercial aviation industry in the United States is undergoing a transition that will see it emerge far more dependable, larger and sounder financially than it ever has been, if it is permitted to operate under continued free competition, Warren Lee Pierson, newly elected chairman of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., declared yesterday.

LONDON, May 11 -- Hundreds of thousands of cheering Britons welcomed the royal family home today as it steamed into the Portsmouth harbor on the battleship Vanguard after a fourteenweek tour of South Africa.
More than 16,000,000 of the approximately 19,000,000 men in uniform throughout the world are organized in ground armies, the military survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES reveals.
GREAT NECK, L.I., May 11 -- Miss Peggy Johnson of New Rochelle shared in most of the honors at the spring horse show on the Rice Farms in Lake Success here today.

Retail stores saw activity last week in dress departments as better than anticipated, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK times by leading resident buying offices. Fall coat and suit lines opened showing interesting style treatments, the report said.

BOSTON, May 11 -- Big Bill Bevens got into difficulties from which he couldn't extricate himself at Fenway Park today and the Yankees suffered their fifth reverse in eight games on this painful road trip which will end tomorrow.

Mid-May brings no let up in the local art season, nearly thirty diverse events being scheduled for this week. Openings today include a non-juried show of work by members of the National Association of Women Artists at the Argent Gallery.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The resignation of Under-Secretary of State Dean Acheson is scheduled to be announced this week, it was learned today. He will be replaced by Robert Abercrombie Lovett, New York banker and former Assistant Secretary of War for Air, on July 1.

Few stage and screen stars have received the homage paid to Ingrid Bergman, who closed a highly successful engagement Saturday night in Maxwell Anderson's play, "Joan of Lorraine." Further evidence of her popularity was given after Saturday's matinee, when a crowd, estimated at 300 persons, almost double the number usually waiting for her on matinee days, congregated in front of the Alvin's stage door.
The Russian armed forces are the largest in the world, exclusive of the amorphous, half-armed masses divided into National Government and Communist armies warring in China.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 11 -- Rains throughout Yugoslavia this week just about assure good crop prospects for July, according to agricultural experts here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- RKO has completed the cast of "I Remember Mama" with the engagement of Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Philip Dorn and Jessica Tandy for major character roles, and the picture is scheduled for the cameras in two weeks, with George Stevens directing.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., May 11 -- Production efficiency and improvement of marketing methods are slated for increasingly important roles in the textile industry as consumer resistance against high prices begins to slow movement of goods from the country's textile mills, Richard S. Cox, dean of the Philadelphia Textile Institute, said today.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 11 -- In an unusual breeze that skipped back and forth across Long Island Sound, the second regatta of the pre-championship season was held today off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

OSAKA, Japan, May 11. -- The possibilities of a sharp clash of interest between the Netherlands and China arose today over 650 tons of copper coins and fifteen tons of nickel coins seized by a Headquarters civil property custodian.

VIENNA, May 11 -- Joseph M. Dodge, the American member of the four-power commission to investigate the Austrian treaty problems on the spot, expressed the hope here today that a concrete approach to the German assets question and other problems would bring success.

If there is anything in omens it will be generally agreed that the new International Bank, in making public over the week-end the terms of its first lending operation, a $250 million credit to France, got off to a most auspicious start. Events themselves furnished the stage directions whereby the announcement was to coincide with news of dramatic victories for the Government of that country in the fields of domestic and foreign affairs.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- Dean Arthur T. Vanderbilt of New York University Law School, a former president of the American Bar Association, has been unanimously selected as director of the association's survey of the legal profession.

PITTSBURGH, May 11 (AP) -- a three-run rally in the sixth enabled the Pirates to escape with a 3-3 tie in an abbreviated seven-inning nightcap game with the Cardinals today, after St. Louis took the teninning opener, 10 to 6. A crowd of 29,315 watched the twin bill cut short by Pennsylvania's Sunday curfew law.
PARIS, May 11 -- France today passed her first breadless Sunday, which will be regular henceforth under the regulations instituted for combating the wheat emergency.
ZURICH, May 11 -- Prices of shares of all leading Swiss chemical undertakings have shot up to record peaks in the last fortnight and show a strong tendency to mount still higher.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 11 -- Unable to agree on the scope of the proposed United Nations' inquiry into the future of Palestine, a fifteen-nation subcommittee will return the matter tomorrow to the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly.

LONDON, May 10 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Board of Trade reported today that consideration of proposals to found a Government owned film industry in Britain has been postponed until later in the year.
CARLSBAD, Czechoslovakia, May 11 -- Czechoslovakia has called in her children from all over the world to fill the vacuum left in the Sudetenland by the expulsion of 3,500,000 Germans.
PONTIANAK, Borneo, Monday, May 12 (AP) -- The Netherlands Commission General signed an agreement today making West Borneo a self-governing territory within the United States of Indonesia.

Attorney General Clark is one of those responsible for carrying out the Presidential order to screen out of Federal employment persons associated with "totalitarian, Fascist, Communist or subversive" organizations. Such persons may not be reassured by Mr. Clark's statement in Boston Saturday that he planned no "witch hunts."

ST. LOUIS, May 11 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians overwhelmed the St. Louis Browns, 16 to 1, today. The Indians' sixteen hits included four homers, two by Joe Gordon, who batted in four runs. A homer by Bob Dillinger of the Browns deprived Red Embree of a shut-out.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,200,597,447. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

WHITE PLAINS, May 11 -- Climaxing a two-day program marked by fine weather and close competition, five championships -- three of them for hunters and one for horsemanship with hunter seat -- were awarded at the annual spring horse show of the Secor Farms Riding Club on the club's spacious grounds at Hillair Circle today.

Western Electric picket lines continued to keep most longdistance telephone operators away from their switchboards yesterday, but the long lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported that it had been able to handle two-thirds of the normal avalanche of Mother's Day calls through its New York headquarters.

Builders were active bidders at an auction sale of lots in Garden City L.I., held on the property on Saturday afternoon, when 173 lots were struck down for a total of $76,287. The sale was held under a tent at New Hyde Park Road and North Railroad Avenue, near the Stewart Manor railroad station, and was conducted by Stephen A. McDonald, vice president of Joseph P. Ray. Inc.

The British were wishful thinkers before the war. The overwhelming response to the "peace ballot" and the acclaim given to Chamberlain after his meetings with Hitler showed how generally they had persuaded themselves to count on "peace in our time." Now the opposite is true.

Spotted in Times Square after a two-month search by his alleged victim, an ex-convict was held in Felony Court yesterday on a charge of grand larceny. The prisoner, David Bender, 48 years old, of 135 Legion Street, Brooklyn, waived examination and was held for the grand jury by Magistrate Morris Ploscowe.
Three large-scale colonial or civil wars, involving millions of men, are raging in the world, and at least 2,000,000 troops are occupying or garrisoning territory beyond their own national borders.

PITTSBURGH, May 11 -- Activity in the steel industry was retarded last week by a strike in the Chicago district, and national steel ingot output was down to 91 per cent of capacity off 3 1/2 points from the revised rate of 94.5 per cent in the week before.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 11 -- The biggest lynching trial in the history of the South is scheduled to open here tomorrow morning with thirty-one white men placing their fate in the hands of neighboring farmers, mill workers and business men on charges of slaying a Negro.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 11 -- Three members of the delegation of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee to the United Nations General Assembly session were described today by The Nation Associates as men who rank with the "worst of the Axis war criminals."

WASHINGTON, May 11 (U.P.) -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders of Vermont predicted today that the Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report may be able to present its national price survey findings to the House and Senate in about six weeks.
CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- The touring Palestine champion Hapoel Soccer Club was held to a 1-1 tie today by the combined SpartaHakoah teams of Chicago before 20,000 at Soldier Field.

BILBAO, Spain, May 11 -- The civil government of Guipuzcoa Province published a note in today's press declaring that all strikes had ended. It thus acknowledged for the first time that there had been labor troubles in that neighboring province as well as here.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 11 -- Virtually all of Fairfield County was blacked out and thrown into confusion tonight by a failure of power on the lines of the Connecticut Power Company.

Raisin growers are declaring this a national "week" for their product. It's easy to see why, for the United States Department of Agriculture announces that this dried fruit is now more plentiful than it has been at this time in any year since before the war.

The Teachers Union, Local 155, United Public Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, called upon all school faculties yesterday to hold meetings in their schools today to protest action by the Board of Education to postpone until July 1, 1948, the granting of pay rises to 10,000 teachers in the kindergarten-to-6B classification.

AMSTERDAM, May 11 -- The granting last week of a loan of $250,000,000 to France by the International Bank for Development and Reconstruction was greatly welcomed in responsible quarters here as a step in the task of bringing relief to Europe.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market last week were featured by strength in spots and nearby futures deliveries, with relative easiness in the distant positions. At the close of trading on Saturday changes in active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ranged from a decline of 12 points to an advance of 82 points.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 (U.P.) -- Officials of the American Communications Association, CIO, admitted today that they had been defeated in the Far Western telephone fight. They said they consider "the strike is broken" and will order their members to return to work at 7 A.M. tomorrow.

Naval construction programs are moderate, and most of the navies of the world are still engaged in reorganization and "shakingdown" after an unprecedented naval conflict, the survey of world armaments by THE NEW YORK TIMES shows.

Good nursery schools make a real contribution to the growth and development of young children, but they do not replace kindergartens, according to Frances Horwich, visiting professor, School of Education, University of North Carolina.
JERUSALEM, May 11 -- Fifty more suspected terrorists were removed from Palestine today to the Gilgil concentration camp in Kenya Colony, East Africa, where there are already 261 prisoners.

PITTSBURGH, May 11 -- Charles P. Taft, president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, told the National Jewish Welfare Board today that business men must cast off "an extraordinary inferiority complex" about our economic system if we are to side-step "economic disaster."
ATHENS, May 11 (Reuters) -- Guerrillas were reported today to have killed twelve persons in a raid in Crete. The Greek destroyer Kriti was ordered to Heraklion, on the northern coast of the island.

IN 1818 in the ancient city of Trier a boy was born who was destined to do more to influence the shape of things to come in the twentieth century than nearly any other citizen of the nineteenth. He was a difficult child, a good student but incurably lazy, and was always "more interested in a subject the farther it was from reality."

Many of the nation's principal producers of both major and traffic electrical appliances are "on the brink" of releasing the most extensive advertising campaigns in the history of the industry, a spokesman for one of the largest appliance distributors in the country disclosed over the week-end.

The Brooklyn Dodgers football team released its fourteen-game league schedule yesterday and announced the signing of two players, Michael Joseph Patanelli, an end, land Walter McDonald, blocking back.

The arrest of a young man in this city early yesterday morning an hour after a policeman was shot in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., brought queries from police in other states who believed the suspect may have been involved in other crimes, including the "Black Dahlia" murder in California.

JERUSALEM, May 12 -- Two hours before the British military commander here planned to announce tonight that Jewish shopping and entertainment centers would be reopened to British troops, two British policemen were killed by assassins at one of the busiest street corners.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 12 -- Following is the text of the first half of a resolution to set up a United Nations inquiry committee into the Palestine question. It was approved today, paragraph by paragraph, by the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly.

Mayor O'Dwyer forced the resignation of I. James Brody as deputy commissioner of marine and aviation late yesterday afternoon. He acted promptly after receiving a report from his department of investigation charging that the Department of Marine and Aviation is not being efficiently administered," and that it had flouted his rule against granting pier permits to stevedores.

HARVE DE GRACE, Md., May 12 (AP) -- Two stablematea of Calumet Farm's Faultless, winner of Saturday's Preakness, maintained the string's blistering pace today at Havre de Grace by posting a pair of new track records.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (U.P.) -- Carl Aldo Marzani, 35 years old, a former employe of the wartime Office of Strategic Services, went on trial before a Federal jury today on charges of disloyalty and concealment of his membership in the Communist party.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 12 -- A quarrel over the selection of a site for a $3,000,000 public housing project led to the resignations today, effective May 16, of all five members of the Municipal Housing Authority. As in several other cities planning state-subsidized housing, the quarrel arose when a neighborhood of single-family houses was chosen for the low-rent apartments.

BOSTON, May 12 (AP) -- R.B. Carrolls Belrate defeated the favored Oran Lodge's Valiente by a length and a half in the feature today before a crowd of 16,141 at Suffolk Downs. Bull Tar finished third. Belrate covered the mile in 1:39 and paid $8.20 for $2.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Phil Marchildon won his own game tonight when he singled across two runs in the eleventh, inning as the Philadelphia Athletics defeated the Washington Senators, 5 to 1, in the first night game of the season here.

Supreme Court Justice Morns Eder approved yesterday afternoon an agreement settling three suits brought by minority stockholders of the Creole Petroleum Corporation against the Lago Petroleum Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Maple T. Harl, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, today opposed immediate reduction of assessments paid to the FDIC on insured bank deposits.

Four units of the Methodist Church, named as legatees of the estate of Mrs. Annie Merner Pfeiffer, share in $3,301,840 of her residuary estate, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday by Deputy Estate Tax Commissioner Charles W. Ferry.

Adolf A. Berle Jr., former Assistant Secretary of State in the Roosevelt Administration, and City Chamberlain and "brain-truster" for Fiorello H. La Guardia as Mayor, was elected chairman of the Liberal party last night at a meeting of the party's state executive committee at the Hotel New Yorker.
DETROIT, May 12 (AP) -- Passenger automobile production neared its lowest point of the last six months as the shortage of sheet steel kept several of the largest car body-making plants closed today.
The Chase National Bank has been appointed registrar of the cumulative preferred stock of Northwest Airlines, Inc.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 12 (AP) -- Dick Chapman of Pinehurst, N. C., made his first appearance in Walker Cup practice on the "old" course at St. Andrews today after a five-day bout with the flu.
A banking syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. and Harris Trust Savings Bank won yesterday the award of an issue of $6,866,000 of bonds of San Diego Unified School District, San Diego County, Calif.

Seventy Greenwich Village craftsmen plied hammers and saws yesterday in a huge lot on Sixth Avenue at Waverly place, oblivious to everything else as they prepared booths for their first annual Village fair.

Clergymen must take an interest in politics and other social problems as well as in social and spiritual welfare, the Right Rev. Dr. John William Charles Wand, Lord Bishop of London, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Churchman's Clericus in the Seamen's Church Institute, 25 South Street.
ATHENS, May 12 (U.P.) -- Thirty members of Parliament, headed by Deputy Premier Stylianos Gonatas, introduced in the National Assembly tonight a bill to outlaw the Communist party in Greece.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Frank R. Creedon, Housing Expeditor, tonight relaxed space restrictions on new housing to permit the building of larger houses and give the lagging construction industry new incentive.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Truman announced acceptance of the resignation of Dean Acheson as Under-Secretary of State and the nomination of Robert A. Lovett, former assistant Secretary of War, to replace him.

Behind some steady relief pitching by Joe Pereira, a rookie, and a heavy attack paced by Dan Perlmutter, the City Cotllege baseball team turned back Queens, 11 -- 7, yesterday at Macombs Dam Park. It was the Beavers' eighth victory in thirteen games.

MONTREAL, May 12 (AP) -- Bobby Bauer, 32-year-old "Kitchener Kid" of the Boston Bruins has been voted the most sportsmanlike player in the National Hockey League during the 1946-47 season and will receive the Lady Byng Trophy for the third time.

HAROLD R. ISAACS, a former Far Eastern correspondent for Newsweek, calls his contribution to the world's gloom "No Peace for Asia." He might with even more accuracy have called it "No Peace Anywhere Ever." Toward the end of his sad record of chaos and catastrophe Mr. Isaacs offers his own formula for making the prospect of permanent Harold R. Isaacs war not absolutely inevitable.

WASHINGTON, May 12--Emphasizing that 12,200 pedestrians were killed and 250,000 injured throughout the country in 1946, H.J. Brunnier, president of the American Automobile Association, today told the national meeting of the association's traffic safety committee here that there will be a greater toll in 1947, with the expected heavy upswing in motor travel, unless the utmost caution is exercised by walker and motorist.

LONDON, May 12 -- Food Minister John Strachey conceded today that the nutrient value of the average Briton's diet last year was 4 per cent less in calories than the pre-war average. He made the statement in a written reply to a question in the House of Commons.

A threat to bring before the attention of the Federal Trade Commission the practice among publishers of permitting book clubs through bonuses and introductory offers, to undersell retailers was made yesterday by Joseph A. Margolies, vice president and merchandising manager of Brentano's.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Kenneth C. Royall, Under-Secretary of War, testified today that former Representative Andrew J. May of Kentucky, accused him in 1945 of starting a Senate investigation against May and munitions makers.

BERLIN, May 12 -- German courts' lenient sentences of men convicted of the murder and mistreatment of Jews during the Nazi regime have brought a storm of protest from newspapers of all political complexions. One case protested occurred in Bremen under American jurisdiction, the other in the Russian sector of Berlin.
A reduction in coffee prices, which may be from 3 to 5 cents a pound on some brands, is expected by retail grocers within the next ten days.

BOSTON, May 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Sam Simon, 52 years old, who, with her late husband, made a fortune by catering at race tracks and sports arenas, was shot to death in her office at Suffolk Downs today by a former employe who then killed himself, the police reported.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 12 -- Whether there can be separation of the races and equality too was the issue raised here today in the trial of the suit of Heman Marion Sweatt, a Negro, to enter the University of Texas.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 12--After one hour and forty-five minutes of dramatic examination in a crowded court room here today, nine jurors were chosen for the trial of thirty-one white men accused of lynching a Negro.

RADNOR, Pa., May 12 (AP) -- Deputy Coroner John Stretch Jr. said that Thomas Newhall, 70 years old, a prominent Philadelphia financier and former head of the Philadelphia Western Railroad, was found shot to death tonight in an old powerhouse.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 12 -- The niceties of diplomatic conversation were pushed to one side today as the Arabs and Jews, warming to their basically opposed concepts of the future of Palestine, indulged in personalities, name-calling and thinly-veiled threats to the peace.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Supreme Court today upheld the contention of the South and West that their industrial development had been retarded by railroad freight rates generally favoring the North and East. The court ordered a blanket correction.
TUNIS, May 9 (Delayed)--A Showdown between the French and their bitter foes, the Tunisian nation lists, cannot be long delayed, according to the prevailing opinion here.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission supported today a measure to give wartime merchant seamen benefits similar to those granted to armed service personnel under the GI Bill of Rights, including education.

The stock market moved again yesterday toward the year's low level but the pressure failed to assume major proportions until the final hour. Heaviest losses, which ranged beyond 2 points, were sustained by the heavy industrial issues while the composite rate declined approximately a point.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Francis Biddle, former Attorney General under President Roosevelt will appear before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee tomorrow in a meeting that may have its effects on the bipartisan foreign policy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 -- Monogram Pictures and its subsidiary, Allied Artists, will halt all film production of Monogram studios when three productions, "Robin Hood of Monterey," "A Guy Named Joe Palooka," and "Code of the Saddle," are completed, according to an announcement by Steve Broidy, president of the company.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, May 12 (AP) -- Petroleum Development (Trans-Jordan), Ltd., a subsidiary of the Iraq Petroleum Company, has been granted a seventy-fiveyear right to explore and develop oil and gas resources for all of Trans-Jordan, high sources said.

The Long Island College of Medicine obtained yesterday title to a three-block tract of land opposite the Kings County Hospital on Clarkson Avenue, Brooklyn, as part of a new expansion program estimated to cost $5,450,000 in the initial phase.
Radar, Loran and other newly developed electronic devices were demonstrated yesterday for 367 representatives of the shipping industry during a four-hour cruise in New York-Harbor.

Streaking ahead in the last few strides, the Woodvale Farm's Halsgal scored a head victory in the featured Apple Knoll purse, $5,000 race for 3-year-old fillies, Belmont Park yesterday. Under the expert urging of Conn McCreary, Halsgal made her move just in time to gain the victory over a pair of others who were so closely locked in the photo that they shared the place spoils.

The survey made in this newspaper yesterday by Mr. Baldwin, showing 19,000,000 men still under arms two years after the end of the war in Europe and almost two years after the surrender of Japan, is a tangible and disturbing indication of the temper of our world today.
NANKING, May 12 -- Conditions of oppressive poverty under which they live and work were described to the press here today by professors of the National Central University.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Leasing J. Rosenwald, industrialist and president of the American Council for Judaism, just returned from Germany, urged today the quick passage of special legislation to permit the accelerated immigration of hundreds of thousands of displaced persons from the American zone in Germany.
RAMAPO, N. Y., May 12 -- Gilbert Pitt, the last of the old Ramapo Mountain men, died in his cabin on Half-Moon at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Now that Congress has approved the loan to Greece and Turkey, may I express through your columns a deep concern that is held by many thoughtful people concerning two aspects of the situation in Turkey. That real progress has been made in Turkey under the leadership of Ataturk and of Inonu must be a cause of gratification to everyone.

LOS ANGELES, May 12 -- Hans Eisler, Hollywood composer and a brother of Gerhard Eisler, the alleged Moscow agent, was examined for an hour today by the House Un-American Activities Committee and then dismissed because, Representative J. Parnell Thomas, chairman, said, "he sought to evade and confuse the issues."

The resignation yesterday of Dean Acheson as Under-Secretary of State and the President's appointment of Robert A. Lovett to take his place are matters of much greater interest and importance than the ordinary shift in junior Cabinet officials. This is because of the special circumstances which have given added responsibility to this particular office.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Today's Supreme Court decision on the class freight rates will affect railroad hauling charges on some 20,000 manufactured articles. There are about that number of items listed by the Interstate Commerce Commission as eligible for class-rate handling.

Stockholders of the St. Joseph Lead Company at their annual meeting yesterday approved a change in the by-laws, creating the position of chairman of the board of trustees. Clinton H. Crane, who had been president for 34 years, was elected chairman.

Establishment of a formal liaison between the motion picture industries of Hollywood and London to facilitate cooperation in matters of common interest, both cultural and commercial, was announced last night here and in England.

TOKYO, May 12 -- An inconclusive meeting was held today among the chief secretaries of the Liberal, Democratic, Socialist and Cooperative parties as the result of the four-party agreement last week on a national coalition.

GENEVA, May 12 -- Andre Philip, French Minister of National Economy, announced today that French control authorities in Germany would co-operate fully with the Economic Commission for Europe in an effort to link German economic policy with the general European recovery programs.

OTTAWA, May 12 (AP) -- Tears in her eyes, Miss Barbara Ann Scott today handed back to Mayor Stanley Lewis the keys to the canary-colored phaeton a grateful city had given her for winning the world figure-skating championship.

William Schuman, American composer, who started his second year as president of the Juilliard School of Music by merging the school's Institute of Musical Art with its Graduate School, announced yesterday that he would open his third year next fall with another major reorganization.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The forces of temperance threw their full support today behind a bill to bar national liquor advertisements as "seductive build-ups" and "befuddling allurements" beguiling "impressionable" youth.

In the face of a "buyers' strike" that already has curtailed construction work sharply, and in spite of President Truman's appeal for price reductions, the cost of building materials has just reached a new peak.

If you're one of those who think that an assortment of food as a present shows lack of imagination you should see the artistic packages that Miss Jeanette Forbes Jack can make out of such prosaic things as crackers, jam and cheese.

CINCINNATI, May 12 -- Silenced for four years by travel restrictions, about 1,600 delegates shouted their approval today at the opening of the convention of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, AFL, as their president, George M. Harrison, called a wage increase of 20 cents an hour a necessity.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The resignation of Dean Acheson as Under-Secretary of State, and the appointment of Robert A. Lovett to succeed him, were announced at the White House today. Mr. Acheson will turn over the reins to Mr. Lovett on June 30.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 12 -- Doctors of the nation, alarmed because the work of the medical profession is "greatly hampered" by the shortage of nurses, will take action in this emergency, Dr. Edward L. Bortz president-elect of the American Medical Association, declared today.

The city-wide spring cleaning drive continued yesterday with the Sanitation Department concentrating on Brooklyn and Queens. William J. Powell, commissioner of sanitation, said last night that he was well satisfied with the department's efforts in these two boroughs.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 12 -- Following are excerpts from today's debate before the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee on the composition one terms of reference of the commit tee of inquiry on Palestine:

BERLIN, May 12 -- Disagreements between the United States and British military governments that have hampered the smooth execution of the bi-zonal economic program as laid down by former United States Secretary of State Byrnes and British Foreign Secretary Bevin in the merger agreement last winter, were reported today to have been largely cleared up.

CLEVELAND, May 12 (AP) -- Stockholders of Cliffs Corporation who were scheduled to vote Friday on a plan of consolidation with the Cleveland Cliffs Iron Company, will meet at a later date, Edward B. Greene. president of the company, announced today.

PITTSBURGH, May 12 -- The National Jewish Welfare Board, at its closing sessions today, approved a proposal to establish an "all embracing Jewish culture council" to promote interest in Jewish history, crafts, literature, drama and other fine arts.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Against a background of stiff legal language, part of the picturesque history of the Hawaiian Islands was related in the Supreme Court today. The high tribunal held by the close vote of 5 to 4 that the United States Government cannot claim Palmyra Island, important aviation base, 1,000 miles south of Honolulu.

The Flying Dutchmen of Hofstra College strengthened their second place position in the Metropolitan League standings as they walloped Brooklyn College, 21 -- 8, in a 7inning contest on the Flatbush diamond yesterday. An 18-hit attack gained their fifth league victory for the Dutchmen.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Air Transportation Association protested today that legislative measures allowing broader participation by steamship companies in air transportation "will lead the way toward monopoly in transportation enterprise."

PARIS, May 12 -- Premier Paul Ramadier tackled one of the toughest economic problems facing his Government when he began discussion today with the Communist-controlled General Confederation of Labor on unions' demands, notably a general bonus for increased output. A two-hour talk was inconclusive and is to be resumed soon.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 12 (AP) -- Carroll Reece, Republican National Chairman, said tonight that "the radicals will be in the saddle" if the Democrats win the 1948 Presidential election.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 12 (U.P.) -- Henry A. Wallace said today that the nation's anti-Communist talk was a "disgrace" and denounced President Truman's loyalty test for governmental employes as "a 25,000,000 witch-hunt."

In the face of pending legislation aimed at curbing abuses in the garage and parking-lot business, operators of some places have introduced a new gouge on the beleaguered motorist, it developed yesterday. They are charging a "retaining fee."

Several thousand employes and executives in two buildings in the financial district found it necessary to climb long flights of stairs yesterday as a result of strikes by elevator operators and porters, members of Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union, AFL.
Most hospital doors here were opened to the public yesterday in Connection with National Hospital Day, commemorating the birthday of Florence Nightingale.

When the American-Soviet Music Society puts on a show it does so with a generous hand. Last night's presentation at the City Center had as its theme "the theatre music of two lands." The stage, screen, ballet and opera were represented, and there were enough people taking part at various times to fill not only the stage but several evenings in the theatre.
Following the formula that she has endorsed for many seasons, Mary Lewis put on a showing that concentrated on cottons and young casual clothes at the St. Regis Hotel yesterday noon.

ROME. May 12 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi will present his own and his Cabinet's resignations to the Provisional President after tomorrow's session of the Constituent Assembly, or a short time thereafter.

MOSCOW, May 12 -- The American movie industry has placed itself at the disposal of monopolistic capitalism and reaction, and its products must, with few exceptions. Be shunned, according to Culture and Life, newspaper of the agitation and propaganda committee of the Communist party.

LONDON, May 12 (AP) -- An international agreement among five major oil companies on participation by two American concerns in the Saudi Arabian oil development is expected within a few weeks, London oil men reported today.

The largest metals refiner in the non-ferrous field, Federated Metals division of American Smelting and Refining Company, opened a drive for improved quality control yesterday with a national conference of their twenty plant superintendents and production executives at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Senate declined today to concur in the $400,000,000 Greek-Turkish aid program as the House passed it Friday night. On the recommendation of Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Foreign Relations Committee chairman, it sent the slightly differing versions to conference for compromise.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 12 -- Overriding bitter Arab protests, the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly decided today to exclude all refererence to the independence of Palestine from the terms of reference of the proposed United Nations committee of inquiry.
A five-alarm fire raged out of control for four hours last night in a dozen or more one, two and three-story brick and frame buildings near the heart of Coney Island's amusement area.

The regular slate of officers headed by Robert P. Boylan as chairman of the board of governors, was elected yesterday by members of the New York Stock Exchange. A total of 883 votes were cast in the annual election, in which Mr. Boylan, a floor broker with offices at E. F. Hutton Co., succeeded John A. Coleman who refused to stand for re-election, for a term of one year.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 12 -- Howard L. Kern, since 1941 general counsel of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, died here of a heart attack early today in his home at 177 South Valley Road. He was 61 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- A House Small Business subcommittee finished hearings today on the continuing status of the Governmentoperated Federal Barge Lines. A. C. .Ingersoll Jr., president, urged the subcommittee to reject a suggestion by railroads that the inland waterways system be sold to private interests.

The RCA Victor Record Company has been obliged to recall from dealers all copies of a recording of Debussy's "The Girl With the Flaxen Hair," made by John Sebastian in an arrangement for harmonica with piano accompaniment, it was learned yesterday.

Because a critical situation demanded a remedy the United States and British Military Governments in Germany are reported to have largely cleared up basic disagreements between them which have hampered smooth execution of the bizonal economic program. Exactly what the compromises are is not revealed pending approval in Washington and London.

Dependence upon the predigested opinions of newspaper columnists is bad for both readers and editors, Sevellon Brown, publisher and editor of The Providence (R. I.) Journal and Bulletin, said last night. Mr. Brown was the only publisher on the New York Newspaper Women's Club forum on "Why Columnists" at Town Hall in which three columnists and an editorial writer also participated.
GENEVA, Switzerland, May 12--The American and other delegations favor opening some sessions of the Geneva Trade Conference to the press and the public, it was learned today.

LONDON, May 12 -- President Ismet Inonu of Turkey said today that Turkey would use the proposed $100,000,000 assistance from the United States for military purposes and would seek a loan from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
Girls took eight of the eleven prizes and honors awarded at Washington Irving High School yesterday at the twenty-fifth Inter-High School Poetry Contest.

SHAWNEE ON DELAWARE, Pa., May 12 -- Pointing out tremendous retail mark-downs on apparel in the last two seasons were due largely to late deliveries. Mack Gordon, Cleveland retail merchant, urged that all segments of the textile and apparel trades get together for a continuing study of consumer habits to improve timing of seasonal merchandise.

Frederic Goudy's name will be remembered as long as the art of printing lasts. It is cast in the metal of more than a hundred type faces. History will rank him with the great designers of the past, Morris, Bodoni, Caslon, Aldus, the Elzevirs and the Estiennes.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Norfolk Western Railway Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to make a four-for-one split of its adjustment preferred and common stocks, authorized by its stockholders in February.

NANKING, May 12 -- Gen. Fu Tso-yi, one of the Government's top North China field commanders, has flown to Taiyuan to assist in the defense of Shansi Province's capital against encircling Communist troops, it was announced here tonight.

PHILADELPHIA. May 12 -- The Philadelphia Company, Pittsburgh, Pa., won a twenty-four-hour continuance today at the reopening of hearings before the Securities and Exchange Commission to determine whether the company should "break up" its $370,000,000 system.

ALBANY, May 12 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey said today that there was no possibility he would call a special session of the Legislature, as requested by some boards of supervisors, for the purpose of making an additional appropriation to help the localities meet increased costs of teachers' salaries.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 12 -- Sir Dalip Singh of India was elected chairman of the United Nations Committee on the Progressive Development of International Law and its Codification today at the Committee's first meeting here.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 12 -- The American Association for Adult Education, with more than 250 members in attendance, began its annual meeting at the Hotel Thayer today. Dr. Eduard C. Lindeman, Professor of Social Philosophy at the New York School of Social Work, opened the proceedings with an address urging the development of democratic disciplines.
A charge of selling an indecent book was dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Frederick L. Strong in Municipal Term Court in the case of "End as a Man," by Calder Willingham.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 12 -- A formal protest was presented today to Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, by the Arab Higher Committee of Palestine, charging that the United States had illegally refused to admit to this country Arab delegates who had been named to attend the General Assembly's special session on Palestine.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 12 -- The total value of Turkey's imports and exports in 1946 was more than 656,000,000 Turkish lire, according to reliable estimates. Until Sept. 7, 1946, the rate of Turkish lire to the dollar was 2.8; thereafter the lira was valued at 1.8 to the dollar.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (U.P.) -- The House Ways and Means Committee asked John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, today to testify next Monday when it starts reviewing the tax structure with an eye to cutting taxes further in 1948.

The Clinton Transportation Company of 406 West Twentyninth Street has leased the trucking terminal to be constructed at 516-518 West Forty-third Street. The property is owned by Seymour Glantz. The Cross & Brown Company was the broker in the transaction.

Negotiations, considered by many shipping men to be the most important to many years, are scheduled to, be opened this week as major maritime unions seek to obtain improved working conditions from leading employers.

The first city-wide hobby show by persons more than 60 years old opened yesterday for three days at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street. The Welfare Council of New York City sponsored the display of 400 articles.

Trade practice rules within tin framework of the Robinson-Patman Act received preliminary consideration yesterday for the cosmetics and toilet preparations industry at a conference under auspices of the Federal Trade Commission at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

LOS ANGELES, May 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Laura E. Treistad, 37 years old, the mother of three children, was found bludgeoned and garroted today, the fifth victim of a series of sadistic sex slayings which began with the butchery of the "Black Dahlia" in January.

Whit Burnett, editor of The Story Press, who has edited a number of anthologies, is working on a new one that is to contain the work of 100 living writers. To help him in his selections he is sending a ballot, containing the names of 457 authors as well as blank lines for write-ins, to various prize committees, critics, publishers, librarians and educators.

The Navy Nurse Corps will observe the thirty-ninth anniversary of its founding today with brief ceremonies at 162 stations throughout the United States and overseas. In a message to all personnel, Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal paid tribute to ''those women whose untiring efforts and skill are in keeping with the high traditions of Naval medicine."

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Stabilization of food prices is unlikely until distributors know what prices will be set on raw and finished products from the 1947 harvest, Nathan Cummings, president of the Consolidated Grocers Corporation, declared today.

Bidders to Try Again Having just cut loose the last of a series of sticky competitive sale bond marketings of late April, underwriting syndicates will try again today to harvest some profit out of that no-man's-land between what a borrower wants for his loan and what investors will pay to hold on to it.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 12 -- Two guest teams from the Winged Foot Club tied for low honors at 65, seven under par, in the second of the weekly amateur-pro tournaments of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Cherry Valley Club today. A record total of 101 teams participated.

Despite recent reports of large scale cancellations, widely circulated in the metropolitan New York area, electric motors continue to be in critically short supply and popular sizes of fractional horsepower motors are in heavy demand, distributors disclosed here yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 12 -- The expulsion of the Germans from Czecnoslovakia not only has substantially reduced the importance of the Sudetenland as a producer of food and fodder, but it also has struck -- at least for the time being -- a heavy blow at industry.

For the first time in his Broadway career Stanley Gilkey will branch out as an independent producer. Early next fall Mr. Gilkey, who has favored representatives of the distaff side as partners in theatrical ventures, will offer on his own "The Richest Girl in the World," a new musical comedy by John Meehan Jr., with music and lyrics by Earl Brent.
TRENTON, N.J., May 12 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll approved today legislative measures designed to increase State financial assistance to school children, teachers, and GI's.
BOSTON, May 12 -- Three magnificent Yankee homers meant just so many empty gestures at Fenway Park this afternoon as the Red Sox thrilled 24,726 onlookers with a 4-to-3 victory.

Because of the opposition of New fork City's teacher organizations, the Board of Education is not expected to take action on the adoption of new salary schedules when it holds its annual meeting this afternoon.

LONDON, May 12 -- The bells of Westminster Abbey welcomed the royal family today. The King, the Queen and the two Princesses drove in an open carriage through cheering-crowds on their way home to Buckingham Palace after their South African tour.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 12 -- Robert R. Wason, New York, chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, said today there would be no depression this year "unless the Government makes it."

Local campaign workers for the World Youth Fund of the Young Men's Christian Association met yesterday at luncheon in the Commodore Hotel and reported pledges and contributions amounting to $553,359, or 51.5 per cent of the $1,075,000 goal for New York City and vicinity.

A campaign undertaken by the Merchandise Delivery Drivers Employes, Local 804, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL to induce department store customers to have their packages delivered led to court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Senate agreed today to vote tomorrow on the Taft omnibus labor control bill, with strong approval predicted.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 12 -- The Soviet Union challenged today the power of a United Nations special investigation subcommission to operate at will in the Balkans.

Store Sales Up 7% Here Sales of the New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 7 per cent in the week ended on May 10, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday. For the previous week a gain of 7 per cent was reported, while for the four weeks ended on Saturday sales were unchanged compared with a year ago.

THE baseball season is approximately a month old and, although it's exceedingly improper to count the chickens before they're hatched, there are a lot of strange looking birds emerging from the shells. The St. Louis Cardinals are in last place, when they were supposed to spreadeagle the field. The Boston Red Sox, who were supposed to do likewise, are staggering near the .500 mark in third place.

New York City needs between 75,000 and 100,000 new homes. That is to say, that many families need homes. The national need is a good deal more than a million, but that figure was set early this year by President Truman, Housing Expediter Creedon and National Housing Administrator Foley as desirable and attainable in 1947.
VIENNA, May 12 -- The first meeting here of the four-power commission on Austrian treaty questions today brought a clash on a fundamental issue.

PHOENIX, Ariz., May 12 (AP) -- Winnie Ruth Judd, the trunk murderess of sixteen years ago, escaped from the State Hospital for the Insane last night and was recaptured twelve hours later in an orange grove near this city. It was the third time the red-haired "Tiger Woman" had escaped.
LONDON, May 12 -- With weekend orders small and professional buying down to a minimum, business in the stock markets today was slack.
LOS ANGELES, May 12 (U.P.) -- The forty-fourth annual American Bowling Congress ended tonight after forty-seven days of play at the National Guard Armory with the crowning of three champions.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 12 (AP) -- The executive committee of the major leagues today considered "favorably" the application of Cuban and Venezuelan leagues for admission to organized baseball, and set Dec. 9, 10 and 11 at New York for the annual major league meeting.
Foreign Relations and Coffee Even when conditions at large are dismal, mention of the quality of British coffee is sure to set off some spirited debate in the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Kenneth Romney, former House Sergeant - at - Arms, was accused today of dealing heavily in Florida real estate in the Nineteen Twenties, then in 1938, of trying to hide a fellow-employe's alleged embezzlement because is would "ruin us all."

ROSCOE, N.Y., May 12 -- A warm sun, rising water temperatures, normal flow, clear waters and a "dry fly" wind conspired to make the past week-end on the Beaverkill a memorable one for every angler who made the trip.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange started 5 to 21 points lower yesterday, steadied for a time owing to covering against sales of spot cotton to domestic and foreign mills, and then sold off again later on hedges and commission - house liquidation.

Silver plaques for the most effective advertising in the Business Paper Advertising Competition conducted by The Associated Business Papers were presented last light to seven companies. Presentations were made in the Drake Hotel, Chicago, and the Belmont Plaza, New York.

MOSCOW, May 12 -- A story in the Communist party newspaper Pravda, dated from South Sakhalin island, said today that American occupation forces in Japan were recruiting Japanese airmen, including Kamikaze (suicide) pilots.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The administration is now employing all its time and talents to bring home to Congress, the American people and the world the larger significance of the President's message of March 12, expounding what has become known as the Truman Doctrine.

Western Electric negotiations in this city and in Washington bogged down yesterday as picket lines established by Western Electric strikers continued to bar restoration of full telephone service in many parts of the country.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 12 (AP) -- Henry A. Wallace said tonight that the "one alternative" to the "Truman policy of loaning money for military purposes" abroad was "to use American money through the United Nations for plows and tractors rather than for guns and fighter planes."

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Greek-Language short-wave broadcasts will be resumed tomorrow, William Benton, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, announced today. The first news beamed to Greece will be an account of the House action last Friday assuring that President Truman's plan for economic and military aid will be carried out.

Summer came back to Brooklyn yesterday with balmy breezes, bright sunshine and a decisive Dodger triumph over the Boston Braves. As a result the Brooks are in second place and are embarking on their first Western tour of the campaign only a game and a half behind the league-leading Cubs.

RYE, N.Y., May 12 -- The warm spring weather lured ninety-seven players to the fairways in the opening one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association over the south course of the Westchester Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Greek-Language short-wave broadcasts will be resumed tomorrow, William Benton, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, announced today. The first news beamed to Greece will be an account of the House action last Friday assuring that President Truman's plan for economic and military aid will be carried out.

Summer came back to Brooklyn yesterday with balmy breezes, bright sunshine and a decisive Dodger triumph over the Boston Braves. As a result the Brooks are in second place and are embarking on their first Western tour of the campaign only a game and a half behind the league-leading Cubs.

Jaromir Weinberger, whose opera "Schwanda der Dudel Sackpfeiffer" has delighted its multitudes, was heard last night as a religious composer when his cantata "Ecclesiastes," for chorus, soloists, organ and at least one pulsatile instrument, was performed by the John Harms Chorus in Town Hall.

ROCHESTER, May 13 -- Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York City was advanced tonight by Democrats of central and western New York as the type of candidate they could support enthusiastically for Governor in the next state election.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A campaign to curb garage rent "gouging" based upon coordinated efforts of communities was urged today by William J. Gottlieb, pres-ident of the Automobile Club of New York, at the national meet-ing of club officials of the American Automobile Association here.

JERUSALEM, May 13 -- A military display by Scottish and Irish troops practically on the spot in Jerusalem where two young British policemen were murdered last night was canceled today to avoid conflict with the funerals of the two men.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- With a hopeful eye on the millions spent yearly by hobbyists, the United Nations, it was learned today, is planning to enter the postage stamp business.

Aroused by the loss in 1946 of $2,000,000 through thefts, the Long Island Rail Road, with the cooperation of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has intensified the policing of its freight yards in an effort to curb the larcenies.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 13 -- Harry Bacharach, former Mayor of Atlantic City and former chairman of the New Jersey Public Utility Commission, died here tonight at his home, 108 St. Charles Place. His age was 73.

An account of Virginia in the seventeeth century, written by Robert Beverley in 1705, will be issued by the University of North Carolina Press Saturday under the title "The History and Present State of Virginia." Edited by Louis B. Wright, the volume is being published for The Institute of Early American History and Culture at Williamsburg, Va.

JERUSALEM, May 12 (Delayed) -- Steel pipes that London used in fighting the Blitz now are carrying a newly found water supply to Jewish pioneer settlements in the arid and half-desolate Negev, the grain-growing southern part of Palestine.

WASHINGTON, May 13--Terms of two agreements calling for $100,000,000 in aid to Mexico, specifically limited in application to purposes of greatest economic benefit, were announced simulta-neously today here and in Mexico City.
Harold R. Medina, president of the Lawyers Club, was endorsed last night by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York for appointment to the Federal Court vacancy in the Southern District.

With Senator Vandenberg leading the battle for the $350,000,000 program for relief of distressed people in liberated countries, it is to be hoped that the Senate will pass the measure with the full amount intact and that it will then prevail over the House, which cut the total 43 per cent to $200,000,000 and bound up its distribution with restrictions, some of which would be difficult of application in the field.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., May 13 -- Readjustment problems in the textile industry arising from excessive prices and quality deterioration would be relatively simple if the bulk of industry had operated on a brand name integrated basis, Royal Little, president of Textron, Inc., declared here tonight in a debate on vertical integration.

Archie O. Joslin, formerly executive vice president, was elected yesterday president of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., succeeding Leon Lowenstein, who becomes chairman of the board and will continue to take active part in the management of the textile company.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 13 -- Tribute to clubwomen of the past and present marked the opening today of the Golden Jubilee Celebration of the Connecticut State Federation of Women's Clubs, beginning its three-day convention here at the Hotel Bond.

The long lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that 1,500 more non-supervisory employes had returned to work, enabling the company to operate nationally at 75 per cent of normal.

Weekly Buyers' Total Higher Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,294 against 894 last week and 1,746 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- President Truman will address members of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation at Charlottesville, July 4. Charles G. Ross, Presidential secretary, told reporters today that Mr. Truman had accepted an invitation to visit Monticello, Jefferson's home at Charlottesville.

LOWELL, Masa., May 13 -- The Lowell plant of Textron, Inc., employing more than 800, will close indefinitely at the conclusion of its present manufacturing commitments, it was announced today by Peter A. Beddow, plant manager.
LONDON, May 13--The great and very much feared crisis in the British zone of Germany has come and today British Government leaders buckled down to see what they could do about it.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 13 -- Mike Turnesa and Jack Horn, both of Knollwood, won the first Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur tournament of the season at Elmsford today. Last of forty-nine teams to tee off, the Knollwood pair posted a combined 30, 35 -- 65 that tied two other tandems at the top, but when cards were matched the Turnesa-Horn duo triumphed.
Richard N. Parks has been appointed general manager of the E.S. Lowe Company, Inc. He for-merly was vice president and gen-eral manager of the Embree Man-ufacturing Company.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Nearly 800 lobbyists, ranging from ministers to former members of Congress and a one-time Presidential confidant, are acting as lobby representatives in this session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, May 13--The roll-call vote by which the Senate today passed and returned to the House a general labor disputes bill follows:...

The stock market plunged yeserday through the lows of the year and returned to the worst levels since last November under the heaviest selling pressure in a month. It was the severest jolt in two months, with the average loss in the industrials about 2 points and a decline of 1.44 in the composite rate.

Animals at the Bronx Zoo yesterday roared a lusty welcome to a party of 150 visitors comprising members of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, their wives and children. Arriving in a fleet of buses at noon from the Chamber Building at 65 Liberty Street, they were greeted at the main gate of the New York Zoological Park by Fairfield Osborn, president of the New York Zoological Park.
VIENNA, May 13 -- Joseph M. Dodge, United States member of the four-power Austrian treaty commission, stated after today's three-hour session that he believed some progress had been made.

BERLIN, May 13 -- Germany has been brought to a state of "stagnant inflation," F. Taylor Ostrander, United States member of the four-power price-control committee, said today. In a special report he declared that instead of increased prices' destroying the value of money, "a money without value has tended to destroy the function of prices."

The Office of the Housing Expediter will withdraw from active participation in channeling surplus property items by July 1, Louis L. Bennett expediter for the Middle Atlantic region, disclosed yesterday.

PARIS, May 13 -- France's shaky economy has forced her to limit her Army to less than 500,000 men for all purposes and to keep her Army expenditures for the last half of 1947 at a level considerably below General Staff estimates. War Minister Paul Coste-Floret reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower disclosed today the details of how he has launched three young Army officers on an independent quest to solve for him the riddle of what warfare -- atomic, or even more terrible -- will be like twentyfive years hence.

The importance of the New York State Canal System as an adjunct of New York harbor was stressed yesterday by the Port of New York Authority, which released a comprehensive survey on the system's present traffic and equipment and future needs, as compared with that of pre-war years.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 13 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, speaking at the opening session of the fifty-third annual Convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs, deplored the limited powers invested in the Governor under the present Constitution.

The State of California yesterday awarded at auction an issue of $10,000,000 of Veterans' Welfare bonds maturing from Feb. 1, 1949, to Feb. 1, 1968, at a bid of 105.59 for fixed interest of 2 per cent to a merged syndicate headed by Bankers Trust Company and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

LOS ANGELES, May 13 -- Scientists of the University of Southern California, in collaboration with engineers of several industrial compaines, have developed the first successful method of taking X-ray motion pictures at normal and slow-motion speeds, it was announced tonight.

CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 7,000 head: total 9,000. Market fairly active and around 50 cents higher: few loads of hogs 350 pounds and up, only steady: sows 50 cents up: top. S25: bulk of

Seven school children were injured, three of them seriously, at about 3:50 P.M. yesterday afternoon when a motorist lost control of his car in swerving to avoid one group and struck another group at 136th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

IN January, 1942, Doris Rubens and her husband took to the hills of central Luzon to camp out "for a month or so until MacArthur came back." Their knowledge of how to live in tropical jungles was no more to be relied upon than their military judgment. So, for more than a year and a half, they lived a dirty, hungry, frightened life entirely dependent upon the kindness of Filipinos.

LONDON, May 13 -- Coal production fell in Britain last week the first five-day week in the industry's history, according to official figures released today. Declines were registered in comparison with the preceding week in which the miners worked six instead of five shifts, and in comparison with the corresponding week a year ago.
LONDON, May 13 -- Although dealing's were limited in the stock markets today, most sections held firm.

The Italian political crisis follows a different pattern from the French, but the basic elements are the same. In both countries the struggle is to organize the majority against a powerful and aggressive minority. Premier Ramadier was able to stay in office and force the resignation of the Communist members of his Cabinet.

The Near East Foundation will attempt to raise $2,000,000 this year for relief work in Greece, Mrs. Florence Spencer Duryea, director of women's activities, announced yesterday. The amount is double the budget or last year. when the foundation aided 30,000 Greek children.

BOSTON, May 13 (AP) -- Ted Williams, who hadn't hit a home run in Boston all season, clouted two today -- both into the screen atop the fence which stretches from the left field foul line to the center field bleachers -- as the Red Sox flogged the White Sox 19 -- 6.

STUTTGART, Germany, May 13 -- Hjalmar Schacht, acquitted last October by the International Military Tribunal as a major German war criminal, was convicted today on similar charges by a German denazification court and sentenced to eight years -- at hard labor if he is physically able.

Railroad and public utility bond issues aggregating $27,600,000, awarded yesterday to underwriting syndicates at competitive sales, will be placed on the market today by underwriting managers as follows: Southern Pacific Company San Francisco Terminal - $22,500,000 of first mortgage Series A 3 3/8 per cent bonds maturing on June 1, 1975, at 100.45 to yield 3.35 per cent, by Kuhn, Loeb Co.
TOKYO, May 13 -- Wide concessions by the Socialist party today appeared to have broken the deadlock in negotiations over the formation of a national coalition Government for Japan.

Few Episcopal clergymen, if any, have ever at so early an age been named to more high offices than has the Rev. Dr. Horace William Baden Donegan, for fourteen years rector of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

Only half or the requests for service made to the Jewish Big Brothers can be handled with the present number of volunteers, Herschel Alt, executive director of the Jewish Board of Guardians, announced last night.

Two thousand little girls, 10 to 12 years old, celebrated May Day yesterday in the old fashioned sense of the word. The children, representing thirty-two schools in Manhattan and one each in Queens and Brooklyn, crowded the Sheep Meadow in Central Park in the fortieth annual park fete of the girls' branch of the Public Schools Athletic League.

Working in pure silk, chiffon, lace and linen, Jane Derby created the charmingly individual at-home and play costumes seen yesterday in a collection at Grey Room Designs, a new salon at 4 West Fiftysixth Street, where this designer's custom-made fashions will be a feature.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Dean Acheson, retiring Under-Secretary of State, appealed to Congress today for swift enactment of legislation enabling the State Department to maintain its "Voice of America" broadcasts overseas as a "vitally important" means of implementing our foreign policy.

CORNWALL, Conn., May 13 -- The recent change in weather brought out the anglers, as well as the flies, and the stretches of the Housatonic near this town were dotted with fishermen who were satisfied not only with the weather but with the trout.

One building strike in the financial district was settled yesterday when forty elevator operators and porters at 42 Broadway returned to their jobs after the impartial arbiter of their industry ruled their day-and-a-half walkout a violation of their contract.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- The Interstate Power Company of Dubuque, Iowa, and the American Cyanamid Company of New York, filed registration statements today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, while a third company, Foremost Dairies, Inc., of Jacksonville, Fla., withdrew a statement filed last March 28.

Scoring in every inning but the ninth, the Kings Point M.M.A. hammered five Fordham pitchers for nineteen hits and as many runs to defeat the Rams, 19 -- 8, at Fordham Field yesterday. The loss was the fourth straight for the Maroon, who committed twelve errors.
NEW DELHI, India, May 13 -- Dismay and disappointment are expressed in almost equal measure in today's press comment on the postponement of Viscount Mountbatten's meeting with Indian party leaders.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of May 3 on the relationship between juvenile gangs and anti-Semitic and anti-Negro activities in the East Bronx, as disclosed by the Mayor's Committee on Unity, is a gloomy reflection on an admittedly gloomy picture.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Senate passed today the Taft omnibus labor bill by a vote of 68 to 24 -- a margin sufficient to override a Presidential veto -- after three weeks of the greatest debate on domestic affairs in the Eightieth Congress.

Plans for a program to establish nation-wide standards for frozen food packaging were made yesterday for the first time by representatives of all branches of the frozen food industry under the auspices of the American Standards Association.

BOSTON, May 13 (AP) -- Fleet West, A. Richers' 3-year-old filly, a 14-to-1 outsider, defeated Mesl, 8-to-5 favorite, by a half length in the feature today at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 13,561. Cherry Quest finished third, a neck behind Mesl.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The proposed project for enlarging and improving the Panama Canal was the subject of controversial discussion today at a closed hearing at the Navy Department, conducted by the Board of Consultants to the Governor of the Panama Canal.

A group of Queens business men turned over to the Police Department yesterday a fifteen-acre plot to be used by the Police Athletic League for sports and recreation. The presentation was made in the office of Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Those commentators and others who confidently construed the results of the 1946 elections to mean that a legislative stalemate between the Republican Congress and the Democratic President wan inevitable must have lost some of their assurance today when the Senate voted on the labor bill.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The writer has just returned from an extended official relief mission in Italy where he had the opportunity to talk with His Holiness Pope Pius XII, President Enrico de Nicola, Prime Minister Alcide de Gasperi, Vittorio Emanuele Orlando, members of the Italian Cabinet, and numerous others who keep their fingers on the pulse of Italian public opinion.

ALBANY, May 13 -- Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein upheld today the constitutionality of the recently enacted Wilson-Pakula law, which is designed to prevent "raids" upon the primaries of a political party by non-enrolled members thereof.

Long-range planning for the Port of New York, to care for its own needs and meet the competition offered by rival east coast ports, is proposed by Goodhue Livingston Jr., member of the City Planning Commission, in a statement yesterday.

Harry L. Hopkins, personal friend and adviser of President Roosevelt for twelve years, who died on Jan. 29, 1946, left an estate of $33,775 and debts of $23,254, it was learned yesterday when his widow, Mrs. Louise Macy Hopkins of 11 East Eighty-sixth Street, petitioned Surrogate James A. Delehanty to exempt her husband's estate from inheritance tax because its value was less than a taxable estate.

Praising the Parents League of New York for efforts in bringing pupils in independent schools into closer relation with their community, Dr. Millicent Carey McIntosh, dean-elect of Barnard College, urged yesterday a continued spread of such activity.

BOSTON, Mass., May 13--The Rev. Stephen H. Fritchman of Bos-ton has been suspended as editor of The Christian Register, Uni-tarian monthly magazine, as the climax of a controversy which has continued for a year over charges that he has been active in Com-munist front organizations.

LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- The case of Miss Barbara Ann Scott's cream-colored convertible is not likely to be taken up at the annual meeting of the International Skating Union in Oslo June 10-11. President H.J. Clarke said today.

SEOUL, Korea, May 13 -- In a statement issued last night Maj. Gen. Archer L. Lerch, Military Governor of Korea, censured members of the Provisional Government in Exile. General Lerch declared that the announced proposed meeting of this group, led by Dr. Kim Koo, "to set up the old Chungking Provisional Government," was illegal.

The center ceiling light fixture was put in its place last night by experts who spoke at a meeting of the Electrical Women's Round Table in The Herald Tribune Auditorium. While suitable for general illumination in a living room, it was criticized as inadequate when used alone in a kitchen or laundry where most of the work is done around the perimeter of the room.
ROME, May 13 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi tendered his own and his Cabinet's resignations to Provisional President Enrico de Nicola today.
Mayor Bernard N. McFeely and his Democratic administration ticket went down to defeat by a substantial margin in yesterday's commission government election in Hoboken, N.J.

The British Government's policy of nationalizing much of the country's economic activity, if expanded to the ultimate objective of complete Government ownership, may lead to state ownership of basic enterprise, Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Committee on Economic Development, warned yesterday.

BERLIN, May 13 -- Bi-zonal committees of Germans will have direct executive authority for the first time since the end of the war if the agreement between Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, and Lieut. Gen. Brian Robertson, Deputy British Military Governor, is approved in Washington and London.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Wheat rallied strongly today after an early break on the Board of Trade and closed unchanged to 1 3/4 cents a bushel higher than yesterday. May showed the most strength. Corn had a range of 1 1/4 to 3 1/4 cents, but weakened late and finished with losses of 1/2 to 1 1/4 cents.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 13 (AP) -- The elderly caddies at St. Andrews confide that this year's United States Walker Cup team is superior to the 1938 crew that lost to Britain. British sportswriters, however, wear smiles that plainly indicate they think Britain will retain the cup.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- James A. Austin, counsel for a committee of holders of $2 preferred stock of the Rhode Island Public Service Company, today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to reconsider its endorsement of the reorganization plan of the New England Power Association.

CINCINNATI, May 13 -- Charles P. Taft, president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, asserted today that it was in the field of human character that the churches could do most and had done the least.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Italy's chief spokesman in renewed efforts to arrange financial assistance here, Ivan Matteo Lombardo, arrived today, coincidentally with the news of his Government's resignation.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser limited the Senators to four singles tonight as the Tigers defeated Washington, 8 to 0. The victory enabled Detroit to retain its one-game American League lead over the Red Sox.
TIENTSIN, May 13 -- Tientsin, the greatest port of North China, has been strangled by a combination of the civil war, administrative incompetence and widespread corruption.

A capsule version of a world's fair in electronics has been assembled by the Radio Corporation of America at 36 West Forty-ninth Street, where a permanent exhibit of advanced equipment will be opened to the public today. The devices will be on view daily, including Sundays and holidays, from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. without charge.

Increasing consumer resistance was found by 95.6 per cent of 345 stores throughout the country in a survey just completed by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday at a press conference at the Hotel McAlpin.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Charles H. Buford, a veteran of forty years in the railroad industry, was elected president of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad today at a meeting of the board of directors. Before the directors' meeting, stockholders elected four new directors and heard a statement that the railroad has had a profitable year thus far.

HANOVER, Germany, May 13 -- The first Landtag [state assembly] to be democratically elected in Lower Saxony since pre-Hitler days convened here today without a cabinet because of the political developments of the food shortage.

The Celanese Corporation of America made $6,180,564 in the first three months of 1947, equal, after preferred dividends, to 98 cents a share on the 5,514,017 shares of common stock, Harold Blancke, president, reported to stockholders yesterday.

Debutantes of the past winter and of the coming season, as well as several young women introduced to society within the last few years, attended a meeting yesterday afternoon in the Palm Court of the Plaza to advance plans for the opening day of the Fashion Fair on June 12 at Madison Square Garden as a benefit for the Memorial Hospital Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases.

After a two-week teaser campaign in metropolitan dailies, a new popular-price cigarette will make its New York showing May 19, when 1,000-line adds for Alligator Cigarettes will start appearing in local newspapers, supplemented by radio announcements.

PARIS, May 13 -- Premier Paul Ramadier assumed the direction of the food-supply services today and, backed by the Cabinet, ordered drastic measures to reduce the wheat shortage and get bread during the next two critical months.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13 -- Jeanette Nolan, radio actress and a newcomer to the screen, was signed today by Orson Welles to play Lady Maobeth in Welles' projected production of "Macbeth" at Republic, Richard Wilson, Welles' partner, announced today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 13 -- Representative J.M. Combs of Texas and Arthur Garfield Hays, national director of the American Civil Liberties Union, clashed here today in a radio debate on "Does the Loyalty Test Endanger Civil Liberties?"

NANKING, May 13 -- The Executive Yuan, China's Cabinet, today raised the salaries of all Government employes and members of the armed forces. The move will add a burden of $3,600,000,000,000 (Chinese) to the budget. The latest estimate for this year's budget was $20,000,000,000,000 (Chinese).
