JERUSALEM, May 13 -- Thousands of dollars' worth of contraband goods were found by the Palestine police in one of the automobiles of the Trans-Jordan royal household in Jerusalem yesterday, a police bulletin disclosed today.
BAYONNE, N.J. May 13 (AP) -- The Garden State welcomed its namesake today -- the 53,900-ton United States battleship New Jersey -- as the vessel paid its first visit to the state.

TOKYO, Ma 13 (U.P.) -- Sir William Webb, president of the International War Crimes Tribunal trying Japanese leaders, today asked Gen. Douglas MacArthur to protect the tribunal against "lying misrepresentations" by the United States Army newspaper Stars and Stripes.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The diplomatic immunity of John M. Cabot, American charged d'affaires in Yugoslavia, was recently violated, his identification papers were taken and his camera and films were seized by local authorities at the small town of Pec, the State Department announced today.

Widespread adoption of "memo" or consignment selling would create "havoc" in the fur industry, although the practice is useful to both retailer and manufacturer under certain limited conditions, John Block of Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers, held yesterday.
Yun Bok Su, winner of the recent Boston Marathon in recordbreaking time, and his team-mates from Korea were honored yesterday at a luncheon given by the Amateur Athletic Union at the New York A.C.

WASHINGTON, May 13--Mildly different Senate and House bills to authorize $400,000,000 in Ameri-can aid to Greece and Turkey for warding off Communist pressures were brought quickly into accord today. It appeared that Congres-sional action would be completed within twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (U.P.) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today authorized Air Commuting, Inc., to provide commuter air service to downtown New York City from points in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York State.

Voluntary health-insurance plans ultimately will cause a shift of hospital patients from wards to semi-private and private rooms, Dr. John B. Pastore, executive director of the Hospital Council of Greater New York, predicted yesterday.

After many a devious turn Hjalmar Schacht has at last reached the end of the road. Before a German court at Stuttgart the former president of the Reichsbank stands convicted as a "major Nazi offender," sentenced to eight years of prison labor and stripped of all his property.

Andrew G. Clauson Jr. was reelected unanimously president of the Board of Education yesterday. The vote of the board members was applauded by 250 spectators, and so were the speeches of ten teacher representatives who declared they were opposed to repairing school buildings with funds budgeted for salary increases.

Agreement has been reached between the Esso Tanker Men's Association, an independent union, and the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey guaranteeing the unlicensed personnel aboard Esso vessels a ninety-day paid vacation each year, it was announced last night.

The city Board of Health made good yesterday a promise by Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein last July that every privately operated swimming pool and bathing beach in New York would be required this season to keep on hand respiratory apparatus to revive bathers overcome in the water.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A complete recount of the Maryland voting that sent former Gov. Herbert R. O'Conor to the United States Senate last November was virtually assured today by a subcommittee recommendation to the Senate Rules Committee.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 13 -- Testimony believed to be unprecedented in the history of Southern lynching cases, including a written statement purporting to be a white man's admission he had joined others in forcibly taking a Negro from a jailhouse "for the purpose of killing him," was spread upon the county court record here today.

The fourteenth annual exhibition of work in bas-relief sponsored by the National Sculpture Society opened with a preview dinner last evening at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street. It will be on for ten days.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIEMS: Chairman Fred L. Crawford of the Sub-Committee on Territorial and Insular Possessions of the House Public Lands Committee has scheduled hearings before his committee on the various bills which have been introduced in Congress with respect to Guam.

In an investment purchase, Max Davidoff has acquired the fourstory building containing twenty apartments at 1521 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, from the David Rosenberg Holding Corporation. The building occupies a triangular plot or approximately 119 by 146 by 70 feet.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 13 -- The task of preparing the nurses of the world for possible atomic warfare rests upon the International Council of Nurses and its component thirty-two national organizations, Miss Ethel Johns, consultant to the Canadian nurses' Association, declared today.

BATAVIA, Java, May 13 (AP) -- The Dutch Navy said today that one of its torpedo boats had engaged in an hour-long artillery duel yesterday with Indonesian shore batteries at Sibolga, on the west coast of Sumatra, and that it was assumed that there were a number of civilian casualties.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., will enter the newsreel field in November, it was announced yesterday. The company has long contemplated such a step, but has been deterred by the wartime shortage of film raw-stock and other factors.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 13 -- After nearly two weeks in conference here the preparatory commission of the International Refugee Organization decided today to assume operational responsibility front July 1. The decision will enable the preparatory group to assure continuity of the activities of UNRRA until a permanent refugee organization comes into being.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Interclub Cup team series ended yesterday amid great excitement. Piping Rock of Long Island and Knickerbocker Golf Club of New Jersey emerged the victors in their district, while a tie resulted in Westchester between the Century Country Club and Winged Foot.

GENEVA, Switzerland, May 13 -- Progress toward a transfer of executive powers from provisional organizations to the Economic Commission for Europe was made today when a plenary session decided that the European Coal Organization should be absorbed into the United Nations agency by the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Department of Justice named 705 railroads in a complaint today to the Interstate Commerce Commission alleging collection of "unjust and unreasonable charges" on the Government's wartime shipments of aluminum airplane landing mats between January, 1944, and June, 1946.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall today accepted the assurances of V.M. Molotov, the Soviet Foreign Minister, concerning the basis of renewed negotiations on Korea.

A broad easing of supply of many heretofore critically short industrial materials has taken place, reports from purchasing agents for large companies revealed here yesterday. Items in better supply, available in larger volume and earlier delivery, included paperboard, paint, hot rolled sheet steel, masonry materials, steel reinforcing bars, form lumber and some types of plastics.

PARIS, May 13 -- Indications that President Truman's foreign policy now tends to place the major emphasis less on military and ideological aims and more on the reconstruction of Europe are received here with mixed feelings.

SCHOHARIE, N.Y., May 13 (U.P) -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, said tonight that plans called for a seasonal increase in farm milk prices, beginning July 1, and another by Oct. 1, to offset the lower May-June formula.
The police of the West Fiftyfourth Street station investigated last night a report of a robbery in an apartment on the twenty-fifth floor of the Essex House, 160 Central Park South.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Evidence that Andrew J. May appealed several times to Secretary of War Patterson in behalf of the munitions-making Garssons and wrote to General Eisenhower in behalf of a court-martialed Garsson was given today.
Under the heaviest liquidation in May and July, 1947, deliveries so far this season, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 70 points yesterday.

BERLIN, May 13 -- Brig. W.R.N. Hinde, British Commandant in Berlin, was arrested on Sunday on a charge of spying on an airfield in the Russian zone. He was taken to the Soviet Kommandatura in Berlin, questioned and eventually released.

MOSCOW, May 13--The Soviet press has emphasized collaboration of the socialist and capitalist systems, especially in economics, since the publication of Harold E. Stassen's interview with Premier Stalin.

LONDON, May 13 -- Britain intends to use "the most vigorous measures to punish Palestinian terrorists who attempt to kidnap or murder British soldiers, John Freeman, Financial Secretary of the War Office, said in the House of Commons today.

The United States Maritime Commission disclosed yesterday that it had warned the city last December that it would not countenance any payments for the use of city piers that exceeded the regular fees.
The Millinery Creators Guild prophesied fall hat trends yesterday afternoon at a showing in the Cotillion Room of the Hotel Pierre.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- The Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly completed today the instructions for the United Nations' Special Committee that will investigate the complex question of Palestine in its entirety.

Attorney General Tom C. dark said yesterday that the insurance business should meet the Jan. l, 1948, deadline of Public Law 15, which ends the period of grace granted to the states and the industry to remove abuses, revise old laws and enact new ones.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- Plans to establish an elevenmember Committee of Inquiry into the Palestine question and instructions for the committee were approved today by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (U.P.) -- The Republican Senate leadership gave the Army-Navy merger legislative "green light" today as Gen. Carl Spaatz told the House that the Administration's plan to bring the services together is a "positive step toward prevention or war."

Despite exhortations from civic, religious and veterans' organizations to aid in the present critical housing shortage, persons who take roomers into their apartments or houses may be guilty of a violation of Section 248 of the Multiple Dwelling Law, as amended at the recent session of the State Legislature.
MONTREAL, May 13 -- Spain ceased to be a member of the International Civil Aviation Organization by a 27-to-3 vote at today's Assembly session.

King Ranch's But Why Not, purchased from the estate of the late Col. Edward R. Bradley, drove to a convincing triumph in yesterday's $19,550 Acorn stakes at Belmont Park as she romped through the homestretch swishing her tail in the faces of twelve rivals.

Business leaders were warned against future campaigns to revive compulsory state trade-mark registration laws by speakers at the sixty-ninth annual meeting of the United States Trade Mark Association at the Ambassador Hotel yesterday.

Two Columbia College seniors, Robert L. Bonaparte of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Joseph Kraft of 211 Central Park West, have been named salutatorian and valedictorian, respectively, of the class of '47, Harry J. Carman, dean of the college, announced yesterday.

The Gold Medal of the National Institute of Social Sciences, awarded for distinguished services to humanity, was presented last night at a dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel to three leaders in the fields of child welfare, music, and international relations.

Boots and Saddles The horses are running at Belmont Park, where, they tell us, the Turf and Field Club, closed during the war, is open again and the flowers that give a festive air to the enclosure are putting on a brave show of color.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The trial of Kenneth Romney, former sergeant-at-arms in the House of Representatives, produced today a letter in which Romney wrote to John H. Smithwick, a former Florida member of Congress, that "we have been jointly guilty of fraud."

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Exposure and punishment of all Filipinos, "no matter who is involved," who are found guilty of graft, black-market operations in surplus war equipment and similar activities was promised here today by Elpidio Quirino.

The Rev. Dr. Horace W.B. Donegan, rector of St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy -first Street, was elected Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday at the 164th annual convention of the diocese.

The Gold Medal of the National Institute of Social Sciences, awarded for distinguished services to humanity, was presented last night at a dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel to three leaders in the fields of child welfare, music, and international relations.

Two Columbia College seniors, Robert L. Bonaparte of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Joseph Kraft of 211 Central Park West, have been named salutatorian and valedictorian, respectively, of the class of '47, Harry J. Carman, dean of the college, announced yesterday.

A canned grapefruit product shows up this week just as fresh citrus begins its early summer eclipse. This is a food as new as next year's calendar, neither mainly juice or segments, but, in a manner of speaking, both.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cottonseed crushed in the nine months from Aug. 1, 1946, to April 30, was 2,841,022 tons, compared with 3,063,149 tons in the corresponding period a year ago.
CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Earl Torgeson, rookie first baseman, led Boston to a 7-4 victory over the Cubs today in the first game of the Braves' Western tour before 11,167 in Wrigley Field.

PEIPING, May 13 (AP) --Chinese Communists today marked the withdrawal of the Fifth Marine Regiment from Peiping by destroying several miles of the PeipingShanhaikwan railway a few hours after 500 marines passed over it.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- The United States attaches the highest importance to the United Nations' development and codification of international law and the American Government desires all nations to observe a "rule of law," Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States representative declared here today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 7: Decreases of $201,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations and $453,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted and an increase of $158,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Following are the texts of recorded statements of Secretary of State Marshall, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan and Assistant Secretary of State William Benton that inaugurated broadcasts to Greece on the Government's "Voice of America" program:

Cotton Consumption Reports indicate that domestic consumption of cotton is continuing to hold fairly high. The New York Cotton Exchange's trade service bureau placed consumption of the staple during April at 890,000 bales, compared with 813,000 bales in the same month last year.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A Hollywood peace conference of American Federation of Labor unions got off to a limping start today with a key union, the carpenters, unrepresented.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 13 (AP) -- Dudley K. Woodward, chairman of the University of Texas Board of Regents, took the stand as the state's witness today in the case of Heman Marion Sweatt, Houston Negro, who seeks admission to the university's law school.
The first two weeks of the Greater New York Fund's tenth annual campaign has resulted in the collection of $2,505,656, or 41.7 per cent of its quota of $6,000,000, it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP) -- Home runs by Elmer Valo and Sam Chapman in the seventh inning enabled the Athletics to defeat the Indians before 23,511 spectators tonight, 7 to 6. The loss was the third of the season for Fireball Bob Feller, against four victories.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- The membership of the elevennation Special Committee set up to investigate the Palestine problem was examined carefully tonight by observers, and the verdict was that it was a fairly balanced group and a good approach to neutrality.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 13 -- Scoring heavily in the first two innings off starting Hurler Bob Flanders, Manhattan downed Hofstra, 10 to 2, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference baseball contest today. It was Hofstra's third setback in eight starts and Manhattan's third victory against a like number of setbacks.

One argument that will be used in an attempt to persuade President Truman not to sign the new labor bill, in whatever form and by however large majorities it finally emerges from a conference of the two houses, is that action in matters of such grave importance as this should not be taken with "undue haste."

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A pilgrimage of next-of-kin to permanent United States cemeteries overseas was advocated by President Truman in a statement issued at the White House today. The visit, however, should be deferred until headstones and memorial chapels have been installed in the cemeteries, along with other "reassurances of the perpetual care which our country will devote to the resting places of our honored dead," the Chief Executive said.

Borough President James A. Burke of Queens called yesterday upon William J. Powell, Sanitation Commissioner, to clean not only the permanently paved but all other streets in Queens. He said the second day of the spring cleanup would have been more effective if the Sanitation Department had carried out the proposed plan to clean all areas.

How Guatemala's new censorship law muzzles the press and radio of that country is shown by a study of the text of the measure The April 28 edition of the official Government organ, the Diario de Centro America, contains the full text of Decree No. 372 of the Congress of the Republic of Guatemala.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 13 -- In this village of historical restorations, the old Dutch Church of Sleepy Hollow marked its 250th year today and $11,600 was sought for repair pf its sagging timbers, crumbling masonry and dilapidated graveyard.

As a part of the city's observance of "Tribute to Women Week," established by proclamation of Mayor O'Dwyer, License Commissioner Benjamin Fielding yesterday took Mrs. Wendell Willkie, Helen Hayes and Fannie Hurst to see the first of the completed floats that are being prepared for the torchlight parade down Fifth Avenue from Fifty-seventh Street next Monday night.

Borough President James A. Burke of Queens called yesterday upon William J. Powell, Sanitation Commissioner, to clean not only the permanently paved but all other streets in Queens. He said the second day of the spring cleanup would have been more effective if the Sanitation Department had carried out the proposed plan to clean all areas.

How Guatemala's new censorship law muzzles the press and radio of that country is shown by a study of the text of the measure The April 28 edition of the official Government organ, the Diario de Centro America, contains the full text of Decree No. 372 of the Congress of the Republic of Guatemala.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 13 -- In this village of historical restorations, the old Dutch Church of Sleepy Hollow marked its 250th year today and $11,600 was sought for repair pf its sagging timbers, crumbling masonry and dilapidated graveyard.

As a part of the city's observance of "Tribute to Women Week," established by proclamation of Mayor O'Dwyer, License Commissioner Benjamin Fielding yesterday took Mrs. Wendell Willkie, Helen Hayes and Fannie Hurst to see the first of the completed floats that are being prepared for the torchlight parade down Fifth Avenue from Fifty-seventh Street next Monday night.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP) -- Home runs by Elmer Valo and Sam Chapman in the seventh inning enabled the Athletics to defeat the Indians before 23,511 spectators tonight, 7 to 6. The loss was the third of the season for Fireball Bob Feller, against four victories.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- The membership of the elevennation Special Committee set up to investigate the Palestine problem was examined carefully tonight by observers, and the verdict was that it was a fairly balanced group and a good approach to neutrality.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 13 -- Scoring heavily in the first two innings off starting Hurler Bob Flanders, Manhattan downed Hofstra, 10 to 2, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference baseball contest today. It was Hofstra's third setback in eight starts and Manhattan's third victory against a like number of setbacks.

One argument that will be used in an attempt to persuade President Truman not to sign the new labor bill, in whatever form and by however large majorities it finally emerges from a conference of the two houses, is that action in matters of such grave importance as this should not be taken with "undue haste."

In its annual report covering the first post-war year the Community Service Society looks back on that period as a time when people's private worlds were tossed about and drastically altered by change and loss. The aftermath of the war, it is pointed out, brought countless uncertainties into the lives of reunited families and in many instances children's futures were at stake.

Herbert Hoover said yesterday that the food crisis in Germany was "very bad" and placed the chief blame on bad weather, undue feeding of livestock, and black marketing. He expressed the belief that the food deficit would be remedied "in a very few weeks" by food shipments from this country.

John S. Sumner of the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice found Magistrate Charles F. Murphy on his side in Mid-Manhattan Court yesterday in the controversy over Vincent McHugh's book of poems, "The Blue Hen's Chickens," recently published by Random House.

Bloomingdale Bros., Inc., the New York unit of Federated Department Stores, Inc., in the fiftytwo weeks ended on Feb. 1 transacted a new high record volume of sales totaling $56,562,447, according to the annual report of James S. Schoff, president, and Michael Schaap, chairman, mailed yesterday to stockholders.

A group within the Maritime Commission that has urged "medium class" reconversion of the former United States liner Washington has waged a losing battle, since the vessel is to get a lowcost conversion that will make her a third or tourist class ship, it was learned last night.

GREENVILLE, S. C., May 14-- Three written statements in which white men described for the first time in Southern court history how other white men actually lynched a Negro were read to the jury today in the trial of thirty-one men of this community.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 14--Heman Marion Sweatt, Negro, of Houston, testified today in his fight in a district court against Texas segregation laws that he would not attend a separate law school for Negroes.

By the overwhelming vote of 79 to 4 the Senate yesterday approved President Truman's $350,000,000 relief program for liberated countries. Though the sum had been cut to $200,000,000 by the House, it should not be too difficult now to obtain a conference agreement on something near the full amount--and preferably on that amount--sought by the President.

CINCINNATI, May 14--The Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks of the American Federation of Labor broke today with a constitutional provision existing since the founding of the union in 1899 by granting to Negroes the full rights of membership, but it was not a clear-cut or voluntary departure from past practice.

WASHINGTON, May 14-- Alarmed by spreading unrest and food strikes in western Germany, the War Department tonight announced emergency measures to rush more than 1,200,000 tons of food into the American and British occupation zones by July 31 to meet the crisis.

WASHINGTON, May 14--Norman MacDonald, executive director of the Massachusetts Taxpayers Association, accused the Federal Government today of failure to make itself, its efforts and its problems understood by the American people.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 14 --With one-third of the world facing starvation, peace on earth can be assured more by stopping the starvation than by teaching people how to use guns, Dr. Aake Ording, Norwegian delegate to the United Nations, declared today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14--Scientists attending the general meeting of the Society of American Bacteriologists discussed today three substances, which after further research, might prove to be reliable curbs on influenza.

WASHINGTON, May 14--The President, as forecast, sent to the Senate today the name of Robert A. Lovett of New York to be Under-Secretary of State. The designation was made amid reverberations and echoes of the chorus of praise for the services of the man he will succeed--Dean Acheson of Maryland.

PITTSBURGH, May 14 (AP)--The Phillies today announced unconditional release of veteran First Baseman Frank McCormick and Lou Finney, optioning of Shortstop Ralph Lapointe to Baltimore and purchase of another infielder from the Red Sox for an estimated $25,000.

Despite the contributions of $150,000,000 given by American Jews to public institutions in Palestine since the inception of the mandate, they will be asked to contribute nearly $82,000,000 this year, Dr. Israel Goldstein, national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, declared yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 14-- Tradition will be broken at Brown University next month for the first time since 1776. Although the commencement exercises will open in the historic First Baptist Meeting House, they will be transferred to the middle campus for the actual presentation of diplomas.

In a Greenwich Village backyard garden a box turtle burrowed into the moist, cool earth sheltered by the blooming spread of a rose azalea bush. The slanting rain blew the tulips about and beat the pink azalea petals into the ground, but the home of the turtle and its brothers, one of several Village gardens on exhibition to the public, had its share of the touring visitors.

Governments Flurries that brought successive mark-ups this week in the Government bond market, especially in the long maturities, have since pretty well canceled themselves out. Compared with prices of last Thursday, the list of forty-four Treasury issues yesterday showed nineteen declines of 1-32 and 2-32 in the shorter maturities, seventeen advances of 1-32 to 4-32 in the longer maturities and eight issues unchanged.

Builders who had hoped that record production of housing this year would "break the back" of the unprecedented demand now fear that declining construction activity may serve to prolong the shortage indefinitely.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts yesterday sold issues of notes totaling $20,000,000. Award of $10,000,000 maturing Feb. 20, 1948, was made to Bankers Trust Company and National City Bank and associates at a bid of 0.68 per cent plus $175.

Despite larger operating expenses, Stern Brothers, New York department store, made more money in its fiscal year ended with last January than it did the year before, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

A funeral service for Louis Fabricant, attorney-in-chief of the Legal Aid Society of New York will be held tomorrow at 11 A. M. in Riverside Memorial Chapel, Seventy-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Mr. Fabricant, who resided at 230 West 105th Street, died of a heart attack Tuesday nigth in the Hotel Statler Washington, where he was attending a convention of the B'nai B'rith, of which he was a former national vice president.

The Catholic War Veterans made public yesterday an editorial appearing in the current issue of the organization's official organ, the Catholic War Veteran, in which it questions the "allegiance to Catholicism" of Quentin Reynolds, Bartley C. Crum, J. Raymond Walsh and Emmanuel Chapman.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 14 (AP)--Marvin (Bud) Ward, veteran member of the United States Walker Cup golf team, fired a brilliant 70 over the St. Andrews course today. It was the lowest score returned by a member of either the United States or British teams in more than a week of practice for the international matches starting Friday.

TO THE EDITOR OF, THE NEW YORK TIMES: As attorney for the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, concerning which you wrote the editorial "Closed Union Nepotism," I would like to call to your attention a number of important facts which the editorial ignored.

Operating "substantially at capacity under exceptionally favorable operating conditions and at satisfactory prices," in the first quarter of 1947, the International Paper Company earned $16,160,540, a new high record, R. J. Cullen, chairman, reported to stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting here.

The presentation of a gold cigarette case studded with diamond stars to Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, founder of the Stadium Concerts, Inc., in recognition of her thirty years of service to that organization, was a surprise feature of the pre-season Stadium Concerts tea given by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Lewisohn, yesterday afternoon, at their home.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The American Federation of Labor adjourned its meeting on Hollywood jurisdictional disputes today with a decision to entrust the problem to a special committee.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and closed steady, 33 to 55 points net higher than the day before, led by July. They started 10 points below to 17 points above the previous close.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)-- The Tigers pushed over a ninthinning run tonight to break up a pitching duel between Freddy Hutchinson and Mickey Haefner and defeat the Senators, 3 to 2, for their fifth straight victory. Hutchinson pitched his fifth successive triumph, limiting Washington to six hits.

CHICAGO, May 14--Henry A. allace proposed tonight a "positive peace program" to restore ar-devastated lands and develop e world's backward areas which ould involve American investments and exports totaling $150,000,000,000 over a period of years.

Recent tightening of Mexican market is a downward readjustment from post-war inflation and speculation rather than a recession, L. L. Horch, regional director, Department of Commerce, said yesterday. He warned, however, that Mexico's efforts to restore equilibrium in its adverse balance of international payments may lead to new import controls on nonessential goods.

SEATTLE, May 14 (AP)--The British-manned motorship Hartington was still picketed by her crew here today in a dispute with the vessel's master, Capt. I. J. Bell. The crew met on ship last night with British consulate representatives.

Following are excerpts from the speeches of Andrei A. Gromyko, Russian representative, and Faris el-Khouri, Syrian delegate, before the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow yesterday: Mr. Gromyko The course of the discussion both in the plenary meetings of the General Assembly and in the first committee have shown that the Question of Palestine has become an acute political problem.

WASHINGTON, May 14--All of the major cities in this country are "rotting at the core" due to the lack of essential route development and adequate parking facilities, William H. Stinchcomb of Cleveland, chairman of the National Highway and Legislative Committee of the American Automobile Association, said today at the annual meeting of the executive committee of the organization here.

BERLIN, May 14--The United States and British Military Governments are expected to cut German food rations for the merged zones from the present 1,550 calories daily for the normal consumer to about 1,200. The reduction probably will go into effect for the next ration period, beginning on the 26th of this month.

WASHINGTON, May 14--The Army and Navy are not likely to accept their expected budget cuts in "dignified silence," high officials predicted today. They intend to give Congress and the country an opinion of what heavy cuts in defense appropriations would mean.

LONDON, May 14--A United Europe, free of nationalistic hates and rivalries that brought on two world wars, is an indispensable prerequisite to a successful world government, Winston Churchill declared tonight. He said such unity in Europe should be achieved within the framework of the United Nations.

ALBANY, May 14--Former Governor Nathan L. Miller, whose drive for economy in state government long was blamed for his defeat for re-election in 1922, told a bipartisan audience tonight that the same "false and powerful propaganda" which fought economies in national government after the first World War was in operation again.

Ezzard Charles, mentioned as a possible opponent for Joe Louis, was signed yesterday for his first New York bout. Mike Jacobs' Twentieth Century Sporting Club announced that the Cincinnati boxer would fight Elmer (Violent) Ray of Hastings, Fla., the night of June 27 at Madison Square Garden.

Slowed by acrid smoke, sulphuric acid fumes and high air pressure, firemen wearing gas masks fought for three hours yesterday to extinguish a minor fire 150 feet underground in the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, now under construction. No one was injured or overcome.
BOSTON, May 14 (AP)--Cherry Oca Stable's Anvelt, 3-to-1 second choice, just lasted to defeat W. W. Water's Land Cruiser by a nose in the feature today at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 13,292.
The converted Liberty ship Joseph V. Connolly was on the high seas yesterday with 6,300 special coffins in which some of America's dead of World War II will come home next fall.

TOKYO, May 14--Six months of quiet Russian cooperation ended today when Lieut. Gen. Kuzma N. Derevyanko returned to his original critical attitude before the Allied Council for Japan. The Soviet member told his colleagues that the Japanese people had been led into an "economic blind alley" and an occupation spokesman retaliated by charging the Russian with speaking for propaganda effect.

Two new committees to foster better interreligious and interracial relations will be established by the New York Chapter of the American Jewish Committee, it was announcd last night by Harold Riegelman, who was elected chairman of the chapter's executive committee at the chapter's annual meeting.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue won two-thirds of the cases hi the Tax Court during 1945 and 1946 in which it charged fraud against income taxpayers, J. P. Wenchel, chief counsel of the bureau, said last night in an address before the annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Tax Executives Institute in the Waldof-Astoria Hotel.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday unless otherwise specified.

Parliamentary procedure was displaced by confusion yesterday at a turbulent annual meeting of the Third Avenue Transport Corporation yesterday. The meeting was adjourned late last night to 10 A. M. today.
The return of the British royal family to England and the bitter debate in the United Nations about the Palestine issue may mark the opening of a new strategic chapter in the history of the world.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 14-- Experts in radio and the press should join hands with adult educationists in order that educational advantages of the so-called "mass media" may be utilized to the fullest extent, according to Morse A. Cartwright, director of the American Association for Adult Education.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14--Considered one of the world's outstanding engravers, Mr. Sinnock was born in Raton, N. M., and studied at the Pennsylvania Museum of Art here. He won the museum's Mifflin Scholarship for advanced study and travel in Europe and later taught at the museum for eight years.

As far back as March debates on the "portal pay" legislation then being considered in Congress were oringing predictions of a Presidential veto. The possibility seemed to be definitely enhanced when Secretary of Labor Schwellenbach stated early in April that he would urge such action unless the then pending legislation were substantially modified.

Elimination of the 20 per cent ederal tax on toilet goods is necssary to forestall a reduction in ales volume and accompanying gher prices which such a decline ould necessitate, Paul H. Dougs, president of the Toilet Goods association, said yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 14 (AP)-- The Indianapolis Motor Speedway, through its president, Wilbur Shaw, and the American Society of Professional Auto Racers, through Joe Lencki of Chicago, today batted back and forth the question of whether the thirty-first 500-mile automobile race will be a firstrate speed contest without the A.S.P.A.R. boys.

PARIS, May 14 -- Replying to fears that American loans would impair France's independence, Raymond Aron will say in an article in Combat tomorrow that all depends on how the loans are used. "If we use dollars to buy machinery to renew our equipment, we shall thus force our independence," he says.

Because the war has helped accelerate the tendency toward making international trade a state function, the United States must obtain aid from other countries in promoting world-wide private trading, Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation and chairman of the board of the Committee for Economic Development, asserted last night.

The bear movement of the stock market spread definitely yesterday to the railway shares, which broke through to the levels of late 1944, while the rest of the list extended losses by moderate margins. A smattering of strength was exhibited by some key issues, notably the leading motors, although the increases proved meager.

LONDON, May 14--The German High Command's records showed that the number of German planes destroyed by the Royal Air Force in the Battle of Britain in 1940 was considerably smaller than that claimed by British communiques at the time. Philip Noel-Baker, Air Secretary, announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)-- Both national income and the national turn-out of services and finished goods rose to record heights during the first three months of this year, the Department of Commerce reported tonight, but there is evidence the boom is slackening.

A special feature of the Spring Bazaar which is being held today at the parish house of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, is an exhibition of paintings of flower arrangements by several members of the National Association of Women Artists.
NANKING, May 14--An incipient movement to get the Government to resume peace negotiations with the Communists was rebuffed by a spokesman of the Executive Yuan here today.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined an additional 2,571,000 barrels, the sharpest drop for any weekly period this year, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Stocks at the week-end amounted to 100,934,000 barrels, against 103,505,000 a week earlier and 98,196,000 on May 11, 1946.

NANKING, May 14--Rail communications between Shanghai and Nanking were restored late today after twenty-four hours of disruption at the hands of rampaging Shanghai college students. The students appear to have won their point.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 14-- Prof. and Mrs. Harwood Lawrence Childs have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Ann, to Arthur Edward Rowse 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rowse Jr. of Lexington, Mass. The wedding is planned for early in July.

A difference of opinion has arisen on whether the city shall follow a strict or liberal interpretation of the teachers' pay law passed during the recent legislative session. The amount of money involved is rather small when set against our whole bill for education in New York.

MONTREAL, May 14--Commission 2 of the International Civil Aviation Organization got down to the discussion of aviation today. Other commissions and committees are still struggling with the details of organization, most important of which now is the election of the council, the body representing twenty-one nations that sits permanently in Montreal.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., May 14 (AP)--T. M. Girdler, chairman of the board, and C. M. White, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, told stockholders at the annual meeting today that the company would "make every effort to maintain its prices without increases," although this may become "economically impossible."
ST. LOUIS, May 14--So far as the Giants are oncerned baseball at the moment knows no softer touch than the world champion Cardinals.

The organization of Ballet Theatre Foundation, Inc., a tax-exempt, non-profit corporation established "for the purpose of insuring the maintenance and continued presentation of ballet in America," was announced yesterday.

The United Nations committee of inquiry on Palestine will probably leave by chartered planes for Jerusalem within two weeks on the first stage of a ninety-day tour that may cost $1,000,000, it was indicated yesterday in plans drawn up at Blushing Meadow.
Those in the crowd of 18,894 who backed the Jayess Stable's Cencerro down to 3 to 4 in the Westbury Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday did some breath holding in the final yards.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 14-- Dartmouth and Harvard split a set of seven-inning Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball games at Soldiers Field today. Jim Doole of Chelmsford held the Crimson to three singles in the opener as his Indian mates victimized Brendan Reilly and Ira Godin, 5-1, but Harvard came back against Bill Callagy for a 6-5 victory in the nightcap.

A bronze plaque, dedicated to the memory of President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, was unveiled yesterday at Brooklyn College before an outdoor audience of 3,000 students, faculty members and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The House rejected all attempts today to restore cuts made by its Appropriations Committee in the budgets of the State and Commerce Departments, and went a step further to effect an additional saving of $1,700,000.

WASHINGTON, May 14--Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, who recently has conducted hearings on a new Cabinet post of Education, Health and Welfare as well as a strong system of Federal aid to education, said today that both were part of the same picture and "inevitable."

The measure of a successful family is no longer its size, its income or its opportunities for special advantages but the quality of the personalities it produces, Dr. Mary Fisher Langmuir, Professor of Child Study at Vassar College and president of the Child Study Association, said yesterday.
The Rev. Dr. Horace W. B. Donegan, Suffragan Bishop - elect of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, will not be consecrated to that office until fall.

CHICAGO, May 14--The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today affirmed the conviction of three Milwaukee industrialists accused of evading $1,500,000 in income and excess profit taxes of the Crucible Steel Casting Company. All the defendants were officers of the company, which is now under new ownership.

Outlawing of industry-wide bargaining was opposed last night by Assistant Secretary of Labor David A. Morse in an address before 1,000 representatives of maritime industry and labor at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.

After more than two weeks of impassioned and at times bitter debate, the special session of the General Assembly of the United Nations has now reached the stage of decision. The nature of that decision is clearly forecast by the resolution adopted by the Assembly's main committee, in which all the fifty-five delegations are represented.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., May 14 (AP)--Lord Grillo, owned by Gustave Ring of Washington, D. C., did the expected and ran off with the Bush River Purse over a sloppy track today. The 4-year-old took command at the first stride and held sway by two lengths at the end of the mile and a sixteenth.

Andrei A. Gromyko, Deputy Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, proposed yesterday the partition of Palestine into two independent states if bitterness between the Jewish and Arab populations made it impossible to set up "one dual, democratic ArabJewish state."

Two key branches of the long-distance operators' union in New York and Philadelphia were ordered to report back to work today through other phone unions' picket lines, further reducing the resistance of phone workers still on strike against the various units of the Bell System.

BACK in ye olden days the shepherd boys batted pebbles along the pasture lands with their crooks. Strictly speaking, it wasn't golf but only a reasonable facsimile of same. The divot-digging pastime actually began in Scotland five or six hundred years ago and for the longest while it was banned by royal edict until one of the Scottish kings was discovered furtively driving the aggravating little pill around the links.

LONDON, May 14--The day when foreign markets will again witness keen competitive bidding for orders is rapidly approaching, Sir Stafford Cripps, President of Board of Trade, told the Engineering Industries Association at a luncheon here today.
JERUSALEM, May 14--Three explosions occurred on Palestine's main railroad line near Hadera, south of Haifa, tonight. Official sources stated that the extent of damage had not yet been ascertained.

WASHINGTON, May 14--Andrew N. Overby, 38-year-old official of the United States Treasury Department, today was nominated by President Truman to fill the post of United States executive director of the International Monetary Fund.

WASHINGTON, May 14--Consideration of the nomination of Philip B. Perlman of Baltimore to be Solicitor General of the United States was taken up by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today, three and one-half months after President Truman announced the selection.

Persons who take no more than four lodgers into their homes need have no fear of violating Section 248 of the Multiple Dwelling Law, as it is enforced here by the Department of Housing and Buildings, it was announced yesterday.

CINCINNATI, May 14 -- The Dodgers headed for Pittsburgh tonight still chasing the will-o'-thewisp of victory--and Judging by "operation Cincinnati" it may be a rugged pursuit. The Brooks are two games out of the National League lead and a game and a half behind second-place Boston.

Despite abominable weather, the Long Island Golf Association's opening one-day tournament, at the Pomonok Golf Club, Flushing, yesterday, turned out to be a success. Thirty-eight linksmen competed despite the rain. Ray M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley carded a two-over par 74 and carried off the main award with 74--3--71.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., May 14--While the major portion of rayon goods produced abroad is treated for muss resistance and shrinkage control, few are so treated in this country, according to Dr. D. H. Powers of the Monsanto Chemical Company.
JERUSALEM, May 14--The Irgun Zvai Leumi has delivered to the United Nations a memorandum, a copy of which appeared tonight in the Irgun's latest propaganda packet for press correspondents.

LOS ANGELES, May 14--Robert Taylor, the movie actor, told the House Un-American Activities Committee today that he had been prevented by Government officials from entering the Navy in 1943 until he had starred in a pro-Russian film, Representative J. Parnell Thomas, committee chairman, said after a closed hearing.

Copyright, 1947, Norm American Newspaper Alliance, Inc. "This is Army 119 calling LI2B, LI2B. Can you hear us ? Over." A plane piloted by Colonel Walton of the United States Embassy in Lima was out over the Pacific Ocean to get a glimpse of the KonTiki raft expedition--the first persons ever heard of drifting on a raft on the high seas without wanting to be rescued.

PARIS, May 14--Pursuing its policy of strengthening colonial administrations to cope with possible uprisings, the Government appointed Gen. Alphonse-Pierre Juin, outstanding military leader and Chief of Staff, as Resident General of Morocco today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J. May 14.--If our forefathers, in spite of their great achievement in producing the constitution, managed to omit the Bill of Rights, it should not be a matter for such strenuous criticism when flaws are discovered in the workings of the United Nations, Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde declared here today.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)-- Vice Admiral Charles E. Rosendahl suggested today that Congress authorize steamship lines to develop a transoceanic flying service by lighter-than-air craft.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Senator Edward V. Robertson, Republican, of Wyoming, introduced today legislation to maintain three independent armed services under a "coordinator of national defense." The bill was offered as a substiture for the Administration measure for unifying the armed forces.

GENEVA, May 14--William L. Clayton, Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, will return to the United States Saturday for two weeks to review progress of the trade conference and Economic Commission for Europe with Secretary of State Marshall, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, May 14--Republicans and Democrats arranged today for strategy meetings to prepare for the opening next week of a Senate fight over reduction of income taxes.

A number of controversial issues between home furnishings experts and authorities in the architectural and building fields were aired at the luncheon meeting held yesterday by the home furnishings division of the Fashion Group at the Biltmore Hotel.

Service employes of three buildings remained on strike yesterday in an attempt to force their employers to honor the terms of an arbitrator's award, but the threat of a large-scale walkout of elevator operators and porters appeared over.

ALBANY, May 14--The fourmonth total of new stock corporations reached 9,901, Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran reported today. While the figure was below the all-time record of 14,882 in the same period last year, it was ahead of 1944 and 1945 and led officials to predict that another record for the year would be established.

TRENTON, N. J., May 14--Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today arranged for auditing of financial operations of the three major pari-mutuel race tracks in New Jersey. The audit will be made through the office of Homer C. Zink, State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance. It was authorized in 1947 legislation designed to increase State revenues from pari-mutuel betting by more than $1,000,000.

CHICAGO, May 14--Edwin R. Embree, president of the Julius Rosenwald Fund, announced today the award by the fund of forty fellowships for 1947 to twenty-three Negroes and seventeen white Southerners. The grants average $2,000.

The United States Section of the International Society for Contemporary Music presented the works of six modern composers last night at its third and final concert of the season at Hunter Playhouse. The event was a memorial to Lillian Morgan - Saminsky, poet and novelist.

Typographical Union No. 6 will honor its twenty-one members who gave their lives in World War n with memorial services and the dedication of a memorial plaque to be held at Manhattan Center, on Thirty-fourth Street, next Sunday at 3 P. M.

Hopes for early and substantial increase in supplies of steel and iron scrap from war surplus sources were dashed yesterday. Two time-consuming steps must be taken by the War Assets Administration before more surplus equipment and machine tools can be shifted to scrap piles, members of the steel, foundry and scrap industries committee for expediting iron and steel scrap disclosed.

New York's fruit and vegetable retailers, who had complained to President Truman that wholesale prices were exorbitant, were assured yesterday of a conference with Department of Agriculture officials on the price problem.

The policy of the City College administration in recognizing American Youth for Democracy as a campus organization while at the same time seeing that the group obeys college regulations was defended by college officials yesterday. Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college, and Dr. John J. Theobold, dean of administration, said this policy was the main reason for the "decline of communizing influences" at the college in the last few years.

TRENTON, N. J., May 14--Observers today appraised the effect on the political power of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, New Jersey Democratic leader, of the clear-cut defeat of one of his lieutenants. Mayor Bernard McFeely, in the Hoboken City Commission election.

"THE MARCH OF FREEDOM,"* by William Harlan Hale, is a chronicle of all our yesterdays. It tells the American story from a candid, skeptical, and yet somehow profoundly idealistic point of view. It skips and rambles around through the battles and issues and personalities and occasions of our past with a casualness and cocksureness calculated to give a professional scholar a stroke.

WASHINGTON, May 14--President Truman signed today the bill barring billions of dollars' worth of portal-to-portal pay claims, past and future, because he believed "that in the interest of the economic stability of our nation, it is essential to clarify this matter by statute."

Twenty-five awards were presented yesterday afternoon to student veterans who were winners in a contest for the best cabinetwork and upholstery done in the new training course at the Manhattan Trades Center, 45 Rivington Street.

Some grisly episodes are acted in an astonishingly cultured style in "Portrait in Black," put on at the Booth last evening. This is the shudder charade by Ivan Goff and Ben Roberts which has been glowering at Broadway for a long time and has finally got inside a theatre.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 14-- Screen Plays, Inc., has acquired screen rights to "The Big Town," a 1921 novel by the late Ring Lardner, and to "Champion," a Lardner short story, in a $75,000 deal with the Lardner heirs, which also gives the film company a seven-year pre-emptive right to all the rest of Lardner's available short stories, Stanley Kramer, president of the company, announced today.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 14--The British Government has refused to let the International Refugee Organization operate in the British zone of Germany, to take care of those displaced persons who will ultimately fall within the scope of the IRQ operations, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)-- Testimony at the trial today in Federal Court of Carl A. Marzani revealed that Fiorello H. La Guardia, while Mayor, organized a secret wartime "sabotage squad" to investigate "subversive groups" in New York.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)-- The text of President Truman's message to Congress on signing the bill outlawing most portal-toportal pay claims: I have today signed H. R. 2157, the Portal-to-Portal Act of 1947. The primary purpose of this act is to relieve employers and the Government from potential liability for billions of dollars in socalled "portal-to-portal" claims.

Charges of illegality, discrimination, oppressiveness and subterfuge were hurled yesterday at Mayor O'Dwyer's proposed automobile use tax at a public hearing before the finance committee of the City Council.

A Bronx couple charged yesterday in a $200,000 damage claim against the city that they were the Victims of a baby substitution recently in the city-operated Lincoln Hospital. They alleged that they became the parents of an infant girl there on March 13, but that the mother brought home from the institution an eight-day-old boy.

Peace was restored last night between the Welfare Council of New York City and Mayor O'Dwyer, Who have been at odds since last February, at the council's annual dinner in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. It also was announced that John D. Rockefeller Jr. had received the council's annual award for distinguished service to the community.

WASHINGTON, May 14--Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, United States Ambassador to Russia, said today that termination of the State Department's broadcasts overseas "simply will turn over the groping people of Europe" to ideologies "not entirely compatible" with American democracy.

LONDON, May 14--The stumbling block that led to postponement of the next British move in India is Mohandas K. Gandhi himself, it was learned here today. He is so firmly against any plan that contains an acceptance of Pakistan, the separate Moslem state, that it was realized that more time was needed to smooth the way.

ROME, May 14--The Provisional President of the Italian Republic Enrico de Nicola, began consultations today with a view to solving the Cabinet crisis precipitated yesterday by the resignation of Premier Alcide de Gasperi's third Government.

WASHINGTON, May 14--The strongest prospect arose today, as the Senate and House prepared to begin conferences tomorrow over their divergent labor bills, that the Taft-Senate version ultimately would be accepted In every essential principle.

Trinity Parish is celebrating its quarter millennium, covering all but a few decades of the history of New York since it ceased to be New Amsterdam. Through all these years a church of Trinity has stood at the top of Wall Street and played a notable part in the life of the city which has literally grown up around it.

A campaign to purchase and collect 100,000 pro-democratic books in the German language for distribution to German youth as part of their re-education in the American occupation zone has been undertaken by the International Rescue and Relief Committee.
James R. Cunningham has been appointed merchandise manager of the hosiery and lingerie division of Belding Heminway Corticelli, succeeding Burt Myron, who has joined Moj d Hosiery Company, Inc.

LONDON, May 14--Lord Camrose, publisher of The Daily Telegraph, today made the following announcement: "The Daily Telegraph has made arrangements to acquire the exclusive rights in a work now being written by Winston Churchill containing his memoirs of the recent great war. The work will be published in several volumes produced in successive years, and serialization will be made from each as they appear, commencing probably in 1948.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 14--The food situation in the American zone of occupation will continue critical for the next few weeks, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, Military Governor, informed his press conference today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 14-- That more than 80 per cent of State and Federal appellate judges follow Supreme Court Justice Hugo L. Black's practice on disqualification is the conclusion, based on answers to a questionnaire, set forth in the current issue of the Tale Law Journal in an article entitled "Disqualification of Judges."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If the House of Representatives passes a bill and the Senate passes the same bill but with some variations, the two Houses consult through conference committees and usually agree on a compromise measure which passes both Houses.

After fifteen days of debate and maneuvering, delegates to the United Nations special General Assembly on Palestine at Flushing Meadow looked forward optimistically yesterday to packing their briefcases and heading for home by tonight.

Wayne L. Morse, Republican Senator from Oregon, delivered a broadside attack last night on his Congressional colleagues, declaring that they were legislating in a spirit of partisanship without regard to the country's welfare. He said that at the present rate, Congress would adjourn on Aug. 1 without having taken a single constructive step.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The threat of criminal prosecution of responsible Government officials was raised today as Senate and House committees sought to prevent Government departments from spending more than Congress appropriates for their operations.
The leasing of the building at 683 Fifth Avenue by Air France from Frederick Brown was erroneously listed as a sale in the Manhattan realty transfers published in Tuesday's paper.

Most consumers believe current advertising is better than advertising of a few years ago. This is one of the trends disclosed in "Consumer Attitudes Toward Distribution," a seventy-six page bulletin released yesterday by the Committee on Consumer Relations in Advertising.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 14-- The public must "rearrange its ideas about the coat of medical care," a panel of four physicians told delegates to the fiftieth annual convention of the Connecticut Federation of Women's Clubs today.

Federal Judge J. F. T. O'Connor of Los Angeles, Calif., before whom Serge M. Rubinstein, international financier, was tried and convicted on draft evasion charges, has refused to recommend to the Attorney General that Rubinstein not be deported.

William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party, told a "Protest Truman Doctrine" rally in Madison Square Garden last night that United States "intervention" was the main threat to trade-union growth and to the "democratic" movement in Europe.
MOSCOW, May 14--A bitter denunciation of the "Reminiscences" of Miss A. S. Alliluyeva on the ground that the book misrepresented the history of the Russian Revolution appeared today.

Making its second appearance at the City Hall since Mayor O'Dwyer welcomed it a month ago, the Hapoel all-Jewish soccer team visited the office of Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, yesterday. A scroll containing the text of a resolution adopted by that body was presented by Mr. Sharkey to Herman Ehrlich, captain of the team.

A wave of liquidation of excess inventories of stock steel has started among metal-working plants throughout the country, industrial purchasing executives disclosed here yesterday. Among the many offerings, one lot of 3,800 tons of steel plate priced at $75 a ton, for immediate delivery from the West Coast and including sizes from three-eights inch upward, marked a new low price, they said.
WASHINGTON, May 14--The Senate passed by a 79-to-4 vote today its bill to authorize up to $350,000,000 of United States relief to hungry and sick peoples in warwracked countries.

WASHINGTON, May 14--The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today an agreement among fifty-six Class I railroads for the pooling of earnings and service involved in their conduct of the sleeping-car business of the Pullman Company, The railroads will pay $40,202,482 for the Pullman stock.

MOSCOW, May 14 (U.P.)--A Pravda dispatch from the newspaper's Teheran, Iran, correspondent said today that The United Press had received an assignment to circulate sensational reports on Iran in a spirit hostile to the Soviet Union.

A committee of newspaper ec tors and executives, members' Sigma Delta Chi, professional jou nalistic fraternity, expressed opposition yesterday to proposed Fe eral legislation, embodied in t Mundt bill, which they said "wou legalize the establishment of Government news service."

LONDON, May 14--The chief British leaders connected with German affairs met here today at the Foreign Office but found themselves unable to take any constructive measures to meet the present acute food shortage in the British zone.

Price Placards to Be Issued The National Council of Millinery Associations will distribute placards to millinery manufacturers in the next two weeks stating that inside prices will not be allowed, it was learned yesterday. The placards which are intended for display in millinery manufacturers' showrooms will also state that the manufacturer will comply with all requirements of the Robinson-Patman Act, according to a spokesman for the council.

PARIS, May 14--President Vincent Auriol appealed to the peasants by radio tonight to surrender now the wheat they hold for higher prices and thus help the Government to restrict food prices and wages and check inflation. Premier Paul Ramadier will make a similar appeal tomorrow.

Construction in New York City felt the full impact yesterday of a two-week-old strike of cement workers at thirty-one of the thirtythree mills in the Lehigh and Hudson Valleys, Maryland and Maine that supply the cement for the entire Northeast.

A drive seeking the support of the theatre-going public in the fight to limit the stage censorship powers of the License Commissioner has been started by the League of New York Theatres, the association of Broadway managers, theatre owners and operators.

Rain yesterday gave Bucky Harris. Larry MacPhail and George Weiss; field and front-office bosses of the Yankees, ample time to ponder the whys and wherefores of their athletes. Since the game with the Browns had been washed out, the first order of business was pruning of the Yankee list to the legal limit of twenty-five.

OBERLIN, Ohio, May 14--Oberlin College's dean of women, Miss Marguerite Woodworth, will be wed to Dr. Henry Merritt Wriston, president of Brown University, late next month. The engagement was announced today by the brideelect's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Smith Woodworth of Sanborn, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)-- One of four defendants in the MayGarsson war fraud trial won acquittal today, but the fate of former Kentucky Congressman Andrew J. May and munitions-makers Henry and Murray Garsson was left to the jury.

Irene, well-known Hollywood designer associated with MetroGoldwyn-Mayer, announced yesterday in an interview that by next autumn she would broaden her field and do some couturier designing. For some years she has concentrated on the movies, completely abandoning the custom-made originations that gave her fame.
LONDON, May 14--The opening of the new account brought in buyers and the stock markets were cheerful today, brokers reporting a big volume of inquiries.

TIENTSIN, China, May 14-- American business men in Tientsin, who are trying to carry on their operations in the face of civil war and soaring inflation, are becoming increasingly critical of what they term "organized confusion" throughout the Chinese administration with which they come in contact daily.

Our Voice to Russia A great variety of criticisms have been leveled at the State Department's Voice of America. We do not recall that any of these has emphasized what may be a valid ground for complaint: that is, that the Voice is overly objective.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Armstrong Poole of Milton, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Molly Manchester, to Dr. George Nathaniel Lenci Jr., Son of Mr. and Mrs. Lenci of Pittsford, N. Y., formerly of Summit, N. J. The wedding is planned for early in the autumn.
The weakfish are getting more plentiful in Peconic Bay each day and with a good weather break the catches should be really large this week-end.

A memorandum on international broadcasting by the United States, sent to the then Secretary of State Cordell Hull on Jan. 9 1943, by David Sarnoff, presidesent of the Radio Corporation of America, has now been submitted to Secretary Marshall, it was learned yesterday.

Charles B. Rairdon, assistant treasurer and general credit manager of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company, Toledo, Ohio, was elected yesterday president of the National Association of Credit Men in the concluding sessions of the group's fifty-first annual convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

One robber was killed by a policeman and another fell four stories, breaking both legs, when four thugs attempted to escape after holding up three Japanese at 1 A.M. yesterday at 45 East 128th Street.

The Board of Estimate will consider at a closed meeting next Wednesday a $270,000,000 proposal by the World Trade Corporation, a public benefit corporation created by the Legislature, to undertake comprehensive rehabilitation and development of all waterfront facilities within the city limits, including city-owned piers and docks and privately-owned docks, warehouses and terminals.
The pre-war steamship Borinquen of the Porto Rico Line is scheduled to depart from here on June 20 on her first post-war voyage to San Juan, Puerto Rico, and Trujillo City, Dominican Republic.

Undefeated New York University became assured of at least a tie for the Metropolitan Baseball Conference title by beating Manhattan College, 1--0, in a tense pitchers' duel at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday. It was the Violets' ninth league victory and their thirteenth of the season.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 15 -- Top-heavy favorites to capture the final Cup One series in the women's metropolitan inter club matches today, the Piping Rock team of five met keen competition in a triangular match with Winged Foot and Knickerbocker at the Plainfield Country Club.

NEW DELHI, India, May 15 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said tonight that India's import policy would be revised to halt the influx of certain consumer and nonessential goods from sterling-bloc countries.

Emerson Prices Guaranteed Distributors of Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation throughout the country were informed yesterday by Benjamin Abrama, president, that radio prices are guaranteed for the remainder of the year.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 2 to 15 points lower than on Wednesday, having lost all early gains.

Twelve Boy Scouts of Troop 782, Manhattan Council, led by Scoutmaster Gus Goldberg, set up camp yesterday in City Hall Plaza a few feet from City Hall. They pitched tents, built a fire and cooked steaks. A crowd of passers-by, attracted by the odor of sizzling meat, urged the Souts to do their daily good deeds by passing the steaks around.

HOLLYWOOD, CALIF., May 15 -- Cathedra Films, producers of religious motion pictures, will make three biblical films this summer, the Rev. James K. Friederich, president of the company, announced today.

CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows. HOGS Salable hogs, 7,500 head; total, 10,500; market moderately active and very uneven, steady to 25 cents higher; most advance on hogs 250 pounds and up; sows 50 cents higher: top in
LAKE SUCCESS, May 15 -- The United Nations has gone $5,936,000 over its $27,740,000 budget for the calendar year of 1947 with more than half the year still to go.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Abandoning, temporarily at least, his demand for industry-wide bargaining, John L. Lewis agreed today to confer tomorrow with coal operators representing 75 per cent of the country's bituminous tonnage. They will try to write an agreement removing the soft coal mines from Government operation.

Bonds aggregating $4,311,000, to be issued by two local housing authorities, will be put up for competitive sale on May 27. Miami Housing Authority, Florida, will offer $3,121,000 of refunding debentures dated May 1, 1940, and maturing serially on Nov. 1 from 1947 to 1998.

BERLIN, May 15 -- Labor leaders in the American zone have indicated that the steadily worsening economic conditions will force them to assume the leadership of strikes and demonstrations despite their past "no-strike" agreements.
LONDON, May 15 -- Although business in the stock markets today showed no signs of expansion, conditions generally were cheerful.

CINCINNATI, May 15 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds smashed out five homers -- two by Outfielder Eddie Lukon -- to humble Philadelphia, 11 -- 3, before a paid gathering of 3,454 here today. It was the Reds third victory in a row.

VIENNA, May 15 -- Alarmed, apparently, by the recent visit of a group of American industrialists, Red Army propagandists here and the Austrian Communist party launched a simultaneous propaganda campaign today.

Dipping into Johann Strauss' voluminous album of music, Dr. Felix Guenther has selected melodies to constitute the score of new operetta, "Gay Masquerade." Sixty per cent of the tunes, we are told by Theodore Bachenheimer, co-producer of the offering with Grete Basch, are unknown here.

Acceptance of cancellations and returns would constitute a violation of the Robinson-Patman Act if it can be shown that the seller has not accorded all purchasers the same privilege on proportionally equal terms, Joseph E. Sheeny, associate director, Office of Legal Investigations of the Federal Trade Commission, said yesterday.

Reporting a total membership of 6,774, Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the New York County Lawyers Association, announced last night that the organization now was the largest local bar association in the country. He made his report at the thirty-ninth annual meeting in the association's law building at 14 Vesey Street.

A group of prominent residents of the five boroughs met yesterday at the Bowery Savings Bank, 110 East Forty-second Street, and established the Citizens Committee for the Fiftieth Birthday Celebration of Greater New York.

LONDON, May 15 -- The United States and Britain have reached an agreement on strengthening and fusing still further their zones in Germany, Foreign Secretary Bevin told the House of Commons this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Truman told a delegation of Western Democratic officials today that an expenditure of $1,000,000,000 for implementing the peace after the First World War would have saved the nation $350,000,000,000 and 300,000 lives irretrievably lost in World War II.
WASHINGTON, Friday, May 16 (U.P.) -- Leaders of striking Western Electric workers canceled today an earlier order for withdrawal of their picket lines around local telephone company buildins.

LONDON, May 15 -- London has made an astonishing recovery in international banking activities and today stands unchallenged as the international banking center of the world, Paul Bareau, joint editor of The Banker, said here today.

The striped bass have arrived at Martha's Vineyard, and a few small fish are now being taken at Buzzards Bay, which means that the surf fishing should be getting under way at Montauk within a week. No word has been received from Coot Hall at Cuttyhunk, but the first big schools should be hitting there any day.

Announcing operations of Abraham Straus, Inc., Brooklyn store of the Federated Department Stores, Inc., for the fifty-two weeks ended on Feb. 1, Walter Rothschild, president, reported to stockholders yesterday an increase of 31 per cent in net sales to $55,381,548 from the $42,282,960 volume transacted in the corresponding period of the previous year.

Easing of paper supplies in some lines was forecast by purchasing agents here yesterday. They said that if other types of paper follow the same pattern being established by folding cartons, corrugated cartons and paperboard, redistribution of production may take care of the needs of active buyers.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 15 -- Attorney General Price Daniel tried unsuccessfully to establish today that prospective students for a Texas State law school for Negroes had been dissuaded from enrolling by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
BERLIN, May 15 -- The noted German actor, Werner Krauss, has been cleared by a German tribunal in Stuttgart and the verdict has aroused active public resentment in the anti-Nazi press here.

Another name was added to the list of candidates for membership in the United Nations when Dr. J.H. van Roijen of the Netherlands announced in the General Assembly yesterday that in about two years his country would propose the admission of the United States of Indonesia.

Ray Robinson will box Georgie Abrams in the ten-round bout that will serve as the feature attraction at Madison Square Garden tonight. The welterweight champion of the world will not be risking his crown against Abrams but the fight, nevertheless, promises to attract a crowd of more than 15,000 fans and receipts of about $80,000.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The marketing of some $250,000,000 of debentures of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in June or July is "the most important job ahead" for investment bankers and security dealers, Edward Hopkinson, president of the Investment Bankers Association, declared tonight.

The spiritual kinship between Trinity Church here and the Diocese of London, from which it derived its charter 250 years ago, was renewed yesterday at a festival service held in observance of Ascension Day in the 101-year-old edifice on Broadway at Wall Street.

The United Nations General Assembly ended its special session at Flushing Meadow at 2 P.M. yesterday after having formally established an eleven-nation committee of inquiry empowered to submit any proposals it desires for the solution of the problem of Palestine.
A Warning on Week-Ends The suddenness with which summer weather arrived earlier this week seems to point to the wisdom of uttering a word of caution on week-end excesses.

PARIS, May 15 (AP) -- France's Davis Cup team, one of the favorites in the European zone competition, encountered little trouble against India today as the second round of play in the European series got under way.

PITTSBURGH, May 15 -- Welcoming the Dodgers to refurnished Forties Field today with resounding bats, the Pirates belted them out of third place and took over that vacancy themselves by a margin of two percentage points. Two home runs by Ralph Kiner and one by Billy Cox, who also hit a tremendous triple, enabled Pittsburgh to score a 7-3 triumph before a ladies' day crowd of 13,471.
Protected by near-perfect relief pitching by Red Tellefsen, Columbia knocked Princeton out of second place in the Eastern Intercollege Baseball League with a 13-5 triumph at Baker Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Presidents have often issued statements to the public on signing bills passed by Congress, and -- though less often -- they have sent comment to the Capitol in message form. But seldom (a cursory search of the record does not disclose an exact parallel prior to 1946) has a President accompanied his signature with a message to Congress construing doubtful or ambiguous sections of the measure he has signed.

FOR the longest while the experts were proclaiming that Sugar Ray Robinson was the best fighter, pound for pound, in the business. They even hailed him as the uncrowned welterweight champion. But now that Sugar Ray has become the welter king in fact as well as in name he's set his sights a bit higher and is aiming at the middleweight crown.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 -- Leroy A. Lincoln, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, denounced today as "unthinkable" the idea that the Federal Government use the power of taxation to raise money for carrying on scientific research "under the guidance of the dead hand of politics."

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Truman signed several bills, nominated George J. Schoeneman to succeed Joseph D. Nunan Jr. as Commissioner of Internal Revenue, named Harold R. Medina to be United States District Judge for Southern New York, designated Charles F. Wennerstrum, Chief Justice of the Iowa State Supreme Court, for service on any tribunals trying war criminals in Germany, and held a news conference.

This week's erratic weather, so dismaying to us cliff-dwellers, has been favorable for fishermen. Heavy hauls are reported in the salt water market by the Fishery Council.
