The quality, it says, is especially appealing to week-end shoppers, for many of the varieties now derive from local waters and the flavor is almost as fresh as if the man of the house had caught the fish himself.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican, of Massachusetts, and six colleagues today introduced a national school health services bill which would authorize $10,000,000 for Federal grants in aid to the states for the first year, and $15,000,000 thereafter to promote school health programs.

The resignation of Msgr. Robert F. Keegan as executive director of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York and the appointment of Msgr. Patrick A. O'Boyle to succeed him in that post were announced yesterday by Cardinal Spellman.

Harnett T. Kane, whose "Natchez on the Mississippi" will be published in the fall by Morrow, is in New York doing research for a new biographical novel, "The President's Wife." It is a story of Varina Howell Davis, wife of Jefferson Davis.

MOSCOW, May 15 -- The Poles have completely repopulated the western territory wrested from Germany at the war's end and have gone a long way toward restoring the economy of this area, it was asserted today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 15 -- Jet aircraft engines have been developed here to an extent that has narrowed the span of British superiority and may allow the "United States to take the world lead in this field, E.R. Newill, general manager of the Allison division of General Motors Corporation, announced today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I take the liberty of calling attention to the Saskatchewan Bill of Rights, which became effective May 1. This Bill of Rights, passed by the Saskatchewan Legislature early last month, is, to our knowledge, the most comprehensive anti-discrimination law that has ever been enacted.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- During the week ended May 14 member bank reserve balances increased $72,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation reported yesterday that consolidated net income for the twelve months to April 30 amounted to $32,029,253, a rise of $10,876,992 over the preceding twelve months.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 15 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, with a two-underpar 68, led today after the first round of the $15,000 Colonial National invitation golf tournament. The Hershey (Pa.) pro shot a two-under-par 33 on the first nine and a 35 on the second nine of the 6,850-yard course.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 15 -- If we are sincere in our wish for a lasting peace we must send food, medicine and building supplies to the peoples of devastated countries, rather than attempt to impose our way of life on them, Mrs. Wendell Willkie said today.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Amid a thundering fourteen-hit barrage that included Bobby Thomson's fifth homer, the Giants today strove heroically to make a success of Clint Hartung's debut as a starting hurler of major league stature.

Weary after a stormy ten-hour meeting on Wednesday several of the 200 stockholders of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation who attended the session returned yesterday for the final round to witness the defeat of Victor McQuistion as president.

Religious instruction is the responsibility of the synagogue, church and home and not of the public school, the National Community Relations Advisory Council and the Synagogue Council of America declared yesterday in a joint statement.

TRENTON, N.J., May 15 -- A nation which in time of war has the power to draft its manpower may certainly contravene property rights arising from zoning, the New Jersey State Court of Errors and Appeals ruled today.

With the exception of a few crisp styles for town, a very dressy feeling dominated the showing of summer hats yesterday at the Hotel Chatham by Laddie Northridge. Laden with flowers or in sheer fabrics designed for dining out, the hats were of the type that women like best because of their pretty flattery.

Mrs. Marty Mann, executive director of the National Committee for Education on Alcoholism, challenged 300 clergymen of the New York East Methodist Conference yesterday morning to lead in helping rehabilitate "hidden alcoholics."
Twelve teen-age boys and girls sitting around a table on the stage of Town Hall talked about juvenile delinquency yesterday afternoon with three adult specialists in various phases of the problem.

BOSTON, May 15 -- Great Britain is happy to see the United States increasing its share of the aid burden in various parts of the world and such help is essential if "our western democracy is not only to survive but to flourish," Lord Inverchapel, British Ambassador to the United States told the Boston Chamber of Commerce today.

Mayor O'Dwyer directed his Commissioner of Investigation, John M. Murtagh, yesterday to turn over all the information obtained in his recent pier-lease inquiry to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan. It is expected that the information will be the subject of a grand jury investigation.

Parking restrictions and lack of adequate thoroughfares to accommodate motor travel in Manhattan are having adverse effect on many phases of business, according to data presented yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, 223 Broadway.

A Bronx radio car patrolman answered an alarm yesterday to find that a playmate of his boy had accidentally and fatally shot a friend of theirs with a revolver in the policeman's home. Each of the boys is 13 years old.

GENEVA, May 15 -- Negotiations designed to coordinate the economic plans of Poland and Czechoslovakia and to reorient the trade of these countries toward the West are well advanced, according to authoritative eastern European sources now in Geneva.

BERLIN, May 15 (AP) -- British officials said today that a fleet of almost fifty ships would be pressed into service from now until the end of the month to speed 392,000 tons of foodstuffs from America to Germany's hungry millions.

BALBOA, C.Z., May 15 -- The Sea Robin, commanded by Comdr. Paul C. Stimson of Danville, Va., cleared from this port today bound for Portsmouth, N.H., around South America by way of Cape Horn, forty-nine years after the famous voyage of the U.S.S. Oregon over a similar route from San Francisco to Jupiter Inlet, Fla.

Members of the stewards department of the new American President Lines' luxury liner President Cleveland will take a special four-week refresher course in shipboard duties before reporting for her maiden voyage to the Orient. The big ship is scheduled to sail in late August.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 15 -- Bob Johnke, 33-year-old sales engineer from the near-by Hempstead Country Club, won the medal in today's qualifying round of the thirty-seventh annual Garden City Golf Club invitation tourney, now known as the Walter J. Travis Memorial, but the talk around the club when the firing was all over was about a veteran who has missed only two of these events since 1909.

Unbeaten Jerry Brown turned in his fifth victory of the season yesterday when he pitched the St. John's University nine to a 7-to-4 triumph over City College in a Metropolitan Conference test at Dexter Park.

PARIS, May 15 -- Former President de Gaulle warned France today that to retain her empire she must create a "strong state" at home. He said this state must be characterized by impartiality, continuity and authority and the existing republic contradicted these requirements.

One serious block in the importation of goods from Germany has been cleared away as a result of a Bureau of Customs decision on the valuation of such shipments, L.L. Horch, regional director, Department of Commerce, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Department stores sales in the week ended May 10 were 13 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:...

Among our boroughs Richmond is in many ways unique, and chiefly perhaps in the extent to which it offers the prospect of future development. Mayor O'Dwyer and other city officials in a friendly expedition yesterday broke ground for the new $12,000,000 ferry terminal which will contribute to that development.

There will be no substantial reduction in retail food prices until costs to the retailer are reduced, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said yesterday in a statement that called for "sense" in food price discussions.

Thomas T. Mott's Floating Isle, second in the event both in 1945 and 1946, finally added his name to the roster of winners of the Charles L. Appleton Steeplechase when he led from flagfall to finish in the twenty-sixth running of the $10,000 added contest at Belmont Park yesterday.

The defense for Mariano Abello, suspended policeman accused of fatally strangling a woman last July 4, abruptly rested its case yesterday in General Sessions without the defendant taking the stand. Edward V. Broderick, his counsel, declared the defense rested on the direction of Judge James G. Wallace.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- A nine-point program for combating deflation and an economic "bust" by increasing purchasing power here and abroad was proposed today by a group of economists headed by Chester Bowles, former Price Administrator and Director of Economic Stabilization.

A $5,200,000 time sale, which the American Broadcasting Company believes the largest in radio history, was closed by the company yesterday. It covers sponsorship of a full hour coast-to-coast music program, to be called the "Paul Whiteman Club," and starts on the ABC network June 30.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Kenneth Romney, former sergeantat-arms for the House of Representatives, was convicted in Federal court today of concealing for two decades a $143,863 shortage in his office account.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 15 (AP) -- Natives of this golfing capital laid their sentiments behind Britain's Walker Cup defenders tonight but feared the worst -- that the great silver trophy would be lifted out of its vault at the Royal and Ancient club by the invading squad of Americans.

The young Philippine Republic, which will be only one year old on July 4, is "the best field for capital investment in the world today," according to its Vice President and Secretary for Foreign Affairs, Elpidio Quirino. He spoke yesterday to business leaders at the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street, a few hours after arriving by air from Washington.

A widely acclaimed and longawaited post-war improvement for the home becomes a reality today with the introduction at Macy's of the Storagewall. This is a series of prefabricated storage units designed by George Nelson and Henry Wright that is adaptable to practically any space and is designed to convert the most careless family into a model of orderliness.

Dr. Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil brought the General Assembly's special session to a close yesterday by pledging the fifty-five members of the United Nations to the finding of a "just solution" for the Palestine problem.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- Registration statements were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two companies, while two others withdrew registrations.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Cleveland mauled three Washington pitchers for fourteen hits tc defeat the Senators, 9 -- 1, here tonight. Bryan Stephens, making his major league debut for the Indians, limited Washington to eight scattered safeties.
The Children's Aid Society rushed its rooftop spring planting yesterday at its West Side Center, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street.
SINGAPORE, May 15 -- Under the new constitutional provisions for the Crown Colony of Singapore the people of Malaya will obtain their first thin entering wedge toward self-government.

ATLANTA, May 15 (AP) -- The stranglation of a socially prominent Atlanta woman, whose body was found in historic Peachtree Creek, left police today with a murder mystery to which there were only meager clues.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The first Senate-House conference toward compromising the divergent labor bills of the two branches brought today House gestures of conciliation so broad as to strongly support earlier predictions that the more moderate Senate approach ultimately would be accepted.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Senate Education subcommittee unanimously voted today in closed session to bring out a Federal-aidto-education bill this session. Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Senate majority leader, author of one of the bills being considered, met with the committee.

Shop stewards representing 35,000 CIO civil service workers in New York made demands last night upon the city administration to make the $660 annual "cost-ofliving" bonus a permanent part of the salaries of all municipal employes.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (AP) -- The league-leading Detroit Tigers had to go fourteen innings today to whip the Philadelphia Athletics, 4 -- 2. A pinch single by veteran Roger (Doc) Cramer and a long fly by Pitcher Paul (Dizzy) Trout provided the scoring punch.

LAKE SUCCESS. N.Y., May 15 -- The chief responsibility for the flare-ups along the northern Greek frontier will be placed on Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania in the majority report of the United Nations' Balkan Inquiry Commission, it was reliably reported here today.
Several hundred children and adults gathered on the lower East Side yesterday afternoon to dedicate a playground to the memory of Capt. Jacob Joseph, USMC, son of Controller Lazarus Joseph.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Two timely transit topics, both scheduled for May 18, are motorization of the Third Avenue car line, decreed by the Third Avenue Transit Company, and the Tri-Borough Trolley Tour, sponsored by the Transit Improvement Association.

GENEVA, Switzerland, May 15 -- After a series of strenuous, keenly debated sessions, the Economic Commission for Europe closed its first conference tonight, deciding unanimously to reassemble here on July 5.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 15 -- With private building construction in Westchester County virtually at a standstill because of high labor and material costs, surveys showed today that investors were waiting for an early chance to begin residential and commercial work amounting to many millions of dollars.

Children who like to push buttons and see things happen will be delighted with the scientific wonders at the RCA Exhibition Hall, 36 West Forty-ninth Street, just opened. Here visitors may be televised and see their images on the screen.

Alliance Ware, Inc. Stockholders of AllianceWare, Inc., approved yesterday a twofor-one split of the company's common stock. American Locker At a meeting in Boston yesterday stockholders of the American Locker Company, Inc., approved a five-for-one split of both the Class A and Class B stocks.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The House passed a $538,976,492 supply bill for the State, Commerce and Justice Departments and the Federal Judiciary today after restoring funds for continued Federal operation of traffic-control towers at municipal airports over the country.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 15 -- The women now attending nursing schools in Europe stand in need of a "strong moral education" to offset their mental and moral deterioration caused by the war, Mlle. Alice Clamageran, superintendent of a training school for Red Cross nurses and social workers in Rouen, France, reported today.

Urging broader trade horizons for American toilet preparations, T.W. Delehanty, associate chief of the chemical and drug division of the Office of International Trade, said yesterday that exports could be doubled to a total of $60,000,000 annually.

Applauded by 130 fellow graduates in the board room of the New York Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street, 33-year-old Louis J. Hefele Jr., blind Bronx native, received a certificate last night on completion of the course given by the Insurance Society of New York.

TOKYO, May 15 -- The Japanese Finance Ministry warned today that serious penalties would be inflicted on black-market artisans who have been making a profit by turning the new metallic currency into articles more valuable than the money.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 15 -- The Connecticut State Federation of Women's Clubs, at the final session of its fiftieth annual convention, took its stand today on subjects ranging from education and the closed shop to rent control and aid for the handicapped.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 15 -- Two British Army lieutenants were killed, two lieutenants were seriously injured and five persons, including an enlisted man, were hurt during a terrorist offensive against Palestine's Government-owned railroads last night and today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- Overruling objections voiced by various holders of preferred stock, the Securities and Exchange Commission today endorsed the Washington Railway and Electric Company's Section 11 (E) plan as "fair and equitable" to all parties.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee held out today a ray of hope for the possible revision of the Italian Peace Treaty when Italy rejoined the community of nations.

Discussing the influence of radio on children, Dr. S. Harcourt Peppard, psychiatrist and acting director of the Bureau of Child Guidance of the New York Board of Education, yesterday discounted charges that broadcasting of children's programs deleteriously affected juvenile listeners.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- J.A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, called today for "a dynamic program of research and exploration" to augment and develop the depleted mineral resources of this country.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The resettlement of displaced Europeans is an international problem. President Truman said today, and its solution can be attained only through international cooperation. He repeated that the United States must accept its share of refugees when international cooperation is finally agreed on.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Advocating Federal aid to the public schools of this country, Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, warned today that, because of inadequate educational facilities America was dissipating its greatest source of wealth -- the young people.

TRENTON, N.J., May 15 -- A plan of the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce for employe sickness benefits through private insurance under state supervision was criticized today by Governor Alfred E. Driscoll.

In the nineteen months since the war ended, the United States Military Academy at West Point has made a smooth transition from war to peace, from an emergency three-year course to the normal four-year course, from a curriculum geared strictly to battle to one broadened to meet new problems of the atomic age.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Croil Hunter, president of Northwest Airlines, declared today that lumping American overseas flying services into a single company "would probably lead to government ownership of all transportation."

For forty seconds today New York City will lie under the shadow of the most powerful bombing formation ever assembled in the United States. One hundred and thirty Superfortresses with a combined horsepower twice that generated by Niagara Falls, will flash from the Battery to the Westchester line, with a comparable roar.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- This country apparently faces the choice of bringing down the cost of housing construction so that private enterprise can do the job or of leaving the high costs to be subsidized by the Government in one form or another, a New York banker said here tonight.

Sixty union elevator operators and porters working at 25 Broad Street won yesterday their fourday strike against their employer, the City Investing Company, for payment of higher wages assured them earlier in an arbitrator's award.

GREENVILLE, S. C., May 15 -- Roosevelt Carlos Hurd, first white man ever named in a Southern court room by other white men as the actual slayer in a Negro lynching, gave a sigh of relief after police told him he had been "fingered" by his fellow-lynchers and remarked, "I know what a mistake I made."

Winston Churchill's vision of the unity of Europe cannot be dismissed as an eloquent evocation of the past or a dream of the future. He spoke in Albert Hall on a favorite theme, with the accent of grandeur and imaginative generosity that distinguishes his most memorable utterances.

Retailers of furs who expect to approach July and August selling at regular markups and with fashion promotions only will find themselves well below their figures of the last few years, according to Miss Cathryn Walter, ready-to-wear merchandise manager of the Mutual Buying Syndicate, resident buyers.

The first extraordinary session of the General Assembly of the United Nations, called together to deal with one of the world's most complex and most humanly poignant problems, has come to an end with a remarkable degree of unanimity. As was clearly forecast, it adopted the proposals of its main committee, in which all the fifty-five delegations had been represented.
GENEVA, May 15 -- Every now and then, to the surprise of its members, an international organization behaves internationally.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Congress, without further debate, completed action today on the $400,000,000 authorization to put the new anti-totalitarian Truman Doctrine to work in Greece and Turkey.
Mayor William O'Dwyer broke ground yesterday afternoon for the new $12,000,000 Staten Island Municipal ferry house at St. George, which will replace the structure destroyed by fire last June.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur Krock remarks, with justice, in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 8 that "few advocates of the cultural relations program of the State Department" are aware of the reasons which have prompted Congressional critics of the program to deny it funds at this time."

PARIS, May 15 -- The resumption of work tomorrow in the Renault automobile plant, whose strike resulted in the recent Government crisis with the Communists, was believed to have been assured today. The Cabinet also hoped for a favorable solution of the strike in Parisian flour mills.

Unable to beat anyone the past week, the White Sox suddenly became robust last night, finding the Bronx air healthy as they fattened up at the expense of the Yankees. Excellent relief pitching by Joe Haynes resulted in an 8-2 victory that snapped a five-game losing streak.
Edward M. Tuft, who joined the company as a radio tube inspector, has been appointed director of personnel of the RCA Victor division, Radio Corporation of America.
Five hundred leaders in education, business and civic affairs paid tribute last night to John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Truman today nominated Harold R. Medina of New York to be United States District Judge for the Southern District of New York. The appointment, if confirmed, would fill the vacancy created by the death of Judge Samuel Mandelbaum.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- House Republican leaders indicated today that there was a strong sentiment among the chamber's majority in favor of continued operation of the "Voice of America" overseas broadcasts by the State Department.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Invitations to a White House conference next Thursday to discuss the "Freedom Train," which will tour the country with historical documents on display, have been sent to heads of large civilian groups, it was said at the Justice Department today.

CRANSTON, R.I., May 15 -- Engineers of three national industrial firms demonstrated here yesterday that they can control the spread of superheated air and toxic gases in fires that occur in multi-story buildings.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Grain markets weakened today after showing early strength. Closing trades on wheat on the board of trade were at losses of 1 1/8 to 2 cents a bushel. May wheat had a range of 12 1/2 cents. Corn was 1 1/8 cents up to 1/4 cent down.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Keeping the control of the country out of the hands of the greedy and the exercise of good common sense by the public are enough to prevent an economic cycle of "boom and bust," President Truman said today.

CINCINNATI, May 15 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, predicted today a merger of the AFL and the Congress of Industrial Organizations in time to permit the formation of a labor bloc of from "40,000,000 to 50,000,000" votes prior to the Presidential campaign next year.

DETROIT, May 15 -- Henry A. Wallace, former Vice President and Cabinet member, tonight told a crowd composed largely of members of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, that Europe wants food and fuel, not tanks and guns, from the United States.

An oversold condition, combined with some short covering, permitted a moderate technical rebound yesterday in the stock market although business returned to a tempo slower than that of recent days. It was the first recovery of any proportion since May 3, but the composite rate only rose 0.70 point, with a wider rally in the industrials.

Facilities for the treatment of the mentally ill are "woefully inadequate," according to data presented last night at a public forum under the auspices of the New York Chapter of the Physicians Forum and the People's Committee for Mental Hygiene on the present-day status of psychiatric facilities.

Edward J. Flynn was praised by President Truman for his "keen political insight and deep appreciation of the true meaning of our democratic form of government" in a letter that was read last night at a dinner in the Concourse Plaza Hotel, the Bronx, held in observance of Mr. Flynn's twenty-fifth anniversary as Democratic leader of the Borough.

Shipping congestion, in South American ports probably will not be alleviated for two years, Otho J. Hicks, executive director of United Seamen's Service, declared yesterday. He added that the problem was traceable directly to a lack of new pier and warehouse construction and improvement of existing facilities.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 10, 1947, totaled 884,242 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,558 cars, or 0.2 per cent more than for the preceding week; 199,300 cars, or 29.1 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year, and 45,478 cars, or 5.4 per cent more than for the 1945 week.
LOS ANGELES, May 15 -- Adolphe Menjou, a veteran actor, told a House Un-American Activities subcommittee today that "Hollywood is one of the main centers of Communist activity in America."

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, May 15 -- In Ciudad Trujillo tonight the public prepared to vote in the general election tomorrow in an atmosphere wholly lacking in excitement. This attitude is general throughout the republic, according to reports.

The report of the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., for the three months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday to stockholders by Donald W. Douglas, president, shows a net loss of $107,109 after giving effect to $700,000 tax carry-back credit.

After the first meeting yesterday of Senate and House conferees on the new labor bill the leader of the House group, Mr. Hartley of New Jersey, ventured the prediction that the final draft of this important legislation will drop both the proposed prohibition of industrywide bargaining and the proposed authorization for private employers to seek injunctions against certain types of strikes.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- After five weeks of decline, average primary market prices remained unchanged during the week ended May 10, the Bureau of Statistics reported today. At 146.7 per cent of the 1926 average the bureau's index of commodity prices in primary markets was 0.9 per cent below a month ago and 3.2 per cent above the corresponding week last year.
LONDON, May 15 -- The British Government today asked Viscount Mountbatten, the Viceroy, to return immediately to London to discuss the critical situation centering on the new British plan for India.

JERUSALEM, May 15 -- A Jerusalem Zionist burst into the officie of two of his English-speaking colleagues today and excitedly addressed them in Russian. He began with the word "Tovarisch" and ended with "Red Front." Then he went away, leaving them startled and uncomprehending.

A rally of the Bronx County chapter of the American Youth For Democracy will be held at 8 o'clock tonight in the Theodore Roosevelt High School Auditorium, Fordham Road and Third Avenue, the Bronx, as scheduled, Frank J. Brennan, assistant director of the Board of Education's division of community education, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Truman accepted today the resignation of Joseph D. Nunan Jr. as Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and sent to the Senate the nomination of George J. Schoeneman to be his successor. Mr. Nunan's resignation will become effective on June 30, when he will re-enter private business.
Effects of the northeastern states cement strike were reported yesterday in cities outside New York while efforts to settle the dispute centered in negotiations in Allentown, Pa.

BOSTON, May 15 (AP) -- Bob Muncrief and his St. Louis Brown team-mates, aided by two Boston errors, snapped a Red Sox winning streak at four games today, beating the American League champions, 2 -- 1, before 11,140 fans.

VIENNA, May 15 -- The vital question whether the Vienna treaty commission will function as a specific fact-finding body or a forum for a general discussion of Russia's right to German property in Austria was still unsettled after its third meeting tonight.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 15 -- The New Jersey College for Women announced today the opening of a campaign to raise funds for the construction of a $300,000 student center building on the campus.

Acting to maintain their reserve position with the Federal Reserve Bank, the sixteen New York City reporting member banks of the Fedeal Reserve System sold $92,000,000 of Treasury bills during the week ended on last Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Arab states will cooperate in the United Nations' inquiry into the future of Palestine, Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, said yesterday in seeking to scotch speculation about a possible boycott.
Within an hour of the close of the General Assembly's special session, the new committee of inquiry on Palestine called its first official meeting for May 26 at Lake Success.

NANKING, May 15 -- The storm center of student agitation shifted from Shanghai to Nanking today. More than 3,000 university men and women swarmed for hours around the headquarters of the Executive Yuan and the Ministry of Education, jeering and insulting high Government officials, denouncing Government policies and stalling the routine of important Government agencies.

LONDON, May 15 -- Fresh from his extended tour through South Africa, King George paid tribute today to the British Empire as a whole and expressed unbounded confidence in the future of Britain herself.

Mayor O'Dwyer displayed keen interest yesterday in a suggestion that the city government investigate conditions in the building trades in an effort to find out why thousands of workmen in that field are idle at a time when hundreds of thousands of new apartments are needed to relieve the housing shortage.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- There is no wedding in prospect, the Congress of Industrial Organizations said today in an official report on its recent unity negotiations with the American Federation of Labor.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 16 -- Heman Marion Sweatt lost today the first round of his battle to destroy Texas segregation laws.

President Truman has chosen an outstanding man to be United States District Judge for the Southern District of New York. Harold R. Medina has had a distinguished record as a court lawyer, as a professor of law, as a writer on legal subjects and in public service of a high order.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics shelled Virgil Trucks from the mound tonight and went on to score an 11-5 victory over the American Leagueleading Detroit Tigers before 10,777 fans.

PARIS, May 16 -- Workers in the Renault motor plant and in the principal Parisian flour mills resumed work today, having accepted the concessions that obliged the French Government for the first time to depart from the strict price-freezing principle adopted under Leon Blum.
TOKYO, May 16 -- The chief secretaries of Japan's four major parties agreed today on a joint policy for the coalition Government under the new Constitution.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 16 -- Judge Klemmer Kalteissen, in sentencing today two men and a woman arrested after a raid on a horse-race wire-room at 9 o'clock at night, criticized the police for the timing of the raid and said it was the subject of "further investigation."

A police program designed to put into practice improved measures for traffic safety education in cooperation with the New York University Center for Safety Education was outlined yesterday at the university's School of Education to several hundred police officers selected for the work.

The contracts have not been signed, but chances are that The Company of Twelve, a group of actors planning to operate a cooperative stock company in Manhattan, will set up shop at the New York City Center. It is understood the deal will be closed next week and that the actors have obtained some unusual terms as theatre contracts go.

Some of the larger food wholesalers are embarking on an all-out campaign to take price and inventory losses immediately to clear their warehouses for new packs at lower prices, it was reported yesterday. Price cuts in the past few weeks have already resulted in an increased volume of sales, wholesalers said.

Jet Pilot, Kentucky Derby champion, and Faultless, Preakness winner, are booked for another meeting today at Belmont Park in the $25,000 added Withers Mile, and in the run will be ten other 3-year-olds that didn't earn tickets to Louisville or Baltimore for the big doings of the past two Saturdays.

MONTREAL, May 16 -- Italy was unanimously voted into the International Civil Aviation Organization at a plenary session of the Assembly here today. Nation after nation whose men had fallen in war against the Italians, welcomed her into the fifth organization subsidiary to the United Nations, which body must still approve Italy's admission here.

Sales volume of department stores next fall is likely to show an increase over last year although sales of non-durable goods may shrink, M.R. Gainsbrugh, chief economist of the National Industrial Conference Board, said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 16 -- Consummation of the long-pending deal for the purchase of Liberty Films by Paramount Pictures was confirmed today by representatives of both organizations. Besides acquiring all of Liberty's assets and outstanding stock, Paramount will obtain the services of the partners in the organization, Frank Capra, William Wyler, George Stevens and Samuel Briskin.
MOSCOW, May 16 -- The United States is attempting to win a place as the most favored nation in every country with which it trades, according to Emil Varga, distinguished Russian economist.

FLANDERS, N.J., May 16 -- Proof that run-down hilly acreage can be redeemed and developed profitably with a minimum of work and experience is being demonstrated at White Gales, the large cattle farm of Eugene K. Denton, president of The Tailored Woman.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 16 -- Nurses from thirty-three nations issued an appeal today to "all people of good-will everywhere" to join the nursing profession in seeking remedies for the present crucial, world-wide shortage of nurses "for which there is no single or immediate solution."

New York University's baseball team clinched its fifth consecutive Metropolitan Conference championship yesterday by downing Hofstra, 10 -- 5, at Ohio Field. It was the Violet's tenth Conference victory without a setback and their thirteenth of the season.

Declining export sales of cottons will mean elimination of one stabilizing influence in the textile industry, according to Worth Street sources yesterday. While strong in the first quarter of the year, cotton textile export sales have fallen off sharply in the last three weeks, it was revealed.

BERLIN, May 16 (AP) -- More than 1,000,000 tons of food was provided for Germans by the United States and the United Kingdom in the first three and a half months of this year, the latest report of the American Military Governor, General Clay, said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 16 -- Elimination of news censorship all over the world was proposed today by the United States. Measures designed to promote the flow of accurate information were submitted to the United Nations SubCommission on Freedom of Information and of the Press.

A banking group headed by Harriman, Ripley Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of an issue of $600,000 of building bonds of Fort Dodge, Iowa, Independent School District, due June 1, 1948 to 1963, at a bid of 100.05 for 1 1/4s.
The Navy will initiate tomorrow its first intensive week of recruiting since the war.
GREENVILLE, S.C., May 16 -- The prosecution played its legal trump at the lynch-murder trial here today by disclosing vital independent corroborative proof that created a furor in the courtroom.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.Y., May 16 -- Rear Admiral Dallas G. Sutton, M.C., retired, director of study, American Hospital Association, Washington, said today that the Veterans Administration expects to have 150,000 hospital beds by 1951.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 16 -- Those who thought that Jack Lyons' victory over T. Suffern (Tommy) Tailer in last year's final of the Garden City Golf Club's invitation tourney was a fluke were proved wrong today. Lyons, the stocky 24-year-old home-club player, accomplished the feat again in the second round of the old club's thirty-seventh spring event.

WILMINGTON, DEL., May 16 (AP) -- The plan for reorganization of the Engineers Public Service Company, Inc., as recommended by the Securities and Exchange Commission, was approved today by Federal District Judge Paul Leahy except for one point.

BERLIN, May 16 (AP) -- At the rate at which German denazification courts are proceeding, Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today, they will require several years to dispose of the vast number of cases still pending before them in the United States occupation zone.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, May 16 -- President Rafael Leonidas Trujillo was today re-elected by a sweeping majority of the Dominican people he has ruled for seventeen years.

PITTSBURGH, May 16 -- Peewee Reese's second home run of the season tonight was enough to beat the Pirates for the Dodgers' first victory on this Western jaunt. Brooklyn took fourth place as a result, while Pittsburgh dropped from third to fifth.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Philip Murray of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and George Meany of the American Federation of Labor, put in heavy attacks tonight on the labor control program now pending in Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- An important preliminary meeting of spokesmen for the United Mine Workers of America and bituminous coal operators was held today to lay the groundwork for a contract that would take the coal mines out of Government operation and restore them fully to their private owners.

Three ex-convicts accused of a $19,000 armed hold-up on Tuesday in Essex House, 160 Central Park South, were rounded up yesterday by detectives of the Safe and Loft Squad. Seized also was a janitor who unwittingly stored the weapons for the gang.

SEOUL, Korea, May 16 -- With the reconvening of the joint United States-Soviet Commission near, Koreans have given an initial hint that they will actively oppose the Moscow decision and its trusteeship clause.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 16 -- The American Lyric Theatre, a new organization formed by concert singers to present operas in English, made its debut tonight with a presentation of "The Barber of Seville" before an audience of 1,000 at the County Center here.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Navy's high command, in testifying at closed sessions of the House Appropriations Naval subcommittee, gave illuminating insights as to new strategic concepts of the role of the Navy, particularly in developing Arctic defenses, it was shown today.

American manufacturers of leather gloves will seek to enlist the aid of British and French producers in maintaining current tariff, it was revealed yesterday by James H. Casey, executive secretary of the National Association of Leather Glove Manufacturers.

Public Responds to Promotions Retail trade continued fairly active here this week. Retailers reported more success with promotional efforts to find price points on merchandise to which consumers freely respond. Department store sales were estimated at 7 to 10 per cent above the corresponding week of last year.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 16 -- The black miniature poodle Champion Cartlane Dernier Cri from the Seafren Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Saunders Meade of West Chester, Pa., took best-in-show today at the thirteenth specialty of the Poodle Club of America.

Ray Robinson beat another middleweight last night. The welterweight champion of the world spotted Georgie Abrams of Washington, D.C., more than eleven pounds and went on to score the expected triumph over his veteran rival in the 10-round main event at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- Augustus C. Studer Jr., receiver for the Standard-Dickerson Corporation of Newark, N.J., testified today that unless the "tight and irregular" sheet steel market "is broken quickly" small users will be forced into bankruptcy.

Exactly 101 B-29 Superfortresses, said to be the largest force of that type of plane ever to fly in formation over an objective in this country, swept in from the Atlantic shortly after the noon hour yesterday to hit New York. Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington in a simulated attack on the eastern seaboard.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 16 -- Former President Miguel Abadia Mendez died last night of pneumonia at his farm, Tegualda, near this city. His age was 80. He will be given a state funeral tomorrow. The body will lie in state in the Governor's palace.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Secretary of State Marshall declared today that the United States was compelled to "spread the truth" about its actions and objectives to counteract "the tremendous degree by which we were misrepresented in other countries."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I hope that I may be permitted to present a few facts in reply to the statements made by H.M. Moolman, director of the Union of South Africa Government Information Office, in his letter published May 6.
New York University lost its suit yesterday to evict the artists with studios in 1, 2 and 3 Washington Square North.

PARIS, May 16 -- Foreign Minister Georges Bidault suggested today that the French might annex the Saar economically by their own independent action without waiting either for the next meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers in London in November or for the Russian approval that was refused at the recent Moscow conference.

Col. Sidney H. Bingham, general superintendent of the city's unified transit system, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer as a member of the Board of Transportation to succeed William H. Davis, who resigned on April 30. A few minutes before he appointed Colonel Bingham, the Mayor announced his acceptance of the Davis resignation and praised the former chairman of the National War Labor Board for his service to the city.

Revealing that he had been sought by other clubs in both major leagues, Claude (Buddy) Young yesterday signed a 3-year contract to play football with the New York Yankees of the AllAmerica Conference. Club officials refused to divulge the financial terms, but it was believed that Young will be paid in the neighborhood of $10,000 annually.
LONDON, May 16 (AP) -- Ireland was eliminated by Yugoslavia from 1947 Davis Cup play today as the field of eight teams for the quarter-final round gradually shaped up.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 16 -- United States Senator Irving M. Ives of New York said tonight that if the nation is to weather the present rough financial seas, the American people must stop the growing notion that it is going to be impossible to liquidate the Federal debt.

Seeing Them Off The iron curtain has been lifted that through all the war years shut off visitors from our steamship piers and made sailing time -- long after it ceased to be top secret -- a grim business.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- A lawyer went into the Municipal Court Building today, shot one Bar Association official to death and wounded another and then killed a policeman and wounded a guard who were pursuing him.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 16 -- In a colorful ceremony attended by representatives of 500 colleges, universities, learned societies and educational organizations, Dr. George D. Stoddard, former New York State Commissioner of Education, was formally installed today as tenth president of the University of Illinois.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican sponsor of the Taft-EllenderWagner housing bill, stated today that he was striving to win over the support of majority colleagues who had raised objections to the measure.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- On the strength of early-inning slugging by his team-mates, Harry (Fritz) Dorish today won his first major league start as the Boston Red Sox defeated the St. Louis Browns, 12 -- 7.

YOU sometimes wonder how the New World ever got colonized at all as you read Col. P.M. Ashburn's "The Ranks of Death, A Medical History of the Conquest of America."* The book is an amazing cavalcade of famines and diseases, pestilences and disasters. A few human ills already were here when the first settlers arrived from overseas.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- Andrew J. May, former chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee, started his defense against war fraud charges today by denying that a $5,000 transaction between him and Murray Garsson, the munitions maker, was a bribe.

With speeches, prayers, scriptural reading, pledges of allegiance and a program of Broadway entertainment, "I Am An American Day," will be celebrated starting at 2:30 o'clock Sunday afternoon on the Mall of Central Park.

Some of the critics of the State Department's Cultural and Information program have argued that generous exports of American food, rather than of American ideas, offer the best means of checking the growth of communism overseas. There is, however, no necessary conflict between the two procedures.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Senate and House conferees agreed today to the authorization of $350,000,000 for relief of hunger and sickness in liberated countries.

FORT KNOX, Ky., May 16 -- The Army's experimental military training unit here at Fort Knox will be extended for another six months after the present course ends on June 30, it was announced here today.
College rowing ofefrs its biggest show today since the last holding of the Poughkeepsie regatta on the Hudson in 1941.

LONDON, May 16 -- The outstanding feature in the stock markets here today was a slump in Brazilian railway stocks following renewed reports that the representative of the Brazilian Government is about to return to Brazil without having made an offer to purchase the British-owned companies operating there.

JERUSALEM, May 16 -- Terrorists blew up an automobile of the Palestine police on the Mount CarmelHaifa road today, causing the death of a British constable and injuries to three other policemen, including a Jewish inspector. Two women in a near-by house suffered concussions and slight facial wounds from splintered glass.

VIENNA, May 16 -- The Austrian Government today petitioned Lieut. Gen. Geoffrey Keyes, commander of United States forces in Austria, to take some 1,400 Jewish displaced persons out of eight leading hotels in the center of Bad Gastein.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- New evidence which he said pointed to the possibility of a fresh approach to the treatment and earlier detection of cancer was presented in Chicago today by Dr. Anderson Nettleship, a staff member of the Alexander Blain Hospital, Detroit.

One of the largest single shipments of ship propellers and tailshafts to a foreign government has started on its way to the Netherlands, it was reported yesterday by officials of the Bethlehem Steel Company's Staten Island shipyard.

The bombing planes that flew over this city yesterday were a small formation in comparison with those sent over Tokyo two years ago this spring, a smaller formation still in comparison with those that attacked Germany during the final stages of the European war.

CINCINNATI, May 16 (AP) -- Backed by a fifteen-hit attack, Schoolboy Rowe posted his sixth consecutive victory today as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 8 -- 4, before a crowd of 2,562.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 16 -- An estate of $10,923,366 was left by the late Joseph Medill Patterson, president of the News Syndicate, publisher of The New York Daily News, according to an intermediate accounting on file here today in the Westchester County Surrogate's office. Mr. Patterson died on May 26, 1946.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 16 -- If Chief Swimming Eel of this southern New England community has his own way, the Dominion of Canada will shortly be brought before the bar of the United Nations to answer to accusations of aggression against the American Indian.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The National Automobile Dealers Association advised dealers today to begin advertising immediately the local delivered prices of new cars.

The stamp collector's "greatest show on earth," the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition to mark the issuing of the nation's first postal paper in 1847, will be opened at 10 o'clock this morning.
ROME, May 16 -- The task of forming the new Cabinet was entrusted to seventy-nine-year-old former Premier Francesco S. Nitti today.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Senate Republicans and Democrats, in formal party conferences, laid the groundwork today for what promised to be a critical battle next week over postponement of a Senate vote on income-tax reduction.
BUFFALO, May 16 (AP) -- The New York State Dental Society was told today that tooth decay among children could be reduced 40 per cent by painting sodium fluoride directly on tooth enamel.

Withdrawal yesterday of Western Electric pickets enabled New Jersey telephone operators to return to work, restoring normal telephone service to that State for the first time since the countrywide strike started on April 7.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Negotiations will begin here on Monday for a settlement of our $32,000,000 lend-lease account with Yugoslavia, it was announced jointly today by the State Department and the Yugoslav Embassy.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 16 -- Harry J. Grant, chairman of the board of The Milwaukee Journal, announced today that employe stockholdings of the Journal Company, now 40 per cent, are to be increased to a majority of the shares, with final control of the company to the employes.

Temporary saturation of the market for many paint materials indicates that the first important signal for lower construction costs has developed, spokesmen for the industry revealed here yesterday following a new break of 1 cent in prices of linseed oil and disclosure that large linseed oil inventories are being dumped at prices 2 and 3 cents below market levels.

Morgan van Roorbach Shepard, who, under the pen name of John Martin, developed a personal association with thousands of children through his books, verses, letters and magazine, died yesterday at The Players, 16 Gramercy Park, of which he had been a member for the last twenty-eight years.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 16 -- Charles R. Denny, Federal Communications Commission chairman, was elected permanent chairman today of the World Telecommunications Conference by delegates from fifty-four nations attending the opening session of the conclave here.
PEIPING, May 16 -- A new Communist offensive in Manchuria is already well under way, according to information reaching Peiping.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., May 16 (AP) -- Two jockeys were injured in a spectacular four-way spill that marred the seventh race today. Jimmy Lynch complained of chest pains and was rushed to a hospital. Apprentice Sidney Manley suffered a possible ankle fracture.

LONDON, May 16 -- Terming Palestine "the most dismal of all quarrels into which we have blundered," Winston Churchill, wartime Prime Minister, said tonight that "we are making fools of ourselves by keeping 100,000 soldiers in Palestine."

The ambitious program proposed to the city by the World Trade Corporation for development of waterfront facilities, construction of a new Washington Market, a promotional trade center and a club-like "World Trade House" certainly addresses itself to a felt need.

ST. LOUIS, May 16 (AP) -- Ron Northey drove in the winning run with a single after two were out in the ninth to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 4-3 verdict over the Boston Braves tonight before 12,413 paying customers. It gave the Cards a 2-0 edge in their series and knocked Boston out of a tie with Chicago for the National League lead into second place.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- At President Truman's suggestion, Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, called today a conference of bankers, insurance company directors, representatives of leading farm organizations and Government officials to meet here June 9 and 10 to discuss inflated prices of farm real estate.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- Walter Masterson stopped Cleveland with four hits tonight as Washington snapped a four-game losing streak with a 2-0 victory before a crowd of 11,909.

New-Capital Market Competitive sales of public utility securities hold the center of interest in the market for new capital for next week. On Monday, the South Carolina Power Company will offer $4,000,000 of bonds and 200,000 shares of no par common stock.

A check for $2,825, representing donations from members of the Immigration and Naturalization Officers Association, has been presented to Mrs. Anthony Oneto, widow of a border patrolman who was killed March 11 while attempting to arrest an alien smuggler, it was announced yesterday.

Increase in garage rates among members of the Upper Manhattan Garage Owners Association was attributed yesterday to an upswing of more than 77 per cent over the 1941 level in labor costs and a corresponding gain in operating expense.

TOKYO, May 16 -- Photographs taken by THE NEW YORK TIMES are being used to teach modern American farming methods to students in the Agricultural College of Tokyo's Imperial University. The university's annual May exhibition, marking the beginning of the academic year, opens tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Three new and improved devices further extending the field of usefulness of electronic microscopy were among the 349 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

The latest reports from the Beaverkill, Willowemoc and Esopus indicate that these streams are slightly higher than normal, but clear, and the water temperature about fifty degrees. What more can you ask?

Gen. George C. Kenney, commanding general of the Strategic Air Command, interpreted yesterday's air maneuver as a demonstration of the threat of air power to the country's most vulnerable target and an illustration of what "a far cry" our present air Strength is from that which we had at the close of the war.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 16 -- The diplomatic battle of the Balkans touched off today three hours of the most sharp-spoken crosstable debate in the record of the United Nations Security Council.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- James M. Landis, chairman of the Civilian Aeronautics Administration, cited the virtues of competition today in vigorously opposing the establishment of a single United States airline for international service.

The Strategic Air Command shot 101 Superfortresses over New York City, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington yesterday at almost four miles a minute, but the display seemed to leave the populace unimpressed. Storms and poor timing spoiled the show.

In a report which has been sent to President Truman and Senator Taft, a group of economists has proposed that business men's committees be appointed to work with the Government in negotiating price reductions. The area of Government responsibility would thus be re-expanded.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 16 -- Following is the text of the proposal submitted to the United Nations Subcommission on Freedom of Information and of the Press by Zechariah Chaffee Jr., United States representative: 1. Measures to facilitate the gathering of news.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 16 -- Mrs. Robert W. Cornelison of Somerville was elected president of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs for a threeyear term at the closing session of the organization's fifty-third annual convention today.

The special session on Palestine of the United Nations General Assembly achieved a success far beyond his original hopes, Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, President of the session, said yesterday. He predicted that the Assembly would solve the Palestine problem in September.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The House Appropriations Committee recommended today a slash of $377,519,200, about 10 per cent, in the Navy's 1948 budget estimates.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange developed irregularly yesterday, closing 27 points lower to 20 points higher.

Appointment of a committee headed my Sumner B. Emerson of Morgan Stanley Co. to direct the sale of United States Treasury Savings Bonds by investment bankers in this area was announced yesterday by Sumner B. Emerson of Morgan Stanley Co., chairman of the New York group of the Investment Bankers Association of America.

JERUSALEM, May 16 -- The United Nations appeal for peace in Palestine was echoed today by members of the Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine. At a meeting they took note of the General Assembly's resolution for a truce.
One year ago Tuesday, the first 404 displaced persons to be brought from Europe by the United Service for New Americans landed here.

LONDON, May 16 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin served warning today that if Britain was faced by "a perpetual veto" in international affairs. British foreign policy would be reviewed. He said this in the House of Commons in winding up a two-day debate on foreign affairs.

Mariano Abello, 36-year-old suspended patrolman, was found guilty of murder in the second degree, with a recommendation for clemency, early today by a General Sessions jury. Abello was accused of having murdered by strangling on July 4 Mrs. Katherine M. Miller, 42, on First Avenue, near Fortysecond Street.

ST. ANDREWS, May 16 (AP) -- The top amateur golfers of Britain and America battled to a draw today in the Scotch foursomes, opening phase of the first post-war Walker Cup Matches. They will square off tomorrow in the concluding eight singles matches of the international classic over the "old course."

ATHENS, May 16 -- Vice Premier Constantin Tsaldaris, who had a long conversation with United States Ambassador Lincoln MacVeagh today, declared this evening that he was satisfied that a common understanding would be reached on an amnesty.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- President Truman today promised Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska, the Republican whip, that there would be no executive moratorium on reclamation projects during the coming fiscal year. Last August he "froze" at $130,000,000 what could be spent before June 30, 1947, on reclamation works.

CHICAGO, May 16 (Science Service) -- An old Indian remedy, podophyllin, from mandrake or May-apple root, is science's newest potential anti-cancer weapon. It may prove too poisonous to be useful for treating humans, but laboratory experiments in test tubes and mice show that it can destroy cancers.
NANKING, May 16 -- Seven hundred striking university students raided the Cabinet staff's headquarters today and ate the waiting dinner.

For the first time in eleven weeks pickets will not parade past headquarters of the Brooklyn Y.W.C.A. on Third Avenue today. Striking building service employes voted yesterday to give up their fight and seek employment elsewhere.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- An aggregate of $207,000,000 of debentures, $40,000,000 of bonds and 175,000 shares of preferred stock was registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three utility companies.

Because of the record pack of tomato juice in 1946, which was more than a million cases larger than at any time before, the United State Department of Agriculture is urging housewives to make good use of the stocks that now are piled high ia groceries.

The 1946 report of the Catholic Youth Organization of the Archdiocese of New York, published yesterday, showed the largest volume of activities of any year since the organization was begun in 1936. Part of the unprecedented increase was attributed to the return of young service men to civilian life.

BERLIN, May 16 -- The American Military Governor of the State of Hesse told the German people tonight that the death penalty would be invoked if necessary to curb disturbances stemming from protests over the shortage of food.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- France has reassured officials of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in writing that they will have every opportunity to supervise expenditure of the recent $250,000,000 loan, it was learned today.

HASTINGS-ON-THE-HUDSON, N.Y., May 16 -- In a raid early today on a ramshackle two-story frame house at 29 Saw Mill River Road, authorities discovered an elaborately equipped gambling dive in operation. The starting bet in dice was generally $100, detectives said, and on the table was $1,981 for the current play.

Emergency relief for critically "saturated" airports of the New York area was promised yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, when the bi-state agency takes over on June 1 the operation of the city's air facilities.

An avalanche of selling orders engulfed the share market on the Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon and returned prices to the lowest levels since last October, with losses ranging up to 7 points or more in key issues and the composite price average falling 2.28 points.

An alleged "master-plotter" behind the $493,000 swindle of finance companies by William B. Benjamin, convicted former war contractor, was indicted yesterday on a fifty-six count information, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced.

LOS ANGELES, May 16 -- Chairman J. Parnell Thomas of the House Committee on Un-American Activities asserted today that a week of hearings on subversive activities in Hollywood indicated that "90 per cent of Communist infitration" was in the screen writing field, but that the Federal Government also had abetted the work.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 16 -- Frank Quinn, who led the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League in strikeouts last season, fanned twenty batters and allowed only two scratch hits as Yale shut out Pennsylvania, 1 to 0, in an eleveninning game today.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's investigation of the subleasing of city piers through middlemen centered last night on the questioning of Al Gross, former business associate of James V. Auditore, boss stevedore, and a number of Auditore employes.

GENEVA, May 16 -- A three-way split on the issue whether the United Nations Balkans Investigation Commission should make any formal findings of guilt, and if so against whom, appeared to be developing today.

A dual price market in bronze has developed, with some standard formula ingots being offered at prices 4 cents a pound below quoted market prices, purchasing agents for large machinery manufacturers revealed here yesterday. Bronze ingots were offered on new contracts, in fifty-ton lots, at prices 1 1/2 cents lower than contract prices set six months ago, they said.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP) -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today launched its second big financing program of the year.

The Federal Bar Association, through Hunter L. Delatour, chairman of its judiciary, has written to President Truman and Attorney General Tom C. Clark, offering to assist in passing on qualifications of aspirants for appointment as United States District Judge in the Eastern District of New York.

PARIS, May 16 -- A financial deal that would make available to France from $300,000,000 to $500,000,000 for financing her trade and recovery program is being negotiated between the French and Swiss Governments and a group of Swiss banks.

The best argument against the United States of Europe is that it is politically impossible in present circumstances. At no period in its long history was the continent so disorganized, so divided and so impotent to act for itself or in its own interests. Never was it so much at the mercy of outside powers.

LONDON, May 16 -- Britain's position as far as electrical power supplies are concerned will be "very much worse" next winter than last, R.H. Gould, Chief Industrial Commissioner of the Ministry of Labor, said today.

Greece's share of President Truman's projected $400,000,000 aid program was described yesterday by Laura Vitray as "laughable" and in any case merely a stop-gap. Mrs. Vitray is special European representative for the Save the Children Federation of 1 Madison Avenue and European editor of United Nation's World.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with much interest your editorial of May 1 entitled "Rising Municipal Costs," particularly the last paragraph, which I quote: "Municipal government generally over the nation is now the weakest part of the structure that administers our way of life.

Use of the family car, hours for coming home at night, allowances, choice of friends, smoking and drinking become family issues as the children grow up. These need not be "problems" as the young people see it.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, today advocated the Public Library Demonstration Bill, which would give limited Federal aid to state library projects, particularly to provide more "bookmobiles" in rural districts.

Concentrating its attack in two big innings, Army's undefeated baseball team overwhelmed Columbia, 14 to 4, at Baker Field yesterday. It was the thirteenth triumph of the season for Paul Amen's cadet nine, which has a perfect record in collegiate competition except for a tie with Yale.

The celebration of the 250th anniversary of Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, will close Thursday with a Sinner in the Hotel Plaza. The guests of honor and speakers will be the Right Rev. John William Charles Wand, Lord Bishop of London, England, and the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, new presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

A new phase in medicine, in which the study of the treatment of disease will be merged equally with the study of the cause of disease, was predicted for the near future here yesterday by Dr. Howard A. Rusk, chairman of Rehabilitation and Physical Medicine, New York University, and associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Three years ago Guatemala drove out its dictator, Jorge Ubico, and later his equally arbitrary successor, General Federico Ponce. Two years ago it wrote into its Constitution a sweeping provision against censorships and suppressions, such as Ubico had practiced. The text of the new Guatemalan law governing publications and radio, which has just reached this country, indicates that the new Government has taken a long backward step.

It is a pleasure this month, on the forty-eighth anniversary of its founding, to call attention again to the work being done for the tuberculous poor by the National Jewish Hospital at Denver, which aptly has been described as an American symbol of cooperation among people of different national and religious backgrounds.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 16 -- The five Arab states that are members of the United Nations are discussing whether they will boycott the Palestine inquiry committee established yesterday by the General Assembly, it was learned tonight.

GETTYSBURG, Pa. -- Favored the year round by tourists, this historic town is preparing for record-breaking crowds May 30 when President Truman is scheduled to give a Memorial Day address. The President will speak at 3 o'clock in the afternoon at the National Cemetery, where Abraham Lincoin gave the famous dedicatory address.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 17 -- The assignment of municipal departments among the five city commissioners-elect was completed today at a meeting of the Good Government group. Fred M. De Sapio, industrialist and former member of the Board of Education, will be Hoboken's new Mayor.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 17 -- Sixteen hundred and fifty-six male voices from eight states participated tonight in a choral festival of the Atlantic Conference of Male Choruses, a division of the Associated Male Choruses of America, in the auditorium of the Westchester County Center here.

ROME (By wireless). BRAVELY the Italian Government has declared war on the black market and, though the outcome of hostilities still hangs in the balance, it is already apparent that it is a thankless enterprise, lacking both public support and cooperation from the police.

IN "Curious Relations" Mr. William d'Arfey, which may be the pseudonymous name of Mr. William Plomer, the editor of the recently published "Kilvert's Diary," has sketched with a thin, elegant stroke a series of Victorian and Edwardian studies that assuredly amuse more than they instruct.

THIS book was first published in 1940, in a high-priced limited edition, was well liked at the time, and has not been available since. The present re-issue is a photo-offset reproduction of the original, with certain differences -- one color rather than two on the title-page, and a somewhat wider and deeper type page, with consequent, and not entirely pleasant, enlargement of the type face.

Quite a battle is going on in Washington over the broadcast "The Voice of America," the outstanding item in the program of the Office of International Information and Cultural Affairs, conducted by Assistant Secretary of State William Benton. Influential backing has appeared for the broadcast. Opposition has developed to some other features of the Benton program. The situation is a tangled one in which it is but natural that some confusion should arise.

Americans can be proud of the statement on freedom of the press which Zechariah Chaffee Jr. submitted on their behalf last Friday to a United Nations sub-commission. We can be proud because we already have most of this freedom in this country. We have no peacetime censorship.

JERUSALEM, May 17 -- Shepherded by two British destroyers, a creaking 1,200-ton former American coastal steamer, Hatikvah, carrying more than a thousand unauthorized Jewish immigrants, sidled up to the cargo jetty in Haifa harbor tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 17 -- Morris M. Townsend, United States Treasury Department official, told the New Jersey Bankers Association today that the management of the public debt for years to come will affect the life of every American.

THE remark that sports writers hear most often from those outside the trade is the wistful statement: "My, but you must meet the most interesting people." The answer generally is the smug and self-satisfied reply: "Yes, and most of them are in the newspaper business." The ink-stained wretches of the Fourth Estate are a clannish lot who seem to prefer their own company to that of athletes and other celebrities.

THE struggle in Palestine resembles Tennyson's "last weird battle in the west" in which "friend slew friend not knowing whom he slew"; and those "falling down looked up for heaven and only saw the mist."

SOME of the national legislation that many industrialists thought would solve most of their problems is now close at hand. The labor bills are in conference. The portal-pay bill was signed last week. The juggernaut of economy is riding rough-shod over essential services of the Government.

THE Horticultural Society of New York will hold a lecture and flower show in its club rooms, 598 Madison Avenue, on Wednesday. Dr. Conrad B. Link will speak on "How New Varieties of Plants Are Developed" at 2:30 P.M.

AUGUST DERLETH has collected, in "Dark of the Moon," an attractive but sinister undertaker's garland of fantastic and macabre poetry. He has permitted himself much latitude in the interpretation of his subtitle: James Thomson's "The City of Dreadful Night," for example, uses the language and symbols of the supernatural, but its subject is only too natural.

GOLF The United States regained the Walker Cup by defeating the British team, 8 matches to 4, at St. Andrews, Scotland. The Americans swept to victory in six out of eight singles matches against Britain's leading amateurs yesterday after tying in the Scotch foursomes on Friday at 2 to 2.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 17 -- Champion Twin Ponds Belle, the Welsh terrier that has been setting a blistering pace ever since the outdoor season started in this zone, added another best in show to her fast growing list in the forty-first annual event of the Ladies Kennel Association today.

WHICH are the ten rarest United States stamps? Probably no two authorities would agree on more than half of the stamps to be included in such a list. The problem involves the question, "What makes a stamp rare?"
LONDON, May 17 (Reuters) -- Results of soccer matches in Great Britain today:

The problem constituted by 20,000,000 crippled and otherwise disabled individuals in the United States calls for coordinated efforts in rehabilitation. Albert G. Milbank, president of the Milbank Memorial Fund, declared yesterday. He announced that the fund had granted $50,000 to promote research for such rehabilitation.

VANCOUVER, B.C. -- The popular "Princess" fleet, with its familiar white, buff and black color scheme, is now almost completely reconverted to peacetime service. By the time the summer vacation season rolls around, at least three magnificent steamships, the fastest in the North Pacific coastwise business, will operate on the "Triangle route" between Seattle, Victoria and the picturesque port of Vancouver on Burrard Inlet.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 17 (AP) -- The United States program to help Turkey establish a compact defensive military organization will get under way next week with emphasis on a communications system to speed up a modern army.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 17 -- The partition of Palestine is believed to be the most likely outcome of the United Nations Committee of Inquiry set up by the General Assembly this week with complete authority to bring in any resolutions it chooses.

IT'S going to be a long, lean summer on Broadway and, as Theron Bambergrer says elsewhere in these columns, it's a good thing for Equity's members that there will be a considerable number of theatres operating on the straw-hat circuit.

IN recent decades much evidence has accumulated to suggest that progress, if a reality, is less likely to be a simple Spencerian unilinear development than a cyclical or spiral process. Today even the layman, after living through the boom and bust and boom again successively of the Twenties, Thirties and Forties, is familiar, to his cost, with the concept of fluctuations around a trend.

In full view of thousands of persons, an unidentified bandit took $80 from a passerby at the busy corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street at 10:45 A.M. yesterday. He then ran into the crowded department store of B. Altman Co., with a policeman in pursuit, and continued through the Thirty-fourth Street entrance, boarded a bus and got away.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, May 17 -- All of Germany is in the midst of one of the worst food shortages the country has experienced. The situation varies somewhat from zone to zone, but conditions in all zones are bad.

THE American Broadcasting Company (WJZ) will undertake an experiment in radio programming next fall when the network will realign its Tuesday night schedule to compete for an audience against what up to now has proved an unbeatable array of top-ranking comedy shows on NBC.

JOHN PALMER'S "Comic Characters of Shakespeare" is now printed for the first time in America, though it was published and reprinted in England in 1946, two years after the author's death. The book contains five studies, part only of what was to have been a much longer work.

The heavy selling pressure that developed in the stock market on Friday afternoon continued virtually unabated in the short session yesterday and prices receded to the lowest level since January, 1945. Losses ranged up to 3 points in the largest volume of business for a Saturday in more than a year.

WASHINGTON. WE cannot solve the housing shortage by building homes only for sale. Nearly half of all families -- veteran and non-veteran -- who are now looking for a place to live want to rent, rather than buy or build. To fill their need is 1947's real challenge to the building industry.

MADRID. LINES of people pour slowly down into the Plaza de Oriente in front of the Royal Palace in Madrid. They come on in thousands until the big square is nearly full, a shouting, jostling crowd, dotted with banners that proclaim their scorn and hatred for the United Nations collectively, for Russia and for France.
HOLLYWOOD. THE motion picture industry was battered from the right and the left last week by political philosophers Who subscribe to the dictum that "if you're not with us you're against us."

HERE is a history of American fiction that was planned backward. Instead of starting with "the first American novel," "The Power of Sympathy," by William Hill Brown (1789), and working slowly down through the years to "The Wayward Bus," by John Steinbeck (1947), Mr. Snell has decided first what seems to him worth while in contemporary fiction and then, like a good prospector, has delved into the sources.

ACTIVE pessimism, as Denis de Rougemont calls it, has impelled him to compose a series of essays on the emotional and social questions forced upon us all by the imminent danger of the atomic bomb. Orderly, ironic, and outwardly untroubled, this slight volume makes as pleasant reading as a man could hope for while waiting to be destroyed.

THE creeping mountain pink (Phlox subulata) makes an excellent ground cover, with a sheet of bloom every spring, for narrow, steep banks. Like all other flowers, this perennial, also known as moss pink, has had difficulty opening this year.
"THE SYMPOSIUM ON MUSIC CRITICISM" held under the auspices of the Music Department of Harvard University on the first, second and third of this month was a very successful and provocative affair.

MILWAUKEE, May 17 -- Because teachers are underpaid there are 100,000 teaching vacancies in the country's public schools, Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican, of Massachusetts, said tonight at the banquet of the fiftieth anniversary meeting of the Associated Harvard Clubs of the United States.

ATHENS, May 17 -- Greek Army forces have inflicted a serious defeat on rebel forces in a number of areas. Gen. Constantine Ventiris, chief of the General Staff, reported to the War Ministry in a dispatch published today.
