ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 17 -- The United States is "pitifully limited in its United Nations leadership because of restrictions in this country on the constitutional rights of women," it was declared here today by Mrs. Nina B. Horton Avery of Richmond, Va., vice president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs.

James V. Auditore, "millionaire stevedore" and one of the most colorful characters on the New York waterfront, has been questioned by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's staff on Mayor O'Dwyer's disclosure that two Auditore companies had profited from subleasing city piers, it was learned yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- By rallying in the last two innings, the Army baseball team defeated Pennsylvania today, 10 to 5, for its fifteenth straight victory of the season.

With the tempo of financing of foreign nations associated with the United States in the war increasing, the question arises whether a revival of interest may not be expected on the part of American investors in securities of foreign corporations, such as occurred after World War I, when we used our funds to help to restore warravaged countries.

Gregory Ferend, president of the Sword Line, announced yesterday that his company had purchased the Newtex Steamship Corporation and would operate it in coastal services as a Sword subsidiary. The new service, to be called the Texas Line, will maintain the fastest freighter service offered between New York and Houston, he said.

TOKYO, May 17 -- The Japanese Government's Central Screening Committee, which administers the Allied purge directives, announced today the dismissal from public life of three more members of the Cabinet.

THE Photographic Carnival, a three-day program of lecture-demonstrations and camera activities, concludes today at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue. Today's program opens at noon with demonstrations of how to hold and load a camera, followed by lectures on exposure meters, light and filters, home portrait lighting, basic exposure problems, zoo photography, enlarging for beginners and darkroom analysis.

IT is difficult for us to comprehend how primitive United States postal conditions were a century ago when our first stamps were issued. In 1847 a few pioneers were journeying toward Oregon in covered wagons, and there were few settlements west of the Mississippi River except in Texas.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Jed Johnson, nominated to be a judge of the United States Customs Court, denied today testimony of Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior, that Mr. Johnson brought undue influence upon the department.

Announcement by Senator Gurney that Senator Taft and the Republican Policy Committee have agreed to put Army-Navy unification on the list of "must legislation" for this session of Congress apparently removes the last real barrier to early passage of the Unification Bill.

To help independent retail stores to compete with chain organizations, Krasne Brothers Bernice Foods, a wholesale grocery concern serving 5,000 independents, announced yesterday price reductions ranging up to 10 per cent on staple food items begininng tomorrow.

BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, May 17 -- More than 1,000 trade-union delegates representing approximately 2,000,000 workers in the Ruhr's great industrial cities presented to the Military Government today a program that they said would save the United States and British zones from the "social disintegration into which we are drifting."

THE story of young America's move to Paris in the Nineteen Twenties has always attracted those who remember the Mencken-Lewis-Volstead decade. Mr. Putnam's record now offers much new information, and a good measure of anecdote, concerning the phenomenon of expatriation.

THE MOST REV. MICHAEL J. CURLEY, Archbishop of Washington and Baltimore, on May 16, at Baltimore, age 67. Born in Ireland, he came to America in 1904. In 1922 he became Archbishop of Baltimore. An early foe of Hitler, he refused to sign a petition circulated by the Baltimore clergy urging that "every possible means" be taken to avoid war.

THE dry-fly fisherman is a purist, and something of a snob in a nice, forgivable sort of way. Conscious that he has mastered the ultimate in the piscatorial art. he shudders at the sight of all the "hardware" and heavy tackle incident to salt-water angling, or even the casting rod and plugs usually used by those who go after black bass.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Continuing their extraordinary streak through the West like something shot out of a gun, the Giants today extended their string of triumphs for this trip to five in a row as they bowled over Charlie Grimm's Cubs in eleven innings 3 to 1.
TO THE EDITOR: I have read with much interest the article "Only Two Terms for a President?" by Henry Steele Commager. It presents, however, only one side of the question.

DENVER, May 17 -- This milehigh city in the Rockies seems even higher up in the air as 150,000 frantically exhorted voters prepare for Tuesday's mayoralty election, where the issue is to continue or put an end to the twenty-year rule of Mayor Benjamin F. Stapleton, candidate for re-election.

POSTAGE stamps were officially adopted by the United States Post Office Department just 100 years ago. event is now being commemorated by the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition, which opened at the Grand Central Palace yesterday and will continue through next Sunday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -- Walter (Hoot) Evers closed the Detroit Tigers' first visit of the season here in a blaze of glory today with a two-run, ninth-inning homer that defeated the Philadelphia Athletics, 2 -- 1.

COUNT as one of the coterie of actors who are entering into independent production Paul Henreid, who, with producer Jack Chertok, recently formed Banner Films, Inc. The company, said Mr. Henreid, who had such matters as a radio show and film business to negotiate during his stay here last week, will start work, come the fall, on "The Heaven We Chase," the first of two properties to be made.

IN this powerful study, published under the somewhat dry title of "The Mind and Heart of Love," the great English Jesuit teacher and philosopher, M.C. D'Arcy, has presented a stimulating exposition of a challenging subject.

Business men, economists and educators are beginning to study the American economic system more intensively than ever before. A striking indication of this trend of thinking was by the proposal made last week by Charles Luckman, president of the Lever Brothers Company, for the joint education of prospective labor and management leaders.

KINGSTON -- More than half a million people vacationed in the Catskill Mountains area last year and hotel operators are anticipating an even larger season this summer. There are something like 1,900 resort hotels and centers in this section offering the summer guest a wide choice of scenery, accommodations and sports.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 17 -- The United Nations Subcommission on the Freedom of Information and of the Press will begin its first session here tomorrow. Its task will be to draft an agenda and otherwise prepare for a conference, the goal of which will be to adopt concrete measures for the attainment of world-wide freedom of information.

BOSTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Barco Stables' Atomic Power, 9-to-10 choice, exploded today to capture the $10,000-added Constitution Handicap by two and three-quarter lengths over William G. Helis' Jobstown before 34,287 fans, the largest crowd of the meeting at Suffolk Downs.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 17 (AP) -- Vic Ghezzi of Kansas City and Johnny Palmer of Badin, N.C., forged to the front at the halfway mark in the $15,000 Colonial National invitation golf tournament today. Each posted 139, one under par for two rounds.

Drying up of foreign supplies of specialty merchandise has resulted in a trend toward substitution of newly developed American goods and temporary curtailment of purchasing abroad, import managers of several large department stores reported last week.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 17 (AP) -- Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Under-Secretary of State for External Affairs, recommended today "a voluntary surrender of some measure of sovereignty to a world authority in the interest of peace and security."

MONTREAL, May 17 -- Its political problems disposed of in two weeks of meetings, the International Civil Aviation Organization will start tomorrow to dispose of purely aviation issues. Authorities predicted the organization would produce an air code more comprehensive than that developed over hundreds of years for the surface-faring seamen.

"Jack Coffey Day" was a great success, greater even than anyone at Fordham had hoped it would be yesterday at Fordham Field, where old friends and grads gathered to honor the silver-haired coach, who has been tutoring Ram baseball teams for twenty-five years.

CINCINNATI, May 17 (AP) -- The Reds increased their home-run leadership in the majors to thirty-three today with three circuit drives, but fell before the Phillies, 6 -- 3, in the rubber of a three-game series.

The law is well settled that an assignment to a member of one's family of anticipated income, like unearned wages or future income from property over which the assignor retains control, does not relieve the assignor of the income tax on such income.
Manhattan College moved up to fourth place in the Metropolitan Baseball Conference by turning back City College's nine, 8 -- 4, before 1,200 fans at Macombs Dam Park yesterday.
Columbia's baseball team made 2,000 Alumni Reunion Day onlookers happy yesterday at Baker Field when it handed Yale its first Eastern Intercollegiate League setback in five starts.

LONDON. THE United States of America is a cozy little country consisting of three small States, California, Kentucky and Texas; a vague area known as the Middle West; a rather demode section called the Wild, or Woolly, West, and New York.

Great Soviet Success When the full story of the Russian Communist Government can be told, it may very well appear that the most remarkable achievement of the regime, all things considered, was its propaganda and censorship.

THE forging of a Hollywood-London film axis, begun last November with the visit to England by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, was completed here last week amid much pomp and circumstance when Joseph Arthur Rank, the colossus of the English movie world and president of the British Film Producers' Association, was honored at a dinner by the American industry.

ALTHOUGH the United States has been issuing postal paper for a century, fewer than 5 per cent of all major and minor varieties released throughout the world have been printed within the United States for American needs.
THE sink is full of breakfast dishes, your 2-year-old is dragging the place mats off the table, the baby has just upset his milk, the postman wants a parcel signed for, the telephone rings.

Discrimination against women lawyers in the courts of this area was charged yesterday by Magistrate Anna M. Kross, speaking at the annual luncheon of the New York Women's Bar Association. It was held in honor of Mrs. Adelaide Burkan Bodow, retiring president, and Miss Esther Glantz, incoming president.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., May 17 -- Avenging last week's 5-2 defeat, Lawrenceville's baseball team beat its ancient rival, the Hill School, in a 2-1 thriller here today before a large Alumni Day crowd.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Helpless before Red Einbree's fast ball hurling for eight innings, the Washington Senators rallied to tie the score in the last half of the ninth and went on to win from the Cleveland Indians, 2 to 1, today in a ten-inning battle.

AN organization called Ballet Theatre Foundation, Inc., came into being last week with the avowed purpose of "dignifying and establishing the permanence of ballet generally, and of Ballet Theatre particularly as the art's currently most representative spokesman."
THE National Sculpture Society is now holding its fourteenth annual exhibition of small bas-reliefs. The work will be found in the upstairs gallery at the Architectural League.

Store-wide activity improved last week, with cotton dresses selling well, vacation shops attracting attention and doing business, coat and suit clearances continually active, blouse business keeping up, men's furnishing activity brisk and girls' and tots' summer clothing moving along, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Glenn L. Martin, pioneer aviator, testified publicly today that the Army and Navy are experimenting with a new atomic weapon -- a radioactive cloud which could be released from aircraft by nonexplosive atomic shells.

Because he believes the construction of suburban garden-type apartment houses is not economically practical today, Sidney Fass has decided to concentrate on the building of one-family dwellings in the Long Island area. Mr. Fass who before the war was active in the New York apartment building field, said he would like to put up garden apartments for forty to fifty families, but finds it impossible to do so today.
CHICAGO, May 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculure follows:

THE praise of Gilbert Murray as lecturer is sounded by all who have studied "Greats" at Oxford, and his talents as essayist are familiar to scholars. To the average American, however, these aspects of his work have been hitherto unknown.
Country-wide telephone service was brought to a near-normal basis last night after all Bell System traffic operating units reached settlements with their unions.

Next Tuesday, May 20, there will be a total eclipse of the sun. The most favorable location in South America for the observation of the total phase is the Brazilian highlands. At Bocayuva, 400 miles north of Rio de Janeiro, the period of totality will be 3 minutes and 50 seconds.

TOBACCO is an herb that soothes both the smoker and the tax collector. For one it invokes urbanity and a certain degree of felicity. For the other it gives assurance that the Treasury will be fattened. As a rule the tax collector cultivates the smoker on the theory that the more tobacco burned the greater the revenue.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- A Mexican desert scene, with cacti, flowers, birds and reptiles, will be unveiled tomorrow at the Academy of Natural Sciences.

HOLLYWOOD. THE first movies were made in barns. They built some scenery, set up cameras, brought in the actors, and let 'em roll. Today, some four decades, two world wars, several atomic bombs, and 21,000 pictures later, they are made the same way.
HANOVER, N.H., May 17 -- The tail-end Ivy League teams split a double-header here today, with Dartmouth edging out Cornell, 5 -- 4, in the opening contest and succumbing, 7 -- 3, in the nightcap.

Dr. Frederick Ernst, associate superintendent of schools, charged yesterday that "hundreds of little censors" were at work in the city's classrooms, emphasizing their personal predilections instead of their public duty as school teachers.

BERLIN, May 17 -- The Military Government has suddenly and dramatically "got tough" with the Germans. Yet it can be stated without valid contradiction that the present economic crisis is largely the result of the "soft" policy of the British and Americans during the past eighteen months.
OMAHA, May 17 -- Despite the closing of many war industries, consumption of electric power has risen steadily throughout the Midwest in the last two years.

ALL kinds of people collect stamps, and for about as many reasons as there are collectors. How people collect stamps is a bit easier to discuss, especially since the field of philately has in recent years changed profoundly in this regard.

The chronic malady known in the vernacular as "itching foot" becomes an "avocational" disease among many members of the angling fraternity each spring, and the first symptom is marked by an overpowering impulse to sit down and write to a rod and gun editor and inquire as to the possibilities and tackle requirements of certain distant waters.

The Seaboard Air Line Railroad will begin a new streamlined-passenger-train service between New York and Birmingham, Ala., today. The train, to be known as the Silver Comet, will provide one-night-out service from the North Atlantic seaboard to Atlanta and other cities in the South.

Duplicating their upset victory over Bishop Loughlin in the indoor C.H.S.A.A. title games, Mount St. Michael's track and field forces captured the thirty-first annual Athletic Association of the Private High Schools championship meet yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Why, Americans may ask, should we be concerned with what goes on in Korea, a country 8,000 miles distant that few of us have ever visited? The reasons are threefold:

PITTSBURGH, May 17-- Other shutouts may be the Dodgers' portion before this campaign ends, but no whitewashing is likely to leave them so red-faced with embarrassment as today's 4-0 beating by the Pirates before a jeering crowd of 17,673 fans.

HAROLD ISAACS was known in China as a writer of awesome industry, profound scholarship and a deep and cheerful cynicism. He is the author of "The Tragedy of the Chinese Revolution" -- an excellent study never, curiously enough, published in America, though it would be valid today.
MOSCOW, May 17 -- Step by step, the United States is winning the domination of Latin America, according to an Izvestia article.

SUPER-ROCKET -- In June the Navy will test at White Sands, N.M., its "Neptune" rocket, the first all-American long-range missile of supersonic speed. The Neptune will carry a useful load to a height of 235 miles, or twice as high as the German V-2. The cost of a Neptune is said to be about $80,000.

COMBS this transitional season, when the frost is finally out of the ground and the warm vernal sun is conducive to all sorts of notional escapades, and the hard-worktng movie reviewer -- this one, anyhow -- finds it increasingly difficult to keep his mind on his work.

PEARL HARBOR, May 17 (AP) -- The battleship Oklahoma, raised from a shallow grave after the Japanese assault on Pearl Harbor, sank quietly in Mid-Pacific today, thwarting the mainland junkyard to which she was being taken.

The ideal of world citizenship might be made a reality it other nations would follow the example of democratic America, according to views expressed yesterday at the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.
A fabulous rise in the stock of American Woolen common led to the arrest of John M. Brown, a Wall Street customers' man, on charges of forgery and grand larceny, it was disclosed yesterday.

LIKE a restaurateur who Knows his business, the wise publisher today provides two types of menu, the table d'hote for those who are rushed, lazy, or merely hungry; and the a la carte for those who have the leisure, the exploratory curiosity, or the good taste to make out their own bill of fare from a long list of possibilities.

THE world has not seen the last of America's erstwhile friend, Richard. He has shown up in England and the British people are undergoing a noisy introduction to the reticent character who wouldn't open the door.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Stiff opposition to the Stratton bill, which would permit the entrance into the United States of 400,000 European displaced persons in four years, was forecast today by Representative Frank W. Fellows, Republican, of Maine.

A capacity audience of 500 school children filled Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday, morning for an entertainment program called "Just for Fun." It was the final program of the season in the "Fun With Book People" series, presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with the Association of Children's Book Editors.
The third concert of Columbia University's Festival of American Music was given yesterday afternoon in the McMillin Theatre by the NBC Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Alfred Wallenstein.

JERUSALEM (By Wireless). WHILE uncertainty clouds the future of Palestine and while violence adds new tragedy to the long story of conflict, Jewish colonization of Palestine goes on at accelerated pace. The Zionists are speeding with all their resources their program of setting up new communities and causing the desert to bloom.

GREENVILLE, S.C. May 17 -- The paradoxical handling of the race problem in the South is being illustrated with unusual clarity in this textile city as thirty-one of its white citizens stand trial for the lynch-murder of a Negro.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (U.P.) -- Representative Taber told his radio audience tonight that the State Department personnel handling the information program "must be subjected to the most stringent loyalty tests."

SEATTLE, Wash., May 17 -- Young Japanese-Americans and their parents who have returned to this area "have been forced to change their living patterns," a study made of their social and economic conditions revealed today. Both the native-born Nisei and their parents, Issei, have found that the old ways are no longer open for them.

HOUSTON, Texas, May 17 -- Attempts by "subversionists" to wreck the American system of government through destruction of public confidence in Congress is the "one very great danger which confronts us at this time," Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House, declared here tonight.

SAN MARINO'S stamps honoring Franklin D. Roosevelt reached New York last week. Above a reproduction of the late President's autograph on postage 1-lira olive and 5L rose is a Roosevelt quotation dated Jan. 17, 1945.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 17 -- Seemingly inspired by the magnificent play of Marvin (Bud) Ward, America's Walker Cup team summoned an amazing burst of golf after lunch today to sweep to victory in six out of eight singles matches against Britain's leading amateurs.

IN the warm May sunshine "primitives" have sprouted with omnipresent lustiness along Fifty-seventh Street. I attended no fewer than three shows last week in which they have things exuberantly their own way.
ROME, May 17 -- After consulting leftist leaders today, Francesco S. Nitti seemed to be more hopeful of being able to form a Cabinet.

HOLLYWOOD. IF Robert Riskin is chewing his gum a little faster these days and more frequently dropping the coins he always is nervously manipulating in his right hand, it is because of his recent experiences with the trials and tribulations of the "sneak" preview.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- President Truman is expected to appoint James Bruce of New York, vice president of the National Dairy Products Corporation, as Ambassador to Argentina when George S. Messersmith ends his service at that post, it was learned today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 17 -- Sydney and Melbourne gave rousing welcomes today to the United States naval squadron, ten ships of which arrived on a visit to Sydney and four to Melbourne. Excepting the USS Louisville's visit in 1934, this marks the first peacetime visit to Melbourne by ships of the United States Fleet in twenty-three years.

MORE trips in near-by waters than have been available for some years are assured New York and its summer visitors with the return of additional excursion boats to peacetime service. Tours along the Hudson and East Rivers, around Manhattan Island and to resorts on the Jersey coast are included in these water excursions.
Through the stretch it was all Faultless in the seventy-second running of the Withers Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday.

AT this writing no riot squads had been summoned to quell public arguments about the Pulitzer prizes for literature -- 1946 was, perhaps, that kind of year in letters. Even the literary critics -- or, anyhow, seventeen of them whom our contemporary The Saturday Review of Literature polled after the announcements -- didn't react as testily as they usually do.

BARSETSHIRE, Angela Thirkell's own enchanting English county, grimly faces up to the ravages of peace in her latest novel. Everyone had grown accustomed to the terrors and discomforts of war and had snugged down as cosily as possible against it.

KANSAS CITY, May 17 -- With President Truman at her bedside, his mother, Mrs. Martha E. Truman, rallied enough tonight to take a soft-boiled egg for her supper, but her condition was described as still serious. She suffered two setbacks last night, causing the President to fly to her home at Grandview, Mo., earlier in the day.

Of the many disabled veterans who charge that the nation has forgotten far too soon, there is one small group banished to the Louisiana lowlands, whose probblems merit special attention. They are the thirty-two veterans at the National Leprosarium at Carville, La., suffering from leprosy.

Early in the century we thought of food in terms of calories because the body was supposed to be primarily a living power plant that had to be stoked. Yet there were puzzling indications that neither mice nor men could live on carbohydrates, fats, proteins and salts alone.

THERE are a number of short stories of Guy de Maupassant -- I can think, for example, of "Vain Beauty" -- which for intelligence, urbanity and resolution remain unsurpassed. Yet today, except for some set pieces like "The String" and "The Necklace," Maupassant is not read at all.

THE unique British Guiana 1-Cent Magenta, most valuable of all the world's stamps, whose present owner's name has never been made public, holds the spotlight as one of the most interesting exhibits at the Grand central Palace stamp show.
A two-day conference to plan for an "Emergency World People's Congress" here in September opened yesterday at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

The American-flag passenger fleet visualized by the Maritime Commission's trade routes committee in its current report is a modern, compact fleet of ninety-four or ninety-six vessels that would be the safest in the world.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Representative John Taber, Republican, of New York, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, and one of the chief critics of the "Voice of America," gave his qualified approval today to a "cleaned-up" State Department counter-propaganda program.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Senate and House were in collision softly and decorously this week, in an atmosphere of the most acute political awareness, as they undertook the first of their conferences to negotiate a compromise between their vastly divergent labor bills.

In a nation-wide broadcast the other evening, William Green, President of the American Federation of Labor, repeatedly referred to the two labor bills which have just been taken in charge by a Senate-House conference committee as "the Taft-Hartley slave-labor legislation" and "the Taft-Hartley slave-labor program."

Mayor O'Dwyer and Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn announced yesterday that the Board of Estimate would consider on Thursday a resolution authorizing immediate acquisition by the city of the property of the New York Water Service Corporation, which now supplies water to most of the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Senate Finance Committee called today for immediate tax reduction as a means of maintaining existing high levels of employment and production.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The President signed the first major bill that was a part of the program of the Republican majority in Congress -- the portal-to-portal legislation -- and he signed it over mild protests from organized labor.

SINCE "Born Yesterday" has been playing to packed houses for more than a year, this vigilant column claim no special powers of divination in earnestly recommending it to theatregoers. The critics who joyfully serenaded it in February, 1946, and the crowds that have been beating their way into the Lyceum Theatre ever since have sufficiently recognized the glow and sagacity of Garson Kanin's exuberant show.

FOR THIS WEEK: Sow seeds outdoors of all vegetables and flowers save cucumbers, corn and those that must have constantly warm weather to germinate. . . . Prune back severely (to three or four eyes) rose bushes planted late this spring, and hill soil around the canes to prevent them from drying out and to hasten leafage.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported tonight that retail food prices dropped 0.8 per cent between mid-March and April 15 while costs of other living essentials continued to advance.

In a major change in production policies many manufacturers of industrial raw materials and parts are revising their current forecasts of profitable operating levels and adjusting them downward to a more realistic level to prevent a more severe decline later, spokesmen disclosed here yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, May 17 (U.P.) -- All mass demonstrations connected with a five-year trusteeship for Korea during sessions of the Joint United States-Soviet Commission meetings were banned today by order of Korean Civil Administrator Ahn Chai-hong.

LONDON. THE desperate search for something new has led the British Broadcasting Corporation to radio crosswords. This also enables them to indulge still further the current craze for listener participation in broadcasting. The main problem with this idea is to insure that the crossword addict has the appropriate diagram in his hand at the right moment.

PARIS (By Wireless). TO the casual outsider France appears an unstable, mercurial country where almost anything may happen. One of the notable and most noticed developments has been the advance of the French Communist party at the ballot box and in Parliament, an advance far greater than has been made by a Communist party in any other democratic country or even in some Russian-occupied countries.

A DIVERSIFIED show at the Mortimer Levitt Gallery brings together paintings and sculpture by artists of the gallery group. Figures by Charles Umlauf reveal the Texas sculptor to be continuing in his characteristic semi-abstract manner, the power and vigor of his compositions unabated, Jose de Rivera contributes abstract metal pieces in color -- streamlined, modern designs, seemingly based on industrial conceptions and strikingly decorative.

The financial crisis facing all educational institutions in the United States today is even more acute for the private Negro college, according to Frank M. Totton, national chairman of the United Negro College Fund, which is seeking $1,300,000 in its campaign this year.

JUST seventeen years ago this week in this Review; Those were the days, the beginning of the Thirties; Long Lost Letters of Shelley Are at Last Discovered, goes the headline, and Herbert German tells us that it was Thomas Love Peacock who discovered the fact of the existence of some ten letters, nine of them written by Shelley to his first wife, Harriet Westbrook. . . .

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- In this Federal Reserve District the department store sales last week showed a 14 per cent increase, compared with a year ago with a like increase shown for the four weeks ended May 10. Central Philadelphia stores showed a 12 per cent gain in sales over last year and 11 per cent for the four weeks' period.

PARIS, May 16 (Delayed) -- The Communist party in Morocco, which has never before backed the Sultan, sent a telegram to the Sultan's Counselor on Tuesday demanding that the French protectorate be terminated and that Morocco become a free, sovereign state, according to French officials here.

Wholesale markets were quiet last week as ready-to-wear and accessories manufacturers prepared fall lines for the expected influx of buyers this week, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

WITH two Stevenson collections launched, we may assume that a Stevenson revival is under way, if, indeed, there has been any real lapse in attention to him. Revive Tusitala? Why, someone has always been reading "Treasure Island" or "Dr. Jekyll" or "Kidnapped" from the day they were published.

"WARM weather" vegetables, the kinds that wait until the ground is thoroughly warm before being planted, occupy the gardener's attention now. In this group are some delicious, less frequently grown crops worth adding to the vegetable plot.

Yankee pitching and clubbing worked harmoniously yesterday at the Stadium. As a result, Bucky Harris' troupe grabbed its first home double-header from the Chicago White Sox the hard way. An amazing crowd of 66,666 excited fans saw the games.

IN the spring of 1942 Lanny Budd, about to undertake the eighth volume of his picaresque career, obligingly passes in review the events of the seventh, in which, he reflects, he had traveled around the earth, "and most of the trip near the Equator, where the distance is greatest."

A survey of savings and loan associations for the first quarter of this year shows assets at a new high mark and an increasing amount of assets invested in mortgage loans, according to the United States Savings and Loan League.

BOSTON, May 17 -- The latest Battle of Beacon Hill (not to be confused with the Battle of Bunker Hill) finally has been settled by a statement of Mayor James M. Curley of Boston: "Let them have bricks."

IN the early part of the eighteenth century there lived in the primeval Carpathian Mountains of eastern Europe an uneducated and poor, yet God-intoxicated Jew named Israel ben Eliezer, who was destined by fate to foment a veritable spiritual revolution among nia co-religionists.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Central Westerners, seeking to determine what effect Henry A. Wallace's attacks upon the Truman foreign policy will have upon the Democratic party's chances in next year's Presidential race, were quick to interpret as "third-party talk" a statement by the former Vice President before an audience here Wednesday night.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 17 -- Hammering four hurlers for 19 hits, St. John's downed Hofstra, 13 to 2, today to take over undisputed possession of second place in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference.

Because of the city's failure to take any action on recommendations made last August, the Mayor's Business Advisory Committee, provisionally headed by Nelson A. Rockefeller, has disintegrated, it was disclosed yesterday at City Hall.

The Hapoel soccer team of Palestine, with one victory and one tie, will meet the third opponent on its nation-wide good-will tour when it plays the American League All-Star eleven at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island today. The game will start at 3:15 P.M.

BERLIN, May 17 -- Widely increased authority for German bizonal agencies, has been approved by Secretary of State Marshall and Foreign Secretary Bevin to cope with the economic crisis. The approval was revealed today on the return of Lieut. Gen. Brian Robertson, British Deputy Military Governor, from London.

In one of the most ambitious post-war housing projects of its kind in the country, a community of 1,206 one-family dwellings has been started in Elmont, L.I., that will represent a total investment of $13,000,000 and take about a year to complete.

With a sixteen-day-old cement strike threatening the lay-off of thousands of construction workers, further meetings are scheduled for tomorrow in Bath and Allentown, Pa., in an effort to break an impasse between the striking union and the largest single company.

PEENEMUNDE, Germany, May 16 (Delayed) -- Here on the tiny pine-covered little Baltic island of Usedom, northwest of Stettin, is all that remains of Nazi Germany's most famous rocket weapon testing base. That "all" is a fairly good road that leads to the tip and a single-line railway used to can away scrap.

BATON ROUGE, La., May 17 (AP) -- If anyone is betraying the millions of American veterans "it is the American Veterans Committee," Richard C. Cadwallader, national vice commander of the American Legion and chairman of its national veterans' housing committee, said today.

The current monthly construction report of the Maritime Commission lists three merchant vessels completed and one launched in American shipyards during last month under commission contacts. The vessels delivered were the Alcoa Clipper and Alcoa Corsair, built by the Oregon Shipbuilding Corporation for the Alcoa Steamship Company, and the Cibao which was constructed for the United Fruit Company by the Bethlehem-Sparrows Point Shipyard.

FORT KNOX, Ky., May 17 -- The substitution of the student-instructor relationship for the "rawrookie-tough-top-sergeant" attitude of the old Army is the secret of the success of the Army experimental military training unit here.

Seven meet records were set in a series of brilliant performances as New York University's heavily-favored squad beat down a surprisingly formidable challenge by Manhattan College to capture team honors in the fourteenth Metropolitan intercollegiate outdoor track and field championships yesterday.

THE people, the mountains and the ancient ruins of Mexico are documented in the current exhibition of sixty photographs by Mary Saint Albans in the Photographic Gallery of the Brooklyn Museum. The show is open daily through June 15.

It is difficult to understand how they could remember it clearly, for it is hardly distinguishable from many other graceful and amiable English country-house comedies.

SKIDMORE -- Anniversary Program As part of its twenty-fifth anniversary ceremonies Skidmore College will hold a four-day program beginning May 29 and dealing with the general theme "The College and Education for Citizenship." The Saratoga (N.Y.) women's institution is seeking a $2,000,000 fund for enlarging and improving its present facilities and for new equipment and additions to the salary budget.

BOSTON, May 17 -- Harvard avenged its 1-0 setback at the hands of Bob Wolcott last Saturday by defeating Princeton and its pitching ace, 4 -- 2, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at Soldiers' Field this afternoon.

THE Financial Branch of Canada's Postoffice Department in Ottawa has announced that it will no longer require collectors who order stamps by mail to pay registration from Ottawa. This has always been the policy of the Philatelic Agency, which the United States Postoffice Department operates at Washington. It is not, however, the policy of some foreign Governments.

HITHERTO, C.S. Lewis has waged his war against skepticism largely by hooks and broadcasts on religion. With the exception of short essays on the English syllabus and the idea of the English school, his published works have hardly touched theories of education.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The economic plight of Europe is not in any sense a new development. In fact, in the two years or more since V-E Day, Europe has waged an uphill economic battle against the devastation and dislocation inherited from the war.

Retail trade here was fairly active last week. Retailers reported increasing success in finding merchandise price lines meeting consumer response. Department store volume was estimated at from 7 to 10 per cent over the like week of last year.

WE become acutely conscious of the repetitions of history in times of great upheaval and momentous change. The historical sense is quickened, just as it becomes dulled in the placid intervals when men are wrapped in a feeling of security and life gives the illusion of being unalterable, forever as it is.

ROME, May 17 -- Italy this week was in the throes of the seventh Cabinet crisis since the liberation of June 4, 1944. The average life of an Italian Cabinet in the last three years has been, therefore, almost exactly five months.

To obtain capable employes, the foundry industry has started a $280,000 national educational program aimed at making employment in this field more attractive to young men, J.H. Lansing, secretary of the eastern section of the Malleable Founders' Society, revealed, following a recent closed meeting at the Commodore Hotel.

SINGAPORE, May 17 -- Relations between the Netherlands and the Indonesian Republic, as reflected in Indonesian broadcasts, communiques and private comments from both sides, appear to have deteriorated seriously in the seven weeks that have passed since the signing of the Cheribon Agreement in Batavia.

BOSTON, Mass., May 17 -- The Rev. Stephen H. Fritchman, who was suspended Tuesday as editor of The Christian Register, Unitarian monthly magazine, made public today material asserting that the difference over the editorship arose from "restriction" of his editorial freedom which was "beyond toleration."

INDIANAPOLIS, May 17 (AP) -- Ted Horn of Paterson, N.J., one of the most consistent money winners in Indianapolis Motor Speedway history, qualified today for the pole position in the 500-mile Memorial Day race by wheeling an 8-year-old Maserati four times around the two-and-a-half-mile track at an average speed of 126.564 miles an hour.

NO decision taken by the Seventy-ninth Congress met with such wide acclaim as passage of the Reorganization Act of 1946. "A great victory for better government," Robert M. La Follette, who co-sponsored the bill when he was in the Senate, called it. There is every evidence the American people thought so, too.

DISTRIBUTION executives have often been characterized as lagging behind production executives in adoption of scientific methods. The recent books emphasize fundamental changes taking place on the distribution front.
ROCK ISLAND, Ill., May 17 -- John W. Potter, editor and co-publisher of The Rock Island Argus, died today of a coronary thrombosis at his summer home near Minocqua, Wis. His age was 50.

LONDON, May 17 -- The House of Commons wound up a two-day debate on foreign affairs on Friday afternoon that a number of speakers had labeled "depressing." Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin, who both opened and closed the debate on behalf of the Labor Government, could not deny that allegation but he refused to give up hope.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The amount of food for world consumption this coming production year will be "little, if any, larger" than the supply for the past year, the Department of Agriculture predicted today.

Bacillary dysentery (also known as Shigellosis), like its cousins, typhoid and salmonella, is transmitted by means of a specific germ from the intestine of one person (or animal in the case of some salmonella infections) to the mouth of another. The conveyers are fingers and flies.

FOR the second time (the first was her "Crying at the Lock") Mrs. Rumsey has found artistic profit in her daily newspaper. The particular item which caught her attention in this instance told of an explosion in a community school of the sort that houses all a town's children from kindergarten through high school.

DANIEL started catering from a pigeonhole of a Manhattan apartment soon after he was released from the Army in August, 1944. Now, leas than three years after this unpretentious beginning, he's installed at 53 East Fiftyfourth Street, just a few doors east of the chic Monte Carlo, where a bright blue awning announces that Daniel not only offers catering services, but has a restaurant as well.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 17 -- The finest Harvard crew that Tom Bolles has boated won the varsity sprint championship of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges today on Lake Carnegie.
KANSAS CITY, May 17 (AP) -- President Truman took two of his secretaries. Charles G. Ross and Matthew J. Connelly, on the four-hour and forty-five minute flight to Grandview.

THE hotel-room situation in New York City continues to rival the spring weather for unpredictableness. A few weeks ago there were indication that the demand for rooms was easing off and coming into balance with the supply.
And American Aid Two bills translating the "Truman Doctrine" into the law of the land reached the final stages of the legislative process last week. They were:

BOOK publishing, as an art, a science, an industry, or as a fusion of the three, faces today the most consuming problem in its long history. The cost of manufacturing -- books has grone up -- and is still going up -- with unprecedented sharpness. What is the book publisher doing about this alarming cost rise? And what is its effect on the reader?

U.N. To Palestine Early next month at New York's La Guardia Field -- two and one-half miles away from the United Nations General Assembly Hall at Flushing Meadow -- a new chapter will open in the history of the U.N. A special U.N. investigation commission of about 120 persons will take off in chartered planes for a flight across the Atlantic.

BRUSSELS, May 17 -- A proposal for a new Constitution in Belgium has been filed with Parliament by French-speaking Walloons who seek to safeguard their interests against the fast-growing influence of the Flemish population.

To the Music Editor: Many of our contemporary writers could do well with a big dose of reader George Brewster's optimism. While I appreciate Mr. Brewster's strong belief in the survival of the True, the Good and the Beautiful (Puccini's "La Boheme" in this case), I find that whittling down the classics by our wham-bam experts tends to debase this music so that it loses a great amount of its fertile beauty.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Cancellation by the State Department of the showing of its collection of American modern art abroad has drawn strong protests from museums, art associations and individuals. The official policy, however, is not being changed for the present, it was said today.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Army, on the two issues of unification and universal military training which it considers most vital in its long-range plans, is fighting a battle against time.

PARIS, May 17 -- A warning that the general strike had not been abandoned as a weapon was given today by Eugene Henaff, Communist secretary of the powerful Federation of Trade Unions of the Paris region. He was addressing the congress of the organization.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Golf of every variety from par to peculiar was dished out today as the two-day national celebrities' golf tournament opened at the Columbia Country Club.

A ROLL of film is just that and nothing more to a great many amateurs, who look puzzled when they hear distinctions made between orthochromatic and panchromatic film. Actually the difference is considerable; it has to do largely with the quality of tone reproduction, in addition to other factors.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 17 -- The five Arab states that are members of the United Nations are being pressed by the Arab Higher Committee for Palestine, which is directed by the exiled Mufti of Jerusalem, Haj Amin el Husseini, to boycott the General Assembly's investigation of the Holy Land, it was indicated today.

THERE are certain outstanding pieces of theatre scholarship which are genuine labors of love. In this country we have all come to watch with affection Professor George Odell's slow progress through "The Annals of the New York Stage" and to cheer as each new volume emerges from the presses.
SEATTLE, May 17 (AP) -- Docks were being cleared for a mass flight of an army of laborers to Alaska late this month for a $51,000,000 job on the Array's air outposts.

A revolutionary reorganization of the nation's educational system that would eliminate summer vacations, establish college classes on a three-shift, fifty-two-week basis, and pay teacher a minimum annual salary of $3,000 was proposed last week at the ceremonies that saw Dr. George D. Stoddard installed as tenth president of the University of Illinois.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 17 -- Henry A. Wallace told an audience of University of Texas students tonight that he was convinced there should be no more war and no preparations for a third and final war.
Federal and city officials will join representatives of the shipping industry in the fourteenth annual observance of National Maritime Day on Thursday.

SALT LAKE CITY. RESIDENTS of this Utah capital city will soon be cast in a rather curious playgoing role. They will serve as audiences for eight scheduled Centennial presentations of "Macbeth" that Orson Welles will put on as auditions for his forthcoming movie version of the Shakespearean tragedy.

"NORTHERN FISHES," now in its second edition, is an authoritative, detailed text on the structure and classification of the fishes of Minnesota and the environs. This revision, with excellent color plates, has corrected various technical errors and obscure passages, has rearranged and expanded the prefatory material.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Secretary of State Marshall declared tonight that agreement on the charter of the International Trade Organization "will mark a great step toward economic stability and the common security."

EDWARD JOHNSON was in town last week to receive one of the medals to the National Institute of Social Sciences. Before rejoining the company for the last few days of the tour, he took time out to relate a few of the things that happened to the Metropolitan Opera in Texas.

-- SHADES DOWN Any civilized community is bound to have its opinion of people who keep the blinds pulled down all the time. The practice may not mean a thing. Still, it suggests shady doings -- counterfeiting, gambling and worse -- and, besides, it is anti-social, for it makes the whole neighborhood nervous.

Roosevelt Raceway will open its eighth season of harness racing next Friday night. With the Old Country Trotting Association and the Nassau Trotting Association each holding two meetings alternately, there will be 125 nights of racing in all before the season ends on Oct. 18.

"VERMILION" is the most ambitious of Idwal Jones' several novels. Laid in California, with excursions into Wales and Spain and China, and opening at a period when California was still a Mexican possession, it follows the fortunes of one family, the Copes, through three generations.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Regardess of whether it's midwifery or dynamiting or any of unnumbered hundreds of other trades, skills and professions, the Veterans Administration will get instruction for you -- if you're a veteran.

TOURISM, a ten-billion dollar industry employing two and a half million workers in this country alone, received official Senatorial recognition last week as a vital factor in international trade. Senator Owen Brewster, Maine Republican, in announcing his proposal to establish a Foreign Trade Bureau, accepted the travel industry's own definition of world travel as an "invisible export."

IN Battery Park and in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn New Yorkers look with some wonderment at miniature jungles of derricks, piling, steel beams, cast-iron segments, lumber, bulldozers and shanties. To ferry riders and thousands of other passers-by the two projects may seem a confused jumble.

A NOTE on the fly-leaf of "Comrade Forest" tells us that this novel "is based on fact, on the story of the heroic Soviet woman guerrilla-fighter, Liza Ivanovna Chaikina." Its author is an Irish writer whose work is appearing for the first time in America, and not, one hopes, for the last time.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 17 -- The prosecution's case against thirty-one white men on trial here for the lynching of a Negro was completed at 11:35 A.M. today after a week of testimony unprecedented in the history of the South.
LONDON, May 17 -- The death was announced today of Sir Thomas Henry Holland, a leading geologist and mineralogist. His age was 78.

LONDON, May 17 -- Greece must use part of the money advanced to her by the United States to make herself secure against aggression, Premier Maximos said today. He made the following principal points in the interview:

WILD flowers hold special enchantments every month from April to November for those who delight in them and seek where they grow in order to admire and learn their ways of life. This pursuit is more than absorbing and is rewarding in many ways.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 17 -- Jack Lyons, 23-year-old Garden City Golf Club member whose ambition is to become one of the country's top ranking amateurs, made a move in that direction today by winning the famous old club's thirty-seventh annual invitation tournament for the second year in succession.

THE calendar of many metropolitan photographers -- amateur and professional -- features the annual flowering of the cherry blossoms in Brooklyn Botanic Garden at Eastern Parkway and Washington Avenue, which should be at its height this week-end.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, believes "we can overcome those difficulties" which handicap peace, and that in both Russia and the United States "there is too much talk about war and too little talk about peace."
New York s big stamp show, the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition, got off to an impressive start in the Grand Central Palace yesterday.

THE announcement by Western railroads of increased rail fares to the Pacific Coast, effective June 1, has resulted in a rush of ticket-buying by prospective transcontinental travelers. Tickets are good for three months and may be used on any dates within that period.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The $350,000,000 fund agreed to by Congressional conferees may complete the foreign relief program in the present session, it was indicated today. The source of this information was Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican of Michigan and chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations.

Will It Be Vetoed? In a drab committee room in the Capitol, with big windows looking out upon the Mall and Washington Monument, ten men met behind closed doors last Thursday. Their job was to work out final details on the most important domestic issue yet placed before the Eightieth Congress.
SPRING can boast no flowering tree lovelier than the native white dogwood that appears in May. Admired in the wild, it is also a favorite small tree for home grounds planting.

TIMED to impose critical order on an age of literary chaos, "Forces in Modern British Literature" is brilliantly successful. William York Tindall, associate Professor of English at Columbia and author of "D.H. Lawrence and Susan His Cow," discusses modern writers in terms of the "forces" which dominate them: "The Troughs of Zolaism" (realism), "The Hunt for a Father" (religion), "The Forest of Symbolism," "The Stream of Consciousness," and six others.

By the end of this week the lofty rooms and halls of the old Murray Hill Hotel, crammed with an astonishing variety of furnishings and equipment, will be denuded. The contents of the landmark's 400 rooms are going under the hammer at 10:30 A.M. each day, beginning Tuesday.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 17 In a simple yet moving ceremony attended by specially invited educators, Miss Charl Ormond Williams, director of field service for the National Education Association, today presented a series of mementos and correspondence to the Franklin D. Roosevelt library.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, asserted today that the Republican party was combating the high cost of living "on two fronts" by seeking to reduce Federal expenditures and increasing production through its proposed labor legislation.

SEOUL, Korea, May 17 -- This coming week discussions of the joint United States-Soviet Commission on Korea are scheduled to get under way. Resuming the conferences broken off one year ago, representatives of the United States and Russia will attempt again to lay the groundwork for the establishment of an independent democratic Government for all of Korea.

The failure of family agenies to make educational use of heir knowledge about marital relationships by conducting premarital courses for young people was criticized yesterday by Dr. Luther E. Woodward, field consultant of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene.

YELLOWSTONE PARK -- Snowplow crews are succeeding in their efforts to open Yellowstone Park entrances and highways in advance of the official opening on Tuesday of this, the country's oldest national park. Unseasonably warm weather and heavy spring rains are assisting them in bucking the drifts.

Hungry Continent Europe is hungry. In no European country does the average citizen's diet reach 3,000 calories -- the amount according to doctors, necesary for a worker to maintain good health. In Britain, a victor nation, the average caloric intake is 2,300.
In the face of an unprecedented housing shortage, more than 2,200 so-called veterans' homes stand completed but empty and unsold in the New York area.

LEONARD DUBKIN was a city boy who wanted to be a naturalist. Instead, he grew up and went to work on a newspaper, was fired because he was more interested in squirrels than in a murderer. So he set out half-heartedly to find another job, and meanwhile He spent most of his days watching the world of nature as he found it in the Chicago streets and parks.

Richard Budd, the leather worker, smiled. "How's that? That's somethin', huh?" As he spoke he cut away with a long knife on a raw piece of leather, made a few twists, and lifted up to his audience a handsome leather belt.

THE announcement by Western railroads of increased rail fares to the Pacific Coast, effective June 1, has resulted in a rush of ticket-buying by prospective transcontinental travelers. Tickets are good for three months and may be used on any dates within that period.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The $350,000,000 fund agreed to by Congressional conferees may complete the foreign relief program in the present session, it was indicated today. The source of this information was Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican of Michigan and chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations.

So he set out half-heartedly to find another job, and meanwhile He spent most of his days watching the world of nature as he found it in the Chicago streets and parks.

Richard Budd, the leather worker, smiled. "How's that? That's somethin', huh?" As he spoke he cut away with a long knife on a raw piece of leather, made a few twists, and lifted up to his audience a handsome leather belt.

STATISTICS -- The average American housewife washes approximately six tons, or 12,000 pounds, of dishes every year, according to a report of the Kansas State College. * * * The time required to milk a cow by machine is threefourths of that necessary for hand-milking.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 17 -- Another record pre-championship turnout featured the regatta today at the Larchraont Yacht Club. Forty-nine craft crossed the starting line and all but two finished.

LILIES are the aristocrats of the garden. They offer an endless variety of shapes, habits, sizes, colors and flowering seasons. The gardener who selects them carefully can have not only a succession of bloom from late spring until frost but also a parade that shifts and changes from day to day and that enriches the whole garden picture.

TLAJUANA, Mexico -- Freshwater fishermen of Southern California who have discovered Lake Rodriguez, the anglers' paradise on the other side of the border nine and one-half miles south of Tiajuana and about 160 miles from Los Angeles, are returning with reports of catches that range from twenty to thirty fish a day in off-season months to sixty fish a day during the summer.

To the Drama Editor: TO take statements out of context and weave a logical rebuttal based on a false premise is a cute, sometimes effective, but time-worn and shabby trick. I refer to the unfair comments made by Claire Leonard and Carl Cowl re Richard Aldrich's "confessional."

THE man who pauses in Mr. Beck's war novel is a young bombardier spending a three-day leave with his girl in the period just before D-day. The sky under which he pauses is the blue sky of his air training, the sky in which he may find death in the next few months.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations declared in a statement today that a concerted effort was being made "to persuade the public that the Senate has passed a mild [labor] bill and the House a harsh one.
Mayor O'Dwyer and Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander will speak at ceremonies at 5 P.M. today in Columbus Circle opening the headquarters of the Damon Runyon Memorial Fund for Cancer Research.

Marshall's Men The Department of State, with 18,500 employes at home and abroad, is a complex organization whose effectiveness in handling foreign problems depends upon close teamwork. Heading the organization, which is now in process of moving into a new building formerly occupied by the War Department, is the Secretary of State.

During the coming week most of those fancy-looking, shiny polished outboard runabouts that will be encountered, on trailers behind autos, on a good many Eastern highways will be converging on Albany. Courageous and ambitious lads -- and probably an occasional girl pilot -- from New England, the Midwest and the South have set their minds on entering and winning one of sportsdom's most grueling efforts.
A major alteration project is being carried out under unusual conditions in the thirteen-story apartment house at 470 Park Avenue, southwest corner of Fiftyeighth Street.

NEVER before has psychoanalysis been so much a matter of general discussion. Movies, the stage, magazines and books have explored the subject widely; the use of its principles among the military for treatment of battle neuroses extended the public's acquaintance with it.

IF you were choosing the worker who had delved most widely and effectively into the elements of American theatrical presentation, you might hestitate between two men, both at the University of North Carolina: Paul Green and Samuel Selden.

The Rev. Dr. John Howard Johnson, rector of St. Martin's Episcopal Church, Lenox Avenue and 122d Street, a Negro congregation, has been elected a trustee of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. It is the first time since the cathedral was chartered more than half a century ago that a Negro has been named to its board of trustees.

People born and raised in America are bigger than recent immigrants of the same racial stock because of an "environmental growth factor" discovered by comparing the measurements of the two groups. Those measurements which are greater in the American-born are all highly correlated and hence can be accounted for by a single factor which seems to be related to environment and especially to changes in diet.

A CONGLOMERATE sort of week makes grouping not too easy as one attempts to sort the returns. There were several "primitives," however, who will be considered in juxtaposition when we come to them. And modernists, as usual, peppered the panorama.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Throughout the agitated discussions on labor problems, spokesmen for both labor and industry have summarily dismissed the principle of compulsory arbitration even in essential industries, despite the knowledge that major work stoppages threaten paralysis of the entire national economy.
WARSAW, May 17 -- Britain advanced to the third round of Davis Cup play in the European zone today by splitting the last two

WILLIAM T. MANNING, for twenty-five years Protestant Episcopal Bishop of the Diocese of New York, is, like his first American predecessor, Samuel Seabury, a "strong, simple, conciliatory, uncompromising man." He is conciliatory because he is Bishop of a Church which -- "between the differences on either side," Protestant and Catholic -- "it has pleased God to set * * * in the middle place"; and he is uncompromising in his defense of this "bridge church."

OTTAWA, May 17 -- Out of development of Canada's national sovereignty and Canada's membership in the United Nations, there has developed a situation that has led to the appointment of a joint committee of both Houses of Parliament to consider just where this country stands in the matter of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

American business vitally needs a clear-cut statement by Government of its plans to meet domestic and world difficulties and should get it as soon as possible, Joseph P. Kennedy, former Ambassador to Great Britain, declared in an interview here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The United States is going into Greece in a big way to administer the aid provided in the $400,000,000 fund voted by Congress for both Greece and Turkey. The program for Turkey will be on a quite secondary scale.

Laughter AS we weep only when we are afflicted, and laugh only when we are gay, it has been reasoned that laughter springs from a feeling of superiority. It is true that man, a risible animal, is also a proud one; but pride does not produce laughter.

JUDGES and prosecutors in many sections of the country are going back to classrooms to study problems created by increasing complexities of traffic movements and the record-breaking volume of motor travel. These courses were undertaken in response to a widespread interest among those who preside in the traffic courts, and others who deal in the punishment of offenders, in extending their knowledge of law enforcement procedure.

JUDGES and prosecutors in many sections of the country are going back to classrooms to study problems created by increasing complexities of traffic movements and the record-breaking volume of motor travel. These courses were undertaken in response to a widespread interest among those who preside in the traffic courts, and others who deal in the punishment of offenders, in extending their knowledge of law enforcement procedure.

NANKING, May 17 -- Feuding between the cliques within the Kuomintang, the Government party, is regarded by observers here as a background cause of the wave of student agitation that is sweeping the country.

All signs indicate the textile and apparel trades will not be able to maintain sales at the high levels of the last few years, according to a survey of advertising and promotion expenditures last week.

Under the direction of General Omar Bradley the Veterans' Administration has been thoroughly reformed. Because of a vast improvement in medical care more than 685,000 patients have been discharged in the past twenty months -- a showing that would be even better if needs were fully met.

CHICAGO, May 17 (AP) -- Grains moved ahead in a strong and active market on the Board of Trade today aided by unfavorable weather for seeding feed grains, unconfirmed rumors that corn may be shipped abroad for livestock feeding and reports that a drought in southeast Europe was intensifying.
In New York Drs. Theodor Rosebury and Elvin A. Kabat announced, simultaneously with Dr. Visscher in Chicago, the report on all that was known about the potentialities of bacterial warfare up to 1942.

Two hundred and fifty Knights Templar, figurative descendants of the Christian soldiers who guarded the pilgrims to the Holy Land in the twelfth century, held a parade yesterday afternoon and then attended their twentieth annual service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

BUENOS AIRES, May 17 (Delayed) -- A Government decree today authorized the unloading of berthed ships directly to trucks placed alongside, as a step toward relieving the serious port congestion prevailing here.
LONDON, May 18 -- The stock markets here maintain a strength that is as impressive as it is welcome, with industrial equities still holding the center of the stage.

To Memory Dear A group of elderly gentlemen, we are told, found themselves discussing art. In all of them a liberal education of the old -fashioned sort had been fortified -- or tempered -- by travel in foreign parts and dutiful inspection of art galleries at home and abroad.

Engineers Public Service Company announced yesterday that as the result of an opinion by Federal Judge Paul Leahy of the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., on Thursday that holders of the company's preferred stocks are entitled only to $100 a share and accrued dividends, rather than a premium, it will seek a court order enforcing its plan for dissolution early this week.

New Yorkers thronged Central Park Mall yesterday afternoon to reaffirm publicly their allegiance and devotion to the United States at the seventh annual city-sponsored I Am an American Day celebration. They stood to repeat the pledge of allegiance, heard Mayor O'Dwyer and other speakers emphasize the privilege of being an American, and were entertained for three hours by stars of radio, screen-and stage.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (U.P.) -- A long-standing "discrimination" against thousands of Federal prisoners will be wiped out soon in a move expected to improve the morale of many inmates.
PITTSBURGH, May 18 -- The volume of steel orders here last week continued strong and in most cases was equal to shipments, although here and there further headway had been made in reducing backlogs.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- Publication of a technically detailed, 40,000word report on bacterial warfare, a weapon bracketed by the United Nations with the atomic bomb as "adaptable to mass destruction," was announced here today.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 18 (U.P.) -- Golfdom's little icicle -- Ben Hogan -- stroked his way to the $3,000 top money in the Colonial National invitation tournament today with a one-under-par 279 -- the same score with which he won the event last year.

Midseason offerings, although being bought cautiously and in small quantities by stores last week, were being reordered promptly, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

LONDON, May 18 (AP) -- Thomas Mann, celebrated German - born writer, who is revisting Europe for the first time since 1939, asserted today that "Germany is again already misusing her liberty and democracy." Self-pity, he said, has led Germany to fail in cooperation with the Allies.

LONDON, May 18 -- Pleas for higher production and warnings against industrial strife are the keynotes of a statement issued today by the Labor party's national executive committee. It will be presented at the party's annual conference opening in Margate on May 26.

Bob Feller has enjoyed better days than the one he had against the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium, but even a lukewarm Feller, who needed ninth-inning relief, was good enough to beat the New Yorkers, 5 -- 3. Blazing his way out of trouble in the sixth, Feller, with the help of Steve Gromek, pitched the Indians into third place, changing positions with the Yankees.

when the British Labor party took over the helm of Government many observers here found it difficult to understand just why its program of nationalizing industry was expected to meet that country's central problem of production more effectively than it had been met under the traditional profit system.

A uniform policy on wages, security and services covering employes of private communal and welfare organizations was proposed yesterday by Local 19, Social Service Employes Union, United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO.

By October of 1942, the pressure of planning Torch Operation had become so great that all of us at Norfolk House [in London] were literally working day and night. We quit for sleep only when fatigue made further accurate work impossible. I finally told the staff that on Sundays, at least everyone should stay away from the office until 10 A.M.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP) -- The Athletics swept a doubleheader from the Browns today. They took the second game, 5 -- 2, by scoring three unearned runs on two St. Louis errors after Sam Chapman knotted the first game with a ninth-inning homer and Denny Galehouse issued a base on balls with the bases filled, to give Philadelphia a 4-3 victory before 12,341.

LAHORE, Punjab, India, May 18 (AP) -- Thousands of persons fled from Lahore, Provincial capital of the Punjab, today, seeking to escape bomb and brickbat fights between Hindu, Moslem and Sikh mobs, which have caused at least fifteen deaths.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 17 (Delayed) -- A German black-market operator went into a village in the Bavarian backwoods last night and obtained 620 pounds of food-potatoes, flour, bacon, ham, lard, eggs and sausage -- in less than two hours.

TEXAS CITY, Tex., May 18 (AP) -- Fire of undetermined origin aboard the gasoline-laden tanker Pan - Massachusetts was extinguished this afternoon after it had heavily damaged the tanker, a tug and a dock.
NANKING, May 18 (AP) -- The increasing Communist offensive in Manchuria forced the declaration of martial law tonight in Changchun, the threatened capital.

JERUSALEM, May 18 -- Palestine's underground fighting forces have agreed not to suspend operations while the Palestine problem is under consideration by the United Nations unless British forces also refrain from action. They are asking the United Nations to take steps to assure that Britain complies with the General Assembly's appeal for an interim peace in the Holy Land.
Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman received last night the 1947 gold medal of the Williamsburg Settlement for services in behalf of the underprivileged in this city and the needy throughout the world.

MONTREAL, May 18 -- With the world's air traffic estimated at close to $400,000,000 in freight and passenger fares this year, Sir William Hildred, Director General of the International Air Transport Association, announced at its headquarters here today that the forty to fifty airlines now members or about to join IATA, will divide the world into three instead of nine rate conference areas.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., May 18 (AP) -- Jersey City and Newark divided a doubleheader before 11,251 today, the Little Giants coming back to take the nightcap, 4 -- 3, after the Bears had won a free hitting affair in the opener, 15 -- 8.

One of New York's largest realty concerns yesterday announced acceptance of the much - disputed apartment - house television antenna plan of the Television Broadcasters Association. A month ago the plan was rejected as "inadequate" by the owners of 700 multiple dwellings in this area.

Using baseball terminology to describe the need for the rebuilding of St. Barnabas House, the six-story mission at 306 Mulberry Street, Walter L. (Red) Barber, sports broadcaster, yesterday addressed the congregation of Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.
New York has failed so far "to tackle its parking problem with any kind of boldness," whereas towns and cities in the suburbs are "acting boldly," the Regional Plan Association declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Women's Bureau today offered the 1947 college girl eight pages of job advice.

SEOUL, Korea, May 18 -- On the eve of the reconvening of the joint American-Soviet commission on Tuesday, Rightist forces, led by Dr. Syngman Rhee, continued today steadfastly to refuse to accept the trusteeship clause in the Moscow decision of the Foreign Ministers.

ALBANY, May 18 -- The State Tax Commission, headed by Alger B. Chapman, gave full credit today to Governor Dewey's taxreduction policy, in its annual report for the fiscal year 1947, as having saved taxpayers the sum of $165,500,000.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, May 18 (AP) -- A Navy pilot and two schoolboys were killed and six young people seriously injured today when a fighter plane went out of control at an air show and crashed on a school playground.

Week Ended May 16, 1947 It was more the show of quiet strength of the Canadian free dollar rather than the size of its gain which drew the interest of traders in the foreign exchange market last week.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 18 -- This is another story about Champion Twin Ponds Belle. The great Welsh terrier owned by Mrs. Edward P. Alker of Great Neck got best in show again today, taking top prize in the annual dog show of the Long Island Kennel Club.

Henry de Forest Baldwin, who died yesterday in his eighty-fifth year, had been a notable figure in this town since the beginning of this century when he became active in the reform movements which played a great part in that era. From that time on, though he never held conspicuous public office, he was closely associated with the men and the causes which have meant most to the city and the country.

The plunge of the dismantled Oklahoma into the ocean deeps marks the last ripple from the churned and bloody waters of Pearl Harbor. If it was a kind of second death for the old battleship it was at least free from the cruel slaughter that darkened her first.

AMSTERDAM, May 18 -- "Allaround economies, quieter investment rates and thorough revision of priorities are necessary for overcoming Dutch difficulties," Dr. Hendrik F. van Leeuwen, senior manager of the Twentsche Bank, said to this correspondent in an interview last week.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 18 -- In response to Russian objections, the United States plans to stress in the Security Council the temporary status of the United Nations subsidiary investigatory group in the Balkans, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- With a net profit of $21,600,000 to show for last year, the Federal Home Owners Loan Corporation predicted today that its ultimate liquidation would be accomplished with a profit instead of a loss to the Government.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- Trading in May grain contracts will cease at the close of business on Tuesday, and brokers on the Board of Trade are making no predictions as to the likely trend of the market during the next two days because of evidence of congestion in May wheat, corn and oats, due to limited stocks of the actual grain available for delivery.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, May 17 (delayed) -- The Communist party here makes one reservation in its suport of the Moroccan movement for national independence, it was learned today.
ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Fiscal Commission will convene at 11 A.M. and will continue throughout the week (open).

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday he would name a special commission to prepare plans for the city's Golden Jubilee in 1948, commemorating Greater New York's fifty years of existence under the consolidation charter that became effective Jan. 1, 1898.

The countries of the world are beginning one by one to open their doors "a chink" to displaced Jews of Europe, Samuel A. Telsey, president of the Hebrew Sheitering and Immigrant Aid Society, worldwide immigration agency, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- All deliveries of lard futures sold at new seasonal low prices last week on the Board of Trade as the result of liquidation by commission houses and pressure of packer hedging sales. Steadily accumulating stocks combined with a slow domestic and export demand were a factor.

BERLIN, May 18 (AP) -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay disclosed today he had launched an extensive campaign to tell hungry Germans the "story" of American efforts to provide them with food. One motive, he said, was to counteract the Communist propaganda that stresses the food shortages in the Western zones.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I would like to associate myself wit the large and increasing number o fair-minded Americans who questio the justice and the advisability of the ratification of the Italian treaty.

Elpidio Quirino, vice president of the Philippine Republic; Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, permanent Philippine delegate to the United Nations; members of their families and a group of uniformed military aides attended solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.
