WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The two top women organizers of the two major political parties, both back from extended stirringsaround in the states, are convinced that women never before have taken such a long-range and widespread interest in an election as now is evident on 1948.

ZURICH, Switzerland, May 18 -- Another stride toward normal financial relations between the United States and Switzerland was taken last week. The National Bank of Switzerland announced that as from May 15 travelers from countries of the dollar group would be permitted to convert up to $200 into Swiss francs each week, instead of $125 as heretofore.

Commercial banks throughout the country made greater use of newspaper space for their advertising during 1946 than they did in the previous year, according to a study released for publication today by the Financial Advertisers Association.

Approval of several large refunding operations at lower rate by utility companies in this state was one of the major accomplishments of the Public Service Commission last year, it was disclosed yesterday in a section of the annual report of that body for 1946.

All the grandiose plans announced by Mike Todd have simmered down so far to a repeat engagement of his successful musical, "Up in Central Park." Locally, Mr. Todd hasn't seed fit to do anything since he deposited "January Thaw" in February, 1946.

An improved course in speech to meet the demand of business leaders for workers with a "pleasant" manner has been introduced in the city's twenty-seven vocational high schools, it was announced yesterday by George F. Pigott Jr., Associate Superintendent in charge of that division.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 18 -- Groping around in fog that followed the rain this afternoon, the early-out Long Island Sound racing craft nosed their way through the sightless going and made back late to the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Art events here this week will include the annual ceremonies at the American Academy of Arts and Letters on Thursday, with the exhibition of work by newly-elected members and recipients of awards opening to the public on Saturday.

PARIS, May 18 -- A free economy must await the revival of the French trade balance, Premier Paul Ramadier declared today, adding that the nation must reduce its imports and produce all the food and clothing it required.
The annual spring book drive of the American Merchant Marine Library Association will be opened at noon today at a fully-equipped lifeboat beneath the Atlas statue in Rockefeller Center.

The third annual Festival of Contemporary American Music closed yesterday afternoon at McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, with a concert of chamber works performed by the Fivewind Ensemble. This recently formed group of accomplished young artists, which made its first public appearance, could be wholeheartedly praised, but the compositions they presented were largely of an inconsequential nature.

LONDON, May 18 -- A big effort was made in April to regain as far as possible the ground lost in British steel production during the fuel crisis. This, however, was achieved only by drawing upon stocks of steel-making materials, and further recovery can be maintained only if fuel supplies improve.

KANSAS CITY, May 18 -- President Truman postponed his return to Washington indefinitely tonight in view of the health of his mother, Mrs. Martha E. Truman. Attending doctors described her condition as grave.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 18 -- A delegation of Helsinki Municipal Councilors has just canceled a projected visit to Moscow. This cancellation, following last Thursday's bomb throwing at the Soviet legation here, is held to be an indication of worsening Russo-Finnish relations.

ALBANY, May 18 -- Infant and maternal mortality established new low records in March and the first quarter of this year, the State Health Department reported today in pointing out favorable aspects of health conditions in general.

JAMESTOWN, R.I., May 18 -- In a field laboratory at the Navy's radar station at the tip of Beavertail Point here scientists from Johns Hopkins University are working on the problem of how to keep machines from getting ahead of mankind.
NANKING, May 18 -- The spreading student strikes and demonstrations provoked a series of emergency State Council regulations and an admonition from President Chiang Kai-shek today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Jesse H. Jones, former chairman of the Reconnstruction Finance Corporation, a statement today, denounced the "many untruths [which] have been purposely publicized" about an $80,000,000 loan made by the RFC to the Baltimore Ohio Railroad.

FORT KNOX, Ky., May 18 -- The tank, an instrument of victory in World War II, is here to stay even in the atomic age in the opinion of many tank experts here at Fort Knox, birthplace of our modern armored forces.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- The largest crowd in the recent history of Wrigley Field, 46,572 paid, today had the very doubtful pleasure of seeing the Cubs lose their fifth straight game as the Dodgers came from behind to beat the Bruins, 4 -- 2.
CAIRO, May 18 (Reuters) -- Nokrashy Pasha said today that Egypt could not accept continuation of the original 1936 treaty with Britain. Attempts to negotiate a revision of the pact have failed.
UKIAH, Calif., May 18 (U.P.) -- Seabiscuit, one-time leading winner of the American turf, died of a heart attack last midnight, owner Charles S. Howard announced today.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,101,121,447. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of Indebtedness, bill and notes as follows:

B.W. Dyer Co., sugar economists and brokers, offered yesterday to wager $5,000 against the correctness of a recent "fantastic" prediction by John L. Hennessy, chairman of the board of the Hotels Statler Company and food consultant to Secretary of War Patterson, that, if sugar is decontrolled, prices will rise to 25 to 30 cents a pound within two months after such action is taken.

Thousands of unused truck cargo bodies, locomotives, steam specialties, aircraft instruments, hospital, laboratory and surgical supplies, graphite, abrasives and other items are among surplus sealed bid offerings in the current sales program of the War Assets Administration New York office, announced over the week-end by Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director.

ALBANY, May 18 -- More than a fourth of the annual operating budget of New York State is now devoted to caring for the mentally ill, according to a report by Dr. Frederick MacCurdy, Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, made public here today.

BADEN, Germany, May 18 -- Listlessness on the part of the voting public characterized the State elections today in the French zone of occupation. It was attributed by French officials to the nonpolitical habits of the population here.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 18 (AP) -- Russell Snowberger, veteran Detroit driver, qualified today for his sixteenth 500 mile Memorial Day race and incidentally saved the Indianapolis Motor Speedway management about $20,000.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Two-run rallies in the ninth innings of both games enabled the White Sox to sweep a double-header from Washington, 4 -- 2 and 3 -- 2, here today before a crowd of 22,036.

GREIFSWALD, Germany, May 16 (Delayed) -- While the Germans in the American and British zones of Germany are being accused of failing to appreciate the tremendous amounts of food being imported for their benefit, such is not the case in the Soviet zone.

CORNWALL - ON - HUDSON, N.Y., May 18 -- Russell Stewart's stalwart bay gelding, My Play Boy, won the open jumping championship in the second annual New York Military Academy horse show held at the school today, defeating Hutchinson Farms' Peg's Pride, a strong contender for the honors throughout the competition.

BRUSSELS, May 18 (ANETA) -- The Belgian Line (Compagnie Maritime Belge S.A.) will pay a 120-franc (about $2.74) tentative dividend for 1946 on each share of its stock, it was announced at the general stockholders meeting last week.

Unless the United Nations organization is effectively supported by the member nations, with each giving up a small part of its sovereignty, the United Nations cannot work, Herbert H. Lehman declared here yesterday. The former Governor of New York and former director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration was the principal speaker at a gathering of 300 persons at the New School for Social Research.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The division between the Administration and the Republican majority on income tax reduction may be widened tomorrow when John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, testifies before the Ways and Means Committee.

PITTSBURGH, May 18 -- The Giants' gay dash through the West came momentarily to a halt today as Billy Herman's Pirates, amid the thunderous cheers of 32,996 onlookers, ambushed the Polo Grounders in the opener of the afternoon's double-header with a pair of nerve-tingling, late inning rallies.

After four consecutive victories each, the Marshall Seniors and Marshall Juniors met in the fifth and final round for the championship of the B division in the Metropolitan Chess League on seven boards yesterday.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 18 (UP) -- Carefree and confident, America's triumphant Walker Cup golf team prepared today to move on to Carnoustie, Scotland, where it will seek additional international honors in the British amateur tournament next week.

Former Postmaster General James A. Farley declared yesterday that Russia was responsible for holding up the peace in a still-troubled world and that "we are almost as far away" from its establishment as when the war ended two years ago.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy presided yesterday afternoon at the annual rally of the Holy Name Societies of the Brooklyn Catholic Diocese at Ebbets Field where 70,000 marchers gathered to honor him on the twenty-fifth anniversary of his installation as Bishop of Brooklyn.

Mrs. Giacinta Sardi (Cinta for short) was out in the kitchen making ravioli when we stopped by one morning at her son's new little restaurant at 313 West Forty-sixth Street. Her quick, nowaste-motion fingers showed she is no cook's apprentice (she has been cooking since she was 11 years old, she told us later).

PITTSBURGH, May 18 -- The executive board of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, may decide this week on a clearcut policy for a wage increase in the fabricating industry. The board will begin sessions tomorrow in Atlantic City.

The Rev. Dr. G. Bromley Oxnam, Bishop of the New York Methodist Area, reiterated yesterday his plea for "all the churches of Christ upon the earth" to unite. He spoke at a service in the Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, Hanson Place and St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, attended by 650 persons.

The Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Congregational, at Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, celebrated its centennial yesterday at a morning service. The Rev. Dr. L. Wendell Fifield, pastor, preached the sermon.

Weakness in spots and near-by futures and relative steadiness in the more distant positions featured the domestic cotton market last week. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net changes ranging from a decline of 62 points to an advance of 39 points.

The negotiating group of the Committee for the Steamship Companies and Operators on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts is studying an outline of the demands of the National Maritime Union, CIO, for a new contract, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Lieut. Comdr. Edward Neal Little of Monrovia, Calif., a hero of Bataan and Corregidor is on trial at the naval gun factory here, it was learned tonight. The charges are that he cultivated the favor of Japanese captors and thus brought about the deaths of two American naval enlisted men and caused others to receive brutal treatment.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Republican leaders in the House expressed strong disagreement today with proposals for implementing President Truman's loyalty program, indicating they believed his request for $24,900,000 to carry it out was excessive and might be cut sharply.

MOSCOW. May 18 -- Liquidation of the United Nations is planned by "aggressive monopolist circles" in the United States because the organization opposes aggression, it is asserted today by E. Zhukov, writing in Pravda, official newspaper of the Communist party.
Seventy-six streamlined redand-cream buses replaced sixtyeight trolley cars yesterday along Third Avenue.

The war record of men and women of jewish faith who served in the armed forces was praised by President Truman in a message read yesterday afternoon at the fifty-second annual memorial services of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, held in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth street.

TOKYO, May 18 -- Those responsible for Japan's finances appear to have maneuvered the country into a money market deadlock. Heroic escape measures are indicated and financial circles naturally are curious to learn which course the Japanese experts and occupation officials who guide them will choose.

LONDON, May 18 (U.P.) -- A Foreign Office source said yesterday that Britain had handed Russia a second draft, for revision, of their twenty-year Treaty of Alliance, signed during the war. The British had submitted a first draft when discussions on the revision first started, but the Russians had objected to some British suggestions.

BADEN, Germany, May 18 (AP) -- Incomplete returns from elections today in three States of the French occupation zone of Germany indicated tonight that the States had adopted overwhelmingly new Constitutions permitting a modified form of socialism.

Now that hand-painted tiles have entered the home in so many forms, artists are decorating them for serving accessories or with scenes significant to the owners. Illustrations of a favorite book, the family homestead or motifs depicting hobbies are suggested by Ruth Norman, artist, for tile insets in large trays, table-tops or fireplaces.
One hundred and nine athletic insignia in five winter sports have been awarded by Columbia University for the 1946-47 season, Ralph Furey, director of athletics, announced yesterday.

Ballet Society last night presented the fourth and final subscription program of its season, this time at the Ziegfeld Theatre. The bill contained two premieres: "The Seasons," choreographed by Merce Cunningham to music of John Cage, with scenery and costumes by Isamu Noguchi, and "Blackface," choreographed by Lew Christensen to music of Carter Harman, with scenery and costumes by Robert Drew.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with dismay the "point with pride" letter of Dr. McCurdy, Commissioner of the Department of Mental Hygiene, in your issue of May 7. Dr. McCurdy was well aware that my letter published on April 28 represents the point of view of the relatives of patients in the state hospitals whose organization I head.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The role of education in helping toward a solution of labor-management problems is receiving increasing emphasis.

DR. JULIUS E. LIPS says that he wrote his book, "The Origin of Things,"* because he got tired of always being asked at dinner and cocktail parties to "tell me everything about anthropology." If he hasn't told everything about it in his book, he has at least told as much as any layman could comfortably digest. The result is a book packed tightly with curious information that you never knew before.

Nine former Great Lakes freighters, taken over by the Army during the war and converted for ocean use, have been purchased from the Maritime Commission by the Overtakes Freighting Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Capt. Dennis A. Moloney, a director of the company.
NEW DELHI, India, May 18 (London Times Dispatch) -- The Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten, accompanied by Lady Mountbatten and members of his staff, left by air this morning for London.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Negotiators settled an important part of the Western Electric strike this afternoon when the company and the union, representing 22,000 production workers at the plant in Kearny, N.J., agreed here to a contract providing an average wage increase of 11 1/2 cents an hour.

When an idea for the rehabilitation of maladjusted youth is good enough to be copied by our occupation forces abroad, to re-educate and re-orient the young men and women of former enemy countries, it should certainly be worth encouraging and expanding in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Secretary of State Marshall's new policy-planning staff will be called upon shortly to re-examine world economic conditions to determine what the long-range United States policy should be.

"Big Six" -- officially known as Typographical Union No. 6 -- paid tribute yesterday to twenty-one printers killed in the last war. A memorial ceremony in which a plaque bearing their names was dedicated was held at the Manhattan Center.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 18 -- A final design for the United Nations headquarters along the East River in midtown Manhattan will be made public Wednesday by Wallace K. Harrison, chief planning officer, it was learned today.

CINCINNATI, May 18 (AP) -- Red Barrett pitched five-hit ball today to give the Braves a 3-1 victory in the nightcap of a double-header after they had lost the opener to the Reds, 2 -- 1. The victory, Barrett's first of the season, enabled the Braves to retain top position in the National League.

In a radio broadcast yesterday in which he extolled the virtues of fishing, Herbert Hoover declared that most Presidents had adopted the sport because there were but two occasions when Americans respected privacy -- praying and fishing.

Valuable original documents dealing with the early history of this city are in the $10,000 collection received by the New York Public Library from the estate of Gabriel Wells, which will go on exhibition in the main lobby today.

OLYMPIA, Wash., May 18 -- Charles R. Savage, 41, an avowed "Progressive" former Representative, who easily defeated a "Truman Democrat," held the Democratic nomination today for Washington State's vacant Third District seat in Congress.
A 20-year-old man was shot fatally at 2 A.M. yesterday as a friend was showing him a loaded 45 caliber revolver on a deserted Greenwich Village street.

According to reports from Washington, Secretary of State Marshall is presumed to have started his new Policy Planning Staff on a world-wide survey of economic conditions to determine just what financial and other aid the United States must provide to foreign nations to start the world on real reconstruction and recovery.

Stabilization of livestock prices on a monthly basis, as is done with milk, was proposed yesterday by one of the major meat handlers of this country as a way of halting "fantastic fluctuations" that are said to have made cattle-growing more speculative than ever before.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 18 -- The question whether the conspiracy count of the lynch-murder indictment against thirty-one white men on trial for the mob-slaying of a Negro should be struck out as a matter of law is expected to be resolved here tomorrow.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 18 -- James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, pledged today CIO support for a Jewish homeland in Palestine. He spoke at the closing session of the National Trade Union Emergency Conference for Labor Palestine.

THE rain drifted down in a steady drizzle almost until game time at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. The players came into the dressing rooms shaking their heads. "We'll never get in a game today," they said. It certainly didn't look like it and it seemed inconceivable that the sun eventually would burst through the layer of gray clouds and make it a pretty fair day for baseball after all.

Adequate appropriations for continuance and expansion of the Veterans Administration's medical program in New York State were urged yesterday by the State Charities Aid Association in a statement approved by its board of managers and made public by Winthrop W. Aldrich, its president.

SEATTLE, Wash., May 18 -- Negro leaders interested in good race relations agreed here today that while the placement of wartime Negro migrants in useful employment was the major problem, housing and training for new jobs were vital side issues.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (U.P.) -- Assistant Secretary of State William Benton said today that it would be a national catastrophe if Congress "cuts the windpipe" of the State Department's "Voice of America" broadcasts to Europe.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- The return of more normal buying conditions in the feminine apparel markets was hoped for here as two major fall exhibits opened for a one-week showing and a third exhibit went into its second and final week. Reactions of retailers, however, indicated a policy of caution in making commitments for fall merchandise.

The recent British decision to make religious education compulsory for all children was defended yesterday by the Right Rev. John William Charles Wand, Lord Bishop of London. He viewed the move as a solution to the problem of building up in man "a right attitude toward his fellow men and toward the whole of life."

The American economic system would be strengthened and the standard of living of the American people would be raised by the restoration of world trade, a Public Affairs pamphlet issued yesterday asserted. It said foreign trade would be to the same advantage of this country now as it was to Great Britain in the nineteenth century, when Britain played the role of the world's greatest creditor nation, which now belongs to us.
The charitable resources of community trusts in the United States and Canada rose to $77,835,014 at the close of 1946, the New York Community Trust reported yester day.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18 -- Enterprise Productions has acquired screen rights to "Proud Destiny," a forthcoming historical novel by Lion Feuchtwanger, for $350,000, plus a bonus if the book sale exceeds a certain figure. Lewis Milestone will produce and direct the screen version of the novel, after he completes "The Red Pony" at Republic.

ST. LOUIS, May 18 (AP) -- Two southpaw pitchers named Kenneth -- Heintzelman and Raffensberger -- were too much for the Cardinals today as the Phillies downed them twice, 6 -- 3 and 1 -- 0. The second contest went twelve innings and was decided when Emil Verban, former Cardinal, singled to score Howie Schultz who had singled and advanced to second on a wild pitch.

Although Russia has already received reparations valued at billions of dollars, her claim is still the same as it was at the Yalta conference, the American-Association for a Democratic Germany charged yesterday in its June bulletin.

The Investment Bankers Association of America will work out plans this week for recruiting investment interests throughout the nation in two major economic programs of the Federal Administration the marketing of debentures of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the establishment of a continuing program for promoting the sales of Treasury savings bonds.

Production workers on strike since April 7 at the Kearny, N.J., and twenty other metropolitan plants of the Western Electric Company are expected to report back to work tomorrow morning following a meeting tonight in Jersey City to vote on ratification of the agreement reached yesterday in Washington between company and union officials.

Eddie Dowling, who in recent years has confined his activities to the Broadway stage, is scheduled to embark on a major radio venture on July 20. He will be master of ceremonies of "The Big Break," a half-hour divertissement which will feature both unknown talent and stars whom Mr. D. helped to discover.

LONDON, May 19 -- The Viceroy of India, Viscount Mountbatten, arrived in London from New Delhi shortly after noon today and lost no time in getting into conferences on the critical developments in India. The keynote, as a spokesman of the India Office said this evening, is "the greatest possible urgency," since the Viceroy must be back in India before June 2.

Arrival in the United States last week of fifty tons of Siamese refined tin on the steamship Longview Victory is the forerunner of a sizable quantity of pig tin and concentrates procured under Reconstruction Finance Corporation contracts, R.C. Clark of the Tin Sales Corporation revealed here yesterday in an interview.

ONE of the greatest feats of exploration in the history of the New World was the discovery and descent of the Amazon River under particularly harrowing circumstances by a Spanish conquistador named Francisco Orellana. Since nothing much resulted from Orellana's feat, neither gold nor a new province for Spain's colonial empire, little is generally known about him, and that little, says Hartzell Spence, is a canard.

E.I. duPont de Nemours Co. announced yesterday that William F. Raskob has resigned as secretary and Lamott duPont Copeland has been elected as his successor. Mr. Copeland. a member of the board of directors and the finance committee, will continue in these posts.

An array of twenty table settings--some purposeful, others fantastic-- opened yesterday on Altman's fourth floor. Planned by the store's staff of window and fashion display artists, the settings offer numerous suggestions for home-makers who want to provide a special atmosphere for guests.

The annual report of the Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries for the year ended with last January, issued to stockholders yesterday, shows a net profit of. $18,378,752 after taxes and all charges. This is equal to $8.52 a share on 2,062,722 common shares and compares with $8,370,401 or $4.05 each on 1,804,882 common shares reported for the previous fiscal year.

PARIS, May 19 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin recently suggested to Secretary of State Marshall that Britain and the United States negotiate an agreement permitting their citizens to visit each other's country without visas. This was disclosed today by a responsible source.

A series of three Saturday concerts devoted to the music of George Gershwin will be offered next month by Paul Whiteman and the American Broadcasting Symphony over the ABC network (WJZ). The programs, which will include such lesser known works of the composer as "Cuban Overture" and "Piano Concerto," will run from 5 to 6 P.M. on June 14, 21 and 28.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Senate, after three days of debate, agreed this evening to vote tomorrow on establishment of a national science foundation. An acute shortage of post-war scientists, sponsors of the program say, has made such a Government agency essential to the preservation of national health, prosperity and security.

Two issues of public utility bonds amounting to $5,300,000 were awarded to investment synidicates at competitive sale yesterday, but scheduled concurrent sales of two issues of common stock brought no bids from underwriters. The announced readiness of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation to buy at $12 each 200,000 shares of new common stock about to be issued by the South Carolina Power Company was effective in shutting out underwriters' bids for the equity issue.

PITTSBURGH, May 19 -- The guaranteed annual wage, prescribed by many labor unions as the cure-all for depressions, was described here today as a "naive" approach in an address by Dr. Emerson P. Schmidt, director of economic research, United States Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Plant guards are "employes" under the National Labor Relations Act and may join the same union which represents production workers, the Supreme Court held today in reversing two lower court decisions.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The searching debate in Congress on the bill to appropriate grants-in-aid to Greece and Turkey, despite the attempt of the administration to limit it with a mandatory "deadline" of March 31, has already proved its value. Various official steps are being taken to determine the approximate costs of the Truman Doctrine, of which the Greek-Turkish bill was the first expression, and our national capacity to meet them.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The British Government protested to the United States Government today against the raising of funds in this country to carry on armed resistance against the British forces in Palestine.

The International Red Cross Committee Conference in Geneva last month to consider treatment of future prisoners of war was unable to complete its work because Soviet representation was absent, Albert E. Clattenburg Jr., head of the American delegation, declared yesterday.
LONDON, May 19 (Reuters) -- South Africa's cricketers appear destined for defeat when their match with the M.C.C. ends at Lords tomorrow, where they will start the day 356 runs in arrears.

Robert Shaw and the Collegiate Chorale, whose healthy influence on the musical life of the city continues to expand, made their second annual sponsors' concert at Carnegie Hall last night an exciting experience. This was accomplished by presenting new contemporary works by Paul Hindemith and Aaron Copland and a choral masterpiece, Mozart's Great Mass in C minor, and by performing them with the intensity that vivifies.

LOS ANGELES, May 19 -- Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman said today he doubted that the United States could ever attain the economic ideal of balanced exports and imports, but suggested that in the present extreme disparity, one great potential factor toward balance was American private investment abroad.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- American scientists will begin late this month on research through the former mandated Japanese islands of Micronesia, to end a scientific blackout dating from 1910.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Trading in grain futures was relatively slow on the Board of Trade today, with many operators disposed to act with caution pending further developments in the May delivery situation.

RANGOON, Burma, May 19 (London Times Dispatch) -- U Aung San presided today at the opening preliminary convention of the Anti-Fascist Peoples Freedom League. This is Burma's majority party and it was called to agree on a new Constitution for Burma.

Net earnings of the Parker Pen Company in its fiscal year ended last February amounted to $4,173,974 after taxes and all charges, exceeding the previous year's net of $2,331,683 by 79 per cent, Kenneth Parker, president, reported yesterday in the fifty-eighth annual statement to stockholders.

Four more American stamp collectors who have won international renown as writers and students in their field were honored by the Philatelic Congress of Great Britain yesterday when they were invited to sign their names to the "Roll of Distinguished Philatelists" set up in 1921 and subsequently signed by the late King George V.

Eight to ten witnesses were questioned yesterday as Assistant District Attorney Alfred J. Scotti, head of the rackets bureau, continued to investigate alleged irregularities in the subleasing of piers.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 19 -- The Rev. Msgr. Thomas J. Tobin, Vicar General of the Archdiocese of Portland, which includes Seattle, Tacoma and Northwest rural areas, said today that the business men of Portland should take steps to hire Negroes and Orientals who live in this area.

The stock market underwent a new attack yesterday of enlarged proportions which carried prices to within striking1 distance of the 1945 low level before steadying operations and short covering on the rebound reduced losses. Smart rallying tendencies in such key divisions as the steels, motors and liquors pulled the list out of its fresh tail spin.

On top of an application pending before the Public Service Commission for an increase in electric rates, the Consolidated Edisor Company of New York, Inc., will apply to the PSC for gas rate increases for itself in this city and for the Westchester Lighting Company, Ralph H. Tapscott, president of Consolidated, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., May 19 (AP) -- After six tries, Christiana Stable's Service Pilot finally made good here today, winning the St. Michael's, a test of a mils and seventy yards.

After topping Fordham by an 8-4 count in the curtain-raiser, City College threatened to make a clean sweep of the Metropolitan Conference double-header at Fordham Field by scoring five runs in the second game yesterday before the Rams could get under way.

LONDON, May 19 (AP) -- British Government sources declined to comment today but unofficial observers said there "was precious little chance" the British Government would make any move toward guaranteeing minimum prices for Malayan rubber.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 19 -- R. B. Roberts Productions, an independent company, in which John Garfield is a partner and to which he is under exclusive contract, announced today that Garfield has withdrawn from a lend-out commitment to Marshall Grant Productions for the leading role in "Moonrise" because the Grant company has not fulfilled the conditions of the agreement.

TOKYO, May 19 -- Japan's four major political parties today agreed to the election of Tetsu Katayama, veteran Socialist leader, as the next Premier. He will be the first to serve under, the new Constitution. He is expected to be named by a majority of the Diet's Lower House shortly after it is called into session by Emperor Hirohito tomorrow morning.

After skipping about the country, "Up In Central Park" has returned to New York at the City Center, where it opened last evening at democratic prices. Many people who are now slowly maturing saw it at much gayer prices when it opened in New York in January, 1945.

Their Untainted Output It may sound like heroic treatment, but instead of exposing Output and pillorying the Communists in Hollywood, it might serve the national interest if as many Communists as possible in the rest of the country could be induced to go to Hollywood and settle there and enter the motion-picture industry.

MANILA, May 19 -- Undeniable connections between the Filipino Hukbalahaps, a militant rebel organization in Central Luzon, and Moscow have been established through the seizure of pamphlets, documents and hammer and sickle flags by Government forces in the last few months, in the opinion of Philippine Army intelligence officers and some Government officials.
Governor Dewey urged yesterday that the displaced Jews of Europe be allowed to resettle in the United States and Palestine as well as the other nations of the world.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- In a move to curb black market operations and resultant inflation in Germany, the War Department announced today that private shipments of cigarettes and tobacco to American personel in the occupied zones would be banned on and after May 26.

LONDON, May 19 -- Competition from widely diverse sources is causing concern among British manufacturers here this week in the wake of the British Industries Fair. According to reports both Russia and Japan are looming as threats to Anglo-American dominance of textile and pottery markets of the world.

Bidding for Utility Stock In view of the new decline in stock prices, the failure of two blocks of public utility company common stock to attract bids from underwriters yesterday was not surprising. Much interest surrounds the scheduled bidding today for 408,000 shares of California Oregon Power Company's common stock, of which 390,000 shares represent holdings of Standard Gas and Electric Company, its parent.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Procter Gamble Company was the leading advertiser in newspapers last year, with an expenditure of $3,723,937, Advertising Age said in its current issue. Another soap company, Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company, was a close second with $3,665,763.

AT SEA, May 13 -- We have now been adrift on our balsa raft for two weeks and have been carried over 500 miles by winds and the Humboldt Current. We have been through a storm, fought sharks, been convoyed by a school of whales, chased a giant sea turtle that was itself being chased by twelve great sea dolphins, and have seen a host of strange and wonderful sea fish.

PEIPING, China, May 19 -- Growing Communist pressure was reported today around the southern suburbs of Changchun, capital of Manchuria, and according to dispatches reaching here the sound of artillery fire could now be heard within the city itself.
PARIS, May 19 -- The French have completed a plan for the conversion of all Saar currency from marks to francs.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court declined today to review a decision that a manufacturer's plan for sharing profits with employes led to violations of the wage-hour law's overtime provisions.

Hyman Fischer has purchased the two sixteen-family houses at 117-119 Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, form the Johnson Holding Corporation. Robert J. Quinn and Quinn and Gustarve Kaye were the brokers and the Inter-Country Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company insured the title.

KANSAS CITY, May 19 -- As Mrs. Martha E. Truman, President Truman's mother, appeared to be gradually weakening tonight, other members of her immediate family were gathering at her bedside. Miss Margaret Truman, her granddaughter, arrived at the home at Grandview, Mo., late today, and Mrs. Harry S. Truman is expected; tomorrow.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 19 -- Apparently few of the metropolitan districts' professionals are anxious to play in the Professional Golfers Association championship which is to be held at the Plum Hollow Club, Detroit, starting June 18.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Once more the Supreme Court, in a decision announced today, has defended the constitutional guarantee of the freedom of the press. In a six-to-three decision the high court reversed the contempt of court conviction of three Texas newspaper men following their written comments concerning a trial before a county judge.

CHICAGO, May 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 8,500 head; total, 11,500: market very slow, generally $1 lower than Friday including sows. Top $24. Bulk of good and choice 170 to 250 pounds, $23 to $23.75; 260 to

The existence of 1,500 unsold small homes in Brooklyn and Queens, and in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, must not be taken as a portent of any immediate drop in prices, the Long Island Home Builders Institute declared yesterday.

The annual survey of membership in religious bodies in the United States, conducted by The Christian Herald, monthly Protestant magazine, was released yesterday. The statistics, to be published in the June issue, show forty-seven major Protestant denominations reporting a total gain of 1,534,787 for last year.
PARIS, May 19 -- A twenty-fourhour dock strike and threats of more strikes in industrial sectors arose today.
JERUSALEM, May 19 -- Palestine Government officials conferred today on preparations for the expected visit of the United Nations committee that is to explore the situation in the Holy Land.

The "revolutionary changes in our environment during the last two or three years" have made the experience of the past "almost entirely irrelevant for the future," Dr. G. Brock Chisholm of Ottawa, Canada, declared yesterday. Dr. Chisholm, who is executive secretary of the World Health Organization, spoke to the American Psychiatric Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation and its subsidiaries operated in 1946 at a loss of $33.716.220, but tax carrybacks and income from special reserves permitted the company to show a net income of $2,472,091, G.W. Vaughan, president, reported yesterday.

There are few cuts of meat today that you can call downright cheap, though there are some that are less costly than the sirloin steaks, standing ribs, lamb chops and veal cutlets that are so popular. These thriftier selections -- like beef chuck and veal and lamb shoulder -- become tender when ground, and may then be put into dishes of variety and flavorsome quality for which recipes appear here today.

To Drs. Theodor Rosebury and Elvin A. Kabat goes the credit for having published the most comprehensive paper on bacterial warfare in print. Even though it takes us only to 1942 the Rosebury-Kabat 40,000-word technical summary will serve the purpose of orienting the United Nations.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today an application filed jointly by the Delaware Power and Light Company and its subsidiary, Eastern Public Shore Service Company, whereby the latter would sell before Dec. 31, 1948, $2,000,000 of 3% per cent promissory notes due on Oct. 1, 1973, and 20,000 shares of $100 par value common stock.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, May 19 -- The Ruhr's majority party, the Christian Democratic, will refuse to participate in the formation of any Government committed to the socialization of the basic industries of Europe's industrial arsenal, Dr. Conrad Adenauer, its chief, said today.

Following is the text of the speech by Andrei A. Gromyko, at the annual dinner of the AmericanRussian Institute at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel: Mr. Chairman: It gives me great pleasure to meet the people who are interested in the work of the AmericanRussian Institute.

ROME, May 19 -- The Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti cabled to Sunnier Welles in Baltimore today denying a statement attributed to him that the Italian Communist party received funds direct from Moscow.

Nurses must not be asked to assume the financial responsibilities for an unsound medical economic structure any more than Government officials should work for sub-standard wages because the budget is not balanced, Dr. Eli Ginzberg, Professor of Economics in Columbia University's School of Business, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- C. A. Boles, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, said today he will recommend that a hearing by the ICC on the applications of Robert R. Young and Robert S. Bowman, officials of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, to sit on the board of the New York Central be postponed from June 2 until later in tne summer.

Fifth Avenue from Fifty-sixth Street to Thirty-fifth glowed red in the rain last night for the Women in White. Three thousand women, thirty-five illuminated floats, thirty uniformed bands moved down glistening black pavement to open the $5,000,000 drive for the new medical center for the New York Infirmary Building Fund.
PARIS, May 19 -- Reverting to pre-war tradition, Pierre Balmain completes his spring collection, but includes advance autumn models as well.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Skeeter Dickey's twelfth-inning double with the bases loaded gave Chicago's White Sox a 4-1 victory over Washington here tonight. It marked the eleventh successive game in which the Senators failed to score more than two runs.

Mrs. Abby Rockefeller Pardee has purchased a vacant plot of about thirteen and one-half acres in Mill Neck, L.I., from the Title Guarantee and Trust Company and Warren Murdock as executors and trustees of the estate of Harvey Murdock.

Conceding that protracted negotiations with officials of the National Theatre, Washington, have failed to lift the ban against the admission of Negroes there, Actors Equity Association yesterday appealed for support from Washington's theatre-going public.

LONDON, May 19 -- Fund-raising activities of the American League for a Free Palestine came up for discussion in the House of Commons today when the Government was pressed to report whether the United States Government had replied to repeated representations by the British Embassy on the League's activities.

Margaret W. Chilholm and others sold the property at 62-66 West Fourteenth Street, southeast corner of Avenue of the Americas and extending through to 63-65 West Thirteenth Street, to John T. Javasile, who in turn conveyed it to Joseph, Harry, Murray, Bessie, Ruth and Paul Jones.

Store Sales Here Rise 7% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 7 per cent over the like week last year, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday. The figure is unchanged from that of the preceding week.

NANKING, May 19 -- The Chinese Government today moved to get tough with student demonstrators as thousands of striking collegians laid plans for a mass march for the presentation of complaints to tomorrow's opening session of the People's Political Council.

GENEVA, May 19--The United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission holds its final public session tomorrow to debate the proposed conclusions concerning responsibility for the trouble in that tense area of conflict between the interests of the Soviet and Western blocs.
The Fourteenth Regiment, New York Guard, is celebrating this week a century of military history. The ceremonies started last night with a dinner-dance at the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.

Rubber manufacturers said yesterday that falling world prices were the result of increased supply of natural rubber plus record tire production which has been catching up with demand in the United States.

Children "are no longer products of a home, but of a neighborhood," Albert B. Hines, executive director of the Madison Square Boys Club, declared yesterday. In presenting the club's annual report last night at the annual trustees' meeting in the clubhouse, 301 East Twentyninth Street, M. Hines analyzed the trends in juvenile delinquency since the club's inception in 1884.
Chester Municipal Authority, Pa., announced yesterday that it would receive bids June 12 on an issue of $2,400,000 of water revenue bonds dated Dec. 1, 1946, and due Dec. 1 from 1947 to 1986.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 10 -- Newspaper proprietors and printers here have been summoned by the State Mediator to meet tomorrow in an effort to settle a strike that has all but deprived Copenhagen of newspapers since the beginning of March.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In reply to the letter of George Weller, published on April 15, wherein he doubts the number of killings by the Communists in Greece, may I inform him that Greek authorities state that the number of murders were about 60,000 in all Greece, of which 20,000 were in the Athens area alone.

JERUSALEM, May 19 -- A spokesman of the Fighters for the Freedom of Israel, known also as the Stern band, declared today that his group might end its antiBritish guerrilla campaign for several years if the United Nations granted to the Zionists sufficiet "living space" in Palestine for "the first stage" in the development of a Jewish state.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (U.P.) -- Andrew J. May told a Federal Court jury today "I never entered into a conspiracy with anyone to defraud my country."
Forty thousand youngsters and 14,000 parents were served by the Children's Aid Society in the last year, it was announced yesterday.

New York found itself yesterday with another embarrassing home relief case on its hands--a family of seven persons that has received municipal aid totaling $640.52 monthly since last December. Ten days ago, it became known that the Welfare Department had disbursed $500 for one month's rent and food for a family of six.

Regardless of how much one may sympathize with the anger of Koreans against the proposed four-Power trusteeship of their country, it is difficult to see what Dr. Syngman Rhee and his followers can possibly gain by insistence on their right to demonstrate publicly against trusteeship during the Joint U.S.-U.S.S.R, Commission meetings in Seoul.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission and the Association of American Railroads urged today that Congress allow railways in temporary trouble to adjust their debts without going through bankruptcy.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation recommended to Congress to day that the agency be continued with virtually all its peacetime powers, but with most of its wartime powers rescinded.

BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- With one out in the ninth inning and the Tigers ahead, 4 -- 3, Ted Williams today blasted a two-run homer into the right-field bleachers for a 5-4 victory for the Red Sox, who thus divided a double-header with Detroit before 28,289 fans.

After deciding that adults have not been successful in coping with the problem of teen-age recreation, twenty-five students from five Bronx high schools met yesterday to organize a Bronx Youth Council and to start the formation of a program of summer recreation that will reach their borough's 400,000 teen-agers.

LOS ANGELES, May 19 -- Continuing his attacks on the Truman Doctrine, Henry A. Wallace, in the first Pacific Coast appearance of his national tour, tonight said the major powers, including Russia, were involved in a world drift toward war.

The Coaching Club American Oaks will serve as the feature attraction at the Belmont Park course today. The race, run for the first time in 1917, has attracted a standout field of 3-year-old fillies who will compete for a purse worth $50,000 added.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 19 -- The United Nations Fiscal Commission, last of the Economic and Social Council's nine major commissions to begin work, held its first meeting today and elected Rodolphe Putman of Belgium as its chairman.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 19 -- Hofstra climbed back over the 500 mark in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference play with an easy 12-to-3 conquest of Brooklyn College today. It was the sixth victory in eleven starts for the Flying Dutchmen.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court set aside today an order by the United States Circuit Court in San Francisco which had held the Times Mirror Compay, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, in contempt of court. The lower court's order was in connection with a newsboys' labor union case.

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University announced here last night that top priority in the new $15,575,000 New York University-Bellevue Medical Center has been given to the construction of the Institute of Rehabilitation.

Tammany completed its judicial slate for the fall elections yesterday, and, by agreement with the Republicans, only two of the fifteen Manhattan judgeships will be contested. The other places -- twelve of the thirteen involving sitting judges -- will be filled by bipartisan endorsements.

Just a year ago, on May 20, 1946, 795 survivors of the Hitler era -- Protestants, Jews and Catholics -- sailed into New York harbor from the Displaced Persons camps of Germany. Joyfully, unbelievingly, they watched customs officials riffle through their few worldly possessions, spent a few days at reception centers of welfare agencies who sponsor their immigration, went to join friends or to make them in the New World.

TOKYO, May 19 -- At the end of next month Japan's stocks of raw cotton will amount to only 228,000 bales, which is less than three months' supply. Because it takes about four months between a purchase in the United States and delivery to a Japanese mill, occupation officials frankly are worried at the situation.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 19 -- The first United Nations conference on freedom of the press tackled today the job of guaranteeing by treaty a world-wide flow of news free from censorship.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 19 (U.P.) -- Owners of the thirty-five cars entered in the Indianapolis Motor Speedway 500-mile race moved tonight to permit members of the boycotting American Society of Professional Auto Racing to drive in the Memorial Day classic.

Frederic Voloninis, Greek violinist, who played under Dimitri Mitropoulos in Athens and is with him now as assistant concert-master of the Minneapolis Sym-phony Orchestra, gave his second New York recital last night at Town Hall.

Dr. Albert Broadus Newman was removed last night as dean of the City College School of Technology by the unanimous vote of the Board of Higher Education at its meeting in Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue.

Picket lines restored in front of telephone exchanges by the Association of Communication Equipment Workers in its wage fight with the Western Electric Company again curtailed service in some sections of the country yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19 -- Charles W. Crawford of Washington, associate United States commissioner of foods and drugs, said today that the nation was suffering an epidemic of violations of the country's drug laws by "unscrupulous adventurers in the business of furnishing cure-all therapeutic devices."

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, told the House Ways and Means Committee today that "a period of tax reduction is approaching," but withheld recommendations on the specific time and method.

LONDON, May 19 -- The House of Commons tonight approved the Chancellor of the Exchequer's L3,181,000,000 over an unusual protest vote by the Conservatives. The vote was 274 to 128 for the budget of approximately $12,724,000,000.
LONDON, May 19 (AP) -- Sir Thomas Beecham and his impresario, Harold Fielding, parted company today.

Opportunity knocked con ily but the Yankees paid no heed, left nine men stranded on the basepaths and presented a 5-4 victory to the Indians yesterday at the Stadium. The home forces had great chances to go places in the second, fourth and fifth innings, but when a base hit was vital none was forthcoming and the Cleveland club made it two straight over the Yankees.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with interest E.O. Matter's letter, "Milk Prices Explained," in your May 10 issue.

On the season's final boxing card in the St. Nicholas Arena last night was a scheduled ten-round heavyweight bout between Leo Matriccini of Baltimore, 208 pounds, and Cleo Everett of this city, 202 1/4.

LONDON, May 19 -- A new and notable undertaking to foster AngloAmerican friendship will be carried forward on Wednesday when Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, commander of the United States Second Army, makes the first lecture on this side of the ocean for the Kermit Roosevelt Memorial Fund.

AMSTERDAM, May 19 (Aneta) --The market was generally lower in light trading on the Stock Ex-change. The decline was attributed to an uneasy feeling concerning the lower prices on the New York Stock Exchange. Weakness was evident from the start and opening prices, with few exceptions, were lower than Friday's closings.

VIENNA, May 19 -- A group of 116 Rumanian Jews has been confined in the railroad station in the Austrian frontier village of Loipersbach since last Saturday night after having spent the three previous days and nights dodging traffic on a railroad bridge leading from Hungary to Austria.

It was not until the early morning hours of Oct. 21 that we came in sight of our rendezvous point. We could spot a light where we thought was the correct location, but it was too near dawn to risk a landing and we were not sure enough where we were.
Professor Taylor of Hunter College gets "lit up" every day but with an iron constitution there is never a hint of a morning after.
Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, warned the United States last night that continuance of its "monopoly" of atomic weapons was "an illusion."
After some early weakness the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rallied yesterday and closed irregular, 12 points higher to 6 points lower.

Reports from Helsinki suggest that the Russians believe they are again being threatened by Finland. It will be recalled that the Finns did prove something of a menace to Russia during the winter of 1939-40, when they defended themselves, at first with some success, against Mr. Stalin's invading armies.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and of the United Steelworkers Union, announced today that negotiations were completed over the week-end with the Oliver Iron Ore Mining Company, Duluth, Minn., granting to 11,000 workers the same 15-cent "package" increase agreed to by basic steel a month ago.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The House Post Office Committee recommended today an upward revision of postal rates which it estimated would bring in "well over" $100,000,000 of extra revenue annually.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The current sessions of the International Civil Aviation Organization at Montreal afford a valuable demonstration of one world or several. The test question is whether there should be one standard air transport (five freedoms) agreement, multilateral and accepted by many or all countries, or whether international aviation should be managed by a series of bilateral, or group, agreements.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, May 19 -- President Dumarsais Estime today expressed confidence in his ability to "liberate" Haiti from the control exercised by the United States over the finances of the island by means of the announced internal loan.

LONDON, May 19 (AP) -- Gordon Richards, who quit as an office boy at 14 to begin a turf career as a stable lad, set a world record today with his 3,261st victory as a jockey, this time aboard Le Bosc Giard at Worcester.

Opening two to four weeks earlier than last year, fall wholesale coat, suit and dress lines attracted substantial buyer attendance here yesterday. Caution was evident, however, in an estimate 25 per cent over-all drop in number of buyer arrivals compared with a year ago, together with the fact that this is the first fall buying period in five years in which allot ments of women's apparel order, are no longer a major factor.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Truman renewed today his plea that Congress enact a longrange public health, program, including provisions for disability insurance.

BOSTON, May 19 -- A move to end jurisdictional disputes between architects, landscape architects and decorators was made here today in the adoption by the American Institute of Decorators of a suggestion to organize a joint conference at which fields of effort and common procedure would be defined.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- A plea for American business to join with Government in a nation-wide effort to gain adoption and support of a unified foreign economic policy to speed up world recovery and freedom for international trade, was issued here tonight by John Abbink, president of the McGraw Hill International Corporation.
The striped bass hit in at several points along Jones Beach on Sunday, which came as an unexpected reward to a number of surfcasters who have been plugging away there without much hope.

PEABODY, Mass., May 19 (AP) -- Jerry Gianferante of Springfield gained the New England professional golf title from thirty-five rivals by posting a thirty-six-hole total of 146 today at the Salem Country Club. By so doing, he led this section's five qualifiers for the P.G.A. championship at Detroit's Plum Hollow Club starting June 16.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- That losing streak that has made Cholly Grimm so grim instead of jolly finally was halted at five games today when the Cubs battered out an 8-7 triumph over the Dodgers. It was a spotty contest that was interrupted an hour and four minutes by rain.

For two days now officials of the Hotel Pennsylvania have been unsuccessful in their attempts to evict a tenant. The manager's office said yesterday that the tenant took up residence in the hotel without registering and that since he came in late Saturday night with a week-end group he had been causing a terrific commotion.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- House spokesmen tacitly abandoned today, in their second meeting with Senate conferees on the labor control bills, the provision in the lower chamber's measure which would prohibit employer contributions to welfare funds in any sense controlled by unions.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 19 -- Italy applied for membership in the United Nations today in a formal bid presented to Secretary General Trygve Lie by Count Alberto Tarchiani, Italian Ambassador to the United States.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 19-- Verdicts of acquittal were ordered today by Presiding Judge J. Rob-ert Martin Jr. for three of the thir-ty-one defendants in the mass lynch-murder trial here. All four counts of the indictment, however, were retained for the jury's con-sideration.
PARIS, May 19 -- French fears that American loans might impair France's independence or sovereignty have at last been officially expressed in speeches by members of the Government over the week-end.

VIENNA, May 19 -- Today's meeting of the Big Four's Austrian treaty commission found the Russians still refusing to budge from their position that only the facts of the ownership of Austria's oil industry be specifically ascertained. The Russians hold that the commission should otherwise confine itself to a discussion of the theoretical aspects of the Russian claim to German assets in eastern Austria.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 19 (U.P.) -- Meteorologists today predicted scattered clouds across the path of a total eclipse of the sun at 9 A.M. tomorrow. Thus months of preparations by scientists of eleven nations, waiting to make observations during the four minutes of total darkness, are threatened.

NEW ORLEANS, May 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias surrendered her Trans-Mississippi women's golf championship today and Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex., became the logical choice for succession to the title.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- President Truman's message to Congress today on a Federal health program follows: To the Congress of the United States: Healthy citizens constitute our greatest national resource.
Twelve thousand New York public school teachers are expected to get their disputed pay increases when the Board of Education holds a special meeting this afternoon to adopt new salary schedules.

Although American governmental aid to the Philippines has provided "tremendous" impetus to the national economic machinery in terms of dollars and commodities, it is but a fraction of what is needed, it wag declared yesterday by Paul V. McNutt, who has submitted his resignation as American Ambassador to that newly created republic.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- More specific therapeutic benefit to patients with advanced heart failure will result, in a large proportion of cases, from the administration of mercurial diuretics than from digitalis, it was reported here today.

Appearing yesterday before the House Ways and Means Committee, Secretary of the Treasury Snyder expressed the opinion that "a period of tax reduction is approaching." Mr. Snyder was talking only in general terms, and declined to elaborate on his statement, but Representative Knutson of Minnesota had a comment to make on it.

John A. Coleman, who retired recently as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, was guest last night at a dinner in the Hotel Commodore arranged by members of the Exchange. He deplored talk of a depression.

Considerable progress has been made by officials of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in the processing of loan applications filed by Denmark and Luxembourg, and it is hoped that decisions can be announced soon, Eugene R. Black, United States executive director of the bank, said yesterday.

BERLIN, May 19 -- In the face of food shortages and the admitted inability to meet the bread ration. Military Government officials of the United States and Great Britain decided today to maintain the existing general ration scale at 1,550 calories a day for the normal consumer.
WARSAW, May 19 -- Soaring prices have precipitated a serious economic crisis for the Polish Government and another breach between the Communist and Socialist parties that rule Poland.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Mrs. Julius Y. Talmadge, president-general of the Daughters of the American Revolution, tonight opened the fifty-sixth or "Home-coming" Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution, the first in five years to be held in Constitution Hall, with a renewed pledge to fight the spread of communism.

Retailers are not seeking merchandise on consignment, Sidney Reisman, vice president and merchandise manager of Blooming dale's, declared yesterday. The majority of offers made by manufacturers to sell goods on consignment, he said, are not worthy of consideration because of the low quality of'goods involved.

Requests from three former deputy police commissioners for pension increases were denied yesterday by the board of trustees of the Police Department Pension Fund at a meeting in Police Headquarters. A similar request from a fourth former deputy was put off until the board's next meeting on June 16 pending a ruling from the Corporation Counsel.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Secretary of State Marshall ruled out today, at least for the present, further appropriations like the $400,000,000 aid for Greece and Turkey and the $350,000,000 relief for other countries.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 20 -- A Southern Jury was urged here today to decide between "wiping out a blot on the fair escutcheon of South Carolina" and "recognizing that Southerners are peculiar people who get along pretty well without Northern meddling."
ROME, May 20 -- Former Premier Francesco Saverio Nitti's efforts to solve the Italian Cabinet crisis seemed today to be less likely to be crowned with success than they did yesterday.

Following a reduction made yesterday in their brass and bronze prices of from 1/2 cent to 1 cent a pound, Thomas A. Hammer, director of sales, Eastern division. Federated Metals Division of the American Smelting and Refining Company, declared in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES that a definite buyer's market has developed in refined ingots.
PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) -- Behind the four-hit pitching of Bob Muncrief, the Browns today coasted to their first Victory in five games this season with the Athletics, 11-1.

KANSAS CITY, May 20 -- President Truman made tentative arrangements today to sign the Greek-Turkish aid bill here Thursday morning, the plan being based on the probability that there will be no great change by then in the condition of his mother, Mrs. Martha E. Truman.

Excessive taxation delays America's embarking on a job-creating "technological revolution," it was argued yesterday by Robert R. Wason, chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers, in a radio forum on "Can We Insure Full Employment?"

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Unions, guilds and governments permitting, the theatre could, and should, become increasingly a force for good in the development of international understanding, John Gielgud, who will appear in New York next week with his English company, which has been playing here in Congreve's "Love For Love," told the Women's National Press Club here today.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The last major dispute in the countrywide strike of telephone workers which began over six weeks ago was settled today.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., May 20 -- Barefoot, his blond hair matted with sea salt, Lieut. Hubert W. Gainer of the Thirty-sixth Fighter Group at Howard Field in the Canal Zone stumbled ashore at Breezy Point at Far Rockaway at dawn today looking pretty much like a latter-day Robinson Crusoe.

LONDON, May 20 -- A slash of 50 per cent in tonnage of coal that Britain has asked of the United States has been recommended by the Secretariat of the European Coal Organization, it was learned authoritatively today.

In preparation for the "hard selling" period now believed imminent, Allied Stores Corporation will feature training and retraining of store advertising personnel in fundamentals of advertising at a clinic in the Hotel New Yorker May 26-27, it was announced yesterday.

TOKYO, May 20 -- Japan's "First National Assembly," the first Parliament to sit under the new democratic Constitution, met briefly for its opening session today. It adjourned without action while the four major political parties attempted to unravel a fresh snarl over the selection of a new Premier and members of the coalition Government.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- A group of stockholders which in two years has acquired more than 20 per cent of the voting power of the Chicago Great Western Railway was successful today in placing two of its representatives on the board of directors at the annual stockholders' meeting.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Broad revision of the military laws governing court-martial procedures to bring these more into line with civil court practices has become the subject of an intensive study by the House Committee on Armed Services.

With an audience of 500 in the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall, Mayor O'Dwyer administered the oath of office yesterday to Anthony J. Di Giovanna, Arthur Markewich and Matthew F. Fagan as new City Magistrates.

Eleven passenger liners carrying almost 7,500 passengers will arrive or sail from New York on Friday, marking the greatest single day's movement of passenger shipping in the port since before the war.

IT takes more than a great many words, numerous characters and an odd assortment of specialized information to make a good novel. But that's all that seems to have gone into the making of "Vermilion"* by Idwal Jones. A more plodding, ponderous, unimaginative and generally tedious three-generation family chronicle has rarely been offered to the reading public.
Led by the July, 1947, position, the cotton future market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 16 to 42 points net higher yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 20 (AP) -- Hammering Hank Greenberg singled home the winning run in the tenth inning tonight as the Pirates defeated the Braves, 4 to 3. The defeat dropped Boston from first to third place.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Bituminous coal operators and the United Mine Workers of America conferred today for the second time since last Friday on a contract to go into effect when the Government relinquishes control of the country's coal mines on June 30.
Zoe De Salle is one of the creators of fashion who does not permit herself to be swayed by the whimsies of changing seasons.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- The $85,000,000 refinancing program of the New England Power Association, the name of which is to be changed to New England Electric System, was approved late today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BERLIN, May 20 -- Military Government personnel has been cut so heavily that the assigned functions cannot be performed with the thoroughness necessary to assure success of the occupation mission. This is freely admitted in all staff divisions here, with the possible exception of the economics division.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Senate, by a vote of 79 to 8, approved today the establishment of a national science foundation to overcome persistent shortages of skills declared essential to preservation of health, prosperity and security.

Mrs. August Belmont, founder and president of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, was awarded the certificate of merit of Sigma Alpha Iota, national musical organization, yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the Opera Guild at Town Hall.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., May 20 (AP) -- Showing as much power as the name implies, Turbine carried 124 pounds to victory in the Alliance purse today. Running in the colors of the estate of Mrs. H. Lebowitz, the 5-year-old won going away by a length over Mrs. E.H. Augustus' Blue Yonder, who was some three lengths in front of H L. Straus' New Moon.

Benjamin Strong will succeed Thatcher M. Brown as president of the board of directors of Union Theological Seminary, it was announced last night at the seminary's annual commencement exercises. Degrees were conferred on 114 students.

SECURITY COUNCIL Vassili Dendramis, Greek representative, told Council that Greece's northern neighbors had stepped up interference with her internal affairs since departure of United Nations Balkans Investigation Commission.

The Board of Education adopted yesterday new salary schedules providing pay increases for 15,000 regular teachers and 4,500 substitutes. The new schedules become effective on July 1. The board also froze into the permanent pay schedules of all the city's 36,000 teachers and supervisory personnel the temporary cost-of-living bonus and other increases ranging up to $900 a year that had been granted previously.

Madison Square Garden was sold out last night as nearly 20,000 persons assembled to see stars of stage, screen and radio give a benefit performance for the New York Infirmary, which has started a campaign for $5,000,000 for a new building at York Avenue and Sixty-first Street.

CHICAGO, May 20. (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 8,000 head, total 12,000. Hogs under 240 pounds opened slow, 25 to 50 cents lower, but these weights later were fairly active and most sales were around 25 cents
Six thousand bouquets of flowers will be delivered to military and veterans' hospitals in the New York area today in memory of Miss Bessie Beatty, radio commentator, it was announced yesterday.

With five European nations to contend with this summer in the racing for the Seawanhaka and Scandinavian Gold Cups, syndicates have been formed to put forth two of the craft in this country. For years syndicates were formed to build a defender for the America's Cup.
MUNICH, Germany, May 20 -- Two hundred and forty survivors of Munich's pre-war Jewish community of some 18,000 persons today rededicated the Reichenbach Synagogue, demolished by the Nazis in 1936.

Investigation of alleged irregularities in the leasing of city piers widened yesterday to include the city's dealings with airlines when Mayor O'Dwyer suspended Major Elmer Haslett, city airports director, for private dealings with the North American Airport Corporation.

The nation's top-ranking rifle and pistol shooters will gather at Camp Perry, Ohio, from Aug. 4 to 16 inclusive, for the national championship matches, which this year are expected to attract more than 1,500 from all over the country.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution today voted endorsement of "world organization as against world government." The very need for understanding and constant cooperation among countries as developed under the charter of the United Nations, their resolution warned, "serves as a means of encouraging attempts to set up a super state or world government which would abrogate national sovereignty."

Bank Savings Rise Deposits held by the 131 mutual savings banks in this state stand at a record level of $9,377,371,776, it was disclosed yesterday by the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York. Accounts in these banks represent one for every two persons in the state.

One of the three American-flag coastwise lines that ventured to return to private operation after the war announced yesterday that conditions were so unprofitable that it was considering abandoning the project this year.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., May 20 (AP) -- Scientists have produced the first "silent" airplane. Two hundred aviation experts, here for a demonstration of the new ship, call it one of aviation's major developments of recent years.
The gibbon family -- mama, papa and junior -- who spend the winter months in the Monkey House of the Bronz Zoo, began yesterday their third annual vacation on Gibbon Island in the Bronx Lake.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 20 (AP) -- A peace move aimed at getting hold-out drivers into the 500-mile Memorial Day automobile race made progress today. Spokesmen for the drivers and the Indianapolis Motor Speedway repeated they would not give in, however, and prospects for settling the disagreement were little brighter.

For the first time since 1940, educational relations on a wide scale will be resumed between the United States and Europe, William Benton, Assistant Secretary of State, announced yesterday. It is expected that 8,000 students will go abroad under this arrangement and that several thousand foreign scholars will come to this country.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, May 21 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, commander of United States occupation forces in Southern Korea, and Col. Gen. Terentyi F. Shtikov, chief Soviet delegate, today will set a date for reconvening the United States-Russian commission charged with establishing a provisional Korean government.

Long City Rides Probably the biggest nickel's worth of anything still to be had in the country, and certainly here in town, is a bus ride inside one of the boroughs or a subway ride across the borough frontiers.

In preparation for a possible major increase in business failures, reactivation of the Tanners Council Associates, dormant for the last six years because of the absence of financial embarrassments, was announced yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Senate Banking Committee established today a subcommittee to examine possible extension of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation beyond its June 30 expiration and explore further the agency's lending policies in connection with the Baltimore Ohio Railroad and other enterprises and institutions.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics took a dim view of the employment situation today, even though the total jobs are still at record levels, considering seasonal factors.

Azaleas are in bloom and the ducks have returned to their pond in the court or the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, where the outdoor garden for summer dining opened yesterday for its thirty-fifth season. Though these "props" do give a rustic charm to the place, the central attraction is the cuisine of the hotel's chef, Louis Diat.

BERLIN, May 20 -- The United States and British Military Governments adopted an exceedingly temperate tone toward the Germans today, patiently seeking to explain the causes of the food shortages through a series of statements and radio addresses keynoted by a joint statement by the two Military Governors.

A graphic exhibition of methods for treating cerebral palsy dramatized a plea for recognition of the plight of its victims yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History. Hundreds of visitors attended the formal opening, at which Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein presided.
TRENTON, N.J., May 20 -- Donal J. Connolly, former State Assemblyman, became Mayor of Trenton today. He is 38 years old and one of the youngest officials ever to hold such an office in New Jersey.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- A high level of resistance to influenza depends on continual exposure to the active virus in natural conditions, as in buses, theatres and other public places, it was asserted here today.
In only two cities were worker groups of Western Electric still on strike last night after the settlement in Washington with the Association of Communications Equipment Workers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 20 -- Greece's northern neighbors have stepped up their interference with her internal affairs since the departure of the United Nations Balkan Investigation Commission, Vassili Dendramis, Greek representative, told the Security Council today.

The shocking waste of public funds revealed in the Welfare Department's expenditure of $640 monthly for one family and $500 in one month for another casts doubt on the good judgment of some of our city officials and certainly calls for thorough investigation.

An international jury, headed by Admiral Frederic R. Harris, USN, retired, announced awards last night to competitors in the Central and South American sectional competition at the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition at the Grand Central Palace.
