The forty Lund University Singers of Sweden, who arrived in this country on Monday, are losing no time in demonstrating their prowess. They gave their first concert last night at Hunter College Auditorium and are immediately starting on a tour that will take them to twenty cities in less than a month.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Carl A. Marzani, 35, former State Department sub-official, shouted denials in Federal Court today that he had ever been a Communist party member, used a fictitious name or advocated the overthrow of the United States Government.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 20 -- Funds for the Zenger Memorial at the national shrine here to freedom of the press reached sufficient size today for building construction, but questions pertaining to maintenance of the property became tantalizing.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- In a general retreat from the sharper provisions of the House labor bill, conferees for the lower chamber agreed in principle today to drop a House proposal to abolish the National Labor Relations Board and to accept the Senate plan for reorganization of that board.
The waves looked impossible, but we had to make a try [to get out to the submarine] during the full darkness or risk ruining the whole mission.

LONDON, May 20 -- Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, revealed in the House of Commons today that $70,000,000 out of the United States loan of $3,750,000,000 to Britain went for supplies to Germany in the first quarter of this year.

BOCAYUVA, Brazil, May 20 (U.P.) -- Seventy American scientists seeking the cosmic secrets of space got a lucky break today when clouds dispersed barely in time for them to photograph a total eclipse of the sun in perfect weather. They achieved up to 100 per cent success in observations, which may give further confirmation of Binstein's theory of relativity.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, May 19 (Delayed) -- A systematic campaign to present the United States as a nation of greedy capitalists seeking to enfold Morocco in their tentacles is being conducted here by the Communists. The truth is that nearly all attempts to interest American capital in entering Morocco on any terms have signally failed, and many of the business men who were here after the war have gone home.

To John J. Watts' filly Harmonica, leading nearly all the way and gamely withstanding the strongest of pressure through the stretch, went first money of $48,200 in the thirty-first Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park yesterday.
" Take It Or Leave It," the quiz show which burdened the American language with the phrase about "the $64 question," is taking unexpected leave of its spot on the CBS network.

Around this time when the season is about to be tucked away into the archives, announcements arrive in wholesale lots heralding all sorts of hopeful ventures for the term ahead. Whether any of them will materialize is for the future to decide.

A proposal to rechristen the State Department's Office of Information and Cultural Affairs, and give it statutory standing, was approved yesterday by a subcommittee of the House of Representatives. We welcome this decision, and hope that it foreshadows action which will enable the Department to carry on the most useful of the various programs with which it has been experimenting since the end of the war.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Marine and Shipbuilding Workers Union, CIO, told a Presidential committee today that the United States needed a "bridge of ships" for the goods of peace as much as for the guns of war and recommended a start this year on fiftynine new merchant ships.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (U.P.) -- The Army announced tonight that it would scrap its controversial "blue" discharge practice on July 1 and substitute a system of releasing personnel honorably, dishonorably, or as either unsuitable or undesirable.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- All the Amana Society -- a prosperous, industrious little community in central Iowa -- wants is steel to build refrigerators. All that is missing is some cold rolled steel.

The report of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation and all subsidiaries, including the National Theatres Corporation and Roxy Theatre, Inc., to be issued to stockholders today shows a consolidated net profit of $5,897,603 after all deductions for the quarter ended on March 29.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Reparations collected from Japan are to be distributed among the victorious Allies on the basis of each country's contribution to victory, under a policy announced today by the Far Eastern Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The House passed an appropriation of $3,469,761,100 for the Navy today, overriding Democratic protests that the 11 per cent cut it makes in President Truman's request will shrink Navy and Marine Corps strength by 82,000.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 20 -- Already a forgotten man, Bernard N. McFeely completed twenty-two years of virtual dictatorship today by presiding at a four-minute meeting of the outgoing city commission. An hour later, before a cheering crowd of 10,000 persons, the new city administration, headed by Mayor Fred M. De Sapio, took the oath of office in front of the City Hall.

Compliance by employers with the state order setting minimum wages for 500,000 workers in retail stores, which became mandatory on Monday, has varied from 80 to 94 per cent throughout the state, Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, reported yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 20 -- A permanent pay scale for United Nations employes, in which temporary per diem allowances will be replaced by pay increases and additional allowances, was announced today by Byron Price, Assistant Secertary General for Administrative and Financial Services, on behalf of Trygve Lie, the Secretary General.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The White Sox overcame a fourrun deficit and mauled Washington's pitchers for fifteen hits to defeat the Senators, 7 -- 4, tonight and sweep a four-game series.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Dr. Oscar Ivanissevich, the Argentine Ambassador, who has just returned from a trip to Buenos Aires, has arranged to see President Truman at an early date. He is expected to discuss at that time American-Argentine relations in the light of discussions he had with President Juan Peron.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 20 -- Eight American and two Swiss medical specialists will make a two-month tour of Austria and Hungary to demonstrate the use of new surgical techniques, serums and drugs, the Interim Commission of the United Nations World Health Organization announced today.

TOKYO, May 20 -- Plans to borrow against Japan's $130,000,000 gold reserve to finance her industrial recovery have been presented to Washington, this reporter has learned from an unimpeachable source.
LONDON, May 20 -- Viscount Mountbatten, Viceroy of India, continued today his intensive consultations with British Government leaders in a growing atmosphere of pessimism.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 20 -- England is facing a religious renascence, the Right Rev. John William Charles Wand, Lord Bishop of London, told the eightieth convention of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island today in the Cathedral House.

NANKING, May 20 -- Student demonstrators attempting to march to the opening session of the People's Political Council were assaulted and beaten by squads of police here today. The police and gendarmes frustrated the students' efforts to present grievances to the Council.

When the Senate and House labor bills went to conference committee last week this legislation faced a hurdle far more formidable than is normally encountered at this stage. While both measures sought to achieve the same general objectives in labor relations reform, the House bill was considerably more ambitious in scope than the Senate version, including a number of controversial provisions which had no counterpart in the latter.

PITTSBURGH, May 20 -- The country's buying public should reconcile itself to the fact that living costs probably will never return to the pre-war level, according to speakers at the closing session here today of the Midwestern spring conference of the Controllers Institute of America.

The American Psychiatric Association and the American Neurological Association, composed of the country's leading psychiatrists and neurologists, have approved the establishment of the Psychiatric Foundation. The foundation will attempt to gain the support of the public for improving the facilities for the treatment of mental ills, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May. 20 -- The problem of getting and keeping experienced men in Government service is becoming a primary concern of both President Truman and Secretary, of State Marshall. Both have been complaining in private that, particularly in the field of foreign affairs, they are not able to retain in the public service men capable of doing jobs of vital concern to the nation and the world.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A recent TIMES editorial commented on the New York State Supreme Court decision of Justice C.H. Johnson, which involved a closed newspaper union having the rule that only sons of the union members could be admitted into the union.
CARNOUSITE, Scotland, May 20 (AP) -- Bud Ward said today the 18 American entries should do well on the Carnoustie Medal course, where the British amateur golf championship will begin Monday.

Buyers' interest in fall openings continued unabated, a survey of New York garment markets indicated yesterday. Showrooms of manufacturers of women's coats, suits and dresses were crowded throughout the day with hundreds of visiting buyers, who for the first time in several years have the opportunity to view all lines before making final decisions on fall purchases.
NEW ORLEANS, May 20 (AP) -- Favorites won by expectedly lopsided scores today in the firstround match play of the annual women's Trans-Mississippi golf tournament.

BOSTON, May 20 -- The board of directors of the American Unitarian Association voted today to approve the suspension of the Rev. Stephen H. Fritchman as editor of the Christian Register. He has been charged with Communist leanings and activities.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Maj. Gen. Lowell W. Rooks, director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, returning from a wind-up tour of Europe, reported today that all missions in countries receiving aid would close promptly an June 30.

An underwriting syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation made yesterday a successful offering of a new issue of 200,000 shares of common stock of the Koppers Company, Inc., at $25.75 a share. Marketing of other new issues of securities scheduled by underwriting managers for today are as follows:

ATLANTA, May 20 (AP) -- The Presbyterian Church in the United States announced today that its committee on Christian relations would ask the denomination to oppose bills pending in Congress which would make Federal funds available to Catholic schools.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., May 20 -- Six producers of Portland cement signed contracts today ending the twenty-day strike that had shut down plants in Pennsylvania, New York State and Maryland. Other companies were expected to agree soon to the principal terms -- a 15cent-an-hour increase in pay being the chief benefit to the workers.

PARIS, May 20 -- A proposed international convention to safeguard the rights of civilians in time of war by preventing mass starvation in occupied countries will be considered by the executive committee of the League of Red Cross Societies in a three-day session beginning here tomorrow.

CINCINNATI, May 20 -- The Giants' grand offensive through the West attained its peak tonight as Mel Ott's Polo Grounders, with their extraordinary Clint Hartung on the mound, astounded 17,091 burghers by flattening the Reds in the opener of a two-game series at Crosley Field, 9 to 1.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee approved unanimously today a measure that would allow the State Department to continue its "Voice of America" overseas broadcasts, other informational activities and the "interchange of persons, knowledge and skills."

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 20 -- Dr. Leo I. Dana, research manager of the Linde Air Products Company, New York, received the Jacob F. Schoellkopf Medal of the American Chemical Society's western New York section at a meeting here tonight.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 20 (Reuters) -- Soviet scientists at Araxa said they were satisfied with their observations, adding that clouds cleared "just at the critical moment."
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened its season with a flourish yesterday as 128 women teed up over the Pomonok Country Club course in Flushing.

Appointment of an "impartial, expert commission" to make a thorough study of city finances and their relation to Federal and State fiscal policy was asked yesterday by the New York City League of Women Voters.

A proposal that the New York City Housing Authority request the resignations of three key members of its administrative staff was submitted to the authority and tabled at an executive meeting last week, it became known yesterday.

Retailers are making progress in putting their house in order and indications are that within sixty days they will be able to attain the pre-war "yardstick" of stocksales relations, Harry A. Barth, assistant to the president of the W.T. Grant Company, said yesterday.

At 5:21 P.M. (EST) twenty years ago today a single-engine high-wing monoplane named The Spirit of St. Louis touched its wheels on a runway of Le Bourget, near Paris, completing the first solo transatlantic flight in history.
Mothers are receiving too much blame for juvenile delinquency, Dr. Sol W. Ginsburg, practicing psychiatrist and instructor in psychiatry at Columbia University, declared yesterday.

BOSTON, May 20 (AP) -- Rushing in between horses through the stretch, Greenhill Stable's Cherry Quest, 5-1 third choice, won the Suffolk Downs feature today, defeating the 6-5 favorite, Mrs. H.C. Wolfe's Herbie G., by three parts of a length before 14,076 fans.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I commend your recent editorial "No 'Deal' in Judges"?

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved a plan of reorganization for the Florida East Coast Railway Company that provides for its merging or consolidation with the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company, cash and securities of the ACL to be allocated to holders of the FEC first and refunding mortgage bonds.

Most psychologists would like to get rid of the "I.Q." in education, but schools and the public are attached to it and will not let it go, Dr. Morris Krugman, chief psychologist of the Bureau of Child Guidance, declared yesterday.

A well-to-do New Jersey manufacturer spent hours of uncertainty in the West 100th Street station yesterday being questioned about the death of Dr. Gertrude Behrens, 53-year-old physician, whose pajama-clad body was found earlier in a partly filled bathtub in her penthouse apartment at 817 West End Avenue.

American cigarettes have long been the favored currency of Europe's postwar black market. They will buy anything. Next week the United States, by postal regulations here and abroad, will attempt to suppress this demoralizing barter in the American zone of Germany, where a chronic food shortage is rapidly mounting into a political crisis.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- A single in the 11th inning by Lonnie Frey with the bases loaded today carried the Cubs to a 3-to-2 victory over the Phillies. The Chicagoans, who had trailed, 2-1, from the third inning, tied the score in the ninth when Bill Nicholson and Bob Sturgeon doubled.

On instructions from Mayor O'Dwyer, Edward E. Rhatigan, Commissioner of Welfare, speeded up his departmental machinery yesterday to find cheaper homes for thirty-seven home-relief families who are now living in midtown Manhattan hotels at the expense of the city.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., May 20 -- John Mikrut of Shore View scored a one-over-par 73 at the Glen Ridge Country Club today to win the Metropolitan Golf Association first one-day medal play tournament of the season. In a field of seventy-one, the Long Island player's nearest rivals were Tommy Strafaci of Plandome and J. Henry Attas of Aldecress, who posted 75's.

Many luncheon parties were given yesterday at the formal reopening of the outdoor garden of the Ritz-Carlton for this season. Mrs. David Rumsey had as her guests Mrs. James Lincoln Ashley, Mrs. William H. Erhart, Mrs. Fielding Lewis Taylor, Mrs. Arthur Ryle, Miss Lynn Curtis, Hugh Duncan Graham and Claude Taylor.

MONTREAL, May 20 -- The impossibility of reaching a multilateral agreement covering any considerable section of the economics of international flying was admitted here today. Commission Three of the International Civil Aviation Organization decided to draw up a resolution proposing consideration of the multilateral agreement at a future special conference.

AMSTERDAM, May 20 (Aneta) -- Stocks continued to decline in brisk trading on the Stock Exchange. Netherlands and Indies issues were unsettled by the Wall Street trend as well as by the apprehension and uncertainty here concerning the forthcoming capital levy and probable liquidations.

Mr. Gromkyo has stated once more Russia's thesis on atomic weapons and general disarmament. The net result is a reiteration of his Government's demand that the United States disarm first by abandoning its atomic bombs, under a simple prohibition akin to the vain Briand-Kellogg pact "prohibiting" war and without any safeguards that other nations will not immediately manufacture atomic bombs for use against us.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Vice Admiral Earle Mills said today "the shipbuilding and aircraft industries of this country are in bad shape."
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The National Intelligence Authority, it was learned today, has compelled the War Department to liquidate its world-wide secret intelligence network.

The exciting tale General Mark Clark is telling in THE TIMES about his submarine mission to Algiers to pave the way for the invasion of North Africa recalls the debate among the top strategists in 1941 and 1942 on where the first Allied landing would be made. President Roosevelt and the Americans favored a cross-Channel expedition to the Cherbourg peninsula, but Mr. Churchill insisted that the second front should be opened in the Mediterranean.

PARIS, May 20 -- On the eve of tomorrow's Cabinet discussion on the loan to France by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which is soon to be submitted to the Assembly, the Paris press emphasized today the risks regarded as intrinsic in dollar loans and the need for caution in negotiating them.

A panel discussion on "Em ployer-Faculty Responsibility in Developing Nursing Personnel on the Job and in the University" was the feature yesterday of the final session of a two-day conference and reunion of 300 alumnae of the Nursing Education Division of Teachers College, Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 14: Increases of $143,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, $87,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and $93,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks, and a decrease of $64,000,000 in borrowings.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 20 -- C. Knowlton Shaw Jr., Pawtucket, R.I., was elected president of the National Paper Box Manufacturers Association by the more than 500 members attending the closing session of the group's twentyninth annual convention at the Hotel Traymore today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The House committee investigating newsprint and paper supplies issued subpoenas today for two officials of the Clinton Paper Company of New York City. Witnesses had testified the company curtailed deliveries of paper to them and raised prices.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Central Arizona Light and Power Company of Phoenix, Ariz., and Manhattan Coil Corporation of New York City filed registration statements today with the Securties and Exchange Commission.

WHETHER or not the movies have contributed very much to civilization is a moot point which need not be discussed here. But the cinema art has made one extremely valuable contribution to harness racing, of all things. The horse-and-buggy boys will begin operations at Roosevelt Raceway on Friday night, and if they make a low obeisance to Hollywood, their bows of grateful appreciation will be understandable.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 Twentieth Century-Fox has borrowed John Garfield from R.B. Roberts Productions, the actor's own producing company, for the role of David Freedman in "Gentleman's Agreement," with Gregory Peck.

The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. Buyers' Arrivals Gaining Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,624, compared with 1,294 last week and 2,103 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Wheat and corn futures closed strong on the Board of Trade today. Buying of wheat induced by reports of rust in Texas wheat fields, unwanted rain in the Southwest and dry weather in Europe brought in free buying and the close was at the top with gains of 3 1/4 to 5 cents a bushel.

RANGOON, Burma, May 20 (London Times Dispatch) -- In his Presidential address before the meeting of the Anti-Fascist People's Freedom League, U Aung San declared today that the league's proposals for a new Constitution would stress a sovereign, independent and democratic republic.

The stock market edged away yesterday from the low levels of 1945 when buying of limited proportions, including short covering, gave prices of selected issues a lift. Most gains were limited to major fractions, but there were slightly larger increases in some key stocks and the composite rate was raised 0.53 point.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 20 -- A program for the eventual complete elimination of capitalist enterprise in the Danubian basin, and looking to interlocking planned economies with special relation to that of the Soviet Union was presented here today in the name of the Danubian Conference of Socialist parties.

Tired after a long day, Mayor O'Dwyer appeared at 10:15 o'clock last night at a dinner of the shoe industry division of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and acted as a fund-raiser. By exhorting the diners and bantering with them, he raised $10,000, putting the industry's' drive over the half-way mark toward its goal of $1,000,000.

An across-the-board price cut, averaging 15 per cent, on the approximately forty commodities manufactured by Dorset Foods Corporation, was announced yesterday by J.J. Akston, president of the organization. A ninety-day guarantee on floor stocks of all distributors to protect them from inventory losses was extended at the same time.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Robert S. Wilson, vice president and sales manager of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, received the Charles Coolidge Parlin Memorial Award tonight at a meeting of the Philadelphia Chapter of the American Marketing Association in the Warwick Hotel.
The pigeon chase that began in the Hotel Pennsylvania lobby last Saturday night ended yesterday.

John Philip Carter visited the Murray Hill Hotel on Park Avenue, between Fortieth and Fortyfirst Streets, on its opening day in October, 1884, and saw J.P. Morgan arid P.T. Barnum enter what was then the finest hotel of the day.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am reminded by our record of the milestones of radio that May 21, 1947, marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Sunday radio page of THE NEW YORK TIMES. That date is memorable to veterans of radio. THE TIMES through its pioneering in this field of journalism gave great encouragement to the young and struggling radio industry.

The two major political parties, while favoring the repeal of proportional representation as a means of voting for the City Council, have decided to let the repealer referendum be presented to the voters this fall by an independent committee representing civic groups, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Senate took up the $4,000,000,000 individual income tax reduction bill today in the face of solid Democratic support of a drive to delay action until June 10.

Buffalo, N.T., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on May 27 on issues of bonds for various purposes totaling $5,240,000. Dated June 15, 1947, the bonds will come due in the years 1948 to 1961.
GENEVA, May 20 -- Discussion of the international trade charter draft here today was marked by sharp criticism from New Zealand's Finance Minister, Walter Nash.
JERUSALEM, May 20 -- Forty thousand Arab and Jewish civilian workers employed in shops and other establishments of the British War Ministry carried out a oneday strike today.
JERUSALEM, May 20 -- A Palestine Government official announced tonight that security expenditures to combat terrorism would cost $32,000,000 this fiscal year, compared with $18,000,000 two years ago.
Restriction of Federal grants-inaid to state and local governments was proposed yesterday by a subcommittee of the National Association of Manufacturers.

Pushing across a pair of runs in the eighth inning, right after the home team had rallied to tie the score, the Indians defeated the Yankees, 4 to 2, to complete a sweep of their three-game series at the Stadium yesterday.

JERUSALEM, May 20 -- Palestine terrorist forces have acknowledged receipt of funds from American organizations whose moneyraising activities have caused British complains to the United States Government. But the terrorist groups are not noticeably enthusiastic about the amounts given.
LONDON, May 20 -- A severe slump in Brazilian railway and utility stocks, many of which were down as much as fifteen points, overshadowed all other price movements in the stock markets here today.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on May 15 was 1,314,391 shares, an increase of 295,760 shares since April 15 and the largest amount since Dec. 14, 1945, according to a report issued yesterday by the Exchange. Furthermore, not since the month ended on Jan. 31, 1934, had the increase been larger than in the period ended on last Wednesday.

GENEVA, May 20 -- The United States and the Soviet Union formally presented to the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission in a public session today their contradictory conclusions as to the origin and causes of the trouble inside Greece and between Greece and Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A Senate investigation into non-action by Tom C. Clark, Attorney General, regarding alleged frauds in a Missouri primary election last year was called for in a resolution introduced today by Senator James P. Kem, a Kansas City Republican.

The meeting of the new Diet in Tokyo marks another milestone on Japan's still uncertain road toward liberty and democracy. This is the first Parliament to be held under the first Constitution in Japan putting the sovereignty of the people's will above the theoretically absolute sovereignty of a hitherto "divine" but now de-deified Emperor.

The progress made since the opening of the New York City Center of Music and Drama was reviewed yesterday by Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of directors, at the fourth annual meeting of the incorporators at the Hotel Gotham.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 20 -- Dr. Edwin T. Dahlberg, president of the Northern Baptist Convention appealed today for a strong, united Protestantism to strive against totalitarian governments and "a totalitarian church," against a military philosophy, and for a return of America to basic religious principles.
ATHENS, May 20 -- The Greek Government accepted tonight with certain qualifications the United States proposals for an amnesty to Greek guerrillas.

The New York City Housing Authority has quietly revised its eligibility rules, it was learned yesterday, and many families now are eligible for subsidized housing from which they would formerly have been excluded.

BOSTON, May 20 (AP) -- The American League champion Red Sox today climbed within one game of the pace-setting Tigers by defeating Detroit, 8 -- 3, "behind joe Dobson, who had little difficulty from the second to the ninth.

The Greenwich Village outdoor art exhibition will open on Friday, at which time Barbara Frost, the author of a mystery novel which has the outdoor show as a background, will be honored at an autographing tea by the Artists Committee of the Judson Memorial Church.

The Flesh Creeps There is apparently no definite time schedule for the British nation's demise by starvation, as signalized by a distinguished London nutrition expert. After seven years of a substandard war diet the ordeal continues.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- House Appropriations Committee members reported today that additional cuts had been recommended to reduce the Agriculture Department's 1948 budget of $1,200,000,000 by almost 40 per cent. The subcommittee in charge of the bill met in closed session today.

CINCINNATI, May 21 -- Sitting pretty in one of the tightest early season pennant races the National League has seen in years, what with six clubs virtually tied in a bowknot, the Giants felt a trifle chagrined today when weather prevented them from continuing their own particularly devastating work.

TOKYO, May 21 -- Brig. Gen. Courtney Whitney, chief of Allied Headquarters' Government Section, in a statement to the Army newspaper Stars and Stripes, denied today that Gen. Douglas MacArthur was taking a hand in Japan's Cabinet crisis, in which Communist influence in the new Government has become the principal issue.
Many Americans are still waiting for new automobiles because of an export racket that brings bonuses of $300 to $1,000 a car, it developed yesterday.

GENEVA, May 21 -- Nine members of the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission have agreed that any support given by foreign powers to armed bands in the future should be regarded as a threat to peace or as an act of aggression and should be dealt with under the United Nations Charter chapter relating to enforcement.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Senators pounded three Browns' pitchers for thirteen hits and a 7 -- 3 victory tonight to snap a four-game losing streak.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The controversial wool bill got clearance from the House Rules Committee today and may come up for three hours' floor debate and a possible vote tomorrow.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closed 20 points lower to 13 points higher than on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Congress sent to the White House today its authorization for $350,000,000 of American aid to combat hunger and sickness in liberated but war-devastated countries.

Senate and House conferees are making such excellent progress toward producing a fair and effective draft of the new labor bill that we venture to call attention to one additional point at which improvement could be made. In this case the improvement would consist of dropping entirely a short section which, in somewhat different form, is included in both present versions of the bill.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 21 (AP) -- The president of the American Hospital Association said today that less criticism and more training would solve the country's nurse shortage.

As a result of the first on-the-spot investigation undertaken by the United Nations, an overwhelming majority of the Balkans Investigation Commission has found the Governments of Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania...

GENEVA, May 21. -- Following is the text, subject to minor changes in wording, of the recommendations the majority group of the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission will propose as the commission's final report: Before coming to its actual proposals, the commission felt it would be useful to recapitulate in brief the situation along Greece's northern border which these proposals are designed to alleviate and remedy.
LONDON, May 21 -- Viscount Mountbatten, Viceroy of India, continued his discussions at the India Office here today against a background of increasing violence and political intransigeance in India.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (U.P.) -- Henry J. Kaiser tonight asked the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to take a loss of $85,329,144 on its loan to his steel mill at Fontana, Calif., on the ground that this would enable him to cut prices and compete with the plant of the United States Steel Corporation at Geneva, Utah.
BERLIN, May 21 -- The big stick in the food crisis behind the softspoken appeals directed to Germans by the Military Government was disclosed in four directives today.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 21 -- The working committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission sidestepped another battle of the veto today but agreed with Russian insistence that any atomic development authority must be set up within the framework of the Security Council.

Mrs. Margaret Jannazzo, 31 years old, the mother of two children, was shot and killed yesterday in the hallway at 1502 East New York Avenue, Brooklyn. A few minutes later the police arrested Mrs. Philomena Scavone, 41, of 1 Thatford Avenue, the mother of three children, and charged her with homicide and violation of the Sullivan Law.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Employes who strike against the Government forfeit not only their jobs but their right to undelivered pay for work done before they walk out, Controller General Lindsay C. Warren ruled today.

The public will await with interest Major Haslett's answer to the record of his activities unrelated to his job in the Department of Marine and Aviation, which the Murtagh report declares "inconsistent with the faithful performance of his duties as the director of airports."
PARIS, May 21 -- Accords were signed here today by France, Britain and the United States establishing a basis for commercial exchanges between France and the merged Anglo-American zones of Germany.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 21 -- Four thousand delegates to the 1947 Northern Baptist Convention were told today that they face a "general denominational deterioration" because of an abundance of ministers and a lack of control over them.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 21 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and head of the United Steelworkers Union, today told the 850,000 members of the union in this country and Canada that under no circumstances must there be work stoppages during the life of the two-year agreements reached last month between the union and the steel industry.

Mayor O'Dwyer denied yesterday the request of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, that he name a fact-finding board to weigh a dispute between the union and the Board of Transportation over the board's alleged unfairness in assigning runs on the IND division of the city subway system among 2,000 motormen and conductors.

TORONTO, May 21 (Canadian Press) -- The Toronto Daily Star said today that, in a telephone interview from his home in Chicago, A very Brundage, president of the United States Olympic Committee, said the United States Figure Skating Association should investigate whether the appearance of Boston's Gretchen Ann Merrill in an RKO movie, "Skating Lady," has jeopardized her amateur standing.

The city-owned tunnel under the Park Avenue ramp near Grand Central Terminal, back of the cityoperated Airlines Terminal Annex on Forty-second Street, is used for private offices and a privately owned and operated parking lot, it became known yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., May 21 -- Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper reported today that his special investigation of law enforcement and gambling in Camden had shown evidence of "laxity and inefficiency" among the police.

SEOUL, Korea, May 21 -- The joint United States-Soviet Commission on Korea reconvened here today. In an atmosphere promising cooperation, five American and five Russian delegates met across the conference table in the Duk Soo Palace to begin discussions, the aim of which is fulfillment of the Moscow decision of the Foreign Ministers in 1945.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 21 (AP) -- The outlook improved tonight for settlement of the row keeping a number of big-name race drivers from entering the Indianapolis Motor Speedway's 500-mile Memorial Day race.

Raymond C. Morse, assistant controller of the American Machine and Foundry Company, was elected president of the Brooklyn chapter of the National Association of Cost Accountants at its annual meeting in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Big Five railroad transportation unions have no intention of resorting to a "quickie" strike when the twelve months Truman moratorium on consideration of rules changes expires on May 25, according to Alexander F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.

An advertising program to promote the use of canned meat was presented yesterday by the National Meat Canners Association and approved by the Can Manufacturers Institute and the American Meat Institute in a meeting at the Hotel Biltmore.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A united Democratic minority opened a drive in the Senate today to postpone further consideration of tax reduction until June 10.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- An ex-GI told Senators today that "so many persons" received commissions on steel sold over the mill price that the final seller sometimes loses money.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters will hold their joint ceremonial exercises this afternoon at 3 o'clock at the home of these institutions, 632 West 156th Street. New members will be inducted and grants presented to recipients in the various fields.

Frank (Specs) Shea is fast becoming the new hero of the Yankees. Going the route for the fifth time in five starts, the right-handed rookie from Naugatuck, Conn., shut out the league-leading Tigers with only four hits to end the Bombers' three-game losing streak last night.

Home deliveries of that wholesome cultured milk known as yogurt begin today in Manhattan for the first time. The service will be extended to other boroughs shortly by Lacto Milk Products Company, the country's oldest manufacturer of yogurt.
This is the fourth of six articles by Gen. Mark W. Clark telling of his submarine mission to North Africa in 1942 and his dealings with Admiral Darlan. The fifth will appear tomorrow.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Here are a few comments on your first editorial, of May 13, entitled "Americans Without Homes."
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Fiorello H. La Guardia, former Mayor of New York, filed a $100,000 libel suit today against the National Home and Property Owners Foundation.

The bill to extend aid to Greece and Turkey, which the President is scheduled to sign today under sad and unusual circumstances, sets a line of policy, but its does not set a precedent committing the United States to a blanket program of relief for all nations on the verge of collapse.

Members of the American Iron and Steel Institute were told at their annual meeting here yesterday of the successful development of techniques that will increase pig iron output by 20 per cent and pen-hearth steel production by 25 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Senate War Investigating Committee disclosed tonight that in 1943 the late President Roosevelt directed that some of his personal and confidential files should never be made public, while others were to be sealed for ten to fifty years.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell indicated yesterday his belief that William Hunt Diederich, 63-yearold sculptor of Tappan, N.Y., had violated no Federal statute in sending anti-semitic postcards through the mails and said that he would have a memorandum ready on the subject by 4 P.M. today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Senator Brien McMahon declared today that the United States could not consider the Russian plan for international control of atomic energy and warned that an atomic war was possible if the world failed to agree on the basis of the American proposals.

The final plans for the future headquarters of the United Nations -- a $100,000,000 to $125,000,000 skyscraper center of starkly modern design -- were formally unveiled here yesterday by Wallace K. Harrison, chief planning officer for the international headquarters.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted sixty railroads in the Eastern District and the Pocahontas region the increases which they requested in parlor, sleeping car and coach fares.
PEIPING, China, May 21 -- Government dispatches reaching here today described the situation in the Manchurian fighting at Changchun, the capital, and in the Kungchuling area as "very critical."
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- Todays report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department at Agriculture follows:

With two crews from the Pacific Coast entered, a record number of eleven colleges will compete in the varsity race of the intercollegiate regatta on the Hudson River at Poughkeepsie June 21, it was announced yesterday by Asa Bushnell, Eastern College Athletic Conference director.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Control of the manufacture and use of amidone, a synthetic and relatively new chemical for the relief of pain, was advocated here today on the basis that its use leads to drug addiction. This contention, advanced by five scientists of the United States Public Health Service, was contested by two scientists of the University of Oregon.

Steel furniture buyers who have mill connections enabling them to buy sheet steel have been asked to furnish light gauge sheets for production of their steel desk and office equipment needs, R.B. Hayward, vice-president, Macey-Fowler, Inc., office furniture dealers, disclosed here yesterday.

DETROIT, May 21 -- The first major strike involving any automobile manufacturer in 1947 was called unexpectedly this morning against the Ford Motor Company by the Foremen's Association of America, an independent union.

CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that the country's sugar situation "should be normal by 1948 if it continues to improve as much as it has during the last few months."

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Permission for American steamship lines to operate aircraft as adjuncts to their snipping was recommended today in testimony at a hearing conducted by the President's Advisory Committee on the Merchant Marine.

A vigorous campaign to increase the efficiency of the merchant marine and to enhance its strength by stepping up the nation's waning import volume was proposed last night by Representative Fred Bradley, chairman of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 21 -- Max Seligman, attorney for Dov Bela Gruner, executed terrorist, proposed today that the British administration suspend the operations of military courts in Palestine pending a decision by the United Nations.

PASO DE LOS LIBRES, Argentina, May 21 (U.P.) -- Means of ending the eleven-week-old Paraguayan civil war were discussed by Presidents Peron and Dutra in their meeting here today, according to authoritative Argentine sources.

Net earnings of the Sinclair Oil Corporation this year are larger than they were at the same time last year, H.F. Sinclair, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting held here yesterday. He expressed the hope that the gain would continue for the remainder of this year.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today. Although May wheat gained 1/4 to 1/2 cent a bushel net, distant months were off 1 1/2 to 2 cents at the close, partly in sympathy with corn and on a denial of the rust reports that had considerable influence yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 21 -- The $40,000,000 appropriated by Congress leaves the Children's Emergency Fund with the job of collecting $30,000,000 more from other members of the United Nations, Maurice Pate, executive director of the fund, estimated today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution, which received wide publicity two decades ago over a "black list" of speakers it considered Communistic, started today what might be called a "white list" of national figures commended for opposing communism.

Consolidated Natural Gas At the annual meeting of the Consolidated Natural Gas Company yesterday the stockholders approved an increase in the authorized capital stock of the company from 2,728,359 shares to 3,274,031.

Like a swarm of butterflies the pretty manikins that were engaged to do the Hattie Carnegie Jeune Fille fashion showing yesterday swarmed into and through the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at the luncheon hour. The presentation showed "Town and Country' and "Night and Day" summer fashions.
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- The Cubs defeated the Phillies, 2 to 1, today, sweeping their two-game series and wresting first place in the National League from the idle Giants.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 21 -- Making its first transcontinental flight from Los Angeles, the American Airlines giant four-engine DC-6 flagship Mercury made an instrument landing at 10:35 A.M. today at the municipal airport here after being unable to get into La Guardia Field because of weather conditions. There were fifty-two passengers aboard.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 21 -- Plans for a nation-wide observance of United Nations Week, Sept. 1420, were announced tonight by the American Association for the United Nations at a rally here. At the same time it was made known that the two Westchester County villages of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown had been linked as the model American community for the educational program designed to enlist public support of the world peace body.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 21 -- D. Emmert Brumbaugh, Pennsylvania Secretary of Banking, declared here today that a "real threat" to the private enterprise system of banking was apparent. He asserted that lack of awareness by some bankers of their real responsibilities to the public might contribute heavily to the trend toward nationalization of banking in this country.

Grand jury indictments charging bribery and conspiracy in connection with irregularities in the leasing of city-owned piers will be sought next week by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, it was reliably reported yesterday.
SECURITY COUNCIL Meets today at 10:30 A.M. to consider Italy's application for membership in United Nations and to continue discussion of Greek question (open).

NEW DELHI, India, May 21 (Reuters) -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah, President of the Moslem League, called today for an alliance of friendship and reciprocity between Pakistan (Moslem India) and Hindustan (Hindu India).

Mrs. Mary Ann Giglio, 28 years old, of 9 Thompson Place, Coney Island, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Coney Island. Court to a charge of endangering the life and health of her 4-year-old son, Robert, who was found naked, bound hand and foot and locked in his room.
NANKING, May 21 -- The "peace offensive" in the People's Political Council got off to a tentative start today as council members began a round of speeches on national problems.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, May 21 -- The Left-Wing parties' indecisiveness left the North Rhine-Westphalia without an elected government today. Following the lead set in Lower Saxony's legislature, the parliament here became the second elected body in the British zone to shirk the responsibility of setting up cabinet rule.

The stock market seized upon several morsels of news yesterday to stage the best recovery of the month in which prices were bid up from 1 to 3 points in the Industrials and the composite rate increased 1.23 points. Although there had been no expectation that American Telephone would not maintain its dividend rate, the mere confirmation of the usual payment apparently inspired considerable buying confidence which developed during the fourth hour.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 21 -- Top leaders of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America expressed their warm approval tonight of Russo-American dealings since the end of the war and will ask for a vote of confidence during the 159th General Assembly opening in the Civic Auditorium tomorrow.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (AP) -- The Athletics, handcuffed for seven innings, exploded a five-run rally in the eighth tonight for a 5-2 victory over the White Sox before 9,846.

JERUSALEM, May 21 -- Haganah, which has long been sitting on the sidelines merely watching developments, sent a punitive expedition last night against Arab brigands operating against Jewish settlers in the Petah Tiqva area near Tel Aviv. One Arab was killed, three were seriously wounded and four were slightly injured.

Senator James E. Murray of Montana last night attacked the Taft and Hartley Republican, labor bills, now before Congress, as punitive anti-labor legislation which "strikes at the legislative rights of our working people and would render them helpless to resist the drive of a few giant corporations for even greater power than they now have in running our economy."

CLEVELAND, May 21 (AP) -- President Bill Veeck of the Indians disclosed tonight that American League President William Harridge had warned him he would forfeit Friday's scheduled night game here with the Browns if the Indians were unable to provide a suitable playing field.

MEXICO CITY, May 21 -- Mexico's national railroad system is operating on a monthly deficit of $1,300,000, Mamiel R. Palacios, general manager, disclosed today. But, he continued, the national railways will continue to enforce a strict economy policy throughout the system.

Participation in "systematic efforts to destroy the public housing movement in New York City" was charged to Robert Moses yesterday by Nathan Straus, former administrator of the United States Housing Administration. The City Construction Coordinator declined to comment on Mr. Straus' statement, which read:
LONDON, May 21 -- How deeply the British Labor party is discouraged by Russian hostility was shown today when the party issued a pamphlet on the Government's foreign policy.

BERLIN May 21 -- The American Military Government took strong exception today to published remarks by a group of American business men who, after a tour of the American and British zones, assailed certain economic policies.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 21 -- Lowell B. Mason, of the Federal Trade Commission, said today that the great need for American businessmen is intelligible rules written in the language of the shop which interpret the Federal Trade Commission and the anti-trust laws in terms of the specific problems that each industry faces.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., May 21 -- A slate of recommendations for reviving the Federal tax structure to make it more consistent with the maintenance of a freeenterprise system was adopted today by the board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association at the association's spring conference at the French Lick Springs Hotel here.
PARIS, May 21 -- The Cabinet approved today the World Bank's $250,000,000 loan to France, which has been much criticized in the press and will probably be criticized in the National Assembly.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial in the times of May 12, "How to Measure Loyalty," amounts to nothing more than a pious hope that Truman's order to screen federal employes will be fairly administered. It fails, however, to note that democracy has come to a bad pass indeed when we must rely upon hope and trust for justice and fairness.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A provision for putting a ceiling on initiation and membership fees of unions was reported to be informally agreed on today by Senate-House conferees adjusting differences in the labor bills passed by the two chambers.

Mayor O'Dwyer ordered yesterday a survey of the organization policies of the city's Welfare Department as a result of the discovery that thirty-seven families were housed in mid-town hotels as recipients of home relief. In taking the action the Mayor made it plain that it was not in criticism of the administration of Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan.

The terrace fringing Central Park Lake north of the Seventysecond Street cross-drive will be dedicated as "Navy Terrace" on Saturday, as Naval Reserve Week draws to a close, it was announced yesterday.

"IT can be said that I am now writing historical novels." That's What P.G. Wodehouse told a head-hunter from this paper's Sunday Book Review the other day. It's a good remark, and it puts the world of Jeeves and Bertie Wooster and Blandings Castle in perspective. But it raises a question. And the question is whether that world ever really existed on this earth at all.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 -- Warner Brothers has borrowed Shirley Temple from David O. Selznick to play the title role in "Mary Hagen," with Ronald Reagan, the studio announced today. Miss Temple will replace Geraldine Brooks, a Warner contract actress, who had previously been named for the picture.

Coca Cola International A rare appearance was made yesterday on the ticker tape of the New York Stock Exchange by one of the most expensive listed stocks when Coca Cola International Corporation flashed on at $1,150 a share, an increase of $680 from the last previous transfer early in 1942.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Votes in collective bargaining elections show a setback to the power of organized labor. In about every fourth election conducted by the National Labor Relations Board, employes have voted for "no union."
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee gave its unanimous approval today to legislation authorizing the State Department to conduct a foreign information and educational program.

Airy brush strokes distinguish a new group of drapery and upholstery fabrics shown yesterday by Stan Taylor at his printing plant, 301 East Twenty-second Street. The new prints are made by a variety of hand techniques combined to lend pleasant variations to silkscreened fabrics.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined last week an additional 1,141,000 barrels, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute, issued yesterday. At the close of the week total supplies were 99,793,000 barrels, compared with 100,934,000 a week earlier and 96,206,000 a year ago.

The university of Chicago Round Table, one of the older and more popular discussion programs, is to undergo a rather drastic change of schedule locally, beginning Sunday. For many years an early Sunday afternoon feature on WNBC, it is to be heard hereafter at 11:30 at night.

Wendell Berge, former Assistant Attorney General in charge of the anti-trust division, urged a "real dose of competition" last night to cure the nation's economic ills. He warned of a business slump unless prices were reduced, and of the loss of political and economic freedom unless the concentration of power in industry was stopped.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Twenty-four executives of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, headed by Darryl F. Zanuck, plan to offer to the public up to 234,300 shares of the corporation's stock which they acquired or have the right to buy under options, according to a registration statement filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recently THE NEW YORK TIMES published an item filed from Warsaw about "Four Peasant Party Men Sentenced in Poland." It deals with the sentencing of Kazimierz Baginski and three other "party men" by a military court.
United States Marine Corps Aviation is thirty-five years old today.

JEFFERSON, Iowa, May 21 -- Harold E. Stassen put forth tonight a broad Production for Peace Program, including the setting aside of 10 per cent of the United States' total national production of goods and foods for the next ten years to build world-wide peace, plenty and freedom.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Wallace H. White, Jr. of Maine, Republican leader of the Senate, protested today when Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, announced plans to speed up hearings of the St. Lawrence seaway proposal.

WARSAW, May 21 -- Both Socialist and Communist party leaders emphasized today that their recent public clashes on economic policies should not be interpreted as the beginning of the end of the coalition government in Poland.

Fifteen boys and girls, 7 to 12 years old, will turn back their text books 250 years tomorrow at the formal opening by the Staten Island Historical Society of the restored Voorlezer's House in Richmond, Staten Island. The building constructed before 1696, was used as church, school, and residence of the "voorlezer," or lay reader and teacher of the Dutch congregation.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A drastic revision of Federal patent policy to require government ownership and non-exclusive free licensing of publicly financed scientific experimentation is recommended in a report to President Truman by Attorney General Tom Clark, which will be made public by the White House soon.

ST. LOUIS, May 21 -- Staging one of their old-time thrillers that kept 16,249 fans on the edges of their seats until the final out, the Dodgers and Cards battled for ten innings today, with the Brooks emerging victorious, 4 -- 3.
PARIS, May 21 (U.P.) -- Some of France's largest provincial cities seethed today with strikes and riots for more bread and against Government economic control and "interference."

KANSAS CITY, May 21 -- Although his mother told him today she was feeling better than she had for some time, President Truman has not yet discussed plans for returning to the White House. He continues to arrange for the transaction of urgent official business from his suite in the Hotel Muehlebach here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Service for the Living Is the Greatest Memorial to the Dead." This is the motto of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York, Inc., a permanent center for enlisted men at 283 Lexington Avenue, between Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets.

Luck was with the American astronomical expedition that stationed itself at Bocayuva in Brazil to observe Tuesday's total eclipse of the sun. The clouds that hovered in the sky were providentially pushed away, so that the astronomers were able to carry out their program.
ROME, May 21 -- Former Premier Francesco Saverio Nitti had to confess defeat today in his efforts to solve the Cabinet crisis, and formally declined the mandate to form a new Government.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 21 -- Neither rain nor fog could stop them as fourteen players braved the elements to open the Women's Long Island Golf Association tournament season at the Piping Rock Club here today.

MONTREAL, May 21 -- With Greece protesting that her plea for help in re-establishing the Hellenikon airport near Athens had brought no action in eighteen months, the assembly of the International Civil Aviation Organization today adopted two resolutions designed to formalize and speed procedures in such cases. It also provided for the election of its permanent council at a session of the assembly tomorrow.

A portrait bust of the late Wendell L. Willkie was presented yesterday to the Council on Foreign Affairs by John W. Davis, like Mr. Willkie a one-time candidate for President of the United States, on behalf of Mrs. Willkie. About 125 persons attended the presentation ceremonies at the council's headquarters, the Harold Pratt House, 58 East Sixty-eighth Street.

Awards in the "British Empire" and "Other Countries" classes at the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition in the Grand Central Palace were made yesterday by the international jury headed by Rear Admiral Frederic R. Harris, USN, retired.
GREENVILLE, S.C., May 21 -- A Southern jury of twelve white men returned a verdict of not guilty on all counts against all of their twenty-eight neighbors on trial here for the lynching of a Negro.

The Council of the American Psychiatric Association at the APA's annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday adopted a resolution urging Congress to increase the appropriation for the medical program of the Veterans Administration "beyond the amount submitted in the budget."

LONDON, May 21 -- King George has not yet begun the elaborate constitutional procedure that must precede any formal announcement of Princess Elizabeth's engagement to Lieut. Philip Mountbatten, it was learned today. It must therefore be supposed that the announcement cannot take place this month, as has been widely reported.

Mayor O'Dwyer officially opened the 1947 Buddy Poppy campaign of the Veterans of Foreign Wars yesterday by purchasing the first flower from Vincent J. Stickles Jr., the 2-year-old son of Capt. Vincent J. Stickles of Kearny, N.J.

A profusion of spring flowers embellished the regular monthly meeting and exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York yesterday afternoon at headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue. They showed no signs of having been affected by the recent unfavorable weather.

Many clergymen of the Episcopal Diocese of New York are expressing a growing resentment at what they see as the repeated snubbing of their Bishop, the Right Rev. Charles Kendall Gilbert, within the last fortnight by the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity parish.
Eleven temples believed to have been built by Mayan Indians about 1,000 years ago have been discovered in the dense jungle near Mexico's southern border, it was announced here yesterday.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 21 (AP) -- A.L. Cornwell, president of F.W. Woolworth Co., told stockholders at the annual meeting today that an increasing number of price reductions from suppliers will enable the company to keep existing merchandise and future purchases at current prices.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 21 -- The Soviet Union is now making its major bid to gain overwhelming predominance in the permanent control of the Hungarian economy.

UNTIL the Boston Red Sox rudely held him hitless in ten trips to the plate on Monday, Detroit's Patrick Joseph Mullin was one of the members of that fast-vanishing breed, the 400 hitters in the big leagues. The big Mullin bat had exploded with such force from the season's opener that he had practically lifted the Tigers to the top of the American League standing.
Random notes. The striped bass have arrived at Montauk Point. Although they are not plentiful or large, more and larger fish should follow very shortly.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The British Embassy inquired of London today whether any responsible official inspired the Associated Press dispatch from that capital Monday which recounted that "informed British sources * * * close to the War Office" were saying:

Harry Young's comedy, "Open House," in which Mary Boland will return to Broadway in the role of a sort of Mrs. Fix-it, will make its local debut at the Cort Theatre the week of June 2, according to an announcement made yesterday by Rex Carlton, producer. The production is now in rehearsal under the direction of Coby Ruskin and next Monday will commence a week's trial run at the Locust Street Theatre in Philadelphia.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Representatives of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., announced late today, following a conference with the staff of the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, that an amended plan of reorganization would be filed by the corporation tomorrow in connection with the proceedings now pending before the commission.

Cotton Week Observed Widely Reports from retail centers indicate that Cotton Week, which began on Monday, is being more widely observed than at any time in the last five years, according to The Cotton-Textile Institute and National Cotton Council, sponsors of the event.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A sustained decline in volunteer enlistments since the end of January, it was learned today, has whittled the Army down to 1,070,000 men six weeks ahead of the date set for reaching that figure.

The textile industry is entitled to legal recognition of the inviolability of original textile designs, according to the briefs filed by industry representatives at the House Judiciary Subcommittee hearings in Washington on the textile design bill.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Chairman Charles W. Tobey of the Senate Banking Committee said tonight that the doors of the committee were "open" to Jesse Jones, former Federal Loan Administrator, to "rebut" allegations that "impugned" his administration.
Fog rolled in on Blemont Park yesterday, visibility was not much above zero during the first half of the program, and the Widener Course was an even more mysterious place than usual.

A resolution which would make available $2,000 to the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association to establish a research foundation for retailing was adopted last night at the meeting of the Metropolitan Controllers Association in the Hotel Martinique.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 21 (AP) -- The bodies of two high Army flying officers and five others were found today in the wreckage of their B-25 bomber which crashed in a cornfield during a violent thunderstorm last night.

LONDON, May 21 -- William Gallacher, Communist member of the House of Commons, was ignored today during a discussion of Palestine when he asked this question: "In view of the fact that the mandate laid it down that Palestine was to be provided as a home for the Jews how then could there be such a thing as an 'illegal immigrant' ?"

Initiating a new merchandising policy designed to conform with present-day consumer needs, the Dutchess Underwear Corporation yesterday announced a complete revision of its price schedule, effective immediately. Comparison of the new and old price charts show reductions ranging up to 13 per cent.

LONDON, May 21 -- With cessation of selling and the appearance of some buyers, stock markets were more cheerful today. The volume of actual buying was small but the change in sentiment, after the last two bad days, was sufficient to cause an appreciable allround rally in industrial shares.
JERUSALEM, May 21 -- The Zionists will present two prime requests to the United Nations' factfinding commission when it begins hearings here.
The State of Tennessee announced yesterday that it will receive bids on June 10 on an issue of bonds totaling $10,605,000.

TRENTON, N.J., May 21 (AP) -- Breakage -- the system whereby tracks do not pay winners in horse race betting any change over five cents on the dollar -- was called "larceny by statute" by Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper today.

Coming Bond Issues Underwriting houses are sitting out the latest sinking spell in the securities markets with crossed fingers because it will not be long before major financing deals will insist upon coming to market, regardless of almost anything.

A relatively heavy decline in loans to non-brokers for the purchase of United States Government obligations during the week ended on Wednesday was disclosed yesterday by the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System.

Taking advantage of a new law, State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi signed yesterday dispensations allowing contractors engaged on public projects costing $40,000,000 to employ their workers more than forty hours a week.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee voted unanimously today to adopt the title of "National Security Establishment" to designate the single Defense Department proposed in the pending bill for unification of the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Representative Adolph J. Sabath of Illinois told the House today that "outrageous, crooked dealings" are going on in Wall Street that may lead to another crash. He said he would introduce a bill to put a 5 per cent tax on all short sales of securities.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- An agreement in principle on a sharp anti-Communist clause was reached today by Senate-House conferees as they neared the end of their job of compromising the divergent labor bills passed by the two chambers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 22 -- Delegates of the Big Four erased today the laboriously gathered list of candidates for the Governorship of Trieste and prepared to start all over again in their search for the right man.

BERLIN, May 22 (AP) -- As ships from America unloaded food in German ports today, United States economists predicted that American taxpayers would have to foot a bill of $750,000,000 in 1948 for feeding 46,000,000 Germans in the western zones.

If the young children of the United States are to receive the full value of elementary education, the school systems throughout the nation must stop emphasizing educational regimentation and discard large school units, Dr. Howard A. Lane, Professor of Education at the New York University School of Education, declared yesterday.

The popularity of disk jockey shows was further evidenced last night when WMCA announced that it had signed the new Tommy Dorsey transcribed program for a five-year period, beginning Sept. 8. The trombone player and orchestra leader will interview guest stars and play records for a twohour session daily, the time of day that his program will be heard not yet having been decided.

A clean sweep of all positions in Wednesday's student and class council elections at City College's main center, 139th Street and Convent Avenue, was achieved by the Student Liberal party, opponents of American Youth for Democracy, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank K. Shuttleworth, associate dean of students.

KANSAS CITY, May 22 -- With a pledge that the United States will act, as well as talk, in support of the United Nations, President Truman signed the GreekTurkish aid bill in his emergency executive office in the Hotel Muehlbach here today.
As the Dodgers returned from their not too successful western swing last night there was deep concern about the condition of two important players -- Eddie Stanky and Bruce Edwards.

Giving a gloomy description of the plight of the Jewish people in Europe, Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the $170,000,000 United Jewish Appeal campaign, deplored yesterday the liquidation of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Adminstration, which ends its operations in Europe June 30.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 6,000 head, total 10,000; market slow, around steady on weights under 300 pounds and on sows; barrows and gilts over 300 pounds, dull and around 25 cents lower;

The jury which has acquitted the twenty-eight defendants in the Greenville, S.C., lynching trial must have justified its verdict on one of two grounds. The textile workers, the farmer, the mechanic, the salesman and the divinity student who made up this jury believed that the defendants did not take Willie Earle from the Pickens County Jail on the night of Feb. 17 and put him to death.

BERLIN, May 22 -- The stumbling bi-zonal economic merger of the American and British zones has turned out to be a major obstacle to a tri-zonal merger including the French zone, it was indicated today.

Elmer Haslett, suspended city airports director, played a game of monopoly with the city's tunnel under the Park Avenue ramp back of the city's Airline Terminal Annex at Grand Central Terminal, inquiry disclosed yesterday.

NANKING, May 22 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's policies in Japan were attacked today by members of the Peoples Political Council in a discussion of China's foreign relations. This followed a report by Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh.

Just after midnight yesterday firemen ran into a three-story loft building at 472 Fulton Street in lower Brooklyn where smoke and flame poured from the windows. On the first landing they stumbled across a dead man.
PARIS, May 22 -- In order to fill the manpower gap caused by the release of German prisoners, France has begun an intensive drive to recruit displaced persons in Germany and Austria.
Another clash between the Board of Transportation and Mayor O'Dwyer appeared imminent yesterday. The board, apparently ignoring a report and recommendations prepared by...

"Unless American industry succeeds in "re-selling our own people on the fundamentals of our way of life," another crisis created by war or business depression will bring nationalization of industry and mediocrity for everybody in the United States, Dr. George S. Benson, president of Harding College, Searcy, Ark., warned members of the American Iron and Steel Institute last night.

A shortage of nurses at St. Luke's Hospital, an Episcopalian institution at Amsterdam Avenue and 113th Street, was emphasized at commencement exercises of the hospital's school of nursing yesterday afternoon as a challenge to members of its graduating class to take positions on the hospital staff to help in the emergency.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 17 were 11 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

ATLANTA, May 22 (AP) -- Officials of eight Negro newspapers meeting here today sent telegrams to President Truman, Attorney General Clark and three members of Congress, protesting against the Greenville verdict.

Reductions up to 25 per cent in the prices of jams and preserves which were announced by the New York Preservers Association are the first indication that lower prices are now being based on lower replacement costs, food men stated yesterday.

MANILA, May 22 -- An irreparable split between American and Filipino members of a joint financial commission appointed to determine whether the Philippines should get further American loans was reported tonight by the Manila Daily Bulletin.

ROME, May 22 -- After a day of alternate optimism and pessimism, 87-year-old former Premier Vittorio Emanuele Orlando was forced to conclude that he was powerless to help the solution of the Cabinet crisis in any way.

THE sports historians seemingly are bent on establishing baseball's private 5-foot shelf with a series of books on the-various big league teams. So far, we've had volumes on Yankees, Giants, Dodgers, Cardinals, Athletics, Tigers and Cubs. The latest addition to the collection is Fred Lieb's "The Boston Red Sox," which is published by Putnam's.

KEY WEST, Fla., May 22 -- This sun-drenched Key and the bluegreen waters around it are the vast stage for dramatic developments that will certainly modify and may completely alter the whole art of war at sea. Key West and its nexus of naval activities is the center of the Navy's submarine and anti-submarine development work and where that may lead, no man can now say.

SEATTLE, May 22 (AP) -- Leadership in the world's scientific fields "has been thrust into our hands and we are hardly ready to assume the responsibility," Dr. L.A. DuBridge, president of the California Institute of Technology, declared today in recommending Federal financial aid for science.

SCHROON LAKE, N.Y., May 22 -- Strong sentiment for endorsing the stand taken by Senator Irving M. Ives of New York on proposed changes in the National Labor Relations Act was manifest among early arrivals for the annual convention of the Association of New York State young Republican Clubs which gets under way at Schroon Manor here tomorrow.

Characterizing Serge M. Rubinstein, international financier, as "an undesirable alien," Federal Judge John C. Knox denied a plea yesterday that he recommend to the Attorney General that Rubinstein not be deported when he has finished his two-and-a-half year sentence for draft evasion.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- E.A. Kerschbaumer, Pittsburgh steel broker, told attentive but somewhat confused Senators today that "apparent gangsters" backed up a demand on him in New York for steel he couldn't deliver.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 22 (AP) -- The New York Conference of the Methodist Church began a four-day meeting today and heard reports that conference membership was now the highest in the 148 years of Conference history.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., May 22 -- A new device known as the electromatic speed meter, utilizing war-developed radar and capable of clocking automobile speeds, has been perfected by engineers of the Eastern Industries at the Automatic Signal Division plant here.

SCHEVENINGEN, the Netherlands, May 22 -- The International Federation of Agricultural Producers announced this afternoon the results of policy negotiations carried on over the past ten days. This marked the highlight and was virtually the finale of the first regular conference to be held by the group, established a year ago.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- A new approach to the study of high blood pressure, by observing the appetites of afflicted rats, may possibly help man discover how to avoid the condition, two Harvard Medical School physiologists reported to the convention.
LONDON, May 22 -- Although the approach of the Whitsun holiday affected business in stock markets today, the general undertone was good.
ROME, May 22 -- The Vatican Press Office today denied charges made by the Yugoslav legation in Warsaw that the Holy See was opposing and preventing the arrest of war criminals.

As a curb to the resale of new cars by individual owners many automobile dealers in the New York area are planning to obtain agreements before delivery guaranteeing to them the sole right of repurchase, it was said yesterday by Verne Murray, first vice president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Prudence Anne Tallman, daughter of Mrs. Inez Foster Tallman of 103 East Seventy-fifth Street and of Frank Gifford Tallman Jr. of Wilmington, Del., to Duard Geis Slattery, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Slattery of Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

The proposed sale of $52,200,000 of State of Connecticut veterans' bonus and University of Connecticut bonds will be held on June 24, the state announced yesterday. The sale, originally posted for May 27, was put off to allow the state authorities to make a change in the interest payment dates.

BOSTON, May 22 -- The membership of the American Unitarian Association by an overwhelming voice vote today sustained the action of its board of directors in its recent dismissal of the Rev. Stephen H. Fritchman as editor of The Christian Register.

GENEVA, Switzerland, May 22 -- A motion by Chile to amend the world trade charter to enable the creation of new fiscal preferences among immediate neighbor countries was rejected today after two days' hard debate in which it was opppsed as contrary to the charter's spirit.
SEOUL, Korea, May 22 -- The first closed session of the Joint United States-Soviet commission to establish a provisional Government for Korea, was held this afternoon.
