A year ago steel production was held up for four weeks because the union and the employers could not agree on a wage increase. This year President Philip Murray of the CIO and also of the United Steelworkers Union reached a two-year agreement with the steel companies.

A single city-wide drive for $455,000 will be conducted this fall by the Young Women's Christian Associations of Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens to replace the three separate drives conducted in former years, Mrs. Edward Perry Townsend, president of the New York City (Manhattan and Bronx) Y.W.C.A., announced yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 23 (AP) -- Babe Ruth is finding the road back to health a long journey, but the way is being eased by a kind host and leisurely days spent sunning or resting beneath palm trees and an occasional game of golf or fishing trip.

According to a dispatch to this newspaper from Geneva, Switzerland, where the International Trade Conference is proceeding, the American delegates have held eleven meetings with the British and five with the Canadians, but have met only once with the Australians.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals bunched half of their eight hits in the seventh inning for three runs and a 4-1 triumph over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight in a four-game series opener which drew 14,034 paying fans.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (AP) -- The Indianapolis Motor Speedway management smoothed the way tonight for holdout members of the American Society of Professional Automobile Racers to get in the 500-mile race on May 30, and ASPAR leaders planned to poll their members quickly on the new proposals.

MONTREAL, May 22 -- The International Civil Aviation Organization had before it again today the British Labor Government's plan for the operation of all the air lines of the world by a single chosen instrument.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Some lawyers who read today a decision in the Federal district court here on the rights of Congress to seek information it considers pertinent to any of its activities believe that, if tested, the decision will be upheld in the Supreme Court.

An old-time school, the Voorlezer's House in Richmond, S.I., built by Dutch settlers 250 years ago, reopens today. A typical Dutch school session will be re-enacted by fifteen children in costume this morning from 9:30 to 11:30 o'clock.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 22 -- The acquittal last night of all defendants in the South's biggest lynching trial brought public reaction in this textile center today which followed precisely the pattern that developed when the crime was committed.

TOKYO, May 22 -- Unidentified Japanese loot held here will be sold and its proceeds devoted to financing essential imports, if plans now under consideration go through. Among such imports wool, rubber and tin would have first priorities.

JERUSALEM, May 22 -- David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, who recently returned from the United States, indicated strongly tonight that the Zionists might accept the partition of Palestine under certain circumstances and that they realized that a Zionist state in the whole country was not practicable now.

ROME, May 22 -- Jacob I. Trobe, director of Italian operations for the American Joint Distribution Committee, called attention today to the plight of 25,000 displaced Jews in Italy at the end of June when the UNRRA ceases operations.

Government controls over goods going into international trade will have to be continued for some time, not as instruments of economic warfare, but to expand production, broaden markets and speed development of international economic life, Thomas C. Blaisdell Jr., assistant to the Secretary of Commerce for international trade, said yesterday.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 22 -- Wilbur LaRoe Jr., head of the legal firm of Clark and LaRoe of Washington, D.C., was elected today as moderator of the 159th general assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

WASHINGTON; May 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 17 were 888,208 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 3,966 cars, or 0.4 per cent more than for the preceding week, 199,998 cars, or 29.1 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 19,294 cars, or 2.2 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

CLEVELAND, May 22 (AP) -- The first round of the "battle of the mud" ended today with all participants apparently happy, for the Indians received the "go-ahead" to play the St. Louis Browns tomorrow night in the Cleveland Stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States recommended to the President's advisory committee on the merchant marine today a continuation of the policies embodied in the 1936 law, based on private ownership and operation, with Government regulation and support.
LONDON, May 22 -- Izvestia long and bitter attack against Mr. Bevin this morning was broadcast in full over the Moscow radio.

In a unique showing, held yesterday afternoon in the Sherry Netherlands Hotel, a complete Paris couturier collection and copies of it were presented to a group of representatives of the press and department stores.

The proposals contained in the bill, H.R. 2,800, which would permit Federal Savings and Loan Associations to make unsecured loans is opposed by the American Bankers. Association, it was announced here yesterday. The ABA, it was explained, has filed a statement with the House Committee on Banking and Currency, asserting that the proposals constitute "a departure from the natural and proper field of operations" of the savings and loan groups.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., May 21 (AP) -- In a pulse-stirring blanket finish Cedar Farm's Black Gang stuck to his running guns long enough to stave off Bobanet Stable's Ariel Song and Mrs. Ella K. Bryson's Neddiecan today. In the Liberty Grove Purse Black Gang won by a head while a neck back of Ariel Song was Neddiecan.

The Knott Corporation, operator of a chain of hotels, cleared about $360,000 in the first four months of this year, William J. Knott, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday. In the 1946 period earnings were $351,000.

Thomas E. Dewey's campaign statements in favor of the Wagner Labor Relations Act, when he was running for President in 1944 against Franklin D. Roosevelt, were quoted against him last night by Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., speaking at a rally of Americans for Democratic Action at the St. Nicholas Arena, 69 West Sixtysixth Street.

The historic and spiritual ties that bind Trinity Church here to the mother church in England were stressed at a dinner given last night by the twenty-two church wardens and vestrymen at the Plaza Hotel, marking the end of ceremonies commemorating the 250th anniversary of the founding of Trinity Parish.
John H. Gividen, superintendent of the Dunbar Furniture Manufacturing Company from 1937 to 1942, has rejoined the company as executive vice president and a member of the board.

WARSAW, May 22 -- Vice Premier Wladyslaw Gomulka said today that the time was propitious for the reorganization of PolishAmerican relations. He expressed the opinion that the American attitude toward Poland's new western frontiers was the "most important problem that contributed to the deterioriation" of those relations.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell issued yesterday an eleven-page opinion holding that William Hunt Diederich, Tappan, N.Y., sculptor, could not be held on a criminal complaint because he had mailed postcards of a nature libelous and defamatory of Jews.
CLEVELAND, May 22 -- The Mid-America Exposition opened its doors today and invited the nation to inspect the latest scientific and industrial wonders.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It would seem vital that any reduction in the rates applicable to individual income should be made in such a manner as to implement to the highest degree purchasing power, and purchasing power which would be utilized to the highest degree.
President Truman, in a congratulatory letter to Abraham Cahan, founder and editor in chief of The Jewish Daily Forward, has extolled the services of that newspaper.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Paul H. Griffith, National Commander of the American Legion, told the Daughters of the American Revolution tonight that immigration has become a "lawless torrent," robbing the veteran and creating a fifth column.

MOSCOW, May 22 (U.P.) -- Izvestia, the Government newspaper organ, charged today that Great Britain was trying to weaken the obligations of her alliance with Russia in current negotiations to revise the treaty.

The local harness-racing season will start tonight at the Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I. A crowd of 20,000 fans is expected to be on hand for the session that will mark the beginning of the eighth consecutive year in which the trotters and pacers have been on view in the metropolitan area.

Sympathetic foster parents and a humanity-wise court successfully joined efforts yesterday to brush aside legal barriers and return to a Queens mother the 6-weeks-old baby girl which, while ill and in grief, she had assigned to a charity organization for adoption shortly after the child's birth.
With no breeze to stir it into life, the rain poured straight down yesterday, as silent and impassive as the shabby men walking to the shabby building in East Twentyfifth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Two series of diplomatic negotiations are being conducted to clear the way for placing the Greek-Turkish aid program into operation now that President Truman has signed the bill.

Stamps portraying religious subjects and others illustrating poems and quotations from the collection of Francis Cardinal Spellman won one of the awards announced by Rear Admiral Frederic R. Harris, USN, retired, at the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition in the Grand Central Palace yesterday.

ALBANY, May 22 -- Describing the plan as a major step toward better government, Governor Dewey approved today a state-sponsored program for specialized training in public administration for men and women graduate students and for state employes.

PARIS, May 22 -- An agreement between the French Government and the World Bank for a loan to France of $250,000,000 was submitted to Parliament today and was immediately approved by the Assembly's Finance Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The "Freedom Train" will start from Philadelphia Sept 17 with its display of priceless United States historical documents on a yearlong journey throughout the nation, Attorney General Tom C. Clark announced today.

By afternoon of Nov. 10, and before the 3 P.M. time of my GiraudDarlan meeting, the news came from Vichy that Marshal HenriPhilippe Petain had fired Darlan as head of the armed forces. He appointed Gen. Alphonse Nogues, Governor General of Morocco, as Darlan's successor.

AMSTERDAM, May 22 (Aneta) -- Trading was light on the Stock Exchange as prices continued irregularly lower. Industrial stocks declined, while shipping shares were higher. Banking stocks and Indies plantations issues were steady. Netherlands State bonds held firm.

Leaders of this country's marine Industry and representatives of Government and maritime labor joined forces throughout the nation yesterday in the fourteenth annual observance of National Maritime Day. Speakers here and in other cities called for a strong American merchant marine as indispensable in peace and necessary in any future emergency.

An expedition will leave the United States about July 15 to investigate the mystery of strange half-ape, half-man fossils found near Johannesburg, South Africa, it was announced yesterday. Organized almost single-handedly by a 25-year-old University of California graduate student, it is now backed by Premier Jan Christiaan Smuts of South Africa, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, President Robert G. Sproul of the University of California, leading American anthropologists and American industrial concerns.

Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil expressed the view last night that the present deadlock between the United States and Russia, even if continued over a period of years, would not lead to war between the two countries.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 22 -- A Soviet resolution to restrict the activities of a subcommission on the watch for new frontier incidents in the Balkans was rejected today by the United Nations Security Council. The vote was 6 to 2, with the Soviet Union and Poland in the minority, and Colombia, France and Syria abstaining.

A happily appropriate choice has been made in appointing the Hudson River villages of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown to serve as a "model community" for a week's educational program to enlist enthusiasm and support for the United Nations. From Sept. 14 to 20 national and even international attention will be centered on this community in Westchester County twentyfive miles north of Grand Central Station.

Backs Regional Board Plan The National Coat said Suit Industry Recovery Board announced yesterday that it Was in accord with the proposal of the National Retail Dry Goods Association to establish regional arbitration boards for settlement of controversies arising from cancellations and returns.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration made "a rough guess" today that 200,000 World War II veterans, fradulently or through error, had cashed in on unemployment or subsistence benefits which are not due them.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Ex-Congressman Andrew J. May said today that he plugged for an Army commission for a friend of Murray Garsson after being told that Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt had originally sponsored the application.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, declared yesterday that corporate business management, dominated by "indirect elections and proxy voting," is far more conducive to autocratic action than is the union system of elections.

At a joint ceremony yesterday afternoon the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters normally presented fifteen $1,000 grants, made four special awards and inducted thirteen new members into the Institute and three into the Academy.

BOSTON, May 22 -- A bit travelworm after their long train haul from Cincinnati but otherwise in fine physical trim, the Giants arived here today. They are to pick up where they left off in the West when they engage the Braves tomorrow afternoon in the opener of a week-end series.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan broadened yesterday his investigation of alleged irregularities in connection with the leasing of city piers and airport facilities, and assigned additional members of his staff to the task of questioning witnesses.

NANKING, May 22 (AP) -- The Chinese Government rushed planes and two armies of reinforcements to the defense of Manchuria today as Communists conducted daring raids inside the beleaguered capital city of Changchun and cut rail links with the metropolis of Mukden.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 22 -- Radio listeners of the world, showing complete trust in the powers of the United Nations, are asking the organization to hunt for used cars, find hard-to-get wireless sets and get rid of unpopular governments.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set June 24 for a hearing at which it will conduct an investigation into the relationships, past and present, between the Market Street Railways Company of San Francisco and its parent, the Standard Gas and Electric Company.

Melio Bettina, the Beacon (N.Y.) left-hander who hopes to fight for the heavyweight championship of the world in September, will have an opportunity to further his cause when he tackles Gus Lesnevich of Cliffside, N.J., at Madison Square Garden tonight.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 21 (Delayed) -- Now that the American loan has been guaranteed and the first burst of enthusiasm has gone, Turks have become more outspoken over the merits and demerits of President Truman's policy.
ATHENS, May 22 -- War Minister Dimitrios Stratos said in Larissa that "the main body of the bandit formations has been dispersed and the threat to the nation has been liquidated."

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 21 (Delayed) -- Juliu Maniu, leader of the Opposition National Peasant party, denied today that a Fascist movement existed within Rumania, as alleged by the Government in justification for the arrest of hundreds of members of the three parties opposed to the Communistdominated regime.

A portrait in oil of Bert Lahr in the costume he uses in the first act of "Burlesque" will be unveiled this evening at an after-theatre party to be held on the stags of the Belasco Theatre. The painting is by Walt Kuhn and will be shown beginning Monday at the DurandRuel Gallery.

The Board of Estimate adopted yesterday a resolution requesting the World Trade Corporation, a state-chartered, non-profit corporation, to make an engineering and expert survey of the city's public and private waterfront installations, with the understanding that a definitive proposal would be submitted to the board by Aug. 31.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (U.P.) -- The advantages of speedy, comfortable and almost noiseless transportation in huge dirigibles were set forth today by President Truman's Air Coordinating Committee.

Five more newspapers have signed contracts as basic members of the American Newspaper Advertising Network, it was announced yesterday. They are: the Little Rock (Arkansas) Democrat and Fort Worth Star-Telegram -- Southwest region; Long Beach Press-Telegram and Tacoma News Tribune -- Pacific region; St. Paul Dispatch Pioneer Press -- Central region.
KANSAS CITY, May 22 -- President Truman announced here today the appointment of Emmet O'Neal, former Representative from Kentucky, to succeed Paul V. McNutt as Ambassador to the Philippine Republic.

The New York Guild for the Jewish Blind spent $698,742 during 1946 in serving the blind and incurred an "unprecedented" deficit of $23,120, it was announced last night at the thirty-third annual meeting of the group at its headquarters, 1880 Broadway.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 12 points lower to 2 points higher, with July, 1947, showing the most weakness.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Carl A. Marzani, 35, Italian-born former State Department sub-official, was convicted today on all eleven counts of an indictment accusing him of hiding Communist party affiliations in a Federal loyalty test.

NEW ORLEANS, May 22 (AP) -- Miss Polly Riley, medalist, advanced today to the semi-finals of the annual women's trans-Mississippi golf tournament, but she shot the worst golf of any of the quarterfinal winners in doing it.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Republicans caught Democrats napping today and rushed through Congress a bill which will make their economy drive for the coming fiscal year look $641,832,000 better -- and President Truman's surplus this year that much less.

Automobile owners were cheered yesterday by the announcement that two Chicago mail order houses had reduced the price of tires and at least one of the "big four" rubber companies had "price cuts under consideration," according to The Associated Press.

A new system of payments must be established by the United States to enable European countries to meet their commitments for American commodities, Alberto Tarchiani, Italian Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Primary market prices rose 0.2 per cent on the average during the week ended May 17, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. This is the first increase in the bureau's general index of commodity prices in primary markets since the week ended March 29.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 22 -- Roland Redmond, new president of the board of directors of the New York Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Francis Henry Taylor, its director, have been visiting here in line with the New York museum's new policy to lend its art on a more generous scale.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 22 -- The 4,000 delegates to the Northern Baptist Convention today adopted a $6,000,000 unified budget for the fiscal year of 1947-48 highest in the denomination's history.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The International Monetary Fund has started operations with the granting of assistance in exchange transactions to France and Holland, Camille Gutt, executive director, announced today. One of its chief purposes is balancing of rates of foreign exchange.

GENEVA, May 22 -- Belgium and Colombia swung today to support of the United States conclusions that Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania had aided the guerrilla uprising in Greece. The two countries' action thus assured an eightto-two margin in the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission which will vote finally tomorrow.

LONDON, May 22 -- A determined scientist whipped out a slide rule in the House of Lords today to prove that the British diet was inadequate as Government and Opposition speakers pelted each other with statistics on the amount of food consumed by the average Briton.

Improvements in intelligence in mentally retarded children and adolescents by the feeding of glutamic acid, one of the building blocks (amino acids) of proteins, was reported yesterday at the meeting of the American Psychiatric Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Legislation sponsored by Republicans to effect lasting economies in government through a two-year study of the set-up and functions of the Executive Branch would lead only to a waste of public funds, Lindsay C. Warren, Controller General of the United States, advised the Senate and House Committees on Expenditures today.

BERLIN, May 22 -- Six shabby, grubby Austrian war prisoners passed through Berlin today from Russia and said: "If you think we look bad, you should see the Russian civilians -- they are in worse shape." The six, two of whom had been civilian internees and four military prisoners, were en route home after two years working in the coal mines of the Donetz Basin.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Trading in May deliveries of grain ceased at the close today on the Board of Trade. A final rush to sell May wheat found support lacking and the close was of net losses of 5 1/4 to 10 cents a bushel, the latter the limit for one day's trading.

Effective merchandising and the consumer appeal of new styles and lower prices will be strong factors making for active retail fur sales during the coming season, it was asserted yesterday at the Carolyn fur coat showing for fall at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The American Federation of Labor protested to the French Government today against French military authorities' refusal to let its representative enter the French zone of Germany.

With several hundred disabled veterans in wheel chairs, on crutches and even on stretchers as guests, the New York Department of the Jewish War Veterans, USA, held last night its second annual all-star show in Madison Square Garden.

Rains that have sapped our patience this week have not interfered too much with vegetables coming to market. This week-end asparagus supplies from New Jersey and Pennsylvania are more abundant here than they have been at any other time this season.

Indian import restrictions which have seriously handicapped trade with that country have been entirely revised as a result of representations made to the Indian Government by United States officials, L.L. Horch, regional director, Department of Commerce, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- During the week ended May 21 member bank reserve balances decreased $7,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- During the week ended May 21 member bank reserve balances decreased $7,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
Brooklyn is going to have a permanent symphony orchestra as completely its own as the Brooklyn Dodgers.

The stock market had periods of strength, and easiness yesterday, and although the leading industrials weakened, the list as a whole made a moderate gain. Announcements of increased dividends spurred several key issues and there was sufficient demand for selected stocks to give the composite rate a lift of 0.72 point on the day.

Time's Long Vistas They have been auctioning off the furnishings in the old Murray Hill Hotel, and we are treated once more to an example of the flexible idea of antiquity in New York. A hotel built in 1884 seems to elicit fully as much sentiment as a Trinity Parish 250 years' old, which latter anniversary has just been celebrated.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 22 -- The solution of the Finnish Cabinet crisis through the withdrawal of the coalition Government's resignation, which was tendered six weeks ago, is regarded in political circles here as merely a deferment of an inevitable inter-party showdown on a number of all-important economic questions.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Spokesmen for the Baltimore Ohio Railroad disputed today previous testimony before the Senate Banking Committee that the carrier had ample working capital which could have been used for part payment on an $80,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Secretary of State Marshall has settled a prolonged controversy within the Government over the transfer of military and naval equipment to other nations in the Western Hemisphere.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial, "Sailing's Resume," tells us that the excursion steamers will again leave the Battery for Atlantic Highlands.

JERUSALEM, May 22 (U.P.) -- Menahem Beigin, leader of the Irgun Zvai Leumi, expressed skepticism today that the United Nations would find an acceptable solution for the Palestine problem. He said peace would return only when the British withdrew.

It's now official that the Company of Twelve is safe at first base. Yesterday contracts were signed with the City Center whereby the newly formed cooperative stock group will occupy the civic house for ten weeks, beginning June 30.

GRANDVIEW, Mo., May 22 -- Mrs. Martha E. Truman, the President's mother, was reported by her doctors tonight to be "still pretty weak." She has been seriously ill since last Saturday as the result of confinement to bed since February when she fell and fractured her right hip.

PARIS, May 22 -- Because of the especially critical state of the French economy in the next few weeks. Premier Paul Ramadier earnestly appealed to French and foreign correspondents today against sensational reporting that might fan internal discontent at a critical moment.

An exhibition of printed fabrics designed by Henry Moore, Feliks Topolski, Andre Derain, Christian Berard and other contemporary European painters of similar note opened yesterday at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fiftyseventh Street.
CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, May 22 (AP) -- Marvin (Bud) Ward of Spokane, Wash., has just about assured himself of drawing the biggest galleries during the British amateur golf championship next week.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Senate agreed today to vote at 4 P.M., Eastern daylight saving time, on Monday on the motion of Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia, to postpone further consideration of tax cuts until June 10. An extremely close vote was looked for by both sides.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 22 (AP) -- The American La France Foamite Corporation of Elmyra, N.Y., and the Seagrave Corporation of Columbus were fined $15,000 each, and each of four officers was fined $5,000 today on charges of conspiring to fix prices on fire-fighting equipment in violation of the Sherman anti-Trust Law.
Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's 10-yearold Boojum II, who apparently is in his second colthood, made his 1947 Belmont Park record two for two yesterday.

LONDON, May 22 -- Prospects that Britain may receive her full request of 400,000 tons of coal monthly from the United States through the coming quarter appeared bright here tonight following the adjournment of the European coal organization meeting.

LONDON, May 22 -- The British Cabinet will make its fateful decision on the proposed plan of procedure for transferring power to the Indians tomorrow morning. Today there was long and intensive conference of the Ministers' Committee on India, which the Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten, attended.

Americans must wake up to the fact that much of Europe is still on the verge of actual starvation, Paul Comly French, general manager of the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, said yesterday.

While confirming the fact that he had fined six players a total of $250 for failing to cooperate with the front office in extra-curricular activities, President Larry MacPhail of the Yankees last night vehemently denied that this action implied any dissension on the baseball club.
BUENOS AIRES, May 23 (U.P) -- Dr. Bramuglia said that with the latest group, Argentina now has expelled a total of sixty Axis agents and has under study the cases of sixty-nine others.

In a major innovation in distribution policies covering lines sold to hotels, restaurants and industrial cafeterias, a nationally known electrical kitchen equipment manufacturer has registered under Fair Trade contracts in forty-five states, it was disclosed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- President Truman's message to Congress today asking continuation of certain limited war powers was as follows: To the Congress of the United States: In March of this year Congress passed and I approved a bill Known as the First Decontrol Act of 1947, extending for three months a few of the powers originally granted in the Second War Powers Act.

The Presidency of the United States is a job that Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt would not wish on any woman, she told members of the Foreign Press Association yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 23 -- Since the eleven nations that are members of the United Nations Security Council likewise compose the Balkan Investigating Commission, there will be the same division between the Western and the Slav powers when the Council takes up the Commission's report.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Bills to bar political broadcasts on election day and the day before and to make other sweeping Changes in radio regulations were introduced today by the Republican chairmen of the Senate and House Commerce Committees.

There probably have been weirder rallies than the one that enabled the Dodgers to turn back the Phillies, 5 to 4, last night, but the 33,136 spectators who filled Ebbets Field to capacity were well satisfied that they had seen something out of the ordinary.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Bituminous coal operators estimated today that John L. Lewis' new demands on them would mean an addition of about $450,000,000 to the present annual...

JACKSON, N.C., May 23 -- A band of masked white men took a young Negro prisoner from the Northampton County jail here at gunpoint before dawn today and Sheriff A.C. Stephenson said: "I am afraid that a lynching has taken place."

Aviation Distributors, Inc., operated by Elmer Haslett, suspended city airport director, was only one of three interests that sought to rent the Park Avenue tunnel back of the city's Airline Terminal Annex early in 1946, it developed yesterday.

The folksy aspects of small-town law practice, as contrived by writers David Howard and Howard Breslin for "Lawyer Tucker," will be offered by WCBS during the summer recess, until September, of the Dick Haymes show. Beginning June 12, Parker Fennelly will have the title role in the comedydrama Thursday nights at 9, with Maurice Wells, Mae Shults and Arthur Anderson reading- supporting assignments.

Now I was able to turn my attention to the military situation, which was both complicated and hopeful. The immediate job was to integrate all available French units into our joint action and to prepare the way for equipping, training and integrating of additional units as quickly as possible.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Truman urged Congress today to extend for another year "a very limited portion" of his wartime power to control domestic use and export of a few critical materials to prevent harm to our own economy and to give concrete support to the nation's foreign policy.

There is no dissension among the Yankees, Bucky Harris insisted yesterday before his charges clashed with the Red Sox at the Stadium. Then, substantiating their manager's assertion, the Yankees, behind Allie Reynolds, walloped the American League champions, 9 -- 0.

CLEVELAND, May 23 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns came up with two runs in the twelfth inning to defeat the Cleveland Indians, 5 to 3, tonight before 61,227, largest major league baseball crowd of the season.

Appointment of an Ambassador to the Philippines to succeed Paul V. McNutt points up the fact that the job of the man who occupies the Embassy at Manila differs from that of the United States Ambassadors in other countries.

WASHINGTON,. May 23 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee, overcoming the greatest hurdle in the bill to unify the armed forces, tentatively approved today an amendment defining the powers of the proposed secretary of national security and promised to send the measure to the Senate next week.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Senate-House negotiators, agreeing in principle on a powerful new Government weapon against "national paralysis" strikes, completed today the greater part of their long job of compromising the labor bills of the two bodies.

The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday that sixty more central offices would be installed in New York City within the next two years to meet the growing list of subscribers. The company added that within recent months, twelve new central offices have been opened in the city.

General Clay's statement yesterday disposes of a good deal of ill-informed comment and futile recrimination on the food situation in Germany. The Military Governor of the American zone discounts the notion that the current shortage, probably the worst that has ever afflicted a Western nation, is a passing crisis.

MONTREAL, May 23 -- In a polite, diplomatic way the United States proceeded today to get tough with the British-sponsored proposal before the International Civil Aviation Organization for a study of international air cartels.

There is no basis for an optimistic outlook on Soviet-American relations, Gen. Mark W. Clark declared yesterday on his return from Europe. The lean, vigorous general who commanded American forces in the fighting in the Mediterranean area and who has been commander of the American zone in Austria, made the statement coming up the bay on the United States liner America.

CLEVELAND, May 23 (AP) -- Predictions for the future of atomic power have been "so fantastic and exaggerated that the reality will undoubtedly seem pretty unspectacular," says E.E. Johnson, engineering manager of the General Electric Company at Schenectady, N.Y.

The death of Lloyd Osbourne, in Los Angeles, at the age of 79, breaks a chain which runs back to the year 1876, when two young men, fresh from a canoe trip, came into an inn at Grez, in France. One of the young men was Robert Louis Stevenson, who described the canoe trip in "An Inland Voyage."

A blockfront on the Avenue of the Americas from Washington Place to West Fourth Street and other parcels in the Greenwich Village area are among twenty properties in Manhattan and Brooklyn to be sold at auction by the city at the Hotel Commodore on June 9, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 -- "The Night Has a Thousand Eyes," Paramount vehicle starring Edward G. Robinson, will go before the cameras early next month, with John Lund playing the second male role in the film and John Farrow directing, the studio announced today.

Termination by the Office of International Trade of all export controls on hides, skins and leather, effective June 1, will have little effect upon the shoe or leather industry, according to views expressed here yesterday. Some two months ago, controls on heavy hides were withdrawn, while the first export quota was set up last February.

BERLIN, May 23 -- Millions of Russian cigarettes of good quality are flooding the Berlin black market at about half the price of American brands. This is the Soviet military administration's answer to the War Department's ban on shipments of cigarettes to Americans for trading purposes.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 23 -- After heated debate the delegates to the Northern Baptist Convention at the closing session today adopted by overwhelming vote a surprise resolution instructing the General Council to define more clearly a "cooperating church" in the convention.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP) -- Two former War Shipping Administration officials have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of bribery and conspiracy against the Government as the Federal Bureau of Investigation nears completion of its investigation into alleged $1,000,000 war frauds on the Delaware River waterfront.

A wave of retail store burglaries in the last several months on the upper East Side ended yesterday with the arrest of a 19-year-old former soldier who admitted ten burglaries. The police said the youth and a companion now being sought, were responsible for about twenty-five other jobs.
TOKYO, May 23 -- Tetsu Katayama, Socialist, Christian and prewar labor lawyer, tonight was elected Premier of Japan by an almost unanimous vote in both houses of the Diet.

On May 10 the International Bank, one of the twin world financial institutions born at Bretton Woods in the summer of 1944, embarked upon its first lending operation, a $250,000,000 credit to France. Now, a fortnight later, the second of these, the Monetary Fund, has gone into action.

The people of New York City are shocked by the sudden barrage of disclosures as to official conduct that has burst upon them in the last few days. Whether any of these reach the depth of criminal misconduct must await the decision of grand jury or court.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 23 -- Cornell pitchers recorded a pair of three-hit seven-inning games at Yale field today, but the best the Big Red could do was divide a double-header with the leagueleading Elis. Cornell took the nightcap, 2 -- 1, after Yale won, 3 -- 1, in the opener.

NANKING, May 23 (U.P.) -- About twenty Americans were evacuated by a United States Army transport plane today from Changchun, now under heavy attack by Chinese Communist forces, the United States Embassy announced. The plane flew to Peiping.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 24 (U.P.) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur said today that the election of Tetsu Katayama as Premier of Japan emphasized the ''middle of the road" course adopted by the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The House Appropriations Committee, striking a crippling blow at many New Deal land and food programs, recommended today at 32 per cent cut in the Agriculture Department's 1948 budget.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, May 23 -- The Basque country, on both sides of the French-Spanish frontier, is indignant at the long-continued closing of the border. This again is becoming a particularly live issue as the tourist season approaches.

Accused of stealing at least $15,000 worth of merchandise consigned for the Army's occupation forces in Germany, three crew members of the freighter Gateway City of the Waterman Line were being questioned last night at the Brooklyn Army Base by operatives of the Army's Criminal Intelligence Division.

LONDON, May 23 -- The plan of the Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten, for the transfer of power to Indian hands was approved by the British Cabinet this morning. It will be presented, as scheduled, to Indian leaders in New Delhi on June 2.

TIENTSIN, China, May 23 -- A United States Marine Corps landing craft evacuated sixty-six Americans, Europeans and Chinese from Peitaiho Beach, 110 miles northeast of Tientsin, at 4 P.M. today. The sound of Communist firing drew nearer to the summer resort.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- The New York Telephone Company, which has under way the largest construction program in its history, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed offering at competitive bidding of $125,000,000 of thirtyfive-year debentures.

NEWARK, N.J., May 23 -- A concern that has been in business in Newark for more than eighty years, the Clark Thread Company, announced today that a fifteenyear program of moving its entire operation to Georgia would be completed this fall.

Trade Here Active in Week Retail trade here this week was active. Estimates indicated department store sales were likely to show an increase approximating 15 per cent over last year. Volume in 1946, however, suffered somewhat from the effects of reduced train services brought about by the rail strike.

SCHROON LAKE, N.Y., May 23 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey told the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs here tonight that there is room in the Republican party for Americans of all shades of opinion so long as they are devoted to the Constitution and the Bill of Rights.

War-ravaged Poland, now in the process of rebuilding its commercial, industrial and financial institutions, was described yesterday as a potential customer for more than $250,000,000 worth of American goods in the next five years.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 23 (AP) -- Reconciliation of the Indianapolis Speedway management and a holdout group of car owners and drivers became official today, and bigname drivers immediately began warming up for the 500-mile race on May 30.

LONDON, May 23 -- London is reviving some of the traditional court events that gave so much color to pre-war social life. The first of the presentation garden parties in place of the courts, which have not been held since 1940, will be held May 28.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The House Public Lands Committee will begin hearings on Monday on measures which would confer United States citizenship on natives of Guam and Samoa and recast the governments of the islands.

The performance of Berlioz's "Romeo and Juliet" by Arturo Toscanini and the NEC Symphony Orchestra, on Feb. 9 and 16, was voted the outstanding musical event of the radio year by music editors of the daily newspapers of the United States and Canada in the fourth annual Poll of Music on the Air conducted by Musical America.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On May 8 a news account in THE TIMES contained part of a letter sent to Senator Vandenberg by George W. Harris, president of the Ethiopian World Federation, which expresses such hatred of Italy that sharp exception must be taken to Mr. Harris' position.

TOYKO, May 23 -- Attempts of the Japanese Government to collect taxes from black marketeers are running into vigorous and often successful opposition. It is understood that Koreans, Formosans and Chinese residents here, and these are certainly the biggest black market operators, have refused point-blank to pay taxes estimated to exceed 5,000,000,000 yen.

While the hammers of workmen are still beating a tattoo of physical change, the New York Regional Veterans Administration is completing reconstruction and administrative reorganization of its outpatient clinic at 252 Seventh Avenue, at Twenty-fourth Street.

GENEVA, May 23 -- The United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission formally approved today a conclusion that Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania had supported the guerrilla uprising against the Greek Government. It also approved a recommendation that the Security Council should regard such support, if repeated in the future, as a threat to world peace.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Senators digging through the story of a big steel deal that failed to come off heard second-hand testimony today about an alleged plan to sweeten it with $18,000,000 in secret payments.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A vibrating motor-driven exercising machine designed to afford the user more benefits than the oscillating bed, recently prescribed for President Truman's mother, has been patented by Nathan D. Mininberg of New York.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 23 -- The new City Administration that took office last Tuesday began its housecleaning today by abolishing the jobs of eight lawyers who had been serving as assistant corporation attorneys.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 23 -- The eighth season of harness racing at Roosevelt Raceway started last night in perfect weather and before the biggest opening night in the plant's history. The paid attendance was 17.098.

After an unsuccessful attempt to drag her 11-year-old adopted daughter with her, Mrs. Leanor Cintron Lopez, 50, of 205 West Eightieth Street, committed suicide yesterday afternoon, by jumping in front of an IRT subway train in the station at Ninety-sixth Street and Broadway.

Overindulgence in bromides leads to four principal varieties of psychoses, sometimes piling up one psychosis on top of another, Dr. Max Levin, New York psychiatrist, reported yesterday at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 23 (AP) -- The Most Rev. J. Francis A. McIntyre, Catholic Coadjutor Archbishop of New York, today described as "patently Nazi" a movement he said was under way to abolish the release time program for religious education of public school pupils.

MUNICH, May 23 -- Ten United States newspaper editors touring Germany and Austria for a survey of the Military Government administration, heard this morning from Dr. Josef Baumgartner, Bavarian Minister of Food and Agriculture, that city dwellers in Bavaria arc in as sorry a plight as the population of the Ruhr.
PARIS, May 23 -- The French Cabinet decided late tonight upon the use of troops and other stringent measures to stave off a strike demonstration by electric and gas workers, called for Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics, unbeaten under the lights, scored their seventh straight night victory by beating the Washington Senators before 17,429 tonight, 8 -- 1. Chet Laabs led the attack on Mickey Haefner with a threerun homer in the fourth, while Elmer Valo also drove in three.

The promptness with which Senator Gurney and his Armed Services Committee have moved to prepare the Unification Bill for presentation to the Senate early next week gives hope for action soon. It cannot be too soon. Senator Taft has promised to put this measure on the Republican "must" list, and with the near unanimity of sentiment behind it Congress should not find it necessary to hold prolonged debate.

A new minimum weekly wage for 12,500 beauty parlor workers in New York State, raising the 1939 base pay by 57 per cent, was recommended yesterday to State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi by a special board of the industry.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 23 -- A proposal that the United Nations committee of inquiry on Palestine inspect Jewish displaced persons camps in Europe will be presented Monday at the committee's first meeting, it was learned today.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 23 -- Word that a half-dozen white men had seized a Negro from the jailhouse in Jackson, N.C., 400 miles away, just twenty-eight hours after a white jury here had acquitted twenty-eight white men on lynch murder charges came as a shock to this community.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., May 23 -- The New Jersey Women's Golf Association group was so intrigued with the bright sunshiny morning that ninety-nine took part in the third one-day tournament of the season over the Essex Fells Country Club course.

The recovery in the stock market turned yesterday further selective, with major increases in individual issues, trends mixed in the industrials and a rise of 0.21 point in the composite price rate. Shortcovering continued to account for part of the extension of the rally, but interest waned and the turnover was the smallest in two weeks.

NEWARK, N.J., May 23 -- An all-male jury returned tonight a verdict for the Government of $1,106,031 in the Federal Court trial of a civil suit against Reuben D. Silliman, 76-year-old retired lawyer of East Orange.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Dean Acheson, Under-Secretary of State, today denied emphatically that there would be any "kickback" to the British out of the $400,000,000 authorized for assistance to Greece and Turkey.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 23 -- Ending a two-year survey of the costly public school system here, a committee of residents listed today a series of recommendations designed to raise the scholastic achievements of pupils closer to basic aptitudes.

Herbert M. Karp. New York attorney who has represented Sir Thomas Beecham, British orchestra and opera conductor on legal matters in this country, telephoned THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday a few minutes after a reporter tried to locate him to ask about reports that Federal marshals armed with subpoenas were searching for him in both New York and Chicago.
BOSTON, May 23 -- The currently hottest team in the National League turned on the heat in the Hub today and forthwith produced some more electrifying results.
HELSINKI, Finland, May 23 -- Finland's industrial production is now reviving so rapidly that the country's paper mills expect to ship about 75,000 tons of newsprint to the United States this year.

SEOUL, Korea, May 23 -- At today's meeting of the AmericanSoviet Joint Commission, Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief American delegate, subsequently revealed, an agreement was reached with the Soviet representatives on the method of informing the press of the work of the commission.

Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, chairman of the American section of the Jewish Agency for Palestine chairman of the American Zionist Emergency Council and president of the Zionist Organization of America, issued a statement last night saying that the Jewish Agency for Palestine in this country had "taken no position favoring either partition or binationalism" in Palestine.
LONDON, May 23 -- A part from some evening up of commitments by professional operators, business in the stock markets today was on the small side.
Fifteen boys and girls ranging in age from 5 to 12 years old turned back into history 250 years yesterday.

VARIOUS authorities prophesy from time to time the impending decline of the hardboiled novel. They may be right, though it would probably be just as prudent to suppose that all forms of the novel will continue to appear, one being more popular than others at a given period. At any rate, there will still be a certain amount of vitality in the hard-boiled style so long as Gerald Kersh continues to produce his rambunctious fantasies.

A charge of "provocative action in defiance of Mayor O'Dwyer and his suggestions and advice" was hurled yesterday against Charles P. Gross, chairman of the Board of Transportation, by Austin Hogan, president of Local 100, Transport Workers Union, CIO.

BERLIN, May 23 -- Any thought of increasing the German food ration must be abandoned, Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today during his press conference. The United States Military Governor said that Anglo-American efforts must be directed to avoiding large-scale starvation.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Making helicopters easier to fly is engaging the attention of numerous engineers and inventors. The problem is tackled in three quite different ways by three men to whom patents were issued this week.

ROME, May 23 -- Enrico de Nicola, Provisional President, today consulted the principal political leaders for the second time and was ready to offer the task of forming a new Cabinet to another candidate tomorrow.

As part of the nation-wide observance of Naval Reserve Week, the Moore-McCormack Lines' cargo -passenger vessel Mormacsaga received yesterday the Naval Reserve pennant, which signifies her fitness and acceptability as an auxiliary of the United States Navy.

ST. LOUIS, May 23 (AP) -- Big Red Munger shut out Pittsburgh, 2 -- 0, with a six-hit performance tonight to give the St. Louis Cardinals their second straight victory over the Pirates before 12,722 fans.

Memorial Sunday will be observed tomorrow as next Friday is Memorial Day. Military, patriotic and civic organizations will hold special services tomorrow and virtually every congregation will honor its own war dead. The American Gold Star Mothers will hold their first church service at 4 P.M. in St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fiftythird Street.

The variety of devices on the market designed for egg poaching seem to prove something we've always contended; that this apparently simple culinary operation is far from simple. How easy -- and how aggravating -- it is to break the yolk during the process or, worse, so handle the white that it wanders at random all over the pan.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I thank you for printing the statements of President Wright and others with regard to the insignificance of Communist influence in City College. This institution, of which New Yorkers may well be extremely proud, so suffers from a hazy public notion that it nurtures Communists that many graduates have found doors closed to them in their search for positions.

Education can be the savior of human freedom and a strong free society in America can lead the world to peace and human brotherhood, but not without radical changes in the educational structure of the United States, Dr. Ernest O. Melby, dean of the New York University School of Education, said last night at the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution followed their first all-night ballot-count session in thirty years with a four-hour ceremonial session of investiture of officers today.

RABAT, Morocco, May 23 -- Relations between the French and the Sultan of Morocco have deteriorated to such a point that the Sultan has declined to sign the Moroccan budget and the country's finances have been conducted provisionally since last March.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- A "lenient" Federal judge today sentenced Kenneth Romney, 63, former House Sergeant-at-Arms, to one to three years in prison in connection with $143,863 shortages in his accounts dating back to the Nineteen Twenties.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 23 -- Hungary's Moscow-trained Communist leaders are disclosing resentment against the conditions of proposed American aid to the Hungarian economy. Their sharp protests against the control clauses in the $350,000,000 relief bill for various countries, including Hungary, are expected to bring a request for modification of these clauses in the agreement to be negotiated with the Hungarian Government.

Interests acting in behalf of several British steel companies and other industrial concerns will attempt next week to place orders in the United States for substantial quantities of steel for immediate shipment abroad, it became known yesterday.

John C. Wilson, back in town after a month's inspection of the theatre situation in London and Paris, brings word that the plan to import to Broadway next September the London production of "The Winslow Boy" will be delayed.

Awards in the "United States" and "Air Mails" classifications in the displays at the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition in the Grand Central Palace were announced yesterday by Rear Admiral Frederic R. Harris, USN, retired, chairman of the international jury.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 18 points higher to 10 points lower than the day before.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 23 -- A special lay committee told the general assembly of the Presyterian Church in the U.S.A. today that it must copy the planning methods of the Roman Catholic Church if Protestantism were to retain its hold on a majority of communicants in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The World Bank will supervise the expenditure of the $250,000,000 credit recently voted France and any other future loans from the compilation of initial lists of purchases to a satisfactory determination that the goods bought with the money have been put to the prearranged usage.
Selected classes in six New York City public high schools will participate in an experimental study of conditions in the "problem areas" of the world, it became known yesterday.

Short of the Goal Dr. Howard A. Rusk, discussing the problems of rehabilitation for disabled civilian workers as well as veterans, said the other day that the average person uses only 10 per cent of his potentialities.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Former Congressman Andrew J. May testified at his war-bribe trial today that he spent money obtained from the Garsson munitions makers to pay his own grocery and department-store bills.
JERUSALEM, May 23 -- It is becoming evident that the Zionists have adopted a new line of approach. They are abandoning an "all or nothing" attitude and indicating a willingness to compromise.
Steady lines of visitors streaming through the house with, the flowered awnings in Columbus Circle should give ample proof, if any is needed, of public interest in new houses and furnishings.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 23 (AP) -- A proposal to solve the nurse, shortage by training registered nurses only in "teaching hospitals" -- those affiliated with a school of medicine -- and practical nurses and nurses' aides in other hospitals was outlined today to the New York State Hospital Association.
LINCOLN, Neb., May 24 (AP) -- Missouri's Tigers almost ran the rest of the league into the ground today as they grabbed thirty places in the Big Six track and field qualifying trials.

New Capital Market The marketing of new securities moved here this week at only a nominal pace. Of five bond flotations totaling $17,650,000, three were municipal offerings. This compares with fourteen issues totaling $58,787,000 last week and twelve issues totaling $107,128,000 a year ago this week.

Warning that colleges are turning out "half-educated" graduates in ever-increasing numbers, Dr. Herluf V. Olsen, dean of the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College, called last night for more liberal arts courses to go with those of a highly specialized and technical nature.

Negotiations for a new contract opened yesterday between the National Maritime Union, CIO, and the Committee for the Steamship Companies and Agents on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, on a peaceful if not productive note.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 23 -- The subcommission on freedom of information and the press decided today to put full discussion of news censorship on the agenda of the forthcoming international conference on a free press. The vote was 9 to 1.

Beaten favorite in both the Kentucky Derby and Weakness, the C. V. Whitney-Abram S. Hewitt colt, Phalanx, will attempt to regain some measure of lost prestige today in the eighth running of the $15,000 added Peter Pan Handicap at Belmont Park.
DETROIT, May 23 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers hoisted their American League lead to a game and a half by whipping the Chicago White Sox, 5 to 2, today in the opener of a twenty-five-game home stand.
Greenwich Village streets bore their perennial exotic fruits yesterday as the spring show of paintings sponsored by the Washington Square Outdoor Exhibit opened for a run through June 8.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 23 -- The newly independent republic of Lebanon expects to get enough American dollars in the next four or five years to enable her to declare her financial independence from France and to bulwark the country against communism.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Lewis E. Lawes had a quality obviously telepathic, which gave him power instantaneously to get in tune with those inner harmonies of a prisoner in punishment or on the fields of sport and parade which wipe out all the urges to disharmony which any man or child of criminal ways theretofore might have felt.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- In the face of a State Department protest the House passed today a wool price-supporting bill in a form viewed in Administration quarters as a threat to United States leadership in foreign affairs and world trade.

Advertising linage in fifty-two cities for the first four months of the year totaled 168,444,597 lines, compared with 144,012,909 lines for the corresponding months last year, or a gain of 17 per cent, according to a compilation of Media Records' figures.

BOSTON, Mass., May 23 -- The Soviet Union has a jet plane, based on a German model, that has been clocked at better than 660 miles an hour, more than forty miles an hour faster than the British world record, John Foster, Jr., executive editor of Aviation Magazine, told the New England Council Aviation Conference here today.

A three-year program of street and highway improvements to cost about $6,782,000 and designed to link the proposed Manhattan Civic Center in the City Hall area with the Frankin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive was tentatively approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

KANSAS CITY, May 23 -- President Truman put in today the heaviest day's work on official papers he has been able to achieve since he flew to Missouri last Saturday to be with his critically ill mother. Aided by Miss Rose Conway, his personal secretary, he was able to dispose of a number of minor reports and bills.

Although the case load in the Veterans Assistance Division of the Department of Welfare is greater than in other relief sections, Edward E. Rhatigan, Commissioner of Welfare, denied yesterday that veterans seeking aid are suffering in comparison to other home relief clients.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade state, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Russell L. Snodgrass, a vice president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, told the Senate Banking Committee today that its hearing's had been the scene of the "besmirching and degrading" of a Senator. His remarks were received with indignation by committee members and publicly disowned by representatives of the railroad.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 23 -- Britain has formally asked the International Court of Justice for a judgment against Albania for the destruction of two British destroyers in the Corfu Channel last October, it was announced today.

As the dual investigations of pier lease irregularities widened yesterday to include the city's dealings with oil companies and airlines, Mayor O'Dwyer delivered a stern warning that any city appointee who "goes bad" must be prepared to face the full consequences.

PARIS, May 23 -- The National Assembly ratified today the World Bank's $250,000,000 loan to France after a debate in which misgiving regarding its terms was expressed by members of the Government and others. The loan was approved by a voice vote.

The policy of the British Government in Palestine found a stanch supporter yesterday in Virginia -born Viscountess Astor, first woman-member of Britain's Parliament, who denounced "gangsterism in Palestine as harmful to Jews throughout the world."

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Grain markets were on the upgrade on the Board of Trade today as the result of general commission-house buying and short covering and talk of a larger export demand. Closing trades on wheat futures were at net gains of 2 1/2 to 2 3/4 cents a bushel. Corn gained 1 3/4 to 4 1/2 cents and oats were up 1 1/4 to 2 7/8 cents.

George Connors' explanation for his nocturnal swim in Central Park lake yesterday was that he considered it a good antidote for flying bullets. The matter of a purse that was snatched from a woman, he said, had nothing to do with the case.

American business must follow a pattern of economic statesmanship in dealing with the Philippines to dispel doubts and suspicions of the motives of Western powers now prevalent in the Far East, Paul V. McNutt, former Ambassador to the Republic of the Philippines, said yesterday.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 23 -- Settlement of the last phases of the Government's 7 1/2 - year - old antitrust suit against the Hartford Empire Co., Hartford, Conn., and other glass container machinery manufacturers was made today in Toledo Federal District Court.
BERLIN, May 23 -- The four powers are in essential agreement that the population of this city desires socialism and that, therefore, a bill paving the way for it ought to be approved.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A cleavage of opinion among member railroads of the Association of American Railroads came into the open today when six Western railroads filed a complaint with the Interstate Commerce Commission asking it to held hearings and set a higher daily rental charge for each other's freight cars when used by other than the owning railroad.

Gus Lesnevich crushed Melio Bettina into instant defeat in their scheduled ten-round bout last night. The light heavyweight champion of the world battered his heavier rival out in 59 seconds of the first round to chalk up a new record for fast endings in Madison Square Garden main bouts.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The consolidation of international air lines operated by American companies into a single, privatelyowned "chosen instrument" was both supported and opposed today. The testimony was heard by a Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee which is considering a bill that would authorize one American-flag international air line under government regulation, instead of the several competing lines as now.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, playing against a jinx that has barred the victory door to him in four previous Philadelphia golf tournaments, slashed six strokes off the Cedarbrook Country Club par today for a recordshattering 65 and first-round leadership in The Philadelphia Inquirer tourney.

The Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association, representing 460 producers, has just completed the last of several briefs calling for immediate repeal of excise taxes on certain gas appliances and will submit it to the House Ways and Means Committee within a week, Harold Massey, assistant managing director, disclosed yesterday.

A memorial shrine, dedicated to members of The Lambs who participated in both World Wars, was unveiled yesterday afternoon in the second floor of the club's headquarters, 130 West Forty-fourth Street. The shrine, a recessed space in a wall with a blue ceiling containing an honor roll, was presented by The Lambs Service Men's Morale Corps as a permanent tribute to veterans of the organization.

Somerville, Mass. Somerville, Mass., will receive bids Wednesday on bonds totaling $1,200,000 to finance remodeling of a school and municipal building and a macadam pavement improvement. Dated April 1, 1947, the bonds will come due April 1, 1948 to 1957.
John A. Kramer, national champion, will head the representation of American players who will compete in the British tennis championships, at Wimbledon this summer.

BUENOS AIRES, May 23 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Juan A. Bramuglia told a news conference today that eight more Nazi agents had been deported two days ago aboard an Argentine liner en route to Antwerp, Belgium, and that Argentina "now considers that she has satisfied all her hemisphere obligations."

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Edward W. Bourne, a New York lawyer, accused Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe in open court today of seeking control of the reorganized Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad Company. He immediately paid a $100 contempt fine for his assertion, which followed entry of an Order by Judge Igoe confirming the roads' reorganization plan, but reserving the right for the court (Igoe) to appoint three of five reorganization managers.

Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan said yesterday he welcomed an investigation by the State Board of Social Welfare of the disbursement of relief funds. He added that neither he nor the members of his staff had anything to fear from such an inquiry.

BUITENZORG, Java, May 23 (AP) -- A comic opera coup d'etat, led by a masked, gun-vaving "Prime Minister" who invented a new technique of counter-revolution by picket line, threw a new scare into complicated Dutch-Indonesian relations here today.

Although, the fishing season is hardly more than under way, the complaints are beginning to show up on the fishing guide situation, and it cannot be denied that many of these complaints are wellfounded.

TO the average GI who fought the war in Europe, the current results of his work may be something of a mystery. The daily reports, however conscientious in authorship, are necessarily fragmentary, incomplete and often contradictory, as are many efforts to synthesize them into a coherent picture.
HELSINKI, Finland, May 24 -- There has been trouble again on the Helsinki-Moscow line, but, for the first time since the armistice, it is the Finns who have hung up the receiver.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 24 -- Princeton's baseball team made it two in a row over Dartmouth for the season by winning on the university field today, 5 -- 1, behind the seven-hit pitching of Bob Wolcott. It was the Tigers' fifth Eastern Intercollegiate League victim in nine games.

IT has been said often enough that the present time is a bad season for the arrival of new poets and poetry. This is salutary talk; it leaves the way open for unpredictable arrivals of individual poets. The "expected" poet, cheered by his fellows, is usually a dull writer, and in poetry dull writing is the greatest of all crimes.

In 1942 the American Association of Scientific Workers asked Drs. Theodor Rosebury and Elvin A. Kabat, both of Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons, to review the whole subject of bacterial warfare. This was to be the association's contribution to the war effort. Drs. Rosebury and Kabat, with the assistance of Martin H. Boldt, then a student and now a physician in the Army, obliged.

PHOTOGRAPHS of historic houses and buildings constitute a large proportion of the pictures the photographer brings back from his vacation. Most amateurs find that a good many of these pictures suffer from "camera tilt."

NEW HAVEN Conn., May 24 -- Yale University will augment its already xtensive program of Southeast Asia studies a the result of a grant of $150,000 for that purpose from the Carnegie Corporation of New York, President Charles Seymour announced today.

The advantages of aviation to mankind outweigh its disadvantages and its development should be directed along peaceful lines, according to students who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

By a vote of 79 to 8 the Senate has prepared the way for a favorable consideration of the National Science Foundation bill by the House. As it now stands, the measure provides that the director of the Foundation shall be appointed by the President with the approval of the Senate.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 24 (AP) -- The New York conference of the Methodist Church adopted a resolution today "affirming our conviction that war with Russia is not imminent or inevitable." It also approved resolutions calling for international control of atomic energy and an end to manufacture of atomic bombs.

THERE have been many rebellions in the Kingdom of Sinclair Lewis since Carol Kennicott rebelled against the standards of the village in "Main Street." It is a turbulent land, and the rebels charge in all directions. There have been rebellions against smugness and inertia, against the standardization of life and the standardization of medicine, against quacks and fakers, against Fascists growing bold and radical youngsters growing bolder.

An automobile driven by a man identified by the police as Hugh Casey, a pitcher for the Brooklyn Dodgers, who gave his address as 406 East Eighth Street, Brooklyn, struck and killed a blind man in Fifth Avenue, near Seventh Street, Brooklyn, at 11 o'clock last night.
FIVE American artists are exhibiting jointly at the Hugo Gallery -- Horace Armistead, Fritz Bultman, Paul England, William Griswold, Frederic Karoly.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (U.P.) -- Administratioa lieutenants on Capitol Hill were quietly canvassing tonight the possibility of a special session of Congress next fall to enact a large-scale program to prop up the economies of Europe and Latin America.

Eight days ago President Truman left the White House and flew to Grandview, Mo., on an emergency visit. His mother, 94-year-old Martha Ellen Truman, was seriously ill. The President hoped to remain briefly in Missouri, then return to Washington. But last week the President stayed on in the Midwest.

BACK in the old (pre-social significance) days, when boy met girl, we had the standard fireworks before the final clinch. Usually Mr. Wrong was in there rabbit-punching, or the railroad tracks intervened, or the demands of a career; often the diamond in the rough simply wouldn't submit to the sort of beveling the bride-to-be demanded.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Even if one were to discount some of the most doleful labor prophecies and some of the most sanguinary hopes of industry, the Senate labor bill, if finally enacted into law, still would make striking changes in the structure of labor relations.

Hand-to-mouth to 60-day commitments in forward buying of industrial materials appear to be the general policy with 90 days the maximum among industrial purchasing agents, according to the composite opinion of members of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, released for publication today.
One of the largest privately sponsored rental housing projects of the post-war era in the New York area has been undertaken on a 175-acre tract in Queens.

The general tenor of many discussions at the annual meeting of the nation's steel executives here last week was one of slight apprehension. Instead of being impressed with the current pressure exerted from all industrial quarters, domestic and foreign, for more steel, the vast majority of these officials deem the present situation temporary and inordinate and look for a recession in steel operations around September or October.

A gift of $50,000 from the Beaumont Foundation to the building fund of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver was announced last night at a testimonial dinner to Morton J. May, St. Louis merchant, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Mr. May is vice president of the hospital.
VIENNA, May 24 -- Headquarters of the United States forces in Austria announced today that nine nations were ready to offer employment to displaced persons who could not be repatriated.

The long-unproductive inquiry into the Scottoriggio murder was revived sharply with the identification yesterday of a badly decomposed body, found in the East River last Monday, as that of a witness who disappeared on the day he was questioned in the case five months ago.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Three errors and two wild pitches by the Chicago Cubs helped the Cincinnati Reds to six runs, five of them unearned, in a messy seventh inning here today and Cincinnati coasted in easily for a 6-0 triumph before a crowd of 22,051 at Wrigley Field.

Department store sales by reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table which gives percentage comparisons with a year ago: 4 Weeks Year Federal 1 Week Ended Ended to
The popular conception that lightning does not strike twice in the same place underwent a slight revision yesterday at the Stadium.

Trading was quiet in the stock market yesterday, which was the final Saturday session until the summer ends. Prices drifted narrowly and closed mixed. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was the smallest for a Saturday in three years, or since May 13, 1944.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., May 24 (AP) -- Speeding to a new track record, Turbine, from the estate of Mrs. Helen Lebowitz, the late Orange, N.J., sportswoman, won the thirty-sixth running of the $20,000 added Havre de Grace Handicap today before a sweltering crowd of 17,000 persons.

WASHINGTON. AFTER more than a decade in which the emphasis was on labor's rights, Congress and several State Legislatures have taken action designed to force labor to accept a system of checks and balances. Now the emphasis is on labor's responsibilities and on greater democracy in labor unions.

In a change of policy described as "one of the most important" in its long history dating back more than sixty years, the Tuxedo Park Association has authorized the disposal at private sale of nearly all of the residential properties it owns in Tuxedo Village, adjacent to Tuxedo Park along the Ramapo River in Orange County, N.Y.

The war of medicine and science against cancer has made strides undreamed of a few years ago in research, and public education. But it has developed "soft spots" in its own ranks at the levels of the medical school and the general practitioner.

The condition of Melio Bettina, Beacon (N.Y.) heavyweight who was stopped in 59 seconds by Gus Lesnevich at Madison Square Garden Friday night, was returning to normal yesterday, according to Dr. Vincent A. Nardiello.

A double by centerfielder Tommy Quinlan in the last half of the seventh inning, scoring Ciro Mattarazzo from second base, gave Manhattan a 1-0 victory over St. Peter's of Jersey City at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. The triumph was the Jaspers' fifth in nine games while it was St. Peter's seventh setback in seventeen starts.

NOBLEST of indoor sports is seeing oneself in the movies. No question about that! The guilty feeling as one looks about at the attentive audience; the apprehension, the suspense; the excruciating excitement as endless time passes and all those artists go on and on with their interminable performances -- until the moment, all too brief, when the beloved figure appears upon the screen.

The warblers are here, on their spring migration, and those ornithologists, both major and minor, who pride themselves on their fine distinctions are having a field day. But for the rest of us, who get hopelessly lost in the maze of yellow throats and chestnut sides and olive-green rumps, the particular joy is in the other migrants and their beauty among this strange May's blossoms.

Establishment of policy-making councils to bring various elements of community life into the task of educating children was proposed yesterday by Dr. Robert K. Speer at the New York University School of Education.

MADISON, N.J., May 24 -- A Bedlington terrier with no previous claim to fame and all but unknown to show followers became one of the biggest dogs in America today. He was Rock Ridge Night Rocket and he won best in show at the Morris and Essex Kennel Club event, biggest outdoor dog show in the world, on the green expanse of Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge's Giralda Farms.

To the astonishment of almost all in the crowd of 41,309, and to the delight of a few, Greentree Stable's Tailspin, a 38-to-1 shot, won the eighth running of the $15,000-added Peter Pan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

BERLIN, May 24 -- The drastic postal ban on cigarette and tobacco shipments to Americans in Germany has again focused the spotlight on a thriving black market which grew like a healthy weed under the Nazis and has continued under the occupation.
SEOUL, Korea, May 24 -- The Joint United States-Soviet Commission meeting here in the effort to establish a Provisional Government for Korea today struck its first snag.

Mindful of the recent Texas City disaster, the New York City Fire Department and the United States Coast Guard are taking every precaution with the steamship Golden West, now docked at Pier 17, Staten Island, to insure against a similar occurrence here.
