Retail store activity last week rose and then subsided, with cotton dress departments reporting good volume, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Trade in the regular dress department emphasized lightweight two-piece types.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Grand Army of the Republic, its ranks thinned by the one enemy it has found invincible, will be able to muster little more than a platoon when the bugles blow on May 30.

ALONG with revivals this fading season probably will be known for its polls, which, some cynics may think, would be just as well. Still, the news this morning is that there's another one on the way, cooked up by the poll-minded Playwrights Company, which sort of started the whole business last February in connection with its "Street Scene" and "Joan of Lorraine."

WHIMSY in the historical novel is rather rare these days when most examples of the type shriek with significance and steam with sex. But Robert Raynolds has told this tale of a highborn Spanish girl (whose search for a husband cuts right across the Mexican Revolt of 1810) in a spirit of sheer playfulness.

THIS is the second novel by the talented young British writer, P.H. Newby, to appear in America in the last few months, and one can say without any hesitation that the effect is anti-climactic. The evocative and sensitive prose style that made "Journey into the Interior" notable, is present in "Agents and Witnesses," but otherwise the present novel carries much less weight.

A group of Welfare Department workers spent forty-three hours of the last seventy-two on the job to complete the repatriation of 1,480 American citizens, ninety-six of them homeless children, who had been stranded in Europe by the war, the department said yesterday.

ONE of the most original and powerful scores composed in the interval between the two world wars was Alban Berg's Wozzeck. Anyone who saw the performance conducted by Leopold Stokowski years ago will remember the savage and yet compassionate comment this opera made on a beaten, disillusioned and self-pitying Germany.

"Tourists are a very gloomy looking tribe. I have seen much brighter faces at a funeral than in the Piazza of St. Mark's. Only when they can band together and pretend, for a brief, precarious hour, that they are at home, do the majority of tourists look really happy." -- Aldous Huxley.

LONDON, May 24 (U.P.) -- The cause of the explosions on the Newhall Hills was not known, but it was believed that a spark ignited oil vapors in two empty forward holds. The tanker was returning to the United States in ballast after unloading oil at Hull.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., May 24 -- A funeral service will be held tomorrow at 2 P. M. in St. John's Episcopal Church for Alfred C. Worley, editor and publisher of the weekly New Milford Times for twenty-eight years until his retirement last September. A veteran correspondent in this area for the new york times, he died yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 74.
Mayor O'Dwyer and Justice James V. Mulholland of Domestic Relations Court had somewhat different stories to tell yesterday about how it happened that an ailing widow, though in need, was...

One respect in which the showing of pure-bred dogs departs radically from other sports is that the season's climax comes not late in the season but almost at its beginning. The thought is prompted by the early date of Morris and Essex, which is scheduled when the great majority of outdoor events still lie ahead.
PARIS, May 24 -- The official announcement says: "Strictly speaking, there exists no scandal concerning the American Army surplus. There are only difficulties arising from a very confused situation."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 24 -- The Cadets from West Point won the annual lacrosse match from the Midshipmen today in Thompson Stadium, 9 -- 3. The game was played under a broiling sun with close to 9,000 in the stands.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 24 -- Cornell's smooth rowing varsity defeated Syracuse today by three lengths in a two-mile race on Onondaga Lake, establishing a new course record of 10:46.8.

Analysis of recent arbitration claims with Latin-American countries, which have more than doubled in the first five months of 1947, indicates a definite trend toward falling international prices and a buyers' market, Joseph S. Cardinale, executive secretary, Inter-American Commercial Arbitration Commission, stated last week.

BERLIN, May 24 (AP) -- The American Military Government told the Germans today that in the first four months of this year the United States and Britain had imported 1,500,000 tons of food products, seeds and fertilizers into the combined zones at a cost of $163,000,000 to taxpayers of both countries.

SOMEONE was lately remarking that, if Charles Dickens were living today, he would indubitably be a writer -- and a top-notch one -- for the screen. The argument was that Dickens, with his genius for vivid imagery and for action-filled story-telling, would find his fittest expression through films.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The plight of America's migrant labor is a serious human problem which calls for coordinated Federal, state and local legislation and community acceptance of responsibility, an inter-agency committee reported today after a year's work.
ST. LOUIS, May 24 -- An attempt by union pressmen to impose censorship of a news story halted publication of The St. Louis PostDispatch and The St. Louis StarTimes today.

In an attempt to train teachers to understand the problems of world peace, teachers colleges and schools of education in this country are now devoting more time to the study of international affairs. Courses have been introduced dealing with current political and social problems, designed to give the future teachers a broad view of the issues America confronts.

JOHN L. STROHM is obviously a man of good-will. He wanted to see and talk with the people of the Soviet Union so that he could "introduce them through stories and broadcasts to the people of America." He applied for a Soviet visa in January, 1946.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 24 -- Harvard defeated Cornell, 15 -- 3 and 4 -- 3, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League doubleheader at Soldiers Field today.

OTTAWA -- The first international post-war religious festival on this continent is to be held here June 18-22 to mark the 100th anniversary of the Roman Catholic diocese of Ottawa and to honor the Virgin Mary.

ALBANY, May 24 -- Over the objections of delegates demanding more militant action, the State CIO Council today designated Tuesday, June 10, as "New York State CIO Veto Day" to mark its opposition to the pending TaftHartley labor bills.

DERBY, Conn., May 24 -- The Yale varsity eight concluded its engagements on its home waters for the season with a clean-cut victory over M.I.T. today preliminary to its final race with Harvard on the Thames at New London.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Senate Republican leaders, supremely confident of sufficient strength to defeat a motion for delay, mapped a drive today for Senate passage of the tax reduction bill by the end of the week.

Running New York City is a more complex and costly job than running the national governments of most of the United Nations. The city's population is 7,853,000 (more than that of thirty U.N. countries). Its budget runs to a billion dollars. It is the world's busiest seaport and airport; its transit system carries triple the passenger volume of all other American railroads combined.

Openings of fall garment lines featured the wholesale markets here last week. While the season is too young for accurate estimates of the season's volume, manufacturers said they were encouraged by buyer response. Buyers agreed the merchandise being shown represented sound values.
MADRID, May 24 -- Details of Spanish efforts to raise credits of many millions of dollars in the United States continue to leak out here although nothing has been revealed officially.
LONDON, May 24 (Reuters) -- Charles Ferdinand Ramuz, one of Switzerland's best known contemporary novelists, died last night after an operation, the Swiss Radio reported today. He was 69 years old.

BALTIMORE, May 24 (AP) -- Battered but exultant students of Johns Hopkins University returned a 400-pound bronze terrapin to the University of Maryland today, thus voluntarily yielding the mascot they did not surrender in a, rousing "battle" involving about 500 undergraduates.

Dauntless is the word for Agents Joseph Schlessinger and Harry Lester of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. In search of a meowing cat, they began ripping out large sections of bathroom walls in every apartment in the four-story, fourfamily dwelling at 2449 Second Avenue late Friday afternoon and kept at the job, with the aid of a police emergency crew, until success crowned their efforts at 1:30 P.M. yesterday.

RUIDOSO, N.M. -- Visitors planning to spend a vacation at Ruidoso, New Mexico's latest boom town, should make reservations well in advance, especially if they want to see the Mescalero Apache Indian encampment festivities beginning July 1.

BROADCASTING at 6:35 in the morning is not the vetran's ideal post-war dream, but to George Monaghan, who disk-jockeys at that hour six days a week over WOR, there is one saving grace. "The hucksters in this business," he says wryly, "don't mind what you play at that time.

VIRGIL THOMSON will be on the podium this afternoon when his opera, "Four Saints it. Three Acts," with libretto by Gertrude Stein, is given its first complete radio performance over CBS from 3 to 4:30 o'clock.

JERUSALEM, May 24 (AP) -- Jewish underground fighters, believed to be Stern Gang members, raided two bridge clubs in the all-Jewish city of Tel Aviv early today and escaped with $3,200 in cash from one of them.
LONDON, May 24 -- Margate, where the Labor Party opens its forty-sixth annual conference on Monday, is already the scene of intense activity.

CLEVELAND, May 24 -- The decreasing value of the American dollar is the greatest present single cause of Inflated prices, James D. Mooney, president and chairman of the board of WillysOverland Motors, Inc., said today at the Automobile Day luncheon at the Mid-America Exposition here.

MR. EZEKIEL has founded his symposium on the proposition that the fundamental postwar economic task is "to complete the industrial revolution -- complete it by spreading industrial opportunity throughout the world; putting the means and mechanisms of large volume, modern production, agricultural and industrial, into the hands of peoples in all countries and aiding them to control and use them wisely and effectively."
A new high mark in expansion of urban areas was reached during the past year, when 259 cities extended their boundaries to include additional suburban territory.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 24 -- The Restoration Fund Commission of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. reported to the General Assembly today the collection of $22,746,717 of a total amount of $27,000,000 set in 1945 as a goal for the financial support of projects designed to restore all damaged or neglected facilities of the denomination at home and abroad.

BOSTON, May 24 (AP) -- Deering Howe's Donor closed fast today to win the $25,000-added Yankee Handicap by a length and a half from the Marlet Stable's Royal Lover before a crowd of 33,196 at Suffolk Downs.

THE annual exhibition in the galleries of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters became current Thursday afternoon, when these institutions held their joint ceremonial exercises.

BOSTON, May 24 (AP) -- Although hampered by a pre-race rudder accident, Boston University's varsity crew completed an undefeated season by winning the five-shell Dad Vail regatta today on the Charles River.

Looking eastward or westward from a Kansas wheatfield today an American might think himself in the best of possible worlds. Our crops promise to be abundant. Most of the employable are at work. Prices are high, but so are wages. If the stock market is nervous the general population is not.

A CHRISTIAN is strictly bound, according to the basic law of his religion, to love his neighbor, whoever and whatever his neighbor may be. The love of neighbor enjoined on a Christian does not mean something maudlin or even emotional.
LOS ANGELES, May 24 -- The knotty problem of labor relations of public employes is being dealt with through two channels of California's governmental machinery.

TOKYO, May 24 -- Police action is beginning to have some effect upon Japan's black market. Threats that they will be under stronger supervision brought about a "voluntary" two-month suspension of Tokyo's main restaurants starting June 1. This in turn will cut beverage prices.
Trailing by one run in the seventh inning, Fordham staged two-run rally to nip Panzer, 7 -- 6 at Fordham Field yesterday. Jim Arbucho, the Rams' No. 1 hurler went all the way, allowing nine hits.

Unemployment within New York City has increased steadily and there are now slightly more than 400,000 unemployed here, M. Joseph Tierney, metropolitan area director, New York State Employment Service, disclosed in an interview last week.

Placing to thirteen of the fourteen events, City College won its own invitation track and field meet yesterday at Williamsbridge Oval. Coach Harold Anson Bruce's team took only three firsts, but compiled 85 points to Hofstra's 37, St. Francis College's 27, Wagner College's 23, St. John's University's 20, Iona College's 10 and Long Island University's 6.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Yale retained the Eastern InterCollegiate Baseball League lead by trouncing Pennsylvania on River Field today, 14 -- 4. It was the sixth victory in eight starts for the Elis and the fifth setback in 10 games for the Red and Blue in the circuit.

ATHENS, May 24 -- A report from Alexandroupolis (Dede Agach), Thrace, that two British soldiers had been attacked and killed Thursday by guerrillas was confirmed today by the Minister of Public Order, Gen. Napoleon Zervas.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 24 -- Mrs. Jane Milligan of 1088 Elizabeth Avenue, one of the founders of the American War Mothers and the Auxiliary of the Elizabeth Post, Veterans of Foreign Wars, here, died yesterday at her home after a brief illness at the age of 79.

A SMALL, simple gadget that looks remarkably like an ordinary household wire brush at first glance may be the means of controlling the static electricity that builds up in fast modern metal airplanes and distorts and disrupts some radio navigational aids and radio reception for the flight crews.

New York University's track and field team, in a final tune-up before the I.C. 4A championships at Philadelphia next week-end, trounced Manhattan, 92-2/3 to 47-1/3, at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Paced by Reginald Pearman, their newest star, the Violets won twelve of the sixteen events.

The report of the Department of Welfare so depressed Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday that he was composing oral editorials and giving reporters problems in multiplication while he read it. The city, he felt, was in a sad state.

TOKYO, May 24 -- Socialist Tetsu Katayama was formally installed today as the Premier of Japan. He has Emperor Hirohito's order to form the first Cabinet under the new Constitution and probably will sign the peace treaty.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 24 -- Three truckloads of Lebanese Army troops with their old French helmets arrived today in the mountaintop resort village of Dhour Shweir on the eve of the first parliamentary election in Lebanon since the French evacuation of the country.

Featuring its triumph with a one-two-three finish in the 220yard low hurdles and then clinching matters with a victory in the pole vault, final event on the program. New Utrecht High School retained its Public Schools Athletic League outdoor track and field crown at Triborough Stadium yesterday.

GEORGES SIMENON, who is a master at applying atmospheric pressure to a provocative situation, has once again squeezed out every last drop of suspense from a story of a man's relentless ambition and the murky and attenuated circumstances under which he finally achieves his ends.

SPECIAL interest in this book derives from the fact that the author, the famous German pastor and resister of Hitler, has recently been in this country on a speaking tour in the course of which he was heard in a score of cities by tens of thousands of people.

American industrial engineering and construction companies, if offered the opportunity of supervising the spending of relief funds in Greece and Turkey, could make certain that they would be used only for actual projects to improve the economy of those countries spokesmen for large engineering companies disclosed in interviews here yesterday.

GOURDS can turn an unsightly fence into the most picturesque and frequently visited part of the garden. This large leaved, luxuriant vine reaches from twelve to forty feet in a season and quickly forms a highly recommendable summer screen for porches, trellises or unsightly embankments.

EARLY reservations on airplanes, trains and buses indicate that travel over Memorial Day week-end will be the heaviest for that holiday since pre-war days. Travel authorities say that on Thursday New Yorkers will start leaving the city, and on the same day visitors will start coming in.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Representative C. Jasper Bell, Democrat, of Missouri, dug some figures out of the Library of Congress today to show that "the Presidency is more of a man-killing job than it used to be."

In announcing its campaign of public education on the fundamentals of the American free-enterprise system recently, the Advertising Council said its intention is to make clear the most important factors that distinguish the American from all other economic systems.

"SLUMS I" and "Slums II," offered last Tuesday evening by the American Broadcasting Company, together represented one of the most provocative and intelligent presentations of a public issue that radio has made in recent years.

SCARBOROUGH ON HUDSON, N.Y., May 24 -- Peg's Pride, the 6year-old gray mare from Teddy Gussenhoven's Hutchinson Farms in New Rochelle, which Miss Peggy Johnson piloted to the national totalpoint jumper championship a season back, made a good start in the Sleepy Hollow Country Club's horse show today, winning three blues.

A couple of scratch singles in the tenth inning accomplished more than all the strategic moves by Managers Ben Chapman and Burt Shotton yesterday at Ebbets Field. At least they enabled the Phillies to beat the Dodgers, 4 -- 3, in a marathon affair that featured more profound thinking by the rival pilots than generally is called for in a baseball game.
NANKING, May 24 -- Student demonstrations that have swept through most of the major cities of China during the last two weeks have been in keeping with a tradition as old as the Chinese Republic.

The surf caster has been described as the "fly caster" of salt water, and whether this term is used in a laudatory or derogatory sense, the consistently successful surf caster certainly is the most skilled of the salt-water anglers.

WHEN Milton Wynne was mustered out he had not finished with the war in Italy. His first grim and uncompromising show at the A.C.A. Gallery was full of echoes of strife, reminiscences of the victims of the Fascists and protest against injustice and horror in a dislocated world.

Revision of certain policies adopted by the International Refugee Organization was demanded yesterday by the Refugees Defense Committee, 112 East Nineteenth Street, in a memorandum addressed to the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

JAMESTOWN. N.Y., May 24 (AP) -- The New York State Council of the Knights of Columbus today requested withdrawal of United States support of the present Yugoslav Government and urged deferral of ratification of the Italian peace treaty.

HOLLYWOOD. THE investigation by the House Un-American Activities Committee of subversive goings on in Hollywood, although initially frightening to the motion picture industry, has actually had the effect of calming almost everyone except the most determined alarmists.

LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP) -- The University of southern California's Mel Patton assumed the rank of the nation's top sprinter after a double victory last night as 48,179 track and field enthusiasts turned out for the seventh annual Los Angeles Coliseum relays.

BLEEDING HEARTS are oldfashioned flowers well-loved by modern gardeners. Graceful, fernlike foliage and pendulous, heart-shaped blossoms are borne on handsome garden plants that still manage to carry with them, through years of cultivation, a carefree, untamed air -- as though they had just moved in from a woodland glen.

THE only realistic military policy for the United States (in the present interval between war and the establishment of lasting peace) is the maintenance of an unchallengeable degree of force, the well-known military commentator of The New York Herald Tribune argues in this cogent exposition of the problem from a viewpoint frankly sympathetic to that of the armed forces.

NEW DELHI, India, May 24 (Reuters) -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Vice President of India's Interim Government, today described as "fantastic and absurd" the demand of Mohammed Ali Jinnah, Moslem League president, for a corridor through Hindustan to connect the two groups of the proposed Pakistan provinces in northwest and northeast India.

A 60-year-old yachting landmark on the Harlem River has moved to a more modern and busier boating center. The famous Consolidated Shipbuilding Corporation, established at the foot of 177th Street back in 1887 and which has served the government through three Wars in the construction of naval craft, now will operate at 154 Pilot Street City Island.

Two young men saved the life of a third early yesterday morning after he had been catapulted into Jamaica Bay through the window of his car as it overturned on the Cross Island Boulevard near the North Channel Bridge in Queens.

LONDON, May 24 -- The Earl of Harewood, King George VI's brotherin-law and husband of the Princess Royal, died at Harewood House near Leeds early this morning. His age was 64. He had been suffering from cardiac complications and asthma.

FOR THIS WEEK: Disbud peonies for finer blooms by pinching out small side buds and leaving only a large terminal one.... Spray roses -- upper and under sides of the foliage -- with a three-purpose spray and repeat every ten days.... Keep hotcaps handy to cover newly transplanted seedlings in case of another drop in temperature.

NEW DELHI, May 24 (AP) -- There is hardly the ghost of a hope here that the Viceroy's expected last minute plea for a United India will bring together the Hindus and Moslems. It is generally conceded that the Congress party and the Moslem League will agree to divide India into at least two states, Hindustan and Pakistan.

THE theme of this novel concerns the efforts of a successful young novelist to free himself from an unhappy marriage. It is much too attenuated to support the perpetual crisis in which the characters find themselves, however, and, as in those drawing-room comedies in which love is batted around like a shuttlecock, the score of the game becomes less important than our wonder at the author's ability to keep it going.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 24 -- Faris el-Khouri of Syria, a chief spokesman for the Arab bloc, served notice today that the Arab states would probably boycott the United Nations committee of inquiry on Palestine if it inspected Jewish displaced persons camps in Europe.

Every sport has its "hot-stove league" for the windy old gaffers to spend the off-season swapping lies about the past and dreaming up new embellishments for the future. The winter's lay-up season for the pleasure boating league ends this week.

Three thousand children, all of whom had been recruited by the promise of a day at Bear Mountain, moved out of the city yesterday as guests on the first excursion arranged this year by the Police Athletic League. But not all saw the mountains.

TOMATOES have always been regarded as a relatively foolproof crop, but last year the late blight fungus (Phytophora infestans) destroyed over $50,000,000 worth. Nearly every tomato patch from Florida to Maine and as far west as Illinois lost from 10 to 100 per cent of the harvest if preventive measures were not taken.

SEATTLE, May 24 (AP) -- The United States, possessing at least half of the world's material resources has a great obligation to mankind, Dr. Raymond B. Allen said today as he was inaugurated as the twenty-first president of the University of Washington.

The lifting of wartime restrictions that kept "seagoing" American women ashore has resulted in a fairly large movement back to sea, with only the lack of adequate quarters holding back thousands of other women, it was learned yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Ben Hogan, Hershey (Pa.) chocolate soldier, marched through the second round of The Philadelphia Inquirer $15,000 invitation golf tournament today and posted a fourbelow par 67 beside his record-setting 65 of the opening round.
MADISON, WIS., May 24 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania crew defeated Wisconsin over the two-mile Lake Mendota course today, finishing two-thirds of a length ahead of the Badgers.

The refusal of the stock market to penetrate last week the low levels of 1945 and the subsequent rebound which canceled out approximately one-half of the inroads of the previous week posed this all-important question: Has the market effectively discounted the business "recession," and embarked on a long-range viewpoint of expanded industrial and business operations later this year, or is this only an interlude such as was experienced from mid-April to early May?

THE foldboat -- that frail canvas-covered craft which resembles a canoe as a Ming vase resembles a flower-pot -- will this season be taken up by sportsmen who left off "downhill yachting" because of the war.

Several hundred persons on the Lower East Side saw a radio car patrolman chase a burglar suspect for several blocks yesterday afternoon and finally capture the man after cornering him in a cellar and firing five shots at him.

TRIS COFFIN, Washington correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, has written a political history of the last two years with the punch and accuracy of a good reporter and the dramatic instinct of a good playwright.

LONDON. WHEN I walked on the stage in Denham studio the other day, I became aware of the interesting fact that film people the world over, whether associated with the production of a picture in Hollywood or 6,000 miles away in London, have one common denominator -- they all wear the same expression of harassment.

With the banks of the United States scheduled to spend about $30,000,000 on their advertising budgets this year, increased attention and effort is being devoted to making their statements and annual reports more readable, understandable and "human," it was reported.

To the Drama Editor: ATTENDING fifteen or more plays a year with my wife and friends, I consider myself a regular theatregoer and desire the right to air my grievances. One of the principal things wrong with the box-office is the general lack of manners of the employes.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 10 points off on July and other months unchanged to 15 points up.

Judging by the actions taken by directors on dividends in May and in earlier months of this year, corporate management is not showing great concern about the question of payments to shareholders in the light of the widespread forecasts of a business recession.

Although the number and dollar volume of realty transactions in Manhattan for April showed a further recession from the peak reached about a year ago, values appear to be holding up, according to the monthly sales survey of the Real Estate Board of New York.

Metropolitan district golfers are in for one of the busiest seasons they ever have faced, judging by the size of the schedule that the Metropolitan Golf Association has just announced. Nine events already have been played, but many remain to be contested before the season is brought to a halt in October.

AMERICA has in recent years been flooded with literature that relates her local legends and folklore, that examines the ways and history of her regions. A guess might be that the headwaters of this stream of particularistic Americana lie in the "made-work" of the New Deal, which produced the vast material out of which the State Guides and their kin were assembled.

"ROSES Indoors and Out" is the name that has been given to a two-day program at Times Hall on June 10 and 11. Differing from former Times Hall meetings in that only a single flower will be considered, the lectures, demonstrations and displays are timed for the peak of rose bloom.

MOSCOW, May 24 (AP) -- The soccer football team of the Kiev Dynamos was accused by the newspaper Trud today or having kidnapped three players from the Odessa club and inserted them in its own line-up.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., May 24 -- William Arnold Bradley, retired perfumer, trout fisherman and a resident here and in adjoining Pleasantville since 1904, died today in St. Francis Hospital in Poughkeepsie after an illness of many months. His age was 69.

OUR operative in attendance at the recent American Booksellers Association convention came away with the impression that it was a fairly lugubrious session, one dolorous address following another until Robert Campbell, chairman of the convention, said at one point: "That was a nice, discouraging speech."

WHAT with our solons in Washington in the midst of their annual great debate on the income tax, this is as good a time as any for some plain talk about taxation. And plain talk is what we need, for most Americans are magnificently uninformed on this unglamorous subject.

THIS volume falls into two parts. The first is a Horatio Alger story in real life. It tells how a poor Danish immigrant boy found opportunity in America, made a reputation as a production genius at Ford and General Motors and because one of the nation's industrial leaders.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, May 24 (AP) -- Eighteen American golfers, headed by eight victorious Walker Cup stars, open a weeklong pursuit of the British amateur championship here Monday against a field of nearly 200 draws from six nations.

MODERN nationalism is a doctrine that seeks to stimulate, artificially, loyalty to the state. Although its foundations were laid as recently as the eighteenth century, in the year 1947 it is one of the greatest forces that keeps sixty-odd sovereign states from living together in peace.

THE growth of medicine in Russia since the formation of the Soviet Union is one of the great scientific sagas of modern times. Starting from scratch -- since there was almost no medicine for the masses of the population -- the Soviets have built up a system of medicine which compares favorably with that of almost any country in the world.

MR. LEOPOLD SCHWARZSCHILD, a German journalist and economist, has for many years been in the forefront of the battle against the rising tide of German nationalism and militarism. He was an indefatigable fighter long before the rise of Hitler, and he continued the fight from Paris after Hitler had come to power, warning the democratic world against the new dynamic forces endangering the peace.

FITZHUGH'S Concise Biographical Dictionary skips alphabetically from Confucius to Calvin Coolidge without leaving so much as an asterisk to mark the absence of William Congreve. No slight is alleged since the brilliant Restoration dramatist chose to live a life that has proved frustrating to biographers.

After wounded ex-service men have had every care that government can give them, there comes what for many of these men is the hardest task of all -- reconversion to the ordinary, yet essential, ways of civilian life. Here is the point where the veterans need more than sympathy.

BAD bridge players break the bidding "rules" (which are not really rules at all but are merely advice expressed in generalizations) and good bridge players break them, if they are good enough. There is one rule that remains substantially unviolated, however.
-- MUSICIANS Radio musicians win a raise and will get as much as $191 a week. Remember, Reader, when you'd rather have played baseball than the piano? And remember what mother said? Mother knew.
KANSAS CITY, May 24 -- President Truman reported tonight on returning from a day spent at his mother's home in Grandview that she was "a little weaker, if anything."
Few auction galleries have scheduled sales for the coming week because of the long week-end that begins with Memorial Day.

Much of the present-day difficulty in adapting a liberal education to modern needs seems to be due to the fact that educators persist in talking about a curriculum in terms of content rather than in terms of what it will do for a student.

TO THE EDITOR: IN THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Sept. 29, 1946, in an article about the Foster Parents Plan for War Children, I wrote that my young son, Paul, and I were about to "adopt" one of the children.

ONE of the commonest phobias tormenting members of civilized society, fear of the dentist's chair, may become as rare as 5-cent cigars if the theory voiced by a psychiatrist at a New York dental convention works for most people.

BERLIN, May 24 -- The Soviet Military Government has slapped down the party politicians and ordered the Premiers of the Soviet zone to attend next month a conference in Munich called by the Bavarian Premier. This leaves only the Premiers in the French zone in a state of uncertainty whether the French Military Government will permit them to attend.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- All grains encountered good support today on the Board of Trade following over-night announcement of supplemental grain export allocations to food deficit areas abroad. Lard advanced on buying traced to eastern commission houses.

LONDON, May 24 (Reuters) -- Liverpool took over leadership of the English League's first division today with a 2 -- 1 verdict over Arsenal, moving one point in front of Wolverhampton and Manchester United.

HEART TROUBLE -- Walter Modell, Morris Pearlmutter and Donald A. Clarke of New York Hospital, Cornell Medical Center, the Cardiac Services of Beth Israel Hospital and the Hospital for Joint Diseases, New York, reported to the pharmacology section of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology that, in patients with advanced heart failure, mercurial diuretics will generally be of more specific benefit than digitalis.

Brother Charisius Leo, F.S.C., for fifty-five years a member of the Brothers of the Christian Schools and since 1933 burser of the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School at 357 Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, died yesterday in the Brothers' Community Residence, at the same address.

The third annual meeting of the Model Congress, composed of students from high schools throughout the city and sponsored by the Political Science Department and Club of Hunter College, rejected a proposal to lower the required voting age of citizens from 21 to 18 years yesterday at the college.

THE military fortunes of the Confederacy were never higher than in 1862, when Lee and Jackson, at Manassas, outmaneuvered, out-fought and completely out-guessed the thoroughly bewildered Pope, who narrowly escaped dismissal for his incompetency and was relieved of command and banished to a frontier fort.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 24 -- Mrs. Lily Morris Hinds Cortelyou, widow of George Bruce Cortelyou, first Secretary of Commerce and Labor, Postmaster General and Secretary of the Treasury by appointment of President Theodore Roosevelt, died here last night at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Jacob F. Weintz of 35 Hollywood Avenue, at the age of 80.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Pennsylvania remained undefeated in three years of dual and triangular competition when it triumphed over Yale and Dartmouth today on Franklin Field. The Red and Blue scored 67 points to the Elis 65 and Dartmouth's 41.

GIVEN an upper middle-class English girl in Soviet Russia, in love with and married to a Soviet scientist, what should be the expected result? It is hardly a major problem, for few upper middle-class English girls marry Soviet citizens and go off to Russia.

On Decisive Bills The Eightieth Congress by yesterday had been in session for twenty weeks. It has enacted seventy-four laws. Of these only two have been of large importance -- in foreign affairs, the Greco-Turk aid program; in domestic affairs, the act for outlawing portal-to-portal pay suits.

WASHINGTON. THE State Department has moved its principal offices in Washington from Pennsylvania Avenue to Foggy Bottom, which, for the benefit of any cynics, is not an intellectual condition but a geographical area down by the Potomac.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Taft bill has been widely acclaimed as designed to bring into equilibrium the relations of labor and management, so seriously unbalanced by the activities of the New Deal. If the enthusiasts for the legislation made a careful analysis of its provisions they might be more doubtful as to the intent of the authors.

ANOTHER fast streamliner service between New York and Birmingham via Atlanta began operation last week when Seaboard's new Silver Comet started its daily 1,088-mile run to the iron and steel capital of the South.

SCHROON LAKE, N. Y., May 24 -- Senator Irving M. Ives told the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs here tonight that there were no longer any differences between himself and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio on the labor bill which is in conference between the Senate and House in Washington.
Mayor O'Dwyer took the offensive yesterday against critics of the handling of relief disbursements by his administration.

The text of the report by Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan on the caseload and staff situation in his department, made public yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer, follows: The pressure on the Department of Welfare has been mounting at an accelerating rate as a result of a rapidly rising caseload.

A full week of openings of fall lines in the New York garment markets have proved heartening to manufacturers of women's apparel, a survey of the trade indicated yesterday. Buyers' reaction to the new styles shown has been extremely favorable, and while final results on orders booked will not be known until the middle of June, much of the pessimism apparent in the market recently has been dispelled.

Speaking at the closing session of a two-day education and business conference held at the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, Park Commissioner Robert Moses last night declared that college training was not necessary in the development of excellent public service personnel.

PERCHED high in the broadcasting booth at the Polo Grounds, where he began his major league career more than twenty-five years ago, Frankie Frisch, the old Fordham "Flash," spins out the play-byplay accounts of the New York Giants' home games with a major portion of the color and vigor that once marked his performances on the diamond.

THE annual big and diversified review of the year has opened at Portraits, Inc. Among the truly arresting pictures as such are Alexander Brook's "Sandra Payson," which on several counts is one of the artist's most interesting paintings; Robert Sloan's sympathetic study of a Negro soldier; Henry Schnakenberg's almost monochrome portrait of a girl; Esther Williams' remarkably vital and understanding "Nina," and a number of others.

ALTHOUGH there may be some scoffers who doubt it, baseball writers are human, too. As such they are prone to likes and dislikes, to favorites and non-favorites. There are not many athletes in the game upon whom they are completely in accord. But one such is Tommy Henrich. They agree that he's absolutely tops both as a person and as an athlete.

HOLLYWOOD. THE shadow of Jack Wrather, a brash young Texan, bent on becoming highly regarded in these parts, looms no larger on the Hollywood horizon, as of this writing, than his maiden producing venture, "The Guilty," an unpretentious little B which was unveiled last week on Broadway to the accompaniment of rather nice reviews.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras -- Elsewhere there would be a sign "No Road." Here in Honduras it's a highway. It's five hours of the bumpiest, bounciest, blackest-and-bluest cow path south of Tehuantepec -- and it's the only road into and out of this capital city. So, the jeep is in a garage having- balm applied to its imiises.

HERE is the story of a remarkable and distinguished woman, told by another remarkable and distinguished woman. Isabel de Palencia's biography of her friend, Alexandra Kollontay, is a readable and wholly admiring book; and yet, the author's failure to fill in the subject's character with a sufficient number of telling details, and her tendency to pass over briefly the notable people with whom Mme.

THE SOCIETY OF AUTOMOTIVE ENGINEERS' study of commercial Vehicles to set up a basis of comparison for selection of the right truck -- right in the sense of most economical to operate and best suited to the job at hand -- is to be extended to lighter vehicles.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- There is one spot in the United States which describes its developments for the coming season with the placid words, "No change." Santa Fe has no new milliondollar swimming pools this year, or chrome tourist courts, or any other kind of super-facility.
The House Appropriations Committee used some noble language in reporting the Agriculture Department's 1948 budget on Friday.

The commission shall proceed with the utmost despatch [to] make specific proposals * * * for control of atomic energy * * * for the elimination from national armaments of atomic weapons and of all other major weapons adaptable to mass destruction.

IT is surprising how few novels with a Portuguese background have appeared during the last decade. In the Nineteen Thirties Lisbon was a city upon which, for honest and nefarious reasons, travelers from all over western Europe converged.

The magnitude of the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition, which will close in Grand Central Palace at 5 o'clock this afternoon, is suggested by the Post Office Department's unprecedented sales of unused stamps and stamped envelopes.
ROME, May 24 -- President. Enrico de Nicola today offered the task of forming a new Cabinet to Alcide de Gasperi, whose third Cabinet resigned on Tuesday of last week.

LINCOLN, Neb., May 24 (AP) -- Running true to the form sheet, Missouri University's well-balanced team placed in all except one event today in winning the Bix Six Conference track and field championship with a total of 158 1-6 points.

MRS. LEE came close to winning this reviewer's heart completely, before he could even open her historical novel. First-off, it was blessedly light in the hand -- no longer, in fact, than a standard item of the old school, when lady-creators were content to dissect their contemporaries as best they could, and left Caligula and the carpet baggers to the specialists.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The House Small Business Committee announced plans today for an investigation of what was termed competition and financial interference by the Government with private enterprise.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 24 -- Dr. James L. Halliday, regional medical officer of the Department of Health for Scotland, declared today that the most important health problem of the present day "is the treatment of the nervous and physical illnesses which are largely the result of social disintegration and its attendant social sickness."

That 1946 was "the most favorable year in the history of retailing" is fully borne out in the complete figures covering last year's operations which now have been issued by leading retail organizations.

The People's Chorus of New York, under Lorenzo Camilieri, gave its first concert since the war yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. In the elaborate program presented as a benefit for the members of the organization, the chorus was assisted by Dorothy Sarnoff, soprano; Donald Dame, tenor, and the Vlachos-Wei Trio, pianists.

A new kind of relationship between diet and disease was demonstrated when it was found that mice fed on a mixture of crude foodstuffs are much more susceptible to infection from pneumonia germs than are mice which are fed a highly refined diet. This was discovered a little over a year ago, and the explanation was advanced that the crude diet contains a substance which has a direct stimulating effect on the bacteria.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A radio-photographic network spread over the Pacific is providing the Navy with up-to-the-minute pictures showing weather, conditions all the way from Washington to the China Coast, the department reported today.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 24 -- Despite threatening weather a crowd of about 15,000 was out at Roosevelt Raceway for the second night's program of the Old Country Trotting Association.

Worcester THE Worcester Art Museum announces the purchase of five paintings (three oils and two water-colors) from the 1947 Biennial, "American Paintings of Today." They include B.J.O. Nordfeldt's "Crucifixion"; Morris Kantor's "Motion"; "Still Life" by Benjamin Kopman; "Maine Shore" by Carl G. Nelson and "Crow and Portrait of Matisse" by Chris Ritter.

MUNICH, Germany, May 24 -- Any failure to improve the food situation in Bavaria would inevitably result in communism or fascism, the group of American editors and publishers who are guests of the United States Military Government were assured this morning.

HOLLYWOOD. THE mechanics of "special effects" photography long have been one of Hollywood's most closely guarded secrets, for producers fear that any public discussion of trick shots would destroy the tender illusions of moviegoers.
CLEVELAND, May 24 (AP) -- Mayor Thomas A. Burke today withdrew the city's 15-year contract offer to the Indians for use of the Cleveland Stadium.

An increase in American imports was described as "imperative" yesterday by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, as he sailed with a group of American business men to attend the ninth congress of the International Chamber of Commerce in Montreux, Switzerland.

Samuel Strausberg of 443 Crown Street, Brooklyn, president of Beth-El Hospital, Brooklyn, and of Interboro Theatres, Inc., died Friday night in Doctors Hospital after an illness of four months. His age was 65.

J.J. Moran, president of the American Union of Telephone Workers, claiming a membership of 23,000 telephone and telegraph employes, announced yesterday that his unit was proposing that it affiliate with the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute THE beauty of fruit trees in bloom, and the equally appealing if less noticeable flowers of small fruits, remind us again that this most worth-while group of plants deserves good care.

SWELTER beneath your mosquito net at the Palace "Hotel" in Belize and try not to overhear the endless banana talk in the next room. Stop at the Tropical Radio office in Guatemala City and get a revealing insight into all Central America from bearded manager "Pop" Rudder.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., May 24 (AP) -- Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, charged today that railroads of the nation had been brought to such a plight that troop transport would collapse in the event of another war.

ST. LOUIS, May 24 -- A new 600mile-per-hour jet-powered fighter plane, the Banshee, was announced today by the Navy. It described the plane, engineered and built by the McDonnell Aircraft Corporation at Lambert-St. Louis Municipal Airport, as the most powerful single-seat fighter plane in the United States.

The nation's banks are cooperating fully in the United States Treasury's "Bond-a-Month Plan" and more than 75 per cent of the 682 commercial banks of New York State already have installed it, Philip M. Light, New York State Director, Savings Bond Division of the Treasury, asserted yesterday.

THE most important factor in personnel relations, thinks Mr. Tootle, is the human being, and he posits and organizes the workings of a personnel office around that assumption. Not that he shuns charts, graphs or statistics, but he de-emphasizes them, and his book, which he calls a "primer," stresses attitudes and approaches rather than tests and training.

LONDON, May 24 -- Tropical climes like India are always subject to hurricanes. Politically speaking, India is being torn right now by storms of peculiar intensity. And here are the British who once upon a time could dominate these elements, now trying desperately to ride the storms and minimize the damage.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Charles A. Rheinstrom, New York aviation consultant, said today that United States airlines could not hope to obtain more than half the international passenger and cargo traffic sold in this country under present operations.

BERLIN, May 24 -- Six paintings bought in 1945 to adorn the walls of the offices of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, the Military Governor, and his deputy, Maj. Gen. Frank A. Keating, are being surrendered to the Netherlands Government for return to the owners.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 24 (AP) -- Bill Holland, roller-skating rink proprietor of Bridgeport, Conn., today gassed a new four-cylinder racer four times around the Indianapolis Motor Speedway in the fifth fastest qualification run in the track's thirty-one-year history and a record for a new driver over the two-and-one-half mile oval.

THE first few warm days of May are a signal that gladiolus planting time has arrived. The popularity of this summer flower has increased by leaps and bounds during the last flew years. In fact, the wide range of colors and types makes this one of the most desirable of all the summer flowering bulbs.
"I NEVER lack material for my humor column when Congress is in session," Will Rogers once quipped.

One of the most haunting specters of increasing age is the fear of chronic disease and disability. This fear is warranted, for in the National Health Survey in 1936 it was found that 58 per cent of all persons 65 and over suffer from chronic disease or physical disabilities.
Cardinal Spellman will dedicate a new residence building on Fordham University's Bronx campus as Cardinal Spellman Hall tomorrow at 8:30 P.M., it was announced yesterday.

In a Shabuoth or Feast of Weeks message yesterday, the Rabbinical Council of America and the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America called on the United Nations "to sanctify its deliberations with the spirit of the Bible, and thus give examples of true leadership to all."

Private enterprise in the United States in 1946, first full year of peacetime activity since the war's end, yielded one of the greatest annual returns in the nation's history. Had not a third of the year's production been lost by a record number of strikes, the year's earnings would have surpassed all records.

THE operas to be presented by the Berkshire Music Center opera department are rumored to be Mozart's "Idomeneo" and "The Trial of Lucullus," the one act work Roger Sessions wrote for student performance at the University of California at Berkeley, where he teaches.

WASHINGTON. WHEN Irving Ives came to the Capitol at the start of this session of Congress, he knew as well as anyone that freshmen Senators were to be seen and not heard. He Intended to take it easy, learn his way around, look up to his seniors, earn a reputation for soundness, and avoid publicity, if possible.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Henri Bonnet, the French Ambassador, declared in a radio interview tonight that France wanted to cooperate "patiently, stubbornly, with the United States, with the other United Nations, to establish a firm and constructive peace."

TAMARlX is an excellent genus of shrubs, with long sprays of profuse pinkish flowers and fine, blue, green cedarlike foliage. A special asset is its ability to grow well near the seashore. Another is the obliging habit some species have' of blossoming in midsummer when there is a dearth of bloom from shrubs.

When the Chinese Government finally broke off negotiations with the Communists last spring Nanking was brimming with predictions that Chiang Kai-shek would end the civil war in a few months with victory in the field. It does not look that way today. Instead Changchun, capital of Manchuria, is ringed by a Red army of 30,000, while elsewhere the apparently interminable struggle is stalemated.

Mayor William O'Dwyer's administration, the first Democratic city regime since 1934, is haunted today by the old familiar ghost of investigation -- the same ghost whose uneasy walking back in 1933 aroused New Yorkers to vote for the fusion regime of Fiorello H. La Guardia.

TO THE EDITOR: The following dialogue came to mind after reading the "debate" between Robert R. Nathan and Emerson P. Schmidt. The disputants, a boy of about 12 and his older brother, are engaged in a neighborhood financial venture.
JERUSALEM (By Wireless.) UNTIL you have experience of it, curfew is only a word in the newspapers. It means that people must go home at a certain time. So what?

RABAT, Morocco, May 24 -- A Showdown between the embattled Sultan of Morocco and the French Government is expected shortly after the arrival of Gen. AlphonsePierre Juin, the new Resident General, who is expected on Tuesday.

TULANE -- Graduate School Tulane University's graduate school program to the Doctor of Philosophy field has been expanded to include mathematics and English. The addition has been made possible by increases in the faculties of the university and improvements in scholarly resources.

JACKSON, N.C., May 24 (AP) -- There were strong indications tonight, officers said, that a terrified Negro, apparently facing death at the hands of armed, masked white men, made a desperate breakaway from his captors and sped into the pre-dawn darkness Friday as a bullet whistled past his head.

TO that ever-increasing number of Americans who are discovering the pleasures of the visual arts this book will be immensely revelatory, for it helps those without benefit of technical training or criticism to see the element of design which makes a picture or which turns the most commonplace object into a minor work of art.

A PHILOSOPHY is always arrogant, and has to be. This is because its raison d'etre is to lay claim to something excessive: possession of truth. Existentialism is no exception. It is a doctrine which aims -- like the philosophies of antiquity -- at disclosing the true measure of man and of his values.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Ever since the Eightieth Congress was elected last November members have been under tremendous direct pressure to reduce taxes. Especially is this true among the Republicans.

In the midst of persisting world-wide political tensions, can a European nation emerging from the devastations of World War II now come to the private money market here and borrow American dollars under its own signature as a plain business risk -- a risk justifiable by its historical credit and by its returning productivity?

To the Drama Editor: THE theatre in Ireland has had a great loss in the death of F.J. McCormick. He is currently to be seen in films in "Odd Man Out" where he plays a down-and-out bird breeder who talks in devious terms of disclosing, at a price, the whereabouts of the hunted Johnny (James Mason).

Before a prizefighter delivers a blow or a pianist strikes a chord or a blacksmith brings his hammer clanging upon a piece of iron, there must be bodily preparation. This is especially obvious in the case of the sprinter who bends low as he waits for the report of the starter's pistol or of the cat that crouches before springing on a mouse.

Conflict in the statements of two figures in District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's pier lease inquiry developed yesterday when Francis J. Barry of Sightseeing Yachts, Inc., reiterated his charge that George Sanders, former Commerce Commissioner, had sought a halfinterest in the company.

NANKING, May 24 -- The Chinese Government advanced a stage further today in the suppression of opposition and criticism. Three of Shanghai's daily newspapers, Wen Hui Poa, Lien Ho Jih Pao and Hsin Min Wan Pao, were suspended.

JERUSALEM, May 24 -- The United Nations Fact-Finding Commission coming here next month to tackle the seemingly perennial Palestine problem will function in a charged atmosphere as strange and undefinable as the Orient itself.

With all three fields offering attractive matches, the 1947 outdoor polo season will be inaugurated today at Bostwick Field in Old Westfaury, L.I., the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club, Purchase, N.Y., and Bethpage State Park, Farmingdale, L,.I.

EGLIN FIELD, Fla., May 24 -- Thunderstorms, forest fires and aerial mapping by radar as well as jet planes, guided missiles, overcoats and E-rations are some of the subjects of special interest to the air proving ground command here.

With a "limited capacity" of 306 passengers, the first triangle cruise service to operate from New York since pre-war days will be started on Wednesday with the departure of the Eastern Steamship Lines Evangeline from Pier 18, North River.
Boaters on Central Park Lake momentarily shipped their oars yesterday afternoon, loungers on the grass rose to their feet, platoons of marines and sailors saluted as a bugler played taps.

BOSTON, May 24 -- New Hampshire is likely to stand out as the only New England state not to resort to extraordinary means of taxation in order to meet mounting expenses. The test came this week with a thumping defeat for two bills legalizing dog racing.

ABOUT twenty years ago a British engineer, J.W. Dunne, published a book called "An Experiment With Time," which has run through several editions. It was a very interesting presentation of the thesis that time is one, that the past and the future exist in the present, and that in certain states of consciousness both are equally accessible to the normal human mind.

LONDON. ALTHOUGH the directors of the new Yiddish Theatre's Folk House to London's East End have orders to quit their present building by the middle of June, they and their patrons are not despondent.

It is now generally agreed that the emergency housing program, launched seventeen months ago from Washington, has failed to achieve its purpose. The housing crisis is just as acute as ever, and even threatens to become more serious.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Fundamental changes in the National Labor Relations Board were charted today by a legal staff under Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. of New Jersey.

Gene Tunney, former world's heavy weight boxing champion, who has been active in real estate in recent years and who will be 50 years old today, celebrated his birthday by announcing yesterday the formation of a new mortgage company in association with Arthur M. Starck.

THE fall buying season for soft goods got off to a better start last week than manufacturers, had hoped for earlier. A qualified optimism has replaced the general air of anxiety, which prevailed a few weeks ago.

Can business prosperity in peacetime be maintained under a wartime income tax structure? Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder has stated in effect that he is not in favor of reducing taxes now because there are no signs of unemployment.

Three Brooklynites charged with assaulting three newspaper photographers attempting to take pictures of Irving Cohen, who is awaiting sentence for grand larceny in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle, were released in $2,500 bail each by Magistrate Charles F. Murphy in Week-End Court, Brooklyn, yesterday for a hearing in Flatbush Court on Tuesday.

"MRS. MIKE," the novel by Benedict and Nancy Freedman, which has been near the top of the nation's best seller lists these past few weeks, will be going before the cameras early next year, if producer Edward Gross' plans do not go awry.

"DE GUSTIBUS * * *." The proverb is somewhat musty. Yet, leave out his Heroic championship of the Boers and his spirited opposition to World War I, and Frank Harris seems a strange hero for the Quaker poet Merrill Root.

DR. MACK'S "Mark Twain in Nevada" deals with but three of Twain's seventy-five years. But they were three exciting and formative years for Twain, as well as a period of mad boom in America's frontier history.

Lipstick and Learning She was blond and pink-cheeked and bright-eyed and therefore in no need of external aids to enhance her personal appearance. Besides, she was only thirteen years old, which would be early for facial make-up, though one does hear things about the increasingly precocious younger generations.
TIENTSIN, May 24 -- Two hundred United States Marines are reported encircled by Communist forces at Chinwangtao, North China's principal coal port, 120 miles northeast of Tientsin.

YONKERS, N. Y., May 24 -- Thomas Francis Lyons of 242 Nepperhan Avenue, Yonkers, who was superintendent of the garage of the City of Yonkers and a veteran of the first World War, died today in his home at the age of 52.

PLEASE listen to us. We are the ones who have lain in hospitals for months and years. The war did that to us. It crushed our bodies. But bodies heal in time. What takes so long to heal are the scars upon our minds and souls.
THE Moholy-Nagy memorial exhibition at the Museum of Nonobjective Painting constitutes a fascinating experience, though one that urgently needs clarification.

THIS ia a delightful, off-thebeaten-path novel by a PulitzerPrize winning author ("Journey in the Dark") who still keeps his laurels green. Ostensibly "The Enchanted" is an episodic tale built around the adventures of seven refugee Spanish children.

A MOVEMENT, rather late in getting under way but vigorous nevertheless, has been started to see that the American dance is represented at the World Youth Festival to be held in Prague from July 20 to Aug. 17, under the auspices of the World Federation of Democratic Youth.

Ulysses Kay, young Negro American composer, who has already received five major awards since his discharge from the Navy, won a sixth yesterday, the $700 first prize of the contest for members of the American Composers Alliance sponsored by Broadcast Music, Inc.
Traveling under her marriage name of Kirsten F. Johansen, Kirsten Flagstad, Norwegian soprano, left LaGuardia Field at 2:41 P.M. yesterday for London on an American Overseas Airlines plane.

AMERICAN and foreign stamp collectors, exhibitors and dealers who have had long experience in attending and conducting shows associated with postal adhesives and covers were unanimous in acclaiming the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition, which closes in Grand Central Palace at 5 o'clock this afternoon, as the "most amazing affair" of its kind within their memory.

EACH of these volumes would find its niche in any not-toosnooty horseman's collection. But the four of them taken together might serve as a handy library for the horse-struck amateur whose interest in a fascinating subject is constantly piqued by ignorance and baffled by lack of access to authorities.

WILLIAM S. HOWELL Jr.: on May 22, at Bryan, Tex., age 56. Mr. Howell died one-half hour before he was to leave for South America to assume his new post as United States Ambassador to Uruguay. A veteran of the United States diplomatic service, he served in many posts, including those in London, Paris, Mexico City and Calcutta.

ALBANY, May 24 -- Tomorrow morning, when most folks will be at church, or dawdling over a second cup of breakfast coffee and reading their Sunday newspapers seventy-five to 100 men and at least one young matron will be racing through spray and puddlejumping Hudson River white caps and waves in one of the most spectacular fantasies of sportsdom.

SHANGHAI, May 24 (AP) -- Dispatches to papers favoring the Government reported that Communist raiders had broken into the northern suburbs of Changchun, besieged capital of Manchuria. The attackers were reported to have failed to take the city power plant, one of their prime objectives.

SEATTLE, May 24 -- It was a good scrap on the Democratic side of the special primary in Washington's Third Congressional District last week-end, and the loggers, fishermen and farmers who inhabit the nine counties stretching along the Pacific Ocean from lower Puget Sound to the Columbia River love a lively fight.

PARENTS soon find out that a baby demands a lot of work, and usually think that he, or she, is worth every lick of it. But if they don't know about the work ahead of time they ought to be told, according to the latest bulletin we've seen, "Living With Baby."

ROME, May 24 -- Premier Enver Hoxha's Government has embarked on a political purge in Albania to remove from office all those officials whose loyalty to Russia is questionable, reports from Tirana said today.

CONVERT your Kitchen into an Italian pizzeria, the place where pizzas are turned out, hot and hearty. A round of dough is baked with tomatoes and anchovies and cheese atop, cut into wedges, then eaten with the fingers between gulps of wine.

Accommodations for 217 families will be provided in a group of cooperative garden apartments in Roslyn, L.I., where ground was broken last week. Sponsored by Roslyn Gardens, Inc., the development is one of the first cooperative apartments financed with a mortgage insured under Title 608 by the Federal Housing Administration.

BERLIN, May 24 -- The Soviet Military Administration made known today a brief summary of recent foreign-trade agreements. They hold interesting portents for the economically merged United States and British zones.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Official Washington, confronted with an economy Congress and a developing European economic crisis, is seriously considering a different approach to the problem of European reconstruction.

The International Association of Public Employment Services, composed of 16,000 members, all government employes in this country and Canada, is making an attempt to become a worldwide organization, it was announced yesterday by the group's president, James H. Bond.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES OF May 13 it was reported that President Ismet Inonu of Turkey said to an interviewer, "There is no Armenian question in Turkey because in this country every citizen enjoys equal rights without any distinction as to religion or race."

A FRIEND of mine who is a critic (he is an English critic. I should explain) has an easy method of padding his column when he is hard up for material. He makes lists. He cites the twelve best soubrettes of all time, the twelve best Hamlets, the great performances by bad actors and the bad performances by great ones.

Another phase of "normalcy" appeared in the wholesale markets as buyers for the first time in many years were again "taking numbers" and shopping around on their pre-season market trips, it was reported last week in the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.
PARIS, May 24 -- Premier Paul Ramadier signed today a decree to keep the personnel of electric power and gas plants on the job under military rule in event of a strike.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 24 -- Mayor Hubert H. Humphrey, who brought about the enactment of a city ordinance to punish as a misdemeanor an act of discrimination in employment by any person "whether acting in an official capacity or in private capacity," defended this statute today as a guide for other cities.
Nipping a ninth-inning Muhlenberg rally through fine pitching by Tom Casey, New York University's baseball team won its fifteenth game of the season at Ohio Field yesterday, 5--4.

The CIO Chorus, which Gertrude Rady has been training and directing for the last two years, made its most important public appearance to date when it presented a program last night at Town Hall. The chorus is a musical credit to the union and it deserved better of the membership than it got last night.

A GARDEN is possible at a summer home, as thousands of people who have tried it will enthusiastically testify. The place that is visited year after year can, of course, have a handsome garden, almost as good as a year-round occupant's.

LARCHMONT. N. Y., May 24 -- Salt-water mindedness, oft claimed to have been given a boost through the war with the number of seagoers getting a taste of it, was manifest today when seventyseven sailing craft competed in the summer season's opening regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

The Jewish National Assembly is the unofficial parliament -- the "shadow legislature" -- of the Jews of Palestine. It is elected by the Jewish community, derives support from the British mandate government (which has contributed $2,000,000 to the Assembly's current budget) and from local Jewish community councils (which have contributed 53,000,000).

THE word "selected" is to be noted: for while Mr. Bernstein has been exceedingly generous in his compilation, it is nevertheless true that of the three poets only Rimbaud is adequately represented. A distorted version of Baudelaire comes through in the translation, published some thirty years ago, by Arthur Symons.

ROMANCE, intrigue, heartbreak and despair vie with lusty, gusty life of California in the gold rush days to keep things lively in this first novel. "Touchstone" is the work of two young women, Janet Cicchetti and Lillian Ressler, who, in combining their talents under the pseudonym of Lillian Janet, lend support to the truism that two heads are better than one.

A FIRST prize of $500 and ten other awards of $100 each are offered for the best sports pictures of 1947 in a contest sponsored by Allsports Magazine. The contest is open to amateur and professional photographers for any sports photographs taken in the United States or its possessions since Jan. 1, 1947.

BOSTON, May 24 -- The Giants' powerful offensive, which for three weeks has been flattening rivals East and West, finally met its match tonight. Warren Spahn, talented left-hander of the Braves, held the straining Polo Grounders to four hits before a cheering crowd of 35,781.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 24 -- After the Army baseball team which he captains had its fifteengame winning streak snapped by Navy's nine, Glenn Davis, the wonder of West Point, hastily changed togs and, with a sensational double triumph in the sprints, led the Cadet trackmen to victory over the Midshipmen in a dual meet.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Army will honor the country's war dead next Friday by decorating thousands of graves and with Memorial Day services at burial sites in all parts of the world.

GETTING the most out of cooking is the theme of each of three new cook books. But where one of them is concerned mostly with the simple pleasures of the table, the other two are devoted to improving kitchen techniques.
DETROIT, May 24 (AP) -- Pitcher Paul (Dizzy) Trout blew himself to a big day today by driving a homer in the tenth to win his own game for the Tigers over the White Sox, 5 to 4.

THE many readers of Kenneth Roberts' "Lydia Bailey" will recall that Albion Hamlin,. the novel's peripatetic protagonist, begins his search for Lydia by interviewing French refugees at the Philadelphia bookstore of Moreau de St. Mery, one of the most celebrated of the group of emigres which included Talleyrand, Demeunier and La Rochefoucauld Liancourt.

WILDERNESS trail trips, unique Journeys afoot into wilderness areas, are to be offered again this summer for the second year in Glacier National Park, Montana. Hikers explore the back country of the park, where the scenery is superb, the trout fishing excellent (no license is required) and where eight species of big game abound.

MOSCOW, May 24 (AP) -- M. P. Tarasov, Russian member of the executive committee of the World Federation of Trade Unions, declared today that American occupation forces had done everything possible to hinder a recent investigation by the committee in Southern Korea.

More than 425,000 consultations with men, women and children facing personal and family problems were given by the staffs of the seven private family agencies in New York City during 1946, a joint report by the organizations showed yesterday.

Out in the bustling, thriving metropolis of Kansas City, Mo., there was enacted last Thursday a bit of drama which, in terms of the international policies of the United States, was as significant as it was symbolic.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Many fishermen and others must have been pleased the other day by reading Herbert Hoover's playful remarks on Presidential fishermen, repeated by your newspaper from a broadcast discussion of Izaak Walton's "The Compleat Angler."

LONDON. BRITISH humor has a quality all its own. Much of the best of the unrehearsed variety is that heard in court proceedings involving married couples. The following examples were recorded by the local press in recent weeks:

WEEDS are no problem when the gardener keeps the upper hand. They must be checked before they grow big; this is the key to the the situation. The presence of weeds has discouraged many would-be gardeners who did not realize they had to start early in the season.

IN September, 1945, Igor Gouzenko walked out of the Soviet Embassy in Ottawa with over a hundred secret documents under his shirt -- thereby proving that his diplomatic colleagues were organizing a spy ring which included Canadian civil servants, scientists and even a member of Parliament.

Frederick Kitzinger, musical conductor for operettas on Broadway and with symphony orchestras in this city and other sections of the country, died on Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital, Following an operation and an illness of three weeks. His age was 43.

MONTREAL, May 24 (AP) -- The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) apportioned its $2,600,000 budget for the next twelve months among forty-one member countries today, with the United States assessed $509,238, or about one-fifth of the total.

Allowing doubting Thomases no loop-holes, John Gielgud capably demonstrated his talents in the recent local presentation of "The Importance of Being Earnest." On his first visit to New York ten years ago, the London actor's ability earned him a nigh rating.

AUGUST BELMONT, one of the elder statesmen of the American turf, once remarked, "The United Hunts is the cradle of racing in this country." However, there aren't too many folks who appreciate what this non-profit organization has done for the sport. Actually, the United Hunts saved the billion-dollar racing industry when it hovered on the brink of-extinction in 1911 and 1912.

If It were not for the idea that mental deficiency is a family disgrace, many persons now committed to institutions could get along as useful citizens outside, and overcrowded training schools could do a "training" instead of a custodial job, the National Mental Health Foundation said yesterday.

TIENTSIN, China, May 25 -- Under covering guns of two United States destroyers, 200 Marines began evacuating Chinwangtao today. The Marines were the Pioneer Company attached to headquarters of the First Marine Division. The destroyers were the Hamler and Hawkins.
LONDON, May 25 -- Queen Mary will be 80 years old tomorrow. The approach of her birthday has demonstrated once more the affection Britons have for her.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 25 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, predicted today that "at the General Conference of the Methodist Church, which will be held in Boston, in May, 1948, the Methodist Church, as the largest Protestant denomination, would take the first steps for the unification or all protestant denominations into a united church."

A "distorted price structure" is the most serious problem affecting business and industry in New York and New Jersey, according to a survey of business and economic trends released over the week-end by L.L. Horch, New York regional director, United States Department of Commerce.
MARGATE, England, May 25 (AP) -- The American tanker Newhall Hills reported today a dramatic twenty-four-hour battle by her crew to save the vessel from, sinking.

PARIS, May 25 -- Mobilized on a military basis, workers in gas and power plants maintained the regular Sunday reduced service today but announced that they had not abandoned plants for the forbidden all-day strike next Wednesday.
CLEVELAND, May 25 (AP) -- The National Maritime Union, CIO, informed its offices rimming the Great Lakes today that "a fugitive freighter" was roaming Lake Erie in search of a port to take on cargo.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, May 25 -- A gloomy statement on the situation in Indonesia is expected to be made by Premier Louis J.J. Beel upon his return to the Netherlands at the end of this week. Homeward bound with Premier Beel is Jan Jonkman, Minister of Overseas Territories.

A tablet "in affectionate memory" of George F. Baker and his son, George F. Baker Jr., New York bankers who aided the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, was unveiled yesterday at the church's morning service by George F. Baker 3d.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 25 -- A proposal to ask the United States to advance the funds necessary for the first unit of the United Nations headquarters buildings on the East River site in Manhattan is now under consideration by United Nations officials, it was learned today.

SINGAPORE, May 25 -- The current recession in Malayan rubber prices, which have dropped one-third in the past month, is being taken in Malaya as a national crisis. Financial interests here are about to take the strongest possible steps to sustain the sagging market through the regulation of production and agitation for international controls.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 25 -- Caught in a blast of southerly wind after a weird session of rain, fog and calm, eleven craft that finished today in the second regatta of the Yacht Racing Association championship series, which was held by the New York Yacht Club, had all they wanted, temporarily, in the way of sailing, or at least those aboard them did.

LIMA, Peru, May 25 (U.P.) -- Negotiations for resumption of payments on Peruvian dollar and sterling loans that have been in default since 1931 will continue despite recent rejection of Peruvian offers by the Foreign Bondholders Protective Committee, according to Finance Minister Luis Echecopar.
The New York County grand jury will begin hearing testimony at 11 o'clock this morning on the pier-subleasing activities of firms controlled by James V. Auditore, Brooklyn stevedore.

LONDON, May 25 -- Commenting on many rumors that plans are afoot for raising a second loan from the United States. The Economist remarks that these rumors are probably as true as those that say the British general staff has plans for waging war on several countries with which Britain is now at peace.

DETROIT, May 25 (AP) -- The Tigers climbed three full games out front in the American League today by dividing a homer duel with the White Sox, the Tigers taking the first game of the twin bill, 10 to 1, and Chicago winning the nightcap, 5 to 2.
