The Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition, which commemorated the 100th anniversary of the issuing of the first United States postal paper, closed its doors at the Grand Central Palace at 5 P.M. yesterday after having attracted 180,000 persons since May 17.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 25 -- Problems of the Indians, Negroes and Mexicans in Minnesota have been studied by the Governor's Inter-racial Commission and generally viewed as related and presenting the same challenge in housing, employment and social acceptance, the Rev. Francis J. Gilligan of the commission said today.

More than $1,582,000 worth of electrical equipment, including small AC and DC electric motors and large generators, are included in new and current surplus listings of about $137,402,000 worth of goods at cost value scheduled for sale by the War Assets Administration, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, revealed over the week-end.

The Electric Boat Company in its forty-seventh annual report to stockholders, to be issued today, by Lawrence Y. Spear, president, reported unfilled orders on Jan.1 approximating $4,541,000, compared with $10,871,000 a year earlier.

NEW DELHI, India, May 25 (Reuters) -- As the stage was being set here for the meeting at which the Indian leaders will be called upon to receive Britain's plan for withdrawal and eventually to make their own choice on India's future, the new wave of communal rioting, which has been sweeping India from coast to coast, continued today.

Student veterans who have attempted to continue their education under the GI Bill of Rights have found that the bill did not provide an open highway to higher education, according to a survey made by the New York City Veterans Service Center. They have found the road beset with difficulties and replete with detours, a statement issued by the center yesterday said.

In the most extensive entomological field research ever conducted by the American Museum of Natural History, museum scientists will search for rare insects and spiders this summer, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Mont A. Cazier, chairman of the department of insects and spiders.

The Maritime Commission made public yesterday a report on the state of the country's domestic shipping, which bore many wartime losses and which, many shipping officials believe, must be restored to pre-war standards to insure an adequate merchant marine.
BERLIN, May 25 -- Food and agriculture experts here believe that the current food crisis will prove to be chronic until at least the fall of 1948.

ROME, May 25 -- Former Premier Francesco Saverio Nitti, who is now biding his time after his unsuccessful effort to succeed Premier Alcide de Gasperi said today that he did not believe the Communists would ever be strong enough to seize power in Italy.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, May 25 (U.P) -- Fog and the Sabbath combined today to frustrate the United States golfers who wanted to sneak in a few final practice licks before teeing off tomorrow morning in the 205-man field seeking the British amateur championship.
Where can one find a good dinner for less than $1?

For the first time since the art season began in September, the number of weekly events registers a marked decline. Three large group exhibitions are scheduled for this week, including "The Year in Review," at the Associated American Artists, opening today, and made up of a selection of work from exhibitions held at the galleries during the year.

TOKYO, Monday, May 26 (U.P.) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported today that the full strength of the Communist influence within the Japanese labor movement was "difficult to determine" since it was a part of the Communist strategy "to consistently and purposely exaggerate their strength."

SHANGHAI, May 25 (U.P.) -- A Central News Agency dispatch from Kweilin charged today that two French planes crossed the Kwangsi border from Indo-China on May 19 to fire at a ferryboat. The report said one Chinese soldier and three ferryboat crewmen were killed.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 25 -- Maurice Podell, owner of several dress factories, is probably the only sculptor in the world whose medium is rye bread. What Mr. Podell, who has never had an art lesson in his life, turns out is not something likened to soap carvings, but rather something that looks like a stone carving. His work has been exhibited in several New York schools.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period May 17 to 23 are given in the appended tabulation: The Senate On passage of the National Science Foundation Bill, passed 79 to 8:

Prices of cotton in the domestic market last week showed small net gains but failed to establish any definite trend. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 20 to 32 points for the week.

The Scindia Steam Navigation Company of Bombay, which will begin a general cargo service between the United States and India in the summer, has applied for membership in the India, Ceylon and Burma Outward Freight Conference, it was announced here yesterday.

Discovery in the East River of the body of Anthony Lagana, long-missing witness in the grand jury inquiry into the fatal election-day beating of Joseph Scottoriggio, will not solve that sinister case. It only adds mystery to mystery. But it should shock the public into a more vigorous demand for complete light on the obscure events which accompanied the November election of Representative Marcantonio from the Eighteenth Congressional District.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 25 -- Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, former commander of American occupation forces in Germany, said today that the United States would have to take charge of refugees and displaced persons in its part of Germany and Austria if the international Refugee Organization was not established promptly.

The Feast of Pentecost, commemorating the descent of the Holy Spirit upon the Apostles, was observed yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral with a pontifical mass at which Cardinal Spellman officiated. After mass the Cardinal bestowed upon the congregation the Apostolic Benediction authorized by Pope Pius XII.
James A. King has transferred from vice president in charge of sales for Textron, Inc., to assistant to Royal Little, president.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 25 -- This resort was buckling at its seams tonight playing host to thousands of Shriners and their families who poured into the city over the week-end for the opening tomorrow of the seventy-third annual session of the Imperial Council, Ancient Arabic Order Nobles of the Mystic Shrine. A total of 50,000 visitors is expected.

Another bit of Manager Ben Chapman's strategy boomeranged at Ebbets Field yesterday when his "provisional" starting pitcher, Dick Mauney, was knocked out by five straight hits in the fourth inning. The Dodgers went on to win, 5 -- 3, behind the five-hit pitching of Joe Hatten.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- A better demand developed last week for cash lard, halting the downward movement which started last March and which carried loose lard down 16 1/2 cents a pound. Loose sold at 15 cents a pound at one time but rallied to 17 cents.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (U.P.) -- The White House has sent to the Senate Wag Investigating Committee additional papers from the late President Roosevelt's files bearing on its inquiry into the Navy's 1945 purchases of Saudi Arabian oil, it was revealed today.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The United States is collecting reparations from Germany at the rate of $6,000 a week from sale of Nazi wartime technical and scientific inventions.

MANILA, May 25 (AP) -- President Manuel A. Roxas announced through his office today that his personal plane, missing for a week with high Philippine Government officials aboard, had been found wrecked on northern Mindanao and that there was no sign of life in the vicinity.

Pullman, Inc., had a net income of $2,288,689 in the first quartet this year in contrast to a deficit of $436,303 for the corresponding three months of 1946, David A. Crawford, president, reported in a statement issued to stockholders today.

Twenty-five years ago today a unique institution of the American theatre was born unostentatiously in the chapel of the Municipal Building. A promising young actor named Alfred Lunt and a promising young actress named Lynn Fontanne took their marriage vows before a deputy city clerk.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The article in THE NEW YORK TIMES for May 18 reporting the comments of Representative Frank W. Fellows (Maine) on the bill now before the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration calls for the thoughtful consideration and responsible expression of opinion of every citizen.

The fiftieth anniversary of The Jewish Daily Forward, a non profit newspaper published in Yiddish, dedicated to the Americanization of the immigrant, social democracy and liberalism, was celebrated yesterday afternoon in Madison Square Garden. The meeting was arranged by a hundred labor unions, the Workmen's Circle, a fraternal order and a number of organizations that were founded on the city's East Side.
Evidence of a divergence of views among Coast Guard officers as to the origin of the fire on the liner John Ericsson on March 7 has been disclosed.
MARGATE, England, May 25 -- Preliminaries for the Labor party's annual conference got under way today in this Conservative stronghold.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Department of Commerce said today that it anticipated that trade between the United States and Latin America, now at record volume, would continue "at a high level for some time."
A critical appraisal of New York newspapers, news magazines and press associations is to be made by the Columbia Broadcasting System in a new weekly program ...

A plea for Christians to seek power through the church was made yesterday by the Rt. Rev Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal diocese or New York. He spoke at the 11 A. M. service of the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, at which he administered the rite of confirmation to seven teen adults and six children.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Americans face a challenge from the nation's war dead to defend and spread the freedoms that form the I foundation of the American, democratic way of life, the Very Rev. Ignatius Smith of the Catholic University of America said today at a memorial mass in the amphitheatre at Arlington National Cemetery.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 25 -- Perry Belmont, former representative and diplomat, who was a grandson of Commodore Matthew Calbraith Perry, died this morning in the Newport Hospital, where he had been a patient since August. He was in his ninety-seventh year.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 25 (AP) -- Appointments in four districts in the Methodist Church's New York Conference were announced today as follows: ...

The Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, announced over the week-end that a campaign for Lucky Strike cigarettes, consisting of twenty advertisements, will appear at the rate of two a week for ten consecutive weeks in every English-language daily paper in the country beginning the week of June 16.

COBH, Ireland, May 25 (AP) -- Some 300 passengers, most of them Americans, left for the United States today on the Marine Flasher after being delayed here ten days while they awaited the ship's arrival. Many of the passengers, who had been vacationing in the British Isles, were admittedly "broke" as a result of the unscheduled delay.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Improvement in the position of the nation's foundries during the last ninety days was reported today by L.E. Roark, executive vice president of the National Founders Association, although deliveries of some types of castings are still a year or more behind. Material shortages continue to hamper the industry in making greater strides in boosting production.
HELSINKI, Finland, May 25 -- The Soviet Union's system of collective farming is about to be introduced experimentally here.

NANKTING, May 25 (AP) -- Communists threatened the Manchu rian railway town of Szepingkai today and continued attacks against the Peiping-Mukden route south of the Great Wall in China proper. Government reinforcements rushed forward by land and air.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 25 -- The Mayor and Council of this city are trying an experiment to improve local housing conditions.

Luigi Infantine, 25-year-old Italian tenor, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. The youthful artist, who made an immediate success at his debut here with the New York City Opera Company in April, is the possessor of a lyric voice of uncommon beauty of timbre, which he employed with a warmth of temperament and intelligence that aroused his audience to a high pitch of enthusiasm.
MOSCOW, May 25 (AP) -- Robert Taylor, the American screen actor, was denounced in Izvestia today for his recent testimony to a Congressional committee investigating communism in Holywood.
LONDON, May 25 -- A widespread setback was experienced on the stock markets last week although resistance was not lacking and there were no pronounced symptoms of a major or prolonged reaction.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (AP) -- The Senators defeated the Athletics, 3 to 1, today in the first game of a Shibe Park double-header that was called in the seventh inning because of rain. The second game was postponed.

Making its first appearance here in fifteen years, the Ulster United soccer team of Toronto, Canadian champion, defeated a German-American League All-Star combination, 3 -- 2, at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday. A crowd of 3,000 braved the rain and sat in open stands to witness the well-played game.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Billions of dollars worth of real estate in major cities is passing into the ownership of governments and such tax-exempt institutions as churches, schools and charitable institutions.

Paul H. Griffith, National Commander of the American Legion, who recently called immigration "a racket of specific racial, religious or economic groups," was criticized yesterday in a statement by Earl G. Harrison, former United States Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization and now chairman of the Citizens' Committee on Displaced Persons, 39 East Thirty-sixth Street.

INDIAN APOLIS, May 25 (AP) -- Four more cars qualified today for the annual 500-mile Memorial Day race at the Indian apolis Motor Speedway, making twelve racers ready to go and leaving twenty-one spaces to be filled in time trials tomorrow and Wednesday.

Veteran and patriotic organizations throughout the city held memorial services yesterday for their war dead. Speakers at the various observances recalled the sacrifices of the men who died in the service of their country and asked that the ideals for which they fought be preserved.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 25 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine has asked the United Nations to allow its representatives to accompany the Committee of Inquiry to Palestine as official consultants, it was learned today.

Week Ended May 23, 1947 The Canadian free dollar edged forward again last week, continuing the recovery in evidence the last fortnight, or since the setback encountered at the end of April, when liquidation, of May 1 maturities and interest checks and some speculative offerings depressed the rate to the lowest in the last two years.

SEOUL, Korea, May 25 -- Until the United States State Department or the joint Soviet-United States Commission "clarifies" the trusteeship clause of the Moscow decision and defines democracy. Dr. Syngman Rhee, conservative Korean leader, will refuse to consult with the commission on the establishment of a Korean Provisional Government, he announced today.

JERUSALEM, May 25 -- King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan warned the Middle Eastern peoples by implication against communism today and urged the adoption of his "Greater Syria" scheme. Speaking in his capital, Amman, he asserted that the recently concluded Trans-JordanIraq treaty would make for better relationships among the territories within the Arab League.

The Senate has approved an authorization of $3,750,000 for the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. This compares with the appropriation of only $2,373,000 made by the House and with a total outlay in the current fiscal year of approximately $5,500,000. The Senate has taken the more realistic attitude concerning the value of the monthly labor and price data compiled by the Bureau.

The Music Education League, now completing its twenty-fourth season, presented at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, the younger winners in its annual auditions. The older winners will be heard there on June 12.

MEXICO CITY, May 25 -- Argentina's declaration that she has complied with all her obligations of the Pact of Chapultepec is taken here as an indication that the longpostponed conference on hemisphere defense in Rio de Janeiro will be held this fall, probably in November.

By meeting "the natural history of aggression" in all children, with a science of child development and intelligent guidance of anger, fear and self-assertion in the rising generation, we can hope to control hostile aggressions and war at their psychological source and make war impossible because it will be unthinkable, it was asserted yesterday.
Yankee power touched new heights yesterday in the rain-soaked Bronx ball yard as Bucky Harris' revivified troupe clubbed seventeen hits to beat the Red Sox, 17 -- 2.
DETROIT, May 25 (U.P.) -- Henry Ford 2d, president of Ford Motor Company, told his 3,800 striking foremen tonight that the company intended to maintain production without them.

Scores of persons interrogated at the District Attorney's office in connection with the fatal beating of Joseph R. Scottoriggio, Republican party worker, early last Election Day will be recalled for questioning anew, it was learned yesterday. They are chiefly residents of East Harlem.
Mayor O'Dwyer gave his "personal promise" last night to "take the program of relief for Italy seriously" and to do all he could as Mayor of New York to aid the Italian people in their homeland.
Mayor O'Dwyer will begin this week an investigation apparently designed to bring about changes in the top personnel of the Board of Transportation, it was learned last night.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 25 -- An unsuccessful finalist for best in show at Morris and Essex gained another chance in a less grand event today, and this time was first dog among 1,176 entries. He was the white standard poodle, Champion Blakeen Osprey, and he was given the chief award at the Plainfield Kennel Club show by Mrs. George B. St. George.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $50,992,582,447. They consist of Treasuary bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Airport financing, state-city fiscal relations and new sources of local, government revenue are among subjects to be discussed by about 800 municipal finance officers meeting from tomorrow through Thursday at the fortyfirst annual conference of the Municipal Finance Officers Association of the United States and Canada in the Hotel Pennsylvania here.

PITTSBURGH, May 25 -- A new post-war high mark in steel production was reached here last week when the rate advanced 1 1/2 points to 105 per cent of rated capacity. The revised figure for the week before was 103.5 per cent. Similar activity was reflected throughout the country when the national ingot rate reached 96.5 per cent, up 1 1/2 points from a revised rate of the week before of 95.

The Real Estate Board of New York has made public the results of a tenant opinion survey in which it asked their rent-payers whether or not they believed property owners were entitled to a reasonable increase in rents.

"We can win the peace not by added physical prowess nor material might, but by the spirit of faith in the emerging truth that the American way of life is the pattern for all mankind," Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, said yesterday at a Shabuoth or Feast of Weeks service.

ESSEN, Germany, May 25 (AP) -- Lord Pakenham, Minister for Britishoccupied Germany, said tonight an important statement affecting the British-American zones would be made Tuesday. "We are on the threshold of a new era in the history of the combined zones," he said.

Gen. Mark W. Clark, in a radio speech last night, accused the Russians in Austria of illegal confiscation of Austrian cattle, food and other resources and of exporting surpluses above their own needs in direct violation of the Potsdam agreement.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- The Cubs collected only three hits here today, but they were enough to defeat the Reds, 3 to 1, for a split of their two-game series. A walk, a triple by Phil Cavarretta and a home run by Bob Scheffing were clustered in the fourth inning for all of the Cubs' tallies.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 25 -- A general strike has been called in Lebanon for tomorrow by Opposition organizations protesting against the manner in which the parliamentary elections, the first since the French evacuation of the country, were conducted today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- "The Red Mill," first filmed in 1927, will be revived this year by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer with Red Skelton in the role of Kid Conner and Keenan Wynn in the role of Con Kidder, according to a studio announcement.

PARIS, May 25 -- As the result of four years of war and many months of partial occupation, the Soviet Union suffered huge losses of population. Soviet scientists and medical specialists are now working to mobilize national health resources in an effort to increase the birth rate, health and manpower.

BOSTON, May 25 -- Coming back with another resounding bound such as they put on in Pittsburgh just a week ago, the Giants today served notice on all and sundry that a setback in their present mood is nothing to toss them off their stride for any appreciable length of time.

As long as there is starvation in Germany neither democracy nor any other ideology can be taught to her people, Brig. Gen. Robert A. McClure, director of Information Control for the United States Military Government in Germany, declared on his arrival here yesterday.

MUNICH, Germany, May 25 (AP) -- Three American Military Government officials, confined to quarters for more than two weeks by order of Brig. Gen. W.J. Muller, demanded today that they either be released or arrested and served with charges.

With the threat of a soft coal Strike looming for July 1, the nation's power and light companies are hurrying to build up dwindling reserves. The average stockpile of bituminous coal is estimated currently to be sufficient to last between sixty and sixty-five days.

Of all the 834,000 homeless persons in the Displaced Persons camps of Germany, the most desperate are the war orphans. Many thousands are the sole survivors of their families. The marvel is that they survived at all.

ROME, May 25 (U.P.) -- Former Premier Alcide de Gasperi received assurances of support in forming a new Government from all large and small Italian political parties today and was reported to be prepared to begin discussions on the distribution of portfolios tomorrow.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 25 (U.P.) -- Wool interests said today that if the Senate passes and President Truman signs a bill imposing a tariff up to 50 per cent on wool imported into the United States, the whole international trade conference at Geneva will be imperiled.

WASHINGTON, MAY 25 (AP) -- A full-scale investigation of James C. Petrillo and his AFL musicians union, to be pressed by a Representative who belongs to the union, was outlined today by Chairman Fred A. Hartley Jr. of the House Labor Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (AP) -- Bobby Locke of South Africa trudged through fog, rain, mud and a pair of sub-par rounds today to win the Philadelphia Inquirer $15,000 invitation golf tournament with a 277 as Ben Hogan, leader by five strokes after thirty-six holes, skidded to five blows off the top place.

Formation of a National Christian Committee of eighty prominent Americans to help the United Jewish Appeal reach its campaign goal of $170,000,000 was announced yesterday by Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the appeal.
Machinery manufacturers are asking the Federal Government to adopt a new and wholly progressive and realistic policy on capital investments, it was learned over the week-end.

The New York Americans defeated the Galicia F. C., 2 -- 1, in the third round of the National Challenge Cup competition under the auspices of the United States Football Association at Sterling; Oval yesterday. They thereby, earned the right to meet the; Brooklyn Hispanos at Hawthorne-Field, next Sunday.

Miss Clara Lamore of the Olneyville Boys Club Auxiliary, Providence, R.I., won the feature event of the opening outdoor A.A.U. meet of the season at Raven Hall Bathing Park, Coney Island, yesterday. She sped through the waters to a six-yard triumph in the 200-meter invitation free style.

Re-examination of automobile drivers every five years, so that eyesight defects -- "a basic cause of highway accidents" -- that may have developed can be discovered and corrected, was advocated yesterday by Dr. Franklin A. Seward, president of the New York State Optometric Association.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Senate Republican leaders remained confident tonight that their taxreduction bill would be the important business of the upper house this week. They pressed plans to get the measure, which would cut individual income taxes from 10.5 to 30 per cent, passed before recessing for a memorial holiday weekend on Thursday afternoon.

According to a dispatch to this newspaper by James Reston, official Washington is beginning to consider a new approach to European reconstruction which will take account of both the developing economic crisis in Europe and the growing apprehensions in Congress and elsewhere as to how far the United States can go in pouring out billions of dollars for foreign aid and relief without ruining itself.

GRANDVIEW, Mo., May, 25 -- In the living room adjoining his mother's sickroom here; President Truman signed today the deficiency appropriation bill carrying $117,438,858 for various Governmental departments and agencies for the remainder of the 1947 fiscal year.

The state inquiry into the city's handling of relief funds will be a searching one, it was forecast yesterday. A member of the three-man committee of the State Board of Social Welfare named to conduct the investigation predicted that it would go into the whole situation carefully and in great detail.

Mrs. John Williams Morgan will give a garden party and tea tomorrow afternoon at her home, 39 West Eleventh Street, in behalf of the Judson Health Center. The honor guests will be members of the organization's women's committee, of which Mrs. Morgan is president.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 -- Union pressmen, who halted publication of two St. Louis afternoon newspapers yesterday in an attempt to censor a news story, yielded today to a mandate of their international president to observe their contract.

The Italian Folklore Society, which was founded in 1932 so that its members could acquaint their fellow-Americans with the folk culture of Italy, presented a program last night at Town Hall that was colorful, interesting, well staged and excellently sung.
CHICAGO, May 25 -- New types of candy or well-known types fortified with vitamins and minerals, were exhibited today at the opening of the annual convention of the National Confectioners Association.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is most distressing that THE NEW YORK TIMES has joined New York City papers which are considered less responsible than THE TIMES, in a clamor for another investigation of the Department of Welfare. Our city is acknowledged, by those who have been in a position to compare, to have the finest municipal welfare organization in the country.

Buyers of ready-to-wear came to openings in considerable numbers last week and were expected to reach a peak this week when openings are expected to be completed, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The Monetary Fund, following by a fortnight the action of the International Bank, has begun to function. At the end of last week its officials announced that it was advancing $25,000,000 in dollars to France and $12,000,000 in dollars and British sterling to the Netherlands.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 25 -- A campaign for $2,000,000 for a hospital on the Great Neck peninsula at Saddle Rock is now under way under the direction of a board of trustees headed by Thomas W. Fitzgerald, town clerk of North Hempstead.

ZURICH, Switzerland, May 25 -- Reports from Washington that the State Department had decided to recommend that $100,000,000 of the $350,000,000 relief project should be allocated to Italy has been much appreciated in that country.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 (AP) -- Lefty Fred Ostermueller ended a brief Cardinal winning streak today when the Pirates edged out the world champions, 2 to 1, in the second game of a double-header. The Redbirds blasted Pittsburgh, 10 -- 5, in the first contest.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 25 -- The upbuilding of the Christian home in the United States as a bulwark against juvenile delinquency was urged today by Wilbur LaRoe Jr., new Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 25 -- Godwin Bush, 24-year-old Negro who escaped from an armed white mob that seized him from jail early Friday, voluntarily surrendered today to Federal Bureau of Investigation agents near Jackson, N.C. He was brought to Central Prison here for safekeeping.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 25 -- Eight championships were awarded as the fifth annual Sleepy Hollow horse show completed its two-day stand at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today. The Palomino, walking horse, saddle horse and equitation classes were held indoors while the hunters and jumpers competed in the outside ring.

Jolly Old Trolley In the good old days we did a lot of moving about this town on trolley cars. We could travel all the way down Broadway in that fashion and get a 3-cent transfer to the Staten Island ferry.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 25 -- Plans for a World War II memorial here in the form of a group of garden - type apartment buildings to accommodate between eighty and 100 families, were revealed today by a special committee of Martin Wallfeerg Post, American Legion.

Instead of a novice, as expected, it took a canny, experienced speed demon who has played the outboard regatta circuits for more than a dozen years to conquer the Hudson River yesterday and win the 130-mile marathon from Albany to Dyckman Street, Manhattan.

The Board of Education approved contracts yesterday totaling $1,074,958 for school construction and repairs. The expenditure will cover modernization work on four schools in Manhattan, one in Brooklyn and one in Queens, and the construction of an addition to a school in the Bronx.

The entire line of Arbuckle's sugars will appear in a new, redesigned package for the first time in seventeen years, it was announced yesterday by the Arbuckle sugars division. National Sugar Refining Company. This completes National's repackaging program, which also included the streamlining of Jack Frost and Quaker sugar containers.

CHICAGO, May 26. (AP) -- Prospects of a price break in the chocolate market between now and fall "depend on how soon and how fast Britain and Brazil need dollar exchange," a chocolate company executive said today.

HOLLWOOD, Calif., May 26 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has revived its project for producing a picture dealing with the careers of Wolfgang Mozart, eighteenth century composer, and Dr. Franz Anton Mesmer, the discoverer of hypnotism. The studio announced today that Robert Walker will play Mozart in the film and Kathryn Grayson will appear opposite him in the role of a blind pianist.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he was preparing to set up a permanent division or bureau of analysis and control, the exclusive function of which would be to maintain day-by-day and year-round supervision over the activities of every city department.

SANTA ANA, Calif., May 26 (AP) -- Louise Overell, aged 18, and George Gollum, 21, went on trial today on the charge of slaying her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Overell, on the latter's yacht by exploding charges of dynamite.

In an attack on Democratic alliances with left-wing groups, Governor Dewey declared last night that the revitalized Republican party offered the only assurance that free government will be maintained in the United States.

CHICAGO, May 26 CS>) - Goeminent propaganda "is a mael strom.of international self-seekin; where wars are brewed," Ken Cooper declared tonight in a criti cism of the State Department' plans for an agency to distribut news abroad.

MUNICH, Germany, May 26 -- From every barracks and from poles throughout the camp in Bad Aibling occupied by Yugoslav royalists, shabby black flags fluttered today, and an atmosphere of gloom permeated the whole contingent of 1,700 officers and men quartered there.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- Purchase of eleven rice mills in Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas and their consolidation into a $15,000,000 corporation by a group of Eastern financiers was announced today 'by R.L. Kutch, a Chicago financial consultant.
The School of Optometry at Columbia University "is in need of a home," Dr. George B. Pegram, dean of Graduate Faculties at the university, said last night.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 26 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, expressed hope today that the Committee of Inquiry into Palestine, set up at the recent special session of the General Assembly, would "prepare the way for a just and workable solution for all."

Contracts signed with fourteen airlines two years ago by former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia wil be accepted as binding by the Port Authority when it takes over Idlewild Airport on Sunday, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission opened bids today for contracts to convert four former troop transports to cargo vessels.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- While the general character of the news showed no change, further early advances in wheat futures met heavy profit-taking and prices receded sharply from the top today on the Board of Trade. Mills were active buyers at times, but there appeared to be a pause in the general demand that lifted prices substantially last week.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A House concession to the Senate in the greatest remaining controversy in pending labor legislation -- the extent of regulation to be put on the union shop-was substantially, arranged today.

WARSAW, May 24 (Delayed) -- The Polish Communist party believes in the retention of multiparty political life and does not seek to impose on Poland a single class society and single party rule, according to Wladyslaw Gomulka, secretary general of the party and Vice Premier in the present regime.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today notified shareholders of Cliffs Corporation, Cleveland, that their vote on the proposed consolidation of the corporation with Cleveland Cliffs Iron Company "must be decided in accordance with their own business judgment."

TOKYO, May 26 -- Japan's Cabinet difficulties entered a new realm of confusion today. Hitoshi Ashida, Democratic party president, emerged from a conference with Premier Shigeru Yoshida and Premier-designate Tetsu Katayama to announce that the three had agreed to have their parties study a four-party Cabinet plan.

Yesterday's foretaste of the warm weather to come made especially timely a talk with Miss Dorothy L. Heald on the kind of molded salads that taste cool on a hot day. Miss Heald, who is in New York from the Staley Manufacturing Company in Decatur, Ill., stopped by at THE NEW YORK TIMES on her way to Macy's where she is giving a cookery demonstration daily through Thursday at 2:30 P. M.

Whether the world is doomed to enter "a new Dark Age" may depend upon the choice betwen Anglo -American or Russian influence to restore order in. post-war Europe, Dr. Alvin Johnson, president emeritus of the New School for Social Research, warned last night.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin's junior Republican Senator and a former Marine Corps officer, warned yesterday that if Congress passes the present bill designed to unify the nation's armed forces, we will "live to regret it more than any other piece of legislation of the last century."
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved unanimously today its own resolution to authorizez United States participation in the International Refugee Organization.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine -- At opening meeting heard Secretary General Trygve Lie urge members to show speed and impartiality in the committee's work.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- An urgent appeal was put before Congress today by Robert P. Patterson, the Secretary of War, for early approval of universal military training as "an absolute essential to our military security."

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Commodity Exchange Authority recommended today that other terminal markets than Chicago he designated as delivery points for grain in settlement of futures contracts made on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Conferences to begin in the next two weeks between the dress industry and the National Retail Dry Goods Association should culminate soon In a standard order blank for the industry, Louis Rubin, executive chairman of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group, said yesterday.

The stock market descended yesterday into a state of dullness unmatched since last July as prices drifted slightly easier and closed moderately lower. Only a few scattered issues showed alterations of a point or more, with the composite average off 0.61 point on the day.

East Sixth Street, between Avenues B and C, can hardly be described as a. Bohemian neighborhood. Nevertheless, for a while yesterday East Sixth Street took on something of the atmosphere of the Washington Square area of Greenwich Village.

JERUSALEM, May 26 -- Five terrorists accused of having taken part in the assault on the Acre citadel on May 4, which liberated 216 felons, went on trial today before a military court. The grim atmosphere and elaborate precautions made it seem as if an unseen enemy might attack any moment.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) -- There are indications that business investment in some fields is "leveling off or declining," and that the rate of inventory accumulation is falling off, the Federal Reserve Board's bulletin for May said today.

SINGAPORE, May 26 -- Chinese rubber Interests in Malaya initiated a move today for the British Government to appeal to the international trade conference in Geneva and also to Washington for new international rubber agreements.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., May 26 (AP) -- Undefeated this season, Mrs. Stanley Sagner's Saggy did the expected today in romping to an easy two-length victory over Equibit in the thirty-fifth running of the $7,500-added Eastern Shore Stakes.
Two of the families that had been living in a hotel while on relief were moved yesterday to dilpidated old-law tenements in Harlem.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Association, of American Railroads, opposing Georgia's antitrust suit against twenty of its members, denied today that it is "the supreme authority" in making freight rates or that members are bound by its decisions.

A large audience of Hindus and non-Hindus assembled at the Belasco Theatre last night for the American debut of the Hindu dancers, Nataraj Vashi and PraVeena, sponsored-by the India. Society of America under the royal patronage of the Maharajah of Baroda.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee restored $1,500,000 to the Customs Service in approving today a 3,243,000,000 bill to finance the Treasury and Poatoffice Departments in the next fiscal year.

NEW DELHI, India, May 26 (AP) -- The Indian Defense Ministry announced today that 10,000 additional troops would be sent into the Punjab to quell disorders, which have killed at least twentyfour persons and wounded fifty others in two days of communal fighting between Moslem, Hindu and Sikh mobs.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Truman urged Congress today to authorize a comprehensive program of military collaboration with all Western Hemisphere nations with a view to modernization and standardizing of organization, training methods and equipment of the armed forces in Latin America and Canada.

One effect of this country's projected loan to Turkey is an announcement by Finance Minister Nazmi Kismir that decrees hindering foreign capital will be lifted. Just how far this goes we shall know later on. The Turks have been forced to borrow, but they have a traditional fear of the foreign investor, whom they knew as a hard master during the days of Abdul Hamid and the system of "capitulations."

MONTREAL, May 26 -- Countries using the metric system today won a long fight to recommend that system of measurement in airground communications. Countries of the British Empire, the United States and Mexico, which use the foot and pound units of measure, bitterly opposed the plan in the Assembly of the International Civil Aviation Organization.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson proposed today that a world conference of ministers of food and agriculture "looking toward improved management of indigenous food supplies" in cerealimport countries be held not later than July.

Going the route for the first time this season, Don Wiederecht turned in the best performance of any Fordham hurler in 1947 yesterday as he held Brooklyn College to one hit. His team-mates, meanwhile, were clouting: a pair of enemy twirlers for eleven nits to give the Rams an 8-1 victory at Fordham Field.

BATAVIA, Java, May 26 (AP) -- Strengthening its hold on Western Java, the Sundanese People's Party seized control today of the Indonesian-held Batavia-Buitenzorg Railway and placed it under protection of the Dutch Army.
The second passenger ship of Poland to enter New York Harbor since before the war, the Gdynia America liner Sobieski, arrived here yesterday with 778 persons from Mediterranean ports.

LONDON, May 26 -- Crowds of cheering and waving Londoners greeted Queen Mary today as she drove to and from Buckingham Palace where thirty-one members of the royal family sat down to luncheon to celebrate her eightieth birthday.

Charging Russian obstructionism with delaying world economic recovery, former President Herbert Hoover yesterday urged the immediate negotiation of a peace treaty with Japan "by as many nations as wish to adhere." Should the next meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers fail, Mr. Hoover recommended that the United States and Britain conclude a peace settlement with their merged zones in Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation's proposal to sell at competitive bidding: $16,677,000 of series L first mortgage bonds, due in 1977, and 50,000 shares of 5100 series G cumulative preferred stock -- a total of $21,677,000 -- will be considered at a hearing" on June 5, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

Dr. Albert B. Newman, in a letter sent yesterday to the faculty of the City College School of Technology, explained his version of the events leading to his removal as dean of the school last week by the Board of Higher Education.
The Yankees scored their most significant victory of the 1947 championship campaign last night at the Stadium before 74,747 fans, a record crowd for a single game.
There are slightly more than 20,000,000 active members of the Communist party in the forty-six principal countries of the world, a United Press survey said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The House Rules Committee gave floor right of way today to an Agriculture Department financing bill which still called for 805,143,576 for the fiscal year 1948 after it had been cut 32 per cent below Presidential estimates.

Orders for new cars exceed the supply by a two-to-one ratio, so the average dealer in the New York metropolitan area and virtually all sections of the country included in a survey by the National Automobile Dealers Association expects to be 50 per cent behind requirements for the remainder of this year, it was reported yesterday.

DETROIT, May 26 (AP) -- Eddie Lake's ringing sixth-inning homer knocked Cleveland out of second place in the, American League today as the league-leading Tige'rs blanked the Indians, 1 to 0, for their sixth shut-out victory of the year.
SEOUL, Korea, May 26 -- The Joint United States-Soviet Commission, meeting here to establish a Korean Provisional Government, today issued the first communique of the current sessions.

The works of Zane Grey, which have received comparatively little attention from a script-hungry radio industry, will provide the subject -matter for a new dramatic series starting next fall on Mutual and WOR. The central figure in the weekly saga of Western adventure will be Grey's character named Tex Thorne.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Pravda, Izvestia, Red Star or some other Soviet publication may burst forth any moment now in a new attack on the American press and a certain United States Senator in pursuit of the familiar Moscow thesis that publicity about Russia in this country is compounded of bias, inaccuracy and deliberate sensationalism.
William Henry Patterson, minling engineer and former Columbia University athlete, died yesterday as a result of injuries incurred in a mine explosion in Michigan on Saturday. His age was 33.
The text of Mr. Hoover's letter to Representative Taber follows: New York, New York May 26, 1947 Honorable John Taber Chairman, Committee on Appropriations House of Representatives Washington, D.C.

The House Committee on Foreign Affairs gave its unanimous approval yesterday to a bill authorizing the United States to join the International Refugee Organization, which was created at the last session of the U. N. General Assembly. The Senate has already given approval to this plan.

Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday continued his tiff with the majority on the city Board of Transportation, but denied reports that be was so displeased with their labor relations policy that he would start an investigation looking toward removal proceeding's.

TRENTON, N.J., May 26 -- Two separate elections will be held in New Jersey next Tuesday, primary election day. This was made clear today by Louis B. Pierce, president of the Mercer County Election Board and former president of the State Association of County Election Boards.

Completing its most successful season, New York University's baseball team beat Manhattan, 6-2, yesterday at Ohio Field, for the Violet's sixteenth victory against one defeat and one tie. The tie game was with Manhattan on April 10, and yesterday's contest was the play-off.

MONTREAL, May 26 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Olympic Committee disclosed tonight it had thanked A very Brundage of the United States body for instigating action that led to Miss Barbara Ann Scott, world figure skating champion, returning a gift-automobile to the city of Ottawa.

Although automatic washer demand still exceeds supply, even in brands where greatly increased production and shipments have been achieved recently, metropolitan distributors conceded yesterday that unmistakable signs of increasing competition are evident.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reiterated today its opposition to merging all United States air service outside North America into a single airline.

How to Sell A few suggestive lines How from a friendly reader has to set the mind working on Sell the subject of slogans and other forms of sales approach for possible future use by the Voice of America.

The Hilton Hotels Corporator had, in the first quartet of this year, the largest business volume and earnings for any three months since it was formed on June 1, 1946, C.N. Hilton, president, reported to stockholders yesterday.

MANILA, May 26 -- Connections between the Philippine Hukbalahaps and several other subversive peasant and labor organizations with Communist organizations in the United States, China and the Soviet Union are charged in evidence gathered by a Philippine Congressional committee.

The Port of New York Authority called upon the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to establish non-trunkline air service between the New Jersey-New York port district and seventy-six communities in the two states and Maryland and Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- A prediction that "in spite of iron curtains and iron heads" it was not too fantastic to hope that eventually the people of the whole world would come to realize there was no security for anyone unless international agreement safeguarded humanity against misuse of atomic power, was made here today by David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

Addressing a group of newspaper editors in Chicago yesterday, Chairman David E. Lilienthal of the United States Atomic Energy Commission answered the questions as to how much the American people should know about the atom, how much they could understand and who should tell them.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 26 (London Times Dispatch) -- The government has suggested an early meeting of delegations from the Governments of the British commonwealth to consider the peace terms for Japan.

Summer theatre announcements show that the straw hat circuit this season will see performances by some of the theatre's leading personalities, as well as visitors, from the Hollywood studios. Most of the fare will be revivals of established hits, but two more playhouses have announced tryouts of new shows.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Prices paid by moderate-income families were one-tenth of 1 percent lower in mid-April than in mid-March, when an all-time high was reached, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. There was a 2 percent increase between Feb. 15 and March 15.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The vote by which the Senate rejected today a motion to delay consideration of income tax reduction legislation until June 10 was as follows: FOB THE MOTION-44 Republicans-2 Morse (Ore.) Wilson (Iowa)

Official action lagged again yesterday in the Joseph Scottoriggio murder investigation after the revival of interest in the case evoked by discovery of the body of Anthony Lagana, a minor witness, in the East River.

PARIS, May 26 -- In electricity and gas plants throughout France, as well as on official billboards in Paris, there appeared today a formal printed notice beneath crossed flags to the effect that all employes of those industries had been "requisitioned" by the Government and must stay on their jobs.

False Move made every move a correct one yesterday as he galloped home to take the Firearm, the Class B event that held the center of the stage at Belmont Park yesterday. The 5-year-old son of Discovery, under a steady ride by Basil James, took the premier award decisively in a wellrun race, and his triumph was a popular one indeed with 25,565 fans on hand.

A spectacular five-alarm fire swept last night through a twostory brick garage and storage warehouse building covering an entire block on Kent Avenue between South First and South Second Streets, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

Twenty-three entries had been received yesterday afternoon for the Storm Trysail Club's Block Island race starting from Larchmont on Thursday night. They included many of the sleekest deepwater craft along the coast.

CINCINNATI, May 26 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates collected nine hits from four Cincinnati pitchers tonight to defeat the Reds, 5 -- 1, before a crowd of 19,967. Kirby Higbe, who allowed the Redlegs only one hit during the first seven rounds, retired in the eighth after giving up two doubles but received credit for the victory.

LONDON, May 26 (U.P.) -- Britain got a taste of what it could expect in the 1948 Olympics today. More than 60,000 crowded into White City Stadium for an international track meet in which an American and a Finn salvaged a lusterless day by breaking two British records.

PIKEVILLE, Tenn., May 26 (U.P.) -- Dr. Glenn A. Millikan, 40, scientist known for his research in aviation medicine, died today as the result of a mountain-climbing accident. He was head of the Vanderbilt University Physiology Department and was the son of Dr. Robert A. Millikan, 1923 Nobel prize winner who specialized in research in molecular physics and with cosmic rays.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 26 -- A star field of professionals took part in the second one-day proamateur best-ball event of the Westchester County Golf Association today. Eighty-two teams started over the Quaker Ridge golf course.

Maj. Gen. Harry C. Ingles, president of R.C.A. Institutes, Inc., told more than 250 members of a national conference on training and education in industry yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that the best and shortest training method for industry is to establish trade schools.
Condititons in state mental hospitals can be improved if the pubic learns certain basic facts, the annual report of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene said yesterday.

OTTAWA, May 27 -- Canada's Foreign Exchange Control Board has clamped down an almost total prohibition on holding of United States currency by Canadians and strict control of their traveling expenses when they visit the United States.

To contribute to the effective maintenance of international peace and security pursuant to the objectives and principles of the United Nations, to provide for military cooperation of the American states in the light of their international undertakings, and for other purposes.

President Truman's resubmission yesterday to Congress of a bill providing for military collaboration with the other countries of this hemisphere in standardizing training, organization and equipment of armed services carries on a long-held desire of military thinkers to weld the defense establishments of North, Central and South American countries into a homogeneous group with common arms and practices as well as a common aim.

Store Sales Here Up 10% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase last week of 10 per cent over the like week of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

IT'S a fortnight since the Giants last pressed their dainty spikes into the Polo Grounds turf and some very astonishing things have happened in the interval. That unfamiliar noise you hear in the background is the buzzing of the pennant bee. The amazing New Yorkers have won nine of eleven since they left Coogan's Bluff.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, May 26 (AP) -- Under changing skies that tried to please everybody, a dozen American challengers for the British amateur golf championship -- Including seven members of the victorious Walker Cup teampounded through the opening round today without a setback.

ATHENS, May 26 (AP) -- American military men conferred with Government leaders today on Greek Army needs to be met with part of the $300,000,000 American loan. Press dispatches told of violent new battles between Government troops and guerrillas in the north.

A man-to-boy study of street gangs in central Harlem has been started under the auspices of the committee on street clubs of the Welfare Council, James McCarthy, secretary of the committee, announced yesterday. He spoke at a meeting of fifty social workers, teachers, police representatives and clergymen of the district, at Public School 120, 18 East 120th Street.

The provision requiring the International Bank for Reconstruca and Developmant to seek funds its loans from among private investers is one of the "most healthy and important" features of project, John J. McCloy, president of the bank, told investment users yesterday.

LONDON, May 26 (Reuters) -- Victories today for the Wolverlampton Wanderers, Manchester United and Stoke City snarled the English League first division race into the closest in the memory of most soccer fans with one point separating the first four teams.
